https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/28/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   New Tactics By Magazine Publishers
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/28/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   New Tactics By Magazine Publishers
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/28/busin.body_text: **********WITH circulation down, publishers of many of the nation's best-known magazines are grappling with ways to keep the bad news from further scaring off skittish advertisers. **********Analysts say a growing number of publishers are trying to placate advertisers by dropping or modifying the offers of cut-rate subscriptions, which go for as little as half of the cover price. Others are doing away with incentives like free telephones or calculators, used extensively in the past to lure subscribers - although some, like Time Warner, still offer them for magazines like Sports Illustrated. **********The latest figures from the Audit Bureau of Circulation showed that for the first six months of this year the average circulation of many consumer magazines has slipped. At Time, TV Guide, McCall's and Better Homes & Gardens, total circulation fell by about 3 percent. The picture was worse for other publications: People magazine had a 5 percent drop and Sports Illustrated was down 7 percent. **********''It is an immediate signal to advertisers of the real vitality of magazines if subscribers are paying the full rate,'' said Paul DuCharme, the director of print media at Grey Advertising. **********Michael Clinton, the publisher of GQ magazine, said that almost every copy of the monthly men's magazine was sold for the full cover price of $3 and that that gave GQ a competitive edge. ''It is a very strong selling point with advertisers,'' he said. **********Publishers are also making these changes to improve their profits. By eliminating expensive premiums and charging subscribers the full price, publishers hope to compensate for revenue lost through steep declines in advertising pages this year. **********''A lot more publishers are concerned about the bottom line,'' said Donald Kummerfeld, the president of the Magazine Publishers of America, a trade group. ''It doesn't make any sense to pump up circulation during tough economic times.'' **********Newsstand sales for many of the biggest magazines were down by 10 percent or more. Elle was down 18 percent, Glamour was off 14 perent and McCall's 30 percent. **********Newsstand sales are important because publishers reap the full cover price. These sales are also a critical indication to advertisers of how much consumers value a publication. The theory is that readers who travel to a newsstand and pay full price are far more interested than those who get a magazine in the mail. **********Analysts and publishers said consumers were buying fewer magazines mainly because prices had escalated - many cost $3 or more - in the last few years. **********Even though circulation is declining at many magazines, publishers are expected to raise advertising rates from 5 percent to 10 percent or even more in 1991, primarily to offset increasing costs for paper and postage - and revenues lost through declines in ad pages. **********But publishers may find it hard to persuade advertisers to pay more, analysts said. Ad pages have been steadily falling this year. In July, ad pages as measured by the Publisher's Information Bureau were down 5.7 percent, and ad pages are off 3.6 percent so far this year. **********Most analysts said that the rise in rates was merely a bargaining ploy and that most publishers were willing to negotiate. Many magazines are already offering discounts of 30 percent or more on ad pages for the fourth quarter. **********Dan Capell, a magazine consultant and the publisher of Capell's Circulation Report, said he expected newsstand circulation to continue to decline for many magazines. Some magazines like Family Circle and Woman's Day are cutting back on their newsstand sales and hoping to attract more subscribers. **********Some publishers are abandoning newsstands because the competition has become fierce. Not only are there more titles fighting for the consumer's attention, but the owners of newsstands are alloting space that used to go to magazines to items like candy and razor blades, which have higher profit margins. **********Still, newsstand sales are still important to some publishers. ''We are more committed than ever,'' said Mark Miller, executive vice president and general manager at the Hearst Corporation, which publishes Cosmopolitan, Redbook, Good Housekeeping and other magazines that rely heavily on newsstand sales. To bolster its position at newsstands, Hearst recently struck a deal with the field sales force of National Enquirer to place Hearst magazines in racks at supermarkets, Mr. Miller said. **********Perhaps the most revolutionary change being contemplated by some publishers is a switch, in part, from paid circulation to ''qualified controlled circulation,'' in which the reader gets it free. **********Avenue magazine, for example, operates on a controlled circulation. Avenue asks a group of selected readers whether they would like to receive the magazine, and those who say yes get a free copy. Controlled circulation has become more attractive because the Audit Bureau of Circulation recently said it would include controlled subscribers in its figures. Although publishers would lose some revenue, controlled subscribers are far less expensive to obtain than paid subscribers. **********But there are risks. ''Publishers will have to be very careful in choosing the kind of people who get free copies,'' Mr. Capell said. ''Otherwise it will mean nothing to advertisers.''

Teleport II Offers Lures At S.I. Site

Teleport II Offers Lures At S.I. Site
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/10/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: IT started as a novel project in an out-of-the way location, but in the five years since construction began, the 250-acre Teleport Complex on Staten Island, one of the nation's first high-tech office and satellite communiciations centers, has grown steadily. **********IT started as a novel project in an out-of-the way location, but in the five years since construction began, the 250-acre Teleport Complex on Staten Island, one of the nation's first high-tech office and satellite communiciations centers, has grown steadily. **********And despite New York City's sluggish commercial real estate market, brokers say the prospects for its continued growth are promising. The latest evidence is the dedication and opening last week of Teleport II, a 166,000-square-foot speculative office building on nine acres. With its completion, the Teleport complex now consists of five buildings with a total of 700,000 square feet out of a potential of 1.1 million square feet. **********The complex, just 11 miles from Manhattan, is a joint project of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the city of New York and Merrill Lynch & Company. It sits in the northwestern corner of Staten Island at the intersection of the Staten Island and West Shore Expressways. **********Already, 800 new jobs have been created at the complex, helping Staten Island's economy as well its image as a corporate address. Among the tenants are Allstate Insurance, Dun & Bradstreet, the capital markets division of Merrill Lynch and Teleport Communications Group, a subsidiary of Merrill Lynch. **********Teleport II was developed by Teleport Associates, a joint venture of Silverstein Properties of New York City and the Murray Construction Company of Springfield, N.J. The three-story concrete building was financed by the Manhattan branch of the Saitama Bank of Japan and cost $16 million. **********The partners, who developed Teleport I, the 112,000-square-foot building next door, are also planning Teleport III, a sister structure of 155,000 square feet on an adjoining site. Construction, however, will not begin until half the space in Teleport II is rented. Only 3,300 square feet has been taken so far. Teleport I is fully rented. **********Opening a speculative office building, no matter the size, at a time when the commercial marketplace has a surfeit of space, looks like a risky venture. In Manhattan alone there is more than 59 million square feet of prime and secondary space available and tenants are not shy about shopping around for a good deal, said Franklin C. Speyer, a vice president at Cushman & Wakefield, the national real estate brokerage firm. **********But Mr. Speyer said the Teleport complex had several advantages that might lure expanding companies as well as those relocating from Manhattan. Prime among them, he said, is the center's access to Staten Island's large and qualified labor force. **********For one tenant, the Teleport Communications Group, being able to retain employees and attract new ones played a role in the decision to move to Staten Island. The company two years ago traded the space it had outgrown at the World Trade Center in Manhattan for 40,000 feet on two floors at the Teleport. **********John J. Reiser Jr, the company's vice president for administration and human resources, said that while he was able to take to Staten Island 60 of the 80 employees, he had no trouble attracting an additional 75 people. ''Half of our employees,'' he said, ''are borough residents.'' **********Further tempering the vagaries of the market is the package of state- and city-sponsored incentives offered to tenants moving into the complex. The incentives, initiated to draw companies to the outer boroughs, and indeed to keep them from leaving the city, are savings on real estate taxes, on commercial occupancy taxes and on sales taxes for any interior construction work. There are also savings on electricity, which is supplied at low rates by the Power Authority of the State of New York. **********Mr. Reiser said that relocating to the Teleport had saved his company 40 to 50 percent on maintenance and operating expenses alone. **********Another factor is Teleport's unusual position as a high-tech office park. The centerpieces of the development are an 11-acre satellite station for national and international telecommunications and a regional fiber-optic network for data transmission throughout the metropolitan region. Teleport's 24-hour security and communications management on-site also helps, Mr. Speyer said. **********Jeffrey C. Siegel, a senior vice president at Murray Construction, said he was ''guardedly optimistic'' about leasing Teleport II. The tenant for the space already leased is Teleport Management division, which is responsible for operating the communications services at the complex. It is moving from Teleport I, where Allstate will take the space it is vacating there. **********Asking rents at Teleport II are $28 a square foot. The rent at Teleport I averages $26 a square foot. **********Another developer, Lehrer McGovern Bovis of Manhattan, is planning a 120,000-square-foot building on 10 acres at the complex, but it will be a build-to-suit structure for a tenant still to be found. Peter Lehrer, the company's chairman, said he hopes this project will be completed by 1991. In addition to that, a final 6.9-acre site remains open for development.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/13/busin.body_text: **********Trading in the stock of the NCR Corporation was halted by the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, after a Reuters news agency headline caused exchange officials to believe there were dramatic new developments in the takeover fight between NCR and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. **********Yesterday afternoon Reuters flashed a headline on its financial wire reporting that NCR's chairman, Charles E. Exley Jr., said NCR had received "expressions of interest" from other companies. **********It was not clear from the headline, however, that Mr. Exley was simply repeating a statement he had made a number of times since last week. Exchange officials stopped trading in NCR stock for the day at 3:29 P.M. The stock closed down 37.5 cents, at $89.50. **********"We halted it for news dissemination, one of the standard reasons we would halt trading in a stock," an exchange spokeswoman, Sharon Gasmin, said. **********The stock of A.T.&T. closed at $30.375, up 87.5 cents. **********The NCR board is scheduled to meet today to consider A.T.&T.'s $90-a-share cash offer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/19/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices took their worst tumble in five months yesterday, with analysts attributing the fall to heavy computer program selling, a weak bond market and renewed worry over corporate profits and the interest-rate outlook. **********The Dow Jones industrial average fell 53.71 points, to 2,882.18, with 12 blue-chip issues in the 30-stock index showing losses of a point or more. **********The 1.83 percent drop was the Dow's worst one-day loss since Jan. 22, when it fell 77.45 points, or 2.89 percent. **********Three American financial exchanges announced plans yesterday for all-night trading of stocks and options, starting in 1992, putting them in potential conflict with a similar system announced last week by the New York Stock Exchange. [Page D2.]  Volume at 133.47 Million The market slid steadily throughout the session in light volume, with no rally to take stocks to higher ground after Friday's record close at 2,935.89. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 6.03, to 356.88, and declining issues outstripped advancing ones, 1,230 to 353. **********Volume reached 133.47 million shares, compared with Friday's heavy trading of 205.13 million shares. **********''I think the main reason for the drop was a lot of sell programs pushing the market down,'' said Sung Won Sohn, the chief economist at the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis. ''There was no fundamental news to trigger such a decline.'' **********He added that the decline in the bond market had a big impact on stocks, as did some of the economic numbers that were issued last week, causing anxious investors to take some profits after Friday's rally. **********The economic reports, investors had hoped, would show a weak economy that would convince the Federal Reserve that it could trim short-term interest rates. **********Last week's figures showed, Mr. Sohn said, that the economy is weak but the inflation rate is unacceptably high for the Fed, dashing any hopes that the central bank will ease credit in the next few months. **********On Friday, the Government reported that consumer prices rose two-tenths of a percent in May; on Thursday, it said prices at the producer level rose three-tenths of a percent last month. **********Focus on Earnings **********''There's a tug-of-war between corporate profits and interest rates in the stock market,'' Mr. Sohn said. ''When corporate profits are not doing well that tends to pull the market down. But that has been more than offset by optimism regarding low interest rates. Now that it seems we're not likely to get low interest rates, the focus is back to profits.'' **********Earnings results for the second quarter will start to come out in early July, and investors who believed this market would finish out the quarter with a strong kick may be surprised, said Robert H. Stovall, head of Stovall/Twenty-First Advisers Inc. **********''A few more days like today, and it might not look so bad to be underinvested when the quarter closes,'' he said. **********I.B.M. lost 1 5/8, to 118 3/4, in heavy volume, leading some technology stocks down. **********Among other blue-chip losers, Procter & Gamble dropped 1 7/8, to 82 1/2; Philip Morris, 1 1/4, to 42 3/4; 3M, 1 1/4, to 86 3/8; Chevron, 1, to 71; Kodak, 1, to 41; General Motors, 1 1/8, to 49 1/8; International Paper, 1 1/8, to 53 1/4; General Electric, 1, to 69 1/8; Merck, 1 3/8, to 81 1/2; Boeing, 1 1/8, to 59, and United Technologies, 1 3/8, to 58 7/8. **********Among technology stocks, Compaq Computer dropped 4 3/8, to 123 5/8. An Oppenheimer analyst, Edmund Spelman, dropped the issue from his recommended list, citing its recent price appreciation. **********Southeastern Banking led the most-active list, down 1/2, to 10 1/2, after Moody's Investors Service downgraded its senior debt and commercial paper ratings, citing a weak Florida real estate market. **********Wells Fargo lost 2 1/2, to 77, and another Western banking institution, HomeFed, fell 1 1/4, to 22 1/4. BankAmerica lost 1, to 29 7/8. Citicorp dropped 1/2, to 23, and Bank of New York fell 1 1/8, to 33 3/8. **********Among financial issues, Federal Home Loan Mortgage lost 1 5/8, to 75 1/2, and Federal National Mortgage 1 1/2, to 40 1/8. **********Chrysler Gains **********Chrysler bucked the trend and finished up 3/8, to 15 1/2. Analysts said speculation about a possible alliance between Chrysler and Fiat had intensified. **********Walt Disney, which gained last week on good reviews for the movie ''Dick Tracy,'' fell 4 5/8, to 127 1/8, after weekend box office results were lower than those of some other blockbuster film debuts. **********Plum Creek Timber fell 2 5/8, to 25 1/4. An article in The Wall Street Journal about the company's forest-cutting policies described it as ''one of the Pacific Northwest's most controversial corporate citizens.'' **********Scott Paper was ahead 1, to 47, on a buy recommendation reiterated by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, while Stone Container, another paper products company, lost 1 3/4, to 17 3/4. **********Software Toolworks, which makes software for Nintendo machines, sank 4 7/8, to 19, in over-the-counter trading after an article in Barron's characterized the company's outlook as lackluster. **********The Nasdaq composite index sank 6.76, to 460.79. In over-the-counter trading, Nike, the athletic shoe company, lost 2 3/4, to 76; Sun Microsystems dropped 1, to 32 7/8, and Intel fell 1 1/4, to 47. **********The American Stock Exchange market value index fell 3.27, to 360.76.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/09/world.main_headline: OPPOSITION GAINING A BIT IN NICARAGUA
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/09/world.print_headline: OPPOSITION GAINING A BIT IN NICARAGUA
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/09/world.body_text: **********In the heated election battle between the Government and its opponents, it is perhaps no surprise that an opposition rally on Sunday ended in a shoving match. What was notable was that the fight involved only one side: bickering leaders of the main anti-Government coalition. **********The scuffle, over who should lead a local march, was overshadowed by an outpouring of support for the coalition's presidential candidate, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, who was greeted by the largest crowd of her campaign when she arrived at the rally. Although estimates of the crowd vary, Mrs. Chamorro has routinely begun to draw 10,000 to 15,000 people at her rallies. **********But to the opposition's friends and enemies, the quarrel was a reminder of the precarious foundation of what has become the most important political challenge to the decade-old Sandinista revolution. With less than three weeks left before election day, Feb. 25, the 14-party National Opposition Union is being carried forward by a surge of support, grounded in unhappiness with economic conditions under the Sandinista Government, largely brought about by United States sanctions. **********Riven at All Levels **********There is little solid polling data on whether the opposition has a chance to defeat the Government, which musters huge crowds for its own rallies. Even with recently released American funds to help it along, the Chamorro group is considered an underdog. **********But even at its highest levels, the group remains riven by personal and political divisions that have undercut its campaign and raised doubts about its ability to govern if elected. **********''When you talk about the opposition, you're talking about the people, not the leaders,'' said a diplomat with long experience here. ''If there is a groundswell against the Government, it will come from the bottom up.'' **********Among the underlying weaknesses of UNO, as the opposition coalition is known, is the extraordinary diversity of its parties, which range from conservatives to Communists. Those differences have led to tensions in the coalition's 14-member executive council, and are compounded because the relative strength of many parties has never been proven in a big election. **********It was largely to overcome those disagreements that party leaders reached outside their own ranks for a presidential candidate. Mrs. Chamorro, the widow of the most respected victim of the struggle against Anastasio Somoza Debayle, the deposed dictator, was seen as an ideal, apolitical compromise among the competing parties. ''Violeta Chamorro doesn't have any political identity,'' a Western ambassador in Managua said. ''So every group could project its views within her silhouette.'' **********Though she has bridged the ideological differences of her alliance, Mrs. Chamorro, publisher of Nicaragua's main opposition newspaper, La Prensa, has introduced new frictions of her own, largely by ignoring party leaders in favor of her close advisers, most of whom are tied to her family. **********Tight Circle of Advisers **********Mrs. Chamorro's adviser for political affairs is her eldest son, Pedro Joaquin Chamorro Barrios. Her campaign manager, Antonio Lacayo Oyanguren, is her son-in-law. And the head of her advisers, Alfredo Cesar Aguirre, is Mr. Lacayo's brother-in-law. **********Although technically responsible to the 14-member political council of party leaders, Mrs. Chamorro has relied almost exclusively on her family advisers for campaign strategy. Opposition officials say that the result has been a sharp growth in suspicion and mistrust on both sides. **********Tension has focused particularly on Mr. Cesar, a former contra leader and respected political tactician whose personal ambitions are the subject of deep distrust among traditional party leaders. Resentments among Mrs. Chamorro's circle have in turn centered on Virgilio Godoy Reyes, the veteran Liberal Party leader who is Mrs. Chamorro's vice-presidential running mate. He is seen by many of her supporters as maneuvering to serve as a shadow president if she were to win. **********''Most of the friction has been due not so much to political differences but to the lack of political experience among all Nicaraguans,'' Mr. Lacayo said in an interview at the coalition headquarters. ''Until now, nobody here knew what a campaign was.'' But tensions broke into conflict in November when party leaders voted to expel Mr. Cesar from a post on the political council. **********The problem reached a point of crisis early this year when Mrs. Chamorro was forced to leave the country for treatment of a broken knee. Delays in financing and bureaucratic infighting left the UNO campaign almost invisible for one of its most critical months. **********The situation was saved, diplomats and opposition members say, not by reconciliation in the leadership but by an unexpected outpouring of support on Mrs. Chamorro's return in January. **********On three successive weekends, UNO rallies came alive with an enthusiasm that opposition leaders are at a loss to explain. That surge has been consolidated by the partial release of long-awaited election funds from the United States and other sources, leading to the first noticeable burst of UNO street signs and posters. And it has reassured some restive party leaders that the alliance is worth the effort. **********Gains Miskito Ally **********In an extraordinary step to head off new differences, Mrs. Chamorro and party leaders last week signed an accord, negotiated by Mr. Cesar, reaffirming her allegiance to the 14-party coalition and promising to take their views into account. And the alliance has grown larger, gaining the support of a Miskito Indian group whose leader, Brooklyn Rivera, was today named to Mrs. Chamorro's advisory group. **********Those changes have helped repair the damage from incidents like last Sunday's onstage scuffle, when Mr. Lacayo and a chief aide to Mr. Godoy squared off over the conduct of an opposition march in the town of Posoltega, 50 miles north of Managua. **********With little time left before election day, diplomats and politicians agree that UNO's health is likely to depend not on strategy from its leaders but on the support it receives from the streets. And opposition leaders are betting that the object of their quarreling will also be its cure. ''Most of these problems will be solved,'' predicted Mr. Lacayo, ''when we see the results.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/28/world.main_headline: STRONG DRUG FOE WINS IN COLOMBIA BY A WIDE MARGIN
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/28/world.print_headline: STRONG DRUG FOE WINS IN COLOMBIA BY A WIDE MARGIN
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/28/world.body_text: **********Ignoring terrorist threats by cocaine traffickers, millions of Colombians voted for president today and elected Cesar Gaviria Trujillo, the candidate who advocated the toughest line on the traffickers. **********''This vote is a triumph of democracy over violence,'' said the outgoing President, Virgilio Barco Vargas. **********Voting was largely peaceful and, in many places, festive - a sharp departure from the tense and bloody campaign that claimed the lives of three presidential candidates in nine months. **********''Although we are all afraid, we are ready to fight for peace,'' Arturo Romero, a 23-year-old university student, said as he waited to cast his ballot for Mr. Gaviria at a polling booth here. ''For me it is important to back democracy and to challenge the violent people by voting freely.'' **********Voters Are Searched **********On the alert after a rash of bombings of public places, police and army units maintained strict security around the country, often inspecting handbags and frisking voters. **********Though it was unclear whether the traffickers' terror campaign succeeded in reducing the turnout, the turnout of some 6 million voters was lower than that of four years ago, when 7.2 million Colombians voted in the last presidential election. **********With 89 percent of the vote counted, Mr. Gaviria, candidate of the governing Liberal Party, claimed victory with 47 percent. Alvaro Gomez Hurtado of the National Salvation Movement was running second with 24 percent. Antonio Navarro Wolff, a former guerrilla leader, had 13 percent , and Rodrigo Lloreda of the Social Conservative Party had 12 percent. **********In his victory address tonight, Mr. Gaviria hailed the vote. ''Everyone who wanted to threaten our democracy, listen to us: The people spoke today with courage and clarity. We will overcome,'' he said. He also chastised the industrial countries who ''are doing little to confront the drug consumption problem,'' and appealed for help in fighting arms trafficking and money laundering. **********Mr. Gomez, Mr. Navarro and Mr. Lloreda conceded tonight that Mr. Gaviria had won the race, but Mr. Navarro expressed satisfaction with his showing. **********''We are new political phenomenon of the 1990's in Colombia,'' said Mr. Navarro, whose party, the M-19, abandoned guerrilla warfare in March for a political role. **********The candidate with the most votes wins the election, even if he falls short of 50 percent. **********The early returns were no surprise, since they were predicted in a series of polls conducted in recent weeks. **********A 30-city survey of 15,000 voters conducted by Caracol, a private radio network, predicted that Mr. Gaviria would win 50 percent of the vote, with Mr. Gomez running second with 23 percent. **********Mr. Gaviria said on television after the polls closed at 5 P.M., ''I am supremely optimistic, tranquil and satisfied.'' **********A 43-year-old economist, Mr. Gaviria will be Colombia's youngest President in this century when he takes office on Aug. 7, succeeding Mr. Barco, 68, who cannot constitutionally succeed himself at the end of his four-year term. **********Mr. Barco began a crackdown on the cocaine traffickers last August after Luis Carlos Galan, a popular reform politician who was also a presidential candidate, was fatally dead on the orders of the Medellin cartel. **********With the death of Mr. Galan, Mr. Gaviria, a former Finance Minister, took up his banners of fighting the cocaine processing and exporting business, an industry believed to earn billions of dollars a year for traffickers here. Mr. Gaviria's campaign against the dealers became more vocal as they turned to terrorism, trying to force Colombia to abandon its policies of seizing laboratories and extraditing Colombian suspects to the United States for trial. **********''We have to break terrorism, we have to defeat terrorism,'' the candidate said in an interview on Friday in his heavily fortified camapaign headquarters here. **********''We don't have many alternatives,'' said Mr. Gaviria, who was better known here in the 1980's as a conservative tax reformer than as a crime buster. ''We can't allow those practicing terrorism to believe that they can change government policies by placing bombs.'' **********Reflecting the pervasiveness of political violence in Colombia, today's presidential race brought together kidnapper, kidnap victim and negotiator. **********Constitutional Revision Endorsed **********In 1988, Mr. Gomez was kidnapped by the M-19 guerrilla movement, whose second in command was Mr. Navarro. At the time of the kidnapping, Mr. Barco was out of the country. The job of negotiating Mr. Gomez's freedom fell to the President's designated replacement and Minister of Government, Mr. Gaviria. **********Official returns showed that 89 percent of the voters were in favor of a calling for a convention to revise Colombia's 104-year-old Constitution. **********In 1988, Mr. Gaviria's successful negotiation of the M-19 kidnapping was a key factor in elevating the young Cabinet minister in the public eye. **********Besides the three presidential candidates, 262 policemen, 93 soldiers, 3 judges, 15 press employees and about 1,700 other people were slain during the nine-month campaign. But today, the only major violence reported appeared to have been caused by the National Liberation Army, a Marxist guerrilla group that urged an electoral boycott. **********The Defense Ministry reported six attacks today by the guerrilla group, with no casualties. The police reported that four Liberation Army guerrillas were killed today in an operation that freed unharmed a kidnapped petroleum engineer in Bogota. **********As of nightfall, the traffickers had not carried out any major attacks. **********In a nationally broadcast television address, President Barco said he had no doubt that the traffickers' assassinations and bombings or recent months ''were undertaken to intimidate the popular will.'' **********The police announced on Saturday the dismantling of a traffickers' bomb factory in a suburb here and the capture of six members of the ring.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/13/world.main_headline: Management Woes Hobble U.S. Air Fleet in Drug War
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/13/world.print_headline: Management Woes Hobble U.S. Air Fleet in Drug War
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/13/world.body_text: **********A private air force organized by the State Department to support United States paramilitary operations against the illicit drug industry in Latin America has developed an array of management problems, officials involved in the program say. **********The program uses private pilots to fly United States Government helicopter gunships, transport planes and crop-dusters used by American drug agents and foreign police officers in operations barred to United States military personnel, like raids on cocaine laboratories. Many of the pilots are veterans of the Vietnam War or of service with the Central Intelligence Agency. **********Tangled Lines of Authority **********The program, begun in 1987, before the Pentagon became active in antidrug efforts, has many problems stemming from the State Department's inexperience in paramilitary and law enforcement activities, documents and officials involved indicate. **********Two outside consulting companies help manage the operations of the private aviation company that runs the program, creating tangled lines of authority. Some of the pilots, who earn up to $150,000 a year, went on strike for higher pay. More than a quarter of the force has been laid off because of cost overruns and 5 of the fleet's 53 planes have been destroyed, resulting in the loss of 10 lives. **********In addition, some personnel were caught pilfering from the Government and a chief operations officer was indicted for conspiring to smuggle drugs from Mexico before taking the State Department job. **********Concern over the program's management has mounted in Congress as the United States has stepped up its anti-drug activities in Colombia, Peru and Bolivia, where the line between fighting drugs and fighting insurgencies is becoming increasingly blurred. **********The pilots played a crucial role in the firefight two months ago at an anti-drug base in Santa Lucia, Peru, piloting a helicopter gunship that repelled an attack by the Shining Path guerrillas, who protect the cocaine barons, and helping kill a number of rebels. **********Military Increases Its Role **********The United States military, now committed to broadening its role in anti-drug efforts but barred from direct participation because of the sensitivity of foreign governments, is providing aid in areas like intelligence-gathering and training. All the activities are coordinated by the State Department's Bureau of International Narcotics Matters, which has been headed since last year by Assistant Secretary of State Melvyn Levitsky. **********In an interview, Mr. Levitsky said that ''while everybody beats up on this air wing,'' the department's management of the operation had improved. He said the program had been successful in building up the ability of other countries to fight drug production and trafficking and in reducing marijuana production in Colombia, Guatemala and Jamaica. **********He added that his bureau was borrowing 30 military officials from the Pentagon to help manage what he called ''an enterprise that is more or less foreign to the culture of the institution in which it is functioning.'' **********The enterprise revolves around a Pennsylvania-based aviation services company, Corporate Jets. Some 150 employees fly and maintain the State Department's fleet of UH-1H and Bell 212 helicopters, T-65 Turbothrush spray planes and various transport aircraft that make up the aerial support program. Based in Opa-Locka, Fla., and operating for security reasons under the name National Air Transport Inc., the enterprise is the linchpin for some of the Government's most sensitive operations. **********The air wing operators use the Florida headquarters for logistical support, but most of the planes are based in Latin America, where they are used in remote areas by agents of the Drug Enforcement Administration and foreign police officers to spray crops, supply food and equipment to base camps, make aerial surveys, transport personnel and help interdict drug supply lines. **********The logistical operation includes the maintenance of the air fleet, the supply of fuel and spare parts, and the training of foreign pilots. The work rules for the contract employees are not clearly defined. They are not provided with weapons, though they often carry them, and are not required to be trained in combat operations, although they find themselves in combat situations. **********The State Department's aerial support role stems from a decision by Congress in 1986 that the United States must retain title to aircraft used in anti-drug operations abroad. As the Pentagon was reluctant at the time to become involved, the State Department, which is responsible for anti-drug operations abroad, turned to an outside contractor. The arrangement, officials said, permits the Government to deny the involvement of Federal officials but leaves the United States with less control over the contract employees' actions. **********In the 1960's and 1970's the C.I.A. operated a secret air force in Southeast Asia and elsewhere, including an air charter company, Air America. The company was liquidated in the 1970's, although some of the people who worked for Air America were hired by Corporate Jets and were involved in operations like the firefight in Peru. **********The State Department program has attracted little public attention, though Congress has provided funds for its expansion and reviewed questions about the program raised by department investigators. **********The State Department's Inspector General, Sherman M. Funk, said last year that Corporate Jets had been allowed to operate ''virtually carte blanche.'' And in January the Pentagon's Defense Logistics Agency found that the company was not complying with numerous parts of its contract. **********Mr. Funk also cited as inappropriate the use of an outside consulting company to prepare the air wing's budget. That company helps oversee Corporate Jets, creating yet another tier of supervision and further blurring the management of the program. **********This same consulting company helped design the 1988 bidding process that was won by Corporate Jets. The contract is now being rebid, again with the consulting company's help, because the earlier contest was flawed, according to public documents. **********Memos Are Unanswered **********State Department investigators praised Mr. Levitsky's recent efforts to improve the bureau's management, but problems remain. The narcotics bureau, which told Congress last year that it provided direction over Corporate Jets on a ''daily basis,'' has not responded in recent months to dozens of memos from the aviation company on all facets of the operation. **********Company officials said they had provided safe and efficient services and charged the State Department with poor management. **********William Smith, a vice president, said in an interview that the department had modified the contract 17 times, had ignored monthly reports and had not responded to 34 memos written between March and May involving issues like export licenses, Pentagon contact, inspections, computer systems, night vision goggle training, and parts and inventory control. **********Andrew Thoms, the narcotics bureau's director of transnational issues, said the memos and reports would be dealt with once an appropriate management information system had been completed by still another consulting company. But department investigators and company employees said the issues raised in the memos required a quicker response. **********Pilots Strike Over Pay **********The issue of combat-related training, including the use of night vision goggles, arose after the Shining Path attack on the Santa Lucia base in Peru, in which at least one pilot, despite rules to the contrary, used night goggles to operate his helicopter. The State Department contract has no provision for such training, Mr. Thoms and Corporate Jets officials said. **********The risky nature of the work led some of Corporate Jets' pilots, who earn $120,000 to $150,000 a year, to strike for higher pay in April. About the same time the company, at the insistence of the State Department, laid off about a quarter of its personnel, including 6 of 14 spray pilots, Mr. Thoms and Mr. Smith said. Budget constraints necessitate a further 10 percent reduction by August. **********Mr. Levitsky said that a 10 percent overrun on spending, one of the causes for the layoffs, was now under control. **********A series of legal problems has also affected the program in the last few months. The company's chief aircraft operations officer in the program was indicted in February for conspiring to smuggle drugs from Mexico before working for the State Department, according to officials and documents. **********And in recent months, according to investigators and documents, a senior company pilot pleaded guilty to theft from the Government and a supervisor pleaded guilty to stealing $150,000 worth of State Department helicopter parts. Other cases involving possible criminal misuse of the program are pending, including an allegation that the former program manager improperly refurbished his own plane with State Department property. **********Last year officials involved in the program told Mr. Funk's auditors that the $64 million cost of aquiring and managing the spare parts inventory could be reduced by a third through better management and procurement practices. **********Mr. Levitsky took issue with that estimate but in the interview referred questions about the department's inventory to Mr. Thoms. Mr. Thoms said he could not provide firm numbers until the Army completed a survey for the State Department. **********Some Planes Are Grounded **********On the loss of the five planes, Mr. Levitsky said that concern about safety had led to the recent grounding of some spray planes. The planes were lost because of mechanical problems, pilot error and sabotage, he said. **********The program's $28 million budget for this year was increased by $4.7 million last month when funds were shifted from other accounts in the narcotics bureau. The bureau, in a shift still under review by Congress, wants to increase its own $113 million budget this year by transferring $16.5 million in military aid for law enforcement efforts in Colombia and Bolivia. **********The Pentagon, which has given its approval to the transfer, is increasingly involved in the air-support program, providing airfields, aircraft, spare parts, investigators and managers, according to documents and officials. **********A new supervisor brought in from the Pentagon, Col. David Rankin, was a military attache in El Salvador during the height of efforts to help the Nicaraguan contras and repel Salvadoran guerrillas.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/18/world.main_headline: Leader Warns Poles of More Change
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/18/world.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;   Leader Warns Poles of More Change
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/18/world.body_text: **********Six months after taking office as the Eastern bloc's first non-Communist Prime Minister since the early postwar years, Tadeusz Mazowiecki counts his major achievement as maintaining the confidence of Poles in the face of difficult changes. **********''Changes are taking place across a very wide range and society continues to grant its trust to this Government,'' Mr. Mazoweicki, once jailed for opposition, said in an interview. ''That is most important. **********''We are making the deepest kind of changes. We are simultaneously making a transformation in politics and in the economy, in the development of democracy and the development of a free market.'' **********Mr. Mazowiecki, a Roman Catholic intellectual and Solidarity supporter, said that perhaps the greatest challenge was what he called his Government's ''courageous'' program of drastic free-market shock therapy, intended to transform Poland's laggard Communist economy into capitalism. **********Dangers of Transformation **********''The very basic issue is the problem of how much the society can withstand,'' he said, referring to the dangers of high prices, production cutbacks and unemployment that could result during the transformation. **********One immediate accomplishment, the Prime Minister said, was Poland's inclusion in border discussions during talks on German reunification involving the two Germanys and the four Allies. ''This insures there will be nothing about us without us.'' **********As Eastern European nations once under Soviet dominance hold elections that will reshape the political map of Europe, Poland remains in the forefront of change. **********When Solidarity was born in the Gdansk shipyards in 1980, Mr. Mazowiecki, along with Bronislaw Geremek, a medieval historian, were among the first intellectuals to support the fledgling trade union. Mr. Geremek now leads the Solidarity bloc in Parliament. **********Eyes Have Haunted Look **********Mr. Mazowiecki, a gray-haired man whose lined, craggy face and deep-set eyes sometimes have a haunted look, was interned for a year after the martial law crackdown in December 1981. Now he is working closely with his old jailers, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, now the President, and Gen. Czeslaw Kiszczak, the Minister of Internal Affairs. **********Mr. Mazowiecki is capable of a certain dry wit. When he suffered a dizzy spell from overwork when his Cabinet was sworn in last September, he told Parliament: ''I have reached the same state as the Polish economy.'' **********Mr. Mazowiecki played a critical role in the talks last year that led to the legalization of Solidarity and free elections. His prominence as a Catholic intellectual and editor is testimony to the political importance of the Roman Catholic Church here. **********From Conspirator to Governor **********But the transition from conspirator to governor is unlikely to be easy. While there has been wave after wave of workers' protests against Communism for the last four decades, the biggest problem now, he said, is transforming the economy. **********''The society is convinced the economic system has to be changed,'' the Prime Minister said. ''It is convinced the existing system is outdated and a new one creates hope. People are somehow determined that we should go in that direction.'' **********But, he added, ''the situation in which prices are free and wages, practically speaking, frozen is certainly a difficult one. **********''I think we have gone through the most difficult period on the beginning,'' he said. ''The second very hard problem is the drop in production. The third likely problem is the problem of unemployment, which does not exceed 1 percent of the work force. These are very new and quite difficult problems for Polish society.'' **********Production to Drop Further **********Prices skyrocketed when the new economic plan was introduced in January but have begun to fall sharply in recent weeks when consumers stopped buying. This was according to the plan, but future steps are to include a drop in production - already off 20 percent -the closing of inefficient factories and unemployment. **********Opinion polls show Mr. Mazowiecki's Government enjoying widespread support among a population viewing the Government, for the first time, as largely their own. One simple measure is that there have been no strikes despite the economic hardships. **********But there are the beginnings of signs of impatience. **********The most immediate threat is in the field of agriculture, with increasing grumbling, and some protest demonstrations, among private farmers. **********'Wave of Unrest' Among Farmers **********''A wave of unrest is mounting in the countryside,'' a Rural Solidarity spokesman, Piotr Dabrowski, said this week. ''This stems from a lack of a clear, understandable and acceptable agrarian policy of the state and the fact that the program is exceptionally tough on farmers and poses a threat of a fall in farming production.'' **********Mr. Mazowiecki, who recently met with angry farmers, acknowledged that ''dissatisfaction is beginning to manifest itself in agriculture.'' **********One long-term problem of Polish agriculture has been a system of inheritance that has left small strips of farms that cannot be effectively worked, but that farmers cling to. **********'There Should Be Larger Farms' **********''This is one of the problems that we note. There should be larger farms,'' Mr. Mazowiecki said. ''But this can only be changed if you create in the countryside conditions for different types of employment. We need the development of services and a processing industry and private investment. This cannot be done fast. This is only six months of this Government and three months of the reform,'' he said. **********In his inaugural speech last September, in which he emphasized he was taking office as a ''man of Solidarity,'' Mr. Mazowiecki pledged that he would overhaul the army and the police so that Poles would learn ''to treat the state as their own.'' **********Earlier this month, in his most significant appointment thus far, he named an outsider, a Catholic intellectual like himself from the former opposition, as Deputy Minister of Internal Affairs, the agency that runs the police, including the old secret security apparatus. The new Minister is Krzysztof Kozlowski, the deputy editor of Tygodnik Powszechny, the respected Catholic weekly that had been the only legal opposition publication under martial law. **********''You might say this is a personnel change, but it is a structural change as well,'' the Prime Minister said. **********''Some people think things are not going fast enough,'' he said. ''But as far as I am concerned, the changes are deep and they require stable conditions.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/07/world.main_headline: Fugitive German Spy Planning to Surrender After Elections
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/07/world.print_headline: Fugitive German Spy Planning to Surrender After Elections
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/07/world.body_text: **********East Germany's former master spy, Markus Wolf, who is in hiding, said today that he intended to return to Germany and hand himself over to the justice authorities after the reunited country holds elections in December. **********As a measure of his influence in formerly Communist East Germany, Mr. Wolf's retirement from the notorious Ministry for State Security in September 1986 was kept secret for six months, apparently not to diminish respect in the West for the foreign intelligence operation he built up over 33 years. **********Mr. Wolf, 67 years old, was interviewed by reporters from the weekly Stern, but the magazine abided by his wish not to disclose his location. "Among your readers there is also the general prosecutor for the state," he said. Since early October, when the two Germanys united, the Bonn Government has made it known that it is seeking Mr. Wolf on espionage charges. **********Puzzlement over the whereabouts of Mr. Wolf has been a major topic of speculation since he disappeared from his East Berlin apartment shortly after the Government said it would seek to arrest him. **********Alluding to that announcement, Mr. Wolf told his interviewers that the publicity surrounding his case prompted him to flee Germany. Reported in Hungary **********Though Mr. Wolf has remained in hiding, the Bild newspaper, a sensational daily that has nonetheless obtained reliable information on espionage and security issues, said it would report in its Wednesday edition that Mr. Wolf escaped Germany through Prague, Vienna and Switzerland to Hungary, where it said he has been receiving treatment for a disk ailment. **********It said he intends to travel shortly to Moscow to present the Russian-language edition of his best-selling book, "Troika." The book describes the lives of three families who lived together in Moscow and followed separate paths during World War II. **********After retiring from the Ministry for State Security, Mr. Wolf became a leading public proponent of change in East Germany. In the interview he described a meeting early in 1989 with the East German Communist leader, Erich Honecker, that Mr. Wolf said he sought to protest censorship of parts of a film about his father, Friedrich Wolf, a prominent doctor and early Communist in prewar Germany. **********But Mr. Wolf said the "main topic of the conversation was the increasing rejection of the Gorbachev course by the party leadership" and the persecution of Communist Party members who promoted change. **********"The G.D.R. was on the way to becoming a second Albania," he said, referring to East Germany by the initials of its formal name. Impression of Thoughtfulness **********Throughout the interview, Mr. Wolf appeared to be at pains to project an image of himself as a reform-minded Communist, and to emphasize the role of Communists, and even officials in the state security service, in promoting change in East Germany. As in past interviews, he projected an image of himself as a man whose access to information and license to ponder the growing problems of his homeland galvanized his oppostion to the status quo. **********In a kind of confession, he said, "Everyone who had a high function in a socialist country in the last decades bears responsiblity, if not in a legal then in a moral sense." **********But he insisted that he remains a Communist, "at least in the sense of the ideals," and a member of the Party of Democratic Socialism, the much-weakened successor to the East German Communist Party. **********Mr. Honecker's steadfast resistance to the changes promoted by the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, long after they had been adopted in other East European countries was among the factors that accelerated his fall and speeded the collapse of Communism in East Germany. **********Mr. Wolf, a large, dapper man who in his heyday sported well-tailored suits, described how officers of the state security, known as the Stasi, posted notices at their headquarters in the waning months of Communist rule calling for change. Rumblings at the Stasi **********In the courtyard of the huge Stasi complex, in a residential area of East Berlin, "there was a demonstration in which demands were raised for changes in the leadership, for changes in activity," he said. **********Criticizing management of the Stasi, Mr. Wolf suggested in the interview that the mountains of information it gathered on people in all walks of life ultimately worked to its undoing. "In this mass of information you could lose sight of that which the security organ of a state is actually supposed to be doing," he said. **********Mr. Wolf said the course of events in Eastern Europe had forced him to re-evalute his work. **********"We know the horrible and tragic example of how Stalin handled the information about the coming war," he said, alluding to the view that the wartime Soviet leader had obtained advance information of the impending invasion of Russia in 1941 by Nazi forces, but had refused to act on it on political grounds. **********Mr. Wolf confessed that until about November 1989, he had been convinced that the suppression of freedom under Communism had been "deformations" in need of correction, but that he had gradually come to the conviction that "this entire system, from the beginning, was incapable of functioning." **********"That is naturally a bitter conviction," he went on, "because one must naturally then pose the question whether one has lived in vain." **********But he said he remained convinced that "certain values"of Communism persisted, "even if for the time being they have been buried over for the long term."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/06/busin.body_text: **********The Securities and Exchange Commission on Wednesday suspended the trading of Southland Communication Inc. for 10 days, citing uncertainty about a possible undisclosed change in control at the small paging company, based in Santa Ana, Calif. **********Southland's stock had attracted attention because of its meteoric ascent since the beginning of March, rising to as much as $17.375 a share, from $8.25. This included a one-day jump of 43 percent. The stock last traded on Tuesday at $16.75. **********The stock's advance was accomplished without any positive news from the company itself. **********The commission said it was ordering the suspension in part because of the recent market activity.
