https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/03/world.main_headline: ISRAEL TO CENSOR NEWS ON EMIGRES
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/03/world.print_headline: ISRAEL TO CENSOR NEWS ON EMIGRES
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/03/world.body_text: **********The Israeli military authorities issued a highly unusual order today requiring news organizations to submit all reports on Soviet Jewish immigration to military censors. **********The order, approved by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, comes as the issue of settling Soviet immigrants in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip continues to plague Mr. Shamir, who said in January that a ''big Israel'' was needed to accommodate the emigres. **********Normally only news reports dealing with certain military and security matters are subject to censorship, and even then the censorship is seldom imposed on material published abroad. It is left to the journalists themselves to decide whether to show their reports to censors, and most never do. **********Request From Immigration **********An official in the Prime Minister's office explained that the new order was issued at the request of the immigration authorities because of Arab opposition to the wave of new immigrants and because of the possibility that some Soviet immigrants might be attacked on their way here. **********But the order was not limited to information about how the Soviet Jews arrive. It was sweeping. The army communique, issued to everyone in the domestic and foreign press, read, ''The army censor announces that all material pertaining to the immigration of Soviet Jews must be submitted to the censor prior to publication.'' **********The Association of Foreign Correspondents in Israel issued a protest today. And recognizing that the order was likely to cause criticism and debate, the official in the Prime Minister's office said the question of whether the censorship requirement would be kept in place will be put before the Cabinet, which is to meet on Sunday. **********It was Mr. Shamir himself who drew Arab attention to Soviet Jewish immigration and the possibility that some of the immigrants might move to the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. **********''Shamir's talk of a big Israel can't be forgiven,'' said the Labor Party leader, Shimon Peres. ''It caused damage that can't be fixed.'' **********Mr. Shamir's ''big Israel'' speech, as it has come to be known, has set off almost two months of extraordinary and continuous complaint from all quarters, and especially from the Arab world. Last month, the Soviet Union retracted a commercial agreement to begin direct flights between Israel and the Soviet Union for Soviet immigrants because of Arab protests over Mr. Shamir's remark. **********Now most immigrants fly to Budapest or Bucharest, Romania, where they transfer to El Al charter flights -a cumbersome and not always reliable process that cannot accommodate the numbers of Soviet Jews who want to leave. Direct flights were badly needed, and Mr. Shamir's political opponents blame him for the Soviet refusal. **********But Avi Pazner, a close aide to the Prime Minister, said it was unfair to attribute all that to Mr. Shamir. **********''That's a mistake,'' he said. ''The Arabs were already worried by the big numbers'' and would have protested to Moscow even without Mr. Shamir. **********Still, no one in the Arab world or anywhere else had openly complained about the huge wave of Soviet immigration before Mr. Shamir's speech -despite at least six months of intense press converage of the matter. **********About 10,300 Soviet Jews moved to Israel in the first two months of 1990, almost as many as arrived in all of 1989. The numbers grow larger every month, causing Israel to constantly enlarge its estimates. **********Last fall, when the state budget was drafted, officials were expecting 40,000 Soviet Jews to arrive in 1990. Money was allocated for settling that many. But by the time the budget was put into place at the start of the year, the estimate had risen to 100,000. Then last week, an immigration official said the latest estimate was that 230,000 Soviet immigrants would move here next year. **********Israel is requesting more than $1 billion in loans, gifts and donations from American Jews and from the United States Government to help pay for resettling the Soviet Jews. And paradoxically, Government officials have openly and repeatedly solicited American reporters to write articles on the size and scope of the immigration wave, in the hope that the news coverage would encourage donations. **********Reacting to the criticism this evening, a senior Government official noted that the subject of immigration is included on the Government's long list of possibly censorable topics, along with most everything else that could be the subject of news articles here. But most items on the long list are never actually subjected to censorship. **********The only recent time when censorship has been imposed on immigration articles was in 1985, when Israel was secretly airlifting thousands of Jews from Ethiopia. As the official noted, when someone broke the censorship and published an article about the airlift, the Ethiopians canceled it. **********U.S. GROUP DECLINES TO COMMENT **********The American Jewish organization that most closely monitors Jewish emigration from the Soviet Union said yesterday that it preferred ''not to comment at the moment'' on the Israeli Government's decision to censor news reports from there on the immigration of Soviet Jews into Israel. **********The remark, by Martin A. Wenick, executive director of the National Conference on Soviet Jewry, was relayed to a reporter by Debra Strober, a spokeswoman for the organization. **********Ms. Strober said the Ministry of Absorption in Israel ''provides figures'' on immigration to the conference ''on a monthly basis and we've had no indication that this will cease.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/30/world.main_headline: Upheaval in the East: Rumania;   To an Old Party Chief, The Menace Is Familiar
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/30/world.print_headline: Upheaval in the East: Rumania;   To an Old Party Chief, The Menace Is Familiar
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/30/world.body_text: **********In the early morning, before angry crowds began to surge against the gates of the headquarters of the Peasants' Party, the party's 74-year-old president, Corneliu Coposu, presided in his corner office, chain-smoking Kent cigarettes. **********Before the revolution, the 19th-century building at 34 Boulevard Republicii, with its high ceilings, antique furniture and lace curtains, was used by the Communist Party for special receptions. Today, the atmosphere inside seemed odd and quaint compared with the high-pitched political drama that soon enveloped the street below. **********By midmorning, the crowds outside had become vociferous and threatening, spreading across the street, stopping traffic. The chants took on an increasingly menacing tone. ''Traitors!'' the demonstrators shouted, jutting their fists into the air. ''Coposu, pack your bags and get out of the country!'' **********Inside, people stayed away from the windows, since each time the curtains parted the roar outside grew louder. **********Show of Support Asked **********The crowds were mobilized after an appeal by members of the ruling National Salvation Front on radio and television Sunday for a show of support against opposition groups that were represented as enemies of the revolution. **********As the day wore on, the drama intensified. Calls were made to the Prime Minister, Petre Roman, asking for police and army protection. A delegation of army officers soon arrived, offering to escort Mr. Coposu and other party leaders out of the besieged building. They refused at first, although Mr. Coposu eventually agreed to leave in an armored personnel carrier to make a statement at the television station. **********At about noon, a man in a fur hat with a matching collar burst into the office, announcing himself to be a lawyer ''with two licenses'' and a spokesman for the crowd. Standing back from Mr. Coposu's desk, he erupted into a finger-pointing lecture, warning the Peasants' Party president to leave the building by 1:30 P.M. and get on a plane out of the country. **********His sputtering speech was a litany of historical grievances against the Peasants' Party, ending with an accusation that had become a commonplace with the crowd. ''On Dec. 21 and 22, while we had a revolution in Rumania,'' he said, ''you were sitting in the warmth of Paris, getting fat on the Champs d'Elysees.'' **********The charge that the Peasants' Party is made up of returning emigres seems to stem from publicity about the decision by several former emigrants to rejoin the party. But Mr. Coposu has been in Rumania through the entire Communist era, a point on which he said he wanted to defend himself today on national television. **********No Calming the Crowd **********At 1:30 P.M., the Prime Minister, Mr. Roman, arrived with Cazimir Ionescu, another leader of the front. Going onto the balcony, Mr. Roman tried to calm the crowd, which by now had grown to several thousand. When they could not hear him, he clambered over the side to a soundtruck that had a megaphone. When that also failed, he climbed back into the building for more intense negotiations with Mr. Coposu. **********Through the day, messengers arrived with news from other parts of the country and the city. Party offices in Roman and other towns were reported under attack, he said. Windows had been broken in two other party offices in Bucharest. **********Mr. Coposu, calm and still except for the heavy smoking, never changed expression during the agitation. ''I am not shocked by this,'' he said. ''We are used to this because we have 45 years of Communist methods. They are using the same measures, and the same men.'' **********Since 1947, Mr. Coposu who had been a young leader in the Peasants' Party, has spent 17 years in prison, eight in solitary confinement. He was amnestied in 1965, and spent a year and a half in internal exile. His wife, tried as a French spy, died in prison. After his return to Bucharest, Mr. Coposu, a legal scholar, worked as a mechanic and was kept under close watch. By his reckoning, his house was searched 27 times and he was called in for questioning by the police 200 times. **********With him in the room today was some old comrades from Communist prisons. Like Mr. Coposu, Serban Ghica, 70 years old, had been arrested on July 14, 1947, with thousands of others from the Peasants Party as the Communist Party tightened its grip on the country. **********''After we were released, we kept in contact, although we never talked about politics,'' Mr. Ghica said. ''But we always knew that when they left, we could find each other.'' **********Seeking a Comeback **********The first gathering of about 50 former Peasants' Party leaders took place on Dec. 23, the day after the revolution that overthrew Nicolae Ceausescu, the Communist leader. They issued a broadsheet that soon made its way around the city. **********Since then, the party has been seeking a comeback, although it is still a pale shadow of its prewar strength. On Jan. 11, it claimed 37,000 members in Bucharest and 148,000 in the rest of the country. **********On Sunday, the Peasants' Party was at the head of a demonstration of about 20,000 people that filed to the headquarters of the National Salvation Front, the ruling group that replaced Mr. Ceausescu. Among its members is Silviu Brucan, who Mr. Coposu today said had been chief of the Communist Party press in 1947 and who had called for the death penalty against Mr. Coposu then. **********Today, the Peasants' Party was hit by a backlash, unleashed by some of the people they had struggled against 42 years ago. **********When Mr. Coposu left his house this morning, he said, there were a dozen men - all drunk, he said - who hurled insults at him as he made his way to the headquarters. He and other leaders said their phones at home had been ringing continuously with threatening calls. **********These continued at the headquarters today until the telephone lines were cut. At one point, Mr. Coposu had to advise a young aide to stop trying to argue with the callers about the legitimacy of their insults. **********''It is a waste of time,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/13/busin.main_headline: GE Credit Offers Notes Due in 2008
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/13/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;   GE Credit Offers Notes Due in 2008
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/13/busin.body_text: **********The GE Credit Corporation, a unit of the General Electric Company, is offering $250 million in 8 5/8 percent notes due 2008 through Kidder, Peabody & Company as sole manager. **********Initially the notes were priced at 99.792 to yield 8.67 percent, or about 20 basis points more than an average of five-year and seven-year Treasury securities. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. **********Underwriters said the financing, which was rated triple-A by both Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation, also features a ''put'' option, which allows noteholders to sell the securities back to the company at a price of par on June 15, 1996.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/25/busin.body_text: **********The Zenith Electronics Corporation today reported a second-quarter loss of $11.2 million, compared with a loss of $5.2 million in the period a year earlier. **********Sales fell 14 percent, to $334 million, from $385 million in 1989. **********A general slowdown in television sales during the second quarter resulted in reduced shipments of the company's color television sets and picture tubes. **********Included in the sales decline was the repurchase of color television and VCR products from an independent distributor whose marketing area was acquired by Zenith during the quarter. **********Expenditures for Zenith's two high-definition systems were about $3 million in the second quarter.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/16/world.main_headline: With Loyalty Split, Arab-Americans Fault Hussein, but Question U.S. Too
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/16/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;   With Loyalty Split, Arab-Americans Fault Hussein, but Question U.S. Too
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/16/world.body_text: **********Since the onset of the Persian Gulf crisis two weeks ago, most prominent Arab-Americans have joined the chorus of denunciation against President Saddam Hussein of Iraq for his invasion and annexation of Kuwait. Yet at the end of the chorus, Arab-American voices add one word: but. *********** But why are the American Government and American news organizations so ready to go beyond condemnation and demonize an Arab leader, evoking images of barbarism that Arab-Americans fear may be rooted as much in ethnic stereotypes as in Mr. Hussein's own history? *********** But why does Iraq's crossing of Kuwait's border lead to a rapid deployment of American troops and warplanes to Saudi Arabia, when Israel's crossing into Lebanon in 1982 provoked no such action? *********** And always there, though often muted: But what will happen to us? **********''It's a serious emotional and political burden when your country is fighting your people,'' said Khalil Jahshan, a Palestinian who handles public relations for the National Association of Arab-Americans. **********A Concept of Nationhood **********Mr. Jahshan was one of a number of prominent Arab-Americans, interviewed in recent days, who responded to the crisis with both dispassionate analysis and emotional reflection on the history that unites and divides their people. **********Among Arab-Americans, as in the Arab world, the concept of Arab nationhood - of respect, power and influence for an entire people - exerts a powerful pull, Mr. Jahshan said. ''It's not a movement, not a political party,'' he went on. ''It's basically an emotional desire for Arabs to be one. It's based on the notion of a glorious Arab past, and it's reinforced by the failures of recent history.'' **********The drawing and redrawing of national boundaries in the Middle East over the last century have left the two and a half million Arab-Americans with emotional ties to both present and former lands - Jordan, Syria, Palestine, Lebanon, Yemen, Iraq - and to a larger concept of kinship. **********''When I was growing up in a Lebanese Maronite home in Utica, N.Y., and an Egyptian would come and visit, we kids would be in the kitchen wanting to get a peek at him because he was one of our guys,'' said James Zogby, the 44-year-old president of the Arab American Institute, a Washington lobbying group. ''There is a sense of commonness in culture, tradition and language.'' **********The ''serious emotional and political burden'' cited by Mr. Jahshan can result from a clash between that sense of unity and Arab-Americans' sense of loyalty to the United States. ''For Arab-Americans, this is their first country,'' said Osama Siblani, a native of Lebanon who is publisher of Sada al-Watan, a Detroit newspaper whose circulation of 20,000 makes it the largest Arab-American paper in the United States. ''America is where they chose to live. They fled persecution, oppression and poverty. And now they will try to prevent a catastrophe on both ends.'' **********Focus of Dialogue Changes **********The crisis in the Persian Gulf has wrenched the Arab-American dialogue away from its usual focus on Israel and the Palestinian question and into equally complex terrain involving the Arab states' relations with one another and the resentment of the impoverished Arab countries toward the sheikdoms enriched by oil. But Israel and the perceived inequities of American policy in the Middle East are never far beneath the surface. **********Mr. Zogby, Mr. Jahshan and others repeatedly invoke the comparison with Israel's 1982 invasion, although the comparison does not take into account a crucial difference: that Kuwait had not attacked Iraq, while southern Lebanon was home to Palestinian bases that had repeatedly shelled Israeli territory. Still, the distinction does little to eliminate the perception of Arab-Americans that United States policy in the Middle East has not been evenhanded. **********''Kuwait must be restored,'' said Mr. Zogby. ''Saudi Arabia must be defended. But it is incumbent on America, if we want to win the hearts and minds of the Arab people, to be consistent to principle.'' He said Arab-Americans were ''looking to see that this is more than just a defense of oil.'' **********Many Arab-Americans share another concern: that an American campaign against an Arab state, in this case Iraq, could lead to a backlash against Arabs at home. James G. Abourezk, a Lebanese-American who is a former Senator from South Dakota and now heads the American Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee, said a violent anti-Arab telephone message had recently been left on an answering machine at the group's Western regional headquarters. In 1985, at the time of the hijacking of the cruise ship Achille Lauro by a group of Palestinians, the Anti-Discrimination Committee's Western regional director, Alex Odeh, was killed by a bomb in his office. No one has been convicted or even indicted for the attack. **********Borders Are Colonial **********''By and large the Arab community supports the economic sanctions'' imposed against Iraq by the United Nations, Mr. Abourezk said, ''but I think they are very much opposed to U.S. troop intervention.'' If war breaks out between Arabs and Americans, he said, ''it's not going to be comfortable for people of Arab descent.'' **********Hisham Melhem, a Lebanese who was the Washington correspondent for al-Qabas, the leading Kuwaiti newspaper, said: ''Most Arabs, emotionally and intellectually, when they look at the map and see the borders among the gulf states or among Lebanon and Syria, Jordan and Iraq, they know that these were not historic national boundaries but boundaries drawn by colonial powers.'' **********People do not want to live in a country controlled by Mr. Hussein, Mr. Melhem went on, ''because they know how repressive he is.'' But he indicated that he was troubled by the reaction of Americans to the Iraqi President. Mr. Hussein has ''taken over Khomeini's position,'' he said. **********''It seems now, beyond Communism, you like to look for someone who is the embodiment of evil,'' he said. ''If it's not Arafat, it's Qaddafi. If not Qaddafi, Noriega. If not Noriega, then it's Saddam. Saddam obviously is a dictator and has his place in the hierarchy of dictatorship. But he is not Hitler.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/21/busin.body_text: **********In a major consumer goods venture with the Soviet Union, a Long Island company has a preliminary agreement to help Russians produce 50 million pairs of shoes over the next decade. **********The M.A.L. Sales Corporation of North Merrick, L.I., said it hoped to sign a final agreement in Moscow next month with Kimray, a Soviet shoemaker, and the Ministry of Light Industry of the Republic of Russia, to convert a factory to produce shoes for sale in both Russia and the West. **********M.A.L., which specializes in making arrangements between American shoe retailers and domestic and foreign suppliers, will arrange for the Russians to buy American shoe manufacturing equipment, for the transportation and setting up of the equipment and for training some 600 Russian workers to use it. **********A Decade of Shoemaking **********The 50 million pairs of leisure and work shoes to be produced over the next 10 years are expected to have a wholesale value of about $5 billion, according to Steve Wald, an M.A.L. consultant. But, he said, M.A.L. could not estimate now how much the deal might eventually be worth. The company expects to make money from the equipment sale and training contract and later to share in the revenue from the shoe sales. **********M.A.L. expects to be paid in Russia with rubles and hard currency and to get additional hard currency from the shoes to be sold to the West, Mr. Wald added. ''Eventually, if all goes well, we hope to be hard-currency self-sufficient, but that may take some time,'' he said. **********''The shoes will be in the economy price range,'' Mr. Wald said. ''That means that a canvas-and-leather jogger shoe will sell for the equivalent of $20. Later, we will also be making work shoes.'' Both the leisure shoe and the work shoe are said to be the types of footwear most in demand in Russia. **********Initial goals are for production of 25,000 pairs of shoes daily and after two years this will be raised 100,000 a day, said Bert Cunningham, assistant to Stephen Latham, the Nassau County Commerce Commissioner. **********'A Unique Deal' **********''We think that this is a unique deal,'' Mr. Wald said. ''It all began when Martin Lorber, M.A.L.'s president, attended a seminar last April in Moscow jointly sponsored by the Harvard University Graduate School of Business and a Soviet Government institute. Both Mr. Lorber and I went back to Moscow in July for more discussions. And now a committee of seven Russian officials, Mr. Lorber and other M.A.L. executives are visiting American shoe-import facilities, retail stores and manufacturing plants to get an idea of what they might need for this project.'' **********Russia may also make arrangements to import shoes from other countries later, Mr. Cunningham said. But the raw materials for the Russian-made shoes, particularly leather, will not be imported, for Russian supplies are said to be ample.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/08/busin.body_text: **********Hong Kong's main financial institution said it had detected a significant increase in capital flight from the jittery British colony, which will revert to Chinese rule in 1997. **********The Hongkong and Shanghai **********Banking Corporation's latest monthly economic report said it estimated a net outflow of private non-trade capital of 22.4 billion Hong Kong dollars ($2.8 billion United States) in 1989. **********The significant increase was the result of a loss of confidence in the economy and can be expected to continue until confidence is restored, the bank said. **********The bank said the capital flight was at least partly the result of Beijing's bloody suppression of the pro-democracy movement last June. Hong Kong's confidence in the future was badly damaged by the crackdown despite pledges that Beijing had no intention of changing the territory's freewheeling capitalist system.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/26/world.main_headline: A Neo-Stalinist Yearns for Old Times
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/26/world.print_headline: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;   A Neo-Stalinist Yearns for Old Times
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/26/world.body_text: **********An afternoon at home with Nina Andreyeva is an experience of cozy domesticity often interrupted by jarring moments of anachronism. **********The white light of a northern Russian summer floods the tiny living room where the chemistry teacher and polemic writer lives. It splashes the geraniums on the window sill, the neat stacks of Marxist reading matter, the little table set for coffee, all homey and familiar. **********But then to hear Stalin spoken of with reverence is, in these days of Soviet transformation, like suddenly spotting a pterodactyl on the wing, or hearing someone burst into Latin on the subway. **********Referred to in the Soviet press as ''the notorious Nina Andreyeva'' since more than two years ago when she published an attack on permissiveness in the era of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Mrs. Andreyeva is the jilted apostle of the Bolshevik true faith. **********Her full-page newspaper disputation in March 1988 buoyed hard-liners and seemed to freeze the policy of glasnost for three weeks, until Mr. Gorbachev commissioned a sharp rebuttal that assured the panicky reformists that he was still in charge, and it transformed Mrs. Andreyeva overnight into a political untouchable. **********''I was a curtain-raiser,'' she says now. ''I raised the curtain on something they did not want to see.'' True Marxism? **********From her little Khrushchev-era apartment in this former summering ground of the czarist nobility a few miles from Leningrad, she now watches the struggle for the soul of her party with a mix of bitterness and hope. A Communist Party member for 24 of her 51 years, Mrs. Andreyeva says she thinks of quitting the party to help form one with a real Marxist-Leninist backbone. **********Then again, after the vigorous anti-Gorbachev language just heard at the founding congress of the new Russian Communist Party, Mrs. Andreyeva said she was encouraged that a revival may already be in the works. **********She was made unwelcome at early meetings to plan the Russian party's congress - her name is so identified with the dark forces that even ambitious hard-liners feel obliged to disavow her. And she says she fears that the new party has failed to rid its ranks of ''revisionists, swindlers, bureaucrats and corrupt elements.'' **********But she heard satisfying echoes of her own remarks this week in the outcries against free markets, dwindling patriotism, the blackening of Soviet history and the betrayal of Communist ideals. [In a telephone interview on Saturday, Mrs. Andreyeva also welcomed the victory of Ivan K. Polozkov, her favorite candidate to head the Russian party. ''This may lead to the departure from the Communist Party of the so-called democrats and social democrats, those who call for civil peace at the cost of betraying socialism,'' she said. ''It will promote the consolidation of the sincerely Bolshevik forces.'']  If Mrs. Andreyeva is slipping to the margins of history, as the polls and election results suggest, she is comforted by knowing she is not going alone. She is now the leader of an organization called Unity, for Leninism and Communist Ideals, whose strength she declines to estimate because the local cells in 38 cities and towns, in true Bolshevik fashion, send her no central list of their members. **********The group is waiting in the wings to reorganize itself as a neo-Bolshevik party, she said, if the new Russian party fails to arrest the Communists' slide toward capitalism. **********There are, moreover, the 15,000 letters - counted, sorted and filed on the bookshelves alongside the memoirs of every Soviet leader. Most, she says, vindicate her view that the ordinary people are not ready for ''bourgeois democracy'' and the marketplace. **********''There is nothing at all to buy this year,'' she says, apologizing for the modest offerings on her table and launching into her indictment of Mr. Gorbachev. **********''Every month it's getting worse. The explanation is that the state-run sector is falling apart, and the black-market speculation results in empty shelves in state stores.'' **********Mrs. Andreyeva's explanation for the chronic shortages, a view widely repeated in the shops of nearby Leningrad, is that greedy speculators stimulated by Mr. Gorbachev's policies are buying goods at subsidized prices and then retailing them at huge markups. **********This, she asserts, is aggravated by ''real sabotage.'' **********''There are warehouses full of goods being withheld by people who are waiting for the prices to go up,'' she adds. **********The object of all this is to foist free trade, private property, hired labor and other capitalist notions on a befuddled Soviet public. **********''The crisis we see today is specially planned and organized, and not the last violin in this orchestra is played by our democrats,'' she said.'' **********Mrs. Andreyeva thinks that state-run system has been sold short. She has never been to the West, but she doubts that it can match the cheap rail pass that takes her by electric train to her job at the Leningrad Chemical and Technical Institute, or the free hospital where her husband is convalescing from a heart attack. **********The heart attack, she adds, is on the heads of those who marked her as the Darth Vader of Soviet affairs and led to her husband's being driven from his job as chairman of the philosophy department at her institute. **********A Capitalist 'Betrayal' Seen **********When Mrs. Andreyeva first met a Western reporter 20 months ago, she was circumspect in assessing Mr. Gorbachev. Now she brands him the mastermind of a counterrevolution in three stages: the discrediting of Soviet history and ''anti-Stalinist hysteria,'' the creation of a presidency not beholden to the party - ''a betrayal of the working people,'' and now the introduction of private property. **********Mrs. Andreyeva prefers not to be described as a Stalinist, the dictator's name being redolent with unpleasant connotations, but she defends Stalin as a man misjudged. **********''Stalin was a wise statesman, an extraordinary personality who performed under extremely complicated historical conditions,'' she said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/13/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Lilly Ends Output Of 60 Products
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/13/busin.body_text: **********Eli Lilly & Company has discontinued manufacturing 60 products and versions of products, according to a notification letter sent to drug wholesalers around the country. Representatives of several pharmaceutical wholesaling companies said that the products involved were either old or slow-selling and that the manufacturing halts would have little or no financial impact. Lilly's stock rose 87.5 cents a share today, to $68.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. **********''It shouldn't cause any problems,'' said a spokesman for the Bergen Brunswig Corporation, a California-based drug wholesaler. ''Our buyers reacted to it as a routine maintenance'' of Lilly's product line. In the letter, dated March 26, Lilly told wholesalers to continue to fill orders from their inventories and then after inventories were depleted, to classify the products as ''manufacturer discontinued.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/20/world.main_headline: India Paves Way for Kashmir Elections
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/20/world.print_headline: India Paves Way for Kashmir Elections
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/20/world.body_text: **********The Governor of the state of Jammu and Kashmir, which is troubled by anti-India agitation, dissolved the state legislature today, paving the way for possible elections this year. **********The legislature had been suspended last month after Governor Jagmohan took control of the state's administration soon after the resignation of Chief Minister Farooq Abdullah, Kashmir's top elected official. **********The Abdullah government, which took office after elections in May 1987, was a coalition comprising the former Chief Minister's National Conference Party and the Congress Party of former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi. **********Alienation of the Young **********It is widely believed that large-scale fraud took place during the elections, helping the coalition gain power and sharpening the alienation of many young Kashmiris from India's democratic process. **********State governors are appointed by India's President. Governor Jagmohan, who is regarded as a tough administrator sent to firmly curb the growing anti-India agitation, has criticized Dr. Abdullah's administration for widespread corruption, squandering of state funds and inefficiency. **********''The events of the last one or two years have clearly demonstrated that the Assembly could not even pretend that it had a representative character,'' said Mr. Jagmohan in remarks quoted by the Press Trust of India from Srinagar, the capital of the state. ''As regards the working of the state government, its catalogue of maladministration was unending.'' **********Mr. Jagmohan, who has only one name, has tried to tackle the movement in the predominantly Muslim state with a mixture of force and economic generosity, promising new schemes that will generate jobs. But bursts of violence and ambushes against police officials and government workers continue to be reported, and there are long hours of curfew in Srinagar. **********A reporter in Srinagar said that small demonstrations criticizing the government and shouting Islamic slogans take place during relaxations in the curfew. Slogans calling for a long struggle against New Delhi also are broadcast over loudspeakers fixed at mosques, he said. **********Toll of Violence Reaches 80 **********At least one person was killed on Sunday when Indian troops fired at a mob that attacked their trucks with gunfire and rocks in the town of Bijbihara in the southern part of the state. The town is the home of India's top law enforcement official, Mufti Mohammed Sayeed, the Home Affairs Minister. More than 80 people have died since violence broke out last month. **********Relations between India and Pakistan have been chilled over the last two months after India renewed charges that Pakistan is assisting the militant revolt in Kashmir with arms and money. Pakistan denies the charge. **********The state of Jammu and Kashmir joined India in 1947 after its Maharaja signed a treaty of accession, and the two neighbors went to war that year over the territory. Parts of the disputed region have stayed with each country, and a section with China. **********Pakistan seeks a United Nations-supervised plebiscite that would enable the Kashmiris on both sides to decide their future. India refuses to allow such a referendum, saying that Kashmir's accession is irrevocable.
