https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/31/world.body_text: **********Two senior members of the Islamic fundamentalist Government accused Western donors today of exaggerating the food shortages in the Sudan and said there was no reason to make a public appeal for international help. **********The United States, traditionally the biggest giver of food aid to the Sudan, has said that the country faces a famine next year unless plans are made to deliver large amounts of grain. **********The director of the United States Agency for International Development here, Dr. Frederick Machmer, said the agency was working on the assumption that the Sudan, Africa's largest country, could have a shortage of as much as a million tons of grain, caused by drought and civil war. The fighting in the south has hampered farming and the distribution of fertilizer. **********Eight to nine million people would be at risk of hunger if the shortage was one million tons, Dr. Machmer said. The Sudan's total population is estimated at 25 million. But he said that the Sudanese Government's refusal to admit that the country faces a severe food shortage next year will make it difficult to get food here on time.  The Optimistic View **********Col. Salah al-Din Karar, the chairman of the economic committee of the ruling Revolutionary Command Council, told a group of reporters invited here by the Government that "a gap might arise" after the November harvest, but that it would not exceed 500,000 tons. This, he said, would not be "a big problem" and would be made up next April by local grain harvested from irrigated areas. **********Western and Sudanese agricultural experts said they did not know how the main irrigated area, south of Khartoum, would produce such quantities. **********Another member of the junta, Brig. Pio Ukwan, said that if international organizations fed what he estimated to be the three million foreign refugees in the Sudan, the Government would be able to look after its own people. **********The office here of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees estimates that there are 800,000 foreign refugees in the Sudan, most of them Ethiopian, of whom about 300,000 receive food aid from Western donors.  Denials of Need **********For weeks now, the Khartoum Government has been publicly denying that the country faces acute food shortages, and has been lashing out at relief organizations based here. **********The military Government, which came to power 16 months ago, has made its distaste for the country's traditional Western donors increasingly evident. The two Government newspapers recently carried a headline "Death to America Should Be the Motto for Every Muslim" over an article about the Persian Gulf crisis. The Sudan has not denounced the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. **********Today's dispatch by the official Sudan News Agency carried a statement by Colonel Karar saying the nation would not accept food aid even if it declared a famine. **********The food situation is a particularly sensitive matter for the Government, which declared self-sufficiency in food as one of its goals when it came to power. But even as the senior officials publicly say they do not want or need Western aid, they have quietly asked the United States for $150 million worth of grain for next year. Washington dismissed the request, made in September, saying the Khartoum Government was obstructing the effort to help the three million people displaced by the civil war. **********Early this month, the United States diverted a ship with 45,000 tons of wheat that had been bound for the Sudan, citing the bombing of southern towns, the cancellation of relief flights and the confiscation of food shipments as the reasons. Ten days ago, the United States resumed delivery of the grain.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/01/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;   Car Loans Back $622 Million Issue
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/01/busin.body_text: **********The Merrill Lynch Asset-Backed Corporation 1990-1 yesterday priced $622 million in debt securities due in 1995 that are backed by Chrysler Credit Corporation car loans. **********The offering is being handled through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets as sole manager. Underwriters said the 9 3/4 percent securities were priced at 99 24/32 to yield 9.22 percent, or about 75 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. **********Moody's Investors Service Inc. and the Standard & Poor's Corporation have both rated the issue triple-A.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/04/busin.main_headline: Savings Agency Ordered to Sell Real Estate Fast
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/04/busin.print_headline: Savings Agency Ordered to Sell Real Estate Fast
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/04/busin.body_text: **********The new agency created to manage the huge savings and loan bailout was instructed today to sell the real estate it inherited from hundreds of insolvent institutions as quickly as possible. The directive from the Bush Administration raised concerns among bankers that the properties could be ''dumped'' in an already weakened real estate market. **********While the mandate to the newly formed Resolution Trust Corporation could mean that billions of dollars in homes, apartment buildings, shopping centers and raw land would be available to investors at bargain prices in 1990, bankers warned that an overzealous sales program could do more harm than good. **********''Dumping is an acute political hot button, and if that is mishandled, then the political problems will end up right on George Bush's door,'' said Kenneth A. Guenther, executive vice president of the Independent Bankers Association. **********Largest in Nation's History **********On Tuesday, the savings agency listed more than 30,000 parcels of commercial and residential property as the first group it will put on the market, making the real estate sale the nation's largest ever. The vast majority of parcels, 26,813, are residential, of which 11,918 are single-family homes. **********The nonresidential properties range from a golf course in South Padre Island, Tex., to a Dairy Queen in Woodland Park, Colo. Also on the list are nursing homes, theaters, marinas and churches. **********The heaviest concentration of properties is in the troubled Southwest. Although the trust agency has not disclosed the total value of the real estate, officials put the value of the properties in Texas and Oklahoma alone at $6.4 billion at the end of August. **********The instructions on how to sell the assets of the failed savings and loans are part of a ''strategic plan'' released today by the agency's Oversight Board, headed by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady. The plan also spelled out general guidelines for the sale of the hundreds of savings institutions the Government has taken over. **********''It is important that the R.T.C. proceed and continue actively to dispose of assets immediately,'' the directive said. ''The R.T.C. should avoid deferring the marketing of properties. Holding properties off the market for an extended period of time may increase the ultimate cost of asset disposition.'' **********Officials of the Oversight Board contended that the real estate sale would stop short of dumping and serve to accelerate the cleanup of the savings and loan debacle. **********But James Chessen, deputy director of economic and policy research at the American Bankers Association, said, ''We are worried that even the perception of dumping of assets is causing trouble.'' Such dumping, or the excessive selling of real estate below market values, the banking officials said, will aggravate a market that is already weak, especially in the Southwest, parts of Florida and the Northeast. **********The impact of the real estate sale on the Federal budget will not be fully known for several years. The trust agency has been allotted $50 billion in Government money over three years to clean up the problems. But if it can manage to sell the troubled institutions and their assets at prices more favorable than expected, the budgetary hit will be less. **********But few banking experts believe that will happen because of predictions that real estate markets are going to continue to soften and that in the end Resolution Trust, which has so far taken over 318 savings units, will have to take over many more than the 500 institutions initially projected. **********Troubles Far From Over **********In fact, figures released by the nation's chief savings regulators today indicated that the industry's difficulties are far from over. **********The Office of Thrift Supervision announced that in October the nation's 2,895 savings and loan associations lost $4.5 billion in deposits, only a moderate improvement from the $5.4 billion loss in September. **********The agency said that for the previous 12 months, the industry lost a total of $65 billion in deposits. **********The deposits have shrunk for a variety of reasons. Beginning late in 1988, nervousness about the financial condition of the industry, as well as much higher rates offered by money market mutual funds, prompted depositors to withdraw large sums. **********More Burden on Taxpayers **********That caused many financial experts to warn that because the President's bailout plan called for the industry to pay part of the cost through higher deposit insurance premiums, any loss of deposits would reduce that contribution, putting more financial burden on the taxpayer. **********The President's plan predicted that deposits would grow at about a 7 percent rate, or $70 billion a year. **********But later in the year, when rates began to fall and provisions of the bailout approved by Congress in August became effective, a different dynamic kicked in. The new law called for savings and loan owners to invest higher levels of their own cash in their institutions, or risk losing control. As a result, many institutions that could not raise new money began to sell assets and offer lower interest rates, letting deposits drain off. **********Bank board officials said today that that trend continued through October and was not likely to stop. **********Playing a key role in overseeing that shrinkage will be the Resolution Trust Corporation, which, along with the Oversight Board, was set up by the bailout plan. The agency is managed on a day-to-day basis by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. **********Four-Volume Listing **********The list released by the trust agency on Tuesday detailed the real estate for sale from the assets of 283 troubled institutions seized as of Sept. 30. **********Effectively putting for-sale signs on 30,123 properties, the agency sent the listing to Congress and began to make it available to the public. **********The agency divides the properties into two books of residential listings, a third book for commercial properties and one for undeveloped land that can be as small as a 2,048-square-foot lot on Frenchmen Street in New Orleans or as large as a 77,626-acre farm in Gilbert, Ariz. **********As expected, the largest number of properties are in the Southwest, where the energy collapse early in the 1980's created a major regional depression, causing both banks and savings institutions to fail. Texas has 15,750 properties listed; Oklahoma, 1,575; Louisiana, 2,434, and Arizona, 1,711. Maine, Vermont, West Virginia and North and South Dakota are the only states in which property is not listed. **********Updates Every 6 Months **********The inventory of properties will be updated every six months, with the next one scheduled for June 1. **********The guidelines under the Oversight Board's strategic plan said Resolution Trust could provide buyers with short-term options for returning to the Government those assets they find are more troubled than first realized. It also permits the agency to give buyers short-term financing in their purchase of ailing institutions to give them time to come up with longer financing. **********The strategic plan also instructs the trust agency to give preferential treatment to minorities in the sale of minority-held institutions. For example, Daniel P. Kearney, president of the Oversight Board, said that if a bid from a minority organization is less costly than a liquidation, ''the R.T.C. is not required to solicit other bids.'' **********It also set certain guidelines to avoid conflicts of interest in any of transaction, like requiring that ''all communications initiated by senior public officials or their staffs that are intended to influence a case are to be logged and the records made public,'' Mr. Kearney said. **********Fair Value Mandated **********But the Oversight Board officials said they did not expect that their mandate to the trust agency to sell assets quickly would result in dumping. They said that the bailout law, signed on Aug. 9, prohibits the agency from selling any asset at less than 95 percent of its current appraised value. **********Moreover, they said their primary concern would be if the trust agency withheld assets from the market in anticipation of an upturn in value; such vast amounts of unsold real estate might keep market prices depressed even longer. **********''The real danger is falling prices if you don't sell the real estate,'' said John Ross, an economist with the Oversight Board. **********One issue that the strategic plan did not address is the need by the trust corporation for vast amounts of interim borrowings so that it can finance the sales of troubled savings institutions. Although the total cleanup by the agency of about 500 institutions has been estimated to cost $50 billion, the actual amount of cash flow far exceeds that. **********Mr. Kearney said he had received estimates from L. William Seidman, chairman of the trust agency, that $50 billion to $100 billion in medium-term borrowings would be needed over the next three years in addition to the original $50 billion. That would eventually be paid back out of the proceeds from the asset sales. **********Basic Bidding Process **********The procedure for buying a troubled institution is primarily through the traditional bidding process set up by the F.D.I.C., in which investors are given basic information about an institution and invited to submit bids. **********Purchasing real estate will be done in a number of different ways. Many properties are listed with local real estate agents, while others will be given to local real estate specialists to market to investors. Resolution Trust itself will end up selling probably some of the largest assets to interested buyers. **********The listing can be ordered by calling 1-800-431-0600. The four books combined cost $50, the two residential volumes are $15 each and the commercial and land volumes are $10 each. The lists are also being distributed to 1.400 libraries across the country. **********Here is the list, by state, of the number of real estate properties for sale by the Resolution Trust Corporation: **********Alabama, 178; Alaska, 349; Arizona, 1,711; Arkansas, 340; California, 397; Colorado, 1,586; Connecticut, 2; Delaware, 2; District of Columbia, 1; Florida, 1,288; Georgia, 744; Hawaii, 5; Idaho, 11; Illinois, 207; Indiana, 27; Iowa, 19; Kansas, 332; Kentucky, 38; Louisiana, 2,434; Maine, 0; Maryland, 16; Massachusetts, 5; Michigan, 12; Minnesota, 113; Mississippi, 384; Missouri, 76. **********Montana, 43; Nebraska, 68; Nevada, 34; New Hampshire 1; New Jersey, 11; New Mexico, 637; New York, 12; North Carolina, 83; North Dakota, 0; Ohio, 115; Oklahoma, 1,575; Oregon, 102; Pennsylvania, 152; Rhode Island, 3; South Carolina, 78; South Dakota, 0; Tennessee, 344; Texas, 15,750; Utah, 629; Vermont, 0; Virginia, 103; Washington, 59; West Virginia, 0; Wisconsin, 36; Wyoming, 12.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/03/busin.body_text: **********Despite a backlog of more than $11 billion in interest owed to commercial bankers, Brazil and Argentina will be negotiating for new official aid when the International Monetary Fund and World Bank meet in Washington next week. **********And both countries are likely to win approval of aid in the next several months, underscoring one of the major changes in third world debt policy since the announcement of the Bush Administration's new approach just over a year ago. **********The new strategy, in addition to calling for the voluntary reduction of debt, also allows for continuing negotiations and financial support from the international financial institutions, even when the countries are far behind in their commercial-loan payments. Bank loans make up the major portion of third world debt. **********Debate Over Policy Change **********There has been strong support for this change in policy within the I.M.F and the Bush Administration and among some experts on the debt crisis. But it also worries others, especially the bankers who are owed the interest. **********The Institute for International Finance, which was established by commercial banks, is expected to criticize the policy in a report to be released today. The report, which says the payment backlog now totals $18 billion, with more than half of it owed by Brazil and Argentina, will conclude that the policy is an incentive for countries to miss their loan payments. The practice, the report says, could become a habit and, even more importantly, spread to international institutions like the I.M.F. and the World Bank. **********Because of this policy, said one official familiar with the institute report, ''it seems that countries are using arrears'' as a way to ease pressure on their economies. **********No Other Option **********But in the case of Brazil, with arrears of $5.1 billion, and Argentina, with $6.1 billion, some officials and bankers see no way to deal with the problems before the countries get aid from the I.M.F., or before they begin debt-reduction negotiations with their commercial bankers. **********To refuse the aid, as long as the countries are taking approved steps to restructure their economies, would just aggravate the problems in each of the countries, officials said, and would favor the banks in debt negotiations. **********A precedent for this kind of negotiation - with countries still in arrears - has been established in some of the deals already reached under the debt strategy named for Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady. **********Venezuela was $600 million behind in loan payments while negotiating with its commercial bankers. As part of the agreement reached in March, Venezuela paid off these arrears. Costa Rica, which also negotiated while in arrears, agreed to pay off 20 percent of its backlog at the time of its agreement and the rest over several years. **********'Bankers Were Very Unhappy' **********''It is true that bankers were very unhappy with this change in policy,'' said one banker who will be involved in negotiations with Brazil. ''But it is also true that it is probably necessary for the I.M.F. to have negotiations with Brazil because the arrears are so large.'' **********If the I.M.F. refused aid outright to countries in arrears, added John Williamson, a senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics in Washington, ''the bargaining advantage is too heavily with the commercial banks. By standing pat they could bring all assistance to a country to a halt.'' **********But Mr. Williamson and the banker insisted that the policy would get out of hand if the I.M.F. didn't insist on strong economic reform programs and some prompt payments to the commerical banks. **********Argentina Exemplifies the Risks **********Argentina is an example of the risks of the arrears policy. Argentina won a standby agreement with the I.M.F. last September and received one payment of $240 million from its $1.4 billion allotment. This agreement came soon after the inauguration of Argentina's new President, Carlos Saul Menem, and amid hope that he would be able to make the changes necessary to bring down rampant inflation and open the economy to foreign investment. But the program has run into serious problems since then, and the I.M.F. has stopped any further aid. **********Argentine officials have submitted a new economic program to the I.M.F. and are hoping to get the standby loan reactivated. One official said that ''it's a strong possibility'' the request would be granted. **********Brazil can make a stronger case to the I.M.F. for aid. However, even if the I.M.F. approves a standby aid program for Brazil, the arrears problem could still make negotiations with its commerical bankers on debt reduction difficult. **********Brazil Seeking Debt Reductions **********Brazilian officials have said the country would not make payments of more than $5 billion a year on its foreign loans, including those from the international institutions and commerical banks. The Brazilian Ambassador in Washington, Marcilio Marques Moreira, said the Government had not yet decided on its strategy for debt negotiations, except that it will seek substantial debt reductions. **********He said that the Government wanted to work out a deal with I.M.F. first so that it could have a ''basic agreement'' before negotiating with the commerical lenders. Such an agreement, which would include I.M.F. approval of the Government's new economic policy, would give Brazil extra support in its negotiations with its bankers. **********Another banker who will be involved in negotiaitons with Brazil said he was not too concerned about the $5 billion limit on loan payments. He thinks it is a negotiating position. But, he added, ''No doubt it is going to be a tough negotiation.'' **********He said that Brazil had more economic potential than Mexico or Venezuela, which have already reached debt agreements under the Brady plan. But President Fernando Collor de Mello must prove that his radical economic program can halt hyper-inflation in Brazil, where prices rose 48-fold in the 12 months through March. The heart of the program is a freeze for 18 months on about 75 percent of the country's bank deposits.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/29/busin.main_headline: UAL Shares Jump On Davis's Offer
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/29/busin.print_headline: UAL Shares Jump On Davis's Offer
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/29/busin.body_text: **********The UAL Corporation's stock price jumped $6.625 today, to $97.25, on the New York Stock Exchange after the investor Marvin Davis offered late Thursday to join an employee buyout of the company, which runs United Airlines. **********In a letter to Gerald Greenwald, head of the United Employee Acquisition Corporation, Mr. Davis indicated his proposal would give the employee group more time to arrange financing for its buyout. **********The UAL board has already accepted $201 a share, or $4 billion, for the company, but Wall Street has doubted whether the group can complete financing for the long-running deal. The union-led group has until Oct. 9 to get financing for its proposed buyout of the carrier.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/30/busin.main_headline: Market Place;   A Corporate Pullback That's Rattling Stocks
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/30/busin.print_headline: Market Place;   A Corporate Pullback That's Rattling Stocks
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/30/busin.body_text: **********Corporate America, one of the biggest buyers of shares during the boom years of the 1980's on Wall Street, is apparently pulling back, contributing to the stock market's recent weakness. **********American companies spent hundreds of billions of dollars in recent years buying other corporations and buying their own stock. But now, with the pace of corporate takeovers slowing and company profits declining, there are increasing signs that corporations will no longer purchase shares with abandon. **********This apparent retreat has worried Wall Street and has played a big role in the recent stock market fall. With the Dow Jones industrial average off 5.85 points yesterday, to 2,553.38, it is now down 9 percent from the peak of 2,810.15 it reached on Jan. 2. **********''The support that corporations provided in the past is no longer there,'' said Carmine Grigoli, chief portfolio strategist for First Boston. **********Concern Is Understandable **********The concern on Wall Street is understandable. Last year, for example, American corporations were the main force behind the 27 percent rise in share prices, purchasing over $100 billion worth of shares more than they sold, Goldman, Sachs estimates. By contrast, American financial institutions and individual investors sold more shares than they bought. **********Rising interest rates around the world, brought on by inflation fears in West Germany and Japan, have also been an important cause of the market's weakness. Those rates stabilized in recent days, helping to stem the decline on Wall Street at least temporarily. **********Other forces cited by analysts as contributing to the slippage include concerns about higher oil prices and falling corporate profits as the economy slows. **********Buyers Must Be Willing **********But in the end, share prices rise when buyers are willing to buy, and decline when they are not. And the prospect of corporations pulling back as a major buying force could well hurt prices considerably. **********Yet it could also help to slow, or perhaps reverse, the trend toward an ever-growing level of debt for American companies, because much of the corporate share-buying was financed with borrowed money. A lightened debt burden would give American companies a more sturdy financial foundation, making them better able to compete with foreign companies and more likely to survive a recession. **********For generations, it was taken for granted that corporations would normally be sellers of stock, as they issued shares to finance expansion and to pay for takeovers. But as debt-financed takeovers became much more common during the 1980's, many companies began to buy their own shares as an act of defense, hoping that by keeping share prices relatively high they would discourage raiders. **********In 1988, according to Federal Reserve figures, all corporations bought $118 billion more in stock than they issued. For the first nine months of last year, the annual rate was about $129 billion. But Mr. Grigoli said he believed that slowed in the final quarter, for which Government figures are not yet available. The pace of announced mergers, he estimated, was down 35 percent in the October-December period from the pace early in the year. **********In 1990, Mr. Grigoli forecasts, American corporations will be net buyers of only about $50 billion worth of shares, less than half last year's level. **********With the ''junk bond'' market all but closed to new issuers, many companies have less to fear from raiders, so they need not be eager to buy their own shares to increase their stock price. ''There will be less pressure on corporate managers to maximize shareholder value,'' said Leon G. Cooperman, chief executive of the asset management division at Goldman, Sachs. **********In addition, corporate profits have been declining since early last year, according to Commerce Department figures, reducing the available cash companies have on hand for buying their shares or for other purposes. **********It is not easy to trace corporate buybacks of shares. Some companies do not announce purchases, except after long delays, and some announce plans for purchases but do not follow through. But in January, Laszlo Birinyi, head of a market analysis firm that bears his name, said, ''There have been very few announcements.'' **********The trend toward corporate repurchases of shares began in the 1970's, when pioneers like Teledyne Inc. made major buybacks despite criticism that such purchases left the companies financially weaker and amounted to an admission by a management that it had no better investment available to it. **********But by the mid-1980's, those repurchases were much more fashionable. The culmination may have come last fall, when the International Business Machines Corporation announced two repurchase plans, totaling $5 billion, and the General Electric Company said it would buy back $10 billion worth of shares over five years. **********Some analysts say companies will keep buying shares even if the volume is reduced. ''There are still strategic takeovers,'' noted John D. Connolly, chairman of the investment policy committee at Dean Witter Reynolds, pointing to the pending attempt by Georgia-Pacific to acquire Great Northern Nekoosa. He added that ''the market for new issues of corporate equity securities is not the best'' and concluded, ''We will see less supply of stock.'' Mr. Connolly said the recent retreat of stock prices has been overdone and created a buying opportunity. **********But there are signs that corporate America, which is more heavily indebted now than after any other economic expansion, may be forced to return to issuing shares even if the market is not receptive. Companies like Shearson Lehman Hutton and First Interstate Banks are now trying to sell stock because they need the extra capital. **********Over all, according to calculations by Merrill Lynch, interest payments ate up 25.2 percent of corporate cash flow in the third quarter of last year, a record level. Until last year, the record was 22.7 percent, set in the third quarter of 1974, when cash flow had been severely reduced by a recession. Just how high the figure would go in a new recession is not clear, but the fact that corporate balance sheets are so laden with debt is likely to restrain stock buybacks. **********No one knows the extent to which recent share repurchases have been motivated by fear of raiders, as opposed to a genuine management belief that the shares were a good investment. But it is clear that many raiders who could have obtained financing to go after a company six months ago could not raise the cash to do so now. That motivation is clearly reduced. **********In the long run, there is no need for companies to buy shares to have a bull market. Both individuals and institutional investors now have a smaller proportion of their assets in stocks than they did two decades ago. If they decide to return to those levels, that could more than offset the reduction of demand from corporations to buy stocks. But such a change is not likely to happen quickly.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/10/busin.main_headline: Bank Accounting Issue Is Dividing Regulators
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/10/busin.print_headline: Bank Accounting Issue Is Dividing Regulators
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/10/busin.body_text: **********As Congress and the Bush Administration move toward overhauling the nation's banking system, a debate has begun among regulators over accounting standards that could have a profound effect on the health of the banking industry and on the Government's ability to clean up the savings and loan debacle. **********Regulators from three agencies are debating several proposed changes in how banks account for certain intangible assets and whether these assets should count in satisfying the capital requirements of banks. **********The standard selected by the Government, which could be disclosed as early as this week, could affect the willingness of banks to buy assets of failed savings and loans and the banking industry's ability to meet new capital requirements.  Tougher Standards Urged **********Intangible values result from an institution's paying more for an asset than its book value. Regulators are seeking to impose more stringent accounting standards on intangibles by excluding most of them from being counted toward capital requirements because little or none of their value can be recognized. Many intangibles cannot be sold separately from an institution's underlying assets. **********But industry officials and regulators at some agencies, notably the Resolution Trust Corporation, say that excluding the intangibles from capital requirements would strongly discourage banks from buying the assets of many savings and loans now under the control of the agency. Banks have an increasing pool of intangible assets because they are buying assets of failed savings institutions and are entering the mortgage business. **********"It will certainly reduce the prices that Resolution Trust will be able to get," said John J. Oros, a partner at Goldman, Sachs & Company who specializes in mergers and acquisitions of financial institutions.  Conflicting Issues **********The debate presents many of the issues, the politics and the tensions that are expected to emerge next year when Congress and the Administration consider how to reorganize the regulatory structure of banks. **********"It illustrates the conflict between regulating these institutions and trying to dispose of the assets at the Resolution Trust Corporation," said L. William Seidman, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which is seeking to encourage banks to increase their capital levels. He is also the chairman of Resolution Trust, which is desperately trying to sell a growing number of failed savings and loans that it has taken over. **********The disagreements between the regulators became apparent earlier this month when the F.D.I.C. board postponed discussion of the matter because of apparent disagreements among the regulators. Mr. Seidman said the board would consider the matter again by mid-December. Focus on Comptroller **********The immediate focus of the debate is at the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, which regulates Federally chartered banks and has generally been strict about allowing intangibles to be counted as capital. The Comptroller's Office has been taking comments from the banking industry and others on what kinds of intangible assets should be used to satisfy capital standards. **********The standards being phased in would require all banks by 1992 to have capital equal to 8 percent of their assets, adjusted for the risk in the assets. Some analysts have predicted that capital requirements may be further increased in light of the financial difficulties confronting many banks across the nation. **********Some of the nation's largest banks, including Chase Manhattan, Citibank and Chemical, have quietly lobbied for allowing intangibles to be used as capital. They have maintained that the regulators, by excluding intangibles, are overreacting because of their experiences with the savings and loan industry.  View From a Law Firm **********"There were true excesses in the thrift industry, and that's clearly what's motivating what's happening to treatment of intangibles for banks now," said H. Rodgin Cohen, a banking specialist at the New York law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell. **********One group of assets whose treatment is being reconsidered is known as core deposit intangibles. It is the value associated with a financial institution's deposits, in effect, the value of its customer base. When an institution's core deposits are paying depositors a yield that is below the market yield for such deposits, many institutions also recognize an intangible asset from the spread between them. **********The Comptroller's existing standards do not permit core deposit intangibles to count for capital, while the Federal Reserve and the F.D.I.C. have considered them on a case-by-case basis. **********The other type of asset whose treatment is being reconsidered is mortgage-servicing rights. These are contracts bought or held by banks and savings associations under which the institution handles a portfolio of mortgages -- processing the monthly payment checks, distributing the proceeds among investors in the securities and handling foreclosures. **********The Comptroller permits up to 25 percent of a bank's capital to consist of the value of such rights. The F.D.I.C. and Fed have no set standard, although they have said that the rights should not represent a significantly large portion of an institution's capital. **********Together, core deposit intangibles and mortgage-servicing rights represent billions of dollars in assets.  An Argument for Stringency **********Regulators favoring more stringent treatment of intangible assets contend that their inclusion as capital would only make banks weaker and more susceptible to collapse. **********"We're trying to make sure that we don't have capital made of air," said Robert L. Clarke, the Comptroller.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/29/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Investor Halts Crossland Plan
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/29/busin.body_text: **********The Crossland Savings Bank said that the Coast-to-Coast Financial Corporation of Chicago had withdrawn its offer to invest new capital into the Brooklyn-based savings bank. Crossland, which had $21.5 million of shareholder capital and needs another $186 million to comply with Federal regulations, said it was developing other plans to raise capital. The savings bank has $13.5 billion of assets and offices in seven states outside of New York. **********The agreement with Coast-to-Coast would have provided $150 million of new capital in exchange for 85 percent of Crossland's stock. Holders of Crossland's common and preferred stock had objected to the plan. Executives at Coast-to-Coast, a privately held company affiliated with the Pritzker family of Chicago, declined to comment. Crossland's stock closed on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday at $2.125, up 25 cents.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/28/world.main_headline: Maan's Relief Society Drops Estimate of Earthquake Dead to 40,000
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/28/world.print_headline: Maan's Relief Society Drops Estimate of Earthquake Dead to 40,000
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/28/world.body_text: **********The president of Iran's Red Crescent Society today lowered the estimate of the death toll in the earthquake that struck the country last week, saying that deaths would end up closer to 40,000 than to the 50,000 that had been feared. **********Iran reported the possibility of the higher figure to the United Nations earlier this week. But the Red Crescent official, Vahid Dastjerdi, said that evidence now indicated fewer casualties. **********Even so, the earthquake that devastated two northwestern provinces, Gilan and Zanjan, was the worst ever endured by this country, which has long been accustomed to living with natural disasters, and dying in them. **********Toll of Injured Cut to 60,000 **********The number of people injured also was reduced, to 60,000 from earlier estimates of 100,000, and Mr. Dastjerdi suggested that the totals were not likely to rise significantly. **********''We do not believe anyone is left under the debris,'' he said at a news conference. **********His comment reinforced a point that had already become clear - for Iranian officials, the hunt for bodies and even possible survivors had become a secondary concern to taking care of the injured and helping the estimated 105,000 homeless families rebuild their lives. **********Nevertheless, there were reports today, nearly a week after the middle-of-the-night disaster, that rescue teams had freed at least half a dozen people from under the rubble. **********'Get Me Out!' **********One of them was said to be a boy of 6 who was found on Monday in a refrigerator in the village of Vieh, near Manjil, covered by more than five feet of debris. According to the official Islamic Republic News Agency, rescue workers heard the boy cry ''Get me out!'' He was said to have suffered only rib injuries. **********The press agency also reported that on Tuesday afternoon, more than five days after the earthquake, rescuers pulled a woman and her son from wreckage in the demolished farm village of Kelishom, 110 miles northwest of Teheran. **********Foreign journalists visited Kelishom late that afternoon but villagers said nothing about a rescue that most of them would have probably considered miraculous. **********In the village of Jirandeh, a couple and their son were saved after four hours of digging by rescue teams, the press agency said. **********An Invitation to Go Home **********As the rescue effort started to wind down, Mr. Dastjerdi all but invited foreign medical specialists and rescue teams to pack up and leave Iran, saying: ''Their presence is not very useful.'' **********His remark struck at the heart of a continuing dispute among Iranians over whether the country should have accepted any outside aid at all, especially from ''enemies'' like the United States, Iraq, and Salman Rushdie, the British author. **********A plane carrying supplies from Iraq landed at Teheran today and after unloading it left at once for home, the Teheran radio reported. **********The Government of President Hashemi Rafsanjani has welcomed assistance from all countries except Israel and South Africa. **********On Tuesday, the English-language Teheran Times, which usually reflects Mr. Rafsanjani's views, said in an editorial: ''Our Islamic ideology urges us to laud such cooperations that can alleviate the pains and sufferings of so many human beings.'' **********Teheran Times Denounced **********Today, the anti-Western Jomhuri Islami denounced The Teheran Times for having ''become one voice with the French Le Monde and Zionist and Western news agencies.'' **********But even those like Mr. Rafsanjani who are known as moderates have endured rather than embraced the arrival of rescue teams from countries that inclde France, West Germany, the Soviet Union and Czechoslovakia. **********The basic message to foreigners has been to send medicine and blankets but leave technical crews behind. **********Televised news broadcasts this evening emphasized that Iran had shown it could handle the crisis on its own, and the Red Crescent leader made a similar point. After the first 72 hours of a disaster, he said, ''sending doctors and rescue workers not only will not help but it will create technical difficulties.'' **********Apparently, some of the foreign countries that have sent in rescue teams now agree that their services are not needed. One of them is France, which is withdrawing a 207-member contingent of surgeons and other specialists. **********''When the authorities say they have too many doctors there, they are right,'' a French official said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/13/world.main_headline: Bush Says He'll Keep Sanctions for Now
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/13/world.print_headline: SOUTH AFRICA'S NEW ERA;   Bush Says He'll Keep Sanctions for Now
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/13/world.body_text: **********President Bush said today that he was not willing to lift economic sanctions on South Africa at this time, but that he was prepared to take other steps to show support for President F. W. de Klerk. **********At a news conference, Mr. Bush hailed Mr. de Klerk as the exemplar of ''a new brand of leadership - a man who is making dramatic changes,'' moving South Africa ''down the road toward racial equity'' and away from apartheid. **********Nelson Mandela, the anti-apartheid leader, was freed on Sunday after more than 27 years in South African prisons. A senior Bush Administration official said today that the United States was considering ''gestures'' of support for South Africa that could be made before Pretoria meets the five statutory criteria for the lifting of sanctions. **********One such gesture is Mr. Bush's invitation to Mr. de Klerk to visit the United States. Mr. Bush said he expected the South African leader to accept. **********Landing Rights Weighed **********Another gesture under study is to grant landing rights in the United States for South African aircraft. But Congressional aides said that such a step could not be taken unless South Africa satisfied the conditions prescribed by Congress in 1986. **********Those conditions include the release of all political prisoners, repeal of the national state of emergency, an end to restrictions on political parties, a commitment to enter ''good-faith negotiations'' with spokesmen for the black majority and repeal of the Group Areas Act of 1949, the basic law requiring residential segregation. **********The 1986 law prohibits South African airlines and aircraft from flying to the United States. It also prohibits American air carriers from taking off or landing in South Africa. **********Asked if he would seek to lift the sanctions before all the statutory conditions have been met, Mr. Bush said: ''We can't do that. I'm bound by the law. And what I do want to do is discuss these with - these provisions -with Mr. Mandela and with Mr. de Klerk. And I've invited both of them to come here.'' **********Herman J. Cohen, the Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, said Mr. Mandela's statements since his release from prison ''have been very responsible and very moderate.'' **********'We're for Privatization' **********''I hope that the rest of the anti-apartheid movement will take a signal from him and get into the negotiating process as soon as they can,'' Mr. Cohen said. **********Mr. Bush expressed some concern about Mr. Mandela's reaffirmation of support for the economic program of the African National Congress, particularly the goal of nationalizing mines. **********''We are not for nationalizing,'' Mr. Bush said. ''We're for privatization and we're for free markets.'' He said it would not make sense for South Africa to adopt socialist policies when ''socialism is folding, folding its hand and going over to the other side all across the world.'' **********Mr. Bush said that the nationalization of major industries would not be ''particularly helpful toward democracy.'' But he said he agreed with Mr. Mandela's efforts to create a society ''that is not a racist society.'' **********On a Mediating Role **********Mr. Bush was asked if he wanted the United States to become a mediator, trying to negotiate a political settlement between the South African Government and the opponents of apartheid. **********''If such a role would be productive, I certainly would,'' he said. ''But I have the feeling from the talks with both men - just short phone conversations with both Mr. de Klerk and Mr. Mandela - that they feel they can talk to each other without the U.S. catalytic role.'' **********Mr. Cohen said he got the same impression when he visited South Africa last month. **********Mr. Bush has repeatedly said he would comply with the 1986 law that sets the conditions for lifting economic sanctions on South Africa. He has also promised to consult Congress before acting. The language of the law is ambiguous on some points, and there is sure to be debate about whether Pretoria has satisfied particular conditions. **********The 1986 law, the Comprehensive Anti-Apartheid Act, bans the import and export of many products and prohibits new lending and investment. Bush Administration officials say they are looking for ways to help Mr. de Klerk and his Government while complying with the law. But they acknowledge that there are relatively few options. **********On the NBC program ''Today,'' Mr. Cohen said ''we're rapidly reaching that point'' where it would be appropriate to relax some of the sanctions on South Africa. **********Mr. Cohen said that South African leaders had ''made some very courageous and bold decisions, and I think they deserve to be recognized because they have political problems at home and need support from the outside world.'' Asked if such recognition should include the lifting of sanctions, Mr. Cohen said, ''That's one possibility, and certainly we're going to consider that very carefully.'' **********No Conditions on Invitation **********Mr. Bush said there were ''no conditions'' on his invitation to Mr. de Klerk. **********In a ceremony at the White House this morning, Mr. Bush said the release of Mr. Mandela was an ''important sign that South Africa may soon begin negotiating a democratic nonracial society and at last be on the way to ending apartheid once for all.'' The ceremony was held to welcome another visitor to the White House, President Denis Sassou-Nguesso of Congo. **********At his news conference, Mr. Bush said he could not judge whether economic sanctions had been effective in forcing South Africa to abandon some elements of apartheid. He asserted that some of the sanctions were ''counterproductive.'' **********''What's really changed is the mindset of the South African leadership,'' Mr. Bush said. ''And I think that we ought to give Mr. de Klerk certain credit for being able to look much more realistically about political change and hopefully more favorably about a society that eventually eliminates this racism that is equated with apartheid.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/29/world.main_headline: Evolution in Europe;   As Marxism Vanishes, Hungarians Argue Over Role of Religion in School
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/29/world.print_headline: Evolution in Europe;   As Marxism Vanishes, Hungarians Argue Over Role of Religion in School
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/29/world.body_text: **********As the last traces of Communist ideology disappear from Hungarian life, a new debate has broken out in this predominantly Roman Catholic country over the role of religion in public education. **********After a meeting with Catholic bishops this month, Hungary's new Minister of Culture stepped into the middle of the controversy by advising public schools that, come September, they will have to provide voluntary religious instruction to students of all ages. **********Such proposals are not surprising from a Government made up of a coalition of conservative and Christian parties. But for some Hungarians, they threaten to set a troublesome test for a society in which ethnic and religious divisions are still open and raw. **********Lively Issue in Hungary **********The question of the role of religion in society, and particularly in children's education, is becoming an issue in many former Communist countries of Eastern Europe. But nowhere is the debate more lively. **********''Those who don't participate in one or other religious class will be branded Jewish, papist or heretic,'' Peter Hanak, a noted historian, said during a recent debate on the church-state issue on a radio talk show. ''And then we will start scattering Hungarian society, which is divided enough as it is.'' **********The first spark in the debate was an attempt last spring by a group of militant Catholics to take over a public school in Budapest's 12th District. **********Done without the sanction of the church, the move by the Our Lady Society at the Arany Janos School ended in failure, but not before it upset and angered some parents and teachers. A Return of Ideology?  ''We expected that ideology was going to march out of the schools, just as it marched out of the workplace,'' said Janos Novak, an engineer with two children in the Arany Janos school, ''We saw this proposal and we were afraid it was marching back in.'' **********The Our Lady Society had wanted to create, within the walls of the Arany Janos school, separate classrooms adorned by Christian symbols but supported by public funds. **********To many, the case posed a gross violation of the doctrine of separation of church and state. But this was apparently not a concern for Bertalan Andrasfalvy, the new Minister of Culture, who has jurisdiction over education. **********Mr. Andrasfalvy, an anthropologist and newcomer to education, said in a statement to the parents that he thought the idea of Christian-type, state-run schools was worth exploring. **********Neglected for 40 Years **********''Religion has to become part of education work all over the country,'' explained Katalin Csonka, a senior official. ''The minister is taking a noble approach, which is based on the recognition that for more than 40 years, religion was neglected in the schools.'' **********Some here see the resurgence of religion in the schools as the start of a trend that could lead to a reconsideration of Hungary's liberal abortion laws and other concerns shared by conservative Catholics. **********In Poland, where Roman Catholicism is strongest in Eastern Europe, Polish bishops recently called for a reintroduction of mandatory religious education in the schools. That proposal was firmly rejected as ''profoundly inappropriate'' by a spokeswoman for the Ministry of Education, who called it potentially divisive. **********Poland Shelves Abortion Issue **********The abortion issue has also been shelved by the Government of Prime Minster Tadeusz Mazowiecki, who is pledged to the creation of a ''nonidealogical and nondenominational state.'' **********In Czechoslovakia, churches have been given the right to teach religion in the schools on demand and to start their own private institutions. In Prague, a former convent school has been split, with one half returned to the nuns and the other remaining an ordinary state school. **********In Romania, where the Eastern Orthodox Church predominates, Archbishop Daniel Ciobotea of Jassy told the opposition newspaper Romania Libera on Wednesday that religious education should return to schools at all levels to broaden horizons. **********Hungarians are still groping for answers to basic questions, from control of schools to the nature of property. With old laws discredited and a newly elected Parliament off to a slow start, many find they must fend for themselves, defining their rights as they go. **********Such was the case at the Arany Janos school, once a convent of the French order of Notre Dame of Zion, expropriated by the Communists after World War II. **********In January, a law on freedom of religion was passed, inspiring local Catholics to go ahead and make a bid for the return of the school, considered an elite institution for 1,500 students. **********'Life Dictates Law Today' **********What the Our Lady Society wanted was a contract to run their own classes, at the state's expense. ''We told them there was no legal framework for this,'' said Maria Terestyenyi, who heads the education department in the 12th District. ''But they said life dictates law today.'' **********In Hungary's unruly transition period, Mrs. Terestyenyi said the tendency is to favor popular demands, no matter how they are made. ''Everybody is afraid to say something is legal or illegal,'' she said, ''because if they say anything, they are stamped a Stalinist. In this way, initiatives from below have the advantage.'' **********Many Hungarians, including nonbelievers, see the interest in religious education as a natural reaction to decades of Communist atheism. ''For the last 40 years, we have suffered a general moral crisis that has left a vacuum,'' said Lajos Elmer, a journalist for a Catholic weekly newspaper. ''The resurgency in Christianity is a search for values to fill up people's lives.'' **********Church Recovers School **********A few schools have already converted to their pre-Communist status. For instance, the venerable Barmadas school in Budapest has again become private and was recently returned to the Protestant Reformed Church, which will assume financial responsibility for the students' education. **********But so far, the Catholic Church has not made a formal bid to take back any schools. It is waiting for a bill in Parliament defining property rights. **********But at Arany Janos and elsewhere, grass-roots Catholic groups tried taking the matter into their own hands. **********Mr. Novak, a Catholic whose children are already receiving a religious education from their local parish priest, had initially supported the idea of returning the Arany Janos school to church control, believing as did some non-Catholic parents, that it would provide a superior education. **********''But we began to get the feeling that education was not a priority,'' he said. ''What the society wanted was to give the children a strict Christian upbringing. Even Catholic parents did not want their children to attend such a school, and it was a definite problem for children who were not Catholic.'' **********The fight reached a dead end at the local district council, which disapproved creating a school-within-a-school. In the meantime, the proposal had the effect of dividing parents and teachers, classmates and friends. **********Children in Conflict **********''Almost a religious war broke out,'' Mr. Novak said. ''The children were the real victims, pointing fingers at each other, calling each other fanatic Catholics or Jews. Our school is as heterogeneous as the rest of society, and it is not healthy to make these distinctions.'' **********Although not as strong as in Poland, Roman Catholicism in Hungary has traditionally been the dominant religion, followed by the Protestant Reformed Church, which has a large following, particularly in the south. But Hungary is also a composite of minority groups - including several evangelical Protestant sects, Romanians who belong to the Eastern Orthodox Church and more than 80,000 Jews, the largest community in Eastern Europe, second only to the Soviet Union. **********The controversy over the Arany Janos School had barely subsided when a debate sprang up around Mr. Andrasfalvi's agreement to offer voluntary religious instruction in the schools. **********The proposal calls for voluntary classes to be held one or twice a week in facilities provided by the school, taught by teachers on state salaries but trained according to their religion. **********Different religious classes will be offered depending on the demands of parents, but many people expect that as a practical matter, most will be Catholic. **********''Since most believers are Catholics,'' Mrs. Terestyenyi said, ''it means the others will be in the minority. Show me one small Hungarian village that will openly call itself Jewish.'' **********Under Mr. Andrasfalvy's proposal, chidren would receive a mark on their year's end report cards, indicting whether they attended the religious classes. Many Hungarians, made suspicious by years under Communist rule, regard this as an ominous start.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/07/busin.main_headline: Patents;   Red Dye Is Produced From Carrot Cultures
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/07/busin.print_headline: Patents;   Red Dye Is Produced From Carrot Cultures
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/07/busin.body_text: **********Two Israeli researchers this week patented a method for producing an intense red dye for foods and cosmetics from carrot cells grown in petri dishes. **********In such cell cultures, plant cells are bred without growing the entire plant. The technique is being viewed by many scientists as a more efficient alternative to conventional methods of agriculture. **********The new colorant is a chemical called anthocyanin, produced by cultures of carrot cells. According to the patent, it has several advantages over existing food dyes: it has an intense color, remains stable under a wide variety of conditions and has none of the carcinogenic risks associated with some artificial red dyes. **********The colorant is produced by isolating anthocyanin from the cell culture and then freeze-drying it into a powder. By adjusting the acid levels of the cell culture, the coloring can be varied from dark red to purple to blue. Ron Vunsh and Michael B. Matilsky obtained patent 4,939,086.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/14/world.body_text: **********An 11-day cease-fire between warring Lebanese Christian factions began to fall apart today as loyalists of Gen. Michel Aoun and Samir Geagea traded artillery shells and rockets in East Beirut and in the hills northeast of here. **********The command of General Aoun's 15,000-man faction of the Lebanese Army said three soldiers were killed in the last 24 hours, and the 10,000-strong Lebanese Forces militia of Mr. Geagea said three of its members were wounded today. **********Fighting intensified on Monday night when the two sides traded artillery fire in East Beirut. At the same time, fighting broke out in the hills 25 miles northeast of here, the police said. **********The cease-fire they were violating was the 16th since the Christian civil war erupted at the end of January. More than 800 people have been killed in the fighting and 2,600 have been wounded.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/06/world.main_headline: SOVIETS UNYIELDING ON A NEW GERMANY IN WESTERN ORBIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/06/world.print_headline: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;   SOVIETS UNYIELDING ON A NEW GERMANY IN WESTERN ORBIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/06/world.body_text: **********The major combatants of World War II opened formal talks on German reunification today with the Soviet Union emphasizing that it did not intend to let a united Germany slide easily into the Western orbit. **********Moscow stated its disagreement with the West on several aspects of unification, but all participants agreed that German unity must not be hindered. **********Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d seemed to reflect this mood when he said, ''Today we engage in an act of reconciliation, of a people too long separated, of a Continent too long divided.'' **********Meetings Last Seven Hours **********The Secretary spoke as he gathered with the foreign ministers of the two Germanys, the Soviet Union, Britain and France for the first full ministerial meeting of what have been dubbed the ''two plus four'' talks. The meetings lasted seven hours and were held at the Foreign Ministry in Bonn. **********From the outset, Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union signaled that Moscow, despite the disintegration of its Warsaw Pact and all its internal problems, would bargain hard for its views in the coming months. **********Using some of the most categorical language on the issue to date, Mr. Shevardnadze rejected the idea of a single Germany joining the North Atlantic alliance, and he said the full gamut of military and political issues involved in unification had to be resolved before Moscow would sign any agreement. **********Differences Played Down **********At the same time, he seemed to take pains to indicate that Moscow did not intend to hold up the talks or German unity. At the news conference held by the six ministers on the end of their talks, Mr. Shevardnadze acknowledged that some ''serious differences'' had been aired, but he emphasized that these ''need not be dramatized,'' that ''this is usual for the negotiating process.'' **********''Happily, we have no problem with any sort of allergy to the wishes of the German nation to unity,'' Mr. Shevardnadze said in his opening comments, indirectly scoffing at reports that the notion of German unification was painful to the Soviets. **********There was a sense among Western officials that some of Mr. Shevardnadze's tough talk may have been intended at least in part to assuage conservative critics in the Soviet Union, who have chafed at the idea of letting the Germanys unite and join the Western camp after the sacrifices made by the Soviet people in World War II. Mr. Shevardnadze explicitly noted the opposition in his opening statement, when he said German membership in NATO was also unacceptable for internal reasons. ''The population of our country, which sustained such frightening losses in the last war, cannot accept the idea of including Germany in NATO,'' he said. **********More broadly, he appealed to the West to understand the difficulty that Soviet politicians faced on an issue that carried an enormous emotional burden. ''We are dealing here with an issue of special importance to Soviet people, to our whole society,'' he said. ''If an attempt is made to push us into a corner on matters touching our security, it will lead to a situation - I will say it candidly -in which our political flexibility would be severely curtailed, because emotions would boil up inside the country, shades of the past would rise to the surface, national complexes with roots in the tragic pages of our history would be revived.'' **********Mr. Shevardnadze's position confirmed expectations that the negotiations could in effect prove to be ''one plus five,'' with the Soviet Union using one of its last remaining levers in Europe - its victor's rights in Germany - to preserve whatever it could by way of political, military and economic influence on a Continent increasingly facing westward. **********Balance of Power Stressed **********German membership in NATO, Mr. Shevardnadze declared, ''would very concretely affect our security interests, it would mean an acute violation of the balance of power in Europe, it would create for us a dangerous military-strategic situation.'' **********Moscow has in the past resisted the Western plan to incorporate Germany in NATO. The Western position, expressed in opening comments by Foreign Minister Roland Dumas of France, is that it is not for the wartime Allies to decree what alliance a sovereign, united Germany could or could not join. **********The broader disagreement between Moscow and the West that emerged from the opening statements was the scope of the ''two plus four'' talks. The Western position was that the allies were meeting only, as Mr. Baker put it, ''to arrive at a formula by which we will terminate and transfer all remaining four-power rights and responsibilities to a fully sovereign Germany.'' **********Other issues, such as the military and security structures in the Germany and the Europe of the future, could be discussed, but on these the ''two plus four'' should act only as a ''steering committee,'' channeling the various issues to appropriate forums or arms talks. **********'Package Approach' Sought **********The position staked out by Mr. Shevardnadze was that the ''two plus four'' must adopt what he described as a ''package approach.'' There would be no agreement, he said, until the participants had resolved all the ramifications of unification - including the military status and the military forces of the united Germany, the presence of foreign forces on German soil, German renunciation of atomic, bacteriological and chemical weapons and renunciation of fascist ideology. **********''We believe that it would be in the interests of Germany itself if the termination of four-power rights would be the culminating step in German unification,'' Mr. Shevardnadze said. **********Mr. Shevardnadze reiterated the Soviet position that Europe has to move toward broad new European security structures to replace the military blocs. To this end, he proposed the immediate creation of a ''pan-European center for the elimination of the military threat'' in Berlin, based in part on existing Allied institutions. **********The center, he said, would serve as a control and observation post for all military activities on German soil, and the ''first block'' in the building of new security structures. **********The proposal echoed Mr. Baker's idea of setting up a center for conflict resolution under the auspices of all-European Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. But the Soviet idea of a pan-European agency controlling all troops in Germany was certain to be rejected by the Western powers and Germany as a revival of special treatment for Germany. **********Agenda Is Formulated **********These differences, however, had not been unexpected at the opening session. Officials from all sides stressed that the ministers had found no disagreement on the principle business of the day, the agenda for their talks. This included: *********** The borders of a future Germany, which all the participants agreed would be the territory of West Germany, East Germany and Berlin - ''no more, no less.'' *********** Political-military questions, an area likely to produce the most serious disagreements. *********** Ending four-power authority over Berlin. *********** Preparing a ''final settlement'' under international law under which the four Allied powers would terminate their rights and responsibilities for Germany. Moscow at one point had indicated it that might hold out for a formal peace treaty - which the Germans resist as a humiliating exercise that would have to involve the many other nations that formally declared war on the Third Reich - but Mr. Shevardnadze signaled that Moscow would settle for a less formal ''final settlement'' with the four allied powers. **********Poland to Join Later Talks **********The six ministers also agreed to allow Poland to take part in the third foreign ministers' meeting, scheduled for July in Paris, when its borders would be discussed. After initial resistance, Bonn agreed this year to let the Poles sit in on discussions of its western border. **********Reading a statement agreed to by the ministers, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, the West German Foreign Minister and the host of the first round of ministerial talks, said, ''I can state that the talks have been taking place in a reasonable, constructive and trustful atmosphere and that they were dominated by the will for understanding.'' **********In his opening comments, however, Mr. Genscher and the East German Foreign Minister, Markus Meckel, cautiously stayed clear of the disagreements between Moscow and the Western powers. **********Mr. Genscher did stress that relations with the Soviet Union ''will continue to be of primary importance,'' underscoring what has been an unstated theme of the talks. The sense in Bonn is that one of Moscow's aims in the unification process is to secure guarantees that a united Germany will honor all East German trade obligations, and that Germany will provide economic assistance to the Soviet Union.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/22/busin.body_text: **********The Chicago Mercantile Exchange's president, William Brodsky, says changes are needed on how foreign securities are listed on United States exchanges so that more Japanese companies may trade on the New York Stock Exchange. **********If the exchange listing requirements were changed, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange could begin trading futures on the Japanese Nikkei stock index because investors would have easy access to the underlying stocks, Mr. Brodsky said. **********Speaking at a University of **********Chicago conference last week on Asian financial markets, Mr. Brodsky said only about a dozen of the 225 companies making up the Nikkei index are listed on the Big Board. He added that Japanese companies were reluctant to list on United States exchanges because the Securities and Exchange Commission requires excessive disclosure of financial information and restrictive accounting standards. **********The Chicago Merc has been granted the right to trade futures contracts on the Nikkei index while the Chicago Board of Trade has the right to trade Nikkei futures options. **********Stock index futures contracts are used by investors as a hedge against portfolio holdings. The contracts allow investors to trade a futures contract reflecting the stocks without having to buy the underlying cash instruments.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/12/busin.body_text: **********In the Pepsico deal, stockholders will receive 0.216 share of Pepsico common stock for each share of Collins common stock. Sizzler closed down 25 cents, at $16.50, in over-the-counter trading.
