https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/29/world.body_text: **********Liberia's shaky cease-fire collapsed today when Government troops and rebels battled for several hours in this capital city. **********Artillery and machine-gun fire erupted before dawn. Government forces fired at random from the presidential mansion where up to 1,000 followers of the late President Samuel K. Doe have been trapped between rival rebel factions. **********The truce broke down despite the presence of 6,000 West African troops who intervened in Liberia on Aug. 24 to impose peace after nine months of civil war. **********Violations of the truce began on Thursday afternoon when rebels from the smaller of the factions, led by Prince Johnson discovered a large Government arms cache in a central warehouse near the Defense Ministry. Government forces tried to retrieve the weapons, but were repelled by Mr. Johnson's fighters. **********''Now I'm ready for Taylor,'' a witness quoted Mr. Johnson as saying. ''Now I'm going to get him.'' Charles Taylor, who heads the larger rebel group, warned on Thursday that he would annihilate Mr. Johnson's followers as well as the five-nation West African peacekeeping force.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/04/busin.body_text: **********While the Frankfurt Bund has been the focus of this year's excitement over investing in the future of Eastern Europe, the Vienna Bourse has quietly crept higher and higher, setting nine new record highs. And this after 1989, a year it outperformed every other major market. **********Both markets are on the edge of an economic revolution and have been swept up in the whirlwind of change. While Austrian stocks have paid off as an entree to hoped-for profits from the Eastern bloc, the small Vienna market does pose some worries. **********Its size can make it volatile. It fell almost 7 percent from its mid-January high before rallying to four new highs last week, partly on the announcement of East German Prime Minister Hans Modrow's proposal for the reunification of the two Germanies. **********In addition, analysts say, far less information is available on stocks in the Austrian market than in larger markets. This makes it harder for an individual, or even fund managers, to follow the market. **********As in West Germany, the easiest access to the market is through a single-country fund traded in the United States. Like the two German funds, the Austria Fund, at about 77 percent, is trading at a high permium to the underlying value of the stocks it owns. **********The run-up in Austria means that the market may be close to overpriced, if it is not already. That could set it up for a big drop. **********Still, the Austrian gain is far ahead of West Germany's. The market is up 26.7 percent this year, according to the Financial Times World Indices, while West Germany has risen just 7.3 percent, even with large gains on Thursday and Friday that sent it to a record high. In the last 12 months, West Germany was up 51.5 percent, but the Austrian market rose 130.4 percent. Austrian stocks have benefited more than West Germany's from the moves toward economic reform in the Eastern bloc. That is because Austria has a long-time relationship with the East, and Austrians have had important roles in many joint ventures there. **********Some analysts also argue that the longer-term commitments some large investors make in the Austrian market means the Vienna Bourse is less volatile than other markets of a similar size. **********The market's boom has been built on its tiny size, - Vienna's market capitalization is 7 percent that of Frankfurt and 1 percent the size of the United States markets. Because the market is so small, purchases that would barely cause a ripple elsewhere, can send a stock soaring in Austria. Conversely, large sales can send prices falling, making investors reluctant to take their money out. This reduces some volatility. **********''This is not a trading market,'' said Marko Musulin, the head of the securities and investment banking division of Creditanstalt in Vienna, the country's largest bank. ''It is not easy to exit this market in large volumes.'' **********When these factors were added to the rising demand for Austrian stocks, the trend had to be up. Part of the demand came from the fact that Austria was so underrepresented in many international equity funds before the Berlin Wall was opened Nov. 9. After that, Morgan Stanley & Company recommended that the weighting given to Austrian shares be increased to 6 percent from 1 percent. In addition, several new closed-end mutual funds, including the Austria Fund, have added to the demand for stocks. **********David C. Roche, the international strategist for Morgan Stanley in London, said that in addition to the attraction of Eastern Europe, Austria is benefiting from the possibility that it now, finally, has a chance to join the European Economic Community. **********He also said that because Austrian accounting requirements with regard to disclosures are not too demanding, many companies and banks are loaded with hidden assets of land and stock that are just now being seen by many foreign investors. **********But the strong rise in the market has caused concerns. One analyst said shares in have become ''ridiculously overpriced.'' **********An Austrian analyst, who asked not to be named, said a good downward move right now would be nice. It would, he said, lower prices enough ''so we could make some more attractive sales to our customers.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/20/world.main_headline: Evolution in Europe;   Romanian Campaign Leaves Trail of Violence
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/20/world.print_headline: Evolution in Europe;   Romanian Campaign Leaves Trail of Violence
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/20/world.body_text: **********At the local headquarters of the ruling National Salvation Front, about 30 party workers watched intently today as a videotape of their campaign rally on Thursday was played and replayed. They were gathering evidence. The rally ended in violence when counterdemonstrators stormed the speaker's platform. About two dozen people, many of them women, were reported injured; several reportedly received knife wounds. **********The tape clearly shows Front demonstrators beating people with what appear to be pipes and clubs. The Front supporters froze the picture whenever they recognized the face of an attacker and drew up lists of the names to send to the police. **********''We can't make any statement about who is responsible,'' said Gheorghe Ilia, secretary of the Front's Timisoara branch, refusing to blame Romania's other parties. **********Violence has marred Romania's election campaign since its beginning, but until Thursday's incident in Timisoara the attacks have been directed against the parties opposing the Front, especially the National Liberal and National Peasant parties. **********These parties have alleged that the Front has organized the attacks, a charge that the Front denies. **********Anti-Front demonstrators in Timisoara's main square claim that Front partisans provoked Thursday's violence. The demonstrators vow to continue their sit-in in support of the Timisoara Declaration, a 13-point document that calls for temporarily barring former Communists and secret police officers from seeking election. Such a ban would disqualify Ion Iliescu, the Front's presidential candidate. **********''I'll maintain my hunger strike until the Communist system falls,'' said Gheorghe Majornic, an anti-Front demonstrator. **********The demonstrators contend that the Front's leadership is riddled with Communists and Ceausescu associates. Front advocates deny this and say the leaders of the Peasant and Liberal parties are carpetbaggers who were outside the country during the worst of the postwar years and who returned this year to steal the revolution.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/05/busin.main_headline: Vanity Fair Plans Edition For Britain
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/05/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;   Vanity Fair Plans Edition For Britain
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/05/busin.body_text: **********IN an experiment in international publishing that its competitors say they will watch eagerly, Conde Nast Publications announced yesterday that it would introduce a British edition of Vanity Fair that would have the same content as the American version except for its advertising, which would be British. **********Publishing experts say that other than Playboy, they are not aware of any other American magazine that has been exported overseas, for local marketing, with its articles and art intact. The international editions of magazines like Time and Newsweek often feature covers or articles different from their United States versions. **********''I'm thrilled about it,'' said George J. Green, the president of Hearst Magazines International, a Conde Nast rival. ''This will be a wonderful test. It will enable us to see whether exporting magazine content works, and what elements of it will work.'' **********In recent years, magazine publishers, like the advertising agencies and consumer-product companies that support them, have increasingly been looking for growth overseas, especially in Western Europe. In an analysis late last year, The Financial Times predicted that North America's share of world advertising expenditures would drop to 43 percent in 1991, from 46 percent in 1988, while Europe's would grow to 31 percent, from 28 percent. **********In an attempt to reap some of the benefits of this expected growth, Conde Nast will introduce Vanity Fair to Britain in March 1991, in an edition that will be published simultaneously on both sides of the Atlantic. By exporting an established brand intact, Conde Nast, like other global marketers, hopes to save the costs of creating a new brand name or refining an existing one for different tastes. **********S. I. Newhouse Jr., Conde Nast's chairman, said he believed that Vanity Fair, which has a circulation rate base of about 600,000, can achieve a circulation of 50,000 to 75,000 in Britain. He said his expectations were based on a three-month test his company started in April, in which it doubled the average monthly distribution of Vanity Fair in England to 20,000, and ''found the sales pattern was consistent with what it was before we doubled it.'' **********Through its subsidiary Conde Nast Publications Ltd., the company now publishes seven magazines in Britain. Four are versions of American titles with British content, and three are specific to Britain. **********Conde Nast executives deemed Vanity Fair to be the only magazine capable of exporting because its content, under the editorship of Tina Brown, a British native, has been international in scope. The publication, one of America's most influential feature magazines, has been a melange of celebrity profiles, gossipy tales of society intrigue, incisive reports on foreign political figures and pungent commentary on art and culture. **********Ms. Brown said she believed that the attitudes and interests held by the affluent and educated classes in Britain and the United States were similar enough to allow one version of Vanity Fair to be published in both countries. **********''American movies go to London with no content changes,' ' she said. ''In a funny way, Vanity Fair is the first magazine to open like a movie.'' **********Ms. Brown said there was no relationship between the creation of a British Vanity Fair and Conde Nast's dismissal last week of the editor of its British magazine Tatler. Ms. Brown edited Tatler - like Vanity Fair, a publication involved with the doings of the upper crust - before coming to Vanity Fair. **********Most publishers go to great lengths to tailor the content of their international editions to the tastes of the individual editions' readers. Reader's Digest, for example, publishes 39 editions in 15 languages. While each magazine can draw from the same pool of articles, most adapt the ideas for their own purposes, said Bruce S. Trachtenberg, a Reader's Digest spokesman. **********Playboy, which has 13 foreign editions, has an international edition that is exactly the same as its American edition, but with ads sold overseas. It is aimed primarily at Americans living abroad, said Lee B. Hall, a former Playboy executive who is now a consultant in Chicago specializing in international publishing. **********Mr. Hall was dubious about Vanity Fair's prospects in London. ''I think you have to adapt your magazine to the language and culture of the readers,'' he said. **********Mr. Newhouse said advertisers were not approached for their reaction to the venture. He also said no discounts would be offered to encourage marketers to purchase advertising packages in the two editions. **********''We expect to find in the U.K., as we have always found in the U.S., that if we publish a magazine that readers like, advertisers will follow,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/15/busin.main_headline: Buchwald Ruling: Film Writers vs. Star Power
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/15/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;   Buchwald Ruling: Film Writers vs. Star Power
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/15/busin.body_text: **********Art Buchwald's victory in court against Paramount Pictures cheered writers, who frequently complain that they are not given proper credit for their part in a movie's success. **********But lawyers, studio executives and producers said last week's ruling was unlikely to change the way Hollywood did business, largely because of the industry's avid courtship of its expensive stars. **********''We haven't told our business affairs people they should be more diligent,'' said Robert Cort, a producer. **********''People are always careful,'' said James Brooks, the writer, director and producer. **********''We won't do anything differently,'' said Joe Roth, president of the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation. **********Many Messages From Writers **********Nevertheless, writers are jubiliant. Alain Bernheim, Mr. Buchwald's co-plaintiff, returned from a trip last Thursday to find 76 messages on his answering machine. ''My machine was blown out,'' he said. ''The messages were mostly from writers, saying, 'well done!' I didn't even know a lot of them, except by reputation.'' **********Most people in the industry had expected the California Superior Court to rule that the blockbuster 1988 movie ''Coming to America'' was based on an idea that Paramount had optioned from Mr. Buchwald in 1982. After all, Paramount had spent $418,000 developing scripts for Eddie Murphy from the newspaper columnist's three-page story about an African king who comes to America, is deposed, goes to live in the ghetto and finds true love. The project was abandoned in 1985.  Studios and producers get nervous when courts uphold writers who have sent them an unsolicited script. But this situation was different. To almost everyone but Paramount, it seemed that Mr. Buchwald had an open-and-shut case. **********Plenty of Star Power **********The question being raised in Hollywood now is why Paramount did not simply pay Mr. Buchwald off. The answer, according to a dozen producers and executives, has a lot to do with star power. **********Mr. Murphy wanted story credit on ''Coming to America.'' He was the biggest star on the Paramount lot. Two of his movies, ''Beverly Hills Cop'' and ''Beverly Hills Cop II,'' had grossed more than $150 million apiece. ''The Golden Child'' had almost reached $100 million despite scathing reviews. And Mr. Murphy, whose contract with Paramount is coming to an end, was known to be unhappy with the studio. **********When he came up with the idea for ''Coming to America,'' Mr. Murphy may have long since forgotten the bits of Mr. Buchwald's story that he had been told. Judge Harvey A. Schneider went out of his way to make it clear that he did not think that Mr. Murphy stole Mr. Buchwald's idea. But the rules of the Writers Guild of America would not have allowed Mr. Murphy the story credit if ''Coming to America'' were based on an idea by Mr. Buchwald. **********Some Coincidences **********If Paramount had not had such obvious access to Mr. Buchwald's idea, the similarities between Mr. Buchwald's ''King For a Day'' and Mr. Murphy's ''Coming to America'' might have been considered a coincidence. As many recent films show, most movies are variations of other movies. **********''Ideas are in the air,'' a producer, Scott Rudin, said. ''How else do you explain five movies in one year about people swapping bodies and ages: 'Vice Versa,' 'Like Father, Like Son,' '18 Again,' 'Big,' and an Italian picture, 'Da Grande?' '' **********In August 1985, three movies about adolescents making strange science experiments were released: ''Weird Science,'' ''Real Genius'' and ''My Science Project.'' **********When Paramount finally made Mr. Buchwald an offer a few weeks before his breach-of-contract case was to go to trial, it was too little too late. ''When they're against the wall, they say they'll settle if you'll just shut up,'' Mr. Buchwald said in a telephone interview from Washington. Paramount agreed to settle for $250,000, exactly what he won in court. ''We agreed to settle if there was no gag order,'' he said. But the studio's condition was that Mr. Buchwald not talk about the settlement. Where Are the Net Profits?  In the next phase of the case, Mr. Buchwald and Mr. Bernheim, who share 19 percent of the net profits of ''Coming to America,'' must prove that there are profits to share. Paramount contends that the movie, which has sold more than $300 million worth of tickets, has no net profits. In the arcane world of studio bookkeeping, every time a gross profit participant like Mr. Murphy gets his profit, it puts the movie a little more in debt. This phenomenon is called a rolling break-even. **********Most industry experts expect that Paramount will settle with Mr. Buchwald rather than open its books to public scrutiny in court. **********There is also pressure on Mr. Buchwald to settle. His lawyer, Pierce O'Donnell, took the case on a contingency basis. Since Judge Schneider did not require Paramount to pay punitive damages, the costs of fighting Paramount greatly exceed the money won by the lawyers so far. **********Action by the Writers Guild **********The Writers Guild has formed a committee to examine the entire issue of credits. Getting credit for work on a script is important to a writer because the public recognition often leads to higher status, more money and other job offers. **********''The most important power the guild has is the ability to arbitrate credits,'' said Naomi Fomer, the writer of ''Running on Empty'' and a committee member. ''I think this case will have a major effect on the committee.'' **********And Mr. Buchwald has received an unsettling taste of what it means to be a movie star. ''My life for 40 years has been that of an observer,'' he said. ''I got a standing ovation when I walked down Connecticut Avenue to my office. It's very frightening. I feel like a slight fraud. And I know I don't want to be at the center of the action for very long.'' **********Paramount Communications

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/12/busin.body_text: **********Dozens of angry investors besieged the office of a Polish financier today after it closed for lack of funds and a newspaper reported that the financier might have vanished abroad. The newspaper, Gazeta Wyborcza, said employees of Lech Grobelny, once Warsaw's best-known black market currency dealer, had closed his Safe Savings Bank after telling a prosecutor it had run out of money. A spokesman for the prosecutor's office said it was checking but had no evidence that a crime had been committed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/12/busin.body_text: **********Prices of some bonds of RJR Nabisco Inc. jumped more than three points yesterday on heavy volume amid rumors that Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company was planning to buy back an entire issue of the bonds. **********A spokeswoman for Kohlberg, Kravis, which took RJR Nabisco private in 1988 in the largest leveraged buyout ever, declined to comment on the rumors. Analysts and traders said one rumor circulated that the investment firm planned to buy all of the outstanding bonds of an RJR issue that is convertible to stock. **********Prices of the company's $1.8 billion of senior converging debentures due in 2009 rose to 81.25, up 3 3/4 points. Prices of the company's $4.1 billion exchange debentures due in 2007 climbed to 68.50, up 4 1/2. **********Prices of RJR bonds have been extremely volatile for several months. And the market has been filled with rumors that the company would make an exchange offer for the depressed bonds or that Kohlberg, Kravis would buy them with some of the cash it has accumulated in its leveraged buyout fund. **********The two bond issues pay interest in new bonds instead of cash. And both issues have a ''reset'' feature, which means that the company must raise the interest rate next year to enable them to trade at their face value. But as the prices of the bonds rise and approach the face value, the pressure of the reset feature is lessened.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/11/busin.main_headline: Caution Replaces Glamour As the Key Word in Books
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/11/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: PUBLISHING;   Caution Replaces Glamour As the Key Word in Books
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/11/busin.body_text: **********MANY book publishers would normally mount eye-catching exhibits of their fall books at the American Booksellers Association's convention. But at this year's gathering, most of the displays were unusually subdued. **********Gone were the caged animals, the hot-air balloons and the preoccupation with Hollywood stars. A few celebrities were on hand, but for most publishers it was back to basics. **********The reason for the low-keyed approach, some visitors assumed, was that the convention was being held in Las Vegas, Nev., where any attempt to get attention could only pale alongside the erupting volcanos, storybook castles and tropical rain forests at the city's hotels and casinos. **********That may indeed have inhibited some publishers at the event last week, but there seemed to have been something more fundamental at work, something that appears to augur well for book publishing: the understanding that smoke and mirrors, glitz and glitter are no substitutes for quality books. **********Most publishers have always known this, of course. But with the rise of the blockbuster book, they either lost sight of it or chose to ignore it. Nowhere was that more apparent than at previous booksellers' conventions, where the promotions and pronouncements of huge first printings were raised to a pitch that Barnum would have envied. **********This frenzy by itself was not too bad, because enthusiasm is essential to successful publishing and bookselling. What was bad was that publishers began to believe their own hyperbole and tried to persuade bookstores to believe it as well. So after paying unrealistic advances for many books, publishers leaned on booksellers to double and triple their orders. **********When the books were returned, sometimes in the hundreds of thousands, the publishers had to write off not just the unearned authors' royalties but also the cost of producing and warehousing the unsold books. **********At last week's convention, however, there were signs of change in the desert air. Despite what is generally regarded as one of the strongest fall book lists in years, few publishers were boasting about the size of their first printings. Instead, they were talking about ''the hand sell,'' industry jargon for selling books individually rather than like soap. And they were talking about writing quality - a departure from the recent past and a welcome recognition that books, after all, are to be read and savored. **********While both the new Jean Auel and Sidney Sheldon novels are likely to have first printings of a million or more, other books will start out much more cautiously - even books by best-selling authors. **********For example, in one case B. Dalton and Waldenbooks have already ordered more than 100,000 copies of a new book. Orders from the other chain stores and independent booksellers could eventually double that number. But instead of printing 350,000 to 400,000 copies, as many houses would do in similar circumstances, this house - whose executives did not want to be identified -plans to print an initial 250,000 copies to minimize the risk of heavy returns. **********''I don't care how many orders we get; I'm not going to be overruled on the initial printing,'' the publisher of that house said. ''If we see a gigantic runaway, I can reprint quickly.'' **********One thing in the publishers' favor is that reprinting is simpler than in the past. ''Paper is widely available and there are a lot of presses with big capacity,'' said Parker Ladd, a director of the Association of American Publishers. ''It used to take as much as three months to reprint; now it can be done in a few weeks.'' **********Moreover, computers allow publishers to keep closer track of their book sales. ''If they find they aren't selling in Colorado, for example,'' Mr. Ladd said, ''they can move them down to stores in Florida.'' **********When publishers have been cautious in previous years, their caution often reflected a sluggish economy. So it would be foolish to predict that the relative absence of glitter at last week's convention represented a permanent condition. But there are reasons to think that the caution may last a bit longer than usual. **********For one thing, the book chains are reducing the size of their orders. They will still place big orders for certain titles, but publishers say the chains are reluctant to fill their stores with stacks of the same titles. **********''They don't get hurt as much as we do if a book doesn't blow out of the store,'' one publisher said. ''But by cluttering stores with lots of copies of books that didn't move, they have missed sales on books that will sell.'' **********Finally, the new-found caution reflects corporate realities. **********''When publishing houses were privately owned, a big mistake was chalked up to experience,'' said the publisher of a quality house owned by a conglomerate. ''But when you're talking to absentee landlords, and they say, 'How come your revenues were up but profits were down,' they and their accountants don't want to hear about write-offs for unsold books - at least they don't want to hear about it two or three years in a row.'' **********So, at least for now, caution is the word.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/07/busin.main_headline: Daimler-Benz and Mitsubishi Negotiating Cooperative Plan
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/07/busin.print_headline: Daimler-Benz and Mitsubishi Negotiating Cooperative Plan
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/07/busin.body_text: **********In what may prove to be one of the most far-reaching industrial linkups, the largest business groups in Japan and West Germany, Mitsubishi and Daimler-Benz, said today that they were negotiating a plan of ''intensive cooperation'' in automobile technology, aerospace, microelectronics and a number of service industries. **********If the agreement is completed, as executives on both sides said they anticipated, it will create a series of joint ventures that will give Daimler access to some of Japan's best technology and give the giant Mitsubishi empire a desperately needed foothold in Europe before that market is integrated in 1992. **********The arrangement could also pose an enormous competitive challenge for the United States, pitting its biggest businesses against the combined talents and marketing skills of the two most aggressive industrial groups in the booming German and Japanese economies. **********Areas of Interest **********Japan is particularly interested in Daimler's jet engines and the prospect of building cars with the world's leading maker of luxury cars, Mercedes-Benz; Germany's main interest is electronics, high-technology equipment and space technology, all areas in which Mitsubishi excels. **********In separate statements today, both companies said they would meet soon to work out specific accords, but Daimler said that they regarded the talks as ''promising of success.'' **********The announcement came after a secret meeting this weekend in Singapore involving the top executives of Daimler-Benz and the presidents or chairmen of the four biggest of the 29 Mitsubishi companies - Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Mitsubishi Motors, Mitsubishi Electric and the Mitsubishi Corporation. The Mitsubishi Corporation, the leader of the group, is one of Japan's biggest trading companies. The meeting was apparently suggested by Edzard Reuter, the energetic chairman of Daimler's managing board. **********Neither side would say whether the two groups planned to take an equity interest in each other or whether the arrangement would go beyond cooperation in technology and marketing. But Daimler said, ''The independence of both groups will be respected.'' Daimler-Benz had sales of $37.3 billion in 1988, before its recent acquisition of Messerschmitt-Bolkow-Blohm G.m.b.H., the aerospace concern; the combined Mitsubishi companies had sales of about $82 billion. **********In an unusual statement, Japan's powerful Ministry of International Trade and Industry appeared to give its blessing to the deal tonight, saying, ''We welcome the two groups entering into broad-ranging cooperation at a time when international cooperation is seen in so many areas.'' **********But a senior ministry official acknowledged that the proposed alliance was rife with political problems. Members of the European Community are deeply suspicious of Japan's rush to enter the European market before 1992. On Monday, amid renewed debates over restraints on Japanese ''transplant'' auto plants in Europe, Edith Cresson, France's Minister for European Affairs, said Japan's ''strategy is to set up plants in Japan, Europe and America wherever they can and switch production so they can destroy U.S. and European auto makers.'' **********Moreover, both companies are closely associated with the rise of the Axis powers 50 years ago, a history that, one Japanese official said recently, ''will never go away.'' Mitsubishi Heavy Industries built the Zero, the durable fighter that led Japan's invasion forces throughout Asia; Messerschmitt built much of the Luftwaffe. Even today, Mitsubishi Heavy Industries is Japan's largest arms maker and Daimler is one of Europe's largest. **********Japan is barred from exporting arms or arms technology, except for special agreements with the United States. And a Mitsubishi spokesman, Masao Takemoto, said tonight that the exchange of ideas and technology would ''specifically exclude defense.'' It is unclear how the two companies would handle what the military terms ''dual use technologies'' that can be used for both commercial and military purposes, like electronics or high-temperature metals used in jet engines. **********The announcement of the agreement comes as a number of Japanese companies are scrambling to link up with European partners, or build their own operations in Europe. Most of Japan's leading car makers, for example, have announced plans to build plants within the European Community, except for Mitsubishi Motors, which has long been rumored to be negotiating with Mercedes for a production partnership. Mitsubishi helps market Mercedes in Japan. **********To Relax Frictions **********At a news conference today, attended only by Japanese reporters, Yoshio Taniguchi, vice president of Mitsubishi, reportedly said the company hoped the business alliance would relax trade frictions between Japan and the European Community. But he gave no specifics of the arrangements, saying only that the companies had scheduled further meetings. **********The Singapore meeting, he said, was attended by Yotaro Iida, chairman of Mitsubishi Heavy Industries; Toyoo Tate, chairman of Mitsubishi Motors; Moriya Shiki, president of Mitsubishi Electric, and Shinroku Morohashi, president of the Mitsubishi Corporation. In addition to Mr. Reuter, Daimler was represented by its deputy chairman, Werner Niefer, who is also chairman of Mercedes-Benz. **********The Japanese executives negotiating with Daimler run one of the most powerful industrial groups in the world, made up of the remnants of one of Japan's leading zaibatsu, or interlocking business groups. It was broken up by Gen. Douglas McArthur when he headed the postwar occupation. **********Today the companies are perhaps more closely linked than at any time since the end of the war, sharing technology, holding one another's stock. The United States has protested that these ties give the Japanese companies an unfair advantage over American concerns trying to enter the market here. **********Internally, the Mitsubishi group calls itself the ''Kinyokai,'' which literally means ''Friday meeting,'' an outgrowth of end-of-the-week meetings of top leaders of each of the companies. **********Corporate Turnaround **********Over the last decade, that meeting has been the breeding ground of a sweeping corporate turnaround involving most, though not all, of the Mitsubishi members. Until the early 1980's the group was known for steady but plodding growth and little imagination. Today revenues and profits have soared, and the group has edged out its three main competitors among the conglomerates in Japan - Mitsui, which includes Toshiba); Sumitomo, which includes NEC, and Fuyo, which includes Nissan and Hitachi. Mitsubishi has also been involved in some of Japan's biggest and most controversial projects. **********Moreover, Mitsubishi's reach within Japan is unusually long, presumably the main reason Daimler sought it out in the German company's diversification plans. Its members make Nikon cameras, Kirin beer, steel, petrochemicals, rockets and luxury cruise ships, and they include the huge Mitsubishi Bank and the real estate group that bought a controlling interest in Rockefeller Center last fall. It also owns most of the central business district in Tokyo, purchased in 1890 by the company's second president, Yanosuke Iwasaki, when it was still covered with grass and bamboo. **********''To the Japanese consumer, we are like the air: invisible but pervasive, providing essential things to sustain life,'' Yohei Mimura, the company's chairman, said some time ago. **********Needed Technologies **********For all of its power, though, Mitsubishi is in great need of several technologies that it may gain from Daimler. Many are in aerospace. Although Mitsubishi Heavy Industries is building the FSX fighter jet with General Dynamics, and is one of three companies working with Boeing on a new aircraft, it has never been able to design its own aircraft engines or develop a successful commercial plane. Daimler owns an engine maker and, through Messerschmitt, owns West Germany's 37.9 percent stake in Airbus Industrie, the European aircraft consortium. **********Mitsubishi Motors, meanwhile, is engaged in a big struggle at home to remain a main force in the Japanese auto market, where it is virtually tied for third place with Honda Motors. The company has had a long association with Chrysler, but the American car maker's recent troubles have sent company executives in search of a stronger partner. An alliance with Mercedes would be a coup, especially at a time that Mitsubishi Motors' two largest domestic rivals, Toyota Motors and Nissan Motors, are bringing out luxury cars directly aimed at the market dominated by Mercedes-Benz and BMW. **********More Pressure on U.S. **********American reaction to the announcement of talks between Daimler-Benz and Mitsubishi suggested that an alliance between the foreign giants would intensify the pressures on American companies to become more competitive. **********''Certainly American industry is not in a position to criticize two private-sector companies getting closer together,'' said Howard Lewis, vice president for international economic affairs at the National Association of Manufacturers. ''It goes on all the time. This is increasingly the way the global environment works. But to the extent that this cooperation makes a competitive world even more competitive, it is all the more incumbent on America to wake up and put our own economy in a more competitive posture. We better get our act together.'' **********And John Ettlie, an associate professor of operations management at the University of Michigan,, said: ''It's definitely an important event with important implications. Clearly this puts more pressure on the European agenda. Up to now, I think there has been a relaxed attitude among American companies that the West Germans were reluctant to do joint ventures with the Japanese. This signifies a softening of that position.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/05/busin.main_headline: Many Authors Seek to Be Heard as Well as Read
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/05/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;   Many Authors Seek to Be Heard as Well as Read
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/05/busin.body_text: **********Books on audio cassettes are becoming such an important source of income for authors that audio rights are increasingly being treated as valuable literary properties. **********According to Ed Victor, the literary agent for Jack Higgins, Douglas Adams and Erica Jong, ''I find myself saying, 'Tell me not only how much you will pay, but how many audios you will print, how will you advertise it, do you plan to release it at the same time as the book, and will the book make reference to the tape and the tape make reference to the book?' '' **********Advances for audio rights are still rather modest, averaging $5,000 to $10,000. ''I don't think anybody will pay a $1 million advance to us or to Judith Krantz for audio-tape rights to their next book,'' said Henry Morrison, the agent for Robert Ludlum, who has many books on tape. **********Still, Mr. Victor and others say they have sold audio rights to books for as much as $35,000. Moreover, a number of big-name authors, including James Michener and Tom Clancy, have earned six-figure royalties for audio books. **********Royalty rates for audio vary, but they are closer to the royalties for paperback books, which range from about 8 percent to 10 percent of the retail price, than they are to hardcover royalties, which start at 10 percent and rise to 15 percent. **********''For most authors it's not an enormous source of income, but it's an additional source, and for some it can be substantial,'' said Ann Rittenberg, a literary agent. ''Plus, unlike the payment of book royalties, the payment of audio royalties is usually very fast.'' **********Industry's Growth **********While the size of the audio book industry is sometimes estimated at about $250 million a year, industry officials say it is nearly impossible to determine - because most audio publishers do not disclose their sales figures and there are so many audio publishers, including a number that sell only via direct mail. **********''But this industry has really grown in the last few years,'' said Jane Friedman, the publisher of Random House Audio Publishing. ''It's now an accepted supplement to book publishing.'' **********Random House, Simon & Schuster, Bantam Books and Harper & Row have audio divisions, and other audio leaders include Dove Books on Tape of Studio City, Calif.; Nightingale-Conant of Chicago; Audio Renaissance Tapes of Los Angeles; TDM/McGraw-Hill of Fullerton, Calif., and Recorded Books of Charlotte Hall, Md. There is also a vigorous market for religious books on audio. A leader in that business is Word Inc. in Waco, Tex. **********Books on audio are typically published on two 90-minute cassettes and sell for about $15. Most audio books include only about 50 percent of the hardcover book's contents, although some companies publish only unabridged versions. One such company, Recorded Books, offers ''To Kill A Mockingbird'' by Harper Lee on nine cassettes totaling 14 hours. Who Reads the Books?  Most books are read by professional actors or broadcasters, but some are read by authors - as, for example, the audio version of ''Russia House'' by John le Carre, ''The Joy Luck Club'' by Amy Tan and ''Talking God'' by Tony Hillerman. **********John F. Kennedy's ''Profiles in Courage,'' recently released by Harper Audio, is narrated by John F. Kennedy Jr., the son of the late President. T. Coraghessan Boyle recently recorded an audio version of his collection of stories, ''If the River Was Whiskey,'' and he will soon record his latest novel, ''World's End.'' **********Georges Borchardt, Mr. Boyle's agent, said he often sold non-exclusive rights, meaning separate rights for both the abridged and the the unedited versions of the same book. Mr. Morrison not only sells rights for the unedited and abridged versions of Robert Ludlum's novels, he also apportions the abridged Ludlum audios between Random House, which publishes Mr. Ludlum in hardcover, and Bantam, which publishes him in paperback. **********Random House Audio publishes about 50 books a year, has some 250 titles in print and is trying to acquire rights to authors' previously publishing works. Its spring 1990 catalogue includes ''The Osterman Weekend'' by Mr. Ludlum, ''Masquerade'' by Janet Dailey, ''Friend of My Youth'' by Alice Munro, ''Hawaii'' by James Michener and ''Rising From the Plains'' by John McPhee. The catalogue also includes an assortment of self-help and how-to titles. **********Problem With Science Fiction **********''Every category of book is possble,'' Ms. Friedman said, ''but the only one that does not work well for us is science fiction. I think the reason might be that sci-fi readers are purists and want the entire book, not an abridgment.'' **********Initially, Random House hoped to sell an average of 5,000 audios per title, but today the average is closer to 10,000 or 15,000, and some big-name authors sell well over 25,000. The company recently issued ''Caribbean'' by James Michener. Ms. Friedman said it had already sold 40,000 copies and will probably sell twice that amount during the year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/10/busin.main_headline: Merrill Banker Quitting To Seek a Faster Track
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/10/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;   Merrill Banker Quitting To Seek a Faster Track
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/10/busin.body_text: **********Not too long ago, a career in investment banking was considered the fast track. In the 1980's, eager executives flocked to Wall Street to reshape companies and to get rich. **********But, as Courtney F. Jones and others have recently discovered, things change. After working as an investment banker for nine months at Merrill Lynch & Company, Mr. Jones, once the treasurer of the General Motors Corporation and Merrill's chief financial officer, is leaving Wall Street, he said, because he wants a ''faster growth path.'' **********The current slow pace of investment banking does not provide him the excitement or satisfaction he enjoyed in his previous jobs. ''I need to reinvigorate that pace,'' he said. **********After serving as chief financial officer at Merrill for four years, Mr. Jones, 50, became a managing director in the company's investment banking group in August 1989. As chief financial officer, Mr. Jones developed a cost-analysis process to evaluate returns on Merrill's various divisions. **********His move into investment banking came shortly before the collapse of the Campeau Corporation, the large Canadian developer, and before the demise of the high-yield ''junk bond'' market drastically changed the climate for takeovers and similar deals. **********Recently, Mr. Jones said yesterday, he surveyed the deal-making scene, concluded that it was ''going south a bit'' and decided that better opportunities were probably available in the corporate world. **********''I've had a terrific career, and I'm anxious to maintain the kind of success I've had,'' he said. ''Rather than stay here a few more years, I thought I would return to corporate management.'' **********Merrill executives said they were sorry to see Mr. Jones leave. ''Courtney's association with Merrill Lynch over the past five years has been an extremely productive one,'' William A. Schreyer, the company's chairman, and Daniel P. Tully, its president, said in a joint statement. ''We wish him every success in his new endeavors.'' **********No successor has been named, the company said. **********Although he has not decided what he plans to do, Mr. Jones will leave Merrill by the end of the year, he said. He joined Merrill in 1985 after 23 years with G.M. He holds an undergraduate degree from Wayne State University and an M.B.A degree from the University of Chicago.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/21/busin.body_text: **********The Indian Government demanded today that a $470 million settlement between an earlier administration and the Union Carbide Corporation to compensate victims of the 1984 Bhopal disaster be overturned. **********Attorney General Soli Sorabjee told the Supreme Court that the 1989 settlement between the Government led by Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and Union Carbide was invalid because crucial information relating to the case was not shared by both litigants with the court. **********Mr. Sorabjee also said the settlement should be overturned because victims groups were not consulted at the time. **********The Government did not specify what it considered an adequate sum. **********The money has not yet been used for the victims because of legal challenges to the settlement, although the earlier Government of Vishwanath Pratap Singh began a system of interim relief. About half a million residents of Bhopal are entitled to receive the equivalent of about $12 per person a month.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/19/busin.main_headline: Setback for the Cubans Benefits the Dominicans
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/19/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;   Setback for the Cubans Benefits the Dominicans
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/19/busin.body_text: **********Even before it officially announced last week that it was severing its ties with Cuba, Davidoff International, which makes some of the most expensive and prestigious cigars, had shifted its production to the Dominican Republic. **********Company officials say the first million Davidoffs produced in the Dominican Republic should arrive in the United States later this month and be offered for sale in the fall. **********About the same time, another million Davidoffs will be shipped to Amsterdam and then to Basel, Switzerland, where Davidoff is based, the officials said. **********After a year and a half of disputes, negotiations and lawsuits, Davidoff said it decided to end its ties to Cuba because quality control had slipped badly and officials of Cuba's tobacco production agency had refused to take back rejected cigars. **********View From Havana **********Officials at the Government agency, Cubatabaco, called the quality control problem a pretext to break off a 1983 distribution pact with Davidoff. They said they had always been willing to take back rejects and that Davidoff's real motive in shifting production is to gain broader access to the United States market. **********Because of the American embargo on Cuban goods, Davidoff has not been able to sell its Cuban cigars in the United States since 1961. So the shift to the Dominican Republic will let the company sell luxury cigars in the American market. **********Davidoff began making cigars in Cuba just after World War II. In 1970, the company was sold to Oettinger Imex S.A., a marketing company also based in Basel, although Zino Davidoff, whose father founded the company, is involved in the company. **********Chris Kull, president of Davidoff of Geneva, which is based in Stamford, Conn., and is a subsidiary of Davidoff International, said Davidoff had a three-year supply of Cuban cigars in 1988 when it stopped buying them. **********Looking elsewhere in the Caribbean for a producer, it turned to Hendrik Kelner, who owns the Tobacos Dominicanos cigar plant on the outskirts of this mountain city. **********Mr. Kelner, who is 44 years old, said his family had been in the Latin American tobacco business since 1920. He said that his 59-acre farm and 150-worker factory produce about four million cigars yearly, and that half the production will be in various Davidoff shapes. **********His plant uses mostly Dominican tobacco. For the Davidoff cigars, he imports the cigar wrappers - the outer leaf - from Connecticut. **********Mr. Kelner said most of his cigars are made by hand. He pays workers $27 for each 1,000 cigars wrapped. The average worker, he said, can wrap around 1,250 cigars weekly, making average pay about $34 a week, high by Dominican standards. **********The Dominican Republic currently provides about 50 million premium-quality cigars annually to the United States. It is the largest supplier to the American market. **********In 1983, Davidoff, with an eye on the United States market, began producing in Honduras the Zino brand of cigars, which sell for $2.75 to $6. The company would not disclose how many Zinos were sold; one cigar expert, who asked not to be identified, said 800,000 to a million were sold in the United States last year. **********George Brightman, the manager of the Davidoff retail shop at 535 Madison Avenue in New York City, said said the Davidoffs coming to the United States would be aged six months, reinspected and repacked at Stamford and introduced in August. Most of the cigars will sell for $4 to $12, he said. Mr. Kull, president of the American subsidiary of Davidoff, said the Aniversario, a nine-inch cigar packed in an individual tube would probably sell for $15 to $18.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/30/busin.main_headline: American Express in Pact on Long-Distance Phone Calls
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/30/busin.print_headline: American Express in Pact on Long-Distance Phone Calls
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/30/busin.body_text: **********The American Express Company waded yesterday into the bitter credit card marketing skirmishes between the nation's largest banks and the nation's biggest telephone company. **********American Express said its card could be used to place long-distance calls through the MCI Communications Corporation and the U S Sprint Communications Company. The carriers will offer a 10 percent discount from their regular calling-card rates, the same discount that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company provides for its Universal credit card. Review Sought by Banks **********The Universal card is a Mastercard or Visa card that is sponsored by A.T.&T. and combines the features of a general-purpose credit card and a telephone calling card. The nation's leading banks have asked regulators to review the legality of A.T.&T.'s sponsorship, have adopted rules to prevent any more non-banks from issuing Visa cards, have added long-distance calling features to their own cards and have even shifted a little of their own long-distance business away from A.T.&T. **********Yesterday's move by American Express came as A.T.&T. said its card business continued to grow faster than expected. A.T.&T. said that by last Thursday, it had issued 5.8 million cards, whereas analysts had predicted the company would only issue 5 million cards by the end of the year. A.T.&T. introduced the Universal card on March 26. **********Consumers have charged purchases and calls totaling $2.2 billion to the Universal card, and owe $1 billion, said Bruce E. Reid, a company spokesman.  Luxury Versus Thriftiness **********American Express has long cultivated an image of luxury and exclusivity for its card, while U S Sprint and particularly MCI heavily advertise themselves as low-cost alternatives to A.T.&T. But Norma J. Arnold, the senior vice president for membership marketing at American Express, said the contrasting strategies would not be a problem. **********"We believe that MCI and Sprint are very viable and successful competitors, as is discernible from the shift of share in the long-distance market," she said. **********American Express cardholders will be able to charge calls to the card on U S Sprint's network beginning on Nov.1, and on MCI's network starting on Jan. 1. To do so, a cardholder must first call a toll-free number and obtain a four-digit personal identification number to use with the card number. **********Effective immediately, cardholders that use MCI or U S Sprint for their home telephone also can be charged for these calls on their American Express card bill rather than on their local phone company bill. Ms. Arnold said the feature would appeal to people who have a separate phone line at home for business calls that their employer pays. Fewer Cards, Fewer Bills **********Market research told American Express two years ago that consumers wanted fewer credit cards and fewer bills, and the company began working on billing procedures then, Ms. Arnold said. She added that American Express had not lost customers to the Universal card nor was the deal with MCI and U S Sprint influenced by Universal's success. **********"The effect of the A.T.&T. card launch has been an internal cannibalization of the bank-card business," she said. **********Peter A. Gallagher, a senior vice president of A.T.&T.'s Universal card unit, said it was unclear whether customers were switching from the American Express card. **********Mr. Gallagher said A.T.&T. had an advantage because, unlike American Express, it had offered never to charge an annual fee to customers who take the card this year. "The bottom line is, why pay up to $75 a year for something you can get free for life from A.T.&T.?" he said. **********A.T.&T. has indicated that it will begin charging an annual fee to customers who sign up next year. Mr. Gallagher declined to say yesterday how much it might be.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/26/world.main_headline: P.L.O. Offers to Mediate for Lebanon's Christians
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/26/world.print_headline: P.L.O. Offers to Mediate for Lebanon's Christians
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/26/world.body_text: **********Two people died and five were wounded today in another day of artillery and rocket duels in East Beirut as the Palestine Liberation Organization offered to mediate in the conflict between rival Christian forces, its past enemies. **********Artillery shells and rockets struck residential quarters in the Christian sector of the Lebanese capital as a joint security committee was trying to remove barricades and confrontation lines. Christian radio stations said members of the security committee ran for cover and dropped their efforts to reopen roads and intersections. Thousands of civilians huddled in bomb shelters. **********The fighting, between soldiers loyal to Gen. Michel Aoun, the army commander, and members of the Lebanese Forces militia led by Dr. Samir Geagea, broke out on Jan. 30. Police and hospital records indicate that more than 800 people have been killed and 2,500 wounded in the fighting, which is turning into the most brutal bout in 15 years of civil strife in Lebanon. **********The number of casualties is already as high as that reached last year in seven months of bombardment between Christian forces on the one hand and Syrian troops and their Lebanese Muslim militia allies on the other. **********General Aoun, with 15,000 trained and well-equipped soldiers, appears intent on keeping up the pressure on the militiamen until they give in to his demands that they disarm and join his ranks. Dr. Geagea has vowed to fight to the end rather than have his 10,000-strong Lebanese Forces suppressed. **********A mediation committee made up of two Maronite Catholic monks and a lawyer appeared to have reached a dead-end in its effort to find common ground between the army and militia chiefs. **********Now the Palestinians have stepped in at the instructions of Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O. chairman. A Palestinian delegation has traveled by boat from the southern port of Sidon to the Christian sector and held separate talks with General Aoun and Mr. Geagea. **********Zaid Wehbeh, who led the delegation as Mr. Arafat's representative in Lebanon, said an 11-point plan for Christian reconciliation was being drafted, and would be offered to the warring factions. **********The P.L.O. endeavor is not without paradox. The civil war began with clashes in 1975 between Christian militiamen and P.L.O. groups seeking to become a state within the Lebanese state. Earlier, Palestinian gunmen fought gunbattles with Lebanese Army troops around Palestinian camps in Beirut.
