https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/20/world.main_headline: Japanese Gunman Tied to Crime Ring
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/20/world.print_headline: Japanese Gunman Tied to Crime Ring
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/20/world.body_text: **********The police said today that a 40-year-old ultranationalist arrested in the shooting of the Mayor of Nagasaki was a member of a shadowy group involved in blackmail and extortion as well as militant acts in the name of the Emperor. **********The suspect, Kazumi Tajiri, was identified as the subchief of a group called Seiki Juku, or Spiritual Justice School, one of several hundred small and scattered right-wing groups throughout Japan. The police in Nagasaki questioned Mr. Tajiri today but have not charged him. **********He is being held in connection with the shooting on Thursday of Hitoshi Motoshima, the Mayor of Nagasaki, who has been the target of protests and death threats after saying a year ago that Emperor Hirohito bore some responsibility for World War II. **********The shooting episode has shaken Japan, but with new details disclosed today it was also casting unusual light on the way that right-wing fanaticism - a longtime feature of Japanese society with roots in the disgruntled samurai class at the end of the 19th century - has evolved in recent years. **********There is widespread agreement that the right-wingers' views glorifying the Emperor did not represent more than a tiny fraction of general Japanese sentiment. Nonetheless, the shooting was taken as a reminder that this small group has the power to shatter a nation's calm. **********Longtime Links Cited **********The emerging details focused on what police experts said were longtime links between militant right-wing groups and organized crime groups, known as yakuza or boryokudan, which are engaged in blackmail, intimidation and the smuggling of drugs and guns. **********News organizations reported that Mr. Tajiri was arrested last June with two other members of his organization for allegedly conspiring to extort money from a Tokyo company. He was also quoted as telling the police after his arrest this week that he did not intend to kill the Mayor but shot him to punish him for remarks about Hirohito. **********Many specialists said today that they saw the shooting of Mr. Motoshima less as the expression of a political sentiment than as a brazen effort by an underworld gang to build its reputation for violence. **********''What you have are these yakuza groups pretending to be partiots,'' said a retired police official involved in investigations in such matters. ''They use right-wingers' names or titles to disguise themselves and give them some politically decent flavor.'' **********Others took a different view, saying the ultranationalist groups represented a dangerous trend in Japan toward a right-wing political mentality that glorifies the institution of the Emperor, makes no apologies for Japan's military expansion of the 1930's and has a low regard for dissent. **********The Asahi newspaper, for instance, labeled the assassination attempt ''a barbarous challenge to freedom of speech'' and said it ''reminds us that our society still remains vulnerable to a nightmare of terrorism against freedom of speech.'' **********Paper a Rightist Target **********Asahi has itself been a longtime target of rightist attacks, with ear-splitting sound trucks - a favorite tactic of right-wing groups - occasionally descending on its offices to protest editorials questioning right-wing ideals. **********Two and a half years ago, an Asahi reporter was killed and another was critically wounded by a masked attacker who opened fire with a shotgun in an incident that, until the attack on the Mayor on Thursday, was been the most prominent recent violent action by a right-wing group in Japan. **********Some of the news coverage focused today on another aspect of the political implications of the case. **********The recently retired senior official said there was some evidence that right-wing groups, with their sound trucks and protesters, were sometimes used by the members of governing Liberal Democratic Party, which has a strong conservative faction, to harass their political opponents. **********It was also pointed out in news analyses today that last year, conservative members of the Nagasaki legislature said that the large security detail protecting Mr. Motoshima was a waste of taxpayers' money, and that in response the Mayor asked that the police detail be cut back in December. **********After he made his comment in December 1988 about Emperor Hirohito, Mr. Motishima was ousted from his position as the head of the governing party's local branch. **********The shooting suspect, Mr. Tajiri, was apparently known by the police as a potential threat well before the episode on Thursday, and there was some question why the Mayor could not have been better protected. **********A Profession of Terrorism **********In May 1987, for example, Mr. Tajiri appeared on a morning television talk show about right-wing groups and was asked if he believed in the use of terrorism against those whose opinions differed from his. ''Yes, because for right-wingers, terrorism is the core,'' he said. **********News accounts said today that the Spiritual Justice School was established in 1981 with headquarters in Nagasaki and branches in other cities. Specialists in right-wing groups said it was a well-known group but not large, with perhaps only a dozen active members. **********One specialist on ultranationalist activities, Masayuki Takagi, an Asahi writer, said there were about 840 right-wing groups in Japan with a total of 125,000 members, with the number increasing each year. **********In an interview, Mr. Takagi said that the increasing numbers were considered part of the ''new right,'' but that these new groups engaged in noisy street demonstrations - with 810 sound trucks clogging downtown Tokyo in August 1988 - and disavowed violent activities. **********Mr. Takagi said that organized crime groups had spread through most of the right-wing groups, but that right-wing terrorism had generally been decreasing in Japan. **********Only about 50 of the right-wing groups, with a membership of 22,000, are said to be watched by the police, Mr. Takagi said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/27/busin.main_headline: Why World Shrugged Off Tokyo's Stock Tumble
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/27/busin.print_headline: Why World Shrugged Off Tokyo's Stock Tumble
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/27/busin.body_text: **********For some time, market watchers around the world have expressed concern that if the high-flying Tokyo stock market ever plunged, other markets would be carried down with it. But the Japanese stock market's 11 percent dive over the last week, a fairly big move by most standards, has not touched off sharp slides elsewhere, and analysts are scurrying to explain why. **********The most common explanation is that the Japanese market had moved up so much more sharply than other markets that some downward adjustment was due, both to bring it into line with the bond markets in Japan and with financial markets in other countries. Some movement, analysts argued, could be accommodated -even expected. **********''I don't see why this should become self-feeding, because there is no real talk of a worldwide recession and earnings are still reasonable,'' said David A. Robbins, head of the international securities department at UBS Securities. ''This should support equity markets.'' **********'Peculiarly Japanese' **********''So far investors look at the Tokyo market decline as a peculiarly Japanese situation, not a global situation,'' said Yuichi Kohashi, executive vice president of Daiwa Securities America Inc. in New York. **********This is not to say investors in other markets have not been worried about the 4,138.45-point decline in the Nikkei 225 index of leading stocks in the last six days. A sharp decline in a major market, even if easily explained, can be unsettling. The United States stock markets fell each day last week, although the Dow Jones industrial average shot up yesterday by 38.29 points, to 2,602.48. For the year, the United States is down about 5 percent, Britain has dropped close to 7 percent and France is off more than 10 percent. **********The relatively benign view of the decline in the Japanese stock market, which is now down 14.4 percent since the end of last year, rests on the fact that many analysts thought the rise to record levels at the end of December had taken the market too high. Because of this, it was expected that the Japanese market would fall, a move known in market jargon as a correction. **********'Its Own Correction' **********''A lot of stock markets I follow have already corrected,'' said Lawrence W. Harris 3d, manager of the Worldwide Value Fund. ''Japan seems to be having its own correction.'' **********In addition, the sharper rise in interest rates in Japan and the unusually public fight over interest-rate policy between the Bank of Japan, the country's central bank, and the Finance Ministry have, for now, made this more a Japanese problem than a global one. **********While interest rates have risen around the world, the increase in Japan has been sharper than in many other countries. Rates on 10-year bonds in Japan are up about 19 percent this year, compared with 7 percent in the United States. This means earnings on bonds became far more attractive than those on stocks, drawing money out of the stock market into bonds. The divergence in Japan has been larger than in other countries, like the United States and Britain. That is one reason the stock markets in those countries have fared better, said Alistair Ross Goobey of James Capel Inc., a London brokerage firm. **********''The Japanese market, more than any other market, was extended in relation to its bond market,'' said Jeffrey M. Weingarten, director of international equity research at Goldman, Sachs in London. **********Fight Over Interest Rates **********Despite the fact that the Japanese wave has not yet swamped the rest of the world, many financial experts say the outlook is still uncertain. The fight in Japan over interest-rate policy could be unsettling. But Mr. Kohashi of Daiwa, for one, thinks Japan's desire to stabilize its market means interest rates will not be raised again soon. **********But not everyone agrees. Some analysts warn that Japan may have to raise interest rates further to prop up the yen, which leaves the door open to a continued decline in Japanese stocks. With higher interest rates and a further decline in stock prices - of perhaps an additional 2,000 to 3,000 points - analysts said Japan's market problems could be contagious. Higher rates in Japan could help push interest rates higher around the world, weakening equity prices everywhere. **********There are other pressures, too, that investors fear could push interest rates higher around the globe. Perhaps the most important is that the unification of Germany and development of Eastern Europe will push world interest rates higher by increasing the demand for credit. If that happens, that could force stock prices in Japan and other nations down further. **********Pressure on Institutions **********Another fear is that Japan's market weakness could spread if Japanese economic officials get so worried about the fall of their market that they put pressure on large institutional investors to bring some of their money back to Tokyo to support the market there. **********''It's not changing my view that the sidelines are the place to be,'' said Barton M. Biggs, director of worldwide strategy at Morgan Stanley, who said he was surprised by the rise in American stock prices yesterday. ''I think it is a silly reaction because the Japanese market is another cloud on the horizon.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/14/busin.main_headline: Big Hoboken Project Back on Track
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/14/busin.print_headline: MIXED-INCOME HOUSING IN NEW JERSEY; Big Hoboken Project Back on Track
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/14/busin.body_text: **********Four years after it was announced and then ran into a number of problems, an ambitious plan to construct more than 400 apartments here for families of varying incomes is back on track. But instead of building a single project on one site, as orginally conceived, the sponsor will deliver the housing in two developments on three parcels. **********In January, 115 of the apartments will be ready for occupancy in Observer Park. The 12-story tower is rising on the corner of Bloomfield Street and Observer Highway in the southern half of this mile-square port city on the Hudson River, opposite Manhattan. It will be followed by Hudson Square North, a 12-story, 150-unit building under construction on Third Street, between Hudson and River Streets. Twenty percent of the units in both buildings will be set aside for low-income households, with Hoboken families getting preference. **********The third project, called Hudson Square South and in the planning stage, will also contain 150 units. All three are being built by the Applied Companies, a local developer. The architect is Becher & Wolczynzki of East Hanover, N.J. **********The projects are welcomed by Hoboken, where housing development, rapid until a few years ago, has slowed considerably. "They provide much-needed affordable housing and show that the city continues to hold appeal as a residential market," said Peggy E. Thomas, director of the Community Development Agency. **********Ms. Thomas was referring to the rejection by voters this summer of the 3.2-million-square-foot project planned by the city and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey for 32 acres of Hoboken's crumbling waterfront. It would have included offices, stores, a park and apartments. **********The housing developments will also bring revenue to the financially pressed city. Ms. Thomas said that when they were completed, the first two projects -- financed through state, Federal, county and private funds -- would generate taxes of $676,502 a year. **********Delivering the units, however, proved to be a formidable task. In 1986, Applied contracted with the city to transform a rundown site, made up of three major parcels along Observer Highway, into a mixed-income housing project. It was to contain 450 residences in five mid-rise and high-rise buildings, as well as a park. **********But homeowners in the neighborhood opposed the project, saying its height and density would destroy the character of the area. They sued the city, contending that its redevelopment plan was arbitrary and capricious. Ultimately the lawsuit, which was redirected to the scaled-down Observer Prk project, was decided in favor of the developer. **********A further problem was the finding of mercury and lead on the tract, rendering it too costly to develop, and the project was shelved. Only the site of the current Observer Park project was salvaged, said Joseph Barry, president of Applied, noting that it has been cleared of contaminants. He said the cleanup had cost $350,000. **********In addition, the company's joint- venture partner at the time -- Hartz Mountain Industries of Secaucus -- pulled out of the project. Nonetheless, Mr. Barry said he had renegotiated with the Hoboken City Council to redevelop for housing the current Observer Park site as well as two vacant parcels on River Street. **********Mr. Barry said he did so because he felt there was a strong need for such housing and that if priced correctly, the units could be easily rented. Applied paid the city $6.1 million for the three sites, which Mr. Barry described as prime because they are near PATH, train and bus depots. **********New Jersey is still saddled with a large stock of new and existing for-sale housing. But the rental market is brisk because an increasing number of people, concerned about the nation's uncertain economy, are choosing to rent rather than buy. **********"Right now, there is a stronger rental than selling market in Hoboken," said Alice Galmann, a partner in Singleton/Galmann Real Estate, a local realty company. Monthly rents in Hoboken range from $800 to $1,000 for one-bedroom apartments and from slightly more than $1,000 to $1,300 for two-bedroom apartments, with some as high as $1,800, she said. **********Market-rate apartments at Observer Park will rent for $850 to $995 a month for a 625-square-foot, one-bedroom apartment, and for $1,400 to $1,600 a month for a 1,100-square-foot, three-bedroom unit. Mr. Barry said all but six units had been rented, most of them to people commuting to Manhattan. **********At Hudson Square North, where the one- to three-bedroom units will be larger, rents are expected to be slightly higher. Mr. Barry said completion of that project is set for next October. The apartments reserved for families with low incomes in both buildings will rent for $220 to $320 a month. **********Mr. Barry said the third project might be a luxury rental. But that decision, he added, hinges on the market and the availability of sewers. At present there is a state-imposed moratorium on sewer hookups until Hoboken expands its treatment plant. The two buildings under construction are exempt because they contain affordable units.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/14/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Introductory Fare By Northwest Air
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/14/busin.body_text: **********Northwest Airlines said it would offer low introductory fares for round-trip travel between San Jose and other points through June 15. The carrier will start service in San Jose on May 15. **********Northwest said fares would be $119 each way to Minneapolis-St. Paul; $129 to the rest of Minnesota, Iowa, the Dakotas, Wisconsin and Nebraska; $139 to the rest of the Midwest, South Central and Southeastern cities, and $149 to Northeastern cities. **********The company said the introductory fares were about $100 lower than the lowest round-trip discount fares now available in most markets.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/21/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;   Interpublic Net Increases 17.6%
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/21/busin.body_text: **********The Interpublic Group of Companies yesterday reported net income for the fourth quarter of 1989 of $27.4 million, or 81 cents a share, up 17.6 percent from $23.3 million, or 70 cents a share, for the fourth quarter of 1988. Revenue rose 2.4 percent, to $380 million from $371.1 million. **********The holdings of Interpublic, based in New York, include the Lintas Worldwide and McCann- Erickson Worldwide agencies. **********For all of 1989, Interpublic reported net income of $70.6 million, or $2.10 a share, up 17.5 percent from $60.1 million, or $1.82 a share, in 1988. Revenue for 1989 was $1.26 billion, up 7.7 percent from $1.17 billion in 1988.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/16/busin.body_text: **********Since the announcement of my impending role at the New York Stock Exchange, I have been meeting with a cross section of people involved in and affected by equities investment and trading. What I have heard can be summed up in a word: Dissatisfaction. **********People are dissatisfied with how the industry has performed -- and not just because the market has turned down. They see that the focus of the industry has changed to include diverse activities. As clients, they are not convinced that those activities are in their best interests. **********The message, I believe, is that they want the industry to get back to basics. **********Today, I find leaders of the corporate world are more disappointed and downright angry with this industry than I have ever seen them before. While there are notable exceptions, their perception is that there has been a gradual but accelerating shift in the industry from being primarily an advice giver to becoming a competitor. **********Among individual investors, if there isn't the same anger or frustration, there is at least a strong measure of dismay. **********Certainly, many things have improved during the 1980's. There is a lot more information available and the reaction time is quicker. Turnaround time for electronic orders at the New York Stock Exchange averages 28 seconds. Customer reporting is efficient and increasingly free of error. **********Despite these and many other advances, a large segment of the public believes Wall Street is increasingly designed to serve only the largest investors and that for whatever reason, the market has become too volatile. **********Institutional money managers are also, in many cases, not too happy with this industry. They also want to be certain that when they seek the service of the securities industry, they are provided with agents who put the customer first. **********The three groups of customers -- corporate, individual and institutional -- are doing more than just complaining. They are also taking a walk. Individuals, when they are not sitting on their hands, are fleeing in droves to professionally managed accounts. Institutions are talking about increasing trading directly with other institutions. Major corporations are bringing some investment banking activities in-house. **********Not all the reassessing that is needed, however, is by the industry. Investors must ask themselves if cutting out the intermediaries is wise. Enlightened manufacturers and retailers learned long ago that destroying suppliers or denying well-performing intermediaries an adequate economic incentive was counterproductive. **********We learned long ago that diversity of interests meeting in a public setting produces the most liquidity. The New York Stock Exchange has gained its position in the world by making certain that the smallest and the largest participants have parity at the point of sale. The diversity of players redounds to the benefit of all. **********I am not approaching Jan. 1 convinced that the New York Stock Exchange is without fault. We can make our auction market better. If we do not reach out to accommodate the needs of all the market participants -- large and small, short term and long term, active and passive -- we will wind up with multiple marketplaces and we will have really lost something. **********At the same time, if we do not balance those interests, put some limits on how much we allow one interest or one trading practice to affect the stability of the market, we will have a professionals' market by default. The other participants will have departed. **********I certainly do not have all the answers. But the questions that must now be considered are vital ones. The securities industry has taken its eye off the customer. In the midst of trying to be all things to all people, can it really say, "The customer is better off"?

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/31/busin.main_headline: American Industry Faces the Challenge of Tougher Times
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/31/busin.print_headline: THE YEAR IN BUSINESS: 1990; American Industry Faces the Challenge of Tougher Times
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/31/busin.body_text: **********William H. Gates  Microsoft's Payoff For Persistence **********More than anyone in the computer industry, 1990 belonged to William H. Gates, chairman and co-founder of the Microsoft Corporation. **********After seven years of unsuccessfully attempting to persuade PC users that his Windows software was the wave of future, Mr. Gates tried a third time this summer. He spent $10 million to introduce Windows 3.0 and managed to convince almost everyone that even if the program is not perfect, it is inevitable. **********The 35-year-old entrepreneur's extraordinary success with Windows 3.0 underlined the increasingly vital role that software plays in the computer industry. And Microsoft's position today seems so strong that many industry executives are now convinced that it is Mr. Gates, and not I.B.M., who will set the direction for computing in the 1990's. **********Since 1987, Microsoft and I.B.M. had been trying to persuade business customers to abandon their MS-DOS-based computers for the more powerful but untried alternative of a OS/2 operating system, which used I.B.M. hardware and special Microsoft software. But few users moved up. **********So in 1990, Mr. Gates decided to improve the lot of the nation's 40 million MS-DOS users by evolution rather than revolution -- and Windows 3.0 was the tool. I.B.M. and I.B.M.-compatible computers may now be operated with a hand-held mouse and on-screen symbols, as is Apple's Macintosh, rather than by typing in commands. **********Microsoft's growth has been stunning at a time when most of the computer industry has stagnated. Its profits jumped 47 percent, to $279.2 million. **********The Redmond, Wash., billionaire has begun to shed his bespectacled-nerd image. He is building a lake-front home that will have a garage large enough to hold 80 cars, evidence of a passion beyond software.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/17/busin.body_text: **********The stock market tumbled yesterday to its lowest close in more than three months after being pummeled throughout the day by a worse-than-expected inflation report, falling bond prices, higher oil prices and unsettling news from the Middle East. **********The Dow Jones industrial average fell 66.83 points, or 2.43 percent, to 2,681.44 - its lowest level since May 1 when it was 2,660.92. The drop was the fourth-biggest one-day decline in points this year. **********With yesterday's close, the Dow has retreated more than 10 percent from its peak of 2,999.75 on July 17. Some traders say that when the market pulls back more than 10 percent from its high, it is an indication that the decline could be more than a correction. **********Overseas markets declined as well yesterday. In Tokyo, the Nikkei stock index fell 562.68 points, or 2 percent, to 27,549.44. Japanese stocks continued their retreat today, with the Nikkei dropping 700.58 points, or 2.54 percent, to 26,848.86 by midafternoon. Pressures on Wall St.  There were other pressures on Wall Street yesterday morning. The Government reported that the consumer price index had risen a sharply higher-than-expected four-tenths of 1 percent in July and that housing starts had fallen 2.6 percent last month. **********These reports undermined the bond market, where the price of the benchmark 30-year bond plunged and its yield soared to 8.92 percent, from 8.75 percent on Wednesday. [Page D12.]  Investors were also unnerved by higher oil prices and tough talk by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. **********Volume on the Big Board remained relatively light, with 138.8 million shares traded, compared with 135.2 million on Wednesday. **********In the broader market, declines outpaced advances by a ratio of about four to one, with 1,300 falling and 330 gaining. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was down 7.67 points, to 332.39, and the Nasdaq composite index of over-the-counter stocks fell 9.18 points, to 402.27. **********'Market Was Disappointed' **********''Basically, the market was disappointed over the C.P.I. in the morning, which crept into the market all day, and that did not include data collected before the Iraqi invasion,'' said Ron Schroeder, chief investment officer at J.&W. Seligman & Company. He expects the next consumer price report to be even higher because of the jump in oil prices following the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. **********Mr. Schroeder said the real damage to stocks might have come from the sharp rise in Treasury yields. Higher yields generally encourage investors to move their money to bonds from stocks. **********He added that bond yields were likely to remain high. ''The threat of higher inflation and a softer dollar makes it hard for the Federal Reserve to ease,'' he said. **********Concern that the Federal Reserve Board would neither be able to reduce interest rates to help avoid a recession or raise them to help fight inflation added more worries to an already unsteady market. **********The last time the Dow dropped more than 10 percent was in late 1987, when it fell 12.9 percent from a post-crash high of 2,027.85 on Oct. 21 to a low of 1,766.74 on Dec. 4. **********Yesterday, traders reported some futures-related selling after the inflation and housing-starts reports were released. **********Hussein Depresses Stocks **********After a slight recovery in the morning, the market was hit when President Hussein of Iraq indicated that he would not compromise his position in the Middle East. Traders saw this as another sign that there would not be a quick resolution of the crisis. **********There was little program trading in advance of today's ''double witching hour.'' The double witching hour, as opposed to a triple witching hour, involves the simultaneous expiration of stock options, stock index options and the major-market index futures. The major-market index is made up of 20 blue-chip issues, but it is not as widely watched as the S.&P. 500. Instead, it is considered confirmation of the Dow because it has 17 of the 30 Dow stocks, including A.T.& T., I.B.M., General Motors, Coca-Cola and General Electric. **********Birinyi Associates Inc., which tracks program trades made by large institutions and brokers, reported only three big sell program trades all day. The net total decline in the Dow from the program trades throughout the day was 25.51 points. **********Yesterday's low volume magnified the selling pressure, some traders said. **********Mr. Schroeder said there could be a bright side to yesterday's activity. ''When the market reacts in the way it did, it does so in a broad-brush way, taking down stocks across the board and creating buying opportunities in certain stocks,'' he said. Among the stocks he mentioned were Dillard Department Stores, which fell 1 3/8, to 82 5/8; Newell, off 7/8, to 26 3/8, and Tyco Laboratories, down 1 1/2, to 54 3/4. **********The most-active stock on the Big Board was Ohio Edison, which fell 2 1/2, to 17 3/8, on 2.19 million shares. The utility received a disappointing rate increase from the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio. **********Pharmaceutical Stocks Off **********Some pharmaceutical stocks also dropped. Eli Lilly, was down 4 1/8, to 71 1/2, and Merck, was also down 4 1/8, to 83 3/4. **********Security Pacific lost 3, to 28 3/4, after the California banking said it was increasing its provisions for loan losses in the second half of the year. **********Bankers Trust New York also fell, losing 1 1/4, to 37, after it said its problem loans might continue to rise for the remainder of 1990. **********Deere dropped 3 5/8, to 60 5/8, a low for the year amid signs that the farm economy will weaken and hurt the company's core farm-equipment business. **********And Hewlett-Packard lost 1 7/8, to 35 7/8, after the electronics company reported worse-than-anticipated earnings.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/01/world.main_headline: Rival Shiite Groups in Lebanon Agree to a Truce
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/01/world.print_headline: Rival Shiite Groups in Lebanon Agree to a Truce
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/01/world.body_text: **********Rival Shiite Muslim factions that have been battling for three years for control of southern Lebanon agreed today to a cease-fire and said they would allow army troops to be deployed in a region near Israel. **********The two factions, the mainstream Shiite Muslim militia Amal and the Party of God, its pro-Iranian rival, said they would free all prisoners and normalize their relations under the agreement, reached under the auspices of their backers, Syria and Iran. **********Reports circulating in the Lebanese capital spoke of an approaching deployment of Lebanese Army regulars in the region, Iqlim al Toffah, in the Shiite heartland of southern Lebanon, where Amal and the Party of God have been fighting since April 1988.  Scaling Back the Militias **********The agreement was the latest in a series of moves that apparently reduce the power of the factions and militias that have carved up Lebanon into spheres of influence over 15 years of civil strife. **********Militias also agreed recently to pull out of Beirut, after troops led by Syrian soldiers forced Gen. Michel Aoun, the renegade Christian general, to give uppower to the Syrian-backed Government of President Elias Hrawi. **********Syria's role as Lebanon's power broker has become even stronger since Damascus sent troops to join the American-led force in the Persian Gulf opposing Iraq and its invasion of Kuwait. **********Despite the Amal-Party of God agreement announced today, a Palestine Liberation Organization official said that a Palestinian force in the Iqlim al Toffah area would not pull out unless formal dialogue on Lebanese-Palestinian relations was started. **********The P.L.O. representative in Lebanon, Said Wehbeh, linked the withdrawal of P.L.O. forces to opening the P.L.O. office in Beirut and creating formal ties between his organization and the Lebanese Government. **********Palestinian guerrillas loyal to Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O. chairman, used fierce fighting between Amal and the Party of God in Iqlim al Toffah as an occasion to leave their refugee districts in Sidon, 23 miles south of the capital, and base themselves in this region close to Israel as a buffer force between the rivals.  Deployment Near Israeli Border **********Agriculture Minister Mohsen Dalloul said the Lebanese Army would replace the Palestinian guerrillas in Iqlim al Toffah and station troops around their camps in Sidon. **********Mr. Wehbeh said any army deployment in southern Lebanon and aroundthe Palestinian districts should include the Israeli-designated security zone in southern Lebanon. The zone, a border strip running 15 miles inside Lebanon, is patrolled by Israeli Army and their allies, the South Lebanon Army. **********Statements by Amal and the Party of God said their agreement today was a "prelude to a final and comprehensive solution" to their three-year feud. The truce was reached after extensive meetings in Damascus, eastern Lebanon and Beirut involving representatives of the two sides, the Iranian Ambassador in Damascus and Syrian intelligence officials. **********The Party of God wants to establish an Islamic nation in Lebanon and wants to fight Israel to the finish. Amal, which takes a secular approach, is opposed to opening the Israeli border for fighters from the Party of God.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/03/busin.main_headline: Bank of Boston Acts to Offset Bad Property Loans
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/03/busin.print_headline: Bank of Boston Acts to Offset Bad Property Loans
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/03/busin.body_text: **********The Bank of Boston Corporation yesterday announced additional losses from its real estate lending but said it expected to break even in the fourth quarter as the losses were offset by profits from selling most of its credit card business to the Chase Manhattan Corporation and the restructuring of its pension fund. **********As the largest banking company in New England, the Bank of Boston has been hit hard by the weakness in real estate in the region. After lending heavily to construct new condominiums and office buildings when real estate prices were rising rapidly, the bank has had trouble collecting on loans to developers now that real estate prices are weak and vacancies are rising. **********About three months ago, real estate problems caused the bank to set aside additional reserves, which resulted in a $125 million loss for the third quarter. In the fourth quarter, the Boston banking company said it was adding $280 million to its reserve for loan losses, and would write off $300 million of loans. **********Real Estate Holdings Climb **********The banking company's holdings of real estate, mostly acquired through foreclosure on bad loans, rose to $600 million from $300 million, and $200 million more of loans became non-performing during the quarter. Non-performing loans, which are 90 days in arrears or whose prospects are poor, declined to $1.1 billion at the end of the year from $1.5 billion on Sept. 30 because of the $300 million charge-off and the increase in real estate holdings. **********To offset the losses from real estate, the Bank of Boston said yesterday that it had sold $645 million of credit card receivables to Chase, which has been a heavy buyer of credit card receivables this year. Chase paid a premium for the receivables, resulting in a pretax profit of about $145 million for the Bank of Boston. **********The Bank of Boston also added about $50 million to its fourth-quarter earnings by financing a part of its pension plan with annuity contracts purchased from insurance companies. The gain occurred because the pension plan held stocks, bonds and other assets whose value exceeded the cost of the annuity contracts. **********Stock Rises 75 Cents, to $19.75 **********Bank of Boston stock rose 75 cents yesterday, to $19.75. In addition to the stimulus from the large gain in broad stock market indexes, analysts said the rise in Bank of Boston stock reflected speculation by some buyers that the company was nearing the end of its problems. **********Thomas J. Tisch, who in combination with other members of his family has bought more than 6 percent of Bank of Boston's stock since late October, said last week that even if the company was to announce additional loan losses, he was convinced that it was a fundamentally sound company whose stock was ''over penalized'' by the troubles of the region's economy. **********Several analysts cautioned that problems in the New England economy were not diminishing and that banks in that region might find even more troubled loans in the future. **********Ira Stepanian, the chief executive at the Bank of Boston, said that the New England economy deteriorated in the fourth quarter and that there are ''continuing uncertain economic conditions for 1990.'' **********Virginia Adair, a banking analyst at Drexel Burnham Lambert, said that ''I expect there will be at least two more quarters of continued problems at Bank of Boston, with increases in loan loss reserves and increases in nonperforming assets.'' **********For Chase, the purchase of Bank of Boston's credit card business was the fifth acquisition in the last 12 months. Including another small purchase at the end of 1988 from the Investors Savings Bank in Richmond, Chase has purchased about two million credit card accounts this year, while adding a million accounts through its own marketing efforts. **********David J. Cornell, a vice president at Chase, said that pretax profits of 4 to 4.5 percent on credit-card receivables made the business one where Chase expected to continue to expand through acquisition and growth of its existing business. Chase said it is the second-largest bank in the credit card business in the country, with nine million accounts and more than $9 billion in credit card receivables outstanding. Citibank is the largest bank in the business, with considerably more than 20 million accounts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/17/busin.main_headline: Dow Drops by 35.15, Despite Late Rally
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/17/busin.print_headline: Dow Drops by 35.15, Despite Late Rally
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/17/busin.body_text: **********Stocks fell sharply yesterday as oil prices rose, but rallied slightly in the final 15 minutes on a report that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq might accept a diplomatic solution to the gulf crisis. **********After two days of gains that lifted the market 51 points, the Dow Jones industrial average slid 35.15, to 2,381.19, recovering a few points in the final quarter-hour. Birinyi Associates, which monitors program trading, said that heavy program selling knocked the Dow down close to 49 points. **********Analysts and economists also began saying cautiously that the bear market could be coming to an end. **********''There's a major bull market going to unfold,'' said David B. Bostian Jr., chief economist for the investment firm of Jesup, Josephthal & Company, ''probably in 1991.'' He said he had advised clients ''to cut cash levels to the minimum and invest in high-quality bonds and stocks.'' Beginning of the End? ''You're looking at a wounded bear,'' said Ronald J. Hill, investment strategist for Brown Brothers, Harriman. ''The beginning of the end of a bear market comes when bond prices perform better than stocks, as they have since Sept. 25. That's generally the first step. The next requires greater investor confidence and that's the hang-up right now,'' Mr. Hill continued. ''They have to step up to the plate and buy stock.'' **********He argued that continuing uncertainty about the budget and the Iraqi crisis ''are holding people back,'' but that ''if we get a positive resolution on those, it'll be much easier for people to come in and buy.'' **********Trading volume slumped to 149.6 million shares, from 165 million Monday, as 1,077 shares dropped in price and an unsettling 276 fell to new lows. Only five touched new highs and 487, or less a fourth of the total, rose in price. **********Near Certainty on Fed **********Mr. Bostian of Jesup, Josephthal argued that ''it's almost certain that the Fed is going to ease monetary policy in a matter of days because a budget accord is expected in a matter of days.'' **********A budget agreement seemed close indeed. After the market closed, the White House said President Bush had canceled a trip to Cincinnati, were he was to attend the second World Series game, so that he could monitor the budget talks in Washington. **********Mr. Bostian also said that ''the probabilities are fairly high that the Middle East crisis will be resolved in a month or so.'' **********''You can't be sure if it's war or peace,'' he said, ''but it's another positive because even if it's war, it could be decisive fairly quickly.'' **********As a result, he said, ''One should be focusing on the stock and bond market to rally in the near future.'' **********No 'Follow-Through' **********But Peter G. Grennan, head of stock index futures for Shearson, Lehman Brothers, said: ''In the last six weeks, there hasn't been a rally where the market's been up more than twice in a row. That means there's no follow-through. Traders can't get any conviction that we've seen the lows for the year.'' **********In a sign, however, that traders were prepared to believe good news from almost anywhere, the stock market turned up a bit in the last 15 minutes - after four hours of weakness - when a news report from Bonn said Iraq might be willing to accept mediation to end the gulf crisis. **********The report said reporters had gotten that impression after interviewing Dieter Schinzel, a German deputy in the European Parliament and a member of the opposition Social Democrat Party. **********Busy Day for Shorts **********Earlier in the day, crude oil declined, bonds rallied and stocks followed. Speculators who had sold short rushed to buy back stock before it rose further. When the rally faded, the short sellers sold stock short again, driving down the market. **********By the end of the session, crude rose 94 cents a barrel, to $38.89; bonds rose sharply, yields on 30-year bonds fell to 8.88 percent, and stocks stood 619 points, or 21 percent, away from their all-time high in mid-July. **********Amid concern about the state of many American banks, Citicorp, the biggest banking company, topped the Big Board active list falling 1 1/8, to 13, with 3.6 million shares changing hands. It said third-quarter earnings per share fell 43 percent largely because of provisions for poor real estate loans. **********Nynex, the phone company, fell 3 7/8, to 72 7/8, after administrative judges of the New York Public Service Commission recommended smaller rate increases than it had requested. **********General Electric reported a small rise in profits but the stock fell 2 7/8, to 51 1/2, on concern about future quarters. PPG Industries, the glass and chemicals company, fell 3 3/4, to 34 5/8, after a new low of 34 1/2. **********Student Loan Marketing, known as Sallie Mae, fell 6 5/8, to 36 1/2, in heavy trading. The F.B.I. said it was investigating allegations that Sallie Mae bought canceled loans to inflate its assets; Sallie Mae called the charges, from two former employees, ''without merit.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/08/busin.body_text: **********The Campeau Corporation has abandoned its attempt to sell Bloomingdale's, The Financial Times reported in its Monday issue. **********The decision by the Canadian retailing company, which is laden with debt, was revealed over the weekend by people involved in efforts to restructure Campeau, the newspaper reported from New York. **********The reason for abandoning the sale of the prestigious department store chain is said to have been the inadequate level of offers received, The Financial Times said. **********Campeau originally predicted a selling price of $1.5 billion for Bloomingdale's, which it bought two years ago, the newspaper said. **********The store chain has been up for sale for more than three months. **********Campeau won a 14-day reprieve from possible bankruptcy on Jan. 2, when Citibank, a major creditor, agreed not to enforce a default on $2.34 billion in loans to the company's United States retail units.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/25/world.main_headline: Dissident South African Rebels Return Home
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/25/world.print_headline: Dissident South African Rebels Return Home
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/25/world.body_text: **********The African National Congress faced the prospect of embarrassing disclosures from within its own ranks as a group of dissident members returned home today with stories of torture and imprisonment at the group's hands. **********The returnees - six men, two women and two children - were taken away by the police as soon as their airline flight from Malawi arrived at Jan Smuts Airport here, giving waiting reporters no opportunity to question them. But they are expected to tell their stories in coming days. A police spokesman said the 10 exiles were being detained under the Internal Security Act, but indicated that this was merely to allow them to be interrogated before they were released. **********Five other dissidents arrived unannounced earlier. There are reports that the returning exiles plan to set up a political movement opposing the African National Congress. **********Walter Sisulu, a senior leader of the congress who arrived at the airport on a flight from Transkei, said it was natural for the dissidents to get assistance from the Government in setting up their organization. But he told reporters that he was not worried. In Cape Town today, a bill was introduced in Parliament enabling President F. W. de Klerk to grant immunity from arrest and criminal prosecution to anyone so designated. The legislation had been promised by President de Klerk to let officials of African National Congress in exile join in negotiations he has proposed with black leaders on a new constitution that would extend political rights to blacks. **********The legislation could cover not only guerrillas accused of committing crimes like murder and arson in armed struggle against Pretoria, but also the dissidents, whose allegations could work to the Government's advantage. On April 14, as he was leaving on a visit to Britain, Nelson Mandela admitted to reporters that the African National Congress had mistreated some of its members, but said those responsible had been removed. **********''Unfortunately, it is true that some of these people who were complaining were in fact tortured,'' Mr. Mandela said. He indicated that it had stopped and said the group opposed torture. **********But some dissidents who escaped to Kenya have asserted that the abuse goes on and that at least 120 people are still locked up by the African National Congress in Uganda and Angola. In an open letter, they asked Mr. Mandela to begin an inquiry. Those returning to South Africa have reportedly prepared a detailed account of mistreatment. **********The disclosures could hurt the African National Congress at a time when it is trying to broaden its base of domestic support in preparation for talks with the Government, which are scheduled to begin next week. **********The state-run South African Broadcasting Corporation said in a radio broadcast that those who arrived today included Mwezi Twala, a former commander of Spear of the Nation, as the congress's guerrillas are known. **********Mr. Twala reportedly helped lead a mutiny in 1984 by Congress guerrillas deployed in Angola to help its Marxist Government fight pro-Western guerrillas of the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola. The guerrillas objected to being diverted from the armed struggle for South Africa's liberation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/21/world.main_headline: South African Exiles Fear to Return
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/21/world.print_headline: South African Exiles Fear to Return
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/21/world.body_text: **********While many South African exiles concede the importance of the changes in their country in recent weeks, few of them are prepared to test the extent and permanence of the new climate by returning home. **********South Africans who oppose apartheid have been leaving the country for decades, some because they feared arrest, others because they were members of illegal organizations like the African National Congress, others because they were effectively silenced by Government bans, and still others because of the continuing turmoil there. **********After the legalization of more than 30 previously banned groups and the partial lifting of state-of-emergency regulations, many exiles in the United States and elsewhere watched the release of Nelson Mandela on Feb. 11 after 27 years in prison with great excitement, seeing the man who had come to epitomize the anti-apartheid struggle walk free. **********However, the joy was tempered by sadness at the realization that Mr. Mandela, who is 71 years old, had lost many of what might have been his most productive years in jail. **********'A Triumphal Feeling' **********Mbulelo Mzamane, professor of comparative literature at the University of Georgia, who left South Africa in 1976, was overjoyed watching the release on television. **********Mr. Mzamane said, ''I had a triumphal feeling that went deeper than one I had felt before, ever.'' **********He said, however, that few exiles were likely to go home until the lead is taken by well-known African National Congress officials, like Pallo Jordan, the congress's director of information. Because Mr. Jordan left in the early 1960's while still a youth, he is not likely to face criminal charges. **********Since the steps announced by President F. W. de Klerk did not include amnesty for those accused of violent crimes, it remains unclear who can return home without fear of prosecution. **********Susan Mnumcana, a New York resident who left South Africa in the wake of the student uprising that started in Soweto in June 1976, voiced doubts that are widespread among the exiles. **********'Who Decides Who Is Charged?' **********''Who decides who is charged?'' asked Mrs. Mnumcana, whose husband, Neo Mnumcana, led the African National Congress observer mission to the United Nations from 1984 to 1988. **********''Some of us left before we were arrested,'' she added. ''We were not charged because we were not there. And others left illegally. What about them?'' **********Precise answers to those questions are not available. Christiaan Badenhorst, the Deputy Consul General at the South African Consulate in New York, said, ''With few exceptions these people can now return, except where criminal charges exist.'' **********He added he was hesitant to ''confirm the finer details.'' **********Mr. Mzamane expressed skepticism about the depth of changes announced by Mr. de Klerk on Feb. 2, when he ended the ban on the congress and other groups and eased the state of emergency. **********Real Test in Parliament **********''The significance of de Klerk's statement,'' said Mr. Mzamane, ''is that for the first time in the history of the struggle against apartheid, he has acknowledged the need to find a political settlement.'' **********The real test, he said, would be whether Parliament would follow Mr. de Klerk's lead and repeal apartheid laws, paving the way for negotiation. **********Miriam Makeba, the singer, who has been an exile for 30 years, said that the continuing repression of protest by the police made her question how much the Government's attitude has changed. **********When Mr. Mandela was released, she said, she fell to her knees and cried with joy, ''because he spent his life in prison for all of us.'' **********Miriam Makeba Wonders **********''But where are we going if people cannot protest peacefully?'' she asked, while praising Mr. de Klerk's initiative. **********Donald Woods, who left South Africa 12 years ago after the authorities issued a banning order against him, forbidding publication or broadcast of his statements, said he had been interviewed for broadcasts by independent radio stations based in the nominally independent black homelands and heard in South Africa. **********Mr. Woods, whose conflicts with the Government and flight into exile were depicted in the film ''Cry Freedom,'' added, ''As soon as Mr. de Klerk sits down to start negotiating, I believe events will move very fast.'' **********Of his own situation, Mr. Woods, who lives in London, said, ''Obviously my family and I can now visit and maybe return,'' although he added that it would be difficult to uproot a family of seven. **********'My Heart and Soul' in Africa **********Many of the exiles have developed roots in their adoptive countries. Some of them, like Mark Mathabane, who came to the United States in 1978, have married in their new homelands. After attending Columbia University he wrote a book, ''Kaffir Boy,'' about his experiences growing up in South Africa, and another, ''Kaffir Boy in America,'' about life in the United States. His books are banned in South Africa. **********Mr. Mathabane says although he would love to be able to live in South Africa, it would probably not be on a permanent basis. But he adds, ''My heart and soul remain in South Africa.'' **********Like many others, Tebogo Mafole, chief African National Congress representative at the United Nations, said emphatically that although he felt overwhelmed by Mr. Mandela's release, it was not yet time for foreign countries to ease the political pressure on South Africa. **********''Sanctions were intended to abolish apartheid, so it is premature to consider lifting them at this stage,'' Mr. Mafole said. **********Nevertheless, for many of the exiles, what was once a distant dream now seems much closer to realization. Ms. Makeba said that although she realized that not everything would happen at once, when the time is right, she will be ''on the first plane home.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/08/busin.main_headline: Financing Of UAL Bid Hits Snag
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/08/busin.print_headline: Financing Of UAL Bid Hits Snag
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/08/busin.body_text: **********The unions seeking to buy the parent of United Airlines said yesterday that they had failed to persuade enough banks to finance their bid, forcing them to present a bid with less cash than the $2 billion they had sought. **********Some analysts said yesterday that a bid offering less cash without the backing of the banks and relying on large amounts of new securities for financing would not be approved by the board of the UAL Corporation. **********''If they come in with less cash, a lower price and lot of paper, it's not going to be accepted by the board,'' said Edward J. Starkman, an airline analyst with Paine Webber Inc. **********Offer to Have Better Value **********Gerry Greenwald, the chief executive of the United Employee Acquisition Corporation, as the buyout group is known, said the unions would present a bid to the board at its meeting tomorrow that would have less cash than originally intended but would be substantially more valuable than the current market price of UAL's stock. **********In trading on the New York Stock Exchange on Friday, UAL's shares fell $2.625 each, to $102.75. **********For a year, United's three unions, the pilots, the machinists and the flight attendants, have tried to put together a bid to buy the carrier that if successful would make UAL the largest employee-owned company in the world. But they appeared to have foundered again on bank financing. $6.75 Billion Bid Fails An earlier bid almost a year ago for $300 a share, or $6.75 billion, also failed after the group was unable to complete the financing. The failure set off a huge short-lived drop in the stock market. **********In the current attempt, the board had approved a bid for $201 a share in April and had given the unions an 60-day extension, to tomorrow, to complete financing arrangements. **********The unions had hoped to get the banks to back a lower bid of about $175 a share, most of which would have been in cash, or $3.82 billion. **********Mr. Greenwald said that while many of the banks thought that the group's proposal was a strong one and one of the best they had seen all year, most were fearful of making such a large commitment because of uncertainties created by the Middle East crisis. **********He said even though the buyout group had received enough commitments from banks that could raise the $2 billion the group had sought, the four lead banks wanted the syndication to be substantially oversubscribed, or about double what they were seeking. **********''They wanted to know that after a several-month period that they could resell what they were holding into the markets,'' Mr. Greenwald said. **********Lead Banks Out **********The four lead banks, the Bankers Trust New York Corporation, the First Chicago Corporation, the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Corporation and the Security Pacific Corporation, were ready to commit $1.4 billion. **********Mr. Greenwald said the cash portion of the bid, which he refused to specify, would come from money put up by United's vendors, the sale of the carrier's airplanes that would be leased back, other equipment financing, employee investments and cash on hand. **********The analyst said the offer to be presented to the board would have approximately the same value as if the banks had agreed to finance the bid. **********''The cash part won't be as big as it would have been,'' he said of the new offer. **********Mr. Greenwald said the group was not seeking the participation of a foreign carrier, which according to some earlier reports was to have put up about $250 million. **********The unions were committed to putting up concessions in wages and benefits that would total about $200 million a year. **********Thus the group was counting heavily on suppliers like the Boeing Company and some of the engine makers and others to come up with most of the cash for the bid. **********No Pressure to Sell **********Mr. Starkman, the Paine Webber analyst, said yesterday that the board was also under no pressure to sell the airline. **********''The industry is in such miserable shape; is this the right time to sell an airline?'' he asked. **********United, based outside Chicago in Elk Grove Village, Ill., has been doing well despite higher fuel costs and low traffic that has generally affected the industry. **********Stephen M. Wolf, UAL's chairman, has also been eager to place large orders for new planes to keep up with the airline's leading rivals, American Airlines and Delta Air Lines. **********Thus the pressure has been building to end the long turmoil that the union bid has brought to the carrier. **********If the board rejects the bid tomorrow, the carrier could face big problems in negotiating new contracts with its unions. Part of the bid was that all three unions would have accepted new five-year contracts with substantial concessions that would give United a competitive advantage.
