https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/19/busin.main_headline: Westinghouse Seeks Growth in Old Lines
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/19/busin.print_headline: Westinghouse Seeks Growth in Old Lines
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/19/busin.body_text: **********Conglomerates may be out of vogue in much of corporate America, but not at the Westinghouse Electric Corporation - the company remains committed to its diversity. But with growth in a number of its lines languishing, the company is forcing itself to look at old businesses in new ways. **********With knowledge obtained in building giant turbines for electric utilities, for example, Westinghouse has created a $1 billion business building and operating plants that burn garbage and use the resulting steam to generate electricity. And Westinghouse's electronic systems group has been focusing increasingly on work not for the Defense Department, which faces budget cuts, but for civilian uses like air-traffic control equipment and security systems for homes and offices. **********Those are but two of dozens of changes being directed from headquarters here as the company founded by George Westinghouse in the last century prepares to enter the next by looking for new applications for its expertise. **********''Even though the labels of the basic business sectors will likely remain unchanged, there will be fundamentally different businesses in them and different challenges,'' said Robert L. Slane, a Pittsburgh-based partner of McKinsey & Company, the management consultants. **********Until now, the company has dealt with the slowdown in its businesses partly by restructuring. Since 1983, it has sold more than 75 businesses it considered undesirable or poorly performing. Among them have been some of Westinghouse's best-known entities, including its light bulb business, its home-appliance unit and its elevator groups. **********The financial results of the restructuring have been striking. Operating margins, defined as operating income as a percentage of sales, nearly doubled in the six years ended last Dec. 31, to 10.7 percent from 6.5 percent. Return on equity has averaged a robust 20.1 percent over that period. **********Sales and net profits have risen steadily, too, reaching $12.8 billion and $922 million, respectively, in 1989, from $10.7 billion and $532.2 million in 1984. **********Now, with almost all of its laggards cut loose, with costs reduced and productivity increased, Westinghouse can turn its attention to realizing one of its main goals for the 1990's: continuing to report double-digit increases in earnings per share. Earnings per share rose from $3.02 in 1984 to $6.31 in 1989, an average of more than 20 percent a year. **********With strong presence in power-generation equipment, military electronics, broadcasting and financial services - even home building and land-development - Westinghouse's strategy is to use its existing knowledge to branch into areas with greater growth prospects than its current lines. **********Shift in Nuclear Plants **********When it became clear in the 1980's that the nuclear power-plant business would remain mired in controversy, for example, Westinghouse used its knowledge in that field to become the leading operator of waste storage operations in the Energy Department's nuclear weapons production program. **********Even Westinghouse's broadcasting group, a chain of 22 radio stations and five television stations, has realized that slowing population growth will limit its expansion to just a few percent annually. It is now attempting to become a leading provider of programming to cable television systems and independent television stations. **********Group W Productions, one of Westinghouse's programming organizations, sells advertising for and distributes the hit television show ''Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles,'' and it is the distributor and advertising sales representative for reruns of the hugely successful television series ''The Cosby Show.'' **********If Westinghouse is successful in broadening its businesses, much of the credit will probably go to Paul E. Lego, a 60-year-old electrical engineer who will become the company's 13th chief executive on July 1. The only son of a Pennsylvania steel worker who rose through the ranks at Westinghouse to become president and chief operating officer, Mr. Lego will replace John C. Marous, another career Westinghouse man, who recently reached Westinghouse's mandatory retirement age of 65. Mr. Lego is expected to continue Mr. Marous's strategy of seeking fast-growing variations on the company's core businesses. **********Some Mature Industries **********He will have his hands full. Westinghouse's electronic systems group, a leading maker of weapons for the Pentagon, is already suffering from the slowdown in military spending. There is no sign of a resumption in new orders for nuclear power plants, which had been an important source of revenue for Westinghouse's energy and utility systems group. Westinghouse's Group W radio broadcasting network, one of the nation's largest, is suffering from the industrywide slump in advertising spending. Even Westinghouse's hugely successful financial-services operation, which finances commercial and residential projects and does business leasing and lending, has begun to show signs of weakness from a growing portfolio of troubled real estate loans. **********''When you review their remaining businesses, you conclude that the underlying growth potential is not all that great,'' said Russell L. Leavitt, the Westinghouse analyst at Salomon Brothers Inc. ''Many of the businesses are mature.'' **********Mr. Lego acknowledged the challenge in a recent interview here. **********''We have to show that we're still capable of growing the company in order to achieve an element of sustained value,'' he said, referring to Westinghouse's stock price, which has never commanded the same premium enjoyed by the shares of the General Electric Company, Westinghouse's leading rival. **********On the New York Stock exchange yesterday, Westinghouse shares closed down 62.5 cents, to $36.375 each. The stock carried a price/earnings ratio of 11, meaning its price was 11 times greater than per-share earnings. In contrast, General Electric shares closed down $1 yesterday, to $69.125 each, with a price/ earnings ratio of 15. **********But many of the new businesses Westinghouse is pursuing - television programming, for instance -are brutally competitive. Others, such as converting municipal garbage to energy through incineration, may get bogged down in the growing array of city ordinances limiting air pollution. **********Westinghouse's past corporate culture also stands in the way. As a 104-year-old company managed by and filled with engineers, Westinghouse prides itself on prudence and conservatism. Many of its top officers have spent their entire careers at Westinghouse, and the company rarely promotes from without. It also likes to stick with businesses: Westinghouse's broadcasting operation, for instance, is 71 years old; the electric-power generation business dates from the company's beginnings. **********''The hard part will be the people,'' said Robert H. Waterman, the co-author of ''In Search of Excellence,'' a best-selling book on management. ''How do you get people to embrace new ways of looking at old markets? It's very tough.'' **********Value in Conglomerates **********Whether being a conglomerate - a collection of separate companies involved in different businesses - is of value to shareholders remains the subject of debate. Many people think conglomerates do nothing for shareholders, arguing that investors can simulate a conglomerate themselves by buying a handful of stocks in different industries. But Westinghouse management remains committed to the concept, arguing that stand-alone companies are often run by outside directors who know little about the business, rather than by managers who grew up within the company. **********''The outside directors certainly would not spend the time managing the operation that is spent by the senior executives of Westinghouse,'' said Donald Povejsil, a retired strategic planner at Westinghouse. **********While Mr. Lego is following a tack similar to his predecessor's in focusing on growth areas related to the company's existing businesses, the men differ in their styles. **********A Chipper Salesman **********Mr. Marous spent many of his early years at Westinghouse in marketing posts. A chipper salesman-type who as chairman has been known for his energy, colorful speaking style and forthrightness, he seems to delight in telling visitors what a bright future he thinks Westinghouse has. **********''Today, our portfolio is stronger than it has ever been,'' he said in a recent interview. ''We don't have any losers.'' **********Mr. Lego, a workaholic who jogs five miles before arriving at his desk at 7:30 A.M., is the stereotypical engineer: soft-spoken, cerebral, highly quantitative and, some people say, a boring speaker. After Mr. Lego spoke recently to a group of securities analysts in Florida, Westinghouse's stock took a dive - a result, some analysts said, of Mr. Lego's low-key, understated speaking style. **********Others, however, come to his defense. ''Once you get to know Paul, you find that he is quite a dynamic person, no less motivated and anxious to put points on the scoreboard than John Marous,'' said Mr. Povejsil, the retired Westinghouse planner.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/25/busin.body_text: **********Eleven members of Congress today asked the Pentagon to reinstate Dr. Craig I. Fields as head of the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, or Darpa. Dr. Fields, 43 years old, had headed the agency for a year until he was transferred last Friday. The agency provides money to industry to develop high-technology goods with military uses. His supporters contend he was removed because he advocated spending money on ''dual-use'' technologies - those with civilian and military applications.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/28/busin.main_headline: Norwest Bank Deal Is Cleared by Fed
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/28/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Norwest Bank Deal Is Cleared by Fed
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/28/busin.body_text: **********The Norwest Corporation said it had received Federal Reserve approval to acquire the First Interstate Corporation of Wisconsin, and it expects to close the deal about May 1. Under the agreement, First Interstate will become Norwest-Wisconsin. **********First Interstate shareholders will receive Norwest stock valued at about $215 million. First Interstate, Wisconsin's fifth-largest bank holding company, has 1,250 employees and assets of more than $1.7 billion. Norwest, Minnesota's largest bank, has assets of about $24.3 billion. Norwest said no other regulatory approvals were needed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/12/busin.main_headline: Two Top Managers Reassigned by Pepsico
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/12/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Two Top Managers Reassigned by Pepsico
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/12/busin.body_text: **********Pepsico Inc. reassigned two of its top managers yesterday. Roger A. Enrico was named chairman of Frito-Lay Inc., the company's snack-food business, and Michael H. Jordan was picked to head a newly reconstituted international division. **********The changes take effect at the beginning of next year. Mr. Enrico, who is 46 years old, is assuming a new post at Frito-Lay, based in Plano, Tex. Robert H. Beeby, the division's president, plans to retire at the end of next year at the age of 60, the company said, and until then will report to Mr. Enrico. **********Mr. Jordan, who is 54, will head a new division that combines Pepsi-Cola International and Pepsico Foods International. The presidents of these divisions, Christopher A. Sinclair, 40, and John S. Pingel, 49, will report to Mr. Jordan. For the last four years, Mr. Jordan has headed the domestic and international snack-food businesses. **********Mr. Enrico is currently president and chief executive of the compay's worldwide beverage operations. That unit will be broken up and the president of Pepsi-Cola North America, Craig Weatherup, will report directly to Wayne Calloway, 55, the chairman of Pepsico . The international unit will be under Mr. Jordan's direction. **********Pepsico, based in Purchase, N.Y., said the moves were in keeping with management's philosophy of giving executives broad experience. The company said the shifts did not mean that the two men were being groomed for a competition to become Pepsico's next leader. **********"Everyone needs new challenges and opportunities to rejuvenate themselves," said Kenneth Ross, director of public relations. He also said Mr. Calloway would remain chairman of the parent company for several years to come. **********Mr. Enrico, who is known as a marketing expert and innovator, made his reputation on the soft-drink side of the company. He was responsible for bringing stars like Michael Jackson into Pepsi commercials "to excite and entertain consumers," Mr. Ross said. **********Mr. Jordan, who is known in the industry as an incisive strategic thinker, has made his mark on the snack-food side of Pepsi and helped to turn Frito-Lay into a powerhouse. It is Pepsi's most profitable division. **********A beverage-industry analyst, Lawrence Adelman of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said Pepsi's ability to move its "major players" showed a strong depth of management. "You don't normally see things like this in a major consumer products company," he said. **********Mr. Adelman said Mr. Enrico would be heading Frito-Lay at a time when competition was growing in the domestic snack-food business. Frito-Lay is expected to report an "outstanding fourth quarter and year," Mr. Adelman said, with operating profits up 12 to 13 percent. **********Mr. Jordan's new post will put him in position to lead Pepsi's drive overseas in both drinks and snack foods. The overseas market is where Pepsi expects strong growth in the 1990's, the company said. **********"A good growth company plans for the future, rather than have the future creep up on it," Mr. Adelman said, applauding the changes. **********Mr. Enrico will be returning to the place where he started, as a Frito-Lay brand manager in the early 1970's. For the last 10 years he has been on the soft-drink side. Mr. Ross said Mr. Enrico had fully recovered from a mild heart attack he suffered on a business trip to Turkey in February.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/13/world.main_headline: Upheaval in the East: Albania;   Harsh Security Measures Are Reported in Albania
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/13/world.print_headline: Upheaval in the East: Albania;   Harsh Security Measures Are Reported in Albania
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/13/world.body_text: **********The official Yugoslav press agency reported today that the authorities in Albania had imposed ''extremely strict'' security measures, but a senior Albanian Communist Party leader called the reports of unrest there ''slander.'' **********The press agency, Tanyug, and the Belgrade television said that ''something is apparently happening'' in hard-line Albania and that travelers from there had reported ''brutal'' measures against dissent. **********As the last bastion of Stalinism in Eastern Europe, Albania is seen by some Western analysts as likely to be the next country to undergo radical change. But its isolation and small population of three million are among the factors that make it different from other Communist countries. **********'Extremely Strict Control' **********''Albanian authorities, in an effort to prevent unrest against the regime, have imposed extremely strict control measures in the country,'' Tanyug said. **********But Foto Cami, a member of the Albanian Communist Party's Politburo, rejected recent reports in Yugoslav, Greek and other Western news media of unrest in his country as ''slander'' and ''anti-Albanian inventions.'' **********His remarks came in an interview with the Albanian state radio and television, carried by the official Albanian press agency and monitored in Vienna. **********Albania has kept its borders virtually closed to foreigners. Information about what is going on there is mostly limited to the official Albanian news media and scant reports from travelers allowed to leave the country. **********Milisav Milic, a reporter for the Belgrade television from Yugoslavia's Kosovo province, bordering Albania, told The Associated Press that the ''frequent sound of firearms'' was heard today from the direction of Albania. **********'A State of Emergency' **********Tanyug said the security measures ''can be termed a state of emergency'' but did not say when they were imposed or attribute its information. The Belgrade television cited unconfirmed reports from diplomats and travelers. **********Mr. Cami's interview was the first known mention by an Albanian official about reports of popular unrest. **********The interviewer asked Mr. Cami what he thought of reports that there were demonstrations in Shkoder, Albania's second-largest city, and other unrest, ''as if the so-called wind of the East is blowing in Albania.'' **********Mr. Cami replied that ''I cannot find a better word than slanders.'' Citing specific reports from Yugoslav and Western news organizations, he said, ''That's all a race of slanders.'' **********Asked why ''this campaign'' was conducted in the Western news media, Mr. Cami was quoted by the Albanian press agency as replying: ''The aim is clear. They wish that what has occurred in the countries of the East will happen in Albania, too.'' **********Albania has opened up somewhat to foreign contacts in recent years, but the country's Communist leader, Ramiz Alia, has denounced the reforms that have occurred in Eastern Europe and pledged that Albania will not stray from its Stalinist path. **********Petrag Simo, an Albanian diplomat in Belgrade, today also strongly denied reports of unrest. He called them ''regrettable rumors that have absolutely no substance.'' **********The nightly news program of the Albanian state television, monitored in Belgrade, made no mention of disturbances or special security measures. **********But in a telephone interview with The A.P., Mr. Milic quoted a Yugoslav of Albanian ethnic background returning home to Kosovo from Albania as telling him that demonstrations took place in the towns of Durres, Shkoder and Koritsa in ''the last couple of days'' and that leaflets by ''dissatisfied Albanian military officers'' appeared in the capital of Tirana.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/01/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Eastern Airlines To Get $50 Million
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/01/busin.body_text: **********Burton R. Lifland, the chief judge of the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan, approved a plan to allow Eastern Airlines to spend $50 million from a special fund to help meet its operating expenses. **********Eastern, which is seeking to rebuild itself under the protection of the bankruptcy court, had originally asked for $100 million. The committee of unsecured creditors said that it would support a payment of only $50 million. Eastern has had heavy losses as it seeks to rebuild itself. The airline has found it difficult to attract passengers and has been hurt by higher fuel prices.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/23/busin.main_headline: Technology; Another New Wave in Sound
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/23/busin.print_headline: Technology; Another New Wave in Sound
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/23/busin.body_text: **********PHILIPS N.V., the Dutch electronics giant, created a stir in October when it announced that it is developing a digital tape recorder that will also be able to play conventional analog cassettes. **********The new system, which is called digital compact cassette, could pose a strong challenge to the digital audio tape (DAT) recorders that went on sale this year. DAT machines cannot play the analog cassettes which consumers have bought by the millions for use as portable stereos and in home and automobile sound systems. **********But after making its announcement, Philips -- which is developing the new system with the Tandy Corporation -- has gone mum, shrouding in mystery how its machine works and sounds. Those details are crucial to determining whether the new machines, which are expected to reach the market in 1992, will be successful. **********Still, information about the design of the system can be pieced together from interviews with industry experts, from Philips's own disclosures to international standard-setting bodies, and from an interview a Philips executive gave in October to Audio Week, a New York industry newsletter. The key is the use of mathematical data compression technology, combined with advanced recording heads and sturdier cassette construction. **********The gist of the new technology is this: Analog cassette systems store the music on linear tracks that run along the length of the tape. The tape moves past a stationary head, which writes information onto the tape or reads information off it. **********The DAT players, by contrast, use a system, borrowed from video cassette recorders, in which both the tape and the heads move and in which data are written on the tape in a helical pattern, like the diagonal stripes on a candy cane. Thus, they are totally incompatible with analog cassettes. **********For the new system, Philips has developed a digital machine that uses a stationary head and linear tracks on a tape the same size as an analog cassette. Such a machine will also be able to play analog tapes. However, digital tapes made on the Philips machine would not be able to be played on analog-only machines. **********Analog systems, like records and cassette tapes, store music as an electromagnetic wave form that mimics the sound wave. Digital systems, like DAT and compact disks, store music as a series of numbers that are written in the zeros and ones of computer code. **********Digital music can be much crisper, free of the hisses and pops that mar analog recordings. The drawback is that it requires a lot more tape to store music digitally. **********In a DAT machine, for instance, the music is recorded by sampling it 48,000 times each second. Each of those samples is represented by a number that is written as a 16-digit string of zeros and ones. There are two such signals, one for each stereo channel, meaning that storing a single second of music requires 1.5 million zeros and ones. **********On top of that, extra bits are added to allow the system to mathematically correct errors and to store information that helps the machine automatically find a particular song on the tape. All together, a single second of music on a digital audio tape requires 2.8 million zeros and ones, or 2.8 megabits. The most powerful floppy disks now used in personal computers would be able to hold only four seconds of such music. **********Japanese consumer electronics companies that developed digital audio tape several years ago contemplated how they could pack that much information onto a tape. **********It would be best, they decided, if the tape moved slowly. Otherwise, an extremely long tape would be needed. But the tape would also have to move fairly quickly past the head, if the head was going to be able to read or write 2.8 million bits each second. **********Fortunately, the Japanese companies, in developing video cassette recorders, had already devised a way of making a tape that moves slowly yet can be read quickly and carries a lot of data. And that solution was adopted for digital audio tape. **********IN this system, known as helical scan, the tape moves slowly past a drum that contains two heads. The drum rotates rapidly in a direction at an angle to the moving tape; data is laid down in adjacent diagonal stripes on the tape. **********Philips, with the benefit of several years of advancing technology, uses mathematical techniques known as data compression to reduce the amount of zeros and ones needed to store digital music enough to be able to use linear tracks rather than helical scans. **********While Philips has not said much about the compression technique it will use in the digital compact cassette system, it is clearly similar to one the company has been promoting for use as a worldwide standard for digital radio broadcasts. **********The system takes advantage of the fact that certain sounds cannot be heard because they are too close in frequency to other, louder sounds, a phenomenon known as psycho-acoustic masking. By eliminating data corresponding to such inaudible sounds, Philips can reduce the number of digital bits needed to represent the music by a factor of four. **********Still, even with compression, cramming all the information onto linear tracks is not trivial. An analog tape has four tracks -- two stereo channels for each side of the tape. **********The Philips machine, using tape of the same width, is believed to have 18 tracks -- nine going in one direction for one side of the tape and nine going in reverse. Of each set of nine tracks, eight contain the musical information and the ninth contains control information. A sophisticated recording head reads all nine tracks in parallel, helping to speed the flow of information onto and off the tape. **********Existing analog tapes are too imprecise to handle so many closely spaced tracks. So the Philips system will use sturdier tapes that are encased in plastic. There will be covers over the part of the cassette where the tape is exposed and over the spindle holes that open only after the tape is in the machine. This is somewhat like the construction of video cassettes and 3.5-inch floppy disks. **********The tapes will have to be high quality, but will not be as high as the metal particle tape used for DAT systems. Hence, officials say, the blank digital compact cassettes will be more expensive than analog cassettes but less expensive than DAT cassettes. **********BECAUSE they will use linear tracks, the digital compact cassettes, like analog cassettes, can be duplicated at high speeds, making it less expensive for record companies to manufacture prerecorded cassettes. "We can get into the business at reasonable cost," said Al Michaels, chief engineer for Warner Bros. Records in Burbank, Calif. **********Right now, record companies can duplicate an 80-minute analog cassette in one minute. But because the helical-scan technology is not amenable to high-speed duplication, copying an 80-minute digital audio tape requires 80 minutes. **********Some people contend that because it uses a stationary head, the digital compact cassette will use less power than the DAT machines and will thus be more suitable for use in battery-operated Walkman-style stereos. **********But DAT systems also have their advantages. The cassettes are smaller and can hold two hours of music, versus a 90-minute expected maximum for the Philips cassette. **********The biggest question regarding the Philips system is whether the compression will damage the music. A few people who have heard samples say the Philips system sounds as good as a compact disk, which uses no compression. "It's quite comparable," said Ralph Cousino, vice president of technology development for Capitol-EMI Music Inc., a record company. More people will get to hear the system and see how it works next month at the Consumer Electronics Show , where Philips promises to take the wraps off its big secret.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/08/busin.main_headline: Riklis and Board Quit E-II, Leaving Debt of $1.2 Billion
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/08/busin.print_headline: Riklis and Board Quit E-II, Leaving Debt of $1.2 Billion
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/08/busin.body_text: **********Meshulam Riklis, the financier who controls the corporate parent of the Samsonite luggage and Culligan water purification companies, said yesterday that he was stepping down from all executive positions with that company, the E-II Corporation. **********Mr. Riklis said the entire board of E-II was resigning along with him, leaving management up to Stephen J. Green, the president of Samsonite. Mr. Green's first job will be to negoti ate with bondholders seeking to restructure $1.2 billion in debt. **********In more than 30 years in business, Mr. Riklis has frequently shuffled assets within the companies he has controlled, sometimes prompting protests from bondholders who said they believed the transfers damaged their interests. **********Yesterday's announcement provided another shuffle. The McCrory Corporation, an E-II subsidiary that owns the McCrory, J. J. Newberry, T.G.& Y. and S. H. Kress retail store chains, is to be sold to another company controlled by Mr. Riklis. Most details of that transaction were not disclosed, but the company said the 66-year-old Mr. Riklis would pay $350 million for McCrory if he still owns it after five years. **********Paul Weiner, E-II's secretary and treasurer, said he did not know what Mr. Riklis would pay if he does not then own it, adding that no further information would be released until Dec. 17. **********Neither Mr. Riklis nor Mr. Green could be reached for comment. **********Although the name E-II is not widely known outside the financial community, the company has become a Wall Street legend. Bondholders, who turned down an offer to sell their bonds for more than face value in 1988, have seen the value shrink. **********Yesterday, E-II's senior bonds, the 12.85 percent senior subordinated notes due in 1997, were quoted at $18 bid and $25 asked for each $100 in par value. The junior bonds, the 13.05 percent subordinated debentures due in 1999, were quoted at $13 bid and $18 asked. **********E-II began in 1987 as a takeover vehicle for Donald Kelly, who had worked with Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company to take the Beatrice Company private. It sold $1.5 billion in bonds to finance such acquisitions but was soon taken over itself when American Brands Inc., at first a target, instead became the buyer. **********American Brands tried to buy back the bonds at a profit for the bondholders, but at prices that the bondholders viewed as inadequate. They were stunned when American Brands turned around and sold the company to Mr. Riklis, and the bonds plunged in value. Early this year, Mr. Riklis offered to buy some of the bonds for about two-thirds of face value, but most of the holders declined to accept that offer. **********McCrory became an E-II subsidiary when it was sold to the company by Mr. Riklis, and so its return to Mr. Riklis completed a circle. **********McCrory has done poorly in recent years, posting a loss from continuing operations of $81.5 million in the year that ended last Jan. 31. For the first six months of the current fiscal year, the company posted a loss of $18 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/25/busin.body_text: **********A RECENT study by a bond research organization concluded that ''junk bond'' interest rates would have to remain 5.3 percentage points above Treasury yields to reward investors fairly for the high risk of default. **********''While a 2.6 percent premium was adequate for the traditional junk bond buyer, bond funds and individuals who participate in the market will not be adequately compensated at these levels,'' the study by the Bond Investors Association said. **********The study, done by Richard Lehmann, president of the nonprofit research organization, offers some startling figures. But perhaps even more startling are the conclusions about the future of the junk bond market one would reach if the study's logic is extended a few years into the future. The association, which is based in Miami Lakes, Fla., is supported by members and publishes a newsletter. **********Among the findings is that in the last decade 651 junk bond issues defaulted on more than $30.5 billion. The group calculated that the junk bond market comprises 3,500 issues with a value of more than $300 billion of debt, a figure up to $100 billion higher than some previous assessments. **********The study, which grouped defaults by the year of issue, demonstrated that for every year about 38 percent of the junk bond issues would eventually go into default. Based on that record of default, Mr. Lehmann predicted $40 billion in defaults in the next three years, with $15 billion of that this year. **********''The high incidence of default should keep junk bond yields at current levels,'' Mr. Lehmann said. ''This means that the new issue volume in 1990 will continue its sharp decline since fewer businesses can justify paying such rates.'' **********An even more important point that the study tries to make is that the rates are high because this is not a good time to be in the junk bond market. Mr. Lehmann regards the present rates as a sign of what is to come, not a buying opportunity. **********''The 5.3 percent premium that we came up with is interesting not only because that's where the market is now, but what it says is the differential doesn't represent a buying opportunity but indicates where the market is going to be in the future,'' he said. ''It's not going back to 2.6 percent premium that was adequate for the junk bond buyer.'' **********There is substantial evidence to support the contention that these kinds of differentials between Treasuries and junk are here to stay. **********First, as junk bonds grow more risky, the likelihood that these high yields will be maintained and that defaults will rise is strong. According to Moody's Investors Service, in December of 1981 $22.6 billion of bonds was graded as junk, or below investment grade. That accounted for 6.5 percent of all corporate bonds rated by Moody's. At that time, approximately 42 percent were assigned a Ba rating, that is, where the least risky junk bonds are. **********Today the amount of junk rated by Moody's has a face value of $226.2 billion, which accounts for 25.4 percent of all corporate bonds rated by Moody's. The least risky Ba-rated category accounts for only 25 percent of rated junk bonds. On the other hand, the B-rated and even lower-rated categories grew. **********''Between 1970 and 1988, the one-year default rate on average for a Ba-rated junk was 1.6 percent,'' said John Lonski, a senior economist with Moody's. ''For B-rated, junk it was 6.7 percent. If we continue to observe the downward shift toward B-rated, then the default rates, of course, will rise.'' **********Mr. Lonski emphasized that the buzzword now among many junk bond buyers is ''conservative.'' And with good reason. ''You have to keep in mind that the junk bond market has been skewed toward increased risk on average,'' he said. ''If I were putting together a junk bond portfolio now, I would skew my portfolio toward the upper echelon of the junk bond universe.'' **********If the picture of steady defaults in a junk bond universe that is more speculative and 10 times larger than it was in December 1981 does not paint a grim picture, the specter of a recession on top it all certainly finishes the job. **********''If we have a mild recession, we may find that banks and other sources will not be able to lend short-term money to make up for cash shortfalls of junk bond issuers,'' Mr. Lonski said, ''and a number of the more precarious issuers may not be able to procure short-term capital at favorable rates.'' **********This, of course, sharply increases the likelihood of a deluge of defaults. ''We've never had such a large and risky junk market come under the weight of a recession,'' Mr. Lonski said. **********But history is not necessarily the best indicator of where the fast-moving junk market will go. Given the variables, the rate of default in the near term may prove significantly higher than the pattern developed in the last decade. **********''If you extrapolate three years forward, you're looking at $40 billion in defaults,'' Mr. Lehmann estimated. ''We're looking for about $25 billion in new issues in 1990 and a 50 percent default rate in 1990 as a function of new issue volume.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/27/world.main_headline: West Germans Get Ready to Scrub The East's Tarnished Environment
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/27/world.print_headline: West Germans Get Ready to Scrub The East's Tarnished Environment
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/27/world.body_text: **********In the halls of Bonn, where the sculptors of a new Germany are at work, one issue taking on urgency is how the orderly and scrubbed half of the country can help clean up the disheveled and polluted half. **********Chemists, biologists and other environmental experts from West Germany have been dashing to and from the Eastern section. They say quick action is needed because four decades of unbridled industrial spewing and spilling in East Germany have created an acute crisis for man and nature. **********The enormous task ahead includes purging most of East Germany's rivers, tackling poisoned soil, rehabilitating sick and dying forests and bringing fresh air back to the suffocating industrial towns. Plans call for dismantling scores of obsolete, polluting factories and reviewing some 15,000, often illegal dumps of dangerous toxic waste. **********Like Chemical Warfare **********Some specialists debating the ecological disaster have compared the challenge ahead to restoring a country after chemical warfare. With financial and technical help from West Germany and to some degree from the European Community, it is expected to go on for most of this decade and cost billions of West German marks. **********''This is very ambitious, but in the year 2000 the two Governments want environmental standards for East and West Germany to be the same,'' said Wilhelm Steven, a liaison officer at the Bonn Ministry of Environment. **********The two Germanys have agreed that the environmental overhaul must begin even before a single German state is formed. **********To prevent East Germany from becoming a dumping ground for discarded or unsafe Western technology, officials here said, new rules effective July 1 require that any newly built industry, smokestack or engine in East Germany abide by West Germany's strict environmental regulations. The East's existing plants, vehicles and waste will be allowed a transition period to meet Bonn's standards. **********''If we applied West German law now, 70 percent of East German industry would have to shut immediately, which is not possible,'' Mr. Steven said. **********In conversations in West Germany, spokesmen take pains to stress that Bonn and Berlin are preparing every environmental project and target jointly. But by all appearances, the kitchen where the scrubbing and expunging is being organized is in Bonn. **********Emphasis Was on Production **********Consultants hired by Bonn in the last month have been probing through East Germany's contaminated cities and countryside, testing air, water and soil to establish a complete inventory of ills. In the rush to compete with the West, Communism's industrial drive had compelled managers only to meet production targets, regardless of the cost or hazards for people's health or the environment. **********Marlene Muhe, spokeswoman for the Environment Ministry, said that while the magnitude of the problems was evident, many precise data were still missing because East German specialists had lacked the measuring instruments. After the inventory is completed, she said, a full estimate of the costs can be made. **********But the bill for some vital environmental steps, officials said, is already painfully clear: providing East Germany with relatively clean energy is expected to cost $20 billion. That involves taking down all the large power stations driven by the country's highly polluting brown coal and replacing those and hundreds of other furnaces and plants that stoke this coal. The brown coal, the region's main source of energy, contains twice as much sulfur as that used in the West and, especially in winter, it poisons the air with sulfur dioxide, leaves everything covered in sticky soot and causes multiple health problems. **********Officials in East Berlin recently disclosed that their country was the biggest per capita producer of sulfur dioxide in the world. East Germany's 16 million people hurl 5.2 million tons of this pollutant into the air every year, compared with West Germany's 60 million people, who annually emit 3 million tons. **********Some Polluters to Be Closed **********Many factories have already been deemed to be too obsolete to merit installation of scrubbers, filters or other antipollution devices. In an initial study, the East German Government recently said it would need to close down at least 400 polluting and outdated plants. **********But the priority, strategists in Bonn said, is first of all to tackle the industries - like coking and chemical plants - that cause the most acute health hazards. Doctors in the industrial south of East Germany report a constant stream of afflictions of the skin, lungs, eyes and bones, and they complain that the growth of children is stunted. The heart of this, they argue, is that people breathe too many noxious gases and not enough oxygen. **********Some of the haste behind these plans is tangible at the new office of cooperation with East Germany in Bonn's Environment Ministry, where a special department was set up to expedite things. Staff members say that within a year they expect to transfer to Berlin. ''These projects are so urgent, we understand we will be first to move,'' said one official. **********The staff members here see it as an important achievement that while three months ago their ''standoffish'' East German counterparts insisted on calling this the office of Inter-German Cooperation, resistance to this cooperation in Berlin has broken down and the name has been switched to Inner-German Cooperation. **********'They Cannot Cope Alone' **********''They are not nervous or suspicious anymore,'' said one West German ecologist speaking of his East German counterparts. ''They have realized how terrible their problems are and that they cannot cope alone.'' **********The environmental planners say they have already been inundated with requests from East German townships asking for money and equipment. By the same token, companies from Europe, the United States and Canada have been lining up to sell antipollution devices and services. **********''Private industry will be indispensible in all this,'' said Mr. Steven, one of the coordinators, describing the crush of people lobbying for business. ''It seems that everyone wants to get cleaning up in East Germany on their curriculum.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/12/busin.body_text: **********OIL AND THE MIDDLE EAST **********Prices at the Pump **********Gas station owners seemed to react to the oil crisis with the quickened reflexes of commodities traders last week. Retail prices soared an average of 12 cents a gallon by Wednesday, with analysts blaming psychological factors, motorists blaming gas station owners, gas station owners blaming Arabs and oil companies. The oil companies fell all but mute. ''You don't see President Bush doing any talking either,'' said a Mobil Corporation representative at the beginning of last week. By Wednesday, the President was talking: ''I'm asking the oil companies to do their fair share,'' he said. ''They should show restraint and not abuse today's uncertainties to raise prices.'' Suddenly, oil company executives recovered their voices, as several announced price cuts and several others defended their increases. **********Iran's Surplus Sales **********Iran, of all nations, to the rescue? Iran is said to have sold millions of barrels of oil from its storage tankers last week. After a long, punishing war with Iraq, Iran is apparently eager to profit from an embargo against its enemy. But oil company executives say that the boycott of Iraqi supplies has been almost completely effective. Western nations, they say, will have to draw from their strategic reserves. **********A Cold Winter? **********President Hussein might have picked the wrong season to start a fight. The world can more easily manage without his oil when it's warm. Oil finished on Friday at about $26.23, where some traders expect prices to settle. Analysts say that other producers can help compensate for a while for the cut-off in Iraqi and Kuwaiti supplies. ''Right now you're in low-demand season,'' said Paul D. Mlotok, an energy analyst at Morgan Stanley. Getting along without Iraq's oil come winter is another matter. ''You're going to have to draw down inventory when people's tendency is to hoard it,'' he said. ''Prices could exceed $30.'' **********THE ECONOMY **********An Architect to Remember **********On Monday, at the age of 81, the architect who gave corporate America its modernist aspirations died. Beginning with Lever House - New York's first glass-walled office tower - in 1952, Gordon Bunshaft's example reverberated until all self-respecting corporations built with metal and glass instead of stone. His influence was amplified by his firm, Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, whose huge New York office he headed. **********Lever House itself was an act of corporate philanthropy. It sacrificed much of its permissible size to create a glade in Park Avenue's high-rise forest. Other architects perverted his principals to give developers the most rentable square feet for the money in boxy buildings that mar many an American downtown. And since Mr. Bunshaft retired a decade ago, architects have rediscovered materials and details that he had consigned to history. But his best buildings remain to embody a timelessness and vision that seem to have passed from the corporate scene. **********Producer Prices Dip **********Producer prices fell one-tenth of 1 percent in July - before the Iraqis invaded Kuwait. Some on Wall Street saw the decline was evidence of an economic slowdown. Steven Axilrod, vice chairman of Nikko Securities International, said that higher oil costs will hurt corporate profits, since demand is too weak for them to raise their prices. **********INTERNATIONAL **********Dual-Currency Soviet Economy? **********Attention Soviet shoppers: Reach into your mattresses, pull out your dollars and marks, and hurry over to the beriozka for all the goodies that hard currency can buy. The Soviet Union opened its hard-currency stores to its own citizens at the beginning of this month, without questioning how an estimated $2 billion in foreign money came into private hands. Most methods of obtaining it, like trading on the black market, remain illegal. A writer for the Soviet news agency, Tass, in an article headlined ''Epitaph for the Ruble?'', predicted the further emergence of a dual-currency economy, ''where a Soviet citizen will be asked to pay in hard currency not only for a packet of Marlboro cigarettes, but also for his airline ticket, a reservation in the restaurant and for mending his television set.'' Businesses, at least, might might soon find it much easier to acquire foreign currency. Moscow announced last week that it would open corporate money exchanges around the country next year. Only selected Soviet companies have been allowed to bid at the country's foreign-currency auctions so far. **********Japan Applies Oil-Shock Lessons **********The outlook for the Japanese economy is healthier than some fever charts indicate. Since the oil shocks of the 1970's - when idled taxi drivers, swept up in the panic, committed suicide - the Japanese have stockpiled oil, turned to nuclear power and made their cars and industries some of the most energy-efficient in the world. ''The Japanese have a great capacity to learn from trauma,'' said Susan J. Pharr, a Harvard professor of government. Japanese investors are not nearly so confident. The Nikkei stock average fell 7.4 percent for the week, to a low for the year. **********COMPANIES **********Lorenzo Bows Out **********After two corporate bankruptcies, three acquisitions and a raging strike, Frank Lorenzo is quitting the airline business. He announced his resignation as chairman of Continental Airline Holdings Inc., formerly Texas Air, on Thursday. The Scandinavian Airline System made his on-time departure a condition of buying his Continental stock, increasing its stake to 16.8 percent. His replacement is Hollis L. Harris, 58, who worked his way up from gate agent to president of Delta Airlines in 36 years. Mr. Harris pledged to transform Continental's image and service and restore its profitability. Investors, who have suffered from Continental's decline, celebrated the news by bidding up its stock 39 percent in a day. With the company doubled over by debt, ''Mr. Harris should be able to open more doors in the financial community,'' said Kevin Murphy, an analyst at Morgan Stanley. The agreement with S.A.S. bars Mr. Lorenzo from the airline industry for seven years. Mr. Lorenzo has even more reason than shareholders to celebrate, as he leaves with $30.5 million from a comfortable severance package and a premium price for his stock. **********Donaldson Heads Exchange **********William H. Donaldson, one of the founding partners of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc., was named to head the world's largest stock exchange last week. He will succeed John J. Phelan Jr. as chairman of the New York Stock Exchange in January. Mr. Donaldson, who is 59 years old, faces the tasks of defending the exchange against challenges from overseas markets, regional exchanges and other new ways of trading stocks and betting on the market. **********The UAL Takeover Plan **********The board of directors gave employees of UAL Inc. a break last week, but the economy didn't. The board decided on Wednesday to give the employee unions two more months to arrange financing for their $4.38 billion, $201-a-share bid. But with fuel prices rising and the economy lurching towards recession, airlines look like the last companies to invest in. The unions have had trouble finding equity partners, and several banks have defected. One hopeful sign: Northwest's corporate parent, NWA, the only major airline to be taken private so far, is successfully paying its debts. **********Asbestos Cases Accelerated? **********Ten Federal District Court judges reached an agreement on Friday to consolidate tens of thousands of asbestos cases. The judges said their unusual agreement can bring about a quicker, less costly way of compensating more than 100,000 victims. As many as half a million more cases could be filed over the next decade as more workers who have inhaled asbestos fibers develop cancer. Some of the judges have estimated that about legal expenses have absorbed about two-thirds of the payments that would otherwise go to asbestos victims. But some companies and lawyers for the victims are likely to challenge the new arrangements. **********In Brief **********A Broadway show with record advance sales of $25 million was canceled after Actors' Equity refused to let an English actor play a Eurasian lead role. ''Miss Saigon'' had been scheduled to open in March 1991 with members of minority groups in 34 of 50 roles. **********The chairman of the world's largest accounting firm resigned after some of his partners objected to his choice of a vice chairman and possible successor. Larry D. Horner said on Wednesday that he will leave as chairman of KMPG Peat Marwick in October.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/09/world.main_headline: Senator Proposes Curbs on Aid to Salvador
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/09/world.print_headline: Senator Proposes Curbs on Aid to Salvador
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/09/world.body_text: **********Senator Christopher S. Dodd of Connecticut introduced a measure today to restrict United States military aid to El Salvador, and the Democratic Senator predicted that Congress would demand new conditions on such aid this year. **********The measure would withhold 50 percent of American military aid unless the rebel Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front refused to take part in talks to end the conflict. The aid could also be released if President Bush certified to Congress that rebel offensives threatened the Government of President Alfredo Cristiani. **********The measure is co-sponsored by Senators Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, Terry Sanford of North Carolina, Dale Bumpers of Arkansas and Jim Sasser of Tennessee, all Democrats. **********Mr. Dodd, who as chairman of the Foreign Relations Subcommittee on Western Hemisphere Affairs has played a central role on the issue, said his measure was intended ''to bolster President Cristiani in his efforts to achieve a negotiated settlement to the Salvadoran conflict'' and to encourage El Salvador to ''improve the human-rights situation in general.'' Mr. Dodd said there was ''a growing sense of fatigue'' in Congress about aid to El Salvador in light of the abuses there.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/12/busin.main_headline: Toshiba Royalty Pact For Texas Instruments
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/12/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Toshiba Royalty Pact For Texas Instruments
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/12/busin.body_text: **********Texas Instruments Inc. said yesterday that it had reached a new patent cross-licensing agreement with the Toshiba Corporation, calling for royalty payments to Texas Instruments that would "greatly exceed" the amounts under an earlier agreement. **********The 10-year agreement is the first to be reached by Texas Instruments, which is negotiating with several Japanese companies. Although the Dallas semiconductor company does not appear to have won all it asked for, the increased royalty payments could still substantially bolster its profits next year, analysts said. **********Texas Instruments has been aggressively exploiting its patents as a source of profits, a practice the company says is necessary to finance its business. **********The company will collect about $160 million in royalties this year, mainly from Japanese semiconductor companies that use its patents on computer memory chips. Most of Texas Instruments' patent agreements with those companies expire at the end of this month. A company spokeswoman said Texas Instruments hoped it could reach new agreements by then, but if not it might sue. **********Strengthened by receipt of a Japanese patent for the invention of the integrated circuit, Texas Instruments has been asking for an unusually high royalty rate of 10 percent of the Japanese companies' chip sales, according to industry executives and Japanese news reports. If the company got what it asked for, its annual royalty revenues would exceed $500 million to more than $2 billion. **********Analysts estimate, however, that Toshiba had agreed to a much lower rate, perhaps 2 to 4 percent. **********Andrew Kessler, an aalyst at Morgan Stanley & Company, said he expected Texas Instuments' royalty revenues to be $250 million to $300 million in 1991. **********But Daniel L. Klesken, with Prudential-Bache Securities, said that based on what he was hearing about the Toshiba agreement, he had raised his estimate of next year's royalties to at least $350 million, from a previous estimate of $300 million. **********Because of weak semiconductor sales, most analysts expect Texas Instruments to show little or no profit on operations in 1991, so that any earnings will come strictly from royalty payments. **********The company's stock rose 50 cents on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, to $34.375.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/05/world.body_text: **********A group of scientists considered experts on world climate called Saturday on all nations to take immediate steps to control global warming, regardless of the many questions that still exist about man-made climate change. **********The scientists, at the Second World Climate Conference here, completed their report late Saturday and made it public today. They said in a statement that the technology already exists to make substantial cuts in the emission of harmful gases without jeopardizing economic growth. The cuts and changes they are pressing for are far more drastic than any government is now considering. **********But the unexpectedly strong statement, a consensus reached by more than 700 scientists and environmental specialists, appears to emphasize differences with the Bush Administration, which has problems with the view that governments should lose no time and set immediate targets for cutting back carbon dioxide. The U.S. Position **********The statement is also expected to leave the United States further isolated diplomatically this week when more than 100 environmental ministers will conclude the conference. **********In recent days, most wealthy nations, including the 12 countries of the European Community, have set targets for slowing carbon dioxide coming from cars, homes and factories, and some countries have even pledged to cut back on today's emissions. **********The Bush Administration holds that it is still too early to decide how the United States, which is responsible for 24 percent of the world's carbon dioxide emissions, should reduce them, suggesting that to do so risks enormous costs and unduly curtailing its economic growth. **********While the United States is not the only country that feels uneasy about assessing how man is tampering with the enormously complex system that makes up the world climate, it is almost the only industrialized nation that opposes committing itself to cutbacks in the present. **********This week large oil producers, including the Soviet Union, Saudi Arabia and Venezuela, have rallied to the American side. Experts said these nations believe they will lose if the world suddenly starts burning less oil, the main source of carbon dioxide.  'Between Science and Policy' **********Scientists involved in drafting the strong 13-page conference statement said the document would serve as the framework for future discussions and would be hard for policymakers to ignore. It carries the stamp of the World Meteorological Organization and the world's Oceanographic Commission and a number of United Nations bodies who sponsored the conference. It was unusual because it was the first official call for political action coming from such a large group of climate scientists, among them a number of Americans. **********"We are at an interesting edge between science and policy now," said Maurice la Riviere, a professor of environmental biology and the head of the International Council of Scientific Unions. "We hope governments and policymakers will understand what scientists mean. Where we go from here is up to them, but given what we know, there is absolutely no excuse for governments not to save on energy." **********The digression from science to politics in the six-day technical conference also made some scientists and specialists uneasy. **********"There is a leap here from science to policy that is not comfortable for some people," said Michael Glantz, a social scientists at the National Center for Atmospheric Research in Boulder, Colo. Change at an Unseen Pace **********Harmuth Grassl, a German professor of meteorology, said that while "as scientists we are basically here as ruminants, it is very important to get out the main message: That change on earth is now so fast there is no analogy during the last 10,000 years." **********For its scientific substance, the conference statement drew heavily on the report released last May by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, which is now considered the most important assessment so far of knowledge available on climate change. **********The new report issued here today included these points: ***********Notwithstanding scientific and economic uncertainties, all countries should take immediate steps to reduce greenhouse gases and find more ways to absorb excess gases already in the atmosphere. ***********Without such actions, global warming will increase between 2 and 5 degrees centigrade over the next century, a rate of change unprecedented in the last 10,000 years. ***********This warming could lead to a sea level rise between 35 and 65 centimeters in the next century. Although the range is large, it is prudent to take precautions. ***********It is now technically feasible and cost-effective to reduce carbon dioxide emissions in all countries. There are enough opportunities for many industrialized countries to cut carbon dioxide by at least 20 percent by the year 2005 if they use energy more efficiently, employ alternative fuels and plant more forests to absorb carbon. **********Scientists also said to understand climate it was vital to expand global observation systems and above all establish a network to study the world's oceans. Scientists say the workings of the ocean, the main regulator of the world climate, are poorly understood.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/10/busin.main_headline: New Pumps to Help Conserve Oil
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/10/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;   New Pumps to Help Conserve Oil
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/10/busin.body_text: **********With the price of crude oil reaching $40 a barrel, industrial manufacturers are re-examining ways to cut their energy costs. One important tactic could be the installation of a new generation of more efficient pumps in their plants. **********Pump makers including Goulds Pumps Inc., Dresser Industries and the Ingersoll-Rand Company are selling or developing more efficient industrial pumps whose functions could include extracting waste water in chemical plants, washing pulp in a paper mill, pumping water through a boiler in a utility plant and extracting water after it has cooled hot slabs of steel. Executives say the pumps could cut manufacturers' energy costs for pumping by 20 to 30 percent, and by more than 40 percent in certain applications. **********Pumps are an important - and energy-intensive - component in the manufacturing process. Pump makers contend that if factories bought variable-speed motors, which consume less power when less work is needed, they could save dramatically on electricity. **********''The current oil situation presents us with some opportunities,'' said Stephen V. Ardia, president and chief executive of Goulds Pumps, based in Seneca Falls, N.Y. ''With customers' interest in energy efficiency being renewed, I would expect that there will be an increase in demand for new, more efficient pumps.'' **********Goulds, Dresser, Ingersoll Rand and other pump makers are now emphasizing variable-speed pumps. The motors of conventional industrial pumps operate at a single speed and the rate at which liquid flows is controlled by a valve. Rather than reduce the speed of the motor when a weaker flow is needed, saving fuel in the process, conventional pumps merely narrow the opening of the valve. The process of forcing the pump to strain against a valve is similar to operating a car's accelerator and brake at once. **********With a variable-speed pump, a sensor placed in front of the area where the valve would have been can measure the amount and pressure of the liquid flowing in. That information is passed along to a microchip that instructs the motor to increase or diminish its speed. **********Savings Called Significant **********''In restricting the flow of material through a pump, the control valve causes a substantial loss of energy,'' said Richard C. Steber, director of marketing for Goulds. ''Applying a variable-speed pump to the same application would allow the system to function far more efficiently without any valve.'' **********With the amount of energy saved with a variable-speed device, pump producers say, manufacturers can recover their costs within two years. **********''The savings in energy using a variable-speed pump can be significant,'' said Alexander Agostinelli, vice president of engineering for Dresser Industries' pump division. ''And these can be used by any manufacturer that uses pumps, whether in waste water treatment, refineries, chemical plants or utilities.'' **********All of the major pump makers have been manufacturing large, variable-speed pumps for utility boilers that are run by steam or gas turbines at rates of 10,000 horsepower or more. These manufacturers are developing electric-driven pumps with motors that operate at less than 200 horsepower - the staple of American manufacturing. Mr. Ardia said that Goulds was still developing such pumps and that they would be commercially available within a year. Ingersoll-Rand and Dresser said their versions would be available on a test basis within that time frame. **********Companies say their initial research into the variable-speed pump motors during the energy crisis in the 1970's indicated that they would be prohibitively expensive. But since then, the cost of the electrical material and the computer technology has declined, said Paul Cooper, director of research and development with Ingersoll-Rand's pump group. ''Also, there is now more competition between pump makers, which has helped to develop a more inexpensive product,'' he added. **********Mr. Cooper said the variable-speed pump Ingersoll-Rand was developing would probably cost $7,000 to $9,000, compared with $5,000 to $6,000 for a constant-speed pump. **********But not all manufacturers are reaching for variable-speed products. At a time when economic growth is nearly at a standstill and corporate profits have weakened, many executives are not eager to spend more on pumps. ''It is unusual to find a company that will spend a large amount of money to improve energy efficiency if it doesn't pay back in a short period of time,'' said Armond M. Cohen, senior attorney at the Conservation Law Foundation, a Boston group that has negotiated efficiency programs with utilities. **********Mr. Ardia of Goulds said he had found resistance among some manufacturers. ''The technology is there, but I guess energy costs have not yet risen enough for manufacturers to come to us,'' he said. **********But he added that he expected more interest in variable-speed pumps as manufacturers modernize their plants. ''Our job is to let manufacturers know that this technology is available and that we can help them bring down their energy costs.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/07/busin.main_headline: Waiting, Eagerly, for Disaster to Hit
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/07/busin.print_headline: Waiting, Eagerly, for Disaster to Hit
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/07/busin.body_text: **********Disasters are Richard Zane's business, and business has been booming since a blackout on Wall Street in August caused palpitations or total arrest in 300 computer centers whose whirring hum is the modern company's heartbeat. **********"It seems like everybody who hadn't realized how dependent they are on computers got a wake-up call on Aug. 13," said Mr. Zane, who is president of the North American division of Comdisco Disaster Recovery Services, which offers backup operations in the form of access to mainframe computers and personal terminals that are compatible with the client's office systems. Comdisco, which is in North Bergen, N.J. and is owned by the publicly traded Comdisco Inc., is the biggest company in this business, with 1989 revenues of $86.9 million. **********Mr. Zane said business has increased 50 to 75 percent since the power failure, the biggest computer crash in American history in terms of the number of computer centers affected. His major competitors, I.B.M. Business Recovery Services and Sungard Recovery Services, are reporting similar windfalls. **********Companies that had disaster plans in place, including Manufacturers Hanover Trust and Credit Lyonnais, are reassessing their lines of defense in the wake of the August failure, while businesses that were working without a net, like Fundamental Brokerage Inc. and the Continental Insurance Company, have been reviewing their options. **********While landmark catastrophes like the Wall Street failure, Hurricane Hugo and the San Francisco earthquake produce surges in business, vendors of backup computer services have enjoyed tremendous growth in the last decade as businesses have increased their reliance on computers and recognized the inherent vulnerability. **********Today, 93 vendors make up an industry growing roughly by 40 percent a year. Just two years ago those companies generated $260 million in sales to 2,542 clients; as of last week revenues had increased to $400 million on sales to 4,600 clients, according to Tari Schreider, president of Contingency Planning Research, a consulting firm in Jericho, L.I. Half that business is controlled by Comdisco, Sungard and I.B.M. **********"When the much larger blackout hit New York in 1977 most companies were largely unaffected because so few of their operations were done through computers that they could actually make up a lot of the work manually," Mr. Schreider said. "Today many companies, especially financial firms on Wall Street, would be in serious trouble if they couldn't use a computer for even a few days."  The Cost of Insurance **********Disaster recovery firms sell subscriptions, generally five years in length, for monthly fees ranging from $200 to $100,000. As a rule, companies spend 1 to 2 percent of their data processing budget on this insurance, said John Nevola, manager of I.B.M.'s recovery service. **********For these fees, clients are allowed to transmit their data on a daily or even minute-by-minute basis to the backup computer centers, so that in the event of a failure their employees can pick up their work where they left off. **********"During the blackout 12 of our customers declared disasters and sent more than 300 people every day for more than a week," Mr. Zane said. "We fed their data into our mainframes, put their people on our terminals, and within a day their home offices couldn't tell that they were completing transactions through systems here, not in New York." **********While most companies with back-up plans for computer failures turn to commercial vendors for protection, others, including American Express and Liberty Brokerage, are more self-reliant. They count on computers at other regional offices or subsidiaries to back up many of their systems.  'Never Missed a Beat' **********Rather than finding an alternative computer site, Bankers Trust has backed up its power supply. During the Aug. 13 blackout "our backup system worked flawlessly," said Alan Freedman, Bankers Trust's vice president for technology strategic planning. "Within one millisecond of the outage our batteries kicked in; a few seconds later our generators went on so we never missed a beat." **********Commercial vendors argue that such internal solutions are unreliable. "Unless you are drawing on reserved space, competing needs are involved," Mr. Zane said. He added that while Bankers Trust's generators worked perfectly during the blackout, Citicorp experienced major delays when its backup generators failed. In addition, generators, which can cost more than $1 million to buy and install in New York City, protect only against power failures, providing no relief in the event of fire or water damage, he said. **********Commercial vendors offer their clients "hardened sites" that are intended to be monuments to security and excess capacity. Comdisco's building is unmarked and surrounded by a barbed-wire fence. It is far from a water course that could flood, a fault line that could quake, or a chemical plant that could explode. Four redundant diesel generators guarantee continuous power.  'Every Precaution' **********To thwart human threats, 12 cameras scan the grounds outside while 50 ultraviolet sensors monitor movement within; computer cards, not keys, provide or deny access to its barren hallways. Although corporate espionage has never been a problem, Mr. Zane said his clients "expect us to take every precaution, so we do." **********The focus of that attention is on three computer rooms or "hot sites." The 9,000-square-foot rooms are actually quite cold from the air-conditioning units that cool the mainframes. A firehouse mentality pervades as tens of millions of dollars of equipment whirs, idling, waiting for a catastrophe; 368 I.B.M. terminals are dormant; 5,000 phone lines are untapped; 600 tables and 700 chairs are packed away. **********As the need for backup computer services becomes widely accepted, industry experts expect vendors to expand their offerings. Mr. Schreider noted that 59 percent of 1,830 companies he surveyed recently have a computer recovery plan but only 15 percent have an even broader plan including contingencies for office space and telecommunications. Developing evacuation plans, providing or arranging for alternative office space, and offering backup telecommunications systems are, therefore, three areas into which they will expand. "The computer is not a company's only vital lifeline," Mr. Schreider said. "As they become more aware of what they need to protect, vendors will be there to provide the service." **********Yet, as more companies seek greater protection, others are gambling. While his company has lost power twice in the last three years, Cleve Christy, office manager of the brokerage Weeden & Company in Manhattan, said: "We're figuring the odds right now, but I personally doubt we'll do anything extensive. After all, what are the chances something like this will happen again?"

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/25/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Omar Karami today formed a 30-man Cabinet of pro-Syrian politicians and militia leaders to try to end Lebanon's 15-year civil war. But the new Government's mission was imperiled by a right-wing Christian boycott. **********An official statement said President Elias Hrawi had decreed the formation of the half-Christian, half-Muslim Government during a five-hour meeting with Mr. Karami and the Parliament Speaker, Hussein Husseini. **********The new Cabinet includes seven militia chieftains as state ministers without portfolio, an apparent effort to get their approval for a plan to disarm and disband all private armies in Lebanon. **********Among them is the Druse leader Walid Jumblatt, whose Progressive Socialist Party fielded the strongest Muslim militia in the civil war, and his Marnonite Catholic archfoe, Samir Geagea. **********But Mr. Geagea's Lebanese Forces, the Christians' main militia, said in a statement that he had refused to take up his Cabinet post because he considered the new Government heavily tilted toward Syrian-backed leftists.
