https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/07/world.main_headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   As Forces in Gulf Build, U.S. Weighs Its Options
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/07/world.print_headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   As Forces in Gulf Build, U.S. Weighs Its Options
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/07/world.body_text: **********A Decision on the Sanctions **********At some point, certainly before the end of the year, Mr. Bush will have to decide whether economic sanctions have been effective. If the answer is no, he will face a decision about whether to use military force and if so, when, where, how much and to what end. **********At this point, much of the military advice the President is getting urges him to rely on air power and technological superiority and avoid a land war to the degree possible. **********Most analysts do not expect Mr. Hussein to force Mr. Bush's hand by launching an offensive of his own before mid-October. If the Iraqis did strike, American forces would lack a land force with heavy equipment sufficient to throw back an all-out assault by the 265,000 Iraqi troops based in the southern half of Iraq and in Kuwait. **********By some estimates, the United States, the Saudis and the rest of the international force would be hard pressed to prevent damage to the Saudis' main oilfields. But they are confident that an Iraqi offensive could eventually be stalled and contained, while air assaults on stategic targets in Iraq would eventually batter Iraq's military capacity and morale. **********The Potential Scenarios **********After mid-October, according to high-ranking Defense Department and White House officials, who spoke on condition that they not be identified, the President's options for offensive action would range from attacks on dams and roads as a way to step up economic pressure, through an attempt to kill or kidnap Mr. Hussein, the Iraqi leader, to an extensive military campaign to push the Iraqis out of Kuwait - and perhaps to continue to move into Iraq itself, perhaps all the way to Baghdad. **********Such a campaign might well involve a drive north by Army units on the left flank, marines on the right, and an amphibious assault, not unlike those at Anzio and Inchon, by other marine forces now held in floating reserve. **********Fighting could begin in one of three basic ways. Iraq could attack Saudi Arabia, which American experts, both inside and outside the Government, now consider extremely unlikely. President Bush could decide that the sanctions would not suffice, in a reasonable length of time, and order an offensive. Or a war could grow out of a small incident, like an inadvertent clash between American and Iraqi warplanes or some grievous mistreatment of hostages. **********The fabrication or exaggeration of a pretext for action by either side is not unthinkable, as the manipulation of the Gulf of Tonkin incident at a key moment in Vietnam shows. **********A Technological Edge **********If war began, American planners would seek to make the most of their technological capacity, which includes such elements as electronic deception to complicate Iraqi air defense, laser- and radar-guided missiles and, above all, an arsenal of weapons and devices that should enable American troops to fight effectively at night, something the Iraqis are not yet able to do. **********The planners would also seek to exploit vastly superior American air power to minimize the huge Iraqi superiority in troop and tank strength. Even when the United States deployment as now envisaged is complete, Baghdad is expected to have at least a two-to-one advantage in men and tanks, officers said. **********Even the battleship Wisconsin could come into play, launching its cruise missiles at important targets like command and control centers. **********By using missiles fired from afar, the Pentagon strategists would hope to limit American casualties and avoid the kind of ''Arab-Israeli desert blood bath,'' as one general put it, that took place in 1973. More than 20,000 soldiers were killed or wounded in the two-week war that year. **********''The numbers are scary, especially their infantry and artillery strength,'' said Bernard E. Trainor, a retired Marine general and former New York Times military correspondent who heads the national security program at Harvard University's Kennedy School of Government. ''But in the end, numbers don't count, if you have a concept that exploits your enemy's vulnerabilities. The Germans were outnumbered 10-to-1 in 1940, but they still overran France.'' **********The Need for Troop Strength **********Col. Harry Summers, a retired Army officer who writes and lectures on tactics, is much less sanguine. **********''You can certainly punish him with air power,'' Colonel Summers said of Mr. Hussein. ''You can destroy his air force. But that's not decisive if what you want to do is forcibly eject Saddam Hussein from Kuwait and make it hard for him to return. That takes troops on the ground, and I wouldn't want to try it with any less than 10 armored divisions, which you could only get by moving most of the Seventh Army down from Europe.'' **********A first step in any offensive operation would be the destruction of Iraqi fighters and bombers, either on the ground or in aerial combat, and the elimination of the 36 SCUD-B missile launchers. **********Anthony Cordesman, the author of ''The Lessons of Modern War,'' a history of the Iran-Iraq conflict, said that ''we have the ability to win air superiority very quickly.'' **********The Iraqi Air Force's planes - a few top-notch Soviet-built MIG-29's but mostly older MIG-23's and French-built Mirages - are considered inferior to the best American hardware. **********Available to American commanders would be Awacs radar planes to help fighter pilots spot enemy aircraft, EF-111 and EC-130 electronic jamming planes to confuse Iraqi electronic systems, and a huge arsenal of fighters, fighter-bombers, ground-attack planes and bombers - F-15's, F-16's, A-10's and Harriers in Saudi Arabia, F-111's and F-117's in Turkey, F-14's, F/A-18's and A-6's on board the carriers Independence, Saratoga and Eisenhower, and even B-52 bombers based on Diego Garcia island in the Indian Ocean. **********For Iraqi forces in the desert, there would be no jungle to provide cover, which greatly reduced the value of American air superiority in Vietnam. **********Talk of 'Surgical Strikes' **********In theory, the economic pressure could be tightened through the limited use of air power. Mr. Hussein's fragile domestic economy, strained by the embargo on food shipments, could be further disrupted through attacks on bridges, highways or even the two big dams just west of Baghdad and other hydroelectric plants. **********There is much talk in Washington of ''surgical strikes'' from the air, but the experience of the Vietnam War, when pilots found it tremendously difficult to hit even large targets like the Paul Doumer bridge in Hanoi, makes some observers skeptical. A former naval pilot who flew dozens of missions over Hanoi and Haiphong said recently, ''Surgical strikes exist only in think-tanks and mental institutions.'' **********In addition, the American military establishment, starting with Gen. Colin L. Powell, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, is firmly opposed to gradual escalation or limited offensives, having concluded that the Vietnam War was lost precisely because of a limited application of force. **********''Once you get air superiority, they will want to flatten Baghdad,'' Representative Aspin commented. **********Flattening Baghdad would inevitably entail thousands of civilian casualties - Muslims killed by Christians - and that might put intolerable pressure on the coalition of western and Arab countries lined up against Iraq. **********''We ought to play to our strength, which is air power,'' said Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who heads the Senate Armed Services Committee. ''But if we use military force in a way that alienates a lot of our partners in this operation, we will lose the embargo, and we will have that erode very rapidly, in which case we will be counterproductive to our own aims.'' **********One Military Solution **********Finally, an extensive campaign of air bombardment would threaten the Western hostages who have reportedly been dispersed to strategic targets around Iraq to act as ''human shields.'' **********Asked what he would do if told that a military solution was needed, a leading Congressional expert on Mideast warfare commented: ''Establish air superiority, launch air attacks on civil and military targets away from population centers, especially in the southern desert, then try to push into and through Kuwait, stopping on a line curving northwest from Basra, where the fertile land ends and the major highways leading south from Baghdad peter out.'' **********Such a plan, which was mentioned in interviews with several other experts, would be dependent for its long-term success on either inducing the downfall of a humiliated Saddam Hussein or a continued program of air interdiction to prevent the effective resupply of Iraqi troops and thus to make a major counterattack impossible. **********''Even that,'' said the expert, who described himself as a hawk, ''would be quite a difficult proposition.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/17/busin.body_text: **********Three former officials of F. D. Roberts Securities Inc. pleaded guilty on Friday to Federal felony charges in one of the largest cases of penny-stock frauds. **********Fred Galiardo of Daytona **********Beach, Fla., and Alan Lieb of Pine Brook, N.J., pleaded guilty to Federal racketeering, securities, mail and wire fraud charges. John Perfetti of Bayville, L.I., admitted securities and mail fraud. Mr. Galiardo, who was F. D. Roberts's chairman, and Mr. Lieb, a co-owner of the company, face a maximum of 20 years in prison and multimillion-dollar fines. **********Mr. Perfetti, former executive vice president in charge of operations, faces up to 10 years in prison and a similar fine. He will be sentenced in November. **********The charges stem from stock sales schemes at the defunct penny-stock brokerage. The schemes netted those involved more than $67 million in profits. Penny stocks represent equity in small companies whose shares typically trade over the counter for less than a dollar or two a share. **********More than two dozen people associated with the firm have pleaded guilty in connection with the case.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/08/busin.body_text: **********A Senate committee voted today to restore Federal regulation of cable television rates and service, after hearing scores of complaints from cable customers nationwide about high rate increases and poor service. The bill was approved by the Senate Commerce Committee by an 18-to-1 vote and sent to the full Senate. It gives the Federal Communications Commission authority to regulate rates for basic cable services, including local station broadcasts, to insure the rates are reasonable. Premium services, like movie channels, which cost more, would not be included.

The company also said its board had declared a regular quarterly dividend, as adjusted for the split, of 10 cents a share, payable Sept. 30 to holders of record on Sept. 14.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/17/busin.body_text: **********Coca-Cola Enterprises, the world's largest Coca-Cola bottler, said yesterday that third-quarter profits rose 80.8 percent, to $15 million, or 13 cents a share, from $8.3 million, or 6 cents a share, in the comparable period a year earlier. **********Third-quarter revenue rose 4.4 percent to $1.07 billion, from $1.02 billion a year earlier. **********Analysts said the 1989 results were sharply depressed because of high marketing expenses, rising production costs for sweetener and packaging, and pressure on profit margins from Coke Enterprises' continuing battle for market share with rival Pepsi-Cola bottlers. **********This year's third-quarter profit was lowered by preferred stock dividends of nearly $4 million, compared with dividends of $4.4 million a year earlier. **********The Coca-Cola Company, which makes the concentrate that goes into Coca-Cola soft drinks, owns 49 percent of Coca-Cola Enterprises.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/26/world.main_headline: 10 Die in Three Clashes Along Israel's Borders
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/26/world.print_headline: MIDEAST TENSIONS; 10 Die in Three Clashes Along Israel's Borders
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/26/world.body_text: **********Four Israelis were killed and more than two dozen wounded today when an Egyptian border policeman crept across the frontier, stationed himself in a ditch beside a highway and then opened fire on passing vehicles. **********The incident was one of three terrorist attacks attempted in 24 hours. **********In southern Lebanon, a teen-age girl who had strapped high explosives to her body ran toward two soldiers patrolling Israel's self-declared security zone about three miles north of the border. "She exploded herself," the army said, "lightly wounding the two soldiers." The National Syrian Socialist Party, a Lebanese group, took responsibility for the attack. **********The navy announced earlier that it had sunk a small boat on Saturday night carrying five guerrillas from southern Lebanon toward the Israeli shore. The Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command said its fighters were aboard the boat. **********In the attack involving the Egyptian border policeman, a security officer and soldiers returned fire, apparently wounding the man, who fled back into Egypt. The Egyptian authorities said the man was under arrest. **********The Islamic Jihad, a Muslim fundamentalist group whose name means Islamic Holy War, took responsibility for the attack in a statement sent to news agencies in Amman, Jordan. **********The group is viewed by Western terrorism experts as an umbrella term for a variety of fundamentalist factions. There was no immediate way of verifying its claim.  Two Egyptians Watch **********Witnesses said two Egyptian policemen in a border post overlooking the highway watched but took no action during the incident, which lasted about 15 minutes. **********The attack was a rare occurence for the southern border. The Israeli authorities are generally well prepared for the frequent attempted guerrilla infiltrations from Lebanon and off the coast. But Egypt and Israel have been at peace since 1979, and the Egyptian border is so quiet that it is rarely patrolled by Israelis or Egyptians. **********Egyptian officials expressed regret over the attack, but Israeli officials were angry. **********"It's a very serious situation that has to come to an end," Foreign Minister David Levy said tonight. "We expect that the Egyptians will do everything necessary to bring this person to trial first of all and second to put an end to the continuation of the slaughter of Israelis on Egyptian territory and along the border." **********The attack was the first of its kind on the Israeli side of the border in recent times. Early this year, nine Israeli tourists were killed when gunmen ambushed their bus on a desert road between Cairo and Ismailia. Border Shooting in 1985 **********In 1985, an Egyptian border policeman shot and killed four Israeli children, two women and an elderly man near the border in the Sinai desert. **********The site of this morning's attack, about 12 miles northwest of Eilat, is a stretch of highway dotted with military installations. It is usually traveled by members of the military and civilians from Eilat who work at the bases. **********The attacker, whom the Egyptians have not identified by name, apparently crept across just after dawn. He wore a border police uniform and a flak jacket and carried an AK-47 assault rifle and a pouch holding 8 or 10 loaded clips. **********One of the Israelis wounded in the incident said the attacker had found a dry river bed that runs under the road about 300 yards from the border. **********"I was the first car that was shot at," Chief Master Sgt. Semach Kapach said as he sat in the emergency room at Josef Tal hospital in Eilat receiving treatment for light wounds. **********"I saw the terrorist lying by the side of the road with his automatic rifle held out front," he said. "He began to shoot, and I immediately ducked over my seat toward the passenger seat, and grabbed tight onto the steering wheel, praying I could still drive straight." **********A brigadier general who did not give his name said another noncommissioned officer drove past alone in a Peugeot. The Egyptian shot him as he passed, "and he managed to go another few hundred meters and apparently died in his car," the general said.  Gunman Emerges From Ditch **********The gunman then shot and killed the drivers of the next two vechicles to come along the road. **********Finally a commercial bus loaded with civilians and military personnel rode by. Standing in the middle of the road, the man sprayed the bus with bullets, pausing occasionally to reach into his bag and change clips. **********A passenger on the bus, a 54-year-old carpenter named Shimon Ben Shitrit, said as he was being treated for light wounds at the hospital this afternoon: "We saw a man who signaled us to stop. An army bus was stopped across the way, and since the man was in uniform, we thought he must need help. But when we got close, he opened fire." **********The driver, 36-year-old Eliezer Wahabe, was fatally wounded. **********"While the shooting was going on," said Yehud Nuriel, one of the passengers, "I told the people to lie down on the floor. I tried to get to the driver," who "was lying on the ground wounded seriously." **********"I moved him aside," Mr. Nuriel added, describing how he struggled to disentangle the man's feet from the pedals. "I got into the driver's seat, turned the wheel and headed back to Eilat."  Gunman Is Wounded **********A security officer on the bus opened fire with his Uzi submachine gun, apparently wounding the Egyptian. At least one other soldier also fired at the gunman, who fled back toward the border. **********Of the bus passengers, 26 people were wounded, 5 of them seriously. **********Dan Ran Bahar, the driver of a bus that arrived on the scene immediately after the firing stopped, wept intermittently tonight as he described carrying the dead and wounded to the hospital. **********"I travel that route a lot," he said. "Sometimes the Egyptians at the border post say 'Shalom' to us. The truth is that there's an Egyptian outpost with two soldiers overlooking the spot where this happened. It occurred right under their eyes, and they perhaps could have done something. I guess that's what's called a cold peace."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/23/world.main_headline: Bush Called Ready to Renew China Trade Status for a Year
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/23/world.print_headline: Bush Called Ready to Renew China Trade Status for a Year
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/23/world.body_text: **********President Bush has decided to renew China's trade benefits for another year, concluding that the potential harm to American companies and to reform-minded Chinese outweighed a desire to register disapproval of Beijing's human-rights record, Administration officials said today. **********There is also a domestic political dimension to Mr. Bush's move to renew most-favored-nation trade status. The President, who has said he agonized over the decision, is calculating that Congress will not react with the outrage that greeted his overtures to China last year, officials said. **********The White House has spent weeks laying political groundwork for the decision, and officials said their soundings of Congress indicated opposition would not be strong, although George J. Mitchell, the Senate majority leader, condemned Mr. Bush's decision today as ''contrary to American interests and wrong.'' **********Emphasis on District Profits **********Representative Nancy Pelosi, the California Democrat who led Congressional opposition to Mr. Bush's China policy last year, said today that a resolution opposing the extension of the trade benefits would be introduced. **********But other Democratic lawmakers and Congressional aides said they could not gather enough votes to block the move as long as Mr. Bush found a way to make it clear that the act did not represent approval of Beijing's policies and that Washington might reconsider the issue next year if the situation in China did not improve. **********Administration officials said Mr. Bush, whose decision was first reported in The Wall Street Journal on Monday, was prepared to offer such assurances when he sends his decision on trade with China to Congress. They said he would also point out that other sanctions against China, including suspension of World Bank loans and a ban on military sales, would remain in effect. **********Sanctions Seen as Ineffective **********Supported by intense lobbying from Hong Kong business interests and other groups promoting trade with China, the White House is also counting on its belief that any undecided lawmakers will be swayed by the profits that their home districts reap from $18 billion a year in trade with China. **********Under a Federal law known as the Jackson-Vanik amendment, China and other countries with nonmarket economies cannot be granted most-favored-nation status, which gives them the lower tariff rates granted to most American trading partners, unless the White House certifies that they are permitting free emigration. **********That certification must be renewed each year and is due for China this year on June 3, the anniversary of the crackdown around Tiananmen Square. **********The Administration also made the decision with an eye to future debates over trade with the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. By sticking to the letter of the Jackson-Vanik rules, which address only emigration, the Administration hopes to reduce the impact that other issues, like the conduct of political activity, will have on discussions of trade with Eastern Europe. **********Administration officials said that the White House and State Department were still completing formal documents on the trade issue for Mr. Bush to sign, but that the President had reached a decision to extend the trade benefits for another year. **********After meeting with Mr. Bush at the White House today, senior Republican lawmakers suggested that Mr. Bush was prepared to approve the extension and said he promised to send his ruling to Congress before it recesses on Friday for the Memorial Day holiday. **********Mr. Bush's decision follows an intense debate in the Administration over the political and diplomatic ramifications of extending the trade benefits. Some officials questioned whether the White House wanted to risk the harsh criticism that surfaced over Mr. Bush's decision to send two aides to Beijing on two secret missions last year. **********Other officials, especially career diplomats in the State Department who opposed the extension of the trade benefits, argued that canceling most-favored-nation status would send a clear signal of American disapproval of the Chinese human-rights record. **********To do otherwise, they said, would fly in the face of Mr. Bush's publicly expressed disappointment that his overtures to China have had little visible effect on Beijing's policies. **********In the end, officials said, Mr. Bush, a former envoy to Beijing who runs China policy personally from the Oval Office, followed his own inclination to keep diplomatic and economic channels open to Beijing. **********He also heeded arguments that canceling most-favored-nation status for China would cost $8 billion to $10 billion in the first year. The Administration has prepared statistics on how that will affect specific profits in individual lawmakers' districts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/12/busin.main_headline: New York City Is Hurt But Still Has Reserves; Banking: Many Questions About the Future
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/12/busin.print_headline: New York City Is Hurt But Still Has Reserves; Banking: Many Questions About the Future
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/12/busin.body_text: **********With their profits and stature at a low ebb, New York's largest banks are realizing that their size and traditions do not guarantee them a place at the top of the financial-services indus try in 10 years. **********The banking industry prob ably faces more questions about its future than perhaps any other important segment of the New York City economy. Banking provides more than 170,000 jobs in the city, up by more than 10,000 in a decade. Still, banking employment has fallen by about 15,000 in the last three years. **********Costly mistakes on loans to less-developed countries and real estate developers have so weakened the largest banks that they now lack the financial muscle to expand into new markets and businesses. **********Still, demand for bank products is growing at a healthy rate, which is one reason why nonbanking companies like the General Electric Company have moved into areas like corporate lending and credit cards. **********For now, the city's largest banks -- with the exception of J. P. Morgan & Company and the Bankers Trust Company -- are so strapped by bad loans that they are concentrating on cutting costs. But in the coming decade, bankers and analysts expect a wave of mergers, acquisitions and joint ventures.  Millions of Dollars in Savings **********The merger of any two big New York banks could raise their profits by hundreds of millions of dollars by eliminating duplicate branches, headquarters and executives. **********Since Citibank, the nation's largest bank, has only about 15 percent of consumer accounts in the New York market, and Chemical, Manufacturers Hanover and Chase Manhattan, the next three, have a total share of only about 18 percent, some analysts see room for large-scale consolidation without any bank gaining monopoly power. **********Thomas Labrecque, chairman of Chase Manhattan, said consolidiation need not be limited to banks. He noted that competitors like the mortgage unit of the General Motors Corporation often have lower costs. Chase would consider merging or creating joint ventures with such companies, he said. **********Analysts are confident that a large banking industry will remain in New York City, but the organizations and even the names of banks are in question. The answers depend on whether banks are allowed and have the inclination to merge with each other or industrial companies, to develop nationwide branches, or to expand into securities and insurance. **********New York City is likely to be headquarters for at least a few of the giant banks in the next generation, but many jobs will be elsewhere. A number of large banks already have credit-card operations in states like Delaware and South Dakota, where taxes and labor costs are lower.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/29/world.main_headline: Revisions Sought in U.S. Food-Aid Program
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/29/world.print_headline: Revisions Sought in U.S. Food-Aid Program
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/29/world.body_text: **********Each year the United States sends so much grain to Egypt that the farmers feed loaves of bread to their cows. **********In Indonesia, officials appealed to the United States Ambassador to stop the shipment of 70,000 tons of American grain that would have put their farmers out of business. **********And every year, tons of food rots on foreign docks because aid shipments are sent without regard to local harvesting and milling schedules. **********Frustrated over waste and mismanagement in the $1.5 billion Food for Peace program, lawmakers, commodity and private aid groups are trying to push through Congress the most sweeping changes in 25 years in the humanitarian food program. **********The versions of the bill that have been approved by the House Foreign Affairs Committee and the Senate Agriculture Committee would reorganize the bureaucracy that distributes the food and would allocate more money to grants, rather than loans. **********American aid officials say what began as a well-intentioned foreign-aid effort to distribute surplus grain has been stymied by mismanagement and political interests. Bureaucratic infighting and agency turf battles paralyze food delivery, they say. And because food is used as a foreign-policy weapon, they say, it is channeled away from the neediest countries to the politically important ones. **********''The present Food for Peace program has so many bureaucratic and political players that it usually serves the political ends before it works to end hunger,'' said Representative Tony P. Hall, Democrat of Ohio, who heads the House Select Committee on Hunger. **********''What we are trying to do is to streamline the decision-making process and basically, if possible, take as much politics out of it as we can,'' Mr. Hall said. He is working with Senators on a bipartisan bill that would reorganize the bureaucracy of five agencies that administer the program. **********''It's used as a slush fund of the State Department to meet political requirements around the world,'' said Owen Cylke, former acting director of Food for Peace, who retired last year. **********According to Congressional testimony, a third of American food aid goes to countries that do not have food shortages. Morocco, which has one of the highest per capita calorie rates, received $70 million in food aid last year, while Angola, a country where there is severe malnutrition, received less than $3 million. **********The United States has provided covert support to rebels fighting the Angolan Government. **********Mr. Cylke said the program lends the world's poorest nations the money to buy American grain and processed foods, which worsens their debt crisis. Meanwhile, countries that are relatively well off receive gifts of food. **********Those leading the revision efforts say most of the problems stem from wrangling among the five agencies involved: the Agency for International Development, the Office of Management and Budget and the Departments of State, Agriculture and Treasury. **********Expertise Seen as Lacking **********Each agency must agree to every aid package, said a staff member on the House Select Committee on Hunger. And except for A.I.D., not one of the agencies has the expertise or manpower in the field, he said. **********Under the Senate legislation, co-written by chairman Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont and the ranking Republican member, Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, the Agency for International Development would have sole authority to make food gifts to the least-developed countries. Grants would be allocated according to per capita income, caloric intake and the mortality rate among children under 5 years of age. **********The Department of Agriculture would be responsible for the credit-sales program, which provides low-interest loans to countries that are poor but not facing starvation. **********The President would also have a $100 million discretionary fund to assist newly emerging democracies. **********The bill was approved by a unanimous vote in the House Foreign Affairs Committee on July 11. It moves next to the the House floor as part of the 1990 Farm Bill. Debate by the House and the Senate is expected in late summer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/15/world.main_headline: Bonn, Heeding Critics in U.S., Will Provide Planes and Ships for Gulf Effort
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/15/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;   Bonn, Heeding Critics in U.S., Will Provide Planes and Ships for Gulf Effort
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/15/world.body_text: **********West Germany will offer transport planes and ships for the use of American forces in an effort to deflect criticism that it has contributed too little to the international military buildup in the Persian Gulf, Government officials said today. **********A spokesman for the West German Transport Ministry said it had prepared detailed lists of civilian planes and ships that could be used to ferry troops, weapons and supplies to the gulf. Costs for the ships and planes will be paid by West Germany, a Government spokesman said. **********The lists will be presented to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, when he meets with Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany on Saturday afternoon in Bonn, when he stops on his return trip to Washington from Damascus. He will see Chancellor Helmut Kohl on Saturday night in Ludwigshafen, Mr. Kohl's hometown. **********''How many planes and ships and how much this will all cost is largely at the wish of Mr. Baker, which he will tell us on Saturday when we discuss further assistance for the gulf forces,'' said an official who insisted that his name not be used. ''Our actions were taken in consideration of what the Bush Administration told us was its most urgent need. That was logistical and transport support.'' **********Government officials also said Bonn will pledge about $260 million in financial assistance for Egypt, Turkey, Jordan and Syria, the nations hardest hit by the United Nations embargo on trade with Iraq. **********Unhappiness in Congress **********But West Germany has been slow in responding to the United States' call for aid from Western industrial countries not directly involved in providing air, sea or ground forces in the gulf region. The delay has brought heavy criticism from Congressional leaders. **********Prompted by an appeal from Mr. Baker, Italy said today that it was sending a fourth warship and eight Tornado jet fighter planes to the region. **********Unlike Japan or its NATO allies, Bonn is saddled with a huge-scale expenditure - the cost of German unification, including a payment of $7.5 billion to the Soviet Union to withdraw its 380,000 troops from East Germany. **********West Germany also has a constitutional clause that keeps it from committing forces outside the area of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. But Bonn officials insist that this has not made the Kohl administration hesitant to offer aid for the international forces in the Persian Gulf.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/31/world.main_headline: Romanian Leader Is Seeking Fall Visit With Bush
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/31/world.print_headline: Romanian Leader Is Seeking Fall Visit With Bush
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/31/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Petre Roman wants very much to come to Washington this autumn and has let the Bush Administration know of this desire. But so far, the Romanian official has received no positive response. **********''I would like to visit the United States,'' he said in an interview in his office here on Wednesday. ''I want to go because I want to be questioned by Congressmen and Senators. I want to be really there to answer every question and every criticism directly in the pure American style.'' **********Mr. Roman, who is 45 years old, is to meet on Friday with Senator Bob Dole, the Republican minority leader, and six of his colleagues. He will be able to answer their questions in English, which he speaks quite well. **********But at this point, it is not clear whether the Bush Administration, which has repeatedly and harshly assailed the Romanian Government for most of the last eight months, will officially endorse a visit by Mr. Roman. **********''We have certain benchmarks,'' a United States Embassy official said when asked about the possibility of a visit by the Romanian head of government. ''We are watching University Square,'' the scene of violent clashes between anti-Government demonstrators and the police earlier this year. ''We are watching the newspapers and the development of a press law.'' **********The Romanian Government has been strongly criticized for its conduct during a demonstration in June, when a call for help brought to the capital a flood of miners who beat up students, demonstrators and others. **********But American diplomats here acknowledge that the Romanian Government, whose United Nations representative is now chairman of the Security Council, has been extremely supportive of United States initiatives in the Persian Gulf crisis. ''That is a positive development'' in the still sour relationship with Washington, a diplomat said. **********Mr. Roman indicated that he intended to go to New York for the annual session of the United Nations General Assembly that starts in September and that ''if I have a clear signal from Washington, I'll go.'' **********He was frank in acknowledging mistakes by his Government, which was overwhelmingly endorsed by Romanian voters in elections last May that were generally acknowledged as fair. **********Referring to clashes in mid-June that left six dead, Mr. Roman said the Government was ''to blame for the fact that we did not succeed in controlling the violence of June 13 and the fact that some miners got out of control the evening of June 14 also.'' **********He said that the events of June were still the subject of investigation, but that it was evident to him that some former members of the Nicolae Ceausescu's secret police had committed acts of violence at the time. ''Some former Securitate men were involved in provocations to force us to return to their methods,'' he said, using the Romanian name for the deposed dictator's state security force. **********Mr. Roman rejected the notion that Romania was, saying, ''I think you have to view our political stability within the framework of the legacy inherited from the Communist regime.'' **********''It was clear to us that we would have a very difficult economic situation in this transition,'' he continued. ''It may be worse than we expected.'' He said other East European countries ruled by Communist governments until last year had the same problems. **********He said his Government had pushed through the necessary legal changes to turn state enterprises into privately owned companies and to encourage small businesses, including a law that every apartment house built after 1948 could be placed on the open market. **********That and other laws encouraging privatization ''haven't operated very well,'' he said, because brakes were being applied ''by ancient members of the bureaucracy.'' **********''We need to accelerate the autonomy,'' he said, although ''even those that want to put things in order, most don't have the means.'' **********The only real bright spot in the economy, Mr. Roman said, was in agriculture, where a record grain harvest of 11.5 million tons is being brought in -with 3 million tons being kept by farmers for sale on the free market.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/01/world.main_headline: Turnover in Nicaragua;   NICARAGUAN RIVALS FOCUS ON CONTRAS IN ELECTION'S WAKE
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/01/world.print_headline: Turnover in Nicaragua;   NICARAGUAN RIVALS FOCUS ON CONTRAS IN ELECTION'S WAKE
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/01/world.body_text: **********Three days after his Government was routed in national elections, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra today declared an immediate cease-fire with the American-supported contras. **********His announcement came a few hours after President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro urged for the first time that the contras disband quickly to allow for a smooth transfer of power. **********The two statements sharply increased pressure for the dismantling of the rebel army and underscored the importance that both sides place on resolving the contra issue before April 25. On that date, the Sandinista National Liberation Front is scheduled to hand power to Mrs. Chamorro's National Opposition Union. **********A Promise Stands **********In Honduras, contra spokesmen told reporters that the rebels would prefer to keep their army intact to insure that the Sandinista National Liberation Front abides by its promise to step down. But a contra military chief, Israel Galeano Cornejo, known as Commander Franklin, said in a statement that the guerrillas had formed a commission that was ready to discuss demobilization with Mrs. Chamorro or her delegates. **********Such a plan to disband was supported here today by former members of the contra directorate like Alfonso Robelo Callejas, who returned to take part in the electoral process. He said Mrs. Chamorro's victory had made the anti-Sandinista war obsolete. **********''They are a thing of the past, they have no raison d'etre,'' Mr. Robelo said of the rebels. ''After the example that the people of Nicaragua gave during the elections, the contras are not a problem anymore. We have to integrate them into the country as soon as possible.'' **********Appeal on U.S. Aid **********Declaring the unilateral truce, Mr. Ortega said combat operations against the estimated 3,000 rebels still operating in Nicaragua would be ended at once. He demanded that any future United States aid to the rebels be channeled through a special international agency set up to oversee the disbanding of 10,000 contras in Honduras and their 40,000 dependents in camps there. **********''Before the Sandinistas turn over power, they need to know that there is not a bunch of armed people out there that is going to turn around and knock them off one at a time,'' said Robert Pastor, a principal adviser to former President Jimmy Carter. Mr. Pastor played a major role in overseeing Sunday's election and mediating between the sides in the aftermath of the results. **********''The opposition understands that,'' he said. **********Mrs. Chamorro's election victory, by a margin of almost 15 percentage points, has changed this country's political landscape overnight. It has also thrust Sandinista and opposition leaders into a complex and politically delicate process of negotiating a peaceful end to more than a decade of revolutionary rule, including the Sandinistas' tight control over Nicaragua's 65,000-member army and security forces. **********''For the opposition, the object is to reassure the Sandinistas without handing over real power,'' said a foreign expert who has been involved in setting up the transition talks. **********On Tuesday night, the designated transition chiefs for Mrs. Chamorro and the Sandinista Government met for the first time, spending a little more than two hours at the house of Mr. Carter's resident representative in Managua, Jennifer McCoy. There, they outlined the agenda for substantive talks. **********Closely Held Information **********But amid an atmosphere of enormous apprehension and political uncertainty, both in the Sandinista Front and the broad opposition leadership, the meeting was not announced to the public, and even the names of the participants were kept secret until today. **********At a news conference this morning, Mrs. Chamorro disclosed that her transition chief was her son-in-law and campaign manager, Antonio Lacayo, an American-educated businessman. Sandinista officials said that the Government was being represented by Humberto Ortega Saavedra, the Defense Minister who is the younger brother and principal adviser to President Ortega. **********The appointment of Mr. Lacayo, a trusted member of Mrs. Chamorro's inner circle whose business interests have involved extensive dealings with the Government, was expected by many diplomats to create a climate of confidence. **********But the choice was criticized by political leaders within her broad alliance, who said they were not consulted about the choice, and they expressed fear that Mr. Lacayo would accept terms on future relations with the Sandinista Front without first seeking a consensus among the 14-party leadership. **********'Does Whatever She Wants' **********''It's just another example of the way Dona Violeta deals with the coalition,'' an opposition party leader said. ''She just does whatever she wants.'' **********Mr. Ortega's appointment, by contrast, was widely seen as a reflection of Sandinista seriousness about the transition process, and the likely importance of military issues in the discussions that are pending. **********A member of the Sandinista Front's nine-member national directorate, Humberto Ortega Saavedra is regarded as the most important political strategist in the Sandinista leadership and its most powerful figure after his brother Daniel. **********In 1988, Humberto Ortega led the Sandinista delegation that negotiated a cease-fire with contra commanders. And he is believed to have had a principal role in the decision to end the 19-month-old truce early last November after the infiltration of thousands of rebel troops into Nicaragua during the election campaign. **********Fear of Violence **********Today's announcements about progress in the transition talks were tinged by apprehension about the violence that has continued in parts of the country since the announcement of Mrs. Chamorro's victory early Monday morning. **********In the northern towns of Esteli, Ocotal, Somoto and Pueblo Nuevo, large crowds of young Sandinista supporters, many among them armed with automatic weapons, have gathered each evening, often at Sandinista youth-organization headquarters, to hold rallies and march on the homes of coalition supporters to show their defiance of the electoral outcome. **********''I was watching TV with my children, and I am six months' pregnant,'' said an opposition supporter, Mailin Ortiz, whose house in Esteli was attacked on Tuesday night. **********''There were hundreds of Sandinistas out on the street, and they told us they would kill us. I had to climb up onto the roof with the children to get away. I have never experienced anything like it in my life.'' **********But international observers have repeatedly expressed confidence in the commitment of the Sandinista central leadership to abide by the results of the vote, and said they believed that such local incidents would diminish as the transition talks progressed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/16/world.main_headline: Upheaval in the East;   Dissident Named Chief Of an East Berlin Party
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/16/world.print_headline: Upheaval in the East;   Dissident Named Chief Of an East Berlin Party
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/16/world.body_text: **********With the first free elections in this country only three days away, a conservative coalition allied with the West German Chancellor elected a longtime dissident as its leader today to replace a man who admitted he had been an undercover agent of the ousted Communist Government's secret police. **********The coalition, the Democratic Reawakening movement, expelled its former chairman, Wolfgang Schnur, who resigned Wednesday after admitting that he had been an underground informer for the Communists' State Security Service for many years. The coalition chose his deputy, the Rev. Rainer Eppelmann, as its leader. Since last month Mr. Eppelmann, a longtime dissident, has been a member of the departing government of Prime Minister Hans Modrow as minister without portfolio. **********Acute Embarrassment **********The Schnur case has been an acute embarrassment not only for the movement he headed but also for the three-party conservative Alliance for Germany, for which Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany has campaigned actively. The East German branches of the West German Christian Democrats and Christian Social Union are the other members of the coalition, which is conducting a joint campaign for the parliamentary elections scheduled for Sunday. **********In a press statement after its leaders met today, the Democratic Reawakening said that Mr. Schnur's failure to offer his resignation forced the leadership to expel him. Mr. Schnur, who initially described the secret police charges as slander, has been in a hospital here since the accusations became public last week. He is said to be suffering from a heart and circulatory ailment. **********''For the human tragedy of Wolfgang Schnur, the members of the executive found words of sympathy and wish him as a human being a speedy recovery,'' the statement said. **********The Schnur debacle did not daunt spirits at the alliance's final Berlin rally tonight, but a group of opponents jeered a speaker representing Democratic Reawakening by shouting, ''Out with the secret police!'' **********The crowd of about 2,000 made up for its small size by loud demands for immediate reunification, rhythmic chanting of ''Deutsch-land, Deutsch-land!'' and angry shouts of ''Out with the Reds!'' at those who had come to wave the East German flag. **********In an unusually undiplomatic speech by a guest in a country that remains sovereign and independent, Eberhard Diepgen, former Mayor of West Berlin and leader of its Christian Democrats, denounced those who waved the national flag for showing a banner ''with such an ugly emblem.'' **********The crowd cheered a man waving a homemade poster that said, ''One currency, one people, one country.'' For some with long memories, the form of the slogan was uncomfortably reminiscent of a motto once popular here, ''One people, one Reich, one Fuhrer.'' **********Racing Against Time **********A block away, the Party for Democratic Socialism, successor to the Communist Party, which ruled this country until November, was racing against time to give its party headquarters a new decor symbolizing the new, voter-friendly image that it has been presenting to the electorate. **********A team of West German commercial artists was working under stage lights tonight to enliven the grim party headquarters, the former Reichsbank, with psychedelic friezes stretching along its extensive facade. The top painting, stretching for nearly 100 yards, is an effusion of acrylic spray, which its designer described as carrying only an implicit message, ''a little color is good for you.'' **********Beneath, in letters hard to read because of the burst of colors, a second frieze spells out a slogan that the leadership of Mr. Modrow and Gregor Gysi, the party chairman, have been conveying to the public since the discredited former leaders were ousted at the end of last year. The new slogan is, ''We are the new ones.'' **********Un-Communist Appearance **********Completing probably the most un-Communist appearance of any Eastern European party headquarters, large portraits of the two leaders, in modern technique and bright acrylic tints, are to flank the motto. By tonight, only Mr. Modrow's had taken its place. The West German artist, showing slight embarrassment, said his heart wasn't in the message. The job is a strictly commercial proposition for him. ''I can't identify with it,'' he said. **********A further block away, the vast, modern glass-and-concrete Palace of the Republic, which houses the Parliament, theaters, restaurants and large open spaces, has been converted into a flight of television studios from which most Western television companies will cover the tallying of the votes on Sunday. **********The palace, which under the old Government allowed journalists to enter only on rare occasions, appears to have been totally taken over, largely by West German networks.
