https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/11/busin.main_headline: Producer Prices Show Decline of 0.1% for July
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/11/busin.print_headline: Producer Prices Show Decline of 0.1% for July
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/11/busin.body_text: **********Prices at the producer level fell by a tenth of a percent in July, the Labor Department said today in a report that economists said showed a weakening economy even before the current oil-price shock. **********Last month's decline was the first drop since April in the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods, which foreshadows price trends at the retail level, but economists worried that it was a sign of falling demand for goods. **********The department noted that the index measured producer prices before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, which has sent oil prices soaring and provoked warnings that inflation would be fired up as increased energy costs rippled through the economy. **********Uncertainty on Severity **********''It's fair to say we're going to see some acceleration in energy prices, but the jury's still out on just how severe that's going to be,'' said Ron Schreibman, vice president of the National Association of Wholesaler-Distributors. **********The price of United States benchmark crude oil has gone to about $26 a barrel from $21.55 on Aug. 1, before the Mideast crisis. A barrel was at about $17 in early July. **********July producer prices were more restrained than economists had expected. Their forecasts had been for a rise of two-tenths of a percent, which would have matched June's rise. But prices at the producer level are expected to soar in August and September as the impact of higher energy costs hits. **********During the first seven months of the year, producer prices rose at a relatively modest annual rate of 3 percent, compared with a 4.8 percent rate of increase for all of 1989. **********Decline in 'Core Rate' **********Excluding the volatile food and energy components, producer prices still fell a tenth of a percent in July after a six-tenths rise in June. This is the ''core rate'' of inflation that is sometimes cited as a more reliable indicator of producer price trends. **********It was the first decline in a year for the core rate, but that was not seen positively by some economists. Richard Rahn, chief economist for the United States Chamber of Commerce, said it was ''a clear sign of weakening demand'' for goods. That impression is bolstered by lower factory orders, declining consumer demand, higher unemployment and more unsold goods, he added. **********''The economy is virtually dead in its tracks,'' said Mr. Rahn, who expects a recession by the year's end. **********After the release of the report, Government bonds rose moderately, but they later fell, and the stock market was sharply lower as the Dow Jones industrial average ended with a drop of 42.33 points, to 2,716.58. Traders said the markets were more affected, however, by Mideast uncertainty than by the price report, which has largely been superseded by recent oil price rises. **********The price report showed that energy prices in July fell five-tenths of a percent after a nine-tenths drop in June. Gasoline prices were down 5.3 percent after a slight four-tenths rise in June. Crude petroleum prices fell 4 percent last month after an 11.9 percent June drop. **********Crude oil prices were 23 percent lower in July than they were a year earlier, while gasoline prices at the producer level were 1.3 percent lower. Wholesalers pushed gasoline prices up strongly in the days after Iraq's invasion, and prices at the pump have risen more than 15 cents a gallon on average. **********Consumer food prices were unchanged in July, after a drop of four-tenths of a percent in June. Tobacco and automobile prices fell, but prescription drugs cost more. **********Speculation has grown that the Federal Reserve Board might be forced to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy, although a Fed governor, John P. LaWare, said on Thursday that it was too early to say how hard the economy would be hit by the higher energy costs. **********Mitsubishi Bank economists estimate that each $1 rise in crude oil prices translates into a 4 percent increase in wholesale gasoline prices and a 2 percent rise in prices consumers pay at the pump. That, in turn, increases producer prices aboout two-tenths of a percent a month. **********The various changes in producer prices put the July index for all finished goods, not seasonally adjusted, at 118, which means that a hypothetical selection of goods that cost $100 in 1982 cost $118 last month, up from $114.10 a year earlier. **********In two companion reports covering earlier production stages, prices for intermediate goods were unchanged, while prices for crude goods rose six-tenths of a percent. Examples of the types of products in each of the three processing stages would be clothing for finished goods, cloth for intermediate and cotton for crude.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/08/world.main_headline: A Sense of Wonder Among the Mere Bystanders
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/08/world.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: WASHINGTON;   A Sense of Wonder Among the Mere Bystanders
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/08/world.body_text: **********Some people were thunderstruck. Others were numb, unable to absorb one more remarkable blow to Communism. Many were wary, waiting to see if Mikhail S. Gorbachev could ''stay one step ahead of the sheriff,'' as the conservative columnist Robert Novak put it. **********There was skepticism from the right, money-making schemes from the Fortune 500 crowd, and a reluctant and cautious response from the President, who always frets that any appearance of gloating on the part of America will tip the precarious balance in the Soviet Union away from Mr. Gorbachev. **********The political experts in Washington had felt it was inevitable that the power of the Soviet Communist Party would diminish ever since the Soviets did not roll into Eastern Europe with tanks to stop the rush of democracy this fall and winter. They were just watching to see, as the Democratic analyst Robert G. Beckel put it, ''if Gorbachev could pull off a six-cushion pool shot and survive.'' **********So today the reaction was mostly muted wonder at the events in Moscow, while everyone still kept watching to see what the Soviet leader's next shot would be. **********Just a Bystander **********''We may have exhausted our capacity for surprise and delight when we watched children in Tiananmen Square quoting Jefferson and children in East Germany taking pickaxes to the Berlin Wall as East German guards smiled for the camera,'' said Peggy Noonan, the speechwriter for Ronald Reagan who wrote many of the former President's most biting Evil Empire denunciations. **********The day symbolized, for many people in this self-absorbed capital, the sense that Washington is more and more a bystander to world events rather than a player. **********''We're not part of history in Washington,'' said Representative Charles E. Schumer, the Brooklyn Democrat. ''We're just watching history.'' Mr. Novak noted that the events in the Soviet Union come ''at a critically dull time in Washington.'' **********''There's a great feeling of passivity associated with this President and the last year,'' he marveled. ''I've been in Washington 33 years and I've never seen a time where all the fascination was focused on something 8,000 miles away.'' **********'Perhaps It's Salutory' **********Ms. Noonan suggested that this might be a healthy turn of events. ''The imperial city of Washington has been taken aback by history because it thinks that it must help the world turn on its axis,'' she said. ''Perhaps it's salutory to know that the world can change without our permission or encouragement.'' **********A top Soviet analyst in the Government, who not long ago was predicting Mr. Gorbachev's removal and a police-state crackdown, echoed the sense that the world seemed to be spinning out of America's control. **********''The whole Soviet world is going down the drainpipe with astonishing speed,'' he said. ''There's very little we can do to affect it. The future will be determined largely by internal, domestic considerations. ''It's mind boggling.'' In political circles, where strategists are accustomed to promoting the notion of good versus evil, the news was discombobulating. The Soviets, the terrifying presence in all those James Bond films and Ronald Reagan speeches, seemed to be trying to kick the traces of their Evil Empire image. **********''It's disorientating,'' Ms. Noonan said, ''because it's hard to know who to assign the evil role to.'' **********In Washington, where everything is cast in terms of winning and losing, the debate was raging today over which party could get bragging rights to the end of the cold war. **********''We can't revel in the glory of what's going on,'' said John Buckley, a Republican consultant, ''because we're too busy trying to claim credit.'' **********The Democrats tried to take credit, pointing to the assessment of Strobe Talbot, a Time editor, that the crumbling of Communism proved that ''the doves in the Great Debate of the past 10 years were right all along.'' **********Weinberger 'Gratified' **********But Caspar W. Weinberger, the former Reagan Defense Secretary who pushed to build up American military forces to counteract the Soviet threat, said he felt personally gratified and was astonished that anyone would have the chance to say such things in Moscow ''without being shot.'' **********He cautioned against declaring democracy the champion this early, arguing that ''it's perfectly possible and within the capability of the Soviets militarily and morally to stop all this.'' **********President Bush took the low-key approach today. Originally, his advisers were going to insert a reaction to the Kremlin events in one of his California speeches promoting the ''Star Wars'' missile defense system and a strong defense. But that idea was canceled when the President decided he did not want to look like he was gloating. In a question and answer session after his speech at the Commonwealth Club in San Francisco, Mr Bush said he could best help the beleaguered Soviet leader by avoiding ''doing dumb things - and that's my cautious approach.'' **********The President reiterated his support for perestroika and praised Mr. Gorbachev for his ''restraint and finesse,'' adding that ''he's a man who you can talk to.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/24/world.body_text: **********Having concentrated entirely on deterring Soviet aggression over the past 40 years, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization is now struggling to find a new role for itself after the collapse of Communism and the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. **********For the moment, the 16-nation alliance seems caught in an identity crisis. The disintegration of the Warsaw Pact alliance has undermined NATO's very reason for existence. And in the Persian Gulf crisis, it has been largely a bystander because its charter forbids it from operating outside Europe and North America. **********''It will survive in the foreseeable future, but I can only see two years ahead,'' the director of the Royal Institute of International Affairs in London, Sir James Eberle, said. ''The role of NATO will have to change, and unless it makes itself useful, it will wither and die.'' **********The public message from NATO's Secretary General, Manfred Worner, is more upbeat. ''The cohesion of the alliance is the most important vehicle for change on the globe,'' he said this week at a conference on NATO's future here. ''It is a decisive factor of stability that will influence the future development of Europe.'' **********Ideas but No Consensus **********But inside NATO's sprawling headquarters, where officials are brainstorming to develop new military and political strategies, there is less confidence that the alliance can keep up with the changes sweeping Europe. **********''There are lots of ideas,'' one NATO official said, ''but there is no consensus about what it should do.'' **********With the shape of a post-cold-war Europe unsettled, the gulf crisis is raising new questions, including whether NATO should revise its charter so that it can deal with ''out of area'' regional conflicts. Officials also are wondering whether the 12-nation European Community will decide to build a defense mechanism of its own that might eventually compete with NATO. **********Criticized for their delay in sending military forces to the gulf, nine Governments in the European Community have revived a long moribund regional defense body called the Western European Union, which is now coordinating their naval activities. Italy has even proposed that the community formally absorb the Western European Union as a way of developing a regional defense policy. **********While seeking to maintain its long-dominant position in Europe, NATO is also facing other challenges. The Soviet Union and France, for example, believe that the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe should become the new umbrella organization for the region. Having acted quickly to pressure Iraq in the gulf crisis, even the United Nations is now viewed as a potential crisis manager in Europe and beyond. **********''We should not attend too closely to defining boundaries and functions among these institutions, which in these new times are in many ways untested,'' William H. Taft 4th, the chief American delegate at NATO, argued. ''Instead, we seek a rich, loosely connected connected, dynamic relationship,'' or ''a system that can absorb shocks.'' **********The United States, Britain and West Germany would like NATO to broaden its focus to include political and economic matters, but its efforts may well be duplicated by other European organizations. **********''Overlap can be handled through coordination,'' said Mr. Worner, an advocate of expanding NATO's role. **********Much of the disarray results from the sheer pace of events over the past 10 months. When the Berlin wall crumbled, NATO began talking about a new political role and reached out to the Warsaw Pact by inviting former Soviet-bloc Governments to name ambassadors to the alliance. **********As the Soviet threat diminished, NATO began preparing for the withdrawal of hundreds of thousands of American soldiers by revising its military strategy. Instead of relying on ''forward defense,'' it has moved toward ''flexible response'' involving smaller forces and fewer exercises. **********Gives Blessing to Conference **********At a summit meeting of leaders of NATO countries in London in July, the alliance gave its blessing to developing the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe as a forum ''for wider political dialogue in a more united Europe.'' It suggested that the conference establish a secretariat, a parliamentary assembly and mechanisms for preventing conflicts and monitoring elections. **********NATO's own role remains the topic of intense debate, with the United States seemingly anxious to prevent the strengthening of the European Community and the security conference from weakening the alliance. **********''Many people in Washington see NATO as essential to maintaining American clout in Europe,'' a former American diplomat said. ''But any attempt to preserve NATO on an artificial life system as an instrument for American influence will backfire.'' **********Despite the calls for NATO to break out of its military straitjacket and redefine its interests to include not only economic and political but environmental and ethnic problems, many European Governments doubt that it is equipped to deal with such issues. **********One problem is that NATO has shown no interest so far in opening its membership to the new democracies of Eastern Europe. As a result, it remains identified with the cold war. **********Several Western European countries, among them Austria, Sweden and Ireland, are neutral and do not want to be associated with a military alliance.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/17/busin.main_headline: CONSUMER PRICES ROSE IN OCTOBER AT A SLOWER RATE
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/17/busin.print_headline: CONSUMER PRICES ROSE IN OCTOBER AT A SLOWER RATE
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/17/busin.body_text: **********In a reassuring report on inflation that appeared to lead to another interest-rate cut by the Federal Reserve, the Labor Department said today that consumer prices had climbed less in October than in the preceding two months. The bond market rallied in response. **********About half the October increase in prices reflected petroleum costs, which have flattened lately. **********The overall price rise, six-tenths of 1 percent, although large by most standards, was a bit better than had been expected and represented improvement from the increases of eight-tenths of 1 percent posted by the Consumer Price Index in both August and September. Prospect of Lower Rates **********Apparently convinced that the risks of serious economic deterioration now outweigh those of inflation, the Federal Reserve moved today to cut an important short-term interest rate by one-quarter point, to 7 1/2 percent. This could lead to eventual cuts in what banks charge for loans to invididuals and businesses, thereby spurring economic activity. **********The impact was felt immediately in the credit markets, as prices of long-term Treasury bonds moved higher and their yields fell. The yield on the 30-year bond fell to 8.44 percent, from 8.52 percent the day before and 8.61 percent a week ago.  [ Page 34. ] **********Indications of a recession have come from a number of recent economic reports, like the one today that showed the trade deficit narrowed in September largely because consumers cut back on buying imports. Given all these signs, an easing of monetary policy was widely anticipated, although the timing remained uncertain. **********In fact, a summary published today of the Federal Reserve's Oct. 2 strategy session showed that 3 of the 11 members of its policy-making committee were sufficiently concerned about inflation to vote against an easing of rates. **********But today's inflation data followed the report last Friday that producer prices, excluding energy and food, remained unchanged in October, and the combined reports seem to have convinced the central bank that the task of arresting economic decline has become paramount and the inflation risks have become minimal. **********Indeed, various analysts said the sagging economy was itself acting as a brake on prices. At the consumer level, price increases, excluding the volatile energy and food components, have now been held for two straight months at three-tenths of 1 percent. **********Mickey D. Levy, chief economist for CRT Government Securities Ltd., called the figures a "glimmer of improvement in core inflation."  Outlook on Oil **********In the oil industry, many executives are saying the price of oil has peaked, a view shared by Patrick C. Jackman, chief of the Labor Department's consumer prices branch. He said today that current indications were that oil would exert little, if any, inflationary pressure in the November report. That would be a contrast to the three most recent months, when oil caused the inflation rate roughly to double. **********During the first 10 months of the year, the index covering all urban consumers has climbed at an annual rate of 6.7 percent, compared with a 4.7 percent pace during the comparable 1989 period. The difference is mainly attributable to oil-price increases that followed Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in early August. **********The main impact has been in the transportation sector, where prices rose 2.1 percent last month, with 80 percent of the increase in motor fuels. Gasoline jumped 7.7 percent, compared with 9.5 percent in September and 7.6 percent in August. **********Prices of new cars rose five-tenths of 1 percent in October, only the second rise in nine months, but used cars continued to fall and now cost 1.4 percent less than they did in December 1989. A 2.7 percent jump in airline fares was mainly responsible for a 1.8 percent rise in the cost of public transportation. **********Housing, the most heavily weighted component, rose three-tenths of 1 percent as fuel oil was up sharply and local telephone service climbed. The cost of cable television fell for the second straight month but was still 12.1 percent higher than in October 1989.  Variations in Food **********Food in general rose the same three-tenths of 1 percent as in September, but dairy products and meats, fish and eggs advanced more sharply. **********Apparel prices fell two-tenths of 1 percent, a surprise result that was partly attributed to premature discounting in a sagging economy. **********Medical care, paced this time by a 1.3 percent advance in hospital costs, rose eight-tenths of 1 percent, bringing medical inflation for the latest 12 months to 9.4 percent. **********In a companion report today, the Labor Department said the real average weekly earnings of American workers fell 2.1 percent last month, the biggest decline since 1979. **********This figure was derived from a 1.4 percent decline in average hours worked and a seven-tenths of 1 percent rise in the price index that covers urban wage earners and clerical workers. **********Other data showed that commodities, about 45 percent of the Consumer Price Index, rose 1 percent last month, mainly because of energy. Services, representing 55 percent of the index, rose three-tenths of 1 percent, down from four-tenths in September and seven-tenths in August. **********Before rounding, the index rose 0.60377, a rate that if maintained for 12 months and compounded would produce annual inflation of 7.5 percent. The index now stands at 133.5, meaning that a basket of goods and services that cost $100 in 1982-84, now costs $133.50.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/12/busin.main_headline: President Talks About a Family Matter
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/12/busin.print_headline: President Talks About a Family Matter
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/12/busin.body_text: **********Near the end of a news conference yesterday after the economic summit meeting in Houston, President Bush was asked if he agreed with a suggestion by his son Neil that savings and loan regulators are conducting something of a vendetta against him largely because his name is Bush: **********I agree that the President ought to stay out of it, and that the system ought to work. And I have great confidence in the integrity and honor of my son. And beyond that, I'm - say no more. And if he's done something wrong, the system will - will - will digest that. I have - this is not easy for me, as a father; it's easy for me as the President because the system is going to work, and I will not intervene. I've not discussed this with any officials and suggested any outcome. **********But what father wouldn't express a certain confidence in the honor of his son? And that's exactly the way I feel about it, and I feel very strongly about it. And for those who want to challenge it, whether they're in Congress or elsewhere, let the system work and then we can all make a conclusion as to his honor and his integrity. **********And it's tough on people in public life to some degree. And I've got three other sons and they all want to go to the barricades, every one of them, when they see some cartoon they don't like, particularly those that are factually incorrect in total - total demeaning of the honor of their brother. They want to - they want to do what any other - any other kids would do. And I say: You calm down now, we're in a different role now; you can't react like you would if your brother was picked on in a street fight - that's not the way the system works. But we have great emotions that I share with Barbara, I share with my sons and my daughter that I won't share with you, except to say: One, as President I am determined to stay out of this and let it work and let it work fairly. And secondly, I have confidence in the honor and integrity of my son, and if the system finds he's done something wrong he will be the first to step up and do what's right.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/01/world.main_headline: Summit in Washington;   Seoul and Tokyo See Major Shift In Coming Gorbachev-Roh Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/01/world.print_headline: Summit in Washington;   Seoul and Tokyo See Major Shift In Coming Gorbachev-Roh Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/01/world.body_text: **********South Korean and Japanese officials said today that the surprise meeting next week between Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader striving to rebuild a collapsing economy, and Roh Tae Woo, a former general who reversed his country's four-decade-long rejection of dealings with the Communist world, symbolizes the beginning of the biggest shift in northeast Asia's power relationships since the end of the Korean War. **********At the meeting in San Francisco next week, the two men are widely expected to agree to establish diplomatic relations between the two nations in the near future, paving the way for broad economic ties. That move seems bound to further isolate North Korea and its enigmatic leader, Kim Il Sung, high-ranking aides to Mr. Roh said today. **********But the initiative also places tremendous pressure on Japan, the region's economic giant, to abandon its continuing unwillingness to join the flow of newly warmed relations with the Soviets. Already Japanese business executives and politicians are speaking openly of their fear that the United States and South Korea will develop a tremendous head start in penetrating the Soviet market, and that Japan will lose a chance to become integrated into one of the world's largest economies. **********Two South Korean newspapers reported tonight that South Korea is considering a $4 billion low-interest loan to the Soviet Union and the establishment of direct telecommunications lines. Also, Reuters reported from Beijing that China and the Soviet Union were planning high-level talks on June 10 in Beijing on how to handle Korean peninsula issues. **********Seoul Hails Meeting **********Until three years ago, South Koreans involved in any contacts with the Communist world could easily be prosecuted in criminal court, and often were. **********But in Seoul today, the announcement of the San Francisco meeting was hailed by the Government as the culmination of a Government strategy begun with the 1988 Seoul Olympics to turn its remarkable economic boom in the 1980's to political advantage in this decade. **********It began with the establishment of diplomatic relations with Hungary in September 1988, and has been fueled by an increasing number of officially sanctioned business deals and the visit to Moscow two months ago of Kim Young Sam, the longtime opposition leader who has joined Mr. Roh's camp. **********The San Francisco meeting, however, will be the first ever between South Korean and Soviet leaders. In restoring that relationship, Mr. Roh hopes to restore the prestige of his presidency, battered in recent months by a spring of violent strikes and a damaging economic slowdown. **********But it also vindicates a controversial policy, one that many of Mr. Roh's army colleagues viewed with suspicion. **********''We knew that we would have to pressure North Korea from three directions,'' said Lee Hong Koo, Mr. Roh's special assistant for political affairs and, until two months ago, the country's Minister for National Unification. ''The first was from our own talks with the North. The second is from the United States and other Western nations. But the third was to build pressure from North Korea's nominal allies. Now the United States, the Soviet Union and South Korea are joining forces to persuade the North to engaged in a new kind of constructive relationship.'' **********Relations May Sour **********Over the next few months, however, both sides seem to be bracing for that relationship to sour, perhaps dramatically. Western diplomats say they expect Kim Il Sung's Government to lash out, not least because the Soviets are their primary supplier of aid and military support. **********''Initially, North Korea will be in shock and full of bitter resentment,'' said Kim Dal Choong, president of the Institute of East and West Studies at Yonsei University. ''But eventually the North will realize that it now has no choice but to pull out of its own closed relationships. It has no leverage against the Soviets.'' **********It is a particular blow to the North Koreans, said Han Sung Joo, a professor of political science at Korea University, that the meeting will take place in the United States, the country that keeps 44,000 troops within striking distance of Pyongyang. **********American, Soviet and Japanese diplomats in Asia all say they cannot predict what will happen when Mr. Kim dies, though they all view his probable successor, his 48-year old son Kim Jong Il, as an even bigger threat to regional security. **********''This is a country that is still far, far removed from any sign of democratization,'' Seiki Nishihiro, Japan's Deputy Minister of Defense, said in an interview this week. ''And Mr. Kim's son is, at best, an eccentric individual.'' He alluded to the kidnappings, bombings and other terrorist acts - including the downing of a South Korean airliner several years ago - that have been linked to the North Korean heir apparent. **********Warning From North Korea **********TOKYO, Friday, June 1 (Reuters) - North Korea said today that a scheduled meeting between President Gorbachev and President Roh would have ''a serious political consequence'' on the future of the divided Korean peninsula. **********It was Pyongyang's first reaction to news that Mr. Gorbachev was to meet the leader of its hated rival state, with whom Moscow still has no diplomatic ties. **********A Foreign Ministry spokesman, quoted by the official North Korean news agency monitored here, said: ''We consider that the President of the Soviet Union, an ally of ours, is quite able to analyze and judge what a serious political consequence will be entailed by his meeting with Roh Tae Woo, who is seeking only the split of Korea.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/04/world.main_headline: Liberia's Capital Calm; Food Aid Is Prepared
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/04/world.print_headline: Liberia's Capital Calm; Food Aid Is Prepared
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/04/world.body_text: **********Relief workers prepared today to distribute food to starving people in the capital after West African troops restored order, ending a three-day flare-up of factional fighting. **********On Friday, the faction led by Prince Johnson attacked remnants of the army of the slain President, Samuel K. Doe, ending nearly two months of relative peace in the capital and breaking a cease-fire signed last week by the three warring factions. Mr. Johnson said he had become impatient with the slow pace of a promised resettlement of the Doe forces outside the capital, where they had been harassing civilians.On Sunday, the five-nation West African peacekeeping force in Liberia turned its guns on Mr. Johnson's forces for the first time, forcing the rebels back outside the city. **********A spokesman for the West African intervention force said Mr. Johnson's attack was ill-considered, but "it has provided a good opportunity for us to demilitarize Monrovia and sort out these two factions." **********Nkem Agetua, press attache to the West African force's commander, Gen. Joshua Dogonyaro of Nigeria, said many of Mr. Johnson's men had been forced to retreat to a base at Caldwell, eight miles northeast of Monrovia.The West Africans were seen arresting more than 50 rebels outside the United States Embassy. No shots were fired then, but there was a shootout when the West Africans forced Mr. Johnson's men to disarm at a bridge linking the city to Monrovia's port. **********Mr. Agetua said that more than 40 of Mr. Johnson's troops were detained on Sunday. Other reports indicated the number might be near 200. **********Mr. Agetua put the death toll from the fighting at about a dozen in all. He said there were no civilian casualties in the operation. **********At least one civilian died during the weekend in an unrelated incident. Mr.Johnson's men shot a Liberian who worked as a guard at the British Embassy, at his home in a northern suburb after neighbors denounced the man as a former Doe soldier. Friends said he was a former policeman. **********All three warring sides have indiscriminately killed civilians, and civilian deaths are estimated at more than 10,000. Food Distribution Interrupted **********Monrovia's first food distribution in months was stopped last month because Doe soldiers immediately stole the food from civilians. **********The last large-scale food distribution took place three weeks ago. What little food is available for sale is too expensive for most people. **********The outbreak of fighting in Monrovia has diverted attention from the mainrebel faction, led by Charles Taylor. It remains in Monrovia, and until Mr. Taylor signed the cease-fire agreement on Wednesday, his was the only faction blocking peace. **********Mr. Agetua said the United States Ambassador, Peter De Vos, was trying to arrange a meeting among all the warring factions and leaders of an interim government chosen by Liberian exiles, which Mr. Taylor does not recognize. **********Mr. De Vos said he hoped the meeting would be held within two days, either in Monrovia or the neighboring state of Sierra Leone. The purpose of the meeting would be to arrange details of a cease-fire, such as the establishment of a camp to which Mr. Taylor's men could be confined, and the negotiation of a new interim government agreeable to all parties.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/14/world.main_headline: U.S. Policy on Cambodia Shifts a Bit
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/14/world.print_headline: U.S. Policy on Cambodia Shifts a Bit
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/14/world.body_text: **********In a break from past policy of shunning the Cambodian Government, the Bush Administration announced today that it had accepted an offer by Phnom Penh to cooperate in examining what could be the remains of Americans missing in action from the Vietnam War. **********The State Department announcement comes at a time when the Bush Administration is reviewing its policy of aiding a rebel insurgency fighting the Vietnamese-backed Government of Prime Minister Hun Sen. Washington is currently sending more than $15 million a year in covert and overt aid to two small non-Communist guerrilla organizations fighting in a loose coalition with the Communist Khmer Rouge against the Government. **********The policy review has been pushed by rising concern in Congress that the Bush Administration could inadvertently help the Khmer Rouge retake power. In the 1970's, the Khmer Rouge radically restructured Cambodian society, clearing the cities of intellectuals and professionals and breaking up families. More than a million people died under their rule. **********''We appreciate the support of the Phnom Penh authorities for this undertaking, which we consider an important humanitarian endeavor,'' said Richard A. Boucher, deputy spokesman of the State Department. Mr. Boucher said the Cambodian Government proposed that American forensic experts travel to Phnom Penh on July 24 to inspect an undetermined number of bodies there. #83 Americans Believed Lost Of the 2,302 American personnel still missing or unaccounted for from the Vietnam War, 83 were lost in Cambodia, the United States Government believes. **********Efforts to cooperate with the Cambodians to identify the bodies gained ground last February when Senator Charles S. Robb met with Mr. Hun Sen in Phnom Penh and expressed his interest in the issue. Since then, the Virginia Democrat and the Cambodian Prime Minister have exchanged a series of letters in which they worked out an arrangement that the Administration eventually agreed to. **********A senior State Department official said the Administration is treating the agreement to cooperate ''as a humanitarian process.'' **********But the official, who spoke on the condition that he not be identified, added that there ''would be some prospect of dealing with Hun Sen'' politically if the Cambodian leader showed greater flexibility in regional peace talks. **********Democratic Elections the Goal **********The Bush Administration hopes the talks will organize an interim government to rule until democratic elections can be held under international supervision. Such an interim government would either be administered by the United Nations or by a coalition consisting of the three guerrilla groups and the current Government. **********The announcement appeared to ease the rising tension between Congress and the Administration on the Cambodia issue. Rep. Chester Atkins, Democrat of Massachusetts, said, ''I am just delighted they are sending over this team.'' **********Mr. Atkins, who is a leading critic of the Administration's Cambodia policy, said he hoped the new cooperation between Washington and Phnom Penh would ''create a better environment for relations between our two countries.'' **********In a related development, Vice President Dan Quayle called on Vietnam to step up its efforts to account for American soldiers missing since the war. **********The Vice President, speaking at the annual meeting of the National League of POW/MIA Families, said the Vietnamese Government ''must realize that cooperation now, to clear up this issue of tremendous national concern, can remove the last vestige of the war and lay the groundwork for improved relations with the context of a comprehensive settlement in Cambodia.'' **********He characterized his speech as ''an important message, a message Hanoi should understand'' so that the two nations ''can move forward together toward a day when relations can be normal.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/04/busin.main_headline: Business and Health; The Squeeze On Drugstores
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/04/busin.print_headline: Business and Health; The Squeeze On Drugstores
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/04/busin.body_text: **********ALTHOUGH few doctors make house calls, many drugstores still deliver prescriptions to the homes of elderly customers. Scrambling to retain customer loyalty in the highly competitive retail pharmacy business, many drugstores specialize in advice and services. Eighty-five percent have also purchased computer systems that cost $10,000 and up, and some even have satellite links to keep supplies and insurers' payments flowing. **********The McKesson Corporation's PCS pharmacy card unit, for example, operates a national electronic claims-processing network. An identification card with a magnetic stripe is passed like a credit card through a $200 device, which quickly tells the druggist what the customer's health plan pays for. The bill goes electronically to a data processing center in Scottsdale, Ariz., which pays the pharmacies every two weeks. **********Prompt payment is vital to the nation's 55,000 pharmacies, for their pretax profit margins have fallen to 3 percent from 5.5 percent in the 1960's. Pharmacists are being squeezed by insurers, which increasingly insist on price discounts. Insurer guidelines on prescribing drugs are followed by about 22 percent of all office-based doctors, and the number is growing, said John Schaetzl, vice president of Scott-Levin Associates, a consulting firm in Newtown, Pa., that surveys physicians. **********As retailing categories overlap and blur, retail druggists have had to compete with big discount chains like K Mart and Wal-Mart Stores, each with 1,000 or more pharmacies; mail-order pharmacy services, and supermarket chains, which are accustomed to even lower profit margins, based onmoving products off the shelf faster than drugstores do. And in the front of their stores, the druggists compete with the health and beauty aids sections of groceries, convenience stores, variety stores and specialty discount stores. **********But the pharmacy business can also be difficult for such competitors. Joseph Thomas 3d, an economist at Purdue University, said the expenses in operating a pharmacy "are very different from operating a grocery." He added, "You need pharmacists, people with knowledge and time, willing to answer questions about over-the-counter products." A sign in the West Main Pharmacy, an independent store in Penns Grove, N.J., says, "Please ask our pharmacists questions before you purchase over-the-counter drugs." **********"We foresee gross margins in the pharmacy business continuing to drop," said David D. Bernauer, vice president and treasurer of the Walgreen Company, which is based in Deerfield, Ill. "The bottom line to the whole thing is: Who can most efficiently distribute that prescription to the customer?" Walgreen stores, which deal with 800 insurance plans, are linked by satellite to a computer center in Mount Prospect, Ill. "In five seconds, we check the patient's eligibility and other parameters like which drugs are covered, the number of days' supply, whether generics are mandatory," he said. "The system greatly reduces the percentage of rejects and dishonored claims and the cost of shipping paperwork." Sales at Walgreen's 1,575 stores are growing by 20 percent annually, reflecting rising drug prices and the addition of 110 stores this year, Mr. Bernauer said. **********To compete with the chains, independents like the West Main Pharmacy work on customer service. "We can't always match the dollar figure," said Louis A. Mitchell, the owner, who is in the store daily from 9 A.M. to 9 P.M. "My main concern is that the patient has to be satisfied that what they are doing is based on good sound advice." **********Don Moore, an independent pharmacist who is president of the Moore Drugstore in Kokomo, Ind., maintains a staff nurse for consultations. **********"All retail drugstores, whether they are independent or chains, are being squeezed much more today," said David Malmberg, vice president for strategic planning with McKesson's wholesale unit, the nation's largest drug wholesaler. **********Insurers that pay most of the cost of drugs directly to the store may account for 75 percent of the prescription business by the end of the decade, said Robert J. Mandelbaum, a pharmacist who is a vice president of the 1,136-store Revco chain, based in Twinsburg, Ohio. Revco is adding patient counseling areas to its stores. **********Some druggists are developing niche markets like joint ventures with hospitals to supply equipment for home health care. And Fay's, based in Liverpool, N.Y., which has 185 drugstores, is opening free-standing operations just to supply nursing homes. "They are a large growth end of our prescription business," said Henry A. Panasci, Fay's chairman.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/03/busin.main_headline: A Call to End Phone Fraud
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/03/busin.print_headline: A Call to End Phone Fraud
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/03/busin.body_text: **********Federal and state officials urged Congress today to expand regulations to combat telemarketing fraud, which costs consumers as much as $1 billion a year. **********The chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, Janet Steiger, and Nevada's attorney general, Brian McKay, said they support increased authority for the F.T.C. and state attorneys general to regulate telemarketers and to sue in Federal court when there is fraud. **********American consumers lose as much as $1 billion a year from telephone scams, in which false information is given about the quality or value of products or services sold, Ms. Steiger told the Senate Commerce Committee's consumer subcommittee. **********Fraudulent telemarketers sell products ranging from pens to vitamins and frequently prey on the elderly and uneducated, Mr. McKay said, adding, ''Telemarketing fraud is one of the most serious consumer problems present today.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/13/busin.body_text: **********The H. J. Heinz Company has signed its chief executive, Anthony J. F. O'Reilly, to a five-year contract that includes options to buy four million shares of stock, company officials said Friday. **********''We see it as a way to put a handcuff on Tony O'Reilly and keep him at Heinz,'' said James McDonald, a board member who heads the compensation committee for the food giant based in Pittsburgh. Under the agreement, Mr. O'Reilly cannot exercise the option to buy the stock until 1995. He would earn a profit on the stock only if the price exceeds the option's exercise price of $29.87. **********''This does not pay off unless the stock does,'' Mr. McDonald said. ''Unless the company continues to perform, it can't be a good deal for him.'' **********Heinz stock closed Friday at $32.50, down 50 cents a share, on the New York Stock Exchange. **********The board struck the agreement to keep the 54-year old chairman and chief executive at Heinz, which has grown steadily during his 11-year tenure into a $6 billion company. **********Mr. McDonald said Mr. O'= **********Reilly had become increasingly attractive to other companies because of his record. **********Other terms of the contract, which must be approved by shareholders at the annual meeting next month, remain the same as last year, when Mr. O'Reilly earned $534,688 in salary and compensation and about $1.4 million in bonuses.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/02/busin.main_headline: Company News;   I.B.M. in Deal to Shed Its Typewriter Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/02/busin.print_headline: Company News;   I.B.M. in Deal to Shed Its Typewriter Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/02/busin.body_text: **********The International Business Machines Corporation confirmed today that it would spin off its low-technology businesses - typewriters, keyboards and personal printers - into a new subsidiary. Clayton & Dubilier Inc., a New York leveraged buyout firm, is to become the primary owner of the new unit, the company said. **********Terms of the proposed deal were not disclosed, but the value is reported to be $2 billion to $2.5 billion. Analysts estimate worldwide sales of I.B.M.'s low-tech products at $2 billion a year and say that the operations are profitable. **********''Today's action further advances I.B.M.'s transformation,'' said John F. Akers, the company's chairman and chief executive. ''We believe the creation of a new subsidiary better positions information products - a strong business that represents the best traditions of I.B.M. - for long-term success.'' **********I.B.M., based in Armonk, N.Y., will market selected printer products made by the new company under the I.B.M. name and will provide service for all printer products. The new company will also offer typewriters, supplies and printers with the I.B.M. logotype through authorized dealers and other resale channels. **********I.B.M.'s strategy is to focus on its core computer business and pare other enterprises. **********Clayton & Dubilier said it thought it could make the business grow by broadening the product line, expanding marketing and creating a sales force dedicated solely to the products. **********''Non-core businesses tend to be starved both monetarily and intellectually,'' said Joseph L. Rice 3d, Clayton & Dubilier's president. ''We have been very successful at taking these stepchildren out of the large business'' and building them up. **********The deal should close by the end of the year, Mr. Rice said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/16/world.body_text: **********Indian security forces clashed repeatedly with Muslim militants today in the capital of the northern state of Jammu and Kashmir, making dozens of arrests. **********The clashes come at a time of growing tension between Muslim Pakistan and predominantly Hindu India over the Kashmir region. The two countries have accused each other of trying to provoke another war. **********The tensions were evident in the angry statements of political factions in the divided region. The leader of a fundamentalist Hindu party warned today that Pakistan would ''cease to exist'' if it began a war with India. **********L. K. Advani, head of the Bharatiya Janata Party, a major force in the governing coalition of Prime Minister V. P. Singh of India, told a crowd in Bombay that Pakistani interference in Kashmir should be recognized as ''undeclared war by Pakistan,'' the United News of India reported. Mr. Advani urged the central Government to send ''a strong signal'' to Islamabad. **********Members of the Indian police reported no casualties in at least five clashes today in the Kashmiri capital, Srinagar. But witnesses said that the security forces shot and seriously wounded a 12-year-old girl on a ferryboat on Lake Dul, outside Srinagar. Witnesses speculated that the boat was violating curfew regulations by taking on passengers. **********Police officials said that 42 suspected militants were detained during the clashes today, but Indian news services reported as many as 170 arrests. **********Among those arrested, the police said, were seven area commanders of the Jammu and Kashmir Liberation Front, one of the Muslim groups leading the movement to establish a separate nation in the Vale of Kashmir.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/30/busin.body_text: **********For the nations of Eastern Europe, freedom may be far dirtier than they expected. **********The nations' desire to curb their dependence on Soviet oil and gas, a legacy of the region's satellite status, is colliding with another goal - cleaning up the environment by burning less of its native dirty brown coal. **********Eastern Europe's energy predicament has become increasingly obvious in recent weeks, officials in the region and Western analysts say. Moscow has told its former satellites that it wants to be paid for oil and gas in hard currency, rather than bartered goods, turning what had been an energy subsidy into a burden. Then last month, the Soviets unleashed their ''oil weapon'' in response to independence moves in the republic of Lithuania. **********A Reminder of Dependence **********The Russian strategy in Lithuania - sending out valve turners rather than tanks - has reminded the countries of Eastern Europe that they are also very dependent on the Soviet Union, which supplies 80 percent of the region's energy imports. Even though the dependence is to some degree mutual, since the Soviets need a market for their exports, Moscow already sells large amounts of oil and gas to the West for hard currency and could sell much more, experts say. **********Moscow's tough new approach to energy exports to Eastern Europe could also seriously hamper the region's efforts to clean up pollution. Since the Eastern European nations are short of hard currency, the new Soviet requirement that oil be paid for with cash may give the countries of the region no choice but to become even more dependent on brown coal, their main domestic fuel. **********Higher Fuel Prices **********Eastern Europe is at the end of a vast umbilical cord reaching from western Siberia and the Ural Mountains, feeding oil and gas, and sometimes electricity, to Poland, East Germany, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Romania and Bulgaria. **********Even the uranium for nuclear reactors in Eastern Europe comes from the Soviet Union. Moreover, officials in Eastern Europe say Moscow has told them it plans to raise fuel prices sharply in January and charge a portion of the cost in hard currencies, like United States dollars or West German marks, which can be readily exchanged on international markets. **********Soviet cutbacks in oil deliveries may drain Eastern Europe of its reserves of hard currencies by forcing the nations to buy OPEC oil on the open market, as some have already done. In addition, it may deprive them of an indirect source of hard-currency revenue; Christina House, an independent oil consultant, says some Eastern European countries have resold Soviet oil at market prices to Western countries, a practice that has annoyed Moscow. **********The energy changes in the East are important to the West, because for years the availability of oil - and hence its price - has been heavily affected by huge Soviet exports. The Soviet Union is the world's largest oil producer, although its production is sharply dropping, partly because of continuing unrest in Baku, a petroleum center. Ms. House said that if the trend set in the first quarter of this year continues, the decline by the end of the year will be 500,000 barrels a day, to less than 12 million barrels a day. **********Suddenly, the new economic ministers of Eastern Europe are confronting a host of problems their Communist predecessors never had to face. They have to grapple not only with the uncertainties of dealing in the world energy market, but also with possibly seeking new buyers for a wide range of goods that had long been swapped with the Soviet Union for oil. **********''We knew this was coming, but we needed more time,'' a Czech official said, noting that much industry in Czechoslovakia and other nations was geared to supplying the Soviet Union goods in exchange for oil, rather than selling products on the world market. These outdated industries were also geared to using inordinately large quantities of cheap oil. **********''We are in the middle of very complicated negotiations with Moscow,'' said Laszlo Lang, deputy director of the Hungarian Institute for International Relations. But, he said, Hungary's dependence on the Soviet market for industrial exports was perhaps an even greater problem than the country's dependence on Soviet energy. **********In fact, the region's total energy needs are not large by the standards of Western industrial countries. Individually, the Eastern European countries are energy midgets, experts say, so even large-percentage changes in production and consumption will have a small global effect. Combined, the former satellites use only about as much oil and gas as does West Germany, and about one-seventh as much as the United States. Total energy consumption from all sources is about one-fourth that of the United States. **********Consumption Likely to Jump **********Clearly, the countries in revolution have grand energy plans. From Albania, which bans private ownership of cars, and Romania, where the deposed Ceausescu regime sharply reduced energy use to cut imports and raise exports, paying off foreign debt, Eastern Europeans aspire to use more. **********The region's dominant fuel, coal, is burned with virtually no environmental-control equipment, and sulfur and ash emissions are so high, especially in winter, that they cause widespread smog and chronic respiratory diseases. Soot and sulfur have already blackened cities and killed forests. **********Yet even environmentally conscious leaders, including President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia, contend that for now coal remains indispensable not only as the cheapest form of heat and electricity, but also as a source of tens of thousands of jobs. **********Distrust of Nuclear Power **********Nuclear power once looked like a clean substitute, but it has been bitterly opposed since the Chernobyl accident in 1986. **********''Nuclear plants everywhere have become associated with centralized, secretive and even repressive power, and this feeling is very strong in Eastern Europe,'' said a Western expert who recently finished an energy fact-finding mission in the region's capitals. ''No politician here is willing to push hard for nuclear energy, even Western nuclear energy,'' the expert said. **********East Germany, in fact, has been pressed by Bonn into shutting down two nuclear reactors for safety repairs, and more may be closed when the West German inspection is completed. **********In a study presented last month at a seminar on Eastern Europe organized by the International Research Center for Energy and Economic Development, at the University of Colorado, John Etling Treat, a vice president of Booz Allen & Hamilton Inc., found that the energy supplied to the region by the Soviet Union accounts for 25 percent of its consumption. **********Possible Energy Sources **********The new governments of Eastern Europe would nonetheless like to move away from dependence on the Soviets. **********Poland is discussing with Algeria a proposal to import liquefied natural gas through the Baltic Sea. Afsaneh Mashayekhi, chief of Natural Gas Development at the World Bank, said the Poles would like to build the tankers for the Algerians in Gdansk. **********The Poles are also discussing the purchase of natural gas from Norway, which would require extending a pipeline from Denmark. **********Currently, Mr. Treat said, Poland imports all of its oil and half of its gas, and has pipeline links only to the east. Czechoslovakia has the same problem, he noted, and is also landlocked. **********Hungary, another landlocked country, has already begun to turn around the situation, quite literally. In January it reversed the flow in a pipeline that used to carry petroleum to tankers at Rijeka, Yugoslavia, on the Adriatic Sea. Now it carries products in the other direction. **********Hungary, which gets 28 percent of its electricity from the Soviet Union, is discussing linking its electric grid with France's. ''The Russian grid is not very stable,'' said one official in Hungary, ''and they can drain electricity off our net. We need a safeguard and linkup with the West.'' **********Western companies are lining up to sell generating equipment to the East, but this, too, will require capital. At present, the electrical grids of Eastern and Western Europe do not mesh because of technical differences, making power transfers cumbersome. **********Conservation and Efficiency **********Still, Eastern Europe's best chance of reducing energy dependence on the Soviet Union in the near future may be greater conservation and more efficient use of fuel. There is considerable room for improvement: Jochem H. Mohnfeld, head of the oil industry division of the Federal Economics Ministry in Bonn, says West Germany uses precisely half as much energy as East Germany for each $1,000 worth of goods and services produced. **********Mr. Treat's study showed that Romania uses more than one-third more energy per unit of production than does the United States, and more than double what Japan uses. Travelers to the region report that homes in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union lack basic energy-saving devices like thermostats. **********But improving efficiency would not stop growth. West Germany uses 2.5 times more energy per capita than East Germany. Yet as the two Germanys are unified, the expected increase in East German economic activity and living standards is expected to raise energy consumption. And more advanced economies burn a higher proportion of oil and less coal. For example, West Germany's energy consumption is 42 percent oil, compared with 13 percent in East Germany. **********But another energy option is coming into focus: local production. Thomas O'Connor, senior petroleum engineer for the World Bank, said, ''The technology they've got access to is state-of-the-art for the 1950's, and they can't find all the subtle stuff.'' But with computers and seismic techniques, he said, several Eastern European nations could find enough small deposits of oil and gas to make a big difference in their level of self-sufficiency. **********Yet shopping abroad for that technology is difficult for the nations of Eastern Europe, and not just because they lack hard currency. For example, Ms. Mashayekhi said Poland was finding that after a half-century of energy policy made in Moscow, it had no legal framework for Western-style oil and gas exploration and production. There is no one, she said, who is familiar with negotiating energy deals.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/16/busin.body_text: **********Ansett Airlines has ordered 10 Airbus Industrie A321 aircraft for delivery between 1995 and 1999, the General Electric Company said Wednesday. G.E. said in a statement that CFM International, which it owns jointly with Snecma of France, had won the order to supply engines for the planes.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/02/busin.main_headline: Business Scene;   Times Are Tough For U.S. Builders
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/02/busin.print_headline: Business Scene;   Times Are Tough For U.S. Builders
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/02/busin.body_text: **********THE big new scare for the already sluggish American economy is coming from the construction industry, particularly home construction. Building loans are hard to get, customers are scarce and the unemployment rate among the nation's construction workers is 10.3 percent, higher than in any other industry. **********Even successful builders, like Frank Wimer, president of the Wimer Construction Company of Pittsburgh, are feeling the pinch. Mr. Wimer built 12 suburban homes last year, selling them as they were built at prices upward of $300,000. But now he has five more under construction and none has been sold yet, a rare and unnerving experience for Mr. Wimer. ''I am not going to start more homes until I sell these,'' he said. **********His caution means that Wimer Construction's 1990 output will be, at best, only eight or nine homes - a 25 percent decline from last year. Mr. Wimer's behavior helps to explain why single-family home construction across the nation plunged from January through May to an annual rate of only 900,000 building starts, down from one million in 1989. Not since the recessionary early 1980's has home building been so weak. **********Still, Mr. Wimer is luckier than many other builders. The nationwide surge in defaults on real estate loans has made lenders extra wary about financing anyone who is not a good credit risk. With 42 years as contractor, Mr. Wimer's two long-time lenders, the Landmark Savings and Loan Association and the Pittsburgh National Bank, continue to give him loans. But they charge him more. **********''We used to get construction loans without upfront fees, but now we have to pay 1.5 percentage points,'' he said. In addition, the interest rate that Mr. Wimer pays on loans has risen to an annual rate that is two percentage points above the prime rate, or a total of 13 percent. Until this year, Mr. Wimer paid only 1.5 percentage points over prime. **********The hard times did not pop up overnight. The construction of offices and other commercial buildings began to decline in 1988, and soon afterward apartment construction also shrank sharply. Both were victims of overbuilding in the 1980's and a backlog of unsold units. But the building of single-family homes remained robust, and this category is the industry's largest, representing 30 percent of all construction. **********Then last fall, single-family home construction began to collapse, with building starts declining by 10 percent since October. The Northeast and the South accounted for most of the fall. ''The only thing that had held the construction game together was single-family housing and now it, too, is in the junk pile,'' said George A. Christie, chief economist for the F. W. Dodge division of McGraw-Hill Inc., which collects industry data. **********Many explanations are offered for the hard times. The post ''baby boom'' generation is providing fewer home buyers. The sluggish economy has made people concerned about job security and therefore reluctant to go into debt for new homes. And the savings and loan crisis has been hugely destructive, on two counts. **********The main one is that savings institutions are a principal supplier of construction loans. Not only have 1,000 of these lenders failed and disappeared, but a law enacted by Congress in August greatly restricted the amount that a savings and loan can lend to a single developer. **********The builders could turn to other lenders, like insurance companies and pension funds. But Francis H. Schott, chief economist at the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, notes that insurance companies seek longer lending periods than those provided by construction and mortgage financing. And pension funds often restrict construction and home loans to 5 percent of their portfolios. **********Aside from the credit crunch, the Federal Government is trying to sell tens of thousands of homes and other buildings, an effort that depresses already-weak real estate prices and helps to kill the demand for new construction. The Government acquired the property from failed savings and loan companies that had originally seized the buildings from borrowers who had defaulted. **********Inevitably, the construction industry's troubles will show up as weakness in the gross national product. The G.N.P. measures the national wealth that is created through the production of goods and services. The construction industry, with five million workers, accounts for 7.5 percent of this wealth creation, and as current construction is completed - without new building to replace it - construction's contribution to G.N.P. will shrink. **********Stephen S. Roach, a senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company, estimates that the construction slump will result in a decline of two-tenths of 1 percent in the G.N.P. in the second half of the year, a not inconsiderable hit at a time when the G.N.P. is growing at an annual rate of less than 2 percent. **********Could the construction slump tilt the economy into recession? Most economists do not think so. But given the credit problems and the big supply of unsold homes (an eight-month backlog, according to a Goldman Sachs estimate), the construction industry is likely to remain a weak sister for months to come.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/06/busin.main_headline: A Corporate Doctor Is Getting Fewer Calls
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/06/busin.print_headline: A Corporate Doctor Is Getting Fewer Calls
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/06/busin.body_text: **********There was a time when Victor H. Palmieri was flying so high he would have balked if clients tried to call the shots. Now, he'd be grateful if they would simply call. **********At a time when businesses are failing by the dozens and the savings and loan industry is in desperate shape, the phones at the Palmieri Company, a 45-person turnaround boutique , should be buzzing. Mr. Palmieri, after all, is among America's best-known workout experts, having handled two of the six largest non-bank bankruptcies of record. **********He vaulted to prominence in the 1970's after nursing the non-railroad assets of the Penn Central Transportation Company back to health and led a daunting reorganization a decade later of the Baldwin-United Corporation. **********But his colleagues in the workout patch, who salvage financially troubled companies, say that Mr. Palmieri has been conspicuously absent from the scene. ''I haven't seen him on any major transactions recently and he should be,'' said Stan Ross, the managing partner of Kenneth Leventhal & Company, a Los Angeles-based accounting firm with expertise in real estate workouts. **********Mr. Palmieri says that he is simply between deals. ''This is a time in between big workouts,'' he said. ''It's not the most exciting time as far as I'm concerned.'' **********In a business where lenders and creditors can ill afford to bring in a savior with a mediocre record and where new stars are always rising, one bad deal can wipe out years of accomplishments. His workout colleagues say that Mr. Palmieri's undoing, was Crazy Eddie, a home electronics retailer that an investor group led by Mr. Palmieri won control of in late 1987. **********Within two years, the company had been liquidated, and the group's entire $13.5 million investment had been lost. Though Mr. Palmieri has sued the former management for looting the company of $65 million in inventory, the debacle has tarnished his reputation and caused his peers to re-evaluate some of his earlier triumphs. **********He is hardly the first company doctor to lose a patient. Sanford C. Sigoloff, his biggest competitor, stumbled in trying to rebuild the Wickes Companies, a retailer, while Q. T. Wiles, a fixer of high-tech companies, badly botched an attempted rescue of Miniscribe, a disk-drive maker. **********Mr. Sigoloff has been given a second chance with the United States department store operations of the Hooker Corporation, which until recently owned Bonwit Teller. But Mr. Wiles has gone into virtual seclusion. **********At age 60, Mr. Palmieri is eager to suit up again. Though Mr. Palmieri was mentioned recently as someone who might help untangle the affairs of Donald J. Trump, the New York developer who narrowly averted bankruptcy last month, advisers to Mr. Trump said that Mr. Palmieri was never in the running. **********Mr. Palmieri insists that Mr. Trump's lenders sought to involve him, but that the developer would not allow it because of past differences over the Penn Central deal. **********Clients Are Smaller **********In the meantime, the Palmieri Company, which has five offices besides its New York headquarters, has been accepting smaller clients. It advises Parelle Sportive, a Los Angeles maker of women's golf attire. Until last month, Mr. Palmieri was also the chief executive of the Chronar Corporation, a maker of solar energy panels whose stock fell to about 63 cents, from $6.25, in the 10 months that he served. **********But he resigned because Chronar's technology was not ready for mass-marketing and the company could no longer afford his $600,000 annual fee. ''I told the board I'm charging you half what I usually charge and twice what you can afford,'' he said. **********Mr. Palmieri's route to the workout business was circuitous. After completing Stanford University law school with top academic honors, Mr. Palmieri, the son of an Italian engineer who emigrated to this country in the 1920's, worked for five years in the Los Angeles office of O'Melveny & Myers. He brought in one of the law firm's largest clients by showing the same unabashed opportunism that would prove handy later in his career. When Mr. Palmieri learned that Edwin Janss Jr., a Los Angeles real estate investor whom he met at a party, had a tax problem, he quietly called his uncle, a real estate tax lawyer, for ideas. Mr. Palmieri wrote Mr. Janss what he calls ''a brilliant memo'' adding, ''I never told anyone who my collaborator was.'' **********In 1959, he joined the Janss Investment Corporation. He and his former client developed ski resorts in Colorado and Idaho as well as land in Southern California. It was at Janss where Mr. Palmieri made enough money to be able to quit and go into government. **********He served on the National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders, known as the Kerner Commission, , in 1967 with John V. Lindsay, but became disappointed when President Johnson ignored the group's findings, refusing to help fuel Mr. Lindsay's Presidential aspirations. **********Mr. Palmieri whisked his family abroad for a year of travel to sort out his options. On return in 1969, he cofounded the American Learning Corporation Inc., a company that aspired to teach Americans how to read. He created the Palmieri Company, the consulting boutique where he is still the chairman and sole owner, as a way to pay the bills until the Learning Corporation took off. **********As it turned out, Mr. Palmieri sold the reading centers to Encyclopaedia Britannica Inc. in 1985. It was consulting that actually put his name on the map. **********Call That Changed His Life **********The phone call that changed his life came in 1970. The investment bankers advising the bankrupt Penn Central suggested he step in and run the Great Southwest Corporation, the real estate investment arm of the Pennsylvania Company, a Penn Central subsidiary. **********His mop-up at Great Southwestern was so impressive that the Penn Central board gave him the Pennsylvania Company to run and had him oversee the divestiture of Penn Central's non-rail holdings. Mr. Palmieri and his associates, who reportedly collected $55 million in monthly fees and performance bonuses from the job, won high praise for their work. But some bankers now say that it was real estate appreciation and tax-loss carry-forwards that carried the day. **********Mr. Palmieri lived for the big deals and his next one came in 1983, when he was hired to keep Baldwin-United, a piano maker that had plunged pell-mell into insurance and financial services, out of bankruptcy. Mr. Palmieri thought he could devise a restructuring that would preserve the company's core assets. **********But three months later, the $9 billion juggernaut became the largest non-bank bankruptcy ever, a title that it lost to Texaco Inc. in 1987. A much smaller Baldwin-United, stripped of its core assets, crawled out of bankruptcy in 1986. Mr. Palmieri earned his monthly fees, but his stock options looked as if they would expire worthless and he traded them in for a $5 million cash bonus. **********''People don't understand how complicated it was,'' Mr. Palmieri said, disputing the widespread assessment that his performance at Baldwin was only so-so. ''You were dealing with financial assets, and in Pennsy you were dealing with hard assets like real estate and amusement parks. So I think Baldwin was a good deal more of a miracle than Penn Central.'' **********Star Is Forgiven **********The market, however, seemed to forgive its star turnaround artist. Rather than coming in as a hired gun with little more than his fees and reputation at risk, Mr. Palmieri decided to alter his operating style, and raised $103 million in 1985 through Oppenheimer & Company, the Wall Street investment house, to invest in underperforming companies. **********In its four years of operation, the fund made three investments, including its ill-fated stake in Crazy Eddie . In late 1988, Mr. Palmieri disbanded the fund, citing a lack of investment opportunities. He returned $56 million of the seed capital that remained in the fund to his partners. **********Mr. Palmieri still contends that the workout fund was ahead of its time. But several investment bankers who recall bringing deals to the fund say that Mr. Palmieri was too picky. They also criticize him for amassing an unsolicited stake in Crazy Eddie instead of pursuing a deal in a company where he would have had an opportunity to review the books and conduct research before committing the fund's money. **********A Calm Period **********The last 10 months have been unusually calm for the Palmieri Company. Sporting a deep tan that has been burnished by twice-weekly tennis games, Mr. Palmieri explains that he wanted to put the Crazy Eddie episode behind him before taking another large case.''Now I'm in a position to take on a big project, and we're actively looking for one,'' he said. **********In the meantime, he spends his days sprucing up Sports Specialties, a maker of caps that the Oppenheimer fund bought for $19 million, and prospecting for work among the savings and loan rubble. **********Mr. Palmieri is also considering returning to teaching. ''I've been talking to a couple of institutions about doing another semester,'' he said. ''But it all depends on whether another big wounded corporate crisis comes along.''
