https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/10/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: From the start, it sounded as surreal as a Kafka novel. Within weeks of assuming power in late December, Czechoslovakia's new Government selected a singular trade emissary: Frank Zappa, an American best known as an absurdist 1960's and 70's rock-and-roll music auteur, the creator of such albums as ''Weasels Ripped My Flesh. **********From the start, it sounded as surreal as a Kafka novel. Within weeks of assuming power in late December, Czechoslovakia's new Government selected a singular trade emissary: Frank Zappa, an American best known as an absurdist 1960's and 70's rock-and-roll music auteur, the creator of such albums as ''Weasels Ripped My Flesh.'' Zappa and his satiric, subversive recordings were a source of inspiration to Czechoslovakia's artistic and intellectual underground - which, from the Prague Spring of 1968 until the revolution last fall, had remained in a 60's time warp. **********In January Zappa was invited to a luncheon at Hradcany Castle with VaclavHavel, a playwright who counts the musician's 1967 ''Absolutely Free'' among his favorite rock albums. The 49-year-old Zappa, aside from his music, is a film maker, guest host on talk shows and outspoken opponent of the Parents' Music Resource Center, a group that advocates warning labels on rock-and-roll albums. He was in Eastern Europe to work on a Financial News Network documentary on Soviet-American business opportunities. **********The Havel-Zappa meeting included several of the president's economic ministers, who listened as the cult hero bubbled with suggestions about coal-burning technology and cellular telephone networks. That evening Minister of Culture Milan Lukes announced on television that Zappa would represent Czechoslovakia to the West on matters of trade, culture and tourism - an arrangement later confirmed in a letter to Zappa by Havel's vice-minister of finance. **********Off went Zappa, brimming with ideas and granting press interviews in which he spoke of possible deals with McDonnell-Douglas, a pet food manufacturer and an Australian tractor company. But within six weeks the Czech leadership reduced Zappa's role to an unofficial cultural emissary. **********Havel aides quietly concede they may have gotten carried away in the revolutionary zeal of the moment. ''We like Frank Zappa, but he is not authorized to negotiate any trade agreements for our government,'' says Michael Zantovsky, Havel's press secretary. **********Zappa, in turn, notes that the sudden Czech coolness followed the February visit to Prague by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3rd, and that Baker's wife, Susan, is a co-founder of the Parents' Music Resource Center. **********Although Zappa was invited to visit Prague again for this summer's presidential election, he already has sent his regrets. ''I really support Havel's idea of establishing a government that has an esthetic, as well as an economic, ethic,'' says Zappa. ''But right now the best thing I can do for them is to stay away.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/15/busin.body_text: **********The economic crisis in the Soviet Union is worsening and forcing President Mikhail S. Gorbachev toward a faster and more radical reorganization of the system, say Western and Soviet economists at an international conference here. **********Trying to convert the Soviet Union to a market-oriented economy in slow stages, said A. W. Clausen, former president of the World Bank and now chairman of BankAmerica, is ''like trying to extract a tooth slowly.'' **********Delegates to the conference, sponsored by the Stanford Research Institute, the Soviet Chamber of Commerce and Industry and Deutsche Bank, got a dim view of the results of perestroika thus far. Vladimir A. Tikhonov, president of the U.S.S.R. Union of Cooperatives, said the Soviet economy was ''falling apart.'' **********When asked about charges of corruption at many cooperatives, which he described as the enterprises closest to the Western model, Mr. Tikhonov replied: ''When a society is sick, its institutions are sick. When a mother is sick, her child is likely to be sick.'' **********Further G.N.P. Drop Expected **********Anders Aslund, a Swedish economist who is director of the Stockholm Institute of Soviet and Eastern European economies, said that despite Soviet estimates of continued slow growth, the economy was in ''a very serious crisis.'' He estimated that real gross national product fell 4 to 5 percent in 1989 and would plummet 8 to 10 percent this year. **********There are severe technical problems in estimating real Soviet G.N.P., because of the suppression of inflation by controls, the paying of under-the-counter prices and bribes, and the disappearance of goods from state stores selling at official prices. Until recently, most American experts on Soviet data have not accepted declines in real output as steep as those offered by Professor Aslund. **********But Ed A. Hewett of the Brookings Institution, a leading American expert on Soviet data, said at the conference that the Soviet economy was ''deteriorating at an alarming pace.'' There is no sign of an improvement in the quality of goods and no gain in productivity; the money supply is out of control, and the Soviet credit rating is at its lowest ebb, he said. **********The ''reforms'' made thus far, he added, are ''half-hearted,'' and entrepreneurs have still not been given authority to run their enterprises efficiently. ''Prices remain fixed, and fixed wrong,'' he said. **********The Soviet economists here did not dispute such assessments. Indeed, high politburo officials have been paying close attention to the analyses made at this meeting. Among the Americans here are Senator Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey and former Senators Edmund S. Muskie of Maine and Gary Hart of Colorado, both now practicing law. **********Mr. Clausen saw some positive factors in the Soviet situation, especially the increased stress placed by Mr. Gorbachev and his key supporters on the need for a ''market orientation'' and a ''pluralistic society,'' which, he said, held hope for the future. But he warned that these positive elements were in danger of being overwhelmed by some strongly negative forces. **********The G.N.P. ''has turned negative,'' he said, ''and will remain so for the next two years. Soviet policy with respect to attracting foreign investment, he said, was ''unsatisfactory to date,'' and policies to stimulate joint ventures were ''not yet in place.'' **********Mr. Clausen said the Soviets did not seem to realize that foreign investors had ''real alternatives'' to investing in the Soviet Union, and particularly in Eastern Europe. He told the conference that he had been visiting European countries and asking investors which countries hold the greatest promise for them. ''The Soviet Union does not get many votes,'' he said. **********He said it was of the greatest importance that the people trust their Government, and that ''one essential underlies all issues: transparency, gaining the support of the people.'' **********'Not Pessimistic' **********Insisting that he was ''not pessimistic about the future of the U.S.S.R.,'' Mr. Clausen urged the Soviet leaders to ''move faster,'' and to concern themselves more with the social welfare. ''There is no social infrastructure in place,'' he said, to protect those hurt by loss of jobs and loss of income that could be expected to result from a radical change toward a market economy. **********Fears of such disuption have been delaying the Soviet Government's movement toward a freer economy. Soviet economists have been talking in terms of making the changes in stages, starting with the reduction of the enormous budget deficit, which V. K. Senchagov, chairman of the state committee on prices, said amounts to 165 billion rubles. **********There were indications here from Soviet economists that Mr. Gorbachev had distanced himself from the gradualism in the plan for economic reform presented by Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov. They said that during the last few years Mr. Gorbachev had focused on political reforms and had left the economic task to Mr. Ryzhkov and others, but was now dissatisfied with the results. Indeed, there was talk here that Mr. Ryzhkov would be replaced. **********Abel Aganbegyan, a Soviet economist who is credited with being a leading pioneer of perestroika, said he welcomed the transition to an executive presidency, in which Mr. Gorbachev would have greater powers, ''especially if he will pay attention to the economy.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/27/busin.print_headline: CONSUMER RATES; Fund Yields Are Mixed
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/27/busin.body_text: **********Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Market Fund Report were mixed for the fifth consecutive week ended yesterday, as tax-exempt funds rose and taxable funds held steady. **********Money fund managers said the year-end seasonal factors that normally affect short-term interest rates were dissipating, and that they expect the usual softening of short-term rates in January. **********Walter S. Frank, chief economist at IBC/Donoghue's, said short-term interest rates had already declined, and that he expected them to hold at current levels for a while. He said the drop in Treasury securities and other money market securities was being masked by seasonal factors, and that he expected significant declines in a couple of weeks.  Tax-Exempt Funds **********In the week ended yesterday, managers of tax-exempt money-market funds decreased the average number of days that they hold securities in their portfolios by one, to 55 days. Assets of such funds declined by $50 million, to $85.5 billion. **********The average seven-day tax-exempt compounded yield was up sharply for the week, reflecting an abundance in supply of municipal securities and a slack demand by investors. The average yield was 5.82 percent, up 32 basis points. The 30-day compounded average yield increased by 15 basis points, to 5.58 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. **********The current seven-day tax-exempt yield is equivalent to 8.15 pecent for investors in the 28 percent tax bracket, and 8.76 percent for investors in the 33 percent bracket. **********Among tax-exempt funds with assets of more than $100 million that are monitored by IBC/Donoghue's, the Evergreen Tax-Exempt Money Market fund produced the best return, with a 7.02 percent yield. The fund is managed by Evergreen Asset Management, Purchase, N.Y.  Taxable Assets Drop **********Assets on taxable funds fell by $1 billion, to $419.2 billion, with institutional funds down by $39 million, to $96.2 billion, and consumer funds down by the remainder, to $323 billion. Donoghue analysts said they saw a trend of small investors beginning to lock in current yields offered on certificates of deposits and Treasury securities. **********The average seven-day compounded taxable yield remained unchanged from the previous reporting week, at 7.42 percent, while the 30-day yield fell by 2 basis points, to 5.47 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/19/busin.main_headline: Trade Deficit of U.S. Worst in 2 1/2 Years
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/19/busin.print_headline: Trade Deficit of U.S. Worst in 2 1/2 Years
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/19/busin.body_text: **********The United States suffered the worst monthly trade deficit in two and a half years in October, an $11.6 billion imbalance that analysts said would make the early months of the recession worse than expected. **********The Commerce Department attributed much of the 24 percent jump in the trade deficit to higher foreign oil prices stemming from the Persian Gulf crisis. But there was also a big rise in car imports. **********The increase in car imports helped total imports jump to an all-time high and swamped a smaller rise in United States exports sales, which also hit a record high. Bleak Forecasts Lowered **********The bad trade news prompted some economists to lower their already bleak forecasts for overall economic performance in the current October-December quarter. **********Export growth and a narrowing trade deficit had been one of the few bright spots in an otherwise lackluster economy. Analysts said a rising trade deficit meant that even this source of strength would be removed in the final three months of the year, the period most forecasters pinpoint as the start of the recession. **********"This is a bad number," David Wyss, an economist with DRI-McGraw Hill, said of the October trade deficit. "It suggests that we are not going to get as much help from net exports as we had hoped and it suggests there is more inventory out there than we had thought." Decline Put at 3 1/2 Percent **********Mr. Wyss added that he had subtracted another half a percentage point from overall economic activity in the fourth quarter based on October's trade number, putting his forecast of a decline in the gross national product at a sharp 3 1/2 percent. **********Analysts said the rise in imports at a time when consumer demand was falling suggested that retailers would be stuck with a lot of unwanted inventories, forcing production cutbacks in the months ahead. "That will tend to deepen the economic recession and add to layoffs," said Robert Brusca, chief economist of the Nikko Securities Company of New York. **********Economists took more encouragement from today's report on consumer prices, which showed that inflation at the retail level rose at an annual rate of 3.7 percent in December after three months of much sharper increases. Energy prices, which had soared after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, posted only a small increase.  Maneuvering Room for Fed **********Economists said the reassuring inflation report gave the Federal Reserve the maneuvering room it needed to fight the economic slump with lower interest rates. The Fed this afternoon reduced the discount rate, the rate it charges banks for loans, to 6 1/2 percent, from 7 percent, the first change in that rate since February 1989. **********About one-fifth of the deterioration in the trade deficit came from a 17 percent jump in America's oil bill in October, which climbed to $7.23 billion, the highest monthly total since April 1981. The volume of imports was little changed at 8.03 million barrels daily, but the average price for a barrel shot up by $4.73, to $29.04. **********For October, imports rose by 12.2 percent, to an all-time high of $46.38 billion, while exports rose a smaller 8.6 percent, to a record $34.77 billion. **********The trade gap, the difference between imports and exports, was at its highest level since a $12.56 billion deficit in February 1988. Rebound From Low Car Imports **********Adding to the deficit in October was a 39 percent rise in imported cars, which climbed to $4.51 billion. Analysts said that represented a bounce back from unusually low car imports in previous months. **********Through the first 10 months of 1990, the trade deficit was running at an annual rate of $103 billion, putting the country on track for its seventh consecutive year of deficits above $100 billion. **********The big jump in car exports, many of them from Japan, lifted America's deficit with that country to $4.9 billion, the highest imbalance with Japan in the last 12 months.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/04/world.main_headline: As India Opens Its Economy, Some Cling to Socialist Ideals
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/04/world.print_headline: As India Opens Its Economy, Some Cling to Socialist Ideals
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/04/world.body_text: **********At a time when the whole of Eastern Europe is changing, some political leaders in India continue to hold fast to socialist ideals. **********Chandra Shekhar and a handful of others remain opposed to foreign and especially multinational investment and to economic liberalization that opens up new enterprise and offers the Indian consumer an array of products that were unthinkable a decade ago. **********Mr. Shekhar is among those who believe that manufacturers should be told what to make, that people should be told what to wear and eat and that there should be curbs on conspicuous consumption. **********'Not Like Any Other Country' **********''India is not like any other country,'' he said. ''What is valid for the Soviet Union is not necessarily valid here.'' **********These days, Mr. Shekhar, the former president of the Janata Party, which merged with other groups in the late 1980's to form the Janata Dal of Prime Minister V. P. Singh, is in a clear minority. The Government, ignoring his views, has announced plans to further liberalize rules for foreign investment. **********His is still a voice that is heard, although with decreasing influence. One industrialist described him as ''a veteran spoiler,'' and there are many who agree with that assertion. **********Mr. Shekhar, 67 years old, was a prominent radical in the Congress Party in the 1970's. His growing influence in the party and his close relations with opposition leaders prompted Prime Minister Indira Gandhi to imprison him in the state of emergency from 1975 to 1977. He became the Janata Party's president in 1977 during the voters' revolt that ousted Mrs. Gandhi. **********Last year, he nearly became Prime Minister, but he was defeated by Mr. Singh, who led the victorious campaign against the forces of Rajiv Gandhi, who was then Prime Minister. He was president of the Janata Party for about 11 years, but has consistently refused cabinet posts. **********Mr. Shekhar still believes in more incentives for the public sector, large parts of which continue to suffer heavy losses. He pointed out that India's public sector took responsibility in areas like power, coal, oil exploration, dam construction and railroads and transportation because private corporations were unwilling to do so after independence, in 1947. **********Mr. Shekhar says the Government is bowing to the demands of the rich and the upper class for a range of consumer products instead of concerning itself with the needs of the poor, the overwhelming majority. **********''Under successive Governments, the rich-poor gulf has widened, creating greater social inequalities,'' he said. **********He said he believed that multinationals and local major industrialists must be controlled to protect entrepreneurs. **********''India is too large a country to experience genuine development with outside aid,'' he said. He argued that officials should seek an India that is ''self-reliant, instead of pursuing an illusion sold with promises of foreign aid and easy finance.'' last sentence can bite

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/28/busin.body_text: **********The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday that its second-quarter earnings were likely to be lower than last year's, and that the company might have difficulty meeting its own targets for earnings growth this year. **********A.T.&T. stock, which is more widely held than that of any other American company, dropped $2.125 a share, to close at $39.125, after trading as low as $37.625. Some 11.5 million shares changed hands in composite New York Stock Exchange trading, nearly six times the volume of the second most-active stock. **********The New York-based telecommunications giant said its earnings for the quarter that ends Saturday would be less than the $699 million, or 65 cents a share, it reported in last year's second quarter. **********The announcement yesterday was the first time since A.T.&T. divested itself of its local telephone operations in 1984 that the company had issued a statement about its earnings before the end of a quarter. Morris Tanenbaum, the chief financial officer and a vice chairman of A.T.&T., said the company felt obliged to make an announcement because its own profit forecasts were considerably lower than the estimates of Wall Street analysts. **********''We hope we don't have to do this again in the future,'' he said in a telephone interview. **********Sale of Equipment Lags **********A.T.&T. attributed the expected fall in second-quarter earnings to lagging sales of computer and telephone equipment and to the high cost of the company's entry into the credit card market. A sluggish economy and, to a lesser extent, conditions in the telephone equipment market were responsible for weak equipment sales, Mr. Tanenbaum said. **********Mr. Tanenbaum said A.T.&T.'s earnings this year should exceed last year's $2.7 billion, which came on sales of $36.1 billion. But problems in this quarter will make it difficult, he said, for A.T.&T. to meet its target this year of 10 to 12 percent annual earnings growth. **********''I don't think it's impossible, but it's going to be difficult. I wouldn't want anybody to count on it,'' Mr. Tanenbaum said. **********Analysts had expected an increase this quarter greater than the 65 cents a share A.T.&T. earned in the second quarter last year, but they quickly cut their earnings estimates after the announcement. Jack B. Grubman, a telecommunications analyst at Paine Webber, changed his recommendation on the stock from a ''buy'' to a ''hold'' and reduced his second-quarter profits estimate to 58 cents, from 72 cents; he also cut his estimate of 1990 profits to $2.65 a share, from $2.90. **********The company's troubles with equipment sales ''were even worse than I thought,'' Mr. Grubman said. A.T.&T.'s credit card introduction may cost as much as $200 million this year, he added, with most of the expense coming in the second quarter. **********Equipment sales accounted for two-fifths of A.T.&T.'s $36 billion revenue last year. Demand has been strong for consumer products, which include answering machines and telephone handsets, but has fallen for equipment typically sold to businesses and to local telephone companies, Mr. Tanenbaum said. A.T.&T. sells electronic switchboards and multiple-line telephones to businesses and sells telephone network switching and transmission equipment to telephone companies. **********Sales and profits from A.T.&T.'s long-distance services have not suffered in this quarter, said Richard A. Gray, a company spokesman. Prices rose yesterday for the stocks of A.T.&T.'s two biggest long-distance rivals, the MCI Communications Corporation and United Telecommunications, which owns 80 percent of US Sprint. **********Heavy Competition **********Demand has been weak and competition fierce for large, expensive telecommunications equipment, said Richard M. Wolf, a consultant in Ridgewood, N.J. The seven regional Bell operating companies created by the breakup of A.T.&T. in 1984 are cutting back, he said, after bolstering their investment programs during the fourth quarter of last year and the first quarter of this year, when the economy did not slow as much as most had predicted. **********Foreign manufacturers are moving into the American equipment market and putting pressure on profit margins, said Frank J. Governali, a telecommunications analyst at First Boston. ''It's hard to find a shred of positive news in the industry,'' he said. **********According to the Gartner Group Inc., a large telecommunications consulting firm based in Stamford, Conn., A.T.&T.'s share of the $27.5 billion telephone equipment industry has been slowly falling, to 40 percent in the first quarter of this year. **********Demand for the Universal credit card, which A.T.&T. introduced on March 26, has been twice as strong as expected but has resulted in high processing costs, the company said. A.T.&T. announced last week that customers had opened a million accounts for the card, which serves as both a telephone card and a credit card for general purchases.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/24/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: A week after recording a heavy loss on its Navy fighter jet program, the General Dynamics Corporation said yesterday that it was dispatching the company's president to Texas to help resolve the problems in that program. **********A week after recording a heavy loss on its Navy fighter jet program, the General Dynamics Corporation said yesterday that it was dispatching the company's president to Texas to help resolve the problems in that program. **********General Dynamics, the big military contractor based in St. Louis, said Herbert F. Rogers, president and chief operating officer, would become general manager of its Fort Worth Division, where the company is developing the A-12 jet in partnership with the McDonnell Douglas Company. **********The company said Mr. Rogers's presence would allow Charles A. Anderson, the corporate vice president and general manager in Fort Worth, to take on a special assignment as program director on the A-12 program. Mr. Anderson replaces John A. Lamers, vice president of the A-12 program, who is becoming Mr. Anderson's deputy. **********''This is meant to focus more attention on the A-12 program,'' said Peter K. Connolly, a spokesman for General Dynamics. ''Charlie Anderson is a good man and we want to put him on it.'' **********Last week, General Dynamics reported a second-quarter loss of $240 million after setting aside $450 million to account for cost overruns on the A-12 jet program. **********General Dynamics and McDonnell Douglas, which are equal partners in the project, have said that the program, which is still in the development phase, is exceeding its budget and is behind schedule. **********The A-12 is the latest program to result in large losses for weapons makers operating under a fixed-price contract, in which any costs incurred over the amount agreed upon in the contract must be made up by the manufacturer. Most companies now refuse to sign these types of agreements. **********Mr. Connolly said Mr. Rogers and Mr. Anderson were not available to talk about their new assignments. **********In a statement, Stanley C. Pace, General Dynamics' chairman and chief executive, said the new assignments, which are temporary but of indefinite length, ''will bring the necessary corporate and division resources and attention to bear'' on the A-12 program. **********General Dynamics, which also manufactures the F-16 jet, will build the A-12 with McDonnell Douglas in Tulsa, Okla. The Navy has ordered 630 to 850 of the jets. The development and initial product contract is worth about $4.8 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/22/busin.main_headline: Zuckerman Talks Reported With Sony on Coliseum Site
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/22/busin.print_headline: Zuckerman Talks Reported With Sony on Coliseum Site
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/22/busin.body_text: **********Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the New York developer, is negotiating with the Sony Corporation to form a venture that might develop the Coliseum site on Columbus Circle in Manhattan, several real estate executives said this week. **********Mr. Zuckerman, whose primary development company is Boston Properties Inc., declined to confirm on Thursday whether he and Sony executives were in such discussions. The developer said it was premature to make public statements about negotiations because no agreement had been signed with any large tenant. **********''We've been having discussions with a number of tenants, and we don't discuss specific tenants before there are agreements,'' he said. **********Real estate executives said that Sony, which is in the market for a large amount of office space in New York, was still actively talking to other possible owners and developers about leasing space for its numerous businesses in New York while its talks with Mr. Zuckerman progressed. Among the other parties Sony is negotiating with is the Kumagai Gumi Company, a large Tokyo building company whose subsidiary, KG Land New York, is developing a new office tower on Sixth Avenue. **********Mr. Zuckerman won approval from New York City more than a year ago to build a 59-story building on the Columbus Circle site, which is now occupied by the New York Coliseum and has been the center of much debate. He is expected to pay $337 million for the 4.5-acre plot. Much of the convention business formerly at the Coliseum has gone to the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. **********The Coliseum site development has been the focus of a stormy civic controversy almost from its inception in the early 1980's. Mr. Zuckerman's first proposal for the development, two 68-story towers to be designed by Moshe Safdie, stirred such resistance that it became something of a cause celebre in New York. Opponents objected to the immense shadow the buildings would cast over Central Park and contended that it would increase congestion in the area. **********Some of those objections were dropped when Mr. Zuckerman agreed to scale down the project. **********Mr. Zuckerman said in the interview that the revised project would take several years before it could be completed. He added that even after he signed agreements with tenants allowing him to begin work on the existing building, the process of removing asbestos would take a substantial amount of time. **********''You have to take out the asbestos in the building before you demolish it,'' Mr. Zuckerman said. ''There is a chance that by next spring we might have a definitive timetable for going forward and could be removing the asbestos by then.'' **********In 1985, Boston Properties was selected to develop the site at the southwest corner of Central Park. Its proposal for a 2.7-million-square-foot complex of towers, one of them 925 feet tall, was approved by the Board of Estimate. But the Municipal Art Society and others, objecting to its size and bulk, defeated it in court.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/09/world.main_headline: Diplomats See Barriers to a Trial of Salvador Military
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/09/world.print_headline: Diplomats See Barriers to a Trial of Salvador Military
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/09/world.body_text: **********Despite President Alfredo Cristiani's announcement that an investigation has revealed Army involvement in the killing of eight people, including six outspoken Jesuit priests, there are major obstacles to a successful prosecution, diplomats and lawyers here said today. **********Officials close to the investigation said they expected completion of the first phase of the inquiry within a week, with several arrests. But the diplomats and lawyers noted that suspects in many other political killings have escaped prosecution. **********''A lot now depends on the judicial system and that's where, if past experience is a guide, problems arise,'' said Scott Greathead, a board member of Lawyers for Human Rights. He has participated in the case by representing Jesuits in the United States. **********Mr. Greathead and other critics of the Salvadoran Government said the announcement was nonetheless the first indication that Mr. Cristiani is seriously trying to bring the killers to justice. **********Rector Demands More Details **********The new rector of the Jose Simeon Canas University of Central America, where the Jesuits were killed, dismissed the announcement as insufficient and demanded that more details of the investigation be made public. **********''He only confirmed what we have said from the beginning,'' said the Rev. Francisco Estrada, who replaced one of the slain Jesuits at the university. ''We need something more complete.'' President Cristiani has been under extraordinarily tight security since a rebel offensive began last fall. He did not respond to requests to elaborate on his announcement that soldiers were responsible for the slaying of the six priests, their housekeeper and her daughter at the Jesuits' campus residence on Nov 16. **********''It has been determined there was involvement of some elements of the Armed Forces,'' the president said late Sunday in a nationally broadcast speech. He did not identify a specific military unit or the rank of any soldiers implicated in the killings. **********A Decade of Political Killings **********Military officials did not respond to messages left at their offices. But in interviews on Sunday night, the armed forces Chief of Staff, Col. Rene Emilio Ponce, said that 45 soldiers and two officers of the United States-trained Atlacatl battalion were being questioned in connection with the slayings. **********The six priests, among the most erudite and outspoken advocates of a negotiated end to the decade-old civil war, were killed by gunmen who apparently were able to move freely about the capital despite a curfew. **********Political killings have characterized El Salvador's civil war since 1980, when five leftist politicians were killed by the military, four American churchwomen were slain and Archbishop Oscar Arnulfo Romero of San Salvador was assassinated. Over the next few years, tens of thousands of Salvadorans were killed. Human rights groups say most of the slayings were the work of right-wing death squads with ties to the military. **********Charges That Failed to Stick **********Suspects were quickly identified in the killings of the politicians and church workers. Despite intense American pressure, however, it took more than three years to try and convict the five National Guardsmen accused of killing the American churchwomen. The other cases collapsed, even though senior Salvadoran and American officials said there was more than enough evidence to proceed with a trial. **********In another attack that attracted strong interest from the United States, the head of the country's land redistribution program and two American advisers were assassinated in a hotel coffee shop in San Salvador in 1981. Two enlisted men were imprisoned for carrying out the assassination. Although two army officers were accused of ordering the killings, they were not convicted. **********The Government's failure to successfully prosecute such cases has strengthened the cause of the leftist guerrillas. Many Salvadorans became convinced that their traditionally authoritarian society was unwilling to tolerate even nonviolent protest, and that justice could only be won by force. **********Many Salvadorans still doubt that the country's inefficient justice system is capable of prosecuting members of the army, which has long exercised a de facto veto over major Government decisions. **********No Officers Convicted **********Not a single military officer has been convicted of a politically motivated slaying since the beginning of the civil war, which so far has displaced one-tenth of the Salvadoran population and claimed more than 70,000 lives. **********President Cristiani is under immense pressure from Washington, which finances his all-but-bankrupt Government, to find and punish the Jesuits' killers. Many senior Congressional officials say that continuing support from the United States depends on the outcome of the case. **********Mr. Cristiani has offered a $250,000 reward for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the killers. He has also appointed what he called a Special Commission of Honor, including high-ranking military officers and civilian lawyers, to investigate the slayings. **********The slayings of the priests has renewed doubts about assertions by the Bush and Reagan Administrations that they had succeeded in efforts to foster democracy in this country. **********Skepticism About Progress **********The killings also have stirred questions about President Cristiani's ability to control the more extreme elements in the armed forces and his rightist party, the Nationalist Republican Alliance, known as Arena, which has been linked to Archbishop Romero's killing. **********Colleagues of the slain Jesuit priests originally said they had been tortured and that their brains had been scooped from their skulls. **********But autopsies performed with the help of independent forensic specialists found that the priests had been killed with high powered assault rifles and that bullets had shattered their skulls. **********Mr. Cristiani has vowed to do everything in his power to press the case. But the timing of the announcement Sunday night and the president's failure to furnish details raised questions about how much progress the investigators have made. **********Some diplomats suggested that the announcement was part of an effort to forestall pressure from senior United States Senators who are planning to visit El Salvador. **********''He now has to follow through,'' one diplomat said of Mr. Cristiani. ''Ironically, he may have done nothing more than turn up the heat.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/15/world.body_text: **********A businessman has dropped plans to kill 30,000 South African seals after protests by international animal rights advocates, the Government said today. **********The businessman, Hsu Hsien-i, had received approval from South Africa to kill 25,000 seal cubs for processing as dog food. He was also to cull 5,000 adult male seals, whose genitals are prized as aphrodisiacs in the Far East. **********But after protests, South Africa suspended plans for the seal kill. Mr. Hsu has since decided to abandon the project, the Foreign Ministry said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/09/busin.body_text: **********Hughes Danbury Optical Systems Inc., citing Federal budget cuts, said it would eliminate about 90 jobs early next month, trimming its 920-person work force by about 10 percent. Layoffs of salaried workers will probably account for most of the cutback, a company spokesman, Tom Arconti, said. **********Mr. Arconti said the company would try to transfer some of those dismissed to jobs in other units of its parent company, the Los Angeles-based Hughes Aircraft division of the General Motors Corporation. Those units are in California and elsewhere around the nation, he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/21/busin.body_text: **********In a changing of the guard that reflects the ascendancy of the consumer banking business, the Chase Manhattan Corporation announced yesterday that Willard C. Butcher, chairman, would be replaced by Thomas G. Labrecque, president, and that Arthur F. Ryan would become the new president. **********The changes, which will be effective at the end of October, were not surprising but were announced sooner than planned. Mr. Labrecque, 51 years old, has been president and Mr. Butcher's heir apparent for nine years. Mr. Ryan's success at developing Chase's consumer banking businesses had made him a favorite for the No. 2 job. **********Mr. Butcher said the changes were announced several months earlier than expected in order to precede a major revamping and cost-cutting program in the bank's corporate finance businesses. ''We wanted to make the line of succession clear and avoid speculation,'' Mr. Butcher said. ''We now have a man of judgment in Labrecque and a great implementor in Ryan.'' **********Arthur P. Sotor, a banking analyst at Morgan Stanley & Company, said, ''The promotion of Art Ryan is a reminder of the fact that Chase and Citibank, two of the biggest wholesale banks in the country, are today making as much or more profit from their retail activities than from the traditional banking activities with corporations.'' **********Branch Network Improves **********Under Mr. Ryan, Chase improved its branch network in New York City and greatly expanded consumer financial businesses like credit cards, student and mortgage loans, and automobile leasing. During 1989 those activities and others included in the individual banking group earned more than $300 million, or about half the profit the company would have earned had it not taken special charges to cover things like troubled loans to less developed countries. **********''Nobody will ever mistake me for an expert in mergers and acquisitions or a credit officer,'' Mr. Ryan said. But he added that earlier in his career, when he was head of the data processing area, he became familiar with the basic operations of corporate lending and other areas of the bank. **********A quick-smiling, fast-talking executive who will admit to a more than occassional urge for a cigarette, Mr. Ryan, 47, was born in Brooklyn and has a bachelor's degree in mathematics from Providence College in Rhode Island. **********Mr. Labrecque, who many analysts credit as the executive most responsible for the decisions to expand retail banking activities and tighten expense controls, has been a prominent executive since the mid-1970's when he was involved in New York City's financial crisis. Tall and smooth talking, Mr. Labrecque has spoken frequently about the need for American banks to have broader powers in the securities and insurance businesses. **********Mr. Labrecque said that as chairman, ''My primary focus will be the strategic and competitive positioning of the bank, corporate financial management, and helping Art on the day to day issues.'' **********Mr. Butcher, 63, who succeeded David Rockefeller as chairman of Chase in 1981, led the bank during a decade when its traditional strength as a lender to businesses was hard hit by competition from foreign banks and the shift by large corporations to raising money in the securities markets rather than borrowing from banks. **********Besides reductions in personnel and other expenses in the corporate finance or wholesale lending part of the bank, Mr. Butcher said, ''We have to deal with some real estate things.'' As a major lender for commercial real estate projects, analysts expect that Chase has been hit in recent months with a large increase in problem loans, which will require it to set aside addtional reserves to cover losses. **********Pending Changes **********The three executives declined to comment on the reorganization at Chase, except to say that it is pending. Analysts say they expect the banking company to announce major cuts in employment, concentrating on its wholesale lending business in the United States and Europe. Chase, which is currently the second-largest banking company in the country behind Citicorp, may also announce the sale of some assets or even whole businesses. **********The retail banking business, which has been growing by more than 15 percent annually, is not expected to be much affected by the revamping. With profits of about $1 for every $100 of assets, the retail banking businesses managed by Mr. Ryan earn a return of about 20 percent on the equity capital needed to operate them. **********The star of the retail banking business is Chase's credit card business. Mr. Ryan has pushed the business to higher profits by overseeing the development of computerized systems to spot risky customers and reduce the transaction costs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/20/busin.main_headline: Revamping of Manville Trust Is Proposed
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/20/busin.print_headline: Revamping of Manville Trust Is Proposed
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/20/busin.body_text: **********The trust set up by the Manville Corporation to compensate victims of asbestos poisoning, which is out of cash and will be unable to pay seriously ill people for decades, announced a plan yesterday for a quick settlement of tens of thousands of asbestos personal injury cases. **********Under the proposal, the Manville Corporation would provide an additional $520 million over seven years to the trust and lift restrictions on the trust's ability to sell a $1.8 billion Manville bond. In addition, fees for plaintiffs' lawyers, which had consumed tens of millions of dollars, would be cut to a maximum of 25 percent of what their clients recover. **********The proposal would give priority to the more seriously ill people -- an estimated 23,000 who have cancer and other debilitating diseases -- over those with less severe asbestos-related ailments, who would get nothing in the first year. Up to 37,500 of the less severely ill could receive a maximum of $2,000 in the second year of the plan. **********If, as expected, the plan is approved by a Federal District Court, it would remove tens of thousands of cases from hundreds of state and Federal courts around the nation and slash the legal fees that have taken most of its available funds. This would be accomplished by combining all the cases against the trust into a single class action. **********The Manville Personal Injury Settlement Trust has become a symbol of the legal difficulties facing many former asbestos makers and their victims. Manville, for decades the nation's leading producer of asbestos products, set the trust up two years ago to enable the company to rise out of Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings. The corporation's legal liability was shifted to the Washington-based trust, with the intention of making timely settlements of claims and helping victims avoid costly litigation. **********The trust is now facing more than 90,000 lawsuits in hundreds of state and Federal courts, legal bills of tens of millions of dollars, and decades-long delays in compensating asbestos victims, many of whom have fatal illnesses and cancers. By some estimates, more than two-thirds of the resources available for victims have been going to legal and administrative costs. **********The announcement of the new plan follows an order by District Judge Jack B. Weinstein of Brooklyn to revamp the ailing trust, which he has said was unfairly denying relief to tens of thousands of asbestos victims. The plan was worked out after months of negotiations among the Manville Corporation, the trust, a committee of seven lawyers representing thousands of victims and Leon Silverman, a New York lawyer appointed by the judge to deal with the trust's problems. **********Experts said yesterday that the new plan marked a significant development in the law governing product liability and was likely to provide a new precedent for the handling of asbestos cases, which are now clogging many courts across the nation.   'Legislated Disability Program' **********"It sounds like a legislated disability program," said Peter H. Schuck, a professor at the Yale Law School who has written a book about Agent Orange, one of the largest product liability cases and the role played by Judge Weinstein. "It will treat the cases more categorically and less individually and set priorities based on the severity of the illnesses." **********Under the plan, it is estimated that an average of $146,000 would be paid for asbestos victims with mesothelioma, $120,000 for lung cancer victims who had not smoked, $70,000 for smokers who contracted lung cancer and $80,000 for other severe, but nonmalignant diseases. Among the less severe diseases, it is estimated that under the plan an average of between $12,000 and $35,000 would be paid. **********At present the trust gives priority to order of filing, rather than severity of cases. To tens of thousands of victims, many with fatal or severe cancers, the trust has handed out i.o.u.'s to be paid without interest, well into the 21st century.   Swamped by Lawsuits **********The trust was initially financed by Manville's contributions of cash and stock, the company's insurers and commitments to share in any future profits of the company. The Denver-based corporation, for decades the largest processor of asbestos, entered into bankruptcy proceedings in 1982, swamped by lawsuits charging that asbestos was killing and injuring thousands of workers and others who breathed its fibers. **********After paying fewer than 23,000 victims, the trust ran out of cash and proposed to give victims i.o.u.'s. **********Under the new plan, the Manville Corporation would contribute an additional $520 million over seven years to the trust through dividends paid on the stock. In addition, the trust's $1.8 billion bond would be modified so that the trust could break it up into smaller debentures and market them to raise cash. **********The payments to the more seriously ill under the plan are impossible to calculate with certainty because they will be based upon the number of claims and the size of the fund. The victims would receive up to 45 percent of their claims in the first year of the plan until all of the more seriously ill people receive compensation, and would then receive payments based on a pro rata share of what is left. By all accounts, most payments would be less than the original claims paid by the trust. **********The proposed resolution of the trust's difficulties is the first element of a broader effort by Judge Weinstein to resolve the predicament of both the asbestos makers that face insolvency from the stream of liability cases, and the victims, who have seen their cases go unresolved for years. **********His proposal is the creation of an enormous fund, financed by the companies. Victims could make claims from the fund, based on the severity of their illnesses and the amount of money available. A second company, Eagle-Picher Industries of Cincinnati, has already asked for similar treatment, and executives and lawyers at several other companies have said privately that they would contribute hundreds of millions of dollars to the fund, if they were assured it would end the costly lawsuits. **********The judge is expected to announce today the appointment of a lawyer to assemble a panel of experts to examine the plan. He also expects to hold hearings in New York, Chicago, New Orleans and San Francisco and could call for modifications of the plan.   Struck Down by Appeals Courts **********But the class action route is far from a certainty. Appeals courts in several jurisdictions have struck down class actions on the ground that there are too many legal and factual disparities among the victims and the causes of their illnesses. **********Nonetheless, there is also a growing concern among scholars, judges and lawyers that asbestos litigation, which is clogging the courts in many jurisdictions, has gotten out of hand. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist recently appointed a panel of judges to make recommendations for changing court procedures and law to resolve what by all accounts has become a crisis in the courts. A New System for Aiding Victims Proposed reorganization of the Manville Personal Injury Settlement Trust, as recommended by the trust, Manville Corporation and a committee representing thousands of claimants. Manville Corporation's preferred stock held by the trust would be convertred so it would hold 80 percent of common stock. A dividend would be paid to holders of common stock, so that the trust would receive $520 million over seven years. A $1.8 billion bond by Manville would be changed so that the trust could break it up and market it to raise cash. Cases in Federal and state courts would be combined into a single class action, which would dramatically reduce legal fees of the trust and the claimants. Judge Jack B. Weinstein has estimated that the legal fees are consuming more than two-thirds of available resources. A cap of 25 percent would be put on the fees awarded to plaintiffs' lawyers. The fees have been as high as 40 percent of awards. The payout system would be changed so that the more seriously ill claimants would receive earlier payments, based on the number of claims and resources available. Payments are expected to be substantially less than comparable claimants received earlier. Those with less severe illnesses would receive nothing in the first year and as much as $2,000 in the second year. Source: Court documents

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/19/busin.body_text: **********The Polaroid Corporation reported Tuesday that weak demand for its instant-picture products pulled second-quarter earnings down 23 percent. **********Polaroid, based in Cambridge, Mass., said earnings fell to $32.9 million, or 45 cents a share, from $42.7 million, or 62 cents a share, in last year's second quarter. Revenues slipped 2.3 percent, to $475.6 million from $486.6 million. **********The company said that worldwide film sales increased slightly in the quarter, but shipments fell as retailers were cautious about maintaining last year's inventory levels. **********It also said higher new product and marketing costs affected the results. **********Polaroid said it was lowering its expectations for the remainder of the year. It said it expects to post 1990 results that are flat or moderately lower than 1989's net earnings of $145 million, or $1.96 a share, on sales of $1.9 billion. **********Domestic sales fell 10 percent in the quarter while international sales rose 8 percent, Polaroid said. **********The company said camera shipments were about the same as in the 1989 second quarter, while videotape and conventional film broadened in distribution. **********Polaroid shares fell $3.25 today, to $36, after Alex Henderson, an analyst for Prudential-Bache Securities, said he had lowered his 1990 and 1991 earnings per share estimates on Polaroid.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/28/world.print_headline: Evolution in Europe;   The Poles Vote for Local Offices: 52,000 Races Are Contested
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/28/world.body_text: **********Poles voted today for community councils nationwide and were expected to push forward democratic changes by ousting holdover Communists from their last bastions of power. **********The vote is the first fully free ballot since World War II and aims to reinstitute local governments that are entirely autonomous of Warsaw. That system was not allowed under four decades of Communist Party rule. **********Unofficial results of the 52,000 individual races were expected on Monday, but official results were not expected until Wednesday. Solidarity citizens committees are expected to dominate local governments, but the vote will be a test of the country's budding independent political parties. **********'Truly Irreversible' **********''The vast majority of society, although angry at the bad situation, understand that we must stick together because there is no other choice,'' the Solidarity chairman, Lech Walesa, said after voting near Gdansk. ''We must take over power from the bottom and build the foundations of democracy.'' **********Voting in Warsaw, Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki said the balloting was fundamental. ''Local government elections will not change the economic situation,'' he said. ''But we can say they are changing the system.'' **********The Senate Speaker, Andrzej Stelmachowski, said the vote ''finally will anchor democracy to the very bottom, to the grass roots.'' **********''After this,'' he said, ''our changes will be truly irreversible.'' **********In previous local elections held under the Communists, only those candidates approved by party-dominated nominating boards were allowed to run. The local councils, considered the agents of the central government, depended on Warsaw for money and their decisions could be overturned. **********The election of local officials answerable to residents and not to Warsaw should make administration of towns and villages more efficient, Mr. Mazowiecki said. More than 146,000 candidates from about 80 parties were vying nationwide. Official posters outside polling places listed the names of district candidates and the parties they represented. **********'Vote Is Important' **********''This vote is important; things will change for the better,'' said Rajmond Radziszewski, a mechanic who voted in Wiskitki. ''Thank God that I lived to see this,'' said Janina Krakowska, who worked on a farm outside the same town until she retired. **********There was little of the enthusiasm displayed during last June's partly free parliamentary elections, when Solidarity plastered towns with posters and manned stands outside polling places. Politicking was illegal today. **********''There were fewer preparations, fewer posters because we didn't want people to say we were wasting money,'' said Maria Simiatowska of the Solidarity citizens committee in Skierniewice, a provincial capital 30 miles southwest of Warsaw. **********The parliamentary vote last June was governed by an agreement between Solidarity and the former Communist government. The accord reserved 65 percent of the seats in the lower house of Parliament for the Communists and their allies, and 35 percent for nonparty independents. **********WALESA WARNS STRIKERS **********WARSAW, May 27 (AP) - Solidarity's founder, Lech Walesa, told striking train workers today that their walkout is propelling the country toward civil strife, but the strikers rebuffed his appeal for a settlement and threatened new stoppages. **********Mr. Walesa also suggested that Prime Minister Mazowiecki, a former ally with whom he has broken, might be forced to resign if the protests spread. **********A week of sporadic strikes has crippled freight transport to Poland's Baltic coast from the industrial south and Czechoslovakia and Hungary. The army has been called in to move essential shipments. **********Mr. Walesa held a three-hour meeting with the strikers, who broke off talks with the Government in Warsaw a day earlier. The Solidarity labor leader, who himself rose to prominence by leading the strike at the Gdansk shipyard, begged the workers to call off the walkout. **********''Please do it for Poland,'' he said. ''We don't want a civil war now, and what's going on now is leading to it.'' **********The Solidarity-led Cabinet has refused to even discuss the strikers' pay demands. It says they could scuttle the drastic economic reforms now under way. Strikers said they will carry out a new stoppage on Monday. The Solidarity railroad union urged members not to participate in the stoppage at midday Monday. The move is being spearheaded by a union that had been backed by the old Communist Government. **********The strike committee is also calling for a work stoppage on Tuesday night. **********Officials said thousands of the nation's 400,000 railroad workers were striking but could give no specific number. Transport officials have noted that it only takes a few strikers to snarl rail traffic. **********Mr. Walesa has charged that the strikers' legitimate grievances are being manipulated by the pro-Communist union. **********The Solidarity Labor Minister, Jacek Kuron, says the wage demands are inflationary. **********''I am willing to talk with everybody about everything except wages,'' said Mr. Kuron, a leader of the old KOR dissident movement that gave birth to Solidarity in 1980.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/31/busin.body_text: **********Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions remained mostly flat in the week ended yesterday compared with the week earlier. **********Analysts said the interest-rate picture remains clouded, with few banks seeing the current high interest rates available in foreign countries as a long-term distraction to the general downward movement of yields in the United States. **********According to 100 Highest Yields, a newsletter covering interest rates published in West Palm Beach, Fla., the same forces currently pushing up mortgage rates affect certificate rates as well. **********It cited the fear of inflation, which has exerted upward pressure on interest rates recently, and the absence of Japanese investors, who are the primary buyers of United States Treasury securities, as among the factors holding up interest rates. **********Influence of Treasury Auction **********At the Treasury's regular weekly bill auction on Monday, interest rates on three- and six-month bills were up. The auction results are considered an influence over what many banks pay on money market accounts and certificates of deposit. **********The average rate for a three-month bill at the auction increased by 11 basis points, to 7.77 percent, its highest level since the auction of Dec. 26. For a six-month bill, the rate increased by 15 basis points, to 7.73 percent, the highest since the Oct. 2 auction. A basis point is one one-hundredth of a percentage point. **********A weekly survey of New York area banks showed that average yields on certificates of deposit offered at commercial banks and savings institutions were mixed compared with the week before. **********Average yields on money market accounts at commercial banks fell 4 basis points, to 6.49 percent, with yields on three-month certificates falling a basis point, to 7.82 percent. The average yields on six-month certificates were up 4 basis points, to 7.85 percent, the survey showed. **********Rates at Savings Units **********Meanwhile, at savings institutions, money market accounts and three-month certificates were unchanged, at 6.60 percent and 8.06 percent, respectively. The yield on a six-month certificate was down a basis point from a week earlier, to 8.08 percent. **********Among 20 large banks surveyed nationwide, average yields on deposits were also mixed, with money market accounts off by 2 basis points, to 6.32 percent, and six-month certificates of deposit up 3 basis points, to 7.80 percent, from a week earlier. **********Average yields on deposits at large credit unions nationwide were also mixed, with money market yields down a basis point, to 6.70 percent, and yields on one-year certificates of deposit down by a basis point, to 8.09 percent. Six-month certificate yields at credit unions were unchanged, at 8.04 percent, while two-and-a-half-year certificate yields were up 2 basis points, to 8.20 percent, and five-year certificate yields were up a basis point, to 8.22 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/06/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Whirlpool in Deal With Matsushita
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/06/busin.body_text: **********The Whirlpool Corporation and the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company said they had signed a joint venture to produce vacuum cleaners for the North American market from Whirlpool's vacuum manufacturing plant in Danville, Ky. **********Whirlpool, based in Benton Harbor, Mich., said that as part of the venture, it would try to expand its relationship with Sears, Roebuck and Company, which sells vacuum cleaners made by Whirlpool in the Danville plant under the Kenmore brand name. Matsushita, based in Osaka, Japan, currently exports Panasonic brand vacuum cleaners to the United States and is expected to use the Danville plant to expand in North America.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/26/world.main_headline: For South African Businessmen, Mozambique Is a Place for Profit
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/26/world.print_headline: For South African Businessmen, Mozambique Is a Place for Profit
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/26/world.body_text: **********As Michael Furze sat in the bar of the elegant Polana Hotel overlooking the Indian Ocean, he could have been forgiven for thinking he was back home in South Africa. His can of beer came from Johannesburg, he was expected to pay in South African rands and the voices of Afrikaans speakers could be heard in the room. **********Mr. Furze, an economist with a South African timber company, was one of the thousands of South African businessmen who have come in recent years to invest in their old friend and neighbor, Mozambique. Plagued by recession at home and enticed by the changed political climate here, South African businessmen see Mozambique, as worn out and war torn as it is, as a place for profit. **********''Mozambique is full of opportunities,'' Mr. Furze said. ''Oil, minerals and forest products.'' **********Increasing Cooperation **********The South African business interest in Mozambique is another sign of increasing economic cooperation between white-ruled South Africa and its black-ruled neighbors, whose official policy has been to shun such contacts. As part of this evolving relationship, President F. W. de Klerk visited Madagascar on Aug. 15 to establish economic ties, and Zambia said this month that its businessmen could now use South African ports for their exports. **********After years of trying to destabilize the Mozambican Government and being the main provider of arms to the rebels of the Mozambique National Resistance, South Africa is now intent on trying to rebuild the country, said David Laubscher, the head of the South African trade mission here. **********Mr. Laubscher said he tells the 120 South African businessmen who visit his office per month that the ''war won't last forever.'' **********Pretoria's goal is to develop a southern African common market, of which South Africa would be the linchpin. ''We feel it will be necessary in the future that southern Africa together be able to negotiate with the European economic community and Asian communities,'' Mr. Laubscher said. **********One of the southern black African states politically committed to the abolition of apartheid, Mozambique has supported international sanctions against Pretoria. But flattened by war and with many of its citizens working as migrant laborers in the South African mines, it has never been in a position to impose sanctions itself. Thus the opportunities for business are more easily opened here than in the rest of the region. **********Presence a Mixed Blessing **********For Mozambicans, the South African presence, so familiar during Portuguese colonial times that ended in 1975, is a mixed blessing. For some, like those doing business with Mr. Furze, it presents economic possibilities unheard of before. For others, it suggests a pattern of recolonization. When the Portuguese ruled Mozambique, South Africans had a large stake in the economy, particularly in the tourist industry. **********''About 250,000 South Africans would come over a long weekend,'' Mr. Laubscher said. ''There were holiday homes, business investments, farms. With independence and nationalization, all these things disappeared.'' **********The initial focus of South African investment has been in hopes of luring back South African tourists who remember the Mozambican sand, surf and shrimp. A South African hotel company, Karos Hotels, has acquired the management contract for the Polana Hotel and plans a $12 million renovation starting this month. **********South Africa is also pouring money into upgrading the port of Maputo, which is the most convenient to the Transvaal citrus groves. South African use of the port increased 20 percent last year and is expected to grow another 30 percent this year, Mr. Laubscher said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/23/busin.main_headline: Candy Maker Dealt Blow on Sugar Quotas
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/23/busin.print_headline: Candy Maker Dealt Blow on Sugar Quotas
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/23/busin.body_text: **********A Chicago candy maker's request to buy sugar at world prices instead of at the sharply higher domestic United States price has been rejected by a Commerce Department examiner, Congressional aides and industry officials say. **********The decision, which was disclosed on Friday, could mean that the company, E. J. Brach & Sons, will be forced to close its plant in Chicago and move abroad. **********The case has thrown a spotlight on sugar import quotas that the United States has imposed for years to protect beet and cane growers. The cost of these quotas to American consumers is estimated by Government and private economists at several billion dollars a year. **********Although the Agriculture Department wants to get rid of the quotas eventually, it defended the program, warning that similar applications by other candy and food processing companies would hurt domestic sugar producers by undermining Government quotas. **********Decision Subject to Review **********The decision is subject to review by an inter-agency Foreign-Trade Zones Board, headed by Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher. **********Brach, which was taken over in 1986 by Jacobs Suchard, based in Zurich, has said that if it did not receive the exemption to buy the lower-cost sugar, it would move the Chicago operation, which employs up to 3,500 people, to either Canada or Mexico. The company's request was endorsed by Chicago civic officials and lawmakers, including Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the powerful chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee. **********The difference between the world sugar price of 15 cents a pound, and the domestic price of 24 cents, would have saved the company $20 million a year. The company said that would be enough to maintain the 68-year-old factory on the economically depressed West Side of Chicago. **********Exemption Called Unfair **********But competitors threatened to seek similar exemptions, complaining that it would have given Brach an unfair advantage. **********Brach has been trying to capitalize on provisions of the Foreign Trade Zones Act of 1934 as amended in 1950. It sought special permission to import lower-cost foreign sugar and use it to make candy sold in the United States. The company contends that its effforts to preserve jobs in Chicago entitle it to an exemption from foreign trade zone restrictions. **********In a foreign trade zone, import fees and other forms of border protection are generally waived to reduce production costs. These products are then designated for export, and only in rare cases can they be sold domestically. **********As the Commerce Department action was disclosed, the House Agriculture Subcommittee on Cotton, Rice and Sugar agreed by a voice vote to raise domestic sugar subsidies as part of a five-year farm law it is writing. **********Fear of Trade War **********John B. Campbell, a deputy Under Secretary of Agriculture, said the Bush Administration opposed the proposals and would seek legislative changes. **********''Sugar dynamics are about to explode,'' Mr. Campbell told the lawmakers, warning that the proposals could result in a trade war over sugar ''that could have been avoided.'' **********Brach executives could not be reached for comment over the weekend. A Commerce Department official said no final decision had been taken, but confirmed that a report by the department's examiner, was ''in the final stages.'' **********The official also said there had been discussions with Brach. Other officials said the talks had been to inform the company that its petition was being rejected. **********Frank R. Samolis, a partner in Patton, Boggs & Blow, a law firm representing Mars Inc., one of the competitors of the Suchard unit, said he had not been officially informed of the decision. But he added, ''It is our hope and expectation that the Suchard application will be denied based on the facts of the case.'' **********Brach's was founded in 1904 as Brach's Palace of Sweets. Its products include hard red-and-white mints called Starlight Mints, caramels, toffee and a wide variety of other candies. The parent company reported that Brach lost $50 million last year on sales of about $500 million. **********The company had been owned by the American Home Products Company, a food, drug and household products company, until December 1986 when it was sold to Suchard for $700 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/17/busin.body_text: **********The Hewlett-Packard Company reported increased sales and orders today, but lower earnings for its second fiscal quarter. Hewlett-Packard's shares fell $1.875, to $46.125, on the New York Stock Exchange. **********For the quarter ended April 30, Hewlett-Packard, based in Palo Alto, Calif., had earnings of $186 million, or 78 cents a share, down 8 percent from $203 million, or 86 cents a share, in the comparable period a year ago. Revenues rose 16 percent, to $3.31 billion, from $2.86 billion in the second quarter of the 1989 fiscal year. **********''This was another quarter of mixed results,'' said John A. Young, Hewlett-Packard's president and chief executive officer. ''While we did see strong increases in some areas, medical-product orders actually decreased from the second quarter a year ago, and a number of other product areas showed only slight growth.'' **********Orders for the quarter totaled $3.5 billion, up 16 percent from the $3 billion reported for the second quarter of 1989. United States orders totaled $1.6 billion, up 13 percent, while orders from outside the country rose 18 percent, to $1.9 billion. All yearly comparisons are with a period in 1989 that does not include the results of Apollo Computer Inc., which Hewlett acquired in May 1989.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/24/busin.body_text: **********The Security Pacific Corporation said today that it had replaced the president and chief operating officer of its Arizona bank unit, one of the few areas of the company to experience operating trouble recently. **********Security Pacific said it had named Ronald Azzolina to head Security Pacific Bank Arizona and its holding company, Security Pacific Bank Southwest. **********Mr. Azzolina replaces William **********S. Thomas, who the company said had accepted a new position as executive vice president and senior executive for Northern California within Security Pacific's Business Bank. **********In the first quarter, Security **********Pacific's Arizona operations lost $30 million, after losing $142 million last year. **********Mr. Azzolina also replaces **********Mr. Thomas as chairman of Security Pacific Bank Nevada and chairman and chief operating officer of its holding company, the Nevada National Bancorporation. **********A spokeswoman for Security **********Pacific said the changes ''have absolutely nothing to do with Arizona economic problems,'' but she declined to elaborate.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/17/world.body_text: **********A survey of voter intentions published in The Times of London today, taken with a grain of salt by many politicians, predicts that Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservative Party would win the next national election if Michael Heseltine headed it. **********Mr. Heseltine, who walked out of Mrs. Thatcher's Cabinet as Defense Minister in 1986, is challenging her for the party and Government leadership in a ballot the 372 Conservative Members of Parliament will hold on Tuesday. He was making appearances for the party in Scotland today, while Mrs. Thatcher was in Northern Ireland. **********The Times survey of 1,088 people by Market and Opinion Research International was viewed skeptically by the party chairman, Kenneth Baker, in part because it showed an unusually high level of support for the Conservatives under Mrs. Thatcher's leadership -- trailing the opposition Labor Party by only 4 percent, compared to around 15 percent in other recent polls. Bigger Response for Heseltine **********Of the 980 people who gave a voting intention if there were an immediate election, 45 percent said they would support Labor, with 41 for the Conservatives and 10 percent for the Liberal Democrats. If Mr. Heseltine were leader, the response was 49 percent for the Tories, 39 percent for Labor and 7 percent for the Liberal Democrats. **********A similar poll by National Opinion Polls Ltd. for The Independent on Thursday showed that Labor, leading by 14 points now, would be only 5 percent ahead of the Conservatives if Mr. Heseltine were the Tory leader. **********Whatever the public really thinks, it isn't the public that will decide whether he becomes party leader; it's the 372 Conservative legislators in Parliament. They will hold the first ballot on Tuesday, when the winner will need at least 187 votes and a margin of at least 56 to prevent a second ballot the following week. **********"Given the nature of the electorate, which is sophisticated and dissembling like fury when talking to each other and to the press about voting intentions, I don't trust any predictions," said John Biffen, a member of Mrs. Thatcher's Cabinet from 1979 to 1987. Mr. Biffen would not discuss his vote. 'Time Has Come for a Change' **********Sir Peter Tapsell, one of Mr. Heseltine's sponsors, said, "It is my impression that a lot of former ministers and a considerable number of serving ministers will not be voting for Mrs. Thatcher." **********One of them is David Howell, a member of Mrs. Thatcher's first Cabinet in 1979. **********"Mrs. Thatcher has been magnificent in the 80's," he said. "But the time has come for a change." **********Some legislators have said they would prefer the Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, to either Mr. Heseltine or Mrs. Thatcher, if he entered the contest on a second or third ballot. But he told a news conference in Leeds today that he would not run "against her," according to the Press Association, the British domestic news agency. **********"I support Mrs. Thatcher," he said. "I hope and think, on what I have heard, that she will win on the first ballot." He and Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major nominated her when it became apparent there would be a contest. **********"The first job of the Prime Minister will be to heal," Mr. Hurd said. "There will not be time for a lot of point-scoring after this election."  Thatcher Visits Ulster **********Nevertheless, the conservative Evening Standard reported Mr. Hurd's "against her" answer to whether he would run as an indication that he was ready to enter the fray on a second or third ballot. **********Mrs. Thatcher was visiting British troops and communities in Northern Ireland, where 27 soldiers, police officers and civilians have been killed since Oct. 1.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/10/busin.body_text: **********McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. said today that it plans to distribute new shares of stock as part of its agreement last month to acquire the Lin Broadcasting Corporation. **********McCaw, which will buy a 50.1 percent interest in Lin for $3.38 billion, made the disclosure in a registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. **********McCaw, the nation's largest cellular telephone company, will pay $154.11 a share to buy 21.9 million shares of Lin, a New York-based cellular-phone, publishing and broadcasting company. Lin, in turn, will buy $425 million of McCaw's stock and distribute it as a dividend for Lin shares not purchased in the tender offer. **********McCaw said that it had extended its tender offer to expire at noon on Feb. 27 but that it could be extended further if all conditions of the offer have not been satisfied. About 13.8 million Lin shares have been tendered so far, McCaw said.
