https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/16/busin.body_text: **********The Alfred P. Sloan Foundation has given a $2.97 million grant to establish a research consortium of five universities to explore the competitiveness and economic performance of the United States, foundation officials said last week. **********Faculty members from the **********University of California at Berkeley, Columbia University, Harvard University, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Stanford University will conduct research across a variety of disciplines, including economics, management and engineering. **********The money will be managed by the Consortium on Competitiveness and Cooperation at the Walter A. Haas School of Business at Berkeley. It will be headed by David J. Teece at Berkeley. **********''Competitiveness issues are deep problems and long problems,'' said Ralph E. Gomory, president of the Sloan Foundation. He said General Electric, General Motors, Hewlett-Packard, International Business Machines and Xerox had promised to support the research activities of the consortium. **********Mr. Gomory said the initial grant would be for three to five years.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/18/busin.body_text: **********The Northrop Corporation said today that its earnings for the third quarter nearly doubled from the corresponding period last year, although the company's future remained clouded by the diminishing prospects for its biggest program, the B-2 Stealth bomber. **********Northrop said its earnings for the period were $42.4 million, or 90 cents a share, compared with $21.5 million, or 46 cents a share, in last year's third quarter. The company's revenue for the quarter rose slightly, to $1.28 billion, from $1.25 billion in the corresponding period last year. In last year's third quarter, Northrop reduced its earnings by $15 million to account for possible losses on a number of fixed-price research and development contracts. **********The company said results also benefited from improved profit mar-gins on 747 airliner components that it supplies to the Boeing Company and lower-than-expected spending on the competition to build a new jet fighter for the Air Force. **********But the results do not reflect the growing chance that the B-2 program, which accounts for nearly half of Northrop's revenues, will be scaled back to a fraction of its planned size or canceled entirely. In Congress today, House and Senate conferees agreed to keep the program alive for another year, but without providing financing for any planes beyond the 15 already authorized. The Air Force wants to buy 75 of the radar-evading bombers at a total cost of $65 billion. **********Northrop's stock closed today on the New York Stock Exchange at $15.125 a share, up 12.5 cents.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/15/busin.main_headline: Dow Advances by 24.25 in Heavy Trading
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/15/busin.print_headline: Dow Advances by 24.25 in Heavy Trading
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/15/busin.body_text: **********Stocks rallied yesterday in the heaviest trading in nearly a month, but analysts differed sharply on whether more big gains or additional setbacks would follow. **********The Dow Jones industrial average, which had advanced as much as 37 points by late in the day, fell back near the close to end at 2,559.65, ahead 24.25. **********The Dow has now risen four of the last five trading days, jumping nearly 119 points in that period. **********Asked whether this was just another rally in a bear market, Michael Metz, chief market analyst for Oppenheimer & Company, said: "I don't agree. Every bull market starts with one uptick. Maybe this is the real thing."  Weaknesses Cited **********But Laszlo Birinyi Jr., president of Birinyi Associates, the research firm, said: "Actually, it was a weak day. We had nowhere near the quality of buying we had earlier in the week." **********He said that stock trades involving blocks of less than 10,000 shares accounted for $89 million of the day's activity, while trades of 10,000 shares or more totalled "a relatively uninspiring" $20 million. **********After what he saw earlier in the week, he said, he expected further gains, but he said, "This was a more limited, weaker rally and we would not expect that after this one it would be better." **********Except for a dip at the start of trading, the Dow took off almost from the opening bell. By 11:30 it was up 15 points; by 2 P.M. it was 27 points ahead, and by 3 it had jumped 37 points, giving way a little by the close. Oil prices moved in the other direction, dropping steadily for most of the day to end at $31.16 a barrel, down $1.96. Higher Volume **********Activity climbed to 179.3 million shares, the heaviest since Oct. 19, when it was 221.5 million. Tuesday's volume had been a robust 161.4 million. Birinyi said that heavy program-buying lifted the Dow nearly 17 points yesterday. **********"There's no news," said Mr. Metz of Oppenheimer. "The market's going up because it didn't go down. Everybody has money; everybody has gone short; everybody's waiting for the market to collapse and it just isn't accommodating them." **********Noting that financial stocks had rallied strongly after serious concerns of major real estate troubles, he said, "It's a feeling that maybe we've seen the worst of the stresses in the financial system." **********He said that cyclical stocks, including paper, chemicals and some capital goods stocks, had advanced in what he viewed as "a feeling the recession will be fairly shallow -- maybe protracted but probably mild."  Moderating Fears **********Recent economic data, he said, including yesterday's retail sales figures, interest rates and earlier inflation numbers, were "not good but not disastrous." **********"It doesn't look like either the economy or the world will fall off the cliff," he said. **********Among the financial stocks, Citicorp, the nation's biggest banking company, rose5/8, to 14, in heavy trading. BankAmerica, No. 2 in the nation, rose 5/8, to 23 7/8, again in heavy trading. Security Pacific, No. 4, rose 1 3/8, to 23 3/8; First Interstate, No. 10, rose 1 3/4, to 21 5/8, and Wells Fargo, 11th in the country, rose 2 1/8, to 53 5/8. **********PNC Financial, No. 14, tacked on 1 3/4, to 23; First Wachovia, ranked 30th, 1 1/4, to 39 3/4, and Bankers Trust, 9th in the nation, 2, to 37 1/4. **********In other interest-sensitive stocks, CNA Financial rose 1 7/8, to 57 3/4; Marsh & McLennan 1 3/8, to 75 1/4, and St. Paul 1 1/8, to 60 5/8. STOCKS DROP IN TOKYO **********TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 15 (Reuters) -- Japanese stock prices fell today, despite Wall Street's broad gains on Wednesday. The Nikkei average of 225 issues lost 449.96 points, or 1.88 percent, to close at 23,487.48. The Nikkei lost 36.23 points on Wednesday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/24/world.main_headline: Warring Cambodian Factions Accept Proposal by Sihanouk
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/24/world.print_headline: Warring Cambodian Factions Accept Proposal by Sihanouk
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/24/world.body_text: **********Leaders of three Cambodian guerrilla factions agreed today to a compromise proposal offered by Prince Norodom Sihanouk in efforts to resume talks that could end the nation's long civil war. **********The three factions, including the Khmer Rouge, agreed on the Prince's latest proposal for the composition of a newly formed Supreme National Council, a central element in a United Nations Security Council plan to end 11 years of fighting. **********A Foreign Ministry spokesman told Reuters in Phnom Penh on Saturday night that Cambodia's Prime Minister, Hun Sen, agreed to this arrangement. **********The first meeting of the council broke up Wednesday in Bangkok, the Thai capital, when the guerrilla factions and the Vietnam-backed Phnom Penh Government could not agree on how many seats each side should have. **********Prince Sihanouk offered a compromise Friday from his home in Beijing. He proposed that he be given a seat as chairman of the council, Phnom Penh be given an additional seat, and that the guerrillas keep their six seats, raising the council's membership to 14.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/10/busin.body_text: **********Richard C. Breeden, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today that he had decided not to delay a new rule that would allow an option to be listed on more than one exchange in the United States. **********Several options exchanges and their allies in Congress had asked Mr. Breeden to consider a delay. **********As a result of Mr. Breeden's decision, the five options exchanges will be allowed to list and to trade all new options beginning on Jan. 22. Under the current rules, options are selected by the exchanges by lottery, and any trading in an option could take place only on the floor of the exchange that selected that option. **********In letters to the heads of the five exchanges, Mr. Breeden asked that they voluntarily refrain from putting into effect the second stage of the new rule, which will allow the exchanges to select 10 options that were already listed on other exchanges for trading. Mr. Breeden said this stage should be delayed until a computer system is in place to insure that price information was available on all the exchanges. **********James R. Jones, chairman of the American Stock Exchange, and Alger B. Chapman, chairman and chief executive of the Chicago Board Options Exchange, said in separate telephone interviews that they supported Mr. Breeden's approach. **********Dale Carlson, a senior official of the Pacific Stock Exchange, said that he would have no immediate comment. Officials of the New York Stock Exchange and the Philadelphia Stock Exchange could not be reached for comment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/06/world.main_headline: New Election-Financing Scandal Linked to Mexico's Ruling Party
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/06/world.print_headline: New Election-Financing Scandal Linked to Mexico's Ruling Party
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/06/world.body_text: **********For years, voters and opposition parties have suspected that Mexican Government funds are routinely used to finance the slick election campaigns of the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party. Now for the first time there appears to be proof of such illegal diversion, and a political scandal has been set off. **********Bank and court records show that more than $10 million in Government money was funneled to the PRI, as the ruling party is known, during the governor's race last year in the state of Baja California Norte. Several officials of the previous PRI administration in the state have been arrested and are awaiting trial, but officials of the new state government have said some important records are missing and may have been destroyed. **********Opposition Is Victorious **********The matter came to light after the right-of-center National Action Party won the gubernatorial election last July in Baja California Norte, which borders California and has a population of two million. The victory of Ernesto Ruffo Appel, who took office last November, marked the first and thus far only time since the Institutional Revolutionary Party first came to power in 1929 that an opposition party triumphed in a governor's race in one of Mexico's 31 states. **********The new administration says an examination of state documents and bank records found that 251 checks had been issued by the previous government to accounts held in seven names that turned out to be fictitious, as well as to Margarita Ortega Villa, the PRI candidate in the governor's race. Most of the accounts were in names that shared the initials of the Institutional Revolutionary Party or its state president at the time, though in a different order. Many of the checks were endorsed by party officials. **********As is the case whenever there is an accusation that taxpayer money has been used for partisan purposes, leaders of the Institutional Revolutionary Party here and in Baja California Norte deny that any government funds were illegally channeled to them. They say the party received only the small government subsidy that is normally made available to all registered political parties here under the terms of the Federal Electoral Code, and accuse the opposition of slander. **********'Eminently Political' **********''The government of the state of Baja California has neither supported nor presented the proof for the accusations it has made,'' Senator Luis Donaldo Colosio, the party's national president, said recently. ''So this is an accusation that we have described as eminently political.'' **********But Mr. Ruffo has said he is merely acting ''with objectivity and respect for the law, in no way motivated by political or electoral considerations.'' On a visit to the capital to discuss the case with President Carlos Salinas de Gortari and Interior Minister Fernando Gutierrez Barrios, he told reporters that both he and the federal Government were eager to avoid a ''vendetta.'' **********Mr. Salinas has had no direct public comment on the case, though last year he acknowledged the existence of ''pockets of corruption'' in the state after forcing Xicotencatl Leyva Mortera, the Governor at the time, to resign. Mr. Salinas came to office in December 1988 saying that the ''era of virtually one party'' was over and he has promised ''clean and transparent elections.'' **********The Organization of American States recently warned the Mexican Government that ''it must comply exactly with the obligation to guarantee the free and full exercise of political rights.'' The admonition, in a report by the Inter-American Human Rights Commission of the O.A.S., came in response to formal complaints by the National Action Party that the Institutional Revolutionary Party and the Mexican Government had committed fraud in elections in the states of Chihuahua and Durango in 1985 and 1986. **********Mexican political analysts said Mr. Ruffo may be reluctant to pursue the Baja California Norte case aggressively for fear of offending the central authorities. Mexican states and municipalities depend on federal funds for most of their budgets, and administrations dominated by the Institutional Revolutionary Party have not hesitated in the past to cut back or delay allotments when opposition-run governments take actions that challenge the party's supremacy. **********In addition, Mayor Milton Castellanos of Mexicali, who was head of the party's state committee in Baja California Norte last year, admitted in an interview with a newspaper here last month that more than half of the $10 million ended up in his hands, but maintained no laws were broken. He described the money as ''coming from dues from party members working in the government, which were deducted and given to me,'' adding, ''It is a revolving fund.'' **********Where the Money Goes **********The ruling party is known throughout Mexico for its lavish campaigns, which usually involve bringing in scores of party workers from around the country, lodging them in expensive hotels and renting several buildings as campaign offices. Hundreds of thousands of election posters, fliers, calendars, key rings, T-shirts and banners are usually distributed, lavish picnics, barbecues and banquets are organized, and all available wall space is painted with the name of the candidate, his campaign slogan and the red, white and green colors of the party. **********Another common practice is to transport huge caravans of farm workers, labor union members and government employees to rallies of PRI candidates, to give the appearance of broad popular support and electoral invincibility. Those attending such campaign events are usually given a bag lunch and coupons redeemable later for cash at party offices or for tortillas, beans or rice at Government-owned grocery stores. **********Party officials say the PRI's large campaign expenditures are made possible by generous donations from party loyalists. But Mexico has no laws requiring the reporting of campaign expenditures, and PRI campaign managers consistently turn aside requests from reporters for an accounting of donations and spending. **********Nearly two years after the 1988 presidential campaign, for instance, the party says it still has no idea how much was spent to elect Mr. Salinas in the most hotly contested presidential vote in modern Mexican history. **********''We do not have the cost,'' Mr. Colosio, who was Mr. Salinas's campaign manager, said when asked last month how much had been spent on the campaign.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/03/world.body_text: **********Ethiopian rebels said today that they seized a third town in central Ethiopia in their drive southward toward Addis Ababa, the capital. **********The rebels have been fighting since 1974 to oust the Marxist Government of President Mengistu Haile Mariam. **********The Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Democratic Front said in a radio broadcast monitored in Nairobi that its fighters captured the town of Jihur after mounting a ''fierce offensive'' on Sunday. **********In earlier combat, after fighting stepped up in mid-December, the rebels said they took the garrison town of Debra Tabor in northwestern Gondar Province and Mehal Meda and Rabel in Shoa, the province that includes the capital. Mehal Meda, Rabel and Jihur all are within 100 miles of Addis Ababa. **********Jihur is 70 miles northeast of the capital and 25 miles west of one of two highways that connect Addis Ababa with the port of Assab. **********The broadcast said a brigade and a company of Government troops were ''taken apart'' in the weekend fighting, making no mention of rebel casualties. The rebels had asserted that the Government lost more than 8,000 dead, wounded or captured in the earlier fighting. **********It was not possible to verify rebel claims. Western diplomats in Addis Ababa said previous rebel claims appeared to be accurate. **********The front is a combined force of the Tigre People's Liberation Front and the smaller Ethiopia People's Democratic Movement. **********Rebels and the Government have held preliminary peace talks, but a diplomat said the talks ''don't appear to be going far now.'' **********In Addis Ababa today, 21 military and police officers accused of involvement in a May 16 coup attempt against Colonel Mengistu were arraigned before a three-member military court. **********Trial for the eight colonels, six majors, three captains and four lieutenants was adjourned until Jan. 11 to allow them time to get lawyers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/15/busin.main_headline: Bond Prices in a Slight Advance
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/15/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS;   Bond Prices in a Slight Advance
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/15/busin.body_text: **********Bond prices rose slightly and long-term interest rates dipped yesterday, as credit market participants reacted favorably to a more stable oil market, rumors of institutional purchases of long-term securities and hopes that the meeting tomorrow between President Bush and King Hussein of Jordan may help to defuse tensions in the Middle East. **********Price gains were concentrated among long-term securities, even though a number of analysts said they are convinced that economic weakness will force the Federal Reserve Board to ease short-term interest rates soon, perhaps as early as next week. **********Indeed, market participants suggested that yesterday's small gains in bond prices were likely to prove ephemeral until and unless the warlike atmosphere that prevails in the Middle East evaporates. **********''It is hard to imagine the market going higher without a solution in the region,'' one government bond trader said. **********''Last week. the long end got killed because of oil prices, and if the situtation over there gets resolved, presumably oil prices will come down and the long end will take off.'' **********Kennebunkport Meeting **********Word that King Hussein would be traveling to Kennebunkport, Maine, bearing a letter from Iraq's President Saddam Hussein to President Bush at his vacation home flashed across trading screens in advance of the President's 4 P.M. news conference and led to some speculation that a deal that would end the conflict might already have been struck. **********That notion was quickly dispelled when Mr. Bush began his meeting with reporters by talking tough on the Federal budget. **********The President's remarks, in which he re-emphasized the need to cut $50 billion from the budget in the coming fiscal year, did not provoke much of a reaction from traders. **********Nevertheless, ''his remarks were somewhat positive for the market,'' said Lawrence N. Leuzzi, a managing director at S.G. Warburg & Company. **********''Given everything that has happened in the Middle East and its likely impact on the economy, he could have used this opportunity to backslide on what was needed and to reset the budget negotiations in a framework where smaller cuts would be sought,'' Mr. Leuzzi said. **********Activity in the secondary market for Treasury securities was light yesterday, due in part to the lingering effects of the widespread power failures in lower Manhattan. **********Although most dealers were fully operational yesterday, two major interdealer brokers, the RMJ Securities Corporation and Fundamental Brokers Inc., were still without power. **********By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 99 22/32, up 5/32, to yield 8.78 percent, down slightly from 8.79 percent late Monday. **********Among note issues, the 8 1/2 percent five-year notes were offered in late trading at 100 21/32, down 1/32, to yield 8.31 percent. And the 8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 1/8, down 2/32, to yield 7.92 percent. **********Short-term Treasury bill rates rose slightly. **********Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.43 percent late yesterday, up four basis points, or hundredths of a point. Six-month bills rose by three basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.32 percent. And one-year bills were offered at 7.17 percent, up three basis points. **********Note and Bill Rates **********Even though the view that the Fed will move soon to lower short-term interest rates was not reflected in note and bill rates yesterday, some market participants said that such a move was very likely. **********''I don't think the Fed has any choice'' but to lower rates after its policy-making Open Market Committee meets on Aug. 21, said William M. Brachfeld, executive vice president at Daiwa Securities America Inc. **********While such a move would do little to help cool inflation, ''we don't want to have a recession in this country,'' Mr. Brachfeld said. **********Elsewhere, activity in the secondary markets for investment-grade corporate bonds and tax-exempt municipal securities was very light, dealers said. **********Prices of most widely quoted corporate bonds were unchanged on the day. Meanwhile, prices of most municipal bonds rose by about 1/4 point. **********New issues priced yesterday included a competitive offering of $115 million worth of insured tax-exempt serial bonds from the Ohio Public Facility for Higher Education. **********The bonds, which are insured by the Municipal Bond Investors Assurance Corporation, were won by a syndicate led by Bear, Stearns & Company. **********The serial bonds were reoffered to investors with coupons from 5.90 percent in 1992 to 7 percent in 2005. **********The issue is rated AAA by both Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/23/world.main_headline: NATO Considering Proposing a Ceiling For German Troops
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/23/world.print_headline: NATO Considering Proposing a Ceiling For German Troops
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/23/world.body_text: **********To satisfy Soviet concerns about the size of a united Germany's armed forces, the NATO allies are considering offering Moscow a specific limit for the future German Army as part of the conventional-arms-reduction treaty being considered in Vienna, Administration officials said today. **********The NATO position has been that it would be ready to include in the current conventional arms reduction treaty, known as CFE-1, a general promise to limit the size of a united Germany's armed forces in the future - but without committing to any particular numbers now. **********New NATO Offer **********Any specific limitations, NATO had argued, should be worked out under a CFE-2 agreement sometime in the future. But the Soviets have declared that they will not sign the first agreement or withdraw their forces from East Germany until they are satisfied that the German Army will be sharply limited. The NATO allies, led by Bonn, are strongly considering offering Moscow not only a general promise to deal with the size of the German Army, as part of the initial agreement, but also to specify an actual limit that would be put into effect as part of the followup accord. **********By offering Moscow some hard numbers, an Administration official said, ''It would not just be a pig in poke for the Soviets.'' Instead, it would be ''a specific commitment, with a number or a percentage.'' **********The subtle but important shift being considered by NATO grew largely out of discussions between Bonn and Washington and was based on several considerations: that the Soviets simply will not withdraw from Germany unless this issue is addressed; that the Germans themselves have already announced their intention to reduce the size of their armed forces, and that there really is no reason to not make the commitment in the initial treaty if an equitable figure can be worked out.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/29/world.main_headline: 20,000 Stage a Rally in Rumania To Protest Against the New Rulers
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/29/world.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: RUMANIA;   20,000 Stage a Rally in Rumania To Protest Against the New Rulers
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/29/world.body_text: **********Shouting anti-Communist and anti-Government slogans, about 20,000 people marched today to the headquarters of the ruling Council of National Salvation for an opposition rally that revealed the widening split over the country's political course. **********The demonstration was led by the three major opposition parties, which are already engaged in round-table talks with the council. As the rally dispersed in a bitter mood early tonight, President Ion Iliescu said the discussions would continue next week. **********Earlier in the week, organizers of the rally, which included the Peasants' Party, the Liberal Party and the Social Democratic Party, issued a communique calling for a new provisional government, to be made up of representatives of the major parties, youth leaders and people who have opposed the Communists over the last 45 years. **********But as the crowd marched to Victory Place on a cool and sunny day, the chant was for the Council of National Salvation to step down. ''Down with Iliescu!'' ''Down with Communism!'' and ''Resign!'' the crowd shouted. **********The placards underlined similar themes. ''We don't want to be laboratory rats for the Communists,'' read one. Another put an equal sign between the Nazi swastika and the hammer and sickle. **********Suspicions in the Streets **********Although the council renounced Communism when it assumed power after the overthrow of the dictator Nicolae Ceausescu on Dec. 22, suspicions about its leading members continue. Many were not only members of the Party, but at one time also held high-ranking posts in the Ceausescu Government. **********A dog-eared clipping from a French newspaper showing a picture, dated 1976, of Mr. Iliescu, a former Party Secretary for Youth, and Mr. Ceausescu bowling together was handed back and forth among demonstrators. **********''We are here because they are all Communists and Stalinists,'' said Juliana Vasinschi, a translator at a construction institute, who was on the front lines of the demonstration, ''and we don't want neo-Communism, any more than we want neo-fascism.'' **********General elections are scheduled on May 20, but the recent announcement that the council will field its own candidates, without reorganizing as a political party, has alarmed the opposition. A series of Government decrees limiting the right to protest has also upset independent groups, particularly students, although today there was no effort by the armed soldiers guarding the council's headquarters to enforce the new rules. **********At about 4 P.M., after standing still for three hours, the chanting crowd burst through a line of soldiers, running past tanks parked in the street, to crowd around the entrance at the council headquarters, which is also the Foreign Ministry. Although generally peaceful, the rally had its ugly moments as pro-Government supporters, called to Victory Place by an appeal on the Government-controlled television, formed phalanxes and pushed and shoved demonstrators away from the area directly in front of the building. **********The men, burly and tough, moved ahead of a large truck that also pressed through the crowd, with a group of chanting council supporters riding on top, waving banners. Within an hour, as a patriotic song was broadcast from giant speakers, drowning out the anti-Government chants, the place in front of the building had been cleared of protesters, leaving in their place a crowd that greeted Mr. Iliescu with cheers instead of boos. **********The strong-arm tactics, eerily reminiscent of the way ruling Communists typically broke up protests, only reinforced people's disgust with the council and its tactics. ''I thought I knew what I thought of them when I came today, but now I am sure,'' said Florin Tanascu, an engineer who was working as a marshal for the Peasants' Party. **********''They are our enemies,'' said Ion Radoiu, who heads the Peasants Party's youth group. ''They were using not workers but gypsies and people let out of prison. They are animals.'' **********Some of the scenes today were also reminiscent of episodes during the revolution that ousted Mr. Ceausescu. But this time, those who had been in the crowd besieging the party's Central Committee building on Dec. 22 were now on the balcony, and the chants from below were not against Mr. Ceausescu but Mr. Iliescu. **********After the speech by Mr. Iliescu from the floodlit balcony, the two groups -supporters and opponents of the council - separated by a swath of ankle-deep mud, yelled bitter, angry slogans at each other. **********''You are not Rumanians!'' and ''Down with immigrants!'' were some chants by the council's supporters, while the protesters shouted back, ''Assassins!'' and ''Criminals!'' **********Foreign Money Assailed **********Several council supporters said they had come because they wanted to defend Mr. Iliescu, who had steered them in the days after the revolution. Others said they had heard that the opposition parties were trying to buy support with foreign money, apparently referring to the well-publicized return of Rumanians from abroad. **********The battle of the crowds outside matched a debate that went on inside the building, where leaders of the opposition sat at a round table with Mr. Iliescu, Prime Minister Petre Roman and other council leaders. Most of the opposition figures are old men who had been active in their parties before the Communist era, and in the case of the leader of the Peasants' Party, Corneliu Coposu, were imprisoned as a result. **********The demonstration today capped a week of almost daily rallies, protesting new issued by the council or its continuing hold over news organizations. **********With the exception of the daily newspaper Romania Libera, most of the press is in the hands of the council, particularly in the provinces. **********New Peasants' Party Formed **********In the Teleorman region, about 70 miles south of Bucharest, the local paper ignored the founding of a new Peasants' Party chapter eight days ago. Still, the party president, Gheorghe Mardale, a 63-year-old forester, said many peasants were besieging its offices asking to join. As of Friday, he said, 1,261 have signed up. Of these, 180 today took a four-hour train ride to make their case before the council's headquarters, he said. **********Marian Mirlea, who was also with the Peasants' Party at the rally today, had a different problem. One of the first members of the Council of National Salvation, he has not been able to make his resignation known. **********''I quit the council on Jan. 24,'' he said. ''But I could not announce it, because no one would print it.'' **********The national television tonight gave lopsided coverage to the demonstration with little attention paid to either the reasons or the people participating in the protests. It did, however, broadcast unedited portions of the round-table talks on the evening news.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/16/world.main_headline: Sri Lanka Rebels Raid Vital Airfield in North
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/16/world.print_headline: Sri Lanka Rebels Raid Vital Airfield in North
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/16/world.body_text: **********Tamil rebels today fired mortars at a vital airfield in the Jaffna peninsula at the north of this island nation, minutes after a Government minister had left at the end of a round of peace talks, military officials said. **********At least 275 people, including 137 unarmed policemen slain by the rebels, have been killed since Monday, when rebels with the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam staged a wide offensive, overrunning police stations and military camps along the east coast and the north. The death toll was put together from reports by witnesses, rebels and military officials. The Government has not given an overall toll. **********Government officials in Colombo said the army switched from defensive to offensive tactics today and killed 50 Tigers, as the rebels are known. A spokesman for the rebels acknowledged 50 rebel deaths in 48 hours. **********Justice Minister A. C. Shahul Hameed talked with rebel leaders for four hours today at the rebel stronghold in Jaffna, military officials said. **********The Tigers have been fighting since 1983 for a separate homeland for the Tamil minority. Tamils comprise 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 18 million people, while Sinhalese account for 75 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/25/world.main_headline: The Mandela Visit;   Washington, About to Receive Mandela, Is Worried About de Klerk
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/25/world.print_headline: The Mandela Visit;   Washington, About to Receive Mandela, Is Worried About de Klerk
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/25/world.body_text: **********When Nelson Mandela meets with President Bush and other officials on Monday, he will receive a warm welcome but polite resistance to his call for maintaining or increasing sanctions against South Africa, officials say. **********The principal concern of the Administration these days is in fact how to shore up Mr. Mandela's adversary, President F. W. de Klerk. Mr. Bush would greatly like to lift some of the sanctions imposed since 1986, officials said, as a show of support for Mr. de Klerk, who is regarded with admiration in the Administration. **********But Mr. Bush is prevented from doing so just yet because a law enacted four years ago over President Reagan's veto provides that the sanctions remain in place until a series of conditions are met, including the release of all political prisoners and the complete lifting of state-of-emergency regulations. **********There is nonetheless a widespread concern that something should be done to help Mr. de Klerk, who officials say may be in danger of losing support among his white constituents because of his initiatives, including the legalization of the African National Congress, of which Mr. Mandela is deputy president. **********'Something of a Visionary' **********''He's something of a visionary,'' an official said of Mr. de Klerk. ''The problem is that he may be out too far in front of his people.'' **********When asked early last week about the impending Mandela visit and the issue of sanctions, Mr. Bush immediately began speaking of his admiration for Mr. de Klerk, although he had not been asked about him. **********''Let me be very clear,'' he said. ''I salute Mr. de Klerk for what he's done. He's come a long way. And I salute Mr. Mandela for his approach to Mr. de Klerk.'' **********The President noted almost wistfully that he was unable to lift sanctions now because of the law, and he added, ''I'd like to find a way to show Mr. de Klerk that we, the United States, are grateful for this new approach that is having South Africa evolve to a much more open society and hopefully one day to one which is color-blind in terms of participation in the political process.'' **********Mr. Bush also said that there were other black leaders in South Africa who were opposed to sanctions and that he was ''looking forward to talking to Mr. Mandela about this.'' **********Comparison to Gorbachev **********Administration officials acknowledge that their approach to the South African President in some respects resembles their attitude toward President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union. In both cases, their policy is heavily dependent on the continuation in office of a specific national leader. **********Robert I. Rotberg, the new president of Lafayette College and an expert on southern African politics, said it was appropriate to regard Mr. de Klerk that way. But he said it would be a mistake not to think of Mr. Mandela in the same terms, as someone on whom the peace process depends. Mr. Mandela, he said, also faces impatient elements in his constituency. **********''We should think of them as an indispensable duo,'' Mr. Rotberg said. ''It would be wrong to tilt in any public way toward de Klerk.'' **********Herman J. Cohen, the Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, said the Administration was sensitive to the idea that both South Africans have to deal with restive supporters. ''The main thrust of our policy now is to support negotiations,'' he said in an interview. ''Last year our policy was to press the Government to accept the idea of negotiations, but now De Klerk has done that.'' **********As a result, he said, it is Mr. de Klerk who now faces political dangers, because of his efforts to engage the African National Congress in negotiations as well as other steps to change the apartheid system. **********'De Klerk Needs Support' **********''Our analysis of the situation in South Africa right now is that President de Klerk is under increasing pressure from the right,'' Mr. Cohen said. He cited a parliamentary by-election this month in which Mr. de Klerk's ruling National Party barely held off a challenge from the extreme rightist Conservative Party in a district once thought to be safe for the Government. **********''This indicates that Mr. de Klerk needs support,'' he said. **********Mr. Cohen said that lifting some of the sanctions would be most useful to Mr. de Klerk now, but that ''our hands are tied by the law.'' **********Representative Howard Wolpe, a Michigan Democrat who heads the House subcommittee on Africa, said there were ways other than lifting sanctions to help Mr. de Klerk. ''We can make clear the tangible benefits that would flow to South Africa from a fully normal relationship,'' he said. ''We would even encourage companies to move there.'' **********Mr. Cohen said sanctions could not be removed, even partly, until all political prisoners are released and a state of emergency imposed by the Government is completely lifted. The African National Congress and the Government have been negotiating over the release of prisoners. The Government has accepted a tentative agreement reached by a working committee representing the two sides, and in an interview last week, Mr. Mandela indicated that the proposal was acceptable to his side as well. **********Lifted in Three Provinces **********Mr. de Klerk has lifted emergency regulations, which gave the security forces broad powers to suppress unrest, in three of the four provinces. Even though the African National Congress has not complained strongly about the Government's decision to leave the state of emergency in place in Natal province, where violence between rival black factions continues. Administration lawyers say this precludes the lifting of sanctions. **********Mr. Cohen noted that Mr. Mandela has pressed his view that pressure should be maintained on South Africa, and he said Mr. Bush and others ''certainly want to hear his point of view.'' **********''But one thing that has to be made absolutely clear is that decisions will be made here on that policy and that Mr. Mandela will not make those decisions for us,'' he said. **********Another senior Administration official expressed this viewpoint more bluntly. He said it was important to signal to the African National Congress that Washington would not back its every demand. ''They might think they never have to compromise,'' the official said. **********Mr. Mandela has said the people chosen to negotiate with the Government should be elected. While Mr. Cohen said that was feasible, other Administration officials have dismissed this idea as absurd.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/11/busin.main_headline: Tokyo Market Uneasy On Fears About Soviets
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/11/busin.print_headline: Tokyo Market Uneasy On Fears About Soviets
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/11/busin.body_text: **********Fears about political turmoil in the Soviet Union helped undermine a record-setting stock market rally, causing prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange to skid over the last week in an increasingly nervous investment climate. **********On Wednesday, investors on the Tokyo Stock Exchange succumbed to concerns that ethnic unrest in the Soviet Union threatened President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's hold on power, sending the Nikkei average of 225 stocks down 254.95 points, to 37,696.51, after a 343.50-point decline Tuesday. **********Last Friday, the index tumbled 438.12 points on another rumor, which proved unfounded, that Mr. Gorbachev had canceled all of his scheduled January meetings with foreign leaders because of growing political unrest. The 3 percent decline from Friday to Wednesday yis comparable to about an 80-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average. Bond prices have also fallen steadily this year and interest rates have popped upward. **********There was evidence today that the fears may have begun to ease as the stock market rallied. The Nikkei index gained 473.62 points, or 1.3 percent. to close at 38,170.13. **********'Realistic Appraisal' **********Still, the market remains worried. **********''Perestroika was a theme that had been driving the market last year because people thought it would stimulate a whole new round of global economic growth,'' said Lawrence S. Prager, senior analyst at the Nikko Securities Company. ''What the rumors have shown is that people are now making a more realistic appraisal of the economic prospects for Eastern Europe.'' **********Reflecting the unsettled state of the markets, the dollar has risen against a weakening yen. The dollar reached 145.30 yen in Tokyo Wednesday, up from 144.95 in New York late Tuesday, despite heavy dollar selling by the Bank of Japan. Currency traders said the central bank has intervened in the foreign-exchange market every day this week, in a largely unsuccessful effort to stabilize the yen. **********Even though the dollar selling was apparently ineffective, the central bank's governor, Yasushi Mieno, said at a news conference Wednesday that the bank would continue to intervene when necessary. **********Overreaction Seen **********''I think in part people were too optimistic at the end of last year and so they were surprised when interest rates rose at first, so they have overreacted by selling the yen and bonds too much,'' said an executive at the Industrial Bank of Japan. ''But there is a real edge to what is happening. Everybody is anxious about everybody else, what the other person is doing.'' **********Some analysts described the tumble as more a symptom of a growing nervousness here than a direct result of concerns about troubles in the Soviet Union. In particular, there are worries about the domestic political situation, with an election approaching. There have been reports in the Japanese press that another stock and influence-peddling scandal may be brewing. **********In addition, the stock market has been falling on relatively light volume, a sign that big institutions have not joined in the selling. **********Shares of smaller companies listed on the second section of the Tokyo Stock Exchange have continued to reach record highs, indicating that speculative interest in the market has not died, analysts said. **********'Red Chip' Stocks **********Nonetheless, the stories about the Soviet Union have clearly hit a raw nerve among investors, who had been betting, perhaps too heavily, that Japanese companies were poised to capitalize on the opening of the Eastern bloc economies. **********The market rally late last year had been led by what came to be known as ''red chip'' stocks, shares of companies expected to benefit from the economic opening of Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. **********Share prices of the major trading companies, heavy machinery makers and electrical equipment producers all rose sharply in the expectation that they might be able to increase their exports to Eastern Europe. **********The recent rumors have hit these shares particularly hard. Two trading companies, Mitsui & Company and the Marubeni Corporation, fell Wednesday, as did Komatsu, which produces tractors, and Toshiba Machinery.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/09/busin.body_text: **********Jury selection began today in United States District Court for the trial of three traders of Swiss franc futures on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange who are accused of swindling customers. The traders - Robert D. Mosky, Danny L. Scheck and David Zatz - represent one of four groups of 47 Chicago futures traders who were indicted last year. **********They were arrested after **********F.B.I. agents posing as corrupt traders secretly tape-recorded conversations that the Government contends disclose organized fraud among traders at the Merc and the rival Chicago Board of Trade, the world's two largest futures exchanges. **********United States District Judge **********Ann C. Williams has decided to allow defense lawyers to introduce evidence of their clients' lawful behavior to show that the difference between legal and illegal trading is unclear. **********Prosecutors have not disclosed how much money they believe was illegally obtained by traders.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/26/busin.main_headline: Canada and Quebec Ratings On Debt Are Reaffirmed
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/26/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;   Canada and Quebec Ratings On Debt Are Reaffirmed
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/26/busin.body_text: **********The collapse over the weekend of Canada's Meech Lake Accord creates an uncertain outlook, but has had no immediate impact on the credit ratings of the Government of Canada or the Province of Quebec, two major ratings agencies said yesterday. **********In separate announcements, the Standard & Poor's Corporation and Moody's Investors Service reaffirmed their ratings on outstanding debt issued by the Province of Quebec and on the guaranteed debt of Hydro-Quebec. **********At current exchange rates, the Province of Quebec has roughly $23.5 billion in outstanding debt. There is approximately $19.5 billion of outstanding Hydro-Quebec debt that is guaranteed by the province. **********In reaffirming its AA-minus ratings on Quebec's debt and on the guaranteed debt of Hydro-Quebec, Standard & Poor's added that its outlook for Quebec's long-term debt ratings has changed ''to developing from positive.'' **********''A developing outlook indicates that credit quality might strengthen or weaken over a 12- to 36-month period,'' Standard & Poor's said in a news release. ''Which in this case depends on how political uncertainty affects underlying economic strengths.'' **********Standard & Poor's also reaffirmed its AAA ratings on the Canadian Government's debt. Moody's did not provide an opinion yesterday on any change in the agency's assessment of the Government's credit-worthiness. **********''Canada's rating is not about to change,'' said Timothy Crowell, assistant director of Canadian ratings at Moody's. The agency has a AAA rating on the Government of Canada's outstanding debt.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/12/busin.main_headline: Former Mulroney Aide Named Campeau Chief
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/12/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Former Mulroney Aide Named Campeau Chief
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/12/busin.body_text: **********The Campeau Corporation, the debt-ridden Canadian parent of two big United States store chains, has named a new president and chief executive officer, Stanley H. Hartt, who until September was chief of staff to Prime Minister Brian Mulroney. **********Mr. Hartt, who is 52 years old, succeeds James D. Raymond and Gary M. Goodman, who have served on an interim basis in the office of the chief executive since August, when Robert Campeau, the company's founder, was ousted. Mr. Campeau remains a director. Mr. Raymond, who represented interests of the National Bank of Canada, and Mr. Goodman, who did the same for another large shareholder, Olympia & York, will remain on the board. **********A spokesman for the Toronto-based company, Richard Wertheim, said the American operations will continue to be run autonomously. Federated Stores Inc., based in Cincinnati, is the parent of Federated Department Stores Inc. and the Allied Stores Corporation, the retailing units that have been under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection since January. The companies own the Bloomingdale's, Jordan Marsh and Abraham & Straus store chains, among others. **********Mr. Wertheim said Mr. Hartt did not plan to give interviews until he got his feet more firmly under his desk at Campeau. Mr. Hartt is an old acquaintance of G. William Miller, the former United States Treasury Secretary who is the chairman of Federated Stores. **********Although he has no real estate or retail background, Mr. Wertheim said Mr. Hartt's strong points for Campeau will be his knowledge of finance, his negotiating skills and his familiarity with people in banking and politics. **********After serving as the Prime Minister's chief of staff, Mr. Hartt returned to his old law firm, Stikeman Elliott, briefly last month as a partner in the Montreal office. Earlier in his career he was a Canadian deputy minister of finance. **********Mr. Hartt is expected to be appointed a Campeau director and its chairman at the next board meeting, succeeding Robert Despres, the acting chairman. **********In another change at Campeau, Paul D. Campbell, its president, announced plans to resign on Jan. 6 to become president and chief executive of Trilea Centres Inc., a Canadian real estate developer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/12/busin.main_headline: Oil Crunch '90: The Game Has Changed
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/12/busin.print_headline: MARKET WATCH;   Oil Crunch '90: The Game Has Changed
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/12/busin.body_text: **********If oil prices stay up, how will the poorer countries - and companies - pay their energy bills? **********That question may take on great importance in coming weeks, as the world watches to see what Iraq will do as an economic boycott takes hold. **********One sure thing is that the patterns established in the two oil shocks of the 1970's will not hold. Then, the oil exporters, awash in cash, deposited the money in Western banks, which in turn lent it to the countries that needed the money to pay for oil. The banks called the process ''recycling,'' and no one spent much time worrying about how those countries would ever repay the loans. It turned out many of them couldn't. Bankers have not forgotten that lesson. **********This time around, the problem may be greater because Eastern Europe no longer can count on cheap Soviet oil. **********It's not only the countries that have problems, of course. ''The combination of recession and oil price shock will create a new wave of bankruptcies,'' forecasts Richard Hoey, the chief American economist for Barclays de Zoete Wedd. ''It's very clear that optimistic estimates of cash flow of a lot of borrowers will be disappointed.'' Mr. Hoey had been forecasting a mild recession before the Iraqi annexation of Kuwait. Now he thinks it will be longer and deeper. **********Two years ago, when Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. was still in business and peddling junk bonds, those companies might have found a friendly lender to tide them over. Now the credit markets are in what Mr. Hoey, a veteran of Drexel, calls a ''risk crunch,'' in which would-be borrowers without excellent credit find money unavailable at any price, while blue chip companies can borrow all they want. **********In the stock market, a free fall in prices early in the week was followed by a mild rally in mid-week and then a new decline on Friday, as Saddam Hussein called for a ''holy war'' against ''evil enemies'' that included the Saudi royal family. That helped send oil prices back up, with crude for delivery next month at $26.23 per barrel, and send the rate on 30-year Treasury bonds up to 8.79 percent. **********The Dow Jones industrial average was down 93.07 points for the week, to 2,716.58, and is now 9.4 percent below the peak it reached less than a month ago. **********Although it seems clear that Mideast news will dominate the markets for some time, and positive developments could start a rally, it is worth remembering that the current dip in prices started before the Iraqi invasion. ''Even if the Iraqi problem disappears,'' said Steven Einhorn, the chief investment strategist at Goldman, Sachs, ''the market still has to confront the fundamentals of a weak economy and earnings disappointments.'' He says stocks remain overvalued. **********If the Mideast standoff drags on, and oil prices stay high, the big division in financial markets is likely to be one of quality and safety. Companies with the financial flexibility to cope with higher oil prices and lower sales are likely to do much better than those that badly need to borrow when no one wants to lend.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/22/busin.body_text: **********With the nation's financial institutions curtailing their real estate lending, the commercial building projects with the best chances - and in some cities the only chances - of getting financing these days are those that are made to order for a specific buyer or tenant. These projects, known as build-to-suit developments, are experiencing a boom as the nation's developers, most of which build on speculation, try to compete in the custom market. **********''The market in build-to-suits is getting really crowded because speculative development has dried up and companies with development staffs are competing for these opportunities,'' said Robert Williamson, the director of national marketing for the Prudential Property Company, a big national developer. **********In build-to-suit projects, developers design and construct buildings to the needs of a primary tenant, which pays the developer a marginal fee for design and construction work and agrees to buy the completed building or occupy all or most of it in exchange for a favorable long-term lease. **********Clear Numbers for Lenders **********The projects are easier for developers to finance than speculative buildings because rental incomes are guaranteed through a contract, allowing lenders to see clearly how their loans will be repaid. **********''The banks will only come into a situation where debt coverage is clear and up front from the beginning, and right now that's in build-to-suits,'' said William Conway, managing director of Jones Lang Wootton, an international real estate concern based in New York. **********But these projects are usually less profitable for developers than speculative developments. Custom builders must absorb any overruns themselves, because they are locked into fixed rental rates or selling prices before they complete a project. **********By contrast, speculative builders can pass on all of their building expenses to their tenants, and they generally charge higher rental rates for taking on more risks, including the possibility that they will be left holding on to thousands of square feet of vacant office space. **********Pricing Problem **********As a result, many speculative builders are not well versed in the intricacies of build-to-suit pricing, leading to predictions that many will have trouble competing in the market. **********Build-to-suit developments were pioneered by a few large developers in the 1970's for designing specialized industrial projects. But office space is increasingly being tailored this way. **********The build-to-suit explosion has been going on in Texas for several years. It took hold there after a drop in energy prices pushed the economies of Houston and Dallas into recession and devastated real estate values. **********David Shulman, the director of real estate research at Salomon Brothers, said, ''It's been happening in Texas for a long while now and it's not surprising that it's now happening elsewhere in the country.'' Texas Project for I.B.M.  Among the most recent custom-made buildings in Texas is the new $150 million office complex in Austin that Dallas-based Prentiss Properties is building for the International Business Machines Corporation. In that deal, NCNB Texas National Bank beat out another large domestic bank and two Japanese banks to provide construction financing. Prentiss, which has generally limited itself to doing build-to-suit projects, prevailed over competition like the Trammell Crow Company to build the 1.1-million-square-foot office space. **********''We got the project because we had already established a real good relationship with I.B.M.,'' said Michael Prentiss, president of the developer. **********Prentiss had completed six other made-to-order buildings, valued at about $1 billion, for I.B.M. **********''They had a tight time schedule and it's an important project, so they needed a partner that could deliver the product on time,'' Mr. Prentiss said. **********Growth for Trammell Crow **********Dallas-based Trammell Crow, the nation's largest developer, has more than doubled its build-to-suit business over the last two years, to 10 million square feet, said Marc Myers, a partner at Trammell Crow who oversees these projects. **********''It's always been about a third of our business, and right now it's about 80 percent,'' he said. **********''Over the next five years, on a sustained basis, I expect it will be about 60 to 65 percent of our business,'' said Mr. Myers, who added that the number of build-to-suits Trammell Crow is doing has doubled this year, to 10 million square feet. But many developers who excelled at speculative building are discovering what the build-to-suit developers have known all along: the two businesses are radically different. **********'A Different Business' **********''Build-to-suits are going to be the largest share of the business, and everyone is going to be competing for them,'' Mr. Myers said, ''but it is fundamentally a different business because it requires greater technical skills, greater pricing precision and a team approach.'' **********In the typical build-to-suit project, a prospective tenant approaches a builder with specifications for the type of building it needs. A period of exploration and negotiation between the developer's technical staff and the client follows. During this period, which can last for months, the developer nails down the specific kind of building the client needs. **********The development team then offers the client a guaranteed price on the building based on computer-estimated costs of construction. Competition among builders prevents padding of the estimates in case of overruns, and usually if the cost of construction runs up because of rising interest rates after the project has begun, the developer assumes the expense. **********Challenge of Pricing **********''You have to price the rent precisely to fit the project and make a slight return,'' Mr. Myers said. **********The developer then works closely with the architects and contractors to deliver the building on time and within costs. **********''In order to be a really strong build-to-suit developer,'' said William Alter, president of the Alter Group, a build-to-suit company based in Wilmette, Ill., ''you have to be able to do the numbers properly because you give the client a guaranteed fixed price up front, and you have to have proper asset management ability.'' **********For instance, an unexpected engineers' strike delayed by six weeks a 1982 project by the Alter Group to build a 350,000-square-foot research center in Naperville, Ill., near Chicago, for A.T.&T.'s Bell Laboratories. Bad weather delayed the project by another three weeks. Nonetheless, the complex still had to be delivered within 17 months of the starting date. Alter not only arranged for nonstriking engineers to keep things going at 60 percent of capacity, but also increased the total hours logged weekly to make up for lost time. **********The developer also had to absorb the cost of design changes ordered by the client. These changes doubled the cost of the cafeteria alone. **********Land Problems **********The most frequent source of overruns is problems with the land. Building codes and zoning regulations can change, and increasingly complex environmental issues can add to a developer's expenses. **********Build-to-suit projects often require more technical skill because they often are specialized projects like research and development centers, manufacturing plants or distribution warehouses. Some projects combine many of these different functions. **********Increasingly, big corporate tenants in such deals are not satisfied with favorable long-term leases or equity positions in the completed project. Many corporate tenants choose to buy the building, several builders said. **********Lower Profit Margins **********In part because they sell or invite tenants to take equity stakes in these buildings, custom developers' profit margins are less than those of speculators, who make much of their money on a property's long-term appreciation. Although it differs with each project, the margin on build-to-suit projects can sometimes be as thin as three-quarters of 1 percent between the rent and the cost of the construction, Mr. Myers said. But generally the industry tries to get closer to 2 percent. **********And developers have no guarantee of getting financing even for those build-to-suit projects with large, well-known clients and long leases. The banks are rigorous in their due-diligence reviews and can be very reluctant to finance even these deals.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/06/world.main_headline: Mubarak Says Israel and Iraq Had Secret Contacts
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/06/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;   Mubarak Says Israel and Iraq Had Secret Contacts
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/06/world.body_text: **********An assertion by President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt that Israel has been secretly in contact with Iraq in recent weeks drew angry reactions from Israeli officials today, but no denials. **********The Israeli officials accused Mr. Mubarak of violating a policy of playing down Israel's role in the Persian Gulf crisis. But one official acknowledged that Israel had informal contacts with Iraq during the 1980-1988 Iran-Iraq war, and a former Government official said the exchanges had continued through intermediaries during the current confrontation. **********Mr. Mubarak's statements followed several press reports of recent contacts between Iraq and Israel. But his highly public statements were the first to draw an Israeli response. **********Keeping a Low Profile **********Eliyahu Ben-Elissar, chairman of the Israeli Parliament's defense and foreign affairs committee, said that Mr. Mubarak's comments were aimed at undercutting Iraq, not Israel. **********''He wants to shame Iraq in the Arab world,'' Mr. Ben-Elissar said of Mr. Mubarak in an interview with Israel's army radio. **********But he added: ''Why in the world is he involving us at a time when we are trying so hard - by the by, at the request of the Egyptians, the Americans and others - not to get involved?'' **********Despite repeated Iraqi threats to attack Israel in the current crisis, Israel has maintained a low profile to avoid undermining United States efforts to mobilize moderate Arab countries to counter Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. **********Role of Harvard Professor **********In a speech on Thursday marking the 17th anniversary of Egypt's last war with Israel, Mr. Mubarak said that Iraq and Israel have had indirect contacts for years. He described secret exchanges in 1987 and 1989 through a Harvard University professor. **********Mr. Mubarak did not identify the professor, but Israeli newspapers said she was Laurie Mylroie, the co-author of a book that discusses these contacts. A spokeswoman for Ms. Mylroie denied she had been a go-between. **********Mr. Mubarak said he was disclosing the exchanges in response to Iraqi allegations that Egypt was subservient to the Israeli and United States intelligence services. **********He also implied that Egypt had access to Israel's intelligence data under the 1979 peace treaty between the two countries. Israel radio quoted unidentified army officials as denying any exchange of intelligence with Egypt. **********The Israeli Foreign and Defense Ministries declined to comment on Mr. Mubarak's statements. Avi Pazner, an aide to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, said in response to a similar report earlier this week that he was unaware of any Israeli-Iraqi contacts during the gulf crisis. **********The first report of such contacts was published late last month in The Economist, a British magazine. It said Iraq had been sending messages in recent weeks to Israel through King Hussein of Jordan. **********Message Sent Through Zambia **********''Iraq offered not to attack Israel if Israel would agree not to attack Iraq in the event of a war in the gulf,'' the publication said. ''Israel replied, again through King Hussein, that it had no plan to attack Iraq or to be involved in the gulf crisis.'' **********The Government-run radio in Jordan reported that the Iraqi message had been sent to Israel via President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia. **********The Economist said the contacts included meetings between Israeli officials and the Iraqi Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, and his deputy, Nizar Hamdoon. It said that at least two proposed meetings with an Israeli Cabinet minister had fallen through.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/02/busin.main_headline: Mexico's President Urges Latin Investments by West
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/02/busin.print_headline: Mexico's President Urges Latin Investments by West
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/02/busin.body_text: **********President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico urged the industrialized nations of the West today not to forget Mexico and the rest of Latin America as they move to help the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe. **********Addressing the opening session of the World Economic Forum, an annual gathering of political and business leaders, Mr. Salinas said Mexico had already carried out many of the painful changes, including economic deregulation and privatization of state entities, that still lie ahead in Eastern Europe. **********''We know that any economic reform takes time and demands sacrifices,'' he said, ''because if hopes are thwarted, the sense of future can be lost, only to be replaced by nostalgia for the past.'' **********Main Theme of Message **********Turning to the main theme of his current five-nation European trip, he said, ''May these splendid signs of change not cloud Europe's global vision, nor turn its attention away from our continent - particularly Mexico - and from other regions of the world.'' **********So far, Mr. Salinas has carried this message to meetings with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher in London and Chancellor Helmut Kohl in Bonn and to the headquarters of the European Community in Brussels. Mexican officials said his domestic economic program had been praised in all three capitals. **********But his audience today was made up largely of senior executives of big European, Japanese and American corporations. And here he stressed that Mexico has relaxed its rules for foreign investment and warmly welcomed outside participation in new growth resulting from completion of the latest talks on its foreign debt. **********Forum Focuses on Shift in East **********This year's weeklong World Economic Forum seems likely to be dominated almost entirely by the challenges facing Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union as they gradually move from centrally planned to market-oriented economies. **********Probably no Latin American country is currently better positioned to speak for the third world to this audience than Mexico. Since taking office a year ago, the Salinas administration has not only obtained the best foreign debt restructuring deal to date, but has also taken steps to control inflation, reduce the budget deficit and trim the state apparatus. **********Mr. Salinas said that development differences advised against linking Mexico to the United States in a common market in the foreseeable future. But he added that sector-to-sector agreements with the United States were working well and that similar arrangements would soon be worked out with Canada.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/14/world.main_headline: Tucurui Journal;   In an Amazon Lake, Underwater Logging Blooms
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/14/world.print_headline: Tucurui Journal;   In an Amazon Lake, Underwater Logging Blooms
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/14/world.body_text: **********Perched on the gunwale of a skiff here, Juarez Cristiano Gomes chuckled to himself as he watched a trail of small bubbles rising to the surface of Tucurui Lake. **********Suddenly, a cedar log shot out of the water like a wooden Polaris missile. **********''The underwater power saw!'' Mr. Gomes cried gleefully as one ton of wood crashed back into the roiled waters of this normally placid lake in eastern Amazonia. **********While a canoeist corralled the floating log, Mr. Gomes, a spry, 58-year-old backwoods inventor, spun his vision of a new growth business for the Amazon: underwater logging. **********Brazil's growing charcoal, furniture and home construction industries are placing mounting demands on the Brazilian logging industry. And there is a lot of wood under the water brought by three hydroelectric power dams that flooded 2,000 square miles of Amazon forest in the 1980's. **********Underwater Tree Cemetery **********A bridge between supply and demand is visible in this lake, an underwater cemetery peopled by millions of gray, leafless tree trunks. In one of the biggest scandals of the military Government that ruled Brazil until 1985, a group of retired military officers received a contract to clear all timber from the area to be flooded by Tucurui, Brazil's second largest dam. Lacking business experience, the group harvested only 5 percent. **********Obeying a construction timetable, Eletronorte, the Amazon's electric power company, closed the dam on the Tocantins River in November 1984. Since then, six million cubic meters of wood have been entombed in a lake the size of Lake Champlain. **********Watching from the shoreline was Mr. Gomes. ''I thought it was absurd to lose all this wood, so I started working on a machine,'' he recalled. ''At first, we played white men and Indians with Eletronorte. We hid in the woods when their boat went by.'' **********Today, however, accusations of wood theft are a distant memory. The power company smiles benignly on Mr. Gomes's enterprise, and takes 10 percent of wood sales. **********Decomposition Is a Threat **********Decomposing wood produces ammonia and hydrogen sulphide - substances that could pit and corrode the turbines of the $5 billion, 3,370 megawatt dam, explained Tacachi Hatanaka, an Eletronorte biologist who monitors water quality. **********Corrosion threatens the two other new Amazon dams maintained by the power company, Samuel in Rondonia State and Balbina in Amazonas State. **********Meanwhile, on land, demand for wood increases. With a mountain of high-grade iron ore being mined 100 miles from here at Carajas, a steel smelter in Maraba at the southern end of the lake requires 500 tons of charcoal a day for production. **********This year, a second smelter in Maraba closed after the federal authorities imposed a $1 million fine for using charcoal without a permit. **********The smelters are part of a series that ecologists warn could chew up much of eastern Amazonia with their need for charcoal. Visiting Carajas in mid-July, Brazil's President, Fernando Collor de Mello, announced a freeze on new smelters and a plan to reforest 2.2 million acres with eucalyptus and other plantation trees. **********Charcoal Contract Signed **********This year, Mr. Gomes signed a contract with the remaining smelter in Maraba to supply half of its charcoal needs with charcoal burned from lake wood. The rest of the smelter's charcoal is to come from sawmill scraps. **********''The part of the tree above the waterline is damaged and will go for charcoal,'' Mr. Gomes said. ''The submerged wood is still green and can be used for furniture and construction.'' **********Mr. Gomes has cut and sold 43,000 cubic meters of underwater wood in the last two years. As word spread, inquiries even came from abroad. **********''This wood is preserved like an olive in a jar,'' Mr. Gomes said as a barge derrick hoisted a dripping two-ton log, Worth $400 uncut. **********Using Trial and Error **********The derrick is part of a new kind of underwater logging that Mr. Gomes and his divers are exploring through trial and error. **********Some woods, such as cedar and mahogany, float. Other woods sink and have to be hoisted aboard the barge, a battered British-made scow appropriately named O Elefante. **********For underwater lumberjacks, the danger is not from falling trees, but from the perils of prolonged work at depths up to 150 feet, using an air hose from the surface. So far, Mr. Gomes said, there have been no accidents, except for several cases of rapid decompression - none serious. **********''My air hose once got tangled in a tree, and I took the airplane,'' Edidarcio Fereira da Silva said of the time he rode a ton of tree that rushed 100 feet to the surface. **********Snakes and Piranhas **********On land, loggers keep an eye out for snakes. Underwater, tree cutters keep an eye out for piranhas. **********''I cut one in half the other day,'' Mr. da Silva, said of a defensive slash he made with his saw. **********The wiry, 26-year-old diver dresses entirely in black - wet suit, jogging pants and sneakers. ''It's harder for the fish to see me,'' he said Not all precautions work. Last year, a piranha took a bite out of a thumb joint, a rare bit of exposed flesh. **********The product of backwoods ingenuity, Mr. Gomes has applied for a patent for his amphibious power saw. Mounted on a boat, a diesel-powered compressor forces oil at 750 pounds per square inch through rubber lines. Running through the saw, the oil spins the saw blade at 3,500 rotations per minute, about one quarter the speed of normal chain saws. **********Employing 15 people, the Amazon entrepreneur calculates that his costs are 25 percent less than above ground. The largest savings is in transportation. Instead of using trucks, he uses the barge or simply tows floating wood to sawmills that are sprouting at the lake's edge. **********Mr. Gomes estimates that it will take 15 years to harvest Tucurui's submerged wood.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/05/busin.main_headline: Citicorp Unit to Revamp Municipal Bond Operations
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/05/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;   Citicorp Unit to Revamp Municipal Bond Operations
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/05/busin.body_text: **********Citing heavy competition, Citicorp Securities Markets Inc., the broker-dealer subsidiary of Citicorp, said yesterday that it was reorganizing its activities in the municipal bond business by dropping out of traditional areas like underwriting and trading and concentrating instead on providing derivative products like interest rate swaps to customers. **********The move is the most recent step by a securities house to redefine its niche in the municipal bond business, which since 1986 has been hampered by a sharp slowdown in underwriting volume. **********Over the last few years, many firms have addressed the slowdown by reducing their municipal bond operations. Some, most notably Salomon Brothers Inc., have left the field. **********In spite of the retrenchment, Glen Sergon, the head of municipal finance at Citicorp, said too many players were in the business. **********''There is excess capacity in the marketplace, and it is not going away as quickly as we thought it would,'' Mr. Sergon said. Although it has been in the underwriting business for many decades, Citicorp has not been an industry leader for some time. **********For all of last year, Citicorp ranked 16th in municipal underwritings, according to the Securities Data Corporation. For the first five months of the year, the company had slipped further, to 24th. **********Aside from the large number of competitors, Mr. Sergon said the decision to phase out of old-line businesses ''is based on our strength in derivative products.'' **********''We think that as municipalities are forced to look at alternative ways to get their financings done, that derivatives will become commonplace in the municipal finance area.'' **********The shift in focus will have a direct effect on half of the municipal finance department's staff of 70 professionals, Mr. Sergon said. Efforts are under way to locate positions for these individuals in other areas, he said.
