https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/10/busin.main_headline:
The Executive Life;

A Spiritual Healer For the Workplace
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/10/busin.print_headline:
The Executive Life;

A Spiritual Healer For the Workplace
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/10/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: One former general manager at the Wagner Mining Equipment Company in Portland, Ore., was a brilliant engineering executive. But he had one fatal flaw - an obsessive need to control. ''He would constantly fly off the handle and give confusing orders,'' recalled Paul Middelhoven, vice president of engineering. **********One former general manager at the Wagner Mining Equipment Company in Portland, Ore., was a brilliant engineering executive. But he had one fatal flaw - an obsessive need to control. ''He would constantly fly off the handle and give confusing orders,'' recalled Paul Middelhoven, vice president of engineering. **********Between the general manager's refusal to accept input from other executives, including Mr. Middelhoven, and their retaliatory sabotage of project deadlines, the office was a battlefield. **********Enter Mary Riley, Ph.D., management consultant and author of the recent book ''Corporate Healing: Solutions to the Impact of the Addictive Personality in the Workplace.'' **********Brought in by the general manager, under pressure from senior management, to fix the problem, Dr. Riley sat in the room while Mr. Middelhoven discussed the problems with his boss. The meeting, Mr. Middelhoven said, made his boss finally realize the seriousness of the problem. ''He saw that he wasn't making his orders clear and that he was just overworking everybody by giving them one vague order,'' he said. **********According to Dr. Riley, many executives struggle with an almost neurotic inability to communicate their desires and goals at work. Stemming from the same addictive-compulsive behaviors that riddle executives' personal lives, these habits can hinder the efficiency, productivity and profitability of their corporations. Executive stress alone is estimated to cost companies $50 billion annually for such things as counseling, disability claims and absenteeism. **********Ten years ago, Dr. Riley and her ilk might have been laughed out of the executive suite, dismissed contemptuously as merely purveyors of ''new age'' psychobabble. Her favorite word, after all, seems to be ''spiritual'' - as in spiritual values, spiritual steps to recovery, spiritual healing and spirituality. **********But corporate America has awakened to the effects of executive health and emotional well-being on the bottom line. Chief executives and others in senior management now voluntarily enter alcohol and drug-dependency programs to cope with their substance-abuse problems. Psychotherapy has become commonplace among top executives.  Against this backdrop come self-proclaimed corporate healers like Dr. Riley. And if her thriving client list is any indication, executives are proving that their free-thinking on emotional well-being knows few limits. Dr. Riley has been hired by scores of corporations to shake up their executive suites by conducting self-help sessions between company executives and their subordinates. **********These $80-an-hour sessions consist largely of each employee stating to the other what he or she specifically needs to get a certain project done. ''One person is likely to be either an addictive personality - too demanding and controlling - while the other is probably going to be co-dependent or not demanding enough,'' Dr. Riley said. ''The addictive person probably has 20 things he or she wants to demand, but I ask them to focus on just the most important. The co-dependent employee is forced to come forward with his or her most important demand.'' **********Many companies tap Dr. Riley to cope with the oversized egos of particular executives. In 1984, after the Bankers Trust Company had entered investment banking, it ran up against a culture split between the aggressive experienced investment bankers it had hired from the outside and its own more conservative commercial banking executives that supervised the new recruits. **********''A lot of the new investment bankers had large egos and were very arrogant,'' remembered Susan Lawley, then the vice president in charge of administration in the investment banking department. ''They were not used to performance reviews or to having bosses tell them what to do.'' **********They put off the reviews as a result. Concerned, the bank called on Dr. Riley, who helped identify another problem: the bank's executives were stressed, neurotic and unable to communicate. Ms. Lawley remembers getting a frantic telephone call from one senior banker, who had been asked for a written appraisal of some of his colleagues' strong points. ''He said, 'Sue, I can't do it!' '' she said. '' 'In my family, we grew up either screaming or saying nothing. I've never been good at telling people what they do well!' '' Dr. Riley suggested that performance reviews be held as informal meetings between investment bankers and their superiors. During the meetings, each executive would be required to voice just one grievance or request of the other. An investment banker afraid to ask his busy boss to accompany him on client calls to help close deals was able to make his point in a calm meeting, without looking like he was whining for attention. **********''The classical review - where the boss is in the authoritative position and the investment banker his subordinate - just didn't work,'' Ms. Lawley said. ''Often, the banker knew more about the business than his boss. The ability to have meaningful dialogue between senior management and the deal-doers made for a more productive, open environment where people could take risks.'' **********It all sounds so simple, this getting together and talking things out. Why does it take a consultant with a Ph.D to get it all going? ''I think we had, and probably still have, some skeptics in our company who thought that boy, this is kind of touchy-feely,'' said Richard Meslang, president at Unicom International Inc. in San Francisco, which has used Dr. Riley's services. ''But it helped reduce our turnover and improve morale. We've even got a company newsletter now.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/13/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Allied-Signal In Valeo Deal
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/13/busin.body_text: **********Valeo, a French car components maker, said it had agreed to sell its brake linings business to Allied-Signal Automotive, part of Allied-Signal Inc., for 385 million francs, or about $106 million, effective Dec. 1. The business consists of two factories - one in the Calvados region of France and the other in Spain near Madrid - and a technical and administrative center near Paris. The business has annual revenue of 600 million francs and employs 1,200. Valeo, which will continue to distribute the brake fittings, said it had realized 500 million francs this year by selling non-strategic assets.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/24/busin.main_headline: Venezuela to Increase Oil Production by 25%
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/24/busin.print_headline: Venezuela to Increase Oil Production by 25%
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/24/busin.body_text: **********Venezuela, the largest oil producer in Latin America, has announced it will raise production by 25 percent to offset oil lost because of the embargo on Iraq and Kuwait. **********Venezuela will increase production by 350,000 barrels a day in September, the nation's Minister of Energy and Mines, Celestino Armas, told a Venezuelan congressional committee here Wednesday night. By December, production is scheduled to rise by a total of 500,000 barrels a day, to 2.5 million barrels, he said. **********A Big Windfall **********Speaking hours after world oil prices rose above $30 a barrel, Mr. Armas calculated that Venezuela stands to gain an extra $1.2 billion to $2.4 billion in oil revenues this year. Last year, Venezuela earned $9 billion, largely from selling crude oil at an average price of $14.62 a barrel. **********The windfall is expected to wipe out the financially troubled nation's 1990 budget deficit of $1 billion. **********The minister's statement appears to end three weeks of indecision here on energy policy. Venezuela's President, Carlos Andres Perez, reportedly promised the United States on Aug. 7 that Venezuela would increase oil production by 500,000 barrels. But he has said his country, a founding member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, needed the group's permission to exceed an OPEC quota of 1.945 million barrels of crude oil. **********In recent days, it has become clear that a full OPEC meeting has been blocked by a militant group of oil producers led by Algeria, Libya and Iran, which oppose higher production. **********On Monday, Mr. Perez, long a spokesman for the third world, expressed concern that the soaring price of oil could hurt the world economy. **********''It is not our plan to allow this crisis to skyrocket oil prices and to cause serious damage to the international economy,'' the President said. ''Venezuela feels it is her obligation to look after our clients and to safeguard the equilibrium of the world oil market.'' **********Big Supplier for the United States **********Venezuela's production increase is good news for the United States. In recent years, the South American country has alternated with Saudi Arabia as the largest source of crude oil for the United States. In 1989, Venezuela sold the United States about a million barrels of crude oil a day - about 18 percent of America's total crude-oil imports. **********During the 1973 Arab oil embargo, Venezuela sharply increased oil production and exports to the United States. This time, Venezuelan public opinion is again heavily in favor of increasing production. **********Frustration over a prolonged recession in Venezuela, a country recently accustomed to the highest standard of living in Latin America, is bolstering the push for more production. Low oil prices forced Mr. Perez to adopt unpopular austerity measures shortly after he took office in February 1989. About 300 people were killed in ensuing riots. **********Last year, Venezuela's gross national product collapsed by 8 percent, partly because of the austerity measures and partly because of adjustment to new free-market policies. Until the recent jump in oil prices, economic growth was expected to be flat this year. **********''This little war is a bonanza for us,'' Teodoro Petkoff, a socialist politician, said in an interview, echoing the sentiments of many Venezuelans. ''We are doing better off the misfortune of others.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/06/world.main_headline: Upheaval in the East;   East Europe Considers Cutting Aid to Indochina
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/06/world.print_headline: Upheaval in the East;   East Europe Considers Cutting Aid to Indochina
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/06/world.body_text: **********The collapse of European Communism and the withering of Comecon, the Eastern-bloc trading association, have led Eastern European countries to consider reducing their diplomatic representation and aid to Cambodia and Vietnam. **********Planned reductions in aid, tied to the negotiation of a new set of five-year plans to begin next year, underline the need for Vietnam and Cambodia to improve their relations with the West. It puts further pressure on both countries to seek a settlement to the Cambodian war, on which improvement of relations with the United States depends. **********A Hungarian diplomat in Hanoi said, ''We want a relationship with Vietnam similar to that of any other Western European country, based on clear mutual and commercial interests.'' **********Prague Recalls Envoys **********In late February, the Czechoslovak Ambassadors in Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos were recalled to Prague for consultations by the new Government. Czechoslovak diplomats say they will be replaced and their embassy staffs reduced, while relations with Laos may be downgraded to charge status. **********The Hungarian Ambassador in Phnom Penh has sent an evaluation of his embassy to Budapest that discusses the options of closing it or reducing its staff. **********A Hungarian diplomat said cost is the main issue, but doubted the embassy would be closed. ''You can see the high tide coming from the West as part of any settlement,'' he said. ''To close the embassy in the face of this high tide would be stupid.'' **********Still, another Eastern European diplomat said, the focus of foreign policy among the newly non-Communist governments must be Europe, the Soviet Union and the West, with Indochina only a distant concern. **********Anxiety in Phnom Penh **********He said the changes are causing severe anxiety in the Cambodian Government, which is trying to secure relations with more countries and fears losing ties with any of the 10 that now have diplomatic missions here. **********Many Eastern European embassies, a diplomat said, are operating with no clear instructions from their tumultuous home capitals. **********''There is a dangerous silence on the part of many East European embassies here,'' he said, while Western countries like Australia, Japan, Sweden, Canada, France and Britain are gearing up for better relations ''as soon as it is seemly.'' **********Cambodia's main aid donors are the Soviet Union, East Germany and Czechoslovakia. **********Change in Trade Relations **********''These relationships will inevitably change, and soon,'' a Polish diplomat said. ''Comecon is moving toward a hard-currency relationship, and no one can afford to subsidize trade in the same ways.'' **********Even the Soviet Union, which supplies Cambodia's oil and gasoline at subsidized prices and provides military aid, is now negotiating a new five-year plan, to run from 1991, that will look very different from the last one. **********''Many figures may change,'' a Soviet diplomat said. **********With the possibility of an Indochina peace settlement and changes in Moscow's foreign policy, military aid to Hanoi is sure to decrease, a Soviet diplomat there said. ''Our relationship, which was before mostly political and military, is now becoming mostly economic and cultural.'' **********'We Start to Count the Money' **********''That creates more problems,'' he said, including how to value old loans. Instead of building huge plants and infrastructure projects all on credit, ''with no thought about cost, now we start to count the money.'' **********The new five-year plan, he said, would concentrate on joint ventures and contracts between enterprises on the basis of hard currency and market prices. ''We seek to balance our relations and make them mutually beneficial,'' he said. **********He said Western estimates of $2.5 billion a year in Soviet help to Vietnam were ''roughly right,'' not including direct aid. But he would not comment on suggestions that this figure may be reduced as much as 40 percent. **********Such considerations clearly worry the Vietnamese. Nguyen Ngoc Minh of the State Bank said Hanoi's 1989 budget deficit was more than double 1988's, increasing inflationary pressures. **********A sizable cut in Soviet aid as Hanoi tries to remodel its industry, create jobs, adopt market prices and eliminate subsidies would be bound to hurt. **********In particular, he said, it would intensify Vietnam's credit squeeze, at least until Washington stops blocking new loans from the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank. **********Planned Comecon projects, like improving the north-south railroad, ''are as good as dead,'' a diplomat said. **********Even the official news organizations of the countries that were once Communist now have little reason to maintain Hanoi bureaus. As Western news agencies negotiate to open offices in Hanoi, at least two Eastern European agencies are planning to relocate to Bangkok or Jakarta.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/04/world.main_headline: Russian Republic Backs Private Farm Plan but Rejects Private Sale of Land
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/04/world.print_headline: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE; Russian Republic Backs Private Farm Plan but Rejects Private Sale of Land
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/04/world.body_text: **********The Russian republic approved a program today to revive the private peasant farm 60 years after Stalin snuffed it out with his collectivization program. **********But the Parliament of the republic, which has most of the nation's farmland and much of the current separatist zeal for private enterprise, stopped short of allowing the private sale of land between farmers. **********The lawmakers, in effect, compromised the plan of Boris N. Yeltsin, the insurgent leader and President of the republic, to allow relatively free sale of land by individual farmers. Instead farmers were restricted to reselling plots only to the state, and not to the nascent private market that Mr. Yeltsin had envisioned. **********"You would never understand the spirit of Russians who never have been accustomed to the terminology and even more to the practice of selling and buying land -- the motherland, as we call it," Mr. Yeltsin told foreign correspondents at a press conference. **********"As some legislators used to say, 'One can not sell his or her mother,' " the Russian leader said, admitting he had to accept a compromise to at least start the revival of the small family farms that were obliterated in Stalin's drive to collectivization. **********The change amended into the Yeltsin plan would require individual farmers to work their plots for a minimum of 10 years, with any later sale permissible only to the state. Mr. Yeltsin, who faced a spectrum of anxious criticism from party ideologues to individuals uneasy about the unknowns of personal land ownership, had proposed a five-year minimum for farmers to work their new plots and then have the right to sell to most buyers other than foreigners. **********The amendment was approved by 602 legislators and opposed by 369, with 40 abstaining. **********In effect the amended proposal accepts the idea of carefully controlled privitization plus individual ownership and inheritance rights, but nullifies Mr. Yeltsin's attempt to pioneer the selling of land among individual farmers. His supporters said the compromise would still encourage tens of thousands of farmers to apply for individual plots of land.  Hard-Line Criticism **********Millions of Soviet citizens died in the forced program of farm collectivization and rural hamlet destruction carried out by the Government against peasant farmers six decades ago. The nation has never recovered from the effects and the tradition of large-scale family farming was virtually lost. **********For four days of debate on the Yeltsin proposal, Communist hard-liners argued long and fervidly against decollectivization of the Russian farmland. They defended the party's bedrock dogma and achieved a victory that to a considerable extent also reflected the Soviet public's doubts about private land ownership. **********President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has led the way in pronouncing his reluctance to see outright land ownership, having cautioned the issue is too vital to be settled by anything but a voters' referendum. In a speech earlier this week, he said he did not fear the general concept, but personally was opposed. **********"I do not accept private property on land," he said. **********Across the city, the national Parliament voted general approval of Mr. Gorbachev's proposed plan for redesigning the lines of authority of the Soviet Union. Mr. Yeltsin, a critic who is seeking a far greater measure of republic sovereignty than Mr. Gorbachev has proposed, gestured with his arms as he said the Soviet President's authority should be reduced considerably. Mr. Yeltsin's hands came closer and closer, as if he were buying a wedge of cheese, as he demonstrated the strait he prefers for his Kremlin rival.  'A Psychological Issue' **********One of the strongest arguments against denationalizing farmland was the concern, amid the current economic spiral, that easily available land would be cornered by profit-minded speculators with no interest in fostering agricultural improvements. **********Mr. Yeltsin said the compromise measure approved was "historic" in authorizing revival of individual farms and that fuller acceptance of privatization would follow across the first decade of experience with individual farms. **********"It is a psychological issue," he said. **********He also contended the example set by Russia would affect other republics to enact private farming. **********"This will not go unnoticed," he said. **********The opposition to the Yeltsin proposal included a coalition of Communist ideologues, state collective farm managers who amount to agricultural moguls under the Communist system, and individuals legislators who criticized the anti-speculation provisions as too weak. **********The original proposal included various assurances that collective farming would continue to be encouraged in a broader, variegated farm market intended to encourage competitiveness rather than state planning devices as the critical arbiter. **********But the amended version had firm devices to guarantee that local authorities would have the final say over the privatization, deciding whether and how a collective might shed some plots for willing individuals. Local authorities also would reacquire the land in behalf of the state when a farmer who worked the land a decade or more might be interested in selling.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/09/world.main_headline: Lebanese Weigh Intervention in Christian Enclave
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/09/world.print_headline: Lebanese Weigh Intervention in Christian Enclave
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/09/world.body_text: **********President Elias Hrawi conferred with aides on a possible military intervention in the war-torn Christian enclave today as sporadic clashes and sharp political disagreement kept tension high between rival Christian factions. **********Three people were killed, including an Army officer, and four wounded, when Lebanese Army troops loyal to Gen. Michel Aoun and rival Lebanese Forces militiamen led by Samir Geagea exchanged intermittent artillery and sniper fire in mostly Christian East Beirut, the police said today. **********The total casualty figure for the 10 days of battles between the two factions stands at 335 dead and 1,400 wounded, according to police records. **********Thousands of Christians came out of bomb shelters and crossed the dividing line into mainly Muslim West Beirut, fearing that a shaky truce that came into force Wednesday would not last. Many bought bread, fruit and vegetables, and then returned. **********President Hrawi, himself a Christian, met at his West Beirut office with the Parliament Speaker, Husseini al-Husseini, Prime Minister Selim al-Hoss and Defense Minister Albert Mansour. ''The legitimate Government of Mr. Hrawi must interfere to end the carnage in East Beirut,'' Mr. Husseini told reporters after the meeting. **********The President's army commander, Gen. Emile Lahoud, and senior officers attended the talks. Mr. Hrawi had reportedly sent messages to world leaders, including President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, asking for their support ''to save my people from destruction.'' **********Government officials in West Beirut would not discuss what President Hrawi plans to do. But there have been noticeable military moves. Seventeen thousand troops under General Lahoud's command have been placed in combat readiness here and in other Syrian-controlled districts. **********A military source said a Syrian armored battalion arrived today in Aley in the hills overlooking Beirut. **********It is widely believed that Syrian troops will not intervene in the fighting unless President Hrawi asks them. The 40,000 Syrian soldiers in Lebanon virtually control two-thirds of the country. **********General Aoun's 10,000-strong militia still controls several quarters in East Beirut and some districts in the northern part of the Christian enclave. **********He has insisted that Mr. Geagea publicly renounce a national reconciliation charter signed in October. General Aoun rejected the pact because it did not give a timetable for a Syrian evacuation, and he announced a ''war of liberation'' to drive the Syrians from Lebanese soil.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/14/world.main_headline: Mexico Asks Action in 33 Rights Cases
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/14/world.print_headline: Mexico Asks Action in 33 Rights Cases
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/14/world.body_text: **********A new Government human rights commission set up in June by President Carlos Salinas de Gortari announced today that it had issued 33 formal recommendations for action against police and Government officials accused of human rights abuses. **********The recommendations, issued in the commission's first official report, call for the arrest and trial of at least 10 police agents for crimes from murder to extortion and kidnapping, and the dismissal or suspension on other charges of at least seven other officials, including a municipal prosecutor and a prison warden. **********The report, made public in a ceremony at Mr. Salinas's official residence today, is part of a well-publicized crackdown that the President has vowed to carry out against Government abuses. It offers frank, if brief, descriptions of human rights violations that Mexican Governments have long sought to keep out of the public eye. **********"Mexico has a human rights problem that it cannot and does not wish to hide," said Jorge Carpizo, president of the new National Human Rights Commission, presenting the report to Mr. Salinas.  Rights Groups Are Critical **********But the report specifically disqualifies the commission from investigating complaints of abuses related to political campaigns or the electoral process. And it was quickly criticized by private human rights groups that have described the new commission as a Government attempt to appear actively concerned about human rights issues while avoiding outside investigations. **********"This commission is just an ornament for the Government," asserted Rosario Ibarra de Piedra, president of Eureka, a human rights group that has been sharply critical of Mr. Salinas's Government. "Its aim is to cover up the situation, to make it appear that a human rights problem does not exist." **********In its six months of existence, the report states, the commission has received 1,343 complaints involving abuses that affected more than 3,500 people. Of those cases, it said, 397 have been fully resolved, 200 had too little information to permit investigation, and 746 are still being processed. **********The largest number of cases in which the commission issued formal recommendations involved members of the state and federal judicial police forces, which have often been linked to corruption and brutality. Many of those cases also involved the most serious crimes reported to the commission, including murder, torture and kidnapping.  Mayor Is Ordered Freed **********On Tuesday, Mr. Salinas ordered the release of an opposition Mayor in the southwest state of Michoacan after the commission found that he had been abused by federal judicial policemen. The Mayor, Salomon Mendoza Carajas, had been held in a Mexico City prison on drug charges after signing a confession that he asserted had been coerced from him under brutal interrogation and torture by the police. **********Other cases in which the commission recommended the investigation or dismissal of Government officials ranged from the abuse of inmates at prisons to unjust imprisonment by local prosecutors. Elsewhere, the commission called for improvements in conditions at specific substandard jails and special evaluations for Indian reform school inmates who do not speak Spanish. **********Mr. Salinas ordered the formation of the new National Commission on Human Rights after an outspoken human rights lawyer, Norma Corona Sapien, was shot dead on May 21 near the university where she taught in the city of Culiacan. **********In recent months, Mr. Salinas has also taken tougher steps to prevent torture, to exclude the use of coerced testimony in criminal trials, and to end notorious forms of extortion like the system of highway roadblocks long used by the police to make spot searches and demand bribes. **********But despite such changes, opponents of the Government say it cannot be trusted to investigate abuses by its own officials. They have also insisted that any effective human rights program must also provide mechanisms to guarantee the security and integrity of Mexico's election process, something that was absent from the report today.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/11/busin.body_text: **********COMPANIES **********The Great American Express Cut-Rate Buyback **********Finally, the American Express Company has found a way to come out ahead at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. But it's at the expense of Shearson shareholders. In 1987, American Express sold the public a minority interest in Shearson at $34 a share. Last week, American Express decided to buy each share back - for American Express stock worth about $11.93. American Express actually had wanted to sell more, but plans for another public offering and for a deal with Sanford I. Weill of the Primerica Corporation fell through. So with the help of more money ($1 billion), fewer employees (at least 2,000 layoffs) and a new chief executive (Howard L. Clark Jr.), American Express hopes to revive its brokerage. Some analysts say it will be years before Shearson can be peddled again. ''These companies are clearly wed for quite some time,'' said Michael L. Blumstein, a First Boston Corporation analyst. **********Coke: Another Generation **********''New'' Coke is about to become even newer. The Coca-Cola Company said last week that it will test a Coke II brand as a renamed, repackaged, remarketed version of ''new'' Coke. The new, sweeter than the old, was supposed to appeal to the Pepsi generation, but its sales have slipped to 1.4 percent of the domestic soft drink market. Analysts say the Coke II name also might help the company distinguish new Coke from its original product, now called Coca-Cola Classic. Coke II cans will have dashes of blue, a color more familiar on the cans of Coke's largest competitor. And what if Coke II succeeds? As Joseph J. Doyle, an analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, put it, ''They have 'Karate Kid III.' I can't wait for Coke III.'' **********Will They Go Back to Greyhound? **********Will Fred G. Currey become the Frank Lorenzo of the bus business? Mr. Currey's Greyhound Lines Inc., like Mr. Lorenzo's Texas Air Corporation, is perilously leveraged. And, as Mr. Lorenzo did at Eastern Airlines, Mr. Currey is trying to replace strikers with nonunion workers. The union walked out March 2, but Greyhound claimed last week to be operating 30 percent of its bus system, a figure disputed by the union. Prior to the current troubles, Mr. Currey arguably improved service, investing in his bus fleet, increasing ridership and, last year, eking out a small profit. But if a 1983 Greyhound strike under previous owners is any guide, it could take the company years to win riders back. **********Demystifying Food Labels **********How not to cash in on the nutrition boom: Dr. Louis Sullivan, Secretary of Health and Human Services, called last week for food companies to have mandatory nutritional labeling on nearly all their packages. Saturated fat, fiber, cholesterol, percentage of calories from fat - all would have to be clearly listed. No longer would food packages rival supermarket tabloids in telling stories that are mystifying, creative and incredible. Ideally, consumers would be able to see at a glance that a frozen dinner now labeled low-calorie was actually a meager, starvation-ration serving laden with fat. Said Dr. Sullivan: ''The grocery store has become a Tower of Babel, and consumers need to be linguists, scientists and mind readers to understand the many labels they see.'' **********The $2,000 Difference **********The main difference between Genentech Inc.'s genetically engineered clot-dissolving drug and a more conventional product is about $2,000 a dose, European researchers reported on Thursday. They found that streptokinase, at $186 a dose, could treat heart attacks as well as Genentech's tissue plasminogen activator, or Activase, at $2,200 a dose. The study raises questions about whether sophisticated genetic engineering can produce drugs any better than those made by cheaper means. **********USX and Dumping the Steel **********Corporate raiding in the post-junk-bond era somehow seems a lot more complicated. The most that Carl C. Icahn has gotten from the management of the USX Corporation so far was a promise on Thursday to have shareholders vote on spinning off at least 80 percent of the steel business. Though he may be the largest shareholder, some analysts say he is unlikely to win the vote. But they note that Charles A. Corry, the USX chairman, has no long-term commitment to making steel. USX also has major interests in oil and gas. **********In Brief **********A 32-year-old great-grandson of the Ford Motor Company's founder moved a step closer last Wednesday to someday maybe running the company himself. William Clay Ford Jr., who already sits on the board, will direct the company's worldwide automotive strategies. **********THE ECONOMY **********Riskier Munis? **********Since the turn of the year, Treasury and corporate bond prices have tumbled but municipals have remained as solid as an old granite courthouse. Rates on long-term municipals have hovered near 7 percent since last year while 30-year Treasury bonds have gone from 7.8 percent in December to about 8.5 percent now. David Johnson, a portfolio manager at Van Kampen Merritt Inc., said municipals have held stable because of relatively low supply. But some analysts see a risk: As more cities and states face financial troubles, their credit ratings, and the value of their bonds, will fall. **********Melamed to Leave the Merc **********Leo Melamed plans to resign as head of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange to spend more time with his family and, in his own fashion, explore outer space. He announced on Monday that he will retire as executive committee chairman at the end of the year. The father of financial futures, he turned a market once most concerned with pork bellies into an arena with global influence on currency exchange levels, stock prices and interest rates. His tenure has also seen a Federal investigation of trading abuses. Mr. Melamed intends to continue trading for his own account. But he might find the cosmos more peaceful than the commodity pits: He also plans to write a sequel to his 1987 science-fiction novel, ''The Tenth Planet.'' **********Coloring for Babyboomers **********How to cash in on the graying of the baby boom: Open a beauty salon and concentrate on hair coloring. American Salon magazine predicts that salon customers will spend $5.5 billion on hair coloring this year, up 29 percent from last year. ''More women are going out into the work world,'' said Norma A. Lee, speaking for next week's International Beauty Show. ''They don't have time to fool around and do it themselves.'' **********Unemployment Holds Steady **********The unemployment rate continues to defy predictions of an economic slowdown. The Labor Department reported on Friday that the rate stayed at 5.3 percent in February for the ninth month in a row. Meanwhile, January's 5.4 percent drop in factory orders, the steepest in 15 years, only reflected weak manufacturing, said Allen Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Company. ''What stands out,'' he added, ''is the enormous strength of the service sector.'' **********INTERNATIONAL **********Brussels: The Boring Boom **********Brussels is blossoming as the headquarters of an increasingly unified Western Europe. The European Community concentrates its offices there, with most European Parliament meetings there as well. As European companies have crowded in, commercial real estate values have doubled and tripled. Construction cranes are everywhere; seven major downtown hotels are going up or have just been completed. But the boom has brought more discount shopping stores than sophistication. The city's real attractions remain the Gran' Place, some classic restaurants and a naughty little statue. The hottest ticket in Brussels come Friday night is for the train to Paris - which is where the Group of Seven industrial nations has chosen to meet next month. **********Mitsubishi Finds a Friend **********The Mitsubishi companies of Japan have found a friend to induct them into the corporate club in Europe. On Tuesday, they announced plans for ''intensive cooperation'' in automobiles, aerospace and microelectronics with Daimler-Benz of West Germany. Japanese companies have been rushing to enter Europe before a single, borderless market takes shape in 1992. Daimler, whose products include Mercedes-Benz cars, stands to gain access to Japanese technology and markets. **********Small Business, Soviet Style **********Soviet leaders seem determined to keep passing laws making small businesses legal until everyone gets the message. In 1988, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev allowed small businesses to open their doors as worker-owned cooperatives. In some areas, they have flourished; in others, they have been squashed by local politicans. Last Tuesday, the Supreme Soviet tried to encourage the spirit of enterprise some more, voting 350-to-3 to allow citizens to own the means of production. But local officials will still apparently own the means of obstruction: Workers can possess a factory, but only the government will be entitled to own the land underneath.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/09/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Trump Documents Ordered Released
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/09/busin.body_text: **********Casino regulators in New Jersey ruled today that more than 1,000 J. Trump's financial rescue package must be made public. The documents, however, will remain secret while his lawyers appeal the decision. **********The Casino Control Commission, which must approve the plan involving Mr. Trump's three Atlantic City casinos, said the release of the documents would not constitute an unwarranted invasion of the developer's private business dealings. The public's interest in casino operations takes precedence over the desire of Mr. Trump to keep his business affairs private, the commission ruled. The commission is expected to hold a public hearing on the financial restructuring plan within a month.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/21/world.main_headline: Court Bars Ex-Dictator From Guatemala Race
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/21/world.print_headline: Court Bars Ex-Dictator From Guatemala Race
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/21/world.body_text: **********An appeals court has eliminated a former dictator, Efrain Rios Montt, from the Nov. 11 presidential election by issuing a final ruling that his past activities disqualified him. **********The Court of Constitutionality said that the candidate, a retired general, was ineligible under an article of the constitution that bars anyone who came to power in a coup from being elected president. **********General Rios Montt led a military junta after the March 1982 coup that overthrew the elected President, Gen. Fernando Romeo Lucas Garcia. On June 9, 1982, General Rios Montt named himself President. He was ousted in another military coup in August 1983. **********General Rios Montt could not be reached for comment on the court's decision. **********Cerezo's Term Is Ending **********The decision left a field of 12 candidates, most of them rightists, running to replace President Vinicio Cerezo, a Christian Democrat, whose term expires on Jan. 14. The Constitution prohibits Mr. Cerezo from running for another five-year term. **********General Rios Montt's bid for the presidency was first rejected when he tried to register on Aug. 22, and the Supreme Electoral Tribunal upheld that decision. **********But he was registered provisionally under a temporary injunction issued while courts reviewed the case. The Supreme Court later ruled him ineligible, but the Court of Constitutionality was the final arbiter. **********Because the Constitution links an entire ticket to its presidential candidate, the decision also bars General Rios Montt's running mate, Harris Whitbeck Pinol, and his three-party coalition's congressional candidates. **********General Rios Montt is backed by the National Unity Front, the Institutional Democratic Party and the Guatemalan Republican Front. His law-and-order image at a time of increasing crime and allegations of government corruption had given him a strong position in some polls. **********Televised Presidential Sermons **********While President, the born-again Christian general addressed the nation in televised Sunday sermons and ordered crackdowns on corruption. **********He also sent more than a dozen people before firing squads for alleged involvement with leftist insurgents. Some were executed during a visit by Pope John Paul II. **********A bloody military campaign against leftist rebels in the northwest highlands under General Rios Montt's Government killed thousands of peasants, most of them Indians.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/08/world.main_headline: General Accepts a Cease-Fire After Victory North of Beirut
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/08/world.print_headline: General Accepts a Cease-Fire After Victory North of Beirut
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/08/world.body_text: **********Hundreds of despondent Lebanese gathered at hospitals and morgues in East Beirut today, looking for relatives who have been missing since clashes erupted between warring Christian factions nine days ago. **********Witnesses said women screamed and men wept as they identified corpses that had crammed morgues and hospital corridors. **********The hospital and morgue visits, as well as an evacuation of wounded by the International Committee of the Red Cross, were made possible by the first real truce since the fighting broke out in the Christian enclave north of here Jan. 30. Gen. Michel Aoun, who commands a 15,000-strong contingent of mostly Christian Lebanese Army regulars, agreed to the cease-fire after his troops gained control of the positions of the rival Lebanese Forces militia north of the capital on Tuesday. **********Police and hospital officials put the number of people killed in the latest fighting at about 300, and the number of wounded at 1,300. **********Some Wounded Flown to Paris **********The International Committee of the Red Cross, in cooperation with the Lebanese Red Cross, evacuated 19 casualties to Paris for treatment on a plane provided by the French Government. **********The aircraft had flown Bernard Kouchner, the French official in charges of humanitarian assistance, to West Beirut to offer aid. Mr. Kouchner said he hoped to be able to airlift 20 more badly injured people to France. **********General Aoun agreed to the cease-fire after taking control of a main militia stronghold in Dbeiye, five miles north of here. Apparently he now believes he can negotiate from a position of strength, for he showed no sign of budging on his insistence that the 10,000 members of the Lebanese Forces must disarm or, if they still want to carry weapons, join the regular armed forces. **********''There is no going back on this principle,'' he said at a news conference at his bunker under the presidential palace in the Christian suburb of Baabda. **********Security sources said the rival combatants were capitalizing on the lull to fortify their positions and prepare for the next round. **********General Aoun's representative, Col. Elias Khalil, appeared before a joint truce committee with the militia today to present the general's terms to the militia. People associated with security said Colonel Khalil told Fuad Malik, who holds the title of chief of staff in the Lebanese Forces, that the militia must give up its remaining pockets of control in East Beirut. **********Aoun Speaks of Unity **********Mr. Geagea, the militia commander, had said his fighters would not give up any position until General Aoun stops what the militia commander called ''suppression of the Lebanese Forces.'' **********General Aoun said at his news conference that it was not his objective to do away with the militia. ''We must unify our guns against the Taif agreement,'' he said, referring to the national reconciliation pact signed by Lebanese Muslim and Christian legislators in Taif, Saudi Arabia, in October. **********General Aoun has condemned the pact as treason and has refused to recognize the reconvened Parliament's election of President Elias Hrawi in November. Mr. Geagea has said the accord should be given a chance to work and has recognized Mr. Hrawi. **********After their defeat at Dbeiye, the Lebanese Forces established a new line of defense north of the town, throwing up earthworks and other barricades along the coastal highway to deter any thrust by General Aoun's forces in the direction of the port of Junieh, 13 miles north of beirut. The Lebanese Forces command said the Junieh area remained firmly in its grip, along with the adjacent district of Byblos. **********The Aoun forces' main helicopter base in the hills above Junieh is reportedly besieged by Mr. Geagea's men. An estimated 500 airmen and soldiers are trapped there. **********President Hrawi sent an emissary to Mr. Geagea, a Beirut newspaper reported. The purpose was to persuade the militia commander to hand over Junieh and Byblos to the Hrawi Government, said the paper, An Nahar.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/19/world.main_headline: Japan to Help Clean Mexican Air
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/19/world.print_headline: Japan to Help Clean Mexican Air
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/19/world.body_text: **********Japan said today that it would provide $850 million in loans to Mexico to help battle air pollution there. It will be Tokyo's first expenditure from a $2 billion fund intended to help poorer countries deal with environmental problems. **********The Government took the occasion of a visit from President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico to announce a series of loans. The loans are to be used to remove sulfur from heavy fuel oil and diesel fuel burned in Mexico; to produce lead-free gasoline, and to refurbish locomotives to improve the cargo-handling capacity of Mexico's rail system, reducing the number of trucks in Mexico City. **********Loans at Low Rates **********Part of the money will come in the form of loans by the Export-Import Bank, which is trying to send some of Japan's huge trade surplus to poorer countries. The interest to be paid by heavily indebted Mexico will be far less than that paid on ordinary loans. **********Japan's efforts are an attempt to resolve two international problems: resentment for amassing hundreds of billions of dollars in trade surpluses in recent years, and criticism that Japanese companies have pursued environmentally unsound practices, such as financing logging operations in some parts of South America and Southeast Asia that destroy rain forests. **********Pledge Last December **********The Government initially announced its intention to help improve the environment in poorer countries last summer at the economic summit meeting in Paris. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu visited Mexico last September, and pledged to make the first such loans to the Latin American country. **********In a speech here today, President Salinas was frank about Mexico's problems, but he made a strong appeal for more Japanese investment. Mexico is discussing a free trade pact with the United States, similar to a pact the United States already has with Canada. **********Given that such an agreement would open the Mexican and American markets to each other, President Salinas hinted that Japanese companies might find it attractive to use Mexico as a gateway to North America.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/10/busin.body_text: **********The MGM/UA Communications Company said today that it had put on hold plans to sell itself and would instead try to rebuild by increasing film production. **********The rebuilding plan calls for **********MGM/UA to reach an output level of 15 primary film releases a year in the fiscal year 1991, which ends on Aug. 31. **********The company reported a net loss of $2 million, on revenues of $211.5 million, in the first fiscal quarter that ended on Nov. 30. In the same period last year, the company had a net loss of $39.4 million, on revenues of $170.3 million, largely because of increased write-downs on theatrical releases and development projects. **********''Our strategy throughout fiscal 1990 is to resume the release of major feature films,'' said Jeffrey Barbakow, the company's chairman. **********MGM/UA cut back sharply on developing new movies last March after it initially agreed to be acquired by Qintex Australia Ltd., an Australian media company. A revised deal fell through in early October.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/14/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Printer System From Kodak
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/14/busin.body_text: **********The Eastman Kodak Company introduced a printing system today that will let personal computer users hook up with high-speed printers previously reserved for mainframes. **********The company billed the system, called Lionheart, as a ''dramatic advance in office productivity.'' Industry analysts were less enthusiastic, in part because of the system's price tag of $250,000. **********The system uses new software with an enhanced version of Kodak's existing Ektaprint 1392 printer, which can print documents at speeds of up to 92 pages a minute. Standard desktop printers turn out about eight to 10 pages a minute. **********Users can also get sets of finished reports - sorted, stapled and hole-punched - by selecting options at their desktop computer, instead of filling out requests at their company's central copy center. **********The system is intended for companies that make or print 500,000 copies a month, including government agencies and big law firms, officials said. **********''It doesn't sound like a really big deal to me,'' said Peter Enderlin, an industry analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company in New York. ''How many places are going to want to spend $250,000 a pop? You have to have a heck of a lot of personal computers to make it worthwhile.'' **********Kodak's stock dropped $1.125 a share today, to $40.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/26/world.body_text: **********Protesters shouting anti-Government and anti-United States slogans tried to stone an American diplomat's residence today in Kwangju and clashed with the police in four other cities, according to Korean news reports and witnesses. **********The police fired tear gas to break up the protests by an estimated total of 3,000 students and other dissidents in Kwangju, Inchon, Taegu, Pusan and Taejon. About 100 people were reported arrested. **********About 50 students chanting ''Yankee go home!'' were stopped by riot policemen about 10 yards from the main gate of the residence of Carlton Ames, director of the United States Cultural Center in Kwangju, this morning, the South Korean news agency Yonhap reported. Two bottles of red paint were thrown at the gate of the Kwangju Mayor's house across the street as the protesters fled, Yonhap said. It was not known if Mr. Ames was home at the time, or if any damage was done to his residence. The police said there were no arrests or injuries. **********Almost simultaneously, two separate groups of about 30 radicals tried to attack two police substations in Kwangju but also were dispersed by the police, Yonhap reported. **********Students hurling rocks and firebombs later fought the police in two areas of Kwangju for about 30 minutes, Yonhap said. It said the students were protesting the merger last month of President Roh Tae Woo's governing party with two centrist opposition groups. Dissidents say the enlargement of the governing party is a return to authoritarian control and a reversal of progress toward democracy. **********Kwangju, 150 miles south of Seoul, is the stronghold of the opposition leader Kim Dae Jung, whose Party for Peace and Democracy was left isolated as a result of the merger. **********Anti-American sentiment is strong in Kwangju because many of its citizens believe that Washington condoned a military crackdown on a democracy movement in the city in 1980. At least 200 people were killed as a result of the crackdown. **********The United States Cultural Center in Kwangju was temporarily closed last May after it had been attacked 28 times since 1980. United States officials have indicated they plan to open the center this summer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/31/busin.body_text: **********The MCI Communications Corporation, the long-distance telephone company, reported disappointing fourth-quarter earnings today. **********The company said its fourth quar-ter profit fell 11.5 percent, to $108 million, or 39 cents a share, from $122 million, or 46 cents a share in the 1988 quarter. Revenues rose 19.6 percent, to $1.71 billion, from $1.43 billion in the 1988 quarter. **********For the year, MCI's profit climbed 61.3 percent, to $558 million, or $2.09 a share, from $346 million, or $1.23 a share in 1988. Revenue jumped 25.9 percent, to $6.47 billion. **********MCI's stock closed off $3.125 a share, at $31.25, and was the most active over-the-counter stock, with nearly 14.5 million shares traded. **********MCI's operating earnings, which excluded special charges, were up sharply, but charges for engineering consolidation expenses and early debt retirement trimmed fourth-quarter earnings by $70 million, the company said. Operating earnings of about 63 cents a share were slightly below analysts' expectations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/01/world.body_text: **********Guerrillas fighting the Liberian Government have reportedly seized control of the city's main hydroelectric installation and water-treatment plant, cutting water supplies and disrupting power. **********Early this morning, rebels of the National Patriotic Front, which has been trying to overthrow the Government of Samuel K. Doe for the last six months, captured the hydroelectric plant near White Plains, a town about 15 miles from the center of Monrovia, the capital. Electrical power was severed, plunging the entire city into darkness. **********On Wednesday, rebel forces reportedly captured the water-treatment center, three miles northeast of the hydroelectric plant, cutting water supplies to the city. **********As the fighting near the capital resumed today, an artillery duel was reported at Roberts Field airport, 35 miles from the capital. A Western diplomat who has been in contact with Government forces in the area said that although the airport control tower was virtually untouched, the main terminal building and customs area were destroyed. **********The rebels are now astride the two main roads out of Monrovia, to the north and the east, effectively cutting it off from most of the rest of the country. Only the road to the west is still open, and that is vulnerable if the rebels choose to attack it. **********Second Source of Power Out **********A huge diesel-run electric turbine plant on Bushrod Island near the outskirts of the city remains under Government control. It is normally used in the dry season and, in theory, supplies about 50 percent of the region's energy needs. **********But because the Liberian Electric Corporation has not been able to obtain enough foreign currency to purchase diesel fuel, the Bushrod plant has been all but inoperable for several weeks. **********Army reinforcements were seen this morning heading up the road that leads to the White Plains reservoir and power station, but reporters who tried to reach the area were stopped by soldiers. **********African and Western diplomats say the attacks on water and power supplies are part of a new rebel strategy of strangling Monrovia's food and energy reserves, but avoiding an all-out military assault on the city. **********The rebels, led by Charles Taylor, have refused to resume peace talks until President Doe and his senior Cabinet members resign, something they have refused to do. **********Expending Their Ammunition **********The rebel raids and daily artillery pounding also appeared designed to force the Government troops to use up their supplies of ammunition, which they have not been able to replenish for more than six weeks. **********As has been the practice in the six-month conflict, there was no word of civilian or military casualties from either side. But residents in the White Plains area said that besides the rebel raids on the reservoir and pumping station, several cars and houses were set ablaze. **********In Monrovia, the streets today were full of people with buckets and other containers looking frantically for water. The city has many wells and is surrounded by swamps, but the water there is not considered potable even under the best conditions. **********With electrical power cut and charcoal and other natural fuel sources in short supply, most households have no way of purifying water by boiling it. Liberian and Western health officials say they fear an outbreak of disease among Monrovia's half-million people, who normally use about 19 million gallons of water daily. **********''Unless this thing is settled soon,'' an African health official said, ''this city is soon going to become a breeding ground for just about every imaginable disease.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/10/busin.body_text: **********The National Association of Securities Dealers said today that it had fined a brokerage for defrauding investors who bought a ''penny stock'' of a small food producer. **********The association, which governs over-the-counter stock brokers, said it had fined a member firm, J. W. Gant & Associates Inc. of Englewood, Colo., $30,000 and ordered it to disgorge nearly $200,000 in excess markups charged to Gant customers who bought the food producer's securities between Dec. 18, 1986, and Jan. 30, 1987. **********The association also said it had suspended a Gant vice president, Salvatore A. Venezia, and a trader, James S. Gad, from associating with any N.A.S.D. member in any capacity for 15 days. Gant, Mr. Venezia and Mr. Gad consented to the finding without admitting or denying the allegations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/23/world.main_headline: Europeans Are Stunned, but Expect Smoother Sailing
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/23/world.print_headline: CHANGE IN BRITAIN; Europeans Are Stunned, but Expect Smoother Sailing
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/23/world.body_text: **********News of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's resignation stunned Europe today, bringing warm tributes from conservative politicians and raising hopes that Britain, under a new leader, will drop its opposition to new moves toward European unity. **********Although Mrs. Thatcher still has a large army of admirers in Europe, particularly in former Soviet bloc countries, over the last 18 months her efforts to slow the economic and political integration of Western Europe had isolated her among leaders of the 12-nation European Community. **********Most recently, when Community leaders met in Rome in late October, Mrs. Thatcher tried -- and failed -- to block approval of adoption of a single European currency by the mid-1990's. A few days later, Sir Geoffrey Howe, her deputy Prime Minister, resigned in protest and set off the leadership crisis. **********Today, some European politicians took satisfaction from the fact that, while domestic problems first undermined Mrs. Thatcher's popularity in Britain, in the end the European question was one of the central issues that split the Conservative Party and forced her to step down as Prime Minister. Welcomed in Bonn **********"I hope this will put an end to divisions on such a vital issue as Europe," said Willy de Clercq, a Belgian representative to the European Parliament in Strasbourg. "Whoever becomes Prime Minister, I hope their policies will be positive and pro-European." **********In a rare public comment from one of her former Community colleagues, Belgian's Prime Minister, Wilfried Martens, said he hoped her resignation "will bring change, meaning we will be able to progress more quickly in the construction of European political union." **********In Bonn, the news was also welcomed by politicians. "Thatcher failed because she either could not or would not grasp the chances of Europe," said Otto Lambsdorff, leader of Germany's Free Democrat party. "The times are gone when you could win applause in Britain by stepping on the brakes in the European Community." **********Hans-Jochen Vogel, leader of the opposition Social Democratic Party, said Mrs. Thatcher's resignation would give "great encouragement to all advocates of speedy European integration." Alfred Dregger, a Christian Democratic leader, said she had "tragically" refused to recognize change in Europe. Some Familiar Figures **********Among the three contenders to succeed Mrs. Thatcher, the Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, and the Chancellor of the Exchequer, John Major, are already familiar figures in Europe because of their participation in frequent community meetings. While always loyal to Mrs. Thatcher, both were considered more pro-European than the Prime Minister. **********But Michael Heseltine, the former Defense Secretary who first challenged Mrs. Thatcher this week, has perhaps raised more expectations in European capitals because, while less well known, he chose to gamble his political career on the European question. **********In Brussels, where the community's Executive Commission is headquartered, the word from 10 Downing Street this morning was particularly well received, not least because Mrs. Thatcher often accused the Commission and its French President, Jacques Delors, of trying to undermine Britain's sovereignty. **********For the record, Mr. Delors merely expressed his "highest esteem" for the outgoing Prime Minister today, but the Vice President of the Commission, Sir Leon Brittan, who held four Cabinet posts under Mrs. Thatcher, said her resignation would enable Britain to play "a constructive part in the European Community." Seen as Symbol by French **********In Paris, a spokesman for President Francois Mitterrand said, Mrs. Thatcher symbolized an important era in the history of her country and Europe while the the Foreign Minister, Roland Dumas, said he expected "an evolution" and "a modification" of Britain's policy toward Europe -- though not toward the Gulf crisis -- under a new Prime Minister. **********Mrs. Thatcher was in Paris on Tuesday attending a 34-nation European summit when she learned she had failed to win an outright victory in the first round of voting for the Tory leadership. As if sensing she was on the way out, several European leaders bade her farewell Wednesday with special warmth. **********While causing mounting irritation to her community colleagues in recent months, Mrs. Thatcher's impact on Europe throughout the 1980's was enormous, not only because of her firm support for a strong Western security posture and for what became known as Thatcherist free market policies, but also because of her special ties to Washington. **********Today, a former French President, Valery Giscard d'Estaing, who is currently a member of the European Parliament, said he now expected Britain to contribute to European union, but he had friendly words for his fellow conservative. 'The Curtain Falls' **********"The curtain falls on the Iron Lady," he said, using the nickname first given to her by the press. "She has earned our applause. The Britain she leaves behind is no longer as she found it. Margaret Thatcher will have been, with Winston Churchill, the greatest British Prime Minister in the last 50 years. The Iron Lady was also a great lady." **********Another French conservative leader, Jacques Chirac, himself a former Prime Minister, praised Mrs. Thatcher's "attitude of dignity and courage" in giving precedence to the interests of her party and country and paid tribute to her "historic role in restoring Britain to its proper place" in the world. **********John Bruton, leader of Ireland's Fine Gael opposition party, spoke of her as "a politician who had sincere convictions and worked with relentless energy to achieve the things she believed in." In a similar tone, Giovanni Spadolini, President of the Italian Senate, referred to her "intrepid character." **********In Eastern Europe, where Mrs. Thatcher won a strong following in the 1980's for her unwavering anti-Communism, word of her resignation came as a shock. Only Wednesday, Vaclav Klaus, Czechoslovakia's Finance Minister, described her as "a wonderful personality and we wish her all the best." Praised Gorbachev in 1985 **********Mrs. Thatcher, who in 1985 was the first Western leader to declare that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is "someone we can do business with," also leaves admirers in Moscow. "She was a historic figure who helped bring the Soviet Union closer to Europe," Gennadi I. Gerasimov, the Foreign Ministry's spokesman, told Reuters. "We will remember her as someone who made a great contribution to the good relations with the Soviet Union and the Continent." **********Mr. Gorbachev's spokesman, Vitaly Ignatenko, said he had no official reaction, but he too noted that she had helped improve relations between Moscow and London. "We regard her very highly and hope to continue our good relations with the new leader," he told Reuters. **********In Stockholm, a spokeswoman for Sweden's Green Party had a different reason for lamenting Mrs. Thatcher's departure. Referring to the frequent "family photos" taken of the British Prime Minister and the 11 men who are community leaders, the spokeswoman, Margareta Gisselberg, said the party would miss "the dress in a row of suits."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/03/world.main_headline: Evolution in Europe;   With Nonreaders Gone, Marxism's Journal Fails
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/03/world.print_headline: Evolution in Europe;   With Nonreaders Gone, Marxism's Journal Fails
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/03/world.body_text: **********One of the world's most widely circulated unread magazines, Problems of Peace and Socialism, is capitulating before the problems that have uprooted Communism and is giving up publication. It is also ceding the handsome building that the former Communist Government confiscated from the Roman Catholic Church four decades ago. **********The church plans to restore the building to what it used be, the seminary of the Archbishop of Prague. The even more imposing building to its left is being converted to a student dormitory, its original purpose. Until this year it was the headquarters of the secret police, with files on most citizens of this country. **********Problems of Peace and Socialism, known in its English-language edition also as the World Marxist Review, has been published here since 1958 as a major propaganda effort by an editorial board dominated by the Soviet Communist Party and including representatives of 69 Communist parties around the world. **********''It was unique,'' Lubomir Molnar, its last editor and the first who is not a Soviet citizen, said in an interview in the spacious seminary building, now nearly empty. ''It reflected the situation inside the movement. Its incapacity to produce a review efficiently was also part of that system.'' **********A Circulation of 550,000 **********''It was very expensive,'' said Mr. Molnar, still a loyal Communist and a former diplomat and foreign-policy assistant to Milos Jakes, the hard-line Czechoslovak Communist Party chief overthrown by the democratic revolution in November. ''No one but the Communist parties could have permitted themselves that.'' **********More than 400 editors, about half of them Soviet citizens, worked in the former seminary to prepare the master edition of the monthly in Russian. Editions in English and Arabic were also prepared here but printed in their countries of circulation. Hundreds of other editors worked around the world to prepare 70 editions of the identical journal in a total of 41 languages, whose global circulation was reported at 550,000 copies. **********The costs were borne largely by the Soviet party, with lesser contributions from East Germany, Poland, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Romania, Bulgaria and Mongolia. As the tide turned, parties withdrew their contributions until, Mr. Molnar said, ''We are ending this historical period with money only from the Soviet Union and Mongolia.'' **********The magazine was standard equipment on desks and tables in Communist offices around the world except China and Albania. But it seemed that wherever they were spotted, the copies always looked mint-fresh. **********The table of contents in March 1989, before revolution came to Eastern Europe, included typical offerings like ''We Have Much to Say on Human Rights,'' by James Stewart, general secretary of the Irish party; ''Humanism: The Gist of Revolution,'' by Trevor Munroe, the Jamaican Communist leader, and ''Forward-Looking Ethiopia,'' by Tesfaye Dinka of that country's Politburo. **********'A New Way of Thinking' **********Mr. Molnar said no article could be published if a single member of the editorial board vetoed it, a fact that prevented anything critical of a Communist country or party. **********But at the end of last year, the editorial board decided on a sweeping change in policy, which brought articles by outsiders like Zbigniew Brzezinski, Alexander Dubcek, Milovan Djilas and Andrei D. Sakharov. **********''The last numbers really reflected a new way of thinking,'' said Mr. Molnar, who took office in February. ''The local perestroika came too late.'' **********Agreeing with that conclusion, the Soviet Union withdrew its contribution in May. The last Soviet editor, Aleksandr M. Subbotin, who headed the more important Trud, the trade-union daily, until Mikhail S. Gorbachev came to power, left earlier in the year. Most of the Soviet staff has followed, and all will be gone in July, Mr. Molnar said. **********The Staff Is Down to 40 **********Where more than 400 used to occupy the long flights of well-furnished offices, only about 40 employees remain, mostly Czech housekeeping staff. **********But Mr. Molnar said he was negotiating with former financial contributors to convert Peace and Socialism International Publishers into an unsubsidized publishing house for left-wing, but not necessarily Communist, writing. ''It will be more democratic, flexible and open,'' he promised. **********The editor has already chosen a non-internationalist name for the new enterprise - Patria. **********Had there been a link between the large Soviet presence in the publishing house and the secret police next door? Mr. Molnar was asked. He smiled sourly and offered no denial. ''I didn't say it,'' he replied.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/04/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Ziff-Davis Jobs
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/04/busin.body_text: **********The Ziff-Davis Publishing Company, a unit of Ziff Communications, has promoted Eric Hippeau to executive vice president for magazine operations. The company also promoted J. Scott Briggs to group vice president for PC publications. Ronni Sonnenberg will replace Mr. Hippeau as publisher of PC Magazine. https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/21/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   United Schedule At O'Hare Backed
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/21/busin.body_text: **********A Federal appeals court cleared the way for United Airlines to revamp its schedule at Chicago's O'Hare International Airport after Oct. 1. The change, which was challenged by American Airlines, had been approved by the Federal Aviation Administration as a means of smoothing out evening arrivals and departures and easing congestion. **********The F.A.A. said a decision by American to adjust its early evening schedule would increase congestion. It said United's proposed schedule changes, intended to separate the Chicago-based airline's flights from those of American, would ease delays after Oct. 1. United's chairman and president, Stephen M. Wolf, said the ruling would benefit passengers using O'Hare. American had called the F.A.A.'s approval of the new United schedule ''outrageous'' and ''a blatant example of agency favoritism.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/04/busin.body_text: **********The European Community Executive Commission said on Wednesday that it planned to spend $363 million to improve and expand natural gas and electricity systems. The projects in the three-year plan include introducing natural gas in Portugal and Greece, connecting gas networks in Ireland and Britain, and linking electricity networks in Italy and Greece.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/29/busin.body_text: **********The Lotus Development Corporation gained a significant victory yesterday when a Federal judge in Boston ruled that its copyright had been infringed by competitors whose software imitates the command structure of Lotus's 1-2-3 spreadsheet program. **********The case, which Lotus brought against two of its small challengers, Paperback Software International and Mosaic Software Inc., in February 1987, had been closely watched by the computer industry. Both Paperback and Mosaic sell $99 spreadsheet programs for I.B.M. and compatible personal computers. Their programs imitate both the appearance and the command set of Lotus 1-2-3, the best-selling spreadsheet program, which lists for $495. **********The two cases were separated when the lawsuit originally went to trial, and yesterday's ruling applied only to Paperback Software and its Canadian development partner, Stephenson Software Ltd. **********Continues Trend **********Executives of Lotus, which is based in Cambridge, Mass., have argued that the two smaller companies copied thea Lotus format - a grid-like design on the computer screen - as well as the sequence of keystrokes used to manipulate information. **********The Lotus ruling continues a legal trend of the past decade that has significantly broadened the notion of what constitutes intellectual property protection for software. Originally, most of the industry felt that only the programmer's underlying instructions were protected under copyright law. But beginning in the early 1980's, a series of lawsuits involving the video screens of game programs extended protections to the appearance of programs. **********Some industry executives contend that the Lotus case could radically change the nature of software competition. Many in the industry fear that companies that are successful in setting an ''industry standard'' might be able to use the case to block newcomers, restricting innovation. Now It appears that the dividing line between imitation and innovation may be clearer. **********''It's an important ruling,'' said Jack Russo, a Palo Alto, Calif., lawyer who specializes in copyright issues. ''In the future, if there's a product that becomes the accepted product in the industry, it will be very difficult to create a program that competes with it.'' without being willing to retrain users extensively.'' **********The Lotus ruling may affect other lawsuits now pending, including a suit that Apple Computer Inc. filed against the Microsoft Corporation and the Hewlett-Packard Company, accusing them of copying certain portions of its Macintosh software, Mr. Russo said. **********''It's an overwhelming victory for Lotus,'' said Thomas M. Lemberg, the company's general counsel. ''There is a larger message to the industry, and it's a very helpful one,'' he added. ''The copyright law really does protect incentives designed to reward innovation.'' **********Executives at Paperback Software said they intended to appeal. the ruling. They said they were still trying to digest the 110-page ruling made by United States District Judge Robert Keeton. and would have no immediate comment. **********'Not Totally Surprised' **********''We're not totally surprised by the direction the judge has taken,'' said Micheal K. Burdick, Paperback's vice president of sales and marketing. ''Our view is that it is just one step in the legal process.'' **********In his ruling Judge Keeton wrote: ''I conclude that a menu command structure is capable of being expressed in many if not an unlimited number of ways, and that the command structure of 1-2-3 is an original and non-obvious way of expressing a command structure.'' **********The ruling would affect only programs that directly copy the visual appearance and the command structure of 1-2-3, Lotus executives said. The principal competitor to 1-2-3, Microsoft's Excel program, has a different appearance and a different menu-based command set. **********Lotus officials said that the ruling did not extend to companies that publish programs that are compatible with Lotus files, and that it had no intention of trying attempting to claim copyright protections over file compatibility. **********Paperback Software was founded in 1984 by Adam Osborne, a personal computer industry executive who also founded Osborne computer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/02/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Pratt & Whitney Planning Layoffs
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/02/busin.body_text: **********Aircraft-engine maker Pratt & Whitney Canada Inc. announced plans to lay off as many as 1,200 workers, about 12 percent of its work force. The company cited a downturn in demand for small jets in the United States for the cuts. Pratt supplies engines for corporate jets, regional commuter aircraft and other markets. **********A company spokeswoman said a significant number of orders have been canceled, but she would not specify how many. Pratt & Whitney Canada employs 9,490 in the Montreal area, Toronto and Halifax. Its sister company, Pratt & Whitney, based in East Hartford, Conn., employs about 39,000. Both companies are owned by the United Technologies Corporation.
