https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/05/world.main_headline: 'Criminal Is Gone,' but Joy Is Fleeting in Land He Ruled
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/05/world.print_headline: NORIEGA'S SURRENDER: PANAMA;   'Criminal Is Gone,' but Joy Is Fleeting in Land He Ruled
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/05/world.body_text: **********With Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega in American custody and out of the country, relieved Panamanians turned their attention today to the arduous process of repairing the damage he inflicted on the political, social and economic fabric of this nation of 2.3 million people during his six-year rule. **********At Government offices, businesses and banks, Panamanians reported to work still aglow with delight from the street celebrations that exploded here when General Noriega's departure was announced Wednesday night. But that joy has been tempered by awareness that the country still faces serious problems that will not be easy to resolve. **********''The criminal is gone, and we are happy to be rid of him,'' said Ligia Cornejo, a middle-aged office worker. ''But I am still here, and my children and I are the ones who will have to live with the consequences of all the evil deeds the dictatorship committed when it pillaged and intimidated this country.'' **********The new civilian Government that took power after the American military invasion on Dec. 20 took no time to savor its victory. While ordinary Panamanians were dancing in the streets, President Guillermo Endara summoned his Cabinet for an unusual midnight meeting, part of a continuing effort to revise or abolish the many institutions that General Noriega and his associates subverted or corrupted. #90% Support Seen for Endara ''This is a golden opportunity to restructure this country in a much more modern light,'' a prominent Panamanian political figure said. ''We need to repeal the political and judiciary systems, cleanse the bureaucracy and get rid of practices that only create corruption.'' **********A senior Panamanian Government official said today that the resignation of Col. Roberto Armijo, appointed on Dec. 23 as head of Panama's new Public Security Force, came after evidence of his corruption surfaced in a Government investigation. The official said he could not rule out the possibility that Colonel Armijo, a member of General Noriega's inner circle, would be prosecuted on the corruption charges. **********Action against other remnants of the Noriega Government continued today. It was announced that Col. Nivaldo Madrinan, the much-despised head of the secret police, is now in United States custody on a military base here. **********For the moment, Mr. Endara is the principal beneficiary of the vacuum left by the collapse of the Noriega Government. Archbishop Marcos McGrath, the country's highest-ranking Roman Catholic, estimated today that ''at least 90 percent of the population'' supports the Endara Government and would vote for it if a plebiscite were held immediately. **********Discord in Panama Government **********But many Panamanian and foreign analysts said they believed it would be difficult for the new Government to maintain that consensus for very long. Members of Mr. Endara's Authentic Panamanian Party and First Vice President Ricardo Arias Calderon's Christian Democrats have already begun sniping at each other in private. **********''So long as Noriega was around, he could be the focal point of the entire nation's hatred and frustration,'' an Latin American diplomat said. ''But now, things will inevitably start to splinter because this is, after all, going to be a democracy.'' **********The most immediate problem, however, is rebuilding the shattered economy that once gave Panama the highest standard of living in Central America and the Caribbean. As a result of the political turmoil of the last two and a half years and the American economic sanctions imposed last year, the economy has shrunk by at least 25 percent and unemployment has doubled, to a quarter of the working population. **********Those difficulties were compounded by the Dec. 20 American invasion, which Panamanian economists and bankers estimate inflicted at least $500 million in damage and looting. They argue that the economy needs an immediate and large injection of credit if the downward spiral is to be reversed. **********Urgent Calls for U.S. Aid **********''The most urgent thing is to replenish commercial activity now, in January and February,'' said former President Nicolas Ardito Barletta, an American-educated economist. ''If that does not happen, then unemployment will rise and the hopeful note struck by getting Noriega out will be reduced.'' **********Since the Endara Government inherited a national treasury that was virtually empty, Panamanian officials are looking for outside assistance, particularly from Washington. But at a news conference here just hours before General Noriega's surrender, Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger and other members of an American economic reconstruction mission made no specific offers or promises of assistance, saying they need more time to assess the situation. **********Several Panamanian economists and businessmen said they thought the Eagleburger mission had failed to understand the urgency of the situation. They emphasized that it is in the long-term interest of the United States to support Mr. Endara's Government and other democratic elements that are seeking to replace the Panamanian military as the country's dominant institution. **********''The new Government now has to really take hold and project its image,'' said Mr. Ardito Barletta, who was forced by General Noriega to step down just months after he was elected in a 1984 presidential election marred by widespread accusations of fraud. ''Also, the United States Government must, at the highest level, announce that it supports the recovery of Panama. That has to be done dramatically, by President Bush at the White House.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/24/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Eastern Planning Vacation Flights
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/24/busin.body_text: **********Eastern Airlines said it would begin special vacation flights during the peak winter travel season to reward frequent business fliers. The airline said that in December it would start special ''Business Break'' flights from Atlanta to Hawaii, Mexico and the Caribbean to serve business fliers fulfilling free travel rewards during peak travel periods. **********In a separate development, Eastern's pilots said in Washington that they were withdrawing from a committee of creditors to protest what they called unfair treatment in the carrier's bankruptcy proceedings. The Airline Pilots Association said it made the decision after the judge hearing the case in Federal Bankruptcy Court in New York, Burton R. Lifland, quashed their attempt to subpoena officials of several of Eastern's large creditors. The union wanted to question the officials about information leaks during the proceedings.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/08/busin.main_headline: Advanced Chip Offered By Texas Instruments
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/08/busin.print_headline: Advanced Chip Offered By Texas Instruments
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/08/busin.body_text: **********Restoring a touch of pride for American makers of computer chips, Texas Instruments Inc. said today that it was delivering limited supplies of its model of the world's most advanced memory chip to some of its largest customers. **********Samsung of South Korea and Hitachi and Toshiba of Japan have made similar announcements within the last two months, and NEC of Japan said it would begin small shipments of its dynamic random access memory chip that stores 16 million bits or two million characters before the end of the year. **********Texas Instruments, one of the few American chip makers that did not quit making memory chips in the early 1980's, accounts for a big share of the nation's memory chip output. Japanese companies held 69 percent of worldwide memory chip sales in 1989, and American producers had 16 percent, according to Dataquest Inc., a research firm in San Jose, Calif.  'Perseverance Has Paid Off' **********"It's nice to know that Texas Instruments' perseverance has paid off in being able to compete," said Ione Ishii, a Dataquest analyst who follows the industry. She said worldwide sales of 16-megabit memory chips would exceed $5 billion in 1994. **********The executive directing Texas Instruments' production of the advanced memory chips, Lionel White, said in a statement that design engineers and computer industry managers say Texas Instruments has a slight lead over its foreign competitors in the race for high-volume production. **********"According to our customers, these 16-megabit samples are the first they've seen that are based on a design developed for high-volume production," he said. Initial output of the chips will be from the company's newest semiconductor plant, in Avezzano, Italy. Other Texas Instruments plants in Dallas; Miho, Japan, and Taiwan will be equipped later to make the chip. **********The International Business Machines Corporation and American Telephone and Telegraph Company have also spent heavily to develop and produce the 16-megabit chip, but virtually all of their output would be for their own products. **********The 16-megabit memory chip is certain to lead to smaller and more powerful products in the computer and telecommunications industries, as well as find broader uses in aircraft, automobiles and other products. It is also a crucial technology being developed for high-definition television. **********A single 16-megabit D-RAM chip the size of a fingernail can provide two million characters of storage in computers. That is about four times the total capacity of the I.B.M. and similar personal computers in the mid-1980's using as many as 20 chips.   Agreement With Hitachi **********Texas Instruments has shared research in developing the 16-megabit chip with Hitachi through an agreement the companies signed in 1988. Stan Victor, a spokesman, said the Texas Instruments' chip was based on the company's own designs and manufacturing process. **********In mastering the high-volume production process, Texas Instruments reduced the width of electronic circuits in the new chip to less than a one-hundredth of the width of a human hair, or nearly six-tenths of a micron. **********Texas Instruments' shares gained 12.5 cents, to $25.75, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange today. The shares traded as high as $27.375 during the session but retreated during the market's broad selloff later in the day.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/18/busin.body_text: **********Citicorp, the nation's largest banking company, said yesterday that problems with real estate loans and loans for corporate takeovers caused its earnings to fall 56.3 percent in the first quarter, to $231 million, from $529 million a year ago. **********Other regional banking companies announced strong gains in earnings. The NCNB Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., grew rapidly enough to raise earnings despite more real estate problems. Earnings also rose at Wells Fargo & Company, San Francisco, which is a heavy lender for real estate and corporate takeovers, but has managed to avoid making loans that turn sour. **********Problems Expected **********As the nation's largest lender for real estate, Citicorp has not avoided lending to projects in regions where a glut of new buildings has caused prices to fall and made some developers unable to repay their loans. Problems with real estate loans began increasing more than a year ago, and Citicorp executives have warned investors that they expected problems to grow this year. **********''The key question for Citicorp is whether they will have another round of loan difficulties after the examiners come in June,'' said Thomas Hanley, a banking analyst at Salomon Brothers. **********Citicorp earned 60 cents a share, slightly less than most analysts had expected, and well below the $1.52 it earned in the first quarter last year. **********Citicorp's chairman, John S. Reed, said last month that examiners would be focusing on real estate loans. In the earnings report released yesterday the bank said that becuase of unsettled conditions in the real estate market, a ''relatively high level of real estate charge-offs may continue.'' **********The real estate loans causing problems are for commercial properties like apartments, shopping centers and offices. Mortgages for single-family houses have not been a problem at major banks recently. **********In the first quarter, the company charged off $135 million of commercial loans in developed countries, including $56 million of real estate loans, mostly in North America. About 40 million of loans to finance corporate takeovers or other heavily indebted borrowers were charged off. A year ago, charge-offs in those countries totaled only $36 million. **********Citicorp said that problems with loans to highly indebted companies involved in corporate takeovers or other refinancings accounted for about half the $548 million increase since the end of the year in loans that are troubled and not paying interest. Analysts noted that Citibank was one of the leading lenders to the Campeau Corporation, whose American retail operations filed for bankruptcy earlier this year. **********Another sign of real estate problems was the $570 million allocated to the reserve for loan losses, up $212 million from a year earlier. About $56 million of the increase was to cover commercial real estate loans. American real estate loans that are not paying interest rose $119 million, to $1.3 billion. **********The strongest aspect of Citicorp's business continues to be consumer banking, which reported record profits of $270 million, up from $214 million a year ago. The credit card business, where Citicorp's various banks are the most active in the country, and the consumer banking business in the New York City market were especially strong,the company said. **********Despite the decline, Citicorp said its long-term prospects were favorable enough to increase its quarterly stock dividend nearly 10 percent, to 44.5 cents a share from 40.5 cents. Citicorp stock rose 25 cents, closing on the New York Stock Exchange at $24.50 a share. **********NCNB **********The NCNB Corporation, the seventh-largest banking company, announced first-quarter earnings of $140.1 million, or $1.33 a share, up 84.5 percent from $75.8 million, or 82 cents a share, a year earlier. Much of the growth reflects the acquisiton last year of a 100 pwercent ownership of the Republicbank Corporation of Texas, now known as NCNB Texas. **********As it warned analysts in March, NCNB said the weakening economy in the Southeastern part of the country caused some increase in problem loans, particularly for real estate. The banking company added $88.7 million to its reserve for loan losses in the first quarter compared with a $57.2 million addition a year ago. Troubled loans not paying interest, or facing other difficulties were $599.1 million, up from 446.1 million at the end of 1989. **********NCNB is benefiting from cost savings as it develops its operations in Texas. Non-interest expnses in the first quarter fell 2 percent from the fourth quarter of 1989. NCNB's shares gained 37.5 cents yesterday, to $37.375. **********Wells Fargo **********Wells Fargo & Company, the nation's 12th-largest banking company, which relied heavily on lending to real estate and corporate takeovers to become one of the country's most profitable banks in the 1980's yesterday reported a 12.9 percent gain in earnings, to $159.8 million from $141.5 million. **********The strong gain in earnings confused many banking analysts, who have expected that Wells Fargo's concentration in real estate and corporate takeover lending would eventually result in losses. **********''They continue to defy Wall Street,'' said Mr. Hanley of Salomon Brothers, ''and the quality of their loans remains squarely intact.'' **********In the first quarter, Wells Fargo added only $75 million to its reserve for loan losses, down from $100 million a year earlier. Troubled loans that are not paying interest or have been restructured rose to $752.1 million, from $625.1 million a year earlier. Wells Fargo stock rose 50 cents, to $71.50.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/09/world.main_headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Iraq Confines 38 Americans, But Their Status Is Unclear
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/09/world.print_headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Iraq Confines 38 Americans, But Their Status Is Unclear
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/09/world.body_text: **********Iraq released an American child today and permitted United States officials to visit 38 other Americans confined to a Baghdad hotel, but it continued to hold them under armed guard, the State Department announced today. **********The detention of the Americans in the hotel, some since last week, including 35 bused from Kuwait, have raised the fear in the Bush Administration that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq may be holding them as hostages. **********President Bush said in his speech today that the safety of the Americans in Iraq and Kuwait was one of four goals he had set in handling the Middle East crisis. Later, at a news conference, Mr. Bush refused to speculate whether President Hussein intended to use the Americans as hostages or negotiating chips. **********''I want to see them out of there obviously,'' Mr. Bush said, ''but what he does, that's a bit unpredictable.'' **********Several thousand citizens of non-Arab nations, including more than 1,400 Americans, have been trapped in Iraq and Kuwait, and the 38 Americans and about 170 other foreigners have been held in Baghdad hotels, since President Hussein invaded Kuwait last week. **********The Administration has played down the fear of a hostage crisis because it is uncertain of the exact condition of the Americans, and because it does not want to further heighten the crisis. In addition, officials are acutely sensitive to the damage that hostage crises inflicted on the Carter and Reagan Administrations. The protracted American hostage crisis in Teheran is believed to have contributed to President Carter's defeat in 1980. President Reagan's effort to free Americans held hostage in Lebanon led to the Iran-contra scandal. **********''It's a terrible dilemma,'' said a State Department official. ''These are horrible political and moral decisions.'' **********Another senior official said ''the welfare of those Americans is critical to the U.S. position and response to this whole affair.'' But he added, ''There has been no clear indication they are going to be used as hostages.'' **********The condition of the Americans in Baghdad has become the most detailed subject of negotiations between officials at the United States Embassy in Baghdad and Iraqi officials. American officials, who are pressing Baghdad to allow foreigners to leave, say there has been little progress in the discussions. **********Americans in Good Health **********They expressed some encouragement over Iraq's modest flexibility in its handling of the Americans at Al Rashid Hotel, and by the Government's promise to let some diplomats leave Baghdad. A State Department official said the 38 Americans at the hotel were in good health. **********Repeated telephone calls to the hotel were not answered. **********Iraqi officials allowed Penelope Nabokov, who is 10 years old, to leave the hotel and enter the American Embassy after American diplomats asked them to exempt her since she is so young and was traveling alone. Penelope, of Albany, Calif., was among 367 passengers on a British Airways jet that landed in Kuwait as the Iraqi invasion began. The girl, who was flying from France to join her mother, an anthropologist, in India, was taken by Iraqi soldiers and bused with other foreigners to Iraq. **********A State Department consular task force has identified 1,468 Americans in Iraq and Kuwait, mostly oil workers, tourists, teachers or technical workers. **********Relatives Less Than Assured **********Richard A. Boucher, a State Department spokesman, refused to characterize the Americans at the hotel as hostages, and described their status this way: ''They cannot leave the hotel grounds, but they have full use of the facility. There are armed guards located at the hotel, but the Americans have not been threatened.'' **********Some relatives of the Americans held in Al Rashid have expressed a different view. **********Margie Walterscheid said she considered her husband, Rainard, a drilling supervisor, a hostage at Al Rashid. ''State says the Iraqi people say they just took them for their safety, that they're not being detained, nor under arrest. But I know the hotel is surrounded by soldiers. If they were free to go, I doubt they still would be in the hotel.'' **********Mrs. Walterscheid, of Jacksboro, Tex., said she felt less secure about her husband's well-being since American troops were deployed to Saudi Arabia. **********Reports on foreigners in Iraq and Kuwait were sketchy. Mr. Boucher said it was his understanding that Americans in Baghdad and Kuwait City were free to walk the streets. **********Telling Americans to Pack **********He said the United States Embassy in Kuwait City was communicating with Americans there by telephone ''to the extent possible; lines, however, are only open sporadically.'' When they can get through, embassy personnel are telling Americans to prepare to leave as soon as borders are open. **********So far, no Americans have been reported harmed. But there have been repeated reports of Iraqi forces' raping foreign women, including a British Airways flight attendant taken by a soldier from an airline bus in Kuwait at gunpoint. **********Mr. Boucher said that should Baghdad comply with its promise to allow American diplomats to leave Iraq, the State Department would keep some embassy employees in the country to maintain diplomatic contacts and consular services. **********Europeans Slip Through **********AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 8 (Special to The New York Times) - European business executives who slipped out of Iraq today said that several hundred foreigners who have been prevented from leaving Baghdad have been segregated by nationality and taken to three hotels in the capital. **********The businessmen said that restaurants and shops appeared to be operating normally and that the foreigners were not being threatened. **********An estimated 3,000 foreigners, including 1,400 Americans, were in Kuwait when Iraqi tanks and troops invaded last Thursday. Dozens of them were taken by bus to Baghdad, where they are being held in the hotels, the executives said. **********Weary, dusty and unshaven as they arrived here after driving for more than 10 hours through the scorching desert, the businessmen said they were treated cordially in Iraq and permitted to move freely about the capital. They were told that they could not leave the country, however, without obtaining permission from the Foreign Ministry. **********Reports of Friendly Soldiers **********''We heard through the grapevine that some people were able to leave yesterday,'' Joseph Gai of Switzerland said today. ''So we left in a company car early this morning.'' **********At the desolate border between Iraq and Jordan, where temperatures regularly soar above 100 degrees at this time of year, ''the soldiers and customs officials were very friendly,'' said Martin Matheis, a construction engineer from Ulm, West Germany. **********''The customs officials asked why we were leaving and we just said we were ready to go,'' Mr. Matheis said. ''So they stamped our passports and we had no problems.'' **********Brian Hume, the British manager of an international shipping company in Amman, said he had hired a taxi in Baghdad and crossed into Jordan on Tuesday. He described the Iraqi capital as ''very calm'' and said he had been unaware that it was the focus of world attention. **********''There were a lot of soldiers on the streets, posted at corners,'' he said. ''But there was no heavy artillery, nothing like that. No threats.'' **********At the border, Mr. Hume said, an Iraqi traveler told him, ''You're not allowed out.'' But ''I got my passport stamped and left,'' the British executive said. **********Mr. Matheis said he had not felt that he was in danger in Baghdad. The people there ''were very friendly to us,'' he said, and many seemed in high spirits over the army's capture of Kuwait.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/28/busin.main_headline: Patents;   A Quiet Alarm Clock: It Vibrates the Pillow
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/28/busin.print_headline: Patents;   A Quiet Alarm Clock: It Vibrates the Pillow
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/28/busin.body_text: **********A New Jersey inventor has developed what seems like a contradiction in terms: a quiet alarm clock. Instead of waking people with a buzz or a bell, it sets off vibrations in their pillows. **********Invented by Jack B. Meister of Convent Station, N.J., the small digital timepiece contains a motor that rapidly rotates a shaft carrying an off-center weight. Mr. Meister said the vibrations were at least as effective as conventional alarms. He said the timepiece, which is placed in the pillow, was designed for people with impaired hearing and for those who want to get up without waking others. **********He received patent 4,920,525.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/28/world.main_headline: Seoul Journal;   After All the Tear Gas, Just the Tears Remain
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/28/world.print_headline: Seoul Journal;   After All the Tear Gas, Just the Tears Remain
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/28/world.body_text: **********The kind of student demonstrations that filled the streets with protesters and tear gas here over the last week have become an unofficial fixture of the South Korean university curriculum and, at times, a genuine catalyst for change. In 1987, students helped force the military-dominated Government to hold its first free elections. **********But behind this youthful enthusiasm is a darker reality not always appreciated by many of the freshmen donning their first gas masks: the price that protesters sometimes pay for their idealism in damaged job and social opportunities. **********Even a young person's marriage prospects here, some maintain, can be harmed by a political record. **********Few Places to Turn **********''Activists can only marry other activists,'' said Myung Ro Keun, a professor of English linguistics at Chunnam University in Kwangju, a well-known dissident and the father of two daughters who were jailed for their student political activities. ''It has been very hard for these students to find jobs, too. Many just become factory workers.'' **********The permanent alienation of so many young people, said Yoo Jong Hae, a professor of public administration at the prestigious Yonsei University, ''is a tragedy for Korea.'' **********Park Shin Il, a Government spokesman, insisted that there was no blacklist against former student leaders who have been imprisoned, and pointed out that there were laws preventing discrimination. But many who have been through that experience tell a different story, even some who are back in the mainstream. **********Two cases illustrate the perils that student protesters face. **********Shim Jae Chul, a 32-year-old who speaks in a clear, confident voice, is one former dissident student leader who made the long journey back from imprisonment; he is now a television news reporter. But he says he sees himself as a token of conciliation, someone given a break denied to many others in a gesture that makes more poignant the problems that other former protesters face. **********'Incredibly Lucky' **********He was chosen for special treatment in part because he was from Kwangju, the southern city where the military brutally suppressed pro-democracy protests 10 years ago. By official count the army killed 200 people at Kwangju, although many say the true toll is in the thousands. The unrest last week was staged to mark the anniversary of those deaths. **********''I was incredibly lucky,'' he said. ''Not many were, though.'' At the same time that Mr. Shim was being given his second chance, another young Korean student was just beginning his passage to the fringes of Korean society, from which he has yet to fully emerge. **********This slender, nervous and intense young student, who spoke on the condition that he not be identified, said he was arrested in 1986 as an underground organizer of student rallies, jailed, tortured and eventually convicted of violating the vague and feared National Security Law. **********Thrown Out of School **********Though he was soon paroled, he said his hopes of becoming an agricultural economist were broken. He got his new job, in communications, through a relative, an edge that allowed him to avoid a potentially damaging background check. **********Today, the ambitions of this young man, who spoke admiringly of an older brother studying to become an accountant, are in many ways the ordinary middle-class dreams of a good job and a better life. **********Mr. Shim's story began when he was elected president of the student council at the prestigious Seoul National University in 1980, the year that the military sought to tighten control after a coup and cracked down on the Kwangju protests. He was arrested in Seoul in a sweep of student leaders and was handed a five-year sentence, then released a few months later as part of an amnesty. But he was thrown out of the university and drafted into the army. **********The experience, he said, left him shattered, not because he was surprised at being arrested, but because of his personal sense of failure and frustration. ''I felt guilty not for losing to the army,'' Mr. Shim recalled. ''That was inevitable. But we failed to give people hope and trust and faith that we could overcome them. You have to understand, at that time there was just fear. It was complete terror. There was no hope.'' Sense of Commitment Mr. Shim said his fortunes turned only when the Government sought to create a more conciliatory image. He was allowed back into the university in 1984, and then found a job as a reporter with the Munhwa Broadcasting Corporation, one of two television networks here. **********He insists that he remains committed to many of his goals as a student leader and sees journalism as a way of continuing to help Korean society in a less fiery way. **********The other young man said he became interested in the student movement when his older brother was arrested in the early 1980's. **********The experience led him to become involved in a political study group that eventually became an underground circle for organizing the students at his university in Seoul. One day when he showed up for a meeting, the police were waiting. **********Like Mr. Shim, he said his brief imprisonment left him with a crushing sense of failure, one that took him two years to shake. **********''It was so hard to accept that my relationships with friends were being destroyed and that I could not trust anyone,'' he recalled. ''That was the moist painful thing I had to overcome. I didn't even trust myself.'' **********The 'Hidden' Violence **********The two former students also expressed misgivings about what they saw as the greater violence used by student demonstrators today. **********But they said their experiences had given them some understanding of why the protesters sometimes resorted to force. **********''People outside the movement just see the violence of the demonstrators,'' said the former student leader. ''What you have to realize is the hidden forms of violence that the Government uses against its opponents.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/04/world.main_headline: Beirut General Seen as Likely to Yield Power
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/04/world.print_headline: Beirut General Seen as Likely to Yield Power
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/04/world.body_text: **********The failure of Gen. Michel Aoun to crush his militia opponents in the Christian sector after five weeks of fierce battles is likely to force him to step down and turn power over to President Elias Hrawi, according to news reports published today and Arab diplomats. **********Beirut's leading daily newspaper, An Nahar, said the army command under General Aoun was seriously considering handing the presidential palace in the Christian suburb of Baabda to the Government of Mr. Hrawi. The diplomats reported that France was trying to persuade the 54-year-old general to leave, and had offered to provide him with safe passage to Paris. **********A two-day onslaught by army troops to dislodge fighters of the Lebanese Forces militia in East Beirut bogged down on Friday, prompting General Aoun to call off the offensive and agree to yet another cease-fire, the 16th since the violent confrontation between Christians broke out on Jan. 30. **********Shell-shocked men, weeping women and hungry children emerged from bomb shelters today to stock up on food and water, walking in streets strewn with fallen mansonry, burned cars and broken water pipes. In Sin el Fil and Al Mabaa, residential quarters that bore the brunt of the army's offensive, almost every building carried shell scars. Both districts appeared to be firmly in the hands of militiamen loyal to Samir Geagea. **********''Not even the Syrians have done to us what this man has wrought,'' a middle-aged woman said on a video film shown by the militia television station, the Lebanese Broadcasting Corporation. The woman, who was not identified, was referring to General Aoun and the Syrian bombardment of the Christian sector last summer. The shelling came after the general declared a ''war of liberation'' to evict 40,000 Syrian soldiers from Lebanon. **********The woman led the television camera to a small basement where, she said, 10 families had lived for days. **********The woman's teen-age daughter, identified as Nadine, said, ''What I want to know is where Aoun has sent his family for protection.'' **********The general has three daughters, one of them Nadine's age. **********At one time, General Aoun's wife and children lived with him in his bunker two stories under the presidential palace, which was demolished by Syrian bombardment. There has been no mention of the Aoun family in news reports since December, when a French weekly, Le Canard Enchaine, disclosed that Mrs. Aoun held signature power to her husband's $15 million account in a Paris bank. **********General Aoun, army commander for five years, has lived and worked in the bunker since President Amin Gemayel named him head of an interim military Cabinet 17 months ago. He has maintained that he is the head of the country's only legitimate government, and he refused to give up the seat of power when Parliament elected Mr. Hrawi in November to succeed President Rene Moawad, who was assassinated. **********The Mood Seems to Change **********But An Nahar suggested in an article today that the mood was changing. Citing senior politicians, the newspaper said General Aoun's military and civilian advisers were seeking a way out of the deadlock, and were proposing that the general hand power to Mr. Hrawi. **********There was no immediate word on the subject from General Aoun, who resumed contacts with mediators between him and Mr. Geagea. **********One of the mediators, a Maronite Catholic Bishop, Khalil Abi Nader, met today with President Hrawi, who is internationally recognized and has the backing of the 22-nation Arab League. **********Government officials said the Bishop discussed relief aid for the devastated Christian sector. Mr. Hrawi is scheduled to leave on Sunday for Saudi Arabia for talks with King Fahd, after which he will proceed to Algeria for a meeting with President Chadli Benjadid. With Morocco, Saudi Arabia and Algeria form the Arab League's three-nation committee on Lebanon. **********They had helped to bring Lebanese Muslim and Christian Parliament members last October to sign a national reconciliation pact, which was rejected by General Aoun.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/14/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   'Junk Bonds' of RJR Holdings Surge
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/14/busin.body_text: **********Prices of RJR Holdings Inc.'s bonds surged in heavy trading yesterday following a report that Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company would invest $1.7 billion in the company. **********The buying set off a sharp rally in the market for high-yield ''junk bonds.'' **********Spokesmen for Kohlberg, Kravis and RJR Holdings would not comment on the report in The Wall Street Journal yesterday. But several limited partners confirmed that they had transferred money to the buyout firm on Monday. And those who had signed a confidentiality agreement that was requested by Kohlberg, Kravis were told that the estimated $1.7 billion would be used to invest in a restructuring of the RJR Holdings debt. **********What the Partners Know **********Kohlberg, Kravis executives, who took RJR Nabisco Inc. private in 1989 in the largest leveraged buyout in history, did not tell their partners specifically how they planned to restructure the debt. But several partners said yesterday that Henry Kravis, a founding member of the firm, had discussed buying back some of the bonds that were issued to finance the buyout. Prices of many of these bonds had dropped sharply in recent months on investor concerns about the company's ability to pay its debts. **********Kohlberg, Kravis, with one of the largest buyout funds in the country, is able to raise cash quickly from its partners - banks, insurance companies and pension funds - by making a ''capital call'' for all or some of the funds its investors have committed. The investors have virutally no say in the way the firm invests that money. **********In the past, Kohlberg, Kravis has financed its equity investments with borrowed money. **********Investors in the buyout fund who provided the equity financing for the original RJR Nabisco takeover said yesterday that they did not think the company was in financial trouble or that the original deal was badly structured. Indeed, operating results of RJR Nabisco and its asset sales have exceeded many investors' expectations, they said. **********Returns of 25 to 30 Percent **********Instead, they said Mr. Kravis had convinced them that they could earn returns of 25 to 30 percent by restructuring the company's finances and buying back bonds at a discount. **********If the debt is restructured favorably, such a move would also increase the return on equity investments in the company. **********For months, rumors about such a transaction had periodically arisen in the junk bond market. Yesterday, analysts and traders in this market reacted favorably to the news. Prices of many low-rated bonds, including those of American Standard, Duracell and Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, rose sharply on heavy buying. **********Investors appear to be more confident that RJR, which had been unable to raise money in the battered junk-bond market, will now have access to a large source of cash, making it easier for the company to repay its debts to banks and shareholders. **********''The market is now comfortable that they have accessed money,'' said Dirk Van Doren, a junk bond analyst at McCarthy Crisanti Maffei, a bond-rating firm in Montpelier, Vt. **********Two Issues Rise $7 **********The heavy buying affected two bonds that were issued in 1989 to help finance the buyout of RJR Nabisco. Yesterday the securities in question - $4.1 billion of exchange debentures due in 2007 and $1.8 billion of senior converting debentures due in 2009 -jumped more than $7 apiece in heavy trading, closing at $77 and $90.50 respectively for each $100 of face value. **********In recent months, the two issues have traded as low as $52 and $58. The convertible issue can be exchanged into 25 percent of the company's common stock in 1993. **********The two issues have been volatile this year. They have a so-called reset feature, and such securities are considered extremely risky. No later than April 1991, the interest rate on both issues must be reset at a rate that will make the bonds trade at 100 cents on the dollar, and some investors have worried that RJR will be forced to set a prohibitively high rate to achieve that. **********Also, the bonds have moved sharply up and down because they pay investors interest in more securities, not in cash, and these ''pay-in-kind'' bonds are more sensitive to market moves. **********Change in Market's Perception **********By demonstrating that RJR has access to new cash, Kohlberg, Kravis is likely to make it less onerous to reset the interest rate on the bonds. A change in the market's perception could cause investors to drive the prices of the bonds up so that the reset feature becomes less expensive to finance. That, in turn, could make it easier for the company to refinance its $1.2 billion of bank debt that is due next February.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/18/busin.main_headline: First Interstate Sets Changes at the Top
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/18/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;   First Interstate Sets Changes at the Top
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/18/busin.body_text: **********First Interstate Bancorp said yesterday that Edward M. Carson, its president, would become chairman and chief executive. He will assume the position on June 1, after the retirement at age 65 of Joseph J. Pinola, who has led the Los Angeles-based banking company for 12 years. **********The company said William B. Siart would succeed Mr. Carson as president of the parent company and would retain his posts as chairman and chief executive of the First Interstate Bank of California, the company's largest operating unit. **********Analysts said the appointment of the 60-year-old Mr. Carson to the top posts was not surprising, although there had been some speculation that First Interstate's board might bypass a generation of management and select Mr. Siart, who is 43. **********Mr. Pinola, who is perhaps best known for his unsuccessful attempt to acquire the much-larger BankAmerica Corporation three years ago, is stepping down at a time when strong performances by most units of the company are being overshadowed by troubles in its Texas and Arizona subsidiaries. **********The devastation of the real estate markets in those states has forced the First Interstate Bank of Texas and the First Interstate Bank of Arizona to establish large reserves for loan losses, causing losses for the company and dragging down its stock. The company reported a loss for the third quarter of 1989 of $15.5 million, compared with a loss of $214.4 million in the third quarter of 1988. The company is also expected to report a loss for the fourth quarter. **********When he engineered the company's entry into Texas two years ago with the acquisition of Allied Bancshares of Houston, Mr. Pinola was gambling that the state's oil-based economy would rebound and that the real estate problems could be kept under control. **********Mr. Pinola said in an interview that the company had tried ''to put the known problems in Texas behind us'' by taking the loss reserves, but acknowledged that shareholders had been angered by the problems there. **********''All of whatever else we accomplished here is now being subordinated in large measure to that one problem,'' Mr. Pinola said, referring to the losses from Texas. ''I'm suffering for it, but I did it and I have to live with it.'' **********First Interstate has assets of $58 billion and operates 28 banks in 14 states, mostly in the West. The company also franchises its name in 11 other states. **********Mr. Carson, who has been president of the parent company since 1985, came up through the ranks of the Arizona subsidiary, which he joined in 1951 after graduating from the University of Arizona. Analysts said he had a reputation as a methodical, low-key manager who had proved adept at cost-cutting. **********''My expectation is that Ed will be more operationally focused than Joe was, and more internally focused,'' said Donald K. Crowley, an analyst at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods in San Francisco. ''They have an excellent franchise, but it continues to underperform.'' **********Mr. Siart is given credit by analysts for improving the performance of First Interstate Bank of California in a highly competitive market. He received a degree in finance from the University of Santa Clara and an M.B.A. from the University of California at Berkeley. He joined First Interstate in 1978 after spending nine years at the Bank of America.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/17/world.body_text: **********The partly burned body of Kenya's Foreign Minister was found today in a cane field near his home, three days after he disappeared. The Government indicated that the Minister, Robert Ouko, was a slaying victim. **********President Daniel arap Moi said the body of the 58-year-old Minister was found ''in circumstances which at the moment suggest foul play'' about four miles from his family farm in Koru, not far from Lake Victoria. **********The President's statement said the body was partly burned. ''Anyone who may be associated with this horrible event will most certainly be apprehended,'' he said. **********Mr. Ouko, considered one of the most skilled members of President Moi's Cabinet, vanished on Tuesday. His disappearance went unreported until Thursday evening, when Kenya's official press agency broadcast an appeal from family members urging him to contact them or Government officials. **********A 'Courageous Spokesman' **********President Moi said Mr. Ouko's death was a loss for ''the whole nation.'' He called him ''a brilliant leader, an articulate and courageous spokesman of this country and a loyal servant of the people.'' **********The Minister's name had rarely appeared in press accounts describing rivalries within Kenya's ruling party. **********Mr. Ouko was last seen publicly on Saturday, when he addressed a service organization in Kisumu, 220 miles northwest of Nairobi and not far from his Koru home. **********State-run radio and television stations quoted unidentified family members Thursday night as saying that no one had seen him leave his farm after he went to bed on Monday night. **********The Kenya Times, a daily newspaper in Nairobi, reported on Friday that a white car arrived at Mr. Ouko's house at about 3 A.M. Tuesday and drove off with the minister inside. The paper attributed its report to two unidentified employees in the minister's home.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/19/busin.main_headline: Ogilvy Wins In Kraft Shift Of Accounts
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/19/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;   Ogilvy Wins In Kraft Shift Of Accounts
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/19/busin.body_text: **********IN a surprise move, Kraft General Foods has realigned the agency roster for some of its leading brands. **********The big winner was Ogilvy & Mather, which picked up the domestic and worldwide accounts for Maxwell House, Yuban and Brim coffees, which by some estimates are together worth more than $100 million. **********The Maxwell House victory was especially good news for Ogilvy, which had lost that $70 million account last year to D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles. Kraft was reportedly unhappy with Ogilvy's advertising, which had not been effective in stemming Maxwell House's slide in market share against Procter & Gamble's Folgers. **********''This is a great vote of confidence for the other work we've been doing for the client,'' said Julian Clopet, the president of North American operations at Ogilvy. The agency creates advertising for Kraft General Foods brands like Tang, Shake 'n Bake and several Post cereals. **********Kraft also chose new agencies for its Kraft mayonnaise, Miracle Whip salad dressing, Polly-O cheese, Birds Eye frozen foods, Breakstone dairy products and Lender's bagels. **********Executives at some of Kraft's agencies said the company made the reassignments after secret talks with its agencies about its new overall marketing strategies. Some agency executives said the extent of the account switches was startling because Kraft executives had not quizzed agencies about how they would handle advertising for any specific brands. **********The company, which spends about $750 million annually on advertising, is expected to make some further realignments. Although Kraft executives would not comment on any future account shifts, agency executives speculated that the company may reassign some of its flagging Post cereal brands that are now handled by Grey Advertising and Ogilvy. **********Kraft made the changes as part of a program to bolster its brands, some of which have been losing market share. ''Our goal is to create an environment that enables us to get the best advertising available to build our business,'' said Eric Strobel, senior vice president for marketing at Kraft General Foods. **********Mr. Strobel said the company wanted to insure that the best people at each agency were assigned to its accounts by significantly increasing the total size of Kraft's business at each agency. **********The company made the reassignments principally based on the kind of Kraft accounts that each agency already has and on an agency's ability to handle a brand's worldwide advertising. ''We want our agencies to build true category expertise,'' Mr. Strobel said. **********Kraft also switched agencies for six other brands in the United States. Leo Burnett gained the $10 million to $15 million Kraft mayonnaise account, which had been at Young & Rubicam. **********Y.&R. also lost the Birds Eye business, which will now be handled by Wergeles & Drazen, a small New York agency that had worked with Kraft on some product introductions. **********But Y.&R. was amply compensated by picking up the larger-spending Breakstone account, which had been at McCann-Erickson. A spokesman for Y.&R. said the account switches ended up adding several million dollars to the agency's billings. **********McCann also lost the Lender's bagels account, which went to D.M.B.&B. McCann now handles no business for Kraft. **********J. Walter Thompson's Chicago office picked up two accounts: Polly-O and Miracle Whip. Polly-O had been at Y.&R. and Miracle Whip at Foote, Cone & Belding in Chicago. **********The company is also revising its system for evaluating and compensating agencies. Under the new system, which will take effect next year, agencies will be judged on how much the company thinks advertising has helped a brand's sales. Domestically, an agency will earn a 16 percent commission based on billings for superior work and a 14 percent commission for work that merely meets established objectives.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/08/world.body_text: **********Kashmiri militants shot and killed an Indian policeman today and killed a Muslim they suspected of spying for New Delhi, the Governor of Jammu and Kashmir state said. https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/11/world.body_text: **********A correspondent for a British newspaper has been sentenced to death in Iraq after being convicted of espionage, and a British nurse has been sentenced to 15 years in prison on charges of helping him, the Foreign Office said today. **********Iranian-born Farzad Bazoft, 31 years old, who works for The Observer, a Sunday newspaper, was arrested in September while investigating reports of an explosion at an Iraqi military complex. The nurse, Daphne Parish, 52, was accused of helping him by driving him to the military complex south of Baghdad, Al Iskandaria. **********In addition, an Iraqi who was in contact with Mr. Bazoft in Baghdad was given a 10-year sentence for communicating Government secrets to a foreigner, the Foreign Office said. **********Under Iraqi law, no appeal is allowed. **********''We utterly deplore these harsh and excessive sentences,'' the Foreign Office said. **********It said it was making an appeal for clemency to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/12/world.main_headline: Soviet Miners Strike for the Day, In Hope of Power and Better Life
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/12/world.print_headline: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;   Soviet Miners Strike for the Day, In Hope of Power and Better Life
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/12/world.body_text: **********The nation's coal miners held a daylong protest strike today to demand the resignation of the Soviet Government and greater local powers for industry and labor. **********Though the nominal target of the protest was Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, the miners' intended effect was to press President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to ease their lives by quickly providing them with better pay, better housing and more available goods. Hundreds of thousands of miners displayed their most confrontational attitude yet toward the troubled reform program of Mr. Gorbachev, saying a full-scale walkout would follow if their situation did not improve. **********The militant edge was a reminder of the three-week strike that shut down the mines a year ago in protest against living and working conditions, a crippling walkout costly to the Soviet economy and the Gorbachev leadership's prestige. **********Even before the protest walkout, Mr. Gorbachev charged that it was instigated for political reasons and was not truly the miners' idea. **********Today, miners rallied in the hot sun of the city square here, frequently praising Boris N. Yeltsin, the President of Russia, the largest of the nation's 15 republics, and playing him off against Mr. Gorbachev. The strikers denied that they were motivated by anything but hard times and their desire to prod the Government. **********A Land Defaced **********The one-day protest strike covered the main coal areas of the nation, including the Kuznetsk Basin field here in Siberia, where verdant summer only partly masks great expanses of land gashed by mines and belching factory smokestacks. **********Other mines were idled in the Vorkuta fields inside the Arctic Circle, the Donets Basin fields of the Ukraine and even a few mines on Sakhalin Island far to the Pacific East, said organizers from the Confederation of Labor, a new nationwide workers' movement. **********The scene here, where last summer's strike erupted, was notable for the stronger emphasis on politics and not just economic need, and for the bold new spirit in which workers have begun ordering Communist Party officials to clear out of the mines. **********Weary of the rambling, inconclusive nationwide congress of the Communist Party continuing today in Moscow, the miners denounced the Communists at scores of rallies across the country. Workers at dozens of factories also staged sympathy strikes and rallies with the miners, organizers said. **********Rally participants mocked the party as a ''mere entertainment.'' They smiled at signs that proclaimed: ''No to the diktat of the party! Yes to the diktat of conscience!'' **********But there was no immediate mood to extend the strike, which was estimated to have involved more than 400,000 workers at more than 250 mines in 24-hour shutdowns or part-time sympathy strikes. **********'Hotheads,' Says Gorbachev **********President Gorbachev, in some heated remarks at the party congress in Moscow, contended that the miners had ''not achieved their goal.'' He insisted that the ''hotheads'' in the Kuznetsk Basin fields had failed. The miners here in the fields contradicted him, saying workers in most mines were taking part. **********''In the last year things have gotten worse,'' said Vasily Grinev, a miner for most of the last three decades. ''The food stores are mostly empty again. The politicization of the miners is growing, and that's the biggest change in a year.'' **********The strike today, conducted in a genial, almost holiday atmosphere, was presented as a warning of more intense job stoppages to come unless the Government helps miners improve their housing, food and health care, and frees the mines of central control so that the miners might make better deals directly for themselves. **********''We will be waiting on the action of the Russian Federation Parliament,'' said Aleksei Soloveov, one of the strike leaders, describing the miners' strategy. ''Many of us trust Boris Yeltsin, and he met with the miners and promised to consider our demands immediately in the Parliament.'' **********Counting on Discontent **********While Mr. Yeltsin, as Russian President, has asked for a respite from strikes, he has also been capitalizing on various political movements across the land. The Communist Party continues to stumble, and insurgent forces are seeking a way to coalesce into an opposition. **********The miners say Mr. Yeltsin's goal of making Soviet laws subordinate to the law of the republic fits in with their agenda of decentralizing more economic initiative to workers. **********One of the miners' rallies today reflected the nation's new political habit of instant cult interest in anyone who is denounced by the Kremlin. The rally, in Novokuznetsk, presented the spectacle of miners' hailing Oleg D. Kalugin, a longtime operative in the K.G.B. security police, who has lately joined the ranks of the reformers. He was recently stripped of his job and privileges for telling the public what it already knows: that the K.G.B. remains untrustworthy. **********The miners' demand for the resignation of the Soviet Government has stung Kremlin officials, who were busy a year ago negotiating compromises to end the worst labor unrest in decades. **********Ryzhkov as Scapegoat **********''This is the Government that took measures to solve their problems,'' Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov said Sunday in condemning the protest along with Mr. Gorbachev. **********The miners are demanding that Mr. Ryzhkov and the rest of the Council of Ministers resign for incompetence, but not Mr. Gorbachev. He is theoretically above the fray, but is actually the national leader under the quasi-parliamentary system. **********A year ago, when his own standing was stronger in the country, Mr. Gorbachev, far from criticizing the striking miners, said they were inspirational for the grass-roots initiative lacking in his reform program. This time, however, the Soviet leader said the ''pushing'' by the miners ''is not acceptable.'' **********The Government-controlled press has been portraying miners as dissatisfied, but with conditions improving. Workers have begun leasing mines now for their own collective management. **********Considerable problems are reported with this new option. But the first results are evident here in the form of some Japanese cars and video equipment received by mines that dealt directly with Japanese companies needing coal.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/12/busin.main_headline: A Troubled Winery Where Debt Is Aging
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/12/busin.print_headline: A Troubled Winery Where Debt Is Aging
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/12/busin.body_text: **********When Paul M. Schlem created the Vintners International Company three years ago by acquiring Paul Masson, Taylor California Cellars and the Taylor Wine Company of New York, he planned to sell assets to reduce debt, cut overhead and move these once- strong brands into the higher end of the market. **********But as it enters the 1990's, the nation's third-largest winery company still has a balance sheet designed in the 1980's and a product mix more appropriate to the 1970's. Debt is about $216 million, more than 16 times the privately held common equity, at a time when banks and Wall Street have turned negative on highly leveraged companies. And more than 90 percent of Vintners' production is inexpensive jug wines, the segment that is suffering a decline in sales even steeper than that of the market as a whole; health-consciousness and shifting tastes are prompting consumers to drink less but better wine. **********Staggering under a heavy debt load, with declining sales of its core products, Vintners must sell major assets if it is to remain solvent, wine industry consultants say. After an aborted move to attract a new minority investor, Vintners has reluctantly put Taylor New York, its only operation not encumbered by mortgages, on the block. **********Mr. Schlem acknowledged Vintners' difficulties, but said they had been blown out of proportion by competitors and disgruntled former executives. ''We're not in dire straits with our financial situation; we just have a huge bank loan,'' said Mr. Schlem, 65 years old, who is Vintners' chairman and chief executive. ''The ratio of debt to equity which was very fashionable in 1987 is now out of vogue.'' By selling Taylor New York and retiring most of the company's bank debt, ''we'll put ourselves in a position that's unassailable,'' he said. **********With 14 million cases of wine sold annually, Vintners trails only the E & J Gallo Winery of Modesto, Calif., the nation's biggest winery by far, and Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. of Britain, which owns Almaden and Inglenook. Vintners' main winery at Gonzales, 125 miles south of San Francisco, is among the most sophisticated in the industry and the Paul Masson and Taylor brand names still enjoy substantial customer recognition in the United States and abroad. **********By selling Taylor New York, which he expects will fetch about $80 million for the brands and operations and about $20 million for inventory, Mr. Schlem said he could pay off nearly all short-term bank debt, leaving about $104 million in mortgages on the California wineries and $12 million in preferred stock. Even then, he said, Vintners will remain the third-largest winery business on the strength of Paul Masson and Taylor California Cellars. **********As a closely held company, Vintners is not required to disclose earnings, but Mr. Schlem said the company was marginally profitable on an operating level even after paying debt, and showed a loss of $8.4 million after depreciation in the fiscal year 1989, which ended July 31. It had $247.5 million in revenues. It expects revenues to be flat in the 1990 fiscal year, with an operating profit of $4 million and a net loss of $3 million. **********Loans Called **********Mr. Schlem said the company must sell its New York operation in part because the troubled Bank of New England, Vintners' major lender, is under pressure by Federal regulators to cut back on loans to highly leveraged companies and is calling Vintners' loans. He said it would be hard to replace those loans because in the new climate banks are demanding equity in exchange for loans to such companies, and he is not willing to offer that. **********Mr. Schlem said the New York operation accounted for about $60 million in revenues and was profitable. In addition to about two million cases of its own brands, it bottles several million cases of coolers for Joseph E. Seagram & Sons Inc. under contract. **********Still, wine industry consultants say that the $100 million asking price is a bit rich, and that without the sale Vintners' survival is in question. **********Given the softness of the wine market and the lack of demand for New York State wines outside a few Eastern states, ''who would want a New York facility?'' asked Tom Pirko, president of Bevmark Inc., a Los Angeles-based beverage industry consulting firm. ''I don't see how Vintners can sell enough assets to get out of the hole,'' he said. ''I don't think they'll make it through the next harvest.'' **********Paul Gillette, a wine industry consultant and publisher of the Wine Investor, said that the list of potential buyers for such a huge winery was short but that there was interest. (Taylor's operation in Hammondsport, N.Y., has a storage capacity of 23.8 million gallons and a bottling capacity of 44,300 cases a day.) If Vintners can make the sale, Mr. Gillette said, it can probably survive. **********''If Schlem can keep the wolf away from the door, he may be able to go on profitably for some time,'' Mr. Gillette said. ''His situation is critical, but it's not desperate.'' **********A Changing Market **********Besides paying down the debt, Mr. Schlem must complete the tricky task of rehabilitating and repositioning Paul Masson and Taylor California Cellars for a changing market. Not counting coolers, wine sales declined about 10 percent in the 1980's, but generic jug wines, the segment where Taylor and Masson make most of their sales, declined 20 percent. In that environment, the big producers battle for market share, which drives down prices and profit margins. **********The solution is to move up to the one segment still growing - premium, so-called varietal wines. These typically bear the name of a single grape type, like chardonnay, rather than a generic label like chablis. Rarely accomplished successfully, moving a brand ''up market'' involves not only using different grapes but also more attractive packaging, store promotions and advertising to recast the brand's image. **********Such a move is proving difficult for Vintners' brands, because while many consumers know them - who can forget Orson Welles's breathy incantation of ''We will sell no wine before its time'' for Masson - they lack cachet. **********'No One Wants It' **********''In this area, no one asks for Taylor, no one wants it, no one cares, and it's the same thing for Masson - it's a nonentity,'' said David Wilce, manager of Pacific Wine and Spirits, a retailer in Los Gatos, Calif., near the original Paul Masson winery. **********Michael Cliff, who was dismissed as Vintners' chief executive in July 1989, said he had been stymied in efforts to move the brands to the higher end of the market by Mr. Schlem's reluctance to enter the fine wine business. **********''We had a major philosophical difference of opinion on the strategy,'' Mr. Cliff said. While it is difficult to shift a brand from the generic to the premium market, he noted that ''Sebastiani did a very good job doing exactly what I wanted to do.'' Sebastiani is now the largest producer of chardonnay with its Country Chardonnay brand. **********But Mr. Schlem is continuing some of Mr. Cliff's strategies, like the split of Masson's varietal wines into two distinct labels: Paul Masson Vintage Selections, which sell for $4 to $5 for a 750-milliliter bottle, and Masson Vineyards, for 100 percent Monterey County varietals, which sell for $6 to $7. The Masson Vineyards wines have won a number of medals in competition, but to Mr. Schlem's frustration, still go unmentioned by wine critics. **********Plus and Minus **********''The negative is your good restaurants all refuse to take the wine in,'' Mr. Schlem said. ''The positive is the supermarkets all take it. Our focus is on good wines at reasonable prices that the consumer will pick up.'' **********Vintners, which had almost no varietal sales when acquired three years ago, will sell about one million cases this year, and more if white zinfandel is included in the count, Mr. Schlem said. The company also has the largest-selling non-alcoholic wine, St. Regis, at 300,000 cases. **********Vintners has ''a lot of pockets of strength in various niches,'' Mr. Gillette said. ''But Taylor California is iffy.'' **********Coca-Cola created the Taylor California brand from scratch after buying the Taylor Wine Company of New York; it sold all its wine businesses to Seagram, which already owned Masson, in 1983. Mr. Schlem bought the businesses from Seagram in a leveraged buyout. **********One area in which Mr. Schlem has made considerable headway is in reducing overhead. While he retains an office on Park Avenue and a private table at the Four Seasons, the company's headquarters are considerably less lavish than under Seagram. The work force has been trimmed. **********''This is not turnover; I've cut the ranks,'' Mr. Schlem said. ''They were very good people, but too many.'' **********Despite declining sales and general gloom in the wine industry, Mr. Schlem said he has no interest in selling any assets beyond the New York operation and is confident the company will be far more valuable in two years. ''Is business wonderful?'' he said. ''No. But we're ahead of the pack in not losing share this calendar year. It's a wonderful business if you don't weaken.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/13/world.main_headline: 42 Poorest Lands, Fearing Loss In Leverage, Plan Drive for Help
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/13/world.print_headline: 42 Poorest Lands, Fearing Loss In Leverage, Plan Drive for Help
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/13/world.body_text: **********In an atmosphere of gloom and foreboding, representatives of the world's 42 poorest nations met here this weekend to devise new ways to convince richer countries that nearly half a billion people need help desperately. **********The sense of urgency is heightened by the fear that the lessening of East-West tensions will reduce the leverage that poor countries can exercise on the superpowers. **********In these nations, which the United Nations lists officially as Least Developed Countries, the 1980's have brought more degrading poverty, declining literacy, worsening health and generally lower living standards - all made worse by large population increases, fragile environments, vulnerability to natural disasters and, often, limited civil rights or outright repression. **********''In a world of plenty they remain poor,'' said President H. M. Ershad of Bangladesh in his opening speech Saturday. ''In a world of movement, their lives are static. In a world full of hope, they are fated to despair.'' **********A Category of Their Own **********Nine of the poorest countries are in Asia, 28 are in Africa, 1, Haiti, is in the Americas, and 4 are island nations in the Pacific or Indian Oceans. Bangladesh, with about 110 million people, 85 percent of them living below minimal nutritional levels, is the largest in population. It acts as spokesman for the group. **********This first ministerial meeting of least developed countries, which ends on Monday, is expected to restate forcefully a plea that aid donors and international lending organizations treat the poorest nations separately from the rest of the developing world. The poorest countries have effectively fallen into a category of their own. **********''The L.D.C.'s, being the poorest and weakest in the international community, deserve first consideration,'' Anwarul Karim Chowdhury, head of the economic section of Bangladesh's Foreign Ministry and organizer of the conference, said in an interview Friday. ''We have done all we can, but the people living in absolute poverty have increased. The effects of our belt-tightening, our structural adjustments, are falling worst on the most vulnerable groups, particularly women and children.'' **********The group of 42 will meet with donor nations in Geneva at the end of March in preparation for a larger international conference in Paris in September on the plight of the most disadvantaged countries. A similar conference took place in 1981, when there were 31 such nations. **********No Goals Are Met **********None of the major development goals set at that conference have been met. **********In the world's poorest nations, there is now additional apprehension that aid, already dwindling, may all but dry up as Europe, the United States, Canada and Japan respond to the unexpected opening of Eastern Europe, where investment returns are likely to be quicker. **********''The world is a safer place to live,'' Mr. Chowdhury said. ''But we feel concerned about the rush to Eastern Europe when the overall resource kitty is limited.'' **********''Now that the East and West have patched up, everyone suffers in the L.D.C.s,'' he added, explaining that with the big power blocs no longer needing to compete for advantage in the third world, a source of leverage was lost. **********According to statistics compiled by the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, average annual per capita income in the 42 countries, about $200, is only a quarter of that in the developing world as a whole. **********Mr. Chowdhury said the eradication of poverty and the improvement of women's - and thereby children's -lives would be given high priority in meetings this year. **********These are the countries: **********Afghanistan **********Bangladesh **********Benin **********Bhutan **********Botswana **********Burkina Faso **********Burundi **********Cape Verde **********Central African Republic **********Chad **********Comoros **********Djibouti **********Equitorial Guinea **********Ethiopia **********Gambia **********Guinea **********Guinea-Bissau **********Haiti **********Kiribati **********Laos **********Lesotho **********Malawi **********Maldives **********Mali **********Mauritania **********Mozambique **********Myanmar **********Nepal **********Niger **********Rwanda **********Samoa **********Sao Tome e Principe **********Sierra Leone **********Somalia **********Southern Yemen **********Sudan **********Tanzania **********Togo **********Tuvalu **********Uganda **********Vanuatu **********Yemen

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/19/world.body_text: **********Masked Palestinians armed with axes and knives roamed a West Bank town today to enforce a strike called to protest United States plans for preliminary Israeli-Palestinian peace talks, Arab reports said. **********The strike closed shops and schools in the occupied West Bank and Arab East Jerusalem. The fundamentalist Islamic group Hamas, or Zeal, called it to protest the proposal by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d's for preliminary Israeli-Palestinian talks in Cairo. **********Arab reports said that in Hebron, a West Bank city, about 50 masked Palestinians armed with axes and knives stopped cars and slashed the tires of at least 10 vehicles that defied the strike call. **********Disagreement over the Baker plan led to the collapse last week of Israel's coalition Government. President Chaim Herzog today began consultations required by law before he chooses a leader to form a new government. **********The Likud Prime Minister, Yitzhak Shamir, opposed United States-backed compromises to get the preliminary talks under way, while more liberal lawmakers supported the compromises. Mr. Shamir's rival, the Labor Party leader Shimon Peres, engineered a vote of no-confidence that passed and brought down the Government. Mr. Herzog was expected to give the mandate for forming a government to Mr. Peres. **********A Palestinian man died in a West Bank hospital today, three days after he was hit in the head by a rubber bullet fired by Israeli soldiers, hospital reports said. The man was identified as Salim Yacoub Rihan, 50 years old . Arab reports said he was shot Thursday night as he drove a horse-drawn cart through Al Amari refugee camp in the West Bank.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/08/busin.body_text: **********The international drive to reform the world's trading system will fail unless industrial nations agree to scrap their barriers to textile imports from developing countries, the head of the O.E.C.D. said today. **********Jean-Claude Paye, Secretary **********General for the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development, said his group's members must back up their words with actions if they want international trade talks, known as the Uruguay Round, to succeed. **********The Uruguay Round, which aims to increase worldwide trade by eliminating barriers to imports, is scheduled to wrap up by the end of this year. **********Developing nations, particularly those in Asia, have been pressing rich countries to abolish the so-called Multi-Fiber Arrangement, which governs most world trade in textiles through bilateral tariffs and quotas. It will expire in 1992. **********Mr. Paye, who was here to take stock of the United States position before the O.E.C.D.'s annual ministerial meeting at the end of this month, urged industrial nations to get rid of the Multi-Fiber Ararangement. **********He also called on the United **********States and Europe to take steps toward settling their dispute over trade in farm goods when they meet in Paris at the end of this month.
