https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/21/busin.body_text: **********To help cocaine users free themselves from their addictions, medical researchers in Maryland and California obtained separate patents this week related to new methods of treatment. **********Researchers at the Government's National Institute of Mental Health in Bethesda, Md., won patent approval for a potential method of weaning cocaine addicts by giving them a drug that limits cocaine's most dangerous side effects and may reduce craving. **********The treatment, still in the early stages of animal testing, was developed by researchers led by Robert M. Post, chief of the institute's branch for biological psychiatry. It is based on treating addicts with carbamazepine, a drug being used to prevent convulsions and to treat manic depressives who do not respond to lithium therapy. **********Dr. Post said research on monkeys demonstrated that carbamazepine blocked the sometimes fatal seizures caused by cocaine, and it appears to limit the panic attacks sometimes experienced. In addition, he said, researchers believe that the drug may decrease cocaine craving and studies are under way to determine if that is true. The hope, Dr. Post said, is that the drug might enable addicts to stop using cocaine gradually without risking their health. **********Dr. Post and two researchers, Susan R. B. Weiss and Thomas Aigner, received patent 4,942,182. **********An Artificial Cocaine **********Patrick J. Frawley 3d, chief of staff at the Schick Shadel Hospital in Santa Barbara, Calif., obtained a patent this week for an artificial cocaine used in ''aversion therapy'' programs for drug addicts. **********Aversion therapy, long used in treating alcoholics, consists of allowing people to use substances while giving them medications that make them violently ill if they do. The goal is to disrupt the deeply rooted associations between, for example, taking a drink and the ensuing high. **********But aversion therapy for cocaine has not been feasible because the drug is illegal. So Dr. Frawley developed a substitute that resembles cocaine in appearance and smell and creates the same numbing sensation in the nose when snorted. The substitute is a white powder that contains a local anesthetic similar to that used by dentists. It is mixed with quinine and a scenting agent to mimic cocaine's bitter taste and distinctive smell. The substitute does not provide any of cocaine's euphoric feelings, however. **********The substitute is intended for use in conjunction with medications that will induce illness as soon as the substitute is taken. Dr. Frawley obtained patent 4,942,175.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/01/world.body_text: **********With prayers and admonitions from Pope John Paul II, 238 Roman Catholic bishops from around the world convened today for a synod to study the ''identity crisis'' and ''burnout'' said to be afflicting many of their priests. **********For the next month, the bishops will meet at the Vatican almost daily to examine the selection and training of priests in a church plagued by a serious shortage of clergymen. **********But church leaders have made clear that a few fundamental aspects of the problem are off-limits to debate, notably the Catholic requirement of priestly celibacy and the prohibition against ordaining women and married men. Repeatedly, John Paul has left no doubt that these rules will remain intact during his papacy. **********If anything, Vatican officials said, the subject of celibacy should arise at the bishops' conference only in the context of how to reinforce the regulation. Their goal would be to help seminary students and priests overcome, as one senior official put it, ''any hidden frailties, poor motivation or deep resistance'' that they may have. **********Nonetheless, church leaders acknowledge that the issue of sex and the clergy cannot be ignored if they are to end a crisis in the recruitment of priests that is especially conspicuous in the United States and Western Europe. It is also a problem, in many poor countries, like those in Africa, where the Catholic Church is growing rapidly but where the ''formation'' of priests lags, partly because the celibacy rule collides with cultural traditions. **********''Some priests question this requirement, and some candidates leave formation for this reason,'' said the synod's working paper, made public in July. ''The problem becomes more serious as priests seek to live in a world characterized by eroticism.'' More broadly, the working paper said, many priests suffer from overwork, loneliness and isolation, ''to the point of becoming deeply demoralized.'' Helping them cope, through improved theologicial and even psychological preparation, is expected to be an important synod topic. **********Archbishop Jan P. Schotte of the Netherlands, who is general secretary of the bishops' gathering, used phrases like ''identity crisis'' and ''burnout'' to describe problems that he said ''priests of all ages seem to suffer.'' **********The Pope ceremonially opened the synod at a Mass today in St. Peter's Basilica, but real sessions do not begin until Monday. He did not mention specific issues he wants discussed. **********The synod is the 11th to be held since such assemblies were created in the 1960's by the Second Vatican Council as a way to enhance the collegiality between the Vatican and the 4,100 bishops who work in the field. **********Although the synod is an important forum for analyzing church problems, it is purely an advisory group to John Paul and has no power to set policy. **********Even though church officials are heartened by a recent increase in the number of men studying for the priesthood, shortages persist. Worldwide, according to the most recent Vatican statistics, there were 401,930 priests in 1988, compared with 406,376 in 1983. **********In the United States, the clergy-lay ratio is more favorable than in many countries - nearly 55,000 priests for an estimated 55 million Catholics. Even so, new diocesan seminarians totaled 4,981 in 1988, roughly half the figure of a decade earlier.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/21/world.main_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Soviet Union;   In Moscow, Heated Cry for an Opposition
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/21/world.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Soviet Union;   In Moscow, Heated Cry for an Opposition
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/21/world.body_text: **********Freely debating how to create a viable political opposition, political insurgents from across the country met today in a gathering that presented the most open challenge thus far to the Communist Party's dominance over Soviet public life. **********The dissident meeting, hailed as an evolutionary step toward pluralism in this crisis-ridden one-party state, drew 450 advocates of change from 78 cities and more than 100 local political clubs. **********A measure of the party's increasingly withered role in national life, the conference included ranking theoreticians from within the party and organizers of ad hoc movements who warned that only more rapid democratization could allay increasing national turmoil. **********Some of the more than 2,000 politicians and academic specialists differed quickly on tactics, posing the basic choice of whether to try one last time to change the party from within or abandon it as corrupt and hopeless. **********Liberals to Party Teachers **********But speakers ranging from embattled liberals in the national parliament to intellectuals who teach communism itself to the party rank-and-file were as one in expressing scathing dissatisfaction with the party's continuing hegemony in the face of communism's collapse in Eastern Europe and separatism's increasingly violent rise in the nation's provinces. **********''All we have now is the politics of crawling liberalization,'' said Vyacheslav N. Shostakovsky, the rector of the famous Higher Party School for Communists, who pleaded for a course more moderate than a direct challenge to the current constitutional ban against party pluralism. He proposed demanding of party leaders something of an intramural revolution: honest and open elections by the 90 million party members of the 5,000 delegates who will set the party's future course at the critical party congress due in October. **********Other speakers, however, argued that the party autocracy and its careerist underlings lacked the courage to reduce their role. **********''My conviction is this party cannot be reformed,'' said Yuri N. Afanasyev, a leader of the informal minority opposition in the national parliament who argued that a ''complete break with the Leninist tradition'' was the party's only chance of survival. **********'Breaking Apart Under Our Eyes' **********He proposed a new democratic party, citing the separatist violence in Azerbaijan as only the latest evidence of ''the collapse of the monster, of the artificially created U.S.S.R., which is now breaking apart under our very eyes.'' **********The gathering took some pride, as a measure of opposition progress, in openly discussing democratic socialism as a more attractive alternative to the party, and in openly planning the best strategy for confronting President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. One proposal is to have the informal opposition's most celebrated representative, Boris N. Yeltsin, present the group's program for party democratization as a member of the Central Committee plenum. **********But the dissidents' gathering also was a measure of the hesitant nature of the opposition movement in this nation after 72 years of party rule. A nationwide opposition organization still has not been formally proclaimed even as the East European rebellions have been ending one-party monopoly with a fast vengeance not lost on party leaders in this country. **********''Is not the plenum approach an illusion?'' asked Arkady N. Murashev, a parliamentary deputy. ''We'll just lose more time,'' he said, measuring the October party congress as far too distant to suit the hyperkinetic pace of communism's collapse. **********'Party Is a Criminal' **********Mr. Murashev disclosed that he crossed his own personal Rubicon on Friday when he declined his pending permanent membership in the Communist Party, sensing that the public itself had given up faith in change from within the party. ''The voters would never understand why I joined,'' he said. **********''Do not yield to illusions,'' he said, pleading for a candid attempt at forming a true opposition party, not some amoebic replication. ''The Communist Party is a criminal that cannot be forgiven.'' **********The goal of the two-day conference is to produce a united strategy for confronting the meeting of the party's leadership later this month with a de facto opposition consensus that the party must democratize itself and quickly face the rising popular pressure for political pluralism. **********In often pessimistic remarks, participants complained of President Gorbachev's fervid defense of the party's monopoly and his dominance of the agenda for political change. **********No Cure-All, Gorbachev Warns **********In a speech last week in Lithuania, where the local party has declared itself independent of the national party in Moscow, Mr. Gorbachev said that a multiparty system was ''not a cure-all.'' But he also said, ''I do not see anything tragic about a multiparty system if it emerges and meets the realistic interests of society.'' **********Mr. Shostakovsky, whose school for training the younger party hierarchy has become something of a hotbed for change, said at the conference, ''At least we are beginning to feel our strength and our future possibilities. **********''We are already a democratic part of the party - that's the reality,'' he said. **********Mr. Afanasyev argued that the various democratic-oriented platforms of the local political clubs quietly emerging around the nation amounted to an opposition consensus for permitting democratic factions within the party. **********Should the party rebuff that approach, he said, ''we will speak of the creation of a different party.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/23/world.main_headline: China and Saudis Open Diplomatic Relations
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/23/world.print_headline: China and Saudis Open Diplomatic Relations
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/23/world.body_text: **********China and Saudi Arabia announced today that they had established diplomatic relations. **********The move has significance for both countries. For Saudi Arabia, it is the first time that it has established diplomatic relations with a Communist Government; for China, it represents a success in wresting from Taiwan recognition by an important country. **********Although the Saudis did not say directly that they would break relations with Taiwan, China usually demands such action. **********''The Government of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia recognizes that the Government of the People's Republic of China is the sole legitimate Government that represents the entire Chinese people,'' the Saudis said in the communique. **********China said, ''The Government of the People's Republic of China supports the policy of the Government of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia in pursuit of achieving its security, stability and national interests.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/16/world.body_text: **********Germany's top law enforcement official told the newspaper Bild am Sonntag in a report published today that he believes 500 to 600 secret agents from the former East Germany have yet to be found. In the past several months, the authorities have arrested dozens of former East German spies who had been planted in various Government offices in the former West Germany.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/14/world.main_headline: SALVADOR LEFTIST IS SHOT TO DEATH
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/14/world.print_headline: SALVADOR LEFTIST IS SHOT TO DEATH
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/14/world.body_text: **********The body of a prominent Salvadoran leftist who was reported kidnapped in Guatemala City on Friday has been found near the border, a spokesman for his political party said here today. **********The victim, Hector Oqueli Colindres, 45 years old, deputy secretary general of the National Revolutionary Movement in El Salvador, had been shot in the head, the party spokesman said. His body was discovered in Jalpatagua, about 100 miles east of Guatemala City, the spokesman reported. **********Gilda Flores, a Guatemalan woman who was driving Mr. Oqueli to the airport in Guatemala City when they were abducted on Friday, also was found dead, the party official said. **********Party leaders in El Salvador said they did not know when the bodies were found. Nor did they have any information on who may have been responsible for the killings. **********Was Headed for Nicaragua **********The party announced on Friday that Mr. Oqueli and Miss Flores were abducted by armed men early in the morning. The politician was reportedly on his way to Managua, where he was to help monitor preparations for the Nicaraguan election, scheduled for Feb. 25. **********Mr. Oqueli, who had been in Guatemala since Jan. 11, was also reportedly planning to attend a meeting of Latin American socialists in Ecuador. **********The leader of the National Revolutionary Movement, Guillermo Ungo, ran for president as the candidate of a leftist coalition in Salvadoran elections last March. He could not immediately be reached for comment today. **********Fled Country in 1980 **********Before Mr. Oqueli's body was discovered, his party condemned the kidnapping, saying it ''demonstrates again the insecurity that exists in our country.'' **********Like many other leftists, Mr. Oqueli left El Salvador after a military coup in 1980, when many of his colleagues were rounded up and killed. He returned to the country in 1987 to take part in politics. **********The slayings come at a time of increasing political violence in El Salvador and Guatemala, whose rightist factions have longstanding ties. The governing rightist party in El Salvador, known by the Spanish acronym Arena, was founded in Guatemala in the 1970's.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/22/world.main_headline: India Sends Soldiers to the Pakistani Border
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/22/world.print_headline: India Sends Soldiers to the Pakistani Border
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/22/world.body_text: **********The Indian Army dispatched tanks and troop reinforcements today to the frontier with Pakistan, where soldiers from the two nations have been exchanging artillery fire for two days, officials and witnesses said. **********Prime Minister V. P. Singh told Parliament that Indian armed forces were ''fully prepared to effectively deal with any eventuality.'' **********Indian and Pakistani troops clashed in a remote border area in the disputed Kashmir region on Monday. Mr. Singh, who is also Defense Minister, said gunfire was also exchanged today. **********In Pakistan, a Defense Ministry spokesman said today that Indian and Pakistani soldiers exchanged artillery fire in the sector of Kel along the cease-fire line dividing Kashmir into Pakistani and Indian regions. He said there were no casualties among Pakistani soldiers. **********The official also said that four Pakistani civilians had been wounded by Indian soldiers firing at travelers on a mountain road on Monday and today. He added that Indian soldiers had fired on an ambulance and a bus. **********There was no report from India on this alleged firing. **********Despite the tension, officials from both sides said the incidents did not appear grave. ''There is no cause for any undue concern since we trust that these localized incidents will be contained and the situation defused,'' the United News of India quoted Mr. Singh as saying in Parliament. **********The Prime Minister also said that military operations directors from both countries were in touch. He did not elaborate. **********The Pakistani official said: ''This is not a serious situation. It's just in one sector. It could be just a local incident. We don't know what it will lead to. We'll just have to wait and see.'' India and Pakistan have gone to war twice over Kashmir, in 1965 and 1971. Both countries claim Kashmir. **********India accuses Pakistan of supporting a Muslim secessionist movement in the Indian sector by providing arms and training to Muslim militants. Pakistan, an Islamic state, denies the charge but says it will back any movement for self-determination by Kashmiris. **********Jammu and Kashmir is the only one of India's states with a Muslim majority. At least 1,034 people have been killed in the Kashmir Valley since New Delhi cracked down on the secessionist movement in January. **********At least 20 Indian tanks and 30 trucks with soldiers left their quarters at Kaluchak and Baridrahamna for the frontier, witnesses said. **********Indian officials said the additional troops were sent to Rajauri and Poonch sectors, which were the scenes of fierce battles in 1965 and 1971.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/06/world.main_headline: REFORM MAJORITIES LIKELY IN MOSCOW AND IN LENINGRAD
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/06/world.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: SOVIET UNION;   REFORM MAJORITIES LIKELY IN MOSCOW AND IN LENINGRAD
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/06/world.body_text: **********Independent Soviet pro-democracy groups today celebrated what appeared to be major gains in elections Sunday, including the election of several former political prisoners and the probability of gaining outright control of local governments in Moscow, Leningrad and some other cities. **********Although runoff elections will be required within two weeks to decide most races, the opposition groups seemed assured of sizable minorities in the parliaments of the Russian, Ukrainian and Byelorussian republics. **********Potentially more important, the insurgents expected to win majorities on district and city councils in several cities, and to transform them into bastions of real democracy. **********'Chance to Speed Up Change' **********Opposition strategists said this would give them a chance to dislodge the Communist-appointed government managers and to create showplaces of political pluralism and market economics. **********''In the larger cities, at least, there should now be a chance to speed up democratic change,'' said Vasily S. Shakhnovsky, a dissident Communist who was favored to win a runoff for a seat on the Moscow city council. **********It was the first time voters in the three Slavic republics were offered a choice of candidates from rival political movements, and opposition leaders said their slates of dissident Communists and non-party independents could well become the basis of alternative parties. No other groups formally constituted as parties took part in the elections. **********Runoffs Due March 18 **********In each republic, Communist Party regulars were challenged by an alliance of dissident Communists and non-party candidates, united by a disenchantment with the pace at which President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has introduced democracy and market economics. **********The elections on Sunday included many races in which numerous candidates competed for one seat. To win, a candidate had to take at least 50 percent of the vote. Thus, many races were thrown into runoffs, which will be held on March 18. **********Outright winners included Boris N. Yeltsin, the populist opposition leader in the Soviet Parliament, who rolled over 11 other candidates and won more than 80 percent of the vote to represent Sverdlovsk in the parliament of the Russian Republic. He has promised to run for president of the republic. **********Vitaly I. Vorotnikov, the current president of Russia and a member of the national Communist Party Politburo, won a seat from his rural home base in southern Russia, defeating a single opponent. **********Sergei A. Kovalev, a former political prisoner and longtime associate of the late human rights champion Andrei D. Sakharov, was elected to the Russian parliament from Moscow. **********Another candidate who succeeded on the first round was Vladislav A. Starkov, chief editor of the popular weekly paper Argumenty i Fakty, whom Mr. Gorbachev tried to drive out of his job last year for publishing an unflattering poll. **********In the Ukraine, Mikhailo Goryn and Vyacheslav Chornovil, two dissidents who have spent much of their adulthood in prison for political offenses, were elected to the parliament on a slate backed by the independent Ukrainian movement called Rukh. **********Many top Rukh leaders won seats on the first ballot, while the republic's Communist chief, Vladimir A. Ivashko, was forced into a runoff. **********Ivan Drach, a writer and president of Rukh, said tonight that the group expected from 20 to 40 percent of the Ukrainian supreme soviet to be from the democratic movement. **********''They will raise questions on a parliamentary level like those that now are usually raised at demonstrations,'' he said in a telephone interview from Kiev. ''That's already progress.'' **********Disadvantages Overcome **********The showing was especially impressive since Rukh was not legally registered in time to field candidates for all races, and was prohibited from publishing its own newspaper in competition with the Communist Party's republic-wide press network. **********The leader of the Byelorussian popular front, Zenon Poznyak, and several other members of that organization won seats in the Byelorussian parliament, despite a concerted campaign by the Communist Party to prohibit them from taking part in the elections. **********Yefrem Y. Sokolov, the party chief of Byelorussia, also won, after chosing to campaign against token opposition in a district heavily populated by Warsaw Pact troops. **********Party apparatchiks in the provinces either found safe rural districts from which to run or used docile election commissions to eliminate opposition candidates from the ballot in the three republics. American diplomats here dubbed the election ''Slavic super Sunday,'' because the people of the three republics are of Slavic descent. **********Turnout Is Low **********The confusion of voters confronted with scores of candidates and little information - and the mood of disappointment - were reflected in a turnout that was low by Soviet standards. In Moscow fewer than 65 percent of the voters came to the polls. **********As the three republics voted Sunday, the Sajudis independence movement in Lithuania enlarged its majority in the republic's parliament in runoff elections on the same day, clearing the way for a declaration of political independence and gradual disengagement from the Soviet Union. **********The Tass press agency said tonight that after the second round 116 of 141 seats in the Lithuanian aparliament had been filled, enough for a session to convene and consider secession. **********Sajudis candidates have won 90 of the seats, and are expected to move quickly to replace the Communist government of the republic with a nonpartisan executive. **********The parliaments in the three republics have the power to deal with matters affecting the entire republic, while the local councils will deal with local matters like housing and sewers. **********Inroads at Local Level **********While most attention in the three Slavic republics has focused on the parliaments, or supreme soviets, it is at the local level that the insurgents made some of their most intriguing inroads. **********Only 32 of the 498 seats on the Moscow city council were decided in the first round, but leaders of the democratic alliance called Democratic Russia said their candidates had moved into the runoffs with the lead in a solid majority of districts. **********In Leningrad, an opposition group called Democratic Elections '90 predicted that it would win 60 percent of the council seats. **********''At first there will be a victory of democracy in various districts, cities, and republics,'' said Ilya I. Zaslavsky, a member of the Soviet Parliament who used sophisticated polling and campaign tactics learned from Western experts to back a slate of 150 candidates in the October region of Moscow.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/05/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADDENDA;   Job for Beber Silverstein
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/05/busin.body_text: **********Ed McCabe, who made a name for himself and Frank Perdue through his copywriting for the chicken seller, will try to do the same for Mel Coleman, a Colorado rancher. Mr. McCabe's new agency, Beber Silverstein McCabe & Partners, has won the advertising account of Coleman Natural Meats, a Denver producer of beef and lamb.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/15/busin.body_text: **********The Bush Administration said today, as expected, that it would not impose economic sanctions on India for trade barriers the United States deems offensive. **********The United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, termed India's barriers to investment by Americans and other foreigners and its exclusion of American insurance companies an unreasonable burden on United States commerce. **********But she said retaliation was inappropriate at this time because of global free-trade talks that are continuing. Mrs. Hills said the Administration would try to resolve its dispute with India during the discussions. **********The talks, being held under the auspices of the 96-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, are scheduled to end later this year. India is considered a critical participant in the discussions, known as the Uruguay Round, because of its influence over other developing countries. **********The White House had to decide by Saturday to decide whether to increase tariffs on Indian imports or impose other retaliatory trade sanctions because of India's refusal to negotiate the dispute.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/06/world.main_headline: Upheaval in the East;   Romania Colonel Tells Of Attacking Protesters
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/06/world.print_headline: Upheaval in the East;   Romania Colonel Tells Of Attacking Protesters
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/06/world.body_text: **********An army colonel told a court today that demonstrators were shot and dragged down dark alleys by men in civilian clothes during the December uprising against the dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. **********The testimony of Col. Dorel Amariucai at the trial of Nicolae Andruta Ceausescu, the executed leader's younger brother, was the first to confirm allegations of violence against crowds on the night of Dec. 21. **********The colonel was in charge of an army unit in central Bucharest, where the younger Ceausescu, in charge of cadets from the Securitate secret police training school, is alleged to have shot seven people and ordered his men to fire on anti-Government protesters. **********Mr. Ceausescu, who faces life imprisonment if convicted, has denied these and several other charges against him. **********Witnesses testified earlier that Mr. Ceausescu threatened Colonel Amariucai at gunpoint to order an assault on the protesters. **********''You have two minutes to launch the attack, otherwise I'll arrest you,'' Colonel Amariucai said Mr. Ceausescu told him. He said his unit fired only warning shots in the air.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/25/world.main_headline: Race to Retain Power Begins For Tokyo's Governing Party
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/25/world.print_headline: Race to Retain Power Begins For Tokyo's Governing Party
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/25/world.body_text: **********Japan's political leaders today opened what is expected to be a closely contested parliamentary election campaign in which the Liberal Democratic Party of Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu is fighting to continue its 35 years of uninterrupted control of the Government. **********After his dissolution of Parliament, which cleared the way for an election on Feb. 18, Mr. Kaifu told supporters that the campaign would be difficult, but that ''we must unite and enter the fray and rule out the possibility of defeat.'' **********A nearly full chamber of Parliament echoed with cries of ''Banzai!'' as the Speaker of the lower house delivered a message from the Emperor dissolving the house. The shouts were followed by rounds of applause as members embarked on their campaigns. **********Among the last official acts of Parliament before dissolution was one aimed by Mr. Kaifu at shoring up his party's support among rice farmers, a longtime key constituent group. Parliament approved a bill to reduce taxes on the subsidies for rice growers. **********'The World Is Watching Japan' **********The step was taken quietly in spite of rising criticism lately among Japan's trading partners that the nation's farmers are among the most heavily subsidized in the world and overly protected by import barriers against outside competition. **********One sign of the political difficulties to be faced by Mr. Kaifu came quickly this afternoon, as four main opposition parties declared jointly that they would try to put aside past disputes and cooperate in fielding candidates and formulating at least some common policies. **********''The election will enable Japan to do away with the old regime and give Japan a chance to be reborn,'' said Takako Doi, head of the Japan Socialist Party, the largest opposition group. ''The world is watching Japan to see how it acts regarding the issues of freedom, peace and fairness for all.'' **********But it is far from clear whether the Socialists can hold the opposition alliance together throughout the election or in the event of a combined victory at the polls. **********Coalition Government Weighed **********Some in the Liberal Democratic Party, for example, say that if it falls short of a majority of 512 seats at stake, which many consider possible, it could try to form a government by bargaining and bringing into power independents and at least some members of the current opposition. **********Party officials say, for example, that they feel confident of winning about 255 seats, barely short of a majority, including sympathetic independent candidates. The latest opinion polls indicated today that Mr. Kaifu and his Cabinet received less than a 40 percent approval rating. **********Besides the Socialists, the opposition includes the Komeito, or Clean Government Party, which is connected to a Buddhist sect; the Democratic Socialist Party, a left-of-center group drawing heavy support from trade unions, and the United Social Democratic Party, a small splinter group. **********The Japan Communist Party also plans to enter candidates in every district, but its chances are considered weaker than usual because of the turmoil in the Communist world and public disapproval in Japan of the crackdown on dissent last year in China. The Communists hold 27 seats. **********Setbacks for Liberal Democrats **********In July, the Socialists and other mainstream opposition parties won the election to the upper house of Parliament by riding a wave of voter resentment over Government corruption, an unpopular sales tax and a scandal over disclosures of extramarital affairs by Sousuke Uno, who resigned as Prime Minister on July 24. **********Since July, many voters say they have become disenchanted with the opposition, and particularly with the Socialist Party's continued questioning of military spending and its refusal to disavow completely its longtime opposition to the United States-Japan security treaty. **********After the defeat in July, the Liberal Democratic Party retained control of the Government by virtue of its majority of 298 seats in the more powerful lower house. **********In the last three years, the party's fortunes have skidded, especially after the enactment in 1988 of a 3 percent sales tax on goods and services that, while accompanied by income-tax cuts and other tax cuts, nonetheless hit hard among the middle class and salaried workers. **********The Government also angered one longtime group of supporters, Japan's farmers, by lowering trade barriers on beef, citrus fruits and other farm imports. **********Mr. Kaifu said today that his party would campaign in favor of the 3 percent sales tax, while promising to reduce it for food, rent, tuition and some other items. **********The opposition reiterated its intention to criticize the sales tax, demanding its repeal, and to accuse the Liberal Democratic Party of corruption and complacency.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/12/busin.main_headline: Talking Deals;   MCI Deal Called Antitrust Test
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/12/busin.print_headline: Talking Deals;   MCI Deal Called Antitrust Test
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/12/busin.body_text: **********THE agreement by the MCI Communications Corporation to buy Telecom USA Inc. raises several antitrust issues. The Justice Department's response to the $1.25 billion deal, in which the nation's second-largest long-distance company would buy the No. 4 company, is widely seen as a test case of the Bush Administration's antitrust policy. ''If you're going to challenge a merger, this would be the one,'' said a former regulator who asked not to be identified. **********But former Government officials and other experts on the long-distance telephone industry say they doubt that the Justice Department will seek to block the deal. **********The department's reaction may also signal whether the Administration intends to continue the Government's oversight of the telecommunications industry through the judicial system, or instead give a greater role to the Federal Communications Commission. **********MCI says its acquisition of Telecom will increase competition in the $52 billion long-distance market because the acquired assets will make it a more fit competitor to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. MCI seeks only to take business from A.T.& T. and does not try to compete directly with the regional telephone companies, said MCI's president, Bert C. Roberts Jr. The Justice Department declined to comment. **********The department's current merger guidelines, released in 1982, do not require a general review of the Telecom deal. The Hart-Scott-Rodino antitrust act does require MCI to give the department 30 days to decide whether to question the takeover. **********The agreement announced on Monday between MCI, with 12 percent of the market, and Telecom, with 1.4 percent, would raise by only 34 points the index the department uses to measure market concentration. The current guidelines call for a review when the move exceeds 50 points in an industry as concentrated as long-distance service, in which A.T.& T. holds two-thirds of the market and U S Sprint has 9 percent. **********But some economists have argued that market concentration indexes should not be applied to industries as heavily regulated as long distance. ''The market shares in this industry are as much a result of regulation as company cost structures,'' said Peter Pitsch, a Washington lawyer and until recently the F.C.C.'s chief of staff. **********Some academics contend that the Justice Department's guidelines underestimate the extent to which small concerns and potential entrants may discourage market leaders from raising prices. By this criterion, the absorption of America's largest regional long-distance company by a market leader is harder to accept, said Alfred E. Kahn, a Cornell University economist and former chairman of the New York Public Service Commission. **********The question raised by Mr. Kahn and other economists and former regulators is whether Telecom, if left alone, could grow into a fourth national competitor. Both MCI and U S Sprint needed more than a decade to become profitable national networks, and there may be cause for concern if these market leaders are then allowed to acquire other businesses trying to follow the same long road, said Eli Noam, a Columbia University economist and New York Public Service Commissioner. **********Telecom's sales have been growing by 25 to 30 percent a year, reaching $713 million last year with earnings of $36.9 million. The company has completed 40 acquisitions since its founding in 1984. It has laid an extensive network of fiber-optic cable in Iowa and the Southeast, and developed several innovative products, like a special calling card that allows users to set up conference calls from any Touch-Tone telephone. **********Telecom has won a strong base among small and medium-sized businesses, and in the last several years has begun to offer 800 numbers and expanded its national services. It is also the keystone of the National Telecommunications Network, a consortium of six of the largest regional carriers that seeks to coordinate their activities. **********Even by the politically sensitive standards of antitrust regulation, the Telecom deal is especially touchy for the Justice Department. On the one hand, the Bush Administration has signaled an interest in increased enforcement of existing statutes, and the Telecom deal is the first large transaction with clear antitrust issues. **********But the F.C.C.'s new chairman, Alfred C. Sikes, and other Government officials have been arguing that the F.C.C. should reassert some of the regulatory authority it lost when the Justice Department and Federal District Judge Harold H. Greene oversaw the breakup of A.T.& T. in 1984. A challenge to the Telecom agreement would put the Justice Department back in the center of telecommunications regulation. **********The Justice Department also has a longstanding interest in the survival of MCI, having shielded it for many years until it grew into a large corporation able to compete with A.T.& T. In the end, the Justice Department may find itself hamstrung by its commitment to the current merger guidelines, Mr. Kahn said. For this reason, he said, a challenge to the Telecom agreement would be a hard case to win in court.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/28/busin.main_headline: C.F.T.C. Role Is Seen at Risk
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/28/busin.print_headline: C.F.T.C. Role Is Seen at Risk
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/28/busin.body_text: **********Representative Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, was quoted today in a newspaper as saying that the Commodity Futures Trading Commission could be the big loser in its dispute with the Securities and Exchange Commission. **********Representative Rostenkowski, an Illinois Democrat, was quoted by The Chicago Tribune as saying that a complete takeover of the C.F.T.C. by the S.E.C. is likely if the C.F.T.C. loses any authority in the squabble over who regulates stock index futures. Such futures are securities that combine features of traditional commodity futures trading with securities trading. The Treasury Secretary, Nicholas F. Brady, and the S.E.C. chairman, Richard Breeden, have indicated they will push hard to shift some powers to the S.E.C. **********''If there's any movement at all with respect to partial consolidation, there will be total consolidation,'' the newspaper quoted Mr. Rostenkowski as saying. **********The C.F.T.C. is charged with regulating all United States futures exchanges, including the Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. The S.E.C. regulates securities trading. **********Chicago exchanges favor continued oversight by the C.F.T.C., because they believe the S.E.C. will be a tougher regulator and will raise the cost of doing futures business in Chicago.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/09/busin.main_headline: Benetton to Make Clothes in Armenia
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/09/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Benetton to Make Clothes in Armenia
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/09/busin.body_text: **********The Italian casual-wear manufacturer Benetton Group S.p.A. said it had entered a joint venture to produce clothes in Armenia for sale in the Soviet Union. Under the agreement, Benetton, based in Milan, and the Armenian Ministry of Light Industry each will invest $4 million to set up production of cotton Benetton products at an Armenian factory. **********The goods will be sold in an unspecified number of stores that Benetton will open in the republic and in other Soviet cities, according to a company statement. Benetton projected profits of $11 million - to be received in Russian rubles - after the first three years of operation. Revenues are expected to equal $81 million after three years, based on an annual production of three million items.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/07/busin.body_text: **********Sales of new homes rose by 9.6 percent in November, the biggest jump in four months, according to the Commerce Department last week. The Northeast and Middle West posted the strongest gains. After months of soft prices and slow sales, do the November figures signal an end to the housing slump? Four experts give their views. **********Ara K. Hovnanian **********President, K. Hovnanian Enterprises Inc., Red Bank, N.J. **********There seems to be a little more activity in the housing market because seller prices are coming into line and developers' prices are too. I think we have probably hit bottom. I don't know if we can say the market is on its way up yet, but buyers are beginning to realize there are real deals out there. **********For the first half of this year we expect the current situation to remain without much change. However, we believe that when the market does begin to recover, particularly in the Northeast and California, there will be a steady upward ratcheting of prices. I don't know if the recovery will happen in 6, 2, or 12 months. But once it happens, it will turn rapidly and we will see a real strong market. Real estate is cyclical. When people start selling, they also start buying and then the market accelerates. **********Lyle E. Gramley **********Chief economist, Mortgage Bankers Association, Washington. **********It would be a mistake to make too much out of this number. The November figures are in part a consequence of the earthquake in California. But even so, the picture for new-home sales is improving modestly. **********Those stories about an impending collapse of the residential real estate market were overblown. An impending collapse was wrong and that's what this upturn tells us. No one doubts that the housing market is different from what it was a decade ago. Prices are not rising as fast, the demographics are different, rental space was overbuilt and housing is now responding differently to lower interest rates. **********If interest rates continue to move down, as I think they will, then there will be further improvement. But the current 710,000 annual rate for new-home sales is higher than can be sustained. **********David F. Seiders **********Chief economist, National Association of Homebuilders, Washington. **********We are looking for a flat period in all of single-family housing through the middle of this year and then a gradual improvement. Those new-home sales figures do jog around a bit. But all of the single housing numbers for November were solid. **********The one place where the numbers signal something really fundamental is the Northeast. We have been forecasting a bottoming out in that market and a resurgence in the Northeast in housing starts, new sales and sales of existing homes. We see confirmation now that it has bottomed out and we're looking for a gradual upturn throughout the year and into 1991 in that market. **********Francis Schott **********Chief economist, Equitable Life Assurance Society. **********This upturn in housing has been part of my forecast and it's why I don't think we'll have a recession. A decline in mortgage rates has happened - so you can get a fixed-rate mortgage below 10 percent - and it created the turnaround. Housing starts looked poor before the Fed eased. There was pent-up demand as people adjusted to higher rates and the lower rates now are making a difference. **********I am convinced that interest rates will go down further until mid-1990. I think the signs are clear that new home starts will be at the 1.5 million rate, seasonably adjusted, for most of 1990 with a possibility of going even higher. In the fourth quarter of 1989, we had the bottoming out of new-home sales. **********The downward adjustment with rising interest rates has ended. The market won't be buoyant, but it will have stability with a little updrift through 1990.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/31/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING - ADDENDA;   Sega Commercials Take On Nintendo
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/31/busin.body_text: **********Sega of America, a maker of video games, will begin a campaign next week that takes a hit at rival Nintendo of America. **********The spots show the action on Sega's Genesis sports video games, like Joe Montana's Football and Michael Jackson's Moonwalker as an announcer tells viewers: ''You can't do this on Nintendo.'' Because of technological differences, Genesis games cannot be played on the Nintendo system. **********At the end of the spot, a message flashes on the screen: ''Genesis does what Nintendon't.'' **********Created by the Los Angeles office of Bozell, the $10 million campaign is an attempt to loosen Nintendo's dominance of the $3 billion video game market. Nintendo has about 80 percent of the market, compared to Sega's 15 percent share. **********Ninetendo is also starting a new campaign next week, and a spokesman for the company said the details would be announced today.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/30/busin.body_text: **********Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that it was looking for new partners in Teleport Communications Group, which operates municipal fiber-optic telephone networks for corporate customers. **********Confirming a report yesterday in Crain's New York Business, Merrill said it would sell part of its stake in order to help finance Teleport's ambitious construction plans. **********Fred Yager, a spokesman for the brokerage, said the company would not sell its entire stake or even a controlling interest in Teleport. **********Teleport has built networks in New York, Boston and San Francisco. It is also building networks in Chicago, Houston and Los Angeles, and is seeking regulatory clearance to build a system in Washington. Merrill Lynch owns most of the New York and Boston systems of Teleport and all of its operations elsewhere. **********Large European and American telephone companies and a consortium of Japanese telecommunications equipment producers have expressed interest in buying Teleport, said Berge A. Ayvazian, a telecommunications analyst for the Yankee Group, a Boston consulting firm. Teleport's revenues last year probably totaled $35 million, he said. Mr. Yager declined to comment on bidders or Teleport's finances.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/06/busin.main_headline: Panama Is Resisting U.S. Pressure To Alter 'Inadequate' Bank Laws
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/06/busin.print_headline: Panama Is Resisting U.S. Pressure To Alter 'Inadequate' Bank Laws
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/06/busin.body_text: **********Officials of the new Panamanian Government are resisting United States pressure to change the banking laws that historically made the country a haven for enormous illicit drug profits before Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega was removed from power. **********The Panamanians say the current laws and the new Government are more than adequate to prevent such abuses. American law-enforcement officials and legislators are concerned that the new Government and the country's appetite for foreign investment will actually lead to even greater use of Panamanian financial institutions to conceal illicit drug profits. **********Edgardo Lasso Valdes, the president of the Panamanian banking association and one of the country's seven banking commissioners, said in an interview: ''The only problem of money laundering in Panama is the newspapers that mention that Panama is a big money-laundering center. , To be honest, we don't feel there is any problem.'' **********But a senior State Department official here, who asked not to be identified, said the existing laws ''are grossly inadequate'' to prevent money laundering, a process in which illegally earned profits are deposited in bank accounts or legitimate businesses, then withdrawn as ''clean money.'' He said the United States was strongly urging Panama to revise them. **********A Growing Tension **********In interviews in recent days, local banking regulators, senior Panamanian officials and United States officials demonstrated through their comments a growing tension between the two nations over the money-laundering issue. A fight appears likely in Congress over a proposed $1 billion aid package for Panama. **********An extensive review of Panamanian banking records and court documents shows that many senior leaders in the Government, while never accused of money laundering, have had strong ties to corrupt banks. Several of the banks have been indicted for money laundering or been shut because of pressure from the United States. **********The nation's new President, Guillermo Endara, has for years been a director of a Panamanian bank used extensively by Colombia's Medellin drug traffickers. **********Guillermo (Billy) Ford, the Second Vice President and chairman of the banking commission, is a part owner of the Dadeland Bank of Florida, which was named in a court case two years ago as a central financial institution for one of the biggest Medellin launderers, Gonzalo Mora. **********Rogello Cruz, the new Attorney General, has been a director of the First Interamericas Bank, owned by Gilberto Rodriguez Orejuela, one of the bosses of the Cali drug gang in Colombia. **********There is no evidence that President Endara, Vice President Ford, Mr. Cruz or other current leaders were aware of or involved with the illegal operations carried out at the banks to which they have ties. But officials of the Drug Enforcement Administration and the Justice Department say the business connections and friendships make it difficult to believe that any real crackdown against money laundering is likely. **********American law-enforcement officials said they had evidence that Panamanian banks were used to launder money through the waning hours of the administration of General Noriega, who is awaiting trial in Miami on drug and money-laundering charges. And though most of General Noriega's senior aides remain either fugitives or in jail, all the bankers with whom they are said to have dealt remain in key positions. **********''I'm very concerned about it,'' said Senator John F. Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, who has held extensive hearings on money laundering and the use of Panamanian banks. ''This is the moment to do something - but it now appears that not enough is being done.'' Long History of Aiding Money Launderers Panama's secrecy laws and tax breaks for foreign depositors, coupled with the country's proximity to cocaine production and trafficking in the Andes, have long made banks here a kind of hidden tub for cleaning dirty money. **********In a recent interview, President Endara acknowledged that the success of Panama's financial center in the 1970's and 1980's was a result of the Latin American drug cartels. **********Increased pressure is now on the nation's banks, whose foreign deposits have fired rapid economic growth for two decades, to lure back more foreign investors, many of whom had left during the turmoil of recent months. Illegalities Aid G.N.P.  The financial community represents as much as 15 percent of the Panamanian economy, according to Government figures. Last year, the gross national product was estimated at $1.76 billion, and virtually all economists agree that laundered drug money, arms sales and other illicit income have played a large role in the accumulation of that wealth. **********The United States imposed economic sanctions on Panama in 1988 in an attempt to halt money laundering. As a result some banks were forced to freeze some deposits, and some banks failed. Until the sanctions, Panamanian authorities would occasionally seize assets of suspected accounts but would generally not provide information to law-enforcement authorities. **********Merchants from Colon, on the Atlantic coast about 50 miles north of Panama City, said one common way of laundering money was the purchase of large amounts of clothes with millions of dollars in drug profits. The clothes are then shipped to Colombia and sold for Colombian pesos, which are deposited in local banks. Hidden Bank Accounts And Secrecy Laws But the strongest attraction for money launderers appears to be Panama's hidden bank accounts. **********The bank secrecy laws permit a depositor to sue a bank if confidential information is disclosed, and prosecutors can also bring criminal charges against the banker who, without authorization, provides information about an account. Panama also has corporate secrecy protection that enables the founder or founders of a business to keep their identity secret. **********Talks on Cooperation **********Negotiations have been under way to forge an agreement of cooperation between Panamanian and American law-enforcement authorities, following a preliminary agreement signed last month by the Panamanian Government and the State Department. **********Nonetheless, the widely held view among drug officials is that as banking restrictions imposed during the period of United States sanctions are lifted over the next four months, illegal profits will again pour into many of the country's 110 banks. **********''Given the chaos and general turmoil of the country following the invasion, there is now an excellent opportunity for organized crime and the cocaine cartels to step back in,'' said James E. Preston, an Arizona prosecutor who has spent recent months on a Federal grant studying international money laundering. **********President Endara has said he sees no need for any significant banking-law changes and so does not expect any. The National Banking Commission, which regulates banks, is dominated by local and international bankers, many of whom agree with the President and Mr. Lasso that the magnitude of the drug problem has been exaggerated. Feelings of Resentment Over U.S. Pressure Disputing reports by the Drug Enforcement Administration and other people at the Justice Department, the new Finance Minister, Mario Galindo, said in an interview that there was no money-laundering problem in Panama. Many bankers and some officials expressed resentment over pressure by the United States to alter the banking system. **********Mr. Lasso, who is also general manager of the Panamanian branch of the International Bank of Costa Rica, said it was hypocritical of United States officials to be citing Panamanian banks. He said the punishment meted out recently in the two largest drug money-laundering cases in the United States shows that American officials themselves are not particularly tough on money laundering. **********The settlements were of $5 million over four years in the case of Banco de Occidente and $14 million for Bank of Credit and Commerce International. Both banks admitted in courts that their Panamanian branches were used extensively to launder drug money. **********''How can you ask us to break a bank in Panama when all they do in the U.S. is pay a fine?'' Mr. Lasso asked. ''We don't understand it. It gives us some doubts.'' **********Reputable Banks Driven Out **********The economic sanctions have driven out some of the more reputable international banks, and many of those left continue to be found to have drug ties, knowingly or not. Testimony in one recent case tied a third of the banks to laundering operations for drug money. Most of those banks were used not as points at which customers would deposit cash but rather as places to which launderers in the United States would electronically transfer funds for deposit. **********Virtually all those banks remain in operation today, and none were prosecuted for laundering. **********''There are already laws here on the books that make money laundering illegal,'' said a senior banker who has been in Panama for more than 20 years and now works at a large Asian bank in Panama City. ''But the laws have only been as good as the people who enforce them.'' Important Banking Ties Of Top Panama Officials It is difficult to find any senior officials here who do not have important ties to banks. **********President Endara has for years been a director of Banco Interoceanico de Panama, one of the two dozen Panamanian banks named in a case based on a Federal Bureau of Investigation case code-named Cashweb/Expressway. F.B.I. agents posing as money launderers were given large amounts of cash in that case by Colombians in the United States who instructed them to transfer the funds to these 24 banks. **********Mr. Endara, a corporate lawyer before becoming President, is a close friend of Carlos Eleta, a Panamanian businessman who was arrested in Atlanta in April on charges of conspiring to set up a major cocaine smuggling ring. Released on bail, he is now awaiting trial. **********The families of First Vice President Ricardo Arias Calderon and the Finance Minister, Mr. Galindo, are also heavily involved in banking. Mr. Galindo's cousin, Samuel Lewis Galindo, is chairman of Banco del Istmo.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/21/busin.body_text: **********Eastern Airlines and its creditors failed yesterday to meet a court deadline for an agreement on how the company could emerge from bankruptcy, an Eastern spokeswoman said last night. **********The inability to reach an accord, together with Eastern's decision yesterday afternoon not to file for another extension of the court's deadline, technically allows any interested party to file a reorganization plan with the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan and to try to buy the carrier. Any plan is subject to the approval of Federal Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland and Eastern's creditors. **********The carrier filed for bankruptcy on March 9, five days after its machinists went on strike and the pilots and flight attendants supported them. Union leaders representing the pilots and flight attendants voted to send their members back to work on Nov. 22. The machinists are still on strike. **********Eastern is a subsidiary of the Texas Air Corporation, which has not filed for bankruptcy. Texas Air also owns Continental Airlines. **********Joel Zweibel, a lawyer for Eastern's unsecured creditors, declined to comment on how the creditors might proceed. The creditors have the right to file a reorganization plan and take over the carrier, but they have shown little interest in doing so. **********Eastern's creditors will continue to negotiate with Texas Air in hopes of an agreement on the carrier's future, said Mac McMullen, a spokesman for the Air Line Pilots Association. Eastern's pilots are among the creditors.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/08/world.main_headline: Argentine Chief Fights to Save Economic Program
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/08/world.print_headline: Argentine Chief Fights to Save Economic Program
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/08/world.body_text: **********Fighting back against those who oppose his economic policies, President Carlos Saul Menem has set out to gather support both in the streets and the political backrooms. **********The most obvious sign of his progress was a demonstration on Friday night that filled the Plaza de Mayo in front of the presidential palace. Police and other officials said 150,000 people turned out for what organizers called ''The March of the Yes.'' **********The turnout was easily double that for a march two weeks ago by striking public sector workers led by a faction of the General Labor Confederation, normally viewed as the backbone as Mr. Menem's Peronist party. The confederation opposes the President's efforts to end decades of state dominance of Argentina's stagnant economy. **********A pleased Mr. Menem blew kisses to the Friday night crowd in a brief thank-you speech and said that while some rough times remained ahead ''we are marching toward stability.'' He assured them that ''we are changing history.'' **********Mr. Menem is helped by what seems to be a general calming of the economic situation, though inflation in March, yet to be officially announced, is believed to have been almost 100 percent. Officials say that most of March's inflation came in the first two weeks of the month and that prices then began to fall. They are predicting inflation of 15 percent or less in April. **********Interest rates and the rate for exchanging the national currency, australs, into dollars have remained fairly steady for several weeks. **********Economy Minister Erman Gonzalez visited Washington this week and reported that the improving economic picture meant that the International Monetary Fund will probably release part of a $1.4 billion standby loan that were held up in February after hyperinflation erupted again. **********Mr. Menem acknowledged in his five-minute speech in the plaza that the country might be settling into depression, but said his program of selling off deficit-ridden state companies like the telephone company and the national airline would lead the way to a free-market economy that would eventually benefit all. **********In addition to reaching out to the public, Mr. Menem has made progress in gathering support from both the Peronist party and the main opposition party, the Radical Civic Union. **********When elected last year, many expected him to revive the tradition of government largesse begun by Juan D. Peron, the founder of the party. But almost as soon as he took office, he said that Argentina's economic collapse and changes in the outside world no longer made that possible. **********As real wages fell and the Government cut spending, opposition grew within the labor-dominated Peronist party. Mr. Menem managed to retain the support of the unions working for private business, but he lost that of the public employee unions. **********Opposition also mounted from party leaders not directly involved in his Government, particularly the powerful group led by Antonio Cafiero, the Governor of Buenos Aires Province and the party president. But two weeks ago Mr. Menem and Mr. Cafiero buried some of their differences. **********The Peronist leadership also called for a ''national truce'' and appealed for broad help in facing the economic crisis. This appeal was directed mainly at the Radical Civic Union, the party led by former President Raul Alfonsin. **********Mr. Menem's main hope seems to be to win the backing of the Governor of Cordoba Province, Eduardo Angeloz, the Radicals' presidential candidate against Mr. Menem. Mr. Angeloz, in his campaign, argued for policies similar to those of Mr. Menem, but he has so far refused to back the Government unless Mr. Alfonsin and the entire Radical leadership go along. **********But Mr. Alfonsin is still bitter over the fact that Peronists opposed his own unsuccessful efforts to reform the economy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/24/world.main_headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Shrinking Supplies of Food Evident in Iraq, Reports Say
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/24/world.print_headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Shrinking Supplies of Food Evident in Iraq, Reports Say
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/24/world.body_text: **********While the American-led military buildup in Saudi Arabia continues, another weapon, the withholding of food for Iraq under the United Nations trade embargo, is beginning to cause hardship, a variety of reports from officials of Western governments and food experts say. **********The Iraqi leadership is struggling to cope with shrinking supplies and an abrupt cutoff of imported food that, until the crisis, was fulfilling three-quarters of the country's nutritional needs. Eggs, sugar, cooking oil, fruits and vegetables have disappeared from store shelves in Baghdad or are in short supply, according to reports from the Iraqi capital that were confirmed by American Government officials. **********Food imports from Jordan, the only neighboring state not to have fully committed to barring trade with Iraq, have not kept up with Iraqi consumption. And even these supplies may be dwindling as ships with Iraqi-bound cargos are being discouraged by United States Navy vessels from entering the Jordanian port of Aqaba, said a State Department official who spoke on condition that he not be identified. ''The clear impression is that they are running down their food supplies,'' he said. **********One possible source of food for Iraq is Iran, which President Saddam Hussein of Iraq is wooing by returning lands occupied in their eight-year war and by releasing Iranian prisoners. But Iran has so far shown no interest in actively helping Iraq, and in any case, routes between the countries are not adequate to support the large food shipments Iraq needs, grain industry experts say. **********Mr. Hussein has exhorted his people to eat less, threatening to limit the food that foreign residents receive and announcing that merchants who hoard supplies will be sentenced to death. **********'I Think They Can Make It' **********But it remains unclear how quickly the pressure of the embargo will mount and at what point it might induce the Iraqi government to come to terms with those blocking its supplies. ''I don't think hunger is going to make the regime capitulate,'' said Daniel Pipes, the director of the Foreign Policy Research Institute in Philadelphia. ''Unless we start bombing bridges and factories, there will be hardship but I think they can make it.'' **********Iraq's people are among the better fed in the Middle East, and their food supplies could last months with rationing, Mr. Pipes said. Farmers could also plant more grain for human consumption and less for animal feed next spring. Iraq has indicated that its soldiers may be fed before civilians. **********President Hussein does not appear to have anticipated an embargo on food before his Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, said John P. Parker, a Department of Agriculture economist who studies Middle Eastern food supplies. While Iraq dramatically increased its food stockpiles on the eve of its 1980 invasion of Iran, these stockpiles fell every year from 1984 to 1990 and had reached unusually low levels by July 25, he said. **********Because Iraq's population was growing in this period, the food supply for each person fell and the country was left with only a two-month supply of wheat as of July, Mr. Parker said. **********Reports by people who fled from Kuwait after the country was overrun say Iraqi soldiers began asking local residents for food. ''It was like the old method of sending armies foraging for food on the ground they occupy,'' said a Kuwaiti businessman in a telephone conversation from Saudi Arabia, where he arrived four days after the invasion. **********Some Stores Looted in Kuwait **********The average Iraqi may notice shortages of sugar and tea first, he said. ''They drink a lot of tea, and heavy tea. It's like triple the amount of tea Westerners use, and that, of course, means you need a lot of sugar.'' **********An executive of a multinational corporation with employees trapped in Baghdad said yesterday that ''there is a shortage of certain food items,'' including eggs. The executive spoke only on the condition that neither he nor his company be identified. **********Many stores in Kuwait were looted immediately after the invasion but others kept their shelves stocked, said Katherine C. Baker, an American store manager who escaped from Kuwait on Aug. 12. She said the banks were closed, she had little money and lived on potatoes, rice and pasta. **********The amount of food seized by Iraq from Kuwait is unclear but may prove important, the State Department official said. The Kuwaiti businessman said his country had enough canned goods stored in warehouses to feed its population for four to six months, and Iraqi soldiers took over these warehouses and sent Kuwaiti employees home soon after the invasion. **********But the canned goods may not feed Iraq for long. In 1987, Kuwait had 1.87 million people; Iraq's population was 16.1 million in 1986. **********U.S. Supplies Had Been Cut **********The United States cut subsidized food shipments to Iraq in half last year because of a financial scandal involving Government credit guarantees and an Italian bank, and Iraq had not found alternative suppliers. **********The United Nations sanctions allow food shipments to Iraq and Kuwait to relieve famine only. The United States and the world's other major grain producers have said famine is not yet a problem. The American naval blockade includes food. **********President Hussein's current predicament has been compounded by the failure of Iraqi agriculture to surmount problems like infertile land and inadequate irrigation. **********Effects of Fabled Rivers **********Two large rivers flow through Iraq, the Tigris and Euphrates, and their banks were the breadbasket of the Middle East in ancient times. Nearly five thousand years ago, the Sumerians built one of the world's first great civilizations there, while the wealth of the court of Harun ar-Rashid, an eighth-century caliph of Baghdad, was described in the famous work of Arab literature, ''Thousand and One Nights.'' **********But in the 12th century, the fields of Iraq became dry and less fertile after the Tigris began flowing faster and dug itself a deep channel instead of periodically flooding and distributing rich silt over the fields, said Engin D. Akarli, an associate professor of Middle Eastern history at Washington University in St. Louis. **********Most of Kuwait is desert, and with the exception of some vegetables grown in greenhouses and limited shrimp fishing, the nation depends on imported food, Mr. Parker said.
