https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/22/busin.main_headline: The Vigil in Foley Square for the Magic Number
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/22/busin.print_headline: THE MILKEN SENTENCE; The Vigil in Foley Square for the Magic Number
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/22/busin.body_text: **********It took 27 minutes for the judge to finally speak the magic number -- and seconds for Michael R. Milken to absorb the shock. **********Throughout a morning of mounting drama in Room 318 at the Federal Court House at Foley Square, probably no one had an inkling there would be the electrifying theater that resulted, for probably no one imagined a magic number as high as 10 years. All that many in the audience could do was squirm and gasp. **********When United States District Judge Kimba M. Wood gave her pronouncement -- 10 years in prison, 3 years probation -- she ended the long, tortured case against what has been viewed as the biggest scalp in the Wall Street investigations. **********She also ended a long morning that began shortly after dawn as members of the press and onlookers blanketed the Court House steps, hoping for pictures and glimpses of the financial wizard, maybe the last for a while.  'Hey, Junk Bond Man' **********Wearing a gray suit, the 44-year-old Mr. Milken and his wife, Lori, arrived in a Lincoln Town Car at 9:30. He stepped out first, turned and waited for his wife, then gave her his hand. He strode up the steps looking straight ahead, never heeding the repeated cries of, "Hey, junk bond man" and "Yo, Michael, baby. Look this way." **********Up in the squarish courtroom, a packed house of nearly 200 people listened patiently to an hourlong plea by Arthur L. Liman, Mr. Milken's attorney. In large part, it was a reading of letters from people touched by Mr. Milken. There was one from a new employee who was so afraid of work she thought of jumping off a chair and breaking her legs so she could stay home. But Mr. Milken soothed her. **********Mr. Liman mentioned the $360 million Mr. Milken had given away. He mentioned he had volunteered to be a math teacher. And he confessed that he wasn't a psychiatrist and, "I can't offer an explanation for how Michael slipped." **********All Mr. Milken wanted to be remembered for, Mr. Liman said, was that he "made a difference to the children in the inner city." **********Jess Fardella, an assistant United States attorney, took just 10 minutes to stress the prosecution's belief that Mr. Milken did not resemble anything like an angel and that his crimes were worthy of heavy-duty punishment.  Indication of a Surprise **********It was during the 27 minutes of prefatory remarks by Judge Wood that one got the impression that a surprise was in the offing. She emphasized that she did not buy the argument that Mr. Milken had committed "subtle" and "technical" crimes. She said one had to wonder whether he calculatedly chose to commit crimes that would be hard to detect. She underscored the fact that Mr. Milken had not yet cooperated with the Government in its inquiries, something that could win a more lenient term. **********Mr. Milken had sat as a silent enigma throughout an eight-day special hearing preceding the sentencing. He sobbed audibly during part of Mr. Liman's plea yesterday, but spoke only a few choked-up words of apology before the sentence was announced. He stood stoical, listening to the sentence, though there was no escaping the feeling that here was a beaten man. **********After the sentence was announced, the spectators were divided in their impressions. "Brutal," exclaimed one grizzled man. "That's a long time to go up the river." **********"I don't know why one man should take all the heat of the battle," a middle-aged woman said. "What about the politicians taking bribes? How about them letting kids buy houses in New Jersey for 10 percent down. It used to be 25 or 30 percent. Why just stick it to this man?"  A Decade of Greed **********But there were people hoping for a verdict condemning a decade of greed. A young woman wearing a ponytail insisted that "even 28 years would not have been enough." **********Rebecca Gessler brought a curious perspective to the sentencing. She was covering the event for her reporting class at the Columbia Graduate School of Journalism. Before enrolling at Columbia, however, she had worked for a firm that had been hired to perform economics research for Mr. Milken's attorneys. From January through August, she and colleagues inspected every transaction that Mr. Milken's department executed, searching for foul play. She said the work was absolutely no fun. **********"When I was working there, my opinion was that what he did wasn't as bad as the prosecutors made it out to be," Ms. Gessler said. "But now that I've been away from it, I feel a little different. I was shocked by the sentence. But I feel the crimes seem to warrant a long sentence." **********Martin Klein, a lawyer and longtime friend of Mr. Milken, was indignant and quick to share his views. "Obviously, it's a miscarriage of justice," he said. "I think the judge may have been reacting to the hundreds of people here and is making Michael a scapegoat for the excesses of the 1980's." **********"He's a good person and a strong person, and he will survive," Mr. Klein went on. "Unfortunately, the country will be deprived of his talents for a long time."  Betting on the Sentence **********Many gambling pools were formed around the magic number. One young woman felt miserable that she had put her money on five years. Only her boss had picked 10, she said, "and we all thought she did that because she was ignorant." **********As the lunch hour neared, hundreds of people waited outside to witness Mr. Milken's departure. An hour ticked by without anyone more newsworthy appearing than a troop of third graders who had dropped by to see a swearing-in ceremony. **********Then someone came up with a reasonable answer. Mr. Milken had abruptly wised up and was upstairs finally spilling all to the Government. All over Wall Street, hundreds of people were being fingered. **********Among those impatiently listening to such theories was Enid Adler, a lawyer from Philadelphia who said she was engaged in a class-action suit against Mr. Milken. She clasped a small Nikon. "After poring through thousands and thousands of documents, I think I'm entitled to a photo," she said. **********But in the end, Ms. Adler and the throng were disappointed. Mr. Milken had ducked out the back.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/14/busin.main_headline: Ex-Judge Named to Study Action Under Asbestos Plan
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/14/busin.print_headline: Ex-Judge Named to Study Action Under Asbestos Plan
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/14/busin.body_text: **********A Federal judge in Brooklyn took the first steps yesterday toward carrying out a national plan for resolving asbestos personal injury cases. Federal District Judge Jack B. Weinstein said that he had appointed Marvin E. Frankel, a former Federal judge, as a special master to conduct hearings on part of the plan. **********Vowing that a class action would not take years to resolve as others have required, Judge Weinstein said Judge Frankel would begin a proceeding tomorrow that could lead to the national resolution of tens of thousands of asbestos cases. **********Judge Frankel will determine whether a class action would be warranted in thousands of cases against Eagle-Picher Industries. To recommend approval of a class action, Judge Frankel must find that Eagle-Picher's assets are so limited that a verdict in favor of some plaintiffs would hurt others. **********He said in an interview following the hearing that he would begin his examination tomorrow at Federal court in Brooklyn, when he meets with lawyers to narrow the issues and set up a schedule for hearings and fact-finding about the financial condition of Eagle-Picher, a Cincinnati-based maker of consumer and industrial products that made wide use of asbestos. He added that he expected to complete the task no later than Sept. 10. **********A lawyer for the company, Arvin Maskin, told the court yesterday that Eagle-Picher was now facing 65,000 asbestos cases, with thousands more being filed monthly, and legal bills of more than $100 million a year. **********An order endorsed by 10 Federal judges last Friday consolidates many of the cases into a series of proposed class actions that would be supervised by Judge Weinstein and two other judges, Thomas D. Lambros of Cleveland and Robert M. Parker of Tyler, Tex. **********The arrangement was reached after lawyers for many asbestos victims sought a class action before Judge Parker, who has a reputation among lawyers for favoring plaintiffs. Judge Weinstein originally called for a nationwide consolidation that set off the skirmish among judges and lawyers last month for class actions. Many of the plaintiffs' lawyers, recalling an order by Judge Weinstein when he supervised the Agent Orange class action brought by Vietnam veterans, feared that a nationwide consolidation exclusively before him would result in a huge slashing of their fees. **********Several judges and lawyers have said that as much as two-thirds of the money companies have been spending to resolve asbestos cases had been going for lawyers' fees and other legal expenses. **********The Judges' Plan **********Under the judges' plan, Judge Lambros will attempt a nationwide settlement, while Judge Parker will try cases that do not settle. Judge Weinstein has told colleagues and friends that he agreed to the arrangement because he is not convinced that the broader class actions would withstand appellate review. **********The judge said that he expects to supervise class actions against a half-dozen asbestos companies with sharply limited money and pool their resources to cut down on enormous legal costs. He also said he was considering the appointment of Bertram Harnett as a special master who would examine the insurance coverage of Eagle-Picher and other companies that move to have their cases consolidated. Justice Harnett retired from the New York State Supreme Court in 1977. Judge Frankel, Justice Harnett and Judge Weinstein have known each other since they studied together at Columbia Law School, graduating in 1948. **********At the hearing yesterday, two plaintiffs' lawyers expressed reservations about the use of a class action, but stopped short of outright rejection. One of the lawyers, Gene Locks of Philadelphia, said that a class action would not succeed in quick relief for asbestos victims but instead would result in more money being spent ''on needless transaction costs.'' He said it would be more beneficial if Eagle-Picher went into bankruptcy. **********Eagle-Picher Claim Questioned **********The other lawyer, Stanley Levy of New York, said he was not convinced that Eagle-Picher actually had limited resources, an issue that will have to be determined by Judge Frankel. The two plaintiffs' lawyers met with Judge Weinstein privately after the hearing. **********Judge Weinstein said that more than 250 cases arising partly out of work at the Brooklyn Navy Yard more than 25 years ago would probably not be tried before October; he had hoped for trial in early September. **********Settlement is expected by early September of 265 Brooklyn Navy Yard cases, Kenneth R. Feinberg, a Washington lawyer appointed by the court to reach a settlement, said yesterday. Attempting to persuade the defendants in those cases to settle, Judge Weinstein said any payments that they made would be taken into consideration in the class action proceedings before Judge Lambros and Judge Parker.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/31/world.main_headline: Nicaragua Set to Free Foes Under General Pardon
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/31/world.print_headline: Nicaragua Set to Free Foes Under General Pardon
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/31/world.body_text: **********The Nicaraguan Government began work today on a final list of more than 1,000 rebel supporters and former National Guardsmen who are to be released next month under a general pardon for imprisoned opponents of the Sandinista Government. **********The release, announced Monday by President Daniel Ortega Saavedra, is expected to free most, if not all, of the Government opponents still in prison. It was described by Sandinista officials as a gesture of good will during the campaign that is to culminate in national elections here on Feb. 25. **********''We hope that when the elections are carried out, these prisoners will be with their families and integrated into the pacification process,'' Mr. Ortega said. **********The release of political opponents of the Government has been a longstanding demand of opposition groups and has often been tied to regional negotiations over the disbandment of contra rebel base camps in Honduras. But despite years of intense diplomacy and bargaining, the contra army has remained intact, and the prisoner issue has remained unresolved. **********New Appeal on Bases **********In his comments about the release, which he said is to be carried out between Feb. 5 and Feb. 15, President Ortega recalled the stalemate over demobilization, and urged the United States and Honduras to dismantle the contra bases, which are still believed to contain as many as 10,000 armed fighters. **********''With this step, the Nicaraguan Government is not only fulfilling 100 percent of its commitments, but overfulfilling them,'' Mr. Ortega said, speaking to gathered members of the diplomatic corps in Managua. **********Government officials said the final list of the prisoners to be released would not be ready for submission to the Sandinista-controlled National Assembly, which must approve it, until Thursday. But they said the decree would cover more than 1,000 imprisoned contras or contra supporters as well as the 39 members of the National Guard of the country's former dictator, Anastasio Somoza Debayle, who remain in prison. **********At the height of the contra war, the number of prisoners held for their opposition to the Sandinista Government reached as high as 5,000, human rights officials say. Opposition groups have repeatedly accused the Government of concealing the existence of what they allege are thousands more political prisoners still being held. **********Large Groups Freed **********But in recent years, Sandinista leaders have freed several large groups of prisoners in special pardons, such as one last March when 1,894 former National Guardsmen were released. Officials of international organizations that have done extensive investigations of prison populations and conditions here say they are satisfied that the number of prisoners being discussed by the Government include all, or nearly all, of the remaining prisoners. **********''I think it includes virtually everybody,'' said Juan Mendez, an official of Americas Watch, one of the human rights groups that has carefully monitored Nicaraguan prisons. **********Human rights groups have taken a cautious attitude about blanket pardons for all prisoners involved in anti-Government activities, arguing that those found guilty of particularly heinous crimes should be distinguished from common prisoners of war. **********But human rights groups, church officials and other foreign experts have questioned the legal proceedings against many prisoners accused of anti-Government activities. International groups, including the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights, had specifically recommended the release of the remaining National Guard prisoners. **********''As far as we can tell,'' Mr. Mendez said, ''all of the National Guard people had been subjected to an unfair trial early on, and therefore required a new trial or an early release, and since they had already served 10 years, we thought they should be released.'' **********In mid-December, the Government also approved a pardon for 464 former members of the Sandinista People's Army and security forces who had been convicted of crimes or human rights violations. But human rights officials said they believed that a number of Government soldiers convicted of particularly serious violations remain in prison.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/03/world.main_headline: Peruvian Rebels Kill Official In Ruling Party and 9 Others
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/03/world.print_headline: Peruvian Rebels Kill Official In Ruling Party and 9 Others
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/03/world.body_text: **********Leftist guerrillas killed 10 people, including an official of President Alberto Fujimori's political movement, in a wave of attacks around the country that began on Thursday, the police said today. **********Members of the Shining Path insurgency gunned down an organizer for the party, Hector Montero, and his maid on Thursday in the city of Ayacucho, the police said. The rebels also killed a policeman and five other people in Ayacucho, 230 miles southeast of Lima, including a student who was beheaded. Rebel gunmen killed the manager of a shoe factory today in Lima and a school principal in the central Andean town of Quilcas on Thursday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/21/world.main_headline: At Home, Hope Raised, Hope Dashed
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/21/world.print_headline: At Home, Hope Raised, Hope Dashed
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/21/world.body_text: **********For Estelle Ronneburg, this was a day to put reason before the dictates of a mother's heart, to seek patience with a process that has still not returned her only child, a hostage in Lebanon, after 39 months. **********''I guess I have to say I support it,'' she said of President Bush's refusal to send John H. Kelly, Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern Affairs, to Damascus, Syria, to coordinate a hostage release, as the captors had asked. ''I have to say I didn't yesterday.'' **********The captors, the militant Islamic Holy War for the Liberation of Palestine, announced on Wednesday that one of three hostages would be released within 48 hours, and with that announcement the group released a picture of Jesse Turner, Mrs. Ronneburg's son. **********She continues to hope. She has kept a small suitcase packed all these years, ready to go to West Germany to meet Jesse. Recently, she said, she unpacked the warm red and black wool jacket she boiught for the reunion and replaced it with a light spring suit. **********A Surge in the Heart **********When a reporter called her at the bank here where she is an accounts clerk to tell her her son's photo had been released, Mrs. Ronneburg said, ''My heart took a big surge and I was almost crying.'' **********Then, Thursday night, she learned of the postponement. She felt anger at both Mr. Bush and the militants. She said she could not understand Mr. Bush's decision because the militants' request had seemed small. ''I was devastated,'' she said. ''All of a sudden, boom!'' **********But this morning Mrs. Ronneburg said that she received two calls from the State Department telling her not to give up hope and that Mr. Bush considered the militants' message a demand. ''If it had been more of a request than a demand, it might have been O.K.,'' she said. **********'Things We Don't Know' **********''If you give in to a demand, it's actually like dealing with a terrorist group,'' she said. ''I can kind of understand that because if we give in this time, maybe a week, a year, two years from now they'll start all over again with taking hostages. But there are so many things we don't know and will never know or understand.'' **********On the streets of Boise, friends and neighbors echo Mrs. Ronneburg's feelings. ''We're all very frustrated,'' said Mayor Dirk A. Kempthorne. ''But there is an acknowledgment that you must not negotiate with terrorists. What they have done is so ill-conceived - to seize noncombatants and people who were friends of their people. It has damaged our perception of them.'' **********Many of these people, descendants of miners and fur traders who founded this city in 1863, have been a source of support for Jesse Turner's mother. Each year on Jan. 24, the anniversary of the kidnapping, they tie yellow ribbons to 50 downtown trees. **********A Tribute From Children **********On Oct. 20, Mr. Turner's 1,000th day as a hostage, Mayor Kempthorne declared it Jesse Turner Day. Sixth grade children at the Liberty Grammar School folded 1,000 Japanese white paper cranes as a symbol of good luck. **********Mrs. Ronneburg keeps a wreath made of 50 of the cranes around the photo of her son's 1965 high school graduation, ''This community has a very personal concern in this,'' Mayor Kempthorne said. ''We get together as a family on this.'' **********Two Views, on the Street **********At Christina's Coffee Shop, Mary E. Kelly, director of the Idaho Conservation League, said: ''It would have been an easy trip for the Assistant Secretary. Asking for Bush himself to come would have been too presumptuous, but the Assistant Secretary was no big deal.'' **********Ms. Kelly said she believed the United States was directing the Syrians to act as its agents. ''I think this was a missed opportunity,'' she said, ''and I think the President has egg on his face.'' **********At the Sav-On Cafe, Frank B. Hayes, a retired heavy equipment operator, said he supported immediate military action. ''I'm in favor of loading up and going on in there and getting them,'' he said. **********Mrs. Ronneburg's home is surrounded by television vans with satellite dishes and electronic equipment in her yard. There is the buzz of talk on cellular phones on her porch. Portable toilets have been set up on the street. There are discussions about flipping a coin to see who will interview her for what broadcast. **********For Two, Escape From Beirut **********In the tiny home she shares with Jesse's stepfather, Eugene Ronneburg, a long-haul trucker, Mrs. Ronneburg slowly spreads on the coffee table recent photos of Joanna, the granddaughter she has never met. **********The child, born 5 months after the kidnapping, will be 3 years old in June. She is shown in sunglasses splashing in a pink plastic tub and in the Lebanese dress of her mother, Badr Turner. Mother and child fled Beirut last May and live in Dubai, in the United Arab Emirates, with her mother's relatives. Mrs. Ronneburg only met Badr once, in Greece in 1986. **********Jesse and Badr met when he was an associate professor of mathematics and computer sciences at Beirut University College and she was the mathematics department's secretary. **********Pictures of a blond teen-ager with cropped hair contrast starkly with recent photographs of Mr. Turner with a beard. His mother said he grew it in the 1960's after serving in the Navy. **********He earned a bachelor's degree in philosophy at Boise State College, then a master's and a Ph.D. in math from the University of Idaho in Moscow in 1981. He taught at the University of Hawaii, then went to Lebanon seeking, his mother said, students who really wanted to learn. **********Encouragement on the Phone **********One of the first phone calls Mrs. Ronneburg received Thursday night was from Mithileshwar Singh, one of three other men kidnapped with her son. Mr. Singh was released in October 1988. ''He said they always do this,'' Mrs. Ronneburg said, referring to the postponement, ''and it will work out, which made me feel better.'' **********Someone recently stole the yellow ribbon Mrs. Ronneburg tied around the apricot tree in her front yard the day Jeese was taken hostage. It doesn't matter, she said. The tree is dying. When he has time, her husband will cut it down.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/12/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;   Entertainment Weekly Editor Quits
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/12/busin.body_text: **********After a clash with senior management at Time Warner Inc. over the direction of the company's Entertainment Weekly magazine, the publication's managing editor, Jeff A. Jarvis, resigned yesterday. **********He was replaced by James W. Seymore, the 47-year-old executive editor of People magazine, another Time Warner publication. **********The move appeared to be intended to redirect the four-month-old publication, which has received mixed reviews from subscribers and advertisers, toward more of a middle American audience and to bring it into the mainstream of Time Warner's magazine group. **********According to company employees, who spoke yesterday on the condition that they not be identified, Mr. Jarvis wanted tough reviews and offbeat subjects to have a prominent place in the magazine, which covers videos, movies, books, music and television. **********More Personality Driven **********But the senior managemers of the magazine group - Jason McManus, the editor in chief; Richard B. Stolley, editorial director, and Gilbert Rogin, the corporate editor - are said to prefer a more personality-driven publication. **********The appointment of Mr. Seymore from People magazine, which has enjoyed great success by chronicling the lives of celebrities, suggests that Entertainment Weekly will now take a less irreverent approach. Mr. Seymore declined to be interviewed. **********''Management wants more celebrity coverage and a more mainstream magazine,'' said one employee at Time Warner, adding that the magazine's staff was ''shell-shocked'' by Mr. Jarvis's departure. **********Along with Michael Klingensmith, the publisher of Entertainment Weekly, Mr. Jarvis, 35, was the driving force behind the magazine. He first proposed the idea in 1984, while he was a television critic at People. **********''I spent six years working on it,'' Mr. Jarvis said in an interview yesterday. ''I am very disappointed. Of course, I am.'' He declined to comment further. **********Peter Castiglio, a Time Warner spokesman, said only that there had been ''creative differences'' between Mr. Jarvis and senior management. **********According to company employees, one clash involved the magazine's review of the movie ''Pretty Woman.'' The magazine group's management was not pleased when Entertainment Weekly panned the movie, which was a box-office success. **********At the outset, executives of the magazine group had promised Mr. Jarvis and Mr. Klingensmith a free rein, believing this worked better than a bureaucratic, corporate approach. But the employees described an increasingly tense situation in which top management had become steadily more involved in the day-to-day operations, to make sure the magazine proved a success. **********The magazine is the first introduced since Time's merger with Warner, which left the company with about $10.6 billion in debt. Media analysts believe the company has been acutely preoccupied with the magazine's success because Time's last big effort, TV-Cable Week, cost the company more than $45 million when it closed in 1983. **********Picture Week, a black-and-white news and photo magazine, was abandoned in 1986 after test-marketing and a $30 million investment by Time. Time Warner has spent an estimated $40 million to test market and introduce Entertainment Weekly. **********Circulation at 600,000 **********Mr. Castiglio said that Entertainment Weekly was doing well, with a circulation of 600,000, including subscribers and newsstand sales, and that advertising was running ''ahead of schedule.'' Mr. Klingensmith said he was ''increasingly satisfied'' with the publication and predicted that it would ''go on and prosper.'' **********But Peter P. Appert, an analyst at C. J. Lawrence, Morgan Grenfell Inc., said, ''This is a very difficult advertising environment for magazines, and I believe Entertainment Weekly is off to a rough start.'' **********Advertising at many leading magazines has been down at least 10 percent this year. **********''The future has to be cloudy,'' said Bob Zach of Chiat/Day/Mojo Inc. ''When there are so many changes in so short a time, you have to ask whether they are focused on where they are going. Such turmoil does not sit well with the advertising community, which tends to be conservative about where it puts its money.'' **********The magazine's design has already changed once since introduction, after widespread criticism that its different graphics, typefaces, column sizes and print colors made the publication cluttered and hard to read. Moreover, initial covers on K. D. Lang, the country-and-western singer, and books on Vietnam, which were criticized as too esoteric, have given way to more recent covers featuring the movie star Tom Cruise and the rock star Madonna. **********The Jury Is Still Out **********''The magazine has improved,'' said Joseph Ostrow, media director at Foote, Cone & Belding Communications, the advertising agency. ''It was too downtown and too young in tone. It looks a lot more like a Time magazine now, and I'm comfortable with that.'' But he added that ''the jury is still very much out.'' **********But Entertainment Weekly faces tough competition from the News Corporation's Premiere and Arrow Publishers Inc.'s Rolling Stone. Analysts said doubts still hanging over the magazine included whether the public would adopt a single publication for news on media and entertainment products, and whether it could really provide a service that was not already available. **********The Time Warner employees are fearful that the magazine will, as one put it, ''become another People.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/27/busin.main_headline: Key Talks On Output For OPEC
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/27/busin.print_headline: Key Talks On Output For OPEC
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/27/busin.body_text: **********As members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries gathered informally here today to confront some of the most crucial issues in the group's 30-year history, some predicted that a formal meeting would be announced on Monday to address questions of oil production and prices. **********But regardless of the forum, a majority of OPEC members expect at least three member nations to carry out their plan to raise oil production to help meet the supply shortfall caused by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. **********There is a growing sentiment here that the member nations would be better off to permit production increases within an OPEC framework instead of allowing a free-for-all that might be difficult to control once the Persian Gulf crisis is over. Once the conflict comes to an end, this logic holds, OPEC can retake control and regulate production under its quota system. **********While there are serious differences among members on how to respond to the turmoil in the world petroleum markets, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Venezuela are pressing to increase their production substantially when the meeting ends. **********Long-Dormant Animosities **********The Iraqi-Kuwaiti conflict has rekindled long-dormant animosities within OPEC that reflect the political schisms separating poor and rich countries and pro-Western and anti-Western nations. **********OPEC officials from Algeria, Libya, Iran, Nigeria and Iraq, for example, argue that it is not OPEC's mission to save the West from an economic crisis caused by rapidly rising oil prices. They say the West has done little for indebted third world nations in the last decade and argue that there is enough oil in world markets to compensate for the interruption of supplies caused by the Iraqi invasion. **********Delegates from Saudi Arabia, Venezuela, Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates and Qatar, however, say that unless OPEC allows members that can raise their output to do so immediately, OPEC itself will pay a high price if demand drops. **********These delegates say higher oil prices will eventually create a backlash as they have done in the past, when industrialized countries countered rising prices with conservation measures that reduced oil consumption. **********A number of member countries, including Indonesia, Algeria and Nigeria, seem to favor a middle ground in which OPEC would raise output to make up for only part of the shortages in the markets. **********Their view is that oil prices had been quite weak for a long time earlier this year, and higher prices now are needed to compensate for the earlier losses. **********A Fundamental Split **********But behind the issues of output and prices is a more fundamental split along political and ideological lines. **********Among the poorer, more militant members of OPEC, there is an unquestionable antipathy toward the United States and a conviction that Saudi Arabia and Venezuela, the prime advocates of higher production, are acting under strong American pressure. **********''We are not here to respond to the wishes of the Americans,'' said an Arab delegate from one of the militant countries. ''This is OPEC, and our mission is to serve the best interest of our members.'' **********In an argument echoed by several moderate countries, including Nigeria and Indonesia, which are allies of the West, an OPEC official from Algeria said: ''There is no real shortage of oil in the market. If the American and Western oil companies release their stocks of oil instead of hanging on to them to make more money, there will be no shortage.'' **********Advocates of this view say that even if OPEC now authorized all its members with surplus capacity to produce all the oil they could, this would not amount to the full four million barrels a day missing from Kuwait and Iraq. **********Delegate From Kuwait **********Among the delegates who gathered today, Kuwait's representative, Ali Khalifa al Sabah, the Finance Minister and a senior member of the Kuwaiti ruling family who has been an architect of OPEC policies for a decade, was greeted warmly by most other OPEC ministers. **********So far, there has been no sign of the Iraqis, who have indicated that they would wait for the meeting to be elevated into a formal session. **********The general sentiment here is that even if Iraq took part, it would not be able to prevent other OPEC members from raising output to compensate for the loss of the four million barrels of oil a day. **********In pressing their case for increased production, Saudi Arabia and Venezuela concede that international oil companies, the United States, Japan and Western European countries hold large stocks of oil that could be released to help make up for the shortfall. **********But they argue that these stocks are held by rich industrialized nations and that poorer third world countries, like India, Pakistan, Brazil and many African nations, which do not have stocks of oil, are experiencing a real shortage and are facing huge, untenable price increases. **********A Middle Ground **********One OPEC delegate, who is among those who are unable to raise production but strongly favor higher prices, advocates bargaining for a smaller increase in output by Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and the United Arab Emirates. ''Perhaps something on the order of two million barrels instead of say 3.5 or so,'' he said. **********But Saudi Arabia and Venezuela have said that under the existing OPEC agreement, which mandates the production of a total of 22.5 million barrels a day by all 13 members at a price of $21 a barrel, there is plenty of room to produce all they can now. Prices now stand at about $31 a barrel and production is substantially below 22.5 million barrels a day. **********Some delegates are hoping that the talks do not raise emotions too high. Sadek Boussena, the OPEC conference president and Algeria's oil minister, said in an interview tonight on CNN: ''I have big hopes that all of us will try to remain calm and stay out of matters that do not concern us.'' **********Making a Decision **********Mr. Boussena added, ''I think we have to make this decision in a way that allows all OPEC members not to consider this decision as against them.'' **********The Algerian oil minister noted that the rise in oil prices is not something OPEC can remedy by itself. **********He and others have said psychology and market speculation are driving prices up and that these elements have little to do with how much oil is on the market or how much production is missing from Kuwait and Iraq.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/12/busin.main_headline: Real Estate; Office Space Slumping In Chicago
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/12/busin.print_headline: Real Estate; Office Space Slumping In Chicago
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/12/busin.body_text: **********SAPLINGS are being planted at the corners of a vacant downtown block that has become a symbol of Chicago's deflated building boom. With trees in place, the site will presumably look less forlorn until the city's slumping property market improves. **********The Block 37 project, as it is known, is on hold. The land is across the street from the Richard J. Daley Plaza and one block from City Hall. It is to be the site of a $350 million office and retail project. **********The development team consists of a consortium of Chicago's largest and most powerful developers, including Metropolitan Structures, JMB Realty and the Levy Organization. "We can't start without tenants, and we don't have them now," said Bernard Weissbourd, chairman of Metropolitan Structures. **********With financing dried up and major tenants hard to find, developers in Chicago are postponing groundbreakings. Sixteen projects amounting to 21 million square feet are on hold. Among these is a 125-story building proposed by Miglin-Beitler Inc., a Chicago development concern. The building was to succeed the Sears Tower as the tallest building in the world, but so far no financing for the project has been obtained. **********The office vacancy rate here reached 14.5 percent in October, the highest it has been since 1974, according to Coldwell Banker Commercial Real Estate Services in Chicago. The rate rose three percentage points since June as five million square feet of office space came on the market. **********Although a total of 8.4 million square feet is now under construction, none of those projects is scheduled for completion this year, leading to expectations that vacancy rates will not rise in the fourth quarter. **********Chicago is no worse off than other cities. The Real Estate Research Corporation's report on emerging trends in real estate in 1991 ranked Chicago fifth in the perceptions of business people about the prospects of real estate markets' attracting developers, investors and lenders. Los Angeles ranked third and New York 12th. **********All the cities in the ranking, based on 112 interviews with real estate experts, have slipped. For 1990, Chicago had a rating of 6.7; for 1991 it is 5.4. New York's 1990 rating was 6.2; 1991's is 3.8. **********Among the projects that are under way in Chicago is a 50-story office building by the Prime Group at 77 West Wacker Drive. It represents a kind of deal that is not available any longer; the tower is being financed by Swiss and Japanese banks, a development partnership of the Prime and the Kemper Investors Life Insurance Company. **********Commercial brokers say that the deals that brought pension funds, insurance companies, foreign investors and commercial banks, sometimes in combinations, into joint ventures with developers on new projects can no longer be made. **********One by one, these sources of financing are drying up. Jolts to Japan's stock market have made investors from that country pull back from American real estate. Pension funds and insurance companies have been disappointed by their returns on real estate and are becoming cautious about investing more. **********Because of the savings and loan crisis, Federal banking regulators are concerned about the heavy commitments of banks in real estate loans. Some developers say that new underwriting requirements imposed on commercial banks by regulators are the immediate cause of the halt in construction. **********"The real estate industry is out of capital," said Richard Hanson, president of Stein & Company of Chicago, which has developed several downtown office towers. "You need lots of equity now, and I'm talking about 40 to 50 percent. We have been put into a regulated recession by changes in the underwriting." **********Many new buildings that have come on the market recently are only slowly being leased. Lincoln Properties' 1.3-million-square-foot building at 311 South Wacker Drive opened in May and is only 25 percent leased. The cleared sites for the project's second and third phases have been landscaped and paved over for parking. **********"Projects like this exert a continued downward pressure on rents," said Richard Kateley, president of the Real Estate Research Corporation. "Tenants have multiple options for low rents, so they can bargain." **********Asking rents for prime space range from $22 to $32 a square foot a year. Deals are actually being made at rents ranging from $16 to $27 a square foot, the reseach corporation said. **********Chicago experienced intensive development over the last 10 years, partly because of its low vacancy rates, which stood at just 4 percent in 1980. Since 1987 Chicago has added nearly 11 million square feet to its inventory of office space. Of a total of just over 100 million square feet downtown, 15 million square feet is now unoccupied. **********Predictions vary as to how long the downturn will last. With two million square feet absorbed annually, estimates are that it will be at least four to five years before significant new construction starts again.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/24/world.main_headline: MOSCOW'S FORCES STEP UP PRESSURE ACROSS LITHUANIA
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/24/world.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;   MOSCOW'S FORCES STEP UP PRESSURE ACROSS LITHUANIA
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/24/world.body_text: **********The Soviet authorities sent a column of tanks and paratroopers rumbling past an all-night session of the Lithuanian Parliament early this morning, in what witnesses described as the strongest attempt yet to intimidate the republic into abandoning its declaration of independence. **********More than 100 tanks and trucks, and more than 1,500 soldiers armed with automatic weapons thundered by the Parliament building in central Vilnius at about 3 A.M. as legislators worked through the night to complete the creation of an independent government. **********The Parliament broke off from its work to pass an emergency resolution declaring that it would transfer all authority to its representative in Washington in the event that legislators were arrested or martial law was imposed. **********No Signs of Takeover **********The column proceeded through the town, stopping at an army base inside the city limits after passing the Parliament, and there were no signs that the central Government was trying to take power in Lithuania, where independence was declared on March 11. **********[United States officials anxiously monitored signs of abnormally high Soviet military activity in Lithuania. as concerns mounted in the Administration that the Kremlin may be contemplating harsher action against the secessionist movement in Lithuania. Page 5.] **********On Friday, the Soviet Government's pressures on Lithuania included movements of military vehicles through the streets and new restrictions on border crossings. **********The Soviet Government also restricted foreign journalists' access to Lithuania and expelled two American diplomats from the republic on Friday, apparently in an effort to stifle information on the conflict over Lithuania's declaration of independence. **********Helicopters Drop Leaflets **********Military helicopters hovering low over a number of Lithuanian cities on Friday dropped thousands of leaflets reprinting President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's decree issued Wednesday, demanding that Lithuanian citizens turn in their firearms and ordering the authorities to defend the Soviet Constitution in the republic. **********Communist Party members loyal to Moscow also seized the party committee headquarters in Vilnius, which the Moscow loyalists had been sharing with the breakaway Communist Party of Lithuania. The Moscow loyalists said they were fulfilling the Government decree ordering the protection of Soviet installations in Lithuania. **********The Lithuanian Parliament here in the capital reported that a Lithuanian soldier who deserted from the Soviet Army was abducted on Thursday evening from the streets of Vilnius by plainclothes military officers and was being held against his will at the city's military headquarters. **********The Lithuanian Government has been sheltering local military deserters, and the Soviet authorities have set today as the deadline for the republic to turn in the young men. **********Protest to Gorbachev **********After the column of paratroopers passed through the city this morning, the Lithuanian President, Vytautas Landsbergis, said he had sent a telegram to President Gorbachev protesting the show of force. **********''This is the same thing that has been going on for a week,'' Mr. Landsbergis said. ''It is a war of nerves, psychological pressure, and humiliation of the Lithuanian people.'' **********''We are under constant pressure from the outside,'' he said. ''A certain kind of psychological warfare is being waged against Lithuania.'' **********The Lithuanian Parliament decided Friday night to go into an all-night session to finish creating Lithuania's independent government, completing a formal step in the republic's declaration of independence from Moscow. Lithuania, along with its sister republics of Latvia and Estonia, were forcibly annexed by Stalin in 1940, as part of a nonaggression pact between Stalin and Hitler that divided Europe into spheres of influence. **********As the members of Parliament were meeting shortly after midnight, they got a telephone call from a police station in a nearby town saying that a column of armored vehicles, including 59 light armored tanks and 50 military trucks, was on the way. In response, the deputies passed their resolution saying that they would delegate their powers to Stasys Lozoraitis, head of the Lithuanian legation in Washington, if they were ''restricted from acting and expressing the will of the nation freely.'' **********After the declaration, the newly appointed Foreign Affairs Minister, Algirdas Saudargas, said he believed that the military may have been deployed in fulfillment of the army's vow to seize deserters from the armed forces. ''There is certainly a basis for fear, which is why we decided to continue meeting through the night to form a government,'' he said.''But we believe that everything is aimed at these deserters.'' **********Rumors of Separate Army **********Several deputies from the Parliament said they believed the dispatch of the column to Vilnius was prompted by rumors in Moscow that the republic was organizing its own military formation, using Lithuanian deserters from the Soviet Army. **********In his telegram to Mr. Gorbachev, Mr. Landsbergis said the republic has been registering civilian volunteers as a contingency, only ''in case of necessity to help in the defense of the general order and in control of roads.'' He added, ''We have no formations of this type, even though we are surrounded by arms.'' **********On Friday, at the borders, where Soviet K.G.B. guards were on heightened alert, new simplified visa-free procedures were suspended between Lithuania and Poland. **********And in the first sign that the Soviet Government is trying to restrict reporting from Lithuania, the Soviet Foreign Ministry telephoned many foreign news organizations in Moscow, including The Washington Post and Reuters, and told them that their correspondents' scheduled trips to Vilnius had been canceled. **********Given 12 Hours to Leave **********Soviet officials also told two visiting American diplomats that they must return within 12 hours to the consulate in Leningrad, where they are based. **********Foreign journalists accredited in Moscow and diplomats stationed in the country must notify the Foreign Ministry in advance of travel. The Foreign Ministry seemed to have randomly rescinded permission for certain journalists, and the duty officer who informed them said that it was for ''temporary reasons.'' **********''If they closed Lithuania to the press, it would be the beginning of an information blackout,'' Algimantas Cekuolis, a Lithuanian journalist and an aide to Mr. Landsbergis, said on Friday. ''That would mean trouble, because you only need a blackout if you're going to do something nasty.'' **********Most of the several dozen foreign journalists now in Vilnius arrived earlier in the week, when the situation between Moscow and Vilnius was not so heated. **********Special Panel for Deserters **********A special commission of the Lithuanian Supreme Soviet has been registering local young men who have left their army units and informing the Soviet military that they are in the charge of the Lithuanian Government. **********The Government has set aside certain hospitals where the deserters can stay under auspices of the Lithuanian Red Cross and the protection of the Lithuanian Interior Ministry. But officials acknowledged that they were powerless to protect the young men in the event of an armed attempt by the military to seize them, and many here are worried that today could be the first violent confrontation between Moscow and Lithuania. **********''If military force is used against us, we would not be able to counter such a great power,'' said Marionis Misiukonis, who was confirmed on Friday by Parliament as the new Interior Minister, a post he held in the previous government. **********Officials say they have only sketchy information about the seizure of a Lithuanian deserter, Vidas Zalazicius, which Mr. Landsbergis labeled a ''kidnapping.'' He was walking with a friend in the city on Thursday night when he was taken, and nobody, including his parents, has been given access to him since. **********Information Is Denied **********A guard at the military headquarters refused to provide information on the case, and Lithuanian officials said they have been similarly denied information. **********The Lithuanian leadership today protested the increased Soviet military presence in the republic. **********''The size of the army keeps growing,'' Mr. Landsbergis told Parliament today. ''It is openly demonstrating that it is armed and very strong and ready for anything.'' **********On Friday, several armored personnel carriers were spotted in the city, as were trucks carrying armed soldiers and several military vehicles hauling bed frames, leading many people to speculate that the military was setting up encampments around the city. Witnesses said they saw the soldiers being dropped off in small groups or pairs in various locations around the city.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/19/busin.main_headline: Japanese Banker to Head A Morgan Stanley Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/19/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;   Japanese Banker to Head A Morgan Stanley Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/19/busin.body_text: **********The Morgan Stanley Group said yesterday that it had hired a Japanese banker, Takeo Kani, to be chairman of Morgan Stanley Japan Ltd. and general manger of the firm's Tokyo securities branch. **********Mr. Kani, 58, is joining Morgan Stanley from the Industrial Bank of Japan, where he has spent 36 years. He came to the United States five years ago to be vice chairman of the IBJ/Schroder Bank and Trust Company in New York after the Schroder bank was purchased by the Japanese bank. **********Mr. Kani will join Morgan Stanley in New York next month and will take over in Tokyo Jan. 1. **********There, he will succeed David S. Phillips, 57, who is retiriing at the end of the year to become an advisory director of the Morgan Stanley Group and senior adviser to the firm in Japan, his home country. **********When Mr. Phillips came to the United States to study at the University of California at Berkeley, he took the name of a professor of economics with whose family he lived and who was a close friend of his father's in Tokyo, a Morgan Stanley spokeswoman said. **********In Tokyo, Mr. Kani will also become co-head of the firm's investment banking business, working with John S. Wadsworth Jr., the current head of investment banking. After a transition, Morgan Stanley said, Mr. Kani will assume responsibility for investment banking. Mr. Wadsworth will continue as president of Morgan Stanley Japan and deputy general manager, as well as head of the firm's investment banking business in Asia. **********Mr. Kani said yesterday that Morgan Stanley was expanding rapidly in Japan and would continue to grow. The company currently employs 700 people there. Of 10 Morgan Stanley managing directors in Tokyo, six are Japanese. **********Mr. Kani declined to make any comments on the direction of the Japanese stock market, saying he had been in commercial banking and felt unqualified to speak on the market at this point. **********Mr. Kani graduated from the University of Tokyo in 1954 and joined the Industrial Bank that year. He founded IBJ International in London in 1975 and was named a managing director of the Industrial Bank in 1984. **********''We are delighted to have a seasoned banker of the stature of Mr. Kani succeed to this leadership role,'' said S. Parker Gilbert, chairman of the Morgan Stanley Group.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/08/world.main_headline: Burma Seizes 6 Opponents, Including Election Leaders
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/08/world.print_headline: Burma Seizes 6 Opponents, Including Election Leaders
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/08/world.body_text: **********The Government of Gen. Saw Maung put the league's two main leaders, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi and U Tin Oo, under house arrest in July 1989. Mr. Tin Oo was later sentenced to three years at hard labor. **********On Thursday, Japanese diplomats reported that General Saw Maung had told a Japanese legislator visiting Yangon, formerly Rangoon, last week that he was willing to free Aung San Suu Kyi if she accepted foreign exile or gave up politics. **********Leadership Incapacitated **********The new arrests deprive the league of the leaders who steered it to victory in the national election on May 27, Myanmar's first free vote in three decades. The league won 392 of the 485 contested seats, but the military has ignored its demands to transfer power. **********The Government has recently issued warnings against protests to mark the anniversary of the military's seizure of power in September 1988. At that time, troops killed several thousand people in crushing a democracy movement. **********At a news briefing today, General Saw Maung repeated the warnings. He also ordered members of the Buddhist clergy, who have been at the forefront of recent anti-Government dissent, not to meddle in politics. **********The Government ''is ruling the country according to martial law,'' the general said. ''Our duty is to maintain law and order, and any attempt to disrupt these objectives will not be tolerated.'' **********Possible Reasons for Move **********Western diplomats in Yangon have reported a heavy troop presence in recent days. A diplomat reached by telephone from Bangkok, Thailand, who insisted on not being identified, gave two possible explanations for the latest arrests. **********''One is that they are pre-emptive,'' he said. ''The other is that they are a deliberate ploy to stir up unrest to create an excuse for an even heavier clampdown.'' **********Mr. Kyi Maung and his deputy, Mr. Chit Hlaing, are members of the executive committee of the National League for Democracy. Both won Parliament seats in the May election. **********Colonel Than Tun said they had been detained under the Official Secrets Act and would soon be tried. He gave no details of the alleged offenses. **********Viewed as a Conciliator **********Mr. Kyi Maung, a 72-year-old retired army colonel, is considered a moderate with the potential to mediate between the military and the more radical members of his own party. **********An American human rights group, Asia Watch, said in an August report that thousands of political prisoners were believed to be held in Burmese jails and that torture was widespread. **********On Aug. 8, troops reportedly killed two Buddhist monks and two students who were demonstrating peacefully in Mandalay. Days earlier, a soldier reportedly bayoneted a student protester in the face.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/29/busin.main_headline: Stocks Continue Rise as Dow Gains 16.58
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/29/busin.print_headline: Stocks Continue Rise as Dow Gains 16.58
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/29/busin.body_text: **********Stocks advanced yesterday for the second day in a row, but volume continued sluggish and is expected to stay light until after next week's Fourth of July festivities. **********Following Wednesday's 19.80-point rise, the Dow Jones industrial average rose another 16.58, to 2,878.71, with a solid 911 stocks advancing and 559 declining. **********Volume slumped to 136.1 million shares from 146.6 million the day before. **********Robert H. Stovall, president of Stovall/Twenty-First Advisers, said of yesterday's action: ''What I find interesting is that the market is able to absorb these hits on important companies reporting or forecasting disappointing earnings and still creep higher.'' **********On Wednesday, the market moved higher despite a pessimistic earnings outlook from A.T.&T., which depressed the company's stock. The best example yesterday, Mr. Stovall said, was Time Warner. ''We had a very negative piece in The Wall Street Journal,'' he said, ''and the stock went up 4 1/8.'' The Journal article noted that Lisbeth R. Barron, an S. G. Warburg analyst, had advised clients to sell Time Warner because of concern about advertising revenues and film profits. **********Mr. Stovall argued that ''it makes investors think the market in July may not be as vulnerable to earnings disappointments as previously thought.'' **********Explaining the rise in the stock to 102 3/8, Edward I. Adler, a Time Warner spokesman said, ''If you read the article carefully, it said that the majority of analysts who cover our company remain positive.'' **********Kenneth P. Ducey, senior vice president in the trading department of S. G. Warburg & Company, said he expected that many traders would take off all or most of next week because of the mid-week holiday and that, consequently, volume could be weak until they returned. **********Dow Industrials Advance **********In trading that can best be described as choppy, the Dow industrials advanced a few points on the opening, fell back and then advanced again, repeating the flow until 1 P.M. when it spurted 15 points. The Dow generally managed to stay in higher ground before the closing. **********Among the blue-chip industrials, Procter & Gamble rose 2, to 85 3/4; McDonalds rose 1 1/4, to 35 7/8, and Merck rose 1 7/8, to 86 1/8. **********As they do in uncertain times, the drug stocks registered impressive gains. **********Abbott Labs rose 1 1/8, to 42; Bristol-Myers gained 1 1/4, to 64 1/2, on more than a million shares; Johnson & Johnson tacked on 1 1/4, to 67 7/8. Eli Lilly rose 2 3/4, to 83 3/4; Schering-Plough advanced 1, to 48 1/4; Syntex added 1 1/8, to n 59 3/8 and Warner Lambert climbed 2 1/2, to 66 5/8. Medtronic, which produces pacemakers, rose 2 5/8, to 82 3/4. It raised its quarterly dividend yesterday. **********A.T.&T., which topped the New York Stock Exchange's list of active stocks on Wednesday, topped it again yesterday. On Wednesday it forecast that second-quarter profits would decline, prompting a selloff that trimmed the stock 2 1/8 on 11.5 million shares. Yesterday, the telecommunications giant fell another 3/8, to 38 3/4, on nearly 3.8 million shares. **********The selloff in A.T.&T. appeared to have lost most of its strength by yesterday. Added to that, portfolio managers still dressing up their investments by removing underperforming stocks have only today left before the second quarter ends. **********Profits - and the prospect of greater profits - continued to dominate investment decisions. Nike and L.A. Gear, two highly successful producers of athletic footwear, were prominent examples. **********Nike rose 4 1/4, to 77 1/2, on nearly 1.3 million shares after saying it expected profits for the fourth quarter ended May 31 to hit $1.70 to $1.75, or far more than analysts predicted. **********In other big moves, Digital Equipment rose 3 1/8, to 85 1/4 after George Elling of Merrill Lynch recommended it along with Hewlett-Packard, which rose 1 1/8, to 47 3/8. Pennzoil rose 3 1/2, to 76 3/8, after canceling a stock offering for a subsidiary. **********Among the averages, the S. & P. 500 rose 2.49, to 357.63; the Nasdaq composite rose 3.49, to 460.38, and the Amex market value index rose 1.52, to 358.57.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/15/busin.body_text: **********An official of the Soviet Union today announced a prize of $25,000 to the person who devises the best plan for making the ruble convertible into hard currencies. **********Dimitri Levchuk, an adviser to Deputy Prime Minister Leonid Abalkin, told reporters that the contest would be held in Washington in May. ''The prize money will be paid in hard currency,'' he said. **********The contest is being organized by private United States foundations and by a non-governmental organization in the Soviet Union, a Soviet spokesman said. The United States economist Wassily Leontief, who received the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science in 1973, is to head the panel of judges. **********Western economists believe the Soviet Union cannot significantly increase trade with the West until its currency is made convertible.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/07/world.main_headline: CHINA WEIGHS SALE OF GAS CHEMICALS
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/07/world.print_headline: CHINA WEIGHS SALE OF GAS CHEMICALS
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/07/world.body_text: **********The United States has received intelligence reports that China is considering the sale of chemicals to Libya that can be used to make poison gas, Bush Administration officials said today. **********The officials said that after Washington learned that officials from Chinese companies and Libyan aides were conducting negotiations about the sale, the Administration asked the Beijing Government not to go through with it. **********Such a sale, Bush Administration officials said, would violate China's stated commitment not to encourage the spread of poison gas to the Middle East. **********Libya's chemical weapons program has been a major worry for the United States. Bush Administration officials said in March that a fire that month at Libya's chemical weapons plant at Rabta might have been a hoax engineered by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader. The Central Intelligence Agency has detected recent activity at the Rabta complex but no firm proof that the plant is back in operation, Administration officials said last week. **********Senators Hold Hearing **********Washington's new concerns came to light today when a senior State Department official testified before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on the Bush Administration's policy toward China. **********Under sharp questioning from Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware, Richard Solomon, the Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, indicated that the Administration was concerned about the possible export of chemical weapon ingredients by China to the Middle East, but declined to identify the possible recipient or to offer any details. **********''We've got some indications that something may be going on in that area, and we have expressed our concerns to them at a very high level,'' Mr. Solomon said. **********Another Administration official, who asked not to be identified, said the American Embassy in Beijing was instructed several days ago to ask the Chinese not to sell Libya precursor chemicals, as the key ingredients of poison gas are known. **********The United States latest concerns have raised new questions about the Bush Administration's concilatory policy toward Beijing. The Administration recently decided to renew most-favored-nation trading status for Beijing and has also maintained high-level diplomatic contacts with China despite continued repression there. **********U.S. Policy Criticized **********At the Senate hearing, Senator Biden asserted that the Bush Administration policy toward China had been a failure. **********''You certainly can't defend China on trade; you can't begin to defend them on human rights; you can't begin to defend them on their handling of the situation since Tiananmen Square,'' said Senator Biden, who questioned whether China was being responsive to concerns over the spread of missiles, poison gas and nuclear weapons. **********In response, an aide to Mr. Solomon noted that China had pledged not to sell M-9 missiles to Syria and had offered a more general assurance not to sell medium-range missiles to the Middle East. **********The aide, Kent Wiedeman, director of the State Department's Office of Chinese and Mongolian Affairs, indicated that the Bush Administration was trying to get China to accept an internationally agreed-upon definition of what constitutes a medium-range missile. The definition is contained in export guidelines agreed to by Western nations and was confirmed in a United States-Soviet joint statement on combating the spread of missiles, poison gas and nuclear weapons that was issued after the summit meeting in Washington. **********''We are ever vigilant, we're concerned, just as you are,'' Mr. Wiedeman said, referring to continuing re= ports and rumors of Chinese efforts to sell missiles, poison gas and nuclear weapons technologies. **********Administration specialists said that while there was evidence that officials from Chinese companies and Libyan officials have been negotiating the sale of poison gas ingredients, there was no firm proof that a transaction had been consummated or that the ingredients had been shipped to Libya. **********Other Nations in Talks **********Administration officials said also that intelligence reports indicated that Libya was not the only country to discuss the possible sale of Chinese ingredients for the manufacture of chemical weapons. **********These chemicals often have legitimate civilian uses as well as military applications. The West has sought to control their export by establishing export guidelines. As a result, some third-world countries have turned to suppliers outside the West like India. **********The movement of a convoy of missiles though Beijing in March prompted concern about possible Chinese missiles sales because they appeared to be headed toward the port of Tianjin. **********An Administration official said today that they may have been short-range surface-to-surface missiles, which would not be formally covered by China's assurance not to sell medium-range missiles to the Middle East. Or they may have been surface-to-air missiles for attacking aircraft. **********The official said it was not clear whether the missiles were shipped outside China or sent elsewhere in the country.
