https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/16/world.main_headline: Monks of Mandalay Feel Lash of the Army
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/16/world.print_headline: Monks of Mandalay Feel Lash of the Army
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/16/world.body_text: **********Mandalay is home to more than 100 Buddhist monasteries and some 70,000 orange-robed monks and novices, who fill the streets at the crack of dawn in search of their daily rice. Nowhere else does Burmese society so symbolize the devotion to religion and ritual as in this city of nearly one million people. **********But in October the military Government, which had until then reserved its violent tactics for opposition leaders and protesting students, took on the church as well. It began a campaign to purify the Buddhist religion throughout Myanmar, formerly known as Burma, and the brunt of the attack was borne by the monks in Mandalay. **********The Government arrested 200 monks for engaging in politics, in particular for staging a boycott against the military. Then, as if to pacify the abbots as well as the indignant population, military leaders made pilgrimages to several monasteries. They took food and lavish gifts like imported color televisions. **********Monks here have played a prominent part in the opposition to military rule ever since anti-Government demonstrations erupted in 1988. Those demonstrations led in the fall of that year to a nationwide military crackdown in which more than 2,000 people died. **********The monks of Mandalay were strongly supported by the country's opposition party, the National League for Democracy, which won elections in May this year. But instead of handing over power to the victors, the military Government has arrested many of them. **********This is a city of fear, where soldiers are as omnipresent as monks. Early in the morning, as the monks make their rounds for rice, soldiers jog in phalanxes, grunting their way past the entrances of monasteries. **********At the Myataung monastery, one ofthe main compounds raided by troops, three soldiers were slumped on a bench, their rifles propped up beside them. **********"The state order forbids you to enter this monastery," a security agent told a foreign visitor as the soldiers blocked the way. The agent, who had followed the foreigner by motorcycle to the monastery, added, "I cannot tell you when the order will be lifted." **********It was not clear whether this monastery and others in the southwest of the city were still occupied by troops, but local residents and foreign diplomats said that the dramatic military presence had diminished substantially since the height of the crackdown in the last week of October. **********The confrontation began on Aug. 8, when monks and students staged a small demonstration in Mandalay tomark the second anniversary of the nationwide crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators. The crackdown ultimately led to a declaration of martial law, which is still in effect. **********The August protest led to clashes in which security guards fired at demonstrators and killed a monk. **********Militant monks then called a meeting at which they persuaded thousands of others to join a boycott of the military by refusing to accept alms from military men and their families. **********While the army was invulnerable to direct attack, it seemed susceptible to this spiritual boycott. Giving alms to monks is considered an extremely important way of earning merit for the next life. **********On Oct. 20, the State Law and Order Restoration Council, the military's governing body, ordered an end to the boycott, and said it would bring recalcitrant monks before a tribunal, which could conceivably sentence them to death. It also announced the abolition of certain Buddhist sects, apparently those linked with the unrest. **********Abbots and senior monks have signed documents announcing that they have abandoned the boycott. **********Now, with the army having apparently succeeded in its crackdown on the monks, diplomats say that the Myanmar Government has crushed the last significant source of opposition. **********"The military is absolutely determined to crush anyone who does not go along with it," said a diplomat in the capital, Yangon, formerly called Rangoon. "It has crushed the spirit of everyone."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/12/world.main_headline: A Firm Step, a Smile: Mandela Floods the Screen
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/12/world.print_headline: SOUTH AFRICA'S NEW ERA: TV CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;   A Firm Step, a Smile: Mandela Floods the Screen
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/12/world.body_text: **********The moment was worth the wait. Along the road leading out of Victor Verster prison he appeared, hand in hand with his wife as though strolling to Sunday church, and everything we had been hearing of the man's dignity and strength was there on the screen. **********He walked slowly, bearing erect, expression composed. He waved a little, then more vigorously with both arms, shook someone's hand and smiled slightly, gave the clenched-fist salute. And then it was over; Nelson and Winnie Mandela were in the limousine that would take them to Cape Town, and the people who had been waiting for hours for a glimpse rushed forward to touch the car. The networks can be forgiven for the somewhat reverential tone of their coverage. **********Ted Koppel of ABC News, who had been talking pretty steadily, uninterrupted by commercials, for most of the 80-minute wait, repeatedly resorting to compliments on Cape Town's natural beauty and splendid weather, understandably welcomed the first view of the freed leader as ''a moment best left alone without commentary.'' But the commentator for South African television, which was supplying the pictures to all the American networks, did not leave it alone. He noted, ''There is a very nice picture of Mr. Mandela and his wife.'' **********Cape Town, Then Soweto **********Until then, the morning had been mostly commentary along with background pieces, interviews and pictures of the scene near the prison as photographers, security forces and Mandela supporters waited. From one angle, the flag of the African National Front, outlawed until the other day, seemed to be flying over the heads of a group of policemen. **********Outside Mr. Mandela's home in Soweto, which he would not reach for at least another 24 hours, a party had been going on all night, and from the look of things would go on until he arrived, with young people dancing, singing, chanting, cheering. Two men were painting the black, gold and green colors of the flag of the African National Congress on the Mandelas' garage. In an inadvertent feat of timing, the CBS News camera broke away from Dan Rather in Johannesburg to relay pictures from Cape Town at the instant that the ABC News camera broke away from Mr. Koppel in Cape Town to relay pictures from Johannesburg. Negotiating on the Air?  Tom Brokaw of NBC News, who had daringly not joined Mr. Rather and Peter Jennings of ABC in Moscow a few days earlier for the meeting of the Central Committee of the Communist Party, was on the spot in Cape Town, where he got into an argument with Denis Worral, a white South African politician, about the value of sanctions. The correspondents left little doubt as to whose side they were on. **********Mr. Koppel, first on the scene and somewhat more objective, began his reports from South Africa on Wednesday. On Thursday, ''Nightline'' showed what it could do by offering three major spokesmen for often clashing groups who chatted warily yet amiably, via Mr. Koppel, across the miles. **********From Cape Town, Foreign Minister Roelof W. Botha appealed to all his ''black brothers and friends'' to build a new South Africa; from London, Thabo Mbeki, who serves as Foreign Minister for the African National Congress, expressed restrained hope; and from Durban, Chief Mangosuthu Gathsa Buthelezi, the leader of the Zulu nation, welcomed the spirit of conciliation. Mr. Koppel said he realized that ''negotiations don't take place on television programs.'' But when Mr. Botha and Chief Buthelezi called for the lifting of sanctions and Mr. Mbeki responded ''it's still early days'' for that sort of thing, they were plainly talking at least as much to the world as to one another. **********The freeing of Mr. Mandela may not be as fraught with international consequence as the Moscow meeting, but it made for richer television, abounding in color and feeling and with a world-class hero at its center. A preview of the big moment came on Saturday morning, with the press conference at which F. W. de Klerk, the South African President, announced the ''open doors'' for Mr. Mandela. **********The cameras brought us dancing and singing in the dusty streets of Soweto set off by the announcement, and there was a jaunty Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu, the Anglican primate of southern Africa, in his cleric's fuchsia shirt, which seemed to have gotten brighter for the occasion. **********A Practiced Performer **********''Hallelujah!'' he cried, ''Hallelujah! Hallelujah!'' He did a little dance. ''Freedom is coming!'' he cried. ''Mind boggling!'' he cried and waved his arms. The Archbishop, a practiced television performer, had a fresh exclamation for every photographer, but even if his reactions were not altogether spontaneous, this South African best known to Americans personified the excitement. **********All the early reports, however, included cautions against expecting too much too soon. Winnie Mandela, interviewed by everybody, was restrained, and Mr. Brokaw talked to a black woman near Cape Town who had never heard of Nelson Mandela. On Sunday, CNN noted that the beaches and restaurants were as busy as ever and that South African television was devoting considerably less attention to the event than American television. **********As the light faded in Cape Town on Sunday, Mr. Mandela returned to the network channels. Standing on a balcony at City Hall, he spoke for about 15 minutes to an enormous crowd. David Brinkley of ABC, in Washington and at some emotional remove from his colleagues, observed by way of dry introduction, ''Whatever he says, I promise you, they will like.'' Again South African television fed the event to the American networks. But, like several of the other events, it was not carried live in South Africa itself.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/21/busin.main_headline: Harleysville to Buy a USLico Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/21/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Harleysville to Buy a USLico Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/21/busin.body_text: **********A Pennsylvania insurance company announced today that it planned to buy the property and casualty insurance operations of the USLico Corporation for $135 million in cash and notes. **********Harleysville Group Inc. and its parent company, the Harleysville Mutual Insurance Company, said they had signed a letter of intent to buy USLico's Hawkeye-Security Insurance Company, based in Des Moines. **********The deal also includes two Hawkeye-Security subsidiaries, the United Security Insurance Company, based in Des Moines, and the Western States Insurance Company, based in Freeport, Ill. **********USLico, based in Arlington, Va., would receive $93 million in cash from the Harleysville Group, $17 million in cash from Harleysville Mutual and $25 million in a seven-year 10 percent note from Harleysville Mutual. Hawkeye-Security would return to USLico 500,000 shares of USLico common stock on Jan. 2. **********The deal, subject to approval by regulators and the directors of the companies, would be effective Jan. 1. **********The companies to be acquired are represented by more than 1,000 independent agents in 15 Midwestern and Western states. **********''This acquisition provides us with a tremendous opportunity to achieve the strategic diversification we have sought since we began pursuit of our strategic goal to build a national network of regional insurance companies several years ago,'' Bradford W. Mitchell, chairman of the Harleysville Group, said in a statement. **********The move would extend the company's territory to 34 states, he said. **********In a separate announcement, Harleysville Mutual said it would sell its subsidiary the Harleysville Life Insurance Company to USLico for $17 million in the form of a seven-year 10 percent note. **********The Harleysville Group is a holding company for four East Coast property and casualty insurers, the Atlantic Insurance Company of Savannah, Ga., the Harleysville Insurance Company of New Jersey, the Huron Insurance Company and the Worcester Insurance Company in Massachusetts. **********The Harleysville Group also manages the operations of the Berkshire Mututal Insurance Group, based in Pittsfield, Mass. **********Last month, the Harleysville Group announced an agreement in principle to acquire the New York Casualty Insurance Company and the Phoenix General Insurance Company from the Phoenix Mutual Life Insurance Company. **********The Harleysville Group had net written premiums of $300.8 million in 1989 and assets of $568.5 million on Dec. 31.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/03/world.main_headline: Japan's Chief Said to Scold Aide for Slur Against Blacks
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/03/world.print_headline: Japan's Chief Said to Scold Aide for Slur Against Blacks
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/03/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan gave his new Justice Minister a stern warning for a racial slur against American blacks but will not demand his resignation, the Foreign Ministry's spokesman said today. **********The Justice Minister, Seiroku Kajiyama, said on Sept. 21 that American blacks and foreign prostitutes in Tokyo were similar because both destroyed good neighborhoods. **********The remark stirred a storm of protest in the United States, prompting condemnations by prominent politicians and a call for Japanese goods to be boycotted.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/15/busin.body_text: **********Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. had a net loss of $51 million in 1989, compared with earnings of $111 million in 1988, its parent company, the Prudential Insurance Company of America, reported yesterday. **********Robert C. Winters, chairman and chief executive of the parent company, attributed the loss to nonrecurring charges, including the costs of acquiring and integrating the Thomson McKinnon brokerage network. Pretax net income from continuing operations was $10 million, while revenues were $3.5 billion. **********''It's a tough period,'' Mr. Winters said at the company's annual news conference in New York. **********''Individual investors are staying away from the market,'' he added, and the firm must ''manage through these wrenching times.'' **********But he praised George L. Ball, the chairman of Prudential-Bache, as ''one of the finest executives in the securities business.'' Answering questions that had not been asked, he said, ''No, George's job is not in jeopardy and, no, Prudential-Bache is not for sale.'' **********Mr. Ball said there would be ''some staff reductions.'' **********The parent company said its net income for 1989 had fallen 10.4 percent, to $743 million, from $829 million a year earlier, while revenues climbed 14.7 percent, to $43.03 billion from $37.5 billion. **********The company reported earnings gains in its individual insurance, group, reinsurance and asset-management businesses, but lost money in residential real estate. It acquired Merrill Lynch & Company's realty and relocation businsses last year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/16/world.main_headline: Denying Pleas, Iraq Hangs British-Based Reporter
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/16/world.print_headline: Denying Pleas, Iraq Hangs British-Based Reporter
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/16/world.body_text: **********Defying all calls for clemency, Iraq today hanged an Iranian-born British journalist it had convicted of espionage, in what Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher described as ''an act of barbarism deeply repugnant to all civilized people.'' **********Britain recalled its Ambassador to Baghdad in protest but did not impose economic sanctions. **********''Mrs. Thatcher wanted him alive; we gave her the body,'' the Iraqi Information Minister, Latif Nassif Jassem, said in Baghdad after the remains of 31-year-old Farzad Bazoft were turned over to the British Embassy there. **********''At a time when the international scene shows many signs of hope and humanity, we have been reminded that there are still regimes capable of a pitiless disregard for human rights,'' Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd told the House of Commons today, expressing the Britain's sense of outrage. **********Mrs. Thatcher had appealed to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to spare Mr. Bazoft's life, reinforcing the appeal through friends like King Hussein of Jordan. King Hussein, ending an official visit to London today, was careful not to criticize the Iraqi leader. **********Donald Trelford, editor of The Observer, the British newspaper for which Mr. Bazoft, a 31-year-old Iranian exile, was writing when he was arrested last September, said that Mr. Bazoft was ''a professional colleague who gave his life for trying to report the truth.'' **********Mr. Hurd said that the British response would enable diplomats to continue to work for the release of Daphne Parish, the 52-year-old British nurse in Baghdad convicted with Mr. Bazoft and sentenced to 15 years' imprisonment, and of Ian Richter, a British business executive sentenced to life imprisonment in 1986 for alleged bribery of Iraqi officials. **********Britain canceled the departure for Baghdad of a trade delegation from Birmingham, Mr. Hurd said, but would not expel the Iraqi Ambassador to London or cancel a $:250 million ($400 million) midterm line of credit for trade with Iraq, on which Britain ran a profitable $571 million surplus last year. It also expelled six Iraqis from military training courses in Britain and asked them to leave. **********The Iraqi authorities accused Mr. Bazoft of spying for both Israel and Britain, but never, apparently, for Iran, with which Iraq fought a costly war of attrition for eight years until 1988. At his trial last week, Mr. Bazoft withdrew a videotaped confession in which he said he had been spying for Israel. He was arrested last September after he traveled to the Al-Iskandariya military site south of Baghdad to check reports that an explosion there had killed 700 people. **********Mr. Bazoft was the eldest of four children of a manager of the national Iranian oil company. He came to England in 1975 to study at the North Oxfordshire Technical College. He was unmarried and had no relatives here, friends said. ---- U.S. Deplores Hanging WASHINGTON, March 15 (Reuters) - The United States deplored today what it called Iraq's undue haste in hanging Mr. Bazoft. **********''We deplore Iraq's decision to ignore the many international appeals for clemency and the undue haste with which the sentence was carried out,'' said the State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler. **********Anxiety in Journalist Groups **********The Committee to Protect Journalists, a New York-based organization that had sought clemency for Mr. Bazoft, said his death marked the first time a foreign journalist had been executed by a government since the committee began monitoring violence toward journalists in 1981. **********''What amounts to the assassination of Mr. Bazoft constitutes not only a human tragedy, but a threat to all foreign correspondents,'' said Seymour Topping, chairman of the international communication committee of the American Society of Newspaper Editors and director of editorial development at The New York Times Company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/12/busin.body_text: **********Several large agencies have made changes among their staff members responsible for creating ads. **********Sue Read will join Ayer from Lintas in December, as co-director of creative services, sharing duties with Keith Gould. Ms. Read has worked on several high-profile campaigns, including Diet Coke, Kodak and Burger King. A person knowledgeable about the move said her new salary would be $500,000 a year. **********Ms. Read would not comment, except to confirm that she was going to Ayer. **********At Ogilvy & Mather, four executive creative directors were named: Gordon Bowen, Rick Boyko, Vel Richey-Rankin and Richard Fowler. **********Grey Advertising is also trying to improve its creative team. Matt Collins, Bruce Glickman and Holly Russell were all named vice presidents and creative supervisors. Tony Alfano and Denise O'Bleness were promoted to vice presidents and associate creative directors. **********And Hal Riney & Partners in New York has found a replacement for Helayne Spivak, who recently jumped to Young & Rubicam. Joe O'Neill will join Riney as executive creative director. He was formerly with Waring & LaRosa.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/14/busin.body_text: **********The struggling Winnebago Industries has chosen not to declare a semiannual cash dividend on its stock, the first time it has omitted a dividend in five years. The company's chairman, John K. Hanson, said the decision had been based on the current slump in the sales of motor homes, the company's main product. The move follows losses in the last two quarters and comes four weeks after Winnebago dismissed its president and chief executive, Richard Conner, who had held the post four months.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/26/world.main_headline: Evolution in Europe;   YELTSIN IS AHEAD IN RUSSIAN VOTING
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/26/world.print_headline: Evolution in Europe;   YELTSIN IS AHEAD IN RUSSIAN VOTING
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/26/world.body_text: **********Boris N. Yeltsin, a rival and fierce critic of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, took the lead early this morning in the contest for the presidency of the Russian republic - a job that would give him an important power base. **********Preliminary results after a first round of secret balloting by the republic's Parliament showed Mr. Yeltsin leading his main opponent, 497 votes to 473. A third candidate trailed with 32 votes, and 31 members of Parliament crossed out all three candidates on the ballot, a deputy who saw the results early this morning said. **********To win the job as leader of Russia, the most populous republic in the Soviet Union, Mr. Yeltsin needs 531 votes - or a majority of the 1,060 representatives elected to the Russian republic's Parliament. A second round of voting is expected today on the candidacy of Mr. Yeltsin, who broke with Mr. Gorbachev three years ago and became a popular hero. **********Gorbachev Assails Yeltsin **********Mr. Yeltsin's original chief opponent, Aleksandr V. Vlasov, the Prime Minister of the Russian republic, withdrew his candidacy at the last minute on Friday. Mr. Vlasov, who was head of the Interior Ministry under Mr. Gorbachev for two years, had been seen as the choice of the moderate wing of the Communist Party and presumably of Mr. Gorbachev. **********Mr. Gorbachev did not openly endorse any of the candidates for the Russian presidency - there were originally 12 - but earlier this week he made a guest appearance before the Russian Parliament to deliver a severe criticism of Mr. Yeltsin, whom he accused of setting ''the people of the republic at loggerheads.'' **********In a campaign speech on Friday, Mr. Yeltsin offered a program of rapid change, starting with greater autonomy for the Russian republic within the Soviet Union, renegotiation of relations involving the republic's constituent parts, closing of nuclear testing sites, creation of a separate and convertible Russian currency, and establishing an independent Russian K.G.B. **********'Relaxed Manner' of Change **********Mr. Yeltsin, who as Moscow party chief three years ago broke with Mr. Gorbachev over the need for faster economic changes, today criticized the Soviet Government's new plan to raise prices. He said the move toward a market economy should not be made ''at the expense of the people.'' **********''The main thing is for us to find the only right solution to the issue: how to switch over to a market in a relaxed manner, without lowering the living standards of the population,'' he said in a speech that won him prolonged applause. **********Mr. Yeltsin became a popular hero in 1987, when he was dismissed from his job as leader of the Moscow Communist Party organization. He attracts huge crowds, particularly in the Russian republic. Since winning an at-large seat in Moscow to the Supreme Soviet in 1989 with 89 percent of the vote, he has become a leader of the insurgent parliamentary opposition organization called the Interregional Group. Repeated attacks on him for his maverick views by members of the party and Government establishment have seemed only to make him more popular. **********The sudden withdrawal of Mr. Vlasov created a quandary for moderate Communist Party members, who had to choose between Mr. Yeltsin and his most serious rival, Ivan K. Polozkov, a doctrinaire party first secretary from the region of Krasnodar in southern Russia who recently created a controversy with a crackdown against owners of private cooperatives. **********Aviation Instructor Trails **********The two men represent the opposite ends of the Soviet political spectrum. Mr. Yeltsin is backed by Democratic Russia, a liberal group that advocates a swift, clean break with the past, while Mr. Polozkov, a staunch defender of socialist ideals, has the support of conservatives in the Communist Party apparatus, who are closer to the hard-liner Yegor K. Ligachev than to Mr. Gorbachev. **********A third candidate, Vladimir Morokin, was also on the ballot distributed to the deputies. But Mr. Morokin, a 44-year-old senior instructor at an aviation institute from the Tatar region and a nonparty member, was seen as running a distant third. **********The contest for the Russian presidency, featuring the highly visible and flamboyant Mr. Yeltsin, has captured popular attention more than any other election to a top post. The bulletin boards in the corridor outside the meeting hall are draped in telegrams sent to deputies from across the republic, urging, chastising and in some cases browbeating their representatives to vote for their candidate. **********''The miners of the Donets Basin region demand that the Russian Socialist Federative Soviet Republic stand up in defense of Mother Russia - without the Communist Party and usurping powers,'' said a message from miners in the Ukraine, asking for support of Yeltsin. **********Backers Send Messages **********Five members of the Miklashevsky family from Moscow sent a telegram asking the deputies to vote for Mr. Polozkov, and to ''stop disarmament, market economy and to bring money reform to a popular vote.'' **********A collective of transport workers from Leningrad warned their representatives to vote for Mr. Yeltsin, ''or else,'' their telegram read, ''we will call for a strike.'' **********Vasily Sondikov, a deputy from the oil-rich Tyumen region, said all but two members of his 20-member delegation support Mr. Yeltsin. ''We need this kind of man - someone who is strong and decisive,'' he said. **********Mikhail Trubitsyn, a doctor from the ancinet Russian city of Vladimir, said he supported Mr. Polozkov because ''he will preserve Russia and not break up the Soviet Union in the process,'' and because he understands Russians' reluctance to endorse business practices that make some people rich while leaving the rest poor. ''He understands the social psychology,'' said Mr. Trubitsyn. **********Brisk Communist Lobbying **********Mr. Polozkov, in his campaign speech today, said the Russian people were not ready to go to a market system. ''I am for a market in principle,'' he said. ''But at the same time, I regard idealizing a market economy as dangerous, particularly based on private ownership of the means of production.'' **********Mr. Vlasov, who until last week was regarded as the favorite to win the election, was widely criticized after he gave a poor performance in a speech outlining the state of the Russian republic's economy. The question today was whether party loyalists simply switched their allegiance to Mr. Polozkov, or whether moderates would decide to resist the apparat's distrust of Mr. Yeltsin. **********Deputies described brisk lobbying by Communist Party officials, particularly within their local delegations. But many deputies were divided between the demands of their local bosses and of rank-and-file voters, among whom Mr. Yeltsin is considered the popular choice. **********An unpublished poll on the Russian republic presidency, made public Friday by the All-Union Center for the Study of Public Opinion, said 41 percent of people interviewed were undecided, while 29 percent supported Mr. Yeltsin. Only 3 percent supported Mr. Vlasov, while Mr. Polozkov was chosen by 1 percent of those interviewed. **********Deputies said Mr. Yeltsin's strength - estimated at a hard-core 350 vote -lies in the Moscow and Leningrad delegations, made up mostly of liberals, and also in the region of Ural Mountains, where he began his career, and other industrial areas. Mr. Polozkov's strength comes from more rural regions in the south and north of Russia, they said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/15/busin.main_headline: Company News;   I.B.M. Introduction May Come Earlier
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/15/busin.print_headline: Company News;   I.B.M. Introduction May Come Earlier
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/15/busin.body_text: **********A computer industry analyst said he expected the International Business Machines Corporation to introduce the next generation of its most powerful mainframe computer earlier than had generally been expected. The analyst, Rick Martin of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., told Reuters yesterday that he expected I.B.M. to upgrade its existing 3090 mainframe computers to permit an incremental switch to the new technology, known by the code name Summit within the industry, in 1991. **********Another analyst, who asked not to be identified, said he believed that the Summit introduction was ahead of schedule and could come as early as June. Introduction of the new mainframe line is crucial for I.B.M. if it is to have significant revenue and earnings growth this year, he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/20/busin.main_headline: Pirelli in Talks On Soviet Deal
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/20/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Pirelli in Talks On Soviet Deal
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/20/busin.body_text: **********Pirelli of Italy is negotiating a joint venture to produce car tires in the Soviet Union, a Moscow-based Pirelli official said. Finding quality tires is difficult in the Soviet Union, where motorists drive on poorly maintained streets full of bumps and potholes. Soviet-made tires have a reputation of shredding easily and have a short lifespan. **********Output from the proposed joint venture would be sold on the Soviet market. The partners hope to sell some of their tires to a proposed Fiat automobile plant near Moscow, but the tire venture is not dependent on a contract with Fiat, the Pirelli official said. The Pirelli official said that the company would pay about $250 million to own a one-third stake in the new plant.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/08/world.main_headline: Teheran Denies Direct Discussions With U.S. on Hostages in Beirut;   Hostage Demands Pressed
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/08/world.print_headline: Teheran Denies Direct Discussions With U.S. on Hostages in Beirut;   Hostage Demands Pressed
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/08/world.body_text: **********A clandestine pro-Iranian group believed to be holding three of the eight Americans missing in Lebanon said today that it would not free the hostages before its demands are met. **********The group, the Revolutionary Justice Organization, declared in a statement delivered to the offices of the daily newspaper An Nahar in mainly Muslim West Beirut that ''no one must expect a solution to the problem of the hostages except within the framework of solutions which we have offered so many times.'' **********The handwritten statement in Arabic was accompanied by a black-and-white photograph of Joseph James Cicippio, 59 years old, the acting comptroller of the American University of Beirut, who was kidnapped in September 1986. **********The group is widely thought also to hold the school principal Frank Herbert Reed and the book salesman Edward Austin Tracy, both of whom were abducted in West Beirut. **********Two other underground factions, Islamic Holy War and Islamic Holy War for the Liberation of Palestine, have asserted responsibility for seizing five other Americans. Ten other Westerners are also missing here. **********U.S. Encouraged by Statement **********WASHINGTON, March 7 (Special to The New York Times) - The White House said today that it was encouraged by statements from Mr. Rafsanjani, but that it had ''no direct knowledge'' that any of the captives might be released. **********Asked about Mr. Rafansjani's statements at his daily briefing, Marlin Fitzwater, President Bush's spokesman, said: ''We're encouraged by the comments. They are in line with statements that we have seen in recent days and weeks that there was some interest in Iran in better relations with the West.'' **********''We hope that that's the case and that it will result in release of the hostages, but we have no direct knowledge that that is going to happen, and we have no direct knowledge of Mr. Rafsanjani's motives or purposes in making those remarks,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/29/busin.main_headline: Agreement Allows Minolta To Market Polaroid Camera
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/29/busin.print_headline: Agreement Allows Minolta To Market Polaroid Camera
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/29/busin.body_text: **********In an arrangement that could lead to closer links between two major photography companies, the Polaroid Corporation and the Minolta Camera Company announced yesterday that Minolta would sell a Polaroid instant camera under its own name. **********Minolta will have the exclusive right to market Polaroid's top-of-the-line Spectra Pro camera in the United States as the Minolta Instant Pro. Polaroid, based in Cambridge, Mass., said it was the first time it had made an instant camera available to another manufacturer for consumer markets. **********In making the announcement, I. MacAllister Booth, Polaroid's chief executive, said the agreement was ''a first step to explore a potential long-term collaboration between our two companies.'' Officials of both companies declined to speculate on what future projects were being considered. **********First Instant Model **********The agreement gives Minolta, which built its business selling 35 millimeter single-lens-reflex cameras, an instant model for the first time. An instant camera produces a picture within seconds, while conventional film needs processing. **********''We view this as another avenue of imaging,'' said John Jonny, a spokesman for Minolta (U.S.A.). ''It is not going to replace anything else, but it is a great party camera, and it has uses in industry as well.'' **********In a statement, Mr. Booth said: ''Minolta is one of the world's best-known and most highly respected camera manufacturers. This agreement will help to expand the market for instant photography to the benefit of both companies.'' **********Analysts described the agreement as a good one for Polaroid. ''The problem Polaroid has been facing is the steady loss of share to 35 millimeter cameras,'' said Eugene G. Glazer, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds. ''Now they are hooking up with a company that has a good brand name in 35 millimeter. That should help boost camera and film sales.'' **********But he cautioned, ''It is still an open question how big the market for instant photography is.'' **********Designed for Serious Amateurs **********A Polaroid official said the Spectra Pro model was designed for serious amateur photographers who tend to consume a lot of film and for business users, like real estate agents who take pictures of properties. Unlike some simpler instant cameras, the Spectra Pro comes equipped with a liquid crystal display control panel, a three-element glass lens and a special lens for taking close-ups. The suggested retail price is $219. **********Even bearing the Minolta name, the camera will use Polaroid's Spectra film and Polaroid will continue to manufacture the camera at its plant in Dumbarton, Scotland. In Japan, the camera will be sold only as a Polaroid. **********Polaroid introduced the Spectra Pro earlier this year, and a spokesman said limited quantities had become available in stores. The Minolta Instant Pro is expected to be available through Minolta's distribution network starting in August. **********A Minolta spokesman said this was not the first time it had sold products of other manufacturers. The company's small video recorders, he said, are made by Hitachi Ltd., another Japanese company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/06/world.main_headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Crisis Breathes Life Into a Moribund U.N. Panel
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/06/world.print_headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Crisis Breathes Life Into a Moribund U.N. Panel
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/06/world.body_text: **********The committee's fortunes were revived last month when the Soviet Union proposed a larger role for it in joint peacekeeping and military actions in and around the Arabian Peninsula. The United States, under pressure from other members of the Security Council not to go it alone against Iraq in the Persian Gulf, announced that it favored the plan, The Soviet Union had shown interest in the committee as early as 1987, when President Mikhail S. Gorbachev announced a major shift in Soviet policy on the United Nations. In urging that the United Nations be given a bigger role in finding political solutions to regional conflicts, Mr. Gorbachev urged that the moribund Military Staff Committee be revived and given the job of coordinating United Nations peacekeeping operations. **********The Soviet Viewpoint **********Last October, Deputy Foreign Minister Vladimir F. Potrovsky reiterated Mr. Gorbachev's proposal when he told Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar that the Military Staff Committee could be a useful forum for discussing peacekeeping operations and other ''politico-military'' affairs of the United Nations. **********Despite Moscow's renewed interest, no new role was given to the committee. That could be changing. Last month, after the Security Council resolution imposing a trade embargo on Iraq and occupied Kuwait, Under Secretary of State Robert Kimmett met with the representatives of the other four permanent members of the Security Council - the Soviet Union, China, Britain and France - to discuss ways in which the Military Staff Committee could help enforce the sanctions. **********A week later, in the discussion leading up to the Security Council resolution permitting military force to back up the sanctions, the Soviet Union insisted that the resolution include a directive that any military actions be coordinated ''as appropriate'' though the Military Staff Committee. **********Historically, the United States has shied away from any commitment that would require American forces to serve under foreign commanders. That sentiment persists, though an American diplomat noted: ''It's not only Americans. No big power wants its people serving under another country's flag.'' **********'Certainly Worth a Try' **********But Brian Urquhart, a former Under Secretary General and a veteran of 40 years with the United Nations, said that the Military Staff Committee is only supposed to have an advisory role. **********''Its job is to advise the Security Council on who should command, on logistics, on rules of engagement, not to do those things itself,'' Mr. Urquhart said. ''It would be difficult to make it work, but it is certainly worth a try.'' **********Representatives of the permanent members are expected to propose that the Security Council await the findings of the special panel it has set up to see whether the sanctions are being observed before discussing a new role for the Military Staff Committee. The sanctions panel's report is not expected before the Military Staff Committee meets again on Friday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/10/busin.body_text: **********Globex, an electronic global trading system developed by Chicago's futures exchanges, will begin to be tested at the end of the first quarter of next year, a spokesman for one of the exchanges said last week. **********Globex is being developed by the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, the Chicago Board of Trade and Reuters Holdings P.L.C. It will link investors in North America, Europe and Asia through an electronic system for trading futures and options contracts. It will operate when the trading floors of the Mercantile Exchange and the Board of Trade are closed. **********Andrew Yemma, a spokesman for the Mercantile Exchange, said the Globex tests would involve about 250 terminals in Chicago, New York and London. The results of the tests will determine the actual starting date for Globex. **********Globex was the idea of the Mercantile Exchange. https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/30/busin.main_headline: Campbell to Shed Its Fresh-Foods Group
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/30/busin.print_headline: Campbell to Shed Its Fresh-Foods Group
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/30/busin.body_text: **********In a further move to cut excess capacity and raise profits, the Campbell Soup Company said it planned to sell small North American operations with total annual sales of more than $300 million. **********The move by Campbell, one of the world's largest food companies, is expected to result in after-tax charges of $302 million against earnings for the 1990 fiscal year. Analysts have been projecting those earnings at as much as $325 million, or $2.50 a share, so the divestitures should lead to a slightly profitable or break-even year. **********The North American action follows a similar move in May to sell off poorly performing European operations with annual revenue totaling more than $200 million. **********Volatile Profit Margins **********But the move announced yesterday also signals Campbell's withdrawal from one of the three major sectors of the modern supermarket. The closings come mainly in refrigerated fresh foods. Fast distribution of these items is sometimes difficult and their profit margins are volatile because of changing commodity prices. **********The main asset being put on the block is Campbell's Fresh Foods Group, which includes mushroom farms in eight states and Canada; a refrigerated salad business, and the Marie's brand salad dressing. Also scheduled for sale is a frozen poultry operation and a salmon processor. **********The drive into fresh foods was a prime goal of Campbell's previous president and chief executive, R. Gordon McGovern, who retired early last year. In January, David W. Johnson, former chief executive of the Gerber Products Company, was named to replace him. **********In an interview yesterday, Mr. Johnson said, ''I'm very focused on producing cash so I can build the sinews of war.'' He said he was referring to competition with other food giants like Philip Morris's Kraft General Foods, the country's largest food company; Conagra, the second largest, and H. J. Heinz, one of the most profitable. **********Campbell will retain relatively strong businesses in the other two major supermarket sectors - frozen foods, like Mrs. Paul's fish sticks, and shelf-stable non-refrigerated foods, like Campbell's soup and Pepperidge Farm cookies. These highly processed foods have higher profit margins. **********The most recent restructuring charges include writing off about $113 million in good will on Campbell's struggling Freshbake Foods operations in Britain. Good will is the accounting term for the premium over book value paid to purchase an asset. **********The proposed sales equal about 5 percent of Campbell's annual revenue of $5.67 billion in the year ended July 31, 1989. Net income last year totaled $13.1 million, or 90 cents a share, after $261 million in restructuring charges. **********Analysts reacted favorably, if without surprise, to yesterday's announcement, which was in keeping with Mr. Johnson's stated goals. **********William Leach, an analyst with Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette, raised his earnings estimate for the 1991 fiscal year to $3.05 a share from $3. **********Investors responded favorably. On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Campbell Soup shares rose 75 cents, to $57.25. **********Family Divided on Future **********The moves come at a time when the Dorrance family, which owns 58 percent of Campbell's common stock, is divided about the future of Campbell, which has substantially underperformed the rest of the food industry. A minority faction of the Dorrances, owning 17.4 percent of the company, announced in January that it favored selling Campbell, prompting months of takeover rumors on Wall Street. **********Mr. Johnson noted that members of both Dorrance factions sit on Campbell's board and that he is in constant communication with the family. ''Whether you want to sell it or keep it,'' Mr. Johnson said, ''this is something that will be absolutely superb. Nobody in the family loses with what I'm doing.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/05/world.main_headline: Iran Reported Ready to Restore British Ties
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/05/world.print_headline: Iran Reported Ready to Restore British Ties
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/05/world.body_text: **********President Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran said today that his Government was willing to restore diplomatic relations with Britain, which Iran severed in March 1989 as a result of its anger over the novel ''The Satanic Verses,'' Iranian news organizations reported. **********The reports came in the wake of comments by Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd, who praised Islam and stressed that Britain had no responsibility for the publication of the novel, which Iranian leaders say blasphemes Islam. **********Reacting cautiously, the British Government said Iran had not yet contacted it through formal channels -meaning the Swedish embassy in Teheran, which is looking out for British interests in Iran. **********And a spokesman for the British Foreign Office also said other issues blocked the resumption of normal relations. ''We've noted the report with interest and we'll study it, but obstacles remain to better relations and we're looking for a substantive gesture of good will from the Iranian authorities,'' he said. **********One obstacle is Iran's imprisonment since December 1985 of Roger Cooper, a British businessman. No formal charges have been brought against him, although Iranian news organizations labeled him a spy. **********The other is the British hostages held in Lebanon: Terry Waite, Jackie Mann and John McCarthy. A fourth hostage, Brian Keenan, is from Northern Ireland, but his family has asked him to be classified as Irish in the hope that might increase his chances of being released. **********''We feel the Iranians have a very significant part to play'' in getting the hostages released, the Foreign Office spokesman said. **********A third condition has been the removal of the order for Muslims to kill Salman Rushdie, the author of ''The Satanic Verses.'' Attacking the novel as blasphemous, Iran's leader at the time, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, issued that death order, or ''fatwa,'' in February 1989. Since then Mr. Rushdie, a British citizen who was born into a Muslim family in India, has been in hiding. **********Foreign Office Optimistic **********A month after the fatwa, Iran severed diplomatic ties with Britain, saying it had shown disrespect for Islam by refusing to condemn Mr. Rushdie and his novel. **********The British Foreign Office spokesman seemed optimistic today that if the Iranian news reports were true then the fatwa would be lifted. ''We feel we're on the way to resolving the fatwa issue,'' he said. **********In the last two months, British leaders, including Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, have made several statements praising Islam. **********But in a letter to a Member of Parliament that was made public on Wednesday, Mr. Hurd not only praised Islam but also distanced Britain from the publication of ''The Satanic Verses.'' **********He called Islam ''one of the world's great religions'' and said that ''we have the greatest respect for it and its values.'' **********He added: ''The British Government had nothing to do with the publishing of ''The Satanic Verses. Nor has it encouraged its publication in other countries. There is no question of the British Government or people wishing to insult Islam.'' **********On Friday, the Iranian press agency quoted an Iranian cleric as saying the comments ''had almost met the conditions'' for restoring relations. That was followed by today's reports from Tehran Radio and the agency that the President and Iran's National Security Council had instructed the Foreign Ministry to work toward establishing normal relations. **********Iran Says It Will Take Steps **********Teheran Radio said: ''The obstacles to the re-establishment of diplomatic relations between Iran and Britain have been eliminated and the Foreign Ministry was delegated by the council to take the necessary steps to re-establish ties.'' **********British officials said they were not certain if Iran's initiative was linked to the invasion of Kuwait by Iraq, Iran's archenemy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/30/world.main_headline: Marxist Universities In Germany Protest Kohl Housecleaning
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/30/world.print_headline: Marxist Universities In Germany Protest Kohl Housecleaning
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/30/world.body_text: **********Three months after the Germans celebrated their national unity with a holiday, teachers and students at universities in what used to be Communist East Germany fear for the future. **********Hundreds of professors and students packed into the big Humboldt University in eastern Berlin on Friday to protest steps by Government officials who are moving to sweep out remnants of Marxist scholarship. The universities are fighting back, with charges of western German patronizing that they say is hindering a self-purification process. **********At the meeting in the main assembly room, still called the Marx-Engels Auditorium, there was only thin applause when the dean of the medical school, Dr. Harald Mau, called for the voluntary departure of Communist teachers who "distorted scholarship." "I demand this," he said. "Renewal without this is impossible." **********But there was stormy, rhythmic applause when the rector, Heinrich Fink, accused the Government of stripping the school of its autonomy and pledged to test the constitutionality of the Government steps. **********The history of the Humboldt University stretches back to the glory days of German scholarship. Situated along eastern Berlin's broad Unter den Linden boulevard, it was once known as the royal Friedrich-Wilhelm University, but was renamed by the Communists for the 19th-century scholars Wilhelm and Alexander von Humboldt. **********After the Communist takeover following World War II, it became the showpiece of Communist control of education, forcing dissident professors in 1948 to desert to West Berlin, where they founded the Free University. **********With the fall of Communism, Chancellor Helmut Kohl's conservative Christian Democrats say that since the universities have not done their housecleaning, Government education planners will have to step in. But measures designed to push out former Communist professors and rid the universities of institutes dealing mainly with Communist theory and practice have bogged down in the intricacies of labor law and the resistance of teachers fighting for their jobs. **********Government officials have reached an agreement with Humboldt University to abolish and then re-establish the law, philosophy, history and teacher training departments, affecting about one-quarter of the nearly 20,000 teachers and students there. **********At Karl Marx University in Leipzig, the institutes of law and political science are to be closed along with the journalism school, whose training courses for Communist propagandists earned it the nickname "The Red Cloister." **********But Prof. Fink said Humboldt University would go to court to fight Government interference. "We now find ourselves in a state of law," he said, "and we will employ all the means that we were once unable to use." Students have been organizing strikes and occupying university buildings in Leipzig, Halle and Rostock, on the Baltic Sea, to press demands for maintenance of their schools.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/24/busin.body_text: **********In the most striking indication yet of how the woes of the ''junk bond'' market have spread to the savings and loan industry, the Government today seized the Imperial Savings and Loan Association, one of California's largest savings institutions. **********Imperial, which is based in San Diego and is held by the Imperial Corporation of America, holds junk bonds with a face value of more than $1.3 billion, making it the industry's second-largest junk bond investor, behind the Columbia Savings and Loan Association of Beverly Hills, Calif. Columbia holds more than $4 billion of the securities, which pay a high yield because they are used to finance high-risk ventures. **********Imperial and Columbia were two of the largest customers of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., and both worked closely with the securities firm's former junk bond chief, Michael R. Milken. Drexel, which pioneered the junk bond market, collapsed last week as its parent company filed for bankruptcy protection from its creditors. **********Big Write-Downs Expected **********Columbia is expected to show write-downs in the value of its junk bond portfolio of several hundred million dollars in its financial results for the last three months of 1989, although the institution remains solvent. The Government has already seized two other savings institutions with big junk bond investments, Centrust Bank of Miami, which was taken over earlier this month, and City Federal Savings Bank of Somerset, N.J., which was taken over in December. **********Besides Imperial, which has $9.7 billion in assets, regulators today took over the Mercury Savings and Loan Association of Huntington Beach, Calif., with $2.2 billion in assets. Mercury's troubles stemmed from the failure of the savings and loan's two biggest borrowers to complete hotel-building projects, forcing Mercury to foreclose on the properties and take large losses. **********Imperial has been battered over the last two years by a series of bad loans and investments in a variety of fields, including its relationship with a fast-growing automobile dealership that went into bankruptcy. But the deterioration of its junk bond portfolio proved to be its biggest problem. **********Effect of Stricter Rules **********Under the Government's stricter new regulations contained in the industry bailout bill signed last August, savings institutions must value junk bond holdings at their market prices rather than at face value, as they had been allowed to do previously. **********As junk bond prices declined last fall, Imperial was forced to reduce its portfolio's value by about $200 million through the end of November, wiping out the institution's capital, which is its buffer against losses. **********The Government indicated that Imperial had to take further write-downs in December, although it did not provide any precise figures. The Office of Thrift Supervision, the primary Federal regulator for savings and loans, said Imperial's most basic level of capital had fallen to negative $60.1 million as of Dec. 31. **********Further Losses Foreseen **********Janis L. Smith, a spokeswoman for the Office of Thrift Supervision, said the additional losses from Imperial's junk bond portfolio in December were substantial. She added, ''There was also the expectation of further substantial write-downs in the first two months of this year, and that had a bearing on the decision'' to place Imperial into conservatorship. **********In a statement, the Office of Thrift Supervision said, ''Due to Imperial's weak financial condition and sustained losses, there was no possibility of its replenishing capital without Federal assistance.'' **********Imperial and Mercury now join the hundreds of other institutions that have been put in the hands of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the Government agency set up last summer under the bailout legislation to merge, sell or liquidate failed savings and loan companies. Junk Bond Holdings of U.S.  The Government now controls at least $3 billion of junk bonds held by the institutions it has seized. Wall Street executives have expressed some concern that the Government might try to sell the holdings quickly, further depressing prices in that market. So far, however, regulators have given no indication that they plan to move quickly in disposing of the bonds, and most analysts think the Government will probably hold on to at least a portion of the securities for some time in the hope that the market will turn up. **********Executives at Imperial spent the last several months trying to convince regulators that they had developed a plan to return the institution to health without Government aid. The plan called for Imperial to sell half of its assets and generate earnings from mortgage lending and investments in mortgage-backed securities. **********Regulators, however, expressed skepticism about the plan and ordered Imperial last month to halt all lending and investment operations. **********Rapid Growth in the 1980's **********Imperial, which was founded in 1950, grew rapidly during the 1980's by taking advantage of California's liberal savings and loan regulations to invest in fields far removed from traditional mortgage lending and deposit taking. Under Kenneth J. Thygerson, who resigned under pressure as chairman last summer, Imperial backed such ventures as the company that imported the Yugo automobile, which proved to be a sales failure. It also provided automobile loans to customers of a Los Angeles dealership that later turned out be involved in what several lawsuits contend was a huge fraud. **********Mr. Thygerson also led the push into junk bonds, arguing that the risks could be properly managed. **********Mercury, by contrast, had long prided itself on sticking close to traditional savings-and-loan activities. Its chairman, Leonard Shane, was a former chairman of the United States League of Savings Institutions, a large trade group, and was a prominent spokesman for the industry.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/30/world.main_headline: Upheaval in the East: Soviet Union;   KREMLIN BYPASSED IN MEDIATION OFFER
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/30/world.print_headline: Upheaval in the East: Soviet Union;   KREMLIN BYPASSED IN MEDIATION OFFER
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/30/world.body_text: **********A new sort of political initiative has emerged beyond the Kremlin's orbit with the resourceful Baltic separatist movements persuading their counterparts in the feuding southern republics of Armenia and Azerbaijan to hold peace talks in the Latvian republic. **********The talks, which are to begin on Thursday in Riga, the Latvian capital, are being treated by the three Baltic nationalist movements with all the care and protocol of a diplomatic initiative. **********The peace gathering amounts to the Baltic republics' latest challenge to Moscow's central authority, an attempt to show that effective governance in the Soviet Union has shifted to decentralized populist politics capable of dealing with problems that have the Kremlin in crisis. Armenia and Azerbaijan accepted the offer as a means of dealing with their conflict beyond the purview of the Kremlin. **********Central Authorities Absent **********Notably absent from the conference, whose details were carefully explained in Riga today after an initial announcement on Sunday, will be the central Government of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. It has sent thousands of troops in an attempt to calm the chaotic Transcaucasus region, but has been at a loss to stir political conciliation in the face of the strong nationalist passions now challenging the Kremlin. **********The Kremlin has not commented on the Baltic initiative. **********The Riga conference will, in effect, gather together five of the most powerful de facto movements in the new politics of separatism sweeping major parts of the Soviet Union in the face of the Kremlin's objections. Negotiators, who already are predicting some sort of a formal final agreement on at least some differences, will be representing populist movements in regions where the central Communist Party, the Moscow Government's normal conduit of political power, has suffered severe rebuff and change. **********The host popular fronts of Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia announced details of the conference in their joint organization, the Baltic Council, saying an agenda has already been formulated through the council's mediation with the Azerbaijani Popular Front and the Armenian National Movement. **********The agenda will focus on the Soviet troop occupation of the region, the large-scale refugee upheaval created by conflict, and various other problems described as ''humanitarian,'' including hostage-taking by warring factions. The Kremlin's sending of troops to defend central authority already has been widely criticized by separatists in both republics. **********The agenda diplomatically puts aside the most explosive and intractible issue of Nagorno-Karabakh, the Azerbaijani region where conflict has raged for two years between the majority Armenians and the Azerbaijanis who retain government control in the semi-autonomous enclave. **********Should the peace talks' implicit end run around the Kremlin produce substantial progress on easing a critical national problem, the popular front movements would undoubtedly compound their prestige as political forces in this changing, troubled nation. **********Originality Demonstrated **********In contrast to the Transcaucasus movements, the Baltic popular fronts have been free of pogrom-like excesses, although controversy has arisen among the Baltics' growing numbers of Russian immigrants because of new voting laws they consider discriminatory. **********In playing the role of national peacemaker, the leaders of the three Baltic movements once again demonstrated some of the political originality that has helped make their campaign one of the most confounding problems faced by the Moscow Government. **********The peace talks were announced as greater calm was reported in Baku, the Azerbaijani capital, which stormed by central Government soldiers nine days ago when Mr. Gorbachev ordered an end to the civil insurrection mounted there under the banner of the Azerbaijani Popular Front. Incidents of violence were decreasing, but only a few factories were reported operating in the general strike organized by the Popular Front. **********The situation in neighboring Armenia was reported still greatly troubled, with shortages of food and fuel worsening in the general railroad blockade being waged by militants in Armenia, presumably one of the ''humanitarian'' issues to be discussed in Riga. **********As in key parts of Azerbaijan, most factories in Armenia were reported idle in sketchy news reports tightly controlled by the central Government, which has closed the region to Western reporters. **********Schools have no heat, television transmission has been reduced and homes ''frequently'' remain unlit at night in Armenia, according to Tass, the Government press agency, which said more than 100 supply trains stood halted short of the Armenian border. **********Militants Withdrawing **********Officials of the Armenian and Azerbaijani movements said militant gangs had begun withdrawing from one of the most tense regions. This is around the border between Armenia and Nakhichevan, a western part of Azerbaijan on the Iranian border that is separated from the main part of the republic by a strip of Armenia. Weeks of protest there have focused on the related issue of Azerbaijani demands for closer ties to their Islamic kin across the Soviet border with Iran. **********Anda Anspoka, a spokesman for the Latvian Popular Front, said the Riga talks were likely to produce ''a serious document'' that would be signed by the leadership of all five separatist movements. **********Nagorno-Karabakh ''is not the problem of the moment,'' she said, adding that it was excluded from the agenda at the behest of the two principals. **********''It should be solved in a while, when the republics have more freedom,'' she said. **********The problem has only worsened in the two years since long-simmering enmities erupted when the enclave's Christian Armenians demanded independence of the Islamic Azerbaijanis. More than 100 civilians, mostly Armenians, have been killed in fighting in the region. **********Dispute Over Death Total **********In the Baku rebellion, Azerbaijani political demonstrations against Moscow's control degenerated this month into pogroms against the city's minority Armenians. The central Government news reported 125 people died when troops reclaimed authority, but popular front members contend many hundreds more were killed. **********The news of the Baltic peace initiative was not mentioned tonight on the main national news program, ''Vremya.'' On Saturday, the Azerbaijan Popular Front proposed peace talks with central officials, but there has been no reaction yet from the Kremlin. **********Russian Explains Action **********WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) - Apparently disagreeing with the Soviet Defense Minister, Ambassador Yuri V. Dubinin said today that troops were sent to Azerbaijan only to stop ''an orgy of killings'' and not to prevent nationalists from seizing power from the Communist Party. **********Mr. Dubinin said, ''The only objective was to stop the bloodshed and to restore peace.'' **********His account appeared at variance with that of Defense Minister Dmitri T. Yazov, who was quoted on Friday as telling a group of Soviet journalists in Baku, the regional capital, that the intervention was designed to prevent the Azerbaijani Popular Front from seizing power from the Communists. **********A State Department spokesman, Richard Boucher, said today: ''Certainly we found those comments disturbing, especially if they represent accurately Soviet policy.'' **********Mr. Dubinin, at a news conference designed to convey Soviet policy, said General Yazov had spoken only about measures taken against ''armed activities'' of the Azerbaijan Liberation Front.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/10/world.main_headline: Liberian President Captured by Rebels In a Fierce Gunfight
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/10/world.print_headline: Liberian President Captured by Rebels In a Fierce Gunfight
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/10/world.body_text: **********He said he could not confirm a report that Mr. Doe had been wounded but said, ''It could well be true.'']  According to sketchy reports reaching here from neighboring Liberia, the incident occurred outside the headquarters of the five-nation West African peacekeeping force sent into Liberia in an effort to end the civil war that began in December. **********More than 60 people, including dozens of Mr. Doe's bodyguards, were reportedly killed in the battle. The President himself was reported to have been shot in both legs before being taken away. **********By nightfall, there had been no word from a rival rebel faction led by Charles Taylor, which controls much of the country outside the capital. Liberia's civil war began last December when forces of the two rebel leaders invaded from the Ivory Coast, moving into Nimba County, about 300 miles northeast of Monrovia. **********The Liberian Government sent troops and provincial policemen to oust the rebels. By most accounts, the soldiers then went on a rampage, indiscriminately killing and maiming hundreds of unarmed civilians - people they apparently believed were sympathetic to the rebels. At least 400,000 Liberians are believed to have fled across the eastern and northern frontiers to escape the bloodshed, most of them settling in the heavily forested hills of the Ivory Coast and Guinea. **********Split in Rebel Ranks **********In early February, the two rebel leaders split into rival factions, with Mr. Johnson accusing Mr. Taylor of corruption. Mr. Taylor, a former Cabinet member, also had been accused of corruption when he was serving in Mr. Doe's Government; the President charged he embezzled nearly $1 million in Government funds. **********Mr. Johnson also accused Mr. Taylor of having received arms and money from Libya, an accusation Mr. Taylor has denied. **********The war has become increasingly three-sided, with the two rebel factions fighting each other and Mr. Doe trying to hold onto the small fraction of the country - mostly central Monrovia -that his troops still control. **********The bitter rivalry between Mr. Taylor and Mr. Johnson took an unexpected turn in late August, when Mr. Taylor announced that he had signed a cease-fire agreement with President Doe. Mr. Doe and Mr. Johnson were apparently discussing the agreement today when they began to argue and fighting erupted. It was not known what role the West African peacekeeping force had played in the incident, although it reportedly occurred outside its headquarters in Monrovia's port area. **********Court-Martial for Doe **********According to a BBC correspondent with the West African peacekeeping force in Monrovia, Mr. Johnson said tonight that he would court-martial Mr. Doe, a former soldier, but that he did not want to kill him. **********The incident reportedly began when the President, who had only rarely left his heavily fortified executive mansion since July, appeared unexpectedly at the port headquarters of the peacekeeping force. About 10 minutes later, Mr. Johnson and several of his fighters reportedly arrived and began to quarrel with President Doe's bodyguards. The rebel troops then reportedly hunted down the President's soldiers from room to room and slaughtered them. **********Eventually, they grabbed the President and carried him off to their base camp outside the city. Members of the peacekeeping force reportedly made repeated appeals to the two sides, but were unable to stop the fighting. **********Bloody Coup in 1980 **********In 1980, President Doe, a 28-year-old master sergeant who dropped out of the 11th grade, came to power after he and other army noncommissioned officers seized power from President William R. Tolbert, who was shot and bayoneted to death. Ten days later, foreign reporters were invited to watch 13 senior Government officials, including most of the former Cabinet, marched nearly naked through the streets of Monrovia, tied to seaside posts and then executed at point-blank range. **********President Doe's international reputation never fully recovered from that incident. His image has also suffered from persistent accusations of human rights abuses. The State Department's 1989 human rights report, released shortly after the rebel invasion, said, ''Brutality by police and other security officials during the arrest and questioning of individuals is fairly common, and there has been no evidence of Government efforts to halt this practice.'' **********Since Mr. Doe came to power, more than 20 senior Government officials and army officers have been executed on charges of plotting coups.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/24/busin.main_headline: French Publishing Feud Ends Up in the Courts
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/24/busin.print_headline: French Publishing Feud Ends Up in the Courts
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/24/busin.body_text: **********The family feud that has convulsed Editions Gallimard for the last two months ended up in court today when Antoine Gallimard's brother and two sisters formally challenged his control over France's most prestigious publisher. **********The Trade Tribunal of Paris said it would rule on April 2 in the suit brought by Christian, Francoise and Isabelle Gallimard, who assert that their ailing father, Claude, acted improperly in transferring large blocks of his shares to Antoine in 1984 and 1987. **********Until then, each of Claude's children controlled 12.5 percent of the family-run company. But with the shares bought from and donated by his father, Antoine's stake rose to 33.5 percent. Alliances with his father and shareholders outside the family then gave him majority control. **********Because of the enormous prestige garnered by Editions Gallimard since its founding in 1911 by Claude's father, Gaston, not least for publishing writers like Marcel Proust, Albert Camus and Milan Kundera, the prospect that it might change hands has alarmed French intellectual and literary circles. **********Two Brothers at Odds **********At the center of the family power struggle is a bitter feud between Christian, who was ousted as managing director in 1983, and his younger brother, Antoine, who was immediately named to take his place and who succeeded Claude as president in 1988. **********Over the last seven years, while Francoise and Isabelle have continued to work at Gallimard, Christian has run a publishing house in Switzerland and has not been on speaking terms with either his brother or father, who, at the age of 76, is seriously ill with Alzheimer's disease. **********The deadlock ended in January when Francoise announced plans to sell her 12.5 percent stake, after first obtaining an independent assessment of Gallimard's commercial value. Antoine had privately estimated the house to be worth around $100 million, but an American investment bank, Henry Ansbacher Inc., told Francoise that its true value was $315.2 million. She said she had first offered her shares to her brothers, but no deal was worked out. **********Subsequently, Antoine formed his own holding company, Societe de Participation et Editions, or Sopared, to secure his continued control over the company. This move apparently prompted his brother and sisters to take the case to court. **********In their presentation to the Trade Tribunal, a court that deals with commercial disputes, lawyers for Christian, Francoise and Isabelle said the disputed shares had been ceded to Antoine at a time when Claude's faculties had already declined. Antoine's lawyer countered that the shares were transferred when Claude was still president of the company. **********Although company statutes make a hostile takeover almost impossible, not least because they require that shares first be offered to other shareholders and that new shareholders be approved by the board, there has been speculation that some large communications group may be looking at the company.
