https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/22/world.main_headline: MORE EUROPEANS TO JOIN GULF FORCE
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/22/world.print_headline: MORE EUROPEANS TO JOIN GULF FORCE
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/22/world.body_text: **********Anxious to demonstrate full support for American moves to isolate Iraq, Western European governments decided today to increase and coordinate their naval activities in the Persian Gulf and to reject Baghdad's demands that they close their embassies in Kuwait. **********At a meeting of the nine-nation Western European Union, a regional organization, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands and Spain said their warships would soon join naval vessels from Britain, France and the United States that are already enforcing the trade embargo against Iraq in the gulf. **********West Germany said its Constitution prohibited it from sending five minehunters and minesweepers beyond the Eastern Mediterranean, but it announced plans to propose a constitutional amendment allowing it to participate in any military operation backed by the United Nations. The other two members of the organization, Portugal and Luxembourg, have not offered naval support so far. **********Coordinating Effort **********Both foreign and defense ministers attended the meeting, which included an agreement to set up an ad hoc group to coordinate members' naval activities in the gulf in areas like logistical support, zones of operation, task-sharing and exchange of intelligence. **********The ministers said that, while naval forces would for the moment remain under national commands, the chiefs of defense staff of the participating countries would meet here on Friday to harmonize strategies. They added that this European initiative should enormously ease cooperation with the United States. **********''It's very important that this should not just be a United States operation,'' Britain's Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, said, referring to enforcement of United Nations sanctions against Iraq. ''It is very important that it should be seen that the European allies are vigorously helping.'' **********The Secretary-General of the Western European Union, Willem van Eekelen, said, ''It seems essential that we do not leave this as an American affair, because Europe is even more interested than the United States in the supply of oil.'' **********Later, at a meeting of foreign ministers of the 12-nation European Community, there was also agreement that Western European embassies in Kuwait should remain open ''as long as practically and physically possible'' despite Iraq's order that they be shut down by Friday. **********Paring Staff in Kuwait **********The foreign ministers reiterated demands for the release of all hostages and further warned individual Iraqis that they would be held personally responsible under international law for any illegal acts committed against foreign nationals. Some 7,700 Community citizens are not being allowed to leave Kuwait and Iraq. **********Mr. Hurd said that while diplomats from Community governments would remain in Kuwait, families and nonessential staff would be withdrawn in the coming days. In Britain's case, he added, ''three or four'' diplomats would stay in Kuwait to assist British citizens trapped there. **********The actions today in both the Western European Union and the European Community seemed intended not only to dispel doubts about Europe's willingness to take part fully in the United States-led response to the Iraqi aggression, but also to demonstrate that Western Europe can work together both politically and militarily. **********The Western European Union, which has been overshadowed by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization since it was created in 1955, was last used by its members in 1987 to coordinate the activities of five countries that sent warships to the gulf to protect oil tankers threatened during the Iran-Iraq war. **********On this occasion, however, the Union has also provided a multilateral framework for several European governments that were reluctant to be seen either acting unilaterally or simply following the United States. Spain, for example, waited until today to announce it was sending one frigate, two corvettes and an auxiliary ship to the gulf. **********France, which over the past two weeks has sought to emphasize its independent posture in the Iraqi crisis, also stressed today that it now shared the position of its Western allies. French officials said President Francois Mitterrand held a long telephone conversation with President Bush on Monday evening. **********Action From Paris **********Today, Mr. Mitterrand said at a news conference that France had responded positively to a request for personnel and materiel from ''different countries of the region'' and would be sending ''reconnaissance squadrons from the ground forces'' to the United Arab Emirates. He did not disclose how many troops would be involved. **********Barely one week after France criticized American and British threats to stop ships suspected of trading with Iraq, Mr. Mitterrand also noted that ''an embargo without sanctions would be a sham.'' He added that only he could order French warships to fire on foreign vessels, although he acknowledged that the crisis had now entered ''a logic of war.'' **********With 8 French and 3 British warships, a total of 32 naval vessels have now been mobilized by European countries as a result of the Iraqi crisis. Among Community countries, excluding Ireland, which is neutral, only Portugal, Denmark and Luxembourg have not offered naval support.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/13/busin.body_text: **********MCA Inc. agreed today to sell its money-losing LNJ Toys Ltd. subsidiary to Acclaim Entertainment Inc. for an undisclosed amount of cash and Acclaim stock that sources said would total about $30 million. **********Acclaim, which is based on **********Long Island, produces game software made under license for the Nintendo Entertainment System and the Game Boy hand-held electronic game. **********LJN's primary business is selling toys based on characters licensed from films and television shows. It now makes several games for Nintendo and the Game Boy hand-held computer game. The company's sales totaled about $70 million last year, most of which came from Nintendo and Game Boy sales. **********''The attraction for us was the work in progress that LJN has in the video game area both for Nintendo and Game Boy, and for its catalogue in the Nintendo area,'' said Gregory Fischbach, Acclaim's chairman and chief executive. **********Although LJN has had some success with toy lines based on ''E.T.'' and the television show ''The A-Team,'' it has not had any big hits in several years. In January, when MCA said it would sell LJN, it said it would take a $53 million after-tax loss from discontinued operations for 1989 because of the decision to sell the company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/11/world.main_headline: Security Council's Rare Unity May Be Threatened Over U.S. Warships in the Gulf
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/11/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION THE GULF;   Security Council's Rare Unity May Be Threatened Over U.S. Warships in the Gulf
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/11/world.body_text: **********The United States appears to be heading for a disagreement with the other members of the United Nations Security Council over the use of naval forces to impose a blockade on Iraq and occupied Kuwait. **********Diplomats say the potential split over timing and procedure threatens the unity the Council has displayed so far in its handling of the crisis, with the Soviet Union, China and most third-world members backing America's call for trade sanctions against Iraq. **********In particular, it raises the danger that United States warships in the Persian Gulf could start stopping, searching and forcibly turning back tankers and other cargo vessels suspected of trading with these countries before the rest of the world community judges such military action necessary or justified. **********Baker Cites Resolution **********The Secretary of State, James A. Baker 3d, said at a meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in Brussels today that the Bush Administration believed the Security Council's resolution declaring a global boycott of Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait gave the United States the right to forcibly prevent other countries from trading with Iraq and Kuwait. **********''It is the view of some of us,'' he said, ''that we have the legal authority necessary to institute such an embargo or blockade, provided that the request comes from the legitimate Government of Kuwait.'' **********Article 51 of the United Nations Charter gives all countries the right of ''individual or collective self-defense'' against an aggressor, and the Security Council affirmed Kuwait's right to invoke Article 51 in the resolution it passed last week. **********But other Council members take the view that while the resolution forbids trade or other financial dealings with Iraq and Kuwait, it only allows countries to send naval vessels to the gulf to monitor ship movements and report suspected violations to the special Security Council committee on compliance. **********Britain's United Nations representative, Sir Crispin Tickell, told the Council on Thursday that this is London's view, and diplomats say Canada, China, Ethiopia, Finland, Ivory Coast, Malaysia, Romania, Yemen and Zaire share Britain's basic approach. **********Moscow's deputy representative, Valentin V. Lozinsky, said military measures should first be discussed by the Military Staff Committee, a moribund United Nations panel that plan enforcement of Council decisions. **********The countries want the Council to adopt a new resolution calling for a naval blockade before any American, British, French or other warships patroling the waters around the Arabian Peninsula uses force to stop ships trading with these countries. **********Most Council members say the time is not yet ripe for the Council to pass a resolution authorizing force in the gulf. They argue that the Council should first wait to see the results of Arab diplomacy and find out whether the embargo proves effective without such naval enforcement action. **********International solidarity in adhering to the boycott is showing signs of strain. Sri Lanka has said it cannot afford to stop exporting to Iraq and Kuwait, and several countries are complaining that they cannot afford the higher oil prices the embargo is causing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/23/world.main_headline: Toll in Iranian Quake Is Put at 29,000
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/23/world.print_headline: Toll in Iranian Quake Is Put at 29,000
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/23/world.body_text: **********Thousands of people, dead and alive, were dug today from the rubble of what appeared to be Iran's worst earthquake. A global relief effort got under way and a stunned nation began to grasp the magnitude of the disaster, which killed thousands and laid waste to a region half the size of New York State. **********The official Islamic Republic News Agency said 29,000 people had been killed and 28,000 injured in the quake, which shook northern Iran early Thursday. United Nations relief officials in Geneva quoted the Iranian Foreign Ministry as saying at least 35,000 had died and more than 100,000 had been injured. **********Toll Expected to Rise **********The numbers were only rough estimates based on surveys taken amid widespread confusion and crippled communications. Iranian leaders said the toll was expected to rise in the coming days as relief teams using bulldozers, dogs and bare hands search the rubble of more than 100 cities, towns and villages that were heavily damaged or destroyed. There was no estimate of the number of victims still trapped in rubble. **********The Iranian Red Crescent Society estimated that 400,000 people were left homeless by the temblor, which struck heaviest in Zanjan and Gilan provinces, a densely populated region of mountains, plains, hilly farmland and beach resorts in Iran's Caspian Sea coast area. **********The earthquake, which struck at 12:30 A.M. Thursday, was measured at Teheran University at 7.3 on the Richter scale, indicating a severe quake. It combined with more than 100 aftershocks to cause huge landslides that blocked roads and relief convoys, knocked out electricity and water supplies in many areas, destroyed crops and left many villages isolated and thousands of people buried in the rubble of their homes. **********Villages and Towns Wiped Out **********''For the next 10 days, we will be digging through the ruins for corpses,'' an official of the Red Crescent Society said today after returning from the stricken region. **********''There are dozens of villages, particularly in Gilan, that have completely disappeared,'' he added. ''Whole towns were flattened as if they never were there. We have no way of getting to many, because the roads are blocked by falling boulders and rocks, and planes have had difficulty landing in the mountains.'' **********Iranian television showed masked rescuers in white aprons pulling dust-covered bodies from under jagged chunks of concrete and placing them on blocks of ice in open trucks, and survivors as if in a daze rummaging through the remains of homes for loved ones and possessions. **********Airborne cameras captured mile after mile of flattened homes and apartment buildings. Hospitals were shown overflowing with victims, including Shakineh Shevediny, a 16-year-old from the village of Manjil, in Gilan province, who recalled waking to find herself buried in debris. **********''I could hear the screams of my grandfather,'' she said. After many hours, she was rescued. **********''But it was too late for grandfather and my little brother,'' she went on. ''We waited for help on the street. Again at noon, another strong earthquake came, and again and again, until nothing was left of the village.'' **********Elsewhere in Manjil, a woman held her dead daughter in her arms as workers unearthed the body of another daughter. And a man in Rudbar, a mountainside village in Gilan province, told Iranian television that ''a rock as big as a building'' had crushed his home, killing four of his six children. His wife lay in the ruins for hours before help came. **********'Not a Single House' **********''There is not a single house in this area that has been left standing,'' said Ali Mohammadi, a farmer in Rudbar, where at least 6,000 people were reported to have been killed. **********Rescuers used dogs to search for victims and survivors trapped beneath the rubble, and relief officials said in television interviews that thousands had been found alive. Television broadcasts from Rasht, the capital of Gilan province, showed young men frantically digging for victims, cranes lifting concrete slabs and bulldozers clearing roads for ambulances and other rescue vehicles. **********About 3,000 trained relief workers and 3,000 tons of supplies were flown into the stricken areas northwest of Teheran aboard 50 flights today, officials of the Red Crescent Society said. Earlier, bad weather and poor visibility had hampered the airlift. **********The Teheran airport was thronged with people trying to reach the quake zone to learn the fate of relatives, but only relief flights were going through. Iranian news reporters were in the stricken area, but foreign reporters were not allowed to travel there. Iranian authorities said they would be allowed into the area on Monday or Tuesday. **********As military helicopters, C-130 transport planes and special Iran Air flights ferried medical personnel and tons of supplies into the region and flew 6,000 injured survivors out to hospitals in Teheran and other cities, President Hashemi Rafsanjani said the death toll was bound to rise as rescue teams reached thus-far inaccessible towns. **********President Asks for Aid **********''Realistic casualty figures would be a lot higher than those already announced,'' President Rafsanjani said as he stood beside a helicopter in the destroyed village of Rudbar and appealed for foreign assistance. ''Everyone is helping,'' he said, ''but with a calamity this disastrous, nothing could be enough.'' **********Despite Iran's recent history of diplomatic isolation, many nations rushed to offer humanitarian assistance and condolences. Those offering aid includied Iran's bitter enemy Iraq and the United States, which has not forgotten the 444 days when 52 members of the American Embassy staff here were held hostage in 1979-80. **********''I convey my sincerest condolences and declare that we are ready to provide any assistance you may require,'' Iraq's President, Saddam Hussein, said in a message to President Rafsanjani. Iran and Iraq each sustained heavy losses in their Persian Gulf war from 1980 to 1988. **********The Red Cross in Geneva said Iran had requested antibiotics, tents and blankets, surgical equipment and thread, blood bags, food, vehicles and heavy equipment to lift and move rubble. It said the Red Crescent Society had indicated that doctors, technicians and other medical personnel were not needed. **********Offers of assistance were received from the European Community, France, Britain, Japan, Israel, Syria, Finland, Sweden, Saudi Arabia, Turkey, Greece, the Netherlands, the Soviet Union, Poland and other countries. **********Tons of Supplies Sent **********Tons of supplies and relief workers were being flown to Iran today, and many more planeloads were expected over the weekend. A senior official in Washington said Iran had accepted the Bush Administration's offer of aid, and the American Red Cross said the organization was raising money for earthquake relief in Iran. **********While the full extent of casualties and destruction was unknown, it appears that the quake was the worst ever to strike Iran and - if the casualty estimates hold true or become worse - the world's worst since 200,000 people, by official estimates, died in an earthquake at Tangshan, China, in 1976. Other estimates say as many as 800,000 people may have died in that quake. Iran's worst previous quake killed 25,000 in 1978. **********The quake caused damage estimated in the billions of dollars, ravaged one of Iran's major farming regions and could have serious implications for the nation's economy. **********The deaths of thousands of laborers, the need to rebuild vast tracts of housing and commercial property, the destruction of irrigation systems and large crops of fruit, rice and wheat are all expected to have major effect on an economy already strained by years of war. **********Reza Asghari, an insurance salesman, reached by telephone, said many people were stranded on the streets of Rasht looking for relatives and children. He described the damages in the city as minor compared with surrounding villages like Fuman, Manjil and Rudbar. The Islamic Republic News Agency said the town of Abbar was 100 percent destroyed. The Loshan Dam near Manjil was said to have been damaged by cracks and flooded surrounding areas, the agency said. **********In Zanjan province, 4,000 bodies were found and more than 8,000 people were injured, reports indicated early today. In many areas, not a single structure was left standing. The towns and cities of Teheran, Qum, Hamadan, Arak, Saveh, Mahallat and Ashtian suffered minor damage to buildings. **********Groups Taking Aid Donations Adventist Development and Relief International, 12501 Old Columbia Pike, Silver Spring, Md. 20904. **********American Jewish World Service, 1290 **********Avenue of the Americas, 11th floor, New York, N.Y. 10104. **********American Red Cross, Iran Earthquake **********Disaster, P. O. Box 37243, Washington, D.C. 20013 Americares Foundation, 161 Cherry Street, New Canaan, Conn. 06840. **********Baptist World Alliance, Iran Earthquake **********Fund, 6733 Curran Street, Mclean, Va. 22101. https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/02/world.main_headline: Seeking to Resolve Hostage Issue, Lebanese Militia Frees 40 Shiites
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/02/world.print_headline: Seeking to Resolve Hostage Issue, Lebanese Militia Frees 40 Shiites
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/02/world.body_text: **********A pro-Israeli Lebanese militia in southern Lebanon released 40 Shiite Muslim prisoners today in an apparent attempt to encourage Muslim fundamentalists to free Israeli and Western hostages. **********Gen. Antoine Lahd, commander of the militia, the South Lebanon Army, said the 40 militants who were freed had been arrested during attacks on patrols by the South Lebanon Army and the Israeli Army in the Israeli-designated security zone in southern Lebanon. **********General Lahd said he ''shared the Israeli point of view that freeing the prisoners could help resolve the issue of 2 Israeli servicemen and 12 Western hostages'' who have been detained by Lebanese militants. **********The status of the hostages is related to the struggle for power in Lebanon involving the Government of President Elias Hrawi and the forces of Gen. Michel Aoun, who has refused to give up power since he was chosen interim president two years ago. At a rally of Aoun supporters in Beirut today, gunners opened fire, killing 25 people and wounding at least 82, hospital officials said. **********Cleric Among Inmates **********General Lahd, a Lebanese Christian, said the release of the 40 men from Khiyam Prison in the security zone marked the birthday of the prophet Mohammed and came at the request of religious figures and others. **********The fundamentalist Muslim organizations holding the 2 Israelis and 12 Westerners have repeatedly demanded the freedom of all Khiyam prisoners, who number more than 300, before hostages are released. Six Americans, two Germans, three Britons and an Italian are among the hostages held here. The pro-Iranian Party of God is also believed to be holding an Israeli soldier and an airman captured during raids on southern Lebanon in 1986. **********General Lahd said the remaining 260 prisoners at Khiyam would also be freed if the first move served its purpose. **********Among the Khiyam inmates is a Party of God cleric, Sheik Abdul Karim Obeid, who was abducted in July 1989 by Israeli soldiers from his village in southern Lebanon. **********The Party of God then retaliated by hanging a United States Marine officer, Lieut. Col. William R. Higgins, who was kidnapped here in February 1988. **********Eight of the freed prisoners were transported by Red Cross ambulances today to Shiite-held villages north of the security zone where they were met by officials of the main Shiite Muslim militia, Amal. The rest, apparently members of the pro-Iranian Party of God, preferred to stay in the zone, security officials said. **********About 3,000 South Lebanon Army militiamen, who are equipped and paid by the Israeli Army, patrol the security zone along with Israeli soldiers. General Lahd and most of his militiamen are Christians. **********White House Praise **********By Reuters **********The United States praised the release of the 40 prisoners today and renewed a call for the release of American hostages there, pledging to develop better relations with nations who contribute to their freedom. **********''We welcome the release of the 40 Shiite Muslim prisoners,'' said the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, who accompanied President Bush to New York for a three-day visit. **********''It is consistent with our position that, for humanitarian reasons, all persons being detained without legal basis in the Middle East should be released immediately,'' Mr. Fitzwater said in a written statement.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/22/busin.main_headline: Oil: Missing That Old, Cartel-Like Feeling
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/22/busin.print_headline: WALL STREET;   Oil: Missing That Old, Cartel-Like Feeling
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/22/busin.body_text: **********Anyone pining for the days when the international oil cartel was worthy of that label would have been heartened last week at the faith displayed by oil traders. Oil prices, of course, have been hammered for more than three weeks, as Middle East producers seemed unable to enforce quotas that would stem the flow of oil into a glutted market. On Wednesday, the spot price for May delivery of crude oil fell below $17 a barrel for the first time in nearly 16 months. **********But the mere report on Thursday that officials of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would meet in two weeks to discuss their supply allocation disputes sent May spot prices soaring. The party may be short-lived. Analysts have warned that any OPEC gathering is likely to become a finger-pointing session that will generate anything but cartel-like solidarity. **********''Just the fact that they are meeting is not enough,'' said one London analyst. ''They pumped too much oil into the market and it will take substantial reductions to remove stocks.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/16/busin.main_headline:
The Executive Life;
The Temporary Answer To the Recession
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/16/busin.print_headline:
The Executive Life;
The Temporary Answer To the Recession
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/16/busin.body_text: **********Even the most determined optimist would be hard put to find much good news for executives in today's recessionary climate; plants and offices are closing and pay cuts and layoffs are widespread. **********But some executives, particularly those who have found themselves out of work, are using the slowdown to evaluate their futures and have come to the conclusion that the traditional executive track is no longer for them. These executives, people like Sally McKinney, a former vice president at Seamen's Bank for Savings who decided to write a novel rather than find another job after Seamen's was taken over by the Government in the savings and loan bailout last spring, have found a way to reap the benefits of executive life while leaving the disadvantages behind. **********They have become temporary executives. "I've spent 20 years in corporations, and I've been through outplacement twice, when my companies went under," said Ms. McKinney. "It's a good feeling to think I'm finally in charge." **********For temporary executives, the work is everything. Solving problems, finishing projects and completing specific tasks are more important than the more social aspects of corporate jobs. These executives are willing to give up the particular brand of security, identity and competition that comes with working for a company on a permanent basis for the instant and more fleeting rewards of "temping." **********"Now when I hear about jobs I want," said Ms. McKinney, "it's more the challenge of the particular job that I like than the structure of the position." **********In these sluggish times, the attraction of temporary executives, who often have an M.B.A. and typically 10 years of managerial experience, is obvious. Companies may pay them $500 a day for three months or so, but they don't have to commit to bonuses, benefits or a salary over the long term. **********"Many companies also use them to replace temporarily an executive who has been lost unexpectedly to another company, or who has gotten sick or died," said Kieran Hackett, president of the Executive Source, a Manhattan search firm that provides temporary executives to companies. "And small companies can use the expertise of a temp without spending the money to hire someone permanently." **********There are also some less obvious benefits for companies that use temporary executives. "You're an outsider, so you see things more objectively in the company," said Roberta Schlaifer Semer, a temporary executive with a master's degree in clinical psychology. "People tend to talk to you much easier about problems because you have no vested interests. As a result, you can usually help point out problems more effectively than others who are there day in and day out." **********While temporary executives have roles that sound suspiciously like those of business consultants, Mr. Hackett says they actually differ. "These temporary executives are implementers -- they do the project, run the office, whatever," he said. "They do not just limit themselves to doing an overall analysis of problems and recommendations, like most consultants do." **********For those executives who decide to take up temping, the job provides the perfect solution to a whole host of life-style problems they may have been confronting. When Ms. McKinney decided to write a novel instead of finding a new job, she quickly discovered that writing would not pay the rent and that she missed her executive income. **********After offering her services to a temporary executive search firm, she landed an assignment last July at a major foreign bank with its American headquarters in New York. As the bank's interim manager of employee benefits, Ms. McKinney, who is in her 40's, works three days a week doing such tasks as writing up benefits plans and compiling data on pension plans. **********She spends the rest of her time working on her book. "I know this job won't last forever," she said. "But while it does it's great. My time there is very pure. I'm there only to do the job they've hired me for and that gives me great freedom." **********Other executives turn to temping to relieve the boredom of everyday corporate life. "I like the excitement of creating a whole new thing -- of going in, finding the problem and actually fixing it," explained Ms. Semer."For example, at the first company I worked for as a temp, I set up an entire computer system. But it would bore me to tears to have to sit there and run it. -- the challenge for me was in getting it up and running." **********But all good things come with a price. The very qualities temporary executives seek in choosing such a style of life, like the ability to work only at their leisure, can pose major problems. "I'm basically just a high-priced Kelly Girl," said Ms. McKinney. "I don't get paid if I don't work, so if I get sick, it can be a disaster. I have to provide my own benefits, which are expensive, and my own retirement funds." **********Starting a new job over and over again can also be emotionally wearing. The first day at any new office is usually a nightmare: Meeting new people, learning the office politics and finding one's way around the building is hard enough. Imagine going through the process all the time. "You've got to be incredibly flexible and very pleasant," said Ms. Semer. "You're cutting in on someone else's space. Sometimes people look sort of funny at you -- they don't believe you're not after their job. I brought cookies in to work early on to kind of warm people up, and I keep candy on my desk so that if people are really stressed out, they can stop by, take a piece of candy and chat."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/05/world.main_headline: As Soviet Oil Becomes a Trickle, Havel Seeks Gorbachev Meeting
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/05/world.print_headline: As Soviet Oil Becomes a Trickle, Havel Seeks Gorbachev Meeting
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/05/world.body_text: **********The Czechoslovak Prime Minister met today with the Soviet Ambassador in an effort to resolve a crisis here as new measures were announced to stop panic buying of gasoline. **********Prime Minister Marian Calfa said he and President Vaclav Havel want urgently to meet with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union and his Prime Minister, Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, to discuss the problems they say are being caused by declining Soviet oil deliveries. **********Czechoslovak officials announced today that starting Friday at midnight car owners will be limited to 25 liters of gas for the month of October at the current prices, 12 crowns (about 50 cents) for regular gas and 13.5 crowns (about 57 cents) for super. Any additional purchases will cost one-third more per liter. **********The panic buying has created lines several hours long at gas pumps. Officials said they expect the restrictions to be eased next month. **********Heating oil is also going up in price by one-third to about 50 cents a liter. **********The Finance Ministers of Czechoslovakia, Poland and Hungary are to meet this weekend in Budapest to try to agree on a united position in negotiations with the Soviet Union on oil deliveries. **********Large Debts at Issue **********''The prospects aren't rosy,'' said Miroslav Zamecnik, a spokesman for the Czechoslovak Finance Minister. ''The Soviets are in arrears in their foreign debt and their pipelines are in a catastrophic state. They probably can't do anything'' to increase deliveries. **********Eastern Europe has long been dependent on cheap Soviet oil. But the old, closed trading system of the East bloc has been disintegrating with the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe and the Soviets have been reserving more of their oil for sale for hard currency. **********At the same time, however, the Soviet Union has large debts with Czechoslovakia, Poland and Hungary. Negotiations on those countries' demands to be repaid in hard currency have been deadlocked. **********The Czechoslovak Foreign Minister, Jiri Dienstbier, recently proposed that the industrialized countries help by creating new credits for the Soviet Union to be used to buy products from Eastern Europe. The earnings would in turn allow Eastern Europe to buy Soviet oil for hard currency. **********Czechoslovakia's decision today to raise prices for gas purchases above 25 liters comes on top of a 50 percent price increase last July. **********Panic buying of gasoline started Tuesday when Vladimir Meciar, premier of the Slovak region of the country, warned that gas supplies would last only two days. But officials said today that the country had a three-week supply.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/20/world.print_headline: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;   10,000 ROMANIANS PROTEST ARRESTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/20/world.body_text: **********More than 10,000 protesters rallied today in the western city of Timisoara, the cradle of the revolution against Nicolae Ceausescu, to urge the Romanian Government to free dissidents seized during unrest last month. **********Bucharest also faced mounting pressure abroad over the arrests, which followed clashes in which six people were killed and hundreds injured. **********Opposition groups, trade unions and students in Timisoara, where the uprising against Mr. Ceausescu began last December, read aloud letters and petitions calling for the release of the student leader Marian Munteanu and other dissidents. They also denounced President Ion Iliescu, whose Government is widely criticized for retaining Communist influence after the ouster of Mr. Ceausescu. **********''There were shouts of 'Down with Iliescu!' and 'Resign!' but it was a peaceful protest,'' said George Serbean, vice president of the opposition Timisoara Society. **********Questions From Thatcher **********Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain said in a letter published today in the newspaper Dreptatea that London had questioned Romania about detained student leaders. The letter was written to Ion Ratiu, an opposition presidential candidate in May's elections, ''We have used the C.S.C.E. human rights mechanism,'' Mrs. Thatcher said, referring to the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, ''to raise with them the case of three arrested student leaders.'' **********President Francois Mitterrand of France questioned Prime Minister Petre Roman of Romania in Paris on Wednesday about Mr. Munteanu. **********Asked by reporters if Mr. Munteanu should be freed, Mr. Roman said, ''My own personal feeling is that it would be possible, and that is President Iliescu's point of view as well.'' **********His comments were met with skepticism by Bucharest students, many of whom were beaten in last month's violence. **********Riots broke out in the capital in June after the police cleared a seven-week occupation of a main square. Mr. Iliescu called in miners who crushed the protests with clubs and pickaxes. **********''We want to express our perplexity over Premier Roman's statement, especially considering we have found out from military prosecutors that Munteanu's detention has been extended for one month,'' a spokesman for Bucharest University Students League said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/04/busin.body_text: **********The president of a small military contractor based here was sentenced today to three years in prison and a $750,000 fine for his role in a 10-year scheme to avoid testing bolts that the company manufactured for use on military aircraft. **********In addition to the prison term and fine, Norman McHaffie, president of McHaffie Inc., a Sylmar, Calif., aerospace company, received three years of probation. The company separately was fined $750,000. **********James Hicks, an employee, received a one-year jail term and three years of probation. A second employee, William Whitman, in June received a sentence of 20 weekends in jail, three years of probation and 150 hours of community service. **********The United States Attorney's office in Los Angeles said McHaffie Inc. did not test bolts used on such aircraft as the F-16 fighter and B-1B bomber and then submitted falsified certificates saying the tests were conducted. In the few instances where the company actually conducted the tests, parts often failed and those results were either whited-out with correction fluid on certificates or were replaced with new, fabricated results.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/29/busin.main_headline: Hanover Deal For Deposits Of Goldome
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/29/busin.print_headline: Hanover Deal For Deposits Of Goldome
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/29/busin.body_text: **********The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy 13 branches in the New York City area and about $1.6 billion of deposits from Goldome F.S.B., a Buffalo savings bank. **********The purchase is the latest example of banks' growing appetites for the consumer deposits of troubled savings institutions. Although banks have generally avoided buying the loans and real estate holdings of savings institions, they have viewed purchases of consumer deposits and branches as an inexpensive way to expand in one of the most profitable parts of the banking business. **********So far this year, commercial banks have bought $43.8 billion of deposits from savings institutions in 185 transactions, up from $11.2 billion of deposits in 41 deals during 1989, according to SNL Securities, a banking research concern in Charlottesville, Va. Excluding deals with failed savings institutions controlled by the Resolution Trust Company, banks have bought $9 billion of savings institutions' deposits this year, up from $2.5 billion in 1989. **********Manufacturers Hanover agreed to pay $16.5 million in the first quarter of next year for the Goldome deposits. Edward D. Miller, vice chairman at Manufactuers Hanover, estimated that it would take about 18 months for the company to recoup the purchase price from profits generated by the branches. Late last year, Manufacturers Hanover paid $65 million for $1.2 billion of deposits at 11 Goldome branches in New York City. **********"It is more of a buyer's market now, with a greater availability of branches from thrifts," Mr. Miller said. **********Purchasing branches is popular with bankers because it is a cheaper way to expand than opening new branches. In New York City, where Manufacturers Hanover is in tight competition with Chemical Bank and Chase Manhattan to be the second-leading bank in the consumer market after Citibank, Mr. Miller said it could take five years for a new branch to become profitable. **********Chase Manhattan has also been an active branch buyer recently, having acquired 25 branches with nearly $2.8 billion of deposits since April.  Avoiding Wholesale Money **********Large New York City banks have sought to expand their local branch networks in recent years as a way to reduce their reliance on borrowing money in wholesale markets. Because of Federal deposit insurance, consumers are generally reluctant to shift funds, even if they know their bank has losses and lower credit ratings. But corporate treasurers and other institutions in the wholesale markets, whose large deposits are not insured, are much quicker to withdraw funds at signs of weakness or trouble. **********"The acquisition is a terrific positive for Manufacturers Hanover," said Judah Kraushaar, a banking analyst at Merrill Lynch. "It allows them to use the new deposits to replace more expensive funds borrowed in the wholesale market." **********Officials at Manufactuers Hanover estimated that the cost of consumer deposits was three-quarters of a percentage point to a full percentage point lower than the millions in Eurodollar deposits they will replace. **********Despite the acquisition, Manufacturers Hanover's stock fell 75 cents a share on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, to $18.625. Goldome, which earned a profit last quarter but is looking for investors to restore its badly depleted capital, closed at 62.5 cents a share, up 6.25 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange. **********Manufacturers Hanover said it would close three of Goldome's Manhattan branches that are near existing Manufacturers Hanover offices. Of the remaining 10 branches, two are in Manhattan, one is in the Bronx, two each are in Westchester and Orange Counties and three are in Rockland County. Goldome will retain 32 branches in western New York, 37 in Florida and 10 in central New York. **********The branch sales are part of Goldome's strategy of concentrating on local consumer business. It has abandoned its strategy of the 1980's, when it bought other savings institutions and was doing business in almost every state. Goldome has contracted to $12.8 billion of assets from about $15 billion at the end of 1988. It has left many businesses, including corporate-takeover financing and computer leasing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/20/busin.main_headline: More Charges Expected In Generic Drug Inquiry
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/20/busin.print_headline: More Charges Expected In Generic Drug Inquiry
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/20/busin.body_text: **********The two-year investigation of the generic drug industry has resulted in more than a dozen criminal convictions, and investigators said today that more disclosures of wrongdoing and corruption were yet to come. **********Breckinridge L. Willcox, the United States Attorney in Baltimore who has been in charge of the Justice Department's investigation, testified at a Congressional hearing that the generic drug industry is corrupted by companies that took shortcuts to get drugs approved, including bribing regulators and submitting false data on equivalency and effectiveness. **********Manufacturers, including some of the leaders in the industry, have tried to cover up past wrongdoing with perjury, records falsification and other illegal acts to obstruct justice, prosecutors and lawmakers charged. 'Greed, Arrogance and Deceit' **********"The evidence we have amassed presents an astounding picture of corporate greed, arrogance and deceit, coupled with reckless disregard for the health and safety of the consuming public," Mr. Willcox told the House Energy and Commerce Committee's Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations. **********Representative Ron Wyden, an Oregon Democrat who is a member of the subcommittee, called corruption in the industry, which makes cheaper versions of brand-name drugs, "a direct byproduct of excessive deregulation during the Reagan Administration," which encouraged cooperation between industry and regulators and reduced the budget of the Food and Drug Administration. "We've got to get the F.D.A. back into the business of serious enforcement of our laws," Mr. Wyden said. **********The committee's chairman, Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, termed generics an "outlaw industry" and called for new legislation to give the F.D.A. more staff and policing power. **********Mr. Dingell said F.D.A. tests indicated that none of the generic drugs from companies under investigation had posed a health or safety risk to patients, but he said that because of the wrongdoing uncovered so far, consumers could not assume that many generic drugs were therapeutically equivalent to the ones that they were imitating. **********Investigators said corruption in the drug approval process had resulted in the conviction of three generic drug companies (American Therapeutics of Bohemia, L.I.; Par Pharmaceutical of Spring Valley, N.Y., and Quad Pharmaceuticals of Indianapolis, a unit of Par); five drug company executives (from the three convicted companies as well as Pharmaceutical Basics and its predecessor company, MY-K Laboratories, of Morton Grove, Ill.); five former F.D.A. employees in the generic drug division, and an industry consultant. **********The latest phase of the investigation, looking into approval applications and manufacturing practices where fraud is suspected, has already resulted in the conviction of one company and two executives and should produce many additional charges, investigators said. **********Daniel L. Michels, director of the F.D.A.'s office of compliance in the Center for Drug Evaluation and Research, testified that the product approval applications of 105 generic drugs had been found to contain fraudulent material. He also said that 231 products had been removed from the market during the two-year inquiry. **********Over the last 18 months, Mr. Michels said, the F.D.A. has audited the operations of 36 generic drug companies, including some industry leaders like Bolar Pharmaceutical Inc. of Copiague, L.I., and found that at least nine had submitted false information with their drug applications. In addition, he said, only half were found in compliance with the agency's regulations on manufacturing practices.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/17/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;   Reorganized Bonwit Reportedly Picks Chief
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/17/busin.body_text: **********Frank Doroff will become the head of the new Bonwit Teller fashion chain to be reorganized by Pyramid Companies, retail executives said yesterday. **********Mr. Doroff is president of the Federated/Allied Marketing Services Company and is regarded in the industry as a highly skilled merchandising executive. He is a former president of the Burdines department stores in Florida and senior vice president of R. H. Macy & Company. **********Twelve Bonwit Teller stores were ordered closed by June 30 at a Federal bankruptcy hearing two weeks ago. Four others are expected to remain open. During the bankruptcy hearing, Pyramid, the Northeast's largest builder of shopping centers, acquired the Bonwit Teller name and two Bonwit store leases, in Buffalo and Boston, from their bankrupt owner, the L. J. Hooker Corporation. Two stores in Hooker shopping centers in Cincinnati and Columbia, S.C. will continue to operate, under a license from Pyramid to use the name. **********Robert G. Congel, Pyramid's managing partner, said he plans to replace the Bonwit Teller flagship store in the Trump Tower in Manhattan with a new site on Fifth Avenue and will attempt to rebuild Bonwit as a retail chain. **********Donald J. Trump, the owner of Trump Tower, had been dissatisfied with the performance of Bonwit as the anchor store of the mall. At the bankruptcy hearing, he purchased the store's lease, saying that he would probably split the 87,000-square-foot property into two parts and lease them to separate retailers. **********Mr. Doroff is expected to head a four-member management team to run Bonwit on a partnership basis. Mr. Congel has said the team will receive almost a 50 percent stake in the business. A spokesman for Pyramid in Syracuse said an announcement naming the members of the new team would be made later this week. **********The other members of the team are also expected to come from Federated/Allied's Marketing Services Company, a subsidiary of the Federated/ Allied department store chains owned by Campeau Corporation. Federated/Allied, which owns nine regional retailing chains, including Bloomingdale's, is also in Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings. In addition to Bonwit, L. J. Hooker had owned the B. Altman department store, which was ordered closed late last year by a bankruptcy judge.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/10/busin.main_headline: No Easy Profits in Soviet Skies
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/10/busin.print_headline: No Easy Profits in Soviet Skies
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/10/busin.body_text: **********Negotiators from the United States and the Soviet Union plan to meet next month to try to complete accords that will significantly expand air service between the two countries. **********But the experience of Pan American World Airways, the United States carrier already flying to the Soviet Union, indicates that attracting passengers and realizing profits on these routes will be a lot harder than reaching agreements. **********Under a preliminary plan announced last week, United States carriers would be permitted to expand their service to Moscow and Leningrad and to begin serving six other cities in the Soviet Union: Kiev, in the Ukraine; Riga, in Latvia; Minsk, in Byelorussia; Tbilisi, in Georgia, and Khabarovsk and Magadan in the Far East region. **********More Aeroflot Service **********The Soviet airline, Aeroflot, would be able to increase service to New York and Washington and could begin flying to Chicago and Miami. The airline could also fly over the Pacific to Anchorage and on to San Francisco. **********United States carriers, including Delta Air Lines and American Airlines, plan to apply to the Transportation Department to fly some of the new routes, hoping that, as tensions ease between the two nations, business and tourist traffic will increase. **********But even though the number of passengers flying Pan Am's Soviet routes has grown by 195 percent since 1987, to 58,638 last year from 19,892, the airline said the recent events in the Eastern bloc had not increased traffic to the Soviet Union, although they may when the tourist season reaches its peak in the summer. **********Although Pan Am has been flying between New York and Moscow without interruption for three years and has four nonstop flights a week, the Soviet Union remains ''a tough market,'' according to John P. McCaffrey, vice president of industry. **********Pan Am has been able to get only a small number of Soviet passengers because all tickets in the Soviet Union must be bought through Aeroflot. Only when Aeroflot sells out its own flights will it sell seats on other airlines, he said, and that rarely happens. **********''There is no way to beat a state monopoly when they control the sale of the tickets,'' said Daniel Kasper, an expert on international aviation at Harbridge House. **********Need for Tourists **********For this reason, American carriers entering the Soviet market would have to rely mostly on passengers from the United States to fill their flights. And that means mostly tourists, because, according to Mr. Kasper, business activity between the two countries has been sparse, producing few of the business travelers who tend to pay full fare and help an airline keep its routes profitable when tourist traffic is light. **********One way both countries hope to encourage tourism is to answer complaints that hotel accommodations in the Soviet Union are inadequate. Many hotel-related joint ventures are currently under way, including one by Aeroflot, the Moscow City Council and the Sheraton Corporation to build a Sheraton Hotel in Moscow by 1993. **********Additional American carriers will also face tough competition from strong European carriers, including British Airways and Lufthansa, which have been serving the Soviet market for a long time. **********In order to help fill its planes, Pan Am has arranged with Aeroflot to, in effect, lease half of its planes to the Soviet carrier, which then pays half the expenses and sells Pan Am seats as if they were its own seats. **********Mr. McCaffrey said Pan Am's flights have in recent years been operating just a little better than break-even as a result of the agreement. **********Currency Problems **********Even if Aeroflot agrees in negotiations to give up some of its monopoly, Mr. McCaffrey said, Soviet customers can pay only in rubles, which cannot be converted into other currencies. He said rubles could not even be used to pay for expenses incurred by Pan Am in the Soviet Union; the country wants to be paid in dollars or other hard currencies. **********Air service between the United States and the Soviet Union has been affected by the prevailing political climates of the past. President Jimmy Carter ordered Aeroflot to stop its flights to New York after the Soviet military incursion into Afghanistan in 1979. Pan Am also had to suspend its flights to the Soviet Union. And President Ronald Reagan stopped Aeroflot service to Washington in 1981 in retaliation for a Soviet crackdown in Poland. **********Flights began again in April 1986, and the two countries agreed last month to cooperate in air-traffic control for flights between Alaska and Siberia, clearing the way for flights across the Bering Strait.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/04/busin.main_headline: Hiring a Preparers Can Ease the Pain
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/04/busin.print_headline: YOUR TAXES;   Hiring a Preparers Can Ease the Pain
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/04/busin.body_text: **********THE 50 million Americans who will pay someone to prepare their income tax returns this year face an important choice: what kind of service to use. **********Tax preparers charge anywhere from $12 to several thousand dollars, depending on the complexity of the return and their own qualifications, which vary widely. **********''Anyone can set up shop and hang out a shingle as a tax preparer,'' the Council of Better Business Bureaus warns in a brochure. ''Tax preparers range from the amateur to the professional.'' **********The Internal Revenue Service defines a tax preparer as anyone who receives compensation for preparing all or a major part of the return for another individual. This includes lawyers, certified public accountants and enrolled agents, who have met the education standards of their professions; personnel trained by the tax preparation services that employ them, and untrained people who are simply cashing in on the tax season. **********Despite the complexities of tax law, there are no nationally recognized educational requirements for preparers, so clients should ask preparers what their credentials are. **********Most people who pay someone to help with their returns choose a commercial tax-preparation service. Employees of such firms typically work on a seasonal basis, from January through the filing deadline - April 16 this year - and come from a variety of educational and employment backgrounds. Although some local services are operated by men or women who do not have specialized experience in tax preparation, the national chains usually have their own training programs to insure that their preparers meet company-wide standards. **********One person using a tax-preparation service this year is Eutisha McClain, a clerk in Kansas City, Mo., who has a relatively simple return. ''They know what they're doing, and they won't mess up my taxes,'' she said. **********Dagmar O'Connor, a New York psychologist and author, decided to use a certified public accounting firm. ''It makes me feel safer,'' she said. ''I'll get more money back, if it's done right.'' **********And the client can help be sure it's done right, by providing adequate, well-organized information. If the taxpayer walks in with a shoe box filled with papers and tells the preparer to make sense out of it, the fee will probably be higher than it would be if information and documents applying to the taxes were better organized. **********The more substantiation for deductions the taxpayer provides, the better organized the papers are and the more honest the taxpayer is in discussions with the preparer, the less time will be required by the person paid to do the work. **********For routine returns, the storefront tax services with their big, unpartitioned rooms and absence of privacy may be adequate. Their average fees are about $50, with the cost normally dependent on the number and type of tax forms filed. **********For instance, one national chain charges only $12 if a taxpayer is filing Form 1040EZ, the simplest of the Federal forms for single filers with no dependents. Yet that same chain charges $85 to a self-employed individual who files a standard Form 1040 with a number of extra schedules attached. **********Thomas M. Bloch, president of H & R Block, the country's largest commercial preparer, said his company also has an executive tax service, which has an average fee of $100. **********''It's for people who prefer a more private type of environment,'' he added. ''The quality of the return isn't different, but the amenities are different.'' **********The next level of sophistication among tax preparers is the little-known category of enrolled agents. These are people who have been certified by the I.R.S. after having worked at least five years as a tax auditor or passing a Federal test. The name ''enrolled agent'' comes from the fact that they are authorized to represent taxpayers before the revenue service. **********''When you get into an area where people have a number of limited partnerships, you want someone who is better qualified'' than a commercial tax preparer, said Bess Messmer, an enrolled agent with a tax practice in Colonial Heights, Va. She said that enrolled agents have the specialized knowledge required for complex returns. **********According to Ms. Messmer, enrolled agents charge by the number of forms prepared, by the hour or by a combination of the two. For filling out simple Federal and state returns for an individual, the price generally ranges from $75 to $150; if a business schedule is added to the return, the cost might go up to $250. **********Certified public accountants who specialize in taxes are not only highly skilled in accounting matters, but also serve as tax advisers. They must have a college degree or the equivalent in work experience, pass a stiff state professional qualifying examination, meet the appropriate continuing education requirements and receive accreditation from the state. As a result, the Better Business Bureau Council pamphlet noted, many people consider C.P.A.'s ''the top of the line'' in tax assistance. **********''Clearly a wage earner who has a W-2 form from an employer and a couple of interest slips doesn't need a sophisticated tax preparer,'' said Robert L. Israeloff, executive partner of Israeloff, Trattner & Company, a certified public accounting firm based in Valley Stream, L.I. ''But when you believe your financial situation is a little more complicated than the ordinary - certainly around the $75,000 level - that's the point when you should seek a professional like us.'' **********Directly or indirectly, most C.P.A.'s set their fees on an hourly basis, with charges typically ranging from $50 to $250 an hour. Many have minimum fees ranging from $250 to $500 for tax preparation. **********The work of tax attorneys appeals primarily to people who want to shelter part of their income. These lawyers - who have passed a state bar examination and may have special tax education and experience - are often consulted on complicated tax-planning matters and are usually well-informed on tax laws and their applications. **********''The practice of taxation is the practice of law,'' said Alexander Gurevitch, a tax lawyer in Pearl River, N.Y. ''A knowledge of what the proper deduction is might well depend sometimes on a Federal law and the interpretation of that law.'' **********''The role of the lawyer is more of giving advice and resolving disputes,'' observed Mortimer Caplin, a partner of the Washington law firm of Caplin & Drysdale and a former I.R.S. commissioner. ''Even though an accountant may be preparing a return, a particular issue may come up, and you may also need the talents of a lawyer.'' **********Legal fees, also set on an hourly basis, are the highest for any tax preparer. The hourly range is about $75 to $350 an hour, depending on the city, with minimum fees between $750 and $1,500. **********One step in picking a tax preparer is to ask professional societies, like the national office or state chapters of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, the American Association of Attorney Certified Public Accountants or the National Association of Enrolled Agents, for the names of a few in the area. Another technique is simply to ask for referrals from friends and colleagues. Then call or visit a few practitioners and ask questions about fees and services. **********''You want to feel comfortable with your adviser,'' said Herbert Paul, a New York C.P.A. and lawyer. ''You want to make sure you have the same chemistry.'' **********Martin Leventhal, senior partner of the New York certified public accounting firm of Leventhal, Zupnick, Berg & Company, added, ''It's like a family physician - you have a personal relationship.'' **********This year, more than half the 109 million Americans who will file individual returns will pay a preparer, and among the key questions to ask in selecting the preparer are: *********** What is your training and experience in preparing tax returns? *********** How many tax forms do you complete each year, and will you have enough time to devote to my return? *********** Will the person who interviews me be the same person who actually prepares the tax forms? *********** Is the accuracy of your work checked manually or by computer to determine if there are mathematical errors or errors in the interpretation of tax rules? *********** If my return is audited, can you - and will you - represent me, and what will you charge? *********** How long will it take between the interview and the completion of all the forms? *********** How much will it cost to prepare my taxes and how is that fee determined? **********Steve Pyrek, a spokesman for the I.R.S., warns taxpayers to ''watch out for anyone who promises to get you a refund. And watch out for anyone who bases fees on the size of the refund. You're responsible for the return, even if it is prepared by somebody else.'' **********At the end of the tax-preparation process, when the return is completed, the taxpayer should make sure the preparer has signed it, complete with Social Security number. Before signing it, the client should verify the information and contact the preparer if there are any discrepancies. The taxpayer should never sign a blank return.
