https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/29/world.print_headline: Managua Journal;   Uniting the Germanys, in a Latin American Setting
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/29/world.body_text: **********If there is an important political upheaval in the world, you can probably find out about it by checking the stack of work in Georg Boomgaarden's in-basket. **********The transformation of Eastern Europe: a bureaucratic nightmare. The fall of the Sandinista Government: more paperwork. German reunification: a blizzard of complications. **********Mr. Boomgaarden, the soft-spoken West German Ambassador in this poor Latin American capital, is hardly an obvious partner in the grand deal making that has reshaped world politics. But his job as the envoy of a fast-changing country has turned his embassy into an impossibly busy back-office of diplomacy, scrambling to sort out the accounts from a yearlong binge of international change that has all, it seems, found its way back to Mr. Boomgaarden's desk. **********''We all think we've got problems,'' said another diplomat here. ''But when you see what the Germans are up against, you want to say a prayer.'' **********Embassy Was Tightly Watched **********The trouble began last fall when Mr. Boomgaarden's West German homeland, a critic of the Sandinista Government of Nicaragua, began talking about reconciling with East Germany, a prominent ally of the Sandinistas and sponsor of the Sandinista spying apparatus that, among other things, kept a tight watch on Mr. Boomgaarden's embassy. **********That set of complications was multiplied when the Sandinista Government was defeated in elections here on Feb. 25, reversing the local alliances and status of the two Germanys, and turning both countries' trade and aid relationships with Nicaragua into a tangle of administrative and commercial contradictions. **********The Ambassador's problems were then compounded again when the fast-merging Germanys and the new Nicaraguan Government announced plans for large-scale privatization and the return of confiscated property, throwing into doubt the legal standing and future ownership of thousands of contracts, commitments, loans and credits on all sides, not to mention dozens of embassy houses in Managua and Berlin. **********When the formal reunification of Germany comes on Oct. 3, the good news for Mr. Boomgaarden will be that he automatically inherits all of the local property and staff of the former East Germany, whose embassy here is six times larger than his own. **********Assuming Economic Burden **********The bad news is that he will also assume responsibility for political and economic problems that include an estimated $500 million in East German debts, hundreds of byzantine barter and aid arrangements, dozens of giant unproductive East German investment projects, an unfinished rice mill, Nicaragua's busiest hospital and a grade school with no teachers. **********The large intelligence apparatus manned here by agents of East Germany's secret police agency, the Stasi, collapsed after the agency's headquarters in Berlin was ransacked by demonstrators. But that abrupt departure has only left more diplomatic detritus for Mr. Boomgaarden and his embassy to cope with, including a set of unfulfilled secret contracts between the Stasi and the Sandinista Interior Ministry that the former Sandinista security chief, Tomas Borge Martinez, has publicly demanded must be paid off. **********''He does not seem to realize that the whole institution has vanished,'' a German diplomat said, somewhat perplexed. **********Sorting out the financial web that linked East Germany and the former Sandinista Government has been complicated by the chaos of Nicaragua's own change in government, which has scattered key files and bureaucrats, and drawn a line that never before existed between the state and Sandinista party. **********Conflicting Sets of Numbers **********Looming over everything, moreover, is the problem of what numbers to begin counting. On the East German side, tens of millions of dollars in trade contracts must now be translated into West German marks under complex protocols unifying the German currency. Nicaragua, on the other hand, now has two completely different currencies circulating at the same time, each floating on a bewildering three-tier exchange rate and with hyperinflation that changes prices by the hour. **********As the pace of German reunification accelerated last spring, Mr. Boomgaarden began a series of weekly meetings with his East German counterpart, Matthias Dietrich, focusing particularly on humanitarian aid. **********''We have made a special effort to avoid development ruins - aid projects abandoned in midstream,'' Mr. Boomgaarden said in a rare public comment about his labors. ''That was not the kind of monument we wanted to leave to German reunification.'' **********A recent West German aid mission gave preliminary approval to a plan that will maintain all of the principal East German aid projects here, turning Nicaragua overnight into one of the principal centers of future German aid in Latin America. **********The smooth cooperation between the two embassies has permitted departing East German diplomats to obtain help with crucial but unfamiliar requirements of their lives in a reunified Germany, like setting up personal checking accounts. **********A Change for East Germans **********It has also meant a rather fundamental turnaround for other East German citizens living here, who formerly could not even go to the movies without embassy permission. Under West German privacy laws, Mr. Boomgaarden's staff must ask each of them for permission before even keeping their names on his embassy's courtesy file of local German residents. **********A few key details still remain to be ironed out. At the stroke of midnight on Oct. 3, East German officials here will lose their special status and, as ordinary Germans without a Nicaragua visa, will turn abruptly into illegal aliens. **********But they can celebrate their country's reunification at a elegant reception that is also on the agenda on Oct. 3 at Mr. Boomgaarden's embassy. And as newly minted Westerners, they will be able for the first time to leave Nicaragua and travel home freely through neighboring countries, even the United States. **********When that moment arrives, Mr. Boomgaarden will take a few hours out to preside over the champagne and the cheers - before he gets back to work.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/02/busin.body_text: **********The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun an ''informal inquiry'' into First Interstate Bancorp's $400 million write-down during the fourth period to cover possible losses at the company's troubled Texas operations. **********First Interstate, the nation's largest multistate bank holding company, said in an S.E.C. filing that it had provided the agency with the ''pertinent documents'' requested. It gave no further details about the inquiry. The S.E.C. declined to comment. **********The Los Angeles-based banking company, which operates more than 1,000 branches in 21 states in addition to 19 branches abroad, had 12 percent of its $58.2 billion in assets in Texas at the end of 1988. **********Aside from First Interstate's shaky Texas business, the S.E.C. has also placed the company's troubled Arizona unit under strict supervisory control, the S.E.C. filing said. The action suggests there is regulatory concern over whether First Interstate has been competently managed. **********On the New York Stock Exchange, First Interstate's shares fell $1.25 today, to $36.75.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/05/busin.main_headline: Dow Up 34.22 Points, to a High of 2,935.19
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/05/busin.print_headline: Dow Up 34.22 Points, to a High of 2,935.19
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/05/busin.body_text: **********Without looking back, the stock market advanced into uncharted territory yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average pushing well past 2,900. With an apparent clear horizon for inflation and interest rates, the Dow gained 34.22 points as buying surged in the afternoon. **********The Dow closed at 2,935.19, setting a record high again after it reached the 2,900 mark Friday, ending a week that saw the average increase 80 points. Other indexes were strong. The S.&P. 500 posted a fifth straight high at 367.40, up 4.24. The Dow Jones transportation index reached a high for the year, gaining 18.43 points, and the utility index rose 3.71 points. **********Trading volume reached 175.5 million shares, down from Friday's 187.9 million. Advancing issues numbered 1,105, while only 477 declined. Financial issues were strong. **********The Dow hugged the 2,900 mark most of the morning as blue chips traded in a narrow range. In the final hours, stocks surged as more money managers bought in and selling abated. **********''It's still a case of some newly converted optimists flush with cash and undercommitted to the equity market,'' said Michael Metz, chief market analyst for Oppenheimer & Company. **********''There's really been no radical change in the external world,'' Mr. Metz said. ''But it looks like we are having a slowdown without a recession. And if the Fed is going to change it will be toward easing interest rates. All of this is a recipe for higher stock prices.'' **********Transportation Index Advances **********Some analysts saw confirmation of broad market strength in the Dow transportation and utility indexes. The transportation index surpassed its high for 1990 as it rose to 1,207.85. The 12-month top of 1,532.01 is much higher, but was distorted by earlier merger and buyout activity, analysts said. **********''A lot of analysts are saying that the market is being narrowly led by blue chips,'' said Robert H. Stovall of Stovall/Twenty-First Advisers. ''There was confirmation that it was not a true-blue market in the form of the S.&P. 500 index. Now today we have a transporation new high for the year and the recently dormant utilities are beginning to move up in response to lower interest rates.'' **********Also helped by the outlook for lower interest rates were financial issues. American Express gained 1 7/8, to 31 5/8. BankAmerica, rose 1 1/4, to 32 5/8, and Federal National Mortgage was up 2, to 43 5/8. **********First Interstate added 6 1/4, to 44 7/8, with a 500,000-share block traded at 41 1/4, and Wells Fargo jumped 3 5/8, to 84 1/2. **********First Interstate said it knew of no corporate developments for the rise in its stock. A Wells Fargo spokesman told Reuters that there has been speculation about a matchup for six months or more but declined to confirm or deny Wells Fargo's interest. **********Corroon & Black, a United States insurance broker that plans to merge with Willis Faber, a London insurance broker, fell 2 1/4, to 34 1/4. The deal valued Corroon & Black shares at $38.15, traders said. **********L.A. Gear, the athletic footwear maker that was hit hard last week on its outlook, fell 1/8, to 30 5/8, leading the most active list. **********Wal-Mart Stores gained 2 1/4, to 60 5/8, as the company told of plans to double the number of stores by the end of the decade. **********Compaq Computer jumped 5 3/8, to 124 3/4. Michele Preston, an analyst with Cowen & Company, reiterated a buy recommendation. **********Philip Morris continued active and strong, at 44 1/2, up 1 1/4. **********The Amex market value index closed up 0.57, to 364.40. The Nasdaq composite rose 3.48, to 465.61.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/24/world.main_headline: Angolan Chief Is Said to Cancel Plans to Visit U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/24/world.print_headline: Angolan Chief Is Said to Cancel Plans to Visit U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/24/world.body_text: **********Americans close to the Angolan Government said today that President Jose Eduardo dos Santos had canceled a visit to the United States scheduled for next month. **********Randall Robinson, executive director of TransAfrica, an American lobby on African issues, said the cancellation resulted from pressure by the United States. **********The United States has no diplomatic relations with Angola and supplies weapons to guerrillas fighting the Luanda Government. But from time to time, American officials meet Angolan officials, and some elements of the Luanda Government have expressed a desire to improve relations with Washington. **********''The trip has been canceled,'' Mr. Robinson said in an interview after meeting with the Angolan representative to the United Nations, Manuel Pedro Pacavira. ''Dos Santos is not coming. This is a result of enormous American pressure to put off the trip.'' **********'A Private Visit' **********Fenton Communications, a public-relations concern that represents the Angolan Government, said it understood that Mr. dos Santos was not coming. He had been scheduled to meet with members of Congress in Washington and to visit Atlanta, Richmond and Los Angeles in an eight-day visit beginning Feb. 6. **********A State Department spokesman said tonight: ''We have heard the reports, but cannot confirm whether President dos Santos has canceled his visit to the United States. The Administration has not placed any obstacles in the way of his visit.'' **********The Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, Herman J. Cohen, is now visiting southern Africa. He plans to arrive Wednesday in Angola and is scheduled to meet Thursday with President dos Santos. **********Arrangements for Mr. dos Santos's visit to the United States were among the topics to be discussed with Mr. Cohen, a State Department official said tonight. The official said the Angolan President's trip to the United States was to have been ''a private visit,'' to attend a United Nations conference on narcotics and to meet with various groups in this country. **********Gillian Gunn, a senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, said ''the question of a visit to the United States by President dos Santos has been a subject of great controversy'' in Angola's governing party, the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola. **********Some Angolans favored the trip because they thought that Mr. dos Santos could lobby for an end to American aid to the Angolan guerrillas, Miss Gunn said. ''But hard-liners in Angola felt that the trip would not accomplish anything and that efforts would be better spent on a military offensive'' against the rebels, she said. **********Mr. Robinson said, ''It violates a cardinal principle of an open society for the Administration to squelch an American opportunity for public debate on this issue.'' **********Miss Gunn said she did not know of American pressure on Luanda to cancel the visit.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/09/busin.main_headline: Dow Falls by 34.95 in Fourth Straight Loss
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/09/busin.print_headline: Dow Falls by 34.95 in Fourth Straight Loss
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/09/busin.body_text: **********The slide in stock prices extended to a fourth day yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average fell sharply, dropping 34.95 points, to 2,862.38. The blue-chip index is now down by 72.81 from its historic high on Monday and off 38.69 from last Friday's close. **********The industrial average finished the week with some computerized sell programs magnifying the trend downward in relatively light trading. Retail and technology stocks were among the weaker groups. **********The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was also off, by 4.44 points, to 358.71. Declining issues outnumbered gainers, by 1,010 to 458. Volume reached 142.6 million shares, down from 160.4 million on Thursday. **********''It was a sleepy market, with not a lot of volume and no conviction on the downside,'' said Tracy G. Herrick, an economist at Jefferies & Company. Soft bond prices contributed to the weakness. **********Bernard Spilko, senior vice president at Bank Julius Baer in New York, said there was little news to move stocks and the fact that the Dow closed below the 2,900 mark on Thursday ''was mentally a little upsetting and that is just feeding on itself.'' **********Some advisers have been telling clients to sell some of the major stocks as overvalued, he said. A favorite, Walt Disney, for example, dropped 4 7/8, to 123 3/8. **********Some other big stocks with losses were Eastman Kodak, off 3/4, to 41 3/4; Philip Morris, 5/8, to 44 1/4; Coca-Cola, 1/2, to 44 1/4; Procter & Gamble, 1 5/8, to 80; Merck, 1 1/2, to 80, and Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, 1 1/8, to 82 7/8. **********Financial stocks were mostly lower as enthusiasm about the possibility of lower interest rates waned. Among money-center banks, BankAmerica dropped 1/2, to 32; Citicorp, 1/8, to 24; Manufacturers Hanover, 7/8, to 36 5/8; J. P. Morgan, 5/8, to 37 3/4, and Chemical Banking, 1/8, to 28 3/8. **********Mortgage issues also slipped. Federal Home Loan Mortgage (Freddie Mac) fell 1 1/8, to 78 1/2, and Federal National Mortgage (Fannie Mae), 1/2, to 42 1/8. **********Several analysts said that bearish comments by Barton Biggs, Morgan Stanley's investment strategist, helped to dampen the market. **********Looking ahead, Mr. Herrick of Jefferies said that next week was a big week for economic numbers and there was a hint that they could hurt the market. The Producer Price Index is scheduled to be issued Thursday, followed by the Consumer Price Index and industrial production figures on Friday. **********The economist said these statistics might show an upturn in inflation, giving the Federal Reserve more reason to hold credit tighter. **********Sell Programs Cause Drop **********In yesterday's trading, four sell programs pushed the market down, said Birinyi Associates, a research firm. The largest sell program started at about 10 A.M. and pushed the market down 15.77 points in 15 minutes. Another took place starting at 1:12 P.M. and took 12.62 points. One buy program pushed the market up by 3.15 points. **********Among computer stocks, I.B.M. fell 1 7/8, to 118 3/4. despite reiteration of a Paine Webber buy recommendation by an analyst, Stephen Smith. He said I.B.M. had aggressive plans for its mainframe computer business. **********Microsoft Rises by 1 1/2 **********Apple Computer, trading over the counter, lost 3/4, to 38 1/4. Sun Microsystems also was down 3/4, to 30 5/8, and Compaq Computer fell 2 5/8, to 119 1/8. Microsoft, however, rose by 1 1/2, to 73 1/2. **********Among retail stocks, the Gap continued to drop as analysts expressed unhappiness with its May sales figures. It lost 2 3/8, to 56 1/8. Melville dropped 1 1/4, to 50 1/4; the Limited lost 1, to 46 3/8; Dillard Department Stores fell 2 5/8, to 85 1/4, and Home Depot was off 5/8, to 56 3/4. **********Conagra, the big agricultural company and food processor, added 1 1/4, to 33 1/4, a day after it announced plans to buy Beatrice Foods. **********Maytag jumped 2, to 19. The appliance company said it did not comment on unusual activity in its stock. **********The Amex market-value index sank 2.40, to 361.17. The Nasdaq composite index fell 3.22, to 460.87.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/31/busin.body_text: **********Japan's vehicle exports fell 4.9 percent in September from a year earlier, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association reported today. The companies exported 509,155 cars, trucks and buses in September, the association said. Exports to the United States and the European Community fell, reflecting increased output from factories abroad. The auto makers shipped 134,827 units to Europe in September, up 2.8 percent from a year earlier. But exports to the 12 members of the European Community were down 7.4 percent, to 88,392 units. Exports to the United States totaled 207,762 units, down 12.7 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/30/world.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;   Ex-Bulgarian Official Is Held On Charges Linked to Camp
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/30/world.body_text: **********Authorities today arrested a retired Deputy Interior Minister who ran a camp in northern Bulgaria in which hundreds of prisoners may have been killed during Todor Zhivkov's Government. **********The arrest of the former official, Gen. Mircho Spasov, 80 years old, came after a series of reports about the camp that have stirred memories of Stalinist repression. **********The arrest, tersely reported by the state press agency, came a day after General Spasov told the Communist Party newspaper Rabotnichesko Delo that he visited the camp in Lovech only once.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/08/world.main_headline: Ethnic Albanian Majority Fights Serbia and Party in a Yugoslav Province
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/08/world.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;   Ethnic Albanian Majority Fights Serbia and Party in a Yugoslav Province
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/08/world.body_text: **********They have scant access to the local press, none to large meeting halls, no computer or fax machine, no legal status and no bank account, but the freshly minted League of Democrats of Kosovo, representing ethnic Albanians, is rapidly becoming a major political force in Yugoslavia. **********Leaders of the league, formed in late December, asserted this week that their registered membership exceeded 300,000 in the population of 1.7 million ethnic Albanians who inhabit the Serbian province of Kosovo. **********This has begun to create headaches for the Yugoslav federal leadership but more specifically for the Serbian officials headquartered in Belgrade and here in Pristina, the provincial capital. **********Later this month, the league intends to convene a congress, said its chairman, Ibrahim Rugova, a 44-year-old literary critic, although that prospect seems somewhat murky, under the martial law stipulations imposed by the Belgrade authorities barring large public assemblies. **********Nevertheless, within two months the League of Democrats has emerged as the principal voice of the Kosovo Albanians. The Communist Party has lost over half its members here, reducing it to about 50,000, the bulk of them Serbs who are locked in a struggle with the more numerous Albanians for control of Kosovo. **********Former Communists Join League **********A number of former Communists have joined the league and Mr. Rugova said that more than 2,000 members were ''non-Albanians,'' including some Serbs and Montenegrins. **********The league's program, issued by Mr. Rugova and his executive board, endorses general democratic principles, including a multiparty parliamentary system and an independent judiciary. But it is vague on the critical question of the intentions of Kosovo's Albanians toward the Serbian republic, which Belgrade holds is sovereign here. **********It says simply that ''Kosovo belongs to Albanians, Serbs, Montenegrins, Turks and others and they should all work together for its development and progress.'' **********This leaves most Serbs highly suspicious that the democratic movement launched by Mr. Rugova and his friends is merely a camouflage for what remains a nationalistic grouping with separatist tendencies. Mr. Rugova and his associates have been denounced in the Belgrade press. **********Mr. Rugova's answer to the charge is that the league is simply seeking ''greater autonomy'' for Kosovo, which was established as an autonomous province of Serbia. The Serbian authorities essentially overruled that autonomy last year, and have moved to impose direct rule from Belgrade. **********Mr. Rugova's associate, Veton Surroi, a 28-year-old journalist, said that he saw Kosovo becoming a ''federal unit'' of a Yugoslavia under a new constitution. The current Constitution established six republics and made Vojvodina and Kosovo autonomous provinces of Serbia, the largest republic. **********''We want to apply democracy to Kosovo,'' Mr. Surroi said, ''with a free parliament, an end to martial law, and the freeing of political prisoners.'' **********There is little autonomy to be seen these days in Kosovo, where in the wake of violent clashes the army and special federal and Serbian riot police units are deployed. A police curfew of 9 P.M. is being enforced. **********Thousands of ethnic Albanians have responded by staying away from work, schools and Pristina University. Mr. Rugova said that despite the league's popularity, it did not have the power to start or stop such Albanian protests. **********Two other ethnic Albanian organizations have become active here. There is the Council for the Protection of Human Rights, founded by two professors at Pristina University, and the Kosovo chapter of the Initiative for a Democratic Yugoslavia.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/13/busin.main_headline: Panel Urges Halt in Stock Trades During Times of Stress in Markets
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/13/busin.print_headline: Panel Urges Halt in Stock Trades During Times of Stress in Markets
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/13/busin.body_text: **********A panel created by the New York Stock Exchange to restore investor confidence after the stock plunge in October 1989 recommended yesterday that the Government require most financial markets to close for as much as a full day at times of great volatility. **********But the panel, which included the heads of Wall Street brokerages and leading corporations, recommended only minor curbs on computerized program trading, an investment strategy often blamed for aggravating market swings. **********''If we had felt there were abuses, we would have recommended more'' restrictions, said Roger B. Smith, chairman of the General Motors Corporation and head of the panel. ''Program trading is not the single big issue, the big bad bear.'' **********Another conclusion of the panel was that regulation of the stock and stock index futures markets be unified under one Federal agency. A proposal for such authority is pending in Congress, and the battle has already become heated. **********The panel, which included the heads of corporations like A.T.&T. and International Paper, was formed amid the public outcry after the Dow Jones industrial average fell more than 190 points in the final 90 minutes of trading on Oct. 13. **********Although the Big Board group, the Market Volatility and Investor Confidence Panel, recommended increased restrictions on a controversial form of program trading, the members concluded that the computer-assisted investing technique was an ''appropriate'' activity for investors. **********But one panel member, an outspoken critic of the form of program trading known as stock index arbitrage, described the panel's meetings over the last six months as contentious and complained that other members were unwilling to compromise on a number of subjects. **********''The recommendations are fine, but they don't go far enough,'' said Stephen B. Timbers, a senior vice president of Kemper Financial Services Inc. in Chicago, who has criticized Wall Street firms for program trading. **********Because the panel was dominated by members from the Wall Street brokerage firms and corporations whose stocks are listed on the exchange, some investors said its conclusions highlighted the rivalry between the stock market in New York and the stock index futures market in Chicago. **********Reaction Is Mixed **********Wall Street reaction to the recommendations was mixed. In general, however, the proposed restrictions, which would apply to stock, options and futures markets, would be likely to convince individuals that another huge one-day drop would not occur, professional investors said. ''In the end it will restore investor confidence,'' said Howard Stein, chairman of the Dreyfus Corporation, a large mutual fund organization. **********The panel also found that investors were more worried about the honesty of brokers than about program trading. [Market Place, page D10.]  A number of traders and financial executives were pleased with the recommendation for a single regulator but were disturbed by the call for the ''circuit breakers'' that would halt trading after specific market moves. ''I'm personally very nervous about circuit breakers,'' said Donald Marron, chairman of Paine Webber Group Inc. **********The proposed restrictions were seen as virtually insuring that there would be no repetition of the situation on Oct. 19, 1987, when the Dow fell more than 500 points. The panel recommended trading halts of various lengths after moves of 100, 200, 300 and 400 points. If the Dow rose or fell 400 points in a single day, the market would close for the day. **********The halts were viewed as giving investors time to learn more about the sudden price moves. But such restrictions will make it more difficult for investors to sell stocks during market turmoil, said the chief executive of a large communications company. ''Somebody who says I want out cannot limit his losses,'' said Charles Wohlstetter, the chairman of the Contel Corporation. **********Relaxation on Buybacks **********The panel also urged that during turmoil the rules governing corporate buybacks of stock should be relaxed. The day after the 1987 crash, the market got a lift when a number of corporations said they would buy back their securities. **********The panel endorsed an exchange proposal that would require firms engaging in arbitrage to use it in a ''stabilizing'' manner after 50-point moves in the Dow. For practical purposes, exchange officials said, nearly all index arbitrage would be impossible after such a move. **********Wall Street firms that abandoned the practice for their own accounts will not immediately resume such trading, some executives said. Spokesmen at Morgan Stanley & Company and Salomon Brothers, two firms that were among the biggest users of the technique in recent years, said the firms would not resume such trades for their own accounts. **********The proposals must be approved by an array of regional stock exchanges and Federal regulatory agencies like the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. Current trading restrictions of stocks are handled by the various exchanges and the S.E.C., while regulation of the futures and options markets is under the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, the Chicago Board of Trade and the commodity commission. **********Bitter Battle Expected **********Earlier this month a bill was introduced in the Senate to transfer jurisdiction of the futures contracts to the S.E.C. Lobbyists for the exchanges expect this battle to be a bitter one. **********In Chicago, where stock index futures contracts are traded on the Merc, officials disagreed with the panel's recommendation for one regulator. In a statement released yesterday the exchange said a single Federal regulator ''would be unnecessary and detrimental to the best interests of United States financial markets.'' **********The panel did not find widespread evidence of trading abuses by professional investors or brokers although executives on the panel stressed that it was not created as an investigatory group. In fact, the executives recommended that the exchanges and regulators should improve their ability to uncover trading abuses. **********''The paper trail is not as well documented as it should be,'' said James L. Cochrane, senior vice president of the stock exchange. **********No Agency Mentioned **********Even though the Big Board's panel urged that one regulator oversee the financial markets, it deliberately did not mention any agency. Because Wall Street firms have traditionally been regulated by the S.E.C., however, it is widely agreed that this agency is favored. The panel members said they found no evidence that a single regulator would affect volatility in the markets but a majority of the members believe that such a step would improve investor confidence. **********The panel's recommendation for trading halts would replace all other circuit breakers in domestic markets. They would affect trading in all domestic markets and would be coordinated among the stock, futures and options markets around the country. To be adopted, the recommendations would have to be approved by the regional stock exchanges and the S.E.C. **********A spokesman for the American Stock Exchange described the proposals yesterday as ''reasonable and responsible'' but said they would require ''detailed'' study. **********The proposed system would work as follows: Trading in stocks would be halted for one hour if the Dow moved up or down 100 points from the previous day's close. If the average moved 200 points from the previous close, trading would be halted for 90 minutes. Trading would be halted for two hours if the market moved 300 or 400 points. Since the trading day is six and a half hours, the cumulative effect of those halts would be to end trading for the day. **********Price 'Indications' Required **********During the halts, market makers would be required to provide investors with ''indications'' of where prices might trade based on their flow of orders. Such ''shadow'' quotes would give investors a hint of expected trading. **********The panel recommended that after the stock moves, trading in all financial instruments around the country be halted for the same period. **********Since the 1987 crash, executives at the stock exchange and the Chicago Merc have experimented with various trading restrictions in stocks and stock index futures contracts, but there has been little coordination between the markets. After the plunge on Oct. 13, 1989, some traders complained that selling was aggravated because they were unable to sell futures contracts. **********A number of market professionals said yesterday that if the proposals were adopted and trading was halted in all domestic markets, institutional investors would be likely to seek to trade in London and Tokyo. ''The era of global capital markets is here, and if the stock exchange doesn't want to fill the need we'll go elsewhere,'' said Michael A. Petrino, president of Matrix Capital Management, a Stamford, Conn., firm that invests $1 billion for pension funds. **********Members of Panel **********Following are the members of the panel: **********Roger B. Smith, chairman and chief executive of General Motors. **********Robert E. Allen, chairman and chief executive of A.T.&T. **********Rand V. Araskog, chairman and chief executive of ITT. **********John S. Chalsty, president and chief executive of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. **********James Cloonan, president and chairman of the advisory board of the American Association of Individual Investors. **********Benjamin F. Edwards 3d, chairman, chief executive and president of A.G. Edwards. **********John A. Georges, chairman and chief executive of International Paper. **********S. https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/12/busin.main_headline: Pepsico Out of South Africa Following Failure of Bottler
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/12/busin.print_headline: Pepsico Out of South Africa Following Failure of Bottler
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/12/busin.body_text: **********Pepsico Inc. is ending its small soft-drink business in South Africa, following the failure of its Cape Town bottler. **********In response to an inquiry, a company spokesman said yesterday that the independently owned bottler, Pepsi-Cola Africa of Cape Town, was liquidating its assets this week following ''serious financial problems.'' **********The franchised bottler's assets, including bottles and bottling equipment, will be sold to a South African Coca-Cola franchisee, the spokesman said. But a spokesman for the Coca-Cola Company in Atlanta could not immediately confirm this. **********No Company-Owned Bottlers **********Like Coca-Cola, Pepsico has no company-owned bottlers in South Africa, but it has about 150 franchised Kentucky Fried Chicken restaurants and 12 franchised Pizza Hut outlets. **********The Investor Responsibilty Research Center, a nonprofit research firm that focuses on social issues, said that 175 American companies, including Pepsico and Coca-Cola, had a ''nonequity'' interest in South Africa, meaning that they maintain contracts, licenses or franchisees. **********Pepsico, which is based in Purchase, N.Y., said it had no plans to search for another franchisee to sell its soft drinks. ''We're effectively out of the business,'' a spokesman said. **********Pepsi-Cola has long been in a losing battle with Coca-Cola in South Africa. Pepsi's bottler sold about two million cases last year for a market share of about 1.7 percent, in contrast to more than 170 million cases of Coca-Cola for about a 70 percent share, the Pepsico spokesman said. **********Small One May Still Be Left **********There still may be one tiny Pepsi franchisee left, bottling about 10,000 cases annually. ''We're not sure,'' the Pepsico spokesman said. ''But at any rate that's so few cases you could practically carry them away by hand.'' **********Pepsico sold its company-owned facilities to Pepsi-Cola Africa in 1985, following Pepsico's acquisition of those facilities from another troubled bottler. It is Pepsico's normal practice to seek franchisees for foreign bottlers. Indeed, about 95 percent of them are independently owned, rather than company-owned. **********Although political conditions have improved with the release of Nelson Mandela, the black South African leader, ''from an economic point of view,'' the Pepsico spokesman said, ''it just doesn't make any sense to stay with the business.'' **********The company said it had not been able to find a viable bottler, ''and whatever strategic sense it may make, we have to admit that Coca-Cola'' is doing a good job there, the spokesman added.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/29/world.main_headline: Pretoria Raids Union and Seizes Leaders
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/29/world.print_headline: Pretoria Raids Union and Seizes Leaders
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/29/world.body_text: **********The South African police raided the Johannesburg headquarters of the country's biggest black labor federation and arrested several of its senior leaders today after union members reportedly abducted a black undercover agent, assaulted him and then forced him to address a news conference. **********Col. Franz Malherbe, the officer who led the raid, said the detained leaders of the Congress of South African Trade Unions - including Secretary General Jay Naidoo and Assistant Secretary General Sydney Mufamadi - had been seized on charges of being accomplices to an assault. The federation, which is allied to the African National Congress and the South African Communist Party, is widely known by its acronym, Cosatu. **********''This is not an operation related to an unrest situation, but criminal charges that we are investigating,'' Colonel Malherbe said. ''One of our police constables was allegedly removed at about 11:30 A.M. from Rissik Street by Cosatu members, taken to their headquarters and allegedly assaulted.'' The officer said the labor officials could apply for bail after 48 hours in detention as suspects in an assault case. Union officials said they would apply for bail tonight. **********Introduced to Reporters **********Earlier, the purported agent was introduced to reporters at a news conference shortly before the police raid. **********Cosatu officials identified him as Joseph Maleka, who appeared before reporters with a sweater pulled over his head. He said he had been recruited in Sebokeng township, south of Johannesburg, at the weekend and given training in Johannesburg's John Vorster Square police station on Monday in the use of a two-way radio. **********When reporters prevailed upon him to use the radio, a voice at the other end told him to ''turn off your radio or shut up.'' **********Before his arrest, Mr. Naidoo, a well-known labor official, told reporters union supporters had seen Mr. Maleka on Rissik Street, a Johannesburg street that leads past National Acceptances House, the modest high-rise in the downtown area where Cosatu and the National Union of Mineworkers have their headquarters. **********Photographs of Militants **********Mr. Maleka had been carrying a two-way radio and two photographs of Geraldine Fraser, a labor militant recently returned to South Africa from exile. His mission, for which he had been promised the equivalent of $200, was to radio the police when Ms. Fraser left the Cosatu building ''so that they can arrest her,'' Mr. Maleka told reporters. **********It was not clear from his appearance at the news conference if he had been assaulted. Labor officials said they doubted Mr. Maleka's assertion that he had been recruited in recent days and Colonel Malherbe said ''that could have been his cover story.'' **********The incident was the second time in a week that Cosatu leaders have been arrested by the police. Last week Cyril Ramaphosa, the federation's leader, was arrested and later freed on $20 bail for purportedly taking part in an illegal march in Natal. **********Further Strains Seen **********Because of the labor federation's close relationship with the African National Congress, the detentions seem certain to further strain the relationship between the Government and the congress. It came after two weeks of factional violence in black townships in which the congress has accused the police of siding with its adversaries. **********''Unless President de Klerk does something concrete, unless he goes beyond his verbal assuarances and roots out those elements committed to undermining the progressive movements, then we must presume tacit Government support for these actions,'' Mr. Naidoo said before his arrest. **********The township fighting pitted supporters of the A.N.C. against the Zulu Inkatha movement of Chief Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi. **********A Cosatu statement tonight expressed outrage at the arrests, saying that the labor federation's representatives had called the security police to take their supposed undercover agent away. When the police arrived, however, they arrested officeholders, invaded the headquarters office and searched it.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/07/world.main_headline: U.S. USED ROMANIA TO GET SOVIET ARMS
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/07/world.print_headline: U.S. USED ROMANIA TO GET SOVIET ARMS
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/07/world.body_text: **********The United States acquired some of the Soviet Union's most advanced weaponry over the last decade from underground arms traders, corrupt military officials and even Communist political leaders, current and former officials said today. **********Created by the Pentagon and run largely by the Central Intelligence Agency, the weapons-buying programs have spent several hundred million dollars since 1980 in Eastern Europe and in third world countries that were Soviet clients, those officials said. **********The Washington Post reported today that the United States spent $40 million in the last 10 years on the purchase of advanced Soviet arms from a network run by two brothers of Nicolae Ceausescu, the Romanian dictator who was deposed and executed in December. **********The report was confirmed by a Bush Administration official and by a retired senior Pentagon officer, who said the Ceausescu operation provided hardware of ''extraordinary significance'' to the United States in the early 1980's. **********Program Declined in Importance **********The strategic importance of the buying program has dimmed somewhat since then, one official said, noting that the Soviet Union has since allowed American military experts to inspect some of that nation's most advanced battlefield hardware. This official and others who described the weapons purchases spoke on the condition that they not be named. **********The account in The Post stated that roughly $8 million of the $40 million spent in Romania was diverted to Swiss bank accounts controlled by the Ceausescu family, with the rest going to middlemen. **********The arms sales were controlled by Lieut. Gen. Ilie Ceausescu, then Deputy Defense Minister, and Marin Ceausescu, who ran Romania's trade mission in Vienna and who negotiated the sales, the newspaper said. It quoted one unnamed official who said the operation could not have progressed without the knowledge of Nicolae Ceausescu, who, though a hard-line Communist, was a bitter rival of the Soviet Union. **********The retired Pentagon official said today that the Ceausescus' principal motive for selling arms to the West was financial. Confirming The Post's account, he said that in the early 1980's, the Ceausescu network sold the United States an advanced Soviet anti-aircraft system called the Shilka as well as mobile rocket launchers and military radar systems. **********Millions Offered for a Tank **********He confirmed that the Pentagon was prepared to spend millions of dollars in 1981 to secure a Soviet T-72 tank through the Ceausescus, but that the deal fall apart hours before the tank was to be shipped from Romania. **********The Pentagon went on to acquire a T-72 tank in the late 1980's from a Middle Eastern nation, that official said. It has since been supplanted in the Soviet Army by a more modern version. **********As in many other weapons-buying programs, officials said, the Romanian venture was initiated by the Pentagon, which selected the types of Soviet weapons it wished to acquire. Case officers of the Central Intelligence Agency negotiated and paid for the arms. **********The operations directorate of the Joint Chiefs of Staff coordinated the roles of the Pentagon and the C.I.A. to insure that the operation worked smoothly, officials said. Pentagon officials have frequently criticized the C.I.A. for assigning a low priority to arms purchases in the intelligence establishment. **********Looking for an Edge **********Like other Soviet equipment that is purchased, the Romanian-supplied weapons were dismantled and studied by Pentagon experts. The findings were used to design American hardware with a specific technological edge over the Soviet models. **********For example, The Post reported, the Pentagon used its analyses of Soviet radar acquired from Romania to design Stealth aircraft that could evade radar detection. **********Two Pentagon officials said today that Romania generally did not receive the most advanced Soviet weaponry because of its strained ties with Moscow. Poland, Czechoslovakia and East Germany, all closely allied with the Soviets in the 1980's, were considered more attractive targets for the secret buying program, they said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/02/world.main_headline: DID GANGS BENEFIT FROM PAPAL VISIT?
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/02/world.print_headline: DID GANGS BENEFIT FROM PAPAL VISIT?
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/02/world.body_text: **********For five days last month, Pope John Paul II traveled in and around hard-pressed Naples, visiting blighted neighborhoods on a crusade against the Camorra, the local version of the Sicilian Mafia. **********Be honest, he excoriated Neapolitan politicians. Be courageous, he urged business leaders. Stand up to gangster threats of violence. "You businessmen must be in the front line in this battle," he said. "Don't give up." **********Now, prosecutors in Naples say they are looking into the possibility that organized crime figures skimmed off some of the more than $7 million in public funds that were spent to welcome the Pope. **********The disclosure of their investigation this week startled even Italians who had considered themselves inured to reports about underworld predators.  Outrages Out of Control **********Italian Government leaders bluntly acknowledged that they have lost control of large segments of the country's southland to clans of the Mafia, the Camorra and their Calabrian cousin, the 'Ndrangheta. Rarely does a day pass without word of a fresh outrage, be it a spectacular holdup or a murder spree like the rapid series of shootouts among rival gangs last Tuesday that left eight people dead in the span of 18 minutes in the decaying Sicilian town of Gela, population 85,000. **********But to steal -- assuming the charges are proved -- from under the gaze of the Pope, especially while he was in town to denounce the mob, struck Italian press commentators and others as carrying temerity to a new level. **********Even before John Paul arrived in Naples on Nov. 9, some people there were warning that public funds for the visit had been misused. At the city's Cardarelli Hospital, the largest in the Italian South, a group of patients sent an open letter to the Pope saying his journey had "unleashed a serious waste of money that could have been used for helpful purposes." **********Among the questionable spending written about in recent days by the Italian press was a $900,000 appropriation to restore an old church that John Paul wound up never visiting because of security concerns.  Where Did $1.3 Million Go? **********But the focus of the criminal investigation, prosecutors say, is the ultimate destination of $1.3 million in construction contracts, including several that involved building a huge platform in the heart of Naples for a papal Mass. **********Opposition politicians, whose accusations got the inquiry under way, claimed that city officials had ignored normal bidding procedures to hand a contract for the platform to a company in Bologna. It is also charged that the platform was put in the wrong place and had to be rebuilt. This time, the contract went to a company in a Neopolitan suburb that is said to be a Camorra stronghold. **********In addition, the investigators are examining charges that the city paid too much for about 1,000 rented chairs that were put near an improvised altar set upon the platform. Beyond agreeing to possibly excessive rental fees, it seems that local officials paid twice in some cases. Many chairs were stolen the night before the Pope's Mass and had to be replaced.  Wrongdoing Is Denied **********A city commissioner responsible for construction, Diego Tesorone, denied any wrongdoing and said he would prove it to the prosecutors. From the Vatican there has been no comment. Nonetheless, the Pope's contempt for organized crime and "the degeneration of public life" that it causes is hardly in doubt. **********His Naples visit, the longest journey to an Italian city during his papacy, was seen as a symbol of the Vatican's faith in the region, despite all its troubles. Another hopeful sign came a few days ago when Fiat, the Italian auto giant, announced that it would build two new factories in the South, creating 8,300 jobs for a high-unemployment area that many industries have fled. **********Still, life is often an uphill fight in that hard-scrabble area. **********One day after the Fiat announcement, the state electric company said it had stopped work on a new power station in the Calabrian town of Gioia Tauro, even though nearly $2.5 billion had already been spent on the project. It had been discovered, the company said, that too many local companies hired for the construction were Mafia-connected.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/12/busin.main_headline: Talking Business; with Breeden of the S.E.C.;   Risks of Market Fragmentation
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/12/busin.print_headline: Talking Business; with Breeden of the S.E.C.;   Risks of Market Fragmentation
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/12/busin.body_text: **********Richard C. Breeden, the 40-year-old head of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has a knack for making waves. In his short tenure, the Bush Administration appointee has taken a hard line toward people suspected of violating securities laws, has made overtures toward helping Eastern Europe develop stock exchanges and has made it clear he wants to eliminate creaky regulations that may inhibit United States companies in global competition. **********One of his most controversial moves has been an effort to regulate some of the financial futures now under the jurisdiction of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. And he is strongly backing a measure introduced by Representative Edward J. Markey, a Massachusetts Democrat, that would empower the S.E.C. to suspend some program trading and close the exchanges in an emergency. Mr. Breeden was in New York recently and discussed several issues. **********Q. Where do things stand legislatively on regulations for Wall Street? **********A. The most important is the Administration's new legislation, which has three objectives. The measure would put the S.E.C. in charge of overseeing margins on stock index futures, would eliminate the ''exclusivity clause'' that has inhibited Wall Street's ability to develop new hybrid products, and would transfer the jurisdiction for regulating stock index futures from the commodity commission to the S.E.C. This is a significant step in dealing with instability in the current system. **********Q. Is passage assured? **********A. There's a vigorous campaign under way by the futures industry to block it. But the odds are very high that this step will be taken. The United States is the only nation that maintains this market fragmentation - and the risk and costs it entails. I don't think we're willing to see leadership in both the futures and securities markets move overseas. **********Q. The Chicago markets see the bill as an effort by the traditional New York markets to assert their dominion. How do you respond? **********A. That's absolutely groundless. The Secretary of the Treasury, the chairman of the Federal Reserve and the chairman of the S.E.C. are urging reform. We've all watched severe risk in the stock and futures markets not once, but twice, in 1987 and 1989. Last Oct. 13, 50 million Americans lost $160 billion of value in their pension and retirement accounts in 90 minutes. The element that introduced the greatest amount of risk was that we went into that day, just as we did in 1987, with 97.8 percent leverage in the stock index futures market. And then, in the midst of the crisis, those exchanges were trying to dramatically raise margins, which sucked out liquidity and created further selling pressure. **********Q. Had you been the S.E.C. chairman in October 1987, what would you have done? **********A. We wouldn't have entered that day with margins of 2.2 percent on stock index futures. If you had a minimum margin of 15 percent, you then would have the flexibility to cut margins to 10 percent when the market was under stress to inject liquidity. Under the Markey bill, the futures exchanges would have the authority to recommend margins. But if they proposed going from 14 percent to 2.2 percent, we would have the authority to say ''that's too low.'' We'd expect to see margins set in line with those in the options market. **********Q. Isn't computer index arbitrage almost always destablizing to markets? **********A. I would not make a blanket statement. Index arbitrage is a symptom of an underlying problem and that problem is the vast differences in leverage rules that apply to the same products. If you have $100,000 you can buy $200,000 worth of S.&P. 500 stocks or $4.4 million worth of them through the index futures market, and the index futures market will react more forcefully to economic stimuli. **********Q. What sort of sentence should Michael Milken get? **********A. A substantial period of incarceration would be appropriate. **********Q. Should we have a clearer definition of insider trading. **********A. The basic prohibition against insider trading as elaborated by the Supreme Court and other courts is reasonably clear and probably more clear than if we had a long, tortuous statutory definition. **********Q. Will the savings and loan crisis lead to securities fraud prosecutions? **********A. It may. It is a matter of public record that several institutions that were customers of Mr. Milken have failed and involved losses to the taxpayers of several billion dollars.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/01/busin.snippet: LEAD: The Tosco Corporation, which owns an oil refinery in California and a fertilizer factory in Florida, said today that it had named John J. Lee president and chief operating officer.
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/01/busin.main_headline:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

Tosco Appoints Director To Management Posts
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/01/busin.print_headline:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

Tosco Appoints Director To Management Posts
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/01/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: The Tosco Corporation, which owns an oil refinery in California and a fertilizer factory in Florida, said today that it had named John J. Lee president and chief operating officer. **********The Tosco Corporation, which owns an oil refinery in California and a fertilizer factory in Florida, said today that it had named John J. Lee president and chief operating officer. **********Mr. Lee is a principal in the Argus Group, Tosco's largest shareholder, and as a Tosco director has been in charge of the company's Seminole Fertilizer Corporation since last fall. **********Another principal at Argus is Thomas D. O'Malley, who became chairman, chief executive and president of Tosco last year. Mr O'Malley and Mr. Lee met in the early 1980's when they both worked for Phibro-Salomon, the financial services and commodities trading company. **********In a statement, Mr. O'Malley said: ''John Lee, with his strong technical background in chemical engineering, knowledge of refining and many years of broad practical managerial experience in the petroleum and chemical processing businesses, provides a key element in the corporation's top management.'' **********Mr. Lee, 53, has had a varied career that includes positions as president and chief executive of the Barber Oil Corporation, manager of the overseas chemical activities of W. R. Grace & Company and president of the Phibro Resources Corporation, which owned energy, natural resources and metals companies. **********Tosco, which is based in Santa Monica, Calif., is moving its operating headquarters to the San Francisco area to be near its refinery in Avon, Calif., but the company is also establishing a small corporate headquarters in Stamford, Conn., where Argus is situated. **********Tosco had been put up for sale but last month was taken off the auction block. **********''The results of our evaluation of perspective offers did not seem to the board to represent values that we thought were in the best interest of the shareholders,'' Mr. Lee said. ''Obviously we thought the long-term values of running the business are better. The Argus Group thinks that Tosco is an excellent investment.'' **********Mr. Lee and his wife, Gayle, have four children and live in Larchmont, N.Y. He holds undergraduate and graduate degrees in chemical engineering from Yale. While at Yale, Mr. Lee was an top basketball player and was a draft choice of the New York Knickerbockers in 1958, but he chose to return to school instead.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/06/busin.body_text: **********The Maine Attorney General asked a state judge today to block on antitrust grounds the Georgia-Pacific Corporation's $3.8 billion hostile bid for the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation. **********The state said in a lawsuit filed in Superior Court that a takeover would ''substantially lessen competition'' in Maine's lumber industry. T. Marshall Hahn Jr., Georgia-Pacific's chairman, said in a statement from Atlanta that the lawsuit was without merit. **********The suit also said an acquisition by Georgia-Pacific could harm Maine's real estate market by reducing competition in ''the sale of remote lakeshore property of significant recreational and scenic value.'' **********Great Northern Nekoosa, based in Norwalk, Conn., has a separate lawsuit in Federal court in Connecticut that challenges the takeover attempt on antitrust grounds. **********On Thursday, Great Northern Nekoosa asked United States District Judge Gene Carter in Portland to issue a preliminary injunction halting the takeover attempt by Georgia-Pacific as well as its move to have Great Northern Nekoosa's board ousted. The company has scheduled a special shareholders meeting for March 2 to decide whether its board should be removed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/06/world.main_headline: ECONOMIC ADVISERS ARE FEW IN BEIJING
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/06/world.print_headline: ECONOMIC ADVISERS ARE FEW IN BEIJING
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/06/world.body_text: **********The question being asked these days among Chinese officials and business executives is, ''Who is running the economy?'' **********The State Planning Commission and other bureaucracies are managing daily decision-making, but Chinese economists and foreign analysts say there is a crucial shortage of trusted and well-trained experts who can help chart China's economic development in the 1990's. **********''The leaders still don't have a coherent strategy for moving ahead with reform,'' said Nicholas R. Lardy, a professor who follows the Chinese economy at the University of Washington. **********Until the military crackdown in June, a host of brilliant young economists were at work at research institutions throughout the country examining problems like price liberalization, inflation, stock markets, bankruptcy, corporate management and private ownership of housing. Some of their ideas found a sympathetic hearing from the Communist Party leader at the time, Zhao Ziyang. **********Leaders Say Reform Proceeds **********Now those institutions are disbanded or out of favor. China's leaders insist that they are plodding ahead with economic restructuring and that even if it proceeds much more slowly than it has in the past, they will still need a reservoir of good economic researchers. **********In their effort to establish their own power bases and assert their own influence, Mr. Zhao's successors are forming their own think tanks, but in the transition there is a lack of fresh talent offering advice. **********The old think tanks played a critical role in developing policy during the 1980's. Not only were they close to senior leaders, but they provided the kind of far-ranging ideas that China needed to transform its vast economy. **********Mr. Zhao's institutions played an important role in the democracy movement last spring, and the effective leader of this ''kitchen cabinet,'' a Zhao aide named Bao Tong, is in prison. Chinese officials say three of Mr. Zhao's think tanks have been closed down. The director of another institute has fled China and a half-dozen of its staff members were arrested. Its economists no longer have any influence. **********Officials say the Communist Party General Secretary, Jiang Zemin, has set up his own institute, the Central Committee Policy Research Center. Headed by Wang Weicheng, an official in the Communist Party Propaganda Department, it has grown rapidly to about 50 people and examines both politics and the economy. **********''They have some smart people there, but they are not thinkers,'' a young Chinese economist said. ''They won't undertake real reform. There is a real gap now. It's a problem.'' **********Team Headed by Hard-Liner **********Prime Minister Li Peng has tried to develop his own research team. The group, the State Council Research Office, is headed by Yuan Mu, a hard-liner with no background in economics who is close to Mr. Li. **********''It's essentially responsible for drafting documents, not basic research,'' a Western economist said. **********The present leadership also calls at times for assistance from a third group, headed by Ma Hong, an old-time economist who was not very influential under Mr. Zhao. **********The shortage of economic advisers will become particularly critical if Yao Yilin, who recently stepped down as Minister of the State Planning Commission, also retires as expected from his post of Deputy Prime Minister this spring. **********Mr. Yao's emphasis on central planning was becoming less popular during the recent months as the economy slowed dramatically, but even his many detractors say he is currently the Chinese policy maker who best understands the enormous and diversified Chinese economy. **********A Westerner in frequent contact with Chinese economists was asked about the implications of a gap in good economic advice. He replied, ''One would expect there would be stagnation, and that could go on for a while.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/03/world.main_headline: Rebel Forces in Liberia Surround the Capital and Begin an Attack
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/03/world.print_headline: Rebel Forces in Liberia Surround the Capital and Begin an Attack
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/03/world.body_text: **********Rebel forces began a major assault on Liberia's capital, Monrovia, today, and have cut all the main roads into the city, a senior Bush Administration official said. **********''The battle of Monrovia has begun,'' said Herman J. Cohen, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs. ''It is serious. The rebels have effectively surrounded the city and they are moving toward the inside of Monrovia.'' **********Mr. Cohen also said that the Government of President Samuel K. Doe was concentrating its efforts on survival. **********Mr. Cohen said a representative of Economic Community of West African States was trying to mediate a settlement to avert a bloody battle in the heart of the city. The representative, he said, ''expressed some hope the talks might resume.'' **********Diplomatic Discussions **********A second Administration official monitoring events in Liberia said Vice President Harry S. Moniba and other officials of the Doe Government were meeting with United States diplomats at the American Embassy in Monrovia. They were discussing ways of removing General Doe from the country and seeking a settlement to the fighting. **********But the official added, ''The march of military events seems to be outpacing the efforts at negotiation.'' **********The Reuters news agency reported that most of the members of General Doe's Cabinet and other senior officials have fled the country, while the President appears to have remained in his fortified mansion in Monrovia surrounded by about 500 special troops. Commerce Minister John Wisseh McClain, General Doe's speech writer, reportedly tried but failed to board an aircraft leaving the country. **********Talks between the Government and the rebels in Freetown, capital of neighboring Sierra Leone, broke down last week when the rebels refused to continue. The fighting began in December, when 150 guerrillas of the National Patriotic Front, headed by Charles Taylor, crossed the border into northeastern Liberia. Since then, the rebels, whose numbers have increased to several thousand, have pushed the Government forces out of virtually all the northeastern and north-central parts of the country. **********The rebels, who have reportedly received training and financial support from Libya, have taken many important economic objectives, including the country's important iron mines, the Firestone rubber plantation, and Buchanan, the second-largest city. **********Reports From Monrovia **********Reports from Monrovia itself were few and vague due to the cutting of telephone and telex lines, but there were indications that at least one army base on the edge of the city was in flames. Rocket, artillery and automatic-weapons fire reverberated from the eastern suburb of Paynesville, while frightened people streamed out of the capital, according to pooled dispatches from journalists in the city and local radio broadcasts monitored from the neighboring Ivory Coast. **********The rebels moved into the capital this morning in a two-pronged attack from the northwest and the east. Some Government troops fled from the fighting, jumping into pickup trucks heading downtown, and Mr. Cohen said there was no sign that the army was effectively resisting. Lieut. Gen. Henry Dubar, the army chief of staff, resigned over the weekend. **********Mr. Taylor, who has accused General Doe's Government of brutality and large-scale corruption, has promised a thorough political house-cleaning but has equivocated about his intention to hold national elections. The war has been fought mostly along tribal lines, with members of the Krahn and Mandingo ethnic groups, who hold most high positions in the Government and army, battling the Gio and Mano tribes. Both the rebels and the Government forces have been accused of brutal attacks on civilians during the fighting. **********The peace talks, held at the United States Embassy in Sierra Leone, failed when General Doe refused to accept a rebel demand that he resign unconditionally. The Liberian President promised not to run for re-election in January and offered to include the guerrillas in an interim government, but the rebels refused to continue the talks. In response to the offensive, General Doe repeated his peace offer on radio today. #4 American Ships The United States Navy has deployed a four-ship task force off the Liberian coast to evacuate about 800 Americans still living in the West African country. American officials in the last few weeks have expressed concern that forces of either side, particularly those of General Doe, were undisciplined and could go on a rampage. There were reports today that drunken soldiers were commandeering cars and extorting money from civilians. **********Mr. Cohen said the Navy ships ''are ready for an emergency evacuation if necessary.'' But, as of Monday evening, he added, ''we don't have any reports of Americans being harmed or asking to leave.'' **********The United States has had close relations with Liberia since it was colonized and founded by freed American slaves in the early 19th century. American installations in the country include a navigational station that guides ships and aircraft across wide areas of the Atlantic Ocean, and two communications relay stations, one that transmits the Voice of America and the other that handles diplomatic and intelligence traffic for nearly all of Africa south of the Sahara. **********Mr. Cohen said the Voice of America station is already behind rebel lines, but remains unharmed. He said, so far, the rebels ''have been disciplined and correct.'' **********Government forces control the area where the diplomatic and intelligence station is situated, and it also remains undamaged, Mr. Cohen said. **********Abuse Is Reported **********Mr. Cohen was less sanguine about human rights in Monrovia. He said United States officials were receiving reports of the abuse of civilians, carried out along tribal lines, by both sides. Such violence, he said, included beatings and shootings. **********Washington has had a sometimes close, sometimes difficult relationship with the Doe Government since it took power in a bloody 1980 coup, which resulted in the execution of President William R. Tolbert and other members of the deposed Government. The Reagan Administration was critical of the executions and later of the Doe Government's corruption. But between 1980 and 1985, the Administration granted Monrovia $500 million worth of military and economic aid. **********The relationship began to sour after accusations that the Doe Government tampered with election results in 1985, leading to a succession of Congressional aid cutbacks. This year, Liberia received no military aid and just $10 million in food and other humanitarian assistance. **********Still, the Bush Administration was reticent about cutting all ties to the Doe Government. In February, two American military advisers were dispatched to a northeastern combat zone in an effort to improve the Liberian Army's human rights performance. Based on the advisers' counsel, some officers were transferred, but American officials have privately admitted that the army continued to abuse villagers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/27/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;   Microchip Technology Names New President
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/27/busin.body_text: **********Microchip Technology Inc., a semiconductor manufacturer based in Chandler, Ariz., has named Steve Sanghi president and chief operating officer. He has been vice president for operations of Microchip, a privately held company that was spun off by the General Instrument Corporation in September 1987. **********Mr. Sanghi, who is 35 years old, succeeds Donald R. Sorchych, 58, who resigned as president and chief executive officer in May. There is no plan to name a chief executive at this time, the company said in its announcement on Friday. **********Mr. Sanghi will report directly to Pierre Lamond, Microchip's chairman and a general partner with Sequoia Capital, a venture capital firm in Menlo Park, Calif. A consortium of venture capitalists led by Sequoia bought Microchip in April 1989. Microchip canceled its initial public offering because of the October 1987 stock market crash. **********Microchip has reported losses for several quarters, but said it expected to post a small profit for this quarter. ''We have made a major realignment of the company's focus away from commodity products to more specialized chips,'' Mr. Sanghi said in a telephone interview. He added that the company had made a sharp turnaround. **********From relatively standard memory chips, Microchip has shifted to more proprietary products, including a line of microcontrollers that use reduced instruction set computing technology - typically found in high-powered computer work stations - to speed computing in consumer electronics products like rice cookers and cellular phones. **********Mr. Lemond said that Mr. Sanghi ''has demonstrated, over the last six months, his ability to run a complex worldwide operation.'' **********Mr. Sanghi has spent more than 10 years in management positions in the semiconductor industry. Before joining Microchip in February, he was vice president for operations at Waferscale Integration Inc. in Fremont, Calif. He previously held manufacturing and product and design engineering management positions at the Intel Corporation, where his last assignment was programmable memory operation general manager. **********He received an M.S. degree in electrical engineering from the University of Massachusetts. He and his wife, Maria, have two children.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/09/busin.main_headline: Market Place;   'Junk Bond' Hopes Amid the Dangers
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/09/busin.print_headline: Market Place;   'Junk Bond' Hopes Amid the Dangers
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/09/busin.body_text: **********WITH representatives of the state regulatory agencies meeting in Washington tomorrow to recommend restrictions on ''junk bond'' investments by insurance companies, many investors in this battered market are worried about another selloff. **********Despite the fear, some market professionals say any decline may mean an end to the yearlong trauma and give investors a chance to buy bargains. Rebecca H. Garner, vice president of Associated Capital Investors in Little Rock, Ark., whose performance in 1989 was No. 1 in a ranking of junk bond managers, expects some clients to profit from any disarray arising from the new regulations. **********''You'd be crazy not to buy them,'' she said, adding that she is working on a list of bonds she hopes eventually to buy at lower prices. ''There are a lot of good names I'd like to own.'' **********In the near term, she still says the fragile market is going to come down, in part because of the proposal by the National Association of Insurance Commissioners that the more than 200 insurers that own junk bonds limit their holdings. ''We're waiting to see what gets battered,'' she said. ''We may have seen the bottom, but it may stay down here for a while.'' **********No matter how she views junk bonds, Ms. Garner may be constrained by the regulators and may be forced to sell low-rated bonds from an account she manages for her parent company, the Monarch Life Insurance Company. Although she sold $50 million of the insurer's bonds last year, Monarch executives may decide to reduce their holdings further in reaction to the regulators' proposals, she said yesterday. ''We truly don't know what we plan to do at this point,'' she said, but she hopes to buy more junk bonds for her pension accounts, Such sentiment about junk bonds is spreading, as some investors are being attracted by what they consider bargains. Robert M. Wallace, president of Gateway Advisors in San Jose, Calif., said he planned to add to his holdings slowly over the next few months. **********But their long-term bullishness is still a contrarian view. Many investors are still nervous about this volatile, thinly traded market. Professional investors who own these bonds have been blind-sided by bad news from these highly leveraged companies, and in many cases their holdings have suffered steep price declines. **********Even Ms. Garner, whose accounts returned 13.5 percent, in 1989, putting her at the top of junk bond managers ranked by Plan Sponsor Network, a Port Chester, N.Y., firm, was burned. **********Her investment performance slipped in the first quarter of this year because one holding dropped sharply. Executives at the Charter Medical Corporation surprised investors in March when they disclosed accounting irregularities, and the bonds dropped from the mid-80's to the low-40's. Ms. Garner sold her bonds at 50. As a result, her accounts so far are down 3.72 percent, compared with the 1.58 percent decline of the Merrill Lynch High Yield Index. **********Ms. Garner declines to name the bonds she plans to buy. But she said she would look at well-known, liquid issues like Duracell and First Brands. She will also be watching to see which bonds insurers are forced to sell. For instance, last November prices of bonds of the Fort Howard Corporation fell on rumors that the First Executive Corporation was selling the bonds, she said. Some market participants think the weakened life insurance company might sell more of these, as well as other bonds, to avoid increasing its reserves. **********''Everybody has reason to believe there is more,'' she said. ''But you don't know what the next name will be.'' **********Ms. Garner has $255 million of assets allocated to junk bonds although $50 million is held in short-term funds like Treasury bills. In addition to investing assets for Monarch and pension fund clients including Eastern Airlines, she and her staff manage a junk bond fund that is included as an investment option for annuity holders of an affiliate, the First Variable Corporation. **********For most of last year, she avoided many well-known issues like American Standard, Kroger and Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, which were hurt when the market selloff accelerated last fall. **********She also reduced her holdings of bonds underwritten exclusively by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. from 42 percent of the portfolio to 19 percent because she worried that without the firm's support these bonds would decline in value. And she managed to avoid some damage by shunning zero-coupon bonds and pay-in-kind bonds, which pay holders more bonds instead of cash. ''Interest is truly all I care about,'' she said. ''I don't want to be a hero.'' **********Her largest holdings include the Tonka Corporation, whose bonds have been trading near their par value, and McCaw Cellular Communications and Ann Taylor Inc. are in the 80's. **********The disarray in the junk bond market, Ms. Garner said, is creating opportunities for investors who are willing to buy when others are selling. ''I love this kind of market,'' she said.
