https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/17/busin.body_text: **********Donald J. Trump got some help with a mortgage today by auctioning 35 luxury waterfront condominiums in this high-society resort. **********The units in the twin 38-story towers at Trump Plaza of the Palm Beaches sold for a total of $8.8 million, 24 percent above the total asking price. The asking prices, however, had been slashed by up to two-thirds. **********Previous asking prices of $300,960 to $1.8 million were trimmed to minimum bids of $150,000 to $600,000 under pressure from his creditor, the Marine Midland Bank. The bank wanted Mr. Trump to get rid of units that had gone unsold since the developer took over the building in 1986. **********About 85 of the 221 units remain vacant or unsold. Officials said that Mr. Trump made the decision not to auction all units and that no decision had been made on their disposal.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/05/world.print_headline: THE IRAQI INVASION;   Rich Zone Shared Since '66
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/05/world.body_text: **********Iraqi troops have advanced to within a mile of the Saudi border, entering the Neutral or Partitioned Zone, an oil-rich area divided between Kuwait and Saudi Arabia, Kuwaiti officials said today, but Baghdad denied the report. **********The officials, who are not in Kuwait and who asked not to be identified, reported the Iraqi advance by telephone. If confirmed, the thrust would be the closest that the Iraqi Army has come to the Saudi border since the attack on Kuwait on Thursday. The troops entered the zone on Friday, the officials said. **********In Baghdad, the Iraqi news agency quoted an Iraqi official as describing the report as ''false news.'' **********One of the Kuwaiti officials said that the Iraqis ''stormed into the homes of dozens of Kuwaitis and evacuated them and their families.'' **********The Neutral Zone, a 5,700-square-mile stretch along the Persian Gulf, is mainly populated by Bedouin nomads and oil workers. But the official said there were usually Saudis and other foreigners in the Kuwaiti part of the zone. **********The Neutral Zone was divided under a Saudi-Kuwaiti border agreement in 1966. Each country administers its own half. But the oil wealth of the whole zone remains undivided and production from the onshore concessions is shared equally between the countries. Most of the oil concessions are owned by the Japanese Arabian Oil Company. **********Revenue from the zone's oil output, 300,000 to 400,000 barrels a day, were donated to Iraq from 1983 to 1988 to help it in the war with Iran.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/27/world.main_headline: Upheaval in the East;   FLOW OF GERMANS EBBING FROM EAST
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/27/world.print_headline: Upheaval in the East;   FLOW OF GERMANS EBBING FROM EAST
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/27/world.body_text: **********The number of East Germans moving to West Germany has dropped considerably since the East German election a week ago, although officials warned that it was too early to declare that the heaviest flow is over. **********In East Germany, accusations that various politicians were informers for the Ministry of State Security today led the chairman of the Social Democrats, Ibrahim Bohme, to suspend his parliamentary duties. Mr. Bohme denied the allegations, which had been made anonymously. **********According to the Interior Ministry, the daily tally of immigrants dropped steadily from 1,359 last Monday, the day after elections, to 551 on Friday. The flow moved back up today to an estimated 1,000, but Monday is usually the heaviest day. **********This arrival of hundreds of thousands of immigrants has placed a heavy strain on West Germany's social services and housing and led to growing resentment of those coming from the East, prompting Bonn to limit benefits and to take other actions to curb the influx. **********Relatives Coming Now **********Adding to a cautious optimism was the fact that many of those now coming over were family members of men who had come alone earlier to look for work and housing. A spokesman for the Interior Ministry said the number of single men had dropped sharply. **********Officials here speculated that many East Germans had assumed that Bonn would shut the doors to immigrants immediately after the election. Thus, those who intended to leave would probably have left by the election. **********Then on Tuesday, Chancellor Helmut Kohl announced that the special benefits for immigrants would remain in force until July 1. That presumably encouraged wavering East Germans to stay home and see if their newly elected Parliament would start to bring real economic improvements. **********Three states - North Rhine-Westphalia, Saarland and the city-state of Bremen - have now stopped accepting immigrants from the reception camps, arguing that the law was written for political refugees and did not apply to East Germans now that they have a freely elected government. Last year, 350,000 East Germans moved to West Germany, and 150,000 more have joined them so far this year. **********A Week's Statistics **********The flow had averaged 2,000 a day until the elections. It then dropped to 1,359 on Monday, 1,156 on Tuesday, 931 on Wednesday, 706 on Thursday and 551 on Friday, the West German Interior Ministry said. Only 287 came over the weekend, and 477 by 2 P.M. today, about half the day's expected number. At the peak of the exodus this year, 4,017 crossed the border on Monday, Jan. 29. **********''It's difficult to say why the flow has dropped so abruptly,'' said Hartmut Zimmermann, a political scientist at the Free University of West Berlin. ''Maybe people now think something will happen soon and so they do not need to come over. Maybe those who have decided to go have already gone. Maybe the word has spread in East Germany that settling in West Germany is getting increasingly difficult.'' **********Mr. Zimmermann said the flood could still resume if East Germans lose faith in the benefits of introducing the West German mark to the East, which Bonn intends to do by this summer. **********In a related matter, the West German Employment Agency in Nuremberg said it would hold back transition money from an East German immigrant for 12 weeks if he lost his job through his own fault. The payment -about $600 to $700 - was instituted on Jan. 1 as a smaller substitute for unemployment benefits that a West German would receive. **********'Changed Political Situation' **********Eberhard Mann, a spokesman for the agency, said the change reflected both the usual practice with West German benefits, and the ''changed political situation'' in East Germany. Mr. Mann said $23 million in transition money had been paid so far this year. **********In East Berlin, Mr. Bohme strongly denied charges published in the West German news magazine Der Spiegel attributed to a former state security officer that the Social Democratic leader had passed information to the police under various pseudonyms as an enthusiastic young Communist in the late 1960's. **********Mr. Bohme announced that he was suspending his parliamentary duties and his party post until the matter was resolved. ''I declare that I have never worked for, or knowingly supplied information to, the office of State Security,'' he said in a statement. **********The wave of anonymous accusations of former security-police connections among the newly elected East German leaders has all but halted the process of forming a coalition government. **********Today, the West German Christian Democrats declared that the accusations should not block the creation of a coalition. ''It would be a success for the dirty methods of state security if people allow delays in forming the first democratic government in East Germany,'' said the party General Secretary, Volker Ruhe.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/07/world.main_headline: GUERRILLA HIDEOUT IS RAIDED IN LIMA
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/07/world.print_headline: GUERRILLA HIDEOUT IS RAIDED IN LIMA
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/07/world.body_text: **********Two pairs of thick eyeglasses left on a writing desk, medicine bottles on a bed stand and a bookcase filled with Maoist and Stalinist literature indicate that the mastermind of Peru's Shining Path rebellion recently stayed at a split-level house on a quiet middle-class street here. **********Abimael Guzman has not been confirmed dead or alive since the philosophy professor began Peru's Maoist revolt in May 1980. **********Ten years and 18,000 deaths later, the police came the closest yet to solving the mystery when they carried out a series of raids in Lima last weekend. The raids netted 31 suspected rebels, 10 tons of printed propaganda and a trove of archives and memorabilia that one analyst called the ''Museum of the Revolution.'' **********'Crushing Blow' to Guerrillas **********Seeking to calm voters before Sunday's presidential election, Interior Minister Maximo Augustin Mantilla described the raids as ''a crushing blow that starts the destruction of the Shining Path by the forces of order.'' **********Responding with dynamite, the rebels resumed a killing and bombing campaign to disrupt the vote. **********On Tuesday night, the Shining Path dynamited a series of power pylons here. Under the cover of a partial blackout, they set off a car bomb against a back wall of Lima's Roman Catholic cathedral. A woman was severely wounded, but the cathedral did not suffer major damage. **********Today, at Casa Palca, 65 miles east of here, the guerrillas set off a dynamite charge that weakened a bridge on the central highway that links this city of six million people with the food-growing areas of the central highlands. **********Series of Bombings **********The bombs are part of a series of attacks that included bombing last Friday the party offices here of the two presidential candidates, Alberto K. Fujimori and Mario Vargas Llosa. In early May, Mr. Fujimori narrowly escaped injury when a bomb exploded near a platform where he had been speaking a few minutes earlier. **********Mr. Fujimori, an agronomist who enjoys the backing of Peru's left-wing parties, advocates defusing the 10-year-old Shining Path rebellion with aid and investment in the central highlands. Mr. Fujimori leads in opinion polls in Peru's interior. **********Mr. Vargas Llosa, the novelist, who is campaigning with the support of Peru's rightist parties, advocates a more military approach to the insurgency. Mr. Vargas Llosa leads in opinion polls in Lima, where one-third of all voters live. **********Inheriting the Rebellion **********Whoever wins on Sunday will inherit a durable rebellion that during the tenure of Peru's President, Alan Garcia, has spread throughout this nation, South America's third largest. **********With the end of his five-year term approaching next month, Mr. Garcia has sought to portray the Shining Path as divided, demoralized and defeated. **********On Monday, after the police gave journalists a tour of the Shining Path hideout here, Mr. Garcia described the raid as ''the hardest blow against subversion in the last 10 years.'' **********Jose Gonzalez, a Peruvian journalist who specializes in the Shining Path, said the contents of the split-level house amounted to a ''Museum of the Revolution.'' **********Located in Lima's affluent Monterrico neighborhood, the house contained 250 identity cards of guerrilla conscripts before they assumed pseudonyms, a collection of 30 red flags inscribed with dedications to Mr. Guzman by Shining Path units from around the nation, and a collection of murals, posters and clay figurine sets executed in an Andean version of socialist realism. **********''The house appears to have been designed as a center for staff work as well as a way station for Guzman,'' Mr. Gorriti said. **********Not resigned to admitting that the mysterious revolutionary chieftain had once again eluded them, the police today started excavating the garden at the house in the hopes of finding his bones.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/16/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   First Chicago Hoax in Paper
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/16/busin.body_text: **********A newspaper article on a potential takeover deal supposedly based on comments made by the president of the First Chicago Corporation was a hoax, the bank said today. **********The article in The Minneapolis Star Tribune today said that First Chicago, the nation's 13th-largest banking company, was interested in buying the First Bank System Inc. in Minneapolis. The article said Richard L. Thomas, First Chicago's president, had said in an interview that his bank would like to buy First Bank for $20 to $22 a share, or up to $1.4 billion. **********First Chicago issued a statement about 1 P.M. calling the article a hoax and denying that the executive spoke to the newspaper's reporters. **********First Bank's shares rose to $16 in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange, but then fell back to close at $14.75, up 75 cents each. First Chicago's rose $1.75 a share, to $35.125. **********First Bank, with $21 billion in assets, is being restructured because of problems stemming in part from problem loans. A bank spokesman reiterated its desire to remain independent. **********Bette Fenton, the communications director for The Star Tribune, said today that an investigation confirmed that it had been victimized. **********A man identifying himself as **********Richard Thomas called the newspaper on Wednesday, Ms. Fenton said, appeared to be knowledgeable and said he was leaving his office and could not be reached later. ''At the time, we had no reason to suspect the person was not legitimate,'' she said. ''We screwed up.'' Cowles Mediad(Minneapolis)

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/15/busin.body_text: **********A Federal appeals panel in New York yesterday affirmed the authority of a Federal judge who has begun to restructure the trust set up by the Manville Corporation to compensate victims of asbestos. **********The three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit dismissed a motion by lawyers for more than 1,100 asbestos victims who had sought to remove a stay issued last month that froze the assets of the trust. **********In challenging the stay, the lawyers had questioned the authority of Federal District Judge Jack B. Weinstein of Brooklyn to restructure the trust, which has run out of cash in settling the first 22,000 claims. It is now facing more than 130,000 claims. **********Christopher D. Cerf, a lawyer representing about 1,100 victims, contended at a hearing yesterday morning that Judge Weinstein lacked the authority to freeze the trust's assets. Mr. Cerf said the trust might not make payouts for years. **********That assertion led two of the three judges to question Kenneth R. Feinberg, who was representing Judge Weinstein on the appeal, about the length of time the temporary stay would entail. **********Mr. Feinberg declined to describe how long the trust's assets might be frozen. Leon Silverman, a lawyer appointed to resolve the trust's financial problems, is expected to issue a report early next month. **********The three judges on the appeals panel - Frank X. Altimari, Robert J. Kelleher and Roger J. Miner - unanimously agreed to dismiss the challenge.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/08/world.main_headline: Evolution in Europe;   Latvia Selects a Premier After Soviet Tanks Roll By
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/08/world.print_headline: Evolution in Europe;   Latvia Selects a Premier After Soviet Tanks Roll By
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/08/world.body_text: **********Latvia's Parliament chose a new Prime Minister today to take it to independence after what appeared to be a Soviet show of strength there this morning. **********Tanks and other armored vehicles rolled through the streets of Riga, the Latvian capital, during the morning rush hour. The maneuvers were officially described as preparations for a World War II victory parade on Wednesday. But many Latvians viewed the military caravan as an effort by Moscow to intimidate them over the declaration of independence issued by their Parliament on Friday. **********Latvia's Parliament elected Ivars Godmanis, an economist and a leading member of the republic's Popular Front, as Prime Minister. A spokeswoman for the Parliament said he would name his Cabinet on Tuesday. **********Mr. Godmanis is expected to lead a drive by the Baltic republic to break away from the Soviet Union, despite the prospect that Moscow will retaliate with sanctions similar to those imposed on neighboring Lithuania, which declared its independence in March. **********In a speech today in Moscow to war veterans, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev assailed separatists, asserting that they were pursuing ''an irresponsible policy leading to deadlock.'' Reports of his speech indicated that he did not specifically name Latvia. **********Before the vote on Mr. Godmanis in Riga, the Latvian President, Anatolijs Gorbunovs, told Parliament that he had received a call from a senior civil servant in Moscow requesting details of the independence declaration. [The Associated Press reported that the Parliament sent a letter to Mr. Gorbachev saying, ''We express the certainty that the character of the declaration, the retention of current constitutional norms and sincere desire to respect the interests of the U.S.S.R. will meet with your understanding and open the way to a fruitful dialogue in the spirit of honest cooperation between equals.'']  As the message was being prepared, the chief Foreign Ministry spokesman in Moscow appeared to cast doubt on a report on Sunday that Mr. Gorbachev had denounced Latvia's declaration. **********The official press agency Tass quoted Mr. Gorbachev as saying the move was a ''violation of constitutional norms.'' Tass said the Soviet President made the remark in a conversation with Alfreds Rubiks, head of the anti-independence faction of the Latvian Communist Party. Tass reported that Mr. Gorbachev held out the possibility of economic or political sanctions against the republic in the conversation. But the Foreign Ministry spokesman, Gennadi I. Gerasimov, said: ''I know as much as you do. There is no official response.'' **********The Soviet Union forcibly annexed Latvia in 1940. The independence declaration adopted by the republic last week restored Latvia's 1922 Constitution while leaving most of the Soviet Constitution in place. Latvian leaders said they tried to avoid angering the Kremlin by taking a moderate tone. **********The Interfax news agency, which is associated with Radio Moscow, said that panic buying was sweeping Riga and that basic foods like meat, flour and salt were no longer in the shops. **********In Vilnius, the Lithuanian Agriculture Minister, Vytautas Knasys, said the republic intended to cut supplies of milk and meat to the Soviet Union by a further 10 percent in retaliation for the Kremlin's blockade.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/19/world.main_headline: A Surprise Spacewalk: Repairs for Soviet Ship
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/19/world.print_headline: A Surprise Spacewalk: Repairs for Soviet Ship
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/19/world.body_text: **********Soviet astronauts aboard the Mir space station are planning an unscheduled spacewalk to repair their damaged transport ship and insure a safe return to Earth, published reports and American experts say. **********Experts see no danger that the astronauts will be stranded in space. The repairs, to be done next month or later, are precautionary. If the repairs fail, the astronauts have alternatives for a safe return. The astronauts have enough supplies aboard Mir to live for months in orbit, and more supplies can be sent to them. **********''There's no crisis,'' said James E. Oberg, an American expert on Soviet space programs. ''This is a prudent action to enhance cosmonaut safety.'' **********The trouble has been discussed in the Soviet press and a detailed account of the planned repair mission appears in the current issue of Aviation Week & Space Technology, an industry journal. The damaged ship, the journal noted, leaves the two astronauts ''without a reliable escape vehicle in the event of an emergency.'' The astronauts are Anatoly Solovyov and Aleksandr Balandin. **********Thermal Blankets Loosened **********The problem centers on the Soyuz craft, which transports Soviet astronauts to and from the 100-foot-long Mir station. The Soyuz now docked at Mir was set aloft on Feb. 11, carrying two astronauts. An inspection of the Soyuz later showed that some of its thermal blankets had come loose, exposing the metallic skin of the ship to space. **********The blankets are not a heat shield for re-entry but rather a many-layered cover meant to help curb the extreme temperatures encountered in everyday operations in space. A device facing toward the Sun can reach temperatures of 400 degrees Fahrenheit on one side, and minus 250 degrees Fahrenheit on the other. **********At first, Soviet concern was rather low, said Mr. Oberg, who monitors the Soviet press. The damage seemed to affect temperature control in the craft and some electrical generation, and was viewed as bothersome at worst. But apprehension rose when it turned out that the torn insulation blocked critical navigation sensors meant to guide Soyuz on its return to Earth. **********Those sensors were the same ones that acted up in 1988, leaving two Soviet astronauts stranded in space for a day before the problem was fixed and the crew landed safely. The sensors locate the Earth's horizon, helping the ship correctly orient itself for its plunge back through the atmosphere. **********A Complex Repair Job **********According to Aviation Week, the repair plan involves a spacewalk in which Soviet astronauts are to fix the torn blankets. The repair job is complex because the damaged area cannot be easily reached. **********The Soviets are planning to send special tools and a ladder to the astronauts. Those are to be carried into space by a 20-ton expansion module for the Mir station, whose flight has been repeatedly delayed and is now scheduled for early June. It is known as Kvant 3. The first Kvant module arrived in April 1987. **********After the new module docks with Mir, a spacewalking astronaut will deploy the ladder, which is to extend about 20 feet from Mir to the Soyuz craft. The Soyuz has few handholds on its exterior to aid a spacewalking astronaut. **********It has not been decided whether to repair the torn blankets or to strip them away so that they would no longer block the sensors. **********Several Alternatives **********''Securing them back in place would be a more difficult task,'' Aviation Week noted, ''but would help improve the spacecraft's thermal problems.'' **********If the effort fails, which is considered unlikely, several alternatives exist, Mr. Oberg said. The astronauts could try the repair again or could take the risk of re-entering the Earth's atmosphere with the blankets unrepaired, since there are other ways to help guide the module's re-entry. **********Another alternative, Mr. Oberg said, would be to abandon the damaged Soyuz and have another one sent into space to pick up the astronauts, especially if an emergency arises. ''There's always one available as a rescue vehicle,'' said Mr. Oberg.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/27/busin.main_headline: Pennzoil Raises Stake In Chevron to 9.4%
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/27/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Pennzoil Raises Stake In Chevron to 9.4%
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/27/busin.body_text: **********The Pennzoil Company said today that it had bought $90 million worth of shares in the Chevron Corporation since Dec. 3, increasing its stake in Chevron to 9.4 percent, from 9.1 percent. **********The purchases, made in the open market at an average price of $69.75 a share, increased Pennzoil's total investment in Chevron to $2.2 billion. **********The company also said today that the Internal Revenue Service had extended to May 31 the deadline for Pennzoil to invest the remaining proceeds from its $3 billion award from Texaco Inc. in April 1988. A Pennzoil spokesman said $390 million from the award had yet to be invested. **********Chevron's shares rose $2, to $73.25, on the New York Stock Exchange. Pennzoil's shares closed at $65, up $1.375, in light trading. **********Analysts said Pennzoil would invest most of the Texaco money in additional Chevron shares in the months ahead, but would stop short of exceeding a 10 percent stake. Last year, Chevron adopted a "poison pill" that would sharply dilute Pennzoil's stake at that level. **********Pennzoil, based in Houston, had faced a year-end deadline for investing the money remaining from the Texaco settlement or paying Federal taxes on that amount. Pennzoil believes that the $3 billion from Texaco will not be taxed if it invests the money in assets related to the industry. **********Pennzoil planned to merge with the Getty Oil Company in January 1984, before Texaco intervened with a higher offer and acquired all of Getty. Texas courts later ruled that Texaco had unlawfully interfered with the Pennzoil-Getty merger. **********A Pennzoil spokesman, Robert Harper, said his company sought the deadline extension from the I.R.S. because Pennzoil had been blocked from buying additional Chevron shares while it waited for a ruling by the Federal Trade Commission. The agency ruled on Dec. 3 that Pennzoil could proceed with the acquisition of addition Chevron shares. At that time, Pennzoil still had $480 million on hand from the Texaco settlement. **********The F.T.C. action ended the Government's inquiry into whether Pennzoil's stake in Chevron would reduce oil industry competition. A ruling by the I.R.S. on Pennzoil's contention that taxes on the Texaco settlement should be deferred could take several years. **********Bernard J. Picchi, managing director and oil analyst at Salomon Brothers, said the Federal Government's decision to extend the I.R.S. deadline was an indication that the I.R.S. might not contest Pennzoil's position regarding the Texaco settlement and future taxes. **********"This must be viewed as a small victory for Pennzoil," he said. **********A Chevron spokesman, Larry Shushan, said that Pennzoil's announcement that it had increased its stake in Chevron was not a surprise. Chevron, the nation's fourth-largest oil company, is based in San Francisco.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/14/busin.body_text: **********The Turner Broadcasting System said today that it had net income of $1.3 million in the quarter ended Sept. 30, down from $35.2 million in the corresponding quarter last year. **********The company, which owns the Cable News Network, attributed the decline to increased expenses, including the costs of covering the Persian Gulf crisis. **********On a per-share basis TBS ended with a loss in the quarter because of adjustments for preferred stock dividends, in contrast to earnings of 10 cents a share last year. **********Revenues for the third quarter rose 54 percent, to $415.8 million, from $269.3 million a year earlier. **********TBS said CNN earned $24.1 million in the quarter, down from $28.6 million a year earlier. **********The start of the Sport South Network Ltd., a regional sports cable channel, hurt earnings in the sports division, as did increased legal reserves. That segment suffered a $3.9 million loss in contrast to a profit of $223,000 a year earlier. **********Turner also reported decreased earnings in its entertainment division and a loss in real estate that was heavier than that of a year earlier.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/16/busin.body_text: **********The Navistar International Corporation, the nation's largest maker of medium and heavy trucks, today reported a loss of $18 million in its first quarter. It attributed the difficulty to lower demand for its products and higher production costs. Navistar said the net loss for the three months ended Jan. 31 compared with net income of $37 million, or 12 cents a share, for the corresponding period a year ago. Revenue for the period totaled $832 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/22/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Scoresby's Response To Success
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/22/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Scoresby's Response To Success
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/22/busin.body_text: **********SCORESBY has become the fifth-largest brand of Scotch in America - without advertising. Scoresby Scotch has grown into the largest brand in California, indeed the Western United States -without advertising. While sales of domestic Scotch declined by 4.6 percent last year, Scoresby's sales grew by more than 11 percent - without advertising. **********So what does Scoresby see as the key to its future growth? Advertising. **********The Glenmore Distilleries Company, which acquired distribution rights to Scoresby when it acquired the Fleischmann's Company in 1988, is about to begin the first ad campaign ever for an alcoholic secret so well kept that it provides the tag line for the ads, ''The secret's out.'' **********''Why start advertising when the brand is doing so well?'' asked Roland Grybauskas, who, as president of Grybauskas & Partners, Scoresby's agency, has a stake in the rhetorical query's answer. ''Because the momentum and the opportunity are tremendous.'' **********Having grown without it, though, Scoresby is trying an alternative approach to advertising. In the print ads appearing in USA Today and in the April issues of such hip magazines as LA Style, Premiere and Interview, 1960's-style cartoon art, similar to the pop art of Roy Lichtenstein, will introduce the brand to drinkers between the ages of 25 and 40. And Grybauskas intends to make the ads' cartoon couple - Todd and Cheryl -running characters, whose loves, desires and intrigues should captivate consumers enough to induce them to order the Scotch. **********Beverage analysts say Scoresby grew because its distributors took the money that would have gone into advertising and put it into price promotions. **********''At a time when premium imports were quite high, they were one of the lowest-priced Scotches in the country,'' said Jerome M. Levy, the marketing director of Jobson's Beverage Alcohol Group. ''It was perceived by the consumer as a good value and a good product. And because they liked the name and the label, they weren't afraid to buy the product even though the price was lower.'' **********Scoresby, it seems, has always bucked trends. Liquor-industry experts say that brands of Scotch, a beverage with a sophisticated European heritage, are generally introduced in the Eastern United States and spread West. But Scoresby was introduced in California in the early 1970's and has slowly worked its way East. **********Such contrariness was evident in the approach to the ads. ''We didn't want to do me-too advertising,'' Mr. Grybauskas said. ''Doing a competitive analysis, we found two things: either the ads were about authenticity, with men in kilts, or they were about life style - 'You work on Wall Street; this is the Scotch for you.' '' **********Indeed, as Americans' consumption of Scotch has declined, the category has turned out numerous attention-getting campaigns aimed at making Scotch a trendy drink. Grace & Rothschild has done whimsical wordplays for J & B; one execution, headlined ''J & B at home,'' has an aerial photograph of a baseball stadium with a bottle of the Scotch at the plate. Smith/Greenland has made waves with its sexy allusions to modern courtship in its ''. . . And he drinks Johnnie Walker'' campaign. **********These notable campaigns presented a challenge to Grybauskas, the $15 million agency that won the Scoresby account on the basis of its work for other Glenmore brands, including Elduris Icelandic Vodka and Chi-Chi's margaritas. Another challenge was the research. ''The Scoresby drinker is a typical Scotch drinker - there is nothing unique about him or her,'' said Cheryl Suhr, Glenmore's group brand director for imports. **********Grybauskas's decision to use cartoons - because they are ''intrusive,'' Mr. Grybauskas said -matches that made by other advertisers, like 7-Up and Jell-O, which now believe that cartoon characters have a way of standing out from the printed page and the television screen. To further the cartoonish associations, Glenmore and its agency have developed point-of-purchase displays that will tie Scoresby in with the home video release of the forthcoming movie ''Dick Tracy.'' **********Mystique has built brands like Coors beer; such mystery-eroding advertising might seem to be risky. But neither the agency nor the client worries about destroying any mystique that might have gathered around Scoresby. **********''The brand was not built on its sexy word-of-mouth,'' Mr. Grybauskas said. ''It's been built on taste. There was a great sensitivity about what it's impact might be. But we say, no risk.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/31/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS;   Treasury Securities Inch Higher
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/31/busin.body_text: **********Prices of Treasury securities inched higher in slow trading yesterday, as dealers began to position themselves for tomorrow's release of May employment data. **********Market participants said generally weak reports on April movements in the Commerce Department's index of leading economic indicators and new home sales had had little impact. **********''The April data has already been incorporated; it was weak, and no one will deny that,'' one Government bond trader said. ''But April numbers don't matter any more. The market wants to see what May looked like.'' **********Much of yesterday's activity was concentrated in longer-term notes and bonds. Traders said accounts were moving out of positions in shorter-term notes and into bonds. **********''The long end continually has a bid,'' the trader said. ''It has since we came back on Tuesday.'' **********Analysts at MMS International, an economic information and forecasting company, noted in their daily commentary that the price action in the last two days suggested that ''the market is looking for more weakness in the employment data than is likely to be seen.'' **********Excluding workers hired by the Government to conduct the 1990 Census, the MMS analysts are projecting that non-farm payroll employment rose by 180,000 in May, slightly above the 150,000 increase that is the consensus forecast among Wall Street economists. **********The session's one mild surprise took place in the Federal funds market, where the overnight rate for bank loans softened considerably throughout the afternoon. **********By late in the day the funds rate was trading at 7 percent, well below the 8 1/4 percent rate that is widely seen as the Federal Reserve Board's target. **********Analysts said the sharp drop meant little, since yesterday was the end of a two-week reserve reporting period for banks. **********''The funds rate is often volatile on the final day of the two-week reserve period, and I would not read anything more into what happened to the funds rate than that,'' said Rudolf Thunberg, an economist at Ried Thunberg & Company, an investment advisory firm in Westport, Conn. **********''There is no reason to suspect the Fed has changed its apparent target of 8 1/4 percent funds.'' **********The Fed did provide some support to the Treasury bill market, as it purchased bills. **********Analysts expected the Fed would buy either notes or bills this week, and the aggressive purchases helped push down Treasury bill rates. **********By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.73 percent, down five basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell seven basis points to a late offered rate of 7.65 percent. And one-year bill rates were offered in late trading at 7.61 percent, down three basis points. **********The Fed's bill purchases took place on a day when the Treasury auctioned a $12 billion of new cash management bills. **********The cash management bills, which will be used to provide working capital for the Resolution Trust Corporation, have two different maturities. **********A total of $6 billion worth of 111-day bills were auctioned at an average discount rate of 7.78 percent. **********The remaining $6 billion worth of bills mature in 20-days, and were auctioned at an average discount rate of 7.93 percent. **********In the secondary market for Treasury notes and bonds, the benchmark 8 3/4 percent bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 101 23/32 late yesterday, up 10/32, to yield 8.58 percent. Late Tuesday the closely watched issue was offered at a price to yield 8.61 percent. **********Among note issues, the 8 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 101 25/ 32, up 6/32, to yield 8.60 percent. And the 8 1/2 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 2/32, up 1/32, to yield 8.46 percent. **********In the corporate bond market, the Westinghouse Credit Corporation offered $150 million of senior notes through an underwriting syndicate led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. **********The 8.85 percent notes, which mature June 15, 2014, were priced at 100, 27 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 1/2 percent four-year notes at the time of pricing. **********The notes carry puts that may be exercised in 1994, 1999 and 2004. **********The issue is rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. **********Activity in the secondary markets for corporate and tax-exempt municipal bonds was very light, dealers said. **********Prices of most widely traded investment-grade corporate bonds were unchanged to up 1/8 point. Municipal bond prices were unchanged on the day. **********Following are the results of the Treasury's auctions of $12 billion of cash management bills: **********(000 omitted in dollar figures) **********Average Price . . . 99.559 **********Discounted Rate . . . 7.93% **********Coupon Yield . . . 8.08% **********High Price . . . 99.561 **********Discounted Rate . . . 7.90% **********Coupon Yield . . . 8.05% **********Low Price . . . 99.559 **********Discounted Rate . . . 7.93% **********Coupon Yield . . . 8.08% **********Accepted at low price . . . 97% **********Total applied for . . . $29,598,000 **********Accepted . . . $6,024,360 **********N.Y. applied for . . . $25,953,000 **********N.Y. accepted . . . $4,818,460 **********The cash management bills mature June 21, 1990. **********(000 omitted in dollar figures) **********Average Price . . . 97.601 **********Discounted Rate . . . 7.78% **********Coupon Yield . . . 8.08% **********High Price . . . 97.604 **********Discounted Rate . . . 7.77% **********Coupon Yield . . . 8.07% **********Low Price . . . 97.601 **********Discounted Rate . . . 7.78% **********Coupon Yield . . . 8.08% **********Accepted at low price . . . 26% **********Total applied for . . . $43,455,000 **********Accepted . . . $6,008,300 **********N.Y. applied for . . . $40,630,000 **********N.Y. accepted . . . $5,802,900 **********The cash management bills mature Sept. 20, 1990.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/28/world.body_text: **********The House and the Senate defied the Bush Administration today and voted to impose economic sanctions on Iraq, citing what lawmakers viewed as the human rights violations and increasingly bellicose policies of President Saddam Hussein's Government. **********The Senate took the stronger action, voting 80 to 16 to cut off $700 million in United States loan guarantees that the Baghdad Government uses to purchase American wheat, rice, lumber and cattle as well as commercial goods like tires and machinery. **********''We shall not give to the Iraqis the kind of special treatment you reserve for friends, for allies,'' said Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, who drafted the measure approved by the Senate. ''We've waited for Hussein to take a more humane course and it has not been done. He is a butcher, a torturer, a manipulator.'' **********The House, by a vote of 234 to 175, first approved a similar measure restricting loan guarantees to Iraq. But, after the pleas of representatives from rural districts, the House voted 208 to 191 to allow the Secretary of Agriculture to waive the sanctions if he determines they cause more harm to American farmers than they do to the Hussein Government. **********Criticized by Texan **********Senator Phil Gramm, a Texas Democrat who opposed the bill, said that the proposal was ''like responding to a bully by pulling out a gun, putting it to your head and saying if you keep threatening me I'll shoot myself.'' **********While conceding that the elimination of loan guarantees would harm farmers in her state, Senator Nancy Kassebaum, a Kansas Republican, countered that some principles go beyond economic interests. **********''There comes a time when we have to stand up and be counted,'' she said. ''I can't believe any farmer in this nation would want to send his products, under subsidized sales, to a country that has used chemical weapons and a country that has tortured and executed its children.'' **********In recent days Mr. Hussein had threatened to use military force against members of OPEC he felt had been exceeding their production quotas and thereby keeping the price low. He massed troops on the border with Kuwait, creating a crisis atmosphere, which has yet to dissipate fully. **********Bush Favors Guarantees **********The Bush Administration had opposed the ending of the loan guarantees, arguing that it would harm American farmers, worsen the country's trade deficit, and not hurt the Iraqis, who could purchase agricultural products from countries like France and Taiwan. **********A State Department spokesman, Richard A. Boucher, said today that the Administration did not believe that proposals like Mr. D'Amato's would help ''in achieving the goals we want to achieve in our relationship with Iraq.'' **********Mr. Boucher said that as a result of a review of Iraq trade relations being conducted by the Administration in recent months, the Commerce Department is developing new regulations that will tighten controls on exports of some items, like industrial equipment, that could be used for the production of nuclear or chemical weapons. **********Although there are many restrictions already in place, the new rules would clamp down more firmly because of special concerns about proliferation of nonconventional weapons. **********Agricultural Credits Reviewed **********The Administration's review is also examining whether agricultural credits should be restricted, he said, but the Agriculture Department has not reached any conclusions in that regard. The review had been in progress before the sudden heightening of tensions between Iraq and Kuwait in the last two weeks, and has been intensified since then. **********The sanctions recommended by Congress would not take effect until final enactment of the farm bill, which was passed by the Senate today but awaits further action by the House. The two chambers would then have to reconcile their differences before sending the measure to President Bush for his signature. **********The Congressional votes to impose sanctions came on the same day the 13-member Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed at their meeting in Geneva to raise the target price for oil to $21 a barrel, from $18 a barrel. The OPEC oil ministers also agreed to limit production to 22.5 million barrels a day, slightly higher than the current ceiling on output, but lower than what the members of the cartel have been actually producing. **********Lobbying by Iraq **********Iraq had been strongly lobbying for the price increase, which comes at a time of a continued glut of crude oil on the world market. That glut had kept oil prices depressed, severely hindering Iraq's ability to repay its foreign debt, estimated to be between $70 billion and $100 billion. **********Abdul Rahman Jamil, press attache of the Iraqi Embassy in Washington, could not be reached for comment on the Congressional action. Telephone calls to a number where embassy staff said Mr. Jamil could be reached went unanswered. **********Today's votes in Congress represent another step in the worsening relations between Washington and Baghdad that had begun to warm in the 1980's. While Iraq was engaged in war with Iran, Washington developed a decided tilt toward Baghdad, several experts on Iraq say. **********During the war with Iran, Washington restored diplomatic relations with Baghdad, which also enjoyed closer relations with Kuwait, as Kuwait heavily financed Iraq's weapons purchases.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/01/busin.main_headline: Beef Cattle Price Rises To Record
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/01/busin.print_headline: Beef Cattle Price Rises To Record
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/01/busin.body_text: **********The price of beef cattle rose to a record high of $75.40 for a hundred pounds in August because of strong summer demand and a reduced number of cattle slaughtered, the Agriculture Department said today. The previous record price was $74.60 set in April, a department official said. **********Milk prices also reached their highest level for any August, as production rose only modestly while demand for cheese and ice cream production was heavy, he said. **********But the sharp increases in beef cattle and milk prices failed to push up the index of prices received by farmers for their products in August. **********Lower prices for hogs, grapefruit and corn offset the rise in beef cattle and milk prices and caused the index to drop 1.3 percent in August after an increase of seven-tenths of 1 percent in July, the department said. **********''Beef cattle prices hit a record because of good demand this summer and there have not been as many of them for slaughter as expected,'' the official said. ''There was no shortage of beef cattle. It was just that it was a low point in the cattle breeding cycle.'' **********The report said milk prices at $14.40 for a hundred pounds in August were 30 cents above those in July and $1.20 above prices last August. **********''Milk prices were sharply higher on continued strong demand for milk for making cheese and ice cream while production only grew modestly,'' the official said. **********The department's report said prices of feedgrains like corn and barley, as well as fruits, especially grapefruit, declined in August.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/13/busin.body_text: **********American Airlines Inc. said Monday it would add 39 domestic flights beginning next month, including two cross-country flights from Newark to Los Angeles. American also exercised options to buy seven MD-11 jumbo jets from the McDonnell Douglas Corporation. The expansion also includes service at Stewart Airport in Newburgh, N.Y., and daily flights between Miami and both Newark and New York's Kennedy Airport - as well as new flights serving Dallas, Chicago and North Carolina.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/03/busin.print_headline: TECH NOTES;   Blueprint for a Better Propeller
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/03/busin.body_text: **********Engineers at the Lewis Research Center of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration in Cleveland have been working for more than a decade on advanced high-speed propeller designs. One promising prototype now undergoing wind-tunnel tests features two counter-rotating propellers, built by the Hamilton Standard Company, that could operate on aircraft flying at speeds as high as Mach 0.85. Powered by turbofan jet engines, the propeller device has eight forward and nine aft blades. Their angles can be adjusted during operation to dampen noise and to achieve the highest ratio of thrust to engine output under different load conditions, ranging from takeoff to cruising to reverse-thrust operations during landing. According to NASA, counter-rotating propellers are up to 10 percent more efficient than single propeller designs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/22/busin.main_headline: Market Place;   Funds Questioned On Quoted Yields
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/22/busin.print_headline: Market Place;   Funds Questioned On Quoted Yields
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/22/busin.body_text: **********IN the fast-growing world of money market funds, two have stood out over the last year, largely because they have managed to pay higher interest rates than their competitors. They have done this by charging either no management fee or a lower one than other funds. **********Now, in a complaint focusing on the lack of a guarantee that those lower management fees will continue, a competitor of the high-flying funds is demanding that the Securities and Exchange Commission take steps to force more disclosures in advertising about the possibility of those yields shrinking. **********The hot funds are the Fidelity Spartan Fund, which began in January 1989 and now has $7.8 billion in assets, and the Dreyfus Worldwide Dollar Fund, which began in February 1989 and now has $6.5 billion. **********At issue are the yields quoted for the funds, which are significantly higher than those of their competitors. Those rates are quoted for a year, but their higher yields are likely to last only as long as management fees stay low. And the funds offer no guarantee that the fees will not be increased within a year. **********For example, the Dreyfus fund says its seven-day compounded annual yield through Tuesday was 8.83 percent, while the Fidelity fund quotes a figure of 8.65 percent. By contrast, Fidelity's largest money-market fund, Liquid Assets, has normal management fees and a rate of 7.99 percent. **********Vanguard Group, a mutual fund organization that charges relatively low management fees, now has funds that have seven-day compounded yields ranging from 7.88 percent to 8.03 percent, depending on whether the funds stick to Treasury bills or venture into more risky assets. It is Vanguard's chairman, John C. Bogle, who asked the S.E.C. to force Dreyfus and Fidelity to reduce the rates they quote to consumers. **********''If you want to guarantee the fee waiver for a year, that's fine,'' Mr. Bogle said yesterday. ''But don't annualize it if it is good for a day.'' He asked the S.E.C. to require that funds cut their stated yields if they reserve the right to raise management fees during the year. He said the stated yields should reflect how low they would be if the fund took its full management fees for whatever period the fund has not guaranteed it will not raise them. **********Kathryn McGrath, the director of the S.E.C. division of investment management, was at a conference and not available for comment, the S.E.C. said. **********Both Dreyfus and Fidelity responded by saying they had not misled customers, and were in full compliance with the rules. ''They miss the point,'' said Laurence Dwyer, a Fidelity spokesman. ''The true beneficiary here is the customer. The yield we advertise is the yield we pay. It's as real as any advertised or paid by Vanguard.'' **********Mr. Bogle insisted that there were no ''sour grapes'' in his complaint, and noted that since the end of 1988, his group's money fund assets had risen more rapidly than either Fidelity's or Dreyfus's. But Neil Litvack, a marketing vice president at Fidelity, said that was changing. Since the end of 1989, he said, Spartan's assets are up 40 percent, and the Dreyfus fund's assets are up 46.9 percent. Vanguard's largest money market fund is up just 12.6 percent. ''You tell me that is not sour grapes,'' Mr. Litvack said. He said Vanguard had been ''the only company to offer a product with low costs,'' but now had competitors. **********When Fidelity began Spartan, it charged no management fee. It imposed an annual fee of 5 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, in June and raised that to 10 basis points in September. Its prospectus says it could raise that fee as high as 60 basis points, but it has promised not to go above 45 basis points before May 1992. It does charge fees for such things as moving money to other funds or writing checks. **********The Dreyfus fund could impose a fee of 70 basis points, but now has no fee, and has repeatedly delayed introducing one. Its latest promise is that no fee will be imposed before April 15, or when it reaches $7 billion. There are no fees for checks or transfers. **********Howard Stein, the chairman of Dreyfus, noted that his ads do not quote a yield, but do say the fund has been the highest-yielding one. He said that even if fees were imposed, it would be done gradually, keeping investors fully informed. **********''This money is from savers,'' he said, adding that most of it seems to be coming from banks, not from other money market funds. **********Gathering the billions for the two funds has been an expensive proposition for Fidelity and Dreyfus. Fidelity now says the fund is marginally profitable at the low fees it is charging, but Dreyfus says it is losing money on its fund. Both concede that they hope to make money later by raising fees, but note that investors do not have to keep their money in the funds after that. **********''If the individual is unhappy with the yield, he can take his money,'' said Julian Smerling, vice chairman of Dreyfus. ''He won't pay any penalties or charges at all, and he will have had a good yield while his money was here.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/19/world.main_headline: Worried About Its Own Azerbaijanis, Teheran Acts With Caution
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/19/world.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: IRAN;   Worried About Its Own Azerbaijanis, Teheran Acts With Caution
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/19/world.body_text: **********The armed revolt in Azerbaijan has been received with apprehension in Iran, where an estimated 16 million Azerbaijanis represent the largest ethnic minority and have at times challenged the authority of the Teheran Government. **********By contrast, within the Arab world, the upheaval seems to have elicited little more than simple curiosity. Much of the Arab press has merely underlined softly that the Azerbaijanis are mainly Shiite Muslims and has stressed the continuing danger of Islamic fundamentalism emanating from Iran. Unlike Iran, which is not an Arab country, many Arab nations of the Middle East are populated by Sunni Muslim majorities who have come to view Iranian Shiite fundamentalism as a threat. **********Arab sentiment about the events in Azerbaijan was summed up by a senior official from an oil-producing country, who said most of the Arab Middle East wants President Mikhail S. Gorbachev ''to succeed in his efforts to liberalize Communist regimes and put an end to the threat of Soviet expansionism.'' **********Iran's Message to Soviets **********Iran's supreme religious guide, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, has cautioned the Soviet Union not to mistake the revolt for a desire among Azerbaijanis to separate themselves from the Soviet Union but to look at it as a manifestation of Islamic sentiments. **********''Anyone who thinks or pretends that the motives behind these movements are ethnic or nationalistic is making a big mistake,'' Ayatollah Khamenei said Wednesday. ''Soviet leaders should face this fact with realism.'' **********Despite the ruling clergy's cautious approach, a militant minority of Iranians have voiced the view that the Azerbaijani revolt should be encouraged as another successful example of the export of the Iranian revolution. Among these are a group of parliamentarians, and the militant newspapers Gumhuri Islami and Abrar. **********Conflicting Interests **********Experts said the Government of President Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani is caught between radicals who openly advocate material and even armed support for fundamentalist Shiites in Soviet Azerbaijan, and those in the Government who think too many vital interests shared with the Soviet Union can be put at risk by such a stand. **********''The Rafsanjani camp wants to work with the U.S.S.R. and has been the driving force behind recent economic agreements concluded between Iran and the Soviets,'' said Baqer Moin, an Iranian author based in London. **********Such policies of compromise with the Soviet Union differ sharply from Iran's approach to similar events under its previous leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, who died last June. ''Had Khomeini been still alive, Iran would have been able and anxious to inspire the revolt,'' Mr. Moin said. **********Until two years ago, the Iranian Government actively encouraged Shiite fundamentalism in Soviet Azerbaijan and among the 50 million Muslims who live in the southern Soviet Union. **********But Mr. Rafsanjani visited the Soviet Union last June and concluded a number of energy and industrial agreements valued at $10 billion - financial aid badly needed by Iran. A few days ago, the Soviet Union offered to mediate an end to the Iraq-Iran war, in a move clearly meant as an incentive for Teheran to stay out of the Azerbaijan trouble. **********Other Reasons for Caution **********But Iran has other reasons to stay put. Leading figures in the Government worry that if the movement of the estimated seven million Soviet Azerbaijanis in the Soviet Union proves to be primarily nationalist, it may lead to similar trouble among the Azerbaijanis of Iran. **********''There is a danger that if the Soviet Azerbaijanis engage Soviet troops, and use Iranian Azerbaijan as a sanctuary, they may embroil their cousins in Iran in their fight, forcing Teheran to make a decision it would rather not make,'' said Shahram Chubin, an Iranian affairs expert at the Geneva Graduate Institute of International Affairs. **********Iran, Mr. Chubin added, ''has no desire to give its minorities much more than very limited autonomy.'' **********Some nationalists in Azerbaijan have called for a Greater Azerbaijan that would unite the estimated 23 million Azerbaijanis on both sides of the Iranian-Soviet border.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/27/busin.body_text: **********Orders to the nation's factories for durable goods rose 2.5 percent in December, climbing for the second consecutive month. **********The Commerce Department said today that orders for durable goods, big-ticket items expected to last more than three years, increased to a seasonally adjusted $133.5 billion in December, after gaining 4.9 percent in November. **********But the manufacturing sluggishness through much of 1989 was reflected in the report's figures for the entire year. While orders were up 5.9 percent, to $1.52 trillion, they advanced at their slowest pace since a four-tenths of 1 percent gain in 1986. Orders increased 10.9 percent in 1988. **********'A Slight Firming' **********''The durable goods report says there is a weak economy but hints at a slight firming in the industrial sector,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist for the Boston Company. **********''It seems to be regaining its equilibrium,'' Robert G. Dederick, chief economist for the Northern Trust Company in Chicago, said of the manufacturing sector. ''It doesn't seem to be spiraling down into a recession.'' **********Mr. Sinai also noted the volatility of the durable goods reports and said the two-month increase does not necessarily establish a trend. The pace of orders in 1989 ranged from November's 4.9 percent increase to a 4.5 percent decrease last May. The data were often affected by big one-time transportation and military orders. **********Mr. Dederick and Mr. Sinai said the industrial economy remained weak and pointed out that if the transportation sector were excluded from the December report, total orders would have been unchanged from November. **********The Commerce Department said the increase in orders last month was concentrated in the transportation sector, up 8.7 percent, to $39.9 billion, after a 10.6 percent gain in November. But this growth was in aircraft, shipbuilding and tanks, the department said, which more than offset a decline in motor vehicles. **********The automobile industry has been in a slump since sales incentives were removed when 1990 models were introduced in October, resulting in excessive inventories and plant shutdowns. **********New orders for nonmilitary capital goods, often a barometer of business investment plans, jumped 18.6 percent, to $46 billion, after gaining 7.9 percent in November. **********The Commerce Department said the December increase was concentrated in the aircraft industry, while the previous month's was shared by all of the categories. **********Orders for electrical machinery rose 1.6 percent, to $22.1 billion, after a 7.9 percent increase in November.But orders for nonelectrical machinery, including computers and a wide variety of industrial equipment, slipped 4.3 percent, to $21.7 billion, after a 5.8 percent increase in November. **********Military Orders Plunge **********Primary metals orders were also off, down 2.9 percent, to $10.9 billion, after a 2.2 percent gain the previous month. **********New orders for military capital goods declined 29.2 percent, to $8.1 billion, after gaining 18.9 percent in November. Excluding the military, orders would have risen 5.5 percent. **********Shipments of durable goods in December slipped two-tenths of 1 percent, to $122.9 billion, after rising 1.1 percent in November.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/28/busin.body_text: **********The United States wants the Soviet Union and all participants at a 35-nation economic conference being held here to sign a declaration committing themselves to Western-style free-market principles, United States officials said today. **********Among other things, the declaration, called the ''Bonn Principles for Economic Cooperation,'' says the 35 nations recognize the importance of ''international policies which support the expansion of free, open trade, investment and capital flows'' and ''full recognition and protection of rights of citizens to hold and use private property.'' **********A high-ranking Soviet official at the conference, Sergei Zotov, said he supports the idea of setting out principles for East-West economic cooperation, but that the document ''presents more a code of behavior'' for East bloc countries rather than concerning itself with ''purely principles of economic cooperation.'' Mr. Zotov is the deputy head of the Soviet Foreign Ministry's Department of Security and Cooperation in Europe. **********The meeting of government officials and business executives began last week and will run through April 11. The 35-nation group includes the United States, Canada and all Eastern and Western European nations except Albania.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/14/busin.body_text: **********President Bush, acting more swiftly than expected, will ask Congress next week for authority to negotiate a comprehensive free trade agreement with Mexico, Administration officials said today. Though not the only reason, the Persian Gulf crisis was a factor in the decision, they said. **********They also said Canada, already a free trade partner of the United States, was likely to participate, giving an accord hemispheric scope and clearing the way for common standards and trading rules in all three countries by the end of the century. **********The integration of economies in North America would follow similar moves in Europe, as the European Community inches toward economic union. **********''Acting at this time is a way of telling Mexico that we're really serious,'' a senior Administration official said. In late August, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari asked the United States to open the talks. **********Mexico's Oil Reserves **********The Middle East crisis has focused the world's attention on global oil supplies. Mexico, with the eighth-largest reserves in the world, would be likely to attract more outside capital with a trade pact to help tap those reserves. **********While the United States wants to work with Mexico on increasing oil production, another factor behind the speed-up, officials said, is a desire to accommodate President Salinas, who has seized on free trade to modernize the Mexican economy. **********Mexico, which has already cut tariffs from 100 percent or more to less than 10 percent, sees an agreement with the United States attracting foreign capital that would spur modernization. **********An economic basket case early in the last decade, Mexico, through deregulation and tax cuts as well as freer trade, has already reduced inflation and interest rates sharply and all but eliminated capital flight. **********Cooperation in Energy **********Bush Administration officials expect a trade agreement to intensify cooperation in the energy sector, for example, by increasing already robust sales of American oil equipment to Mexico. **********One recent sign of cooperation was Mexico's pledge to lift overall oil exports by 100,000 barrels daily to help ease the current pressure on global supplies. Mexico exports about half of its 2.5 million barrels daily. The United States takes about 60 percent of the exports, Japan 15 percent and Europe most of the rest. **********Far more controversial is the issue of American participation in Mexican oil and gas exploration, for 50 years the exclusive preserve of the state-owned Petroleos Mexicanos, or Pemex. **********Because of political sensitivity about oil, many analysts consider it unlikely that international oil companies would be permitted to operate in Mexico. **********''The political cost associated with accepting foreign investment in the upstream sector of the petroleum industry would be substantial,'' said Rafael G. Quijano, director of the Petroleum Finance Corporation, a Washington energy consulting group. **********Still Mr. Quijano, a former Pemex executive, suggested that ways might be found to get around the issue. **********Foreign Investment Fund **********One possible solution, he said, is a financial mechanism, like a trust fund established by foreign investors in a Mexican bank with which Mexican operators would carry out drilling activities. **********Decisions on such issues are not likely to be taken before the Salinas Government tests its strength at the polls in 1991 midterm elections. **********The Presidents of the United States and Mexico agreed in June to go forward with the pact, but the expectation then was that little progress would be made before yearend. **********George W. Grayson, a Mexican oil expert at William and Mary College in Williamsburg, Va., said that Mexico was producing about at capacity and that because of rising domestic use from its rapid industrialization, it badly needed to find new oil. **********Immigration is another sensitive issue. Mexico had wanted to take up freer movement of workers as well as goods. Washington had warned that this could doom the talks and won its point. Immigration will not be negotiated, American officials said. **********Immigration Issues **********But immigration could be affected indirectly. If a free trade pact leads to a more prosperous Mexico, there will be less pressure on workers to come north. **********Organized labor in the United States has already signaled its strong opposition to a free trade pact with Mexico. But most industry groups, seeing a large potential for exports, have come out in favor. **********''Mexico is a wonderful potential market,'' said Colleen S. Morton, director of the United States Council of the Mexico-United States Business Committee. The council represents key American business groups. **********If, as expected, Canada joins the talks, in return for greater access to Mexico, Canada would have to be willing to offer Mexico the same tariff cuts and privileged access to Canada as the United States offers. **********The Administration's request to Congress starts a clock in which Congress has 60 legislative days, or at least four months, to determine whether such an agreement would be in the United States' interest. **********If Congress gives its assent, which is considered likely, negotiations will probably continue until 1993, officials said. It took about 18 months for Canada and the United States to negotiate a free trade pact in the late 1980's. Though still controversial in Canada, that pact has been so successful that the two nations agreed recently to accelerate scheduled tariff cuts. **********Mexico is the third-largest American trading partner after Canada and Japan. In 1989 two-way trade exceeded $51 billion. The United States is Mexico's primary export market.

Betting that the Japanese would raise interest rates after the Parliamentary election on Feb. 18, traders bought yen aggressively last week for the first time in months. By the end of the week, the dollar had fallen to 142.85 yen, down from 146.00. At the same time, the Canadian dollar continued to fall sharply against the American dollar as interest rates in Canada appeared to be headed even lower. Since the Bank of Canada signaled in mid-January that it would allow interest rates to fall, investors have been dumping their Canadian dollars. Two weeks ago, the Canadian dollar was worth 86.3 cents. Now it is down to 83.6 cents. https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/29/world.main_headline: MOSCOW PROMISES TO REMAIN STEADY IN FOREIGN AFFAIRS
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/29/world.print_headline: MOSCOW PROMISES TO REMAIN STEADY IN FOREIGN AFFAIRS
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/29/world.body_text: **********Soviet officials have pledged to the Bush Administration to continue coordinating efforts to resolve the Persian Gulf crisis and several civil wars, from El Salvador to Cambodia, in keeping with policies promoted by the departing Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze. **********"They are conveying continuity and we are reasonably optimistic," said a State Department official. **********American officials said meetings held by President Bush and Robert M. Kimmitt, the Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, with Ambassador Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh this week, along with lower-level exchanges in Moscow, convinced the Administration that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev remains fully in charge of Soviet foreign policy, at least for the time being. Doubts had arisen because of his severe domestic problems, including economic shortages and challenges from rebellious republics.  Reassurances for Washington **********Officials refused to comment on the contents of a New Year's note Mr. Gorbachev sent to President Bush, but they said its friendly tenor signaled Moscow's desire to improve relations further at the summit meeting scheduled in Moscow in February. **********They said the Soviets continue to express a willingness to complete work at the summit on a new treaty limiting strategic nuclear arms. That initiative was pressed by Mr. Shevardnadze before his surprise resignation last week and apparently was resisted by some conservatives in the Kremlin. **********A senior Administration official said Mr. Gorbachev may have given himself more latitude in foreign affairs "at least in the short term" by appearing more open to the concerns of conservatives on domestic and security matters. Speaking of traditional elements in the Communist Party, the military and K.G.B., he said, "The focus of their pressure is much more on internal policy than on external policy."  Recurring Theme: Continuity **********He said that most Soviet conservatives who want to limit democratic changes at home tend to believe that Mr. Gorbachev has coordinated his foreign policy too closely to Washington's and "given away the empire," but they have not come up with a unified proposal on how to redirect foreign policy. **********Mr. Bessmertnykh requested the 30-minute meeting he held with Mr. Bush on Thursday to reassure the Administration that no policy swings were anticipated in the Kremlin. American officials said the Soviet Ambassador held a more detailed 45-minute session with Mr. Kimmitt on Monday, in which he made a series of commitments that cheered the Administration. **********A State Department official said Mr. Kimmitt emphasized the need for Moscow to continue promoting its "united front" with Washington with the approach of the Jan. 15 deadline for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait or face eviction by force under a United Nations Security Council resolution. "Mr. Bessmertnykh agreed to that," the official said. **********The official said "the recurring theme" of the Kimmitt-Bessmertnykh meeting was: "They want to continue working with us and we want to continue working with them."  Kremlin's Central America Role **********The two diplomats devoted the most time to the month-old guerrilla offensive in El Salvador, with Mr. Kimmitt suggesting that Moscow use its influence to stop Cuba and Nicaragua's Sandinista Army from sending arms, particularly antiaircraft missiles, to rebels of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front. **********Mr. Bessmertnykh reiterated Moscow's traditional line that its influence over Cuban and Nicaraguan arms transfers is limited. But he pledged that Moscow would do what it could to restart the stalled United Nations-sponsored peace talks between the Salvadoran rebels and the Government of President Alfredo Cristiani. **********Administration officials said they valued the Soviet Union's involvement in Central America now that it no longer actively supports revolutionary movements. They said Moscow had helped prove that SA-14 antiaircraft missiles deployed not long ago by the Salvadoran guerrillas came from Nicaragua by identifying the serial number on an SA-14 missile casing found near a downed aircraft as that of a missile the Soviets had donated to the Nicaraguan Army in 1985. **********The Administration hopes such evidence will strengthen the hand of the Nicaraguan President, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, as she tries to control the Sandinista-dominated military.  Talks on Afghan War **********Touching briefly on a series of other regional conflicts, Mr. Bessmertnykh promised Mr. Kimmitt that Moscow intended to continue nudging the pro-Soviet Government in Cambodia to compromise on forming an interim Government with a guerrilla coalition, in advance of United Nations-sponsored elections. **********He also pledged that Moscow would continue discussions with Washington to settle the civil war in Afghanistan, in which rebels armed by the United States are fighting a regime supported by the Soviet Union. Those efforts have stalled in recent months over several issues, including the timing of future elections, the details of a proposed cutoff of Soviet and United States arms shipments and the future political role of President Najibullah. **********Soviet-American relations in the post-Shevardnadze age will face their first test in early January, when peace talks to resolve the civil war in Angola between pro-American guerrillas and a pro-Soviet Government are to resume in a potentially decisive session in Portugal.  Complications Ahead? **********An American official said Mr. Bessmertnykh and Mr. Kimmitt expressed their Governments' willingness "to keep up the heat on both sides." **********Leonid Sofanov, an aide to Mr. Bessmertnykh, said "we completely agree with our American colleagues that we can work together" on helping the two sides in Angola find a fair solution. **********But Administration officials cautioned that complications in United States-Soviet relations could lie ahead. One warned that the appointment of one of the Soviet Government's Arabists as Foreign Minister could soften Moscow's apparent support for the use of force to drive Iraq out of Kuwait.

A Reality Check for the 'East Fantasy'
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/10/busin.print_headline:

A Reality Check for the 'East Fantasy'
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/10/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: Since the Berlin Wall opened last November, West German stock trading has been dominated by a phenomenon called Ostphantasie, or east fantasy. **********Since the Berlin Wall opened last November, West German stock trading has been dominated by a phenomenon called Ostphantasie, or east fantasy. **********The idea is simple, if not simplistic. East Germany's shift from a centrally planned, socialist economy to democracy and free markets will mean quick profits for West German companies racing to rebuild the country. Buy stock in the companies most likely to benefit from that process and you are in on the ground floor of a second German economic miracle. **********That thinking was pervasive enough to spawn a four-month rally on the Frankfurt Stock Exchange that pushed the Deutsche Aktien Index to 1,969 in mid-March. But prices have fallen steadily since late April, and with a July 2 target for German monetary and economic union just weeks away, the DAX is hovering around 1,830. Fantasy is being tempered by fears that economic reunification will prove far more difficult than expected. The new buzzword in the West German stock market is Realitat - reality. **********While West German companies, led by the nation's powerful commercial banks, are indeed moving into East Germany en masse, they see it as a costly, long-term process that may not pay off for 5 to 10 years. Market analysts are counseling patience and caution. They do still recommend Deutsche Bank A.G. and a handful of other West German companies as solid blue-chip investments. **********''Euphoria has been replaced by realism,'' said Heino Ruland, a director of Bank Julius Baer Deutschland A.G. in Frankfurt. ''People are realizing now that there are two sides to German reunification and that hopes for the future do not make West German stocks immune to ordinary problems like interest-rate movements, corporate earnings and international liquidity.'' **********But it is West Germany's robust economic growth that is fueling the return to reality. The nation's gross national product grew 2.5 percent in the first quarter of this year from the preceding period, and by 4.4 percent from the comparable period a year earlier. Inflation is running at a scant 2.3 percent annual pace.  But interest rates are high and most industries are already operating at the limits of their capacity, raising fears that inflation will rise. Additional inflationary pressure is coming from the settlements reached recently with unions in the metalworking and printing industries. **********Karl Otto Pohl, the president of the West German Bundesbank, said in a recent interview that he was less worried about East Germany than about the possibility that West Germany's economy will overheat. The Bundesbank, he added, will act to keep inflation in check; economists called it a clear signal that interest rates are not coming down soon. **********Some sectors, like the housing industry, are already overheating, according to Mr. Pohl. Demand for housing in both East and West Germany far outstrips construction capacity. West German construction companies were an early favorite in the Ostphantasie scenario. But they have fallen out of favor with many analysts and fund managers, who see them as financially suspect. One problem has been surging labor costs, in part from high overtime charges. **********Other sectors may also be peaking.
