Profits and production in West Germany's vast chemical industry were weak in the first quarter, and analysts have since revised full-year earnings estimates downward. **********Similar revisions are being made for a growing number of companies. Many West German businesses are faced with the choice of passing on higher unit labor costs to consumers or squeezing profit margins. They appear to be choosing the latter. **********As a result, Mr. Ruland said, foreign investors, who have long played the dominant role in West German equities trading, are shifting to other European markets and to Wall Street. **********''While we may still have good earnings growth for some companies this year, I think it's clear we also have a slowing economy in the pipeline,'' he added. ''International liquidity is going where the interest rates are lower. For the next three or four months the general outlook in the West German stock market is fairly negative.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/10/busin.body_text: **********Asia is replete with economic miracle stories, so it is little surprise that Thailand has joined the list as having one of the world's fastest-growing economies. As evidence, the number of cars have tripled, choking traffic, and cement is in short supply as prosperous-looking houses and industrial parks rise almost at once. **********But Thailand's remarkable boom has a twist that in many ways signals the future of much of Southeast Asia. The money, the technology, the business strategies and now even the emergency shipments of cement all come from Japan. And with a mixture of elation and misgivings, Thais themselves sometimes talk about their country as Japan's newest ''economic colony,'' a country whose prosperity is partly attributable to its role as a relief valve for Japan's skyrocketing land prices and acute labor shortage. **********The torrent of Japanese investment so apparent in Thailand is also cascading into Indonesia, Malaysia and Singapore, where the skills of workers are rising and Japan sees a chance to lock up the booming Southeast Asian market while the United States and Germany are distracted by the rush into Eastern Europe. The question increasingly being asked here, though, is whether it is wise for Southeast Asia to place so much of its economic destiny in Japanese hands. **********''It is not in our interest to be too dependent on the Japanese,'' said Snoh Unakul, chairman of the Thailand Development Research Institute and a former Government official responsible for drawing in foreign investment. ''But we are having a difficult time getting the attention of America and Europe. They are simply not competitive.'' **********And though there are still conflicts with Japanese investors here, Dr. Snoh notes, corporate Japan is coming in largely on Thailand's terms -a change that has dampened the resentments and tensions that go back to Japan's brutal occupation of Southeast Asia 50 years ago. **********''The land and labor problems in Japan have left them with no choice,'' Dr. Snoh said. ''They are forced by circumstances to be more open with technology and shared management responsibility. Now, we feel we are being treated more equally.'' **********The Thais have also encouraged the transfer of Japanese skills, notably by trying to enforce stringent local-content laws governing the automobile industry. **********Japan's influence permeates Thailand in a way it did not even four years ago. The cars and pickup trucks jamming Thailand's city streets and back mountain roads are almost exclusively Toyotas, Nissans, Isuzus and Hondas - all with no emission controls. By 1992, Japanese officials predict, 300,000 Thais, or 15 percent of the country's manufacturing workers, will be employed by Japanese companies. That figure is now a little under 10 percent. **********Adopting the Japanese Way **********Japanese managers experienced in setting up plants in the United States and soothing political squabbles have arrived here, hoping to do in Bangkok what they did in Georgetown, Ky., and Smyrna, Tenn., the American production sites for Toyota and Nissan, respectively. **********And like an uncertain student who decides the safest course is to mimic the teacher, Thailand's businesses are already adopting Japanese corporate behavior. At 8:30 one recent morning, employees at a nearby industrial park dominated by Japanese companies performed stretching exercises at their desks, while manufacturing workers outside sang a Japanese company song, translated into Thai. And deals are made by players on new golf courses. **********So far, Japan's widening business role in Southeast Asia has had two dramatic effects, business executives and government officials say. The first is a significant erosion of American economic influence in the region, where the United States had been the biggest investor. When talking about money or technology the countries in the region invariably look to Japan. **********The trend is clearest in Thailand: Last year Japan provided nearly half of the $8.2 billion foreign investment in Thailand. Taiwan, also stepping up its offshore investments, came in second, though far behind Japan. The United States invested only $1 in Thailand for every $6 that came from Japan. **********A Shift in Strategy **********The second effect, which is more subtle, is a fundamental shift in the way Japan is fitting Southeast Asia into its plans to internationalize its industries and blunt the political backlash from Japan's huge trade surpluses. Japanese companies have long had a significant presence in Southeast Asia, but in the past it was a small market for Japan and a cheap place to make low-cost, low-technology parts. Now the Southeast Asian market itself is exploding, and Japanese companies are carving the region into a loosely coordinated manufacturing bloc. **********Under agreements with the major Southeast Asian nations, except Indonesia, companies like Toyota and Mitsubishi Motors plan to make diesel engines and electrical equipment in Thailand, then trade them for transmissions built in the Philippines or steering gears in Malaysia. **********The result will be complete cars -most of them for sale in Asia, some for export to the United States and Europe - that never pass through Japan, and so do not add to Japan's trade surpluses. **********Mitsubishi Motors is already assembling Japanese-designed cars in Thailand, then shipping them to Canada, where they are sold under an American nameplate - Chrysler. The car is not a Japanese import, but it is hardly entirely Thai, either. **********'It Is Profitable' **********''We are in Southeast Asia because it is profitable, especially now,'' a senior Japanese auto executive said recently. ''But it also solves a lot of political problems, not only in Asia but across the Pacific.'' **********Still, economists and business executives in Thailand say that in two or three years, Japanese investment may tail off, at least until the country's roads, dilapidated telephone system and work force catch up to the breathless 11 to 13 percent annual growth over the last two years. **********''I can't imagine that the Japanese investment can keep increasing this fast,'' said Isao Kubokawa, a former official of Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry who now runs the Japan External Trade Organization's office here. ''There are very few Japanese companies that are not already here.'' **********The reach of Japan's investment can be seen throughout Thailand. Industrial parks are springing up around Bangkok; one recent morning, scores of Thai employees lined up, Japanese-style, at a new Toshiba plant to salute the company's first shipment of color television tubes, bound for other Southeast Asian nations. A few days later the president of Fujitsu Ltd. dedicated a new factory - owned by Fujitsu itself, a departure from the usual Japanese practice of taking on a local joint venture partner - that will produce computer parts. **********The influence can even been seen in the smaller towns to the north, near the borders of Myanmar, formerly Burma, and Laos. One recent weekend in the ancient city of Chiang Rai, Buddhist monks lined up in their saffron robes at a temple, while next door at a Mitsubishi Motors dealership farmers inspected a pickup truck. **********A Strong Auto Market **********For years Japanese companies kept small operations here, even after American companies left at the end of the Vietnam War. In Tokyo, though, Thailand was considered something of a poor backwater, a market that would bloom some day in the distant future. **********Now, for the Japanese and the few Americans who stayed, that day has arrived. The International Business Machines Corporation says that Thailand is now its fastest-growing Asian market. But American auto makers, who earlier shunned what they deemed a small and difficult market, are missing an explosion in auto sales. **********In 1987, sales of cars and pickup trucks - Thailand's favorite mode of transportation - topped 100,000 for the first time. Last year they totaled 208,000, and some say they may approach 300,000 this year. ''I keep wondering where the Americans are,'' said Takashi Murasawa, a senior official of MMC Sittipol Company, the Mitsubishi Motors joint venture here. **********The beneficiaries are all of Japan's car makers, who control 92 percent of the market despite stiff local-content laws that have required them to produce half to three-quarters of their components in Thailand. **********Wages Are Low **********But if Thailand thought it was about to learn the high-tech secrets of auto making it was wrong. Factories here look like flashbacks to the 1930's. ''We don't have any robots here,'' said Suparat Sirisuwanangkura, the manager of component engineering, ''because the labor is still very cheap.'' An average auto worker in Thailand earns about $200 a month, about what a skilled Japanese auto worker would make in a day. **********A key element in the Japanese auto makers' regional strategy lies in persuading Southeast Asian nations to abandon their hopes of building ''national'' cars, in which every component is produced in their own country. **********''The volumes are too low and they are very uneconomical,'' said Ninnart Chaithirapinyo, associate director of Toyota Motor Thailand. So the auto companies have assigned subsidiaries in each country to produce certain key components of each car, and in most cases have persuaded governments to treat those parts as if they were ''domestic content.'' **********''The idea is to trade parts roughly equally,'' Mr. Ninnart said. ''In practice, though, it is difficult to balance.'' **********Indonesia has refused to participate, apparently fearing that efforts to build its own cars would be undermined. Malaysia has already mounted its own effort. For five years, the country has been building the Proton Saga, a national car, although two years ago Mitsubishi had to step in to rescue the project. **********Whether Japan is really willing to share its high-tech knowledge with countries like Thailand is a matter of considerable debate. The companies all say they share generously, often bringing Thai or Malaysian engineers to Tokyo for training. But employees say that Japan is keeping its most sophisticated manufacturing processes to itself. **********''We need to put more emphasis on getting Japan to part with its technology,'' Dr. Snoh said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/21/busin.body_text: **********Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that William W. Moore, the senior vice president in charge of its municipal markets group, would step down from his post at the start of next year. **********Mr. Moore, who has been with Merrill Lynch for 18 years, will assume a senior banker position that will allow him to focus on maintaining key municipal client relationships and recruiting new clients. **********Mr. Moore will be succeeded by John D. Miller, who is currently manager of the public finance group, which is a component of the municipal markets division. Mr. Miller, a 19-year Merrill employee, has specialized in municipal finance since joining the firm. He has managed both Merrill's municipal finance department and the municipal utilities department. **********Mr. Moore, who has worked in the municipal area for about 12 years, largely owth as a major player in the municipal markets. He started with the firm in 1972 as a vice president of what is now Merrill Lynch Hubbard, where he headed the Ginnie Mae, health care and mortgage banking departments. **********Succeeding Mr. Miller as the manager of Merrill's public finance group will be Marsha Eisenberg, a managing director who has been part of the company's public finance department since 1980.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/04/busin.main_headline: How One Man Rescued Basketball, and Its Bottom Line
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/04/busin.print_headline: How One Man Rescued Basketball, and Its Bottom Line
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/04/busin.body_text: **********David J. Stern is a friend of the Famous Chicken. He thinks it's wonderful that Orlando hates Miami. He sees no reason why fans shouldn't stuff themselves with Charlotte Hornets Caramel Corn. **********Is this really the way for the commissioner of the National Basketball Association to behave? Apparently so. **********It has been six years since Mr. Stern moved into the half-court-sized office on the 15th floor of Olympic Towers in Manhattan and began calling the plays as the N.B.A. commissioner. During his stewardship - reflected in pugnacious rivalries among teams, an explosion of spinoff goodies and exhortations to bring jugglers and men in chicken suits onto the court - basketball has risen from its death bed to become the world's hottest sports business, and a paragon worthy of study by the other leagues. **********By working as hard at crunching numbers and cuddling corporate sponsors as at disciplining unruly players, Mr. Stern has demonstrated how deeply pro sports must rely on applying business discipline and thumping the marketing drums to flourish in a world rampant with entertainment options. The N.B.A., more than any other league, is profuse with Disney-like hoopla, practically murdering people with fun. The National Hockey League, in fact, has mimicked some of the N.B.A.'s marketing notions. And as they wrestle with the dizzying rise in player salaries, the National Football League and Major League Baseball have looked to the N.B.A.'s unique labor agreement, which limits salaries. **********''No question about it, basketball has done a stunning job,'' said John Ziegler, the president of the N.H.L. **********''They've changed the game from a sports package to an entertainment package,'' remarked Joel Steckel, a marketing professor at New York University and a rabid fan. **********One sign of the league's prosperity is the thickness of Mr. Stern's wallet. He was just rewarded with the highest-paying contract of any sports commissioner, a five-year package worth $10 million in bonuses and an annual salary of $3.5 million. He previously made do on an estimated $1 million a year. **********Just 10 years ago, the N.B.A. was an object of pity. A good 17 of its 23 teams lost money, and the league pondered folding as many as four of the most anemic ones. The sport's demons included skyrocketing player salaries, quarrelsome owners and a poor public image fomented by drug abuse. Attendance, television ratings and corporate sponsorship were all dwindling. Go to a basketball game? Better to just paint the living room. In 1983, when he was the league's executive vice president, Mr. Stern helped achieve a collective bargaining agreement with the Players Association that caps team payrolls while guaranteeing players 53 percent of league revenues, bringing extended labor peace to the sport. It also led to a system that provides care and discipline for drug users. **********Then Mr. Stern taught himself the ropes of marketing and began to sell the N.B.A. shamelessly. ''I'm the chief executive officer of an entertainment company,'' he said. ''And so you have to sell and sell and sell.'' **********The result is a striking rise in the sport's attendance, revenues and sponsorships. This year, the N.B.A.'s gross revenues should top $500 million, up from $118 million in 1980. Only a few of the 27 teams, including Washington, Indiana, Atlanta and New Jersey, are expected not to be profitable this year, but all are likely to be snugly in the black in 1991, when the roar of money begins from a sugary $600 million, four-year NBC contract for basketball rights, triple the prior deal with CBS. An additional $275 million will arrive over the next four years from Turner Network Television for cable rights, up from the previous two-year, $50 million package. **********Now, the 47-year-old Mr. Stern is embarking on his next big gambit: peddling the sport abroad (see box). And he likes nothing better than hustling. ''We had people in this league who would have trouble selling Blue Cross to Humpty Dumpty,'' said Pat Williams, the general manager of the Orlando Magic. ''David Stern can sell an anvil to a drowning man. He can sell a pogo stick to a kangaroo. You ready for this? David Stern could sell a stethoscope to a tree surgeon. That's the ultimate tribute I can pay the man.'' **********David Stern has a quicksilver mind, a sphagnum-soft voice, a mischievous face and a contemplative stare. He grew up in New York, the son of delicatessen owners, and attended Rutgers University and the Columbia Law School, before joining the New York law firm of Proskauer Rose Goetz & Mendelsohn. He was a very low scorer on his firm's basketball team in the unobtrusive New York Lawyers League until he injured his knee and retired his sneakers. **********At the firm, Mr. Stern, a fervid basketball fan, toiled on innumerable N.B.A. cases, until, in 1978, he was hired by the league as its general counsel. Two years later, he was elevated to executive vice president. And in February 1984, Mr. Stern became the 38-year-old league's fourth commissioner. **********Early on, he worked at weeding out owners with shaky wealth and those disposed to fluctuant behavior. Nearly half the teams have changed hands in the last six years. **********One who got brushed with an unusual amount of tar was Theodore Stepien, who owned the Cleveland Cavaliers in the early 1980's, when the team's abysmal record earned it the nickname, the Cadavers. Mr. Stepien authorized so many dismal trades that the league imposed a moratorium on future Cavaliers' exchanges. He hired a ''Super Fan'' to attend games and rip apart beer cans with his teeth. When Mr. Stepien finally wanted out, the N.B.A. had to thrash out an arrangement that let the Cavaliers buy back draft picks that had been traded to get somebody to buy the team. **********In the Stern era, franchise values have rocketed faster than in any major-league sport. While some teams once couldn't be given away, the latest four expansion teams paid $32.5 million apiece to join. How well do teams pay? The Celtics, one of the most prosperous franchises and the only publicly owned team, reported a profit of $12.2 million last season, while an average team is thought to earn close to $4 million. **********A looming worry for the league is the widening gulf between the monetary opportunities available to smaller teams like the Utah Jazz and those playing in large markets - especially as local television deals mushroom in big cities. Thus the N.B.A. formed a committee a year and a half ago to probe ways to prop up the fortunes of the smaller franchises, like subsidizing smaller teams. **********Another potential thorn for owners is the practice of many players to defer part of their pay. Unlike in football and baseball, teams are not required by league rules to set aside funds to handle those obligations. ''We're paying for some players I never heard of,'' said Larry Miller, who inherited the debts when he bought the Jazz three years ago. If revenues shrink, some owners may be hard-pressed to find the cash. **********Charismatic players like Michael Jordon, Larry Bird, Patrick Ewing and Magic Johnson have had no small impact on the sport's popularity. The league has also benefited mightily from the fact that teams from populous areas with a fabled history - the Celtics, Lakers and Knicks -are among the current powerhouses. ''I think the popularity of basketball would quickly revert if the winningest teams were from San Antonio, Dallas and Milwaukee,'' said Mr. Steckel of N.Y.U. **********Lopsided matches are another danger, and may already be hurting television ratings. After rising sharply for a decade, ratings slipped last year - 7 percent on CBS, 17 percent on cable - and are off this season by the same amounts. **********Because not every team has mega-stars, Mr. Stern nudges owners to do more than just put teams on the floor. ''Game presentation is vital,'' he said. ''The way fans are shown to seats, the music, how breaks in action are used, the cheerleaders, how the arena is dressed, whether you play two minutes of a song and end on an upbeat.'' **********The new Orlando Magic tries hard to make fans overlook that its opponents usually score more points than it does. Magicians and dancers regularly delight fans. Stirring interest is a year-long contest that earns the winner a $150,000 home donated by Ryan Homes. Further shoving up ticket sales is a vitriolic feud with Miami Heat fans. **********To help owners with their pizazz, the N.B.A. operates a Team Services division. It spreads the word on such things as the best high-energy tunes to play to work up a crowd: ''Shout,'' ''Bad,'' ''Twist and Shout,'' ''Proud Mary.'' It also has the dope on the niftiest half-time acts - like Tanya Crevier, an expert dribbler who can spin nine basketballs on her fingers at once. **********In David Stern's view, basketball must always be conjoined with Big Macs and Tide detergent and - who knows? - thermal hosiery if need be. Do you have the N.B.A. Baby Bib? How about Dr. Scholl's Foot Powder, the one Dr. J says you must use? What about chomping some Charlotte Hornets Caramel Corn? Last year, $525 million worth of 140 different N.B.A.-licensed products were sold, up from less than $200 million in 1987. **********The league has also found a small gold mine in game videos. Last year, it sold 1.3 million tapes, about six times more than five years ago. It is now pushing into collectibles and is thinking of auctioning off player jerseys from next year's All-Star Game. **********Why not even have teams open their own retail stores to sell sports merchandise? There are three outlets for the Detroit Pistons, while the Utah Jazz leads the league with seven. **********The sport boasts 20 full-time corporate sponsors, up from three a decade ago, including Schick, Gatorade, Miller and Coca-Cola. Mr. Stern is tireless in ingratiating himself with sponsors. In fact, he's not above appearing in plugs himself. Watch for him in print ads for the Digital Equipment Corporation. **********N.B.A. LOOKS ABROAD FOR NEW FANS **********Zambia. Finland. Kuwait. These and some 70 other countries now regularly broadcast N.B.A. games. Nobody can resist. Last February, the Soviet Union began putting league contests on its tube, replete with plugs from Coca-Cola and Mastercard. **********Five years ago fewer than half that many countries were showing the N.B.A. With many teams playing close to capacity and with television contracts set for several years, the most promising way to grow is abroad. And foreigners swoon over basketball players. When Larry Bird spent two hours signing autographs in Madrid recently, he supposedly beat the popularity record set by Sophia Loren. **********Foreign broadcasts now bring only about $5 million to the N.B.A., but that sum is growing at 25 to 50 percent a year. Some day, David Stern imagines, the N.B.A. may garner as much money abroad as it does at home. **********The National Football League is planting a minor league of teams in Europe to start play in 1991. It faces some competition from the fledgling World Basketball League, which begins its third season in May with a few impressive sponsors, like Coca-Cola. Still, its games averaged crowds of only about 3,000 last year. **********The N.B.A. doesn't feel ready to create franchises in foreign cities, but it recognizes the value of live contests. Thus, three years ago it hatched an annual tournament, known as the McDonald's Open in honor of its hamburger sponsor, that pits an N.B.A. team against the best foreign teams. The game gets shuttled among foreign and American cities. What's more, Mr. Stern is discussing playing some regular season games next year in Japan. **********Meanwhile, he keeps cajoling, plying, exhorting. ''David will never be happy until he's able to walk down the street in Peking and see on every kid's head an N.B.A. cap,'' said Pat Williams. ''And don't think he won't do it.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/03/busin.body_text: **********Comerica Inc. said it had agreed to acquire Inbancshares, a bank holding company based in City of Industry, Calif., for $20.25 a share, or about $40 million. The acquisition, which is subject to regulatory approval, would add $242 million to Comerica's assets of about $12 billion. Inbancshares has four offices and 70 employees.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/28/busin.body_text: **********Swiss authorities have begun a formal inquiry into the possibility of insider trading in shares of Jacobs Suchard A.G. before the Swiss chocolate and coffee group agreed to be bought last month by the Philip Morris Companies for $3.8 billion. **********''We have come across some aspects during our informal inquiries that could indicate insider trading,'' Daniel Tewlin, a Swiss prosecutor, said today. ''We now want to get some information that we could not get through informal inquiries.'' **********By starting a formal investigation, Mr. Tewlin can seize documents he thinks are pertinent to the case. **********Insider trading has been illegal in Switzerland since 1988, but no one has ever been prosecuted for the practice. **********The Zurich Stock Exchange last month urged a Government inquiry into whether insider trading was behind sharp rises in Suchard's shares before Philip Morris announced the takeover on June 22. **********At the time, the stock exchange's director, Richard Meier, said no concrete evidence indicated that insider trading had taken place. **********A total of 83 million Suchard shares changed hands on Swiss stock exchanges on June 20 and 42 million on June 22. Volume on June 19 had been only 13 million. The day before the takeover was disclosed, Suchard's shares surged 200 Swiss francs ($141.40), to 7,800 francs ($5,514). Philip Morris set a public offer of 8,500 francs ($6,000) a share. **********Philip Morris also said today that it would not change its $3.8 billion tender offer for Jacobs Suchard. A Swiss bank, Bank Vontobel in Zurich, had suggested that public shareholders refuse the offer as being too low.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/04/busin.body_text: **********Hit hard by lower production and a decline in new orders, the nation's manufacturing economy slowed in November to the lowest level since the recession of the early 1980's, a survey of purchasing managers has found. **********The National Association of Purchasing Management said yesterday that its index of economic activity fell to 41.3 percent, the weakest showing since November 1982, when the index stood at 39.2 percent. In October, the index was at 43.3 percent. **********Economists said the report underscored their feeling that the nation's economy was heading into recession. The Commerce Department said on Friday that the Government index of the leading economic indicators fell in October, for the fourth consecutive month, by 1.2 percent. And Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, told Congress on Wednesday that economic activity had been contracting since last month.   Wide Range of Industries **********The purchasing managers' report is considered an important economic indicator because it is based on a survey of managers from a wide range of the nation's industrial companies. It is also the first important indicator released each month. **********The report for last month also stated that the December index, if unchanged from the November level, would mean that growth in the gross national product for the entire year would be nine-tenths of a percent and that G.N.P. would decline in the fourth quarter by about six-tenths of a percent. **********In contrast, G.N.P. rose by 2.9 percent in 1989, and by five-tenths of a percent in the fourth quarter of last year.  Weakness in New Orders **********"The negative growth in the United States economy, registered in October for the first time in 10 years, has deepened in November," said Robert J. Bretz, chairman of the purchasing managers' business survey committee and director of materials management at Pitney Bowes Inc. "With the engine of the economy, new orders, at its lowest point in over eight years, it appears likely the negative trend will continue for some time." **********The weakness in new orders reported by the purchasing managers was cited by economists as the greatest indicator of troubles in manufacturing. The index of new orders dropped to 39.4 percent in November, from 43.8 percent in October. The November level is the lowest since May 1982, when the index stood at 38.1 percent. **********"The economic decline will not bottom until this index stops falling," the report said. **********Neal Soss, chief economist at the First Boston Corporation, said: "The industrial sector has been in recession for some time and there is nothing that suggests an early rebound. New orders are weak and inventories are already low, which suggests that you won't get the rebound that sometimes comes when there is too little inventory." **********Production fell in November for the fourth consecutive month, with the association's production index falling to 41.8 percent, from 43 percent in October. "Considering that the new-orders index is the weakest in over eight years, it is unrealistic to expect a reverse soon," the report said.  Prices Rise Again **********Prices that manufacturers pay for goods rose in November for the sixth consecutive month, but the rate of increase dropped from that of October. The report said that despite increases in the costs of raw material to manufacturers, customers had resisted price increases. The report said that inflation as a result of the crisis in the Persian Gulf had probably peaked and that price increases would largely subside in the next year or so. **********The level of exports continued to increase in November, with the association's index of new export orders rising to 55 percent, from 51 percent in October. **********The level of imports declined in November for the seventh consecutive month, with the imports index dropping to 42 percent, from 46.5 percent in October. **********Prices of several items were said to be higher in November, including chemicals and other items that contain crude oil or derivatives. Other items that were higher priced included solvents, sulfur, ammonia and caustic soda, which is heavily used in making paper.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/05/world.print_headline: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;   Anti-Communist Radio Endangered by Success
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/05/world.body_text: **********In a number of ways, this is a banner year at the American institution known as Radio Free Europe-Radio Liberty. **********Its budget is fat and it is reveling in plaudits from the new democratically elected leaders of Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, whose countries were the targets of the stations' anti-Communist broadcasts since the 1950's. **********But the cold war, in which the stations were a weapon, has ended. While directors and staff members see at least several years of useful work ahead of them, they appear to share a feeling that the timer has begun to tick. **********Asked whether he could imagine a termination date for Radio Free Europe's broadcasts to Poland, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Bulgaria and Romania, Eugene Pell, president of the twinned stations, replied: ''My personal impression is that the process is very fragile. A two-year process? Five years? Ten years? I don't know the answer to that.'' **********Mr. Pell went on to say that he felt there was still a need for Radio Free Europe but added, ''I am not interested in perpetuating something for the sake of perpetuation.'' **********Uncertainty About the Future **********The future of the Munich stations will be decided in Washington by the Bush Administration and by Congressional oversight and appropriations committees. No one is calling publicly for a shutdown at this time. But there are proposals afloat both on Capitol Hill and in the White House to restructure international broadcasting operations. **********This has created what Bill Marsh, Mr. Pell's deputy, described as ''a lot of nervousness'' among the employees in Munich since one of the restructuring variants might be to fold Radio Free Europe-Radio Liberty into the Voice of America, meaning it would become part of a Government agency. **********For the people in Munich, the optimal solution would be to empower the Board for International Broadcasting, which has supervised the Munich stations since their ties to the C.I.A. were severed in 1971, to assume the added role of supervising the Voice of America. That would mean separating the V.O.A. from its parent, the United States Information Agency. **********The board, a sort of corporation funded by Congress, allows the Munich stations a somewhat greater degree of independence from Government control than that accorded to V.O.A. **********''There will be some sort of amalgamation,'' Mr. Marsh predicted. **********Recruiting Is Under a Cloud **********Did the end of the cold war make it more difficult for the stations to recruit and retain staff members? **********Mr. Marsh said that several people had turned down job offers recently, citing articles saying the stations would be going out of business, but he added that in the last recruiting drive there were 200 applicants for 7 jobs. **********''Morale is pretty good but people are worried about the future,'' a young journalist said. ''Older staff members are quite concerned about the prospects of reaching pension age.'' He quoted an older employee as saying, ''We did such a good job that they are going to pull the carpet out from under us.'' **********''I wouldn't say there is a great deal of tangible fear,'' said a station official familiar with personnel issues, noting that he knew of only three employees who had left in recent months. ''There are more people coming than going.'' **********Whatever their expectancy, the Munich stations seem to be acting as if the future is forever. In the last few months, Radio Free Europe has opened bureaus in Warsaw, Prague and Budapest, with fanfares that included flying planeloads of European executives to the ribbon-cutting ceremonies. **********Radio Liberty Seems Stronger **********For the service to the Soviet Union, to which Radio Liberty broadcasts in 12 languages, the Munich station has hired seven reporters. Given the continuing uncertainty about the future of reforms in the Soviet Union, Radio Liberty's survival chances are probably better than those of Radio Free Europe. **********While he seeks to put Radio Free Europe's best foot forward by opening bureaus in Eastern Europe, Mr. Pell acknowledged that ''we have given a lot of thought'' to cutting broadcasting services ''country by country'' if forced to by budget cutters. **********He said the obvious candidates for trims or elimination of service would be those East European countries that had moved furthest on the road to democracy. Those would be Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungary, although not necessarily in that order, he said. **********Until then, Mr. Pell and his associates will continue to show budget cutters the rave notices from Eastern Europe's new leaders. **********Hungary's Prime Minister, Jozsef Antall, sent a notice dated in June that says, ''Your programs in the coming years can still help the strengthening of democracy in Hungary in many ways.'' **********Poland's Prime Minister, Tadeusz Mazowiecki, wrote a letter in May saying that he trusted that ''RFE may continue to serve as a reliable source of information.'' **********From Czechoslovakia's President Vaclav Havel came the comment in May: ''It seems to me that there are numberless spheres where it can continue to serve our nations well at this time - better than our own mass media.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/02/busin.main_headline: Caesars Sees A Profit Drop For Quarter
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/02/busin.print_headline: Caesars Sees A Profit Drop For Quarter
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/02/busin.body_text: **********After a run of bad luck at the gambling tables, Caesars World Inc. said today that it expected to report drastically reduced earnings for the quarter ended Jan. 31. **********Caesars World said in a preliminary report that its earnings for the period, which is the company's second quarter, would range from 3 cents to 10 cents a share, compared with 42 cents a share for the similar period a year ago. **********The poor results, it said, reflected ''substantially lower win percentages'' for the casinos at the company's two Nevada operations. **********Business Was Strong **********''The laws of probability work in strange ways,'' said Henry Gluck, Caesars World's chairman and chief executive. ''We've had enormous quarters at a time when it surprised us as much as this kind of thing surprises us.'' **********The company said it had lower win percentages even as business remained strong. The volume at its three casinos increased significantly last year, it said. **********In fact, Caesars World said, it set quarterly company records for gaming activity at Caesars Palace in Las Vegas and Caesars Tahoe in northern Nevada. The records were achieved in a period when a rival company, Golden Nugget Inc., opened its giant Mirage hotel and casino on the Las Vegas Strip. **********Besides its two Nevada locations, Caesars World, based in Los Angeles, operates the Caesars Atlantic City Hotel-Casino through its 86.6 percent ownership of Caesars New Jersey Inc. The company, which also operates four resorts in the Pocono Mountains in Pennsylvania, did not disclose how its Atlantic City casino had fared. **********Mr. Gluck said that because the quarter had just ended and earnings estimates were preliminary, he could not discuss why the company did so poorly in Nevada. **********Gambling odds generally work in favor of the casino. In the short run, however, earnings are subject to ups and downs. Casinos that concentrate on slot machines, in which the stakes are smaller than in other forms of casino gambling, generally have less volatile results. **********Caesars is known, however, for offering high-stakes gambling in card games like baccarat. In addition, during the holiday season, when casinos are full, volatile swings in gaming results can occur. **********''In the gaming business, you can get hit really hard, especially when you have high stakes players,'' said Marvin B. Roffman, an analyst at Janney Montgomery Scott Inc. in Philadelphia. ''They got absolutely murdered at the baccarat table. But the key thing is they still have good business.'' **********In trading on the New York Stock Exchange today, Caesars World shares fell to a new 365-day low of $22.50, before rebounding to close down 37.5 cents, to $24.375. **********'Not Unusual' **********Analysts said the stock recovered because the earnings decline did not represent a fundamental change in the company. **********''These things happen over time,'' said Michael G. Mueller, an analyst at Montgomery Securities in San Francisco. ''It's not unusual to have lower results because other times you make it up. The important thing to look at is demand, and that was O.K.'' **********Mr. Mueller said that because of increased competition in Las Vegas, higher expenses might account for some of Caesars World's downturn, particularly the practice of offering complimentary lodging, meals and transportation to big-stakes gamblers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/25/busin.main_headline: Protest in Canada Cuts Auto Output
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/25/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Protest in Canada Cuts Auto Output
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/25/busin.body_text: **********Canada's two largest auto makers -General Motors of Canada Ltd. and the Ford Motor Company of Canada Ltd. - reduced production at their plants because of a blockade by Canadian truckers at several Canada-United States border crossings. The truckers have blocked commercial traffic at various crossings in Ontario to protest what they call the unfair advantage American truckers have under the Free Trade Act. **********A Ford spokesman said 3,800 workers at its plants in Oakville worked only four hours of an eight-hour shift on Wednesday. G.M. Canada said its Scarborough van assembly plant and a truck and two car assembly plants in Oshawa closed today, idling 13,200 workers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/06/world.main_headline: WESTERN LEADERS CALL FOR NEW NATO TO ASSURE SOVIETS
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/06/world.print_headline: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;   WESTERN LEADERS CALL FOR NEW NATO TO ASSURE SOVIETS
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/06/world.body_text: **********President Bush and other Western leaders opened a crucial summit conference today with calls for a reshaped NATO alliance that would both reassure the Soviet Union of the West's peaceful intentions and guard against a possible revival of Soviet expansionism. **********Meeting at a moment of triumph for democratic values that has nonetheless created strategic problems for the 40-year-old alliance, the NATO leaders held two sessions at Lancaster House, an imposing 19th-century mansion in central London. The second ended two hours early, with the leaders instructing their foreign ministers to work late on a communique melding Mr. Bush's views with those of his colleagues. **********Mr. Bush formally presented his plan to redefine NATO nuclear doctrine, envisaging the use of nuclear weapons in Europe not as part of a ''flexible response,'' as before, but only as a ''last resort.'' **********Gorbachev Address Urged **********The President also proposed that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union be asked to address a future alliance summit meeting, and his aides continued to speak of sending a special NATO envoy to Moscow this weekend to deliver a copy of the communique to Mr. Gorbachev. [Georgi K. Shakhnazarov, adviser to the Soviet President, said in an interview on the ''MacNeil/Lehrer Newshour'' that Mr. Gorbachev would address the members of NATO if invited.]  While the ministers toiled on the communique under the chairmanship of the Dutch Foreign Minister, Hans van den Broek, the 16 national leaders attended a dinner given by Queen Elizabeth II at Buckingham Palace. **********There appeared to be no rifts so severe within the alliance they could not be bridged, and a German official said the day's meetings went smoothly, but both the British and the French were arguing for language somewhat more hawkish than that proposed by the United States. **********Thatcher's Strategy **********Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain implictly criticized Mr. Bush's proposal about weapons of ''last resort,'' remarking that ''we must not replace flexible response with inflexible response.'' **********Her spokesman later disclosed that Britain was trying to make Mr. Bush's proposed language more ambiguous, in the belief that only imprecise language would leave the Soviet Union in sufficient doubt as to when and where nuclear weapons would be used and thus constitute an effective deterrent. **********The President, on the other hand, proposed the phrase ''last resort'' precisely because it might allay some of Mr. Gorbachev's strategic concerns. **********'Generally Positive Response' **********Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said the allies had given ''a generally positive response'' to Mr. Bush's opening presentation. **********''But as of yet, we don't have agreement on all the points,'' he added at a briefing tonight. ''The debate is real. The discussion is real.'' Trying to sum up the purpose of the meeting, Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti, a key figure in arranging it, said, ''If we admit that there is a real risk that the Soviet Union and the other Warsaw Pact countries might feel left out of things, then our role is to reassure them and to integrate them in a system of stability.'' **********Although this conference has often been described as the one at which NATO's new mission will be defined, its purpose is in fact more limited, allied diplomats said. The goal is to promise such a redefinition to help persuade Moscow that the cold war is really over, but it is also to prod the Soviet Union into action of its own on arms control, economic change and, above all, acquiescence in NATO membership for a reunited Germany later this year. **********Bush Presents Ideas **********''We want to reassure them and bring pressure on them at the same time,'' a senior American official said. ''We want to say, 'We are prepared to go down this new road, but we'll do it only if you're ready to join us.' '' **********To that end, Mr. Bush offered his ideas on altering the NATO nuclear doctrine. **********The participants in the meeting here were intensely conscious of the fact that it coincided with the potentially pivotal Communist Party Congress in Moscow. Mrs. Thatcher said she had received messages in the last 24 hours from both Mr. Gorbachev and President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia. **********''They are just as interested in this summit as we are here who attend it,'' the Prime Minister said in her speech. ''This century has been marked by war and suffering on an unparalleled scale. Nevertheless in its closing decade we are seeing new hope and new aspirations about the world.'' **********Mitterrand Has Reservations **********Endorsing what he called ''the spirit'' of United States proposals for redirecting NATO, President Francois Mitterrand of France also expressed some reservations about language. NATO's nuclear policy, he said, ''should have the unambiguous aim of nipping war in the bud, of preventing it breaking out, not simply of attempting to win,'' which sounded like a veiled criticism of the ''last resort'' formulation. **********None of the senior national leaders explicitly proposed a ''no first use'' nuclear policy for the alliance, but the NATO Secretary General, Manfred Worner, a German, insisted in a radio interview in West Germany that NATO had always been ''a purely defensive alliance and would never be the first to use weapons of any sort.'' **********Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany, who has set the pace over the last year in building a new Europe in the wake of Communism's collapse, said publicly for the first time today that he would be prepared to negotiate at the conventional arms talks in Vienna ''the level of forces to be maintained by a united Germany.'' The Soviet Union has expressed concern about the size of German forces now that the Warsaw Pact buffer zone has all but vanished. **********Germans Ready to Talk **********Previously, the plan had been to address that issue later. But Mr. Kohl's spokesman, Hans Klein, said West Germany was ready to talk now, even though the Government in Bonn has not yet agreed upon a force level. **********Mr. Kohl also expressed willingness to sign a nonagression agreement along with other NATO and Warsaw Pact nations, as did Mr. Mitterrand. But though the French President said he would prefer to act through the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, France's favored vehicle as a pan-European organization to eventually supersede NATO and the Warsaw Pact. **********Mrs. Thatcher appeared somewhat less enthusiastic. **********President Bush's package of confidence-building measures, which had been sent in a letter to NATO leaders several days ago, included withdrawal of nuclear artillery shells from Europe in addition to the nonaggression declaration and the proposal for the use of new language in stating NATO's policy on the use of nuclear weapons. **********New Institutions Weighed **********Mr. Bush's timetable for artillery shells, most of which are based in East Germany, would require Moscow to complete troop withdrawals from Eastern Europe before the last of the 1,400 shells were pulled out. But Mr. Kohl, whose country has a large anti-nuclear lobby, said he favored acting after the conclusion of a treaty cutting conventional forces, before actual withdrawals.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/14/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Bally Delays Interest Payment
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/14/busin.body_text: **********The Bally Manufacturing Corporation said yesterday that it would not make an interest payment of $5 million scheduled for Dec. 15 on its 10 percent convertible subordinated debentures due in 2006. The company said it would take advantage of a 30-day grace period to continue a review of the company's finances and consider various restructuring alternatives. **********Bally said that delaying the interest payment would not create cross-defaults on other borrowings. The company, squeezed by debt and a downturn in business, lost $87.7 million in the third quarter. In October, Bally decided not to make an interest payment of $18.4 million to holders of mortgage notes and began negotiating a restructuring.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/17/busin.snippet: LEAD: An experiment in retirement living next door to a general hospital is getting under way in the Catskill Mountains 90 miles northwest of New York City.
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/17/busin.main_headline:
An Experiment in the Catskills;

Elderly Community Linked to Hospital
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/17/busin.print_headline:
An Experiment in the Catskills;

Elderly Community Linked to Hospital
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/17/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: An experiment in retirement living next door to a general hospital is getting under way in the Catskill Mountains 90 miles northwest of New York City. **********An experiment in retirement living next door to a general hospital is getting under way in the Catskill Mountains 90 miles northwest of New York City. **********The unusual feature of the 211-unit Harris Village in Harris, a Sullivan County town near Monticello, is that it is a private community whose residents will have ready access to a wide range of medical and support services to be provided on a fee basis by the adjoining Community General Hospital of Sullivan County. The 280-bed, not-for-profit voluntary institution, which contains a 60-bed nursing home wing, was established in 1977. **********Harris Village differs significantly from the so-called life-care communities proliferating around the country. Such communities also offer health services along with housing, but they charge high entrance fees that give buyers no equity in their homes and that are seldom refunded in full. The Harris Village plan allows buyers or their heirs to resell their units at any time, with any profits going to them. Residents will also have all the tax benefits of homeownership. They will pay for any medical services needed through Medicare and private supplemental health insurance. **********Hospital officials developed the concept and brought in a private developer, Harris Village Partners of Chappaqua, N.Y., as a joint venture partner. **********Harris Village is believed to be one of the few communities in which a hospital and a developer have teamed up to serve the elderly. The land for the project, a 35-acre tract, is now part of the hospital's grounds but will be deeded to the developer when sales begin next month. **********The community will look no different from other residential complexes springing up in this vacation resort area. The development is structured as a cooperative, but it has no underlying mortgage. Purchasers will buy their units as they would in any other cooperative, and they will pay a monthly fee to cover real estate taxes, maintenance, housekeeping and one meal a day. **********Buyers, or one spouse in the case of couples, must be 55 or older, but the average age is expected to be in the mid-70's. Health problems are not a limitation. Although some residents at Harris Village may ultimately have to enter a nursing home, the hope is that many will be able to avoid it because the hospital's comprehensive geriatric services will be provided on an outpatient basis. **********Indeed, the idea for Harris Village grew out of the realization by hospital administrators that the elderly can often be kept out of nursing homes if they have other options, like home care and day care. **********In return for its land, the hospital will receive a percentage of the sales, which is expected to net it more than $1 million. Hospital services to residents, home care and other services are expected to add more than $300,000 to annual revenues. **********''We have a housing project that's first class, and we're saying that if you come live here, we'll keep you with friends and loved ones as long as possible,'' said Martin I. Richman, Community General's executive director. **********Harris Village, whose architect is David Smotrich & Partners of Manhattan, will have a mix of one- and two-bedroom town houses and apartments. A 15,000-square-foot community center will offer dining, a cocktail lounge, a convenience store and a library among other amenities. There will also be an outdoor swimming pool and a tennis court. The Life Care Services Corporation of Des Moines will be the operator and manager. **********The development's first 99-unit phase, on which construction will start once contracts are signed for at least 60 of the units, will offer a range of choices from a 750-square-foot, one-bedroom apartment priced at $137,500 to a two-bedroom, 1,700-square-foot two-story town house for $225,000. Occupancy will be available in 1992. **********The 60-unit, three-story U-shaped apartment house, with front porches, gabled rooflines and traditional facades, has been designed to look like a turn-of-the-century Catskills hotel. All apartments have either a balcony or a porch. The town houses, most of which will be on one level, will be built in clusters of three to six units and each will have a one-car garage. They will also have front porches to promote the feeling of a small village. **********''The whole idea is one of aging in place with a degree of security, and that security also comes from interchange among people,'' said Mr. Smotrich, who is also the managing partner of the Chappaqua development group. **********Monthly maintenance fees, over which the cooperative corporation will have future control, will initially range from $1,014 to $1,195. Couples who want a second meal each day will pay an additional $300 monthly.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/27/busin.main_headline: British Utility In Loss for Year
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/27/busin.print_headline: British Utility In Loss for Year
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/27/busin.body_text: **********National Power P.L.C., a Government-owned British electric utility that is preparing for privatization, today posted a loss of $:605 million, or $1.1 billion, for the year and said it would cut 5,000 jobs over the next five years. **********The company said it expected to make the cuts through attrition and voluntary retirements. It eliminated 800 jobs earlier this year and currently employs about 16,000 people. **********National Power and the smaller PowerGen are the two generating companies officially formed in March from the breakup of the Central Electricity Generating Board. **********Their shares were to be offered to the public next year. **********But the Government said this week that it held discussions with the British conglomerate Hanson P.L.C. that might lead to the private sale of PowerGen. **********The results for the year ended March 31 were presented as if National Power had been an autonomous business throughout the year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/23/world.main_headline: Senate Votes, 97-1, To Give Israel Arms Worth $700 Million
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/23/world.print_headline: MIDEAST TENSIONS; Senate Votes, 97-1, To Give Israel Arms Worth $700 Million
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/23/world.body_text: **********The Senate voted today to give Israel at least $700 million worth of American weapons, despite a complaint by one senator that the United States was becoming "a bottomless pit" of aid for its chief Middle East ally. **********The assistance was added to a $15.5 billion foreign aid bill for the new fiscal year that already includes $3 billion in cash for Israel and several other non-cash benefits worth hundreds of millions more. Israel is the largest recipient of American foreign aid, followed by Egypt and Turkey. **********The lawmakers voted 97 to 1 to endorse an amendment by Senators Daniel K. Inouye, Democrat of Hawaii, and Bob Kasten, Republican of Wisconsin, who argued that the help was needed to counter the threat of attack by Iraq. **********"The best interest of this country is served by assuring the viability of Israel," Mr. Inouye said, citing that country's sharing of Middle East intelligence with the United States. "It is the best ally we have." **********Mr. Kasten said that maintaining the Israeli military at a high state of alert during the Persian Gulf crisis already has cost as much as $1 billion extra. **********But the chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, the only senator to oppose the aid, countered that "the United States is not a bottomless pit of aid money." **********"No one can say this amendment should be passed because we have not done enough for Israel," Mr. Byrd argued, saying that Israel's supporters have included hundreds of millions of dollars worth of additional new benefits in a Pentagon spending bill. **********"No other country has gotten anywhere near this range of initiatives from the United States," he added. "Why $700 million more, at a time when our own Government is strapped for funds?"

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/12/world.main_headline: A FATIGUE MANDELA REST, THEN HEADS FOR SWEDEN
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/12/world.print_headline: A FATIGUE MANDELA REST, THEN HEADS FOR SWEDEN
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/12/world.body_text: **********Nelson Mandela ended a two-week, four-country African tour today and headed for Sweden despite suggestions that he might cancel his trip because of fatigue and mounting violence in South Africa. **********At a news conference on the veranda of the State House here, Mr. Mandela ascribed the violence in the nominally independent black homelands of Ciskei and Bophuthatswana to long-held black opposition to the existence of the homelands. He added that African National Congress officials in South Africa could deal with the crisis without his presence. **********''We have the leadership in the country,'' he said. ''They can handle any such situation. When I return I will contribute my own humble bit.'' **********Told to Slow Down **********Mr. Mandela appeared relaxed after canceling a speech Saturday night and a meeting today so that he could rest. After a punishing two-week schedule, the 71-year-old Mr. Mandela has admitted to feeling tired in the last several days and was advised by a doctor traveling with him to slow down. **********This is Mr. Mandela's first foreign tour since being released last month after 27 years of imprisonment. Since his release, there has been an increase in political violence across South Africa, resulting in hundreds of deaths. **********Mr. Mandela said the unrest was a continuation of South Africa's long experience with violence as a result of apartheid. ''Since the National Party took power there have always been disturbances,'' he said. **********Asked about a reported remark by President F. W. de Klerk that the violence could derail planned negotiations between the National Party and anti-apartheid forces, Mr. Mandela said: ''I've always regarded him as a man of integrity. If he makes that statement, there will be grave doubts as to his honesty.'' **********Attends Four Rallies **********Mr. Mandela attended four public rallies in different parts of Tanzania, including one on the island of Zanzibar. **********But the primary purpose of his visit was to meet with members of the African National Congress, many of whom have been in exile here for more than a decade. Mr. Mandela met with members of the congress's military wing, Spear of the Nation, who came to Tanzania last year after leaving Angola as part of the settlement for Namibian independence. In Sweden, Mr. Mandela is to meet the ailing president of the congress, Oliver Tambo. **********Mr. Mandela visited the military wing at a site about 20 miles outside the town of Iringa. He also visited an educational complex at Mazimbu, where more than 2,000 congress members attend school and work as administrators and teachers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/11/world.main_headline: U.N., Bowing to Soviets, Halts Its Baltic Contacts
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/11/world.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;   U.N., Bowing to Soviets, Halts Its Baltic Contacts
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/11/world.body_text: **********Bowing to Soviet pressure, the United Nations Secretariat has agreed to suspend the informal contacts it has conducted for several months with Baltic nationalist groups seeking independence from Moscow, a senior official has announced. **********The United Nations decision comes on the eve of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's visit to Lithuania, which was annexed by Stalin in 1940 along with Estonia and Latvia. The goal of Mr. Gorbachev's trip is to investigate the reasons for the Lithuanian Communist Party's decision to secede from the Soviet Communist Party. **********The Secretariat's decision to stop meeting with Baltic nationalists when they visit New York was discussed by Assistant Secretary General James O. C. Jonah in an interview with The Toronto Globe and Mail earlier this week and confirmed by other officials today. **********In the interview, Mr. Jonah, who had been a central figure in the Baltic talks, said the Soviet Union was angered when The New York Times published an article about the contacts in December. ''The Soviets were very angry,'' he was quoted as saying. ''Now we won't talk with any of them.'' Mr. Jonah is traveling and could not be reached for comment. **********Calls It Embarrassing **********In the interview, he accused Baltic nationalist leaders of exploiting their contacts with the United Nations and said ''they really embarrassed the Secretary General.'' **********The contacts were never publicly announced by any official of the United Nations. **********The United Nations decision to end the contacts with the Baltic nationalists provoked an angry reaction from Americans of Baltic extraction, who accused the organization of failing to defend the ideals of freedom and self-determination in its Charter. **********''This is a shocking submission to Soviet pressure, which diminishes the effectiveness of the United Nations,'' said Margers Pinnis of the Baltic Appeal to the United Nations, one organization seeking United Nations help in winning self-determination for Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia. **********Ojars E. Kalnins, spokesman for the Latvian American Association, called the United Nations decision ''outrageous,'' saying it ''follows a pattern of craven surrender to the Soviets.'' **********Ginte Damusis of the Lithuanian Information Center said ''it is scandalous to see United Nations officials running scared of Moscow.'' **********Contacts Are Ended **********Americans of Baltic extraction say the contacts were with the Office of Research and the Collection of Information, a division of the Secretariat headed by Mr. Jonah that briefs Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar on world trouble spots where he might be asked to mediate. Officials of that division confirmed today that the contacts had ended, as Mr. Jonah said in the interview. **********''Mr. Jonah's position is illogical,'' Mr. Pinnis said. ''His office should keep up with events in the Baltic region because all the nationalist movements say the United Nations may have a role to play in securing a peaceful transition to independence.'' **********The Soviet Union, which opposes independence for the Baltic republics while admitting that their incorporation in 1940 was illegal, apparently considers that such contacts not only encourage the nationalist movements but also constitute interferance in its internal affairs, officials say. **********Under its Charter, the United Nations is barred from interfering in members' internal affairs, although the organization may be pushing the limits of that prohibition as it sets international standards in fields like human rights and environmental protection.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/17/busin.main_headline: S.& L. Failures Benefit Seller of Troubled Assets
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/17/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;   S.& L. Failures Benefit Seller of Troubled Assets
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/17/busin.body_text: **********The misfortune of the savings and loan industry has brought good fortune to Joseph E. Robert Jr. Mr. Robert is chairman of the J. E. Robert Companies, an organization that was in the right place at the right time when the Government needed to contract for managers to dispose of the assets of failed institutions. **********Robert Companies is scheduled to assume control today of the $2.4 billion in assets of the University Federal Savings Association in Houston. The contract from the Resolution Trust Corporation, to manage and dispose of the assets, is the largest awarded to date by the Government. **********The Robert organization, which is based in Alexandria, Va., will be paid about $21.8 million over three years to manage the properties that were owned by the association and $19.6 million to dispose of the properties over the same period. The fees will depend on the company's performance. **********Mr. Robert said his company acted like a giant loan collection department and as a manager of property that has already been foreclosed. ''The better we do at maximizing the recovery, the better off the taxpayers are,'' Mr. Robert said. **********Mr. Robert, 38, said he got into the real estate workout business ''by default'' when he was working for a Washington developer whose business failed in 1974. As the economy turned around most people got out of the workout business. ''The difference was, I stayed in it,'' he said. **********From 1974 to 1981 he concentrated on such projects as condominiums. In 1981 he formed his company and began to focus on troubled debt portfolios. **********In 1984 he won his first contract from the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation. ''The business has grown since with the rising tide of failures,'' Mr. Robert said. Today the company oversees $10 billion in assets and is adding 80 to 100 employees to a staff of about 170, he said. **********Mr. Robert grew up in the Washington area and attended three colleges without earning a degree, working in the real estate business at age 19 and going to school at nights, he said. ''I'm the only one around here without a degree,'' he added.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/21/world.body_text: **********Iran's Foreign Ministry said today that Iranian pilgrims would stay away from the annual Muslim pilgrimage to Mecca for the third successive year because of sharp differences with Saudi Arabia. Iran has boycotted the pilgrimage, called the haj, since 1987, when more than 400 people, mainly Shiite Iranians, were killed in clashes with security forces. The clashes came after some Iranians staged anti-Israeli and anti-Western demonstrations in defiance of a Saudi ban.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/15/world.main_headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Goods Reach Iraq Through Jordanian 'Back Door'
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/15/world.print_headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Goods Reach Iraq Through Jordanian 'Back Door'
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/15/world.body_text: **********A line of battered frighters unloaded and picked up cargo today at this Jordanian port, which serves as an outlet to the sea for Iraq. **********Eight days after the United Nations Security Council imposed broad trade sanctions against Iraq for its occupation of Kuwait, Jordan has yet to take action to enforce them and, at least for the moment, appears to be serving as a back door for goods flowing to its powerful neighbor. **********In a brief, formal exchange with reporters this afternoon, Awad Tell, the director general of the port, asserted that ''everything is operating normally in the Port of Aqaba.'' **********Mr. Tell said he was not authorized to go into detail on sanctions. As for how much of the cargo at the pier today was going to Iraq, he replied briskly, ''No comment.'' **********Seven Ships a Day **********Aqaba receives an annual average of seven ships a day, according to port officials, and seven were tied up today at the modern long wharf at the foot of a craggy range of mountains rising from the desert floor, within sight of Israel's Red Sea port, Eilat. Three other vessels swung at anchor near beaches crowded with European vacationers. **********But there are signs that the Security Council's sanctions and the actions of countries enforcing them are likely to slow Iraqi traffic through Jordan and may already be having an effect. **********Ahmed Issa Habaiba of the Iraqi-Jordanian Land Transport Company said a vessel he had been expecting was eight days overdue. Abdul Amro, an agent for another freight-handling concern, said he understood that five of his ships had been detained by Egyptian authorities in the Suez Canal. [According to Lloyds Shipping Intelligence, a ship-tracking unit of the Lloyds of London insurance market, ship arrivals at Aqaba have already fallen off sharply, with only 11 vessels docking there in the last week.]  Could Lose Millions Jordan is not flatly refusing to abide by the sanctions. But in contrast to most other countries, which acted immediately, it says it is studying how and when to put them into effect. **********Privately, the Government is straining every possibility to avoid joining the embargo as it confronts the prospect of inflicting harm on a neighbor with which it has good relations and depriving itself of millions of dollars in earnings from exports, tariffs and transportation charges. **********Iraq is Jordan's main trading partner. Jordanian economists estimate that 40 percent of Jordan's fruit and vegetables and light manufactured goods, as well as more than 20 percent of its phosphate and other minerals, go to Iraq. In turn, Iraq provides Jordan with 90 percent of its oil, much of it in lieu of payments on longstanding debts. Though they could offer no precise figures today, private cargo handlers and truckers said a high percentage of the cargo that passes through this port annually is destined for Iraq. **********''Jordan will suffer enormously when it applies sanctions,'' Crown Prince Hassan said in a television interview this week. **********The unemployment rate is already 16 percent in Jordan, and The Jordan Times predicted in an editorial this week that sanctions would ''break the back of the economy.'' **********One strategy being explored by Jordan is an appeal to the United Nations for compensation. **********A shipping agent who would not give his name said he usually loaded 20 to 25 trucks a day at the port, most of them bound for Iraq. ''I sent more than 20 out of here today,'' he said. **********Then he shot a look of defiance at a stranger and his voice dropped to a growl. ''No one is going to close this port,'' he said. ''The people here will not accept it. No one can close it.'' **********Shipping Decline Reported **********LONDON, Aug. 14 (Special to The New York Times) - Iraq is continuing to receive supplies through Aqaba, while the United Nations trade sanctions and the American-led naval force have shut down shipping to Kuwaiti and Iraqi seaports, shipping experts said today. **********But Lloyds Shipping Intelligence said only 11 ships had docked at Aqaba in the last week, while normally 15 or 16 arrive every day. A spokesman for the ship-tracking unit said shipping agents were reporting that business for Aqaba had virtually dried up. Many ships that had been on their way to Aqaba ''are diverting,'' he said, adding, ''the number of ships going into there is dropping drastically.'' **********John Prescott, a reporter for Lloyds List International, a newspaper that specializes in shipping, insurance, trade, energy and finance, said he had been told by people in the shipping industry that three vessels waiting to unload at Aqaba were carrying Iraqi-bound cargoes. **********The newspaper also said today that the Tanga, a ship owned by Jebsen, a company based in Bergen, Norway, was ''reportedly forced to continue discharging grain for Iraq at the weekend.'' The Tanga is a Liberian-flagged storage vessel that receives grain from ocean-going ships and then transfers it to trucks. **********In a telephone interview today from Bergen, Jan Pedersen, executive vice president of Jebsen, said today that the Tanga's master had tried to stop operations to comply with Norway's decision to abide by the United Nations sanctions. ''Then the master was threatened, I suppose by the Jordanian police,'' Mr. Pedersen said, and the ship continued operating today. **********Since Jordan's imports also largely come through Aqaba, some experts questioned whether the port had the capacity to handle the volume of cargo that is normally shipped to Kuwait and Iraq via other routes. ''It's a small port, and whether that will be sufficient to sustain Iraq remains to be seen,'' said John Landells, another shipping specialist at Lloyds List. **********But Marvin Zonis, Professor of international political economy at the University of Chicago's Graduate School of Business, said that in normal times Aqaba handled a significant amount of Iraq's foreign trade. He added that he believed Iraq could get enough cargo through Aqaba ''to significantly extend the life of this regime,'' referring to President Saddam Hussein's Government.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/10/world.main_headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   IRAQI VISITS IRAN, A FIRST SINCE WAR
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/10/world.print_headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   IRAQI VISITS IRAN, A FIRST SINCE WAR
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/10/world.body_text: **********It was not known whether Mr. Aziz would hold further talks before his departure, scheduled for Monday. **********First Contact in a Decade **********The visit, the first such contact since before the Iran-Iraq war began in 1980, has been viewed as an opportunity for the two nations to lay the groundwork for a meeting between President Saddam Hussein of Iraq and President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran. The two leaders are expected to meet on a peace treaty officially ending the hostilities between the two nations. **********The treaty initiative frees up hundreds of thousands of Iraqi soldiers along the 750-mile Iranian border who could presumably be used to confront American troops in Saudi Arabia. **********Talks on a formal treaty had been mired in dispute since a cease-fire ended the fighting between Iran and Iraq in 1988. After Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 prompted the United States and other countries to rush forces to the gulf region, however, President Hussein began withdrawing troops from Iranian territory and exchanging prisoners with Teheran. **********Mr. Aziz was expected to ask Iranian officials to allow the shipment of food and medicine to Iraq. A diplomat in Iran, speaking on the condition that his name not be used, said, ''The aid in food and medicines that Iran could provide could be of crucial important at this stage.'' **********Sanctions Limit Food Aid **********United Nations sanctions imposed on Iraq permit only humanitarian shipments of food and medicine.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/17/world.body_text: **********At least 18 Argentine tourists, including 4 children, died today when their bus overturned near the southern Brazilian city of Porto Alegre, radio reports said. The bus had left the town of Trenque Lauquen in Argentina on Sunday loaded with tourists bound for the coastal Brazilian town of Camboriu when it flipped on its side before dawn, the reports said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/26/busin.main_headline: Amid the Publishing Slump, Norton Thrives
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/26/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;   Amid the Publishing Slump, Norton Thrives
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/26/busin.body_text: **********At a time when many publishing houses are complaining about declining revenues and even losses, W. W. Norton & Company is not only profitable, but also independent. **********And unlike other houses, it has never conducted sweeping layoffs or bought other publishing concerns to strip them of their backlists before disbanding them. Indeed, Norton is the only major house owned entirely by its employees. **********''I think they're the best there is,'' said Roger W. Straus, president of Farrar, Straus & Giroux, another quality independent house. ''They're absolutely first rate.'' **********Two Best Sellers **********Two Norton books are riding high on the best-seller lists: ''Liar's Poker'' by Michael Lewis and ''The T-Factor Diet'' by Martin Katahn. Earlier this year it had three best sellers at the same time. But the fortunes of Norton, which has a rich backlist of about 2,500 titles, do not rise and fall on best sellers. **********''We're happy to have them, because they're good for the morale of our authors, editors and sales force,'' said Donald S. Lamm, Norton's chairman and president. ''But our aim is to publish good books as well as we can. We don't see this as a trendy publishing house. In fact, I always say you can tell a trend has passed when Norton publishes a book on the subject.'' **********Actually, Norton publishes many books on many subjects - about 250 titles a year, of which 30 percent are college textbooks. Mr. Lamm will not disclose revenues, but he said the college divison accounts for most profits. He also said the 67-year-old house has been profitable for the last 25 years, although for a couple of years profits were ''razor thin.'' **********'Very Open and Very Smart' **********''Norton has very little bureaucracy,'' said Thomas C. Wallace, a literary agent and former Norton editor. ''Don runs the company, but he consults with others and he listens.
