He's very open and very smart.'' **********Educated at Yale and Oxford, Mr. Lamm, 58 years old, is partial to what he calls ''undermanagement.'' While there is a weekly editorial meeting, Mr. Lamm said he could not remember ever having a vote on whether to acquire a book. ''We aim for a meeting of the minds,'' he said, ''but there's a strong predilection on my part to let an editor with a passion for a book go ahead with it.'' **********Moreover, there is no end-of-the-year tally of how much money an editor's books made or lost, now common in some houses. **********Norton editors calculate the size of advances on the basis of what the house alone can earn on a book - not from potential earnings from the sale of paperback or book-club rights. While that policy has kept the house from having to write off substantial unearned advances, it has also cost it an occasional name author. **********Norman Cousins, for example, wrote two best sellers for Norton, ''Anatomy of an Illness'' and ''The Healing Heart.'' But when Norton decided the asking price was too high for ''Head First,'' the house and the author reluctantly parted company. That book recently published by E. P. Dutton. **********Norton is best known in educational circles for books on economics and psychology, and for its anthologies and critical editions of literary classics. It also publishes an extensive list of music and science books. **********Its longtime slogan is ''Books That Live,'' and Norton has in fact published many such books, including ''The Feminine Mystique'' by Betty Friedan, ''The Revolt of the Masses'' by Jose Ortega y Gasset, ''The Greek Way'' by Edith Hamilton and ''Philosophy'' by Bertrand Russell. **********A Norton speciality is the ''crossover'' book, published for both general and academic markets. A leading crossover author is Stephen Jay Gould, the Harvard paleontologist who has written nine books for Norton. **********''Probably three-quarters of the books I personally edit have double markets,'' said Edwin Barber, the editorial director, who has edited textbooks for about one-half of his 33-year publishing career. **********Mr. Lamm, who has spent his entire 34-year professional career at Norton, was also an editor in the college department. **********Value of Continuity **********''The thing Norton has, and I think we have, is continuity,'' Mr. Straus said. ''Don Lamm and many other Norton people have been there for years, and they consider themselves part of a team.'' **********In 1973, when independent houses were considered fair game for takeovers, George P. Brockway - Mr. Lamm's predecessor as chairman -vowed that Norton ''has never been for sale and is not likely to be.'' Mr. Lamm has also spent many hours discouraging potential suitors. **********After five years, employes are eligible to buy stock that under a 38-year-old ''joint stockholders' agreement'' must be tendered back to the company by retiring employes. The stock is currently held by about two-thirds of the 160 employees on the New York payroll. The company says that arrangement is the best safeguard against a takeover.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/02/busin.body_text: **********Construction spending rose 1.8 percent in January, the biggest increase in more than a year, the Government said today. Analysts said the warmest January on record caused the improvement. **********The Commerce Department said residential, nonresidential and government construction spending totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $424 billion in January. The gain was the largest since a 2.3 percent advance in December 1988. **********The January increase came after a one-tenth of 1 percent decline in December. **********It was the warmest January since the Government began keeping track of temperatures 96 years ago, while December was the fourth coldest on record. **********''If you average January and December, you come up with a number more in line with what we saw in the previous four months,'' said David Berson, chief economist with the Federal National Mortgage Association. **********Mr. Berson said lower mortgage interest rates should produce a slight improvement in the months ahead. **********Spending on residential building was up 2.9 percent, to $195.8 billion at an annual rate, in January, largely because of a 2.4 percent gain in single-family homes. Multifamily spending was flat at $20.4 billion. Residential spending accounts for about 50 percent of the total. **********Nonresidential construction spending was up 5.9 percent, to an annual rate of $100.8 billion, lifted in part by a 15 percent gain in the industrial category. **********The often volatile government sector, however, declined 4.2 percent, to $490.9 billion, after rising 6.8 percent in December.

He was given until today to try to drum up support from opposition parties to form another administration. That entailed revising his economic package. **********Mr. Carlsson said he would present his new economic proposals at a news conference Friday. He did not say which opposition parties would be likely to support his reappointment, or which had agreed to back a revised economic package.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/03/busin.main_headline: G.M. Seeks Sharp Increases In Top Executives' Pensions
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/03/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   G.M. Seeks Sharp Increases In Top Executives' Pensions
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/03/busin.body_text: **********In a move aggravating its already strained relations with the United Automobile Workers, the General Motors Corporation is seeking to increase sharply the pensions of its retiring chairman, Roger B. Smith, and 3,350 executives. **********The plan would increase Mr. Smith's annual retirement payout to about $1.25 million, from the current $700,000. Last year, Mr. Smith's total compensation was about $2.5 million; about 43 percent was salary and the rest a bonus of cash and stock. **********Mr. Smith will retire this August after 41 years with G.M. **********Over all, the pension change, which was disclosed in the company's proxy statement, will cost the nation's largest auto maker an extra $41.6 million this year, the statement said. **********The new plan would apply a pension formula to the salaries and bonuses of top executives instead of just to the salaries, as is done now. **********G.M. is seeking shareholder approval of the proposal at its annual meeting on May 25. **********A spokesman said a survey carried out by the company with the assistance of compensation consultants indicated that General Motors' executives were in the bottom 21 percent in pension compensation among the companies surveyed. The proposed change would put them into the 39th percentile, he said. **********The pension plan change was proposed, a company spokesman said, to make G.M. pensions ''more competitive with other U.S. corporations that base their pensions on total compensation, not just salary.'' **********The auto workers' union assailed the proposed pension increase, promising that it would become an issue during the industrywide bargaining later this year. **********''G.M. is unable to find any justification for this outrageous move because there isn't any way to justify it,'' said Owen Bieber, the U.A.W. president. ''Everyone realizes G.M. is confronting numerous competitive issues, but we'd be surprised to learn that competitive pensions for over 3,000 extremely well-compensated executives is one of them.'' **********Mr. Bieber hinted that the union might demand improved pensions for G.M.'s blue-collar retirees as part of the U.A.W.'s bargaining strategy. **********The issue of more lavish pensions for G.M. executives is expected to strengthen the political hand of Stephen Yokich, a U.A.W. vice president in charge of relations with G.M. Mr. Yokich has been critical of some of his predecessor's efforts to make relations between G.M. management and rank-and-file less adversarial. **********Union Restrictions **********Last year Mr. Yokich suspended the union's participation in a newspaper published jointly with a G.M. manufacturing group and forbade union officials to fly on G.M. airplanes. **********In its proxy statement, G.M. said the pension proposal could be passed by directors and did not require shareholder approval.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/22/busin.main_headline: World Markets;   The Glut in Europe; a Stir in Japan
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/22/busin.print_headline: World Markets;   The Glut in Europe; a Stir in Japan
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/22/busin.body_text: **********In the first quarter of this year, country funds traded in the United States raised more than $2 billion to invest in stock markets outside the country - a record and almost four times the amount raised in any previous year. **********About $1.78 billion, or 87 percent, of the $2.03 billion is for funds investing in Europe, and of that, $810 billion was for three funds investing in West Germany and one in Austria. **********The figures for these closed-end mutual funds, which raised money from both Americans and foreigners, are another sign of the quick shift in capital toward Europe that followed the opening of Eastern Europe. This money flow has helped push the West German, Austrian, French and Norwegian markets to new highs and may now give a boost to Spain and Italy, where analysts are pointing their latest recommendations. **********Americans have joined wholeheartedly in this trend of buying abroad and show signs of finally breaking out of their long-term reluctance to buy anywhere but Wall Street. **********In 1989, investors from the United States increased their purchases of foreign stocks to a record $13.7 billion, according to the Securities Industry Association. This was three and a half times greater than the previous record in 1985, and the $13.7 billion was more than half of the $25 billion in total foreign stock purchases by Americans in the last 10 years. **********''All signs are pointing to the trend continuing,'' said David Strongin, the director of international finance at the S.I.A. **********Michael T. Porter, the country fund analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, said that in addition to the $2 billion boom in the first quarter, there is a long line of new country funds getting ready to raise more money for investment abroad. As many as 10 new funds have indicated that they want to raise about $828 million. **********But because of the first-quarter glut, he is not as sure these funds will do as well. By the time the third new Germany fund this year - the Emerging Germany Fund - began trading at the end of March, the market was overloaded. It fell to $11.625 on its first day and closed Friday at $10.375, below its initial offering price of $12 per share. **********The Japanese stock market found a little life last week. And there are signs that the end of the slump could be near, if not precisely at hand. **********Even with a sharp 750.74 decline on Monday, Tokyo finished the week up 662.52 points, or 2.13 percent, at 29,835.44, and some Tokyo brokers spoke of a positive mood. **********Analysts, who had advised getting out at the beginning of this year, are now saying it is time to get in again. More important, there is a feeling that the yen, whose decline was a major factor in the stock market's 28 percent plunge, may be stabilizing. **********Several pieces of data support this view. For one, the figures for the first 10 days of April show that Japanese inflation may be moderating. The report for all of April will be watched closely because it is the first month that does not include the one-time impact of the 3 percent consumption tax the Japanese Government imposed last year. **********The preliminary figures for the first ten days of April show overall inflation at 2.6 percent over the previous 12 months, compared with the 12-month increase of 3.9 percent through March. And price increases excluding imports (which have gone up sharply because of the declining yen) have fallen even more, to seven-tenths of 1 percent, from 2.5 percent in March. **********In addition, the March report for the Japanese trade surplus indicates that it may be beginning to grow again, another change that would support the yen. In fiscal year 1989, Japan's surplus with its trading partners fell to $47 billion, from $78 billion in 1988. **********A third factor is that the Bank of Japan has allowed interest rates to creep up slightly as the new fiscal year began in April while not moving its official discount rate again. **********Last week the yen-to-dollar exchange rate weakened to the key 160 level, but then bounced back to fall under 157. It ended the week at 157.45. **********Nicholas Sargen, director of international bond market research at Salomon Brothers, said these factors mean a sharper fall of the yen, to the 170 level, which had seemed possible, is now very unlikely. ''There is a more balanced sentiment in the market now,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/15/busin.main_headline: Philips Ouster Tied to Loose Management
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/15/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Philips Ouster Tied to Loose Management
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/15/busin.body_text: **********The forced resignation of Cornelis J. van der Klugt, the chairman of Philips N.V., announced today as expected, represents a dramatic fall from grace for a man regarded as one of the statesmen of European business and a highly visible supporter of the economic integration of Europe. **********But, according to analysts today, the executive was ousted from the chairmanship of Europe's largest electronics company for the basic management mistake of failing to keep close watch over its operations. **********The resignation of Mr. van der Klugt comes at the end of an unusual storm of protest that began on May 3, when the company said that its earnings on normal operations fell by 97.3 percent in the first quarter, a development that was a surprise not only to investors, but also to many senior Philips managers. **********In response, the usually patient investment community of the Netherlands demanded major changes at the company, not only because they were upset and surprised by the poor results but because they worried that Mr. van der Klugt did not have a firm grip over his company. **********At Philips's annual shareholders meeting on April 10, Mr. van der Klugt painted a rosy picture for 1990, saying earnings would be up over last year. **********''Investors feel that they were misled,'' said Dorian Foyil, an analyst with UBS Phillips & Drew Ltd. in London. ''I don't think he misled anyone on purpose. I don't think he was aware of what was happening inside the company.'' **********At a news conference today at its headquarters in Eindhoven, the Netherlands, Philips said Mr. van der Klugt would resign effective July 1 and would be replaced by Jan D. Timmer, the 57-year-old Dutchman who is often praised for revving up the company's consumer-electronics operations. **********Mr. Timmer, the director of the consumer-electronics division since 1987, had been designated to replace Mr. van der Klugt as chairman on July 1, 1991, when Mr. van der Klugt, 65, was scheduled to retire. The analysts say Mr. Timmer is a tougher executive and is likely to manage the company more tightly. **********The analysts said Mr. van der Klugt's downfall came because even as he implemented a long-term plan to cut costs and focus Philips's activities that had been widely praised, he failed to pay sufficient attention to the immediate trouble spots that drained company earnings. **********What is more, the analysts said, Mr. van der Klugt apparently did not get the information he needed to make accurate profit projections. One of the big surprises in the poor quarterly results was a $44 million loss taken for currency translations. The losses were caused partly by the decline of the dollar and yen. **********The analysts said it was unusual for a company as large and sophisticated as Philips not to have done more, through hedging or other means, to prevent such a large currency translation loss. **********The analysts said Mr. Timmer would have to speed up the restructuring program at the $31 billion-a-year electronics giant and would have to plug losses at Philips's most troubled areas, notably computers and integrated circuits. **********''Strategic vision hasn't been Philips's problem,'' said Bill Coleman, an analyst with James Capel & Company in London. ''But maybe that vision took their focus off of the short-term management of areas where they needed to get a quick grasp of the problems.'' **********On May 3, Philips said it had barely broken even on its operating earnings in the quarter, reporting a net income of $3.2 million, on revenues of $6.9 billion. **********Mr. Timmer will have to tie Philips more closely together and assert authority over its operations, the analysts say. ''To turn this thing around is going to take a heck of a lot of time,'' said Mr. Foyil of Phillips & Drew. **********Confidence Is Damaged **********At the news conference today, Wisse Dekker, the chairman of Philips's supervisory board, said: ''Confidence in Philips had been damaged. That's the worst thing that can happen to a company. Drastic measures are needed to restore confidence.'' **********Soon after taking the helm in 1986, Mr. van der Klugt announced a huge restructuring program that has reduced the work force by more than 20,000. The company has also spun off its heavy appliances division into a venture with the Whirlpool Corporation in the United States and has sold some of its military electronics business to Thomson-CSF S.A. of France. **********Many of the analysts say the computer division might be sold next. But as Philips weighs the computer division's long-term future, it has not taken the tough measures that concerns like Ing. C. Olivetti & Company S.p.A. and Nixdorf Comptuer A.G. have taken to control costs during a shakeout in Europe's computer industry. **********Mr. Timmer has shown far greater toughness that Mr. van der Klugt in closing plants and consolidating operations. **********Preserving European Jobs **********Mr. van der Klugt, who frequently talked about the importance of preserving jobs in Europe, has said that a factor making it hard to compete with the Japanese was that so many Philips plants were in high-cost European countries. **********To help turn around the company's consumer-electronics division, Mr. Timmer placed far more emphasis on marketing. Philips is an acknowledged technological leader - it invented the videocassette recorder and compact disk. But it has consistently fallen behind the Japanese in transforming its basic concepts into hot-selling consumer products. **********The analysts expect Mr. Timmer to continue cutting costs and emphasizing marketing strategies in the consumer electronics and lighting divisions. Philips is the world's No. 1 producer of lightbulbs and television picture tubes. **********But more radical measures are expected in ''non-core'' fields, like computers and medical systems, where many of the analysts say Philips's operations are too small to achieve the size needed to thrive.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/23/busin.main_headline: Chemical Said to Plan Job Cutbacks
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/23/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Chemical Said to Plan Job Cutbacks
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/23/busin.body_text: **********The Chemical Banking Corporation is planning to cut more than 300 jobs in its consumer banking business in an effort to improve profits by reducing expenses, according to Chemical employees, who asked not to be indentified. **********Most of the affected jobs are in the marketing, administration and operations offices at 277 Park Avenue and 52 Broadway in Manhattan. The employees have not yet been informed of the plan. **********Charles Salmans, a spokesman for the banking company, said yesterday that ''as a matter of policy, we do not discuss any prospective actions the bank might take regarding future employment levels.'' **********Some Reassignments **********The cost-cutting moves, which are intended to save at least $10 million, come soon after Chemical reported expenses in the fourth quarter that were higher than some analsyts expected. Some employees at the Park Avenue and Broadway offices would be reassigned to Chemical's 202 branches, in some cases as managers. Other employees would not be relocated. **********The first part of the cutback came in late December when 17 administrative jobs were eliminated by dividing the consumer banking unit into three geographic parts rather than four. **********According to data compiled by Salomon Brothers, Chemical is the third-largest bank in the New York area in terms of its share of checking account deposits, second in savings deposits and third in consumer loans. The banking company employs about 10,000 workers in its consumer banking business. **********Acquired New Jersey Bank **********In 1989, when non-interest expenses rose 11.4 percent, to $2.73 billion, the bank said the rise was entirely due to costs involving its Chemcial New Jersey unit and real estate owned by its Texas Commerce Bancshares subsidiary. **********But some bank analysts also pointed to the rise in other expenses, which do not include salaries, benefits, occupancy costs or equipment, as an area of concern. Those expenses rose $42.4 million in the year, to $809.4 million, excluding a $90 million charge for real estate owned by Texas Commerce. **********Some of the rise in expenses, a Chemcial executive noted, resulted from the introduction of new consumer banking products at Chemical New Jersey, formerly the Horizon Bancorp. Chemical acquired the New Jersey company, and its 168 branches, early last year, for $659 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/01/busin.main_headline: New United Air Executive Plans to Build Brand Loyalty
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/01/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; New United Air Executive Plans to Build Brand Loyalty
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/01/busin.body_text: **********UNITED AIR LINES, America's largest carrier, has big ambitions. So does Adam M. Aron, its new senior vice president for marketing, who starts work on Monday when he leaves his current earthbound employer, Hyatt Hotels. **********Mr. Aron says he wants to spend more advertising dollars to build brand loyalty to United, which he says will be especially important as a recession looms and the price of jet fuel soars. And he hopes, competitors willing, to escape the industry's destructive round of fare discounting. "For every person who wants a cheaper airplane ride," he said in an interview, "there is another person who wants a better airplane ride." **********He would also like to see less emphasis on destination in United's marketing. "My message would no longer be, 'We fly the Pacific,' but, 'Here's how we fly the Pacific.' " **********Mr. Aron has his job cut out for him. With United's recent deal to buy Pan Am's routes to London, which is subject to British regulatory approval, United must cast itself as more of an international airline and must learn to sell itself to Europeans. **********For clues to Mr. Aron's brand-building approach, one needs look only at his successful "The Hyatt Touch" marketing campaign, which emphasized Hyatt's facilities, room service and frequent-guest program, modeled after the airlines' frequent-flier programs. **********But the Hyatt television commercials are also frankly sensual. As the Platters sing a version of their hit "The Magic Touch," the camera pans past fluttering curtains, bedsheets in artful disarray and enough lithe limbs to outrage retired hotel detectives everywhere. Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, in Boston, handles the Hyatt account. **********The UAL Corporation, United's parent company, is not feeling quite that frisky, but it is getting there. UAL spent an estimated $127 million last year on print and broadcast advertising. But its marketing has been pretty much in a holding pattern because of the three-year battle over who will own the carrier. The airlines' unions had sought to it, as did other parties. The unions' latest bid collapsed last month. **********Mr. Aron said he admired United's current campaign, devised by Leo Burnett USA of Chicago, and planned no changes in the agency or its longtime slogan, "Fly the Friendly Skies of United." Burnett's commercials are lushly colored, briskly edited montages of airplanes and foreign ports of call, with the booming strains in the background of George Gershwin's "Rhapsody in Blue." **********With the ownership question apparently resolved, UAL's chairman, Stephen M. Wolf, has taken firm control of United. He is buying a record number of new planes and also wants a new marketing approach. That effort will be led by Mr. Aron, a Wolf protege from 1982 when Mr. Wolf was senior vice president for marketing at Pan American World Airways and Mr. Aron was liaison to Pan Am's travel agencies. **********At 36 years old, Mr. Aron has a Harvard M.B.A. and is a marketing veteran from Western Air Lines as well as Pan Am. When Mr. Aron was with Western in 1985, the California carrier emphasized such amenities as steak, shrimp and champagne on its $59 flight from Los Angeles to Seattle. **********Mr. Aron also revived Western's venerable slogan, "Western Air Lines -- the Only Way to Fly." He said the slogan helped a great deal in a brutal competitive battle in California, which nonetheless resulted in Western being acquired by Delta Air Lines. **********"There was a lot of equity in that Western slogan and there is a very big lesson for United Airlines in that," Mr. Aron said. "Way too many marketers underestimate the brand loyalty of airline customers." **********Mr. Aron sees many similarities between airlines and his most recent employer, the hotel business. Both are similarly seasonal, have similar business and leisure customers, and, most of all, have similar kinds of "perishable inventory." **********"An unsold hotel room is like an empty airline seat," he said. "Once the sun sets or the airplane door closes, you're not going to make any money from it."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/26/world.main_headline: Coup Leader in Suriname Promises to Yield Power Within 100 Days
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/26/world.print_headline: Coup Leader in Suriname Promises to Yield Power Within 100 Days
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/26/world.body_text: **********The Suriname Army chief who staged a bloodless coup on Monday night pledged today to give up power to an elected government within 100 days. **********"The army is not bent on having and keeping power," Comdr. Ivan Graanoogst said on the state radio, a day after he and other officers overthrew the elected Government of President Ramsewak Shankar, who has been in office two years. **********A high-ranking Government official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the military carried out the coup without firing a shot in this jungled land of 400,000 people. **********Normal holiday activity resumed in the capital, Paramaribo, today. Churches were heavily attended for Christmas services, and there was no unusual military presence. Phone Service Restored **********International telephone service, cut Monday evening, was restored this afternoon. **********Commander Graanoogst said that Paramaribo's international airport and two smaller airports remained open and that there would be no curfew because "there is no danger whatsoever." He said everything is "quiet and normal." **********Mr. Shankar, reached by telephone at his house, said he and his Cabinet members were not hurt and were free to come and go. **********The President said he would meet with his Cabinet later in the day to decide on his next move, and would make a statement to the nation if allowed to do so. During Christmas Mass **********The coup occurred at 11 P.M. on Monday, while many Surinamese were attending Christmas Mass. The President and his Cabinet were holding a meeting at the palace to discuss an escalating dispute between Mr. Shankar and the army chief, Desi Bouterse, who had resigned earlier in the day. **********The high-ranking Government official said the military notified the President that it was assuming control and asked him and his Cabinet to leave the presidential palace. They decided to do so to avoid bloodshed, the source said. **********Later Monday night, Commander Graanoogst appeared in uniform on state television to announce that the military had taken control. **********Because of Mr. Bouterse's resignation on Monday, Commander Graanoogst, head of the nation's military police and one of four military commanders, acted as nominal head of the new military Government. But Mr. Bouterse, the dictator of the former Dutch colony from 1980 to 1988 and the army commander since, was believed to be the real mastermind of the coup. **********The United States and Dutch Governments today denounced the military takeover. A State Department spokeswoman, Sondra McCarty, said: "We condemn this violation of constitutional order in Suriname. We call on the Surinamese military to restore power immediately to the democratically elected authorities of that country." She added that it did not appear that American citizens were in danger. **********The Dutch Foreign Ministry said it "sharply condemns the undemocratic seizure of power by the Surinamese Army." **********Mr. Bouterse led a coup in 1980 that toppled an elected Government. He allowed the elections in November 1987 that were won by Mr. Shankar's Front for Democracy and Development. **********Relations between the two have been strained since Mr. Shankar began a five-year term on Jan. 25, 1988, and Mr. Bouterse continued to wield considerable influence as the country's military chief.

The agency also raised the Indiana utility company's secured pollution control revenue bonds to Baa-1, from Baa-2, and its unsecured pollution control revenue bonds to Baa-2, from Baa-3.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/12/busin.main_headline: Toyota Said to Plan Big U.S. Test Site
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/12/busin.print_headline: Toyota Said to Plan Big U.S. Test Site
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/12/busin.body_text: **********In a move reflecting its push for growth in the United States and other markets, the Toyota Motor Corporation will build the world's biggest automotive proving ground near Phoenix, auto industry executives say. **********These executives said Toyota would announce Monday that it was applying for local permits in Maricopa County, Ariz., for a 12,000-acre test area 47 miles northwest of Phoenix that will include a 10-mile test track and roads that simulate various driving terrains. **********Toyota also wants to build a 6,600-foot airstrip on the property so it can ship test vehicles to the track. **********A Proving Ground in the Desert **********An automotive executive said the cost of the test track would be about $20 million. **********Construction of the track and test facilities is expected to begin in 1991 and take two years to complete. The test track will eventually employ about 150 workers, the auto industry officials said. **********The proving ground, which would join several in the southwestern United States established by auto makers for testing vehicles in a desert climate, will serve as a testing area for Toyota car and truck models intended for the United States, European and Japanese markets. **********Toyota operates a large test track in Shibetsu, Japan. **********In recent years, Toyota, which has more than 35 percent of the Japanese automotive market, has said it is trying to capture 10 percent of the world automotive market. **********To reach that goal, Toyota would need substantially higher sales in this country, as well as in Europe, where its presence is embryonic. **********Three Main Markets **********To increase sales in the United States, where the company has about 7.3 percent of the market, Toyota is building an independent American auto-making company with design, engineering and manufacturing responsibilities. This strategy is typified by the opening last year of an assembly plant in Georgetown, Ky. **********A company spokesman said recently that Toyota wanted to be able to create distinct vehicle models for its three main markets - North America, Japan and Europe - as well as models that are similar and use the same name but vary according to local tastes and product requirements. The recently introduced Previa van was designed in California, is built in Japan and will be sold on all three continents. **********The most conservative of Japan's auto makers, Toyota lags slightly behind the Nissan Motor Corporation and the Honda Motor Company in establishing a full-fledged United States auto-making entity. Toyota started operations in the United States 30 years ago, primarily as an importer of Japanese-made vehicles. By contrast, Honda and Nissan have been building cars in the United States for some time. But Toyota has gradually developed the ability to produce original cars and trucks tailored to American tastes and needs. **********A year ago, the company announced plans to invest $144 million to expand research and development in the United States over several years, including new laboratories in Ann Arbor, Mich., and Torrance, Calif., and enlargement of its design studio in Newport Beach, Calif. **********Toyota's Global Plan **********The company has a fairly strong presence in some European markets, including Sweden, that have few restrictions on imports, but almost nothing in such large markets as France and Italy, where the local industry is protected. Its overall position is weak in Europe. After 1992, when the European Community plans to drop all internal barriers to trade, Toyota hopes to expand its share of the market through production at an assembly plant in South Derbyshire, England, and an engine plant in Clwyd, in North Wales. The company has also opened a European design studio in Brussels. **********The General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company, the Chrysler Corporation and Nissan operate test tracks in Arizona. Honda has a track in the Mojave Desert in California.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/16/busin.main_headline: The 1st Amendment Is Safe at Prodigy
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/16/busin.print_headline: FORUM>; The 1st Amendment Is Safe at Prodigy
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/16/busin.body_text: **********"I'm thinking of killing myself. Which is less painful: hanging or slashing my wrists?" **********"My neighbor, William, embezzled $10,000 from his company and is still stealing to this day." **********"Little girls in tight jeans and T-shirts are a real turn-on to guys like me. Write to me at P.O. Box. . . ." **********"Here's how to avoid paying for HBO: Climb the telephone pole outside your house and. . . ." **********These are examples (fortunately not typical) of electronic submissions to the Prodigy Services Company for publication on Prodigy, an information service sent through telephone lines for display on home computers. The company, using its editorial discretion, chose not to publish these submissions and other similar material. **********Yet some authors have made the bizarre suggestion that Prodigy is required to publish whatever is submitted and that failure to do so is censorship in violation of their Constitutional rights of free speech. Prominent newspapers, including The New York Times, have taken the bait, suggesting that a new area of First Amendment law is emerging. They should know better. **********The First Amendment protects private publishers, like The New York Times and Prodigy, from Government interference in what we publish. The Constitution bestows no rights on readers to have their views published in someone else's private medium. What the Constitution does give readers is the right to become publishers themselves. **********The issue here is not the law -- that was decided 200 years ago. Nor is it public access -- Prodigy is not a common carrier. The real issue is freedom of choice. If consumers want to read uninhibited, titillating conversation, they can find it on hundreds of wide-open electronic bulletin boards. But if some of them want to subscribe to a family service, confident that what appears on their screen is appropriate for any family member, should they not have that option too? **********Is the home computer screen conceptually different from the home television screen? If the Disney Channel chooses to exclude certain types of raw movies, does that make them guilty of censorship? For my chidren's sake, I hope not. **********One of the blessings of our society is its diversity, letting citizens choose anything from Disney to X-rated movies, from Prodigy to "adult" computer bulletin boards. If that makes Prodigy "the Disney of on-line companies," that's fine with us. **********We make no apology for pursuing a value system that reflects the culture of the millions of American families we aspire to serve. Certainly no responsible newspaper does less when it chooses the type of advertising it publishes, the letters it prints, the degree of nudity and unsupported gossip its editors tolerate. **********In discussing this matter, some people confuse private messages with public editorial features published by Prodigy. Private messages sent between Prodigy members through our network are just that, strictly private. The content is a personal matter between sender and receiver, who are the only ones to see it. So the question of censorship does not apply. **********But separately, Prodigy -- like a large newspaper -- publishes hundreds of daily editorial features. A few of these features are topical forums, on such subjects as travel, personal finance and the arts, that include material selected from what our readers submit for public posting. It is the publisher's responsibility to control that selection. **********That control is what any newspaper does. It is called editorial discretion and it does not limit speech in any Constitutional sense. It does expand choices by creating an alternative family service. And the vast majority of our 700,000 members agree with us. If a few of them don't, they have a plethora of other services from which to choose. That does not weaken our resolve to act responsibly. **********Social responsibility was the basis of our decision against publishing this bit of advice from a young reader to fellow teenagers: "You can't get pregnant if you don't have an orgasm." We don't believe that our decision not to publish that raises a Constitutional issue.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/19/busin.main_headline: Business and the Law;   Brokerage Case Goes On and On
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/19/busin.print_headline: Business and the Law;   Brokerage Case Goes On and On
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/19/busin.body_text: **********Three years ago the Supreme Court was swayed by arguments of the securities industry that arbitration is swift, relatively inexpensive and fair. In their ruling in Shearson/American Express Inc. v. McMahon, the Justices locked the doors of Federal courthouses to most customers who contend that they were defrauded by stockbrokers. **********The case that set the precedent is now entering its seventh year. The couple who brought the action are still pursuing their claim that they were defrauded of $560,000 through ''churning'' - excessive buying and selling to create commissions. The dispute has cost both sides hundreds of thousands of dollars. **********In one of several decisions in the McMahon case, a Federal appeals court said last week that the tactics of Shearson ''unreasonably and vexatiously multiplied'' the proceedings. **********The case seems to have fulfilled the prophecy of Justice Harry A. Blackmun, who predicted in his 1987 dissent that the Supreme Court ruling would have the opposite effect of its intentions, actually leading to more litigation over satellite issues. **********In its landmark decision, the Supreme Court reversed course on 24 years of rulings. Previously, securities fraud disputes, even those in which the parties had signed agreements favoring arbitration, had been accepted by the courts. But in the McMahon case, the Justices approved standard form agreements signed by customers and brokers that have clauses, usually in fine print, relegating all such disputes to arbitration. **********The McMahons had argued that they should be allowed their day in court. Like other customers who challenged the securities industry, they said the arbitration panels, often made up of former securities executives, tend to award smaller damages and favor broker-defendants. But in the McMahon case, the Supreme Court ruling has done little to reduce legal bills or insure swift justice. **********''It's getting to be more and more like a court case,'' said Theodore G. Eppenstein, the McMahons' lawyer, who said the two sides are now fighting over what evidence can be obtained. **********The plodding pace has not been lost on Wilfred Feinberg, a Federal Appeals judge who was part of the panel from the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit that last week issued the ruling on a related aspect of the McMahon case. Told during arguments where the case stands, Judge Feinberg said, ''So much for a speedy and economical method of resolving the dispute.'' **********Jeffrey L. Friedman, a lawyer for Shearson, declined to comment on the appeals court's unusually critical language regarding his client. **********The McMahon proceeding has interested some members of Congress who are examining the arbitration process. Three weeks ago, the House Committee on Energy and Commerce asked the General Accounting Office to review how the industry conducts arbitration. **********The latest wrangling in the McMahon dispute has been over a move by Shearson to have Mr. Eppenstein penalized for one aspect of the case. **********Mr. Eppenstein said he had elected to file with the American Arbitration Association because he considered it fairer than the New York Stock Exchange, in which a person from the securities industry is included on each panel and the parties in the dispute can challenge the seating of only one member of the three-member panel. **********Despite a Federal District Court order saying the McMahons had the right to choose where to file, Shearson filed the arbitration with the Stock Exchange. Mr. Eppenstein then went to New York Supreme Court to stop Shearson's move, provoking Federal District Judge Lloyd F. MacMahon to impose a $1,000 fine on the lawyer. **********In a significant decision on Rule 11, the Federal Rule of Civil Procedure that has been increasingly used to penalize lawyers for filing frivolous motions, the appeals panel exonerated Mr. Eppenstein and criticized the brokerage house, saying it had drawn out the legal proceeding. **********Quoting Charles Dickens, Federal Appeals Judge Richard J. Cardamone said Rule 11 was motiviated by a fear that lawyers had been engaging in ''stages of an endless cause, tripping one another up on slippery precedents, groping knee-deep in technicalities, running their . . . heads against walls of words, and making a pretense of equity with serious faces, as players might.'' **********Despite Mr. Eppenstein's vindication on the Rule 11 issue, Shearson has had its way on the forum. The case is in arbitration at the New York Stock Exchange, although not even a pre-arbitration conference has been scheduled. **********Asked why the case wound up there, Mr. Eppenstein said that another move in the Federal courts would not be worthwhile for his clients. ''We decided that we didn't want to take that issue up to the Supreme Court,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/11/busin.body_text: **********THOUGH analysts may be impressed with how rapidly the Thermo Electron Corporation has been growing, George N. Hatsopoulos has a more ambitious perspective. Thermo Electron's founder and chief executive believes his 36-year-old company would be a $7 billion business, roughly 10 times its current size, if he had been running it in Japan instead of here in suburban Boston. **********Mr. Hatsopoulos envies the access Japanese executives enjoy to cheap capital for investment in new ventures. Not only are Japanese interest rates lower, but Japanese companies are able to raise money by selling their stock at prices that Americans would regard as wildly inflated. **********"A new venture here has to have twice the rate of return it would need in Japan to pay off," grumbled Mr. Hatsopoulos recently. **********If any executive in American industry has demonstrated how to brood constructively rather than cower in the face of such discrepancies, it is Mr. Hatsopoulos, a 63-year-old Greek immigrant who has fashioned Thermo Electron into an unusual mini-conglomerate of high-technology businesses. A sampling of the Thermo product family: small power plants that burn agricultural waste; trucks designed to incinerate petroleum-soaked soil; bomb detectors; more than 100 types of instruments to monitor environmental contamination; dressings for wounds, and gas-fired air conditioners. **********The common theme for most Thermo products is that they represent gambles on innovative technology to attack potentially huge markets in socially important areas, like the environment. Lately, the company has been bouncing from success to success while many of its more famous neighbors in the high-tech corridor surrounding Boston report slumping earnings. On Thursday, it reported that earnings in the quarter ended Sept. 29 rose 35 percent, to $9.5 million, while revenues jumped more than 27 percent, to $181 million. **********A mechanical engineer by training who taught thermodynamics courses at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology during the company's early years, Mr. Hatsopoulos began worrying about the cost of capital nearly a decade ago. Thermo Electron stumbled into an earnings downturn as recession gripped the country, but Mr. Hatsopoulos wanted to forge ahead with investments in a number of technologies he believed would become useful for dealing with the world's energy and environmental problems. And he wanted to do it without borrowing heavily. **********Mr. Hatsopoulos, who cultivates a wide circle of influential friends in government, industry and academia as part of his effort to anticipate business opportunities, delved so deeply into capital formation issues that he eventually became recognized as one of corporate America's leading experts on the subject. In 1982, he joined the board of the Federal Reserve Bank in Boston and served a two-year stint as its chairman that ended last year. **********"I learned some things from him, and I never had a quicker student," said Lawrence H. Summers, the Harvard economist, who was one of the first experts Mr. Hatsopoulos turned to for help. "Today, he's right at the research frontier in this field and in a better position than most academics to say where theory meshes with experience." **********THE research also led Mr. Hatsopoulos and his younger brother John, the company's chief financial officer, to gradually invent Thermo Electron's unique corporate structure. Starting in 1983, Thermo Electron has repeatedly set up pieces of the company as separate businesses and sold anywhere from 10 percent to 40 percent or so of their shares to institutional investors or the public at large. The goal was to give investors a chance to bet directly on the development of various pieces of Thermo Electron's broad technology base and to establish a clear market value for the strongest subsidiaries, which in turn raises the value of Thermo Electron shares. **********"Spinning off some of our best divisions gives investors a simple picture," said Mr. Hatsopoulos. **********It also allowed Thermo Electron to give managers stock options in their businesses, an incentive that is widely recognized as a heady stimulant for most executives. In addition, the option packages have helped Thermo Electron recruit and hang on to talented executives who wanted to run their own show. And dealing with outside shareholders helps groom potential successors for the top jobs in the company, according to Mr. Hatsopoulos, who says he hopes to stay at the company's helm another 10 years. **********About 850 of the company's 5,000 employees are in various option plans and 95 percent of all employees are shareholders, according to John Hatsopoulos. The company has to grow to make those investments attractive because George Hatsopoulos is dead set against paying dividends. **********Thermo Electron's spinoff strategy is by no means unique. Waste Management Inc., for example, won applause on Wall Street for selling 20 percent of its hazardous waste handling subsidiary, Chemical Waste Management Inc., to the public. But no company has taken the strategy as far as Thermo Electron. **********THERMO ELECTRON's publicly traded subsidiaries currently include: Thermo Instrument Systems Inc., a leading supplier of environmental monitoring equipment, as well as engineering and testing services; Thermo Process Systems Inc., which makes high-temperature metal treatment equipment and waste incinerators; Tecogen Inc., which makes gas-fired equipment ranging from experimental auto engines to energy-saving air conditioners marketed by the Carrier Corporation and small-scale cogeneration systems that simultaneously generate electricity and steam heat, and Thermedics Inc., which makes a number of medical products and has been a pioneer in the development of supersensitive devices to detect explosives and drugs. **********Through Thermedics, Thermo Electron also controls Thermo Cardiosystems Inc., which makes implantable pumps that keep damaged hearts beating regularly until patients can receive transplants, and Universal Voltronics Inc., which makes equipment to convert electricity supplied by utilities to currents and voltages used in industrial and military tasks with unusual power needs. **********The next Thermo "pup," as analysts call the spinoffs, is likely to be Thermo Energy Systems Inc., which makes other cogeneration equipment, waste heat recovery systems and power plants fueled by alternate energy sources like agricultural wastes. Thermo Electron sold a 10 percent stake in Thermo Energy to institutional investors in Europe last summer for $8.5 million and hopes to have a public offering next spring. **********The private placement reflected the strong following the company has built up overseas as part of its effort to court longterm investors. Well over 80 percent of the debt of Thermo and its spinoffs is potential equity, in the form of debentures that are convertible into stock in the parent company or the various spinoffs, and more than half the convertible debt has been placed in Europe. Foreign investors now hold 35 percent of the parent company's shares, according to John Hatsopoulos. **********The Thermo spinoffs account for more than two-thirds of the company's sales. The most obvious drawback of the strategy is that accounting costs and other administrative expenses are relatively high, reflecting the extra filings required by the Securities and Exchange Commission and multiple annual reports. Each company has its own board of directors, but making sure that all dealings between the subsidiaries are fair to each company's shareholders is no mean feat. **********"We don't make one move without the blessing of the legal department," said John Hatsopoulos. **********The strategy also results in frequent profits from stock sales that make earnings look stronger than the actual results from the operating companies. At times, some analysts believe, investors have bid the price of the company up higher than its operating achievements warrant. **********"But Thermo has a relatively low degree of risk for a high-tech company," said Otis Bradley, who follows the company and its offspring for H. C. Wainwright & Company, a Boston brokerage. "They have always had a fetish about maintaining a strong balance sheet. And they seem to get a strong market position in almost everything they do." **********THE spinoff strategy has led some observers to describe Thermo Electron itself as a venture capital holding company, a research and development firm, or, in the word's of one analyst, a "perpetual idea machine." Such views square with Mr. Hatsopoulos's track record of pursuing many intriguing-sounding concepts in the belief that a few will become commercially successful enough to compensate for the disappointments. **********Thermo Electron existed in its early years entirely on research contracts from government agencies and industry groups like the Gas Research Institute. Last year, more than half of Thermo Electron's $45 million research budget was financed by outside sources. **********But Mr. Hatsopoulos's goal is to lead a multibillion-dollar company. With that in mind, the company sticks to projects where it can retain the right to commercialize the results. **********"We have been working 25 years on artificial heart projects that we expect to bear fruit in the next three years, but the $70 million that has been spent was N.I.H. money," said Mr. Hatsopoulos, referring to the Federally funded National Institutes of Health. "That's the advantage of working on socially important technologies."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/14/busin.body_text: **********A Brazilian judge has freed the stock speculator Naji Robert Nahas, who was placed under house arrest after causing a crisis in Brazil's stock exchanges last year, officials said today. **********Federal Judge Augusto Guilherme Diefenthaeler, who ordered Mr. Nahas arrested last July, released him on Friday night while an inquiry into his stock dealings continued. **********Mr. Nahas had been confined to his apartment in Sao Paulo for seven months. **********Mr. Nahas, 43 years old, who was born in Lebanon, said he would return to work as the head of his own firm but would not deal with the Brazilian stock markets. **********Mr. Nahas still faces charges of fraud and crimes against the economy. The judge ordered his release, saying more information is needed and this could prolong the investigation past legal time limits under which an arrested defendent must stand trial. **********Mr. Nahas rocked the nation's exchanges last year when he bounced checks worth the equivalent of $29 million. Eleven other people were involved in the scandal, which led to the resignation of the central bank president, but only Mr. Nahas was arrested. **********Brokerages lost up to $500 million when Mr. Nahas stopped payment on his checks, according to market estimates. The move forced authorities to close the stock and options markets last June 12, and the options markets remained closed until Nov. 1.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/15/world.print_headline: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;   ALL-GERMAN VOTE COULD COME IN '90
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/15/world.body_text: **********With uneasiness growing in both Germanys over the possible costs of reunification, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany indicated today for the first time that all-German elections could be held as early as Dec. 2. **********The Chancellor had previously projected such elections for the latter half of 1991, but with his remarks today he appeared to be responding to what he perceives as a desire among many Germans to end their uncertainty about the reunification process by putting it more rapidly behind them. **********Mr. Kohl's willingness to revise his agenda and consider early all-German elections came a day after his Christian Democratic Union suffered losses in two West German state elections, losses he attributed partly to public uncertainty about the cost of unity. **********Issue to Be Discussed Soon **********At a news conference today, the Chancellor said there were no plans at the moment to replace West Germany's Dec. 2 federal elections with all-German ones. But he added, ''Whether, in addition, it will be possible to combine elections in East Germany with that date will be a question for discussion in the very near future.'' **********The Chancellor would not comment specifically on when all-German elections would be held or how they would be organized given the postwar limits on West German sovereignty. **********Mr. Kohl's reaction to the public uncertainty over reunification, which he blamed for Sunday's electoral losses in North Rhine-Westphalia and Lower Saxony, seemed at first blush contradictory. But political analysts said his suggestion that the unity process might be stepped up was rooted in several factors, most notably the boost that the prospect of reunification has given to the Christian Democrats' political fortunes. **********While the Christian Democrats have lost 11 of 12 regional and national elections since the previous general election in January 1987, the margin of defeat has narrowed substantially since the Berlin wall was opened in November. **********The Christian Democrats also scored a major victory when their East German counterparts won East Germany's first free elections on March 18, emerging as the nation's strongest party. If all-German elections were held today, the Christian Democrats would be likely to win. **********Those gains are threatened, however, by the pan-German anxiety about the social and financial costs of unity and international developments, Bonn officials said. **********The opposition Social Democratic Party, which favors a slower approach to German unity, scored a narrow win in Lower Saxony and retained power in North Rhine-Westphalia, West Germany's most populous state. While political analysts said the results were a setback for the Christian Democrats, they were largely decided by local issues and cannot be seen as a referendum on Mr. Kohl's unity policy. **********Three Elements Seen **********A senior West German official said there were three main elements behind Mr. Kohl's hint today that unity could be expedited. **********''First there is uncertainty concerning the Soviet Union,'' he said. ''Gorbachev could come under even greater pressure through the economic situation and the nationalities struggle. That could result in slowing down the process of German unification or raising the stakes.'' **********The second factor is the financial cost. ''Every month that goes by without unification makes the whole thing even more expensive,'' he said, adding that East Germany ''has to fulfill its international economic obligations while the economic condition gets worse.'' **********Finally, the official said, Bonn fears that if the expectations of East Germans not rapidly met, they will begin pouring into the West again. **********Mr. Kohl may also be worried his appeal among West Germans will decline the longer the unification process takes, thereby reducing his chances to become the first leader of a unified Germany. **********'Two Plus Four' Talks Held **********But obstacles must be cleared away before all-German elections can be held, experts said. Foremost among them are the the so-called ''two plus four'' talks involving the two Germanys and the four World War II victors: Britain, France, the United States and the Soviet Union. **********Calling for early all-German elections would put more pressure on the talks, which began May 5. The negotiations center on the relationship of a united Germany with the Eastern and Western alliances, the presence of foreign troops in the two Germanys, and an end to the limits on sovereignty that the four powers have imposed on Germany. **********It is unclear whether the issues of the two-plus-four talks must be resolved before all-German elections are held, and whether the four victorious Allies would have a say in the timing of the elections. **********Those questions appear to worry Mr. Kohl less than pressing ahead with reunification. **********''Our course remains clear,'' Mr. Kohl said. ''Yes to the unity of Germany, yes to European unity.'' **********''Everyone who understands anything about international developments advises me: 'Act soon,' '' Mr. Kohl said. **********Meets East German Leader **********That appeared to be Mr. Kohl's main message when he traveled to West Berlin late today and met with the East German Prime Minister, Lothar de Maiziere, who is head of East Germany's Christian Democratic Union. **********After the talks, Mr. Kohl said the two had discussed details of the treaty to join the two Germanys economically. ''We have a very tight schedule,'' Mr. Kohl said. ''We have a lot to work on.'' **********A draft of the treaty merging the two nations' currencies and economies was worked out by East and West German negotiators over the weekend. Hans Klein, the Bonn Government spokesman, said today that the treaty should be formally approved by Bonn on Friday. The treaty then goes to the East and West German Parliaments for approval. Formal political union and all-German elections would follow, although the sequence of those two steps is uncertain.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/28/busin.main_headline: Creator of Companies Builds Profit by Region
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/28/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;   Creator of Companies Builds Profit by Region
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/28/busin.body_text: **********Ten years ago, Ian R. Wilson was a vice chairman of the Coca-Cola Company when, as he put it the other day, ''they chose the wrong guy as chairman, and I left.'' **********Instead of Mr. Wilson, Coca-Cola chose Roberto C. Goizueta as its leader. Mr. Goizueta is still there, and Mr. Wilson is now as a builder of companies for private investors. **********One of his deals came to the fore last week when he sold Wyndham Foods, a cookie company, to President Enterprises of Taiwan for $335 million. **********Wyndham is made up of eight cookie companies in the South, including the nation's largest baker of Girl Scout cookies. ''I hate the word synergy,'' Mr. Wilson said, ''but they are a lot stronger as one entity.'' **********In the same way that Mr. Wilson assembled the cookie companies, he most recently put together the Windmill Corporation, another food-products enterprise that is already larger than Wyndham. ''And maybe there will be a third company, in time, called Windfall,'' Mr. Wilson said. **********At Coca-Cola, Mr. Wilson ran the Pacific operations, and some reports at the time said a less-than-sparkling sales performance did not help his designs on the chairmanship. After he left, Mr. Wilson tried his hand at soft drinks with Wilson Bottling. ''Then I did a spell with Castle & Cooke as president and chief executive,'' he added. **********Mr. Wilson, who is 60, joined the big food and land company in San Francisco in 1983 and resigned his $450,000-a-year post the next year as losses and cash flow problems persisted. ''It was time to stop working with the big public corporations and start something on my own,'' he said. **********Doing that, Mr. Wilson said, ''is where the fun starts. My boast is that I can fit my headquarters staff in San Francisco into a can.'' In addition to himself, there is a chief financial officer and three office workers. **********Mr. Wilson, whose parents were Scottish, grew up in South Africa during World War II and graduated from the University of Natal. He took a job as an accountant with Price Waterhouse in Johannesburg, and soon became chief accountant for Coca-Cola there. He was moved to the United States in 1973. **********''It's a long way from chief accountant in Johannesburg to vice chairman in Atlanta,'' Mr. Wilson said, ''and I did everything in between.'' **********As a buyer of companies, Mr. Wilson said: ''I look for businesses that don't compete against the major, well-established companies and that have a long record of profit. I don't like turnaround situations. I like areas where there are lots of small regional companies. The cookie business met all these criteria.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/06/world.main_headline: Burmese Military Slow In Handing Over Power
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/06/world.print_headline: Burmese Military Slow In Handing Over Power
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/06/world.body_text: **********It took the military government of Myanmar, formerly Burma, over a month to count the votes in the stunning election of May 27, in which the main opposition party won more than 80 percent of the seats. **********But it may not be until September, Western diplomats say, that the military Government will allow the parliament eleated in May to actually meet. **********There have been many signs that the military was stunned by the repudiation it received when it finally allowed the Burmese a free and fair vote, their first chance to judge public afdairs since General Ne Win and the military took power in a 1962 coup. The military has run the country openly since crushing pro-democracy demmnstrations in September 1988. **********The main opposition party, the National League for Democracy, itself emerged from the 1988 demonstrations behind the charismatic leadership of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the daughter of the country's founder. The military put her under house arrest, incommunicado, nearly a year ago. **********Military Said to Be Split **********Faced with this overwhelming victory by the League, the military has been stalling, say diplomats here and in Yangon, formerly Rangoon. The diplomats suggest that the military is puzzled and divided, and at the very least wants to insure that its own interests and reputation are protected by any new civilian government. **********Even before the election, Gen. Saw Maung, the leader of the State Law and Order Restoration Council, the military junta that runs the country, said any transfer of power would occur only after the new parliament writes a new Constitution. **********Diplomats say they think the military expected a split result, with no party winning a two-thirds majority or even a simple majority, meaning a drawn-out negotiation over a new constitution. **********In official results finally announced on Saturday, a month and three days after the vote, the National League for Democracy won 396 of the 485 seats at stake, nearly 82 percent of the total. Since the League only contested 450 seats, it actually won 88 percent of the seats for which it ran. **********Defeat for Ruling Party **********Just 10 seats went to the military-backed National Unity Party, the direct inheritor of General Ne Win's Burma Socialist Program Party that for many years was the country's only party. **********The remainder were shared among various smaller parties opposed to the military or representing Myanmar's many ethnic minorities. Some minority parties themselves were affiliated with the League. **********In the immediate aftermath of the vote, when the size of its majority became clear, the League said it was ready to install a new constitution, based largely on the country's last democratic one, dating from 1947, within a matter of weeks. But nothing happened. **********Calls from the League's current leadership for talks with the military on a handover of power have been rebuffed. There has also been no response to the League's request for the release of political prisoners. Both Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi and the party's co-leader, U Tin Oo, are still under detention, along with most of its executive committee. Hundreds of other Burmese who took an open political stand against the military also remain in jail. **********'When the Time Is Right' **********Military spokesman simply say that they will meet with the League ''in due course,'' or ''when the time is right.'' **********Diplomats have read comments in the one official newspaper printed in Myanmar as suggesting that no national assembly meeting could be held until September, because the Electoral Commission first had to investigate charges of fraud. **********Today, the line from the military altered slightly, appearing to postpone matters further. In a statement by a military spokesman in Yangon, the army said all 27 parties winning seats should first hold meetings among themselves to discuss a new constitution. **********Meeting With Parties **********''Only after they have done so'' will the army ''meet and coordinate with them,'' the spokesman said. But there was no indication what might follow those meetings, or when the parliament will actually convene. **********Diplomats point to July 20 as an important date. Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi was put under house arrest a year ago on that date, with a year's sentence, renewable yearly. League officials hope the military will release her then. **********But Western diplomats are less optimistic. Some suggest she may simply be bundled secretly onto a plane, her Burmese passport revoked, and sent to rejoin her British husband. **********But if she is not released or deported, diplomats warn, popular demonstrations against the military could again break out, with violent consequences. The military killed at least 3,000 civilian demonstrators in 1988, diplomats say.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/24/world.main_headline: Upheaval in the East: The Germanys;   Bush to Press Kohl at Camp David On Easing Poland's Border Fears
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/24/world.print_headline: Upheaval in the East: The Germanys;   Bush to Press Kohl at Camp David On Easing Poland's Border Fears
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/24/world.body_text: **********When President Bush meets over the weekend with Chancellor Helmut Kohl, he will urge the West German leader to calm Polish concerns about the future of the Polish-German border, Administration officials said today. **********Mr. Kohl arrives on Saturday morning for two days of talks with Mr. Bush in the informal atmosphere of Camp David, the Presidential retreat near Thurmont, Md. **********Mr. Bush will ask Mr. Kohl to clarify his timetable for German unification and will urge him to address Polish concerns about the boundary between Poland and Germany, the Administration officials said. Poland has asked for guarantees that the current border, along the Oder and Neisse rivers, be made permanent and that a united Germany formally forswear any effort to reclaim part of prewar Germany that is under Polish control. **********Poland's apprehensions are rooted in history. Poland has often been a victim of German aggression. Germany invaded Poland in 1939, and the Nazis occupied Poland in World War II. **********So far Mr. Kohl has been ambiguous about the border. When traveling abroad, he says Germany has no intention of tampering with the boundaries established after World War II. But when he is in Germany, he says the issue can be decided only by the parliament of a united Germany. **********Mr. Kohl's vagueness is motivated in part by domestic politics. He does not want to lose the votes of strongly conservative Germans who might want to reassert territorial claims in western Poland. **********Mr. Bush and Mr. Kohl are also expected to discuss ways to keep a united Germany in NATO and defy heavy Soviet pressure to weaken German links with the Atlantic alliance. **********Mr. Kohl is expected to ask Mr. Bush to support a speed-up in the process of unification that would conceivably permit East Germans to vote in West Germany's December elections. **********The visiting German leader is expected to contend that only rapid unification can avert the economic and political collapse of East Germany and stem the flood tide of East Germans leaving for West Germany. **********Mr. Kohl's visit comes just three weeks before East Germans go to the polls to choose a new government. One of the chief functions of the new government will probably be negotiating the terms of union with West Germany. **********Food Subsidies Reduced **********In the last few weeks, East Germany's economic crisis has become more severe. Alarmed at the reduction in Government food subsidies, East Germans have rushed to buy flour, sugar and meat, and the East German Government has promised emergency measures to keep up basic food supplies. **********West German officials now say that East Germany might seek union as soon as possible after its March 18 elections. **********Robert Gerald Livingston, director of the American Institute for Contemporary German Studies at Johns Hopkins University, said that under the West German ''constitution'' - the Basic Law of May 23, 1949 - the constituent states of East Germany could vote to become part of West Germany. American officials say they believe that some of the East German states, or Lander, might do just that after the elections next month. **********American and West German officials said Mr. Kohl would probably discuss that possibility with Mr. Bush when they meet over the weekend. The West German Interior Minister, Wolfgang Schauble, apparently discussed it with American officials when he was in Washington this week to help prepare for Mr. Kohl's visit. **********'Reconstituting the Lander' **********A Western diplomat said tonight that Germans were ''thinking more and more'' about that provision of the Constitution, Article 23, as a vehicle for the swift unification of the Germanys. **********Mr. Kohl's plan for German unity, issued in December, made no reference to that article. But ''things are moving so fast in Germany'' that there is increasing interest in the constitutional procedure for incorporating East German states into West Germany. **********After the March 18 elections, Mr. Livingston said, ''the East German Parliament will probably pass a law reconstituting the Lander'' abolished in 1952. Then in May of this year, he said, the constituent states of East Germany will elect their own legislatures, which could adopt resolutions to merge with West Germany. **********Thus, it appears that Mr. Bush will get the clarification he seeks on Mr. Kohl's timetable for unifying Germany, and the Chancellor will make clear that he wants to achieve that goal sooner rather than later. Administration officials said that Mr. Bush believed it was in the long-term strategic interest of the United States for Germany to be unified and solidly anchored in the West. **********Mr. Bush is expected to use his meeting with Mr. Kohl to underline the importance of continued German membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Mr. Bush will probably urge Mr. Kohl to stand firm in support of that position as a way to reassure his neighbors in Western and Eastern Europe that they have nothing to fear from a unified Germany. **********Kohl's Vision of Unification **********In Canada on Feb. 13, East and West Germany and the four major World War II Allies agreed on a framework for negotiating German unification after 45 years of division. Under that formula, the ''two plus four'' concept, the two Germanys would discuss the economic, political and legal aspects of unification. Then the four Allies would meet with the two Germanys to discuss security issues like the size of the army for a unified state and its ties to NATO. **********'' 'Two plus four' is a misnomer,'' Mr. Livingston said. ''It will be one plus four. The Germans will come into those discussions with a united delegation. They'll come in under one flag.'' Administration officials said Mr. Kohl would discuss such questions when he lays out his vision of a unified Germany at Camp David this weekend. **********The White House press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, said Mr. Bush and Mr. Kohl would talk about ''the full range of issues related to changes in Eastern Europe,'' including the future of NATO and the Warsaw Pact. **********''We don't anticipate any new agreements or announcements,'' Mr. Fitzwater said. Rather, he said, the weekend provides ''an opportunity for the two leaders to discuss the status of events, where they think things are going.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/15/world.main_headline: A Car Bombing in Peru Damages Fujimori's Presidential Residence
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/15/world.print_headline: A Car Bombing in Peru Damages Fujimori's Presidential Residence
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/15/world.body_text: **********A car bomb exploded next to the government palace as Peru's new President, Alberto Fujimori, was meeting with advisers, injuring four passersby, the police said today. **********Other car bombs were set off in the highland cities of Cuzco and Ayacucho, killing one person. The attacks ended a lull in political violence since Mr. Fujimori took office on July 28. **********The car-bomb attack against the palace late Monday shattered windows in the residential section of the building. The blast also blew a three-foot-wide crater in the sidewalk and knocked chunks of concrete from the wall. **********The police blamed the pro-Cuban Tupac Amaru revolutionary movement in the attack. They said the car contained 22 pounds of dynamite. **********Cordons Set Up **********Soldiers and policemen sealed off the streets around the palace and the Plaza de Armas facing the building after the attack. **********One man died and at least 17 people were wounded in the blast in Cuzco, a tourist center in the Andes 350 miles southeast of Lima, the police said. **********The bomb exploded Monday in front of an army barracks, one block from a leading tourist hotel. No tourists were hurt in the explosion, though four soldiers were among the wounded, the police said. **********They added that the attack was probably carried out by the Shining Path rebel movement, another far-leftist group. **********The Shining Path exploded 22 pounds of dynamite before dawn Tuesday in a car in the center of Ayacucho, 230 miles southeast of Lima, the police said. **********No one was injured in the blast, which broke windows and damaged buildings. Two other bombs exploded in Ayacucho earlier today, the police added. **********Shining Path rebels also killed three village officials near Huaras, the police reported. Huaras, 175 miles north of Lima, is a popular destination of mountain climbers. **********The rebels staged a trial of the three men in the plaza of a small village and then killed them each with a shot to the head. **********More than 19,000 people have died in political violence in Peru the last 10 years.
