Your Own Account;

Taking Time Off for the Family
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/25/busin.print_headline:
Your Own Account;

Taking Time Off for the Family
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/25/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: Mary Loftus had spent six years working her way up and was prime-time news anchor at KSNT-TV in Topeka when she became pregnant. She arranged to take a six-week leave after her son, John, was born in June 1983. The day she got home from the hospital, the station manager and executive news director called to say they wanted to stop by. **********Mary Loftus had spent six years working her way up and was prime-time news anchor at KSNT-TV in Topeka when she became pregnant. She arranged to take a six-week leave after her son, John, was born in June 1983. The day she got home from the hospital, the station manager and executive news director called to say they wanted to stop by. **********''I thought they were going to bring a gift for the baby,'' says Ms. Loftus, 37 years old. ''Instead they fired me.'' Although she was able to get a job at a competing station, she started at the bottom again, for half her former pay. ''The economic loss was substantial,'' she said. ''And I took a giant step backward careerwise.'' After working her way up again, she is now prime-time anchor. **********Things haven't changed much since 1983. Ms. Loftus is one of thousands of women - and men - who have lost their jobs when compelling family or medical needs have forced them temporarily out of the workforce, said Donna Lenhoff, legal director of the Women's Legal Defense Fund. **********There are no Federal laws protecting an employee's job if he or she takes medical leave, and more than half the states have no laws on their books. In fact, the United States is one of only two industrialized countries - the other is South Africa - that fails to insure that a woman can return to her job after taking time off to have a child, said Sally F. Goldfarb, staff attorney for the National Organization for Women Legal Defense and Education Fund. **********What was once ''maternity leave'' now has two components, Ms. Goldfarb said. The first is disability leave, when a woman is physically unable to do her job. The second - ''parenting leave'' - allows a mother or father to take time off to care for a new baby. **********But a broader, newer category - family leave - has drawn attention in Congress and in statehouses nationwide. Efforts are afoot to pass legislation guaranteeing a minimum amount of unpaid ''family leave'' to men and women for the birth or adoption of a child, to care for an elderly parent or to attend to their own medical needs. The trend is toward laws guaranteeing a range of family and medical needs, Ms. Lenhoff said. **********Employees in states without laws are subject to the whims of their employers, Ms. Goldfarb said. For example, a 1978 amendment to Title VII of the Civil Rights Act requires that pregnancy be treated in the same way as any other disability, like a heart attack. The company sets policy: If it typically gives an employee six weeks off to recover from a heart attack, a woman who bears a child could insist on the same leave time. ''If an employer is stingy enough to give disability to nobody, then a worker would have no claim,'' Ms. Goldfarb said. **********Supporters of the family and medical leave laws argue that employees need a guarantee of far broader rights and the only way to get them is through Federal action. **********''American families need a minimum labor standard to protect jobs in times of compelling family need,'' Ms. Lenhoff says. ''Sometimes it is joyous and wonderful, as when a child is born. Sometimes it is horrible, as when a child dies or has a serious medical condition.'' Either way, she says, employees ''need a job to go back to.'' Family leave bills were approved by the House and Senate Labor Committees in 1989. They are expected to be debated on the floor soon. But they face opposition from business and from the Bush Administration. Elizabeth Dole, Secretary of Labor, has said that she will advise the President to veto the bill if it is passed by Congress. **********Employers worry that mandatory family and medical leave laws would hamper their ability to run their businesses, said Fred Rumack, director of tax and legal services at Buck Consultants in New York. And some employers are concerned that, although the bill specifies unpaid leave, ''It may someday require paid leave,'' he said. **********The Senate bill would require employers of 20 or more persons to provide 10 weeks of unpaid medical leave to care for a newborn, newly adopted or seriously ill child or parent and 13 weeks of unpaid medical leave for serious illness of the employee. **********The House version, which would apply to employers with 50 or more workers, would provide up to 10 weeks of unpaid leave and 15 weeks of temporary medical leave. Employers would also have to keep providing health care coverage during unpaid leave. **********This year, 14 states are considering family or medical leave legislation, Ms. Lenhoff said. Only eight - Connecticut, Maine, Minnesota, New Jersey, Oregon, Rhode Island, Washington and Wisconsin -have what she considers progressive family and medical leave protection for most employees. **********Although New York has no family leave law, it is one of a small number of states with temporary disability leave insurance, which allows employees to collect a maximum of $170 a week while on disability leave. And a group of business and labor leaders appointed by Gov. Mario Cuomo is studying ways to expand that system. **********Despite the opposition from business, Mr. Rumack believes Federal legislation will be passed. ''It will continue to be passed at the local level and maybe this year, maybe next, at the Federal level,'' he said. **********WHEN TO TAKE THE CASH **********Receiving a lump sum distribution from a qualified retirement plan presents a problem: Is it best to roll this money over into an Individual Retirement Account? **********Financial planners generally recommend an I.R.A. rollover. However, William H. Mears Jr., a partner at Ernst & Young, points out that you should consider two things before rolling the money over: How long you intend to leave it in an I.R.A. and whether tax rates might increase during that period. **********Many experts expect tax rates to go up in 1991. If they do, and if you are over the age of 59 1/2 and thus will not have to pay the l0 percent penalty for early withdrawal, you may be better off paying tax on the lump sum at the current, lower rates, Mr. Mears says, particularly if you will need the money within the next 10 years or so. **********You also may be eligible for a special tax treatment on the money such as 5-year or 10-year income averaging if you pay the tax up front. **********In fact, Mr. Mears suggests that taxpayers over 59 1/2 who will need their money within 10 years consider withdrawing money from an I.R.A. and paying taxes this year rather than facing higher rates later.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/11/busin.main_headline: Prices Encourage Search for Oil, but Labor Is Short
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/11/busin.print_headline: Prices Encourage Search for Oil, but Labor Is Short
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/11/busin.body_text: **********''We've been a very depressed industry,'' said John G. Nikkel, president of the Unit Corporation, a drilling and production company in Tulsa, Okla. ''Getting qualified, skilled people in the right spot, at the right time, is going to be a significant problem for us.'' **********Most of the major oil companies, as well as hundreds of independent producers, hold mineral rights to large proven reserves. But to tap those reserves, they turn to drilling companies that hire workers for 30 days at a time. After the collapse four years ago, many of these workers found jobs elsewhere, whether driving trucks or working in convenience stores, and many are not eager to return to the oilfields. **********The Houston-based Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, for example, had to delay a drilling program in Kansas because payroll cuts among drillers had reduced the number of specialists it needed for the deep wells it planned. **********Speaking of one drilling contractor Anadarko uses, Paul Taylor, a company spokesman, said: ''There used to be crews in every office that knew this technique. Now there are only two. So, you wait.'' **********Drillers in southeast Oklahoma's Arkoma Basin and in the Austin Chalk range of South Texas also turned down bids from major oil companies to sink new wells because they could not find enough rig workers. **********After 40 years in the oil business, James E. Russell, an independent driller in Abilene, Tex., who operates in Texas, Oklahoma and Kansas, is drilling with 15 rigs, down from 50 during the boom years and is cautious about expanding. **********'A Lot of Interviewing' **********''If we thought the price would stay up to $25 or more for an extended period, naturally we would work into it,'' he said. ''Most people think this could just be a spike in price, and then fall back down.'' **********Earl Ritchie, vice president of Maxus Energy's exploration unit for North America, said Maxus had been able to hire petroleum engineers and other oilfield brainpower, mostly by luring them from other companies. But he said it was becoming harder to find good job candidates. ''It takes a lot of interviewing now,'' Mr. Ritchie said. ''I don't think a lot of the people who have gotten out of the industry are going to come back.'' **********Given the nation's production and consumption figures, this points to a serious problem. The domestic oil industry's output fell to an average of 7.3 million barrels daily in the first seven months of this year, from an average of 9 million barrels a day in 1985. In the same seven months, the nation's consumers - chemical manufacturers, utilities, car drivers, homeowners and others - used an average of 17 million barrels a day. **********The shortfall was made up by imports, which averaged 8.5 million barrels a day in the period, and by a slight drawing down of existing crude stocks. But the Persian Gulf crisis has led many to fear that the country is depending on imports from an insecure source. Still, the industry feels there is too much uncertainty in that area to conclude that it is time to sink expensive new wells. #1,000 Operating Rigs If the industry believed oil prices would hold above $25 a barrel in the coming years, it would be worth putting hundreds of rigs into exploratory drilling, as well as stepping up output in producing fields. **********Analysts say that if drilling was expanded to 2,000 rigs, from the 1,000 now operating, the slide in output would be halted, and production of natural gas, which is far more plentiful, would be sharply raised. But acute personnel shortages are likely to delay drillers before the count reaches as far as 1,300. **********More than 200,000 rig workers and other oilfield service employees abandoned the drilling business in the last seven years, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Their total employment peaked at 434,500 in 1982 during the waning months of a 10-year boom during which the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries pushed oil prices higher than $39 a barrel from less than $4 in 1972. **********One producer in the aging fields of East Texas, T. D. Howell, kept all 18 of his rigs during the four lean years and kept an average of 12 of them active during that period. His drilling and production companies have increased the payroll to 418, from 250 in the early 1980's. He was able to do that because as a unusually conservative businessman, he had no debt to repay during the downturn. **********A School for Roughnecks **********''One of my fears is the potential pirating of our employees,'' he said. ''If we tried to kick off another couple of rigs now, I don't know where we would get the personnel. Our rig rate has to go up so we can pay more.'' **********One potential source of workers is a school for roughnecks that Texas A & M University reopened in July for the first time in four years at an extension center in Abilene. But its costs - $2,200 a person for room, board and instruction - kept enrollment down to a dozen men for its first two five-week sessions, despite hundreds of callers. **********''Most of the guys seeking to become rig hands don't have much savings,'' said Will McNair, the program director. ''We approached the oil industry for help and they said, 'We don't have the money, but we need the people.' '' **********In two dozen recent interviews, analysts, academics and executives of drilling companies and independent producers said the tight market for rig crews would sweep the entire oil and gas industry next year if drilling activity rose. **********That, in turn, would lead to higher the offer of higher wages to attract a new generation of workers, and would force drilling costs higher - perhaps pushing rig rates up to $7,000 a day from the present average of $5,000. **********Geologists as Consultants **********George S. Dotson, president of the international drilling unit of Helmerich & Payne Inc., in Tulsa, predicted that higher oil prices would cure recruitment worries. **********''If I had a 25 percent increase in wages across the board, we would be able to attract good people into the business,'' he said. ''They won't be as effective while we train, but we'll be able to man the rigs.'' **********There are also concerns about professionally educated specialists like petroleum engineers, geologists and geophysicists. **********Fred A. Dix, executive director of the American Association of Petroleum Geologists, based in Tulsa, said many geologists laid off in 1986 and 1987 have tried to get by financially as consultants to independent producers. Others took jobs with ground water companies or government agencies. **********''There is no shortage of professional geologists right now to handle an accelerated domestic drilling program,'' Mr. Dix said. ''The immediate supply is very good, but as older people move out of the profession, there aren't going to be enough younger ones to replace them.'' **********Need for a Policy **********Collegiate membership in the geologists' association plunged to 300 last year from a peak of more than 2,000 in 1985. And the number of graduate and undergraduate students in petroleum engineering majors fell last year to 2,000, down from 11,500 in 1982, when oil prices averaged $31.22 a barrel and the rig count was more than 3,100. **********Moreover, the squeeze on bank loans, capital and oilfield drilling equipment that began after the debacle in 1986 will also contribute to a longer wait for more domestically pumped oil. **********''The whole industry has been saying we need an energy policy just for the very reason of what is coming up before us right now,'' said Dillard S. Hammett, a vice president and director of the Energy Service Company, an oilfield service company based in Dallas. ''Experienced rig workers have been in short supply for the last six to eight months.'' **********But some players are ready to respond to casting calls from the industry. Sam Wade, a 40-year-old geophysicist in Dallas who quit his job in offshore exploration at ARCO in 1985 amid a huge layoff program, says he is eager to return to the oil business, even though the three video franchise stores he and his wife bought before he left ARCO have prospered. **********Another hopeful sign is at Texas A & M, where the petroleum engineering department registered its biggest freshman class in five years last month, with more than 300 entering students, compared with 46 last year. Starting salaries for those who received bachelor's degrees last May averaged $37,500, while those with master's degrees were paid an average of $39,500. **********And Harry E. Wingfield, a 19-year-old farm boy from Jasper, Tex., dug into his savings to attend the Abilene roughneck school. ''A derrick man has lots of responsibility,'' he said. ''I want to see the oilfield part of the world, make some money and go to college later on.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/02/busin.main_headline: Loophole to Be Used To Keep Bailout Afloat
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/02/busin.print_headline: Loophole to Be Used To Keep Bailout Afloat
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/02/busin.body_text: **********The Bush Administration said this evening that it would use a loophole in the bailout law adopted last year to borrow money to keep the rescue of the nation's savings and loans from grinding to a halt. The new borrowing would enable the Administration to spend an additional $8 billion to $10 billion to continue the rescue, Treasury officials said. **********The decision by the Oversight Board of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency overseeing the bailout, comes less than a week after Congress adjourned until next year without authorizing any new funds for the bailout, which had virtually been out of money.  'Loss Fund' **********Last year's legislation authorized a "loss fund" of $50 billion to cover the losses of failed savings institutions. For working capital, the law enabled regulators to borrow up to 85 percent of the value of assets the Government has taken over from failed institutions. **********If the Government needed more money for working capital, the law required it to charge any additional amount against the $50 billion loss fund. **********Working capital is used for a wide variety of purposes, notably the management of assets and institutions under Government control. Government outlays for working capital are supposed to be recouped through the sale of those assets. The assets held by the Government range from mortgages and securities, to land, buildings, golf courses and uranium mines. **********The regulators had run up against the 85 percent cap on working capital and had been forced to keep in reserves just under $15 billion in the loss fund for more working capital. **********But by deciding today to borrow more working capital, the regulators will be freeing $8 billion to $10 billion in the loss fund, out of the amount that had been held in reserves, for spending to continue the bailout. **********The regulators authorized the borrowing of up to another $18.8 billion for working capital.   Error in the Law **********The decision to borrow was based on a loophole that even the authors of last year's legislation have called a drafting error in the law, the Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery and Enforcement Act. **********Literally interpreted, the provision enables the Administration to borrow the $18.8 billion, which is in addition to the Treasury's original borrowing authorization of that same amount, even though the report accompanying the legislation acknowledged that such an intepretation was clearly not what was intended by either the Congress or the Administration when the law was passed and signed last August by President Bush. Before today, the Resolution Trust Corporation had consistently declined to interpret the legislation to permit further borrowing. **********A spokesman for the Resolution Trust Corporation said any new appropriation would be used primarily to begin the process of resolving the plight of 18 institutions with assets of more than $30 billion. The spokesman, Stephen J. Katsanos, said those sales would not be completed before January because their sales require a lengthy bidding process involving weeks of advertising followed by fact finding by potential buyers and negotiations with regulators. **********Regulators have warned that the failure to continue the rescue at a sustained pace could ultimately cost taxpayers billions of additional dollars as losses at many institutions still in private hands continue to mount, and as the Government must pay to maintain those institutions already in its possession.  New Interpretation of Law **********The Administration's latest interpretation of the law means that it will now be continuing the bailout without the explicit approval of Congress, a move that could ultimately be challenged in the courts and also subject regulators to criticism for deciding to act without the authority of the lawmakers. The bailout has already been criticized by both Democrats and Republicans for being too costly and inefficient. **********Shortly before it adjourned last Sunday for the elections, the Senate by a voice vote passed a measure clarifying the legislation to explicitly permit the borrowing of additional funds, but an identical measure died in the House. **********Administration officials have been saying for days that they might have to resort to using the ambiguous provision to justify the additional borrowing because of the failure of Congress to come up with any new funds. For their part, those lawmakers who opposed new funding have said they were angry at the failure of the Adminstration to appear before Congress to justify the Treasury's request of $40 billion for the next 12 months.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/30/busin.body_text: **********Eleven Japanese toy retailers have formed an association to try to protect domestic toy stores from competition by Toys ''R'' Us. **********The Japan Association of **********Specialty Toy Shops will ''provide support'' to local toy stores in areas in Japan where Toys ''R'' Us opens branches, a director of the association said last week. **********Toys ''R'' Us Japan, which is 80 percent owned by Toys ''R'' **********Us Inc. of the United States, said in June that it planned to open about 100 stores in Japan in the next 10 years. **********The Large Retail Store Law, which is intended to protect small retailers, was relaxed in May as part of efforts by Japan and the United States to reduce trade barriers. The United States argued that large stores offer more imported goods. **********Since the easing of the regulation, several large foreign retailers have announced plans to open stores in Japan, including the Virgin Retail Group of Britain and Barneys, the New York retailer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/11/world.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;   Soviets Assail Radicals
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/11/world.body_text: **********The Soviet Communist Party Central Committee sharply attacked a group of party radicals agitating for drastic changes and said today that if they did not conform they had no place in the party organization. **********An ''open letter'' from the committee read on Soviet television denounced the Democratic Platform, which has called for changing the party into a parliamentary grouping with a socialist program. **********It appeared to pave the way for expulsion from the party of Democratic Platform supporters and other dissenting factions who have been attacked as anti-socialist by hard-liners, including the Politburo member Yegor K. Ligachev. **********''The time has come to decide what to do about those who put themselves outside the party. How can they stay in the Communist Party of the Soviet Union?'' the Central Committee asked. **********Although it denied it was seeking a purge, the letter said local party organizations should focus on Democratic Platform members and ''try to persuade them of their mistakes.'' It made no secret of the fact that the goal was to purify the ranks before an important party congress in July at which a new program and rules are to be adopted. **********Among the leaders of the Democratic Platform, formed earlier this year, are Yuri Afanasyev, a member of Parliament, and Vyacheslav Shostokovsky, rector of the Higher Party School.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/12/busin.body_text: **********Failure of a public offer to sell 46 million Government shares in three state-run commercial banks will delay Taiwan's efforts to privatize state companies, bank officials and stock analysts said today. **********''The offer is a total failure,'' said Huang Feng-yi, manager of the state-owned Bank of Communications, the chief underwriter for the deal. **********By today's deadline, only 257 people out of 46,343 eligible applicants had bought Government shares in the First Commercial, Hua Nan Commercial and Chang Hwa Commercial banks, he said. **********The offer, intended as a showcase introduction to Taipei's privatization drive, dimmed as the gloom surrounding Taiwan's once-booming stock market carried share prices below the prices set for the Government stocks. **********Finance Ministry officials said they had not decided whether the Government would attempt a second offer this year. **********Bankers and stock analysts said the failure would also cause other state companies, including the China Steel Corporation, to delay its plans to sell 350 million shares. China Steel, which successfully sold about 150 million shares last year, had planned to make the offer in late June.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/31/busin.main_headline: A Push to Curb Lung Disease
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/31/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; A Push to Curb Lung Disease
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/31/busin.body_text: **********The American Lung Association hopes that smokers who make New Year's resolutions to quit will get some inspiration from a fish. **********The organization has begun a public service campaign that uses a live carp as a stand-in for people with chronic lung disease. In one spot, the fish struggles for breath in a body of polluted water. In another it gasps on land while an announcer says: "Deprive us of air for a short time and we suffer. Take it away and we die." **********The spots were created by JMCT/Health, the health-care services unit of Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor, New York. "We felt the fish theme was a graphic way to communicate what it is like to have lung disease," said Stephen Kling, president and creative director of the agency. "The fish concept offers a simple yet powerful theme which can be used thoughout the yearlong campaign."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/24/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Farm Credit Bank Funding Corporation yesterday priced $200 million in 8.94 percent callable consolidated systemwide bonds due Sept. 7, 1995, at par through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. **********The Government agency said it had the option to redeem the bonds at a price of par, in whole or in part, on any interest payment date beginning Sept. 7, 1992. https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/07/world.main_headline: Afrikaner Cleric Asks Blacks to Forgive
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/07/world.print_headline: Afrikaner Cleric Asks Blacks to Forgive
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/07/world.body_text: **********A prominent Afrikaner theologian surprised a multiracial church conference discussing South Africa's future today when he stood and begged black churchmen to forgive him and other Afrikaner communicants of the Dutch Reformed Church for having condoned apartheid. **********The theologian, Prof. Willie D. Jonker, who is also an ordained minister in the Dutch Reformed Church, said it must acknowledge responsibility for the sufferings that apartheid had inflicted on the country's black majority. His confession seemed bound to agitate many Afrikaans-speaking Christians. **********The five-day conference, which attracted 85 black and white denominations, the most to assemble together in South Africa, was convened to work out guidelines acceptable to all Christians in a changing South Africa. Seventy-eight percent of all South Africans call themselves Christians. **********Professsor Jonker, who is Professor of Systematic Theology at Stellenbosch University, the premier Afrikaans-speaking academic institution, has a liberal reputation in Dutch Reformed circles. He had been invited to address the conference today on the theme of "understanding the church situation and obstacles to Christian witness in South Africa." Tutu Responds to Professor **********But when he was into the fourth page of his prepared speech, the slight, gray-haired professor pulled out another piece of paper on which he had scribbled his confession by hand. **********It said, "I confess before you and before the Lord not only my own sin and guilt, and my personal responsibility for the political, social, economical and structural wrongs that have been done to many of you and the results of which you and our whole community are still suffering from, but vicariously I have also to do that in the name of the N.G.K. of which I am a member, and for the Afrikaner people as a whole." **********Professor Jonker used the Afrikaans initials of the Nederduitse Gereformeerde Kirk, the largest of three white branches of the Dutch Reformed Church in South Africa. The N.G.K. has been described as the governing "National Party at prayer" because of the influence that its members exert over white politics. **********The Anglican Archbishop, Desmond M. Tutu, who contended on Monday at the opening of the conference that racial reconciliation must be followed by white reparations to blacks, asked for a minute to respond to Professor Jonker's unexpected confession. 'Confession Goes With Deeds' **********"When that confession is made, then those of us who have been wronged must say, 'We forgive you,' and together we must move to the reconstruction of our land," Archbishop Tutu said. **********The audience of more than 200 delegates and observers, visibly moved by the words of both churchmen, sprang to their feet and applauded. **********But the Rev. Frank Chikane, a black Pentacostal minister who is secretary general of the South African Council of Churches, said later that "confession goes with deeds." Mr. Chikane said the majority of people victimized for many years by apartheid expected compensation for their suffering. **********Louws Alberts, a white Dutch Reformed layman who is co-chairman of the conference with Mr. Chikane, said it was the first time that so prominent a representative of the Dutch Reformed Church had confessed the sin of apartheid in public. Shifts to Black Denomination **********A few other Afrikaner clergymen, notably the Rev. Beyers Naude and the Rev. Nico Smit, broke previously with the Dutch Reformed Church over its tolerance of apartheid and taken their ministries into the black denomination, the Dutch Reformed Church of Africa. **********"I am a member of the Dutch Reformed Church and I've been living with these things through all these years," Professor Jonker told reporters after his speech. "But my decision to do it is my own. I am quite sure that there are many who will take exception to it. There will be many who will not feel I had the right to speak in their behalf." **********But the professor said he hoped that the majority of Afrikaners would agree with his confession.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/05/world.main_headline: Parliament Backs Gorbachev Food Theft Crackdown
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/05/world.print_headline: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE; Parliament Backs Gorbachev Food Theft Crackdown
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/05/world.body_text: **********The Parliament voted quickly today to grant President Mikhail S. Gorbachev enlarged emergency powers as the Soviet leader vowed to start an effective crackdown on food thieves and black marketeers within the next three weeks. **********Mr. Gorbachev, stressing the need to deal with the nation's food shortages, said that he was continuing to arrange food loans and credits from foreign nations. He also said the Government was preparing a program to enlarge food production by setting aside more than 10 million acres of land for small-scale farming. **********"We think we can control the situation," the Soviet President told the Parliament, referring to the widespread, long-standing abuse in which state store workers and food distributors pilfer large supplies of food and sell them to the black market or barter them for other goods. **********With the economic crisis and food shortages dominating the public agenda, Mr. Gorbachev found the Parliament ready to enlarge his executive powers and to extend a larger Kremlin role to the restive Soviet republics through a strengthened Federation Council, an advisory board in which the leaders of the nation's 15 republics will have representation.  Council to Share Power **********"It will turn into a linchpin in the system of higher state power and administration and be vested with extensive authority," he promised of the Council. Mr. Gorbachev will retain final authority under the revamped executive system, but promised that the Council would not only be able to look after the republics' interests but also "share in exercising federal powers on an equal footing." **********One surprise in the package of constitutional amendments is that Mr. Gorbachev will not eliminate the post of Prime Minister under a revised Cabinet system that he is supposed to control more closely. **********The promise of closing out that post and effectively removing its present occupant, Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, was one of the strong points of initial legislative support for the package when the Soviet leader offered it on Nov. 17 in the face of parliamentary demands for firmer action. Mr. Ryzhkov is widely criticized as a defender of the Government's increasingly ineffective and corrupt method of attempting to dictate all details of the nation's economy. **********With the Prime Minister post now spared, the Gorbachev package nevertheless was approved and sent to the Congress of People's Deputies for final ratification later this month, with many details still unclear. Even at that, Mr. Gorbachev requested and was granted emergency permission to begin changing the Government immediately.  'Worse by the Day' **********"While we sit here arguing, the situation outside these walls grows worse by the day," he declared. **********"Many foreign countries are now offering humanitarian food aid and credits to buy foodstuffs," said the President, noting that he has a special commission to handle this aid as well as a special executive group working "round the clock" to finish an emergency food plan to see to the nation's needs into spring. He promised to discuss the plan with the republic leaders within a few days. **********"We will take resolute actions," he vowed, speaking about the need to get control of black marketeering and state food pilferage. **********"A survey of 50 stores in Moscow by security bodies has shown that when stores close, a 'third shift' starts working," he said, referring to internal thievery. "The same thing happens at state warehouses." Trying to Halt Theft of Aid **********The problem is deeply engrained in the Soviet system and has been worsening with the erosion of the national Government's authority and the rapid growth of private and black markets. Mr. Gorbachev is revising leadership of the Soviet police and reviving vigilante workers' committees in an attempt to cope with the problem. He is seeking to guarantee, among other things, that newly arriving foreign charity food shipments will not be stolen. **********While some insurgent opposition politicians say worker vigilante groups long have been attempted in the Communist system and long have failed, Mr. Gorbachev promised the new ones "the right to control plants and warehouses," as well as "premises and transport facilities" to work with the police. **********The Soviet leader said a wide range of measures to stimulate food production was under consideration, including urban agriculture in the form of new garden plots. The republics, he said, should solve the food question in accordance with local conditions, within the national Government's "general principle." **********The revamped executive system designed by the President is to include a National Security Council to focus on military and security considerations. The Government also is to have unspecified new agencies to monitor compliance with national emergency laws and presidential decress that lately have been increasingly ignored. Mr. Gorbachev also is to have a Vice President -- "the President's right hand," as he put it.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/28/world.main_headline: Vatican Synod Reaffirms Celibacy for Priests
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/28/world.print_headline: Vatican Synod Reaffirms Celibacy for Priests
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/28/world.body_text: **********Roman Catholic bishops from around the world ended a monthlong synod today, calling for better-trained priests but firmly ruling out any change in a celibacy rule that has hindered the recruitment of clergymen in the United States and elsewhere. **********In a closing speech to the assembly, Pope John Paul II assured the bishops that he was not about to alter his insistence on celibacy or his basic opposition to married priests. **********Some speakers at the gathering had suggested that to help overcome a shortage of clergymen in some dioceses, the church should consider ordaining "viri probati," married men judged to be spiritually mature. Indeed, midway through the synod, a Brazilian cardinal disclosed that the Pope himself had allowed two married Brazilian men to become priests on the condition that they abstained from sexual relations with their wives. **********But without any reference to these exceptions, the Pope insisted in strong language that his position had not changed. The matter of "viri probati," he said, speaking in Latin, "is too often evoked in the framework of systematic, hostile propaganda against priestly celibacy." He did not identify who wasresponsible for such propaganda but added that it "finds support and complicity from some mass media." **********The recommendations that the 238 bishops at the synod sent to John Paul reflected general agreement that priests must be more carefuly selected and educated to overcome the isolation, overwork and low morale that many of them are said to suffer. **********These and other problems have contributed to a shortage of Catholic clergymen in many countries, although the Vatican says the recruitment crisis is behind it. Worldwide in the last 13 years, there has been a 50 percent rise in the number of seminary students.Even so, the 401,930 priests registered by the Holy See in 1988 represented a decline of 31,000 from the early 1970's, and in the United States the number of new seminarians continues to drop. **********The synod, whose formal theme was "The Formation of Priests in Circumstances of the Present Day," serves as an advisory body to the Pope, who eventually will issue a formal response. The assembly was the 11th of its kind held under reforms set into motion by the Second Vatican Council of the 1960's. For the first time, it included representatives from formerly Communist countries in Eastern Europe, where the church had endured decades of repression. **********In effect, the bishops acknowledged that the church had to try new methods to recruit and train young men capable of withstanding the rigors of the modern priesthood. **********They proposed, for example, that a would-be priest go through a year of special theological training even before he entered the seminary. The purpose would be to make up for gaps in basic knowledge because of shortcomings in lower schools and also to "let the candidate learn what it is all about," said Archbishop Jan P. Schotte of the Netherlands, the synod's general secretary. **********Other suggestions included allowing women to teach in seminaries, improving seminary instruction and making sure that priests received continued training even after ordination. Some countries already have procedures that put these principles into effect. **********On the question of celibacy, it was clear almost from the synod's start that there would be no significant change, even though a few bishopsargued that the church had to adapt itself to modern realities. The assembly's response in effect was to leave the rule intact and concentrate instead of culling out those young men who cannot live by it, even by means of psychological testing if necessary. **********"Chastity in the celibate state of life is a precious gift of God that perfectly suits the image of the priest," said Msgr. Henryk Myszynski of Poland, a senior synod official. That was true, he said, "today more than ever before." **********The head of the American bishops' conference, Archbishop Daniel E. Pilarczyk of Cincinnati, described the synod as a "ringing reaffirmation of the ideals of the priesthood" and said his group believed in the need for celibacy even though the centuries-old rule was under particular attack in the United States.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/29/busin.body_text: **********The Fluor Corporation said it had won a contract worth more than $200 million to upgrade a Valero Refining and Marketing Company oil refinery in Corpus Christi, Tex. The construction giant, based in Irvine, Calif., also announced a $50 million contract to engineer, build and manage a copper ore and molybdenum processing plant 200 miles north of Santiago, Chile. https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/23/busin.body_text: **********The Sony Corporation said today that its third-quarter profits jumped 44.8 percent on strong sales gains. **********Net income for the fiscal quarter ended Dec. 31 totaled $292.7 million, or 85 cents a share, compared with $202.1 million, or 65 cents a share, a year earlier. **********Sony's net sales grew 40.1 percent, to $6.01 billion, from $4.29 billion a year earlier. The company said all of its electronics divisions in all geographic regions posted sales gains. Sony noted sales growth in the United States of 59 percent, in Europe of 48 percent and in Japan of 30 percent. **********Sony said the decline of the yen in 1989 added about 10 percentage points to overall sales growth in the third quarter by raising the value in yen of overseas sales. With stable exchange rates, sales growth would have been about 32 percent, a company spokesman said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/27/busin.body_text: *********** To attract younger volunteers, the American Red Cross introduced a television commercial yesterday in which the performers Carly Simon, Randy Travis, Branford Marsalis and Paul Shaffer do volunteer work to the music of the Rolling Stones' ''Gimme Shelter.'' https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/06/busin.main_headline: Board of UAL Meets To Study Unions' Offer
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/06/busin.print_headline: Board of UAL Meets To Study Unions' Offer
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/06/busin.body_text: **********The board of the UAL Corporation met late into the evening yesterday to consider a bid for United Airlines of about $200 a share, or a total of $4.36 billion, by the airline's three unions, which would end up owning 75 percent of the company. **********People familiar with the meeting said that there were ''substantive talks'' taking place between the board and the representatives of the three unions but that the board had not made a decision on the bid. **********If the board accepts the bid and the union's investment advisers can get the financing, United would become the largest company owned by its employees under an employee stock ownership plan. **********The board began meeting in Chicago this morning and continued late into the night. **********Approval of the bid would eliminate the need for Coniston Partners, a New York investment group that owns 11.8 percent of the airline, to begin a proxy fight to oust the present board. **********Coniston has prepared itself for such a fight if the board does not accept the union bid. Some UAL directors have privately acknowleged that Coniston had a good chance of winning the proxy fight at the annual meeting scheduled for April 26. The new board would then approve the bid by the unions. **********Bid Higher Than Earlier One **********The bid submitted by the unions is higher than an earlier bid worth from $180 to $190 a share. That offer, valued at about $4 billion, was made up of $150 a share in cash, $25 a share in 10-year notes yielding 15 percent and would give UAL shareholders an equity stake of 25 percent. **********The unions improved their offer by proposing to sell United's 50 percent stake in Covia, which could bring in about $500 million. Covia is a holding company that controls the Apollo computer reservation system, one of the largest such systems in the country. **********Sharon Kalin, an arbitrager who has a big holding of UAL stock, said that she had been told by people close to the unions, that the unions had sweetened their bid to $155 in cash, $30 a share in notes plus the sale of the Covia reservations system, which could be worth from $25 to $30 a share. **********She said, however, that the unions were no longer offering 25 percent of the stock in the company as they had done in their previous offer. **********She said she considered the revised offer not as good as the original because no equity was being offered. ''There is no chance to share in the upside of the company,'' she added. **********The major obstacle to the bid is Stephen M. Wolf, the chairman of UAL, who would lose his job if the union bid was accepted. The unions, the pilots, flight attendants and machinists have had their advisers interview candidates to replace Mr. Wolf. **********Mr. Wolf was part of an effort to buy the airline with the pilots' union for $300 a share. The effort collapsed last October when the pilot- and management-led group could not complete the financing. **********Mr. Wolf also alienated the leaders of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers when they found themselves left out of the buyout effort. **********The leaders of the machinists' union have supported the present buyout effort but have made it clear that Mr. Wolf and his top managers would not reamin if the bid was approved. **********As part of the buyout, the unions are offering $300 million a year in concessions, which provide the group with a strong bargaining position to get the financing for the bid. Not only would United have more competitive labor costs but the unions are also offering five-year contracts, which would insure labor peace.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/21/world.main_headline: Burmese Forces in Mandalay Ring Buddhist Monasteries
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/21/world.print_headline: Burmese Forces in Mandalay Ring Buddhist Monasteries
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/21/world.body_text: **********Burmese soldiers today cordoned off monasteries in Mandalay, the country's second-largest city, after the military Government threatened to disband Buddhist groups whose members are refusing to minister to soldiers. **********The Government threat, carried on the Burmese state radio, also said the offending Buddhists would be expelled from their orders because they had violated the rules of their religion by becoming politically involved. **********Thousands of monks in Myanmar, formerly Burma, have stopped ministering to soldiers to protest crackdowns on pro-democracy protests.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/10/world.main_headline: Murree Journal; Hill Station Thrives, a Piece of Time Gone By
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/10/world.print_headline: Murree Journal; Hill Station Thrives, a Piece of Time Gone By
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/10/world.body_text: **********In the days of the British raj, when the white-hot sun of the subcontinent's summer drained colonial administrators of energy and patience, and stifling nights under mosquito nets robbed them of sleep, the empire was saved by the hill stations. **********From the Hindu Kush to the South China Sea, the hills of Asia were dotted with them: small European-style country towns with chalets, lodges, churches, boarding schools, libraries, tea rooms, shops and the obligatory promenade for taking in the bracing mountain air, scented with pine. **********The concept was not limited to the British. The French in Vietnam had Dalat, and the Dutch in Indonesia cooled themselves in Bogor. There was also Baguio in the Philippines. In the days before air conditioning, vaccines and wonder drugs, the hill stations were considered necessary havens of health and restoration. Fell Into Disuse **********With the nd of colonialism in Asia, the hill stations almost everywhere went into decline. Buildings became dilapidated and wooded hillsides were stripped and eroded. Though still valued for their mountain scenery and refreshing air, most hill stations were no longer the fashionable resorts of the past. **********Murree (pronounced MUH-ree) is proving to be the exception. It is riding a tourist boom that can only get better. A luxury mountain lodge is under construction by Pakistan's Pearl Continental chain in nearby Bhurban, the only new hotel of its class to be built in any subcontinent hill station in more than half a century. **********The large lodge, designed to nestle into a mountainside, will overlook the snowy peaks of Kashmir and the Karakorams. Local tourism officials hope it will further enhance the town as a year-round resort. **********In a tourist information center along the Mall Road, a young man wrapped in woolens was doing a modest business in maps of Murree's labyrinth of hillside hiking trails. **********"There is no single tourist season anymore like in the old days," he said. "People come here all year, even in the snow. And with the new hotels coming up, we think there will be thousands more."  Hotel Makes a Comeback **********Murree's once-grand Cecil Hotel, which had sunk into bleak austerity, is beginning to spruce up -- to judge from an imposing new front door and polished brass in the front parlor. **********The government of Punjab province, in which Murree is situated, has contributed to the boom by building chairlifts and first-class roads into the hills, the latter with guardrails -- tourist attactions in themselves in a part of the world where buses, trucks and cars regularly plunge into ravines or tumble into valleys. **********In colonial days, come about April, the administrations of entire provinces decamped to the hill stations. **********When the most famous one of them all was built at Simla, in the foothills of the Himalayas in what is now the Indian state of Himachal Pradesh, the whole entourage of the Viceroy of British India plodded upward, first on elephants and in later years by train or car. The ball gowns, porcelain and silver went along. Judging by diaries of the time, only inhibitions were left on the plains. **********Murree, at an altitude of 7,400 feet, began to develop in 1851 on an expanse of mountain pastureland to serve the administrators of the Punjab, then a unified territory the British annexed in 1849. Murree was Punjab's summer capital until 1876, when offices moved to Simla. Punjab is now two states of the same name, one on each side of the Indian-Pakistani border. Proximity to Duller Places **********Part of Murree's attraction then and now is its proximity to Rawalpindi, a commercial center and military headquarters for first the British and then Pakistan. In the mid-19th century, the trip to Murree from Rawalpindi could be made in less than a day in a horse-drawn carriage. It takes little more than an hour and a half now, with the distant promise of a helicopter service one day that will reduce travel time to minutes. **********Another catalyst in Murree's resurgence was the siting of Islamabad, Pakistan's new capital, about 30 miles to the southeast. Islamabad is having a boom of its own, as rich Pakistanis from the troubled and increasingly violent city of Karachi, and similarly wealthy Afghan refugees, buy houses and open businesses. **********A planned city that took a long time to begin to develop a personality, Islamabad is now pleasantly green with spacious avenues, some fashionable shops and, lately, a new crop of restaurants. But there isn't much entertainment in this Islamic capital. **********That's where a weekend in Murree comes in. The hill lures expensively dressed Pakistanis and diplomats' families, who also visit other nearby resorts known as the Galis. Boutiques and a Brewery **********On the Mall Road, which runs through Murree from Kashmir Point to Pindi Point, young people in Western-style clothes idle away hours in coffee houses and restaurants, or browse in boutiques offering woolens from Kashmir and consumer gadgets from China. **********In its heyday, Murree was known across the subcontinent for its beer and whisky. The ruins of the Murree Brewery's original stone buildings cling to a hillside, a victim of the havoc that surrounded the birth of Islamic Pakistan. **********Incredibly, the brewery survived, and now bottles its product, officially for non-Muslims, in Rawalpindi. Old-fashioned Murree beer, like old-fashioned Murree, is still part of the landscape.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/15/world.main_headline: Ex-K.G.B. Official Is Trying to Sue Soviet Leaders
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/15/world.print_headline: Ex-K.G.B. Official Is Trying to Sue Soviet Leaders
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/15/world.body_text: **********A former K.G.B. counterintelligence chief who has been criticizing the agency publicly in recent weeks is setting his sights on other targets, among them President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Izvestia reported today. **********The Government daily said that Oleg D. Kalugin, who worked as an operative in the United States from 1958 to 1970, has applied to a Moscow court to sue Mr. Gorbachev, Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov and the K.G.B. chief, Vladimir A. Kryuchkov. **********Izvestia said Mr. Kalugin is accusing President Gorbachev of illegally depriving him of his Government honors and wants to sue Mr. Ryzhkov for stripping him of his major general's rank in the K.G.B. and Mr. Kryuchkov for removing his pension. Visible Critic of the K.G.B.  Mr. Kalugin has been speaking at demonstrations and in interviews with reporters, saying the K.G.B. still taps telephones, infiltrates Soviet life and engages in dirty tricks. **********He was nominated as a candidate to the Russian republic's Parliament from Krasnodar. **********Last month, the Soviet prosecutor's office said it was investigating Mr. Kalugin under a law against divulging state secrets. **********Izvestia quoted a Moscow city court official as saying that Mr. Kalugin's applications to sue were not properly filed and that procedural questions must be resolved before the case could proceed. **********Soviet television tonight showed what it said was the arrest of a citizen accused of spying. An announcer read a report from the official press agency Tass that said K.G.B. personnel had uncovered attempts by Soviet citizens to pass state and military secrets to foreign secret agents. **********The dispatch said a staff member of a Moscow research institute was caught trying to give defense-related top-secret documents to a foreigner. **********Man's Face Not Shown **********Television segments shown while that part of the Tass dispatch was read showed men grabbing a gray-suited man near a yellow car. A roll of papers fell to the ground. The man, whose face was not visible, was then forced into an automobile. **********The man's name, that of his alleged foreign contact and other details were not reported. **********Tass also said a resident of the Grodno region, a former Soviet Army soldier, was arrested while trying to exchange military secrets for money. No details were released. In neither case did Tass say if legal action had been taken against the foreigners.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/31/world.main_headline: Mitterrand Is Said to Agree to Free Hunger Striker
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/31/world.print_headline: Mitterrand Is Said to Agree to Free Hunger Striker
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/31/world.body_text: **********President Francois Mitterrand has promised to release a convicted pro-Iranian terrorist in exchange for his agreement to end a four-month hunger strike, published reports said today. **********The French weekly satirical newspaper, Le Canard Enchaine, said the 36-year-old terrorist, Anis Naccache, who had lost nearly 80 pounds, agreed over the weekend to stop his hunger strike after weeks of secret negotiations. **********He had been sentenced to life in prison in connection with an attempt to kill a former Iranian Prime Minister, Shahpur Bakhtiar. **********One of Mr. Naccache's lawyers, Jacques Verges, has indicated that the terrorist received a direct request from Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, to end his strike, leaving the strong impression that the Iranian leader was part of a deal. **********Spokesmen at Elysee Palace, the Prime Minister's office and the French Foreign Ministry all refused to comment on the report in the French newspaper and another, in a Kuwait daily. **********President Mitterrand said on Jan. 5 that Mr. Naccache could not obtain his liberty by going on a hunger strike, but added that ''he can always hope to be liberated when the time comes.'' **********The release of Mr. Naccache has repeatedly been demanded by Iran, which has officially stated that it was part of complicated agreements that led to the release of all French hostages held in Beirut in 1988. **********Several Iranian leaders, including President Hashemi Rafsanjani and the Foreign Minister, have said they expected France to live up to the accord, which included a pledge by Iran to refrain from sponsoring any acts of terror against France and a French commitment to normalize ties and resume economic and industrial cooperation. **********The accord has been largely upheld, except for the continued detention of Mr. Naccache, who went on a hunger strike Sept. 8, saying he would stop only when France lived up to its agreement to release him. **********U.S. Hostages in Lebanon **********A report in the Kuwaiti daily Al Qabas today said ''extremely secret high level'' talks have recently been held between senior Iranian and American officials in Paris, Geneva and an unidentified West German city about the fate of the American hostages in Lebanon and about normalizing ties between Iran and the United States. **********Al Qabas went on to say that the administration of President Rafsanjani was persuaded that the hostages have outlived their usefulness and is ready to release them. **********But a few days ago, a senior Iranian official said that Iran was putting the issue of improved ties with the United States at the end of its list of priorities, concentrating instead on better ties with Western Europe. **********In 1988, Jacques Chirac, who was then Prime Minister, pledged that France would do what it could to bring about the release of other nationals after it negotiated the release of its own hostages. **********A number of pro-Iranian terrorists are held in France as prisoners. A group of 10 led by Fouad Ali Saleh, a Tunisian accused of terrorist acts, went on trial Monday in Paris.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/19/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Hun Sen plans to meet this month with Prince Norodom Sihanouk and renew a proposal that the Prince break with the Khmer Rouge guerrillas and return to Cambodia as the country's President and Commander in Chief, Cambodian officials said today. **********Mr. Hun Sen and Prince Sihanouk, leader of one of the three guerrilla groups fighting the Phnom Penh Government, plan to meet in Bangkok before Feb. 26, when new talks on a settlement in Cambodia are scheduled to open in Jakarta, the Indonesian capital, Government officials and an American senator said. **********The meeting will take place at the invitation of the Thai Prime Minister, Chatichai Choonhavan, Cambodian officials said. Mr. Chatichai has made strong efforts to bring the Cambodian adversaries together and bring about a cease-fire. **********Meets With U.S. Senator **********After a three-hour conversation this morning with Mr. Hun Sen, Senator Charles S. Robb, Democrat of Virginia, said the Prime Minister and the Prince would meet. Senator Robb, on a private one-day visit to Cambodia, said he would discuss his findings with Congressional colleagues and Bush Administration officials on his return to Washington. **********At talks in Jakarta last May, Mr. Hun Sen said he thought he had an agreement from the Prince to return as head of state in November, after the scheduled withdrawal of Vietnamese troops at the end of September. But the Prince declined, saying that he was not satisfied with a new, more liberal Cambodian Constitution and that he wanted international monitoring of the withdrawal. **********The posts of President and Commander in Chief are currently held by Heng Samrin, Secretary General of the Cambodian Communist Party. **********Even Cambodian officials said they were not optimistic that the Prince would accept Mr. Hun Sen's offer. But they said the Prince was running out of room to maneuver and now realized that his coalition with the Communist Khmer Rouge had damaged his credibility inside and outside the country. **********Prince's Fifth Resignation **********Before they were ousted by invading Vietnamese forces, the Khmer Rouge presided over a brutal remaking of Cambodia, from 1975 to 1979, during which more than a million people died. **********The Prince recently resigned for a fifth time from his post as leader of the opposition coalition, saying he was hurt by Western charges that he was an accomplice of the Khmer Rouge. **********In previous meetings with Mr. Hun Sen, the Prince said he only represented his own faction. Prince Sihanouk's group is part of an awkward coalition with the Khmer Rouge and the followers of a former Prime Minister, Son Sann. The coalition holds Cambodia's seat at the United Nations. **********The Jakarta talks are to include representatives of the Cambodian Government and the three guerrilla groups, as well as officials from Southeast Asian countries, Australia and France. **********Indonesia and France are presiding over an international conference on Cambodia, which has been suspended since the end of August, and the new talks are intended to find enough progress to revive it. Australia will attend as the author of a Cambodian peace proposal that has gained some support and that will be the basis for the Jakarta talks. **********A Wider U.N. Role **********The Australians have suggested dropping the seemingly impossible task of negotiating a four-party coalition government to rule Cambodia before new elections can be held. Instead, they propose an enhanced role for the United Nations, either by supplanting the two rival Cambodian governments or by monitoring their work, with the goal of organizing and supervising a cease-fire, a halt in foreign aid to the combatants and a free election. **********The latest Australian working paper on the peace effort includes three options for an interim arrangement involving the United Nations. Under the first, replacing about 200,000 Cambodian officials with United Nations officials would be required; under the second, senior levels of leadership would be supplanted, requiring about 300 to 500 United Nations officials; under the third, only the top 10 or so officials from each side would be replaced by United Nations officials. **********The second option would preserve the two rival governments but would give United Nations officials authority either above or alongside the current administrations. Mr. Hun Sen has said that to insure fairness he would allow the United Nations to organize and supervise free elections and to monitor his Government's work. But he has rejected any idea of dismantling his administration, saying this would mean chaos and would allow the Khmer Rouge to continue its fight for control of Cambodia. **********Following Namibian Approach **********A Foreign Ministry spokesman, Chum Bun Rong, said Mr. Hun Sen had made a significant concession, since in Namibia the United Nations merely supervised an election organized by the South African colonial administration. Although Cambodia is not a colony, he said, the United Nations could organize the election, too. **********In any event, he said, the election in Namibia was fair and the South African-supported party lost. ''Even in Poland,'' he said, ''the Government lost the election it had organized to Solidarity.'' **********Prince Sihanouk, he said, could only gain by breaking with the Khmer Rouge and returning to Cambodia with real power while the Khmer Rouge, knowing it would lose a fair election, would put up any obstacle to block a Cambodian settlement.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/24/busin.body_text: **********The Marriott Corporation said that it now controlled more than 50 percent of Basic American Medical Inc. and that it planned to dispose of its holdings in the Indianapolis-based health care concern. **********In a filing with Securities and Exchange Commission, Marriot said that it had acquired the Basic American shares as the result of a default in a loan to a group including three senior executives of Basic American. The Basic American stock was pledged to secure the loan. The amount of the loan was not disclosed. Marriott told the S.E.C. that it controlled 4.1 million Basic American shares, or 52.26 percent of the company's outstanding shares.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/31/busin.body_text: **********Marion Merrell Dow Inc., the recently merged pharmaceutical company based in Kansas City, Mo.. said yesterday that its net income fell 59.3 percent in the fourth quarter of 1989. Meanwhile the Warner-Lambert Company said its net income for the quarter rose 19.1 percent. **********Marion Merrell Dow said earnings for the final quarter of 1989 totaled $22 million, or 11 cents a share, compared with $54 million, or 35 cents a share, earned by Marion Laboratories Inc. alone in the 1988 quarter. **********Marion and the Merrell Dow Pharmaceuticals unit of the Dow Chemical Company completed the merger last month. **********Special Charge **********Marion Merrell Dow said the quarterly results included a $44 million pretax special charge related to the merger transaction. Financial results reflected two months of performance by Marion alone and one month for the new company. **********The new company's sales rose 53.2 percent, to $337 million, from $220 million in the 1988 period. **********Marion Merrell Dow said special pretax charges of $297 million related to the merger resulted in a net loss of $79 million in the six months that ended Dec. 31. **********Analysts said the results were disappointing. ''They have been telegraphing that it wasn't going to be a great quarter,'' said David F. Saks at Wedbush Morgan Securities. ''But that's quite a lot of charge.'' **********Marion Merrell's shares fell 62.5 cents today, to $26.50, in New York Stock Exchange trading. **********Marion Merrell Dow said sales of both its heart drug Cardizem and Carafate, an anti-ulcer product, had increased. But Hemant K. Shah, an analyst with HKS & Company in Warren, N.J., said both drugs had been losing market share. **********Warner Lambert **********Confirming forecasts it presented to securities analysts last week, the Warner-Lambert Company said yesterday that net income was $92.3 million in the fourth quarter of 1989, up 19.1 percent from $77.5 million in the 1988 quarter. Earnings per share were $1.37 in the quarter, compared with $1.14 in the 1988 period. **********Warner-Lambert, a diversified pharmaceutical company based in Morris Plains, N.J., said sales in the quarter were $1.04 billion, compared with $998 million in the 1988 period. **********Earnings for the year rose 21.3 percent to $413 million, on sales of $4.12 billion. Warner-Lambert had net income of $340 million on $3.91 billion in sales in 1988. **********Warner Lambert shares fell 50 cents, to $109, on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/02/world.main_headline: Tearfully, Romanians Recall a Wartime Partition
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/02/world.print_headline: Tearfully, Romanians Recall a Wartime Partition
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/02/world.body_text: **********A village teacher spoke in a flat voice of ''savagery worthy of the Mongol invaders,'' and old peasant women in the large crowd wept copiously. Then a mixed choir sang a hymn to ''our heroic martyrs,'' and eight Orthodox priests intoned a prayer. **********This scene was repeated in scores of ceremonies across the country commemorating the time 50 years ago when Romania lost 40 percent of its territory to the Soviet Union, Hungary and Bulgaria in a sequence of dismemberments that took less than 11 weeks. **********The specific occasion marked on Thursday was the anniversary of the so-called Vienna Dictate imposed by Hitler and Mussolini upon Romania, forcing it to cede more than 16,000 square miles of territory to the Hungarian fascist Government of Adm. Miklos Horthy on Aug. 30, 1940. Days of Violence The old people of Ip, a farming community of 30,000, remember it because only two weeks later, Hungarian troops came here and killed 157 townspeople with rifles, bayonets and grenades and by setting their victims afire. The Hungarian border, then as now, is less than 40 miles away. **********The mass grave where the teacher spoke has a tablet with the names of those killed, ranging in age from infants to an 81-year-old woman. One family named Bucovan lost five members - Floare, Vasile, Paulina and two men named Petru, ages 5 to 38. **********Such atrocities were repeated throughout this region, northwestern Transylvania, in the weeks after the Vienna Dictate, leaving 919 Romanians dead and thousands wounded. In the period thereafter, a total of 218,919 people were expelled to the Romanian territory that remained while about 100,000 Romanian Jews were deported to Nazi Germany, where almost all ended in the death camps. **********Hungary had owned this part of Romania, lost it at the end of World War I and thirsted for it ever since. The Hungarian minority here now numbers 2.3 million - 10 percent of the total population - most of it inhabiting Transylvania. Romania's relations with Hungary are bad. **********Prime Minister Arrives **********Prime Minster Petre Roman traveled to Ip on Thursday morning by plane, helicopter, automobile and on foot to lay a wreath at the mass grave bounded by orchards and cornfields rustling in gusts of wind. He was accompanied by Foreign Minister Adrian Nastase and Interior Minister Doru Ursu. **********It was the first time that the annexation of northwestern Transylvania by Hungary and the accompanying atrocities were publicly commemorated here. The Communist Government that ruled after the war until it fell last December forbade such ceremonies in keeping with the Stalinist doctrine of ''proletarian internationalism'' -which meant the denial of ethnic rivalries. **********The party called the Union of Democratic Hungarians, the second largest in the Romanian Parliament, condemned Thursday's ceremonies as ''a diversion to intimidate the Hungarian minority'' that ''threatens an interethnic crisis.'' **********Although showing the Romanian flag here close to the Hungarian frontier, Prime Minister Roman remained low-key in his remarks at the ceremony in Ip and at a second in the Transylvanian village of Traznea, where 86 people were killed by Hungarian troops in September 1940, including members of two Jewish families named Izrael and Weiss. **********No Longer a Taboo Subject **********''We can forgive, but we cannot forget,'' Mr. Roman said, adding, ''never again will we allow Romanian blood to be spilled.'' **********There seemed to be a kind of national sigh of relief over the opportunity after half a century to talk and write openly about events that touched the lives of virtually every Romanian family. **********The sequence of dismemberment began on June 26, 1940, when the Soviet Union annexed traditionally Romanian territories - Bessarabia in the east, which is now an autonomous Soviet republic, and Bukovina in the north, which is now part of the Ukraine. Both were taken with Hitler's blessing, according to the secret protocol of his 1939 pact with Stalin. **********Coercive Arbitration **********This was followed by the Vienna Dictate, the result of a crudely camouflaged ''arbitration'' by Hitler and Mussolini between Hungary and Romania. Hitler favored Admiral Horthy, advising the Bucharest Government that a refusal to cede territory ''would mean Romania's annihilation sooner or later, probably sooner.'' **********Then Hitler compelled Romania to cede a region called southern Dobrogea, a rectangle of territory south of the Danube, to neighboring Bulgaria, on Sept. 5. Both the Bessarabia-Bukovina and southern Dobrogea annexations involved transfers of populations, but no loss of life as in the case of northwestern Transylvania. **********Romanians today, as in the past, consider Transylvania more an integral part of their country than the other territories, which is why the daily Romania Libera called Aug. 30, 1940, ''the blackest day'' in the nation's history.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/06/busin.main_headline: Ex-GTE Colleagues Now at FPL Group
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/06/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;   Ex-GTE Colleagues Now at FPL Group
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/06/busin.body_text: **********James L. Broadhead and Stephen E. Frank, former colleagues at the GTE Corporation, will be working together again at the parent of the Florida Power and Light Company. **********In 1988, Mr. Broadhead left as president of GTE's telephone operations to become president and chief executive of the company, FPL Group, a diversified utility based in North Palm Beach. **********Mr. Broadhead, 55 years old, now chairman and chief executive of FPL, announced yesterday that Mr. Frank had been named president and chief operating officer of Florida Power and Light. **********Mr. Frank, 48, also left GTE in 1988. At GTE, based in Stamford, Conn., he was vice president and controller. He left to join the TRW Company in Cleveland, where he became executive vice president and chief financial officer. TRW, a diversified high-technology company with more than $7 billion in annual sales, said it had not yet named a successor. **********In Florida, Mr. Frank is replacing Robert E. Tallon, 63, who retired as president on June 30. Mr. Frank is expected to take over his new post in mid-August. **********Neither Mr. Broadhead nor Mr. Frank could be reached for comment yesterday. In a statement, Mr. Broadhead said Mr. Frank ''has wide exposure to a variety of businesses, with experience in unregulated as well as regulated industries.'' **********In addition to Florida Power and Light, FPL owns the Colonial Penn insurance group and other non-utility businesses, including agriculture, real estate and cable television interests. **********Before Mr. Frank joined GTE in 1984, he spent 18 years with the United States Steel Corporation, now USX, in Pittsburgh. He is a Dartmouth graduate with an M.B.A. from the University of Michigan. **********Mr. Broadhead also joined GTE in 1984, from U.S. Industries, where he was executive vice president. Earlier he was president of the St. Joe Minerals Corporation. **********Florida Power and Light serves 3.2 million customers in more than half of Florida. The parent company has said it is considering selling or spinning off its Colonial Penn insurance subsidiary.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/11/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Reader's Digest Starts Monthly
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/11/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Reader's Digest Starts Monthly
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/11/busin.body_text: **********Reader's Digest Association Inc. said yesterday that it would start its first new magazine in 10 years with Budgets Famille, a French monthly magazine to help families manage their finances. **********The magazine will appear on newsstands in late September. **********It will be published by the company's French subsidiary and be aimed at prosperous 30-to-45-year-old readers. **********''We do have a plan to look for additional start-ups and acquisitions throughout the world,'' said Bruce Trachtenberg, a spokesman for Reader's Digest. ''With our local subsidiary companies, we are in a position to react to markets throughout the world and build on the base of our Reader's Digest publications.'' **********Last year more than half of the Digest's revenues of $1.8 billion came from its 16 international operating subsidiaries, which publish at 54 sites around the world.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/23/busin.body_text: **********A delay in settling the offering of a $24 million tax and revenue anticipation note by the City of St. Louis could have negative implications on the city's general obligation bond rating if not resolved soon, Moody's Investors Service said yesterday. **********The rating agency said it was monitoring the effects of the delay resulting from a dispute over whether the city's counselor or Comptroller has the authority to appoint note counsel. **********Moody's said that the remedy was well within the control of the offices of the Mayor and Comptroller and that it expected the matter to be resolved quickly. **********The city needs money from the note issue to finance continuing operations. A protracted delay would jeopardize the city's general-obligation bond rating of Baa-1.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/27/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   The Masses, Fashion and J. C. Penney
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/27/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   The Masses, Fashion and J. C. Penney
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/27/busin.body_text: **********THE name is J. C. Penney, but the advertising portrays a style-conscious retailer that is sort of a Saks Fifth Avenue for the masses. **********The new $10 million fall television campaign is the biggest ever for Penney. Created by Ayer, it is the first image campaign to emphasize the company's repositioning as a fashion department store. **********It is an abrupt about-face from the giant retailer's previous, workmanlike campaign that stressed the store's sale-priced items with only a nod to Penney's new style. **********The latest campaign, ''Fashion Comes to Life,'' shows fashionably dressed men and women living the kind of good life that is usually pictured in ads for Ralph Lauren or Bloomingdale's. **********One spot is an upscale urban montage: chic young women in funky hats and short skirts are shown clowning around at a hip diner; a painter takes Polaroid pictures of an Irish setter whose portrait she is about to paint; a couple is seen dancing at dawn in an empty restuarant. **********Another shows what appears to be ideal days for some young men. The smiling men - all outfitted in the latest style - are seen working out, playing with their children, goofing off at the office or having a heart-to-heart with dad. **********The five new 30-second television spots will be broadcast on Sept. 9, during network prime time in what is known in the advertising industry as a ''roadblock.'' That is when an advertiser will buy the same time slots on the three networks so its commercials will be seen by all their viewers simultaneously.
