The idea behind the rarely used technique is to broaden the reach of the advertising and make the introduction of the campaign an event. **********Some retail industry consultants said Penney's strategy was a wise move. During the last decade, the company stopped selling such items as washers, refrigerators, most electronic items and sporting goods. The stores, many of which have been redesigned, now primarily sell clothing and accessories. **********''The company has given itself a new identity,'' said Kurt Barnard, a consultant and the publisher of the Retail Marketing Report. ''Now that it has been transformed, J. C. Penney has to convince fashion-conscious shoppers that it is the savvy place to go.'' **********Because of the sluggish economy and the slump in retail sales, it is difficult to assess just how successful the company's changes have been, some industry consultants said. Retail sales for Penney were up only 5 percent in the first quarter of this year. The figures were disappointing, but Mr. Barnard said that ''if the company had not reinvented itself, the outlook would have been disastrous.'' **********Penney, which will spend about $400 million on advertising this year, has allocated more money to television ads because the company wants to reinforce the growing conception among consumers that the store has drastically changed, said Ronald L. Suhler, the director of marketing communications at Penney. **********''We haven't dropped off the edge in advertising,'' he said. ''We are just using a softer sell.'' **********Penney has also changed its uninspired print ads. For decades, the company has run print campaigns that showed a stiffly posed gaggle of models who sometimes looked like they were in danger of being crushed by the gigantic ''30 percent off'' sale headlines above them. The new ads feature elegant models lounging in beautifully decorated settings and the references to prices, when they are included, are small and discreetly placed. **********To reinforce its with-it image, the company is testing a fashion newsletter called Premiere that chronicles trends in men's and women's clothes. If the test is successful, the newsletter will be sent to the 29 million holders of the chain's credit cards. **********The company has also created a 90-second spot that will be shown to employees at its 1,400 stores during a closed-circuit broadcast by the company's chairman. The broadcast is part of an internal public relations and training campaign to educate employees about Penney's new fashion strategy and to teach them how to deal with more sophisticated customers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/22/busin.body_text: **********Crude oil prices climbed sharply yesterday, following big jumps for both heating oil and gasoline. **********Traders said a flurry of buying on Thursday afternoon carried over into early trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday, while concerns remained high about the tense Persian Gulf situation. **********Oil for delivery in November settled at $35.43, the first time that oil has sold for more than $35 a barrel since the start of trading in oil futures on the mercantile exchange in 1983. The close was $2.01 higher than the November settlement on Thursday, when the October contract expired with a rally in the closing minutes of trading. That contract ended at $34.71, up $1.53 a barrel from Wednesday's close, and the enthusiasm spilled over into yesterday's trading. **********Rush to Buy Contracts **********Rising prices for crude oil yesterday were driven by sharper increases for gasoline and heating oil, said Robert S. Jonke, an energy futures trader at Cargill Investor Services. When the price of a barrel of gasoline and heating oil yesterday morning rose well above the cost of buying a barrel of oil and refining it, traders rushed to buy oil contracts, he added. **********The price of heating oil for October delivery ended the day up by 5.35 cents, at 97.21 cents a gallon. That capped a series of large increases during the week that could mean higher bills for homeowners this winter. For the week, October heating oil was up 14.42 cents a gallon, or 17.4 percent. **********Gasoline for October delivery rose 5.91 cents a gallon, to 97.45 cents, The October contracts for oil products do not expire until next Friday. **********Anger and Investigations **********If heating oil prices stay near $1 a gallon, a homeowner who has spent $1,000 a winter on oil in recent years could end up spending $1,400 to $1,500 this winter, said a New York heating oil executive who insisted that he not be identified. The result would be angry consumers and possible government investigations, he added. But prices would likely fall, he said, if war did not break out in the Middle East. **********The price of heating oil usually overtakes the price of gasoline in the autumn, although the increase is usually spread out over the October and November contracts, said Thomas G. Burns, the manager of the economics staff at the San Francisco-based Chevron Corporation. This week's increase in heating oil prices ''is just a faster-than-normal movement toward that happening,'' he added. **********October gasoline was up 7.09 cents a gallon during the week, or 7.8 percent, while November oil climbed by $4.27 a barrel, or 13.7 percent, to its highest level in nine years. **********Heating oil stocks are fairly high in the United States, and the lack of additional storage capacity has tended to prevent companies and individuals from accumulating large stockpiles to use for speculative purposes. But the availability of extra storage in Europe has sent prices higher there and prompted some eastbound trans-Atlantic shipments of oil, pulling up prices in the United States this week, the New York heating oil executive said. **********'Flows Toward Highest Price' **********Such international movements of oil are common, and some heating oil was shipped from Europe to the United States last winter, when American prices were higher. ''Oil is international, and flows toward the highest price,'' the New York executive added. **********Virginia Wiater, an energy futures broker for United Energy Inc., a New York trading company, said oil and oil product markets remained preoccupied with how high prices might rise if a Mideast war broke out and many oilfields were destroyed. ''People feel at any moment the top may be blown off,'' she added. **********Traders are particularly nervous about repeated hawkish statements by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq and one of his ministers, Ms. Wiater said. The Iraqi leaders have threatened to fight a war with the United States lasting for years, and to destroy all Persian Gulf oilfields during such a war. **********Some traders expressed particular alarm about a World Bank estimate this week that oil prices could rise to $65 a barrel if fighting started. **********Disagreement on Contracts **********Some market participants have contended that at least part of the recent run-up in crude on the New York Mercantile Exchange has reflected the type of futures contracts traded there. But experts disagree on the effect. **********The contracts are for light, sweet crude, which consists of 10 grades of oil that are less dense and have a lower sulfur content than other grades, making them easier to refine. **********Iraq and Kuwait exported mostly light, sweet crude before the imposition of a United Nations trade embargo on Aug. 6, four days after Iraq invaded Kuwait. Other countries are producing mostly heavy, sour oil to make up for the shortfall, and some refineries are poorly equipped to handle this lower-quality oil. **********Ms. Wiater said a shortage of light, sweet crude was driving up prices. ''People are now beginning to see that, short term, we're going to have a problem,'' she said. **********Drop in Premium Cited **********But John H. Kingston, the managing editor of Platt's Oilgram Price Report, a daily New York newsletter, said high-grade oil could not be in especially short supply because the premium for the light, Louisiana sweet grade of oil, compared with the slightly heavier and more sour West Texas intermediate grade, had shrunk dramatically in the spot market over the last week. ''That number is absolutely a dead-on barometer'' of light, sweet crude supplies, he said. **********The recent increase in oil prices is based on emotion, not supplies of light, sweet crude, said Peter I. Cardillo, the director of commodities research at Jesup, Josephthal & Company, a New York brokerage. ''As far as fundamentals are concerned, there's no news to account for it,'' he added. ''It's pure speculation based on the Persian Gulf situation.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/12/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES; T.V.A. Plans Bond Offering
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/12/busin.body_text: **********The Tennessee Valley Authority plans to return to the public bond market before the end of next year with a new $1 billion financing, its chairman, Marvin Runyon, said yesterday in an interview on the Financial News Network. **********He said the financing would be used for maintenance of the T.V.A.'s power plants. It will be the third time in two years that the T.V.A. has come to the bond market with a large offering. The two previous offerings were refinancings, which were undertaken in 1989 and totaled $8 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/14/busin.main_headline: U.S., Despite Dispute, Will Go to Trade Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/14/busin.print_headline: U.S., Despite Dispute, Will Go to Trade Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/14/busin.body_text: **********As the first of a series of high-level meetings leading up to global trade talks was being held today, the Bush Administration sought to quash speculation that it planned to walk out of negotiations on liberalizing trade because of sharp differences with the European Community over agricultural protection. **********The assurances that the United States still plans to attend a crucial negotiating session in Brussels next month despite the split over farm trade came as President Bush met with Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti of Italy, who also holds the community's six-month chairmanship, and Jacques Delors, the president of the community's Executive Commission. **********At a White House departure ceremony after two hours of meetings, both Mr. Bush and Mr. Andreotti stressed the importance they attached to a successful conclusion of the trade talks, known as the Uruguay Round, for the country where the talks started four years ago.   'We Must Succeed' **********"We discussed at length our goals for the Uruguay Round and our strong conviction that we must succeed," Mr. Bush said, standing in a gray topcoat beside the Rose Garden. **********Mr. Andreotti, who was instrumental in breaking a recent deadlock within the community over farm trade, said there was a "will to reach a positive conclusion," and warned that if an accord was not reached, it would mean "serious damage in particular to developing countries." **********In Geneva today, thousands of angry European farmers, ringing cowbells and riding tractors, protested against reductions in the farm subsidies proposed in the talks. **********Today's Washington meeting was the first of those scheduled for the next 10 days in an effort to generate the political will for fostering an agreement in the 105-nation talks. The talks are aimed at setting new liberal rules not only for agriculture, but also for financial services, investments and intellectual property like patents and copyrights. They will move as well along the more traditional negotiating lines of global tariff-cutting. **********The Administration had been debating whether to walk out as a signal of displeasure with what was seen as a meager European farm trade offer. The proposal has angered not only Washington but other leading exporters of farm goods. Lately, however, European officials have been telling Washington that the offer is negotiable. **********European officials said they understood that Mr. Andreotti and Mr. Delors, both of whom are eager for the talks to succeed, made a similar point in their conversations with President Bush.  Seen by Dutch as Opening Bid **********On Friday, the Dutch trade minister, Yvonne van Rooy, told reporters after meeting with American trade officials that "it's not a final offer, but clearly an opening bid." **********The United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, said today that she would attend the Dec. 3-7 global trade meeting in Brussels. While attacking the European Community for what she termed its inadequate offer, she stressed at a news conference that "I want to leave no stone unturned." **********"I do not want to look back and say that if I had made one more flight, or attended one more meeting, or spent one more overnight maybe it could have come off," she added. **********Asked what Mr. Bush would tell Mr. Andreotti and Mr. Delors, Mrs. Hills said she expected the President to stress that "if we are to have a conclusion of the Uruguay Round, which affords the world such a fantastic opportunity for economic gain, for geopolitical harmony and for realizing the economic aspirations of the poorest nations, it won't happen unless the Europeans permit the negotiations to take place in the two areas that they see fit not to permit."  New Cuts of 15 Percent **********For the Uruguay Round, the Europeans have offered to cut internal farm income supports by 30 percent over 10 years, using 1986 as a starting date. Since 15 percent has already been cut since 1986, this would mean new reductions of 15 percent. **********The United States and the principal agricultural exporting nations have proposed cuts of 75 percent in farm income over 10 years beginning this year. But a group of exporters of farm goods and the United States are also insisting on action in two other sectors: opening the European farm market and sharp cuts in export subsidies. **********The Europeans are expected to spend $12 billion on such subsidies this year, in effect "buying market share abroad," as Mrs. Hills put it. The United States will spend about $280 million on export subsidies this year. **********Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who is the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said he was concerned about getting approval by Congress if an agreement comes out of the Brussels meeting. **********Mr. Bentsen, whose committee oversees trade matters in the Senate, warned that, hard as it might be to achieve, a Uruguay Round agreement would not be approved unless it "gives Americans greater access to markets abroad."   Backed by 37 Senators **********He said at a news conference that he was particularly worried that a resolution, now backed by 37 senators, could jeopardize passage in Congress of the accord, with its delicate balance of concessions from 105 nations. **********Under "fast track" authority, which expires next June 1, the Administration would present the entire package to Congress, and members would either vote for it or against it. This, Senator Bentsen said, was the only way such an agreement could win legislative approval. The resolution by the 37 senators would withhold the fast-track authority from the agreement.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/22/busin.main_headline: The Doughboy Gets A Streamlined Look
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/22/busin.print_headline: The Doughboy Gets A Streamlined Look
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/22/busin.body_text: **********Four years ago, with the roof about to cave in on his head, Jay Morgan still could not get his bosses at the Pillsbury Company to act. Mr. Morgan, who oversees the buildings that house Pillsbury's research and development staff, evacuated a pair of converted livery stables in the complex after an engineer's report confirmed his fears that they were in danger of collapsing. But until recently, he was unable to get authorization to raze the buildings. **********''It was a real source of frustration,'' he said. ''I've been trying to get rid of that building for 15 years. When Grand Met took over, they said, 'Go ahead.' They don't get paralyzed by analysis.'' **********Mr. Morgan is not the only Pillsbury employee whose outlook has brightened since Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. acquired the company for a generous $5.7 billion a little more than a year ago. The British conglomerate's commitment to cut bureaucracy, take risks and spend money to rebuild the food company has revived employee morale and generated enthusiasm among many Wall Street analysts and grocery retailers who stock Pillsbury's products, which include Green Giant vegetables, Poppin' Fresh Doughboy baking products and Totino's pizza. **********Grand Met's strategy is simple. It is returning to those basics abandoned by Pillsbury in the mid-1980's when the company, beset by takeover rumors, turmoil within the top management and earnings problems at its Burger King subsidiary, slashed spending on advertising, research and new product development to prop up earnings. Pillsbury lost market share for its brands. Since Grand Met's Ian Martin was installed as chairman and chief executive, the company has lopped off nearly $1 billion worth of Pillsbury businesses. It turned Haagen-Dazs and Burger King, previously units of Pillsbury, into free-standing operations. Pillsbury and Burger King now represent a large piece of Grand Met, nearly 40 percent of revenues. For the year ended September 30, 1989, Grand Met had sales of over $15 billion and after-tax profits of $836 million. **********To muster more cash for new product development and advertising for its biggest brands, Mr. Martin, who is also chief executive of Grand Met's food sector, cut Pillsbury's overhead. He saved an initial $30 million by hacking away 2,600 employees from Pillsbury's notoriously bloated work force and an additional $163 million in 1989 by streamlining operations and closing plants. In January, the company announced a $140 million plant modernization program that will further consolidate operations. **********As a result, this year Green Giant will be able to introduce 12 new products, while the bakery group will unveil nearly 20 - more than in the last three years combined. Some of them will capitalize on the growing appetite for healthy and nutritious products. **********Advertising spending on most brands will be up 30 percent to 50 percent, while expenditures on Green Giant will double. New television commercials are on the air, including one with the well-known doughboy, whom Pillsbury had let fade in recent years. **********Mr. Martin said the increased brand advertising has already translated into increased sales. While Grand Met does not break out figures for Pillsbury, he said that the company is meeting or exceeding the annual earnings increase of 15 percent targeted by the parent company. **********Still, some in the industry doubt that certain brands can be revived. For instance, Michael G. Spinozzi, a buyer at Jewel Food Stores Inc. in Chicago, says Pillsbury's plans to increase the advertising of its microwave cake mixes may be ''14 or 15 months late at this point.'' **********Though food industry analysts are generally encouraged by Grand Met's moves, some worry about the competition. New products are a key component of Mr. Martin's growth plans, but grocery warehouses in this country are already stuffed to the brim with more new products than consumers want. **********''They are saying the right things,'' said Michael Kennedy, an analyst with IDS Financial Services Inc., a division of the American Express Company here. ''The test will be whether they can execute.'' **********Ronald B. Morrow, an analyst with Smith, Barney Harris Upham & Company, agrees. ''Grand Met management is spending a lot of time, effort and money to get the Pillsbury business turned around,'' he said. ''They have repaired a lot of damage. But we haven't seen the results of it yet.'' **********Grand Met indeed acquired a troubled company. Because of its cash crunch, Pillsbury even lost its dominance in categories that it pioneered, like microwave cake mixes and popcorn. **********For instance, when Pillsbury was introducing its new mixes several years before the takeover, earnings problems at Burger King forced the company to divert money away from the profitable baked goods division. A bungled attempt to integrate the Jeno's pizza acquisition into Pillsbury's existing pizza business put additional pressure on the company's bread-and-butter brands. At the same time, Pillsbury's cross-town rival, General Mills Inc., was rolling out its own line of Betty Crocker microwave mixes. **********''We had limited funds available to defend some of these franchises,'' said Michael J. Paxton, president of bakery products for Pillsbury. **********Betty Crocker soon wrestled away the lead, a position it holds to this day. And the same thing happened in microwave popcorn: stronger competitors emerged and edged out Pillsbury. ''Morale was at an all-time low,'' said Mr. Paxton. **********The company's problems introducing new products were equally frustrating. Before the takeover, Pillsbury had failed twice in its attempts to introduce a new Funfetti frosting, which, with a separate package of decorative candy bits, was designed for birthday and other festive cakes. ''Twice, we pulled back because of insufficient funds or some technical issues,'' recalled Mr. Paxton. **********The frosting was finally released last August, a swift four months after Pillsbury decided to add a companion cake mix. **********Mr. Martin has since restructured the new product development cycle to accelerate the process companywide. He transferred product development experts out of the research and development area directly into the operating units to help speed up the process. ''If you're not careful, the train has passed before you've got your luggage on the platform,'' he said. **********Mr. Martin has forced a significant cultural change at Pillsbury as well. Pillsbury's bureaucracy was legendary, with its more than 3,000 separate forms to keep track of such things as who used which photocopier. **********Grand Met is far more willing than the cautious Pillsbury executives to take risks. Before the takeover, Pillsbury's general sales manager, Tony Scherber, had pushed management to dissolve a longstanding distribution arrangement with Kraft, under which it ''brokered'' Pillsbury's frozen dough products, that is, sold and maintained it on grocery shelves. The two companies were increasingly competing head-to-head in several related areas, and the arrangement was expensive, with Kraft's 7 percent commission crimping Pillsbury's margins. **********''Because of the risk associated with it, the previous management wasn't willing to take that step,'' Mr. Scherber said. ''Grand Met did it.'' **********The change involves increasing the size of Pillsbury's sales force to 800, from 500. ''In the sales organization, this is the biggest thing we have ever done in the history of the company,'' he said. **********The changes have been noticed externally. ''I sense an air of confidence at Pillsbury today,'' said Jeffrey Noddle, senior vice president for marketing with Super Valu Stores Inc., a food wholesaler in Eden Prairie, a suburb of Minneapolis. ''The company is leaner. There is a quicker reaction time.'' Grand Met has ambitious plans for Haagen-Dazs, which Mr. Martin refers to as the 'hidden jewel' of the Pillsbury acquistion. Plans call for the company to more than triple Haagen-Dazs sales, to $1 billion, in five years by undertaking a rapid global expansion. The company is also exploring the risky, but potentially lucrative business of selling fresh vegetables in the United States. And, Pillsbury's troubled pizza unit has aggressive growth plans that center on introducing a variety of pizza snacks and a premium-priced frozen pizza. **********Grand Met's vision has even won over George S. Pillsbury, the 68-year-old grandson of the company's founder who, as a board member, initially opposed Grand Met's bid before supporting a sweetened offer: ''They very definitely have done some things that needed to be done.'' **********POLISHING A 'RESTLESS' COMPANY IMAGE **********There is considerable historical irony in Grand Metropolitan P.L.C.'s attempt to revitalize the Pillsbury Company's wayward fortunes. **********In 1889, the owners of the C. A. Pillsbury & Company sold the Minneapolis flour milling company to a group of English investors. Lax management damaged Pillsbury's reputation, and the company floundered. In 1923, the Pillsbury family repurchased it and began the process of building a modern corporate food giant. **********When the company was again beset by problems in the 1980's, it was the British to the rescue. So far it appears that the current British owners of Pillsbury will have a good deal more success than their predecessors. **********In recent years, Grand Met, which began in the hotel business, has been concentrating on companies with products that it believes have worldwide appeal. Its holdings include Pearle Vision Centers and International Distillers and Vintners, the largest seller of wine and liquor in the world, whose brands include J & B scotch and Smirnoff vodka. Grand Met is now out of the hotel business. **********The company is spending a great deal of energy trying to improve the standing of one brand name in particular - its own. Grand Met's fast-paced management style, which its literature describes as ''restless,'' has made some investors nervous. **********They are worried about Grand Met's propensity ''to turn from buyers to sellers overnight,'' in the words of Martin Hawkins, an analyst with Kitcat & Aitken in London. The discomfort has hurt Grand Met's share price, which is currently trading at the equivalent of $9.54 on the London Stock Exchange. **********Grand Met has made several major acquisitions in the 80's, only to sell them quickly. It sold the Inter-Continental Hotels, after seven years, in 1988, and the William Hill betting shops, which they held for only a year, last year. The sales brought handsome profits, but the strategic reversals raised questions. **********Michelle Proud, an analyst with County Nat West Securities Ltd. in London, said the company's reputation is undeserved. ''It's hard to find a deal that Grand Met has done that's been bad for shareholders,'' she said. **********To try to find a more receptive audience, Grand Met is planning to be listed on the New York Stock Exchange next fall in the form of A.D.R.'s. Kitcat's Mr. Hawkins described Grand Met's shares as ''staggeringly cheap'' in comparison with American companies, based on earnings per share and other financial measures.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/15/busin.main_headline: Loss Posted In 2d Quarter At Columbia
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/15/busin.print_headline: Loss Posted In 2d Quarter At Columbia
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/15/busin.body_text: **********The Columbia Savings and Loan Association, whose financial troubles have been related primarily to the plummeting value of its ''junk bond'' portfolio, reported a loss in the second quarter because of other factors, including problem real estate, the institution said today. **********Columbia said it lost $136.5 million in the quarter ended June 30, in contrast to earnings of $6.4 million, or 16 cents a share, in the comparable period a year earlier. **********Columbia's deteriorating condition suggests that returning to health and escaping a seizure by the Government will be more difficult than the company had anticipated. **********Three months ago, Columbia reported a first-quarter loss of $293.3 million, but that was caused primarily by a $273.6 million drop in the market value of the institution's high-risk, high-yield bond portfolio. In the second quarter Columbia said there had not been a substantial change in the market value of its junk bonds, meaning its continued losses came mainly from other areas. **********The largest components in the loss were an $88.5 million provision for credit losses on investment securities and loans, and a $65 million loss from real estate investment operations, largely because of the declining commercial real estate market in Southern California. **********Edward G. Harshfield, Columbia's president and chief executive, said the company spent the second quarter identifying assets it would sell. In July, Columbia agreed to sell its junk bond portfolio to an investment group headed by the Gordon Investment Corporation and a Hong Kong businessman for $3 billion. **********Sale Planned **********That sale could could bolster Columbia's capital position by about $70 million. Mr. Harshfield said last month that the planned sale of the company's private equity securities could be enough to restore the savings and loan to a positive capital position. However, at the time of that statement, Columbia's stockholders' equity was at negative $215.6 million. **********Now stockholders' equity, which is an important measure of a company's financial health, has fallen an additional $135.6 million, to negative $352.2 million, making the climb back to health even steeper. **********Columbia executives did not return telephone calls asking for comment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/01/world.main_headline: To a Fading U.S. Bugle, Rhineland Sings a Dirge
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/01/world.print_headline: To a Fading U.S. Bugle, Rhineland Sings a Dirge
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/01/world.body_text: **********At 5 P.M. each day, life at the United States 8th Infantry Division headquarters comes to a brief standstill as the American flag is lowered for the night. **********Soldiers and civilians stop whatever they are doing and stand at attention as Old Glory is slowly brought down at Rose Barracks and a bugle sounds Retreat. The final notes echo through the twilight, rolling across the vineyards of the Nahe River valley toward the medieval town center. **********This ceremony may soon end. Since the Bush Administration proposed major troop reductions and base closings in January, it has been widely expected that the 8th Infantry Division would be one of the major units to be withdrawn from West Germany. Just the possibility of its departure is sending economic shock waves through this area's 40,000 people. **********Such tremors are being felt in many West German communities, but particularly in the state of Rhineland-Palatinate, known among some in the military as ''NATO's largest aircraft carrier'' because of the high concentration of American air bases there. #1 Out of 10 Could Close Defense Secretary Dick Cheney is already planning to close Zweibrucken Air Base, in the southwest corner of the state about 100 miles from Bad Kreuznach. Of the 800 American military installations great and small in West Germany, the commander of American forces in Europe, Gen. John R. Galvin, estimates that about 80 will be closed in the first round of reductions. **********Many here complain of the annoyances and hazards of having thousands of foreign troops living and training on West German soil. But United States military spending pumps about $8 billion annually into this country's economy. Scores of companies depend on the military for business, thousands of civilians rely on it for employment, and countless German families have boosted their incomes by renting housing to soldiers and their dependents. **********For those people, troop reductions will mean lower incomes, a loss of jobs and wrenching economic adjustment at a time when West Germany's Government and business sector are concentrating their resources on reunification and the enormous task of rebuilding East Germany's decrepit economy. **********The Bush Administration proposed the cutbacks in response to the political changes that have swept Eastern Europe in recent months. But those developments are small comfort to people like Katherina Gruneberg, 70 years old, who works at a snack stand just up the road from Rose Barracks and spent 21 years as an employee at the base commissary. **********'I Want Them to Stay' **********''I want them to stay, not to go,'' Mrs. Gruneberg said. ''They are still a great protection for us. The American soldiers are very nice young rascals. And they account for most of the business at this stand. **********''For Bad Kreuznach, it will be very bad economically, very damaging if they go,'' she continued. ''There is no big industry here, and I can't think of what they will do with the U.S. installations. They are so big only a large company could use them.'' **********The United States forces employ 33,000 civilians, the vast majority of them Germans. About 1,000 of them work for the 8th Infantry in Bad Kreuznach and at Dexheim, an outlying base. The gross payroll for these 1,000 civilians amounts to about $25 million a year, said Maj. Michael Maher, the 8th Division's spokesman. **********Money flows from the military in other ways. The 8th Infantry spends about $2.2 million a month in Bad Kreuznach on a variety of goods and services. In 1989, it awarded construction contracts totaling $6.35 million and spent about $225,000 more on transport contracts with local bus and trucking concerns. It paid $155,000 to local hospitals for services to military staff members and their dependents. **********The 8th Infantry is a mechanized division with about 21,000 officers and enlisted men. About 8,000 are stationed at the Rose Barracks headquarters, and the rest are spread over an area about the size of Rhode Island, with installations in Mainz, Wildflecken, Baumholder, Dexheim, Mannheim and Wiesbaden. **********No Decision Yet **********Major Maher said no decision had been made to move the 8th Division out, and that no such move was expected until a new agreement on limiting conventional forces in Europe is completed, perhaps late this year. **********Until then, it is business as usual. ''We're busy training,'' Major Maher said. **********When the troops are not training, they can part with their pay at the auto dealerships, insurance agents and fast-food restaurants that surround all big American bases in West Germany. Without the troops, these businesses would probably close. **********''All of our business is with the military. If they go, that would be it,'' said Veva Hepler, an insurance sales representative for American International Underwriters, which has an office next to a car dealership just up the hill from Rose Barracks' main gate. ''I guess it was bound to happen anyway.'' **********If the mood is one of resignation in Bad Kreuznach, it is more like disbelief in Zweibrucken, where the 17th Air Force is based. The Air Force is the town's largest employer, providing jobs for 20 percent of the 35,000 residents. **********Groping for New Job Skills **********''My skills and knowledge are all oriented to the military,'' said a civilian clerk in the unit's administration building. ''German businesses have different requirements. They want something else, and that will make it hard for me to get another job.'' **********Zweibrucken city officials said that the town's unemployment rate already stands at 14 percent, well above the national average of about 8 percent. If the Zweibrucken Air Base closes, as proposed, and the 8th Infantry leaves, the state government of Rhineland-Palatinate will face serious economic problems. **********The state government is considering industrial development projects that could at least ease the pain of a military departure. A ministerial working group is examining the potential problems. **********''We think we will have some problems finding jobs for the military workers,'' said Jurgen Dietzen, a spokeman for the state Interior Ministry. ''We want to know what these workers can do, and if there are similar civil jobs they can do.'' **********One proposal is to convert one of the six American air bases in Rhineland-Palatinate into a civilian airport to ease the severe air-traffic congestion at Frankfurt International Airport. But many West Germans working at the Zweibrucken base are skeptical that the lost jobs will be replaced. In their minds, troop cuts mean unemployment. **********''It's good for them because they save money,'' a mechanic working in the Zweibrucken motor pool said of the Americans. ''It's bad for me because I'll lose my job.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/27/busin.body_text: **********Under pressure because of a generic-drug scandal, the Bolar Pharmaceutical Company said on Wednesday that it would discontinue making 14 drugs and recall 4 other drugs. **********Bolar, once a leading manufacturer of low-priced generic drugs, has virtually halted manufacturing since Federal regulators charged that the company had acted fraudulently in gaining Federal approval for some of its most profitable products. **********The company's two top executives resigned in February, one day before securities regulators sued Bolar. The company's stock, which last year traded for $32.25, now lingers around $5 a share. **********Bolar said it recalled the four drugs Wednesday after determining that its manufacturing processes or test results did not meet the standards of the Food and Drug Administration. The drugs account for about 5 percent of the company's sales and 16 percent of pretax income, Bolar said. **********The other 14 drugs were discontinued for economic reasons, Bolar said. The discontinued drugs made up about 6 percent of 1989 net sales and 16 percent of pretax income, it said. **********Bolar also said it had settled on six months' severance pay for its former president, Robert Shulman, and former executive vice president, Jack Rivers, who resigned in February. Earlier the company said it would countinue paying the two executives for two years.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/31/busin.main_headline: Market Place;   Mutual Funds Are Resilient Despite Last Week's Plunge
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/31/busin.print_headline: Market Place;   Mutual Funds Are Resilient Despite Last Week's Plunge
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/31/busin.body_text: **********Mutual fund investors seem to have generally shrugged off last Monday's sharp break in the stock market, and cash continues to be drawn into stock funds, mutual fund executives said yesterday. **********But in what may be an indication of more nervousness about the American stock market, much of the money is pouring into international and global funds, which invest some or all of their money overseas. **********Over all, fund executives said, July saw cash flow into stock funds, but not at the rate of previous months. ''Sales are continuing steady, but they are off what they were in the first five months,'' said Hank Schmelzer, an executive at The New England, which sells funds through brokers and insurance agents. ''July was a little slower than June, and June was down substantially from May.'' **********In June, the Investment Company Institute, a trade group, reported yesterday, the total cash flow into stock funds came to $1.7 billion, down from $4.4 billion in May. Those figures include sales and redemptions, as well as transfers between different funds in the same group, but they do not include reinvested dividends. **********While some fund managers said it was too soon to assess the effects of last Monday, when the Dow Jones industrial average fell more than 100 points in early trading, only to stabilize and close 56.44 points down, others said the effect was small. ''It appears that investors did not take much notice,'' said Steven Norwitz, a spokesman for T. Rowe Price Associates, which sells fund shares directly to the public. For all of last week, he said, more cash was put into equity funds than was taken out. **********At Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., the effect of the fall was noted, but not for long. ''We had a very big redemption day, three or four times normal,'' said Robert Leo, the firm's director of mutual funds. ''But after that, sales returned to normal. It was a one-day aberration, and then we got back into a positive cash flow.'' **********At Fidelity Investments, Michael Hines, a vice president, said there was some cash outflow after the fall, but that by the end of the week there were also signs of ''bargain hunting,'' as investors hoped to buy stock funds before they went back up. **********Fund investors were severely shaken by the 1987 stock market crash, as cash poured out of the funds for more than a year afterward, even as the stock market recovered. But last October's mini-crash was quickly followed by buying from investors convinced that such falls created buying opportunities, and such buying may be happening now. **********Among stock funds, international funds have been the strongest in the last month, some managers said, in part reflecting the fact that many foreign markets did better than the American one in July. Mr. Norwitz of T. Rowe Price said that 57 percent of that company's equity fund sales came from its international funds in July, up from 40 percent for the entire first half of the year. **********In June, the Investment Company Institute said, international stock funds had a net cash inflow of $675 million, up from $622 million in May. **********Global funds, which invest in all markets, American as well as foreign, brought in an additional $79 million in June, down from $114 million in May. Mr. Hines said a new Fidelity global fund, the Worldwide Fund, has been ''phenomenally popular'' since it was introduced at the end of May. **********Several managers said sales of municipal bond funds had picked up in the last month, as talk of a tax increase rose in Washington. But in June, net cash flows into muni funds slowed to $992 million, from $1.8 billion in May. **********United States Treasury bond funds were reported by a couple of managers to be seeing a pickup in interest, too, perhaps reflecting the fact that long-term rates are now substantially higher than short-term ones. ''There is no question we have seen a pickup in our Government securities fund,'' said Ron Lynch, a managing partner at Lord Abbett & Company. **********If so, that pickup would represent a substantial turnaround. In June, the net cash flow out of Government funds was $719 million, a bit more than in May. Not since February 1988 has there been a net inflow into those funds. **********''Junk bond'' mutual funds, which had been dumped for much of the year, seem to have returned to investor favor as prices of many junk bonds have started to recover. Several fund managers said junk bond funds were now bringing in the most cash so far this year. The June figures showed a net cash inflow of $171 million, up from $57 million in May. During the previous 10 months, $6.3 billion was taken out of such funds. **********The professionals who manage stock funds had grown very cautious earlier this year, and they built up cash reserves by not investing the money that was being poured in by investors. At the end of April, managers had 12.5 percent of stock fund assets in short-term money- market instruments, called ''cash'' in the industry. That fell to 11.3 percent by the end of May, and to 10.9 percent at the end of June. **********The managers of aggressive-growth funds, which generally invest in smaller stocks, were among the most aggressive at investing money over that period, with the cash level falling from 13.5 percent at the end of April, to 10.6 percent at the end of June. **********The opposite trend was seen in precious-metals funds, where fund managers seem to have grown discouraged by the decline in gold prices earlier this year. Although there was a net cash inflow of $38 million into such funds, the managers chose to invest none of it and to raise cash by selling shares. As a result, the cash percentages in such funds rose to 10.3 percent in June, from 7.3 percent a month earlier.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/14/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Intergroup Move By Centaur Fails
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/14/busin.body_text: **********The Delaware Supreme Court ruled that the effort by Centaur Partners L.P. to expand the board of National Intergroup Inc. had failed. The parties said the court had upheld National Intergroup's position that Centaur's proposal to amend the company's bylaws to increase the size of the board to 15, an increase of three members, required approval of 80 percent of the outstanding shares. Centaur's solicitation fell short of the 80 percent vote, they said. **********National Intergroup said that as a result of the decision, three board seats would be up for election at the company's annual meeting on July 25. Centaur, a New York-based investment group, said it would try to elect its nominees to those seats.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/16/world.main_headline: WEST EUROPEANS FORMALLY INITIATE CLOSER FEDERATION
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/16/world.print_headline: WEST EUROPEANS FORMALLY INITIATE CLOSER FEDERATION
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/16/world.body_text: **********The European Community today formally started the process of turning its 12 member nations into a more unified political federation with common foreign and security policies and a single currency. **********At the same time, community leaders eased their economic sanctions against South Africa, affirmed a massive program of emergency aid for the Soviet Union and told Iraq once again that it must withdraw completely from Kuwait. Baghdad, they warned, bears responsibility for insuring peace in the Persian Gulf. **********Looking at its own affairs, the community opened negotiations among its members on redesigning its basic structures, an arduous task that is likely to take months and whose probable results are still unclear. 'A Rendezvous With History' **********"We really have today a rendezvous with history," said Jacques Delors, president of the European Commission, the community's executive body. **********The broad goal is to propel the bloc toward eventual political and monetary union, moving well beyond the unified economic market already scheduled for the end of 1992. But this new step may prove far more complex. The various countries have a wide range of opinions on how much sovereignty they are prepared to yield to centralized bodies in the name of a common voice on political, social, diplomatic and possibly defense matters. **********Nonetheless, all 12 agreed at a summit meeting here to get the process under way. Joining the movement was Britain's new Prime Minister, John Major, who made it plain that his country was still leery of a united Europe. But Mr. Major avoided the pugnacious style that ultimately caused his predecessor, Margaret Thatcher, to be isolated by the others.  [ Page 24. ] Advancing Monetary Union **********Mrs. Thatcher was abandoned by the other 11 in late October when they ignored her vociferous objections and pressed ahead with a 1994 deadline for creating a central bank that would lead eventually to a single European currency. **********How to advance this so-called economic and monetary union is the focus of one inter-governmental conference that got under way in Rome today and will probably continue well into next year. A parallel conference on "political union" also began, but it is expected to follow a thornier path, for it must consider how far to go toward centralizing policies on a kaleidoscope of sensitive issues from the environment to military control. **********In effect, Mr. Major decided that, while he shares many of Mrs. Thatcher's doubts about moving too fast toward a federal Europe, he would wage his battle from within instead of filling his predecessor's self-designated role as perennial outsider. Easing the New Leader In **********To help ease the new British Prime Minister into the fold, the other 11 avoided setting rigid guidelines for the conference on political union, which is charged with rewriting segments of the Treaty of Rome, which established the European Economic Community in 1957. **********Instead, the community leaders broadly listed topics for their negotiators to consider. That represents a soft approach that also satisfied countries other than Britain, since London is hardly alone in its reservations about giving up sovereignty to a central organization. **********France and Germany, for example, proposed last week that the community develop a regional foreign and security policy, but they have been cool to an Italian proposal that a basic building block be a largely dormant defense group called the Western European Union. **********Some members are convinced that joint security policies would lead inevitably to common military positions, a point that is particularly troublesome to neutral Ireland. In a joint statement, the 12 leaders said that a future defense role for the community ought to be considered, but as a conciliatory gesture to the Irish they added that the traditional positions of member states should not be undermined. Strengthen European Parliament **********The political conference was instructed to study the possibility of strengthening the basically powerless European Parliament, creating a European citizenship and dropping the present unanimity rule to allow a majority vote for decisions. Those favoring the rule change argue that no single country should be allowed to block important policies, especially if the community expands its membership. But Britain, for one, wants to keep the old rule and the protection it provides against being pushed into unwanted actions. **********Mr. Major pronounced himself satisifed with the final summit statement, saying that "we have a menu" for the conferences that began today and that "our favorite dishes are on that menu." **********Warming to the metaphor, Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti of Italy, whose country holds the community's rotating presidency, observed that in looking at a menu "you are in a state of grace." **********"The important thing," he said, "is that all 12 guests have sat down at the table." Central Government's Role **********Under the loose mandate from the summit meeting, conference negotiators were asked to look into possibility that individual nations could turn over to the community powers to set social, scientific and environmental policies. Immigrations, visas and the battle against organized crime and drugs were mentioned as specific areas that a central government might absorb. **********On South Africa, the summit leaders lifted a 1986 community ban on new investments there as an acknowledgment of recent reforms and as an inducement for Pretoria to dismantle the rest of its apartheid apparatus. In a joint statement, the leaders said that other sanctions would be eased if South Africa drops laws that prohibit blacks from buying land and living in certain areas. **********These would apply only to measures adopted in 1986, including bans on imports of South African iron, steel and gold coins. Mandatory United Nations sanctions that the community accepted in 1985 would remain in force in any event. These include prohibitions on arms deals with Preotria and restrictions on scientific and cultural agreements. **********The African National Congress, South Africa's main anti-apartheid group, was reported today to have urged the European Community and the United States to keep their sanctions intact. But the Italian Foreign Minister, Gianni De Michelis, argued that "it would be a mistake to lift the sanctions only at the end of the process, and it would also be a mistake to lift the sanctions only when the A.N.C. would have said, 'please.' " Soviet Food Crisis **********Turning to the Soviet Union's food crisis, the 12 community countries ratified their decision on Friday to give Moscow $1 billion in immediate emergency aid and to authorize perhaps $1.4 billion more in technical assistance in 1991 and 1992. The exact figures for the technical aid were left vague because the summit leaders said they wanted to see what the true needs were before committing themselves for 1992. **********In addition, they endorsed a Dutch proposal to try next ear to create a European energy network that would include the Soviet Union. This would amount to a mutual-benefit society, with Moscow receiving dollars and other hard currencies for its oil and natural-gas exports, and Western Europe getting a stable energy supply. **********Leaders of the 12 nations, which also include Belgium, Denmark, Greece, Luxembourg, Portugal and Spain, made a brief reference to the breakdown last week of a four-year-old round of talks to create a new world trade order under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. They expressed their regret, and expressed hope that negotiators would return to the table in January. **********But individually, some of them lashed out the United States for blaming the community for the collapse of the talks because of its inability to devise a common policy on government subsidies to farmers. Mr. Delors was especially angry and said that the fault lay with the Americans for having asked "too much too soon."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/10/world.main_headline: Reporter's Notebook; Upheaval in the East;   From a Harvest of Grief, Georgia Culls Its Pride
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/10/world.print_headline: Reporter's Notebook; Upheaval in the East;   From a Harvest of Grief, Georgia Culls Its Pride
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/10/world.body_text: **********The Georgian way of grief has always included wine and tears. **********Today, this ancient flow glistened with the modern images of videotapes. The tapes, the wine, the tears shaped a powerful new ceremony across the republic in behalf of 19 Georgian lives that are no more and a Georgian state that is not yet. **********This afternoon, all of Georgia could see on television at home a broadcast of the horrific images taped a year ago, when people in a crowd of gaily dancing and singing protesters supporting independence were suddenly beaten to the ground by Soviet troops attempting to enforce the central authority of Moscow. **********The event is undeniable on the tapes. Those outside Georgia have not grasped the critical nature of that moment, the mass emotional bonding that took place in Georgia's spirit, so long rebellious toward Moscow. **********''There was the last dance,'' said Maya Doksopulo, tremulously watching the screen in a friend's apartment as thousands of demonstrators of a year ago repeated their peaceful protest for independence. **********''They never realized what was coming,'' she said, as the tape cut away to a camera further down the road to show Soviet tanks slowly advancing four abreast, followed by phalanxes of troops brandishing their shovels like scimitars. **********A toast to the lives then lost was offered in the apartment by the hostess, Iamze Machavariani. Georgians once more drank to their dream of independence. **********''Near the end they sang a wonderful song,'' Mrs. Doksopulo said, watching the protesters amid their candlelight and music on television. She recited the lyrics: ''First there was a song and a human being was created for song, and then there was smile, and a human being was created for the smile.'' **********The Soviet troops continued marching across the television screens, finally using their shovels as the songs turned to screams. Georgians wept together in Miss Machavariani's apartment and across the republic. **********Manna vs. Mush **********Out in the street and beyond in the countryside, sunshine poured onto the weathered old porched houses tucked handsomely in vineyard hillsides and riverfront palisades. **********Pedestrians hugged wheels of fresh flat bread like wafers of the sun itself as they headed home through narrow streets from neighborhood bakeries. In the sunshine, a sense of nature's abundance seemed to vie with the memories of the deaths. **********At a cut-rate hotel on the outskirts of the city, busloads of Russian tourists arose, then lined up for the cafeteria fare of communism, a gray mingling of boiled sausage and mashed potatoes. **********Georgians out beyond the treelines that concealed the Russians' hotel brewed hot coffee and broke their fast with the loaves of crusty bread. **********Children Know the Words **********Up in the mountain village of Tskhenet, overlooking Tbilisi, more than a dozen 6- and 7-year-old children scrambled down the stairs of their orphanage to show off by the piano. As a teacher played, they did Georgian dances in miniature and offered a throaty chorus of the lyrics of Ilya Chavchavadze, the beloved Georgian poet: ''A new generation of Georgians will make something fresh of life.'' **********They are abandoned children, some of the 1,500 cared for by the Children's Fund of Georgia, a charity that is very uncharacteristic for the Soviet Union in the enterprise it has shown in raising money from overseas donors and generous Georgians. **********More than the endless polemics of the weekend of mass mourning, the Children's Fund hints at the de facto independence slowly moving across the republic. Officials boldly decided to cut the central Government out of its traditional 40 percent share of all charity contributions raised locally. This has allowed the children here greater benefits. **********This is a riskier step, in a way, than the Georgians' new iconoclasm, the tearing down of Lenin statues. A dozen or more of the major ones have been unceremoniously torn from their pedestals across the republic in the year since the troops killed the demonstrators. **********At some monuments, Lenin is now protected by the police. One Lenin is caged like a go-go dancer, his right hand extended behind a screen, his visionary stare clearly fading. His likeness has been boxed off from an angry public that had taken to peppering him with ink pots. **********Laughter's Longevity **********A man drank his red Georgian wine and, surfeited with cheese and bread and spicy beans and big red tomatoes, burst into song. **********''Lenin is always alive,'' he sang, extending the song's rhythm to make room for his mocking laughter. ''He is always with us,'' he sang, recalling the schoolboy song. **********The man ended fully in laughter, as if all the decades of communism in Georgia, with its documented deaths and still daily resentments, were winding down on a note of absurdity.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/25/busin.body_text: **********The Christmas shopping season, which concluded last night with a soft thud, held a number of surprises, but none were very jolly. **********In telephone interviews yesterday, merchants around the country generally expressed disappointment with the 32-day season, which began the day after Thanksgiving. Most said their business was flat, or about equal to their 1989 sales. Some said they had a small decline, and others reported a slight gain. **********But when merchandise inflation of 2 to 4 percent is excluded from their results, almost everyone interviewed had a real decline from the figures a year earlier. "The poorest Christmas season in years" was a common expression. **********Perhaps the biggest surprise, merchants said, was that retailers' predictions of a dismal season were not pessimistic enough. Many forecasts called for a 5 percent gain, but it is now expected that when all the numbers are in the industry will probably register a decline.   No 'Cliffhanger' **********Another surprise was that the much-hoped-for "cliffhanger" never developed. Increasingly, in the last few years, heavy consumer buying has come later and later in the holiday season. Many merchants this year hoped that a late surge would reverse the season's earlier sluggishness. Although stores were busy over the final weekend and yesterday, the sales were lower than expected. **********And a third surprise was that in some stores higher-priced goods outsold medium-priced items. "The customer has been clearly value-oriented," said Arthur Martinez, vice chairman of Saks Fifth Avenue, "but the irony is that the bigger-ticket, mostly designer goods sold well, while the real lag was in the more moderate-priced merchandise."   Dominated by Price-Cutting **********Both direct and indirect consumer concerns hampered sales. "Consumers are so bombarded with bad news, the economy, the deficit, the Mideast and so on that it's no wonder they bought less than last year," said Kenneth A. Macke, chairman and chief executive of the Dayton Hudson Corporation of Minneapolis. Price-cutting dominated the season's merchandising. Some of it was done by retailers trying to stimulate a season already in trouble. **********But also, in the big cities and their suburbs, hundreds of stores, run by more than a half-dozen highly leveraged or financially troubled retail chains, slashed prices to raise cash. This brought in many customers, but also caused others to wait for still lower prices elsewhere. **********"We'll show a gain over last year, but it's been a difficult season because we had to compete with the 'broke' competition," said William Dillard Sr., chairman of the Dillard Department Stores of Little Rock, Ark. **********Holiday business was also hampered by unseasonally warm weather in the East and South. This created a huge inventory buildup in cold-weather apparel. Such clothes are both a seasonal item and a holiday gift. This prompted Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's biggest retailer, to advance its usual post-Christmas sale to two weeks or so before Christmas. **********The 30-degree swing in the weather from a cold 1989 to a warm 1990 was also cited as a particular problem by Bloomingdale's in New York and Rich's in Atlanta.  K Mart Stocks 'Under Control' **********"We'll be flat to 1 percent ahead, despite the extra shopping day this season, unfortunately," said Joseph Antonini, chairman and chief executive of the K Mart Corporation, the nation's second-largest retailer after Sears. "I wish it were better," he added, "but we kept our stocks under control, so that we are $600 million less in inventory in our K Mart division." **********Mr. Macke of Dayton Hudson said: "The season was less than great. We think our same-stores will be flat. But our Target discount stores will be up 1 to 2 percent, our Mervyn's promotional apparel stores will be flat, and our Dayton Hudson department stores will be down by 1 to 2 percent. But all our inventories are surprisingly good." **********Bloomingdale's 15 stores will wind up with "a very small decrease over all -- and a couple of percentage points down in our same stores," said Julian Taub, senior vice president for planning. But costume jewelry, Christmas decorations and men's furnishings had a strong season. Still, Mr. Taub said, speaking with a light touch, "December was our second-best month of the winter; October was a better month with less of a drop."   Saks Margins Held Up **********Saks Fifth Avenue will be flat for the month, said Mr. Martinez, its vice chairman. But he added: "We operated with below-normal expenses so our margins held up. We should have a fine profit." He said that the markets in Boston and New York were the chain's hardest hit. Markets in Florida and Texas were strong while California's was satisfactory, he added. **********Roger Farah, chairman of Rich's, said he expected the department store chain to register a slight decline in December because of warm weather and the regional economic slump. But Wilbur A. Fix, chairman of Bon Marche in Seattle, said that despite "a kick in the pants from a 12-inch snowfall last week," in a city that is unaccustomed to snow, "our business picked up, so we expect a 5 percent increase in our same stores this month."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/13/world.main_headline: France Offers Troops to Stop Fighting in Lebanon
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/13/world.print_headline: France Offers Troops to Stop Fighting in Lebanon
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/13/world.body_text: **********France has offered to send troops to Lebanon's Christian enclave in an attempt to avert intervention by the Syrian army and stop fighting that has killed 450 people, Arab diplomats said today. **********The diplomats said the French Government had sent signals to Christian leaders about its readiness to dispatch military units to work as a peacekeeping force and disengage the fighting Christian factions, led by Gen. Michel Aoun and Samir Geagea. **********Mr. Geagea has welcomed the offer, the diplomats said, but General Aoun is said to believe that such a move would only increase outside meddling in Lebanon's internal affairs. **********For about two weeks, General Aoun, who commands a force of about 15,000 Lebanese Army regulars, has been battling with Mr. Geagea, who commands about 10,000 fighters of the Lebanese Forces militia, for control of the Christian enclave north of here. Neither side has been able to gain the upper hand in fierce battles involving tanks, heavy artillery and rockets. **********Msgr. Pablo Puente, the Papal Nuncio to Lebanon, is in the Vatican for consultations on alternative measures after the cease-fire he brokered last week between the Aoun and Geagea forces collapsed. **********A special French envoy, Bernard Kouchner, the Minister for Humanitarian Action, said before returning to Paris on Sunday that his pleas to the two Christian leaders to stop fighting had been to no avail. Mr. Geagea issued two appeals to President Francois Mitterrand last week for help. **********General Aoun has said he could not accept foreign troops on Lebanese soil, diplomats said, citing the general's campaign for total withdrawal of the Syrian forces that now control of two-thirds of Lebanese territory. **********The daily newspaper As Safir, published in mostly Muslim West Beirut, said today that it had learned from what it called unidentified reliable sources that France was planning to rush troops to the Christian enclave ''under the pretext of separating the combatants.'' **********It said the French Government and the Vatican would do all within their power to prevent intervention by the Syrian army in the Christian districts. **********As the reports about a possible French role circulated, news photographers and witnesses who visited the scene of a battle for the strategic town of Qlaiaat northeast of the capital reported that 20 tanks were destroyed and 70 combatants were killed on both sides in the 14-hour confrontation. **********General Aoun's army reportedly managed to advance less than two miles, and the town, between the districts of Al Matan and Kesrouan, is now reported to be split into two parts dominated by opposing fighters. **********''The two leaders are too far apart, and intermediaries have not been able to find a common denominator,'' the leading daily newspaper An Nahar reported today. **********The paper said General Aoun had insisted that a political accord be worked out before the military situation could be stabilized. Mr. Geagea, in turn, has refused to give in to the general's insistence that he publicly renounce a plan for Muslim-Christian reconciliation brokered by the Arab League. **********Before he departed for Rome on Friday, Monsignor Puente appealed to President Elias Hrawi to avoid military intervention in the Christian conflict. President Hrawi, like General Aoun and Mr. Geagea, is a Maronite Catholic. **********Speculation has been rife in the news media here that President Hrawi is seriously considering an offer from Syria to have its units cross into the Christian enclave in a bid to check the factional fighting. **********The Syrian President, Hafez al-Assad told Mr. Hrawi when they met in Damascus last month that he was placing the 40,000 Syrian troops in Lebanon at his disposal. **********Syria's daily Al Baath, in an editorial today that was quoted by Damascus radio and monitored here, reminded President Hrawi of President Assad's offer and urged him to act ''against renegade General Aoun, who is destroying his own Christian people.'' The newspaper speaks for the ruling Baath Arab Socialist Party, which is headed by Mr. Assad.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/22/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Buchwald Suit: Profit Study Set
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/22/busin.body_text: **********The judge in Art Buchwald's lawsuit against Paramount Pictures has named an entertainment accountant to look at the studio's books. **********Judge Harvey Schneider of Superior Court is trying to establish how much Paramount owes Mr. Buchwald and his producing partner for their script that ultimately became the huge Eddie Murphy film hit "Coming to America." **********Franklin Johnson, a managing partner of Price Waterhouse of Los Angeles, was chosen last week by the judge to help him make a determination. The judge previously ruled that Paramount had stolen Mr. Buchwald's idea and owed him a share of the profits. **********Paramount contends that the film, which has grossed about $300 million, has never shown a profit and that Mr. Buchwald and his partner, Alain Bernheim, are owed nothing. The two contend that they are owed $6.9 million to $14.6 million.
