https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/07/busin.main_headline: Trader Settles Anti-Fraud Charges With the S.E.C.
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/07/busin.print_headline: Trader Settles Anti-Fraud Charges With the S.E.C.
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/07/busin.body_text: **********Salim B. (Sandy) Lewis, a former leading Wall Street trader, settled Federal civil anti-fraud charges today that he had manipulated the price of a stock in 1986. Mr. Lewis was also barred from the securities business. **********In today's settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Lewis agreed to repay the Government $475,000, which the S.E.C. said represented ''partial recompense'' for the effect of his manipulation of the stock price of Fireman's Fund. Mr. Lewis agreed not to violate Federal securities laws in the future. **********Herbert F. Janick, an S.E.C. staff lawyer, cautioned that the consent was not official until it had been approved by the court, which is expected in a few days. **********In a statement, the lawyer for Mr. Lewis, Theodore V. Wells, said, he was unhappy with the terms of the settlement. **********''Although we believe no one was hurt by the trades in question and there were no financial losses by investors in the market place, the settlement was made to avoid lenghthy and costly litigation with the Government.,'' Mr. Wells said. **********Today's action represents the culmination of the Government's case against Mr. Lewis and his firm, S. B. Lewis & Company. Last summer, Mr. Lewis pleaded guilty to three criminal counts stemming from the same case. Mr. Lewis was sentenced to three years of probation and fined $250,000 According to the S.E.C.'s complaint, filed in Federal court in Manhattan, Mr. Lewis conspired with Boyd L. Jefferies, a prominent West Coast trader to cause Fireman's Fund stock to close at $38 a share on May 8, 1986. To reach that price, Mr. Jefferies purchased 410,000 Fireman's Fund shares just before the close of the market. According to the S.E.C., Mr. Lewis said that he would cover any loss that Mr. Jefferies suffered as a result of the trade. **********The American Express Company, a long-time client of Mr. Lewis, benefited from Mr. Lewis's actions because it sold a large portion of its Fireman's Fund holdings to the public on the next day. **********American Express has not been charged with any securities law violation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/08/world.main_headline: A Soviet Union Without a Communist Monopoly: The Academics' View
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/08/world.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;   A Soviet Union Without a Communist Monopoly: The Academics' View
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/08/world.body_text: **********Richard Pipes **********Professor of history **********Harvard University **********I believe this is a revolutionary decision which completely reverses Lenin's policy adopted in October 1917, calling for the ''dictatorship of the proletariat.'' Lenin understood this to be a complete monopoly by his party, not only of all political processes, but of all organized life in the country, the economy included. All other parties were to be barred from this process on the alleged grounds that they were either counterrevolutionary or did not express the true interests of the working class. Gorbachev seems to call for an abandonment of this policy. He is essentially jettisoning the Communist Party as the ruling organ in the country, casting it adrift and asking it to draw its strength from popular support, such as it can obtain. It is to compete with other parties for a role in the Soviet state. **********My impression is that the Communist Party would receive no more than 5 percent or 10 percent of the popular vote, which would mean that it would become a relatively small minority party in the political spectrum. I believe that in free elections, if such are to take place, the majority of the Russian voters would cast ballots for one of three new parties. One of these I would tentatively call a Social Democratic party, which might absorb a considerable portion of the present Communist Party membership. This party would combine appeals for democracy with a program of socialism, such as we know from England under Labor, or Sweden. The other party would presumably be what I would tentatively call Christian Democratic, which would probably combine democracy with appeals to free enterprise and a strong pro-Western platform. The third major party would be a Russian nationalist party, which would stand on a platform of Russia for Russians and assume a strong anti-Western stance. This sort of party would probably demand very powerful centralized authority of the state. And then in additon there would be nationalist parties in most of the border lands, which would either espouse separatism or demand extensive regional autonomy. And finally my impression is, from what Gorbachev said, that he plans to shift the base of his power from the party to the state and, I believe, to run for President. A model for this could be the recent events in Hungary and Poland, which I think he orchestrated. Then the question remains whether he would really win office in a democratic election, because he is not popular in the country and he gains support from the street primarily when he is assailing the entrenched Communists. Whether he would obtain the same kind of support to carry out a broader program on his own, I am not certain, because there are people who are more popular than he, in whom the citizenry has greater confidence. So, to conclude, this is a historic event, but given the country's lack of experience with democracy, and the existing internal tensions, the future is murky and unpredictable. **********Stephen F. Cohen **********Director of Russian studies **********Princeton University **********The abolition of Article 6 is a step forward, but it's not a decisive development. **********First, Article 6 only appeared in the Constitution in 1977, decades after Communist Party dictatorship was well established. **********The second reason is that there has been de facto multiparty politics in the Soviet Union for the last three years anyway - politics, though not a multiparty system. **********Third, even in a multiparty system the Communist Party is going to retain enormous advantages, much in the way for example that party machines dominated what were in effect various one-party cities and states in America for many years. **********Fourth, the focus of a Soviet multiparty system would be the thousands of local soviets - or councils, or local assemblies - all across the country. Though Gorbachev has promised to shift ''all power to the soviets,'' those soviets remain powerless, in the fullest sense of the word, without their own authority and even revenue. **********And fifth, more generally, dictatorships can be born in one night but durable multiparty democracies take a generation, if not more. **********Ellen Mickiewicz **********Professor of political science **********Emory University **********The Party Congress this spring will ratify the decision of the Central Committee plenum introducing a multiparty system. It has no choice; a number of parties have already come into existence. Besides, the Communist Party is facing rising defections in its ranks: large numbers of Communists, young and old, are turning in their party cards. Exposes of malfeasance, corruption, and incompetence are leading to ousters of party chieftains, as in Volgograd, where the main square was filled with people arguing, ''Down with everybody and everything.'' **********The Soviet party has to try to earn the leadership it can no longer take for granted. There isn't even a single Communist Party any more: the impetus for drastic political change has been generated for the most part by elements within the party itself. And the parties of the republics will be increasingly diverse. **********Can the Communist Party retain its leadership in a system with genuine competition? It has the edge in resources, media control, and organization, but that won't be enough, in my view. The move to a genuine parliamentary system is under way. **********Roman Szporluk **********Director of Russian studies center **********University of Michigan **********I believe that the renunciation of the party's monopoly of power literally means the end of Communism as a distinct current on the left. Lenin's most original contribution to Marxism was his concept of the party. Lenin made the right of the party to rule independent of an actual popular mandate. In Lenin's point of view, a majority vote was not enough to have the right to rule. What really mattered was to be right, and one was right by knowing what was good for the worker and what was good for the peasant without getting their formal approval through competitive elections. So the real, momentous significance of the declaration that the party requires the people's approval through elections in order to remain in power is that it is a repudiation of Leninism. It means that the party does not have a right to rule automatically, as the party. Such a declaration, coming from Moscow, is comprable in its importance for the Communists to a declaration, coming from the Pope in Rome, that there is no God. From now on, Soviet politics will increasingly become an ethnic politics, and people like Gorbachev and others will increasingly present themselves as Russian leaders. **********Zbigniew Brzezinski **********Former National security adviser, **********under President Carter **********Just as Khrushchev's secret speech before the 20th party congress in 1956 marked the beginning of the end of Stalinism, Gorbachev's reform at the just-concluded plenum marks the beginning of the formal break with Leninism. Gorbachev in effect is embracing the prescriptions of Lenin's old ideological rival, Martov, and his Mensheviks. It took years for the struggle against Stalinism to be successfully concluded. It will take years to dismantle the remnants of Leninism, but the battle has now been joined. **********However, it would be a mistake to see the recent decisions as marking a breakthrough to democracy. Much more likely is a prolonged period of democratizing chaos. One will see the rise in the Soviet Union of increasingly irreconcilable conflicts between varying national political and social aspirations, all united by a shared hatred for the existing Communist nomenklatura. One is also likely to see a flashback of a nationalist type among the Great Russians, fearful of the prospective breakup of the existing Great Russian empire. **********The recent developments are the consequence of the progressive polarization of the situation in the Soviet Union. Gorbachev has come to realize that zigzagging increasingly meant a stalemate, and he thus had a choice of either moving dramatically towards democracy or towards repression. He chose the former, because he knew that repression would mean political violence and social stagnation. But the depth of the existing economic crisis in the Soviet Union and the intensity of rising national apirations is such that the plunge towards democracy is likely to produce not an operating democracy, but a prolonged internal crisis, marked by turbulence, some chaos and fragmentation. Gorbachev nonetheless should be admired for his historical boldness. **********Adam Ulam **********Professor of history and political science **********Harvard University **********I think that the present change in a sense is more symbolical rather than realistic. We don't have currently parties in our sense of the word in the Soviet Union, but what we do have is that the Communist Party itself is split into many factions, and in a sense that poses a greater danger to the survival of the Soviet system than the appearance of other parties, I think. The threat of secession by various national republics from the Soviet Union is a much greater threat than the threat posed by the still theoretical possibility of another party. It's much smaller than the threat being actually posed by the threat of secession by the Baltic republics or other republics of the Soviet Union. Of course, on the face of it, it's a welcome change, but it also opens the way, to be realistic about it, to the rise let's say of a right-wing party, let us say which could combine, say ,intense Russian naitonalism, with the stress on russian, with what might be called elements of neo-Stalinism. So, like in any political situation, this kind of reform opens the door not only, from the democratic point of view, to favorable but also to somewhat dangerous developments.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/07/busin.main_headline: Patents;   New Cream To Combat Wrinkles
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/07/busin.print_headline: Patents;   New Cream To Combat Wrinkles
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/07/busin.body_text: **********The quest for relief from wrinkles, a hallmark of aging, goes on. This week, two medical researchers in Madison, Wis., patented a cream they said embodies a natural process for reclaiming skin damaged by sun and old age. **********The cream was developed by Michael R. Schinitsky, a pathologist, and Lorraine F. Meisner, an associate professor of human oncology at the University of Wisconsin. The cream's principal ingredient is something found in medicine cabinets everywhere, ascorbic acid, or vitamin C. Dr. Schinitsky said that ascorbic acid is known to stimulate the growth of fibroblast cells, which are central to the health of the skin, gums and other connective tissues in the body. The patent is based on using ascorbic acid in conjunction with zinc and tyrosine, an amino acid. The inventors say that together the substances help reverse the decline of the skin's fibroblast cells caused by aging and sun exposure. That would in turn reverse the process of wrinkling. **********''This provides nourishment to an area of the body that is undernourished,'' Dr. Schinitsky said. In informal tests, he said, the cream appeared to curb wrinkles after being used for about six weeks. The product has not been put through formal clinical trials, however, and the Food and Drug Administration has not approved any of the researchers' claims. **********Their discovery is not related to the widely reported research published this week about the possible anti-aging properties of human growth hormone. **********Dr. Schinitsky and Dr. Meisner obtained patent 4,938,969.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/15/world.main_headline: Drug Bosses Give Up Laboratories On Eve of Bush Visit to Colombia
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/15/world.print_headline: Drug Bosses Give Up Laboratories On Eve of Bush Visit to Colombia
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/15/world.body_text: **********With world attention focused on Colombia for President Bush's summit conference on drugs, the country's most prominent cocaine traffickers made a grab for the spotlight today by turning over to the authorities an enormous complex of cocaine-processing laboratories. **********The traffickers, who have been waging a war of press releases with the Government for the last month, said in a statement to news organizations that they were giving up the laboratory complex as yet another sign of their desire to quit the cocaine business and live in peace with their illicit fortunes. **********In Search of a New Image **********The traffickers, who United States officials suspect are being advised by professional public relations counselors, revealed the laboratory complex near the border with Panama to a group of more than 20 Colombian journalists who were secretly gathered and taken to the site. **********They left Medellin, the headquarters for one of the world's largest cocaine trafficking organizations, on Sunday and returned to tell their stories today as the traffickers were issuing their statement. **********The traffickers' gesture with the laboratory, which they said could produce 20 tons of cocaine a month or the equivalent of more than two-thirds of Colombia's estimated total production of 325 tons last year, came as President Virgilio Barco Vargas arrived at his secluded and heavily fortified weekend retreat here. In Cartagena, he will be joined by Mr. Bush, President Jaime Paz Zamora of Bolivia and President Alan Garcia of Peru. **********In their statement today, the traffickers identified themselves, as usual, as ''the Extraditables.'' The organization is believed to be made up traffickers who face extradition to the United States for narcotics offenses, mainly the leaders of the Medellin cocaine organization. One of their main objectives is to force the Government to stop extraditing traffickers. But that would be tantamount to amnesty because the traffickers have defeated all attempts to prosecute them in Colombia by killing and bribing judges and investigators. **********The national police emphasized again today that there had been no threats against President Bush and that they believe the risk to him and the other Presidents is minimal. Still, some 5,000 soldiers, policemen, marines and sailors have set up a defensive wall around Cartagena. **********Colombian officials have said that if there is any threat to President Bush it is from leftist guerrilla groups. On Tuesday, one group, the National Liberation Army, announced that in protest against Mr. Bush's visit it had kidnapped two Americans, David Kent, a teacher from Indianapolis, and James Donnelly, an employee of a company that maufactures water pumps and accessories. The police said that reports that one man had been released were inaccurate. **********After radio stations began broadcasting the traffickers' statement on the laboratory complex this morning, police units, accompanied by other reporters, set out for the jungle site near the town of Turbo on the Gulf of Uraba. **********President Barco and United States officials, who have scoffed at previous peace gestures from the traffickers since mid-January, again reacted skeptically. ''We don't think the offer is sincere,'' said Gen. Miguel Gomez Padilla, the national police commander. **********Many Colombians and some American experts on internatonal narcotics trafficking said the latest gesture seemed likely to increase public pressure on President Barco to enter negotiations with the traffickers. **********Terror Bombings Stop **********Colombians who follow the narcotics trade say they doubt that cocaine shipments to the United States would stop as a result of a Government settlement with the traffickers. But they believe that the traffickers would keep their promise to abandon violence. Since the traffickers' latest call for negotiations in mid-January, there have been no drug-related bombings or assassinations, the police say. **********When President Barco stepped up the campaign against the traffickers last August after the assassination of a presidential candidate they retaliated with scores of bombings that killed more than 200 people. **********Rensselaer W. Lee, an expert on international drug trafficking based in Washington, said, ''I think this is something that should be very, very carefully considered.'' **********He said he did not think discussions with the traffickers ''should be ruled out given the shape of Colombian public opinion in which a slight majority seems to support some kind of dialogue as a means of ending the violence.'' **********Mr. Barco says it is morally unacceptable to negotiate with people who are accused of killing scores of Colombians. **********For years, the drug traffickers have been getting their point of view across by sending statements to news organizations. **********A TV Reporter Invited **********One Colombian journalist who traveled to the laboratory site near Panama was Heiner Castenada, a correspondent for the nightly television news program Noticero de las Siete, or News at 7. Colleagues said the traffickers telephoned Mr. Castenada on Sunday morning and asked if he wanted to cover ''something big.'' **********He agreed, the colleagues reported, and was told to go to a certain street corner in Medellin with his crew and wait. Within a few minutes representatives of the traffickers turned up and took the crew to join other journalists and begin the trip to the laboratories. **********United States and Colombian officials said that while the laboratory complex may have had a capacity of 20 tons a month, it was not clear how much was actually being produced there. There are thought to be hundreds of laboratories in Colombia and the experts believe the traffickers shift chemicals and other supplies from one laboratory to another depending on their sense of risk at a particular place. **********The traffickers said in their statement that there were 15,000 drums of chemicals - acetone and ether - that are used in processing cocaine at the laboratory complex. The police noted that no processed cocaine was apparently left at the laboratory and cited this as evidence that the traffickrs were not giving up an active installation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/22/busin.body_text: **********It takes only one shout of, ''It's the Japanese; they're buying!'' in a Wall Street dealing room to throw traders into fits of nervous activity. It is easy to understand why. **********The Japanese buyers are a group of money managers at Tokyo's big banks and insurance companies who control the largest pools of investment funds in the world today, multibillion-dollar symbols of Japan's economic strength. **********Their buy or sell decisions can send financial markets gyrating in New York, London or Frankfurt. Every time the United States Treasury sells bonds to finance America's huge budget deficits, the anxious question in Washington and on Wall Street is whether the Japanese will buy. If they do not, interest rates are likely to rise. **********Widespread Influence **********While their influence is greatest in the stock and bond markets, these conservative Japanese money managers are also large investors in American real estate, Western works of art and even such American finance houses as Shearson Lehman Hutton and Paine Webber. **********These powerful money men have been called the ''gnomes of Tokyo,'' successors to the ''gnomes of Zurich,'' the Swiss bankers once believed to hold sway over world finance. Like those secretive Europeans, Tokyo's money managers are generally regarded on Wall Street with fear and envy because of their vast influence over the markets. **********But in interviews with the tiny group of managers who make the international investment decisions for two of Japan's largest financial institutions, the Nippon Life Insurance Company and the Mitsubishi Trust and Banking Corporation, these corporate bureaucrats did not speak of their power. Rather, they talked of how they felt hamstrung by the very size of the funds they control. **********''Bigness itself has become a problem,'' said Kozo Nogami, general manager of Nippon Life's international securities investments division. **********Mr. Nogami and his counterparts at Mitsubishi Trust described how they can move the tens of billions of dollars they have already invested overseas only in tiny increments, because a large move could destabilize the markets, create a panic and end up causing them losses. **********'It Would Be Suicide' **********That concern is a sober counterpoint to people in Japan who have advocated that the Japanese money managers consider dumping their Treasury bonds to punish the United States when it threatens protectionist actions. **********''Those remarks are ridiculous,'' Mr. Nogami said. ''It would be suicide because we would end up losing so much money.'' **********The risks are awesome. Nippon Life, the biggest insurer in the world, has $164.3 billion in assets, with more than $30 billion invested abroad. Mitsubishi Trust, the largest trust bank with $209 billion in total funds, has $14 billion in international investments. **********The money managers acknowledge that they are in the midst of a major shift in their international investment strategies. First, they are putting less money into bonds - largely American - and more into foreign stocks. Second, they are buying more West German stocks, because Germany is expected to benefit from the opening of Eastern Europe and the European Community's move to a single barrier-free market in 1992. **********Shinpei Ohashi, the 39-year-old chief manager of Mitsubishi Trust's treasury and securities division, said that as much as 20 percent of the new capital his group invests overseas goes to West Germany, compared with 5 percent a year ago. Similarly, Nippon Life will put more than half its new capital for overseas investment into West Germany. **********Cautious Newcomers **********Despite the vast sums they control, the money men themselves emerged in the interviews as a distinctively Japanese breed of cautious newcomers to the turbulent global markets, methodical and disciplined in their ways but disconcerted by the volatility of this new realm. **********The Japanese also provided a telling contrast to their Western counterparts. In the United States, the financial markets are regarded as a bastion of individualism, a place where hot-handed money managers can lay down huge bets and reap part of the rewards if they are successful. They are business stars, highly paid and mobile. **********The Tokyo managers are duty-bound bureaucrats in the traditional mold of the regimented Japanese ''salaryman.'' They are means by which the group expresses its will. **********For the Japanese, there is no fast track. They can move only slowly, by seniority, up the corporate ladder of prestige and pay, rather than being rewarded in proportion to the returns they earn with their portfolios. A 45-year-old section chief overseeing the investment of $10 billion or so might earn $100,000 a year, at the most, compared with many hundreds of thousands of dollars for a successful American fund manager, who could be nearly 20 years younger. **********Cadres of Generalists **********An American money manager may dart from firm to firm, selling his specialized skills to the highest bidder. The Tokyo managers typically remain in their assignments only three or four years before getting shuffled to another department. This method develops cadres of strong generalists, but not the kind of specialists that some Japanese executives acknowledge are necessary in an area as tricky as international investment. **********For instance, Makoto Toda, a chunky, amiable man who heads Nippon Life's international planning department, has a law degree from the University of Michigan and has built his career as an international expert. **********But several years ago, he was suddenly appointed head of a provincial branch 60 miles west of Tokyo, managing 800 housewifes who sold insurance door to door. (Insurance is sold almost exclusively by women in Japan.) The job, he noted tersely, ''was not at my request.'' **********Although the Japanese managers put safety above all else and think of the long term, they acknowledge that they have inadvertently become some of the globe's largest risk-takers. They have a conservative buy-and-hold strategy but because their overseas holdings are so huge, they run enromous risks that swings in currency rates will undermine the value of their portfolios. **********''We buy and hold and hope,'' said Shigeru Noma, a short, trim 38-year-old who heads the international stock department for Nippon Life. **********Overnight Losses **********Every night they go to bed with the prospect that if the dollar declines just one yen on currency markets while they sleep, they can suffer tens of millions of dollars in losses in their American investments before they sit down to their first cup of coffee. They have struggled without success to protect themselves from such swings. **********The declines, to be sure, remain paper losses unless the securities are sold. But the concern in Tokyo is that the swings make the value of the overseas portfolios highly unpredictable. **********For example, Japan's life insurance companies suffered combined paper losses on their foreign investments equivalent to an astounding $30 billion from 1985 through 1987 because the dollar lost about half its value against the yen. **********''We are running out of examples to follow because we are the first investor in world history to have $30 billion of currency risk,'' said Keiji Tsuda, a slight, intense man who has a degree from Duke University and heads Nippon Life's international bond portfolio. ''There may be a system for handling that, but nobody has found it yet. I think it's impossible.'' **********Too Big for Most Markets **********Another problem these investors face is that they are simply too big for most of the world's financial markets. Outside of New York, Frankfurt and London, the markets simply cannot absorb the capital the Japanese have to invest. **********''Even if we put all the time needed into researching these other markets, we just couldn't invest enough to make it worth our while,'' said Yuya Saijo, a confident 34-year-old who manages a slice of the $14 billion that the Mitsubishi Trust invests abroad. **********Mr. Tsuda added: ''We're like a big oil tanker. We can't change direction rapidly, and we can only work in the widest area of the sea.'' **********Nippon Life and Mitsubishi Trust are two primary repositories of the spectacular wealth that accumulated in Japan during the 1980's because of the country's huge trade surpluses. **********In addition to collecting premiums from policyholders, Nippon Life manages corporate pensions. Mitsubishi Trust takes deposits, manages assets for both individuals and corportions, and also oversees corporate pension plans. **********Largest Single Stock Owner **********Huge as their assets are, the official figures understate the real value. Nippon Life, for instance, is Japan's largest single stock owner, holding 3 percent of all shares on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. That stake is worth about $125 billion - about three times the value at which the shares are carried on the insurer's books. The books show what Nippon Life paid for the shares. **********It was hard to square the visions conjured up by the unprecedented wealth of these institutions with the scene in the large, open, conspicuously unadorned dealing rooms of Nippon Life and Mitsubishi Trust on several days recently. **********In typical Japanese fashion, the senior executives sat at large metal desks, all the same, at the head of parallel rows of other metal desks facing each other under fluorescent lights. They were occupied almost exclusively by men in blue suits, almost all of them young; it was hard to spot a face that looked more than 45 years old and most seemed in their 20's. Women, who generally dressed in identical company outfits, did clerical work and fetched tea. **********Japan's financial institutions are so new at international investing because during most of the postwar years the Government hoarded capital at home to rebuild and then modernize Japanese industry. **********Markets Awash With Surpluses **********Insurers and trust banks used most of their capital for making loans to industrial concerns. But with Japan's markets awash in surpluses during the 1980's, the Government liberalized its rules and the institutions began looking to foreign markets. **********The executives conceded that they had been remarkably naive in their first big moves overseas. **********''Theoretically, the logic was that we could reduce our overall risk by spreading out investments over many different countries,'' explained Tokuo Banba, chief manager of international investments for Mitsubishi Trust's pension fund division. ''But practically speaking, people just looked at the interest-rate differential and thought this was an easy way to get a higher return.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/15/world.main_headline: Brasilia Journal;   Brazil Gets the Picture: A Dynamo Is Taking Over
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/15/world.print_headline: Brasilia Journal;   Brazil Gets the Picture: A Dynamo Is Taking Over
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/15/world.body_text: **********In Japan, he limbered up with karate kicks. In Italy, he bounced a soccer ball on his forehead. And here in Brazil's capital he donned a T-shirt and set out for a well-documented jog. **********On Thursday morning, cameras will be clicking here again as Fernando Collor de Mello, Brazil's first freely elected President since 1960, is sworn into office. **********As Brazil's youngest President in history, the 40-year-old Mr. Collor inherits challenges the size of this giant land: 80 percent monthly inflation, billions of dollars of arrears on the foreign debt, glaring income inequalities and an entrenched state sector. **********Holding up a vision of Brasil Novo - New Brazil - the energetic President-elect is determined to turn his country around during his five-year term with wide-ranging free market changes: selling state companies, slashing the federal payroll, encouraging foreign investment and cracking down on tax cheats. **********Awaiting the Word **********A three-day national banking holiday started today to quiet markets in anticipation of far-reaching measures to be announced Friday to this nation of 145 million people. **********Over the last year, Brazil's old-school politicians consistently underrated Mr. Collor. His springboard to Brasilia was the governorship of Alagoas, Brazil's second smallest state. His party, the National Reconstruction Party, controls only 5 percent of Brazil's powerful Congress. **********But in recent weeks, Mr. Collor has steadily gained popular and political strength, largely through a fresh style, an astute use of the news industry and careful political footwork. **********''Collor is assuming the government with more support than when he was elected,'' Helio Jaguaribe, an independent political scientist, said in an interview on Tuesday. **********A poll made public today showed that Mr. Collor had won the ''confidence'' of 62 percent of respondents in Rio de Janeiro, an opposition stronghold that last December gave 64 percent of its vote to Luis Inacio da Silva, a Socialist candidate. In this two-man runoff, Mr. Collor won 53 percent of the vote nationwide. **********The Photo Opportunity **********A former journalist, Mr. Collor has shaken up Brazil's old-style politicians with his relentless pursuit of the photo opportunity. **********In the last month, Mr. Collor, a onetime karate champion, has transmitted a dynamic image by being photographed swimming, kayaking, riding a motorcyle, riding a motorized skateboard, and bucking motorboat waves on a jet ski. Or sometimes jogging with a ''Collor'' or a ''Save the Amazon Rain Forest'' T-shirt. **********''Brazilian presidents are usually older people with absolutely no athletic ability,'' said Herbert de Souza, a sociologist who supported Mr. da Silva. ''To see Collor in a kayak is news. He is systematically working the media and the polls.'' **********Mr. Collor also impressed Brazilians with a world tour that for three weeks in January and February produced a daily diet of photos of the President-elect meeting world leaders, including George Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev. After having Mr. Collor and his 25-year-old wife, Rosane, over to the White House for dinner, President Bush wrote an approving note to a friend, describing Brazil's President-elect as Indiana Jones. **********Delegations from about 100 nations are to attend the inauguration on Thursday, an unusually high number for a South American swearing-in ceremony. ''The foreign trip mobilized a large mass of public trust,'' Mr. Jaguaribe said. Indeed, international approval helped to confer legitimacy on a man who won a bitter, sharply polarized campaign. **********Long political negotiations, coupled with table-hopping by the President-elect at political dinners, has apparently culminated in a coveted congressional majority. **********Parties Rally to Him **********Today, a half-dozen center-right parties have closed ranks behind Mr. Collor. ''Coming from a party that practically doesn't exist, he has succeeded in getting a very reasonable base in Congress,'' Mr. Jaguaribe said. **********Always seeking to occupy the front page, Mr. Collor recently doled out Cabinet appointments, spacing them once every two or three days. **********One day he named as Secretary of Sports Zico, one of Brazil's most popular soccer players, whose formal name is Arthur Antunes Coimbra. Last week, he named Brazil's ''supercop,'' Romeu Tuma, to head Brazil's equivalent of the Internal Revenue Service. As director of Brazil's Federal Police, Mr. Tuma won international fame in 1985 when he announced the discovery in Sao Paulo of the skeleton of Josef Mengele, the Nazi death-camp doctor. **********In other unexpected choices, Mr. Collor named a 36-year-old economist, Zelia Cardoso de Mello, as Economy Minister, and the former president of the Supreme Electoral Tribunal, Francisco Rezek, as Foreign Minister. **********Some Dissenting Voices **********Not all Brazilians have been seduced by Mr. Collor. **********''In my 40 years of public life, I have never seen such a weak, inexpressive and unrepresentative Cabinet,'' said Leonel Brizola, a Rio de Janeiro Socialist who placed third in the November round of last year's presidential elections. **********''How can someone from the elite criticize the elite?'' asked Mr. da Silva, the Workers Party candidate, who won 47 percent of the vote in the runoff. **********On Thursday morning, Mr. Brizola and Mr. da Silva will be absent from the crowd of notables at inauguration ceremonies here. Instead, they will be advancing plans to forge a leftist opposition bloc. **********Under Brazil's electoral rules, the two are to get free air time this month on national network television. If the past is a guide, each will endeavor to snap the media spell that Mr. Collor has woven over his compatriots.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/11/busin.main_headline: Foreign Companies in U.S. Cited Again on Tax Record
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/11/busin.print_headline: Foreign Companies in U.S. Cited Again on Tax Record
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/11/busin.body_text: **********Congressional investigators and tax officials reported new evidence today that American subsidiaries of foreign automobile and electronics companies have been underpaying Federal income taxes, with at least $13 billion in back taxes now being sought by the Government. **********The disclosures have angered many on Capitol Hill, where legislators are seeking new sources of revenue to reduce the Federal budget deficit. **********''Before Congress acts to raise taxes on the average citizen in order to reduce the deficit, we should be sure that U.S. subsidiaries are paying their fair share of the current tax load,'' said Representative Richard T. Schulze of Pennsylvania, the ranking Republican on the House Ways and Means Committee's Subcommittee on Oversight. The avoidance of taxes by foreign-owned companies creates ''unfair competition'' for American businesses, he said. **********In 1987, the subcommittee staff found, eight foreign-owned electronics companies reported almost $14 billion in gross receipts in the United States, but paid no Federal income taxes. That is the last year for which data are available. **********Fred T. Goldberg Jr., the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, said that American subsidiaries of Japanese, West German, British and Canadian companies ''may be substantially understating their U.S. income-tax liability,'' through the manipulation of prices paid by the subsidiaries to their foreign parents. **********At a subcommittee hearing today, David A. Lowry, an Internal Revenue Service auditor from Jacksonville, Fla., testified that noncompliance with United States tax laws by American subsidiaries of Japanese car manufacturers ''has been evident for several years.'' **********In a nine-month investigation, the subcommittee staff examined 212 tax returns filed over 10 years by the American subsidiaries of 36 foreign companies. More than half paid ''little or no Federal income tax,'' the staff reported. **********The main reason, according to the staff, was that foreign-owned companies overstated the price of goods manufactured abroad and shipped to the United States, so that profits were transferred out of this country. In addition, the staff said, foreign-owned companies shifted income away from the United States ''through excessive freight, insurance, interest and other fees or charges.'' **********Mr. Lowry said that Japanese auto manufacturers sought to ''remove profits from the United States'' by charging their own subsidiaries more than the price charged for identical vehicles sold directly from Japan to American-owned companies. **********The calculation of prices in transactions between units of the same company has long been a thorny issue for tax lawyers and accountants, but Congress has paid much more attention to the question this year. Companies Challenging I.R.S.  Under Federal tax regulations, a parent company is supposed to charge its subsidiary the same price a buyer would pay an unrelated seller in the open market - the ''arm's length price.'' **********The I.R.S. told the subcommittee that it was trying to collect $13 billion of additional taxes in cases involving sales of manufactured goods by foreign companies to their American subsidiaries. Companies are challenging the proposed levies through administrative appeals and litigation. **********No corporate executives testified at the hearing today. The Organization for Fair Treatment of International Investment, which represents American subsidiaries of about 30 foreign companies, has acknowledged that I.R.S. data show low tax payments in the early 1980's. The organization says, however, that there were legitimate reasons, including the fact that many foreign-owned companies were just entering the American market in those years. **********Mr. Goldberg said that the data were ''certainly cause for concern.'' But he added that the statistics by themselves did not prove widespread violations by American subsidiaries of foreign companies. **********The subcommittee staff reviewed 106 Federal income tax returns filed by American subsidiaries of 18 foreign electronics companies in the last decade. ''On these returns,'' it said, ''the companies reported $116 billion in gross receipts and paid $654 million, or one-half of 1 percent, in Federal income tax. Over 10 years, only nine companies reported positive taxable income.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/06/busin.main_headline: Developers in China Hit Hard Times
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/06/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;   Developers in China Hit Hard Times
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/06/busin.body_text: **********After a five-year development binge that has dotted Beijing's perpetually hazy skyline with dozens of new office and hotel towers, the Chinese are suddenly learning that the flip side of a boom is a bust. **********With the chill in business and political ties between China and the West during the last year, offices designed especially for foreigners are lying vacant, rental rates are tumbling, loans for many building projects have had to be renegotiated and foreign residents are facing something they never imagined possible during the heady days of expansion - competition for their business. **********As more buildings open in the coming months, the situation, many people here say, will get worse. **********The excesses are in some ways a metaphor for the West's difficult business relationship with China during the past decade. The West's enthusiasm has tended to swing to extremes, and many foreign and Chinese developers are paying a price for the spurt of over-optimism. **********Harsh Austerity Campaign **********When the Chinese Government ended several years of fast growth, openness and economic reform in mid-1988 with a harsh austerity campaign to quell inflation, it was too late for many developers to turn back. Office buildings they had started earlier were already coming on the market. **********The Government's bloody suppression of the pro-democracy movement last year only intensified the existing trend and frightened off some foreign corporations, the prospective tenants for the new office space. **********Probably the best illustration of how bad things were before the building boom, and how things have changed, is the story of Shell China Ltd., a subsidiary of the Royal Dutch/ Shell Group, the world's second-largest oil company. Seven years ago, when Shell was shopping for office space, the best it could find was half of the sixth floor of the Hepingmen Roast Duck Restaurant building, about a mile south of Tiananmen Square in the center of the capital. **********'It Always Smelled of Duck' **********''All in all, it was quite adequate compared to the other choices, mostly hotels,'' said Christopher Evans, head of administration for Shell's 26-person staff here. ''The real problem was that it always smelled of duck; it was not inferior duck or anything like that, but it's the largest Peking duckery in the world, and so they were cooking them all the time.'' **********Shell moved several months ago to the new China World Trade Center, the largest office complex in the country, which includes two hotels, a convention center, apartments, a shopping complex and much better ventilation. **********''We like it because the telecommunications are a bit better than at the duck, and it's a better location,'' Mr. Evans said. An additional benefit, he said, is he can again enjoy ordering Peking duck at restaurants, something he could not bear while ensconced in the old quarters. **********As one of the premier new buildings in the capital, the China World Trade Center, with 550,000 square feet of space, was expected to be filled by now. But its managers are generally happy to have commitments for about 70 percent of the space, all taken by foreign companies. **********Rental Prices Fall **********The maximum rents being charged are about $3.25 a square foot - less than the top rate of $4.15 a square foot they had expected before China's military crushed the pro-democracy movement last summer. **********Yoshiaki Hashimoto, an administrative officer here for the Mitsubishi Corporation, said that after the turmoil in Tiananmen Square his negotiations with the World Trade Center's management took a decided turn for the better. The rent sought for the 26,000 square feet fell sharply. **********Although he would not give the exact figure, Mr. Hashimoto said Mitsubishi ended up paying about half what it was being charged at its previous site, the Capital Hotel, whose facilities he said were poor. Like many other foreign companies here, Mistubishi had moved into a hotel in the mid-1980's because it was the only space available. **********The granddaddy of hotel-office complexes here is the Jianguo Hotel - an exact replica of the Holiday Inn in Palo Alto, Calif. (The American investor in the joint venture to build the Jianguo Hotel was also an investor in the Holiday Inn and brought with him a set of plans.) It opened in 1982 and enjoyed close to 100 percent occupancy for years, drawing on tourists and companies taking rooms on long-term leases. **********Now it is feeling the squeeze, too. Over the last year the Jianguo has lost about half its long-term corporate tenants and the overall occupancy rate is barely 50 percent, said Peter J. Hierzi, deputy general manager. $2 a Square Foot Some offices in other new buildings built for foreign occupants are being let for $2 a square foot, down from a minimum of about $2.75 just 18 months ago, according to Richard Ellis Ltd., a real estate brokerage firm. That is still high for what many companies regard as a hardship post, but nearly 25 percent below the peak. **********Richard Ellis estimated that earlier this year there was 1.6 million square feet of office space suitable for foreign companies in Beijing, of which only 65 percent was occupied. The broker added that many new buildings have only let about 25 percent of their office space. **********Apartments designed for foreigners - with central air-conditioning and Western-style toilets - have the same problems. A 1,600-square-foot three-bedroom apartment at the World Trade Center complex, a joint venture between a Hong Kong company and a Chinese Government entity, is going for about $4,000 a month -compared with $6,000 a month for the same size unit at the Holiday Inn Lido complex, on the airport road. Those apartments, among the few modern apartments for foreign business executives when they opened in 1985, had been fully rented before they were even completed. **********Apartments Go Begging **********Even with the price drop, most new apartments have gone begging for tenants. According to Richard Ellis, which recently closed its Beijing office because of the slow market, only 75 percent of the 2,400 apartments built for foreigners in the last five years are leased. **********Another 1,270 apartments are scheduled to come on the market this year, with another 150 expected next year. Rents for a 1,600-square-foot apartment could tumble to $3,000 a month. **********Caught in the squeeze are a number of foreign property developers. But the blow has fallen hardest on Japanese companies, which were partners in 12 projects under construction as of early 1988, amounting to several hundred million dollars, according to a study done by the National Council for United States-China Trade. **********The lengthy list the council compiled gave evidence of how Chinese entities had leaped blindly into the development fray. Among the Chinese partners in these projects, many of which have been completed, were affiliates of the People's Liberation Army, the Ministry of Justice, the provincial government of Inner Mongolia, the State Farm Bureau and an aluminum factory.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/06/world.main_headline: Syrian Likens Invasion to Law of the Jungle
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/06/world.print_headline: THE IRAQI INVASION;   Syrian Likens Invasion to Law of the Jungle
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/06/world.body_text: **********President Hafez al-Assad of Syria, denouncing Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, was quoted today as saying Baghdad was following the law of the jungle. **********''If every country were to impose its illegitimate viewpoints through aggression and the use of force, the world would resemble a jungle,'' Iranian television quoted Mr. Assad as saying. **********The Iranian Foreign Minister, Ali Akbar Velayati, meeting Mr. Assad in Damascus, also criticized the invasion. **********''Ten years ago, when Iraq attacked Iran, we said that if no serious action were taken against the aggression, its dangerous consequences would affect other countries in the future,'' the television station, monitored by BBC, quoted Mr. Velayati as having said. **********Iraq and Iran began an eight-year war in 1980.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/01/busin.main_headline: Exchange Chairman Aims to Polish Image Of Futures Industry: LEO MELAMED, Chicago Merc
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/01/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE: FINANCIAL NEWSMAKERS OF 1989 - SIX WHO MADE THE HEADLINES IN AMERICA AND ABROAD;   Exchange Chairman Aims to Polish Image Of Futures Industry: LEO MELAMED, Chicago Merc
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/01/busin.body_text: **********In the world of commodity futures trading, Leo Melamed is widely considered to be the chief lobbyist, spokesman and public relations man - and an adept one at that. In 1990, Mr. Melamed, the chairman of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange's executive committee, will need all those qualities and others to restore his industry's tarnished image. **********The problem is the continuing investigation into trading abuse on the floor of the Merc and the Chicago Board of Trade. In addition to producing about 47 indictments and about half as many guilty pleas, the investigation has prompted lawmakers to consider tighter regulation of the futures business. **********That is something Mr. Melamed dreads, having championed the idea of ''self-regulation'' in futures and been a founding chairman of the National Futures Association, a self-regulatory group. **********This is not the first time Mr. Melamed has had to beat back attempts at tighter control. In 1987 the Merc was accused of contributing to the market crash but Mr. Melamed appeared before Congressional committees to give Chicago's version. It was his testimony, experts said, that partly led Congress not to impose a tighter lease on the industry. **********Around the time the indictments were made public, the Federal Government issued a report charging that both Chicago exchanges' systems for policing trading activity were lacking. It has thus fallen heavily on Mr. Melamed - a diminutive, black-haired man - to ease the concerns of those who have begun to question whether the futures markets can be trusted. **********He must do this while pursuing another important project, Globex, the Merc's computerized trading system that is already several months behind schedule. **********If his history is any guide, however, Mr. Melamed is almost certain not to shun a battle with critics. His background is filled with stories of personal struggle and extraordinary efforts to succeed. **********Born in Poland, Mr. Melamed moved with his parents to Chicago shortly before Pearl Harbor. Years later, to support his wife and child and pay his way through law school, he drove a cab. He borrowed $3,100 from his father to begin trading egg futures at what was then the Merc's predecessor. Striking it rich later in pork-belly futures, he organized the young Merc members who created committees to develop new contracts. **********Mr. Melamed's contribution to that effort: The creation of futures contracts based on foreign currencies and on the interest rate being paid on Eurodollars. That success, and others, has already earned Mr. Melamed a reputation as one of the driving forces behind financial futures.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/13/world.main_headline: World Bank May Grant Teheran First Loan Since 1979 Revolution
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/13/world.print_headline: MIDEAST TENSIONS;   World Bank May Grant Teheran First Loan Since 1979 Revolution
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/13/world.body_text: **********The World Bank is expected to lend as much as $300 million to Iran next year, in the bank's first loan to the Teheran Government since before the 1979 Islamic revolution, American officials and banking specialists said today. **********American officials said the Bush Administration hoped that the loan would offer it leverage to prevent Iran from violating the United Nations embargo imposed on Iraq after the invasion of Kuwait. The loan would be used to rebuild areas of Iran devastated by an earthquake last summer. **********''If Iran were suddenly to break the embargo on Iraq, then obviously we'd oppose any World Bank lending to Iran,'' an American official said. ''For now, we will not oppose it.'' **********Although the United States does not have veto power on World Bank loans, it could almost certainly round up enough Western support to block a loan to Iran. **********Banking specialists said Iran's request for the loan was an important signal of its intention to resume involvement in world financial markets, and of its desire to improve relations with the United States and other Western nations. **********For the first 10 years after the fall of the Shah in 1979, Iran did not seek international loans, fearing that borrowing from the West could pose a threat to the nation's independence. **********First Since Revolution **********Iran has made requests for loans from private Western banks in the last year. Banking experts said they understood that the earthquake relief loan would be the first major substantial loan to Iran under the Islamic Government from the International Monetary Fund or the World Bank, the two giant international lending agencies. **********Loans made by the World Bank, a Washington-based agency that is nominally part of the United Nations system and is formally known as the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, are largely underwritten by the United States and other Western nations. **********''There is great psychological significance in this,'' said Sharif Ghalib, director of the Africa and Middle East department of the Institute of International Finance, a Washington-based research organization. ''The loan itself is not as important as the signal it sends that Iran wishes return to a financial and technical relationship with the West.'' **********American officials and banking authorities said they understood that the loan would be approved by the World Bank later this year or early next year. It would be intended for housing reconstruction in a coastal area along the Caspian Sea, which was left in rubble after the June earthquake. Nearly 35,000 people are said to have died. **********Peter Riddleberger, a spokesman for the World Bank, said it had recently sent a delegation to Iran ''to investigate the feasibility of an earthquake reconstruction loan.'' **********''Some of the members of that team are back in town now and are assessing their findings,'' he said. ''It seems like things are moving along at a fairly normal pace and perhaps by the end of the year, there would be a proposal for a reconstruction loan.'' **********He said he could not predict whether the loan would eventually be approved by the bank's executive board. **********Loan decisions are based on a vote on World Bank member nations. The voting is weighted, and each member's share of the vote is roughly equivalent to its economic strength. The United States has about one-fifth of the vote. **********In international financial circles, Iran is seen as a relatively good credit risk, especially after the dramatic jump in the price of oil that followed the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in August. **********''Iran has a good history of making payments on its debt, even during the Iran-Iraq war,'' Mr. Ghalib said. **********Break From Khomeini Policies **********In a major break from the policies of the regime of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, who died in June 1989, the Iranian Government announced last year that it would begin borrowing abroad for development projects. **********Since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, the Bush Administraton has sent a number of conciliatory messages to Iran through diplomatic channels and has urged Iran to adhere to the economic and military sanctions imposed on Iraq by the United Nations. **********While the United States has little first-hand information about Iran's intentions regarding the sanctions, the Administration is hoping that Teheran's interest in obtaining Western aid to rebuild its economy will override any impulse to break the embargo. **********The Iranian Government has publicly vowed to support the sactions against the Iraqi Government of Saddam Hussein. **********''The World Bank loan could be another carrot to the Iranians, another sign from the United States that we want to improve relations with Teheran and that we want their help in isolating Saddam,'' an Administration official said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/01/busin.main_headline: Harvard Economist To Join World Bank
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/01/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Harvard Economist To Join World Bank
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/01/busin.body_text: **********Lawrence H. Summers, a Harvard professor and Keynesian economist who specializes in tax, labor and financial issues and who served as Michael S. Dukakis's chief economic adviser during his 1988 Presidential bid, is joining the World Bank as vice president and chief economist. **********The appointment has caused some sniping from Washington conservatives but was endorsed by the Bush Administration. **********Besides working with Mr. Dukakis, Mr. Summers, who is 35 years old, served as a domestic policy economist in the Council of Economic Advisers in the Reagan Administration and has been a consultant to the Labor and Treasury Departments. **********He will replace Stanley Fisher, an international economist who just returned to his tenured professorship at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. **********Mr. Summers, whose annual salary will be around $120,000 after taxes, was picked after a list of possibilities had been narrowed from 60 to 4 -- three Americans and a Briton, said a World Bank official yesterday who requested anonymity. **********Professor Summers holds the Nathaniel Ropes chair of political economy at Harvard. He has a Ph.D. from Harvard and joined the faculty in 1983, after a year as an associate professor of economics at M.I.T., where he had been an undergraduate. He will leave Harvard for two and a half years to serve the World Bank. **********Although he has worked with the Governments of Jamaica, Indonesia and Mexico on debt and other financial problems, he is known more as a domestic than international economist, fitting into a mainstream consensus that has believed that the United States needs a tax increase to reduce its budget deficit. **********In an interview yesterday, Professor Summers emphasized his position in mainsteam economics and elaborated on some of his views on taxation. He said he "recognizes that taxes have important adverse incentive effects, particularly on capital formation," but added that "taxes are the price of government services, and running budget deficits doesn't avoid pain, it only postpones it." **********Some conservative critics, led by Senator Bob Kasten Jr., Republican of Wisconsin, have questioned the appointment because of Mr. Summers's support for higher taxes and his alliance with Mr. Dukakis. An aide said yesterday that Mr. Kasten was "disappointed because Mr. Summers does not share the President's economic views and does not have a grounding in development economics." **********Although the World Bank is owned by 155 member governments, the United States, with about 20 percent of the agency's stock, has a big influence on its internal matters. An American has led the organization since its founding in 1945. **********He will join the World Bank on Jan. 14, after the current Harvard term. He and his wife, Victoria, a lawyer, have twin daughters.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/23/busin.main_headline: Professor at Harvard To Head Benckiser Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/23/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;   Professor at Harvard To Head Benckiser Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/23/busin.body_text: **********''This is a good chance to practice what I preach,'' said Thomas V. Bonoma, a Harvard Business School profesor who has written 17 books on marketing. Mr. Bonoma has been named president of Benckiser Consumer Products Inc., the maker of Electrasol dishwasher detergent and other household brands. **********Mr. Bonoma, 43, a full professor for the last five years, plans a two-year leave to take the post, with some admitted trepidation about falling on his face. It's somewhat unusual, he said, for a tenured professor to venture so far from academia. ''For those who believe that if you can't do, you teach, then it's incredibly unusual,'' he said yesterday. **********A senior executive might try academia in the later years of his career, he said, adding, ''It's a bit rarer to see an academic try line management, and rarer still to see an academic try line management in a C.E.O. position.'' **********Mr. Bonoma will take his new post in June. He will be responsible for the company's operations in the United States, Canada, Britain and Puerto Rico. **********The Benckiser Group, a private West German company, is adding to its American products. It is in the process of purchasing the United States and Canadian household products business from SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. for $106 million. The sale will add Calgon bath water additives, Cling-Free fabric softener and Delicare detergent to the Benckiser lineup. **********Mr. Bonoma said he became acquainted with Benckiser as a consultant for it. ''I've been working with these fellows since 1986,'' he said. ''We had discussions about the job before, but I didn't think the time was right for me. They kept asking, and I forgot to say no.'' **********He will be an executive vice president with the Benckiser Group as well as head of the consumer prducts unit, of which he has been a board member. Before now, the unit was run by an operating committee of the board, rather than by a chief executive. Mr. Bonoma was a member of the committee. **********Mr. Bonoma's business experience outside academia has been limited to consulting and family business interests - a coal-mining equipment company on his wife, Elaine's, side. The company, in the Pittsburgh area, has since been sold to interests in Scotland. **********Mr. Bonoma studied psychology at Ohio University, the University of Miami and the State University of New York at Albany, where he received his doctorate in social psychology in 1972. **********He switched to teaching business from psychology courses because, he said, the money was better and, besides: ''The work I used to do in psychology involved power, influence and negotiaiton. Marketing was not so far away from those kinds of issues.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/22/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;   Loss at Westwood One
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/22/busin.body_text: **********Westwood One Inc. reported on Tuesday that it lost more than $4 million in the fourth quarter on sharply higher revenues and operating income. The company, which owns two radio networks and several radio stations, attributed the loss to the heavy cost of recent investments, including the acquisition of a radio station here. For the quarter, the company lost $4.1 million, compared with a $1.3 million loss a year earlier. Revenues in the fourth quarter rose 49 percent, to $38.6 million from $26 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/17/busin.body_text: **********Pathe Communications Inc. paid an additional $53 million in cash yesterday toward its $1.3 billion merger with MGM/UA Communications. That brings Pathe's total cash commitment to $253 million. **********MGM/UA will distribute $4 a share to all MGM/UA common and preferred stockholders on July 20. **********It is still unclear how Pathe will come up with the balance of the financing for its merger, particularly since its agreement with Time Warner Inc., in which Time Warner would have lent Pathe $650 million of the purchase price, has fallen apart. **********Stock in MGM/UA rose 50 cents, to $18 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/25/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;   Papers Urged to Include Minorities
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/25/busin.body_text: **********The nation's newspaper publishers heard a blunt warning here today that they must change or risk becoming irrelevant. **********''You're a great electric company, but I live in an all-gas house,'' said Virginia Dodge Fielder, a vice president for Knight-Ridder Inc., paraphrasing what she has concluded is the attitude of a growing number of people toward newspapers. **********Hand-wringing about the gradual decline in newspaper readership, especially among the young and non-whites, is not new for the American Newspaper Publishers Association, which is holding its 104th annual convention. **********Focus on Readership **********In the last 20 years, daily newspaper circulation has been stagnant. The number of papers sold each day is now equal to about 64 percent of the number of households, compared with household penetration of 99 percent in 1970, according to a study by Lisa Donneson, a newspaper analyst at County NatWest Bank in New York. **********Improving household penetration has emerged as a top priority of newspaper publishers, now more than ever with advertising volume in a deep slump at most papers. Higher circulation is considered essential to retaining advertiser loyalty and charging higher ad rates. **********'Window Dressing' **********To reach new and occasional readers, many papers are trying to add special interest sections and install snappier graphics. But Ms. Fielder dismissed most of the changes as ''window dressing.'' **********Jeff Greenfield, a political and media analyst for ABC News who moderated the program on readership, said that a large part of the problem might be that the nation's papers are ''edited and owned by white, middle-aged men,'' who are essentially out of touch with those they are trying to reach. **********Some publishers agree that to attract greater numbers of women and members of minorities as readers, more women and minority workers must be in positions of authority to shape newspapers' content. 8% of Work Force But blacks, Hispanic people, Asian Americans and Native Americans constitute less than 8 percent of newsroom employees, and 54 percent of the nation's dailies have no minorities at all in their newsrooms, according to a recent survey by the American Society of Newspaper Editors. **********Gerald Garcia, the editor and publisher of The Knoxville (Tenn.) Journal and the chairman of the association's task force for minority hiring, said that publishers had tended to put diversificaton on the back burner whenever profits got tight. **********He said that with the current slow advertising climate, many papers might reduce their staffs. Hiring freezes, which he thinks likely at some papers, will shut out new minority employees, he said. **********On the other hand, at the convention of the National Association of Hispanic Journalists in San Francisco earlier this month, editors from a number of big newspapers were pursuing aggressive efforts to hire reporters and editors, as they often do at such meetings.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/20/world.main_headline: Iraqi Tankers' Loading Oil in Gulf May Signal Iranian Help in Breaking Embargo
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/20/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;   Iraqi Tankers' Loading Oil in Gulf May Signal Iranian Help in Breaking Embargo
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/20/world.body_text: **********Three Iraqi tankers have recently docked and taken on oil at an Iraqi pipeline terminal in the Persian Gulf, American officials said today, a move that may signal new efforts by President Saddam Hussein to export oil and to enlist Iran into breaking the global trade embargo against his Government. **********The development comes as the Director of Central Intelligence, William H. Webster, said that Mr. Hussein has managed to smuggle up to three million barrels of oil out of his country, either by truck or by ship, since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. **********No Sizable Leak Seen **********Mr. Webster, in an appearance in Manhattan on Tuesday evening, said the smuggled oil totals only 2 or 3 percent of Iraq's potential production during that period and does not represent a significant leak in the United Nations embargo. **********Before the economic sanctions against Iraq were imposed by the United Nations, Iraq and Kuwait were authorized by OPEC cartel agreements to ship a total of 4.6 million barrels of oil daily, but production for export has virtually ceased since the trade embargo began on Aug. 6. **********Fear Iran Transshipment **********The movement of the Iraqi tankers has raised concerns among Government analysts that the oil they take on is destined for Iran, where it could be moved onto Iranian tankers for sale on the world market. **********United States intelligence officials say they have recently detected a new push by Mr. Hussein to win Iran's help in breaking the embargo, said the officials, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. **********They said that Iran recently had discussed with Iraqi officials the possibility of linking the two nations' pipeline networks, a project the Central Intelligence Agency believes could be completed in about a month. Such a link could move up to 500,000 barrels of Iraqi oil into the Iranian system each day, C.I.A. analysts are said to believe. **********Iraq and Iran also have discussed an arrangement under which Iran would sell Iraq's oil on the world market in exchange for a share of the profits, one Administration official said today. **********Unloading at Kharg **********Officials say that the three oil-laden Iraqi tankers now anchored in the Persian Gulf could easily sail for Iran's main oil terminal, at nearby Kharg Island, where they would unload their oil for export through Iran's tanker facilities there. **********Those concerns are heightened by the fact that all four Iraqi tankers now off the Fao peninsula arrived there by a circuitous route, hugging the Iranian coast and avoiding international waters where they might be stopped and inspected by foreign warships. **********The United Nations resolution that authorizes military action to enforce the embargo, passed on Aug. 25, does not specify whether that authorization is limited to international waters, but instead ''invites'' member states to cooperate to insure compliance. **********A State Department official said tonight that the United States would not enter another nation's waters to enforce the embargo without first asking permission. It is not known whether Washington did so in the case of the Iraqi tankers. **********The route apparently was approved in advance by Iran. It worked for most of the tankers, but the last of the four, called Al Fao, was stopped by an American warship and inspected before it reached Iranian waters, a senior Pentagon official said today. The inspection found no contraband and the tanker was allowed to proceed. **********A Matter of Sanctuary **********That official and other Government experts said today that the coast-hugging gambit raises questions of whether Iran intends to help Iraq slip the naval blockade by giving its tankers sanctuary while they shuttle between Iraqi pipeline terminals and Iran's Kharg Island terminal. **********The tankers all anchored off Iraq's southern coast in the last three weeks. They are the first to load Iraqi crude oil since the invasion and the blockade that followed it. Al Fao tied up in the same area this week, but has yet to take on oil, United States officials said. **********On Tuesday, after an address to a private group in New York, Mr. Webster said that C.I.A. experts believe that the embargo has stopped 97 to 98 percent of the oil that left Iraq before the invasion. Iraq had been exporting 3.14 million barrels of oil daily. **********Most Going to Jordan **********Mr. Webster said the vast majority of the oil that has escaped the embargo has gone to Jordan in exchange for forgiveness of Jordanian debts to Iraq. Other Government officials said today that Jordan is receiving up to 45,000 barrels of oil a day from Iraq, all by truck - the same amount it received before the embargo. **********Jordan has told the United States that none of the oil is being re-exported, one official said today. **********By accepting the oil, Jordan is technically violating the United Nations trade ban, which orders member states to bar the import ''of all commodities and products originating in Iraq.'' **********The rest of the oil that is known to have escaped the embargo was shipped to Yemen shortly after the invasion and is sitting in the Iraqi tankers anchored off the Fao peninsula, officials said. **********U.S. Sharing Intelligence **********In a related matter, Mr. Webster said Tuesday that American intelligence agencies are distributing some of their reporting on the Kuwait crisis to allies around the world, but that they were not exchanging intelligence with the Soviet Union. **********He said the United States ''would be very happy if they'd share some things about their weapons and equipment'' sold to Iraq's military, but that the Soviets appeared unwilling to provide that sort of data. **********Today, Vladimir Kryuchkov, head of the Soviet intelligence service, the K.G.B., told The Associated Press in an interview that his agency would welcome an exchange of intelligence on Iraq. **********The C.I.A.'s spokesman, Mark Mansfield, said today that the agency does not comment on intelligence relationships with other nations. **********Mr. Webster has often said that the United States would not deal directly with the K.G.B. until the Soviet Union is proven to have abandoned its support of terrorism and instituted democratic reforms.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/16/busin.main_headline: Whittle Says Channel One Is on Target
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/16/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;   Whittle Says Channel One Is on Target
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/16/busin.body_text: **********Channel One, the daily news service for schoolchildren that has provoked intense criticism because it will include commercials, has signed up more than 2,500 schools and $200 million worth of advertising, Christopher Whittle, the chairman of Whittle Communications, said yesterday. **********Mr. Whittle said Channel One had met the targets he set a year ago, and he attacked critics and competitors who had predicted that Channel One would fail. The news service is scheduled to start in schools on March 5. **********Larry Gerbrandt, a vice president and senior analyst at Paul Kagan Associates, said it was too early to judge whether Channel One would be successful in the long run. **********'Jury Is Still Out' **********''He can make that claim only in that he's entering a brand new area,'' he said. ''I feel like the jury is still out on this. Schools are still not sure that they want to have this kind of programming. If he's met his own benchmarks, though, you have to give him his statement that he is successful.'' **********Whittle Communications, based in Knoxville, Tenn., offers schools free television sets, video equipment and satellite dishes in return for their carrying a 12-minute daily news program with two minutes of advertising. The program will be transmitted via satellite. **********Several educational groups have denounced bringing advertising into schools, and New York and California have banned the program. **********Mr. Whittle also faces competition from several cable television companies, primarily the Cable News Network, which is offering schools a free 15-minute news program without commercials. CNN, a unit of the Turner Broadcasting System, says that 7,000 schools, compared with Channel One's 2,500, have signed up for its ''CNN Newsroom'' program. **********Unlike Whittle, which is 50 percent owned by Time Warner Inc., CNN and other cable companies do not offer free equipment, and only schools in areas already wired for cable can use the programs. **********Mr. Whittle accused his competitors of making false claims that cable news programs reached 6,700 schools across the country. **********Disputed by CNN **********CNN issued a statement denying Mr. Whittle's accusations.
