''Today, just over 7,000 schools are enrolled to use 'CNN Newsroom' and based on our surveys, over one-half are actively using the program,'' Bert Carp, Turner Broadcasting's vice president for government affairs, said. **********Levi Strauss & Company, which had advertised in Whittle's pilot program, said yesterday that it had decided not to continue advertising because it found it more cost-efficient to place ads with its usual outlets, including MTV: Music Television, said Dan Chew, the clothing company's marketing manager.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/21/busin.main_headline: Bush's Warning to Iraq Spurs Gain by Dow
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/21/busin.print_headline: Bush's Warning to Iraq Spurs Gain by Dow
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/21/busin.body_text: **********President Bush's warning yesterday that he would hold the Iraqi Government responsible for the safety of American hostages being held in Kuwait and Iraq helped give the stock market its first lift since Wednesday. **********But in a sign that investors remained cautious, trading volume continued sluggish and buying turned selective. **********The Dow Jones industrial average of 30 blue-chip issues climbed by 11.64 points, to 2,656.44. **********But Peter G. Grennan, senior vice president of Lehman Brothers Inc., pointed out that only four stocks -I.B.M., Exxon, Texaco and Chevron -accounted for about 75 percent of the gain, with the three oil issues accounting for most of that. **********Stocks opened higher in Tokyo today, but drifted down in slow trading, and the initial gain was wiped out by late afternoon. The Nikkei average of 225 stocks closed at 26,297.84, down 192.63 points, or 0.73 percent. **********Volume Declines by 39% **********In the United States, trading activity sank to 129.6 million shares, down sharply from the abnormally high 212.6 million shares in Friday's ''double witching hour,'' when stock options, index options and index futures all expired. Declining issues outran advancing ones yesterday, 920 to 629, with 203 stocks falling to new lows. **********''Three hundred more stocks were down than up,'' Mr. Grennan remarked. ''It was a selective, blue-chip energy rally.'' **********Commenting on the President's strong remarks, Mr. Grennan said, ''The firmer he is, the better the market will like it.'' **********Asked why the market was up, Michael Metz, chief market analyst for Oppenheimer & Company, said: ''Is it up? Far more stocks are down than up.'' **********With many issues selling at depressed levels because of strong declines on Thursday and Friday, yesterday brought ''selective bargain hunting,'' Mr. Metz said, but ''an obvious low level of conviction.'' **********He pointed to the low trading volume and that ''few stocks participated in the advance - oils and a few leaders, like Wal-Mart, Bristol-Myers Squibb and I.B.M. **********''Investors and traders didn't have the courage to go for the secondary names,'' Mr. Metz continued. ''They chose to stick with the high-visibility brand-name companies.'' **********I.B.M., benefiting from a favorable mention in Barron's, rose by 7/8 in heavy trading, to 102 1/4, representing at least 10 percent of yesterday's rise in the Dow. **********Chevron surged by 1 3/8, to 80, its high point for the day. Texaco climbed by 1 3/4, to 65 5/8, its high point yesterday. And Exxon gained 5/8, to 52 3/4, only slightly off its high for the day. Together, the three accounted for about 65 percent of the Dow's rise. **********The rest of the Dow industrial stocks changed only slightly. USX, which has a large oil component, rose by 5/8, to 33 1/8, while Du Pont, which also owns a huge oil company, increased 1/4, to 37 5/8. **********Oil stocks may be rising, but prices in general may not follow. H. Erich Heinemann, chief economist at Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company, said, ''Some institutional investors are beginning to speculate that the impact of the 1990 oil shock on the general price level may be a lot smaller than many people originally assumed.'' **********The Federal Open Market Committee, which sets monetary policy, meets today amid speculation that the Federal Reserve will take little action to pump more money into the steadily weakening economy. **********''I think very little will happen,'' Mr. Heinemann said. ''The Fed will continue to hold short-term interest rates at approximately the present level. The result of this will be a further tightening of money supply.'' **********On a more positive note, he argued that ''you have the potential for a very large reduction in interest rates once the Middle East crisis is settled - assuming it's settled.'' **********Wal-Mart Rises to $28.25 **********Bristol-Myers Squibb, a market favorite that fell by 1 5/8 last week, gained 3/8, to 60. Wal-Mart, another market stalwart, which dropped by 1 7/8 last week, rose by 1/4, to 28 1/4. **********Fannie Mae, a quasi-Government agency that buys mortgages and then resells them and the only one among the 10 most active stocks to change as much as a point, fell by 1 1/8 yesterday, to 29 3/4, after sliding by 3 points last week. Freddie Mac, a Fannie Mae competitor, fell 3 1/8, to 59 1/4, after falling by 5 5/8 last week. Their weakness was thought to be related partly to Congressional sentiment to reduce their Government ties. **********Gitano, the apparel manufacturer, plunged by 4 7/8, to 19 3/8, also hitting a new low of 19 after Goldman, Sachs & Company downgraded the stock. **********In a broad decline among the high-technology issues, Compaq Computer fell by 2 3/8, to 47 3/4; Hewlett-Packard by 1/4, to 34 3/8; Digital Equipment by 5/8, to 66 3/8, and on the Nasdaq, Microsoft, the software producer, by 4 3/4, to 55 1/2. **********Despite the oil crisis, the Dow transportation index rose by 6.38, to 930.29, with most transportation stocks showing strength. UAL rose by 3, to 104 1/2, after The American Banker reported that Gerald Greenwald, head of a union effort to buy the airline company, would meet in Tokyo this week with several Japanese bankers. Union Pacific, which has important oil interests, also rose, by 2 7/8, to 73 3/8. **********Among other market averages, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose by 0.68 point, to 328.51. The Nasdaq composite index fell 4.90, to 388.59 after hitting a new low for the year of 388.31. The American Stock Exchange's market-value index fell by 2.32, to 331.29, after also reaching a new low for the year of 330.82.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/19/busin.main_headline: A Saudi Oil Windfall? If Prices Remain High and Fields Intact
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/19/busin.print_headline: A Saudi Oil Windfall? If Prices Remain High and Fields Intact
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/19/busin.body_text: **********Whether Saudi Arabia reaps a windfall from the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait depends on two big ifs - if its oilfields are undamaged by war and if oil prices stay high. **********If those conditions are met, the profit is likely to exceed even the substantial new commitments Saudi Arabia undertook after the invasion: subsidies of $1 billion a month to the United States and the Saudis' neighbors in the Persian Gulf that are supporting the United Nations embargo of Iraq; about $1 billion a month in extra operating expenses for the Saudi military, and the purchase of $7.3 billion in American weapons. Much of that equipment has already been sent to Saudi Arabia, although it is not clear exactly when payment will be made. **********Last week, with crude oil selling at $40 a barrel, the Saudis were thought to be able to earn as much as an additional $16 billion in the fourth quarter, which would more than cover those expenses. Oil has fallen in recent days to below $37 a barrel, and should it stay at that level the extra Saudi profits for the quarter might be closer to $14 billion. **********The real windfall could begin in 1991, if Persian Gulf tensions and oil prices remain high and the Saudi Government does not incur additional costs, said Edgard H. Habib, the senior director of the Middle East and Africa service at the WEFA Group, a large consulting firm in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa. ''What is critical in this situation is how long it lasts,'' he added. $65 Billion Extra Based on the rough-and-ready arithmetic of multiplying expanded Saudi oil production next year by nearly $37 a barrel - which is what Saudi Arabia actually receives when the world price is $40 - analysts estimate that the extra revenues could total as much as $65 billion over the next 12 months. Balanced against that would be continued monthly subsidies and military expenses, the proposed purchase of another $14 billion of American weapons for delivery over the next several years - which has drawn hostility in Congress -and a range of other expenses that are hard to estimate, like the accelerated development of oilfields. **********The estimates of additional annual oil revenues are highly conditional. They assume that Saudi oilfields will not be damaged by military action or sabotage, while tensions nonetheless keep oil prices high. Yet oil traders and analysts say the surge in crude oil prices after the Iraqi invasion reflected, in part, concerns that a Persian Gulf war would destroy some Saudi oilfields, which would limit the Saudi Government's ability to benefit from higher prices. **********If Saudi oilfields continue to produce at full capacity, oil prices may fall, said Fareed Mohamedi, an oil industry analyst at the Petroleum Finance Company. Contracts for delivery of oil next spring are trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange for $29 to $31 a barrel, meaning that the consensus of the market is that there will then be nearly adequate supplies and lower prices, he said. **********Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, Saudi Arabia's former oil minister, said recently that crude oil should drop to $15 to $18 a barrel when the Persian Gulf crisis was settled. Reimposing production quotas may be difficult then for the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. **********Long-Term Commitments **********Higher oil prices also represent a two-edged sword for Saudi rulers, producing extra revenues now but increasing the risk that Western nations will look harder for new sources of energy. ''They've got 120 years of reserves - it's not in their long-term interest to have oil-shale production, geothermal energy and other alternatives become economical,'' said Ronald J. Rizzuto, a finance professor at the University of Denver who specializes in the economics of the industry. **********Saudi Arabia has acquired several long-term commitments since the Iraqi invasion, the cost of which may dwarf any oil windfall that lasts only a few months, experts say. **********Countries that have sided with Saudi Arabia are likely to expect economic assistance, said David T. Mizrahi, the editor and publisher of the Mideast Report, a New York newsletter. Saudi officials hinted at such aid when the Soviet Union and Saudi Arabia established diplomatic relations on Sept. 17, he said. **********Some Aid Is Halted **********At the same time, Saudi Arabia has cut off its aid to Jordan and the Palestinian Liberation Organization in response to their support of Iraq. Jordan has lost $350 million a year, plus subsidized oil, while the P.L.O. has lost $80 million to $100 million a year. **********The biggest expense to the Saudis may be a permanently larger and better-equipped army. Prince Bandar bin Sultan, the Saudi Ambassador to the United States, said recently that his country had begun a review of the size of its armed forces. Iraq has a little more than twice the population of Saudi Arabia, but its regular army is nearly 10 times as big. **********Prince Bandar and the Saudi Embassy in Washington declined to comment on how extra oil revenues would affect Saudi Arabia. **********The country has relied more on diplomacy and lavish foreign aid and less on the size of its armed forces to maintain its independence for the last several decades. Since World War II, Saudi diplomacy has emphasized the kingdom's devotion to Islam and its defense of two of the religion's holiest cities, Mecca and Medina, in contrast to the secular Pan-Arab nationalism espoused by President Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt in the 1950's and 1960's and Saddam Hussein now. **********The Social Costs **********The average Saudi is unlikely to perceive any dramatic benefit from higher oil prices, said Sharif Ghalib, the director of the Africa and Middle East department at the Institute of International Finance, a Washington-based research organization supported by international banks. That is because the Saudi Government had planned to cover a projected deficit this year of $6.7 billion by selling bonds, but may instead keep the additional oil revenues. **********Estimates of Saudi Arabia's financial gains and losses as a result of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait also ignore the social costs to the kingdom of being unable to defend itself and forced to accept more than 100,000 foreign troops. **********The clearest beneficiaries of Iraq's invasion, although not in total dollars received, may be the oil exporters that do not border Kuwait or Iraq and are receiving higher prices for their oil. These countries include Algeria, Egypt, Indonesia, Mexico, Nigeria and Yemen. **********''For the countries that have high populations and low incomes, this is a fortune'' because they spent their previous oil revenues and ran up large foreign debts, said Marvin Zonis, a professor at the University of Chicago Graduate School of Business who studies Middle Eastern politics and business. ''The other countries are living and dying on these barrels,'' he said. Algeria has already said it will devote most of its extra oil revenues to the payment of overdue foreign debts. **********''When the creditors see these windfall gains, they will not say, 'Sow it in your economy and pay us later,' '' Mr. Habib said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/21/world.main_headline: Bulgaria's Former Leader to Face Charges
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/21/world.print_headline: Bulgaria's Former Leader to Face Charges
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/21/world.body_text: **********The former Communist leader, Todor Zhivkov, will face trial on charges of misappropriation of funds and abuse of power, Bulgaria's prosecutor general announced today. **********The 78-year-old Zhivkov ruled Bulgaria for 35 years but has been under house arrest since he was ousted last year by former colleagues. **********Prosecutor General Martin Gounev was quoted by BTA, the official press agency, as saying that Mr. Zhivkov would be tried for misappropriation of $3.7 million. Mr. Gounev gave no date for the trial, but said it would be held soon. **********Mr. Zhivkov's right-hand man, Milko Balev, is also to face trial for the misappropriation of funds, BTA reported. **********Mr. Zhivkov has admitted he made mistakes but has denied committing crimes. **********The announcement came as public pressure mounted on the government of Andrei Lukanov to resign. Mr. Lukanov's Socialist Party, successor to Mr. Zhivkov's Communist Party, won a majority in the June elections and holds 210 of the 400 seats in Parliament. **********But Mr. Lukanov has been unable to push his economic reform program, which includes steep price increases, through Parliament. The legislature is to vote on the controversial package on Thursday. Mr. Lukanov has said he would resign if it is not enacted. **********The opposition Union of Democratic Forces issued a statement today supporting a call by the trade union confederation Podkrepa for a general strike next week if Mr. Lukanov's Government does not resign before then.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/17/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Northeast Bancorp Merger Bid Ended
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/17/busin.body_text: **********After hinting for months that it was willing to forgo a previously announced merger with Northeast Bancorp of Shelton, Conn., the Bank of New York set terms yesterday for the merger that the Connecticut bank found unacceptable. **********According to Northeast Bancorp, its book value, or the difference between the value of its loans and securities and its liabilities such as deposits, was $33.53 a share on March 31. According to the Bank of New York, book value was only $12.31 a share at the end of 1989 if the loans are valued according to its standards. The difference over book value is crucial because the Bank of New York agreed in 1986 to pay Northeast shareholders two and a half times book value as of next Aug. 31.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/25/world.main_headline: Moscow Journal;   To Leninists, It Smells Like a Purge
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/25/world.print_headline: Moscow Journal;   To Leninists, It Smells Like a Purge
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/25/world.body_text: **********These are not easy times for the people charged with looking after Lenin's good name. His theories are falling into disrepute, his historic role is being re-examined and now, in a half dozen cities around the Soviet Union, his statues are being dismantled, not by bands of hooligans but by local city councils. **********Once the most common form of Soviet public sculpture, Lenin monuments have been toppled in towns and cities in the western Ukraine, the Baltic republics, Georgia and Moldavia in the last few months. **********In Nikolayev, near Odessa, the statue of Lenin was unceremoniously dumped in a warehouse of the local utilities department. In the Moldavian capital of Kishinev, the city council ordered a commission to examine whether the monument possessed enough intrinsic ''historical or cultural value'' to warrant a spot in the local museum. **********Even in an era of free and open criticism, such cavalier attitudes toward the founder of the Soviet state are too much for the Soviet Communist Party. At a specially called meeting last week, the party's Secretariat appealed for a ''decisive rebuff to manifestations of a disrespectful attitude toward works of art embodying heroic pages of the chronicle of the revolution, its battles and its labors.'' **********Insult to 'History Itself' **********It noted with disapproval that the local authorities had not only failed to prevent attacks on Lenin monuments but had in several cases even incited such actions, ''demonstrating disrepect not only for the Soviet state founder, but also for history itself.'' **********But history is a difficult business in the Soviet Union, as the keepers of the Central Lenin Museum in Moscow well know. It is only in the last few years that the museum has been able restore to its exhibits the names and faces of historical figures repressed during various epochs of the Soviet state. **********After 50 years of invisibility, Trotsky and Bukharin, the Bolshevik leaders who were among Stalin's most prominent victims, are back on the museum's walls, along with a giant painting of the second Communist International, two thirds of whose delegates were later killed at Moscow's orders. Until a year ago, the painting had been kept in the basement. **********''We had preserved all this material,'' said the museum's director, Olga S. Krivosheina, ''It was just that we could not show it.'' **********Putting Him Into 'Context' **********As history enters another cycle, the task of the museum is shifting again. Once dedicated entirely to Lenin (20 of the big red brick buildings's 34 exhibit halls describe his life and works), the idea now is to turn into it a museum of Lenin and his era. **********''Our main goal is to restore the context for Lenin's ideas,'' said Tatyana Koloskova, a senior researcher at the museum. ''All the arguments that were the backdrop for his theories disappeared with the people who made them. We have to restore the debate as it was.'' **********Her worry is that Russia will again going to try to blot out its past, as it did in 1917. ''Then, using a kind of vulgar Marxism, we tried to destroy our previous history,'' she said. ''Now there are some who are trying to do the same thing to the last 70 years. When I hear people at meetings cry, 'Let's try Lenin,' I say we have had enough trials in this century.'' **********But, she said, it is the Russian character to swing between extremes. ''Lenin, by the way,'' she said, ''warned against this.'' **********The Central Lenin Museum, which employs 250 people, including 50 guides and 22 researchers, is also about to undergo a change in its financing. The museum, which charges no admittance fee, has up to now been subsidized entirely by the Communist Party. Now that it is in the process of a divorce from the state, the party is taking a sharper look at its expenses, including the Lenin legacy. In the Russian republic alone, that legacy consists of 34 museums, 26 of which are places where Lenin worked or slept. **********Museum Attendance Drops **********Even before Lenin came under attack this summer, the number of visitors to the Central Museum off Red Square had dropped from 1.5 million to 1 million. Part of the decline is explained by the virtual disappearance of Eastern European visitors, who are now free to go elsewhere, and by a new apathy among Soviets, who are spending less time at museums, theaters and public spectacles in general. **********But there has also been a sharp decline in Lenin's public stature. Two years ago, it was popular among Soviet publicists to quote Lenin condemning Stalin. Since then Lenin's role has also been re-examined in the harsh light of Soviet history, as new articles are published on atrocities in the pre-Stalinist era. Like the Communist Party and the K.G.B., Lenin is no longer taboo. **********Mrs. Krivosheina, the museum's director, came to work there 21 years ago as an unabashed Lenin admirer, and her feelings have not changed since. But she is among the first to admit that the current debunking is in direct proportion to the idolatrization of Lenin in official Soviet propaganda over the last decades. For purists like her, the endless quotes from Lenin that once sprinkled the Soviet landscape were almost as painful as the blanket accusations now hurled against him at public meetings. **********''Before, they invented ways to dress him up,'' said Mrs. Krivosheina, whose office is free of Lenin memorabilia except for one modest statue on her desk. ''Now, they invent ways to dress him down.'' **********Like 'Blaming Christ' **********She argues that the attacks reflect the ''low cultural level'' of the critics. Historically, she said, it is as justified as blaming Christ for all the sins commmitted in the name of Christianity. **********''There are some forces that have appeared that want to do harm to our party, to socialism,'' she said. ''You read the papers, and every day a new party appears. Yesterday, I was reading about the monarchists who are waiting for the czar's relatives to come back. Now, it is unlikely that these people have good feelings about Lenin.'' **********A staunch party member, Mrs. Krivosheina still believes that Lenin is the role model the country needs. ''It is like a family where children must learn to respect their parents, '' she said. ''It is the same with history. People have to understand that history was made by their own grandfathers.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/12/world.main_headline: 40 Killed in Rebel Offensive in Colombia
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/12/world.print_headline: 40 Killed in Rebel Offensive in Colombia
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/12/world.body_text: **********About 40 people were killed in fighting between the army and leftist guerrillas as the rebels mounted their biggest offensive of the year, the local Governor's office said today. **********The army and the police drove back 1,000 members of two guerrilla groups who jointly attacked the adjacent towns of Taraza and Caceres in northern Colombia on Saturday, the official statement said. **********In Taraza, 250 miles north of Bogota, 500 rebels attacked an army base and the police station with mortar and automatic-weapons fire. **********Nine soldiers and 16 guerrillas died in the five-hour battle, which lasted until the rebels were driven back into the mountains, said the Governor's office in Antioquia state. **********Rebels also attacked the town of Caceres, killing a police officer, destroying the municipal building and damaging the police station. Rebels Pursued Into Mountains **********Troops and helicopters pursued the retreating guerrillas, who carried more than 10 dead and several wounded with them into the mountains late Saturday, the Governor's statement said. **********The authorities said the rebel offensive was carried out by the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia and the National Liberation Army. The attacks came days after the two guerrilla groups offered to initiate peace talks with the Government and released 22 police hostages as a good-will gesture. **********Among those killed in the battle in Taraza was the commander of the army base, Lieut. Col. Jaime Farjardo. **********Four rebels were killed late Saturday in another battle between the army and the National Liberation Army, a Defense Ministry statement said. **********President Cesar Gaviria Trujillo has conditioned talks on the guerrillas' laying down their arms. The rebels maintain that both sides should commit themselves to a cease-fire. Fragility of Order **********In a statement today, the Government said that "the possibility of peace talks is being driven farther into the distance" by the growing rebel attacks. **********Over the last 25 years, more than 75,000 people have died in rebel attacks. The April 19 Movement, or M-19, became the first of the country's six major rebel groups to transform itself into a political party when it laid down its arms in April. **********A leading newspaper, meanwhile, urged the Government today to resume its crackdown on Colombia's leading drug traffickers while a second major daily offered to let the cocaine cartel publish its views in its pages. **********The commentaries reflect the country's divided opinion on how Mr. Gaviria should deal with the traffickers. **********"President Gaviria and his Government now more than ever have the opportunity to exercise their authority," said an editorial in El Espectador, which advocates a tough policy. **********The Medellin drug cartel is accused of bombing the Bogota offices of El Espectador last year as part of a campaign to press the Government into calling off an anti-drug crackdown. It is also accused of assassinating El Espectador's publisher, Guillermo Cano, in 1986. **********The traffickers have been much friendlier to Juan Gomez Martinez, the publisher of El Colombiano in Medellin. **********In a letter published Sunday, Mr. Gomez Martinez offered "the pages of El Colombiano" to drug traffickers who want to denounce the authorities' violations of their human rights.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/29/busin.main_headline: Tool Orders Rose by 14% In December
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/29/busin.print_headline: Tool Orders Rose by 14% In December
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/29/busin.body_text: **********Reversing a three-month decline, orders for American-made machine tools jumped 14 percent in December. For the year, however, machine tool orders were down 21.7 percent from their level for 1988. **********Analysts have contended that a slowdown in orders from the automotive industry has been the principal factor in the declining level of new orders for machine tools, which are power-driven devices that cut or shape metal parts used in the manufacture of everything from appliances to vehicles. Because of declining auto sales, car makers have scaled back their purchases of new machine tools and manufacturing systems. **********Decline from 1988 **********In a monthly report to be released today, the Association for Manufacturing Technology said new orders in December climbed to $209.7 million, from $184.4 million in November. But it said the December orders were 34 percent lower than new orders in December 1988. **********Economists consider sales and orders of machines tools important indicators of capital spending patterns by makers of large products like automobiles and aircraft. Some analysts said the December increase reflected increased capital spending by many companies. But they also called the increase relatively insignificant. **********''Orders will slow down because there is a great deal of nervousness among manufacturers about whether there is going to be a recession,'' said James J. Paper, an analyst with Kirkpatrick, Pettis, Smith, Polian Inc. in Omaha. ''And fourth-quarter earnings for manufacturing companies are not the best, and that will also have an effect on new orders.'' **********For the year, machine tool orders stood at $2.81 billion, down from $3.59 billion in 1988. While the figures for the year are significantly higher than the $2.1 billion during the industry's slump in both 1986 and 1987, analysts predict that the level of new orders will decline to $2.3 billion to $2.5 billion this year. **********Slide in Foreign Orders **********The December figure included a 21 percent increase from November in domestic orders but a continued slide in orders from foreign customers. Foreign orders, which account for about a sixth of the total number of orders, were down 16 percent in December from November's level, and down 53.1 percent from the level of December 1988, when the dollar was weaker. **********For the entire year, domestic new orders were down 20.3 percent, while orders from foreign customers were down 30.1 percent, the association said. **********Machine tool shipments were up 22.6 percent in December over November, to $384.4 million. Shipments domestically were up 21 percent from November's level, while shipments to foreign customers were up 31.2 percent in Decmber. Shipments in December were up 31.4 percent from the level of December 1988. **********''We are pleased with the rise in shipments in 1989,'' said Albert W. Moore, president of the association. ''It's good to see exports rising, but we still have a long, long way to go. More exports are absolutely essential if United States manufacturers are to regain the strength they've lost in recent years.'' **********James A. Egbert, president of the Cross Company, a unit of Cross & Trecker Inc., a machine tool maker based in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., said he remained optimistic about business conditions despite the downturn in automotive orders. **********'Catch-Up' for Car Makers **********''I think the domestic auto companies are going to play catch-up with the Japanese and that will necessitate spending on modernization and purchasing new machine tools and machinery,'' Mr. Egbert said. **********December orders for metal-cutting tools, which include boring mills and lathes, were up 23 percent, to $158.8 million, from the November level. That category usually accounts for three-fourths of the industry's orders. December orders for metal-forming tools were down 8 percent from November's level, to $51 million. **********The backlog of machine tool orders stood at $1.8 billion, down from November's $1.97 billion. It was the lowest monthly total for the industry backlog in all of 1989. The level of cancellations of new orders soared to $179 million in 1989, from $131.1 million in 1988. For December, cancellations were down, to $13.2 million, from $14.9 million in November.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/12/busin.body_text: **********He was scheduled to give evidence on Monday in a liquidator's examination of a failed shipbuilding company, Lloyds Ships Holdings, a unit of his Quintex Australia Ltd. **********As the chairman of Qintex, the media and leisure conglomerate, Mr. Skase unsuccessfully tried to take over the MGM/UA Communications Company last year. **********Qintex Australia, with debts estimated at $1.3 billion, was placed in receivership last November, a few weeks after the MGM/UA deal collapsed. **********Mr. Skase's attorney told the court that his client was unable to appear because he was in Spain and had been threatened with dismissal if he left his job. The court has suppressed details of Mr. Skase's job and address.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/22/world.main_headline: U.S. Drug Agency Denies Role in Mexican Capture
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/22/world.print_headline: U.S. Drug Agency Denies Role in Mexican Capture
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/22/world.body_text: **********An investigation by the Drug Enforcement Administration has concluded that the agency's employees did not cross into Mexico and take part in the apprehension of a Mexican doctor who is charged with aiding in the killing of an American drug agent in 1985, Justice Department officials said today. **********They refused to say whether American officials may have played an indirect role in planning the abduction of the Mexican suspect, Dr. Humberto Alvarez Machain. **********But the Justice Department officials, who spoke on the condition that they not be named, said the Drug Enforcement Administration's inquiry had found no evidence that American drug agents had broken United States laws or violated Mexican national sovereignty in the capture. **********Dr. Alvarez has been charged with aiding in the torture and murder of Enrique Camarena Salazar, the American drug agent, who was abducted in February 1985 near the American consulate in Guadalajara, Mexico. **********Warnings From Mexico **********The capture of Dr. Alvarez has set off protests by the Mexican Government, which has warned that it will curtail drug-control operations with the United States if it is proved that American agents helped plan the abduction. **********Frank Shults, the drug agency's chief spokesman in Washington, said Justice Department officials were briefed within the last few days on the findings of the internal investigation. The Drug Enforcement Administration is part of the Justice Department and reports to Attorney General Dick Thornburgh. **********Mr. Shults would not discuss the specific findings of the inquiry, but said, ''We find no violation of Federal law, no violation of sovereignty, no improper behavior by the D.E.A. and nothing that even smells bad.'' **********At a court hearing this month in Los Angeles, Dr. Alvarez testified that one of his abductors in Mexico identified himself as an agent of the Drug Enforcement Administration. **********U.S. Credits Bounty Hunters **********The Justice Department has disputed his account, saying it appears that bounty hunters took Dr. Alvarez into custody in Mexico in hopes of collecting a reward offered by the United States Government for the capture of anyone involved in the murder. **********In a statement late Friday about the Alvarez case, Mr. Thornburgh said, ''It has been confirmed that no D.E.A. personnel were present when he was taken into custody in Mexico or when he was boarded onto an aircraft.'' **********''In addition, no D.E.A. personnel were aboard the aircraft that brought Dr. Alvarez Machain to the United States,'' Mr. Thornburgh said. **********The Attorney General ordered the inquiry after news reports last week in Mexico and the United States suggested that the Mexicans who captured Dr. Alvarez had been paid a bounty of as much as $100,000. **********U.S. Silent on Reward Money **********Officials at the drug agency and elsewhere within the Justice Department have refused to say whether any reward has been paid as a result of the arrest of Dr. Alvarez. **********A Justice Department prosecutor said in a court hearing on Thursday in Los Angeles that the bounty hunters had apparently responded to a reward offered by the United States Government for suspects in the Camarena murder. But he did not disclose how much money had been promised, or whether it would be paid in this case. **********The Drug Enforcement Administration has continued to deny that it offered a reward in Mexico for Dr. Alvarez. But it appears the agency may be playing a game of semantics. **********While insisting that the drug agency does not pay bounties and that there was no formal reward for Dr. Alvarez, Mr. Shults, the spokesman, acknowledged that the Drug Enforcement Administration ''pays for information and pays for evidence, like every other law-enforcement agency.'' **********Dr. Alvarez has been considered a central figure in the inquiry. American officials have said Dr. Alvarez injected Mr. Camarena with stimulants to prevent his heart from failing as he was interrogated and tortured by Mexican drug traffickers. Dr. Alvarez has denied any involvement in the killing.

The Two-Family House Is Revived in Jersey City
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/29/busin.print_headline:
Affordable Housing;

The Two-Family House Is Revived in Jersey City
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/29/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: The two-family house, a traditional form of affordable housing largely ignored by developers in the 1980's, is being revived in Jersey City, just across the Hudson River from lower Manhattan. Construction of a colony of such houses will begin next month on the 10-acre site of a former factory in the heart of the city's **********The two-family house, a traditional form of affordable housing largely ignored by developers in the 1980's, is being revived in Jersey City, just across the Hudson River from lower Manhattan. Construction of a colony of such houses will begin next month on the 10-acre site of a former factory in the heart of the city's Greenville section. **********The project, called Franklin Park, will contain 127 detached homes, each with a two-car garage and a lot of 2,500 square feet. It is being developed by the Franklin Building Corporation of Montclair, N.J., and Van Leer Container Inc. of Chicago, a subsidiary of Dutch Royal Packaging Inc. of the Netherlands. The project, which will be built in phases, is estimated to cost up to $38 million. **********Van Leer is the owner of the property and the last operator of the factory, which produced containers for shipping and storage. The factory on Danforth Avenue had been in operation for nearly 100 years until it shut its doors in 1987. A year later the building was razed, providing a rare vacant parcel in the primarily residential neighborhood about a mile from the waterfront in the southern half of this city of nearly 224,000. **********Franklin Park is good news for local officials and area homeowners who felt the old plant had become an anomaly because of the residential nature of the neighborhood. That, plus frequent complaints from residents over the vapors emitted by the factory helped lead to its closing, said C. Jack Smith, who is overseeing the project for Van Leer. **********Recognizing that the property could be adapted for housing, Van Leer joined with Franklin early in 1989 to develop the tract. The city rezoned the property last year from industrial/residential use to residential-only use. **********Robert Cotter, director of urban research and design for the city's Department of Housing and Economic Development, said Jersey City welcomed the project because it meets two important municipal goals: improving the neighborhood and producing much-needed housing that residents can afford. **********Two-family houses, with their income-producing apartments, are ''the key to home ownership'' for many people, Mr. Cotter said. **********A glut of condominiums on the market is another reason for building two-family homes, said Paul DeBellis, a partner at Franklin. ''The time is right to go back to the basics,'' he said, noting that ''the city was built on two- and three-family homes.'' **********Each of the homes, which were designed by Dassa/Richardi Architects, a subsidary of Franklin, will have either two or three apartments. **********In accordance with a city ordinance, the third unit, which can be created from 600 square feet of space behind the garage, may only be rented to someone related to the owner. Otherwise, it can be used for storage or extra living space. **********The developers are also planning to apply for tax abatement from the city. Under a 1989 New Jersey law, municipalities with urban enterprise zones, like Jersey City, can effectively cut taxes in half for five years for the owners of newly constructed homes, thus making the project more economical. **********For its part, the city must still draw up an ordinance to take advantage of the new law. Mr. Cotter said he expects it to be completed in the next few weeks and adopted before the end of the summer. **********To reclaim the property for housing, the developers had to comply with environmental regulations, including the state's 1983 Environmental Cleanup Responsibility Act, dealing with tests for toxic wastes. Mr. Smith of Van Leer said several oil tanks buried on the site have been removed, as have minimal amounts of copper, zinc and chromium. **********Providing adequate parking in so cramped a community as Jersey City was another concern. Martin Dassa, a partner at Franklin, said that the houses were pushed back 20 to 22 feet from the street, rather than the typical 5 feet. That yields enough space to park two cars on the driveway as well as build a two-car garage. The developers also agreed with the city's request to widen Lembeck Avenue, a side street, to provide additional parking. **********Franklin Park will join many other housing complexes either fully or partly completed in Jersey City in the last decade, aiding its transition from a gritty manufacturing center to a residential magnet for city dwellers. **********Among the developments are Society Hill at Jersey City, the 1,176-unit condominium community further down Danforth Avenue, and the 9,000-unit Newport project on the Hudson. Mr. Cotter said that between 2,000 and 5,000 residences will be produced in the city by 1995. **********Ground will be broken on the first 25 houses at Franklin Park, including two models, on July 10. They will contain two 1,200-square-foot apartments, each with two or three bedrooms. Mr. Dassa said there will be six traditionally styled models, with either brick or vinyl-siding exteriors, and all will have terraces and decks. **********Prices range from $279,900 to $319,000. Refinishing the space behind the garage to create a third apartment will cost about $6,000 more. **********''What we are providing here,'' said Mr. Dassa, ''are all of the amenities of suburban living in an urban setting.'' Franklin Park is one-quarter of a mile from Route 440, a retail strip, and 35 minutes by PATH train to Manhattan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/21/busin.body_text: **********The United States economy will worsen next year, the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development said today, but the group's economists said that thanks to robust growth in Germany and Japan, America's troubles would not drag the world into recession. **********Economists for the Paris-based organization predicted the American economy would show no growth in the second half of this year and would decline in the first half of 1991. A month ago, the organization forecast that the American economy would grow by six-tenths of 1 percent in the first half of next year. **********David Henderson, the O.E.C.D.'s chief economist said he thought the American economy would start to grow again sometime in 1991, with overall growth for the year falling under 1 percent, which would mean two consecutive years of growth under a slim 1 percent. **********The organization's economists projected that unemployment in the United States would rise to 6.4 percent next year and 6.7 percent in 1992, from 5.9 percent at present. **********The jump in oil prices was said to be an important factor in the slowing of the world economy since early 1989, but the organization added that the United States and many other nations were already slowing before Iraq invaded Kuwait in August. **********The O.E.C.D. consists of 24 wealthy industrial nations. It works to promote economic growth and cooperation. In its semiannual outlook, the O.E.C.D. forecast that the industrial world's economy would grow faster than the American economy, with the industrial nations registering 1.8 percent growth in the second half of 1990, 2.8 percent for all of 1990, and 2 percent next year.  No Pneumonia **********"It's popularly supposed that when the United States sneezes the rest of the world catches pneumonia," said Stephen Potter, a senior O.E.C.D economist. "We don't believe that is going on at the moment." **********Nonetheless, Britain, Sweden and Finland are expected to join the United States in experiencing recessions, although for different reasons. **********Mr. Potter said that continued strength in Germany's and Japan's economy "puts some kind of floor under" the world economy. According to the O.E.C.D., Japan's economy will grow at a robust 3.7 percent next year, after bounding ahead at a 6.1 percent rate this year. The O.E.C.D. said that thanks in part to German reunification, economic growth in western Germany would be 4.2 percent this year, its strongest since 1973, and 3 percent next year. **********The organization also said that inflation in Germany and Japan was lower than that in the United States. American inflation was expected to reached 4.2 percent this year and 4.9 percent next year, while Japanese inflation was projected to be 1.5 percent this year and 2.2 percent next year. In Germany, inflation is expected to rise from 3.4 percent this year to 4.3 percent next year. **********The report, entitled O.E.C.D. Economic Outlook No. 48, is available from the organization's Washington office.
