https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/06/busin.main_headline: S.E.C. Said to Review Trading by Simmons
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/06/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   S.E.C. Said to Review Trading by Simmons
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/06/busin.body_text: **********Harold C. Simmons, the Texas billionaire, said today that the Securities and Exchange Commission had begun an investigation into his trading in the stocks of the Lockheed Corporation and the Georgia Gulf Corporation. **********In separate filings at the commission, Mr. Simmons said that ''based upon information available,'' the agency was examining the adequacy of the information that he provided about his holdings in the companies. Such information is required under Federal securities laws. **********When investors buy more than 5 percent of a public company's securities, they must file a form 13-D, stating the purpose of the purchase. Thereafter, investors must file an amendment should they buy or sell 1 percent of the stock, or if their motives change. **********Active Trader **********During most of last year, Mr. Simmons controlled more than 5 percent of Lockheed and Georgia Gulf shares, and he was actively buying and selling their stock. **********In a telephone interview, Mr. Simmons characterized the S.E.C. investigation as routine, and he said it would not adversely affect his tender offer for Georgia Gulf or his Lockheed investment. **********Mr. Simmons controls 9.6 percent of Georgia Gulf and has begun a hostile $45-a-share cash tender offer for the company, a chemical maker based in Atlanta. **********He holds a 19 percent stake in Lockheed and said for the first time last week that he might seek control of its board. Lockheed, based in Calabasas, Calif., is an aerospace concern. **********At a meeting today, the Lockheed board supported the decision by the company's management to deny Mr. Simmons board representation. **********Lockheed Posts Loss **********LOS ANGELES, Feb. 5 (Special to The New York Times) - The Lockheed Corporation today reported a fourth-quarter loss of $109 million, compared with a profit of $104 million, or $1.75 a share, in the similar period of 1988. The loss was created after the military contractor subtracted $300 million from pretax earnings because of a miscalculation it made in bidding for a contract to develop an antisubmarine aircraft for the Navy. Lockheed disclosed the mistake in November. **********The company's quarterly sales increased 3 percent, to $3.03 billion, from $2.94 billion last year. **********For all of 1989, Lockheed earned $2 million, or 3 cents a share, compared with $624 million, or $10.37 a share, in 1988. The 1988 results included a gain of $202 million on the sale of Lockheed's Dialog Information Services unit. Sales for the year declined 5 percent, to $9.90 billion from $10.43 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/18/busin.body_text: **********Sweaters made in Taiwan of synthetic fibers are being sold in the United States at less than fair market value, the Commerce Department ruled today. **********The National Knitwear and **********Sportswear Association in New York filed complaints in September 1989 against sweater manufacturers in South Korea, Hong Kong and Taiwan. **********The department ruled against the manufacturers in Hong Kong on July 21 and against those in South Korea on Aug. 3. **********The findings clear the way for the International Trade Commission to determine whether sales of the products are harming American industry. If the commission finds they are, the Government can impose duties on the imports to make their prices comparable with those of products from United States companies. **********The department said that imports represented 72 percent of the $1.3 billion American market and that the three countries supplied 55 percent of the imports. It said the value of sweaters imported from South Korea in 1989 was $476.1 million; from Hong Kong, $208.8 million, and Taiwan, $485.5 million. **********The department said the imports are made predominantly of acrylic fiber. Sweaters with at least 23 percent wool are excluded.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/28/busin.body_text: **********Sales of existing homes rose 3.3 percent in July, the second straight monthly increase, as mortgage rates dropped into the single digits, a real estate trade group reported today. **********The group, the National Association of Realtors, said house resales totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.44 million units, compared with 3.33 million in June. The gain in sales in June - nine-tenths of a percent - was the first advance in seven months. **********Fixed-rate, 30-year mortgages fell to 9.8 percent in July from 10.06 percent, according to surveys by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. But they moved up again after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 and reached 10.29 percent by Friday. **********The national median existing-home price was $98,400 in July, up nine-tenths of 1 percent from June. The median price means half of the homes cost more, and half less. **********Sales increases were posted in the Northeast and South. The Northeast had a 14.3 percent rise, to 560,000 units, and the South gained 6.9 percent, to 1.4 million units. **********Sales fell 10.3 percent, to 520,000 units, in the West, and declined 3.1 percent in the Midwest, to 930,000 units.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/24/busin.body_text: **********The Bankers Trust New York Corporation announced yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings dropped 45 percent as sharply higher profits from bond and foreign-exchange trading only partly compensated for losses in its loan business. **********The banking company, the nation's ninth largest, earned $101.2 million, or $1.17 a share, in the fourth quarter. That compared with $185.5 million, or $2.29 a share, in the comparable quarter of 1988. **********Profits in the quarter were reduced by the previously announced need to set aside $147 million in reserves to cover losses from its leading role in the leveraged buyout of Magnet P.L.C., a British company, and loans to a Memphis-based cotton broker. **********''The loan losses were a reminder that even the best bankers in the leveraged buyout business can get stuck with a bad one from time to time,'' said Brent B. Erensel, a banking analyst at the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation. $979.9 Million Loss for Year For all of 1989, the company announced a loss of $979.9 million, compared with a profit of $647.7 million, or $8.09 a share, in 1988. **********Bankers Trust's full-year loss resulted from a $1.6 billion reserve that it set aside in the third quarter to cover possible losses on loans to less developed countries. The company now has reserves equal to more than 80 percent of its medium- and long-term loans to those countries, a level high enough to insulate the company from additional losses, analysts said. **********In 1989, Bankers Trust continued to shrink as it relied increasingly on profits from its trading and financial advisory businesses rather than interest on loans. **********Trading of bonds and foreign exchange produced profits of $150.6 million in the fourth quarter, up from $57.2 million a year earlier. For all of 1989, trading profits were $580.9 million, up $206 million from the $374.9 million in 1988. **********On the other hand, the volume of loans held by the bank fell 12.4 percent, to $21.1 billion at the end of 1989, from $24.1 billion a year earlier. Loans totaled $29.2 billion at the end of 1986. **********Troubled British Buyout **********Most of Bankers Trust's fourth-quarter loss stemmed from participation in the buyout of Magnet, which ran into difficulties when Britain's rising interest rates brought a decline in home construction, cutting Magnet's sales of lumber products and contruction supplies. Bankers Trust, which has undisclosed holdings of Magnet stock, issued loans estimated at about $130 million that it tried unsuccessfully to sell. **********The largest loss in the quarter stemmed from loans to the Julian Company, a Memphis cotton broker. The bank is still examining the circumstances of the loss, but has not made any claims of fraud. **********In trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Bankers Trust shares rose 12.5 cents each, to $40.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/10/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Saab-Scania Plans Plant in France
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/10/busin.body_text: **********Saab-Scania of Sweden said it would open a new truck and bus factory in Angers on a site where Fuji Heavy Industries of Japan abandoned plans for a Subaru vehicle plant. The Swedish group, which also makes Saab cars and aircraft, said it would invest 1.7 billion francs, or about $300 million, in the next four years in three new plants in Angers to build Scania heavy vehicles and diesel engines. **********The first stage involves taking over a factory left empty five years ago by the United States company International Harvester, now named Navistar. In 1988 Fuji expressed strong interest in building Subaru small jeep-like vehicles at Angers, but later dropped the idea. France has taken a hard line against Japanese auto imports, limiting them to a 3 percent share of the domestic market.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/02/world.main_headline: BUSH, AT U.N., SEES HOPE IN DIPLOMACY IN THE GULF CRISIS
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/02/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;   BUSH, AT U.N., SEES HOPE IN DIPLOMACY IN THE GULF CRISIS
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/02/world.body_text: **********Stepping back from the tough tone of recent days, President Bush told the constellation of world leaders gathered here today that he was hopeful that there may be a diplomatic solution to the Persian Gulf confrontation. **********Addressing the opening session of the General Assembly, where Iraqi delegates sat listening near Kuwaiti delegates in the alphabetically ordered chamber, Mr. Bush continued to insist that ''the annexation of Kuwait will not be permitted to stand.'' He referred to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq as ''the dictator.'' **********''Iraq's unprovoked aggression is a throwback to another era, a dark relic from a dark time,'' he said in the General Assembly Hall. ''It has plundered Kuwait, terrorized innocent civilians, and held even diplomats hostage. Iraq and its leaders must be held liable for these crimes of abuse and destruction.'' [Transcript, page A12.]  A Carrot of Conciliation But he told reporters later that he was not pressing for the idea -raised on Friday by his national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft - of another Security Council resolution that might include an explicit mention of military force. And in his speech, which was received with respectful applause, the President offered a carrot of conciliation to Iraq. **********''In the aftermath of Iraq's unconditional departure from Kuwait, I truly believe there may be opportunities,'' he said, ''for Iraq and Kuwait to settle their differences permanently, for the states of the gulf themselves to build new arrangements for stability, and for all the states and peoples of the region to settle the conflict that divides the Arabs from Israel.'' **********An Implicit Link **********At the recent meeting in Helsinki with the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Mr. Bush brushed off a question about Mr. Hussein's attempt to link the invasion of Kuwait with the dispute over Israel's occupation of land that Syria and Jordan lost in the 1967 Middle East war. He said the solution of the debate over a homeland for Palestinians was a matter ''separate and apart'' from the Kuwaiti invasion. **********But today, in what appeared to be a gesture to Mr. Hussein, the President implicitly linked the disputes by mentioning them in the same sentence of his speech. It could not be determined whether Mr. Bush's new emphasis on a diplomatic solution and his mention of the Arab-Israeli conflict was intended to provide the Iraqi leader with a face-saving opportunity, or, indeed, whether Washington had any reason to believe that Mr. Hussein was seeking such an opportunity. A senior Administration official said that all the President was trying to do today was ''to remind people that the diplomatic option is still our preferred option.'' **********At the same time the official said the Administration was not abandoning its policy of keeping the gulf conflict and the Arab-Israeli conflict separate. The official said the Administration was simply trying to signal to the Arab world some of the diplomatic opportunities that would exist after an unconditional Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait. **********Administration officials said the President's speech was written before Mr. Scowcroft unveiled the idea of a new, tougher United Nations resolution on Friday. **********From the beginning of the conflict, Mr. Bush has blended the diplomatic glove with the military fist, seeming sometimes to favor one approach and then the other. **********President Francois Mitterrand of France made a similar link in a peace proposal he offered last week at the United Nations that was designed to appeal to the Iraqi President. **********Mr. Mitterrand suggested that an Iraqi promise to withdraw from Kuwait would be sufficient to start negotiations, which could also deal with the division of Lebanon and the Arab-Israeli conflict. **********On Sunday, Mr. Hussein responded by saying that he would talk to France but that he would not withdraw his forces from Kuwait. He reiterated that before negotiations could begin, all Western forces would have to withdraw from the Persian Gulf and an independent Palestinian state would have to be established. **********Speaking to reporters after his speech today, Mr. Bush said he might have offered a shift in emphasis but denied that it showed any ''flexibility'' in his attitude toward Mr. Hussein. **********Optimism for an Iraqi '180' **********He said his whirlwind round of meetings this weekend with other leaders had given him ''a little optimism'' that Mr. Hussein might ''do a 180 and get out,'' referring to a 180-degree turn. **********He said the rare united stance of nations against Iraq, combined with the economic sanctions, might persuade the mercurial Iraqi President to suddenly change his mind and let Kuwait go, just as he abruptly caved in to Iran by conceding much of what the two nations had fought over for eight years. **********Mr. Bush said he had heard from other leaders here ''rather optimistic words on two points.'' **********''One, that Saddam Hussein is beginning to understand that it is him against the world - he against the world,'' he said. ''And secondly, more optimism in various quarters that the sanctions are really beginning to bite hard.'' **********Thatcher's Comments Raised **********Asked about the comment today by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain that Article 51 of the United Nations Charter gives the allies sufficient authority for military action, Mr. Bush said he agreed. But he added that the United States had been careful to seek more specific authorization for halting and boarding ships. **********''You may remember,'' he said, ''that we waited until we got a resolution before interdicting ships that more directly confirmed the right to do that.'' **********In his speech, Mr. Bush tried to assure other leaders that the American presence in the gulf is not permanent. ''We seek no advantage for ourselves,'' he said, ''nor do we seek to maintain our military forces in Saudi Arabia for one day longer than is necessary.'' **********After a 35-minute meeting with Mr. Bush this afternoon, the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, echoed Mr. Bush's hopeful note. **********''We and the Administration believe that there is still a chance for a peaceful settlement,'' Mr. Shevardnadze said. ''And we are ready to work together to achieve such a peaceful settlement.'' **********House Backs Gulf Policy **********WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (Special to The New York Times) - The House overwhelmingly approved a joint resolution today that supports President Bush's current policy in the Persian Gulf, but stops short of endorsing future military action against Iraq. **********Despite concern expressed by a number of lawmakers about the possibility that the United States might engage in a full-scale war with Iraq, the resolution passed by a 380-to-29 vote. **********Today was the first time since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 that the House or the Senate had put the weight of Congress behind the American deployment in the gulf. **********The measure, which is nonbinding, now goes to the Senate for its consideration, where a similar resolution is pending. It also withholds open-ended authority for the President to use military force in the gulf. A Senate vote is expected on Tuesday. **********Mr. Bush has not asked Congress to approve military action, nor would he necessarily do so if he decides to sent United States troops into combat in response to Iraqi action. **********Some lawmakers wanted to send a signal to the White House that they are not necessarily prepared to see the United States go to war in the gulf.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/28/world.main_headline: Gorbachev Sees 'Some Signs' That Iraq May Reconsider Its Position
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/28/world.print_headline: MIDEAST TENSIONS; Gorbachev Sees 'Some Signs' That Iraq May Reconsider Its Position
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/28/world.body_text: **********With a senior Soviet official currently engaged in a new effort to negotiate a settlement to the Persian Gulf crisis, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev hinted today that Iraq may be reconsidering its refusal to withdraw from Kuwait. **********"There are some signs the top leadership in Iraq has understood that a solution cannot be found through ultimatums," Mr. Gorbachev told a news conference during an official visit to Spain. "Perhaps I am wrong. In the next days, things will become clearer." **********The Soviet President's personal emissary to the Middle East, Yevgeny Primakov, is to travel from Cairo to Baghdad on Sunday for his second meeting with President Saddam Hussein in a month. "His mission is not finished yet," Mr. Gorbachev noted. "The Soviet Union has this possibility of finding a solution." **********Mr. Gorbachev flies to Paris on Sunday, with the gulf crisis certain to feature prominently in his talks with President Francois Mitterrand. Along with the Soviet Union, France has been probing ways of persuading Iraq to pull out of Kuwait without losing face. Gulf Situation 'Too Dangerous' **********Warning of the consequences of a military conflict in the gulf, both to the "women, children and old people" of Iraq and to foreign hostages, including 3,000 Soviet specialists, the Soviet leader said "the moment has perhaps come for the Arab world to become fully involved and to give its word." **********He added that, while Iraq's aggression should be condemned, a political solution must be sought more energetically. "We cannot just freeze the current situation," he said. "It is too dangerous. We must act." **********But Mr. Gorbachev, who noted on Friday that peace efforts should not be interpreted by Baghdad as signs of weakness, also had a word of caution for Iraq today. "President Hussein should not base his calculations around the idea of dividing us, of creating a split among us," he said, referring to the anti-Iraqi coalition. "If he thinks like this, he is very wrong." **********The Soviet leader argued that during this first major crisis of the post-cold-war period the international community had acted through the United Nations "in an extraordinarily uniform, decisive and compact way," a fact that demonstrates the enormous change that has taken place in international relations. 'Dominating' the Situation **********"We're going through a dramatic period," he went on. "Some may think we are losing positions, that we cannot dominate the situation. But I think we're dominating it. We're acting together and the region is still functioning." **********Sitting beside Mr. Gorbachev in the Moncloa Palace in Madrid, Spain's Prime Minister, Felipe Gonzalez, added that a solution to the gulf crisis should lead to a serious effort to deal with other pressing Middle East problems. "And on this we also agree," he said. **********Mr. Gorbachev's visit here was the first ever by a top Soviet leader, and it was highlighted by the signing of 16 bilateral agreements, including one that committed Spain to opening a $1.5 billion line of credit to finance both the export of consumer and industrial products and the transfer of technology and services to the Soviet Union. **********"Perestroika is not only of interest to the Soviet Union," Mr. Gonzalez said, referring to Mr. Gorbachev's program of change. "It's also important to my country. The success of this project will largely define the stability of the future. It is in Spain's interest to invest in perestroika." Assistance the Primary Theme **********Spanish officials said Mr. Gonzalez would also convey Mr. Gorbachev's urgent appeal for Western economic assistance -- the dominant theme of his brief visit here -- to leaders of the 12-nation European Community who are meeting tonight and Sunday in Rome. **********Echoing remarks he made in a meeting with Spanish Congressmen on Friday, Mr. Gorbachev said today that although some people in the West felt the arrival of a new Soviet system would be accelerated by withholding economic help, he believed others recognized that credits "would provide us with room for maneuver and make the change less painful for the population." **********"We have counted on Western cooperation in our plans," he told reporters. "But if the West does not help, this will brake our transition to a market economy and make us depend on our own resources. This would mean we will have to rely on our traditional command economy rather than the market." **********Mr. Gorbachev said Moscow recognized that it was principally responsible for bringing about change and he mentioned as evidence of this two Presidential decrees signed before he flew here on Friday. One devalued the rouble and the other opened the country to foreign investment. **********But he insisted that it was also of "strategic interest" to the West to collaborate. "We're not asking for charity," he said. "We're asking for credits and we will return the money." And then, with a laugh, he added: "We'll keep a red list and a black list to see how different countries behave."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/30/world.main_headline: In Managua, New Rulers and Never-Ending Battles
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/30/world.print_headline: In Managua, New Rulers and Never-Ending Battles
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/30/world.body_text: **********When striking Sandinista workers chained themselves inside state buildings this month and set barricades on fire, forcing the new Government to a halt, Yolanda Navarro Castro came to a bitter conclusion about her country. **********''I could see that this was never going to end,'' said Mrs. Navarro, who spent long hours getting to work each day after the strikes paralyzed Managua's bus system. ''The conflicts, the fighting, it won't ever stop.'' **********Like hundreds of thousands of other weary Nicaraguans, Mrs. Navarro, a 39-year-old food vendor, voted in national elections in February in the hope that whatever side won the balloting would mark a clear break with a decade of turmoil and civil war. **********But in dozens of recent interviews, Nicaraguans indicated that their optimism has begun to unravel as political confrontation and economic crisis continue. A month after taking office, the Government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro faces almost daily protests from the still-powerful Sandinista Front. The economy, despite the prospect of new American aid, has been battered by drastic currency devaluations and inflation. And deadlines for disbanding the contra army have dissolved in a game of perpetual negotiation. **********''We voted so that things would change, but nothing has changed,'' Mrs. Navarro said, watching black marketeers on the street waving stacks of devalued local currency to sell for American dollars. ''We had hope. Everyone had hope. But look what has become of it. Every day, our lives get worse.'' **********Like Mrs. Navarro, many Nicaraguans blame the Sandinista Front for their unhappiness. ''It's like a plot,'' said Eberto Tapia Tapia, a 40-year-old carpenter, referring to the Sandinistas' aggressive tactics of pressure and protest against Mrs. Chamorro's Government. ''They had it planned so that she would never be able to govern. Everyone sees what they're doing.'' **********Government Viewed as Weak **********Although Mrs. Chamorro is usually spared direct criticism, Nicaraguans on all sides are voicing deep pessimism about her Government, calling it weak and without clear direction. Sandinista supporters portray the new Government as a tool of right-wing interests while Mrs. Chamorro's own sympathizers accuse it of failing to hold the line against Sandinista demands. **********Government officials say that their compromises are in the spirit of national reconciliation and that criticisms of their performance are premature, that they need time to put their program in place. But few in the diverse ruling coalition agree on what the new program should be. **********Nicaraguans from the two political camps appear to agree on the one thing that they believe still offers hope of improvement in their lives: $300 million in American aid that was recently approved by Congress after repeated delays. **********''The last devaluations have been too hard on the people,'' said William Antonio Castano Hernandez, a 19-year-old Sandinista supporter who works as a bricklayer in Managua. ''Violeta has promised a lot of things she couldn't fulfill. Maybe if she had the money she could keep her promises.'' **********Sandinistas' New Role **********But most Nicaraguans interviewed appear to harbor little hope that even the greatest foreign windfall can overcome the effects of a political conflict that cuts across the heart of Nicaraguan society. **********Since their election loss on Feb. 25, Sandinista leaders have repeatedly stated their commitment to act as a constructive opposition in rebuilding the country. But in a remark that is now famous, former President Daniel Ortega Saavedra has also declared that the Sandinistas intend to ''rule from below'' despite their defeat. **********The strength of that threat was demonstrated this month when the strike by Sandinista-led Civil Service unions forced Mrs. Chamorro's Government to grant broad concessions on wages and job guarantees. **********Sandinista leaders have sharply criticized currency devaluations and inflation under the Chamorro Government, but the Sandinistas' own record in the waning days of their rule has fed a belief that the current crisis was deliberately planned to discredit the new Government. **********A Stop to Devaluations **********Sandinista economists have insisted that no important changes were made in the Government's monetary policy between the February elections and Mrs. Chamorro's inauguration on April 25. But central bank records show that official currency devaluations, which had occurred regularly for years, virtually ceased in that period. At the same time, the amount of currency placed in circulation sharply increased, in what Mrs. Chamorro's advisers have charged was a deliberate move to cause a surge of inflation. **********In the same lame-duck period, the Sandinista-controlled National Assembly approved a series of sweeping new laws on the ground of protecting the ''conquests of the revolution.'' **********One such law, which grants permanent ownership rights to Nicaraguans who had been renting or squatting on Government property, is widely supported. But other measures, like those protecting the jobs of Sandinista bureaucrats or insuring the autonomy of university administrators, have drawn denunciations from many Nicaraguans. **********University autonomy, they note, was largely respected even under the former dictator, Anastasio Somoza Debayle, but in the last decade it was revoked by the Sandinistas themselves as they extended close control over higher education. **********Strikes Are Criticized **********Nicaraguans interviewed also appeared overwhelmingly to criticize the Sandinistas' decision to press their demands against the new Government by means of strikes, a form of protest that was rarely tolerated by the Sandinistas. **********''The Sandinistas would never have allowed the kind of strikes that they're using now,'' said Rolando Montiel Castillo, an auto mechanic, who noted that the Sandinista Government had used riot policemen and tear gas to break up strikes as recently as last June. ''They're fighting for turf, not for principle. Do they think we can't remember?'' **********Sandinista leaders have made clear their determination to fight on each issue as it comes up. They accuse the Government of trying to dismantle 10 years of change and of reinstituting the right-wing policies of the Somozas. **********In the resulting atmosphere of conflict, the process of demobilizing some 10,000 contra guerrillas now inside Nicaragua had been one of the few signs of concrete progress. But it too has stalled as contra leaders have stopped handing over their weapons and have demanded new concessions from the Chamorro Government. **********In interviews, a striking number of Mrs. Chamorro's supporters said they did not believe the contras should disarm if the political situation was not stabilized. Some went even further. **********''If they tell me, I'll go to the mountains in a minute,'' a 34-year-old man said, referring to the contra army with which he fought before accepting amnesty last year. ''This can't go on.'' **********But most Nicaraguans remain clearly anxious to see the demobilization completed. And to most of those interviewed, the very suggestion of new fighting has only reinforced doubts that their country will ever find its way to lasting stability. **********''Nobody should be talking about force,'' said Ricardo Hernandez Aleman, a 46-year-old construction worker. ''That will just put us back into the same trap all over again.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/03/world.main_headline: EL SALVADOR LAGS IN JESUIT INQUIRY
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/03/world.print_headline: EL SALVADOR LAGS IN JESUIT INQUIRY
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/03/world.body_text: **********Despite President Alfredo Cristiani's vow to push the investigation of the killing of six Jesuit priests, the Supreme Court has disclosed that a central piece of evidence in the case was destroyed and that the judge took evidence from the wrong soldiers. **********Whether the judge, Ricardo A. Zamora, was deliberately misled by the military or whether the mistake grew out of the complexity of the case is not clear. But several diplomats said the incident would certainly have been avoided if the Salvadoran Army had cooperated. **********''This isn't going anywhere fast,'' said a diplomat monitoring the case, which is increasingly being viewed as a test not only of the judicial system but also of the value of continuing United States support for the Government. ''It's not going anywhere slowly. It probably isn't going anywhere.'' **********In a statement, the Supreme Court said a defendant had burned a logbook that could have provided the names of co-conspirators. The court also said four cadets questioned last week on the assumption that they were on guard duty on the night of the slayings were actually on duty a month after the killings. **********Arrests Called Historic **********The Jesuits, whom many army officers regarded as the intellectual mentors of the leftist rebellion, were slain in November along with their housekeeper and her daughter. In what President Cristiani has called a ''historic'' step, a colonel and seven lower-ranking military men were arrested and charged with the killings in January. **********In disclosing the latest setback, however, the court may have linked the killings to another officer, Lieut. Col. Carlos Camilo Hernandez, who is accused of ordering the destruction of the logbook. At the time of the killings, Colonel Hernandez was the acting commander of the military school that was the meeting spot for the accused soldiers. **********The lieutenant in charge of the unit has testified that he received a radio call ordering him to assemble his men at the school. The lieutenant did not say who gave him the order. But at the time, Guillermo Alfredo Benavides, the commander of the base, who has been charged with ordering the killings, was at a meeting of the high command. **********''This means that the radio call was received either from Colonel Benavides while he was still at the meeting of the high command or from someone else,'' a recent United States Congressional study of the case noted. ''If someone other than Colonel Benavides made the call, who was it and why would his instruction have been obeyed?'' **********Two Other Cases Collapse **********The new setbacks in the case come after the collapse of two other prominent cases involving charges of human rights abuses by members of the military. The cases had been viewed as crucial tests of the United States effort to build an independent judiciary here, subject the military to civilian control and foster democracy. **********In the first, a judge in April dismissed for lack of evidence charges against all but 1 of the 11 defendants accused in the massacre of 10 peasants in the hamlet of San Francisco in September 1988. Few diplomats expect the remaining defendant - a major who was not at the scene but has been accused of ordering the killings - will ever be put on trial. **********In the second case, a judge has dropped for lack of evidence charges against six people accused of running a right-wing kidnapping ring, which allegedly included senior officers and close associates of a leader of the governing party. One of the eight original defendants was released last year, leaving one to stand trial.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/27/busin.body_text: **********The Bush Administration is close to agreeing to compromise legislation that would give the Securities and Exchange Commission far less than the broad new authority it had wanted to regulate stock index futures, Congressional aides said tonight. **********The compromise would allow the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, which regulates the futures industry, to retain its oversight of stock index futures, and it would give the S.E.C., which oversees the securities industry, the added authority to regulate only new instruments that share the qualities of both a future and a stock. It would also give some new power to the Federal Reserve Board. **********Would Be Defeat for Brady **********Treasury officials, who acknowledged this evening that compromise language was being discussed between the Treasury and important members of the Senate, insisted that Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady had not seen the final legislative language and had not agreed to the compromise. They described the negotiations as ''fluid'' and said the attempts to reach a compromise could still break down. **********Congressional aides said that senators were seeking to complete the agreement behind closed doors this evening. **********The compromise would represent a personal defeat both for Mr. Brady and for the Securities and Exchange Commission chairman, Richard C. Breeden, who have lobbied hard to wrest regulatory control over stock index futures from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission and give it to the S.E.C. **********It would be a victory, however, for Wendy L. Gramm, the commodities commission chairman, who in defiance of the Treasury and the White House has supported the futures industry's position that regulation of index futures should be kept at the commodities commission, on the ground that her agency, as the regulator since the early 1980's, is more capable of regulating stock index futures than the S.E.C. **********Futures Agency Strongly Backed **********Mrs. Gramm, who is up for reappointment, is one of the few agency chiefs to openly oppose the preferences of the Administration. **********The bitter dispute developed between the two commissions over the jurisdiction of index futures because both stocks and the futures, whose values are based on the level of stock indexes, like the Standard & Poor's 500, are seen as part of the same market. Many trading strategies involve both instruments, and the S.E.C. has argued that having one regulator would assure that rules were complementary and that abusive trading tactics could be efficiently investigated. **********Congressional aides said that after months of efforts by the Treasury to persuade members of the Senate that the larger, more widely experienced S.E.C. should oversee trading in stock index futures, they have now realized that the opposition from the futures industry as well as from members of Congress in the Midwest agricultural states is too strong. **********The compromise bill, which is likely to be included as an amendment to the farm bill now under consideration by the Senate, would do three things. **********First, it would give the Fed authority to set broad guidelines on margin levels for stock index futures. The Fed currently has the authority to set margin levels for trading in stocks, but futures margins are now set by the exchanges. At the same time, it would permit the futures exchanges where stock index futures are currently traded to continue to make incremental daily adjustments on index futures margins, as long as they were within the Fed's guidelines. **********New Rule for New Instruments **********Second, the legislation would keep regulation of index futures with the commodities commission. But it would permit new instruments combining elements of a futures contract and stocks to be traded on either a futures or stock exchange, and each new instrument would be regulated by the primary agency overseeing that exchange. That would give the S.E.C. a regulatory authority it does not have now. One such instrument was briefly traded on stock exchanges last year, until it was blocked by a lawsuit from the futures industry. A court ruled that the law that established the commodities commission requires that an instrument with any element of a futures contract has to be regulated by the commodities commission and traded on a futures exchange. The proposed compromise would change that law. **********Finally, the law would mandate that the S.E.C. and the commodities commission work closely to monitor market manipulation. **********Congressional aides said that the compromise was worked out after it became clear that the Treasury did not have enough votes in the Senate to transfer authority over stock index futures to the S.E.C. **********The compromise will carry a sting for Mr. Brady, who has conducted a personal campaign for the change. His view dates from the 1987 market crash, when he headed a study that concluded that the link between the stock markets and the stock index futures markets was so close that they should be considered one market and regulated by one agency. **********Controlling Abuses **********The study argued that trading in stock index futures had immediate and profound effects on the underlying stock market and that abuses of trading could best be controlled if one agency regulated both markets. Mr. Brady has said repeatedly that failure to do away with the split regulatory jurisdiction will eventually result in other wild market plunges. **********Earlier this year, the Bush Adminstration was optimistic that it could get the votes to change jurisdiction, but in recent months lobbying by the futures industry eroded crucial support. **********The compromise under review this evening was hammered out by senators on the Banking and Agriculture Committees, the two panels that have jurisdiction, respectively, over the S.E.C. and the commodities commission. The key members working on the agreement on the Banking Committee include Senators Christopher S. Bond, Republican from Missouri; John Heinz, Republican from Pennsylvania, and Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat from Connecticut, and, on the Agriculture Committee, Senators Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, and Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/21/world.main_headline: India's New Prime Minister Appoints 32 Cabinet Officers
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/21/world.print_headline: India's New Prime Minister Appoints 32 Cabinet Officers
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/21/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar appointed 32 new ministers to his 11-day-old Government today, including a new foreign minister and finance minister. **********The post of external affairs went to Vidya Charan Shukla, a former Information and Broadcasting Minister who was known for his tough implementation of censorship rules during a 1975-to-1977 state of internal emergency, in which Mr. Shekhar himself was imprisoned as a critic of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi. **********Yashwant Sinha, a close aide of Mr. Shekhar who was sworn in as Finance Minister, faces a major economic crisis, including a growing balance of payments problem and inflation. Mr. Shekhar retained the key posts of Home Affairs, which controls the law enforcement agencies, and Defense. **********After the ceremony, Mr. Shekhar left for a conference of regional leaders in the Maldives.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/20/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Farm Credit Unit Prices 3 Issues
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/20/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Farm Credit Funding Corporation yesterday priced three bond issues totaling $2.33 billion through a nationwide group of securities dealers and dealer banks. **********A $1.12 billion of consolidated systemwide bonds due April 1, 1991, was given a 7 percent coupon and priced at 100, to yield about 23 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity, while an $45 million bond issue due July 1, 1991, was also given a 7 percent coupon and similarly priced at 100, to yield about 14 basis points more than Treasury issues. For $365 million of one-year bonds due Jan. 2, 1992, the coupon was 7.05 percent and price of 100, or more than 15 basis points over Treasury issues.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/26/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Record Earnings Expected at USX
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/26/busin.body_text: **********The chairman of the USX Corporation, Charles A. Corry, said USX's operating earnings would again be at record levels this year, despite the distraction of the shareholder proxy battle with Carl C. Icahn. The executive said he expected USX's operating profits this year to be higher than the record $1.6 billion of 1989, fueled by expected strong performances in both the energy and steel businesses. **********But Mr. Corry still must deal with the lingering effects of the fight with Mr. Icahn, notably the future of USX's steel unit and continuing shareholder discontent. USX announced earlier this year that its shareholders had voted down a non-binding resolution proposed by Mr. Icahn, USX's largest shareholder, calling for the company to spin off at least 80 percent of its steel business to concentrate on its energy activities.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/09/world.main_headline: Evolution in Europe;   Piles of Bones in Yugoslavia Point to Partisan Massacres
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/09/world.print_headline: Evolution in Europe;   Piles of Bones in Yugoslavia Point to Partisan Massacres
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/09/world.body_text: **********After the discovery of masses of human bones in secret graves in caves here and nearby over the last two weeks, a series of witnesses have come forward to report seeing large-scale shootings 45 years ago, painting a grisly picture of mass murder by the Communist Partisans led by Marshal Tito. **********The revelations are certain to produce an emotional re-evaluation of the Partisans, of Marshal Tito and of the Communist Government he dominated for 35 years until his death in 1980. **********The evidence of the killings of thousands of Yugoslavs by other Yugoslavs, emerging within weeks of the inauguration of non-Commmunist Governments in the Yugoslav republics of Slovenia and Croatia, will reopen old wounds. **********Ethnic Tensions Worsening **********Ethnic tensions have been growing in this country of many nationalities, which were long held together by Marshal Tito's strong leadership, Communist Party propaganda and a police presence. Some Yugoslavs fear the effect of the atrocities now being brought into the open. **********After Yugoslavia was invaded in April 1941 by the Germans, Italians, Hungarians and Bulgarians, the country was torn by guerrilla warfare. An estmated total of 1,700,000 Yugoslavs were killed, both in combat and in atrocities and reprisals by and against civilians. **********The fighting pitted Germans, Italians and other occupation forces, allied with a Croatian fascist movement called the Ustashi, which governed a puppet state, against the Partisans and the Serbian royalist Chetnik movement. **********The Partisans and Chetniks fought against each other as well as against the Ustashi and the foreign invaders. #45 Years of Frightened Silence The evidence of the Partisan atrocities lies in masses of human bones found at the bottom of caves in Slovenia and Croatia and statements by witnesses who, after 45 years of frightened silence, have come forward. **********''I drove a busload of wounded Croatian soldiers from Holy Spirit Hospital in Zagreb to Sosice in the last half of May 1945, after the war ended,'' said Branko Mulic, a 79-year-old ex-Partisan. **********He disclosed the site of a mass grave in a cave near Sosice, a Croatian village. ''I watched Partisan officers line them up and, one by one, bring them to the hole in the roof of the cave, shoot them in the back of the head and let their bodies fall into the pile at the bottom. The officers alternated who did the shooting so their guns would not overheat,'' Mr. Mulic said. **********Bones and Rope Bindings **********Skulls with holes at the back, bullet fragments, crutches and wrist and arm bones bound with rope are all clearly visible in the remains, said Nikola Solic, one of a team of journalists from the Zagreb newspaper Vjesnik. **********They used spelunkers' gear to descend the cave's sheer limestone walls to reach the bones, about 120 feet below the surface. The depth of the pile of bones is still unknown, he said. **********''As far as I know, they came every day for two weeks and from time to time thereafter,'' said Jela Smeciklas, 80, a woman who said that she saw people being transported to the cave in trucks while she was tilling a plot. ''I heard more screaming than shooting, and there was a lot of shooting.'' **********''I could hear the voices of men, women and children,'' she said. ''Night and day they came. We heard the screams at night.'' **********Several Killing Sites Known **********The Sosice cave is just one of several known sites where Communist Partisans settled accounts with members of the Ustasi, who themselves were responsible for mass killings of Serbs, Jews and gypsies during the war. **********But historians and witnesses say most of the Partisans' victims in 1945 were Croats, Slovenes and Serbs drafted into armies allied with the Axis occupation forces amd members of the Cetnik movement. In addition to combat personnel, nurses, nuns and children were killed. **********Since the news of the Sosice cave broke in Croatia last week, people from throughout Yugoslavia have been telephoning Vjesnik to report mass graves and massacre sites, said Silvije Tomasevic, a Vjesnik editor. **********Historians have estimated that the Partisans shot from 70,000 to 100,000 people without trial within weeks of the war's end. **********Reports by anti-Communist emigres that about 500,000 people were killed are exaggerations, said Darko Bekic, a historian in Zagreb whose father narrowly escaped one of the massacres. **********Victims Turned Back by British **********Most of the victims were people who fled or were trying to flee at the end of the war, Mr. Bekic said. They were returned by British troops from detention camps in Austria or were turned back at the border by British troops occupying southern Austria and northeastern Italy, Mr. Bekic said. **********On the basis of the limited evidence now available, the Sosice cave contains 4,000 to 5,000 victims, most of whom were wounded soldiers brought from hospitals in and around Zagreb, Mr. Bekic added. **********He discounted some reports that the cave might contain the remains of as many as 40,000 people. ''Nobody knows for sure,'' he said. ''The Government must excavate it to find out the real answer.'' **********Croatia's new Parliament announced this week that it would form a committee, including foreign experts, to investigate the cave and Croatia's overall casualties. **********While accounts of postwar Partisan atrocities have been published in the West since the war and in Slovenia for the last six months, the issue was made public in Croatia only after the disclosure of the Sosice grave last week. **********''There has been a change in the chief of police and people no longer fear repercussions,'' said Milovan Sibl, a Croatian spokesman. ''It wasn't in the interests of the old regime to expose the caves, not because of Communism, but because the victims were Croats and the Government would then no longer be able to pin the blame for the Ustasi crimes on the Croatian people as a whole.'' **********During the war, nationalist and religious enmity erupted throughout the country, driving members of virtually all the country's nationalities to commit acts of brutality. **********Yugoslavs Killed by Yugoslavs **********Most of the nation's war dead were killed by other Yugoslavs. The Ustashi championed Croatian separatism. while the Chetniks were largely in Serbia, which had dominated the new Yugoslav state during the period between the world wars. Only the Partisans tended to cut across the country's ethnic divisions. **********In the postwar era, Marshal Tito, himself half-Croatian, reorganized the country on a federal basis, in which each republic nominally exercised a wide degree of autonomy. Nevertheless, until his death, the one-party Communist Government kept most real authority in its hands. **********To underpin its legitimacy, it fostered an image of Marshal Tito and the Partisans as humane, heroic liberators of all of Yugoslavia's people from fascism and nationalism. **********''When I heard that Partisans carried out the killings, it made my head spin because it went against everything I heard in school,'' said Nikola Hranilovic, a Sosice resident who said he learned of the killings years ago but kept silent because he feared the police. **********''I always heard that the Partisans fought for our side and for our people. It never became clear to me why they did this to women and men who were forced to join the army.'' **********Both Croatian and Slovene officials and journalists have expressed concern that the disclosure of the mass graves might worsen the already-tense national relations within Yugoslavia, especially between Croats and Serbs. **********Requiem Mass Near Caves **********Today in a clearing in Kocevski Rog, in a mountain region about 45 miles south of Ljubljana, Archbishop Alojzij Sustar, President Milan Kucan of Slovenia and 30,000 Slovenes took part in a requiem Mass and reconciliation ceremony. Two nearby caves contain the remains of as many as 16,000 Slovenes and Croats. Croats conducted similar rites in Sosice. **********Some Partisan veterans have already condemned these commemorations as anti-patriotic. The press in Serbia and other Communist-ruled republics has scarcely mentioned the issue. **********''It would be the worst situation to turn this into another cycle of vengeance,'' said Hido Biscevic, Vjesnik's chief editor. ''Until now, the political system was able to hide it and now it can't be hidden anymore. But we must see that it does not lead to new instability.'' **********''Serbs and Croats will all be better off if they adopt the old Indian practice and bury the hatchet forever,'' Mr. Mulic said. ''They should realize that we are not born as Serbs and Croats, but naked.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/24/world.main_headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   U.S. Gains Some Support at U.N. for a Resolution Endorsing Force
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/24/world.print_headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   U.S. Gains Some Support at U.N. for a Resolution Endorsing Force
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/24/world.body_text: **********American French and British representatives have agreed on the text of a Security Council resolution endorsing military action to enforce the embargo against Iraq, diplomats said today. **********The text has been sent to the Governments of the Council's five permanent members for review, the envoys said. The permanent members, who have veto power over resolutions of the 15-member Council, are the United States, Britain, France, China and the Soviet Union. **********The diplomats said the draft had not yet been approved by the Soviet Union. China has indicated that it will abstain from the vote on the resolution but will not veto it, they added. **********The Soviet representative, Valentin V. Lozinsky, and other diplomats suggested that the timing of the resolution had been a sticking point in the talks. **********Conflicting Remarks **********After a meeting of the five permanent members this morning, the United States representative, Thomas R. Pickering, said, ''We agreed on a text to send to capitals.'' **********But Mr. Lozinsky, pressed by reporters before the talks resumed this afternoon, said, ''No, no, that's a wrong impression.'' **********''There are still negotiations,'' he said. The Soviet diplomat said that diplomatic efforts to enforce the embargo should be given a chance to work before a resolution endorsing force is adopted. **********Late today Mr. Pickering and the British representative, Sir Crispin Tickell accused Iraq of violating the Council's embargo resolution by trying to buy weapons to export oil. At a meeting of the Council's Sanctions Committee, they presented what they said were photographs of tankers breaching the embargo. **********Cuba Disputes Photographs **********Cuba's representative, Ricardo Alarcon de Quesada, asserted afterward that the photographs were not genuine and that the United States and Britain were trying to generate hysteria. **********Diplomats have said in recent days that the five permament members agree in principle that minimum force can be used to enforce the trade sanctions, which were imposed on Iraq by the Security Council on Aug. 6. **********But envoys of the five permanent members have differed on when such a resolution should be issued and what role the United Nations should play in overseeing the use of such force, diplomats say. **********The United States has sought quick adoption of the resolution, they say, while the Soviets have indicated that they would prefer to wait until a clear violation of the embargo has occurred. The Soviets would also prefer that the United Nations take a significant role in overseeing the use of force, the diplomats said, while the Americans prefer a lesser role for the organization. **********Denies Any Contradiction **********Asked this evening for a clarification on the divergence between Soviet and American statements today on progress toward an agreement, Mr. Pickering said, ''There is no disparity between Mr. Lozinsky and me.'' He added: ''We have agreed to send a draft to be considered by our Governments. That's it.'' Some diplomats here suggested that the text sent by the five representatives to their Governments was similar to a draft circulated on Wednesday. **********A paragraph of that version said the Council ''called with immediately effect upon all member states which are deploying maritime forces to the area to use such minimum force as may be necessary under the authority of the Security Council to halt all inward and outward martime shipping in order to verify their cargoes and destinations and to ensure strict enforcement of measures related to such shipping laid down'' in the resolution on the embargo approved on Aug. 6.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/23/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Belzbergs Consider Armstrong Plans

**********F.B.I. agents today searched two Northrop Corporation plants where parts for the Navy's FA-18 fighter-bomber are built, the company said.
