https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/20/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS;   Treasuries Mixed in Slow Trading
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/20/busin.body_text: **********The prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in quiet trading yesterday, and the difference between short-term and long-term interest rates widened further. **********As has been true for the last few sessions, bond prices came under selling pressure, while short-term notes and bills held steady or improved slightly. **********Aside from the lingering negative effects of June's unexpectedly poor consumer price figures, market participants said, the sale of $800 million worth of new seven-year notes by the Federal National Mortgage Association and a big revision in the Treasury's third-quarter borrowing needs provided additional incentives to sell bonds. **********The Treasury said that from July to September it would borrow between $62 billion and $66 billion. In May the estimated borrowing need was $30 billion to $35 billion. **********Linked to Savings Bailout **********Virtually all of the increase is attributable to the financial needs of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the Federal agency created to oversee the bailout of the nation's savings and loan industry. **********Even though the Treasury has not borrowed so much since the fourth quarter of 1985, when it tapped the financial markets for $63.3 billion, ''the numbers shouldn't have been much of a surprise,'' said James R. Capra, a senior vice president at Shearson Lehman Government Securities. ''The Treasury has been borrowing at that sort of rate for the past few weeks. Even so, the market didn't like it.'' **********The $800 million worth of 8.80 percent Fannie Mae notes sold yesterday, which mature on July 25, 1997, were priced at 100. **********The offering prompted some accounts to sell longer-term notes and bonds and buy the shorter-dated securities, continuing a trend that has been been evident for the past two weeks. **********''The Fed has shifted the probabilities toward a further easing of policy at some point,'' said William V. Sullivan Jr. a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds. ''That is supporting the front end of the yield curve and pushing up bond yields.'' **********By late yesterday, the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 102 5/32, down 3/32, to yield 8.54 percent, unchanged from late Wednesday. **********Among note issues, the Treasury's 8 1/2 percent five-year notes were offered at 100 22/32 in late trading, up 2/32, to yield 8.31 percent. And the 8 3/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 1/2, up 2/32, to yield 8.08 percent. **********Short-term Treasury bill rates dipped slightly. **********In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.33 percent, down a basis point, or hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by 3 basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.43 percent. And one-year bill rates were unchanged at a late rate of 7.32 percent. **********On a bond-equivalent yield basis, a measurement of the rate of return on a security sold on a discount basis that assumes actual days to maturity and a 365-day year, the yield on three-month Treasury bills late yesterday was 7.78 percent. Treasury bills are auctioned on a discount basis. **********Compared with the prevailing yield on the 8 3/4 percent bonds, the 76-basis-point spread between bonds and three-month bills is the widest it has been since mid-May, Mr. Sullivan said. At the beginning of July, yields on 30-year bonds exceeded the bond-equivalent yield on three-month bills by just 40 basis points. **********''The steepening yield curve has been the major feature in the market over the past few weeks,'' Mr. Sullivan added. **********Corporate and Municipal Issues **********Activity in other segments of the credit markets was very light. **********Corporate bond traders said that prices of most investment-grade issues were unchanged on the day. **********In the secondary market for tax-exempt bonds, participants said that prices of most widely quoted issues dipped by about 1/8 point. **********The Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that two of the three measures of the nation's money supply fell during the week ended July 9. The third, broadest measure, M-3, rose by $2.8 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/26/world.main_headline: Taiwan Accused in Deaths of 25 Refugees at Sea
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/26/world.print_headline: Taiwan Accused in Deaths of 25 Refugees at Sea
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/26/world.body_text: **********Late last month, Chinese fishermen spotted a small oceangoing fishing boat that was stranded and seemed to be in trouble. Upon boarding they discovered the problem: the boat contained 25 corpses and a few more gasping passengers locked in several cabins below deck. **********Like many poor Chinese, the victims had sought a new life by sneaking onto Taiwan to find work. But they were captured, and in the process of repatriating them the Taiwanese authorities are accused of locking them into crowded cabins, where they suffocated before they reached the mainland. **********Chinese indignation over the incident was compounded after a Taiwanese military vessel accidentally rammed and sank a fishing boat on which 50 mainland Chinese were being repatriated. Twenty-one people died in the Aug. 13 incident, and some survivors charged that the rescue efforts were lackadaisical. **********''Facts prove that responsibility for the two incidents should be borne completely by the Taiwan authorities,'' the official New China News Agency said in a commentary published Thursday in newspapers, next to a grisly photo of corpses from the first incident. The Government of Taiwan has not given an explanation of the latest incident, but an officer in the Government Information Office said in a telephone interview on Friday that repatriation is conducted humanely. On Wednesday, Prime Minister Hau Pei-tsun ordered a thorough investigation. **********According to an extensive account by the New China News Agency, the episode began July 21 when Taiwan's military police put 63 mainland Chinese into four cabins of the 57-foot boat. The police reportedly bound the hands of the mainlanders and ordered the boat's crew to seal the cabins with planks. **********''We felt extremely thirsty, and in an hour we were suffocating,'' the news agency quoted Lin Licheng, who lived through the voyage, as saying. ''To survive, we tried to break the door with our heads and hands. But it was useless.'' **********Taiwan repatriates such illegal immigrants on private fishing boats because the Taipei Government disdains formal contact with the mainland. **********While the illegal immigrants were suffocating in the cabins, the crew steered the boat back to the mainland and then apparently fled. Twenty-three occupants of one of the four cabins forced their way out and ran away without releasing others. **********The Chinese police have found 16 of the people who fled, but the authorities have said that all blame rests with Taiwan and there is no indication that those who ran away will be punished. The deaths have focused attention on the thousands of Chinese who sneak into Taiwan to find jobs as construction workers, rural laborers or prostitutes. Illegal migration has soared in the last two years, as political tensions have eased and word has spread of the wages that can be earned on Taiwan, where there is a labor shortage. **********While the Nationalist forces lost the war with the Communists in 1949 and had to flee to Taiwan, they have done far better in the cold war for the hearts and minds of mainlanders. Most Chinese speak with awe and envy of their cousins on Taiwan, and while Taiwan officials find this gratifying, they are alarmed at the consequence: enormous numbers of mainlanders are willing to pay several years' earnings to be smuggled to Taiwan to find jobs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/19/world.main_headline: Emigre From Canada Running Well in Poland
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/19/world.print_headline: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE; Emigre From Canada Running Well in Poland
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/19/world.body_text: **********A wealthy Polish-born emigre businessman from Canada has suddenly emerged as a dark-horse candidate in the Polish presidential election campaign. **********In just a few weeks, Stanislaw Tyminski, who is 42 years old and operates a cable television system in Peru, has risen from anonymity to a strong third-place showing in the polls, and is threatening to overtake Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, who now places second. The latest survey by Polish television, released Friday, shows Mr. Tyminski with 17 percent, Mr. Mazowiecki with 19 percent and Lech Walesa, the Solidarity chairman, holding the lead with 35 percent. **********Under the rules for the 25 election this coming Sunday, a runoff will be held on Dec. 9 unless one candidate tallies more than 50 percent of the votes. Polish law permits Poles living overseas to vote in the coming elections, and Mr. Tyminski is actively campaigning for the support of hundreds of thousands of expatriates in Canada and the United States. **********Political experts in Poland still do not see Mr. Tyminski as having a serious chance to win the presidency. Those same experts two weeks ago saw Mr. Tyminski as nothing more than a footnote, not a legitimate contender for second place in a two-candidate runoff. But the experts also felt that Mr. Tyminski could not defeat Mr. Walesa in a runoff.  Little About Him Is Known **********Mr. Tyminski, who holds Canadian, Peruvian and Polish citizenship, has revealed little about his background to voters here and he refused a request to detail his biography since leaving Poland 21 years ago. **********Business associates and friends recount a remarkable journey in which Mr. Tyminski founded a successful computer company in Canada, lost and made a fortune in Peru and underwent a spiritual transformation after traveling among Indian tribes in the Amazon jungle. **********His political background is similarly eclectic. Earlier this year, Mr. Tyminski was elected President of the 3,500-member Libertarian Party of Canada. The co-author of the book he published this year in Poland with his own money is Roman Samsel, a former correspondent in Mexico for the Communist Party's daily newspaper, Trybuna Ludu. Mr. Tyminski was the only presidential candidate to attend the party given in Warsaw by the Soviet Ambassador to mark the anniversary of the Russian Revolution. **********If Mr. Tyminski's background is elusive, there is no secret about his electoral appeal. His posters, plastered on the sides of Warsaw buses, are an appeal to voters put off by the prospect of a Walesa presidency and uninspired by Mr. Mazowiecki. "Neither one nor the other: Vote Tyminski," they say.  Attractive to Poles **********Mr. Tyminski's self-described success in Western business -- his campaign literature says he is among the richer men in Canada -- make him attractive to Poles looking for a candidate who can rebuild the nation's shattered economy. He frequently criticizes the Government's proposed program for privitizing industry in Poland, saying it would sell assets far too cheaply and invite foreigners to take unfair advantage of low wages in Poland. **********"He's very appealing to people who would like to live in a rational world," said Jadwiga Staniszkis, a sociologist who supports Mr. Walesa. "Walesa is really rather unpredictable. When Tyminski speaks, he sounds terrible, but his campaign has been brilliant, his documents and television are brilliant. He is a very mysterious man." **********His style of campaigning has created a stir. Mr. Tyminski, who speaks Polish with a slight foreign accent, travels around the country in a helicopter. On Saturday, he told an election rally that he would soon release documents proving that Mr. Mazowiecki was guilty of unspecified "treason," and he accused the Government of falsifying its econmic statistics. **********The Government issued a denial. **********According to his campaign literature and book, Mr. Tyminski was born in 1948 and went to Sweden in 1969 because he saw no opportunities in Poland. Neighbors in the small Warsaw suburb where grew up recall that he had a talent for repairing radios. After a brief stay in Sweden, he emigrated to Canada.  Founded Computer Company **********Maciej Bebenek, who works on the presidential campaign, said that after arriving in Canada, Mr. Tyminski studied computer science and took a job at Hewlett-Packard. In 1975, he founded a company called Transduction that found a niche designing computer systems for factories and power plants. Today, Mr. Bebenek said the company has between 10 and 15 full-time employees. **********Frank Ollie, Mr. Tyminski's partner in Transduction, would not disclose the company's sales but said published reports that put the amount between $5 and $10 million were not inaccurate. Mr. Ollie said the company did so well in the late 1970's that Mr. Tyminski "felt somewhat guilty about all the money he was making" and began contributing to an orphanage in Peru. In the early 1980's, Mr. Tyminski took a vacation in Peru to get a first-hand look at the orphanage. **********Mr. Ollie said Mr. Tyminski saw a business opportunity and built a large barge to carry fuel to Iquitos, a city in the upper Amazon. **********"He was a bit naive about all the goings on in this part of the world, with the drug dealings and so on, and had his boat taken over by the Army, which considered it an excellent gunboat," Mr. Ollie said. This cost Mr. Tyminski between $800,000 and $1 million in losses and prompted him to journey into the jungle with the local tribes, Mr. Ollie said.  Described Travels in Book **********"Stan got very close to the people and many of their mystic ways," Mr. Ollie said. "I think Shirley MacLaine talks about these things. Stan was there long before that and participated in all that." **********Later, Mr. Tyminski returned to Iquitos and founded a cable television company called TVS which, Mr. Ollie said, "put him back on the road to personal prosperity. **********He returned to Canada in 1985 and made it a point to employ Poles at a home, a factory and a farm he had in Canada, Mr. Ollie said. Mr. Tyminski was said by several associates to have decided to enter the race after discovering that his book was being quoted by Polish candidates, including Mr. Walesa. Supporters of the Solidarity chairman said they could not recall him ever citing Mr. Tyminski's book.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/16/world.print_headline: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE; Berlin City Government Fails
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/16/world.body_text: **********The city's coalition government collapsed today in a dispute over a police crackdown on hundreds of leftist squatters. **********The environmentalist Green Party said it was bolting the two-party coalition led by Mayor Walter Momper, a Social Democrat. The Greens say they were outraged by the police crackdown, which has resulted in more than 260 injuries and about 450 arrests since Monday. **********Gerd Poppe, a Greens candidate for Parliament, said "the unbelievable police presence" set off the violence. But Mr. Momper and other officials blamed the leftists, many of whom are veterans of the West Berlin anarchist movement. Hundreds of the anarchists have moved into run-down, vacant tenements in what had been East Berlin. **********A new city government will be elected on Dec. 2, as will a united German Parliament. Mr. Momper will likely govern Berlin with a minority until then. The Greens' move is seen as largely a symbolic gesture of protest. **********City officials began evicting leftist radicals on Monday. A large-scale protest turned into a rock-throwing spree that resulted in 160 injuries and 20 arrests. **********Tens of thousands of people marched through Berlin on Wednesday night to protest the raid and the lack of affordable housing in Berlin. Later, some protesters began throwing rocks and firebombs at the police. About 100 people were arrested.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/09/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;   Brazil Backing Computer Imports
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/09/busin.body_text: **********The office of an American multinational company here recently received a knock on the door of the sort dreaded by business executives across Brazil: it was the computer police. **********''They went wild when they saw 'Made in Taiwan,' '' recalled the American representative of the company, who insisted that he be identified only by his first name, John. ''They threatened to call a van and take away our fax and our word processors.'' **********Such scenes may soon be a thing of the past as Brazil, the world's sixth largest computer market, drops tariffs and liberalizes its economy. To make Brazilian industry more competitive and to fight inflation by making goods less expensive, the new Government of President Fernando Collor de Mello plans to do away with protectionist legislation gradually. **********Booming PC Market **********During the 1980's, such laws hindered joint ventures with foreign computer manufacturers, tightly restricted imports and made this booming personal computer market the largest in the third world and the lucrative preserve of domestic manufacturers. **********''We are effectively very backward because of this senseless nationalism,'' Zelia Cardoso de Mello, the Economy Minister, said Tuesday about Brazil's computer restrictions. ''We will be more pragmatic in this area, more open to foreign capital, to imports and to joint ventures. **********''The computer problem effectively blocked Brazilian industry from modernizing,'' Miss Cardoso told Brazilian reporters last week. ''It does not make any sense to retain this cyst, which is the computer market reserve.'' **********Next month, the Government is to send Congress a bill to phase out gradually the controls on imports and on joint ventures. But the domestic computer industry, which employs 60,000 people, is expected to ally with nationalist lawmakers to fight the opening of the market. **********''We are opening in exchange for nothing,'' Fernando Gasparian, a Sao Paulo deputy, said Thursday. ''An opening could kill our computer industry.'' **********To date, the only concrete step by the Goverment occurred two weeks ago, when it removed a $960 million limit on 1990 computer imports. Last year, the 31 multinational computer companies here had revenues including imports of $1.5 billion. In contrast, Brazil's 324 domestic computer industry companies had revenues last year of $3.6 billion. **********The law cost Brazilian consumers about $600 million a year because of higher domestic manufacturing costs, said Jose Goldemberg, Secretary of Science and Technology. **********Lag in Competitiveness **********The new Government, which took power on March 15, has also been spurred by studies that indicate that during the 1980's, Brazil's industry lagged behind many major nations of the third world in terms of competitiveness. **********In the late 1980's, computer controls became the single largest trade dispute between Brazil and the United States. After investigating Brazil's Informatics Law for ''unfair trade practices,'' the Reagan Administration imposed punitive tariffs on a series of Brazilian exports in 1987. **********The tariffs were lifted last week after Robert A. Mosbacher, the United States Commerce Secretary, visited here. Mr. Mosbacher praised Brazil's ''ambitious program of open markets.'' **********The mood these days is a far cry from that of 1984, when Brazil's Congress overwhelmingly voted to reserve the market for micro- and minicomputers for national manufacturers for eight years. Sovereignty and national security were the bywords of an odd, if effective, alliance forged among the military, left-wing nationalists and businesses seeking protection from international competition. **********In 1986, Jose Sarney, then the President, declared computer restrictions ''fundamental for our survival as a sovereign nation.'' **********In this nationalist environment, the computer police - actually treasury agents - started zealously enforcing restrictions. **********Last year, police seized 20 Apple and Macintosh computers from classrooms at the American School in Brasilia. In May, Federal police conducting an anti-hijacking search of passengers on the Rio-Sao Paulo air shuttle detained one man carrying a Japanese laptop. Last week, Federal police near Brazil's border with Argentina seized a van loaded with fax machines, computers, computer parts and televisions. **********Incentives to Smuggle **********The incentive to smuggle is great. In the United States, a facsimile machine can be bought for $600; its Brazilian-made equivalent costs $4,000. Brazilian personal computers, often made of pirated technology, generally cost double the international prices of their foreign equivalents. **********After six years of limited access to the world computer revolution, Brazilian public opinion is increasingly skeptical about the high domestic prices and about Brazil's ability to match computer research and development going on overseas. Manoel F. Thompson Motta, vice president of the Brazilian Association for the Development of the Capital Goods Industry, complained in a speech two weeks ago about how Brazilian computers were ''excessively expensive and technologically out of date when compared to their foreign equivalents.'' **********''This factor blocks increased competitiveness of Brazilian products in the foreign market,'' Mr. Motta said. **********Relaxed Regulations **********Even without new legislation, growing complaints have forced greater flexibility from the Special Informatics Secretariat, a high court of computer affairs. In the last six months, the secretariat has allowed three American companies - the International Business Machines Corporation, the Hewlett-Packard Company and the Digital Equipment Corporation - to enter into joint ventures with Brazilian manufacturers. **********After a battle with the United States over the Microsoft Corporation's right to sell software here, a law went into effect in 1988 extending copyright protection to software. The Government is now discussing allowing foreign companies to distribute software here. **********And in modern offices where secretaries look through door peepholes to check for computer inspectors, there is growing optimism. **********''I think we are cooked on the fax, but we can keep the word processors,'' John said after the raid by the computer police. ''They are going around heavily this month because they know their time is running out.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/01/busin.body_text: **********Consumer spending jumped 1.1 percent in September, the Government said today, outpacing a five-tenths of 1 percent growth in personal income and contributing to the lowest savings rate in three years. **********The Commerce Department report "shows consumer purchasing power obviously is under intense pressure in the aftermath of the oil shock" from the Persian Gulf situation, said Stephen S. Roach, senior economist with Morgan Staney & Company. **********Nevertheless, Mr. Roach added, "consumers are really sort of clinging tenaciously to their life styles." **********"Their spending is holding up just fine," he said.  Waning Confidence **********The Federal Reserve reported separately today, however, that the confidence of consumers and businesses was waning in many regions of the country because of "greater uncertainty and higher fuel prices." Every one of the central bank's 12 districts was reporting either slower growth or an actual decline in economic activity. **********The Commerce Department said that the incomes of Americans reached a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $4.7 trillion in September, a $23.8 billion increase over August. **********At the same time, it said spending reached a rate of $3.73 trillion, up $39.9 billion from a month earlier. It was the biggest increase since a 1.2 percent gain last June. **********In its report on the third-quarter gross national product on Tuesday, the department had said consumer spending from July through September rose 3.6 percent, well above the two-tenths of 1 percent advance from April through June. **********But Mr. Roach of Morgan Stanley said he expected spending would drop to "the 1 percent vicinity" during the current quarter. **********"There's no way we'll be able to hold up" the 3.6 percent pace, he said, "in the weak income and low savings environment."  Decline in Growth **********Consumer spending represents about two-thirds of United States economic activity, and Mr. Roach said a lower level of consumption this quarter would mean a temporary decline in overall economic growth. **********But he said his company was not projecting a recession, which is defined as two consecutive quarters of declining gross national product, the total output of the nation's goods and services. **********The Commerce Department report said the rate of Americans' savings as a percent of disposable income fell to 3.5 percent, down from 4.1 percent in August and the lowest since a 3.3 percent rate in October 1987. **********The report said Americans' income after taxes increased by four-tenths of 1 percent, up from a two-tenths of 1 percent gain in August. Adjusting for Inflation **********The spending and income figures were not adjusted for inflation. When adjusted, spending rose three-tenths of 1 percent, after declining one-tenth of 1 percent in August. Disposable, or after-tax, income fell three-tenths of 1 percent, compared with a five-tenths of 1 percent drop the previous month. **********A key component of the income category -- wages and salaries -- rose $17.4 billion, up from $600 million the previous month. **********The $39.9 billion increase in personal consumption, which includes all types of consumer spending except interest payments on debt, was up from a $20.1 billion gain in August. **********Spending on durable goods -- relavitely expensive items expected to last more than three years -- totaled $487 billion, up from $477 billion from August. **********Spending on nondurable goods rose $11 billion, to $1.2 trillion, following a $10.6 billion gain in August. Spending on services was up $18.2 billion, to $2 trillion, after a gain of $18.2 billion the previous month.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/05/busin.print_headline:

HDM Mattingly Wins Myer-Grace Account
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/05/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: HDM Mattingly, the Australian arm of HDM Worldwide, was relieved to learn yesterday that it had won the bulk of the $80 million advertising account of the Myer-Grace Brothers department store group. The agency will be responsible for merchandise marketing and day-to-day advertising at the Australian retailer. **********HDM Mattingly, the Australian arm of HDM Worldwide, was relieved to learn yesterday that it had won the bulk of the $80 million advertising account of the Myer-Grace Brothers department store group. The agency will be responsible for merchandise marketing and day-to-day advertising at the Australian retailer. **********A smaller share of the account, primarily for overall company branding, was awarded to the Australian agency Omon. **********The account was put up for review last August, after the merger of the marketing departments of Myer and Grace Bros., which Myer had purchased in 1983. Mattingly had held the Myer account, which last year billed about $56 million, since the early 1970s, said Tim Pollak, chief executive of HDM Worldwide. Leo Burnett's Sydney office had held the Grace Brothers account. **********HDM Mattingly's share of the combined account should be about $63 million, Mr. Pollak said. **********HDM New York also won an account yesterday, for Credit Suisse in the United States. Billings for the account are believed to be between $1 million and $2 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/23/busin.main_headline: Sudden Fame for a Compromise on Trade
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/23/busin.print_headline: Sudden Fame for a Compromise on Trade
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/23/busin.body_text: **********A Dutch civil servant with a dry sense of humor and an endless supply of patience was in bed with the flu in Geneva when leaders of the world's seven major industrial powers found themselves struggling to pronounce his name at the Houston summit meeting earlier this month. **********Not the sort of man interested in even a Warholian 15 minutes of fame, Aart de Zeeuw shrugged off the repeated mangling of his surname. But what did make him feel better was the unlikely interest stirred in Houston by an eight-page document he had prepared on freeing world trade in agricultural products. **********''I was surprised,'' Mr. de Zeeuw (pronounced ''duh-ZAY-ow'') said in an interview squeezed between meetings at the headquarters of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade here. ''I didn't realize the paper would be so central to the summit. The entire subject is very detailed and complicated, but they spent five or six hours discussing it.'' **********The fact that they did so, though, reflected their alarm that a bitter dispute over farming subsidies and supports is threatening to ruin four years of trade liberalization negotiations. And with the United States and the 12-nation European Community moving toward confrontation, the seven turned to the ''de Zeeuw text'' as a possible peace formula. **********Although they did not adopt the text, which calls for across-the-board reduction of farm supports, their final communique commended it ''as a means to intensify the negotiations.'' President Bush referred to Mr. de Zeeuw by name in a news conference, while Britain's Prime Minister Thatcher told Parliament that the report by ''a Dutchman called de Zeeuw'' would be the basis for future talks. **********The first real test of the suddenly famous text will come Monday in Geneva when a 96-nation Trade Negotiations Committee begins to draft final agreements on agriculture and a range of other trade issues. Without rapid progress, there are doubts whether the December deadline for completion of what is known as the Uruguay Round of GATT-sponsored trade negotiations can be met. **********Mr. de Zeeuw was made chairman of the agriculture negotiating group, because the Netherlands stands roughly midway between the free-trade stance of the United States and the more protectionist position of most Community countries. After traveling widely and listening intently, it was his job to present a compromise plan on July 2. **********Yet Mr. de Zeeuw - both as drafter and ''referee,'' as he calls himself -has now assumed still greater importance because of the disproportionate weight that agriculture carries in the trade talks as a whole. ''We all know that we can expect no real result from the Uruguay Round without an agreement on agriculture,'' he said. **********The Uruguay Round, the seventh in a series that began 30 years ago, aims to reduce trade restraints in 15 areas, ranging from textiles and tropical goods to services and intellectual property. At present, existing GATT agreements cover $1 trillion of a total annual world trade of around $3 trillion. If successful, the Uruguay Round will liberalize an additional $1 trillion worth of international sales. **********Many governments, including that of the United States, have warned that they will not accept any package that excludes agriculture. Some developing countries have also indicated that unless they obtain concessions on agriculture they will not endorse draft accords in, say, services. **********The clash between the United States and the European Community over agriculture dates back to the early 1960's, when the community -at the time, still a six-nation common market - began what became known as the Common Agricultural Policy. Justified as a way of insuring ''food security,'' it sought to protect millions of small farmers, mainly in France and West Germany, through a system of direct subsidies, import barriers and export incentives. **********The United States, which failed to have agriculture included in previous GATT rounds, complains that this policy enables European countries to keep out cheaper foreign food products at the same time they are dumping their surpluses abroad at below-market prices. As a result, the United States claims to have lost $11 billion in agricultural exports in 1989 alone. **********The United States itself plans to channel $8.5 billion in subsidies to its 2.2 million farmers this year, with other assistance hidden in Federal irrigation programs, low-interest credit and price supports. But Washington argues that the community's program of export subsidies has an immediate and disruptive impact on world trade. And it is these subsidies that it most wants reduced. **********In contrast, while Washington often bows to pressure from the American farming lobby, the European policy is defended as the ''economic cement'' binding the community together. Europeans pay dearly to shield 11 million farmers, 7.5 percent of the work force, from market forces. In 1990, $45 billion in tax revenues will be channeled through the community as subsidies, while consumers will pay $54 billion extra for food because prices are fixed above market rates. **********The debate is further complicated by bitter charges of protectionism against the United States, the European Community and Japan by the 13-nation Cairns group that represents leading agricultural exporters, including Australia, Canada, Argentina and Brazil. For them, the answer is a total liberalization of trade in farm products so that their cheaper exports can find markets. **********Mr. de Zeeuw's Targets **********In drafting his text, Mr. de Zeeuw identified four areas in which protectionism should be reduced: domestic supports, like subsidies; nontariff barriers, like quotas; export subsidies, and plant, animal and human health controls that serve to restrict trade. He did not suggest when and by how much the reductions should take place, although he asked governments to provide a list of all their farm supports by Oct. 1. **********But, to the distress of the community, Mr. de Zeeuw did express his belief that priority should be given to reducing export subsidies, which happens to be the United States' view. ''Export subsidies are the most trade-distorting measures,'' the 66-year-old agricultural economist said. ''Therefore we have to do more here than in other areas.'' **********The community, though, favors ''aggregate measures of support,'' meaning that all farm supports should be looked at as a package. And it points to a recent report by the Paris-based Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development showing that total producer subsidies for each farmer were worth $8,000 in community countries and $20,000 in the United States. **********Mr. de Zeeuw brushed off the suggestion that his recognition at Houston had increased his responsibilities. ''I don't decide these things,'' he insisted. ''Governments do. I'm just a mediator; I don't count. When my name was mentioned on television from Houston, my son called up and said, 'So that's what you've been doing all these years.' ''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/14/world.main_headline: Tiananmen Protest Leader Credits 'Lots of People' for Escape to West
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/14/world.print_headline: Tiananmen Protest Leader Credits 'Lots of People' for Escape to West
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/14/world.body_text: **********A leader of the Chinese student movement that was crushed in Tiananmen Square in June said here today that she was able to avoid arrest for 10 months thanks to the help, protection and encouragement of ordinary Chinese citizens. **********The student, Chai Ling, a 23-year-old psychology major who played a central role in the democracy movement, and her 24-year-old husband, Feng Congde, who is also on the Beijing Government's list of 21 ''most wanted,'' said they were finally able to slip out of China two weeks ago. **********In their first interview since arriving in France, where they have requested political asylum, the couple called on the West to adopt tougher sanctions against China. They said it was also important to keep the Chinese people informed about events abroad. **********Miss Chai said a ship that will soon be used for broadcasting news into China from off-shore international waters would bring great encouragement. The ship, the Goddess of Democracy, set sail from the French port of La Rochelle on March 17 with several exiled Chinese dissidents on board. **********Secret Groups Aid Dissidents **********Beijing was rebuffed this week when it asked France to outlaw A Boat For Democracy, the foundation that is financing the broadcast ship. China also formally protested the French Government's decision to allow Miss Chai and her husband into this country. Their request for asylum is under consideration. **********Miss Chai said she went into hiding immediately after the Tiananmen Square movement was crushed, staying first in Beijing and then moving to places she refused to identify. ''All this time, I had the support of lots of people,'' she said. ''People who had their own problems of family and work to worry about, but who helped and protected us with their own resources.'' **********She said secret organizations sprung up after June to help the dissidents, while those who hid her always knew her identity and assumed the risks. She said the same people helped her and Mr. Feng to leave the country, although she would not disclose how they escaped or where they first arrived. **********Speaking in Chinese through a French interpreter, Miss Chai said her worst moment was when she thought her husband had been captured. ''My friends said I had to move places, but I felt very bad,'' she said. ''I thought I would never see him again. If at that moment someone from security had found me, I would not have had the strength to react. I saw the limit of my will.'' **********'We Did Not Go Far Enough' **********After one week, she said, she learned that Mr. Feng was safe, but she did not see him again for four months. She said that occasionally she was accompanied by other fugitive students and dissidents, but that ''most of the time I was hidden alone and I had lots of time to reflect on what happened in Tiananmen Square.'' **********''Today my feeling is that I am not 100 percent satisfied with what we did,'' she said. ''We did not go far enough, take our actions far enough. For example, we were not in contact with people abroad and had little understanding of the impact we had. But I think that, after 40 years of repression, this was the most pacific and reasonable revolt imaginable.'' **********She is believed to have been in charge of protests in Tiananmen Square during the final days of the movement, but she was unable to cast much light on the continuing debate over how many people died when the army tanks and troops moved in shortly before dawn on June 4. **********''I was in the center of the square, but all around I heard shots being fired and ambulance sirens,'' she said in response to a question noting that the Chinese authorities assert no one died in the square. ''We sent out observers and some came back with blood stains on their clothes.'' **********Darkness of Tiananmen Square **********Mr. Feng said that since all lights were switched off in the square, it was difficult to know what was happening. ''Those who were in the square can only testify to what they saw around them,'' he said. ''I don't think even the army or the Communist Party know how many people died.'' **********It is now generally accepted that most of the killings in the crackdown took place not in the square but on the north side, along the Avenue of Eternal Peace, and in other parts of the city. **********Miss Chai said that she would continue the fight to emancipate China, but that first she needed time to adjust. ''I feel very disturbed,'' she said. ''Every time I close my eyes, I see nightmarish scenes that prevent me from sleeping. I feel the souls of the dead are seeking my help. I need time to recover.''
