https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/17/busin.body_text: **********Robert A. Hanson, who directed Deere & Company through its stormiest financial period and into profitability, announced today that he would retire as chairman. **********Mr. Hanson, who is 65 years old, said he will step down on June 1. He has spent 40 years with the company, which manufactures tractors and agricultural equipment. **********Deere's president and chief executive, Hans W. Becherer, is expected to be named chairman at the company's next board meeting. **********Last August, Mr. Hanson gave up the chief executive title in anticipation of his retirement, which is mandatory at Deere when an executive reaches age 66. Mr. Hanson, a native of East Moline, was the first person to run the 153-year-old company who was not a member of the Deere family by blood or marriage. **********He became president in 1978, and a year later was named chief operating officer. He became chairman in 1982 as the company stood on the brink of economic collapse. **********Deere accumulated $328 million in losses in two years and its operating losses totaled $637 million in the six-year period beginning in 1982. **********Mr. Hanson instituted a deep cost-cutting program and laid off about 12,000 workers. His problems were compounded by a 163-day work stoppage at 13 Deere plants in six states that ended on Feb. 1, 1987.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/10/busin.main_headline: A French Paper Brings The World to Children
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/10/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; A French Paper Brings The World to Children
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/10/busin.body_text: **********One of the fastest-growing publications in France is an offbeat four-page newspaper that looks like a cross between USA Today and a coloring book. **********It also has a fast-growing audience: children 8 to 14 years old. **********Le Journal des Enfants, or The Children's Newspaper, began with 10,000 subscribers six years ago, and today it has about 120,000, mostly in France and in French-speaking Switzerland. About 11,000 schools use the weekly in the classroom, and over all the paper has nearly 434,000 readers, mostly children. **********Each issue of the broadsheet newspaper has three pages of national and world news and a fourth page with comics, jokes, contests and mail. The paper is also brimming with graphics and cartoons.   'Children Want More' **********"I was inspired to do this after I saw children trying to understand their parents' newspapers," said the paper's founder and editor, Beatrice Dufourcq. "Children want more than just television. Here they have a newspaper that arrives with their names on it. It is important that they consider the paper their own." **********Recent issues explained why student protests in Paris dissolved into riots, sorted through tribal divisions in Rwanda and tried to make sense of the United States budget crisis. Illustrations are lively and meticulously multiracial, reflecting Ms. Dufourcq's strong editorial stand against racial politics. **********Charging 3 francs a copy or 115 francs (about $23) a year, the paper has been profitable since 1988, and it earned about $1 million last year without a line of advertising. **********"We start with the notion that a child is a serious reader," Ms. Dufourcq said in her office in this mill town in northeastern France. "We don't want to dilute our paper with a hodgepodge of publicity."  Profitable Niche **********Le Journal des Enfants began after Ms. Dufourcq (pronounced doo-FOORK) gained the support of the leading daily newspaper here, L'Alsace. Its publisher, Gilbert Klein, was swayed by her insistence that there was a profitable niche for a paper that spoke to children without speaking down to them. **********He agreed to print the weekly if 6,000 subscribers could be found, and his initial investment was a few thousand dollars in desks and telephones. In exchange, the emblem of L'Alsace appeared at the top of each issue. Le Journal des Enfants has since gone national and international, with a bureau in Paris and a publishing deal with the Swiss daily L'Express. **********If the circulation of Le Journal des Enfants grows just a bit more, to around 130,000, it will surpass that of the daily that wet-nursed it. **********"She's hard-working and hard-headed," Mr. Klein said of Ms. Dufourcq. "I can't convince her to run ads, even though it would mean a bigger paper, with more color pages." **********Le Journal des Enfants receives 100 fan letters a day, and they are usually exultant. **********"Everytime the paper arrives, I jump on it," wrote Franck Nombret, a 13-year-old from Grenoble. "My brother and I don't read it; we eat it up. Le Journal des Enfants is super!" **********But children are not the only ones who appreciate the short, crisp, easy-to-digest articles. **********"We have many older readers, because they find the type size easier to read," said Francoise Itamard, one of the paper's seven staff members. "And, frankly, we're a lot easier to understand than Le Monde." **********"It's true," Ms. Dufourcq said. "Parents often tell me that they look forward to reading us after their children are done."  Death Threats Are Received **********But having adult readers has pitfalls. Ms. Dufourcq has not hesitated to criticize Jean-Marie Le Pen, the French rightist who has made a rapid political career of militant anti-immigrant statements. **********This has led to death threats against Ms. Dufourcq, who writes under the pseudonym of Beatrice D'Irube. **********"I won't hesitate to speak against the parts of French society that I don't like," she said. "Maybe I'm overreacting, but for now, I'll keep the pseudonym. It hasn't hurt the success of my newspaper."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/01/world.main_headline: Northern Bangladesh Floods Kill 14 and Strand Thousands
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/01/world.print_headline: Northern Bangladesh Floods Kill 14 and Strand Thousands
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/01/world.body_text: **********Flooding in dozens of northern villages has killed 14 children, stranded tens of thousands of people and damaged crops across wide areas of Bangladesh in the last several days, news organizations reported today. **********Nine children drowned in flooding over the past week in Sirajganj, 65 miles northwest of Dhaka, said United News of Bangladesh, a news agency. The rain-swollen Jamuna river overflowed its banks in Sirajganj last week, displacing about 300,000 villagers. Many took refuge on the roofs of their mud-and-straw houses. **********The Bengali-language daily Sangbad said five children drowned in northwestern Pabna and Manikganj districts after they fell off rooftops into floodwaters Friday and Saturday. The paper also said floods have affected about 100,000 people in the Sylhet and Netrokona districts in the northeast. **********Flooding in this low-lying delta nation annually kills hundreds of people. The region's worst recent floods killed 1,400 people in 1988.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/10/busin.main_headline: Union Bids for UAL Rejected by Directors
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/10/busin.print_headline: Union Bids for UAL Rejected by Directors
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/10/busin.body_text: **********An audacious and persistent drive by three unions to buy the UAL Corporation apparently ended yesterday when the company's board turned down two offers because they did not have financing and were lower than an offer the directors had accepted in the spring. **********The unions, led by their investment bankers and Gerald Greenwald, a former Chrysler Corporation executive, made a last desperate attempt to come up with bids for the parent of United Airlines after the banks had refused to finance their $175-a-share offer last week. **********Largely Empty-Handed **********The unions, however, could not come up with definite commitments for new cash, from either vendors or other sources. So when Mr. Greenwald appeared before the board yesterday morning he was largely empty-handed and could only offer various plans to obtain cash and financing. **********UAL's stock closed at $88 a share, down $3.25, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange, People at the board meeting, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said it was businesslike and at times cordial, with Mr. Greenwald complimenting the board and Stephen M. Wolf, UAL's chairman and chief executive, for the consideration they had given the bids. Mr. Greenwald would have replaced Mr. Wolf if the takeover by the pilot, machinist and flight attendant unions had succeeded. **********The board, which began deliberating yesterday at an airport hotel and then moved to the board room at UAL headquarters in a suburb of Chicago, was presented with two proposals. **********The first, with a potential total value of $205 a share, included $70 in cash, $31 in senior secured notes, and $74 in various types of trust certificates backed by airplanes. The additional $30 would have depended on the future profitability of United. On Monday, those involved in the bid had said that it would total about $160, excluding the money that depended on future profits. **********The second included no cash but was made up of $178 a share in secured notes and $25 of preferred stock, for a total of $203 a share. **********''The board did not have much to consider,'' said Edward Starkmann, an airline analyst with Paine Webber Inc., considering that there was no financing to back up the bids. **********The United Employee Acquisition Corporation, which represents the unions, said it would continue to pursue employee ownership of UAL. But the group also urged union members to return to their more traditional role of seeking new labor contracts. **********''The three unions are working under open contracts and must now also return to traditional trade union activities while continuing to pursue employee ownership,'' the group said. **********Hank Krakowski, a spokesman for the pilots, said that United's pilots would seek to get increases in their contract similar to those won by pilots at Northwest, Delta and USAir. He added that the union would also seek retroactive increases to cover the two and a half years during which the pilots kept their contract open to pursue the buyout bid. **********The negotiations with the unions could be turbulent, with Mr. Wolf having become a focal point of hostility among some union leaders who believed that he was trying to undercut their takeover efforts. **********''A labor war is going to break out between the unions and Steve Wolf,'' said Joseph Blasi, a professor at the Institute of Management and Labor at Rutgers University. Mr. Blasi, a specialist on employee buyouts, has advised the unions in their takeover efforts. **********Mr. Wolf received a strong endorsement yesterday from the board in a statement by Richard P. Cooley, the chairman and chief executive of the Seafirst Corporation, and a longtime UAL director. He said one key ingredient in building United was ''an able, experienced and dedicated management team led by Steve Wolf, whom we unanimously support.'' **********To get contract talks moving, the board said it had asked the National Mediation Board, a Federal agency, to begin talks with the three unions. Bargaining in the aviation industry is governed by the Railway Labor Act, which provides for certain procedures in reaching a new contract before either a management or union can take certain actions. **********Huge Order for Planes **********The board also asked the management to resume negotations with aircraft and engine makers to put together a huge new order for planes that would total about $10 billion. The board had put off completing the order to give the unions time to put their bids together. **********An unknown faced by the board is what will be done by Coniston Partners, a New York-based investment group that owns 11.8 percent of UAL's shares, which it acquired at an average of about $160 share. With the stock now at $88, Coniston faces huge losses. **********Coniston said yesterday that it was reviewing its options. One that the group had threatened to use in the past was to seek to get the board replaced by soliciting support from shareholders to vote for a new slate. **********Hefty Sum for Greenwald **********Mr. Greenwald will walk away with a hefty sum even though the effort failed. He was paid a $5 million fee by the unions for leaving Chrysler and leading the union drive. He will also collect a $4 million fee from the unions and part of what would have been his annual salary of $1.2 million. **********United's future will depend on how the unions react to their defeat. They had been willing to grant wage and work-rule concessions in return for owning United. Now they will face a Mr. Wolf who will be asking for concessions to help cope with the current grim period, with fuel prices almost doubled and traffic low. **********In the past the unions, particularly the pilots, who spearheaded the takeover drive, have displayed considerable power. They were largely responsible for the ouster of Richard J. Ferris as UAL's chairman after he was tough in negotiations and sought to blunt their drive to win control. **********''Until now, the unions' bargaining position has been pretty much predicated on ownership,'' said Robert Decker, the airline analyst at Duff & Phelps Inc. ''There will be a lot of hard feelings after the lost deal.'' **********The pilot union has said that its members are owed hundreds of millions of dollars in wage increases and that they will want raises similar to those recently granted to Delta and Northwest pilots. The pilots also have the power to cripple United's operations if there is a strike. **********Possibility of Resignation **********Some analysts have raised the possibility that Mr. Wolf could voluntarily resign. He is a wealthy man, having received millions of dollars from the buyouts of Republic Airlines and Flying Tiger Airlines, where he was also chairman and chief executive, and from his recent exercise of United stock-appreciation rights. **********''Wolf could take the funds he got in this most recent round and seek greener pastures,'' said Kevin Murphy, the airline analyst at Morgan Stanley & Company. **********The position of the unions is that largely outside events caused their offers to collapse. One year ago the pilots could not complete the financing for a bid of $300 a share because banks and investors had become concerned about the amount of debt that huge leveraged buyouts were adding onto acquired companies. **********In the current bid of $201 a share, those involved in the negotiations said the union effort to get financing faltered when the Middle East crisis caused banks to become reluctant to commit huge amounts. Thus the drive to acquire the airline could revive when the industry enters more stable times.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/29/busin.main_headline: Technology;   Molar Movies and Other Dentists' Aids
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/29/busin.print_headline: Technology;   Molar Movies and Other Dentists' Aids
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/29/busin.body_text: **********Lights, camera, open wide! The ongoing miniaturization of video technology is bringing tiny cameras into the dentist's office and right into a patient's mouth. **********It's all part of the new world of dentistry, in which the general public's oral hygiene has improved, leaving dentists to spend less time filling cavities and derive an ever greater percentage of their incomes from elective and cosmetic work. **********No bigger than a dentist's mirror, an intraoral video camera sends a high-resolution image to a standard color monitor screen, where it can be viewed by the dentist and patient simultaneously. Primarily intended - and used, so far - as a patient education and awareness tool, intraoral cameras are also beginning to find a place in operations, such as root canals. Dentists say the magnified image makes their job easier. **********Fuji Optical Systems Inc., a Los Gatos, Calif.-based subsidiary of the Fuji Photo Optical Company Ltd. of Japan, introduced the first such system about three years ago and remains the market leader. Also in the field are DentSply International Inc. of York, Pa., and Lester A. Dine of Farmingdale, N.Y. **********Fuji's DentaCam, similar in shape and size to a dentist's mirror, contains a light source to enable visualization of any part of the mouth. The highly magnified image is displayed on a monitor or color television screen. **********Using video processing technology Fuji developed for broadcast cameras, the DentaCam's two fiberoptic light guides strobe a sequence of red, green and blue light across the viewed surface. When the sequential images are combined in the monitor, they provide higher resolution and better color fidelity than images produced by a single full-spectrum light source, according to Fuji. **********A wide-angle lens mounted in the instrument's tip allows it to focus as close as 5 millimeters from a tooth, and a built-in air jet prevents fogging and keeps debris from collecting on the lens. Using foot pedals, the dentist can freeze the display on any view, and can record any image on video floppy disks or print out an instant picture on a video printer. The system also maintains a database of patients' records and images. **********Although sales have been relatively slow so far, the Fuji device and its competitors are beginning to find broader acceptance. **********''I was very skeptical initially because it seemed like just another expensive gadget, but as I used it I became more and more impressed,'' said Gordon J. Christiansen, a Provo, Utah, dentist who is senior consultant to Clinical Research Associates, which reviews and rates dental equipment. **********Dr. Christiansen said he sees intraoral cameras' main benefit as providing better information to patients, which would increase their acceptance of treatment plans. But, he added, after becoming accustomed to using the DentaCam, ''I am at the point where I can actually operate on the screen.'' With its built-in light, the camera can provide better views of rear molars and other difficult areas than a mirror can. **********Others see the new technology more as a sales aid than a diagnostic or educational tool. ''Anytime you can show a patient they have a problem, they say, 'O.K., fix it.' '' said Tom Jow, a San Francisco dentist who has investigated the cameras but does not use them. ''Just another way to get a sales pitch in there.'' **********In any case, at $35,000 for the complete system, DentaCam is out of reach for most dentists, Dr. Christiansen said. What's needed to develop a broader market is a lower-priced camera with similar capability. **********And a much lower-priced camera is just what Michael Williams, president and founder of the AcuImage Corporation in San Carlos, Calif., plans to offer beginning next month. Rather than borrowing from broadcast technology, Mr. Williams has used parts normally found inside the small camcorders popular with home video enthusiasts. ''I'm taking consumer electronics technology and making a medical device out of that,'' he said. Price: about $12,000 for a system. **********Using a color-processing chip developed by Toshiba for camcorders, AcuImage's AcuCam can operate with natural light, as opposed to the red-green-blue light used by Fuji and others. It can also be attached to the halogen light sources and fiberoptic cables used for dentists' drills. Mounting the lens directly on the processing chip reduces the device's complexity and cost, and AcuImage will offer snap-on mirrors and other attachments. **********Mr. Williams explained why price is a bigger factor for dentists than for other medical professionals. **********''Dentists have to buy their own technology, unlike a heart surgeon affiliated with a major hospital,'' he said. ''This is the perfect time to go into the market with a lower-priced camera because Fuji has spent the money to develop it.'' **********AcuImage is billing its camera primarily as an educational device and a sales tool. **********''When a patient's stained front teeth are magnified 18 times and displayed on a bright color screen,'' said Ronald Asti, a San Carlos dentist and co-founder of AcuImage,'' ''it is easier to sell bonding operations, which cover the tooth surface with hard enamel.'' **********An even more advanced technology, oral radio visiography, combines X-rays with video technology. In this technology, a small electronic sensor replaces paper-lined X-ray film. **********Some dentists believe oral radio visiography will be a more important development for serious diagnostic and therapeutic work than the dental video cameras. Like a conventional X-ray, radio visiography can show the interiors of teeth, but it does so instantly, without film, development time or chemicals. And because it requires only 20 percent of the radiation of conventional X-rays, patients and technicians suffer less exposure. **********Trophy U.S.A. Inc., the Atlanta-based subsdiary of the French manufacter Trophy, received Food and Drug Administration approval for the device at the first of the year, and has sold 12 systems since. Depending on configuration, complete systems, including video monitor and printer, sell for $20,000 to $27,000. **********One early user is Michael J. Melde of the Valley Dental Group in Phoenix. He uses the system during root canal operations, but said he finds it primarily aids in diagnosis and in communication with patients. ''If I do see a problem, I can enlarge it on the screen and they're right in there diagnosing with me,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/30/busin.print_headline: FORUM;   Why Schools Belong in Offices
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/30/busin.body_text: **********The preliminary census results remind us once again that America is not an agrarian society. Probably less than a quarter of the population lives in rural areas, and even fewer toil in the amber fields of grain. Why is it, then, that the American educational system continues to be based on an agricultural model? A respite during the summer and short school days made sense when children were needed at home during harvest and chore times, but currently it is competitiveness that counts, not cows. **********As is well known, the Japanese spend many more hours per year in school than our students. Perhaps less appreciated is that the West German school year is also two months longer than ours. The American educational clock should be switched to the industrial mode: year-round activity, approximately eight hours per day. **********With 65 percent of all mothers working outside the home, it's logical to place schools in or very near the workplace. The purposes behind ''neighborhood schools'' cannot be fulfilled if there is no one at home in the neighborhood. **********Although it may seem odd to suggest putting our schools on a work place schedule and calendar, locating them by our places of work would address some of our most pressing social concerns. **********Recent educational reports, for instance, bemoan the lack of parental involvement in a child's learning and in school activities. Work place schools would enable parents to attend parent-teacher meetings and after-school events and even to eat lunch with their children. Commuting could be done together. **********Placing schools in working areas would also be an efficient use of resources. The current glut of downtown office space throughout the country is a convenient match with educational needs, particularly because the present baby boomlet reaching school age may be too transitory to justify building traditional schools. **********As for funding, businesses might be willing to lease space at advantageous rates or even donate space for limited, experimental periods. True, a workplace school system would spell the demise of the local property-tax funding mechanism, but other notable trends - such as constitutional challenges to this system in at least 12 states point toward state-based funding for schools. **********There are a handful of American companies that have established such schools, both public and private, but such efforts are not well-publicized nor applauded as a trend. The dismantling of American family life may date from the Industrial Revolution, when the work place and the home became separate. Better to see if bringing education into the workplace will restore an aspect of unity to life than to leave education stuck on ''Old McDonald's Farm.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/04/world.main_headline: France Stops Issuing Lebanese Visas, Citing Army Blockade
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/04/world.print_headline: France Stops Issuing Lebanese Visas, Citing Army Blockade
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/04/world.body_text: **********France stopped issuing visas to Lebanese today, apparently because of President Elias Hrawi's refusal to lift a blockade intended to end the rebellion by Gen. Michel Aoun. **********The Communist-run Voice of the People radio station reported that France was no longer issuing visas to Lebanese, and a French Embassy official confirmed the report. **********The official said the military blockade of the area controlled by General Aoun prevents French consular officials from commuting between their two embassy branches to complete visa formalities. **********The French Ambassador to Lebanon, Rene Ala, told Mr. Hrawi on Monday of France's displeasure with the blockade, saying it would hurt the blockaded region's population of 150,000 more than General Aoun and his 15,000 Christian soldiers, the Voice of the People said. **********Sympathy With Maronites **********France has sympathized with Lebanon's Maronite Catholics, who supported its 1920-43 mandate in Lebanon and have dominated the country since independence. Many wealthy Lebanese Maronites have adopted the French language and culture, and prize their freedom to travel to France. **********Mr. Hrawi and General Aoun are Maronites. The Syrian-backed Mr. Hrawi was elected President on Nov. 24 with a mandate to enforce an Arab League-brokered plan to end the 15-year-old civil war between Muslims and Christians. **********Mr. Hrawi's mainly Muslim 20,000-man army last week closed all crossings and prevented essential supplies from reaching areas controlled by General Aoun in an effort to pressure the general into submission. **********On Monday night thousands of General Aoun's supporters demonstrated to protest the blockade. The rally was raked by gunfire, and police said at least 30 people were killed and 100 wounded. **********Aoun Blames Militia **********General Aoun blamed the massacre on the Christian warlord Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces militia, which shares control of the area near the bridge with Mr. Hrawi's soldiers. **********Mr. Hrawi's Government said its troops did not fire on the demonstrators. Mr. Geagea accused General Aoun of engineering the killings to win sympathy. **********Earlier this year, General Aoun and Mr. Geagea fought a four-month war for control of the 300-square-mile Christian area in central Lebanon. The confrontation, which took more than 1,000 lives, left the area partitioned. Mr. Geagea's 6,000-strong militia hold about 80 percent of the region.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/01/busin.body_text: **********The former chairman of Modulaire Industries and the wife of Modulaire's former president settled Federal charges today that they had violated the anti-fraud provisions of Federal securities laws by tipping off friends about a pending merger between the company and Waste Management Inc. in the spring of 1987. **********In a civil complaint filed in Federal court in San Francisco, the Securities and Exchange Commission contended that Waste Management officials met repeatedly with Joseph Behar, Modulaire's co-founder and chairman, and David Wailes, Modulaire's co-founder and president, in April and May 1987 to discuss a possible acquisition. **********Modulaire, based in San Francisco, sells, rents and services nonresidential modular structures. It is now part of Waste Management. **********The S.E.C. said the two sides concluded an agreement on a purchase price of $16 on share at a time that Modulaire's stock was trading for about $7. **********The S.E.C. said Mr. Wailes telephoned his wife, Adrienne, who ''started calling friends and relatives in rapid succession to tip them to buy Modulaire before the acquisition was announced.'' **********All of the individuals who received the tips settled anti-fraud charges without admitting or denying the allegations. **********Mr. Behar paid $43,200, the amount of illegal profits made by the person who traded on his information, and an additional penalty of $43,200. **********Mrs. Wailes was forced to pay a penalty of $78,130.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/27/busin.main_headline: Dow Falls 25.99 on Signs of Weak Economy
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/27/busin.print_headline: Dow Falls 25.99 on Signs of Weak Economy
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/27/busin.body_text: **********Stocks turned around again yesterday and continued to burrow deeper into negative territory as investor sentiment darkened, the price of oil rose another notch and new data showed that the economy was still weakening. **********The Dow Jones industrial average, which slid as much as 42 points by noontime, was off 25.99 at the close, to 2,459.65. **********Birinyi Associates, which tracks program trading, said six waves of selling starting within an hour of the opening bell chopped 29 points off the Dow. **********A.T.& T., the nation's most widely held stock and one of the weakest of the blue chips today, dropped 3/8, to 31 1/2, after Joel D. Gross, telecommunications analyst for the Wall Street firm of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, trimmed his earnings estimates because of the weak economy. **********It was the most actively traded stock on the New York Stock Exchange, with 7.4 million shares changing hands, and gave further confirmation that investors were abandoning even solid blue chips at the first sign of weakness. **********Trading activity on the Big Board fell slightly, to 155.6 million shares, from 155.9 million a day earlier. **********In another sign of the daily erosion of stock prices, 1,119 stocks dropped in price and 309 fell to new lows, while only 421 issues advanced in price and only 2 rose to new highs. **********While much of Wall Street seemed to feel that a huge pool of capital was waiting to jump into the market, Ronald J. Hill, investment strategist for Brown Brothers Harriman, argued that the cash level was ''not so high.'' **********One thing that would lift the market quickly, he said, would be a resolution of what he called ''the stalemates.'' **********''Investors are giving up on the stalemates,'' he said. ''There's a stalemate in the Iraq crisis. There's a stalemate on the budget and there's a stalemate on lower interest rates. The longer the stalemates continue, the more likely the negative effects move deeper into the economy.'' **********In New York, the price of oil continued to move higher, ending the day at $38.67 a barrel, up $1.14. But in London, some analysts urged clients to get out of oil shares, arguing that even if war broke out, crude prices might not move much higher. **********Although several analysts are still bullish on oil, nearly every leading oil stock fell yesterday. Among the Dow stocks, Chevron sank 1 1/8, to 76; Exxon 5/8, to 49 7/8; Texaco 5/8, to 62 5/8, and USX 3/8, to 31 5/8. Among other oil issues, ARCO fell 1 7/8, to 137; Unocal 1 1/8, to 32 1/8, and Pennzoil 2, to 77 5/8.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/27/world.main_headline: Turnover in Nicaragua;   NICARAGUAN OPPOSITION ROUTS SANDINISTAS; U.S. PLEDGES AID, TIED TO ORDERLY TURNOVER
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/27/world.print_headline: Turnover in Nicaragua;   NICARAGUAN OPPOSITION ROUTS SANDINISTAS; U.S. PLEDGES AID, TIED TO ORDERLY TURNOVER
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/27/world.body_text: **********The leader of Nicaragua's opposition coalition crushed President Daniel Ortega Saavedra in national elections here on Sunday, apparently bringing an end to 10 turbulent years of Sandinista rule. **********The landslide victory by the opposition candidate, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, turned the closely monitored elections into a powerful repudiation of one of Latin America's most prominent and fiercely debated revolutionary Governments. **********Celebrating her victory early today after the results were made public, Mrs. Chamorro said, ''We have shown the world an example of civic duty, demonstrating that we Nicaraguans want to live in democracy, want to live in peace and, above all, that we want to live in liberty.'' **********Ortega Pledges Acceptance **********President Ortega, looking subdued as the results became known, said, ''The President of Nicaragua and the Government of Nicaragua are going to respect and obey the popular mandate coming out of the vote in these elections.'' [Excerpts from the two speeches appear on page A12.]  Despite Mrs. Chamorro's victory, and President Ortega's seeming acquiescence in defeat, there remains skepticism that Mr. Ortega, a lifelong revolutionary and politician, will be able to persuade the Sandinista Front to accept a Chamorro government. Mrs. Chamorro is scheduled to be inaugurated on April 25. **********The vote lays the groundwork for the first democratic transfer of power that this country has known, a turnover that parallels to some degree the changes in Eastern Europe, where Communism has little by little given way to democratic change. **********Lead of 14 Percentage Points **********Mrs. Chamorro, 60 years old, is the widow of Pedro Joaquin Chamorro, the newspaper publisher whose assassination touched off the rebellion that led to the Sandinista takeover. She ran as the candidate of the 14-party National Opposition Union, a coalition of leftists, rightists and other Nicaraguan parties. **********The official voting results, supervised by a large contingent of international observers, including former President Jimmy Carter, gave Mrs. Chamorro a lead of 14.4 percentage points. Her vote total with 82 percent of the ballots counted was put at 633,357, or 55.2 percent of the presidential vote. Mr. Ortega of the Sandinista National Liberation Front received 468,040 votes, or 40.8 percent of the total. **********Small parties received the rest of the votes as Nicaraguans elected a President, Vice President and National Assembly, which the opposition will now control. **********Across the country, beginning in the early morning, there was the almost surreal sensation of imminent change. Nicaraguans shared a widespread sense of awe at the power of their own votes, and disbelief that something so pervasive and apparently entrenched as the Sandinista Front had suddenly been swept aside. A huge rally planned near Sandinista headquarters slowly dissolved into a mournful gathering, while opposition loyalists whooped it up at the restaurant that has become their staging ground. **********The Chamorro victory has stunned many political analysts, and American officials also appeared to be caught off guard by the depth of the Sandinista defeat. Polls by outside groups consistently suggested that the Sandinistas would sweep to victory, and just last week the Government mounted a rally of at least 300,000 people, dwarfing similar opposition demonstrations. **********But reporters and other outsiders who spent hours interviewing average citizens in working-class neighborhoods became convinced that the polls were misleading. Their view was that the electorate of about 1.7 million in this country of 3.5 million was articulating support for Mr. Ortega while secretly looking to oust the Sandinistas after a decade of civil war and economic ruin. **********In recent days the White House softened its line toward the Sandinistas, suggesting that after an expected Ortega victory, Washington would try to mend relations with the Government, against which it has waged a civil war by proxy for about eight years. Today, President Bush exulted in the opposition's victory. **********Threats to Orderly Transition **********But an orderly transition is far from certain. In recent weeks, Interior Minister Tomas Borge, who controls the secret police and is considered one of the most rigid members of the nine-member Sandinista National Directorate, has repeatedly suggested that the election of Mrs. Chamorro would make Nicaragua ''ungovernable.'' **********Tonight, truckloads of Interior Ministry riot troops clashed with crowds of youthful opposition supporters in Managua. Using tear gas and truncheons, the police repeatedly charged at the youths, who responded by throwing sticks and pavement stones and taunting the officers. **********In the ranks of the Sandinista People's Army, which is headed by Mr. Ortega's brother, Humberto, and in the Interior Ministry, virtually all officers and most enlisted men are subject to Sandinista political training. And Mr. Borge has pointedly said that attempts to change the current leadership would be met by insubordination and even violence from Sandinista forces. **********The military is particularly suspicious of members of the opposition coalition who have longstanding ties to the United States-armed contra rebels. The civil war has killed 30,000 Nicaraguans since it began in the early 1980's. **********''Given the existence of revolutionary armed forces,'' the official Sandinista newspaper Barricada said, describing Mr. Borge's views, ''how could the officers obey the wild orders of those who were named Minister of Defense and Minister of the Interior?'' **********No Comment From Borge **********Aides to President Ortega said he was speaking for all Sandinista party members and officials, including Mr. Borge, in his promise to respect the election results. But Mr. Borge did not appear at the gathering, and he has made no public comment on the defeat of the Sandinista Front, of which he is the last surviving founder. **********The election results appeared certain to produce a dramatic improvement in deeply strained relations between Nicaragua and the Bush Administration, which gave political and financial support to Mrs. Chamorro's candidacy. They were seen as a virtual guarantee of an end to the American-sponsored insurgency. And they promised to deal a powerful blow to American adversaries like the Cuban leader, Fidel Castro, and to the leftist guerrillas in El Salvador, both longtime allies of the Sandinista Government. **********Mr. Ortega, who said in an interview on Friday that Mrs. Chamorro did not have ''even a hypothetical possibility'' of victory, compared his party's defeat to the bitterest moments of the Sandinistas' long guerrilla war to overthrow the former dictator, Anastasio Somoza Debayle. He said the party would accept without malice the prospect of leaving power. **********''We were born poor and are satisfied to die poor,'' said Mr. Ortega, who remained composed as he spoke to journalists and cheering supporters at a large, modern Government convention hall here. ''We worked in these elections to emphasize a project which has become a challenge to the intelligence, the imagination, the creativity of the people in their permanent struggle for their liberation.'' **********The Associated Press reported tonight that Mr. Ortega briefly visited Mrs. Chamorro at her home to offer his congratulations. Accompanied by several foreign observers, including Mr. Carter, he hugged the victorious candidate, who spoke to him affectionately. **********Mr. Ortega reportedly said, ''You know that I respect you, and that I love you and congratulate you on your victory,'' adding, ''I am ready to contribute to the national reconciliation.'' **********Effort to Reassure Military **********Seeking to allay fears of possible retribution or wholesale dismissals from the military and security forces, Mrs. Chamorro and her advisers have repeatedly emphasized that they will remove only high-ranking Sandinista officers, and will not take abrupt or arbitrary action against soldiers or other social or political groups. **********''This is an election that will never have exiles, or political prisoners, or confiscations,'' Mrs. Chamorro said in her acceptance statement. ''Here we have neither victors nor vanquished.'' **********There was no immediate word on how such a policy might be received by the estimated 10,000 remaining members of the contra army. Nor was there a clear sense of how contra fighters who return to the country under an expected total amnesty would be received by former Sandinista military units, or integrated into those units. **********But both issues promised to add to the burdens of the diverse and frequently divided opposition leadership, which has never shown the success at internal politics that it showed in Sunday's balloting. **********Results Were Delayed **********Although election results were promised to reporters and international observers beginning just two hours after the 6 P.M. close of voting, initial returns were abruptly discontinued at mid-evening on Sunday. Official radio stations stopped broadcasting news reports, playing only a stream of music. **********Questioned by reporters, election officials attributed the problem to slow receipt of information from outlying districts and inexperienced computer technicians at the large convention center, where hundreds of special phone and telex lines were installed to process the election results. **********Several diplomats suggested that the counting had been stopped to give international officials time to persuade Mr. Ortega and other Sandinista leaders to accept the vote. But that version of events was denied by Mr. Carter, who said the announcement was held up by a previous agreement among the political parties not to release incomplete results. So far, independent election observers have reported few if any irregularities, and appear ready to judge the voting fair. **********At the barn-like Managua restaurant that has served as an opposition meeting place during the campaign, hundreds of cheering, dancing, crying opposition supporters arrived to celebrate Mrs. Chamorro's victory, yelling loud chants and signaling ''No. 1'' with their fingers. The coalition's acronym, UNO, means ''one'' in Spanish. **********Across town at a large fairground that had been reserved for a Sandinista victory celebration, crowds began appearing before the scheduled start of the midnight rally. In place were giant sound systems, spotlights and the other equipment that has become a standard feature of mass Sandinista rallies. **********But as the news of Mr. Ortega's defeat filtered through the crowd, preparations for dancing and drinking gave way to silence and ashen faces. **********In the working class neighborhood of Batahola North, 25-year-old Lorena Sanchez Barrios sat with her child and wept openly as she listened to Mr. Ortega's speech accepting the results. **********''I can't believe it,'' she said, expressing an emotion shared by supporters of the Sandinistas and the opposition alike. ''I just can't believe it.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/13/busin.main_headline: Door Revolves Again At Top of Winnebago
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/13/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;   Door Revolves Again At Top of Winnebago
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/13/busin.body_text: **********The revolving door at Winnebago Industries turned again yesterday, and out went Richard D. Conner as president and chief executive. **********In a terse announcement, the maker of recreational vehicles in Forest City, Iowa, said the board had terminated the employment of Mr. Conner. He had been in the posts since December. **********John K. Hanson, the company's 76-year-old founder and chairman, who has been unable to put a successor in place, was named acting chief executive. **********The company has lost money in the last three quarters, and sales of its top line of recreational vehicles are down significantly, said an analyst, Frank P. Rolfes of Dain Bosworth Inc. in Minneapolis. ''The overall recreational vehicles business is not good,'' he said, ''but Winnebago is suffering more than the industry.'' **********He attributed Winnebago's performance to quality and production problems and misjudgment in building inventory. Yesterday's termination of Mr. Conner, however, did not move the stock, which closed at $5.125, unchanged, on the New York Stock Exchange. **********''They've had a revolving door there for several years,'' Mr. Rolfes said. ''It didn't hurt the stock today, but this uncertainty about management has hurt in the long run.'' **********Mr. Conner and Mr. Hanson were not available to comment, a company spokesman said. In December, when he was named to the top posts, Mr. Conner said he was not concerned about management flux. ''I've worked as a consultant for John K.,'' he said. ''We've tested out our relationship and found it extremely enjoyable and fruitful.'' **********Mr. Hanson, who Mr. Rolfes said has not been in good health lately, has tried out several people in the chief executive post in the last decade, including a son, John V. Hanson, and all have been found wanting. The elder Mr. Hanson is ''the key to the thing,'' Mr. Rolfes said, ''and anything that happens will be based on his influence.'' The Hansons own 45 percent of the company. **********Mr. Conner, 57, joined Winnebago in 1988 as chief executive of a Winnebago subsidiary, Cycle Sat, which distributes commercials to television stations via satellite. He was made deputy chairman last August, succeeding Mr. Hanson's son, who left the company. **********At that time, a 10-member management council was in operation. The council was set up after the departure a year ago of Gerald Gilbert, president and chief executive. **********Mr. Conner and Mr. Gilbert once both held senior management positions at the Control Data Corporation in Minneapolis but were not well acquainted there. Mr. Conner left Control Data in 1985 after 18 years, to set up a consulting firm. He was a Winnebago board member since 1984.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/25/world.main_headline: BUCHAREST ENVOY TO U.S. IS NAMED
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/25/world.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: DIPLOMAT;   BUCHAREST ENVOY TO U.S. IS NAMED
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/25/world.body_text: **********Rumania's provisional Government has named new Ambassadors to Washington, Moscow and Paris and forbidden its diplomats from joining political parties, the country's United Nations Mission said today. **********The new Government's charge d'affaires here, Ioan N. Voicu, said Bucharest had asked the United States to accept Virgil Constantinescu, the country's Deputy Foreign Minister and a former Rumanian diplomat who fell afoul of President Nicolae Ceausescu, as Rumania's new Ambassador in Washington. **********Earlier this month, Rumania's new leaders withdrew their country's envoys in Washington, at the United Nations and in Moscow and Paris because of their affiliation with the ousted Ceausescu Government. **********Mr. Constantinescu became Deputy Foreign Minister in the new Rumanian Government after Mr. Ceausescu was executed last month. Before the revolution, he had worked for several years in the Government department dealing with religious questions after being removed from a senior Foreign Ministry position on Mr. Ceausescu's orders for undisclosed reasons. **********Law on Political Parties **********In Washington, Adminstration officials confirmed that Rumania has asked President Bush to accept Mr. Constantinescu as its new Ambassador but said that the process of reviewing the application has only just begun. **********Mr. Voicu said the new Rumanian Government has asked the Soviet Union to accredit Vasile Sandru, a retired diplomat who has served as Ambassador to Spain and Yugoslavia, as its new envoy there. Mr. Sandru is being brought out of retirement to take the post. **********The nominee for Paris, whose name was not available, was described as a writer who was ''outside the Ceausescu circle.'' **********The Rumanian Mission to the United Nations today issued an English translation of a new Rumanian law dealing with the formation and registration of political parties in the country after the decision to establish a democratic political system. **********Article 5 of the new law seeks to assure the political independence of the Rumanian diplomatic service as well as of the armed forces, the judiciary and the radio and television services. **********The article states that members of the armed forces, civilian Defense Ministry officials, judges, prosecutors and ''operative personnel of the free Rumanian radio and television services'' may not be members of any of the political parties established under the new law.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/21/busin.body_text: **********Penguin Books USA announced yesterday that it had appointed Michael Jacobs president of its Viking Penguin division. **********Mr. Jacobs succeeds Morton **********Mint, who resigned abruptly last week. **********Mr. Jacobs, who was senior vice president for sales and marketing, joins Marvin Brown, whose appointment as president of Penguin's NAL Dutton division was announced last week. Mr. Mint had been responsible for both divisions during his nine-month term as chief executive. **********Viking Penguin publishes about 730 new adult titles a year, and NAL Dutton about 550. Penguin is owned by Pearson P.L.C., the British conglomerate, which also owns The Financial Times of London. Both Mr. Jacobs and Mr. Brown will report to Peter Mayer, who is executive chairman of Penguin Books USA.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/30/world.main_headline: Upheaval in the East;   RUMANIAN RULERS CALL OUT THRONGS AND STAGE A RALLY
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/30/world.print_headline: Upheaval in the East;   RUMANIAN RULERS CALL OUT THRONGS AND STAGE A RALLY
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/30/world.body_text: **********In a show of strength for the ruling Council of National Salvation, about 20,000 demonstrators poured into the capital today and laid siege to the headquarters of opposition parties. **********The well-organized demonstration, which included many workers who came by truck from local factories, was a response to a protest Sunday by three opposition parties. That rally ended in a tense face-off between pro- and anti-council groups at the central Victory Place. **********The showdowns this week have heightened tensions in Rumania, where mounting chaos is threatening the country's move toward democracy. **********The council includes high-ranking members of the ousted Communist Government of Nicolae Ceausescu. It has been in power since Dec. 22, and in recent weeks the public has grown impatient with the council's rigid control. Free elections are scheduled for May 20. **********Menacing Slogans **********Shouting menacing slogans, crowds of demonstrators today massed in front of the headquarters of the Peasants Party and the Liberal Party in downtown Bucharest and demanded the dissolution of both. While the police stood by, protesters broke into the offices of the Liberal Party, forcing its leaders to flee, and pasted pro-council slogans in the second-story windows. **********The president of the Peasants Party, Corneliu Coposu, left the headquarters building in an armored personnel carrier, together with the council-appointed Prime Minister, Petre Roman, in an effort to guarantee his safety against the crowd of several thousand. **********The chanting demonstrators demanded that Mr. Coposu be driven from the country; he agreed to leave to make a statement on television, but none was broadcast. **********Small groups continued to gather on the city's dimly lit streets into the evening. Students interviewed on University Place tonight said they were dejected by the day's events and were certain the protest demonstrations would start again. **********Some politicians also said that public demonstrations, which have become almost a daily event here, had gone too far. **********But a few members of the ruling council expressed concern about the course the demonstrations were taking. Standing today at the headquarters of the Peasants Party, where he had come with Mr. Roman in an attempt to defuse the tense situation, Cazimir Ionescu, the deputy chairman of the council's executive committee, lamented the threats from the crowd. **********''We have a great sickness in this country,'' he said. ''We are apolitical because we have been indoctrinated for 25 years. These men outside are well intentioned, but they don't know the rules of democracy.'' **********But another leader in the council's ruling body accused the opposition of orchestrating a ''putsch'' on Sunday, which he said justified the council's appeal for help from its supporters. **********Spokesmen for the council insisted that today's protests were spontaneous, but opposition leaders charged that factory workers had been given the day off and paid 500 lei - worth $55.56, or the equivalent of an average week's wage - to demonstrate against the opposition. **********Little Violence Reported **********Despite the threats and animosity, there were only a few detailed cases of violence late Sunday night and today. At a news conference today, Sylviu Brucan, a prominent leader of the council, said three people had been ''lightly or half stabbed'' at Victory Place on Sunday. **********Mr. Brucan said the opposition's ''assault'' Sunday against the council headquarters at Victory Place was bound to produce a backlash. **********''We told them not to come to Victory Place,'' Mr. Brucan said in an interview after the news conference. ''But no, they wanted to come to the headquarters. Well, now they have reaped the fruit of what they have done.'' **********The demonstrations today heightened suspicion between the opposing political groups, even though Government and opposition spokesmen said the sides have agreed to meet again Thursday for roundtable talks. **********Council Urged to Yield **********Mr. Coposu said that in the talks held Sunday he had demanded that the council abandon its monopoly of power. ''They have put themselves in the absurd position of holding all the levers of power, and they want to run in the election,'' he said. Mr. Coposu said he had proposed a broader coalition that would include representatives of the three main opposition parties, the Peasants' Party, the Liberal Party and the Social Democratic Party. **********The council's counter-offer was to expand itself to include all registered parties, which now number about 18. Mr. Coposu said this was unacceptable because all but four or five parties were ''phantom organizations, invented as diversions.'' **********Mr. Brucan said today that the council would refuse to limit participation in the roundtable talks. ''We will never again meet with just those three parties, never,'' he said. ''We have had it with them up to here.'' **********The latest round of demonstrations, which took on a more threatening tone, reminded many Rumanians of the Communist era, when local party organizations dispatched crowds to drown out dissident voices. **********Workers Replace Students **********The demonstrations today and Sunday seemed to split along class as well as political lines. Whereas the demonstrators on Sunday were mostly young students and professionals, today's protesters were mostly factory workers who came and left the city in large Government-owned trucks. **********One political division is between those who see the revolution as a revolt against 24 years of Ceausescu rule and those who see it as a rejection of Communism. **********At a rally of the pro-council demonstrators today at Victory Place, the Rumanian President, Ion Iliescu, repeatedly said the revolution was still not over. He said the council would never succumb to pressure like that applied at the demonstration on Sunday, and he applauded today's demonstrators for rising up in support of the council.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/27/world.main_headline: U.S. Warns of Possible Terrorist Attack on a Ship
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/27/world.print_headline: MIDEAST TENSIONS; U.S. Warns of Possible Terrorist Attack on a Ship
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/27/world.body_text: **********The State Department issued an unusually explicit warning tonight of a possible terrorist attack against a passenger ship in the eastern Mediterranean, saying that "such an operation may be undertaken at any time." **********Although the department has issued a number of advisories of terrorist dangers since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and the American military buildup in Saudi Arabia, this one was the most direct and detailed. **********But the statement, which said that the risk of terrorism in general is increasing in the Middle East and Europe, did not offer any advice to passengers who might hold reservations on ships. **********It warned that civil aviation, too, "remains a potential target" for terrorists, especially in those regions. **********Richard A. Boucher, the State Department spokesman who issued the warning, said that the Government "has received information which it believes is specific and credible" that led it to issue the public warning. Extradition Due Soon **********Other officials said that the information was not precise enough to allow the United States or other governments to take specific countermeasures to prevent an attack. **********Since the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland in December 1988, the Government has adopted a policy of warning the public about terrorist threats when they are considered credible but cannot be countered. **********In this case, the risk of an attack is increased because the United States is about to extradite an accused member of the Abu Nidal terrorist organization to Israel, where he is to stand trial for charges stemming from an attack on an Israeli bus in 1986 in which the driver was killed and a passenger wounded. **********The suspect, Mahmoud Atta, who also uses the name Mahmoud El-Abed Ahmad, was arrested in the United States three years ago. He exhausted his appeals against extradition in August, and the move is imminent, officials said. The Abu Nidal organization has repeatedly said it would respond to his extradition with an attack on American interests, and the State Department said today that it "takes these threats seriously in view of the A.N.O.'s notorious history." Achille Lauro Recalled **********In July 1988, Abu Nidal was blamed by Western intelligence agencies for two attacks against an excursion vessel, the City of Poros, in Greece. **********The organization was not involved in the attack in December 1985 against the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro as it left an Egyptian port. That attack was by a group led by Abu Abbas. **********A Government official said today that although the Abu Nidal group was mentioned in the latest warning, the possible attack on a passenger ship might well come from another group. **********Another official said that the threat was believed to involve a ship that would be moving between Cyprus and Israel. **********But the officials declined to say that passengers should cancel reservations on ships. **********One official said it should be up to individuals to make their own choices, and that the State Department's job was simply to provide cautionary information.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/23/world.body_text: **********In two primitive thatched-roof shrines dimly lit by torches and bonfires, Emperor Akihito concluded a solitary all-night vigil of prayer and thanksgiving this morning as part of his accession to the throne, amid a continuing dispute over whether the rites transformed him into a "living god." **********The ceremony, known as the daijosai, or great food-offering ritual, brought a solemn, mysterious and debate-filled conclusion to the events installing the 56-year-old Emperor, who succeeded to the Chrysanthemum Throne upon the death of his father, Hirohito, in January of last year. **********Akihito is the 125th Emperor of Japan, in a dynasty that traces its roots to the seventh century. For most of history, the emperor has held little power, and since the end of World War II he has been defined as a mere "symbol" of the state. **********But the daijosai -- last performed by Hirohito in 1928 -- was an extraordinary moment in Japanese cultural history, for the first time transporting the ancient origins of the world's oldest monarchic dynasty into the glare of modern publicity.  Criticism of Government **********Before the ceremony, the top Government spokesman dismissed criticism that the attendance at the Shinto rite by Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu and his Cabinet violated the separation of religion and government as provided in the Constitution. **********"This does not mean that politics is meddling in religion, or that religion is increasing its influence in politics," said Misoji Sakamoto, the chief Cabinet secretary. **********Indeed, the daijosai came two days after the Cabinet approved what it said was the Government's view that the ceremony was not -- as maintained by many Christian and Buddhist leaders and constitutional scholars -- a Shinto religious rite that traditionally rendered the emperor into a deity. **********The issue is a sensitive one because a handful of militant nationalists still espouse emperor worship, the credo used to justify Japanese military aggression in World War II. The polls show that only about five percent of Japanese believe in the divinity of the Emperor. 'Special Conditions' Cited **********Acknowledging that pre-war Japanese textbooks stated that the Emperor was united with the spirit of the sun goddess in the rite, the Cabinet said in a statement, "We consider the text as written that way because of the special conditions of the time." **********Scholars say that the daijosai, which has its origins in harvest festivals, has been conducted in one form or another since prehistoric times, although it was suspended for more than two centuries before Japanese reunification in the 17th century, and that much of the meaning of its traditions was lost. **********After a ritual bath, the Emperor, wearing white silk robes symbolizing purification, marched solemnly surrounded by courtiers. **********After his entrance, the Emperor went out of public view and, inside two shrines, offered food and rice wine to the spirit of his mythical ancestor, the sun goddess Amaterasu Omikami. He then consumed some of it himself while praying for the well-being of the nation and for peace on earth. **********He carried out this ceremony twice, first in one specially built shrine of rough-hewn pine logs and grass mats from 6:30 P.M. to 9:30 P.M. Thursday, and then in another from 12:30 to 3:30 A.M. this morning.  Spectators See Little **********The ceremony ended at 3:33 A.M. By then the near-freezing weather had persuaded almost a third of the spectators in a separate open building, who could only see glimmerings of the ceremony in the dark, to leave. **********By contrast to the more formal enthronement ceremonies last week, no statements were made and no foreigners were allowed at the rites today, and 980 Japanese dignitaries led by Mr. Kaifu were kept in a separate room. **********The Government has also drawn criticism because it budgeted about $20 million for the ceremony, insisting that it is primarily secular. **********On Monday, representatives of 14 Christian denominations, including the Catholic and Episcopal Churches, presented a petition from 130,000 people opposing the Government's transformation of "a ceremony of one specific religious sect into a state function with the use of public funds." **********The Socialist and Communist Parties boycotted the ceremony today, charging that it violated the constitutional ban on state support of religion.  'Public Is Very Interested' **********But Mr. Sakamoto, the chief Cabinet secretary, said it was legitimate for public funds to be used to pay for the rites. "The public is very interested in the ceremony, so it is natural to pay for them with public funds," he said. **********Christians make up less than one percent of the Japanese population, but polls show that as many as a third of Japanese are opposed to the $20 million public expenditure for the daijosai. **********Left-wing opponents of the rite have firebombed several Shinto shrines in protest, causing heavy damage. **********Meanwhile, the daijosai has been the focus of intense news coverage. Many articles, for instance, have put forth various theories of scholars about the function of a matted bed and coverlet in the inner sanctum. Some experts have suggested that the Emperor lies on the bed and transforms himself into a god or in some fashion communes, perhaps in a symbolically sexual way, with the spirit of the sun goddess. **********In response to these theories, the ritualists of the Imperial Household Agency have said that the bed is used as a resting place for the sun goddess but that the Emperor never touches it.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/23/busin.body_text: **********In an attempt to stem a flight of capital, the Belgian Government approved plans today to reduce its rate of withholding tax on investors' interest income. **********The Finance Minister, Philippe Maystadt, said that if legislators passed the measure, the tax would be cut on March 1 to 10 percent, from 25 percent, for interest revenues from new fixed-rate securities and bank accounts. **********Mr. Maystadt blamed the 25 percent rate for an increase in the flow of capital from Belgium, to some $3.6 billion last year, mainly to Luxembourg, West Germany and the Netherlands, which have no such tax. **********He said a shortfall in tax revenues because of the cut would be recouped by limiting certain business tax breaks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/02/busin.body_text: **********The Chancellor of the Exchequer, John Major, said today that the outlook for Britain's overheated economy was good if high wage increases did not cripple the Government's anti-inflation strategy. **********''Providing we are able to deliver, economically, a low inflation-high investment economy, then the prospects for us in the 1990's are very bright indeed,'' Mr. Major told the British Broadcasting Corporation. **********He emphasized that an expected round of pay settlements in private industry would be crucial to lowering inflation and preventing more unemployment. **********''To a very large extent, the fate of employment rests in the hands of those who are negotiating wages at present,'' he said. **********Wage increases in the public sector have inched above 9 percent despite the Government's efforts to enforce an unofficial 7 percent ceiling, which is in line with inflation. **********The Ford Motor Company, which sets the standard for much of private industry in Britain, is facing a strike from unions seeking pay increases of more than 10 percent and a 35-hour work week. **********Pay militancy has been reinforced by the Government's loss of control of the economy during the last 18 months, which has resulted in sharply higher inflation and a trade deficit of more than $32 billion last year. **********Mr. Major said today that he did not believe the strategy of high interest rates, which has damaged the Government politically, would tip the economy into recession this year as some critics have warned.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/03/world.main_headline: Guilin Journal;   China's Arms Wide Open for Army From Taiwan
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/03/world.print_headline: Guilin Journal;   China's Arms Wide Open for Army From Taiwan
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/03/world.body_text: **********For years, Chinese have treated Western visitors to a glimpse of the Li River, which spills through a landscape of jutting mountains and misty skies that have inspired poets and painters for centuries. **********But now, as fewer Western tourists visit China's famous landscapes and historical sites, Chinese find themselves catering to another kind of visitor: the Taiwan tourist. **********Walk into any large hotel in a major city in China and there are probably Taiwanese there, filling the lobby with their lively chatter and carrying bags of strange-looking local specialties like dried squids, musk and tiger-bone plaster for arthritis. **********''They know how beautiful the Guilin landscape is,'' said Liu Bijun, deputy general manager at China International Travel Service in Guilin in southern China. ''But they come here and to the rest of China because they want to know if it has changed in the last 40 years.'' **********A Long Separation Ends **********Taiwan allowed its citizens to come here only in late 1987, breaking a forced separation lasting nearly 40 years after the Nationalists fled to the island of Taiwan on their defeat in the Chinese civil war. **********Now its citizens travel here in large groups and fill the seats in Chinese planes and tour buses. They are far more noticeable now than last year, partly because their numbers are increasing at the same time those of other foreign tourists have dropped. **********Chinese tourist officials welcome the influx from across the Taiwan Straits as a way to help compensate for the losses suffered after the military crackdown on the democracy movement last June nearly caused the tourism industry to collapse. **********Asked about their occupancy rates recently, major hotels in Guilin, Shanghai and Xian said they were higher than last year, but still only 27 percent to 45 percent. It is the Taiwan visitors who are causing the statistics to rise throughout the country. **********''There's no question that without the Taiwan groups we would be in a terrible situation,'' said Paul Hung, business manager at the Sheraton Guilin Hotel. The hotel has seen its occupancy rate climb from an average of 26 percent in January to 66 percent in March, with hardly any Americans. **********Special Routes Added **********China's main tourist organization, the China Travel Service, says 540,000 Taiwan citizens, or 2.7 percent of the island's population, came to China in tour groups last year, 90,000 more than in 1988. The numbers do not include Taiwan business executives and individual travelers. Other foreign tourists, mostly Western, numbered 1.5 million last year, down 300,000 from 1988. **********Tourist officials estimate that at least 200,000 more Taiwan visitors will come to China this year, partly because of a marketing effort by hotels and Chinese tour agencies, who have added special routes through China for Taiwan tourists. **********The phenomenon is influencing the habits of local communities. Although tour guides find it easier to speak their mother tongue, many stuttered a bit with their first few Taiwan groups because they had memorized most of the legends and histories of the tourist sites in English and had to translate them back to Chinese. **********Taiwan Money Accepted **********Hotels have also had to adjust. The Holiday Inn Guilin, a joint venture hotel, exchanges the New Taiwan dollar for local foreign exchange certificates and street vendors accept Taiwan money. **********Vendors in Guilin used to blanket the roadsides, selling silk embroidered tableclothes and T-shirts to Western tourists. Now those goods have been stashed away to make room for Chinese herbal remedies, preserved fruits and traditional silk pillows - Taiwanese favorites. **********Many hotels offered Taiwan tour agencies rates as low as half those offered to individual travelers, and the Government gave discounts, too. In Xian, hotel managers report that the authorities issued circulars stipulating discounts for Taiwan groups, including a full-course Chinese breakfast for the equivalent of $2.50 and lunch and dinner for $5 each. The Guilin Tourism Bureau says Taiwan travelers receive a discount of up to 15 percent on tour arrangements. **********Not all hotel managers are entirely happy with the new business. Their new clients have different habits from previous customers, sometimes altering the atmosphere of the hotel as they walk around the halls in pajamas or banter loudly among themselves. They also spend much less in the hotels. **********''The Europeans and Americans are bigger spenders, and they like to drink at our bar or eat at our coffee shop,'' said Zhang Fuxi, chairman of the Sheraton Guilin Hotel. ''The Taiwan people like to go to the local restaurants to eat turtle, snakes, tortoise and cat and dog.''
