https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/07/world.main_headline: From Petrograd of 1917, Musty Consular Files
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/07/world.print_headline: From Petrograd of 1917, Musty Consular Files
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/07/world.body_text: **********The Soviet Government has returned to the National Archives a potpourri of 73-year-old records from the American consulate in Petrograd. The files have 6,250 thin crackling sheets bound with red-white-and-blue twine, containing items like inventories of vodka shipments and coded telegrams about ships carrying military supplies to Murmansk. **********Under an accord reached in 1987, the Archivist of the United States, Don W. Wilson, and the chief of the Main Archival Administration of the Soviet Council of Ministers, Fyodor Vaganov,have authorized the return of materials. **********A Soviet official delivered the papers to the Archives in late October, after the United States had given the Soviets 62 years' worth of the records of the Imperial and Provisional Governments from six American and two Canadian consulates. **********Archivists and historians said the documents would be unlikely to add more than a footnote or two to accounts of the events in Petrograd, which was then the capital, between the February Revolution, which ousted the imperial family, and the November Revolution, which brought the Bolsheviks to power.The most interesting dispatches, Consul North Winship's accounts of the upheavals in Petrograd, are apparently copies of material already well thumbed by historians, said an official of the National Archives, Joseph Dane Hartgrove. **********Also in the six heavy folders is history of another sort, the detritus of consular life, requests for passport renewals, currency regulations and letters from Americans wanting to go home or marry, all considered too unimportant to forward to Washington. **********In May 1917, when crowds marched along Nevsky Prospekt demanding an end to Russia's participation in WorldWar I, when one provisional government had fallen and another was struggling for stability, two American circus performers, Tiger Lily, "the dancing acrobat," and Texas Hattie, "the great tightrope artiste," needed their passports renewed, tp continue performing with the Circus Fermia in Vyborg. **********In October, when the Bolsheviks were preparing to seize power, the consul general in Moscow, Maddin Summers, advised his colleague Roger Tredwell in Petrograd to simplify the conversion of rubles to dollars by recognizing "that the Russian official rate is purely fictitious, nominal and constantly changing." Average out the various exchange rates and use one, Mr. Summers advised. **********In November, two days before the final fall of the Provisional government, a metallurgist at the KyshtymMining Works, Ray Knickerbocker, wrote the consul complaining that the regulations would permit him to take only 500 rubles form the country, but that the ruble was so devalued that "this amount will not pay my expenses to America." **********Mr. Tredwell advised, "I believe it would be possible for you to carry more than that sum." Mr. Tredwell then noted that, if asked, he intended to deny giving the metallurgist that advice. **********Most of the new material portrayed consuls in Petrograd, under the stewardship of Ambassador David R. Francis as they tried to shepherd Americans through a land of raging uncertainty and also report on the events. **********Mr. Summers, who, George F. Kennan, the former diplomat and historian, has said was one of the most astute diplomatic observers, was surprised bythe final Bolshevik takeover. In a soothing letter to Mr. Tredwell on Sept. 26, about five weeks before the revolution, Mr. Summers said he did not believe the upheaval presaged danger. **********"I think that little by little the extreme left will assume the reins of government and that they will do this without apparent opposition," he wrote. "I then think that the chaotic state of the country will become so great that the conservative democratic elements will be charged with guiding the country's politics." **********The archive was apparently left when diplomats moved to to Vologda to escape from the oncoming German armies. In the early 30's, American diplomats returned to Petrograd, then Leningrad, and retrieved some archives from under straw in a stable. The new papers were not among them.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/26/busin.main_headline: New Strategies Being Tried Against Drunken Driving
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/26/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; New Strategies Being Tried Against Drunken Driving
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/26/busin.body_text: **********THE Advertising Council has begun its first new public service campaign in six years aimed at preventing drunken driving. The campaign also adopts a new strategy calculated to help people overcome the embarrassment of interceding with friends who have had one drink too many. **********"This is the best time to launch a drunk driving campaign because people are more aware of the problem," said Len Fink, an executive creative director at Wells, Rich, Greene in New York, which created the Ad Council campaign. In addition, Mr. Fink said this was the one time of year when the public service announcements were guaranteed to be shown on prime-time network television. **********Taking advantage of this seasonal good will, the Harvard School of Public Health has started a separate campaign against drunken driving in which President Bush tells viewers that during the holiday season they can become the life of the party by simply volunteering to be a designated driver. **********In another of the segments filmed at the White House, the President tells viewers that more than 20,000 lives are lost each year because of alcohol-related auto accidents. **********Organizations are beefing up their public service campaigns against drunken driving because they have found their efforts effective. Between 1980 and 1988 the number of intoxicated drivers killed in traffic accidents dropped 22 percent. Katherine V. Pastre, the manager of the Ad Council's drunken driving campaign, said research indicated that the decrease was in large part a result of better public education about the dangers of drinking and driving from campaigns like those from the Ad Council, Mothers Against Drunk Driving and the Harvard project. **********The Ad Council's seven-year-old drunken driving campaign, sponsored by the Transportation Department's National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, changed its tactics because the public has gotten the original message. Earlier efforts told people that friends do not let friends drive drunk. **********It was an easy message for the public to understand, but a hard one for many people to put into practice. "Our research showed that people understood it is necessary to intervene to keep someone they knew from driving while drunk," Ms. Pastre said. "But people also said they are reluctant to intervene because they did not want to risk embarrassing a friend." **********The new spots point out the high price of being timid. In one, the camera focuses on a gravestone as a young woman tells her mother she could have saved her boyfriend's life if she had just taken away his car keys when she realized he was too drunk to drive. "I was afraid to embarrass him in front of his friends," she says. "Why didn't I do something." **********To help make the job easier, some common sense prevention techniques are offered, like taking the keys away or calling a cab. **********The campaign also features the council's original public service announcement on drinking and driving, "Crashing Glasses," which was created by Mr. Fink. The award-winning spot shows one of the most well-known images in advertising. Two wine-filled glasses are tapped together in a toast, but instead of good wishes, viewers hear the sound of screeching tires and metal being mangled as the glasses shatter.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/25/busin.main_headline: Special Concern to Finance Some Merrill Unit Securities
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/25/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;   Special Concern to Finance Some Merrill Unit Securities
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/25/busin.body_text: **********Merrill Lynch Money Markets Inc., the largest dealer of short-term securities on Wall Street, yesterday adopted an increasingly popular kind of commercial paper financing to pay for part of its inventory of short-term securities. **********Although executives at Merrill Lynch Money Markets declined to discuss the financing, analysts said the technique, which has become popular among banks, would make Merrill Lynch appear stronger financially and raise its capacity to borrow. **********Many of the securities, which Merrill Lynch buys from other corporations and sells to investors, will now be financed by a special-purpose corporation called the Hamilton Funding Corporation. Every night, proceeds from the paper issued by Hamilton will be used to buy part of Merrill Lynch Money Market's inventory. In the past, Merrill Lynch financed its inventory directly, without using any outside corporations. **********Although Hamilton Funding -named after Frank W. Hamilton 3d, a managing director at Merrill Lynch who developed the idea - is closely tied to Merrill Lynch, it is not a subisidiary of the giant securities firm. Because Hamilton Funding is not part of Merrill Lynch, its assets - the inventory of securities bought from Merrill Lynch Money Markets - and its liabilities - the commercial paper it issues - are not part of Merrill Lynch's balance sheet. **********The new financing started yesterday with $200 million of commercial paper and is expected to grow to $1.5 billion by the end of the year. Off-balance sheet financing is especially useful near the end of calendar quarters, when Merrill Lynch and other securities dealers want to keep down their inventory of securities to make their balance sheets appear stronger. As dealers try to reduce their inventories at the end of a quarter, rates for short-term securities, like commercial paper, sometimes rise by about 20 one-hundredths of a percentage point. **********Securities eligible for purchase by Hamilton Funding must have two top-notch credit ratings from Moody's Investors Service Inc., the Standard & Poor's Corporation or Duff & Phelps. Hamilton's paper is backed by a letter of credit from Credit Agricole, a large French bank, and has top ratings from credit rating agencies. **********About a dozen banking companies have issued more than $40 billion of commercial paper through special purpose companies to finance assets ranging from trade and credit-card receivables to business loans. ITT Note Offering Has 8.795% Yield The ITT Corporation yesterday offered $150 million in two-year notes due on Oct. 1, 1992. **********Underwritrers led by Goldman, Sachs & Company gave the note issue a coupon of 8.75 percent and priced it at 99.919 to yield 8.795 percent, or about 63 basis points above Treasury securities with a similar maturity. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. **********The notes are noncallable through maturity and rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and A+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/03/busin.body_text: **********The Nynex Corporation announced yesterday that two of its subsidiaries - the New York Telephone Company and the New England Telephone and Telegraph Company - were combining their jointly owned purchasing company with their jointly owned product development and regulatory affairs company. **********Ownership of the purchasing operation, known as the Nynex Materiel Enterprises Company, was transferred to the regulated subsidiaries from the Nynex Corporation earlier this year. The move came in the wake of reports that Nynex Materiel had generated illegal profits by overbilling the two telephone companies and that some Nynex Materiel managers behaved unethically. Nynex acknowledges that some of the managers attended lewd parties but denies all other charges. **********The new combined company has been named Telesector Resources Group Inc. Its staff consists of Nynex Materiel's 1,600 employees and the 6,500 employees of the Nynex Service Company. Peter Goodale, a spokesman for Nynex, said the move was intended to improve efficiency and make regulatory oversight easier.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/24/busin.main_headline: U.S. AND JAPANESE IN COMPUTER PACT
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/24/busin.print_headline: U.S. AND JAPANESE IN COMPUTER PACT
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/24/busin.body_text: **********The United States and Japan said today that they had reached preliminary agreement on measures that would significantly open the Japanese market to the most powerful American-made computers. **********The agreement will make it easier for American companies to sell such supercomputers to the Japanese Government and public universities in Japan, trade officials from both nations said. **********The agreement should eliminate what has become, in effect, a requirement that companies doing business with the Japanese Government offer deep discounts on supercomputer prices. The Japanese budget for supercomputers is so low that successful bidders have had to offer discounts of up to 80 percent of the list price. **********The United States is continuing to try to persuade Japan to buy American-made commercial satellites and to open up the Japanese market to American wood products, two other areas in which Washington has accused Tokyo of unfair trade practices. The satellite talks are reportedly stalled and the talks on wood products may resume next month. **********The agreement on supercomputers, reached here late Thursday night and announced today, has not been signed and is subject to review and approval in Tokyo and Washington. **********Supercomputers are used by scientists and engineers to forecast the weather, to design aircraft and automobiles, to explore for oil and to predict the behavior of the economy and financial markets, among other tasks. **********American computer companies like Cray Research Inc. and the International Business Machines Corporation cautiously welcomed the agreement but said they did not know whether it would result in additional sales, as the American negotiators intended. **********Members of Congress also welcomed the agreement, but said they wanted to see results. **********Empty Promises **********''Japan must recognize that promises without performance are simply unacceptable,'' said Senator John C. Danforth of Missouri, the ranking Republican on the Commerce Committee. **********Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, chairman of the Finance subcommittee on trade, said that in the past ''American trade negotiators have fallen in the trap of declaring success too soon.'' **********The United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, looked on the positive side: ''American supercomputer manufacturers already compete successfully in the Japanese private sector. The real test of this agreement, therefore, will be the actual success of our companies in the Government procurement market.'' **********The new agreement ''should give us full and effective access to that market,'' Mrs. Hills said. **********Four Purchases Planned **********The pact does not require Japan to buy a specific number of machines from the United States. But the Japanese Government plans to buy four supercomputers this year, an American trade official said. Such machines cost $7 million to $30 million each, he said. **********The agreement appears to be one of the first fruits of meetings in California three weeks ago between President Bush and Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan, trade negotiators said. The talks were prompted by a sense of alarm among officials in both countries that a continued impasse in trade negotiations would permanently damage their alliance. **********An American trade official said the Japanese negotiators came to the talks on supercomputers, held here Wednesday and Thursday, ''with instructions to make a deal.'' As a result of high-level political pressure, he said, the Japanese showed a more forthcoming attitude. **********Meeting Called Helpful **********The Bush-Kaifu meeting definitely helped, he said. The Japanese negotiators ''said O.K. more often.'' **********A 1987 agreement between the United States and Japan called for an open, ''nondiscriminatory procurement process.'' Nevertheless, in May 1989, President Bush charged that Japan was maintaining an array of unfair trade barriers, and supercomputers were one of three areas chosen for special investigation. Japan faced the prospect of retaliatory trade sanctions, including high tariffs, if it did not relax the retrictions identified by the United States. **********Mrs. Hills said it was ''too early to say'' whether the pact would resolve the case against Japan, filed last year under the so-called Super 301 section of the Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act of 1988. **********Dennis McGrath, a spokesman for Cray, said: ''We haven't had a chance to study the initial draft of the agreement. We just hope it will contain the provisions we need to open up the Japanese market.'' **********'The Real Test' **********''The real test,'' he said, ''is whether this agreement, unlike the one signed in 1987, actually results in true competitive equity. By that, we mean actual sales and market-share increases for the American supercomputer industry.'' **********Mr. McGrath said Cray had 80 percent of the world supercomputer market outside Japan but only 66 percent when the Japanese market is included. **********In 1988, 31 supercomputers were sold in Japan, 26 by Japanese manufacturers and 5 by American companies, according to Dataquest Inc., a market research concern in San Jose, Calif. **********American companies supplied only 6 percent of the supercomputers bought by the Japanese Government and publicly financed universities in Japan, the United States trade representative's office said. **********Under the agreement, the Japanese Government accepted the American contention that it should buy supercomputers on the basis of a combined assessment of price and value. In the past, American officials said, Japan bought the cheapest supercomputer that met its specifications, turning down superior American machines that were slightly more expensive. The main Japanese computer manufacturers, which all produce supercomputers, are Fujitsu Ltd., Hitachi Ltd. and the NEC Corporation. **********Bursts of High Speeds **********In addition, an American trade official said, Japan agreed that it would no longer use ''theoretical peak performance'' as a factor in buying supercomputers. Japanese companies have designed computers to meet such standards; as a result, some Japanese supercomputers can reach extremely high speeds, but only for a fraction of a second. **********American negotiators argued that supercomputers should instead be judged by their overall performance in solving practical problems. **********Under the agreement, the Japanese Government is supposed to throw out ''excessively low bids.'' These are below-cost bids sometimes offered by Japanese companies that hope the deals will give them prestige and influence, and perhaps access to new software. Japan is to publicize the names of companies that submit such bids. American trade officials said such publicity would embarrass Japanese companies by indicating that they had engaged in unfair trade practices. The agreement, however, does not define excessively low bids. **********American companies can file complaints with an ombudsman in the Prime Minister's office if they think they have been shut out of the market as a result of excessively low bids. **********The American delegation in the talks was led by William Piez, a deputy assistant trade representative, who had been an economic officer at the American Embassy in Tokyo. The Japanese delegation was led by Mitoji Yabunaka, an official at the Foreign Ministry. I.B.M.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/15/busin.main_headline: Dollar, Mixed Abroad, Ends Higher in Domestic Trading
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/15/busin.print_headline: CURRENCY MARKETS;   Dollar, Mixed Abroad, Ends Higher in Domestic Trading
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/15/busin.body_text: **********The dollar finished mostly higher in domestic dealings yesterday after putting in a mixed performance overseas. **********Currency trading was moderate in Europe, but interest in the dollar was rekindled when activity shifted to the United States. Traders attributed the dollar's advance to optimism ahead of today's release of merchandise trade figures for April. **********Market players are ''expecting a very good number,'' said Bob Morrissey, senior trader at the Bank of Boston's New York office. The market consensus is that the Commerce Department will report a trade deficit of about $7.2 billion, which would represent a significant decline from March's wider-than-expected $8.45 billion deficit. **********Rumors of a Better Figure **********But Mr. Morrissey said rumors began circulating in the market that the figure could be as good as $5 billion. In that case, he predicted the dollar would break out of its current trading range. **********A lower dollar helps the deficit by making United States goods more competitive on foreign markets, thereby increasing exports. A low deficit would indicate that ''United States goods are competitive, and there is room for the dollar to go higher,'' Mr. Morrissey said. **********Also to be released today are reports on the Consumer Price Index and industrial production and capacity, both for May. **********Dealers said yesterday's Goverment report showing a moderate increase of three-tenths of 1 percent in United States wholesale prices for May was not surprising. **********Against the West German currency, the dollar rose to 1.6948 marks, from 1.6865 late Wednesday. **********It was also stronger in New York trading against the British pound. It cost $1.7080 to buy one pound, less expensive than Wednesday's $1.7115. **********Against the Japanese currency, however, the dollar closed in New York at 154.20 yen, down from 154.75 late Wednesday. Earlier, in Tokyo, the dollar closed at 153.53 yen, down 1.02 yen. In London, it was quoted higher at 153.90 yen. **********Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Wednesday's late rates, included: 1.4355 Swiss francs, up from 1.4240, and 5.7015 French francs, up from 5.6720.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/09/world.main_headline: LARGE EVACUATION OF U.S. HOSTAGES IS EXPECTED TODAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/09/world.print_headline: STANDOFF IN THE GULF; LARGE EVACUATION OF U.S. HOSTAGES IS EXPECTED TODAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/09/world.body_text: **********The United States Embassy announced tonight that an Iraqi airliner had been chartered to fly American hostages out of Kuwait and Iraq on Sunday. **********The embassy said an Iraqi Airways Boeing 747 would fly first to Kuwait to pick up hostages in the morning, then return to Baghdad for others before leaving in the afternoon for Frankfurt, Germany. Amid the confusion over exit visas, it was unclear how many of the 750 American hostages in Iraq and Kuwait would be allowed to depart on Sunday. **********The flight was arranged after President Saddam Hussein's announcement on Thursday that all foreigners, including some 2,000 Westerners, would be allowed to leave Iraq. Many of the hostages have been held at strategic installations in Iraq as "human shields" against an attack by the American-led forces sent to the Persian Gulf after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2.   24 Leave With Connally **********The American Embassy made its announcement as 23 American hostages and one Briton flew out of Iraq today on a special charter flight arranged by John B. Connally, the former Secretary of the Treasury, and Oscar Wyatt, chairman of the Texas-based Coastal Corporation, a company that was formerly a major importer of Iraqi crude oil. It was the first group of Americans to be freed since Mr. Hussein's decree on Thursday. **********[ President Bush, ending a visit to Caracas, Venezuela, denied that the release of hostages would take the pressure off Iraq or erase the threat of war. He said the release would even "clear the decks" for decisions ahead, and he denied that the decision to vacate the American Embassy in Kuwait was a "payback" to Mr. Hussein. Page 14. ] **********Two-thirds of the seats on Mr. Connally's plane were empty when it took off at dusk. Mr. Connally, Mr. Wyatt and American Embassy officials traded recriminations over the level of assistance to the private evacuation effort, which the State Department discouraged as it has previous private American trips to Baghdad. **********About three dozen Japanese hostages also flew out on a chartered Iraqi plane. British officials also expect many of the 1,100 British nationals held in Iraq and Kuwait to be flown out in the coming days.  Call to Americans in Kuwait **********In a call sent out on Voice of America short-wave radio broadcasts, the United States urged Americans in Kuwait to assemble at the country's international airport to meet the special Iraqi Airways charter flight, an official at the American Embassy here said. **********Reports reaching Baghdad from the besieged American Embassy compound in Kuwait indicated that the Ambassador there, W. Nathaniel Howell, was confident that 90 percent of the Americans in hiding in Kuwait had been notified of the evacuation plan by tonight. American officials hoped that others would hear of the plan during the night through the clandestine communication networks still functioning in Kuwait. **********United States officials here did not know tonight whether Mr. Howell, his deputy chief of mission, Barbara Bodine, and several other diplomats who have been holding out without electricity or municipal water supplies in the embassy compound since August would leave on Sunday, the embassy official here said. **********The departure time of the flight from Baghdad on Sunday depends on how rapidly the Iraqi authorities process exit visas for all of the Americans who wish to leave. American officials are hoping the flight can leave as early as 3 P.M. **********Hostages will be offered medical and other assistance in Frankfurt before they board flights there for other destinations, the embassy official said. .  Exit Visas Issued **********Iraq began processing exit visas this afternoon for other foreign residents wishing to leave. A number of Canadians and Britons successfully obtained exit documents, an indication that Baghdad wants to remove the hostage issue in its confrontation with the international coalition seeking to bring Iraq's occupation of Kuwait to an end. **********Tonight, Iraq's Foreign Ministry summoned the deputy chief of mission of the American Embassy, Joseph C. Wilson 4th, and presented him with a counterproposal to President Bush's plan to exchange foreign ministers' visits. **********The crucial round of diplomacy is supposed to take place before the Jan. 15 deadline set by the United Nations for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait or face the use of military force. **********The United States had proposed that the Iraqi Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, come to Washington next week, and that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d travel to Baghdad the following week or no later than the first week in January.  Date for Baker Visit **********But Mr. Wilson was told that Iraqi officials could not receive Mr. Baker in Baghdad before mid-January. Baghdad television and radio broadcasts tonight suggested that this new timing had been accepted by Washington, but a American official here said this was not the case. **********[ Administration officials said in Washington that after the United States proposed Dec. 10 for the Aziz visit, Iraq countered with Dec. 17. The Americans agreed on the condition that Mr. Hussein meet with Mr. Baker on Dec. 20, 21 or 22 or Jan. 3. The Iraqi response was that Mr. Hussein was so busy he could not see Mr. Baker before Jan. 12, three days before the United Nations resolution authorizing force takes effect. ] **********Dozens of Americans who had expected to be on today's flight organized by Mr. Connally and Mr. Wyatt were angry and disappointed that they and their relatives were not allowed to leave, since more than two-thirds of the 175 seats on the charter flight were empty. **********One man who got on the flight, Charles Keegan, 57, of Des Moines, Iowa, said that during the last 24 hours, "half the time I was choked with emotion and half the time I felt like choking somebody." Relatives in Turmoil **********A large group of hostages' relatives who arrived here this week in a self-described "Coming Home" mission was in turmoil throughout the day as various unofficial spokesmen seeking to assist them inadvertently gave them erroneous information that they would be able to depart as a group. **********On Friday night, Scott Nelson of Los Angeles, an unofficial hostage negotiator associated with Mr. Connally's mission and with the Fellowship of Reconciliation, a pacifist group, met with the 17 "Coming Home" hostages, their wives and their relatives at a downtown Baghdad hotel and told them they all would be allowed to leave on the Connally flight. **********Mr. Nelson also told American Embassy officials that he expected to fill as many as 100 seats on the plane with additional Americans, including diplomats and others who had taken refuge at diplomatic residences in Baghdad. **********In a brief interview, Mr. Nelson said he had sat in on a meeting between Mr. Connally and Mr. Hussein this week in which the Iraqi President authorized a hostage evacuation mission that Mr. Nelson indicated might fill the 175-seat Boeing 707.  U.S. Embassy Faulted **********But by mid-afternoon, the Iraqi authorities told the Connally group that they would approve exit visas for only 22 Americans, 8 of their relatives and 1 Briton. Only 5 of the 22 were from the "Coming Home" group, and many complained that the American Embassy should have intervened with the Iraqis or given them more assistance. **********A spokesman for Mr. Connally, Samir A. Vincent, an Iraqi-born consultant from Washington, D.C., said as he ushered the 30 Americans into a bus bound for the airport at 4 P.M.: "We did our damnedest to get everybody out. If they are angry, they should be angry at the American Embassy. They didn't do anything for us." **********Mr. Connally and Mr. Wyatt made similiar remarks to reporters at the airport before departing. Later, an American Embassy official defended the embassy's performance, noting that Mr. Connally's mission to Baghdad had been officially discouraged by the State Department. **********"Connally never called me; Wyatt never called me," said the embassy official, who did not want to be identified. "I don't know why the Iraqis didn't let Connally fill his plane up." **********The plane, which is due to arrive in Houston on Sunday after a stop in Shannon, Ireland, took off before nightfall .  Need for Hard Currency **********An Iraqi official, speaking on the condition that he not be identified, said most of the hostages would have to leave on Iraqi Airways charters and not on private missions like Mr. Connally's because Iraq needed all the hard currency it could get from such charters. **********The American Embassy officials said embassy personnel had provided consular services to the hostages who were gathered at the Melia Al Mansour Hotel by Iraqi authorities for the reunion with the "Coming Home" relatives and for departure.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/02/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Forstmann President Named Chief Executive
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/02/busin.body_text: **********Forstmann & Company, a privately held maker of woolen and worsted fabrics that is seeking to revamp $160 million in debt, has named Christopher L. Schaller chief executive, succeeding James J. Ammeen. **********Mr. Schaller, 49, has been president and chief operating officer since April, when he joined Forstmann. Mr. Ammeen, 51, an investor in the 1989 leveraged buyout of Forstmann, will remain on the board. **********In another change, the company named Fred D. Matheson executive vice president of manufacturing, succeeding J. C. Robinson, who left the company. Mr. Matheson will be based at the company's Dublin, Ga., plant. **********Forstmann, with marketing headquarters in New York, employs some 3,000 workers in Dublin, Milledgeville and Louisville, Ga., and is the nation's largest producer of wool fabrics. **********Right now it is having its financial problems. A committee of its bondholders has agreed to the debt revamping, and the deal hinges on approval by 95 percent of Forstmann's bondholders. Mr. Schaller said he was confident the deal would be approved. The debt was incurred when an investment group, including Mr. Ammeen and Odyssey Partners, bought the company. **********"Customers want to be assured we can supply them," Mr. Schaller said yesterday. "It's time to say, yes, we are going to be in business and we are going to supply the right products." **********The textile business has been suffering for the last 18 months, he said, with problems in the retail business backing up to the mills. "I think our part hasn't felt the problems as much as some of the others," he said. "What we need to do is get this restructuring behind us and focus on our core customers." **********Mr. Schaller said he wanted to emphasize service and styling for customers, with quicker response to customers' needs and more innovative fabrication. **********Mr. Schaller came to Forstmann from West Point-Pepperell, where he was president of the apparel fabrics division. **********After receiving an M.B.A from Northwestern, Mr. Schaller joined the Celanese Corporation and in 1973 became an executive with Texfi Industries. Then he spent six years running his own textile fabric businesss in New York before joining the VF Corporation as a vice president and then moving to West Point-Pepperell.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/08/busin.body_text: **********A spokesman for Bond Corporation Holdings Ltd. said today that the company is willing to listen to Jeff Reynolds, an American businessman who announced Saturday that he wanted to take control of the Australian company. **********The spokesman, Peter **********Lucas, said that Bond ''looked forward to the next communication'' from Mr. Reynolds, but added that the American's proposal was lacking in detail. **********On Saturday, Mr. Reynolds announced in Los Angeles that he was prepared to invest $250 million in Bond and in return take control of the company, whose beer brewing interests are now in the hands of receivers. The breweries include the G. Heileman Brewing Company, in La Crosse, Wis. **********Mr. Reynolds, 28 years old, is chairman of Weatherby Investments, based in Los Angeles. **********He said he was confident that he could refinance Bond's $6 billion debt and would talk again with Alan Bond, who runs the company, once a court hearing into the receivership is concluded in Australia. **********Mr. Reynolds said California **********Pacific International Holdings, the Singapore-based parent of Weatherby, had been interested in buying Bond for some time.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/04/busin.main_headline: The Executive Computer; When a Company Promises Service, Does It Mean It?
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/04/busin.print_headline: The Executive Computer; When a Company Promises Service, Does It Mean It?
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/04/busin.body_text: **********VIRTUALLY every computer maker boasts, one way or another, that its No. 1 goal is to serve the customer. It is no secret, though, that some companies simply pay lip service to the idea, while others do an extraordinary job of keeping customers happy. Unfortunately for corporate customers, it is often difficult to discover which is which until after the equipment is purchased. **********Now there is help, in two surveys of business computer users -- one by Dataquest Inc., a market research firm in San Jose, Calif., and the other by PC Magazine, published in New York by the Ziff-Davis Company. The results, which reflect the experiences of thousands of companies, are intriguing. **********"Although technology remains a crucial factor to business success, it is no longer enough," said Manny Fernandez, Dataquest's president, in a statement accompanying the results of his company's survey. "Whatever competitive edges that might have once been found in this area have long since been diminished in importance. Over the past few years, PC's have taken on all of the characteristics of commodity products." **********In other words, a PC is a PC, and one company's 386SX box is generally indistinguishable from another's, as if the computers were television sets or toaster ovens. Significant technical differences today are found mainly in the newest high-end systems, not in the standard-issue PC's on most office desks. **********Few corporate buyers are willing to justify spending $10,000 on a premium-brand personal computer when a virtually identical one is available elsewhere for $4,000. Recognizing this, most computer companies have cut prices sharply in recent months. Price cuts will get customers in the door, but to make the sale, computer companies are emphasizing product reliability, service and support.How long will this computer run before something goes wrong? How painless will repairs be? Where can a user get help? **********In both the PC Magazine and Dataquest studies, mail-order companies made their customers happier than the big-name companies, with a few exceptions. What is more, the Dataquest survey for the first time put hard evidence behind something that many industry executives suspected. "Vendors who finished in the top third in overall customer satisfaction really gained market share, and those in the bottom third lost market share," said Greg Chagaris, a Dataquest vice president. **********Mr. Chagaris declined to identify the companies that finished at the bottom of the survey. He was willing to say only that Compaq, Zenith, Epson, Toshiba, Wyse, A.T.& T, Unisys, Grid and Wang finished "in the bottom two-thirds." **********Dataquest, a subsidiary of the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, asked more than 1,000 corporate buyers how satisfied they were with the PC's they used most often. The companies that led Dataquest's customer satisfaction list were, in order: * CompuAdd, of Austin, Tex. * Hewlett-Packard, Palo Alto, Calif. * Dell Computer, Austin * Tandy, Fort Worth. * AST Research, Irvine, Calif. * Everex Systems, Fremont, Calif. * International Business Machines, Armonk, N.Y. * Apple Computer Inc., Cupertino, Calif. **********Two of the top three, CompuAdd and Dell, are primarily direct-sales companies, taking orders by phone, mailing out the goods and answering the buyers' phone calls. Joel Kocher, a senior vice president at Dell, said the impressive showing by some mail-order companies underscored a major shift in the personal computer industry. "PC buyers are moving away from traditional retail stores and to distribution channels that are tailored to their particular needs," he said. **********In its survey, PC Magazine, whose readership is heavily weighted toward computer buyers in the corporate community, received nearly 20,000 responses to its questionnaire on customer satisfaction. Those readers also said direct-order companies provided superior service and support. **********Swan Technologies Inc. of State College, Pa., had a remarkably strong showing in the PC Magazine survey, finishing first in three of four categories: overall repair service, overall technical support and percentage of respondents who said they would buy more computers from the same company. But PC Magazine editors noted that Swan, a small company formerly known as Tussey Computers, had relatively few responses in the survey, which did not provide as reliable a statistical base as the other companies. In the fourth category, overall reliability, Hewlett-Packard was first, echoing its impressive standing in the Dataquest survey. Close behind Swan in overall satisfaction were Dell and Northgate Computer Systems Inc. of Eden Prairie, Minn. **********In what is perhaps the most telling category of the PC Magazine survey -- the percentage of those who said they would buy more computers from the same company -- Swan was followed by Hewlett-Packard, Dell and Northgate. **********Unlike Dataquest, PC Magazine reported the worst performers in each category. The mail-order companies PC Brand Inc. and Austin Computer Systems were rated worst in overall reliability, followed by Packard-Bell, Wyse and Gateway 2000. Commodore Business Machines of West Chester, Pa., finished last in both technical support and repair service. It also had a small number of responses in the survey, which may have skewed the results. **********The loser in the PC Magazine poll was Compaq, which has a longstanding policy of referring all customer inquiries and problems to its dealers. Compaq finished next-to-last in technical support and fourth from the bottom in repairs. For a company whose prices are typically the highest in the industry and whose reliability rating in the survey was only average, those results are striking. **********Michael Berman, a Compaq spokesman, said the company had not seen the Dataquest survey, and he challenged the PC Magazine findings. "Our information is very different from what PC Magazine reflects," he said.  Compaq did its own survey of management information service executives who typically oversee large corporate computing systems, he said, "and they said Compaq was unsurpassed in overall satisfaction." **********Compaq recently announced that it was beefing up its training of authorized dealers. "Our research shows that the dealer channel is the way to go for distributing and supporting our products," Mr. Berman said. **********In contrast to customers' experience with Compaq, Dell and Northgate customers report that their calls are occasionally answered by the chairmen of the companies. At CompuAdd, a red "hot line" in each of the company's retail stores rings just outside the Austin office of the company's director of sales, in case the customer is not getting waited on or has a question the store personnel cannot answer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/08/busin.main_headline: Talking Deals; Satellite TV's Appeal to Comsat
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/08/busin.print_headline: Talking Deals; Satellite TV's Appeal to Comsat
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/08/busin.body_text: **********WHEN the Communications Satellite Corporation bought a majority stake in the Denver Nuggets basketball team, a lot of people wondered why. Now, as the company contemplates investing $100 million in a new satellite television venture, the answer seems clear. **********Robert J. Wussler, president of Comsat Video Enterprises and formerly the second-in-command at Turner Broadcasting System Inc., wants do with satellites what his former boss, Ted Turner, did with cable television. Mr. Turner, who owns the Atlanta Braves baseball team and Atlanta Hawks basketball team, has used his franchises as a cornerstone for sports programming over the TBS and Turner Network Television cable channels. **********"Just as VCR and cable television were methods of distribution for the 1980's, we think direct-broadcast satellite is the technology of the 1990's," Mr. Wussler said in an interview. **********But even the most charitable securities analysts are reserving judgment. Comsat's record is littered with earlier, botched attempts to enter new businesses, from satellite antennas to telephone equipment, that have cost the company hundreds of millions of dollars since 1980. **********Based in Washington, Comsat serves as the Federal Government's representative to Intelsat, the international satellite consortium owned by 119 governments, and its core business has been providing international communications through Intelsat. It is a strong business that earned $105 million on revenues of $280 million last year. **********But with both its rates and profits are determined by the Federal Communications Commission, Comsat has repeatedly tried to move into less regulated areas. **********A year ago, the company paid $18 million for a 62.5 percent stake of the Denver Nuggets. Company officials say the move was primarily intended to give them an entree in negotiating broadcast rights with other teams and leagues. **********Comsat is now weighing an investment of $100 million to $125 million in a new direct-broadcast satellite company, the Skypix Corporation, of Seattle, its officials confirm. It wants to broadcast about 80 channels of programming, including 40 to 50 movies and a rich array of sports events, directly to households around the nation using antennas less than 2 feet in diameter. Viewers would be charged for each program they watch. **********Skypix has spent $20 million developing its technology and estimates that it needs $200 million to $300 million more to bring the system to market. Comsat is reported to have signed a memorandum of understanding to invest a big chunk of the capital, provided Skypix can line up other investors and get the F.C.C. to approve its transmission technology. "We have made no firm commitments yet," a Comsat spokesman, Richard McGraw, said. **********Mr. Wussler thinks satellite broadcasting has considerable appeal. He likes that direct-broadcast satellites can reach rural viewers who cannot be connected to cable television. Also, by using new transmission technologies, Skypix and other companies hope to send multiple channels of programming over a single satellite transponder, offering the promise of lower costs and greater variety in programming. **********Two large rivals are developing their own satellite systems: Sky Cable, a joint venture backed by NBC, Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, Hughes Communications Inc. and the Cablevision Systems Corporation, and K-Prime Partners, a venture backed by several large cable television companies. **********But analysts are dubious about Comsat's plans, given its record. At Comsat Video Entertainment, losses on a "pay per view" movie service for hotel rooms that began several years ago climbed to $18 million in 1989 from $5 million in 1987 and are expected to reach at least $25 million this year. Part of the trouble is that a software glitch allowed some customers to watch movies without being billed. But the more enduring problem is that Comsat Video lags the industry leader, Spectradyne Inc., in signing up hotel chains that cater to business travelers. **********Also, in the early 1980's, Comsat sank $193 million into building two direct-broadcast satellites, only to stop the project amid poor market prospects. There have been other dead ends in manufacturing: Since 1987, the company has sold off or abandoned operations that made satellite dishes, earth stations, microwave amplifiers and a host of other equipment. **********After all this, some analysts contend that Mr. Wussler should stay closer to Comsat's core business, where demand is growing. "We urge our clients to sell their shares now, before Comsat management buries them even more with their next fiasco," wrote James M. McCabe, an analyst at Normura Securities, in a recent report. **********Mr. McGraw of Comsat responded that his company would not make a rash move. "This is not a fly-by-night decision that Comsat is trying to make," he said, noting that it has been looking at direct-broadcast satellite for more than a year. "When we do make a decison, it will be one based on good market research and a good business plan that provides a good return for our shareholders."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/29/world.main_headline: Disaster Zone Is Urged After Soviet Nuclear Blast
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/29/world.print_headline: Disaster Zone Is Urged After Soviet Nuclear Blast
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/29/world.body_text: **********The Soviet republic of Kazakhstan asked the central Government today to declare an ecological disaster zone around the city of Ust-Kamenogorsk, saying that an explosion at a nuclear fuel plant there had spewed ''extremely harmful'' gas across inhabited areas. **********No loss of life or evacuations were reported in the republic's complaint, which described widespread contamination in eastern Kazakhstan, near the Soviet borders with China and Mongolia. **********Only skimpy details have been reported. Soviet news accounts said that an explosion on Sept. 12 at the Ulba metallurgical works released a ''poisonous cloud'' across the region, which is about 2,000 miles southeast of Moscow. **********Soviet accounts said the plant's process involved beryllium, a heavy metal that is an element used in fuel for nuclear power reactors. Beryllium is not radioactive but is a toxic chemical. **********Explosion Leaves Residue **********The local Soviet authorities, who are reported to have waited four days before announcing the nature of the explosion to the public, have said that it left a residue variously reported as an ''insignificant increase,'' an amount double the normally permissible level of beryllium contaminants in the air. A quantitative measurement of this was not reported, nor was there any description of how harmful this might be to human health. **********President Nursultan A. Nazarbayev of Kazakhstan said in his message to the Kremlin that the local authorities had already declared the region an ecological disaster area, Tass reported. The Soviet press agency is the only source of information about the explosion so far because the region is closed to foreign correspondents. **********''The Kazakh public and the town's population demand urgent measures and compensation for their damaged health,'' Mr. Nazarbayev was quoted as saying. **********Beryllium is used as a source of neutrons, subatomic particles needed to begin chain reactions in nuclear fuel. **********Tass said the plant was among the major suppliers of the nation's nuclear fuel. ''Unfortunately it is located in a densely populated area of Ust-Kamenogorsk,'' its dispatch said. **********The 1985 census reported a population of 307,000 in the city, with more people living in the surrounding region. Kazakhstan, a land of desert and rocky plateaus, is second only to the Russian republic in area. **********President Nazarbayev's message to the Kremlin clearly reflected the heightened concern of the Soviet public about the ecological risks of nuclear fuel. That concern is rooted in the Chernobyl nuclear plant explosion of 1986, which caused the deaths of more than two dozen people and contaminated vast areas of Byelorussia and the Ukraine. Many villages were evacuated and abandoned. and much of the land still has not been cleaned up. **********The Kazakh authorities called on the Kremlin to act urgently and dispatch experts to the region to determine whether the nuclear fuel plant should be closed. They asked that an ecological study of the accident's effects to be carried by a commission that would include international experts. **********Traffic Stirs Contaminants **********On Sept. 17, Izvestia, the Government newspaper, reported that the situation around the plant had returned to normal. But the paper's correspondent said that four days after the cloud passed over the region, contamination appeared in scattered land areas, indicating that road traffic was stirring contaminants that had falled from the sky. **********Izvestia said the city's authorities wanted to wash the city streets four times a day to protect against fallout contamination, but were unable to do so because of a shortage of gasoline for the Government water and work trucks. **********There are many chemical plants in the Ust-Kamenogorsk region, and there has long been a ban on street sweeping so as not to stir potential contaminants into the air, the newspaper reported. **********The Izvestia dispatch said the regional government and Communist officials had for four days denied the local authorities permission to go on television and inform the public.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/20/busin.main_headline: Big Charge Is Expected At Merrill
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/20/busin.print_headline: Big Charge Is Expected At Merrill
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/20/busin.body_text: **********Merrill Lynch & Company is expected to take a charge against its 1989 fourth-quarter earnings of more than $100 million to pay for a significant reorganization of the firm that was undertaken late last year, analysts and Wall Street executives said yesterday. **********They said that the accounting move, which could have been done in 1990, will meet the full cost of shutting down some operations and cover expenses from the dismissal of employees, like termination pay. **********A spokesman for the company said that as a matter of policy Merrill does not comment on its quarterly financial results until they are reported. The spokesman declined to say when the quarterly report would come out. **********Assessing the Damage **********Such a charge would be one of the largest in the firm's history. In 1987, Merrill had a gross loss of $377 million that resulted from a single day's trading in mortgage-backed securties. Wall Street executives said that the current revamping should not cost Merrill more than that episode. **********In addition to the charge, the firm might have other losses in the fourth quarter, such as any resulting from the Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing of the Lomas Financial Corporation. Merrill underwrote Lomas securities and still holds some of them, analysts said. They added, however, that Merrill might spread any loss from Lomas over several quarters. **********Analysts said yesterday that a decision by Merrill to take the full charge for its reorganization would be a positive move. **********Stock Is Up Slightly **********''That would help them get the costs out of the way as soon as possible,'' said Perrin Long, a securities industry analyst with Lipper Analytical Services. Mr. Long added that he did not expect such a charge would have a significant impact on the firm's stock price. Yesterday, Merrill's shares rose 25 cents, to $24.75, in New York Stock Exchange trading. **********Merrill is expected to dismiss between 2,800 and 3,200 employees as part of the reorganization, and a large number of employees have been told in the last two days that they are being dismissed. **********Merrill officials said that the firm's work force had been reduced by about 1,500 in the last three weeks. Merrill had employed more than 40,000 people at the end of last year. **********Wall Street executives said yesterday that Merrill dismissed about 10 percent of its investment banking division this week. About 70 professional employees and 70 support workers were dismissed in all, with both New York and London operations affected, they said. A number of people from the equity research department have also been dismissed. **********A 'Siege Mentality' **********The staff reductions have created a ''siege mentality'' at the firm, some employees said. Rumors have swept Merrill that all of the planned dismissals will be made by the end of next week. But Merrill officials yesterday denied those rumors. **********Nevertheless, the speed of the reductions and changes indicate that the efforts at streamlining could be more extensive than Merrill officials had previously indicated. Merrill executives originally said that as many as 1,000 people would be laid off. **********Merrill has also reduced its employee roster this month by selling off some assets, including its Canadian retail securities brokerage business. **********In addition, some of the firm's executives have left. People at Merrill said that Mario J. Nigro, a top executive in the firm's operations and systems division, had resigned as part of the reorganization plan and left the firm Thursday. **********Departure Confirmed **********A spokesman for the company confirmed yesterday that Mr. Nigro was no longer an employee. The spokesman said that Mr. Nigro had resigned to pursue other interests, but that he would serve as a consultant during the reorganization. A telephone call to Mr. Nigro was not returned. **********Merrill has long been criticized by analysts for not sufficiently cutting its operations after the stock market crash of October 1987 and for continuing in some of its weaker businesses. **********In a letter to employees late last year, Merrill executives said they intended to cut operating costs, overhaul or eliminate unprofitable lines of business and place greater controls over commitments of the firm's own capital. **********In addition, Merrill said it would modify its compensation system, reducing the bonuses for many of its investment bankers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/06/busin.main_headline: Bush Said to Have Chosen Interim Savings Regulator
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/06/busin.print_headline: Bush Said to Have Chosen Interim Savings Regulator
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/06/busin.body_text: **********President Bush plans to name an Assistant Secretary of the Treasury who has a reputation as a tough enforcement official and strong manager as an interim successor to M. Danny Wall, the nation's top Federal regulator of the savings and loan associations, Administration officials said today. **********The officials, who asked not to be identified, said that Salvatore R. Martoche, currently Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Enforcement, would be named Tuesday as acting director of the Office of Thrift Supervision. He is expected to serve for several months until the Treasury finds a permanent replacement for Mr. Wall. **********Mr. Martoche has no direct experience as a banker or savings and loan executive, but he is a former United States Attorney from Buffalo and is expected to focus heavily on the agency's growing case load of lawsuits against savings executives accused of fraud and illegal lending practices. **********In addition, Mr. Martoche is considered a seasoned Government manager and administrator, and he will be given a mandate to set up a long-range management plan for the agency, which has undergone major organizational and jurisdictional changes in the last six months, an Administration official said. **********Over the last 20 months, Mr. Martoche has had management responsibility for the Treasury's Secret Service, customs, money-laundering and drug intervention operations. **********Mr. Wall announced in December that he intended to resign as soon as the Bush Administration found a replacement. He had been criticized frequently during his two-and-a-half-year tenure for underestimating the crisis in the savings industry. But he encountered the most criticism for delaying the closing of the troubled California-based Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, which had been run by Charles H. Keating Jr. That criticism grew so intense, Mr. Wall said, that he decided to step aside before a replacement was named. **********The Treasury has been struggling to find a permanent replacement for Mr. Wall, with several leading candidates turning down overtures out of fear they would be operating a stripped-down agency and have to cope with excessive oversight from the Treasury. **********The savings and loan bailout bill, which was signed last August and authorizes the Government to spend $150 billion over 10 years to sell or close hundreds of insolvent associations, stripped the Office of Thrift Supervision, formerly the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, of many of its powers and placed it under the control of the Treasury. **********A key factor in Mr. Martoche's appointment is that he is a Presidential appointee, which was considered vital in the wake of a lawsuit filed by a Massachusetts savings association last month. **********That suit contended that the bailout legislation had unconstitutionally designated Mr. Wall as the agency's director, saying that such appointments by law require a Presidential nomination and Senate confirmation. **********The lawsuit, which the Treasury has taken seriously, contended that Mr. Wall's regulatory actions and seizures of insolvent institutions should be invalidated by the courts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/02/busin.body_text: **********The Dow Jones industrial average scaled the 2,900-point benchmark yesterday to set another high just as the final bell sounded. **********The Dow closed at 2,900.97, up 24.31, as news about the economy - specifically a report on weak May employment - eased fears on inflation and interest rates, setting off a bond market rally, with stocks following in response. **********The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index finished with a strong rise of 1.93, to 363.16, its fourth consecutive high. **********Trading volume reached 187.9 million shares, up from 165.7 million on Thursday, as 978 issues advanced and 579 declined. **********Quick Drop After Early Gain **********After the opening bell, the market soared by 25 points to break the 2,900 barrier on the economic news, but quickly fell back. Selling programs caused the market to give up the opening gains, traders said. The market marched upward in the afternoon, only to weaken again before the final rise. **********The Dow Jones transportation index showed exceptional strength, finishing with a rise of 17.89, to 1,189.42. UAL, the airline company that its unions are seeking to acquire, rose 3 1/2, to 159. AMR, the parent of American Airlines, rose 1 1/2, to 65 3/8; Airborne Freight was up 1 1/8, to 23 1/8; Delta Air Lines rose 1, to 77 7/8, and Union Pacific was up 1 5/8, to 72 3/4. **********Other strong areas were autos, food companies, banks and other financial stocks. **********Bucking the trend was the stock of L. A. Gear, a maker of athletic footwear, which has been under pressure for the last few days. The stock, which topped the most active list, fell by 8 1/2, to 30 3/4. The company said its second-quarter net income would amount to 50 to 60 cents a share, sharply below the profit a year ago of 91 cents a share, an announcement that one analyst called ''a thunderbolt.'' Lack of Euphoria Cited Despite the strong market gain, some analysts remarked on a general lack of euphoria. That the market crossed the 2,900 mark ''candidly, doesn't really matter that much,'' said Hugh Johnson of the First Albany Corporation. He added: ''This is a tentative rise. There is some concern starting to creep into the dialogue about the economy slowing.'' **********Richard G. Unruh of Delaware Investment Advisers, which manages pension funds, said, ''From our point of view we're not sure this is the time to become real aggressive; the market might be getting ahead of itself.'' **********Others, however, said the May employment figures set the stage for further gains. ''With the carrot out there that the Fed can ease interest rates, that gives a positive environment for stocks,'' said Peter G. Grennan of Shearson Lehman Hutton. **********The employment figures showed that even though the jobless rate declined to 5.3 percent, from 5.4 percent in April, the number of new jobs created outside farming amounted to only 17,000, not counting 147,000 temporary workers hired for census duty. Rates a Factor in Autos The auto stocks were said to have benefited from the prospect of lower interest rates, which would reduce auto financing costs. Chrysler rose by 1, to 16 3/8, and General Motors also added a point at 49 5/8. Ford Motor rose by 3/4, to 46 7/8. **********Among bank stocks gaining were BankAmerica, up 3/4, to 31 3/8; Citicorp, up 1 1/4, to 24; Wells Fargo, up 1 1/2, to 80 7/8; Mellon Bank, up 1 1/8, to 29 1/4, and Manufacturers Hanover, up 1, to 37 5/8. **********Stocks on the active list showing good gains were Philip Morris, up 1 1/8, to 43 1/4, and Upjohn, up 1 1/2, to 40 1/8. I.B.M. was off 1/2, to 119 1/2. The Federal National Mortgage Association rose by 1 7/8, to 41 5/8. Analysts at Goldman, Sachs and Smith Barney reiterated buy ratings for Fannie Mae, citing the outlook for lower interest rates. **********The Amex market-value index rose 0.77, to 363.83, and the Nasdaq composite was up by 3.16, to 462.13.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/16/busin.main_headline: Squeezing More Data Onto a Disk
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/16/busin.print_headline: TECH NOTES;   Squeezing More Data Onto a Disk
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/16/busin.body_text: **********A TEAM led by Tuan Vo-Dinh at the Department of Energy's Oak Ridge National Laboratory is working with the Internal Revenue Service to vastly increase the storage capacity of optical disks. The researchers can put 1.5 million times more data on a 12-inch optical disk than on a 5 1/4-inch floppy disk for a personal computer. **********Conventional disks store information digitally in microscopic pits burned into aluminum-coated disks with laser light. The new method works on the molecular level. Certain molecules, when exposed to laser light, emit bright pulses called Raman light. When the optical disk is exposed to pulses of laser light, its molecular structure is altered as the information is encoded into its structure. When it is again exposed to a laser, the altered molecules emit Raman light, which can be read by a photo diode.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/30/world.main_headline: Survey in Moscow Sees a High Level of Anti-Jewish Feeling
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/30/world.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;   Survey in Moscow Sees a High Level of Anti-Jewish Feeling
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/30/world.body_text: **********A survey of tolerance in the Soviet Union has reported ''disturbingly high levels of anti-Jewish feeling,'' according to the American Jewish Committee, which helped finance the project. **********Asked to rate whether they liked Jews, on a scale of one to 11, 18 percent said they disliked them. Another 18 percent said they liked Jews, and 65 percent said they were neutral. **********Asked about the anti-Semitism of others, 17 percent said ''most people in the Soviet Union are anti-Jewish,'' 60 percent said ''only some people are anti-Jewish,'' and 19 per cent said ''very few people are anti-Jewish.'' **********The study, based on face-to-face interviews in the Moscow area with a random sample of 506 Soviet adults between Feb. 16 and March 4, found that 8 percent of those questioned agreed with the statement, ''More than any other group in society, it is the Jews who are responsible for the problems the Soviet Union is experiencing today.'' Seventy-nine per cent disagreed, and 13 percent were uncertain. **********Thirty-three percent agreed that ''when it comes to choosing between people and money, Jews will choose money,'' and 23 cent agreed that ''Jews have too much influence over Russian culture.'' **********Negative Figures Seen as High **********The study was financed by the American Jewish Committee, the National Science Foundation and the University of Houston, and conducted under the auspices of the Institute of Sociology of the Soviet Academy of Sciences. The study directors were two political scientists from the University of Houston, Prof. James Gibson and Asst. Prof. Raymond Duch.  Interviewed by telephone yesterday, Dr. Duch said the figures for anti-Semitism in the study were significantly higher than similar figures for the United States. ''Most research in this country indicates a level of hard-core anti-Semitism equal to about 5 percent of the population,'' he said. **********He acknowledged that the Soviet study, which comes at the time of an increased Jewish exodus from the Soviet Union under the more liberal emigration policies of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, was confined to Moscow. Attitudes toward Jews in the capital were expected to be relatively liberal compared with the rest of the Soviet Union. Jews make up only about 2.5 percent of Moscow's population, but there are more Jews in Moscow than in any other Soviet city, Dr. Duch said. **********The survey questionnaire consisted of 350 questions, and the margin of sampling error was plus or minus 5 percentage points. Eighty-eight percent of the respondents said they were of Russian descent, 3 percent said they were Ukrainian, 2 percent said they were Armenian and 2 percent said they were Jewish. **********The question of anti-Semitism was only a part of the overall survey, which had a broad theme of political tolerance in the Soviet Union. **********Skepticism on Perestroika **********On general issues, the survey found increasing skepticism about perestroika, Mr. Gorbachev's program of political and economic restructuring, and concern over insufficient glasnost, or the new increased openness in the press. It recorded a decline in Mr. Gorbachev's popularity and a serious lack of political tolerance. **********The high number of negative responses to Jewish-related questions early in the survey prompted the directors to expand that part of their work. But not all the responses to Jewish-related questions were negative. **********Of those queried, 91 percent said that ''Jews should be free to decide for themselves whether they want to remain in the Soviet Union or emigrate.'' Ninety percent agreed that ''the Government should make every effort to see that the rights of Jews to equal educational opportunity are respected.'' And 88 percent said the Government should see ''that the rights of Jews to equal employment opportunities are respected throughout the Soviet union.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/21/busin.main_headline: Soviet and Polish Sites for Cargill
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/21/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Soviet and Polish Sites for Cargill
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/21/busin.body_text: **********Cargill Inc., the giant international commodities concern, said it would open offices in Moscow and Warsaw to pursue increased investment opportunities in the Soviet Union and Poland. Cargill has had trading relationships with the two countries for more than 25 years, but has had no physical presence there. **********The Warsaw office is scheduled to open on Oct. 1 and the Moscow office should open in early 1991, the company said. Leonard Alderson, chairman of Cargill International, will supervise the new offices. He said Cargill will pursue investment possibilities in five principal operating areas: commodity merchandising, processing, agricultural products, industrial products and transportation.
