https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/21/busin.body_text: **********The Control Data Corporation reached a tentative deal to sell VTC Inc., its money-losing computer chip subsidiary, to Seattle Silicon of Bellevue, Wash. Seattle Silicon would buy the assets of VTC, and Control Data would own 20 percent of the new company, which is to be headed by Amaury Piedra, Seattle Silicon's president and chief executive. No price was disclosed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/06/world.main_headline: London Will Divide Its Telephone Prefix, Fraying Composure
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/06/world.print_headline: London Will Divide Its Telephone Prefix, Fraying Composure
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/06/world.body_text: **********London telephones jangle to new numbers on Sunday, when city codes 71 and 81 replace the simple No. 1. If only it were that simple. ''I am totally confident that all the necessary adjustments will be made as planned on Sunday,'' said Millie Banerjee, general manager of British Telecom's London network. **********She was speaking for the company, not the customer. **********British Telecom is ready for as many as 50,000 misdialed calls a minute and has prepared recorded messages in the appropriate languages to intercept international calls placed with the wrong number. And in the Colonies. . .  For international callers, London numbers will be preceded by the country code, 44, and either 71 or 81 depending on location in the city. **********Callers within Britain will be dialing 071 or 081 instead of 01. **********With Britain enjoying a three-day weekend, the real test will not come until Tuesday when banks, exchanges and businesses reopen. **********British Telecom says London is the city that receives the most calls from the United States - up to 100,000 a day. **********Because of the proliferation of fax machines and direct-dial business systems that assign a telephone number to every desk, the company said it had used up nearly all the potential five million numbers under the old London prefix. Splitting the city will double the pool. Geography and Status The 71 code has been assigned to inner London and the Docklands, and 81 to the outer reaches. **********John Turner, British Telecom's communications manager for the code change, said Friday that as many as a quarter of the 380,000 businesses in London had not reprogrammed their telephones or fax machines. **********David Fletcher, chief executive of the British Security Industry Association, estimated that a fourth of the capital's 100,000 burglar alarms had not been adjusted to contact the new numbers. **********Some people are upset by the change for other reasons. They believe that self-esteem and property values will decline in areas with the 81 code like Finchley, Hornsey, Shepherd's Bush, Hammersmith, Wembley, Putney and Tooting. **********Elsie Burch Donald, author of ''Debrett's Etiquette and Modern Manners,'' laid down the law a year ago: ''071 will be a superior number to have,'' she wrote. ''Clearly there is an advantage socially, culturally, economically to be living in central London.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/13/busin.main_headline: Oil Industry Shows Caution In Spending Sudden Profits
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/13/busin.print_headline: Oil Industry Shows Caution In Spending Sudden Profits
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/13/busin.body_text: **********The American oil industry's response to the surge in oil prices in recent months is to sit tight and hope prices do not crash after the crisis in the Persian Gulf ends. **********Chief executives of several oil companies, here for the annual meeting of the American Petroleum Institute, said in separate sessions today that higher prices were giving some of them a windfall. But these gains cannot be turned into huge investments to find more oil, they said, because money spent on exploration and production is slow to earn a return, and the higher prices are unlikely to last. In fact, several experts said, prices may plunge with a vengeance. **********"This is a long-term business," said Lawrence G. Rawl, the chairman of the Exxon Corporation. "You don't turn the money on because the oil price spikes, and turn it off because the price goes down. Every time someone clears his throat in the Middle East or elsewhere, the price goes up and down." **********Exxon's capital budget this year is $8.5 billion, Mr. Rawl said, and next year's will be higher, "but not by a whole lot." **********As he emerged from the institute's board meeting here, Mr. Rawl told reporters that making investment decisions was difficult amid the uncertainty. "When prices go up and down like a window shade, it creates problems, not just for you, but for anybody in a long-term business," he said. **********Executives of other companies made similar comments. Texaco Inc. will raise its capital budget to $3.1 billion in 1991, from $2.9 billion, said James W. Kinnear, president and chief executive officer. But, he added, "we try not to run up and down with the morning newspaper." **********The price of oil has fallen in recent days, to $31.87 a barrel. But it closed over $40 in mid-October, and is still nearly 40 percent higher than the level at which it was trading when Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. **********The expectation that prices will plunge from this level is in marked contrast to the oil crises of 1973 and 1979, said Thomas A. Petrie of Petrie Parkman & Company, a Denver brokerage that specializes in oil stocks. "There is no excess of optimism or expectation," he said. "It is important to maintain a sober attitude, but not to block well-crafted reinvestment plans for the cash flows now being generated." **********Mr. Petrie said the stock market shares an assessment that high prices cannot last. When Iraq invaded Kuwait and the price of crude oil took off from the low $20's it was trading at then, oil company stocks outperformed the market. But when the price got above $30 a barrel at the end of August, the market soured on the stocks. Stock prices of five of the six biggest international oil companies have since fallen, as have 10 of the 11 big domestic companies, while one is unchanged. **********Independent oil producers are not burdened with refining or marketing operations that can become unprofitable in times of rising crude prices, but even among that group the stocks of 21 of 30 companies have declined. **********The market's reading, Mr. Petrie said, is that "this is too much of a good thing, and in fact could be described as a bad thing."  Potential for a Glut **********The potential has emerged for a glut of oil once the Persian Gulf crisis ends, with any post-embargo exports by Iraq and Kuwait likely to end up as a surplus on the world market. **********"If production from Iraq and Kuwait comes back, which is a real possibility, OPEC will be back in the problems very similar to what they had early this year, except there has been a change in OPEC," said John B. Boatwright, an economist with Exxon. **********Oil analysts presume that after the crisis ends, Iraq will no longer be in a position to enforce production limits by bullying its neighbors. As a result, Mr. Boatwright said, "a future production agreement would be even more difficult."  Finely Balanced Market **********Even without an end to the standoff over Kuwait, production will eventually outstrip demand, experts here said. Several described the current market as finely balanced, with oil production and especially refining capacity strained to the limit. But Mr. Boatwright said that by next summer "demand will be 1.5 million barrels a day less than OPEC capacity." **********"You can make your own conclusion about what that will do to prices," he added. **********James H. Ross, the president and chief executive of BP America Inc., the United States subsidiary of the British Petroleum Company P.L.C., said demand for OPEC oil in the first quarter of next year would run 20.5 million barrels a day, while production is now 22.5 million barrels a day and Saudi Arabia is planning to pump even more. Prices will stay high while there is a fear of war, he said, but if the perception took hold that the price would plunge, that is exactly what would come to pass, because purchasers would delay buying to wait for a bargain, demand would fall and prices would drop in response. "OPEC needs to get its act together, whoever OPEC is," Mr. Ross said.  The Role of Iraq **********The chief economist of the Amoco Corporation, Theodore Eck, said, "Everyone knows Iraq's going to come back into the market, and clearly Saudi Arabia's going to make a place for them, but how it fits together I don't know." **********Discussing the difficulty of predicting future market conditions, an executive of one big oil company said that every year he presents his board with a proposal for capital spending, prefacing his remarks by saying, "We face an uncertain situation." This year, he said, he would say the same thing but would pound the table as he said it.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/24/busin.snippet: LEAD: A few miles south of Disneyland on Interstate 5, in Irvine, Calif., lies what some consider to be the real Magic Kingdom: Traveland U.S.A., billed as the world's largest sales lot for recreational vehicles.
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/24/busin.main_headline:
All About: Recreational Vehicles;

Will Motor Homes And Trailers Tempt A New Generation?
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/24/busin.print_headline:
All About: Recreational Vehicles;

Will Motor Homes And Trailers Tempt A New Generation?
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/24/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: A few miles south of Disneyland on Interstate 5, in Irvine, Calif., lies what some consider to be the real Magic Kingdom: Traveland U.S.A., billed as the world's largest sales lot for recreational vehicles. **********A few miles south of Disneyland on Interstate 5, in Irvine, Calif., lies what some consider to be the real Magic Kingdom: Traveland U.S.A., billed as the world's largest sales lot for recreational vehicles. **********Spanning 35 outdoor acres - as much as eight Manhattan blocks - Traveland has more than two dozen independent dealers selling motor homes, travel trailers, converted vans and other recreational vehicles costing several thousand to hundreds of thousands of dollars. Itasca Windcruisers and Georgie Boy Cruisemasters gleam in the California sun, beckoning to those who dream of an open highway ahead, a loved one at their side and a shower and bed in back. **********Even as RV makers vie for customers with conveniences like videocassette recorders and microwave ovens, the crowds at the RV lots have thinned. Sales peaked at 427,300 in 1988, slipping to 395,700 last year. Analysts say a slowing economy deserves much of the blame. Some also criticize RV marketing and design, which seem to advance as slowly as a motor home chugging up the Continental Divide in a gale-force headwind. **********Motor homes - large, self-propelled coaches - are the most expensive recreational vehicles, starting at $35,000. Then come trailer units, including folding campers, and converted vans, which accounted for half of all RV's sold in 1989. Some classify the vans as a separate industry, because they are sold through different dealers and often lack the amenities of other RV's. **********The typical recreational vehicle customers are like Clarence Callear, 69, and his wife Gloria, 47, of Simi Valley, Calif., with cash to spend and time to spend it. They are planning to drive all the way to Alaska. **********''We like to go traveling and this is like having a little house on wheels,'' Mrs. Callear said after inspecting a Rexhall on the Traveland lot. **********William J. Rex, president of Rexhall Industries Inc., a small California manufacturer, knows his customers well. They tend to be affluent blue-collar families, known in the industry as ''Mr. and Mrs. Folks.'' As Mr. Rex puts it, ''We're talking Middle America; a good old guy and his wife who have some grown kids. The average buyer of a motor home is over 50, and over 50 percent of the time they pay cash.'' **********The Industry Leader **********Still Susceptible To Economy's Whims **********In a fragmented business with hundreds of manufacturers, Fleetwood Enterprises Inc. of Riverside, Calif., stands out like a motor home parked among motorcycles. The company, the industry's largest with about 29 percent of motor home and trailer sales, competes in almost every RV category but vans. Fleetwood has grown much more rapidly than the industry through financial might - it also has a large manufactured home business - and a strong dealer network. ''They've been innovative in design, adding new features, and they have been successful in holding down their costs,'' said Robert Curran, an analyst at Merrill Lynch. **********But Fleetwood is not immune to industry gyrations. The company's sales depend heavily on the economy and the availability of fuel. Sales plunged in 1974 during the oil embargo and again in 1980 during the Iranian Revolution. They hurtled upward as the economy boomed in 1984, but fell when consumer confidence weakened in 1986. ''These cycles are a combination of economics, gasoline shortages, high interest rates, consumer sentiment and satisfying demand,'' said David R. Marriner, Fleetwood's treasurer. **********Fleetwood's sales set a record of $1.05 billion for the year ending in April 1989, then declined 7 percent to $978 billion for the most recent year. ''For two years people have been just flat out expecting a recession,'' Mr. Marriner said. ''So they backed off. We expect the industry to be flat this year and probably for the first part of 1991.'' **********Fleetwood has fared much better than the second-largest RV maker, Winnebago Industries Inc., which has less than half Fleetwood's revenues. Analysts say that Winnebago has been troubled by frequent changes of command and a troubled foray into satellite communications. **********The industry as a whole has hit a major slowdown in the last year and a half as consumers delayed major purchases. Almost 8.5 million recreational vehicles cruise the nation's highways, with as many as 400,000 more, worth $9 billion at retail, shipped to dealers every year. But according to the Recreational Vehicle Industry Association, shipments through April of this year fell 6.7 percent. **********A Transition Time **********Reaching 'the Folks' And Baby Boomers **********The new decade may bring a record number of potential buyers. The Recreational Vehicle Industry Association predicts that the prime RV-buying age group of 45-54 year olds will increase 23 percent by 1995, another 18 percent by 2000. ''With the Baby Boom reaching its 50's in huge numbers in the next 10 years, we are really going to have some opportunity,'' said Fred G. Emmert, senior vice president of marketing at the Holiday Rambler Corporation, a subsidiary of Harley-Davidson Inc. **********But will all these new 50-year-olds buy? Maybe not, says Morton J. Marcus, director of a center at the University of Indiana School of Business to study the state's industries. Today, when both spouses work, vacation time is precious, and inexpensive airfares make it more convenient to fly, he said. Most of those born after the war have spent less time outdoors than their parents. ''Many of the people who bought RV's in the '50s and '60s bought on their experiences as children,'' he said. **********Then there are all the other competing forms of recreation. ''There is the boating industry, the hotel destination resort industry, even things like large home entertainment systems,'' said Elden L. Smith, a senior vice president at Fleetwood. ''You aren't going to spend $3,000 or $4,000 and then leave home on the weekends.'' **********The market is changing, but the sales pitch isn't, say some analysts. The Recreational Vehicle Industry Association's major marketing effort is a travelogue show on cable television's Nashville Network. Fleetwood has forged marketing links with Walt Disney World, a favorite RV destination. Many manufacturers sponsor owner clubs, and local dealers hold weekend RV shows. **********But manufacturers have made few attempts to entice younger buyers. Most of their mass-market advertising is in RV magazines, with almost no national advertising to convince a new generation that the open roads can be as exhilarating as a Club Med. **********''It is quite true that baby boomers are different types of consumers,'' said Dr. Richard Curtin, a University of Michigan professor who studies RV ownership. ''But the market is at an awkward time, when the primary buyers of new RVs are not yet part of the baby boom generation. The industry has to walk a tightrope and not alienate mainstay customers. The marketing transition will be slow.'' **********RV executives themselves say members of this generation are more active and affluent than their parents, and likely to be better customers. The trick will be convincing them to regard an American RV as a status symbol equal to a plush imported car. Mr. Rex says the new generation can have it both ways: ''I've heard that baby boomers want BMW's, not motor homes, but I think they'll just tow that BMW behind it.'' **********A Lack of Innovation **********Sticking With That Boxy Shape **********Recreation vehicle research and design progress as slowly as RV marketing. RV designs are likely to remain boxy because a squared-off configuration offers the most storage space and the chassis the industry uses allow little flexibility. All manufacturers buy chassis, complete with engines and steering wheels, primarily from Ford, General Motors and John Deere, then build frames over them, mostly by hand. **********Most manufacturers content themselves to improve on the basic, recognizable RV design. The most recent breakthrough came a while ago, in 1985, after John Crean, Fleetwood's chairman, drove a company motor home across the country. He decided to create a basement storage area by raising the interior floor a foot above the chassis. Competitors quickly copied the idea. **********Recreational vehicle designers say that besides a lot of storage, most buyers crave conveniences like microwave ovens and energy-efficient power sources. ''Ten years ago, a standby generator could make all the noise it wanted,'' said Mr. Emmert of Holiday Rambler. ''You didn't worry about heat dissipation or how precise the frequency of electricity was. Now the RV industry has demanded that these generators be quiet, fuel-efficient and their frequency response be narrow. We've got VCR's and TV sets and computers on board and they can't stand the energy spikes.'' New features, but in the familiar, reassuring, RV settting. Said Mr. Emmert, ''That's the kind of gradual change the industry is experiencing.'' **********The Comforts Of Home **********The price of a Ferrari, the size of a bus - top-of-the-line motor homes are mansions on wheels. **********Take the $300,000 Marquis, made by Beaver Coaches Inc. of Bend, Ore. Forty feet long and diesel-fueled, it is built expressly for people who spend at least half their lives on the road. Inside are two television sets, a full kitchen, a bedroom with queen-sized bed and jacuzzi. No major engine work should be needed before a quarter-million miles, says Marcus Vucinivic, Beaver's sales manager. The company sells 90 a year. **********Not good enough? Try the Beaver Coach, a $450,000 recreational vehicle that is actually a converted bus. Favored by rock stars and other entertainers, the Coach has a huge 450 horsepower engine. Every vehicle's interior is custom designed. Satellite dishes, skylights, marble counters and oak flooring are popular options. Beaver sells 18 a year. The latest buyer: Ernest Borgnine.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/18/busin.main_headline: Stocks Drop on Low Earnings Reports
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/18/busin.print_headline: Stocks Drop on Low Earnings Reports
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/18/busin.body_text: **********Stocks fell broadly yesterday after disappointing earnings reports and some futures-related trading quelled a midmorning rally. **********The Dow Jones industrial average fell 33.49 points, or 1.24 percent, to 2,659.13. Declining stocks on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered advances, 867 to 649. **********Volume on the Big Board was substantial for the second consecutive day, with 170.5 million shares trading. That was lower, however, than the 186.1 million shares that changed hands on Tuesday. **********In the broader market, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 3.35 points, to 337.40, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index lost 1.51 points, 186.86. **********Disappointing earnings reports had a negative impact, traders said. Alcoa, for instance, plunged 5 7/8, to 66 7/8. The company reported fourth-quarter net income of $1.88 a share, well below last year's $2.47 a share and the $2.45-a-share range most analysts had expected. **********I.B.M. fell 1 1/4, to 98 7/8, after reporting that its yearly earnings dropped 35.3 percent, to $6.47 a share in 1989 from $9.80 a share in 1988. The AMR Corporation, parent of American Airlines, slipped 1/2, to 56 1/2, after reporting a sharp drop in fourth-quarter earnings. **********''Professionals are very unforgiving when earnings do not come up to expectations,'' said Robert H. Stovall, president of Stovall/21st Advisers. ''The Alcoa performance portends what we might see for the next 10 trading days. Good earnings tend to be reported early while poorer earnings tend to be reported later.'' **********Earlier this month and late last month there was profit taking in 1989 winners like tobacco, food, telephone and utility stocks, he said, adding, ''Money transferred into cyclical stocks won't stay there very long if today's action is any example.'' **********Big Trade Deficit **********The Government reported that the nation's trade deficit rose 2.4 percent, to $10.5 billion, the biggest monthly deficit of 1989, and the Dow was down about 10 points after a half-hour. **********But it moved into plus territory quickly, and by 12:30 P.M. was up about 12 points. Then sell programs affected the market at about 1 P.M. and again at 3:30 P.M., bringing the Dow to a 42-point deficit before it recovered a bit near the close. **********Among individual issues, Manufacturers Hanover rose 7/8, to 33 1/2. The company said it was not a lender to Allied Stores and Federated Department Stores, the Campeau Corporation subsidiaries that filed for bankruptcy protection on Monday. **********Aristech Chemical was the most active stock, rising 1/2, to 25 1/2, on a volume of nearly 5.6 million shares. The Mitsubishi Corporation said that it would make no changes in the operations or management of Aristech if it was successful in its $26-a-share bid for the specialty chemicals maker. **********Holiday Corporation rose 1 1/4, to 66 1/4. It said that it had raised the tender offer payment for the 8 3/8 percent notes due 1996 of its Holiday Inns subsidiary to $990, from $942.50 per $1,000 principal amount. Holiday also said that it had extended the consent solicitation period for the notes to Jan. 19. **********McGraw-Hill stock rose $3.125, to close at $59.25, amid talk on Wall Street that Paramount Communications would bid for it. Paramount slipped $1.50, to $45.625.  Bank of New England dropped 1 1/4, to 5 7/8, and was the biggest percentage loser. Analysts said the stock was depressed by fears that Federal regulators will delay or stop the rumored sales of Bank of New England subsidiary operations to the Fleet/Norstar Financial Group. **********Active blue chips included Citicorp, up 3/8, to 26 3/8; Philip Morris, off 7/8, to 38 1/2; General Electric, off 1/4, to 63; A.T.& T., off 5/8, to 42 1/2, and General Motors, off 1/2, to 42. **********On the American Stock Exchange, the Amex market value index slipped 0.35, to 368.06. In over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index declined 1.48 points, to 438.68.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/23/world.main_headline: White House Defends Main Points of Arms Control Deal Against Right-Wing Critics
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/23/world.print_headline: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;   White House Defends Main Points of Arms Control Deal Against Right-Wing Critics
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/23/world.body_text: **********The White House today defended the key elements of the arms control deal that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d struck with Moscow last week, dismissing as groundless criticism from the Republican right wing that Mr. Baker made too many concessions. **********A senior Administration official, briefing reporters in the White House before next week's summit meeting between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, focused in particular on criticism of the Administration's handling of the question of how to limit Soviet SS-18 heavy missiles. **********In his talks in Moscow last week, Mr. Baker and the Soviets resolved most of the other key differences holding up the proposed treaty limiting long-range nuclear weapons, leaving only the problem of SS-18 modernization and a few others to be worked out. But the fact that on SS-18's, the most dangerous in the Soviet arsenal, Mr. Baker proposed a limited concession to Moscow in hopes of tying up the treaty now, has enraged some Republican conservatives. **********''We are strong, and just at the moment when we are strong, we are making concessions.'' said Richard N. Perle, who served as an Assistant Secretary of Defense in the Reagan Administration, and has added his voice to that of the Wall Street Journal editorial page and several conservative columnists in attacking the deal being negotiated by Mr. Baker. ''Any American official making concessions to the Soviets today has to explain himself, as much as would any corporation which made a deposit in a crumbling savings and loan.'' **********Reductions Agreed **********The Soviets have already agreed to reduce by 50 percent their arsenal of SS-18's - each of which carry 10 warheads - from 308 missiles to 154. The Kremlin, however, has been insisting that no restrictions be placed on its ability to modernize the 154 that would be left. Critics of the Administration point out that since the negotiations began in 1982 the Soviets have already modernized their SS-18 arsenal - they are currently deploying the SS-18 Model 5 - in a way that has made the missiles so accurate that they can get by with half the number, without any serious dimunition of their overall firepower. **********Therefore, they argue, the treaty must make certain that their existing SS-18's cannot be upgraded, and for years American negotiators did insist that the Soviets freeze modernization as part of the proposed Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty. **********For the first time, the Administration official confirmed today that Mr. Baker in Moscow offered a minor compromise on SS-18's that would allow for limited modernization, but, he argued, it would be so limited as to not allow the Soviets to ever seriously upgrade the missile from its present capabilities. **********Called a Minor Incentive **********Considering the concessions to Washington Moscow has already made on SS-18's - accepting a 50 percent cut with no similar cut by the United States - what Mr. Baker offered was a minor incentive for the Kremlin designed to help lock in the treaty right now, the official said. **********''It is a truism that agreements can only be reached if they are acceptable to both sides,'' the State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, said. ''So the bargaining process, especially in the final phase, will inevitably involve tradeoffs in which we take steps to meet Soviet concerns in return for their acceptance of our requirements. **********''We are not making concessions in arms control as a means of 'helping Gorbachev.' We are making sound proposals, fully examined in Washington and supported by our military leaders, aimed at closing out agreements very much in the United States interests.'' **********On SS-18's, the previous American position, the official said, ''is to ban all production, all modernization, all flight testing of heavy ICBM's.'' What Mr. Baker indicated in Moscow was some flexibility in that position which would allow the Soviets to build a limited number of their modernized SS-18's and to conduct a limited number of flight tests. **********'So It's a Cap' **********If the Soviets can be induced to agree to this - and thus far they have not -the official said, ''that would mean that instead of being able to go on and produce something beyond the Mod 5, it would be Mod 5 and no more; stop.'' **********The official continued: ''If you can get the Soviets to agree on a limit on flight tests so you can only do one or two or three or some number like that a year, what that says to the Soviets is, 'Okay, you can do enough flight testing to preserve the reliability of your current SS-18's, but you can't do enough flights that you can go off and develop yet another one.' So it's a cap. **********''Remember where we already are,'' the official concluded. ''The Soviets have 308 heavy ICBM's. They have agreed to unilaterally cut that number in half, to 154, okay? We've got that nailed; that's in the can. What's at issue now is what else we can get on SS-18's.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/19/world.print_headline: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE: LITHUANIANS SAY MOSCOW HAS CUT MAIN OIL PIPELINE;   Growing Pressure
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/19/world.body_text: **********After a confusing day of threats and denials, Lithuania reported tonight that the Soviet authorities had cut off the principal supply of oil to the republic as part of the Kremlin's campaign to force Lithuania to retreat from its declaration of independence. **********The Lithuanian information office said the pipeline supply of crude oil to the Mazeikiai refinery in the northwest of the republic was cut off at 9:30 P.M. Vilnius time, five minutes after notice was telephoned to the plant in the name of Kremlin officials. On Tuesday, Lithuania said it had been warned that the supply would be halted today in keeping with an ultimatum issued by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev last Friday. **********Search for a Solution **********Even as the announcement came, it was clear that attempts to find a solution to the crisis were continuing. During the day in Vilnius, the Lithuanian Parliament offered a conciliatory gesture to the Kremlin by voting to refrain from enacting new laws for two weeks if Moscow agreed to begin preliminary consultations on the independence campaign. **********But the Parliament also said that it ''confirms its loyalty to the acts of March 11,'' when the Parliament declared independence and suspended the Soviet Constitution. [Text of the Parliament's resolution and letter to Mr. Gorbachev, page A10.]  There was no confirmation in Moscow tonight that the ultimatum threatening an oil cutoff had, in fact, been carried out. **********Signs of Pressure **********Its enactment would signal a far higher level of pressure from Mr. Gorbachev than has previously been seen in the five-week-long sovereignty crisis and would also increase the calls in other nations for retaliatory economic measures against the Soviet Union. [In Washington, the Bush Administration said that until it could confirm reports of the cutoff it would not have any response. The reports came only a few hours after Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d told a Congressional committee that the United States would consider severing certain commercial arrangements with the Soviet Union if Mr. Gorbachev continued tightening a economic noose around Lithuania. Page A10.]  Soviet officials denied earlier today that orders for a cutoff had yet gone out. But managers at Mazeikiai, the sole refinery in Lithuania, said tonight that the pipeline supply from the city of Polotsk in the republic of Byelorussia in the western Soviet Union was finally stopped tonight. **********Resolve Called Deeper **********''The Soviet Union, being unable to find a humane solution, is resorting to economic coercion against a neighboring country,'' the Lithuanian President, Vytautas Landsbergis, said after receiving the news and vowing that the pressure would only deepen the republic's commitment to independence. **********There was no immediate indication of how long the reported cutoff might continue. The struggle between the Kremlin and the republic has been marked by steady psychological pressure and changing Kremlin tactics, with alternate waxing and waning of the sense of crisis. **********The reported cutoff of oil itself would presumably mean no immediate industrial hardship or shortage of refined oil in the republic, because Lithuanian officials estimated earlier this week that there was a stockpile of up to four months of crude oil with which to continue operations in the event of a cutoff. **********Plant officials confirmed tonight that work was continuing after the pipeline inflow fully stopped, about an hour after a decrease was first evident. **********Lithuanian officials quoted plant officials on the night shift as reporting that the authorizatiofofor the toppage was gngned by uhe Soviet Primeininister, Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, under a resolution of the Council of Ministers. **********A 48-Hour Ultimatum **********On Friday, just before the long Easter weekend, President Gorbachev issued a 48-hour ultimatum to the Landsbergis government to repeal a series of independence laws or face reductions in supplies from the rest of the Soviet Union. On Monday, the Lithuanians had responded to the ultimatum with an offer of talks on central issues mentioned in the ultimatum. **********Before the cutoff, a Soviet deputy oil and gas industry minister, Aklim Mukhamedzyanov, said in a telephone interview that ''allegations that these supplies have been terminated are completely groundless. **********''We have received no instructions from the Council of Ministers to implement such measures,'' he said. **********Republic Dependent for Energy **********With no fuel resources of its own, Lithuania is completely dependent on the crude oil, natural gas and petroleum shipped in from the Soviet Union, and panicked citizens have been lining up daily at gas stations around the republic to fill up their cars and trucks. There was no sign today of a cutoff of natural gas, which had also been threatened. **********The Mazeikiai refinery processed almost 13 million tons of oil last year. About 7 million tons of that was used in Lithuania, while the remainder was sent to the other Baltic republics and elsewhere. Small amounts also are sold into northwestern Europe through Hamburg, West Germany. **********Lithuania imports 97 percent of the fuel it consumes, with nearly half of the total supplied by oil produced in other Soviet republics that is used to heat and power Lithuanian factories. Factories and other industrial activities also run on coal. Homes are heated mainly by natural gas. Lithuania does produce some energy at a nuclear power station at Ignalina and in some small hydroelectric stations. **********Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Ryzhkov threatened Lithuania on friday with a cut-off of critical supplies if the Parliament there did not revoke within 48 hours recently passed legislation, including a call to boycott the Soviet spring military call-up and the introduction of mandatory citizen identity cards. **********The ultimatum from Moscow did not include a demand that the republic revoke its declaration of independence, made March 11, a move the republic has repeatedly rejected. **********A Gesture to Moscow **********Lithuania's Parliament, in a conciliatory gesture to the Kremlin, voted unanimously today to refrain from passing new laws for two weeks if Moscow agrees to begin preliminary consultations about the republic's drive for independence. The Parliament's resolution did not specifically mention the status of laws passed since the independence declaration, except to say the Parliament supports a statement made Monday by the Lithuanian Prime Minister, Kazimiera Prunskiene. **********In that statement, the first sign that the republic was willing to compromise with Moscow, Mrs. Prunskiene sent a telegram to the Soviet leadership saying that Lithuania would not stand in the way of Lithuanian men willing to serve in the army and would not take action against Soviet citizens choosing to stay in the republic while maintaining their soviet citizenship. Then, Tuesday, as the specter of a fuel blockade loomed, Lithuanian legislators began urging that serious concessions be offered to Moscow in the hopes of encouraging the Kremlin to agree to negotiations. **********In addition to the proposal on temporarily suspending the passage of any new laws, the Lithuanian resolution urges Moscow ''to refrain from using force, including economic pressure, against Lithuania and it citizens.'' **********It further calls on Lithuanian citizens and economic organizations ''to prepare for a period of austerity and spiritual endurance.'' **********Letter to Soviet Leaders **********The Parliament also unanimously adopted a letter to Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Ryzhkov, outlining its latest position and supporting the points raised by Mrs. Prunskiene in her telegram to the Soviet President earlier this week. **********The parliamentary letter says that a Lithuanian delegation will soon be going to Moscow and will be ready to meet with Kremlin representatives to begin the proposed ''preliminary consultations.'' The delegation is to be led by Bronius Kuzmickas, deputy chairman of the Lithuanian Parliament. **********In the one critical note raised in the letter, the Parliament says it ''regrets the position and methods chosen by the U.S.S.R.'' during the current crisis. **********Mr. Gorbachev issued his ultimatum to Lithuania after a month of steadily increasing threats and warnings that Lithuania must rescind its declaration and all subsequent legislation. Moscow has maintained that Lithuania and all other Soviet republics are free to secede from the Soviet Union provided they follow guidelines recently adopted by the national Parliament in Moscow, which include a referendum requiring a two-thirds vote to approve secession, a transition period running a minimum of five years and approval by the Congress of People's Deputies, the full Soviet Parliament. **********Lithuanian officials insist that they are seeking not to secede, but rather to re-establish the independence that was lost in 1940, when Lithuania and the neighboring Baltic republics of Latvia and Estonia were forcibly incorporated into the Soviet Union by Stalin. **********As the Parliament worked today on a political solution to the stalemate with Moscow, Mrs. Prunskiene and the Lithuanian Foreign Minister, Algirdas Saudargas, left for a trip to Norway, trying to find practical help for the fledgling republic through foreign investors and economic aid.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/29/busin.main_headline: Talking Deals;   Group May Gain Control of Penrod
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/29/busin.print_headline: Talking Deals;   Group May Gain Control of Penrod
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/29/busin.body_text: **********WITH the Hunt brothers of Texas removed from any role in the Penrod Drilling Corporation, a syndicate of 10 banks and an investor group headed by Richard E. Rainwater are expected to decide soon who will control the world's largest offshore oil and gas driller. If events work out, the group led by the Fort Worth investor may end up controlling the company for far less than rival bidders have offered to buy it outright. **********Several bidders for Penrod have emerged: The Tisch family has offered $450 million; the Rowan Companies, a Houston-based driller, offered $325 million; a Norwegian group has made a bid, and others higher than $500 million have been reported. But the Rainwater group may find that after negotiating with Penrod's creditors, its $95 million investment for a 27 percent stake in the company is enough to give it operating control. **********The Rainwater-controlled Energy Service Company, a drilling company that is part of the Penrod investment group, is pushing for a recapitalization of Penrod that might include a public sale of common shares. Other drillers, including Odeco and the Western Company of North America, have been successful in selling stock in the last year, and a Penrod offering could draw a large crowd. **********Penrod's lenders, headed by Manufacturers Hanover and First Chicago, could thus avoid new write-offs, recoup some past losses and have a role in whatever recovery unfolds in the coming years in the drilling industry. **********Values for used drilling rigs are up more than 50 percent in the last year, to $16 million for models operating in 250 feet of water. Penrod has 39 offshore rigs, and 45 more rigs used for drilling on land. With oil prices firming, drilling budgets rising at big oil companies and prospects for further increases in the rigs' value, many Penrod lenders are unwilling to sell their notes at a discount, people close to the situation said. **********Founded more than 60 years ago by H.L. Hunt, who was considered the world's richest man when he died in 1974, debt-laden Penrod has been starved for cash since oil prices plunged four years ago and leading oil companies pulled the plug on their drilling budgets. **********At first, three of Mr. Hunt's sons who controlled Penrod, William Herbert, Nelson Bunker and Lamar Hunt, filed costly lawsuits to stall the banks' attempt to seize rigs to cover more than $750 million in unpaid loans. In a partial truce two years ago, the banks wrote off $250 million of the loans in exchange for 50 percent of Penrod's stock. **********Last week, with a March 31 deadline looming for the first of 32 consecutive quarterly principal payments on $525 million in remaining principal and accrued interest, and Penrod's cash flow still depressed, the Hunts handed over the rest of their holdings. **********The note holders, including the Rainwater group, agreed to drop a potential claim on up to $300 million in future profits from the Placid Oil Company, which the brothers still control. **********The lenders' improving prospects at Penrod made their claim on Placid profits less important than removing the Hunts from the bargaining table at Penrod, said Russell E. Miller, an analyst at Alex. Brown & Sons Inc. in Baltimore. **********The Rainwater group, a partnership consisting of Energy Service; Goldman, Sachs; Mr. Rainwater, and others, had paid $95 million to acquire $135 million of the Penrod bank debt, or 27 percent of the total, before the Hunts' departure last week. The Rainwater group's stock holding in Penrod has now doubled, to 27 percent. **********Mr. Rainwater, once the principal deal maker for the Bass family, also of Fort Worth, entered the industry three years ago when he acquired a large stake in Blocker Energy. Blocker's debt-laden balance sheet was later restructured and the company's name was changed to Energy Service, or Ensco. Mr. Rainwater owns 21 percent. **********Ensco operates in the Middle East, South America, Canada and the United States and has five offshore rigs and 24 land rigs. The company, which is listed on the American Stock Exchange, earned $2.6 million on $158.5 million in sales last year. It is also a supplier in the growing market of horizontal drilling equipment. **********Does Mr. Rainwater intend to use the 27 percent stake in Penrod to squeeze more money from other Penrod bidders eventually? Or is he trying to become a catalyst for a reshaping of the world's offshore oil industry? **********Mr. Miller of Alex. Brown said the Rainwater group was bargaining with each bank, searching for agreements either to acquire the debt or for the banks to ease the 1988 repayment terms and allow Ensco to take command of Penrod operations. **********Others in the industry are not so sure. Two years ago, a Rainwater group delayed for several months the takeover by Halliburton Inc. of Gearheart Industries, a cash-short maker of gauges and other equipment used in testing well sites. Halliburton eventually paid $67 million for Gearhart debt that the Rainwater group had acquired for $33 million. **********Still, control of Penrod could prove far more lucrative. Unlike most sectors of the oil industry, offshore drilling did not contract through bankruptcies, mergers and takeovers after prices collapsed in 1986, said James L. Carroll, an analyst at Paine Webber Inc., in New York. Many companies still have more debt than future revenues are likely to cover, he added. **********''Whatever happens to the Penrod assets is very important to the whole offshore industry,'' Mr. Carroll said. ''If it ends up in the hands of other operators, you could see the beginnings of a major consolidation. This means whoever gets Penrod is going to be in an instant leadership position.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/14/busin.main_headline: Patents;   Using a Gene To Prevent Crop Spoilage
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/14/busin.print_headline: Patents;   Using a Gene To Prevent Crop Spoilage
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/14/busin.body_text: **********A biotechnology company in New Jersey won a patent this week for a method of preventing fruits and vegetables from spoiling by using genetic engineering to enhance their natural defenses against fungus. **********Developed by researchers at the DNA Plant Technology Corporation in Cinnaminson, N.J., the method is designed to protect crops during the long trip from farm to market. Farmers and shippers now spend millions of dollars fumigating soil and spraying harvested crops. **********The new technique consists of inserting into plants a bacterial gene that produces an enzyme called chitinase, which has long been known to break down the cell walls of many fungi. Plants produce small quantities of chitinase themselves, but not enough for reliable protection during shipment. **********''What we're doing is enhancing and augmenting the natural immune system of the plant,'' said David Gilbert , a company spokesman. Thus far, he said, researchers have successfully transplanted the chitinase gene to tomato, potato, lettuce and other plants. But he added that they had not been successful in doing so with rice, corn, wheat and other grains. **********The company said it hoped that plants containing the gene would reach commercial markets by the mid-1990's. **********Two DNA plant researchers, Trevor V. Suslow and Jonathan D. G. Jones, obtained patent 4,940,840.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/21/world.main_headline: Baker and Soviets Confer on Strategic Arms
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/21/world.print_headline: Baker and Soviets Confer on Strategic Arms
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/21/world.body_text: **********Two senior Soviet officials met with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today and suggested some new ideas on strategic arms, Administration officials said. **********A senior Administration official described the negotiating session, which was held on short notice at the behest of Moscow, as ''productive.'' **********The American official said the discussions, with Viktor Karpov, a senior Soviet arms control official, and Col. Gen. Branislav Omelichev, first deputy director of the Soviet General Staff, included possible compromises on limiting air-launched and sea-launched cruise missiles, two issues holding up completion of a strategic arms treaty. **********Another senior official said that while the Soviets' new ideas on cruise missiles resulted in some movement, the meetings today did not resolve all differences over the weapons. **********The meeting suggested that Moscow and Washington were trying not to allow the situation in Lithuania to disrupt American-Soviet relations and the push for new arms accords. **********The arms control discussions held earlier this month between Mr. Baker and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze went poorly, and today's session appeared to be an effort to put things back on track before the summit meeting scheduled for May 30 between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/08/busin.main_headline: Bankers Trust Sells Notes Due in 2000
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/08/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;   Bankers Trust Sells Notes Due in 2000
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/08/busin.body_text: **********The Bankers Trust New York Corporation priced $200 million in 9 1/2 percent subordinated notes due 2000 yesterday through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. **********The noncallable notes are priced at 99.397 to yield 9.595 percent, or about 115 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. **********Underwriters said the notes were rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and AA- by Standard & Poor's. **********Shearson was also the lead underwriter for another Bankers Trust offering earlier this week, a $240 million issue of money market preferred stock that was divided into four series. **********The initial dividend rates included 6.55 percent, 6.60 percent, 6.625 percent and 6.65 percent. Dividend rate adjustments will be through a Dutch auction process every 49 days.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/20/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   2 Drug Concerns In Product Accord
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/20/busin.body_text: **********The XOMA Corporation, a therapeutic products company in Berkeley, Calif., and Ortho Biotech, a division of the Ortho Pharmaceutical Corporation, a Johnson & Johnson subsidiary, will develop two products for treating immune-related diseases. The products are designed to eliminate specific disease-related cells without causing harm to other cells. The products can be used with grafts and organ transplants. **********XOMA retains worldwide manufacturing rights for the products. Ortho Biotech has worldwide marketing rights except in Japan, Korea and China. The products will be marketed domestically by Ortho Biotech and internationally by Cilag International, also a Johnson & Johnson affiliate.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/15/world.main_headline: U.S. Prepares to Reduce Spying Posts in Germany
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/15/world.print_headline: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;   U.S. Prepares to Reduce Spying Posts in Germany
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/15/world.body_text: **********As a result of the political upheaval in Eastern Europe, American intelligence officials are preparing to close down expensive electronic listening posts and to conduct a major re-evaluation of United States operations in the region. **********Any such change has important security and budgetary implications for the United States and its allies because the frontier between East and West in Europe has been among the world's most active spots for intelligence-gathering in the postwar period. **********The most sweeping transformation, German and American officials say, could be the first to take place, as the United States dismantles or begins to share control over more than $1 billion in sensitive electronic eavesdropping stations in West Berlin and along West Germany's border with Czechoslovakia and East Germany. The officials, who were interviewed in the last three weeks, insisted on anonymity. **********Discussions about the future of those outposts are already under way, the officials said. American intelligence officials and private experts said a decision on the installations could come within one or two years. **********Reunification Speeds Changes **********United States officials have said for some time that the easing of tensions in Eastern Europe would lead to changes before the end of the decade in the American intelligence presence along the postwar frontier between East and West. But the changes are being forced much more quickly than had been anticipated by the rush toward reunification of the two Germanys. **********West Germany is the locus of American espionage operations along the old dividing line in Europe. Some American eavesdropping posts in Berlin exist under a postwar military agreement between the four victorious powers that presumably will be repealed before the two Germanys merge politically. **********Other American intelligence operations inside West Germany are conducted under agreements between the two nations that are expected to survive reunification. But many of the operations are aimed at East Germany or at Soviet troops based there, and West Germany already has made it clear that most if not all of those operations must cease once unification is achieved. **********''Their cooperation with us is based on the idea that across the inter-German border is a hostile power and a hostile intelligence establishment,'' a Bush Administration official said in an interview. ''Now they're realizing that doesn't exist anymore. And the first thing to disappear is our targeting against that territory.'' **********Effect of German Elections **********The retrenchment could be speeded if West Germany's Social Democrats score a political victory over Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Conservative Party in national elections in December, American officials indicated. **********The Social Democrats would be far less sympathetic to United States operations against the Soviets or against Communist elements within the old Warsaw Pact alliance, those officials noted. **********But a German official said that some joint operations will probably continue indefinitely, including those ''against the Soviet Union and the Warsaw Pact, as long as it exists.'' Operations against nonpolitical targets like terrorists and drug dealers may well expand. **********Some American electronic listening posts will also be recycled to monitor arms-control agreements and to collect data from new, mutually chosen targets, the German official added. **********''I don't think anyone knows what parts can be used as before, and what parts have a need for new targets,'' he said. ''You can use these facilities in different ways - to look more at developments on a political level, and to focus more directly on military things. **********''Some of these techniques will not work because of our legal situation,'' he said, referring to West Germany's strict controls on domestic surveillance, which are similar to those of the United States. **********Americans Debate the Haste **********In the United States, officials differ over whether the discussions on dismantling surveillance posts are a natural result of improved international relations or an overly hasty reaction to political developments that, while promising, are still in flux. **********The bulk of American operations against the old Eastern bloc are aimed at penetrating Soviet military operations or detecting preparations for a Warsaw Pact invasion. As that threat recedes, some American officials say, the need for a large intelligence presence should also diminish. **********But some United States officials are said to fear that operations may be shut down before the military dangers have ebbed. Officials at the National Security Agency, which controls electronic intelligence gathering, were said to be among those most troubled by that prospect. **********''Their only concern is to keep the information flowing,'' an Administration official said. ''If you come to the conclusion that these facilities that they've obviously worked so laboriously to create aren't going to be needed, well, they don't even care to think about that.'' **********Sophisticated Eavesdropping **********Although the National Security Agency's most productive eavesdropping operations are largely conducted elsewhere, some of the German posts at issue are among its most sophisticated anywhere. **********The primary post, a United States Army facility called Field Station Berlin, is said to monitor Warsaw Pact military operations throughout East Germany and in parts of Poland and Czechoslovakia. It is also a testing ground for new eavesdropping equipment and techniques. The Air Force runs operations for signals gathering and reconnaissance from Tempelhof Air Base in Berlin. **********Other United States facilities in West Germany are said to monitor Soviet activities deep inside Eastern Europe. **********West German and American officials acknowledge that the United States has collected information, by electronic and other means, on some West German targets that Washington regards as a threat to national security. **********The talks on listening posts presage a much broader debate over the future role of American intelligence in Europe should the Soviet conventional military threat continue to fade. **********Old Relationships Cooling **********Intelligence officials in other Western countries are already questioning whether the United States needs an intelligence presence on their territory now that the Eastern bloc threat appears to be receding, the Democratic chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, Senator David L. Boren of Oklahoma, said earlier this month. **********American officials say the United States expects its unusually close intelligence relationship with West Germany, carefully fostered since the end of World War II, to cool as the Germans become a European superpower with interests separate from those of the United States. **********Almost from the moment of Hitler's collapse in 1945, Germany has been an arena for the world's major espionage services. Their first tasks after the war included rounding up suspected Nazi war criminals, recruiting rocket scientists and competing for the members and dossiers of Germany's intelligence agencies. **********With the political division of Germany and Berlin between Western and Communist forces in 1949, that competition increased. Germany was viewed as the likeliest theater of combat between the Soviet bloc and the West, and intelligence services were considered the first line of Western defense. **********Scene of Swaps and Betrayals **********An official history compiled by the Senate indicates that in 1952, the Central Intelligence Agency was conducting 40 covert operations simultaneously out of West Germany, most of them directed against targets in East Germany. For the last four decades, many of the most spectacular East-West espionage stories involving spy swaps, defections and betrayals have been set in Germany. **********The United States and West Germany have long conducted joint intelligence operations against the Warsaw Pact and shared much of the intelligence on Eastern Europe that each nation gathered separately. **********But with East Germany and the Soviet Union assuming new roles, the interests of the United States and West Germany in gathering and using intelligence against the old Eastern bloc are about to diverge, a senior American official said in a recent interview.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/21/world.main_headline: Israel Halts U.S. Radio Relay To Study Negev Environment
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/21/world.print_headline: Israel Halts U.S. Radio Relay To Study Negev Environment
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/21/world.body_text: **********Israel has decided to suspend work on a Voice of America radio relay station in the Negev for two years to allow completion of an environmental study, causing the United States to express disappointment in a statement today. **********On Tuesday night, Israel's National Planning Board voted not to approve plans for the powerful relay station until a study to determine the effect of its electromagnetic waves on migratory birds is finished, even though Israel and the United States agreed to build the station two years ago. **********Thousands of birds from Europe migrate to Africa across the Arava Valley in the Negev. **********A brief statement released by the United States Embassy in Tel Aviv today said that the American Government was ''disappointed in Tuesday's decision by the planning board.'' **********Goals Are Questioned **********''The reasons for implementing the V.O.A. agreement signed by our two nations in 1987 remain valid,'' the statement added. **********Opponents of the relay station say the station's original goal - to boost broadcasts of Radio Liberty and Radio Free Europe - is irrelevant, given the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe. **********But the American statement said ''events in Eastern Europe and elsewhere have underscored the major role international radio can play in fostering democracy.'' **********Ground-breaking ceremonies for the station were held early this year, and workers have spent months rerouting a highway that cut through its designated area. The United States has already spent $40 million on the project. **********Still, the Israeli board voted, 8 to 6, to suspend work. **********Half the Board Absent **********More than half the board members were absent from the meeting, and some American officials here said they thought the full board might reverse the decision at its next regular meeting, in July. **********The station compound is supposed to occupy 2,000 acres and will include 37 antennas, some up to 300-feet high, and 16 transmitters with a maximum capacity of 500 kilowatts each. **********Since the United States first proposed the project in 1984, environmentalists have maintained that the powerful radio emissions could be harmful to migratory birds and people living in the area. The United States maintains, however, that no evidence exists to suggest the transmitter would be hazardous to birds or humans. **********The American statement said the issue of possible damage to birds had been well studied. But opponents of the project, led by the Society for the Protection of Nature in Israel, say the studies are incomplete. **********''There is a whole lot of new evidence, and the essence of the whole problem is that the United States and Israeli Governments went ahead on an immense project without waiting for the proper environmental impact studies,'' Joel Shadur, a spokesman for the society, said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/02/busin.main_headline: 3 Investment Banks Itemize Federated Fees, as Ordered
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/02/busin.print_headline: 3 Investment Banks Itemize Federated Fees, as Ordered
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/02/busin.body_text: **********Three of the nation's leading investment bankers submitted itemized accounts of their monthly fees yesterday to a Federal court overseeing the voluntary bankruptcy of Federated Stores Inc. **********The move is said to represent an effort by the United States trustee monitoring the bankruptcy to limit the fees paid to investment bankers involved in these proceedings. **********Such fees, which can be substantial, are paid before creditors' claims are settled. Under a new requirement, the fees must be detailed before they can be approved by the bankruptcy court, which up to now has approved retainers without a breakdown. **********Responding to a May 22 order by Bankruptcy Judge J. Vincent Aug, Shearson Lehman Hutton, Smith Barney and Lazard Freres, all involved in various phases of the Federated bankruptcy, furnished breakdowns of their fees, which range from $100,000 to $250,000 a month. The itemized accounting follows a long-established practice among other professionals, like lawyers, accountants and consultants, who work with bankruptcy proceedings. They already furnish detailed accounts of fees, which are subject to approval by the bankruptcy court. **********''This would be a precedent for bankruptcy cases,'' said Lewis S. Rosenbloom of Winston & Strawn, a Chicago law firm that represents Federated's unsecured creditors. ''However, while the new accounting would represent a precedent in this case, it would need a higher court ruling to give it widespread application.'' **********The bankers' documentation of their retainers will be studied to determine whether it meets the requirements of Judge Aug and Conrad Morgenstern, the United States Trustee for Ohio and Michigan. Federated is based in Cincinnati. **********''We have 45 days in which to evaluate whether the details of time spent and activities involved in the retainers are adequate,'' Mr. Morgenstern said in a telephone interview from Cleveland. ''This is a novel issue in our view because it hasn't to our knowledge come up before in bankruptcy situations.'' **********Mr. Morgenstern was said to have been instrumental in pushing for a detailed breakdown by investment bankers. His findings on the lists, according to lawyers involved, will be influential in any disputes in the matter. **********''Each lawyer must keep a daily record specifying service time spent on as many as 30 different categories of matters involved in the Federated bankruptcy,'' Mr. Rosenbloom said. Such categories include the question of whether litigation involving the debtor company before the bankruptcy can be renewed afterward; consideration of store leaseholds under the bankruptcy code, and payment for professionals in bankruptcy cases. **********Shearson Lehman reported the highest fees in the Federated case, about $250,000 a month, Mr. Rosenbloom said. Lazard Freres, which represents the bondholders of Allied Stores (a division of Federated Stores), gets $150,000 a month. And Smith Barney, representing the pre-merger bondholders, gets $100,000 a month. **********Both Allied and Federated were acquired by the Campeau Corporation, the Toronto-based developer, in 1986 and 1988, respectively. The American arm, known as Campeau U.S., which operated both Allied and Federated stores, was renamed Federated Stores Inc., several months ago. **********In a separate issue, the question of whether Shearson Lehman Hutton should be allowed to continue to advise Federated arose before Judge Aug, who ruled that the New York-based investment banker could be retained. The issue was raised because Shearson had been a lead underwriter of 11 issues of securities before the Federated acquisition by Campeau. **********But Mr. Morgenstern, exercising the trustee's responsibility, is contesting Judge Aug's decision and has filed an appeal. ''The Bankruptcy Court erred in approving Shearson's employment,'' Mr. Morgenstern said in his appeal.
