https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/15/world.main_headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   BUSH THREATENS A BLOCKADE OF JORDAN PORT AIDING IRAQ; KING COMES TO U.S. FOR TALKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/15/world.print_headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   BUSH THREATENS A BLOCKADE OF JORDAN PORT AIDING IRAQ; KING COMES TO U.S. FOR TALKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/15/world.body_text: **********As truckloads of cargo rolled from the Jordanian port of Aqaba toward Baghdad today, King Hussein of Jordan arrived in Washington for a meeting with President Bush in an apparent attempt to mediate the worsening crisis in the Middle East. **********Mr. Bush said at a news conference in Washington on Tuesday that if Aqaba was ''a hole through which commerce flows,'' the United States would blockade the port, which seems to be the only gap remaining in the international quarantine of Iraq. But the President also hinted that if Jordan cooperated with the embargo, the United States would help compensate it for the economic suffering that sanctions would cause. **********Seeking Aid for Jordan **********American officials said Tuesday that the United States was also pressing West Germany, Japan and Saudi Arabia to help offset financial losses by Jordan and by Syria. **********The stated purpose of the Presidential news conference was to talk about the Federal budget, and Mr. Bush lambasted Democrats on Capitol Hill for their attitude in negotiations on the Federal deficit. [Page A21.]  But the focus shifted to the Middle East. King Hussein is under domestic pressure to keep Aqaba open. Amman imports 90 percent of its oil from Iraq and sends 40 percent of its total exports to Iraq. In addition, Jordan's large Palestinian population is sympathetic to the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein, whom they see as a champion of the have-nots. **********Doubts on Workable Formula **********Reports in several Middle Eastern capitals said the King was carrying a letter to Mr. Bush from President Hussein, whom he met in Baghdad on Monday. **********ABC News, in a report from Baghdad, said that Foreign Ministry officials said the letter conveyed that President Hussein would like direct contact with United States officials and a sign that negotiation remains a possibilty. CBS News, citing unnamed Jordanian sources, said the message called for an international conference to discuss terms for an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait in exchange for a freeze on the buildup of United States forces in Saudi Arabia, which has passed the 20,000 mark. **********But two ranking Administration officials said they had no reason to believe that a workable peace formula would be produced by Mr. Bush's meeting with King Hussein, scheduled for Thursday at the President's vacation home in Kennebunkport, Me. The King arrived at Andrews Air Force Base outside Washington early today. **********Mr. Bush himself, speaking to reporters at the White House on Tuesday as he took a brief hiatus from his 25-day holiday, said he saw no prospects for a diplomatic solution to the crisis until sanctions had bitten deeply enough to convince the Iraqis ''that they've got to get out of Kuwait, and they've got to let the rightful rulers return to Kuwait.'' Iraq annexed Kuwait last week. **********Although the President deflected questions on the subject, aides said he had agreed to try to work out a plan under which American warships and those of other nations, some already committed to the blockade and others not, could operate under United Nations auspices. **********Idea Discussed at Meeting **********The idea, first broached several days ago by the Soviet Union, was discussed at a meeting at the State Department among officials of the five nations with permanent seats on the Security Council - the United States, the Soviet Union, China, Britain and France. **********Mr. Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d were said to see the plan, which could involve a joint command or ships under separate commands all flying the United Nations flag, as an opportunity to involve Moscow in concerted international action, if complex problems of coordination could be resolved. **********With American paratroopers moving into joint positions with Saudi soldiers to defend crucial oilfields, Pentagon officials said the Administration was considering a partial mobilization of the reserves. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney told a veterans' group in Atlanta that the President had the authority to call up as many as 200,000 members of the National Guard or reserve forces. **********Mr. Bush is to meet with the Joint Chiefs of Staff and other officers at the Pentagon today before returning to Maine, and the question of the reserves could come up then. **********U.S. Focuses on Aqaba **********Although rules of engagement have not been issued for the blockade of Iraqi commerce, which the Administration prefers to call an interdiction, Mr. Cheney said that ''we are watching all traffic that may be headed for Iraqi ports or may have cargo intended for Iraq.'' Among a handful of ships under surveillance, officials said, is the Iraqi-flag Balqees, believed to be carrying a cargo of tanks, engines and other military equipment from Gdynia in Poland to an unknown port in the Middle East. **********The biggest worry for those trying to complete the economic encirclement of Iraq is the port of Aqaba, which lies at the head of an arm of the Red Sea. It is linked to Baghdad by a highway and a small pipeline, the last functioning outlet for Iraqi oil. **********During the Iran-Iraq war, much of Iraq's war materiel and food flowed through Aqaba. It is easily accessible to the Mediterranean Sea through the Gulf of Suez and the Suez Canal, which Egypt declined today to close to Iraqi shipping, although Cairo is the leader of the group of Arab nations that have sent troops to Saudi Arabia to deter an Iraqi invasion. **********A dozen ships were berthed at Aqaba on Tuesday or anchored offshore. While it was impossible to establish the destination of all the cargoes, John Prescott, a London shipping specialist, said he had been told that at least three of the ships carried goods bound for Baghdad. **********The Associated Press reported from the Ruweishid border post, on the main highway linking Baghdad and Aqaba, that an unusually large number of heavy trucks and tankers were crossing from Jordan into Iraq. Military officials in Washington confirmed that Iraqi trade through Aqaba appeared to be proceeding at a brisk pace. **********Mutasem Belbeisi, an under secretary at the Jordanian Foreign Ministry, said that although the United Nations sanctions voted on Aug. 6 were binding on all member states, ''every country whose economy can be severely affected can consult with the Security Council to see what measures could be adopted and what sanctions could be imposed, if any.'' He said such consultations were under way in New York. **********Israel to Take No Action **********Israel, whose port of Eilat also lies at the head of the Gulf of Aqaba, just a few miles down the coast from Aqaba, said it would take no action to interefere with Iraqi shipping through Aqaba. Only if Iraqi troops move into Jordan, officials said, will Israel become involved in the crisis. **********So far, the blockade, to which American, British and Australian vessels have been committed, has not had a significant test. Arab harbormasters in the Persian Gulf turned away two Iraqi freighters, and a British warship stopped a third merchant ship but released it when an inspection showed it to have no cargo. **********The buildup of forces in Saudi Arabia accelerated further with the arrival of the vanguard of Syrian troops. The Syrians joined about 5,000 Egyptians, and contingents from Morocco and possibly Pakistan are expected within a week or so. **********A total of at least 100,000 American ground troops is expected to reach Saudi Arabia in the next month or two, and Mr. Cheney said today that an Iraqi force of 200,000 was now deployed in Kuwait and southern Iraq. **********In Kuwait and Iraq, at least 3,000 Americans, by the State Department's estimate, remained trapped. **********Iraqi officials made conflicting statements about the status of the Americans and thousands of other foreigners. ABC News reported that a senior Foreign Ministry official in Baghdad called the Americans in Iraq ''restrictees'' who would have to remain until the crisis was over. And Iraq's Ambassador to Greece said in Athens that they could leave only when ''the threats from the United States and its allies have been eliminated.'' But the Iraqi Ambassador in Washington indicated that the release could come much earlier than that.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/25/world.main_headline: Poles Voting for a President Who Can Face Up to the Ordeals
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/25/world.print_headline: MIDEAST TENSIONS; Poles Voting for a President Who Can Face Up to the Ordeals
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/25/world.body_text: **********There is wide agreement here that the winner on Sunday in Poland's first direct presidential elections will immediately face difficult political and social choices in the struggle to rebuild the devastated economy. **********The front-runner is Lech Walesa, the Solidarity leader, who has been drawing more than 35 percent in public-opinion polls, a showing suggesting that he will win less than the majority of the vote required to avoid a runoff of the top two finishers on Dec. 9. In second place with roughly 25 percent is Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, a former Walesa ally. Running a strong third with somewhat less that 20 percent is Stanislaw Tyminski, an emigre businessman with Canadian and Peruvian citizenship who has emerged as a dark-horse candidate. There are three minor candidates. **********The winner is to succeed Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Communist general who ordered martial law to crush the Solidarity labor movement and imprisoned Mr. Walesa and Mr. Mazowiecki in December 1981. President Jaruzelski has been eclipsed in the upheaval sweeping Eastern Europe beginning late last year, and he has agreed to step down after just over a year of his six-year term as Poland moves toward full democracy. **********Politically, the new president faces the task of assembling a Government that can hold a working majority in a Parliament that still contains many former Communists. Over the next few months, he will also take part in important decisions as Poland's radical economic-reform program continues, including how much longer to keep alive the huge, money-losing state enterprises that employ thousands of people.  'An Ocean of Problems' **********Nascent political parties will be maneuvering for advantage in next spring's parliamentary elections even as the lawmakers draft a new Constitution that redefines the powers of the presidency. **********"We are heading into an ocean of problems," declared Jacek Merkel, a respected economist who is campaign manager for Mr. Walesa. **********Political analysts say that with their choice of president, Poles will be setting a course for its future. **********Mr. Walesa, a Nobel Peace Prize winner, has said Poland needs a president with broad powers who can intervene at all levels of national life. **********Mr. Mazowiecki, a soft-spoken former journalist who was Mr. Walesa's ally in the Solidarity movement for 10 years, envisions a chief executive whose powers are balanced by other branches of Government. Mazowiecki Urges 'Tolerance' **********Mr. Walesa often touches the chords of Poland's religious and national history. Mr. Mazowiecki has spoken of moving toward Europe and of "tolerance" for minorities. **********Many uncertainties will confront the new president. **********At present, for instance, his powers are defined by the existing Constitution, drafted under the Communists, which allows the president to veto legislation and appoint a prime minister. There are also provisions for issuing emergency decrees. Mr. Walesa has made conflicting statements about how he would use these powers. **********The Constitution is now being rewritten and will probably be approved by the new Parliament elected next spring. **********Supporters of both candidates agree that whoever wins the presidency will soon be asking Poles to swallow further bitter economic medicine. Government economic forecasts predict a doubling of unemployment from one million to two million by the end of 1991.  'Shock Privatiization' Urged **********Walesa strategists seem to want the process to go even faster. Jaroslaw Kaczynski, a top Walesa lieutenant, said in an interview recently that Poland needs "shock privatization" even if this causes deeper social unrest. **********The new president will face a nation that is becoming increasingly disillusioned. Labor unrest is rising, and veterans of the Solidarity movement see the success of Mr. Tyminski as evidence of how far people's spirits have fallen. **********Mieczyslaw F. Rakowski, Poland's last Communist Prime Minister, agrees, and he contended in a recent newspaper interview that Mr. Walesa's courtship of the workers had created unrealistic expectations. "The Communist dream about the dictatorship of the proletariat is about to come true," he asserted. **********Supporters of Mr. Walesa argue that the Solidarity chairman is uniquely positioned to say no to the wage demands of the urban working class and to exhort them to search for new jobs as their state-run employers are restructured. **********"Of all the leading Polish politicians, I think Walesa has the best chance of giving Polish society this spirit of activation," Mr. Merkel said.  Challenge of a Premier **********The first challenge for the new president will be to choose a prime minister who can appoint a cabinet that will have majority support in Parliament. Sixty-five percent of the seats in the lower house are held by former Communists or their allies under an arrangement negotiated between Solidarity and the Communist Government last year before Eastern Europe's upheaval gathered force. **********It will be a delicate, perhaps impossible task. Mr. Walesa recently likened the position of prime minister to a bumper on a car, and he predicted that Poland would need a lot of them in the next few years. **********Mr. Mazowiecki's Government survived in Parliament by forging a shaky alliance with some members of the Peasant's Party and by retaining the united support of the legislators elected under the Solidarity banner. **********With the Solidarity legislators now divided between adherents of Mr. Mazowiecki and Mr. Walesa, it seems clear that the new prime minister will have to look elsewhere for support, possibly by offering the Peasants' Party a stronger voice in the Government. **********Some supporters of Mr. Mazowiecki believe that while they may lose the presidential race, they could regain power in a few months with a strong showing in the coming parliamentary election. Mr. Walesa's backers are also planning to secure an independent political base from those elections.  'It Will Be Very Difficult' **********Mieczyslaw Gil, a pro-Walesa delegate who was recently elected chairman of Solidarity's Citizens' Parliamentary Club, said that for the next few months an alliance supporting Mr. Walesa could be formed with the Peasants' Party and independent lawmakers. "It will be very difficult," he said. "It will require a lot of political and parliamentary skills." **********Mr. Gil recently replaced Bronislaw Geremek, the first chairman of Solidarity legislators, who has been a supporter of Mr. Mazowiecki. **********Rumors are rife in Warsaw about who might become prime minister. One possibility mentioned by both Mr. Walesa and supporters of Mr. Mazowiecki is Leszek Balcerowicz, the current Finance Minister and author of the economic plan. **********Mr. Walesa himself has promised to "air out" Warsaw, a statement generally taken as a promise that he will sweep out most of the Mazowiecki Cabinet and bring into prominence such figures as Mr. Merkel. **********Poland has had several free elections in the 20th century in which voters picked members of Parliament who in turn elected a president. Sunday's ballot will be the first time, however, that the president is chosen in an election in which all Poles can vote.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/23/busin.main_headline: Rule to Widen Trading In Options Takes Effect
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/23/busin.print_headline: Rule to Widen Trading In Options Takes Effect
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/23/busin.body_text: **********A new Securities and Exchange Commission rule that will allow stock options to be traded on more than one exchange went into effect today. **********The rule change, which will be phased in over the next year, has been widely debated by traders and government regulators. Proponents contend the rule will end trading monopolies that are outdated and inefficient. But some exchange executives say it will only increase costs and confusion for investors. **********A handful of new stock options were listed today on several markets to permit so-called multiple trading, as the exchanges reluctantly began complying with the new S.E.C. regulation. An option gives someone the right to buy or sell 100 shares of a certain stock at a specified price during a specific time period. **********Allowing options to be listed on more than one exchange will increase competition and lower prices to investors, Richard C. Breeden, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said in a Jan. 9 letter to exchange presidents. **********''The public interest in more competitive and efficient markets justifies the immediate cessation of the allocated monopoly system,'' Mr. Breeden said. **********'Layer of Costs' Seen **********But some exchange officials argued that the S.E.C. rule change would make options trading more costly and less efficient. ''It is going to build a layer of costs that is totally unnecessary into the marketplace,'' said Alger Chapman, chairman of the Chicago Board of Options Exchange, the world's largest options exchange. ''Investors will pay that cost.'' Under the old system, exclusive trading privileges in new stock options were allocated to one of the different exchanges on a rotating basis. With the abolishment of the allocation system, all exchanges are eligible to trade newly listed options. **********Next year, there will be a further easing of restrictions - on trading in existing stock options, not just newly listed options. On Jan. 21, 1991, the Securities and Exchange Commission plans to eliminate all exclusive trading privileges for options. Currently, multiple listing is allowed in over-the-counter stock options. **********''In the long run, it will be beneficial,'' said Tony Miliote, first vice president of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.'s options department. ''Anything that brings some competition will be good.'' **********New Options **********The American Stock Exchange added four new stock options today, and the Chicago Board Options Exchange added seven. Not all options were listed with different exchanges. **********Both exchanges began trading options in Biogen Inc., Racal Telecom P.L.C. and Sotheby Holdings Inc. The Pacific Board of Trade also began trading in Sotheby options. Of the New York Stock Exchange's five new listings, only one, the Sundstrand Corporation, was a multiple listing. Sundstrand was also listed on the Pacific Board of Trade. **********The Philadelphia Stock Exchange added two new companies, but they were not listed on any other exchanges. **********The S.E.C. is expected to relax standards on new listings within the month, creating dozens of additional new stock options and providing the first real test of the impact of multiple listings. **********Mr. Chapman of the Chicago Board Options Exchange conceded that in the short-term multiple listings would ''tighten the spread'' between the bid and asked price for options with less volume. But Mr. Chapman added, ''The competition doesn't last forever.'' After a month or two, one exchange generally emerges as the dominant market for a specific issue and then the spreads widen again. **********As part of the phase-out of exclusive contracts, exchanges are also permitted to begin trading up to 10 contracts already traded by another exchange. Earlier this month, Mr. Breeden asked exchange officials to delay listing options of other exchanges until June 30. Mr. Breeden wants to allow the exchanges time to study a system for electronically linking the exchanges so that orders can flow to the exchange with the best price.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/06/busin.main_headline: Technology;   Sensing the Presence Of Potential Problems
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/06/busin.print_headline: Technology;   Sensing the Presence Of Potential Problems
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/06/busin.body_text: **********When people get bruised, cut or fatigued, their nervous systems send signals of pain and soreness that effectively warn them to address the problem before it leads to more serious damage. **********Now, a small but growing group of researchers is envisioning analogous nervous systems - dubbed ''smart skins'' - for human-made structures: airplanes, bridges, long-distance pipelines and even buildings. The goal is to embed such structures with smart-skin technology: networks of fiber-optic sensors that use light pulses to measure the often invisible signs of cracking, bending, stress and overheating. **********A ''smart'' airplane fuselage, for example, would detect microscopic internal cracks and relay signals to a computer that would alert pilots and ground crews. A smart bridge might produce reports on any failing girders, and pipelines would allow gas transmission companies to monitor the ground shifts caused by seasonal changes in remote Arctic regions. **********''You have the opportunity to do vehicle health monitoring that you couldn't do otherwise,'' said Eric Udd, senior staff manager of fiber optics at McDonnell Douglas Electronic Systems Company, part of McDonnell Douglas Corporation. **********Researchers also believe smart skins could improve the research on and manufacture of structural parts made with advanced composite materials. Engineers could bury sensors in experimental materials while they are being constructed, then plug the samples into signal-processing equipment to search for any internal weaknesses. As envisioned now, the sensors would consist of hair-thin optical fibers - like those now used in long-distance communications - that would relay light signals through a particular structure. If the fiber underwent some form of stress or change in temperature, the light signals would change in measurable ways. Using this principle, optical fibers could register minute changes in position, pressure, temperature, strain and vibration. **********Ultimately, proponents of smart skins would string hundreds or even thousands of such sensors in complex grids covering an entire fuselage or wing. The signals from these grids would then be interpreted by computer to produce up-to-the-second portraits of the structure's health. In an even more advanced system envisioned by some aerospace engineers, on-board computers would identify problems, calculate the necessary adjustments for pilots and even carry out some corrections automatically. **********But even the most enthusiastic proponents agree that smart-skin technology is still embryonic. ''We are just scratching the surface,'' said Donald Bartlett, chief engineer for Boeing Company's two-year-old smart-skins program. Sensors are still quite crude and the development of proper signal processing systems has barely gotten under way. Prototype systems for aircraft are easily five to ten years away, and utilities and gas transmission companies are only beginning to express interest. **********Still, the basic ideas have been demonstrated in laboratories and have attracted serious interest. All of the nation's aerospace companies have launched research efforts in the field, as have the Pentagon, the Department of Energy and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Southern California Edison has decided to install a prototype smart system to monitor stress and fatigue on a steam boiler that drives its electric turbine generators. **********''The proof of principle has been established,'' said John Kreidl, a fiber-optic consultant in Cambridge, Mass. ''The issue is how badly do you want it and how much are you willing to pay for it?'' **********In theory, it has long been possible to build nerve-like systems using existing electronic sensors that measure strain and temperature. But electronic systems have been impractical. Because of their sensitivity to electromagnetic interference, they would require shielding and be too heavy for aircraft. Beyond that, copper wires have only a fraction of the data-carrying capacity of optical fibers. The new sensors can solve many of these problems. Optical fibers are excruciatingly sensitive to changes in pressure and temperature and they can relay volumes of data. And because they use light pulses rather than electrical signals, electronic interference poses no problem. **********Prototype devices are making progress. At Virginia Polytechnic Institute in Blacksburg, Va., a leader in the field, researchers recently rigged a wooden model plane with sensors. In table-top tests, they were able to distinguish between signals associated with a damaged propeller, a loosened strut and simulated ice on the wings. The researchers are now building a model that would transmit signals by radio to a ground-based controller. The G2 Systems Corporation, a start-up company in Pacific Palisades, Calif., is now preparing to mount optical sensors on a boiler owned by Southern California Edison. It is also working on proposals to develop pipeline monitoring systems and is working on aircraft sensors for both McDonnell Douglas and the United States Air Force. **********To be sure, developing smart skin's systems requires overcoming a slew of challenges. Boeing's Mr. Bartlett noted that no existing sensor is mature enough to implant in a working system. Much remains to be learned, moreover, about the best method for imbedding sensors in structural materials, as well as for stringing sensors into complex grids. **********Perhaps the biggest challenge, however, is developing the computers and software that can convert blizzards of optical signals into meaningful information. That means developing standards for normal stress and vibration and for signals associated with particular problems. ''It will be the middle or the end of the decade before the technology is mature enough for practical use,'' said Mr. Udd of McDonald Douglas.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/23/busin.main_headline: Expert on Turnarounds Needs Loan to Win Job
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/23/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;   Expert on Turnarounds Needs Loan to Win Job
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/23/busin.body_text: **********Kenneth C. Cleveland has an unusual deal: he will become chairman and chief executive of a failing maker of circuit boards, Metropolitan Circuits Inc., if he can find financing for the company within 30 days. **********Mr. Cleveland, 57, runs Kenneth Cleveland Associates in Malibu, Calif. He is a consultant who specializes in risk management and has turned around companies in the past. **********In the Metropolitan Circuits deal, Mr. Cleveland said last week that he had talked to a number of people on the financing and ''gotten one verbal proposal that we're not real happy with but that would do the job.'' He is looking for a $4 million line of credit, but $2.2 million would be enough for starters, he said. **********Metropolitan Circuits, which is based in Santa Ana, Calif., has not been profitable for four years and has been surviving by selling parts of its business. The problem is one of management, Mr. Cleveland said. ''They need somebody to run the operation real efficiently,'' he added. **********If financing is arranged, Paul G. McNamara, former president of Aeroscientific, a maker of printed circuit boards in Anaheim, Calif., will be brought in as president and chief operating officer. The current Metropolitan president, Richard J. Sandberg, would become vice chairman. **********If Mr. Cleveland gets the financing, he and Mr. McNamara will receive options to buy up to 1.5 million shares of the company's stock at 50 cents a share, and could end up owning 35 percent of the company. **********Mr. Cleveland, a graduate of the University of California at Los Angeles, worked for TRW Inc. for six years at the beginning of his career. ''I didn't want to work for a large company,'' he said, so he joined a small one, but it was in trouble. Its name was Houston Fearless, a maker of photoprocessing equipment, and Mr. Cleveland was chief financial officer. **********''The first day I was there, the bankers came in and said our $3 million loan was in default and asked me what I was going to do about it,'' Mr. Cleveland said. That was his introduction to the workout business. ''I found I had some aptitude for it,'' he said, and he has been in it ever since.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/26/busin.main_headline: House Passes Bank Bill On Money Laundering
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/26/busin.print_headline: House Passes Bank Bill On Money Laundering
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/26/busin.body_text: **********The House voted today to set up a process that would allow the Government to close banks and savings and loans convicted of laundering drug money. **********But it bowed to intense opposition from the Bush Administration, the Federal Reserve Board and the banking industry in refusing to make banks and savings institutions keep records on the most widely used method of laundering money. **********Closing Not Automatic **********Under the bill, regulators would be authorized to revoke a bank or savings institution's charter and lift its Federal deposit insurance if the institution or its officials were convicted of money laundering. But the closing would not be automatic. **********In weighing the bank's future, regulators would have to consider the extent to which it had cooperated with investigators and whether it had adopted measures to avoid laundering in the future. **********The House, on a 406-to-0 vote, approved a bill its sponsors said would impose ''the death penalty'' of being put out of business on banks laundering drug money. It rejected, by 283 to 127, a measure to require the Treasury Department to test a project requiring banks to keep records of international wire transfers. **********'A Huge and Gaping Loophole' **********''We're leaving a huge and gaping loophole in this bill,'' said Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn. ''We're telling the drug lords to transfer this way because if you do it by wire, you won't be affected.'' **********Opponents of the measure - which would have required targeted banks to keep records of the names, addresses and account numbers of parties on both sides of a wire transfer -had said it would impose a new paperwork burden costing up to $350 million a year. **********''There's nothing more emotional than the issue of trying to punish those involved in drugs,'' said Representative Doug Barnard Jr., Democrat of Georgia. But, he added, ''This, while very well meaning, is overkill.'' $110 Billion Laundered Annually The legislation is aimed at addressing the $110 billion in United States cash drug transactions that the Treasury Department estimates continues to be laundered through the world financial system every year despite laws in 1979, 1986 and 1988 aimed at stopping it. **********''We put the street dealer in jail and we put the drug kingpin in the penitentiary, but no one has found a way to imprison a bank,'' said the bill's chief author, Representative Frank Annunzio, Democrat of Illinois. **********A similar measure has been introduced in the Senate and has received widespread support. It could be adopted as early as this summer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/08/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;   Benetton Changes Its Ads
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/08/busin.body_text: **********The Benetton Group has traded in its handcuffs for handholding in its new advertising campaign for the ''United Colors of Benetton.'' **********The company's previous campaign, which was intended to promote harmony between people of different races and cultures, was criticized by consumers who considered it to be racist. One ad showed a black man and a white man handcuffed together and appeared in both American and European magazines. The other pictured a black woman nursing a white infant. It appeared only in European magazines. **********The new worldwide campaign for the Italian retailer's colorful line of casual clothes still addresses race relations, but in a more subtle way, said Carlo Tunioli, Benetton's general manager in the United States. ''We like to follow up a strong, controversial campaign with a softer approach,'' he said. **********One ad in the campaign that begins in April shows the hand of a black child resting in the palm of a white man's hand. Another pictures the hand of a white relay runner passing a baton to a black teammate. $8 Million Budget Benetton spends about $8 million a year for advertising that appears in American magazines and on billboards across the country. **********Benetton, which handles its own advertising, decided to use race relations as a theme in its more recent advertising because it is an important issue, Mr. Tunioli said. The company likes to address difficult issues in its advertising because it is a good way to grab the consumer's attention, he said. **********The long-running ''United Colors of Benetton'' campaign, which was created by the photographer Oliviero Toscani, is also considered unusual for the retail category because many of the advertisements, including the new campaign, do not show off the company's line of clothing. **********''We try to avoid the obvious,'' Mr. Tunioli said. ''We think we can stand out better by talking about how people live, and not the clothes.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/20/world.main_headline: Ethiopia Backs Use of Port Held by Foes for U.N. Relief
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/20/world.print_headline: Ethiopia Backs Use of Port Held by Foes for U.N. Relief
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/20/world.body_text: **********The Ethiopian Government agreed on Tuesday that a rebel-held port on the Red Sea could be used for United Nations relief supplies. Western diplomats said the conciliatory move bode well for a peace process to solve the 30-year civil war in Ethiopia. **********The main reason for allowing the port of Massawa to be operated by the United Nations was for the distribution of food to drought- and war-afflicted northern Ethiopia. **********The chief Ethiopian negotiator at fledgling peace efforts, Ashagre Yigletu, announced the agreement to open the port, which the Government lost to separatist rebels of the Eritrean People's Liberation Front in February.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/01/world.main_headline: Mandela Refuses to Make Concessions to Pretoria
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/01/world.print_headline: Mandela Refuses to Make Concessions to Pretoria
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/01/world.body_text: **********Nelson Mandela said today that the African National Congress would make no concessions to the South African Government until South Africa met the organization's conditions for opening talks, including putting the congress on an equal footing with the Government. **********''The A.N.C. is not in the same position as the National Party in regard to negotiation,'' Mr. Mandela said. ''We can't be expected to make any concessions to the Government, no matter what difficulties it has.'' **********Speaking at a news conference, Mr. Mandela said that the congress was ''prepared to meet the Government if they are prepared to meet us,'' but that Pretoria had yet to meet the congress's conditions for talks on a shared future for blacks and whites in South Africa. **********Officials in Pretoria have been hoping that Mr. Mandela would deliver some conciliatory words to ease the pressure that the National Party is feeling from hard-line white politicians. **********Mr. Mandela mentioned three areas in which he said the Government of President F. W. de Klerk had shown that it was not ready to sit at a negotiating table with the A.N.C. as its political equal. He said those areas were the Government's continuing refusal to lift the 3 1/2-year state of emergency, to free all political prisoners and to end uncertainty over the legal status of exiles who could face prison if they return to South Africa either independently or as members of a negotiating team. **********''It is quite clear that the Government is not yet prepared to meet us and you can't expect us, therefore, to make any concessions to the Government,'' he said. Mr. Mandela made the comment after President Kenneth Kaunda of Zambia said the congress should suspend its military operations in South Africa as a gesture of support for President de Klerk's efforts at change. **********President Kaunda, whose country is the headquarters of the congress, echoed the concerns of some governments and opponents of apartheid by suggesting that ''some little'' move by the congress might help ease the pressure on Mr. de Klerk from the political right. The Zambian leader described Mr. de Klerk's antagonists as ''lunatics on the right-wing fringe.'' **********There has been pressure on the congress to suspend or abandon its armed struggle, which has essentially been inactive. Some Western leaders say the military actions could be misinterpreted by some who would otherwise give the congress their full support. **********Mr. Mandela, who is meeting with African leaders, diplomats and commonwealth officials, will begin talks on Thursday with the congress's National Executive Committee. The committee announced earlier this month that it would send a delegation to South Africa to meet with Mr. de Klerk. **********Mr. Mandela reiterated his support for the Palestine Liberation Organization, which he made plain on his arrival in Lusaka on Tuesday. In response to a question about whether such remarks might alienate South African Jews, Mr. Mandela said ''if the truth hurts'' South Africa's Jews, ''it is too bad.'' **********There are about 100,000 Jews in South Africa, and many are prominent among the nation's business elite and in the anti-apartheid Liberal Party. **********''We expect everybody who is exploring the possibility of lasting solutions to be able to face the truth squarely,'' Mr. Mandela said. ''I sincerely believe that there are many similarities between our struggle and that of the P.L.O. We live under a unique form of colonialism in South Africa, as well as in Israel, and a lot flows from that.'' **********Mr. Mandela met with Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O. chief, on Tuesday. **********Plea Against Sanctions **********WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -Chief Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi, a South African Zulu leader, met President Bush today and urged him to lift sanctions against South Africa. ''The vast majority of black South Africans reject sanctions and the isolation of South Africa,'' Chief Buthelezi said. **********Chief Buthelezi is chief minister of the tribal homeland of KwaZulu and president of the 1.5-million member Inkatha movement, which has opposed the African National Congress's guerilla war against the Government.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/07/busin.main_headline: Dow Plunges by 93.31; Stocks Slide in Tokyo
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/07/busin.print_headline: Dow Plunges by 93.31; Stocks Slide in Tokyo
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/07/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices plunged again yesterday as continuing tensions in the Middle East pushed up oil prices, leading to investor fears that inflation will heat up. **********The Dow Jones industrial average fell 93.31 points, or 3.3 percent, to 2,716.34, its biggest one-day decline since Oct. 13, 1989, when it fell 6.9 percent, or 190.58 points, to 2,569.26. Volume was 240 million shares, with declines exceeding advances by a ratio of roughly 6 to 1. **********In Tokyo, the 225-share Nikkei average fell 916.23 points or 3.1 percent, to 28,599.53, yesterday. The average dropped quickly in the morning session again today but rebounded somewhat in the afternoon and closed down another 946.17 points or 3.31 percent, at 27,984.29. **********Yesterday's decline in New York followed a 55-point tumble in the Dow on Friday and an 88-point overall loss for last week. **********The anxiety over inflation also caused a plunge in long-term Treasury prices. The yield of the benchmark 8.75 percent bond maturing in 2020 climbed to 8.79 percent, the highest in almost three months and nearly a quarter percentage point above Friday's close. As stock prices tumbled however, investors shifted funds to Treasury bills and other short-term investments, causing bill rates to fall to their lowest levels since 1988. [Page D14.]  Oil stocks continued to move higher on the prospects of rising prices, while declining issues included transportation stocks, which are sensitive to oil prices, and utilities and banking issues, which are sensitive to higher interest rates. **********Officials of the New York Stock Exchange held a briefing to calm concerns about how the exchange and its member firms withstood yesterday's sell-off. **********Richard Torrenzano, an executive vice president of the Big Board, told reporters that all the computer systems for executing trades were operating without difficulty. He said that market ''circuit breakers,'' which delay or halt some trading in times of big declines, appeared to have steadied the market. **********Confusion on Index Trading **********Some traders asserted, however, that new rules made trading in stock index futures even more volatile than they otherwise would have been and left many traders confused because they were uncertain how markets would act after the rule went into effect. [Market Place, page D8.]  At the opening of trading in New York, the stock market reacted swiftly to the sharply lower Asian and European markets. The beginning of trading in many stocks, including several of the 30 issues of the Dow Jones average, was delayed. **********In the first few hours, the Dow average dropped more than 107 points, as rumors spread that Saudi Arabian troops were headed for the Kuwaiti border. The rumor was later denied by the Saudi Press Agency. **********By noon, the market had recovered some earlier losses, but was still down more than 80 points on about 190 million shares traded. As volume slowed in the afternoon, the Dow lost only about 13 more points for the day. **********Traders at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company noted that institutional investors, who normally trade in large blocks of stocks that require special handling, were active in the market but that there was no panic. **********''There is scattered selling and the institutions are picking their spots to buy or sell,'' one trader said late in the day. ''The blocks are ordinary and there were none of any real size.'' **********Similarly, some brokerage firms reported that retail selling was busy, but not extraordinarily so. Declines were broad, with what are normally lower-volume stocks suffering as well as widely traded issues. On the American Stock Exchange, which includes many oil companies that rose in price because they are expected to benefit from higher oil prices, the index was off by only 1.83 percent, or 6.36 points, to 340.27. But the Nasdaq composite index fell 4.17 percent, or 17.42 points, to 400.04, its lowest level in more than a year. On March 20, 1989, it closed at 398.50. **********The Standard & Poor's 500 index closed at 334.43, down 10.43 points, its lowest level since May 1, when it was 332.25. **********The new ''circuit breaker'' rule on the Big Board, which was used for the first time on Friday, came into play again yesterday. When the Dow falls more than 50 points, the rule restricts traders who use computer programs to initiate sell orders. Such program traders are not permitted to sell stock on a downtick, which is when a stock's last sale is lower than the one before. **********The rule is part of a package of measures the stock exchange approved earlier in the year to try to curb market volatility. **********As a result of the those rules, there were far fewer program trades than normal yesterday. Program traders were in the market only twice, to buy and not to sell, said Birinyi Associates, which tracks such activity. **********The effect of both trades added 21.04 points to the Dow. The first program, from 10:25 A.M. to 10:30 A.M., added 18.07 points, and another from 1.59 P.M. to 2:03 P.M. added 2.97. **********Top 10 Gainers **********Among the top 10 gainers on the Big Board yesterday were ARCO, up 3 1/2 to 137 1/8; Great Northern Iron, up 3, to 56 1/4; Oryx Energy, up 2 5/8, to 54 5/8, and Phillips Petroleum, up 1, to 82. **********Some of the top losers included UAL, down 12 1/2, to 110. An employee-led buyout of the airline company is still reported to have financing problems, but there is speculation that the company's board may agree to extend by a day or two the Aug. 9 deadline for a financing package. **********Walt Disney was down 7 1/8, to 102 3/8, following a recommendation by a First Boston analyst to hold instead of buy the stock because of lower projected 1991 per-share earnings. **********If the economy slips into recession, entertainment stocks are considered among the first to be affected. Time Warner, another entertainment concern, hit a new low during the day of 83 5/8, closing down 6 3/8, to 83 3/4. **********Phelps Dodge, the big mining company, closed down 5 1/8, to 62 5/8, and Warner-Lambert, the pharmaceuticals and consumer products company, closed down 5, at 62 1/2. **********Tokyo Stocks Drop **********By Reuters **********TOKYO, Tuesday, Aug. 7 (Reuters) - Tokyo stocks regained in the afternoon some of the morning's sharp declines. Brokers said a flood of futures arbitrage-related index buying brought the Nikkei average of 225 stocks back up to 27,653.07, which was 946.46 points or 3.31 percent below Monday's close. **********The average fell quickly after the opening, dropping 1,327.67 points at the midday recess over over fears that rising oil prices will cause serious problems for the oil-dependent Japanese economy. **********Volume was a thin 150 million shares by midday, against 170 million on Monday morning. Volatility from light trading had already been exaggerating market declines in the two weeks before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Thursday drove up oil prices sharply.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/30/busin.main_headline: Saks Being Sought By Eight Suitors
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/30/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Saks Being Sought By Eight Suitors
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/30/busin.body_text: **********Eight potential buyers have been invited into the second round of bidding for Saks Fifth Avenue, the fashion chain put up for sale by B.A.T. Industries P.L.C., according to executives close to Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., which is handling the sale. The bidders include several foreign companies. About a dozen potential bidders indicated their interest in the 47-store chain. But the number invited to remain for further reviews of Saks's operation is considered large and promising in terms of strong bids. Saks is estimated to bring around $1 billion. **********Three companies or groups have disclosed that they are bidding -Saks's management, led by Melvin Jacobs, the store's chairman, with Tobu Department Stores of Tokyo; Joseph E. Brooks, chairman of Ann Taylor stores, with Merrill Lynch Capital Partners, and the General Cinema Corporation, which has a majority ownership in the Neiman Marcus Group.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/10/busin.main_headline: Dow Rises 4.95 in 2d-Slowest Day of Year
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/10/busin.print_headline: Dow Rises 4.95 in 2d-Slowest Day of Year
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/10/busin.body_text: **********Stocks rose slightly yesterday, and trading slowed to its second-lowest level of the year. **********The Dow Jones industrial average advanced 4.95 points, to 2,722.07, and volume fell to 114.97 million shares,from 137.49 million last Friday. On March 12, volume was 114.79 million shares, the lowest point of 1990. Declining stocks outnumbered advances,839 to 652. **********''Most portfolio managers no longer appear to expect a market decline because the market is very quiet,'' said David B. Bostian Jr., the chief investment strategist for Jesup & Lamont. ''But I think of it as the eye of the storm.'' **********'Could Be Vulnerable' **********''With the onset of earnings reports soon,'' he said, ''the market could be vulnerable.'' He said he looked for earnings to be weaker than generally expected. **********Economic problems in New England, banking problems in general and big merger deals continued to dominate the market. Banks, drugs, food, beverages and telephone stocks gained; gold weakened and computers were mixed. **********Ames Department Stores, which has had difficulty turning around its Zayre stores, headed the New York Stock Exchange's most-active list, falling 1/4, to 3 1/4, on 4.14 million shares. Institutions accounted for most of the selling. Ames said last week that sales in March fell 12 percent. **********Telecom rose 16 1/4, to 41 7/8, the second-most-active Big Board stock, on 3.56 million shares. It announced with MCI that the telecommunications companies had agreed to merge in a deal in which MCI paid $42 a share for Telecom. MCI headed the over-the-counter active list, falling 1 1/8, to 35 3/4, on 3.4 million shares. **********Among other telecommunications stocks, United Telecom rose 1 3/8, to 39 3/4, and Rochester Telephone rose 1 1/8, to 36 7/8. **********Banks Show Strength **********Among the bank stocks, Citicorp rose 3/4, to 23 5/8; BankAmerica rose 7/8, to 26 3/8, and Norwest of Minneapolis fell 1/4, to 18 3/8, all in heavy trading. the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, rose 1 3/8, to 33 3/8, and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, or Freddie Mac, rose 1 3/8, to 66 5/8. **********After weakness last week, Charles W. Peabody, a banking analyst for Kidder, Peabody & Company, recommended BankAmerica, Chase Manhattan, Manufacturers Hanover, Mellon, Norwest, J. P. Morgan, Suntrust and First City of Texas. **********Chase rose 1/2, to 28 1/2; Manufacturers rose 5/8, to 31 5/8; Mellon rose 7/8, to 25; Morgan rose 1 1/8, to 35 3/4; Suntrust rose 3/8, to 21 1/2, and First City rose 1/2, to 32 1/2, all in brisk trading. **********Near the start of trading, the market seemed to respond for a time to the stronger tone of Japanese stocks. But by 11 A.M., after advancing by about 12 points, the Dow industrials drifted for the rest of the session. **********Except for Procter & Gamble and Coca-Cola, none of the stocks among the Dow Jones industrials rose by as much as a point. P.& G. rose 1 1/8, to 69 3/4, on 391,000 shares. Coca-Cola rose 1 3/8, to 79 1/4, on 475,000 shares. I.B.M., one of the more closely watched industrials, fell 3/8, to 105 1/2. **********Pepsico, which is not a part of the Dow industrials, rose 1 1/2, to 66 1/2, on 775,000 shares, after it announced a barter deal to swap more than $3 billion of the soft drink for Soviet ships and vodka. **********The Dow Jones transportation index fell 3.03 points, to 1,171.05, with UAL continuing to account for most of the change in either direction. UAL, the parent of United Airlines, fell 2 1/2, to 161, in strong trading as uncertainties persisted over its unions' plans to buy the carrier. **********Food Shares Gain **********Food shares were strong, with Kellogg up 1 1/2, to 63 5/8; CPC International up 1 1/8, to 70 7/8; Hershey up 1, to 33 5/8, and Quaker Oats up 1 1/4, to 50 3/4. **********Among individual stocks, the Tribune Company rose 1 7/8, to 43 1/2, after it announced a 10-year cooperative production deal for six Tribune television stations, including WPIX in New York, KTLA in Los Angeles and WGN in Chicago, to join the CNN. **********In another sign of nervousness over earnings, Network Equipment, a maker of communications products, fell 5 3/4, to 15 1/8, in heavy trading. After saying last week that it expected a disappointing fourth quarter, it said yesterday that it expected revenues for the fourth quarter ended March 31 to total about $44 million. **********Other market indicators were mixed. The Standard & Poor's 500 stock index rose 1.29, to 341.37; the Amex market-value index fell 1.33, to 359.68, and the Nasdaq composite index fell 0.72, to 430.18.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/02/world.main_headline: Evolution in Europe;   Walesa Wins a Test Against Premier
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/02/world.print_headline: Evolution in Europe;   Walesa Wins a Test Against Premier
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/02/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki of Poland decisively lost a test of strength with Lech Walesa this weekend, exposing his Government's precarious foundation of support and raising questions about whether his Cabinet could survive without changes. **********On the day his Government was imposing significant increases in the prices of energy, postal services and hot water, Mr. Mazowiecki failed in his attempt to take control of the local political organizations that helped Solidarity candidates win the last two elections. **********After a weekend of intense politicking, nearly all of the delegates from the local committees rejected Mr. Mazowiecki's suggestion that they form a federation supporting his Government. Instead, most chose to remain under the loose guidance of a committee led by Mr. Walesa, apparently making a choice in the dispute between the Solidarity founder and the man he chose to be Prime Minister. **********Walesa's Primacy Reaffirmed **********The weekend's events reaffirmed Mr. Walesa's primacy on the Polish political scene and added significance to the economic program the Solidarity chairman has said he plans to announce soon. Government officials have warned that the political turmoil could threaten the fragile consensus for their ambitious program of ''shock therapy'' for the Polish economy, and Mr. Walesa has hinted he has an alternate approach in mind. **********''The Mazowiecki position is threatened, and Walesa knows it,'' said Zbigniew Bujak, a supporter of the Prime Minister. ''If it is further threatened, it could cause an immediate breakup of the Cabinet.'' **********Representatives from the local political groups, called Civic Committees, met for two days. On Saturday, they held a nonbinding ballot on the Government's proposal for a federation, and only 10 of 110 endorsed the Government's position. **********Today, Mr. Mazowiecki made a surprise appearance at the meeting of the representatives and called for a meeting between himself and Mr. Walesa to agree on the boundaries of acceptable political debate. **********The Prime Minister, appearing even more wan than usual, acknowledged that a split in what was once the Solidarity movement ''is unavoidable, but it should be done in such a way that it does not destroy the common good of Poland and common heritage of Solidarity.'' **********Mazowiecki's Complaint **********Mr. Mazowiecki complained that although he had kept in touch with Mr. Walesa, the Solidarity leader had not returned the favor. The Prime Minister said he was startled when Mr. Walesa declared two months ago that Polish politics were stagnant and needed to be reinvigorated by a ''political war'' among its leaders. **********''It cannot be the telephone only works one way,'' Mr. Mazowiecki said. ''I don't know why his telephone could not work before this war was started at the top.'' **********The divisions between the two men have become increasingly public in the past few months, as Mr. Walesa's criticisms of Mr. Mazowiecki and his Government have become more and more pointed and as Mr. Mazowiecki has developed his own political base while Mr. Walesa has suggested that he will run for President. **********''We have not at any point set our sights on deposing Mazowiecki,'' said Slawomir Siwek, a founding member of the Center Alliance, which supports Mr. Walesa's drive for the presidency. ''We've just said he should reorganize the Government.'' **********On Saturday, Mr. Walesa showed his skills as a master tactician when, addressing the local representatives, he framed the question of the federation in terms devastating to the Government. He asked the party workers, in essence, to make a choice: Stay with the Walesa side, keeping local automony to chose candidates from any party, or join the federation, and thus being obliged to follow Mr. Mazowiecki's line. **********The meetings showed how Mr. Walesa and his supporters have appropriated some of the most potentially appealing messages and slogans. They call themselves ''the center'' and, without providing details, urge ''acceleration'' in economic and political changes. They demand the ouster of old-line Communists from both Government and factory management.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/18/world.main_headline: Gorbachev Sees Saudi About Restoring Ties
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/18/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;   Gorbachev Sees Saudi About Restoring Ties
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/18/world.body_text: **********President Mikhail S. Gorbachev met today with the Saudi Foreign Minister, Prince Saud al-Faisal, to discuss the restoration of diplomatic relations. **********The two officials discussed the Persian Gulf crisis in a meeting at the Kremlin. Tass, the Soviet press agency, said they showed a determination to resolve the standoff through use of the United Nations. **********Before the meeting, the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, told reporters that he hoped that an agreement to resume relations and exchange ambassadors would be reached at the meeting. But an initial announcement by Tass that the accord had been completed was later retracted with no further explanation. **********Saudi officials elsewhere expressed confidence that the Arab kingdom would soon announce the restoration of ties and an exchange of ambassadors. **********Moscow and Riyadh broke off relations 52 years ago. Among the factors prompting them to seek a reconciliation were the Soviet decisions to withdraw from Afghanistan and to denounce Iraq for the invasion of Kuwait. **********Beyond the gulf crisis, Mr. Gorbachev and Prince Saud discussed the relationship between their countries, but no details of the discussions were released.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/05/busin.main_headline: Genentech-Roche Deal May Spur Similar Ties
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/05/busin.print_headline: Genentech-Roche Deal May Spur Similar Ties
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/05/busin.body_text: **********The agreement announced Friday in which a large Swiss drug company will buy a majority stake in the biotechnology pioneer Genentech Inc. could be the start of a wave of similar transactions, some industry analysts said this weekend. **********The announcement of the deal, in which Roche Holding Ltd. will pay $2.1 billion for 60 percent of Genentech's stock, pushed up the stock prices of several other leading biotechnology companies, including Amgen Inc. and the Chiron Corporation. **********''I think the realities of this transaction will cause a lot of other large corporations, both foreign and domestic, to say, 'If Roche can do it with Genentech, I can do it with anyone else,' '' said G. Steven Burrill, national director of high technology industry services for Ernst & Young. **********Deal Could Be Model for Others **********Some analysts and industry executives said the arrangement, in which Genentech will keep its present management and operate autonomously, might provide a model for other such deals. **********Other analysts, however, argue that a buying binge of biotechnology companies is not in the works. One thing that protects many biotechnology companies is that they have established alliances with other companies, like licensing larger companies to sell their products. **********Buying a company whose products are already promised to others would not be attractive to a large drug company, analysts said. Genentech, which was intent on selling its own products, had fewer such relationships. **********A similar wave of buyouts was predicted in 1986, when Eli Lilly & Company bought Hybritech and the Bristol-Myers Company purchased the Genetic Systems Corporation. But no trend developed. **********But since 1986, several factors have changed. The market valuations of biotechnology companies have been low since the 1987 market crash, making them less expensive. The promise of biotechnology has turned to reality. And the drug industry is going through its own consolidation, making it hard for even well-established companies to remain independent. **********Interest From Abroad **********Foreign companies are also becoming interested in biotechnology, as shown by Roche's deal with Genentech and Chugai Pharmaceutical's purchase late last year of Gen-Probe Inc. of San Diego. Analysts also expect more biotechnology companies to be bought by other biotechnology companies, like Ingene was by Xoma Corporation. **********In the Genentech agreement, Roche Holding, the parent of Hoffmann-La Roche, said it would pay $36 a share in cash for half the outstanding shares of Genentech. It would also pump an additional $492 million into the company for new shares, bringing its total ownership to 60 percent. **********The remaining 40 percent of the shares will be exchanged for special redeemable shares that will continue to trade publicly. Roche will have the option of buying the remaining shares for a price that starts at $38 a share this year and escalates to $60 by 1995. Genentech's management will continue to run the company. **********The arrangement generally drew praise from industry executives and analysts. ''It is good for both of them,'' said Viren Mehta of Mehta & Isaly, a pharmaceutical industry consulting firm. **********But others said the purchase represents the end of the dream of Robert A. Swanson, Genentech's co-founder, to build a large independent pharmaceutical company. ''If you listened to what Swanson said over the last few years, being part of a big drug company wasn't part of the common narrative,'' said Mr. Burrill of Ernst & Young. **********Independence at Risk **********Mr. Swanson said the capital infusion from Roche would allow Genentech to realize its potential while retaining its independence. But analysts say Mr. Swanson has essentially put the company's independence at risk, since Roche can buy the rest of Genentech any time it wants. **********To some, the fact that Genentech would risk its independence was discouraging for two reasons. One, if Genentech could not go it alone, what hope is there for the many other, less prosperous biotechnology companies. **********Further, they said, the agreement was another reflection of how difficult it is for biotechnology companies to raise money at favorable rates in the American financial markets. ''There is a sad message here, one that the United States should listen to,'' said Robert Fildes, chief executive of Cetus Corporation, another biotechnology company. **********The purchase price of $36 a share is far higher than the $21 or so Genentech's shares were selling at before the deal was announced. That could please Genentech shareholders, who will be asked to approve the purchase in April. **********Still, Stuart Weisbrod, biotechnology analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities, said the deal also puts an effective price ceiling on the remaining shares. No one will pay more for the Genentech shares this year than $38, knowing that at any time Roche could buy those shares for that price, he said. ''I think shareholders have been left in the cold,'' he said. **********Mr. Weisbrod said that reaction among Genentech's scientists, who are considered the core of the company, was also mixed, based on the conversations he had with a dozen of them. **********Some scientists like the deal because it will provide more money for research and will shield Genentech from the Wall Street pressures that had been forcing the company to curtail some of the researchers' freedom. But others were worried. ''Some people think the company has sold out,'' Mr. Weisbrod said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/22/busin.main_headline: 'Jack of All Trades' Named To Chairman's Job at Boots
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/22/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;   'Jack of All Trades' Named To Chairman's Job at Boots
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/22/busin.body_text: **********The Boots Company, the British retail and pharmaceuticals group, has appointed Sir Christopher Benson chairman. He will succeed Robert Gunn, who had the post for the last five years and will retire in July at age 65. **********Sir Christopher, 56, became managing director of MEPC P.L.C., Britain's second largest property investment and development company in 1976, rising to chairman in 1988. He became a director of Boots in April 1989 and was chairman of the London Docklands Development Corporation between 1984 and 1988. Of his years at the latter, he said: ''My time here has taught me to be a jack of all trades. I have a lot of common sense to offer.'' His appointment at Boots was announced Thursday. **********Sir Christoper also spent three years as a director of House of Fraser P.L.C and is on the boards of Reedpack Ltd., one of Europe's largest and most successful office supplies, paper and packaging groups, and the Royal Opera House. **********Earlier this month, Boots began a $255 million Eurosterling convertible bond issue to refinance some short-term borrowings that it incurred when it paid $148 million for Ward White Group P.L.C., the auto parts retailer. Boots is expected to sell Whitlock, Ward White's American auto parts retailer, before the end of the financial year in March, further reducing the debt. **********Sir Christopher, who was awarded a knighthood for public service in 1988, spent his early life in the Merchant Navy and is a amateur pilot. **********At Thursday's meeting Mr. Gunn said, ''I am confident that under Sir Christopher's leadership, Boots will continue to prosper.'' **********Sir Christopher is married and has two sons and lives in Salisbury, Wiltshire, in southwestern England, where he farms 300 acres.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/28/world.main_headline: Evolution in Europe;   U.S. Said to Mute Opposition To European Aid to Soviets
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/28/world.print_headline: Evolution in Europe;   U.S. Said to Mute Opposition To European Aid to Soviets
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/28/world.body_text: **********Under pressure from some NATO allies, the Bush Administration appears to be softening its opposition to Western European financial support for the Soviet Union and is considering expanding its own technical aid to Moscow. **********President Bush and the State Department remain reluctant to give American cash aid directly to the Soviet Union in the absence of major economic changes in which the centrally planned economy would be put firmly on a free-market path. **********But the Administration has begun looking for more ways to provide technical economic assistance, particularly in the form of experts to help transform Soviet economic institutions. **********For instance, the Administration is considering a proposal to send experts to help the Soviets develop and operate a private housing industry. Other proposals include technical help on private banking, a stock market, management training, accounting programs, various forms of entrepreneurial advice, and support for Soviet membership in the International Monetary Fund. **********The Administratioon is also adopting a more tolerant attitude toward West Germany and other European countries that are prepared to grant or loan Moscow some of the $15 billion to $20 billion it is seeking. **********Behind the Change in Attitude **********Behind the Administration's shift, officials said, are pressures from West Germany to give Moscow economic aid in return for its accepting the idea of a united Germany joining NATO and pressures from other European allies for the West to back its professions of good will for Mr. Gorbachev's liberalization program with cash. **********Mounting concern in Washington that a collapse of the Soviet economy could weaken the fledgling democracies of Eastern Europe has also contributed to the Administration's change in attitude, the officials said. **********Last March, when the House majority leader, Representative Richard A. Gephardt, Democrat of Missouri, suggested that the United States consider economic aid to the Soviet Union, President Bush dismissed both the proposal and Mr. Gephardt by saying, ''Maybe he'll come on a good idea one of these days.'' Three months later, though, the Bush Administration is no longer dismissing such proposals out of hand. **********'The West Can Help' **********The State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, said today, ''We believe the success of perestroika depends fundamentally on Soviet choices, but the West can help the Soviets through this difficult period.'' **********The West, she said, shares ''a common interest in the success of political and economic reform in the Soviet Union.'' **********''We expect there will be a discussion on this subject'' with the European Community and at the July 9 economic summit meeting in Houston, she added. **********With that in mind, discussions have begun within the Administration on whether the Western allies can reach understandings that allow West Germany and France to give financial aid or credits to Moscow while the United States and others limit their help to technical assistance. **********Administration officials want to avoid a split within the Western alliance on this issue and take the attitude that if the Germans are prepared to give cash aid in return for Soviet backing for their membership in NATO, then why not? as one official put it. **********A senior Administration official remarked, ''The United States cannot be in a position of being isolated on this issue'' or it could lose its leadership position in the alliance. **********Differences in Attitude **********There already appear to be subtle differences among senior Administration officials on the issue. **********Secretary of State James A. Baker and the President have cited the political and economic difficulties of granting aid to Moscow, but have clearly gone out of their way not to rule anything out. On the other hand, Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney has emphasized that as long as Moscow is spending ''enormous amounts of its national wealth on military hardware'' it would be a mistake for the West to give economic assistance. **********The Germans and French disagree. Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany asked his 11 colleagues in the European Economic Community Tuesday to consider a $15 billion Western aid package to help Mr. Gorbachev get through his current political and economic crisis. He was backed by President Francois Mitterrand of France, but strongly opposed by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain. **********The European leaders decided to study Soviet needs and make proposals for short-term credits and longer-term support for economic restructuring. **********In the United States, however, there is less political support for aid at a time when the Administration is under pressure to hold down spending. Also, until the Soviets enact legislation freeing emigration, various American laws prevent the government from providing trade benefits, government guaranteed credits or Export-Import Bank loans to Moscow.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/24/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS;   Treasuries Decline in Hectic Day
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/24/busin.body_text: **********Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved lower yesterday, gyrating wildly most of the day, as credit market participants reacted to the huge swings in the stock market. **********Before the stock market opened in New York, bond traders had pushed prices of some securities down by as much as 3/4 point, a slide that may have been a reaction to a slide on Japanese financial markets earlier. **********But once stock prices started their deep initial slide after trading opened on the New York Stock Exchange, Treasury issues recovered rapidly. Later on, when stocks had recovered from their lows, traders began to sell securities again. **********''This was not your typical sleepy Monday,'' said Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J., firm that provides research and commentary on developments in the fixed-income and foreign-exchange markets. ''For the first time in quite a while, we had a classic flight-to-quality response in the bond market to what was going on in the stock market.'' **********Effect on Treasuries **********The effect of the stock market slide was most readily reflected in the bidding for new three-month and six-month Treasury bills auctioned yesterday. **********At the auction, three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 7.49 percent, down sharply from the average rate of 7.62 percent at last week's sale. Six-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 7.40 percent, compared with an average rate of 7.52 percent a week ago. **********However, traders said the price decline that resumed once conditions seemed to stabilize in the stock market was indicative of the bond market's mood. **********''Things look pretty negative for the credit markets,'' one bond trader said, ''the long end of the market, which for the past month or so has responded positively to comments by President Bush, Fed chairman Greenspan and now this slide in the stock market, wants to go down.'' **********Changes on Greenspan **********To a significant part of the trading community, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, damaged his credibility as an inflation fighter last week when he indicated to Congress that the central bank had redirected its policy efforts to help shore up the banking system and the economy. **********Mr. Greenspan returns to Capitol Hill today to provide members of the House of Representatives with his semiannual review of monetary policy and the economy. **********''His image has suffered a little bit over the last week, and he may want to use the testimony as a way to reassert the Fed's longer-term commitment to fighting inflation,'' Mr. McCarthy said. **********In late trading, the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 102 1/8, down 7/32, to yield 8.55 percent, compared with 8.53 percent late Friday. **********Among note issues, the price of the 8 7/8 percent 10-year notes dipped by 1/8 point, to a late offered price of 102 17/ 32, to yield 8.48 percent. And the 8 1/2 percent five-year notes were offered at 100 25/32, down 3/32, to yield 8.29 percent. **********Impact on Other Markets **********The steep slide in stock prices had a limited impact in other debt markets. **********Traders in the market for high-yield ''junk bonds'' said that prices of most issues dipped by about 1/2 point, but that trading was quite light. **********''Most market participants were sitting back, trying to find out why stock prices fell, and weren't finding any real reasons,'' said Kingman Penniman, a specialist in the high-yield market at McCarthy, Crisanti & Maffei, a research and credit-rating agency. **********Traders in the seconday market for tax-exempt municipal bonds said that prices of most actively quoted issues closed higher by 1/8 to 1/4 point after moving lower early in the day. Activity was light, the dealers said. **********Following are the results of yesterday's auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills:

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/13/world.print_headline: SOUTH AFRICA'S NEW ERA;   The Lincoln Touch
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/13/world.body_text: **********The Rev. Jesse Jackson compared President F. W. de Klerk of South Africa to Abraham Lincoln today on the 181st anniversary of the American President's birth. **********The American civil rights leader praised Mr. de Klerk for freeing Nelson Mandela from prison and legalizing the African National Congress. **********''This was a courageous step for President de Klerk,'' Mr. Jackson told journalists at the Cape Town Press Club. **********He compared Mr. de Klerk to Lincoln, who moved to free American slaves in 1863 with the Emancipation Proclamation. **********''Both men rose above history and tradition at the risk of losing themselves,'' Mr. Jackson said in remarks coinciding with Lincoln's birthday - Feb. 12, 1809. **********Mr. Jackson met Mr. Mandela briefly on Sunday evening, but most local newspapers ignored the encounter and he was given little time with the African National Congress leader. **********Mr. Jackson met Mr. de Klerk today and the encounter was equally brief. ''It was just a courtesy call,'' a presidential spokesman said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/23/busin.main_headline: Market Place;   House Bill Fuels Cable TV Stocks
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/23/busin.print_headline: Market Place;   House Bill Fuels Cable TV Stocks
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/23/busin.body_text: **********AFTER a year of seeing its stocks hammered by the market, the cable television industry is at last getting some good news. Since Friday, when a draft of a bill that would only mildly regulate the industry was made available, cable stocks have suddenly taken off, rising roughly 10 percent in the last three trading days. **********''The stocks had bottomed out,'' said James Mooney, president of the National Cable Television Association, during the industry's annual meeting yesterday in Atlanta. ''Institutional investors have been waiting for some signal to go back into the stocks, and now they have it.'' **********What has investors somewhat reassured is a draft of a new bill from the House Energy and Commerce Committee that proposes only limited regulatory measures. It would let the Federal Communications Commission regulate the broadcast channels that are carried by the cable companies but would leave cable operators free to determine what they charge for cable services. **********The comparable Senate committee draft, reported out some weeks ago, was significantly more stringent and would have given the Government the right to regulate all cable services. **********''The ball is rolling in favor of cable because the industry has the momentum of a compromise going,'' said Sharon Armbrust, a media analyst at Paul Kagan & Associates. ''And cable's opponents - that is the telephone companies, the broadcasters, regulators and movie companies - have not developed a competing consensus.'' **********The response to the new draft was evident in many cable share prices.
