Tele-Communications Inc. the nation's largest cable operator, closed at $15.15 yesterday, up from $13.875 last Thursday. Time Warner Inc. rose to $100.875 from $92.625 on Thursday. Comcast Communications closed at $14.50, compared with $12 on Thursday. American Television and Communications Inc. has gone up to $38.25, from $34.875 on Thursday. **********Despite the higher stock prices, executives and investors remained concerned over the continued illiquidity in the cable deal market. Because banks are treating cable deals as highly leveraged transactions and refusing to finance them, there have been almost no deals in recent months. **********''Transactions validate the value of the assets, and therefore the value of the stock,'' Ms. Armbrust said. ''Without them, it is hard to keep the stock prices up.'' **********In recent weeks, there was only one transaction. First Carolina Communications sold 100,000 subscribers to Falcon Communications, a Los Angeles cable operator, for about $1,867 a subscriber. The original pricing on the deal a year back was higher by about $100 a subscriber. While the subscribers in the deal were not in a fast-growing market, the pricing does reflect the difficulties in cutting and closing deals in the current environment. **********Tele-Communications' president, John Malone, said yesterday that he anticipated that deals would begin to pick up in six months to a year, in part because if American bankers do not get back into the business, foreign bankers will play a bigger role. **********Others, however, disagreed. One investment banker who declined to be named said the pickup in activity would come only if American bankers again became active in the market. **********Meanwhile, attention remains focused on the activity in Washington. Privately, a number of cable executives said that the House draft was acceptable, and they appeared relieved that the committee had not made it tougher. There was also relief that the House draft did not provide for letting the telephone companies into the cable business. Although such an amendment could still be introduced, one industry executive who declined to be named said that he found it unlikely. **********Ideally, of course, the industry wants to operate unregulated. But if there is to be legislation, several executives agreed that the House bill would be viable. Moreover, it might relieve some of the uncertanity that has impeded cable deals, and in turn diminished the value of cable television stocks. **********Some companies have already positioned themselves to offset the impact of legislation as much as possible. Tele-Communications, for example, recently reorganized its program services so that a basic cable subscriber would get only the broadcast channels in his market as well as a handful of other services including C-Span. Tele-Communications took five services including Turner Network Television, USA Network and ESPN and put them on a separate tier. **********Mr. Malone said that his company could not control the programming costs of those services and therefore wanted to treat them separately. **********For now, the consumer has not felt the impact. Instead of charging the full price for basic services and the five advertiser services as it had, Tele-Communications now charges slightly less for the basic services and adds a charge for the five additional services. But were reregulation as it stands in the House bill to become law, the company would be able to raise its prices at its discretion for the second tier of services.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/05/busin.main_headline: Alliance Is Formed by Fiat and French Company
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/05/busin.print_headline: Alliance Is Formed by Fiat and French Company
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/05/busin.body_text: **********Fiat, Italy's largest industrial group, and Compagnie Generale d'Electricite, France's largest electronics group, announced today that they were forming a far-reaching strategic alliance and that C.G.E. would acquire control of Telettra, Fiat's $1.4 billion-a-year telecommunications subsidiary. **********With some analysts suggesting that this alliance was formed to counter Germany's growing industrial might, Fiat and C.G.E. announced that the two companies had agreed in principle to combine their railroad equipment operations, which will expand C.G.E.'s lead as the world's largest rail equipment producer. In addition, Fiat and C.G.E. agreed to merge their automobile battery operations, a move that will create Europe's largest battery maker. **********''The fact that two large Italian and French groups come together a day after German unification has made many people think that this is a response to a unified Germany,'' said Paul Dionne, an analyst with Pasfin, a Milan-based investment bank. **********Stakes in Each Other **********Fiat and C.G.E., which is France's third-largest industrial group, also announced a cross-shareholding agreement in which C.G.E. was to take 3 percent of Fiat for $390 million dollars, making the Paris-based company one of Fiat's largest shareholders after the Agnelli family. For its part, Fiat agreed to take a 6 percent stake, valued at $825 million, in C.G.E., which controls Alcatel, Europe's largest telecommunications equipment company. **********In explaining today's agreement Cesare Romiti, Fiat's chief executive, said European companies had to think increasingly beyond their borders to prepare for the barrier-free market that the European Community is seeking to form by the end of 1992. ''We live in a European market that is not being created on Jan. 1, 1993, but is already forming.'' he said at a news conference at Fiat's headquarters in Turin. ''Reasoning in nationalist terms does not make sense anymore.'' **********Some analysts suggested that the French-Italian alliance had been inspired by the alliance between Daimler-Benz, the German automobile and aviation group, and Mitsubishi, the Japanese conglomerate. In both alliances, the companies hope to benefit from each other's technologies. **********High-Tech Cooperation **********Fiat and C.G.E. said they were forming a small holding company that would work on joint development in high-technology areas like advanced materials and artificial intelligence. **********C.G.E. had net income of $1.16 billion last year on revenues of $24 billion, while Fiat's net income was $2.8 billion on revenue of $41 billion. **********The decision to merge Telettra into Alcatel's Italian subsidiary followed Fiat's efforts to find a partner for its telecommunications subsidiary. **********''Telettra is a good company, but it's not big enough to make it by itself in the industry,'' said John Dinsdale, an analyst with Dataquest in London. **********Fiat will maintain a 25 percent stake in the group formed from merging Telettra with Alcatel's Italian subsidiary. Fiat placed a value of $2.15 billion on Telettra, which had profits of $337 million last year. In their statement, the two companies said Alcatel would now be the world's largest supplier of microwave and cable transmission equipment. **********Fiat and C.G.E. also announced a tentative agreement in which GEC Alsthom, a joint venture formed by the General Electric Company of Britain and C.G.E.'s Alsthom railroad equipment subsidiary, takes a 50.1 percent interest in Fiat Ferroviaria, Fiat's rail equipment division. Fiat will retain 49.9 percent in Ferroviaria. **********Many analysts speculated that Fiat would announce a link with the Chrysler Corporation. Industry officials say Fiat is discussing a possible joint venture with or equity stake in Chrysler.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/12/busin.main_headline: Saatchi Twist In Developing New Products
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/12/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;   Saatchi Twist In Developing New Products
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/12/busin.body_text: **********EAGER to reap the benefits agencies receive from helping their clients develop new products, Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising has begun to promote a novel system that turns product development into a school game. **********With impish homework assignments, required reading and assorted knickknacks, the New York headquarters of the world's second-largest agency hopes to channel the ideas of marketing and advertising executives into viable proposals for new products. **********While playful, the procedure, called ''funneling'' by Saatchi, is far from an idle curiosity. Several products invented this way are being developed. And for the agency, the point of the game is quite serious: new billings in a stagnant ad market. **********Ad executives are fond of saying the best growth comes from existing clients. Not only are such new assignments a vote of confidence in the agency's work, but they arrive without the agency having to prove its mettle in an expensive and time-consuming new-business presentation. **********To enhance their chances of grabbing new accounts from old clients, several agencies have put together formidable new-product units. The most successful belongs to FCB/ Leber Katz Partners in New York. In the last 18 years, its marketing planning department has developed products like Prego spaghetti sauce for Campbell Soup and More and Now cigarettes for R. J. Reynolds. **********Like Leber Katz, Saatchi boasts as clients a raft of giant consumer-products companies, like Procter & Gamble and General Mills. Saatchi also has one of the industry's more innovative research departments. Led by Penelope Queen, it has helped legitimize the role of cultural anthropologists in advertising, and has worked to move large clients to accept other forms of emotional and cultural research, to supplement the more conventional research into consumers' conscious motivations. **********New products have traditionally resulted from technological breakthroughs at client companies - like a new process for making tissues softer - rather than a perception of a consumer need or desire. Increasingly, however, large consumer-products companies are becoming technological equals, forcing them to distinguish themselves through their insights into customers' minds. **********New-product consultants have arisen to help companies along this otherwise unfamiliar road. Saatchi, with funneling and a daylong meeting it calls the Creative Resources Workshop, says it is taking the invention process a step further by bringing its own advertising experts together with its clients' marketing experts. **********''The important thing is we will gain consensus among decision-makers as to the best ideas to bring forth,'' Ms. Queen said. ''In a day's time, we'll come out of a session with ideas that make sense in terms of marketing, research and development, and an understanding of the consumer.'' **********To prepare for a workshop with Johnson & Johnson, Saatchi sent several executives, including brand managers in its sanitary protection division, as well as to its own personnel, an umbrella with various products dangling from it. These included a body sponge, Odor Eaters for shoes and a travel toothbrush. The point: to stimulate the participants to think broadly and creatively about personal care. **********They also received a chocolate bar, to keep them happy through their homework, which additionally included observing women commuters and creating ''life style scenarios'' for them that explained how they might use personal-care products. **********The client and agency executives were also required to do a ''closet excavation'' to find everything in their own lives that protected them, and they were told to find examples of notable improvements in products by sailing through supermarket and drugstore aisles. **********The result of this project may be a new sanitary protection product from Johnson & Johnson. General Mills has already brought to market a product developed through funneling: Shark Bites, a fruit snack for children. Nabisco and Burger King have also gone through the process. **********Ms. Queen made it clear that while solid new-product concepts were the goal of funneling, another aim was bonding the client to the agency, a benefit often missing when a company gives an ad agency an existing product to market. **********''This way, everybody has some stake in the process,'' Ms. Queen said, ''but nobody's left to pass or fail.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/27/world.main_headline: Release Opposition's Funds, Carter Warns Nicaraguans
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/27/world.print_headline: Release Opposition's Funds, Carter Warns Nicaraguans
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/27/world.body_text: **********Concerned over reports of intimidation of opposition candidates, former President Jimmy Carter warned today of a ''great uproar'' in the United States unless official delays in releasing United States funds to the opposition were stopped. **********Arriving in Nicaragua for his third visit as head of an electoral team observing the campaign for the Feb. 25 elections, Mr. Carter said he would take up the reports of intimidation with Nicaraguan leaders as well as delays in handing over funds approved by Congress for the main opposition alliance, the National Opposition Union, and an institute that trains opposition election officials.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/09/world.main_headline: 2 Die in Attacks by Rival Groups in Ulster
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/09/world.print_headline: 2 Die in Attacks by Rival Groups in Ulster
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/09/world.body_text: **********A truck driver was killed today in a machine-gun attack that the Irish Republican Army took responsibility for, and a Protestant paramilitary group said it killed an I.R.A. backer the day before. **********The police said the victim of today's attack was driving a concrete mixer when he was attacked outside Donaghmore village near Dungannon, 40 miles west of Belfast. **********The I.R.A. said its members shot the unidentified driver, who delivered construction materials to police stations and military bases. It said his employer ignored warnings to stop working for security forces. **********The outlawed Protestant Ulster Volunteer Force took responsibility tonight for killing Sam Marshall, 31, on Wednesday night after he left the Royal Ulster Constabulary base in Lurgan, 20 miles southwest of Belfast. Two survivors of the shooting accused the police of cooperating with the gunmen. **********Supporters of the I.R.A. identified Mr. Marshall as a member of its legal political wing, Sinn Fein. **********The two survivors, Tony McCaughey, 31, and Colm Duffy, 22, said they were under police surveillance when the gunmen attacked. The three men were free on bail after being charged with illegal possession of ammunition and were required to report to the Constabulary. **********The Constabulary denied the charge of collusion with the killers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/18/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene;   Does Gorbachev Know Best?
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/18/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene;   Does Gorbachev Know Best?
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/18/busin.body_text: **********SUPPOSE Mikhail Gorbachev threw a free-market party and nobody wanted to dance? **********Soviet leaders make no secret of their worry that people reared in a socialist cocoon would be unable to adjust to the rough and tumble of open competition. Indeed, many apparently fear that the proletariat would take to the barricades before accepting the loss of guaranteed employment and cheap bread, or tolerating the rise of self-made millionaires in their midst. **********But pathbreaking survey research by Robert J. Shiller, an economist at Yale and expert on the psychological underpinnings of economic behavior, suggests that the Kremlin is behind the times: Not only did Mr. Shiller discover that Muscovites were reasonably open to capitalism, but also, the survey shows, in some ways they were more open than their counterparts in New York. **********The research, done with a Soviet economist, Maksim Boiko, and a Soviet sociologist, Vladimir Korobov, and being presented today at a National Bureau of Economic Research conference in Cambridge, Mass., will not be easy to brush aside. Like a few other pioneering analysts, Mr. Shiller has used opinion polling to gauge Soviet resistance to capitalist ideas. But unlike others, he has created a controlled scientific experiment, asking the same questions of Soviet and American citizens, and comparing their responses. **********The telephone survey, conducted in May, covered some 360 people in each country with similar age, sex, employment and education profiles. The poll included 36 questions crafted to minimize spurious differences linked to language or culture. A few of the questions explored attitudes toward capitalist institutions head on - i.e., ''What inheritance tax rate for really wealthy people do you think we should have?'' A few asked about current behavior: ''Did you save any money from the income you earned last year?'' But most set up hypothetical situations and asked individuals how they would react, or whether a given result was fair. **********One question, for example, asked whether they would accept a 10 percent increase in working hours in return for a 10 percent pay increase. Another asked whether they would charge market-rate interest to a friend who needed a six-month loan to buy a summer house. Yet another asked whether it was fair for a furniture factory to raise the $200 price of kitchen tables by $20 if it could not meet demand at the current price. **********In a few cases, responses divided along the anticipated ideological fault lines. Soviet respondents were generally more suspicious of business success: Some 54 percent agreed that ''people who try to make a lot of money will often turn out to be not very honest,'' compared with just 37 percent of the Americans. And Soviet answers showed more reluctance to mix arm's-length business with friendship. Fives times as many Americans (though still a minority) would charge interest on the summer house loan. **********In most cases, though, Soviet and American attitudes were quite similar. Roughly the same proportion would be ''tempted to invest a substantial portion of their savings'' in a risky enterprise that might make them rich. Nearly identical percentages thought it fair to buy vegetables from farmers and resell them in the city at a large profit. Most Soviet respondents (64 percent) thought it unfair to raise the price of those scarce kitchen tables - but so, too, did a majority (70 percent) of Americans. **********Some answers suggested that Russians are actually more willing capitalist tools than Americans. Just two-thirds as many Soviet people believed that speculation would cause more frequent shortages of bread. More Soviet respondents (49 percent versus 30 percent) would be willing to tolerate the tripling of incomes for a lucky minority to gain a 1 percent increase for everyone else. And a higher percentage in Moscow were ready to tolerate 30 percent inflation as long as their own incomes rose by more. **********The survey results may not be entirely representative of attitudes in the two countries. Muscovites with sufficient clout to rate working telephones may be relatively confident they would emerge as winners in the capitalist lottery. New Yorkers, inured to rent control, may be less market-oriented than other Americans. **********But such considerations hardly explain away this striking research. At the very least, the results shift the burden of proof to those who view this generation in the Soviet Union as inflexible followers of the socialist god who failed. **********An obvious question, then, is why Robert Shiller seems to know better than Mikhail Gorbachev -why the Kremlin is so reluctant to ask people to take a chance on another economic revolution. The good Marxist answer is that the primary beneficiaries of the old system can hardly be expected to remain in the vanguard of change for very long.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/14/busin.print_headline: REAL ESTATE;   Cinemas Blossoming In Manhattan
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/14/busin.body_text: **********THE collective message blaring from the marquees of all the new cinemas in New York might well be ''Movie Mania Grips Gotham.'' **********In just two years, 43 movie screens have gone into operation in Manhattan, while at least 32 more are in various stages of development, some of them in neighborhoods that had not seen a new theater in more than 50 years. **********People in the movie theater and real estate businesses attribute the boom to a record - and unexpected - public demand for new films despite the competition of television and home videos. They also cite the need to replace aging neighborhood theaters, a perception that Manhattan had too few screens, and tie-ins with new real estate projects. **********''The owners of a lot of big new residential and commercial developments are looking for increased values in the land they bought and investments in new movie screens are an ideal solution,'' said Robert H. Sunshine, executive director of the Metropolitan Theater Owners Association. **********The Zeckendorf Company, for example, incorporated six screens in the commercial and residential development named World Wide Plaza that it just opened on the West Side in midtown, and it is planning others in a residential project at 87th Street and Third Avenue. **********Mr. Sunshine said that domestic exhibitors took in a record $5 billion last year and that there seemed to be no slackening of public demand. Another factor in local expansion is the opening of theaters to keep pace with population shifts to such areas as the Flat Iron District and the East Village. In all about a dozen movie houses have opened recently. **********New projects dot traditional Rialtos like Times Square and midtown, but Mr. Sunshine said that ''for years there had hardly been a new theater south of 34th Street.'' Now, more than 20 screens have gone into operation there. **********The association has no count of how many movie theaters the city has. It is known, however, that the city has lost many since World War II, and that many old large theaters have been divided into multiscreen complexes. Cineplex Odeon Theaters opened a nine-screen operation containing almost 2,000 seats on 23d Street between Seventh and Eighth avenues in Chelsea in a new building last summer and now has 46 screens in Manhattan, the largest of any company. **********Stephen Carducci, director of publicity for Cineplex in New York and New Jersey, said, ''This is the only area in the country that people in the industry believe has fewer screens than demand can carry, so development in this area still seems attractive to us.'' **********Movies will even arrive next year in Battery Park City, the huge development next to the financial district that has been lacking in entertainment. The theaters are being incorporated into the Cove Club development of 170 apartments now under construction. **********''We will have three theaters with a total of 770 seats,'' said Steven Goodstein, the developer of the Cove Club project. ''These will be the first new screens south of Canal Street in many, many years and we know they are going to be well received.'' **********Battery Park City officials said the theaters, which will be in the basement of the main building, had been sought as part of the development deal to provide a community amenity to residents. **********The City Cinemas Corporation, which went into operation three years ago, has been acquiring existing properties, then expanding them by adding as many as six screens. It has such a renovation under way now in the East Village at 12th Street and 2d Avenue, where an old one-screen operation is being enlarged into seven. The company has a total of 17 screens now. **********Herb Millman, City Cinemas' vice president for theater operations, said: ''Until several years ago many people in the industry believed that VCR's were going to take the place of going to the movies, yet this hasn't happened. What has evolved is that people see the film, then rent the video.'' **********Expansion is even under way at nonprofit cinemas. The Film Forum, for example, is moving its operation on Watts Street in SoHo seven blocks north to 209 West Houston Street at Varick Street in the south Village. **********The old theater with two screens was torn down to make way for an office building, and the new theater will open late this spring with three screens, each equipped for 16-millimeter and 35-millimeter projection. Karen Cooper, the director of Film Forum, said one screen would be used for new movies, one for rerun films and the third for longer runs that might be moved over from the other two. There will be a total of 458 seats. **********Ms. Cooper said the $2.5 million cost was being met by donations from 10 private foundations and from the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company and a film company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/24/world.main_headline: After Silence, Japan's Army Pushes for Armed Gulf Role
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/24/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;   After Silence, Japan's Army Pushes for Armed Gulf Role
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/24/world.body_text: **********After four decades of silence, Japan's military has openly split with some of the country's political leaders in a bitter debate over whether and how Japan should contribute forces to the Persian Gulf in what may become the military's first excursion abroad since World War II. **********Because of its history as the moving force behind the rightist Government that plunged Japan into the invasions of China and Southeast Asia, and ultimately into a disastrous war against the United States, Japan's military has stayed out of virtually all political discourse since being reconstituted as the Self-Defense Forces in the 1950's. **********'This May Be the Moment' **********Since that time, the ''peace constitution'' written for Japan by the United States has been interpreted as barring the country's military forces from venturing beyond the Japanese archipelago, even as part of United Nations peacekeeping forces. **********But the Iraq crisis, and demands from the United States, are driving many in the Japanese Government to put more at risk than just its money. Suddenly the country is facing the issue of whether Japan is psychologically or legally prepared to use military forces to protect its vast economic interests abroad, even in noncombat roles as part of a United Nations or international force. **********''This may be the most heated and emotional debate since the end of the war,'' said Masashi Nishihara, a professor at Japan's leading military college and an influential figure in the country's struggle to define a role that goes beyond that of economic superpower. ''It is a question that Japan has never faced squarely. But this may be the moment.'' **********The issue has taken on a particular urgency within the Government because it seems bound to come up later this week when Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu prepares to go the United States for a United Nations General Assembly session and a meeting with President Bush. **********But just as the Prime Minister is leaving, his initial proposal - to create an unarmed, civilian ''United Nations cooperation force'' to provide behind-the-lines support to American and other forces in Saudi Arabia - has begun to collapse, under attack from opposition parties, the Japanese military establishment and even leaders of Mr. Kaifu's own party. **********Socialists Are Opposed **********The largest opposition party, the Japan Socialist Party, has never recognized the legitimacy of the Self-Defense Forces, contending that their existence is a violation of the Japanese Constitution. **********The party has said it will oppose any effort to send Japanese abroad into a war zone, charging that Mr. Kaifu's ''peace cooperation team'' is simply a guise for sending military forces. Indeed, under Mr. Kaifu's original proposal many members of the team would be soldiers from the Self-Defense Forces, though the others would include police officers, firefighters and doctors. In theory, they would provide communications support, surveillance and medical treatment, but stay out of the front lines. **********Because the Liberal Democrats lost control of the upper house of Parliament a year ago, the Socialists and smaller opposition groups could bottle up Mr. Kaifu's ''U.N. Cooperation Law'' for months. **********Moreover, they could probably win popular support along the way. Polls show that more than 60 percent of the Japanese public opposes sending Japanese personnel to the Persian Gulf. Opposition is even higher among older Japanese, who blame the military for the chaos and ruin brought on by the war. **********In conversations, many Japanese of all ages question whether the United States is being foolhardy or trigger-happy; many say they would prefer to pay more for oil than be pressed by Americans to send Japanese personnel to the gulf to protect sheikdoms. **********But the bitterest criticism of Mr. Kaifu's proposal has come not from the left, or from the public, but from within the Liberal Democratic Party's own leadership. With support from the military establishment, many are arguing that Mr. Kaifu's unarmed force, without military training and discipline, would be ineffective and vulnerable to slaughter. **********''It is nonsense,'' a senior officer in the Self-Defense Forces said a few days ago. ''We would be laughed at as a toy army. Frankly speaking, I think if I asked my troops to go under those conditions, many would refuse.'' **********No Longer on the Sidelines **********Japan took up a similar issue once before, in 1987, when it was under pressure to send minesweepers to the gulf to rid the area of mines believed to have been planted by Iran. But the debate was far less intense, and in the end the minesweepers never left port. **********Now the country fears that inaction could lead to international condemnation of Japan, which is heavily dependent on Middle East oil. **********''What we are doing is wasting time,'' said Moto Shiina, a former member of Parliament and a leading defense expert. ''We have to identify our national interest in this post-cold-war era and make ourself available to our allies. The political structure, though, is not prepared to deal with it. At least not yet.'' What separates the current debate from past discussions about the scope of Japanese power is that this time the military is hardly sitting on the sidelines. **********Technically, neither the uniformed officers nor the civilian heads of Japan's military have any role in debating defense policy. When Mr. Kaifu was first formulating a response to American demands for help, he pointedly kept the Defense Minister, Yozo Ishikawa, out of the meetings. But both the civilian bureaucracy and the uniformed services have deep ties to the Liberal Democratic Party, and already their efforts to head off Mr. Kaifu's hopes for a nonmilitary force are showing results. **********The military has also been insisting that any personnel sent to the gulf carry sidearms, at the very least. ''It is a matter of definition,'' a senior officer in the Maritime Self-Defense Forces said. ''If you are carrying a pistol or a rifle, that is essentially unarmed. But to this country, unarmed means completely unarmed.'' **********The other day Mr. Ishikawa backed away from his earlier contention that Japan could do nothing, and publicly termed Mr. Kaifu's proposal a ''half-measure.'' He urged a reinterpretation of the law, which would not require parliamentary action. **********On Saturday, Noboru Takeshita, the former Japanese Prime Minister and one of the governing party's most powerful figures, told reporters that the Government should push through a revision of the Self-Defense Law that would permit military personnel to be sent to the gulf, in uniform, as part of the multinational force. **********Ichiro Ozawa, the secretary general of the party, split with Mr. Kaifu by arguing that it made more sense to revise Japan's Self-Defense Law and enable Japanese forces to take part in multinational peackeeping efforts rather than to draw up a new law. **********That is exactly what Mr. Kaifu and Japan's Foreign Ministry have been trying to avoid for fear that any revisions of the Self-Defense Law would give Southeast Asia exactly what it is often looking for: evidence that Japan seeks a new regional role beyond its borders. **********''Southeast Asian countries, which suffered during World War II, have shown a serious interest in this issue,'' warned Taro Nakayama, Japan's Foreign Minister. ''It is extremely important to draw up a flawless bill.'' **********Even in Japan there is an unspoken fear that someday the Japanese military could once again spin out of control, and that it is unwise to set a precedent for overseas ventures. It is a fear that some Japanese say the country must finally get over. **********''What is the use of elections, of a democracy, if you do not think it will enable you to control the country's policy?'' Mr. Shiina asked. **********The issue is ambiguous enough, however, that the one country with the biggest stake in the outcome - the United States - is remaining silent. The constitutional ban on offensive forces was formulated by Gen. Douglas A. MacArthur, who commanded the American occupation of Japan. Now it is the United States that, warily, is seeking greater help from Japan. **********''It is something for the Japanese to decide,'' a senior American diplomat here said the other day. ''I can't imagine that if the United States took a position it would do anything than make things worse.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/03/busin.body_text: **********The president of the Asian Development Bank warned today that the political and economic changes in Eastern Europe may divert attention from this region throughout the 1990's, forcing Asians to rely on their own momentum for further growth. **********The shift in focus comes at a critical time for Asia, the bank's new president, Kimimasa Tarumizu, said in his opening address to the bank's annual general meeting. **********Although Asian economies continue to grow, he said, the gaps between the rich and poor nations are widening and growth rates among the least developed are declining. **********Over all, the cumulative growth rate of those nations the Manila-based bank calls ''developing Asia'' - most of the region excluding China, Hong Kong, South Korea, Singapore and Taiwan -dropped from 9.3 percent in 1988 to 5.4 percent in 1989. Most of that growth was in Southeast Asia, with Thailand and Indonesia among the better performers. **********''The spectacular success of the newly industrializing economies is proof of the dynamism of the region,'' Mr. Tarumizu told his audience of bankers and government leaders from more than 40 countries today. ''Yet in many parts of Asia, modest economic growth, growing populations and severe constraints on development keep millions of people desperately poor.'' **********He said that Asians would be increasingly thrown on their own resources to close those gaps. Asia has some of the developing world's richest and poorest countries. While the per capita gross national product is more than $9,000 in Singapore and Hong Kong, the figures for India, Bangladesh and Vietnam are all below $400, the bank said. **********At meetings this week, the subject of Vietnam's exclusion from bank programs is likely to be raised. Vietnam, along with China and Afghanistan, is suspended from most activities on political or security grounds. **********Reviewing the Asian Development Bank's activities for 1989, Mr. Tarumizu said that the institution had approved $3.6 billion in loans for 60 projects, a 15 percent increase in lending. **********The Asian Development Bank is owned by the governments of 49 countries in the Asia-Pacific region and in North America and Europe. It was established in 1966 to assist in developing Asian nations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/22/busin.main_headline: Hanson Officer Picked For Smith Corona Post
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/22/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;   Hanson Officer Picked For Smith Corona Post
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/22/busin.body_text: **********The Smith Corona Corporation yesterday announced the appointment of a new president and chief operating officer, William D. Henderson, effective July 1. **********Mr. Henderson, 43 years old, is joining Smith Corona from Hanson Industries, the United States arm of the British company Hanson P.L.C., which last year sold more than half its shares in Smith Corona to the public. **********G. Lee Thompson, 56, president, chairman and chief executive of Smith Corona, is relinquishing the presidency and will continue in his other posts. **********''Mr. Thompson has been wearing both hats as a chief executive and a chief operating officer, and that's a big job for a company that size,'' Mr. Henderson said. The company is the world's largest maker of portable electronic typewriters and personal word processors. **********Mr. Henderson spent nine years with Hanson, joining at a time when the British company had 18 people in the United States and just as it started its aggressive expansion that saw it buy dozens of companies, including the SCM Corporation, former parent of Smith Corona, which Hanson bought in 1986 for $930 million. Hanson still holds a 48 percent interest in Smith Corona. **********Mr. Henderson is currently group vice president at Hanson, in charge of building products, the aircraft and industrial unit and the fabric group, some 20 businesses in all. **********Four years ago, he was named president and chief executive of Durkee Famous Foods, another Hanson property at the time. ''The president of Durkee was retiring and the business was reporting to Lee Thompson,'' Mr. Henderson said. ''That's how Lee and I first got to know each other.'' **********Mr. Henderson was in the Durkee job four months when Hanson decided to sell the business, and Mr. Henderson returned to Hanson. ''I was glad I hadn't sold my house,'' he said. **********In his new post at Smith Corona, Mr. Henderson will be responsible for operations, including worldwide marketing, sales, manufacturing and engineering. **********Before he was recruited by Hanson, Mr. Henderson was an executive at the FMC Corporation, a diversified Chicago-based company. He is a graduate of Denison University and the University of Virginia, where he received his M.B.A.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/26/world.main_headline: Rome Journal;   Marcus Aurelius Rides Again, but Behind Glass
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/26/world.print_headline: Rome Journal;   Marcus Aurelius Rides Again, but Behind Glass
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/26/world.body_text: **********On this day of Italian liberation, the most unliberated soul in town happened to be a figure often regarded, Shakespeare notwithstanding, as the noblest Roman of them all. **********An equestrian statue of Marcus Aurelius, Rome's philosopher-emperor of the second century, was back on the Capitoline Hill after a nine-year absence for study and cleaning. **********But the gilded bronze statue, considered an important symbol of this enduring capital, is not where many believe it belongs - in the center of the Piazza Campidoglio, the majestic square on the Capitoline where it was put in 1538. Instead, it has been relegated to a side courtyard, on public display but trapped behind glass in a small room where temperature and humidity levels are controlled. **********And there, local officials say, he will remain until they settle one of the burning issues before them: whether to return Marcus Aurelius and his horse to their old pedestal, as many here demand, or keep them under glass, confined but free of the corrosive air of modern Rome that threatens to destroy them. In a sense, it is a battle of tradition versus pollution, and for now pollution is winning. **********Warning of a Rail Strike **********For the last few days, Romans have celebrated the Emperor's return in tandem with other important events. Today was given to commemorating the day 45 years ago when Italy was freed from the last vestiges of Nazi occupation during World War II, and the country noted the occasion in familiar style, with ceremonies and warnings of a national rail strike 24 hours later. **********Last Saturday, April 21, was the date set aside to mark the legendary founding of the city by Romulus in 753 B.C., and there were traditional fireworks and speeches. But the real star was Marcus Aurelius, whose two-ton likeness is the only equestrian statue from ancient Rome known to have survived. **********Ten days earlier, he had returned to the Capitoline in a latter-day version of an imperial victory procession. **********Riding in a specially designed truck, while his horse rode in another, he traveled three miles through the streets of Rome, from an institute across the Tiber River, where they had been scrubbed clean, to the hill that is the seat of municipal government. Hundreds of loyal Romans on foot escorted them along the slow march, a tiny fraction of the many thousands that turned out on Rome's birthday last Saturday for the statue's first public display since 1981. **********It is so popular a symbol of the city's link to its glorious past that on that day alone, starting in the morning and continuing until 11 P.M., a reported 40,000 people trooped into the small side courtyard to view it in its glass cage. Yes, they said with satisfaction, Marcus Aurelius sparkled, in civil robes instead of a warrior's armor, his right hand extended in what some see as a gesture of peace. **********Rome Is Divided **********But how to keep him sparkling has divided the city council, art restorers and ordinary citizens. **********Some traditionalists insist that he be speedily returned to the marble pedestal in the heart of the square, designed in the 16th century by no less than Michelangelo, who had the Emperor in mind as the centerpiece. The empty pedestal there now is plain wrong, these people say. **********But others respond that it borders on madness to expose Marcus Aurelius once more to Rome's notorious pollution, which is bearable only to those who do not trust air that they cannot see. They say it is wiser to keep the original statue safely indoors and to put a faithful bronze copy out on the main square. **********Certainly, there is ample precedent for that in Italy. Michelangelo's David, standing in the Piazza della Signoria in Florence, is a copy; the original statue has been in the city's Accademia di Belle Arti since 1873. In Venice, the famous Greco-Roman bronze horses above the entrance of St. Mark's Basilica are also copies, the originals having been moved indoors long ago. **********Just One More Falsehood **********The debate over Marcus Aurelius is expected to continue for a long time, possibly years. For what it is worth, a journalist's informal survey this week of Italian visitors to the statue, an endeavor utterly devoid of scientific pretense, suggested that most thought it made sense to leave the sheltered Emperor where he now is. **********The director of the Capitoline Museums, Anna Mura Sommella, agreed that it was pointless to put Marcus Aurelius back on his pedestal until a substance has been found that can truly protect the bronze from acid rain and other corrosions. The statue, Dr. Sommella noted, is rather fragile in places after centuries of enduring the slings and arrows of outrageous treatment. There are even soft spots, she said, that reflect flawed attempts at restoration in the past. **********Yet somehow, the director added, it does not seem right to her to put a fake in the heart of Michelanglo's square. ''Little by little,'' she said with a faint sigh, ''we are getting used to the idea of a world that's entirely false.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/04/busin.main_headline: Panel Established by Judge To Oversee Drexel Portfolio
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/04/busin.print_headline: Panel Established by Judge To Oversee Drexel Portfolio
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/04/busin.body_text: **********For the first time since its parent company filed for bankruptcy in February, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. lost its ability to exercise independent control of purchases and sales of securities in its portfolio. **********In a decision signed late yesterday, Federal Bankruptcy Judge Howard Buschman 3d ordered that a four-person investment committee be established to approve purchases and sales in the Drexel portfolio. **********After the parent company filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, Drexel reached a short-lived agreement that allowed oversight of its investment decisions by its creditors. Any objections to the decisions would then have to be taken by the creditors to court. **********In an apparent effort to preclude delays in approval of the transactions, Judge Buschman ordered that the chairman of the committee alone would be allowed to approve or deny a planned asset sale or purchase. **********George D. Gould, a former Under Secretary of the Treasury in the Reagan Administration, was appointed by Judge Buschman as chairman of the group. **********''I don't know of any other case where there has been this kind of a process, where a group of outsiders had the ultimate voice in the dealings of a portfolio,'' said Wilbur Ross, senior managing director at Rothschild Inc., the financial adviser to the creditor's committee of Drexel Burham Lambert Group Inc. **********A spokesman for Drexel said the new system would ease any efforts to change the portfolio. ''We view it as a workable solution for maximizing assets,'' said Steven Anreder, a spokesman for Drexel. **********The move by Judge Buschman was an attempt to defuse a growing antagonism between the firm and its creditors, who have complained that they feared the firm was mismanaging its assets. **********Those concerns grew significantly in late May after Drexel terminated a number of guidelines that had been agreed upon with its creditors to allow for oversight of its transactions. Two days after terminating those agreements, Drexel's brokerage subsidiary also filed for Chapter 11 protection from its creditors. **********Under the system ordered by Judge Buschman, only those transactions that Mr. Gould approves as giving creditors fair value could be executed. If any other member of the committee objected to Mr. Gould's decision on any transaction, the objection would then be heard by Judge Buschman.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/16/world.main_headline: 55 Mozambicans Die In a Guerrilla Attack
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/16/world.print_headline: 55 Mozambicans Die In a Guerrilla Attack
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/16/world.body_text: **********Fifty-five people were killed when rebels attacked a train in southern Mozambique on Wednesday, officials said today. **********The attack was the third by rebels of the right-wing Mozambique National Resistance reported this month. **********The train was ambushed about seven miles from the town of Ressano Garcia on Mozambique's border with South Africa. **********The Mozambique National Resistance, known as Renamo. has fought the Mozambican Government since soon after the country won its independence from Portugal in 1975. **********A relief train took survivors of the attack and the bodies of the dead to Mozambique's capital, Maputo, on Wednesday night. About 40 wounded people were taken to a hospital. **********The railway line linking Maputo with South Africa has been relatively free of rebel attacks in recent months and survivors said the train had no military escort. Officials said the rebels exploded a remote-controlled land mine and used bazookas, automatic weapons and bayonets in the attack. **********The rebels seized money and other possessions from passengers. Earlier this month Renamo guerrillas killed 13 civilians in central Mozambique and kidnapped and killed 17 people near the town of Xai-Xai in the south. Both groups of victims were robbed. **********The robberies indicate the guerrillas' supplies from outside the country could be drying up. **********President Joaquim A Chissano said recently that South Africa had cut support for the rebels. Pretoria has long denied financing Renamo, which gets no overt aid from any foreign country.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/02/world.main_headline: Evolution in Europe;   SOVIET COMMUNISTS CONVENING TODAY ON PARTY'S FUTURE
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/02/world.print_headline: Evolution in Europe;   SOVIET COMMUNISTS CONVENING TODAY ON PARTY'S FUTURE
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/02/world.body_text: **********The Communist Party of the Soviet Union, divided, demoralized and endangered by democracy, is convening Monday for its 28th congress, where the main issue will be not so much where the party will lead the country but whether it will lead the country at all. **********The congress, the highest authority of the party, promises to be more contentious than any such meeting since Lenin's day, if only because the presence of television cameras and the passion for gloves-off debate have become routine since the last congress in 1986. **********In choosing a new leadership and adopting a new platform, the 4,700 delegates, with a high proportion of professional party functionaries alarmed over their slipping power, will be rendering their verdict on President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his program of market-oriented economics and political pluralism. **********Gorbachev Opening Congress **********The congress is opening with a report by Mr. Gorbachev, who seems assured of re-election as general secretary. **********But on its eve, the event shows little sign of being the climactic showdown on the future that many expected. **********The radical reformers who once hoped for a purge of the hard-liners and fresh commitments to reform now say they believe that Mr. Gorbachev will settle for much less to appease the newly aggressive conservative wing of his party. **********The officials who speculated that Mr. Gorbachev would hand over management of the party and devote himself to the presidency now say the party is still too conservative - and too powerful if only as a force of resistance - to be freed from his direct control. **********An Illusion of Unity **********The analysts who once predicted that the party would cleave into two or three factions, giving birth to parties of the left and right, believe that Mr. Gorbachev will try to paper over the differences as an illusion of unity. **********If he succeeds, the party will continue to shrivel. But rival parties will have to be built the hard way. **********The 28th congress is the first one since the Seventh Congress in 1918 in which the party is not confident that it is the dominant political force in the country. In February, the Central Committee agreed to surrender party monopoly on political power, which was guaranteed in the Soviet Constitution. **********Nothing the congress does is likely to restore the party's credibility, which is lower than it has ever been after five years without an improvement in the standard of living. **********Party Is Pulled and Pushed **********And the changes originated by Mr. Gorbachev are being propelled less from within the party than from the increasingly assertive elected government bodies, especially the Russian republic's Parliament, headed by Boris N. Yeltsin, the independence-minded Baltic republics and the democratically controlled city councils in centers like Moscow and Leningrad. **********In Moscow today, the approaching congress was a topic of great popular indifference compared with the latest City Council sensation: a decision that all of the millions of state-owned apartments in the city are to be turned over to their occupants free of charge. The policy, announced Friday night, has yet to be put into effect by Moscow's several regions and the details remain unclear. **********''If the Communist Party was the only force defining the fate of perestroika, as it was five years ago, the congress would play a great role in the country's life,'' said Gavriil K. Popov, chairman of the City Council. ''But now the party is struggling just to keep up.'' **********Fate of the Party at Stake **********''The congress is important, first of all, for the fate of the Communist Party itself,'' Mr. Popov continued. ''Will it be able to change itself enough to remain one of the organizers of the movement?'' **********The makeup of the delegates suggests that a majority will be conservative but not necessarily rebellious. **********About 2,700 of the delegates, more than half, represent the Russian republic. They are the delegates who attended the founding congress of the Russian party organization, where the tone was resoundingly conservative. **********Ivan K. Polozkov, head of the Russian party, is so widely regarded as a reactionary that the Moscow party leader, a centrist, Yuri A. Prokofiev, broke party etiquette to describe him in Pravda as ''an odious figure.'' **********More telling are these estimates published by Moscow News: 48 percent of the delegates will be full-time party functionaries, and 20 percent are government ministers, industrial directors or other high-ranking officials with a vested interest in the status quo. **********Reformers Threaten to Walk Out **********Only about 100 delegates represent the Democratic Platform, a reformist faction that threatens to leave the party unless sweeping internal changes are enacted. **********This group wants the party to end stringent discipline and allow organized factions, to withdraw party cells from the military, K.G.B., law enforcement agencies and other organizations, and to surrender much of its property. **********The Democratic Platform is so outnumbered that its only leverage is the threat to leave the party, possibly taking with it prominent and popular Communists like Mr. Yeltsin, Mr. Popov and Anatoly A. Sobchak, chairman of the Leningrad City Council. **********Pavel Voshchanov, a delegate and writer for the Communist Youth daily Komsomolskaya Pravda, said Mr. Gorbachev's struggle in the congress would be be to avoid a repudiation of what he has already done. **********Fight for Reform 'Already Lost' **********''The fight for radical changes in the party, for radical reform, will not be won this time,'' Mr. Voshchanov said in an interview. ''It is already lost. The main problem is to save what has already been achieved.'' **********Mr. Gorbachev's nightmare would be something like the 12th Party Congress, in 1923, which became a revival meeting of reactionaries. The hard-liners of the time, led by Stalin, curbed Lenin's private-enterprise economic liberalization, denounced nationalist ''deviators'' and invoked firm discipline against budding factions. **********Lenin was too ill to attend and died the following January. **********But Mr. Gorbachev is not nearly so enfeebled. And unlike the recent Russian congress, which was organized in large part by conservative insurgents, the groundwork for the nationwide congress is in the hands of the Central Committee apparatus, which answers to Mr. Gorbachev. **********Selection of New Leaders **********Probably the most important event of the congress, which party officials predict will last about 10 days, will be the selection of new leaders. **********Mr. Gorbachev is expected to stay on in the role of party chairman, a new position whose occupant would be less involved in daily party affairs than he is as general secretary. **********Current decorum tends to require some competing candidates to lend a democratic gloss to the affair, and a serious challenge is posible. But the leader of the conservatives, Mr. Polozkov, has endorsed Mr. Gorbachev. **********The conservatives seem to have decided they will have more influence over Mr. Gorbachev if he remains party leader as well as president. **********A more serious fight is likely over the governing bodies of the party. Draft documents call for the Politburo to be replaced by a larger, policy-making Presidium, incorporating the leaders of the Communist parties in all 15 republics, as well as others. **********A Leaner Central Committee **********The Central Committee is to be largely replenished, and perhaps trimmed by a third, to about 200 members. Mr. Gorbachev has operated for five years with a conservative Central Committee and some of his supporters say it has prevented him from moving as quickly as he would like. **********Finally, probably soon after the congress, the Central Committee is to elect a Secretariat, made up of the heads of commissions that oversee such specific policy areas as foreign policy, ethnic affairs and ideology. As the Presidium is expected to be larger and more diffuse, this body could gain importance, and its leader, or first secretary, will wield a lot of power. **********The party's platform, a document once studied by Western Kremlin-watchers as a blueprint of Soviet policy, has receded considerably in importance. Many of the issues in the draft program that the party will debate -such as private property - have already been overtaken by new laws and it breaks no new ground. **********The transition to a market economy is only alluded to. The document makes no mention of ''depoliticization'' of the security police, the army and the courts, although the Russian Parliament has already embraced it as the basis for a new Constitution. **********No party gathering can now be fully choreographed or reliably forecast. But many participants say the most likely outcome is that the congress will be inconclusive, even a bit confusing. **********The party, they say, will not die, nor will it veer sharply in any direction.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/31/world.main_headline: Two Algerian Army Deserters Surrender in Jet's Hijacking
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/31/world.print_headline: Two Algerian Army Deserters Surrender in Jet's Hijacking
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/31/world.body_text: **********Two army deserters who hijacked an airliner and held dozens of hostages during a two-day standoff surrendered today after freeing all passengers and crew members, the Algerian press agency reported. **********The hijackers were taken into custody in the eastern city of Annaba after releasing the pilot and co-pilot of the Air Algeria Boeing 737. Earlier, the 46 remaining passengers were freed. **********There were no reports of injuries, and the motive for the hijacking was unclear. The press agency said the men were army deserters from a Saharan town, Ghardaia, where the flight originated Friday. The jet was forced to land in Annaba early Saturday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/14/world.main_headline: U.S. WEIGHS SHIFTS IN AFGHAN POLICY
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/14/world.print_headline: U.S. WEIGHS SHIFTS IN AFGHAN POLICY
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/14/world.body_text: **********President Bush sent a delegation of senior American officials to South Asia today to accelerate efforts to find a negotiated settlement of the war in Afghanistan. **********Nearly a year after Soviet troops withdrew from Afghanistan, the American-armed guerrillas seem no closer to military victory in the effort to establish a non-Communist government in Kabul. . **********The mission to South Asia, led by Robert M. Kimmitt, the No. 3 official at the State Department, is unlikely to produce a reversal of longstanding American policy itself. But Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d visits Moscow early next month, and officials are clearly analyzing all the options on Afghanistan. Among the possibilities are a cutoff of arms from both superpowers, a coalition government, or a larger role for the United Nations. **********The Kimmitt trip comes as the United Nations is also stepping up the pace of its Afghan diplomacy with a visit to Moscow by Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, who is to meet on Monday with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. [Page 15.] **********Mr. Kimmitt will meet in Pakistan with Afghan guerrilla leaders and Pakistani officials. He also plans to visit Saudi Arabia, which helps finance some Afghan guerrilla groups. The delegation will also visit India, where Mr. Kimmit may meet the new Prime Minister, V. P. Singh, to discuss Afghanistan and other issues. **********The delegation led by Mr. Kimmitt, who is Under Secretary for Political Affairs, includes Peter Tomsen, the special American envoy to the Afghan rebels; Michael E. Malinowski, a former consul in Peshawar, Pakistan; A. Peter Burleigh, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Intelligence and Research; William J. Burns, deputy director of the State Department's policy planning staff, and Sandra Charles, a member of the National Security Council staff. **********Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, said the trip did not signal a change or formal review of American policy toward Afghanistan. But Afghanistan will be high on the agenda when Mr. Baker meets Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze in Moscow on Feb. 6 and 7. **********Among the policy options are a larger role for the United Nations, simultaneous termination of arms deliveries by both Moscow and Washington, and the creation of a coalition government including Afghan guerrillas and some Communists not closely identified with the current Government. Another option is to ask the exiled King, Mohammed Zahir Shah, to return to Afghanistan and help unify the country. **********A Hard-Liner's Softer Views **********The United States insists that Najibullah, the Afghan President, resign as part of any political settlement. But the Soviets refuse to abandon him and note that he has shown much more staying power than Washington expected. In February 1989, American officials were predicting that the Najibullah Government would crumble within a few months. **********Representative Charles Wilson, a Texas Democrat who is a staunch supporter of the Afghan rebels, visited Moscow this month at the invitation of the Soviet Government, and he came back saying he would no longer insist on military victory for the Afghan guerrillas. **********Mr. Wilson once explained that he wanted to help the rebels in Afghanistan because ''it's the only place in the world where we are killing Russians.'' But in an interview this week, he said: ''The trip to Moscow softened me. I got a better understanding and appreciation and sympathy for the Soviet position. I saw what a God-awful mess they're in. My No. 1 objective now is a negotiated solution.'' **********''The mujahedeen have got to be more flexible,'' Mr. Wilson said, using the Arabic word for holy warriors, as the Afghan rebels style themselves. ''It's not desirable now for anybody to be hanging from lampposts.'' **********The Congressman said he detected ''some flexibility in the Soviet position'' and ''an extreme desire on their part to get this irritation out of the way.'' **********Objections to Najibullah **********Richard N. Haass, director of Near East and South Asian affairs at the National Security Council, said the Afghan guerrillas ''will not sit down and talk with or work with Najibullah'' because he is ''seen as being responsible for too much destruction and devastation.'' Mr. Najibullah is associated with the Soviet invaders of Afghanistan and ''has lost political legitimacy,'' he said. **********''The Soviets have only departed Afghanistan in form, not fact,'' Mr. Haass asserted. ''What enables Najibullah and his associates to hang on is Soviet military and economic assistance, now estimated at $250 million to $300 million a month,'' or $3 billion to $3.6 billion a year. **********American military aid to the Afghan guerrillas is estimated to have totalled $600 million last year, but the exact figure is a secret. **********The departure of Soviet troops from Afghanistan ''does not provide much opportunity for cheering,'' Mr. Haass said. ''The fighting and the suffering continue. Afghans continue to die. More than three million Afghans remain refugees in Pakistan.'' **********Mr. Haass said that ''Najibullah and his closest associates will have to agree to transfer political power as part of a process leading to a settlement.'' Beyond that, he said, ''we are not wedded to any single political course or political outcome.'' **********Inflexibility Is Assailed **********Selig S. Harrison, a senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, who has followed Afghanistan for 35 years, said he was disappointed with the Administration's position, as described by Mr. Haass. ''It does not indicate any flexibility on a key issue: support for the U.N. as a vehicle for bringing about a political settlement,'' Mr. Harrison said. **********Nor, he said, does the Administration show any willingness to halt arms deliveries to the guerrillas in return for Moscow's willingness to halt military aid to the Kabul Government. **********The United States supports the rebels' government-in-exile based in Pakistan. **********''In effect,'' Mr. Harrison said, ''the United States is hostage to Pakistan's policy, which is to stall movement toward a political solution until the Afghan interim government becomes capable of prosecuting the war more successfully. That means indefinite American involvement in the Afghan civil war because the interim government was created under Pakistani sponsorship and is seen by many Afghans as a Pakistani tool.'' **********State Department officials said they were encouraged by reports of serious rifts in the Afghan armed forces and the recent defection of more than two dozen Afghan Army officers. Such reports emerged last month after many officers, including several generals, were arrested for plotting against the Kabul Government. **********But the Washington policy suffered a setback this week when France announced plans to reopen its embassy in Kabul, becoming the first Western power to be represented in the Afghan capital since the Soviet pullout last February. The United States has encouraged the diplomatic isolation of the Najibullah Government.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/18/world.main_headline: Elated Sandinistas, Ending Strike, Declare Victory Over Chamorro
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/18/world.print_headline: Elated Sandinistas, Ending Strike, Declare Victory Over Chamorro
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/18/world.body_text: **********Jubilant leaders of the opposition Sandinista Front declared victory today in a weeklong Civil Service strike that ended late Wednesday with broad Government concessions to Sandinista-led unions. **********Asserting that the unions had taught the Government ''a lesson in maturity and flexibility,'' the Sandinista party newspaper, Barricada, warned that the Sandinista workers were prepared to take similar action whenever needed to oppose future Government policies. **********''If the Government wants social stability,'' the newspaper said today, ''it must act with more responsibility rather than launching new attacks against the workers.'' **********Diplomats and politicians here said the strike and its outcome represented an serious blow to the prestige of the new Government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, which had declared the strike ''illegal and nonexistent'' just three days ago. **********Cardinal's Intervention Asked **********The declarations also added new force to Sandinista demands that Mrs. Chamorro accept a ''dialogue'' with Sandinista leaders on issues ranging from the restoration of land confiscated by the former Sandinista Government to the annulment of legislation rushed through in its last days. **********On Wednesday, the Sandinista leader, Daniel Ortega Saavedra, who was defeated by Mrs. Chamorro in elections Feb. 25, asked Nicaragua's Roman Catholic Primate, Miguel Cardinal Obando y Bravo, to help arrange negotiations between Mr. Ortega and Mrs. Chamorro's Government. ''We are not interested in overthrowing this Government,'' Mr. Ortega said. ''On the contrary, we are interested in stability. But the President is acting in a unilateral fashion, not taking the people into account but instead acting against them.'' **********In declaring their strike last week, the Sandinista-led Government workers' unions demanded salary increases of 200 percent and restoration of a disputed law that would give sweeping job protections to the Government work force. **********Protection for Workers **********The law, which was suspended last week by Mrs. Chamorro, was approved by Sandinista leaders after their election defeat but before their departure from office on April 25, and would protect even high-ranking Sandinista bureaucrats from dismissal from their jobs. **********Mrs. Chamorro's Minister of Labor, Francisco Rosales Arguello, declared the strike illegal and threatened to dismiss any workers who did not return to their jobs by Tuesday morning. But striking workers ignored the ultimatum, locking Government ministers out of their offices and paralyzing everything from telephone service to state-run banks, airports, border crossings and public transportation. **********On Tuesday, riot policemen were deployed near Government buildings as the Government apparently considered whether to try to dislodge the strikers. But in the settlement announced Wednesday night, the Government ultimately chose to placate the strikers by accepting significant concessions on virtually every major issue. **********Under the terms of the accord, the Government agreed to approve an across-the-board salary increase of 25 percent, which, when applied after an earlier raise of 60 percent approved early last week, amounts to a total increase of 100 percent in Government salaries in the month of May. **********The agreement stipulates that the Government must immediately reinstate any workers dismissed in violation of the suspended Civil Service law. The Government is also obliged to proceed with enforcement of the law on the basis of new negotiations between the Ministry of Labor and the Sandinista unions. **********Mr. Rosales and other Government officials defended the accord as a victory of negotiation over confrontation, asserting, in the words of the Labor Minister, that Nicaragua's fledgling democracy ''is not a fiction.'' **********Aid Bill Advances **********WASHINGTON, May 17 (Special to The New York Times) - Congress made progress today toward approval of a bill that provides emergency aid for Panama and Nicaragua. House and Senate negotiatiors agreed to remove abortion and death penalty provisions from the bill, clearing the way for a final compromise on the measure. **********The bill, which provides $420 million for Panama and $300 million for Nicaragua, has been delayed for months while lawmakers debated those two provisions and more than $1 billion in unrelated spending for domestic programs. **********The negotiators hope to complete their work on Friday, but final passage of the bill still depends on resolution of yet another dispute involving military aid to El Salvador.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/28/busin.main_headline: The Executive Computer; Will Next Inc.'s New Machines Find a Place in the Market?
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/28/busin.print_headline: The Executive Computer; Will Next Inc.'s New Machines Find a Place in the Market?
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/28/busin.body_text: **********TWO years after its first machines generated a lot of light but little heat, Next Inc. has completely overhauled its high-performance, Unix-based personal computers. The new machines will be available next month, with color versions delayed until early next year, and Next showed them off earlier this month at the Seybold Seminars electronic publishing exposition in San Jose, Calif. **********The heavy crowds at the Next booth were evidence that the company retains its exotic cachet, even though analysts say fewer than 10,000 Next machines were sold in the company's first two years. Yet whether these new computers have a chance of capturing a significant share of the business computer marketplace is far from clear. **********"The real question is, 'What are the chances for Next as a company?' " said Patricia Seybold, chief executive of the Patricia Seybold Office Computing Group of Boston. "The information community is somewhat skeptical at this point." **********The skepticism arises from early disappointments, all the more striking because expectations were unrealistically high, it is now clear, in part because of the reputation of Steven P. Jobs, Next's founder and chief executive, who had been a founder of Apple Computer Inc. The original Next computer was a dazzling technical showcase, featuring optical disk drives, multimedia integration, digital signal processors, a beautiful graphical interface that hid Unix from the user and other "gee whiz" components. But it simply did not work well enough or have enough uses to attract corporate customers. Many companies bought a Next machine, praised it for its potential and good looks and spent their big dollars on other computers. **********The problems with the first Next machine were that it was too expensive, lacked color, was slow, had nonstandard disk drives and was difficult to integrate into existing PC networks. What is more, there were no compelling software applications to entice potential business customers to buy more than one. **********Mr. Jobs is typically portrayed as a charismatic but tempermental genius who clings zealously to his design ideals. But the new Next work stations reveal him to be a pragmatist above all else. He and his engineers have addressed each shortcoming of the original Next computer. **********The new Next machines are very aggressively priced, starting as low as $4,995. The 16- and 32-bit color options with high-resolution color screens promise to be dazzling. The new Motorola 68040 microprocessor, as well as a revved-up version of the system software, greatly improve performance. The optical drive of the original is now an option, and magnetic diskette and mass storage drives are now standard. Industry-standard 10BaseT Ethernet networking is built in. And new software fromthe Lotus Development Corporation and the Wordperfect Corporation finally gives the Next machines a practical use in businesses. **********Some major customers apparently believe the machine is worth buying. Mr. Jobs said Next had already received orders for 15,000 new computers, more than twice its installed base. Among the companies identified as customers were Bozell, the New York-based advertising agency; the First Boston Corporation, which plans to use the machines for an equities trading system; O'Connor & Associates, a Chicago options and futures trading firm, and several small universities. **********The new computers have a floppy disk drive, although, in keeping with the exotic image of the machine, these are 2.88 megabyte drives, in contrast to the 1.44 drives used by all other high-end personal computers. The new drives will be able read data written on the more conventional 720K, 1.44 MB, MS-DOS and Unix-formatted disks. The machines are the first to use the new Motorola 68040 microprocessor, a powerhouse that is reported to be in short supply after manufacturing problems. While Apple Computer declared its plans to incorporate the 68040 into its line next year, Next got a head start. **********The familiar black "cube" design of the Next computer is still in the line, but there is also a sleek new "pizza box" design called the Nextstation. Next says the Nextstation performs 15 million instructions a second, and 2.8 million floating point operations a second -- performance that would put it on a par with the Sun Microsystems' Sparcstation 1+. And those two machines would be a level ahead of the new computers that use the Intel Corporation's 80486 microprocessor, like those made by Advanced Logic Research, Northgate Computer Systems and AST Research, as well as the most powerful personal computers made by I.B.M., Compaq and Apple. **********The Nextstation comes with eight megabytes of random access memory, a 105-megabyte magnetic hard disk and the high-capacity floppy disk drive (the optical drive is optional). The list price of $4,995 includes a 17-inch Megapixel monochrome display that has a resolution of 1,120 dots horizontally by 832 vertically. With all that, the Next machine is thousands of dollars less expensive than its closest rivals. **********For those who want color, the Nextstation color system uses 12 megabytes of memory and a 16-inch color display, also with a million pixels. It will cost $7,995 when it becomes available early next year. The original cube computer has been officially named the Nextcube; it also boasts the 68040 chip and the new floppy drive. Owners of the original cube can upgrade their machines to 68040 power for $1,495. **********But for all the impressive features, "it may be too little too late," said Ms. Seybold. "The people I talk to in large corporations are in charge of establishing information superstructures and enterprise-wide computing. Yes, they have Unix work stations, but the Next machines never come up in any of these strategic discussions." **********Next's problem is that in the two years that the company spent revising its product line, Sun, International Business Machines, Apple, Hewlett-Packard and others have been pushing ahead, and they may well be hot on the heels of Next's new machines. **********The key to acceptance is probably software. Of all the applications demonstrated at the Seybold show, Lotus's Improv was the most impressive. Promised for delivery late this year or early next year, at a price of $695, Improv allows the user to deal with the spreadsheet in English-language formulas that are separate from the data. The program's ability to separate the data from the commands that act on them allows users to manipulate and view the numbers in ways that no other personal computer spreadsheet can match. Lotus says it will tuck a free copy of Improv into the box of each new Next machine. And Wordperfect of Orem, Utah, has demonstrated a version of Wordperfect for Next. People who have seen it say it takes impressive advantage of the Next machines.
