https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/10/world.body_text: **********'Apartheid Is Dying' **********''There are some who argue now that since apartheid is dying, our job as Democrats is done,'' Mr. de Beer said. **********''Well, my friends, I don't know how you feel, but I'm certainly not inclined to leave democracy in the hands only of the Nats and the A.N.C.,'' he said, referring to the National Party and the Congress. **********Mr. de Beer, a legislator who once served as a director of the Anglo-American Corporation, was elected the party's new national chairman Friday evening, defeating a fellow Member of Parliament, Tian van der Merwe, by 274 to 195 votes. **********Mr. de Beer, who is 62 years old, was one of the three leaders chosen when the Democratic Party constituted itself from the old Progressive Federal Party in April 1989, in an arrangement that reflected efforts to bring together supporters of the Progressive Federal Party, independent English-speaking liberals and younger Afrikaners uncomfortable with the National Party. **********But this solution was also viewed as manifesting the new party's vacillation and lack of cohesion. One of the three leaders, Wynand Malan, resigned from the party in July. Another, Denis Worrall, a former South African Ambassador to Britain, decided not to run for the leadership, although he remains a Member of Parliament. **********Gains in 1989 Vote **********The Democratic Party picked up 11 seats from the National Party in the parliamentary elections held among whites last September for a total of 33 seats in the white chamber of Parliament, the House of Assembly, with 21 percent of the white vote. **********As Mr. de Klerk shifted his party closer to the Democratic Party, some Democratic voters moved to support him, if only to fend off the right-wing Conservative Party, which won 31 percent of the white vote and remain the official opposition in Parliament. **********In a by-election in June, the National Party retained the Natal blue-collar constituency of Umlazi because voters crossed over from the Democratic Party to defeat the Conservatives. **********Saturday, Mr. de Beer said the party would ask the Government to ''open up the negotiation process more widely to include us'' and would also renew a separate dialogue with the African National Congress. **********Dual Membership Forbidden **********But the party amended its constitution to forbid any member from belonging to other political organizations without the consent of the party'e policy-setting National Council. The decision, which angered some delegates, appeared intended to stop white party members from joining the African National Congress, while leaving the option open for those of other races who joined the Democratic Party. **********''Discipline in a party is not reconcilable with dual membership,'' Mr. de Beer said on Saturday. ''We may be able to live with a few who join other parties, but not with those who advocate different policies to ours.'' **********While both organizations oppose apartheid, the Democratic Party believes that change can be achieved though parliamentary means, while the African National Congress has rejected Parliament as currently constituted because it excludes blacks. The Democratic Party also endorses a free market economy with a role for big business; the Congress's economic platform has called for the nationalization of major economic sectors and redistribution of wealth. **********Mr. de Beer also said that the Congress's longstanding alliance with the South African Communist Party ''simply has to be clarified and indeed terminated.'' **********David Dalling, a Member of Parliament from Sandton in Johannesburg's northern suburbs, proposed that the party look beyond its white membership to forge a multi-racial pact with the African National Congress, the foremost black anti-apartheid group. **********But Harry Schwartz, who represents the Johannesburg suburb of Yeoville in Parliament, expressed his concern that ''we do not at this stage of our party's history sacrifice the principles for which we have walked in the wilderness, for the sake of being winners.'' While he knew and liked Nelson Mandela, Mr. Schwartz said, ''that does not mean I must join the A.N.C. or form a pact with the A.N.C.'' **********Excerpts from the debate were circulated by the South African Press Association.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/29/world.body_text: **********A mine exploded during a United States Army training exercise today, and 10 American soldiers were wounded, two seriously, a military spokesman said. Lieut. Col. Jim Gleisberg, spokesman for the VII Corps, said the accident occurred at the rural Wildflecken training area, 55 miles east of Frankfurt.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/06/busin.body_text: **********Savings and loan regulators are moving to ease a controversial new lending regulation after builders complained it was unfairly choking off their credit, an official said today. **********The Office of Thrift Supervision has proposed a temporary increase in the limit on how much a savings institution may lend to one borrower, said an agency official who spoke on condition of anonymity. **********Last year's saving and loan legislation had sharply reduced the limit, aiming to end the cozy relationship between high-flying savings institutions and some builders. In the past, loan limits were so high that the default of a single loan could bankrupt some institutions. **********But builders complained that the shift was too abrupt and that many reputable builders were left without financing for sound projects. Last month, the National Association of Homebuilders cited the regulation as one element in a credit crunch that they predicted would cut housing construction nationally by 100,000 units, to 1.28 million this year. **********Under a draft regulation, the strongest savings institutions would be allowed to lend up to 60 percent of their capital to a single American developer for single-family house and apartment construction. **********That is four times the 15 percent limit imposed by bailout legislation enacted last August. The limit would drop to 30 percent before returning to the 15 percent mark at the end of 1991.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/11/world.main_headline: Evolution in Europe;   CONFRONTING FOES, GORBACHEV KEEPS PARTY LEADERSHIP
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/11/world.print_headline: Evolution in Europe;   CONFRONTING FOES, GORBACHEV KEEPS PARTY LEADERSHIP
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/11/world.body_text: **********Mikhail S. Gorbachev swept confidently to re-election as head of the Communist Party today, after confronting the party's hard-liners with a militant defense of the changes he has ignited in his society. **********The party's nationwide congress chose Mr. Gorbachev, who is also President of the Soviet Union, overwhelmingly over the only other candidate who stayed in the race, a Western Siberian party official best known for helping lead a coal mine strike a year ago. **********Before the voting today, Mr. Gorbachev shed his conciliatory tone and lashed out in a fighting speech at hard-liners who had vociferously criticized his economic and foreign policies at the congress. **********'No Way to Bring Back the Past' **********Either they must learn to live with liberty and the free competition of ideas, or the party is doomed, he declared, adding that the party is now in crisis because it has moved too slowly toward democracy and a market economy. **********''There is no way to bring back the past, and no dictatorship - if someone still entertains this crazy idea - will solve anything,'' he thundered. **********Although the congress is to continue for a few more days, Mr. Gorbachev seemed to have it now firmly in hand and appeared to have headed off for now any danger of a major split in the party. **********He has forcefully tamed the hard-liners and then, with his speech today, reached out to party radicals who want even faster change in hopes of keeping them from deserting the party in huge numbers. **********Holding Two Posts Criticized **********Senior party leaders said today that there was little doubt Mr. Gorbachev's choice for the important new post of deputy party leader would be elected. He is said to have settled on Vladimir A. Ivashko, the centrist leader of the Communist Party in the Ukraine, the second largest Soviet republic. **********Despite outspoken criticism and some calls for him to step down, in the end Mr. Gorbachev easily won his new term as General Secretary - the first time the post has been filled by a nationwide party convention rather than by a secretive circle of top leaders. **********The main argument used against him today was that it was time for him to chose between the two important jobs he holds - President of the country, and General Secretary of the party. **********Mr. Gorbachev and his supporters conceded that the combination of jobs should eventually be phased out, but not until the more democratic new government structures are firmly in place. **********Elected With 3,411 Votes **********He was elected with 3,411 votes, to 501 votes for Teimuraz G. Avaliani, a party official from the mining center of Kiselyovsk in the Kuznetsk coal basin. Voting against both candidates were 615 other delegates. **********Six other candidates were nominated from the floor, most of them close associates of Mr. Gorbachev, but they withdrew. **********Mr. Avaliani, a self-educated mining engineer, was summoned by the K.G.B. in 1978 and accused of slander after he wrote a letter to Leonid I. Brezhnev, who was then the Soviet leader, condemning his handling of the economy. **********Mr. Avaliani, who was not identified with either the hard-line or radical factions, was elected a local party official after helping lead the strike that made coalfields idle last summer. **********Sympathetic Toward Miners **********Today he expressed sympathy with the miners, who have scheduled a one-day protest strike Wednesday to demand better living conditions and the resignation of the Government. But he also warned: ''The endless rocking of our already leaky and unstable boat -and I mean the economy - will get us nowhere.'' **********Neither the hard-liners or the party radicals put up a candidate to challenge Mr. Gorbachev. **********Leading conservatives in the party had already endorsed Mr. Gorbachev, fearing that otherwise he would swing to the radical camp and leave them with nothing. **********Yegor K. Ligachev, the foremost hard-liner in the Politburo, had hinted that he might be available for some senior party post, but no one nominated him for the top job. Senior party officials said that, at 69, Mr. Ligachev's political career was probably now over. **********Radical Faction a Minority **********''Rumors of the conservativism of the delegates were a bit exaggerated,'' said Yuri A. Prokofiev, the Moscow party leader. **********The faction calling for more sweeping moves toward democracy and free markets was a tiny minority of the congress delegates from the outset. After their favorite, Aleksandr N. Yakovlev, a close ally of Mr. Gorbachev, declined to be nominated, some of the more radical delegates voted for Mr. Gorbachev while others scratched out the names of both candidates. **********Anatoly A. Sobchak, the chairman of the newly democratized Leningrad City Council, said he voted against Mr. Gorbachev on the theory that if he lost, he could devote himself to the presidency without being held back by the party. **********''The fact that Gorbachev will still keep the position of party leader will not speed up this process of transfering power to the Governement and re-creating a state, but it will slow this process down,'' he told reporters. ''It will keep this party in power, along with its traditional forms and methods of working.'' **********Mr. Gorbachev's fiery speech today was clearly designed to prevent the defection of popular figures like Mr. Sobchak, which could further diminish the party's electoral appeal. **********Rejects Slow Approach **********Mr. Gorbachev said that while many party leaders were stunned and confused by the new liberties, the party's greatest failing was that it was too slow to recognize the need to abandon the centralized economy and the danger of long-suppressed ethnic grievances. **********Echoing a warning issued last week by Boris N. Yeltsin, the populist president of the Russian republic, Mr. Gorbachev said the congress had shown how many Communist leaders are out of touch with the times. **********''If any of the delegates, and going by the speeches there are some such delegates among us, came to the Congress hoping to take the party back to the old conditions of commands and orders, I must say they are deeply mistaken,'' he said. **********He called on them to stop using authoritarian methods to frustrate the work of elected Government bodies, and to enter coalitions with non-Communist parties and political organizations. **********'Do You Want Tanks Again?' **********''We must put an end to sectarian moods, put an end to this monopoly forever, erase its vestiges from the mind of party workers and all Communists,'' he said. **********''Believe me, the party's success depends on whether it realizes that this is already a different society. Otherwise it will be pushed to the margin by other forces, and we shall lose ground.'' **********Implicitly confronting the military officers who have challenged his handling of foreign policy, Mr. Gorbachev warned that those who work for the state must carry out Government policies or resign. **********''People ask if our policy not to interfere in the processes in Eastern Europe was correct,'' he added. ''Well, do you want tanks again? Shall we teach them again how to live?'' **********Questions on Policies **********Answering charges that he had let allowed Communism to founder in Eastern Europe, Mr. Gorbachev issued a blunt warning to ''those who occupy important posts in the state and are directly related to our international activity.'' **********''The President and the Government cannot have one policy and someone else has another and pursues it,'' he said. ''This does not happen in any state. All officials must be loyal to the Government. And if they are decent people and they disagree with Government policy, they must resign.'' **********Party officials said today that Mr. Gorbachev's remarks would not prevent a continued drop in membership, but the party would weather this decline. **********''Is it necessary that the party consist of 19 million members?'' said Mr. Ivashko, the leading candidate for the new number two post. ''And what if there were only 15 million?'' **********Mr. Sobchak, one of several prominent public figures who are contemplating leaving the party, said: ''His speech today was great, but it should have been made a year ago.'' **********Party officials said the congress, scheduled to end Thursday, might spill over to Friday or Saturday. Besides electing Mr. Gorbachev's deputy, who will shoulder much of the day-to-day management of the party, the congress is to adopt a platform and elect a new Central Committee, the party's regular governing body.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/22/world.main_headline: Upheaval in the East: East Germany;   East German Party Purges Ex-Leaders
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/22/world.print_headline: Upheaval in the East: East Germany;   East German Party Purges Ex-Leaders
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/22/world.body_text: **********Faced with growing rebellion and defections in its ranks over the slowness of internal change, leaders of East Germany's Communist Party decided after an emergency session that ended early today to purge several more former leaders, but rejected calls that it dissolve altogether. **********Those expelled included Egon Krenz, who took over as party chief in October after Erich Honecker fell and was himself replaced in December, and 13 other former Politburo members. **********No sooner was the meeting over than the party was rocked anew, this time by the defection of 40 party members in Dresden led by Wolfgang Berghofer, the liberal mayor and a vice chairman of the party since it ousted its old leadership in December. The group said it would support social democracy but would not run in the May elections. **********A Liberal Communist **********Mr. Berghofer, a close ally of Prime Minister Hans Modrow, was one of the liberal Communists who had led the movement for change last fall. Though he subsequently declined the party leadership, he played a major role in trying to change it and was a leading figure in the round-table talks between the Communists and the opposition. **********In a letter to Gregor Gysi, the lawyer who took charge of the Communist Party in December, Mr. Berghofer said he had concluded that the party could not get rid of its past and so could not be a credible source of renewal. Any attempt to take a new path with the old party would only increase the popular suspicion that it was trying to get back to power, he said. **********Mr. Gysi acknowledged the resignation with ''deep regret.'' **********New Wave of Discontent **********The buffeting of the party reflected a new wave of discontent that has swept the country since the New Year, prompted by revelations that the Communist-led interim government had tried to revive the security apparatus under a new name and by accusations that it was trying to undermine opposition movements and parties. **********The disaffection has been demonstrated in the resignation of more than a million members of the party, reducing its strength from 2.4 million to about 1.2 million. In the general public it has found expression in wildcat strikes, increasingly angry demonstrations and a continuing flight of almost 2,000 East Germans daily to West Germany. **********The Communists called the weekend meeting after dissident members from East Berlin's Humboldt University, the Academy of Sciences and other institutions called for the party's dissolution on the grounds that it had become a ''security risk.'' The meeting was closed, but the fact that it lasted 15 hours and ended only after midnight indicated a heated battle between dissident members and Mr. Gysi. **********Decision Not to Disband **********At the end, Mr. Gysi acknowledged that the party had failed to rid itself of its Stalinist past in the five weeks since he took charge. But he said that ''after long, mature and sometimes controversial debate, the party's ruling council decided that disbanding would lead to greater social tension, not less.'' **********At the same time, the leaders agreed to several measures intended to satisfy the internal critics. Most significant were the purge and a proposal that Prime Minister Modrow, a Communist, offer to give the 15 seats the party now holds on the 27-member interim Cabinet to the opposition. **********There was no immediate comment from Mr. Modrow, and it was not likely that the ill-organized opposition would agree to take charge of the Government until after elections scheduled for May 6. **********The party also announced plans to move up a party congress, now scheduled for mid-March, and at that time to change its name from Socialist Unity Party-Party of Democratic Socialism - the clumsy double title assumed in December - to simply Party of Democratic Socialism. **********The announcement of the expulsions of former party leaders was published without explanation by the official press agency, A.D.N., which said only that ''every decision was conscientiously examined.'' **********But it seems clear that the party leadership was trying to answer charges that it has been slow to cleanse its ranks, especially of those who had run the country until street demonstrations and mass emigration forced the old guard to surrender power last October. **********'New Image' Leaders Ousted **********Those ousted included several former Politburo members who had led the first effort to present a new image of the party and had gone so far as to open the Berlin wall to convince the nation of their good intentions. **********Most notable among these was Mr. Krenz himself. The 53-year-old politician, who had been charged with overseeing the security apparatus under Mr. Honecker and was considered the former leader's preferred heir, had tried in his two months in power to portray himself as the leader of a reformed party. **********In an interview with the West German tabloid Bild, Mr. Krenz complained that he had been given no credit for leading the change. ''What I did for the change counted for nothing,'' he said. ''We were all measured with the same yardstick as Honecker.'' **********Mr. Krenz has said he initiated the change of direction in East Germany by personally countermanding an order by Mr. Honecker for the police to fire on a demonstration in Leipzig on Oct. 9. The demonstrators were not interfered with, and soon Mr. Honecker was toppled. **********Mr. Krenz's future remains uncertain. In the Bild interview, he was quoted as saying: ''Finding another job is difficult. I will probably become a writer.'' **********Those ousted with Mr. Krenz included Gunter Schabowski, the East Berlin party leader who announced the opening of the border on Nov. 9, and Heinz Kessler, the former Defense Minister. Mr. Gysi said he expected more party members to be purged. **********The turmoil in East Germany was not limited to the Communists, as other parties also began to position themselves for the May 6 vote, the state's first free election. **********One persistent threat was that the interim government under Mr. Modrow could fall if some of the smaller parties traditionally associated with the Communists pulled out to assert their independence. **********Last week, both the Liberal Democrats and the Christian Democrats considered pulling out but decided against it. The Christian Democrats in particular have been under pressure to assume a new image and then to seek support from their namesake in West Germany, Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democratic Union.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/07/world.main_headline: Oil Price, a New Blow to Central Americans
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/07/world.print_headline: Oil Price, a New Blow to Central Americans
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/07/world.body_text: **********The crisis in the Middle East has set off a new round of inflation throughout Central America, wreaking havoc with ambitious economic development efforts and threatening to plunge the region into a full depression. **********Government and economic development officials throughout the region -- which imports nearly all its crude oil, about 130,000 barrels a day from Mexico and Venezuela -- are warning that the crisis could set off new social instability and reverse the region's tentative progress toward democracy."Many things are endangered by this type of crisis, even democracy," said Roberto Dobles, a Costa Rican petroleum expert and former executive president of the national refinery, Recope. "Make no mistake," he added, "the crisis in the gulf affects even the level of crime in the streets." **********The rise in crude oil prices has broken budgets throughout the financially strapped region. In several of Central America's five main countries, the unexpected costs total one-fifth of public spending. **********"We have several choices to make, but obviously we have to increase revenues, which may result in less growth," said Ernesto Altschul, an economist and El Salvador's Vice Minister of the Presidency. "We will have to raise taxes and make some cuts. But we have just barely kept up, nominally kept up with social programs, so our room to cut is very limited." **********One after another, the region's five governments have been forced to impose strict austerity programs. All have sharply raised gasoline prices, provoking an immediate inflationary surge and widespread protests. Honduras and Costa Rica have also announced plans to lay off thousands of public employees and have warned of further cutbacks, like gas rationing. Guatemala, the only country in the region to produce any crude oil, has restricted firefighters to responding "to urgent emergencies" and despite rising crime has cut back on national police patrols and other operations. **********"There is no question they will be hit hard," said Alfredo Milian, a former Salvadoran diplomat who is now an associate at International Business and Economic Research Corporation, a Washington-based business consultant group that specializes in Central America. "It will hit everything from cement plants to sugar processing to transportation." **********The jump in oil prices comes at a particularly difficult moment for Central America. Throughout the region, revolution, counterrevolution, civil war and incompetent leadership have led to a decade of uninterrupted recession and a plunge in the standard of living. **********In the last two years, center rightists have been elected in all of the region's five countries. They have promised economic reform through privatization and the free market. But now their plans have run aground because of the gulf crisis. One after another, the region's governments have been forced to delay or cut back on plans to remove subsidies, balance their budgets and control inflation. **********The effect of the oil price increases is aggravated by widespread energy inefficiencies. Most third world countries produce much less per unit of energy than industrialized nations. A Costa Rican refrigerator, for instance, uses four times as much electricity as the average Japanese unit. As a result, growth is very expensive -- a 2 percent increase in oil imports for every one percent jump in gross domestic product, Mr. Dobles estimated. "We need oil for economic growth, but we cannot afford to pay for it," he said. **********The Salvadoran Government estimates the crisis will add almost 5 percentage points to the rate of inflation. Honduras has estimated that it will increase inflation by 10 points to almost 35 percent. **********Already the Honduran Government has doubled the price of fertilizer, raising the cost of food, and raised cement prices by 70 percent, a blow to the vital construction industry. The Government now says it will soon be forced to close some schools and cut back on other essential services. **********"We are going to have to make many sacrifices for an economic recovery," said Ramon Medina Luna, the Minister of the Economy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/27/world.main_headline: Fear Enters Israeli City After a Terrorist Attack
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/27/world.print_headline: MIDEAST TENSIONS; Fear Enters Israeli City After a Terrorist Attack
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/27/world.body_text: **********In some ways, this city has been an optimist's vision of Israel's future in the midst of its present: a growing Jewish community, sharing quiet borders with Jordan and Egypt, untroubled by political strife or nationalist bloodshed. **********But events seemed to catch up with Eilat when Kathy Waxman's 8-year-old son left school on Sunday. The boy's teacher told the pupils to run straight home because an Arab gunman had killed four Israelis just outside of town that morning and might still be at large. **********"The kids put rocks in their pockets to throw in case an Arab came near them," Mrs. Waxman recalled this afternoon. Selling newspapers in the downtown bookstore where she works, she shook her head. "That's unbelievable," she said. "That's so strange for Eilat."  Distrust and Fear **********Most people in this small resort on the Gulf of Aqaba have for years marveled from afar at the suspicion and animosity between Arabs and Jews that is so common elsewhere in Israel. But now, for the first time, many of them have their own small stories of distrust, anxiety and fear. **********Eilat was quiet, calm and sunny today, and groups of lean athletes jogged around town preparing for the city's annual triathlon. Still, everywhere in this community of 28,000, Israelis were talking about the Arab gunman's infiltration from Egypt and the four local men he killed. **********It was the first attack of its kind in the Eilat area. All the victims, three army officers and a public bus driver, lived here. They died when the gunman, believed to be an Egyptian, crossed the border about 10 miles from Eilat and opened fire with an assault rifle on vehicles that came along the highway near the border, killing the 4 and wounding 26 Israelis.   Comments From Shamir **********Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today that Israel would "demand from the Governments of our border states -- Egypt and Jordan -- to insure that these types of attacks do not recur." **********But the Government also took pains to indicate that Egypt was not to blame for the attack. Mr. Shamir said: "We are sure that this action was not done with Egypt's consent. It was done in opposition to Egyptian policy." **********This afternoon, Israel agreed to allow a group of Egyptian Army officers investigating the shooting to come to Eilat and interview witnesses. The Egyptians will also visit the site of the shooting on the highway outside of town. It will be the first time Egyptian officers conduct such an investigation in Israel.  Far From the Uprising **********Eilat is separated from most of Israel by the vast Negev desert. There are no indigenous Palestinian communities anywhere nearby. For three years, Eilat has calmly watched from afar as the Palestinian uprising raged in the occupied territories and Jerusalem residents became accustomed to political stabbings, arson and revenge attacks by both Palestinians and Israelis. **********The city has been so removed from Israel's political problems, in fact, that local Government and tourism officials promote it in Europe as "Eilat on the Red Sea." They deliberately omit Israel's name from advertisements so the resort will not be associated with the turmoil elsewhere. **********Eilat's Mayor, Avi Hochman, continued to insist today that the bloodshed on the outskirts of the city had nothing to do with Eilat. **********"It didn't happen in Eilat," Mr. Hochman averred. "It happened on the road between Taba and Rafia. If the men killed had not been Eilat citizens, this would not have affected Eilat at all." **********Other Eilat residents were not so blithe. They were concerned and upset by the deaths and the introduction of terrorism to Eilat. **********"One of the men who died came in every day to buy a newspaper," Mrs. Waxman said. There was a run on papers this morning by Israelis eager to read about the attack. **********The bookstore is on Hamaterim Street, the main commerical avenue running through the middle of Eilat. City Hall is on the same street, and opposite it are a department store and cultural center.  Concerns Are Realized **********"We always felt detached from the rest of the country, and we hoped the problems wouldn't come down here," Mrs. Waxman said. "But in the back of my mind, I thought something could happen, and that the probability is greater now than ever before." **********Still, most Eilat residents seem to fear random attacks like the shootings rather than the entrenched street violence common in Jerusalem. Many believe that since Palestinians who work in Eilat are strictly controlled, there is no chance for the uprising to take hold in this city. **********"Lots of Arabs work here, and they all have permits to enter the city and sleep here," said 32-year-old Yossi Morad, sitting outside the department store. "They have to pass through roadblocks on the highways and show these permits." **********"This is a small town; everyone knows where the Arabs live, and we can kick them out," he added. "If anything happened there is nowhere for an Arab to run." **********Up the street, three teen-age boys crossed the cultural center's wooded grounds. They wore light-blue T-shirts, Israel's school uniform. **********"We don't have the problems here like they do in Jerusalem," said Itamar Amer, a ninth grader whose uncle was on a bus that was attacked but was not wounded. "They're close to the Gaza Strip and West Bank." **********"We're afraid, sure," he added. "There could be other terrorists in Israel." **********<HB<No Details on Killer **********CAIRO, Nov. 26 (Special to The New York Times) -- Egypt withheld all details today about the identity and mission of a conscript soldier it said it arrested on Sunday for crossing into Israel in Sinai and killing four Israelis by shooting at a bus and other vehicles. **********The Egyptian Foreign Minister, Esmat Abdel-Meguid, said on Sunday that the border killings were "very regrettable" and promised a detailed investigation. But Egyptian Interior Ministry officials said they would make no comment on the attack. **********In Amman, Jordan, a group calling itself Islamic Holy War of Jerusalem took responsibility for the attack. It said in a statement that Egypt had arrested the conscript wrongfully.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/19/world.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;   European Assembly Urges Grant to Armenia
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/19/world.body_text: **********The European Parliament urged the European Community today to grant emergency aid to Armenia and the Nagorno-Karabakh region in Azerbaijan, but did not specify an amount. **********It also suggested that the 12 nations send a fact-finding mission to the region in the southern Soviet Union. **********In a resolution backed by almost all political groups in the 518-seat assembly, the Parliament called on the Soviet Government to order an end to the blockade of Armenia and Nagorno-Karabakh and to guarantee the safety of people there. **********Parliamentarians said they were concerned that ''repeated threats of secession'' would have dire consequences on the ''budding process of democratization in the Soviet Union.'' https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/22/world.main_headline: Contras' Statements in Conflict on Disarming
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/22/world.print_headline: Contras' Statements in Conflict on Disarming
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/22/world.body_text: **********The demobilization of the contra army remained clouded by confusion today amid conflicting declarations about whether guerrilla commanders would fulfill their commitments to disband their army. **********On Friday, the senior contra commander, Israel Galeano Cornejo, known as Commander Franklin, issued a statement that the rebel army had stopped giving up its arms to international authorities because of continuing political unrest in the country. **********But Government officials in charge of negotiating with the rebel forces said that his declaration had been ''invalidated'' and that they had been assured by contra commanders that the scheduled demobilization would continue as agreed under accords signed by the Government and rebel negotiators. **********Foreign officials and diplomats familiar with the dispute said the confusion had apparently been compounded by divergent opinions among contra leaders over whether to continue with the demobilization, which was to end with the complete disarming of the rebels by June 10. They said that the declaration that the process had been suspended appeared to be intended to draw new concessions from the Government, and that it did not seem to threaten a full breakdown in the demobilization. **********In Friday's statement, the contra commanders made no suggestion that they would try to return to active combat or move their troops outside the internationally monitored security zones that have been established for them. **********Some 10,000 armed rebels are camped in the zones under demobilization accords signed since the new Government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro was elected on Feb. 25. About 1,000 contras have given their weapons to international forces since the demobilization formally started this month. **********Some reaction from the rebel army, which has sharply criticized Government concessions to the opposition Sandinista National Liberation Front, had been widely expected after the Government made broad concessions to win a settlement of a nationwide civil servants' strike led by Sandinista unions last week. **********In declaring a suspension of the demobilization, the rebel high command accused the Sandinista front of ''provoking a climate of uncertainty and social instability'' despite its electoral defeat on Feb. 25. The rebels also demanded new talks with the Government, accusing it of failing to provide enough aid and security for demobilized contras, and of permitting a ''progressive deterioration of its authority.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/08/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Sundstrand Pact With Milton Roy
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/08/busin.body_text: **********The Sundstrand Corporation reached a confidentiality and standstill agreement with the Milton Roy Company in return for access to the company's confidential financial information. Sunstrand has made an offer of $28 a share, or $160 million, for Milton Roy, a waste-water equipment manufacturer based in St. Petersburg, Fla. **********The standstill agreement was contained in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Sundstrand, a Rockford, Ill., industrial equipment concern, already controls 15 percent of Milton Roy's outstanding shares.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/07/world.main_headline: MANDELA REBUFFED BY A RIVAL GROUP
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/07/world.print_headline: MANDELA REBUFFED BY A RIVAL GROUP
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/07/world.body_text: **********In one of his first setbacks since he was released from prison last month, Nelson Mandela's effort to form a broad anti-apartheid coalition has been rebuffed by a rival South African opposition movement. **********The rival group, the Pan-Africanist Congress, flatly rejected calls by Mr. Mandela, the de facto leader of the African National Congress, to join in discussions with the Pretoria Government of President F. W. de Klerk. **********''At this stage there exists no basis for genuine negotiations with the Pretoria regime,'' the Pan-Africanist executive committee said in a communique issued Monday after a three-day conference here. **********Mandela Leaves Zimbabwe **********Mr. Mandela left Harare today after a three-day visit. He did not meet with Pan-Africanist Congress officials. **********At an airport news conference before leaving for Tanzania, Mr. Mandela avoided criticizing the Pan-Africanists' stand. **********''I cannot predict what will happen if and when we have discussions with the P.A.C.,'' he said. ''All that I can tell you is that we intend approaching all political organizations amongst the people in the country to persuade them that we should present a united front. What they do is their affair. We hope that they will regard this question in a serious light, as we do.'' **********The Pan-Africanist Congress, smaller and less influential internationally than the African National Congress, appears to have opened a rift with its chief African benefactor, President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe. He had hoped to bring the two South African groups together during Mr. Mandela's visit, but the Pan-Africanists' president, Zephania Mothopeng, declined Mr. Mugabe's invitation to attend a state banquet in Mr. Mandela's honor on Sunday night. **********'A Discordant Note' **********In a speech at the dinner, Mr. Mugabe criticized the Pan-Africanists, referring to the group's stand as ''a discordant note coming from other quarters saying that negotiations are not the correct thing today.'' **********At the airport news conference, Mr. Mugabe reiterated his backing for Mr. Mandela's efforts ''to lead a team of negotiators to the conference table to discuss a new political order in South Africa.'' **********Harare has been a center for the exiled Pan Africanists for years. Mr. Mugabe has previously stated his preference for the Pan-Africanist Congress, which envisions a more limited role for whites, especially in the ownership of land, than does the African National Congress, which calls for all the people of South Africa, regardless of color, to share political power on the basis of one person one vote. **********With the failure of his plan to bring the two groups together during Mr. Mandela's visit here, Mr. Mugabe has clearly thrown his support to the African National Congress. **********Mr. Mandela indicated the Congress is already talking with Pretoria about its demands that state of emergency regulations be lifted and that all political prisoners be released before negotiations can begin. **********''These are matters under discussion,'' Mr. Mandela said at the airport. ''I will not be surprised if we are able to reach some consensus with the Government on these two questions.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/16/world.body_text: **********In the bitterest days of the conflict between this country's former Sandinista leaders and American-backed rebels, all Nicaraguans shared one crucial piece of common ground: their reliance on the American dollar. **********Against a background of economic sanctions and hyperinflation, Sandinistas and contra supporters alike scrambled to convert their Nicaraguan cordobas to American currency. Sandinista leaders created an elaborate empire of official dollar-based stores and enterprises to help keep their cash-starved government afloat. **********Now, with the war years presumably behind it, Nicaragua's new Government is attempting to break free from the economic legacy of that chaotic era - not by breaking the country's addiction to the dollar, but by embracing it. **********Gradual Introduction **********Backed by $900 million in foreign commitments to help shore up the country's foundering economy, economic advisers to President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro have inaugurated an entirely new, convertible hard currency that is to be pegged permanently to the value of the American dollar. **********The new money, known as the gold cordoba, is being introduced gradually as a complete replacement for the current inflation-battered cordoba. Government officials say it is to be backed on a strict one-to-one basis with official dollar reserves, making it, in effect, a direct local substitute for the American bills that Nicaraguan black-marketers now wave at potential buyers on street corners throughout the country. **********In contrast to the old cordoba, which does not circulate internationally and is thus considered a ''soft'' currency, the gold cordoba is to remain freely convertible with American dollars. **********Economic Straitjacket **********The rigid, one-for-one structure would have the effect of imposing an economic straitjacket on the new government, eliminating its ability to finance its future deficits simply by printing money. But Government economists assert that such a radical, self-imposed solution is the only reliable means of choking off annual inflation that has reached as high as 36,000 percent in recent years. **********''What we want to do with the gold cordoba is to erase the memory of hyperinflation in the people's minds,'' said Francisco Mayorga Balladares, the new president of Nicaragua's central bank, who has been the driving force behind the new currency. ''No one will believe a promise to allow just a little inflation. If you want to convince people in a country like this, you have to have a firm commitment that inflation will disappear.'' **********The introduction of the new currency, which was first suggested by Mr. Mayorga in his capacity as chief economic adviser to Mrs. Chamorro's election campaign in February, began in May with the introduction of the gold cordoba as a unit of account for Government bank credits. **********Transition Produces Hardships **********Beginning July 1, the Government began calculating taxes in the new currency. The new bills themselves then began appearing on the street last month, and the new money now accounts for $2.5 million of the $50.7 million in national currency now in circulation, according to the central bank. **********The switch to accounting with the gold cordoba has produced an immediate crisis for hundreds of thousands of Nicaraguans who are paid in old cordobas and must pay for electric power, telephone services, gasoline and other necessary purchases in the new currency. The old cordoba floats against the new currency in the same way as it did for years against the dollar on the black market. **********Since May, inflation has already stripped the old cordoba of five-sixths of its value relative to the new currency. The resulting hardships have produced a sharp political backlash that has been reflected in Sandinista slogans and widespread graffiti declaring that ''The cordoba of gold is the cordoba of hunger,'' and ''We aren't paid in gold; we don't pay in gold.'' **********Officials Discount Opposition **********''It is not possible to tranquilize an entire people with the fetish of a new currency, one that today scarcely exists and that tomorrow will inevitably be devalued,'' declared the official Sandinista newspaper, Barricada, in a recent editorial. **********Government officials discount the opposition to the new currency, arguing that some degree of public shock was inevitable, and that economic indicators show that the country is quickly adjusting to the new money. **********Supporters of the gold cordoba say its ultimate effect will be to move Nicaragua's economy closer to the model of Panama, which uses the American dollar as its official currency. **********Praise From Other Countries **********Nicaragua's public sector deficit has been reduced from $35 million a month in May to $11 million in August, largely through the effect of the new currency in eliminating indirect subsidies that had been created through exchange rate fluctuations. Savings in the new cordoba have grown rapidly with each passing month, according to central bank figures. **********The new currency has also received strong praise from foreign countries, including the United States, which has pressed the Government to speed up the transition to the new currency. Government officials have insisted that a full transition must follow, not lead, other progress toward economic recovery, and have set no firm date for achieving it.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/06/world.main_headline: Baker Reports 'Progress' on Strategic Arms Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/06/world.print_headline: Baker Reports 'Progress' on Strategic Arms Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/06/world.body_text: **********The United States and the Soviet Union have revived the stalled strategic arms talks and may be able to complete a pact reducing long-range arms before the end of the year, Secretary of State James A. Baker said yesterday. **********The talks on cutting strategic nuclear weapons have languished for months, jeopardizing the Bush Administration's goal of completing a treaty this year. **********But after two rounds of talks with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, Mr. Baker said ''good progress'' had been made on some of the remaining strategic arms questions. **********''With the progress that should follow now in the strategic arms talks, it is still very possible that we would be able to complete a strategic arms agreement during the balance of this calandar year,'' Mr. Baker said. **********Nonetheless, the progress cited by Mr. Baker today fell considerably short of the sort of breakthrough on conventional arms announced on Wednesday, when the United States and the Soviet Union said they had reached an agreement in principle on nonnuclear forces in Europe. Today, Mr. Baker said they had resolved some remaining issues so that the conventional arms pact could be signed in Paris next month. **********Other Issues Discussed **********They agreed on ceilings for NATO and Warsaw Pact aircraft, limits on helicopters and the question of what regional ceilings should be established on conventional forces in Europe. **********Mr. Shevardnadze generally echoed Mr. Baker's positive assessment of the progress made on strategic arms. But the optimistic notes sounded today have been heard from American and Soviet officials before; completing a strategic arms treaty was a goal of the Reagan Administration. **********In addition to arms control, the meetings between Mr. Baker and Mr. Shevardnadze also dealt with the Persian Gulf, Angola and Ethiopia. **********On the Persian Gulf, Mr. Baker said that Washington and Moscow agreed that ''partial solutions should be avoided,'' a reference to the American position that Iraqi troops must unconditionally withdraw from Kuwait. **********Three Major Issues **********Mr. Baker said the two sides had not discussed the possibility of additional United Nations resolutions, which some observers have said might be sought to authorize military action against Iraq. **********''The important thing today is to see that the resoutions already adopted are implemented,'' Mr. Shevardnadze said. **********Three issues have been the main barriers to a strategic arms pact - ''noncircumvention,'' limits on the Soviet ''Backfire'' bomber and Moscow's ''heavy'' SS-18 missile. **********The ''noncircumvention'' issue has centered on Moscow's demand that the United States agree to limit its nuclear weapons cooperation with Britain. Specifically, Moscow has proposed a provision that would limit American cooperation with Britain to submarine-launched missiles. **********Without such a provision, Soviet officials have asserted, Washington would be able to compensate for cuts in the United States nuclear arsenal by helping to build up the nuclear weapons of its allies. Bush Administration officials have countered that Washington has no intention of undercutting the spirit of a strategic arms pact and have viewed the Soviet demand as meddling in American-British relations. **********The Most Accurate Weapon **********Mr. Baker said that progress had been made on the non-circumvention question but added that it had not been resolved. The Secretary suggested that the resolution of a number of other issues were contingent on the 'non-circumvention'' question. **********On the ''Backfire'' bomber, the two sides have had differences over the number of planes that Moscow should be allowed, a question that Mr. Baker suggested has now been largely worked out. Moscow has stoutly rejected Washington's demand that the Soviet military limit the number of flight tests of its SS-18 missile and thus restrict efforts to maintain and improve the weapons. The SS-18 is the most accurate weapon in the Soviet arsenal. **********Even though Moscow had already agreed to cut its force of 308 SS-18 missiles in half, the inability of the United States to get Moscow to agree to a total ban on flight tests has made Mr. Baker a target for conservative critics of arms control. And there was no public indication of a change on this question. **********Bush Administration officials said earlier this week that Soviet leaders had been channeling all their energy into the conventional arms talks. They said that the Soviet Government seemed to be unable to focus on strategic arms issues or perhaps was unwilling to overrule the Soviet military, which has already seen Moscow make a series of concessions in the strategic arms talks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/15/busin.body_text: **********In a significant advance for the production of small ''notebook'' computers, the Intel Corporation said today that it had developed a vastly shrunken, power-saving version of the chips that form the processing power of some of the most advanced personal computers. **********The introduction marks the first time Intel has announced a new microprocessor in Japan, an acknowledgement that virtually none of the new generation of notebook and ''palmtop'' machines, which weigh less than five pounds, are produced in the United States. **********But by consolidating nearly a score of separate chips into a three-chip set that includes the microprocessor, Intel will essentially be taking over some of the key elements of designing notebook-computer systems. **********Made in Japan **********Intel executives said they expected the first of the new computers, equal in power to a machine using the Intel 80386 microprocessor, to be announced by Japanese manufacturers by the end of this year. The Japanese makers who dominate the business today - primarily the Toshiba Corporation and the NEC Corporation -are expected to embrace the new chips as a way to reduce the weight of their next-generation machines and greatly extend the life of the batteries that power them. **********At a news conference here this morning, Andrew S. Grove, Intel's chief executive, said the new chip set would solve a vexing problem facing the computer industry: Notebook machines have been unable to run some of the most powerful software available for larger personal computers. **********''Now, the same richness that is available on a desktop can be achieved in a notebook computer without sacrificing battery life or size,'' Mr. Grove said. **********A Force Overseas **********Though American chip makers have long complained that they have a difficult time breaking into the Japanese market, Intel, based in Santa Clara, Calif., has been a notable exception. Almost all of the leading Japanese personal computers -those made both for export and for the Japanese market - are based on Intel processors. **********NEC is now Intel's third-largest customer, after the International Business Machines Corporation -whose adoption of Intel chips made its line of processors an industry standard - and the Compaq Computer Corporation. Intel estimates that 10 percent of its roughly $4 billion in annual revenues now comes from Japan. **********The key to Intel's new chip set is the 386 SL microprocessor, a project code-named Genesis during its development. It allowed the circuitry for a ''clone'' of an I.B.M. PC/AT to be placed on a board about 4 by 6 inches, integrating many crucial ''support'' chips into one. The two key chips in the set have more than 1.1 million transistors. **********Solving a Big Problem **********More important, the new 386 SL solves a big problem retarding the development of truly capable notebook computers: Ordinary Intel 386 processors consume large amounts of power. The new chip has a ''clock'' that shuts off automatically when not in use, one of several power-saving features. **********But in the process of integrating several functions into a smaller group of chips, Intel is now competing head-on with a relatively new group of competitors: companies that have marketed ''chip sets'' used to build clones of the I.B.M. personal computer line. **********Small companies like Chips and Technologies Inc. have carved out an enormously profitable business by combining the functions of many chips onto three or four and selling them to computer makers for use alongside Intel microprocessors. Intel is betting that it can take back that business and expand it as the notebook computer market takes off. Intel's two-chip set will be sold for $221 initially, but in time the price is expected to fall sharply. A third chip that will control a high-resolution color screen will soon be introduced. **********Somewhat surprisingly, growth of the market for smaller computers has been much faster in Japan -where computer developments usually lag the American market - than in the United States. With Japan's cramped offices and homes, notebook computers, instead of bulkier desktop models, have become the preference of many Japanese. From the offices of Toyota to the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, midlevel managers keep their computers under their desks. **********Furious Competition **********In the last few months, the competition to bring out new laptops has been furious - two or three new models have been announced in some weeks. Also on Monday, NEC is expected to introduce a palmtop computer not much larger than a checkbook and Compaq is expected to introduce a more powerful laptop model, also using an Intel microprocessor, the 386 SX. The Sony Corporation introduced notebook machines for industrial uses earlier this month. Fujitsu, Matsushita and Hitachi all have new products in the works. **********For the United States, however, the growth of the notebook market has created a serious competitive threat. Historically, the American personal computer industry has been relatively impervious to Japanese competition. That is changing quickly, as the technology of portability moves the competition onto Japanese turf. American makers are turning to Japan to produce their notebook models: Compaq's is made by the Citizen Watch Company, and Apple Computer Inc. is talking to Sony and Toshiba about a laptop Macintosh. **********Tough Licensing Policy **********The new Intel chip set will insure that an important element of the machines is made in the United States: Intel has no manufacturing plants in Japan. Nor does the company seem likely to license the manufacturing of the chip set to Japan, a policy that has angered some of Japan's biggest electronics companies. **********But Japan continues to strengthen its abilities in what may be the most vital component of the notebook computer: the flat, liquid-crystal display screen. The screens themselves are essentially chips, and manufacturing them in high volume requires much of the same process technology that has given Japan its huge success in memory chips. **********''In an ordinary personal computer, the display is a relatively small part of the system's cost,'' Mr. Grove said. ''In a notebook, it is relatively large.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/10/busin.main_headline: Late Drop Sends Dow Down 28.37, to 2,766
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/10/busin.print_headline: Late Drop Sends Dow Down 28.37, to 2,766
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/10/busin.body_text: **********Stocks ended sharply lower yesterday as trading accelerated near the close of the session. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 28.37 points, to 2,766. **********About 26 points of that loss came in the final 45 minutes of trading, reflecting program-related trading. On Monday, a late wave of program-related trading pushed the market up. **********Declines on the New York Stock Exchange outran advances, 959 to 565. **********''The stock market currently is being driven by technical factors,'' said Peter G. Grennan, head of stock index futures trading at Shearson Lehman Hutton. ''The Dow tested the 2,800 level and failed, and, on that failure, traders sold stock index futures.'' **********Mr. Grennan said the selling of stock index futures narrowed the spread between futures and cash, which, in turn, opened the door for index arbitrage sell programs. That depressed a market that climbed to record levels a little more than a week ago. **********Volume Is 155.2 Million **********Volume on the Big Board was 155.2 million shares, up from 140.1 million shares on Monday. **********In the broader market, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 4.17 points, to 349.62, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 1.98 points, to 193.35. **********Among individual issues, UAL jumped 7 3/8, to 164, and was the biggest point gainer. UAL's board said late Monday that it would explore a recapitalization that would be used for a stock buyback. **********Philips Industries dropped 1 5/8, to 20 1/2. Analysts said the company's stock fell on growing concern over the future of its leveraged buyout agreement with a unit of Merrill Lynch. **********Foreign funds were among the big gainers. Germany Fund rose 2 1/4, to 20 7/8; Malaysia Fund 1/8, to 22 1/2, and Italy Fund 1, to 17. **********Cray Research dropped 2 3/4, to 37. Shares of the company fell sharply on concern that a new supercomputer from Intel could match Cray's Y-MP machine at one-tenth the cost. Intel, which is traded over the counter, gained a point, to 37. **********Magnetek Up 1 5/8, to 9 5/8 **********Magnetek climbed 1 5/8, to 9 5/8, and was the Big Board's biggest percentage gainer. ''The stock rose sharply in a down market after a jury found the company not guilty of antitrust violations although it awarded the plaintiffs $25.8 million in damages,'' one analyst said. He added that the removal of this uncertainty, coupled with an expected surge in earnings, helped buoy the stock. **********Among active blue chips, Citicorp dropped 1 1/8, to 27 1/4; Philip Morris 3/4, to 40 1/4; I.B.M. 1, to 99 3/8, and A.T.&T. 1/2, to 45 1/4. **********On the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index dropped 1.18 points, to 380.44, while in over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index dropped 1.94 points, to 456.77.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/24/world.main_headline: Guerrilla Says Arafat Can Penalize His Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/24/world.print_headline: Guerrilla Says Arafat Can Penalize His Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/24/world.body_text: **********The Palestinian guerrilla leader Abul Abbas said today that he and his faction were prepared to accept disciplinary action by the P.L.O. chairman, Yasir Arafat, for the raid that they staged on an Israeli beach last month. **********The raid, and Mr. Arafat's refusal to condemn it, led the United States to suspend its dialogue with the Palestine Liberation Organization. **********Abul Abbas issued a statement saying he had given Mr. Arafat a file on the attack plans to show that the raid had been aimed at military targets. **********The shore near Tel Aviv was crowded with holiday beach-goers at the time of the seaborne attack on May 30 by 16 guerrillas of Abul Abbas's Palestine Liberation Front, a P.L.O. group. Israeli forces foiled the raid, and there were no Israeli casualties. **********Abul Abbas said he had agreed that Mr. Arafat could ''take any measure he sees as necessary to protect the national achievements of our people.'' **********Abul Abbas, who masterminded the 1985 hijacking of the cruise ship Achille Lauro, in which a passenger, 69-year-old Leon Klinghoffer of New York, was shot to death and dumped overboard, said his group would continue its armed struggle against Israel. **********His statement came as Saudi Arabia urged the Bush Administration to reconsider its decision. Egypt and Jordan have made similar appeals.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/28/busin.main_headline: Market Place;   Investors Return to Stock Funds
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/28/busin.print_headline: Market Place;   Investors Return to Stock Funds
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/28/busin.body_text: **********Despite a choppy stock market in February, investors resumed their purchases of stock mutual funds at a rapid rate, fund managers said yesterday. Investors had moved out of such funds in January for the first time in seven months. **********''The public is beginning to realize what the stock market did in 1989, and it is much easier to sell these funds,'' said Edward M. Mahoney, the president of Amev Advisers Inc., whose funds are sold through brokers and insurance agents. ''Our net sales in February are 30 percent better than in January.'' **********Michael Hines, a vice president of Fidelity Investments, said: ''Every time the market has dropped in the last several months, our investors have seen it as a buying opportunity. I think they are viewing equities as a long-term investment.'' He said Fidelity's giant Magellan Fund, managed by Peter Lynch, had attracted especially strong interest. **********The January figures, released by the Investment Company Institute, a trade group, showed a sharp split in attitudes toward stocks. Over all, including sales, redemptions and net exchanges among different types of funds, $241.6 million came out of mutual funds in the month, the first net loss since June. In the intervening six months, $7.4 billion came into the funds. The figures do not include reinvested dividends. **********The January withdrawals were entirely accounted for by the so-called ''hot money'' - money that is ferred among different types of mutual funds in an effort to time market moves. A total of $2.3 billion was transferred out of stock funds in the month, the heaviest outflow for any month since the market crash in October 1987. Long-term bond funds also had net transfers out, as money poured into safe money market funds. **********Excluding transfers, and looking at only sales less redemptions, a very different picture emerges. Net sales of stock funds came to $2 billion in the month, the best performance for any month since August 1987. **********The market timers, as a group, have a hard-won reputation as poor investors. ''They've been wrong four times in a row,'' said Greg Melvin, the manager of the Federated Growth Fund. ''The last of the hot money went out about two weeks ago, just when the market bottomed.'' **********Perhaps for that reason, fewer investors are trying to time markets through mutual funds. Mr. Hines said the percentage of assets being moved between mutual funds at Fidelity is ''less than half what it was three years ago.'' **********As a group, the managers of stock mutual funds were thoroughly scared in January, when the Dow Jones industrial average declined 5.9 percent. The managers raised the percentage of stock fund assets invested in short- term money market securities, called cash in the industry, to 11.5 percent, from 10.4 percent at the end of 1989. **********That figure is the third-highest for equity funds in the 29 years that the institute has been keeping track. Only in September 1974, when 11.8 percent of stock fund assets were in cash, and in June 1982, when figure hit a record 12.2 percent, has the cash level been as high. Both those levels came late in major bear markets, and preceded the beginnings of bull markets by only two or three months. By conmajor bear markets, and preceded trast, the Dow hit a record high in early January before dropping. **********While sales of stock mutual funds have been generally rising for more than a year, until recently much of the strength had been concentrated in funds that are sold directly to investors, often without a sales charge. But now some funds that are sold through brokers and insurance agents are also reporting good sales. **********''Over all, net cash flow in equities is up 30 percent over January,'' Henry L. P. Schmelzer, an executive vice president of New England Securities, which sells mutual funds for The New England, a large insurance company. ''It's really heavy in our growth fund.'' **********Massachusetts Financial Services also reported cash coming in this month. ''In equities, we're on the plus side,'' John Reilly, a spokesman, said. ''Investors are going for the most conservative funds.'' **********There was a more mixed report from the direct-marketers, who see the most switching between funds. ''In January, the conservative stock funds did well, but they seem to have tapered off,'' said Jane Nelson of T. Rowe Price. But she said that over all, money flowed into that group's equity funds. At the Janus Group of no-load funds, ''we are still experiencing tremendous growth,'' said Chrissy Snyder, a spokeswoman. She said cash flow for the group's three equity funds was a positive $49.7 million for the first three weeks of February, compared with $35.6 million for all of January. **********The cash continued to pour out of ''junk bond'' mutual funds, but once again some managers saw signs the flow was abating. ''Most of the people who wanted to get out, I think, have done so,'' said Mr. Hines of Fidelity. **********In January, the net flow out of such funds was $829 million, up from $664 million in December. But the figure was below the ones recorded in September and October. ''It's a little heavier than in January,'' said Mrs. Nelson of T. Rowe Price, regarding the February outflow from junk bond funds, ''but not back to the darkest days of the fall.'' **********Since money began leaving the junk-bond funds in July, $4.9 billion has been withdrawn, according to the institute. Total assets of junk funds have fallen 24 percent, to $26.7 billion at the end of January, from $35.2 billion at the end of June. **********Funds that buy tax-free municipal bonds drew in $678 million in January, but other long-term bond funds saw money leave as interest rates rose. Excluding muni-bond funds and junk-bond funds, $218 million came out of debt funds in January, the worst performance since September. **********While investors seem thoroughly scared of taxable junk bonds, fear of so-called high-yield bonds does not seem to have spilt over into the tax- exempt market. At Massachusetts Financial, a high-yield muni fund was opened to new investments for two days, then promptly closed when $218 million poured in. And Mrs. Nelson of T. Rowe Price reported a ''nice inflow'' into a similar fund there. She emphasized that the fund had only about one-third of its investments in bonds rated below investment grade, making it ''a better quality fund'' than one that invests only in junk bonds.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/23/world.main_headline: U.N. AND U.S. REACH ACCORD ON ARAFAT
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/23/world.print_headline: U.N. AND U.S. REACH ACCORD ON ARAFAT
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/23/world.body_text: **********The Security Council agreed on a face-saving formula tonight that would spare the Bush Administration the political hazards of allowing Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, to enter the United States, or barring him. **********Under the agreement worked out after a day of difficult negotiations here and with the P.L.O. leadership in Tunis, the Council's current President, Klaus Tornudd of Finland, simply declared that the Council will meet in Geneva next Friday afternoon to hear Mr. Arafat's complaint about Israel's recent treatment of Palestinians living in Israel and the territories it occupied after the 1967 war. **********This means that the Bush Administration does not need to decide whether to give Mr. Arafat the entry visa he asked for this week to address the Security Council in New York. The Swiss Government has no objection to allowing entry to Mr. Arafat. **********Provision for Observer Team **********In return, the Administration has agreed not to oppose a Security Council decision to send a team of observers to the West Bank, the Gaza Strip and East Jerusalem to investigate charges that Israeli forces are mistreating the Palestinians there. **********Implicit in the agreement, diplomats said, was an understanding that the United States would try to persuade Israel to allow such a mission to enter the occupied territories. **********A mission would probably be headed by Francis Blanchard of France, the Special Adviser to the United Nations Secretary General on economic development in the occupied territories. Israel has previously refused to allow Mr. Blanchard to enter the territories. **********Commenting on the agreement tonight, the Arab League Representative, Clovis Maksoud, said that Arab countries regretted that the United States had again refused to grant Mr. Arafat access to visit the United Nations headquarters in New York. **********Arab diplomats said that the Bush Administration's readiness to support the mission to the occupied territories represents the most serious expression of concern by the United States over Israeli practices in these areas. **********U.S. Obligation Is Seen **********All of the 14 other members of the Security Council, including Washington's Western allies, made clear today that they believed the United States was obligated under international law to provide Mr. Arafat with access to the United Nations. **********Two years ago the Reagan Administration refused to allow Mr. Arafat to come to New York to address the United Nations General Assembly, which promptly moved its session to Geneva to hear him. **********The International Court of Justice in the Hague then ruled unanimously that the United States was in breach of its legal obligations as the host country of the United Nations by refusing to admit Mr. Arafat.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/13/busin.main_headline: Market Place;   Common Worry: Brokers' Honesty
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/13/busin.print_headline: Market Place;   Common Worry: Brokers' Honesty
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/13/busin.body_text: **********BROKERS say their customers are petrified by program trading, but the customers themselves say they are much more worried about the honesty of brokers. **********Neither investors nor corporate financial executives seem to know much about program trading, although the executives say they are worried about it. **********Those results, from surveys conducted by the New York Stock Exchange and two brokerage firms, were disclosed yesterday by the panel on market volatility and investor confidence, appointed by the exchange after the sharp market fall in October, in which the Dow Jones industrial average fell 190 points in one day. **********''I have a feeling,'' said Roger B. Smith, the chairman of General Motors and head of the panel, ''that if a man loses $100 and calls up his broker to ask about it, the broker will say, 'Maybe it's those index arbitrage guys.' '' **********The Big Board survey asked 150 people who said they owned stock in their own accounts, to indicate how concerned they were about a variety of factors, on a scale of one, for not concerned at all, to five, for very concerned. **********More than half of those who responded, 58 percent, said they were very concerned with the ''honesty and ethics of brokers,'' and 18 percent ranked their concern at the fourth level. The percentages were similarly high for other groups polled, including those who do not own stock directly but are investors in stock mutual funds, investors who are stock investors only indirectly through pension plans, and people who own no shares at all. **********A total of 560 people were interviewed, with an accuracy of plus or minus four percentage points for overall results, and plus or minus eight points for different investor categories. **********The level of concern expressed about broker honesty was greater than for any other item listed in the survey. At least a third of shareholders said they were very concerned about five other problems: interest rates, inflation, insider trading, recession and corporate bankruptcies. **********And program trading? Only 11 percent of shareholders said they were very concerned about that. Of the 13 categories in the survey, program trading drew the least concern except for index futures and options trading, which was of great concern to just 9 percent. Ranking third from the bottom was volatility, of great concern to 18 percent of shareholders. **********The lesson of those results may be that the public is not much worried about the items that have produced great handwringing on Wall Street. That should not be a great surprise. The Dow Jones industrial average set a record high last week, and investors have flocked into stock mutual funds for the last year. Last October individual investors were heavy buyers following the 190-point drop, assuming that the market would soon regain its losses. **********The Big Board also asked both investors and financial executives of companies whose shares were publicly traded what they knew about program trading. Of the individual shareholders, 53 percent said they had never heard of it, but most of the rest seemed to think it was not an especially good thing when asked direct questions about it. Of the 200 financial executives of publicly traded companies, 51 percent said they did not know what program trading was, and many of the rest gave answers that indicated they did not know much about it. **********But 45 percent of the executives said they were very concerned about program trading, and 28 percent expressed serious concern. In other words, many executives conceded they did not know what program trading was but nevertheless said they were worried about it. **********Program trading, as defined by the Big Board, includes any investment strategy that involves the simultaneous sale or purchase of 15 different stocks. Index arbitrage is a form of program trading, involving the sale or purchase of stocks in an index, and the simultaneous offsetting purchase or sale of stock index futures or options. **********The other survey released yesterday was conducted by A. G. Edwards and Dean Witter Reynolds, two retail-oriented brokerage firms. Asking leading questions, and not including any questions about broker honesty, those firms found evidence that program trading was of great concern to almost every group. **********For example, one question asked if investors agreed with the statement: ''I will be more likely to invest in individual stocks if market volatility is once again attributable to the underlying value of the stocks rather than to program trading.'' Having been told that program trading was a problem, 79 percent of shareholders agreed, while 90 percent of retail brokers agreed that their customers would be more likely to buy. **********Some Big Board officials are not persuaded by that study. ''When you're dealing with the public on a question that they don't fully understand, the wording of a question can be very important,'' said James L. Cochrane, the Big Board's chief economist. ''The question itself can provide the information for the public.'' He said the study had been carefully prepared to avoid asking leading questions.
