https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/15/world.main_headline: Free to Speak, Bulgarians Aren't Sure What to Say
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/15/world.print_headline: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;   Free to Speak, Bulgarians Aren't Sure What to Say
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/15/world.body_text: **********Bulgarians like Stefan Dankov are having a hard time deciding if these will be the ''good old days.'' **********There is no question, Mr. Dankov said in this town's main square, but that the new emphasis on democracy has given Bulgarians more freedom to speak their minds - even, he added, if a lot of what one hears these days is blather. **********But free opinions, or for that matter elections to Parliament like those held last month, he said, do not put bread on the table. **********''For me,'' said Mr. Dankov, deputy manager of the local consumer cooperative, ''the important thing is not who wins but that I have enough money to buy things, and enough things to buy.'' **********At the moment, he has neither, he complains. Nor do many others in Pravets, a farming center of 6,000 that is 45 miles northeast of Sofia, the capital. **********Sugar, flour, dairy products and detergents are only a few of the basic items in short supply. The food store in town is a study in half-empty shelves. The meat counter is an unappealing display of salamis and a few chunks of pork. At that, a woman visiting from Sofia said enviously that there was a better selection than she could normally find at home. **********Politics vs. Economy **********It is a scene that is common across Bulgaria, as is Mr. Dankov's quandary of how the country's political gains stack up against its economic stagnation. **********For many Bulgarians, the jury is still out on whether their lives are better eight months after the palace coup that toppled a hard-line Communist Government and replaced it with a leadership of old Communists, who now call themselves Socialists and say they honestly believe in democracy. **********Pravets may have a harder time adjusting to this new world than many, for it is the hometown of the disgraced former leader, Todor I. Zhivkov, and it has benefited from that accident of birth, especially in the latter part of Mr. Zhivkov's 35-year rule. **********''This was definitely a privileged town,'' said Tzanko Marinov, a local official of the Bulgarian Socialist Party, as the Communist Party is now known. There was more food, more clothing and a better variety of both, he and others say. A computer plant was built and provided jobs for 1,500 workers, mostly from out of town. **********A supervisor acknowledges that there is only one explanation for it all. **********Zhivkov's Influence Helped **********''Those were the rules of the game,'' he said, referring to the Zhivkov influence. But rules change, and so do other things. **********The old Zhivkov house, with its thatched roof, is untended now behind a tile-topped wall. The town where he was born 79 years ago has fallen from grace, although its residents insist that their lives were not as gilded as many Bulgarians think. Now, they say, they definitely are living as well, or as badly, as the next fellow. **********They have fresh political leadership, too. More of them voted last month for the Socialists than for the opposition Union of Democratic Forces, but the faces of the new local leaders are different and decidedly younger. **********Old Zhivkov cronies were swept from power and some are reported as likely to join their old boss in facing criminal charges of abusing power. **********It is nice, Mr. Dankov said, to be able to tell political jokes in public for the first time. Still, this is a small and conservative town and freedom of expression has not landed with both feet as in Sofia, which culturally seems considerably more than 45 miles away. **********Protesters Occupy Sofia Square **********There, hundreds of anti-Government protesters have camped out for a week in a central square and seem to be in no danger of being clubbed into submission, Romania-style, by the authorities. **********Street enterpreneurs are suddenly thriving, selling everything from pocket calculators to cans of coffee in a park and on a downtown corner, under the gaze of a 20-foot statue of Lenin. **********Newspapers are crisper than in the dreary days of not long ago, when the latest tractor reports were considered sexy stories. And television, though still under state wraps, has tried to respond with genuine news and public affairs programs. It has even dug up old Hollywood films long buried in its archives, treating viewers this week, for example, to classics like ''Casablanca'' and ''Suspicion.'' **********But many Bulgarians say that after decades of repression and acquiescence, they still lack a full sense of what democracy means. The Socialists, who are flailing about despite having won the June elections, acknowledge that they have not made it any easier to figure out. **********Challenge of Alien Concepts **********''There is very little cultural comprehension of the notion of compromise,'' said Georgi Pirinski, the party's deputy chairman. ''There is little understanding of the need to engage in a process. All these are notions that are not in the national psyche.'' **********Economic hardship, including a rising foreign debt of $10 billion, only makes the task of producing change more difficult. **********In Pravets, Mr. Marinov said, the problem is not just poor food deliveries but also inadequate housing, bad roads and supply shortages at cotton processing plants and even at the computer plant. **********The situation is likely to get worse, people say, and if next winter is a hard one everyone will be pulling their belts tighter. **********''I think there will be a period of sickness,'' said Angel Georgiev, who is in charge of the consumer cooperative. ''I only hope it will be a short one.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/19/world.body_text: **********The money awarded to Nobel Prize recipients is being raised to $653,000 from $489,000, the head of the Nobel Foundation was quoted as saying today. The foundation is hoping to return the ultimate value of the award to what it was worth in 1901, when it was created by Alfred Nobel, said the official, Stig Ramel.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/04/world.main_headline: Evolution in Europe;   Ex-Party Aide to Lead New Latvia
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/04/world.print_headline: Evolution in Europe;   Ex-Party Aide to Lead New Latvia
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/04/world.body_text: **********A former Latvian Communist Party official who once denounced pro-independence demonstrators was re-elected by Parliament today to lead the Baltic republic out of the Soviet Union. **********Anatoly Gorbunov, who had been President since October 1988, was reconfirmed by the republic's newly elected nationalist-dominated Parliament. On Friday, it is expected to take the first steps toward secession by reinstating parts of the republic's constitution of 1922, when it was independent. Latvia and the other Baltic republics, Lithuania and Estonia, were annexed by the Soviet Government in 1940. **********In a speech shortly before his re-election, Mr. Gorbunov warned deputies that the path to independence would not be easy. **********''We must show the world that we are not endangering East-West dialogue,'' said Mr. Gorbunov, who once denounced those taking part in a nationalist demonstration as ''traitors'' but is now backed by the pro-independence Popular Front.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/18/busin.main_headline: Czechs Have an Edge In East's Reform Efforts
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/18/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;   Czechs Have an Edge In East's Reform Efforts
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/18/busin.body_text: **********There is much talk nowadays about how bumpy Eastern Europe's road to capitalism will be, but Czechoslovakia hopes to defy the odds and engineer a relatively smooth transition. **********The dream of many Czechoslovak officials is to follow up the quick, peaceful ''velvet revolution'' that toppled Communism last December with a speedy ''velvet transformation'' to capitalism. **********An impossible dream? Many economists say that if any Eastern European country can make a relatively smooth metamorphosis, it is Czechoslovakia. But other economists - and some Western investors - complain that Prague's perfectionist officials are becoming bogged down in haggling over the fine points of a reform package and are moving too slowly toward change. **********Cushioning the Shocks **********The move to the free market will certainly push up prices and throw people out of work, but the Czechoslovaks are confident that they have several important advantages over other Eastern European countries that will cushion the shocks. Their nation of 15.5 million has a stronger industrial base, lower debt burden and a more skilled labor force than in most other Eastern European countries. And the country's inflation rate is a modest 7 percent, its stores are well stocked and it has the second-highest per capita income in the region after East Germany. **********''We have a much better chance to go through this unhappy period than some other Eastern European countries,'' said Deputy Prime Minister Vladimir Dlouhy, who also heads the State Planning Office. **********Czechoslovaks are fond of reminding visitors that before World War II they ranked No. 10 among nations in per capita income and were called the ''Yankees of Europe'' because of their industriousness and pluck. **********But officials in Prague admit their efforts to build a market economy will take longer than East Germany's, mainly because West Germany's large aid to East Germany means less money for their country. Even so, Czechoslovakia's shift will probably be less painful than East Germany's because German currency unification is expected to cause a violent shakeout for East German industry and an explosion of unemployment. **********The Case for Fast Action **********Many economists are prodding the Government in Prague to move faster with reforms to prevent the heavy hand of central planning from further dragging down the economy. ''People feel they are in a vacuum'' said Jan Klacek, an economist with the Czechoslovak Academy of Sciences. ''They feel that the old system has been abolished and that there is not yet a substitute for it.'' **********The main force behind the drive to speed up reforms is the hard-charging Finance Minister, Vaclav Klaus, who is urging Czechoslovakia to avoid the mistakes that threw Poland and Hungary into crisis. **********Poland's old Communist government let its money supply run wild, and prices went haywire. To avoid Poland's high inflation, Mr. Klaus says that before removing price controls, Prague should clamp down on the money supply, which will restrict demand and make it hard for companies to raise prices. Mr. Klaus, who at age 48 has become a star in national politics, pushed through a tight budget that aims to produce a surplus and to fight inflation. **********The Finance Minister said he abhorred half measures like the modest reforms undertaken by Hungary over two decades. ''Partial reform of a distorted economy is much worse than non-reform,'' he said. **********Mr. Klaus said Czechoslovakia should avoid a ''reform trap'' and implement changes in a careful sequence so they do not undermine each other. For example, price controls should not be removed before competition has been created. **********For months, Mr. Klaus and his team battled with First Deputy Prime Minister Valtr Komarek, who argued that a slower reform strategy was preferable because it would produce less pain. But officials in Prague say Mr. Klaus has won that dispute, thanks to the backing of President Vaclav Havel and Prime Minster Marian Calfa. **********Novel Reforms **********Under Mr. Klaus, Prague is undertaking several novel reforms: *********** Over the past three months, the Government has gone further than other Eastern European countries to break monopolistic conglomerates into smaller units to help create competition. In a nation where 70 percent of the enterprises had more than 1,000 employees, officials say this will help hold down inflation once price controls are lifted. *********** To move prices toward less distorted levels, the Government plans to raise prices on 30,000 food items by an average of 24.6 percent on July 9. To cushion the blow, the Government said it would give every citizen an additional subsidy of $10 a month. Mr. Klaus hopes to remove all price controls on Jan. 1. Food subsidies are so large that farmers use bread as fodder for their animals, and consumers pay only half of what farmers receive for milk. *********** Recognizing that Czechoslovaks have little money to buy corporate stock, Mr. Klaus wants to distribute stock-buying vouchers to the public for free. People could then use the vouchers to acquire stock in the companies of their choice once state-run enterprises are privatized. **********Dusan Triska, the senior adviser to the Finance Minister, whom Mr. Klaus wants to head a state privatization office, said new profit-minded owners would press enterprises to be more efficient. He said he hoped to sell 1,000 companies in the first round of privatization scheduled for this fall. **********Prague has also disclosed plans to make the currency, the crown, convertible beginning Jan. 1. Convertibility is expected to help attract much-needed Western investment and technology and increase trade with the West. It will also make it easier to import goods, thereby heightening competition for long-insulated industries. **********Government officials say the nation would never tolerate the huge price increases that Poland experienced during its shock therapy to develop a market economy. But many economists say that because its economy is stronger, Czechoslovakia does not need shock therapy. **********''Reforms in Czechoslovakia won't create the very high inflation that Poland experienced because there is much more balance in the economy,'' said Zdenek Lukas, an economist with the Vienna-based Institute for Comparative Economic Studies. **********Resentment Over New Wealth **********Deputy Prime Minister Dlouhy said he was not scared of inflation, but did fear that the move to capitalism might make some people very rich very quickly and cause resentment among others. **********Despite the overall optimism about Czechoslovakia's prospects, it faces some daunting challenges. Huge investments are needed to clean up the environment and more than 70 percent of its trade is with the nation's of the fragmenting bloc once centered on the Soviet Union. **********Czechoslovakia is dangerously dependent on heavy industry - it produces more than one ton of steel per capita, one of the highest levels in the world. About 70 percent of its exports involve machinery and heavy engineering, and with the Soviet economy in crisis, exports to its biggest customer will probably plummet. In addition, crucial oil imports from the Soviet Union are falling. **********Although some economists say Czechoslovakia's heavy industry is too backward to quickly increase exports to the West, some officials are optimistic. ''There is demand for not only super-top quality,'' said Frantisek Nevaril, the Prime Minister's chief economic adviser. ''The world is also buying many standard products. We can shape up so that we'll do well in a year or two.'' **********During last December's revolution, many economists were confident that, with its skilled labor force and low wages, Czechslovakia would be a magnet for Western investment, especially from neighboring West Germany. But economists now say investment is being hurt by the nation's slow pace of reform and by West Germany's preoccupation with East Germany. Yet West Germany is expected to be the No. 1 foreign investor. **********Mr. Nevaril, the Prime Minster's aide, is optimistic about the transition to a market economy. ''If we don't make any big mistakes, then there is not much we can lose,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/16/busin.main_headline: Agency Votes to Sell Houses Owned by Savings Units
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/16/busin.print_headline: Agency Votes to Sell Houses Owned by Savings Units
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/16/busin.body_text: **********The Oversight Board of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency managing the bailout of the nation's savings and loan industry, today approved its first program to sell the housing stock of failed savings institutions to low- and medium-income families. **********The board approved a joint financing program between the trust corporation and the State of Texas under which the Texas Housing Authority would issue $140 million in tax-exempt bonds to provide financing for low-rate mortgages for the low- and moderate-income families. **********The trust corporation will select the private lenders and the mortgages will be used exclusively to buy half of the 5,200 housing properties for sale by the agency in Texas. **********No Borrower Fees **********The agency will be allowed to spend up to $6 million in commitment fees for the new mortgages. Under the plan, low-income borrowers will not have to repay the fees. The program will be put into effect within 30 to 60 days pending the final approval of the Texas agency, which originally proposed the plan. **********In addition to managing the bailout, the Resolution Trust Corporation has a separate mandate to sell affordable housing. The program was inserted in the bailout legislation by Congressional Democrats. **********''We hope that R.T.C. will actively negotiate with other states and local housing agencies to form affordable housing partnerships to provide low-interest-rate loans to buyers of R.T.C.'s housing properties,'' said Jack F. Kemp, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development and a member of the Oversight Board. **********Officials of the Oversight Board said there are an estimated 10,000 properties held by savings institutions in conservatorship across the country that will ultimately be eligible for the affordable housing program. **********The board urged the agency to negotiate similar agreements with other states. Florida has expressed interest in a similar program. **********Nomination Made **********In a separate development today, President Bush nominated Robert C. Larson, the chief executive officer of the Taubman Company, a national real estate developer based in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., to a three-year term on the Oversight Board. He would fill one of two remaining vacancies on the board if he is confirmed by the Senate. **********In addition to Mr. Kemp, the other members of the Oversight Board are Nicholas F. Brady, the Secretary of the Treasury, and Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. **********Noting that the Oversight Board had been criticized for moving slowly to fill vacancies, Mr. Brady, chairman of the board, said that the delay was caused because of Mr. Larson's long experience in the real estate business. **********''We had a choice to approach people who really knew something about the business and therefore would have a long period of examination because of the possibility of conflict, or we could have taken somebody with no knowledge and move it quite quickly,'' Mr. Brady said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/09/busin.main_headline: Market Place;   Behind Delay in Farley Deal For West Point-Pepperell
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/09/busin.print_headline: Market Place;   Behind Delay in Farley Deal For West Point-Pepperell
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/09/busin.body_text: **********It has been nine months since William Farley took control of West Point-Pepperell Inc. with the promise that all remaining public shares would be promptly purchased at $58 each. **********But now Mr. Farley, who built his empire on borrowed money, appears unable to complete the transaction. The remaining public shares have tumbled to $37.75, after falling $2.375 yesterday. That is 35 percent less than the promised price, reflecting growing doubt that the merger will ever be completed. **********Yesterday, West Point-Pepperell disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that the banks that made a $1.03 billion bridge loan to the company had agreed to extend the loan, through March and perhaps through June, in return for additional fees and higher interest rates. Instead of paying 1.5 percentage points over the prime rate, West Point-Pepperell will now pay 2.5 percentage points over the prime. **********In return for the new fees and higher interest rates, the banks, led by the Wells Fargo Bank and the Bankers Trust Company, gave permission for West Point-Pepperell to advance money to the West Point Acquisition Corporation, the company owned by Mr. Farley that owns 95 percent of West Point-Pepperell. Without such cash infusions, it appears that West Point Acquisition might run out of cash and default on the interest payments it owes on more than $1.4 billion in debt it took on to buy the West Point-Pepperell stock. **********Whether the bank agreement removed all the obstacles for such cash infusions, and whether they were made, could not be determined yesterday. Mr. Farley did not return phone calls and other West Point-Pepperell officials declined to answer questions. **********A key part of Mr. Farley's strategy called for selling a major West Point-Pepperell subsidiary, Cluett, Peabody & Company, and using the money to pay down debt. But that sale has been delayed, and a lower price is likely. **********In October, it was announced that the Biderman Group, a privately held French company, had tentatively agreed to pay $600 million for most of Cluett's assets. Gene de Nicolais, a spokesman for Biderman, said last week that the negotiations were still under way, and said a closing was expected in the middle of January. A closing was originially expected in November. **********''The price has been an issue,'' he said, declining to give details. One person, with second-hand knowledge of the talks, said a price of around $500 million, not all in cash, was possible. **********A spokesman for Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., which played a major role in financing the first part of the takeover - and owns some of the securities issued to finance the deal -said last week that it hoped to raise the money to enable Mr. Farley to complete the acquisition by the middle of 1990 but cautioned that doing so depended both on the sale of assets and on an improved ''junk bond'' market. The plan had been to sell more than $1.6 billion in junk bonds both to pay for the remaining shares and to refinance debt taken on in the first round. **********If the money cannot be raised, it is unclear what will happen. To get access to substantial cash from West Point-Pepperell, West Point Acquisition would have to complete the merger and take over the remaining public shares. Revising the terms of the takeover would need the consent of two of the three West Point directors who were on the board before Mr. Farley took over and might not be forthcoming. **********Until the merger is completed, the only asset that West Point Acquisition has is its shares in West Point-Pepperell. They pay no dividends and have a deteriorating market value. To pay interest on the loans, it needs money from West Point-Pepperell itself. **********It is conceivable that Mr. Farley will have to give up substantial equity in West Point-Pepperell to arrange financing, and possible that he will lose control. There has been speculation that to raise cash, Mr. Farley might put Fruit-of-the-Loom, another company he controls, on the block. **********The losers now are those public shareholders who, for whatever reason, failed to sell their shares to the first tender offer, and have seen their value plummet. But there are other probable losers. **********Mr. Farley himself could end up a big loser. He has sunk more than $170 million into West Point-Pepperell stock, not counting the money borrowed by West Point Acquisition, and could lose it if the deal cannot be completed. Those who lent money to it could also wind up with substantial losses, reflecting the current view that if West Point-Pepperell went on the block again, the top bid would be well under $58 per share. **********Mr. Farley's problems were not brought on by a sudden change in fortunes of West Point-Pepperell but by a financial community suddenly less willing to risk money on junk bonds to finance takeovers. For him, the music stopped at a very inappropriate time. **********''This is a kind of one-act play in financial leverage,'' said James Grant, the editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer and a critic of junk bond financing, about the West Point saga. ''It is about optimism and debt and disappointment, and we have not yet come to the end of it.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/08/world.main_headline: U.N. PUTS OFF MOVE ON MIDEAST TALKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/08/world.print_headline: STANDOFF IN THE GULF; U.N. PUTS OFF MOVE ON MIDEAST TALKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/08/world.body_text: **********The United States today postponed a meeting of the United Nations Security Council until Saturday, saying it wanted more time to prepare a new resolution dealing with a possible international peace conference to settle the Palestinian question and other Middle East problems. **********The Bush Administration is pressing for changes in a draft Security Council resolution that for the first time would give the Council's endorsement to such a conference, which is vehemently opposed by Israel and would be seen as a significant United States concession to the Arabs. **********Diplomats said tonight that the Bush Administration appeared reluctant to veto the present resolution, which it opposes, because of the embarrassment this would cause its Arab allies in the Persian Gulf crisis. But they expressed doubt that Washington could find a new and more vague formulation that would satisfy all other members.  Protection for Palestinians **********The proposed Council resolution, which seeks to provide more United Nations protection to Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied territories, also gives the Council's support to an international peace conference at the "appropriate time." **********It is this provision that the United States is now resisting, even though the language endorsing an international peace conference is the same that the Bush Administration used when it finally accepted the idea last year, over Israel's vehement opposition. **********Moreover, the resolution's four sponsors -- Malaysia, Colombia, Cuba and Yemen -- say the United States Mission here was consulted on the text and gave them the impression a few days ago that Washington might accept it. **********But that gesture was viewed as an important American concession by many in the Middle East, diplomats say, arousing fears in the Administration that President Saddam Hussein would interpret it as a sign of weakness before the two sides start direct talks on Kuwait later this month. **********Others said that an American vote for the Security Council resolution might seem to be a quid pro quo for Iraq's announcement on Thursday that it would release all foreign hostages. Linkage of the Kuwait crisis and the Arab-Israeli issue is a top diplomatic priority for President Saddam Hussein. The Bush Administration, on the other hand, opposes such linkage and has insisted that it will make no compromises with Iraq.  Reluctant to Use Veto **********But with most of the Council's 14 other members favoring the proposed resolution, the United States is reluctant to exercise its veto because this would anger its Arab allies against Iraq. As a result many diplomats speculated that Washington might accept some reference to an eventual Middle East peace conference. **********Israel would have rejected such a Security Council decision. But the United States wants to prevent the Council from doing anything Israel will not accept because that would put Israel in breach of the United Nations Charter, and could produce pressure for sanctions similar to those imposed on Iraq after it refused to surrender Kuwait. **********Most other Council members also reject linkage between the Persian Gulf crisis and the Arab-Israeli issue. But they do not want the Bush Administration to throw away the opportunity its Arab alliance against Iraq offers to promote a wider Middle East settlement. And they argue that a decision to let the Council endorse a Middle East peace conference that nearly everyone else accepts might underscore Washington's determination to seek a broader Middle East settlement after the gulf crisis is over.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/29/busin.body_text: **********The New York City Employees Retirement System said today that it would vote its shares of the Lockheed Corporation in favor of the company's current management and board in their proxy battle with the Texas investor Harold C. Simmons. **********The New York City pension fund owns 326,000 shares of Lockheed, or one-half of 1 percent of the company's shares outstanding. **********The office of the New York City Comptroller, Elizabeth Holtzman, said in a statement that Lockheed's management ''should have the opportunity to execute its business strategy to improve the company's performance.'' **********But the Comptroller's office said it hoped to see Lockheed make more progress in diversifying into commercial and non-military businesses, generating higher returns on assets in the technology services and electronics sectors, naming new independent directors to the board and showing greater regard for shareholders' rights. **********The New York City pension fund made its statement as both Lockheed and Mr. Simmons completed several weeks of lobbying institutional investors before Lockheed's annual meeting, which is to be held Thursday in Burbank, Calif. **********A number of large institutional shareholders have said they are backing Mr. Simmons's group in its effort to oust Lockheed's board, and the vote is expected to be close.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/30/busin.body_text: **********Brushing aside Britain's objections, leaders of the European Community decided this weekend to set up a common central bank in early 1994, and thus greatly advance the hope of creating a single European currency. But many economists questioned whether unforeseen obstacles would prevent the bank's establishment so soon. **********The idea of a single European currency has long been a dream. And with a date on setting up a central bank fixed at the European Community's summit meeting in Rome over the weekend, some European officials say a single currency could become a reality by the end of this decade. The resounding support of 11 of the 12 community members -- with only Britain opposed -- to form a central bank in 1994 could bode well for a decision three years later on a single currency. **********But numerous economists predicted that an economic crisis or widely disparate inflation rates within Europe could discourage community nations from forming such a bank in early 1994, thereby delaying any progress on the currency issue. **********"In the next three or four years, a lot of things could happen on the international scene that would make moving ahead with this plan much more difficult," said Eric Taze-Bernard, senior economist with Banque Indosuez, the Parisian investment bank. **********At the same time, many economists said they doubted that Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's outspoken opposition to setting up a central bank so soon would keep the 11 other community nations from going ahead with the plan. **********Mrs. Thatcher has said that a single currency would mean too much a sacrifice of national sovereignty. Nevertheless, the economists said she might eventually be persuaded to join a European central bank, just as she ultimately came around to joining the European Monetary System. Besides, they add, she will not be Prime Minister forever. **********"It's partly a game of brinkmanship," said Richard Reid, chief European economist for UBS Phillips & Drew, a London-based brokerage. "If the other 11 say you cannot prevent the rest of us from moving ahead, then that's a big stick to beat over the head of the U.K. to join the group." **********In the debate over if and when to set up a European central bank, the key vote was cast by German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who overrode the objection of Germany's powerful Bundesbank in backing the Jan. 1, 1994 date. The bank's officials, led by the president, Karl-Otto Pohl, have repeatedly objected to fixing a date, arguing that inflation rates and economic policies within the community must first be harmonized.  Need for 'Harmonization' **********Following the Rome meeting, however, it appeared that many community leaders had decided that the convergence of inflation rates could come after the so-called Eurofed bank was established. Indeed, such a bank, by creating a community-wide monetary policy, could promote convergence. **********Even so, some economists said that if the spread between inflation rates of the member nations remained vast as Jan. 1, 1994, approached, then European leaders might balk at pushing ahead with creating the central bank. **********"Even the politicians know that you cannot only fix a date, but you have to reach some degree of harmonization of the economies," said Peter Pietsch, a senior economist with Commerzbank in Frankfurt. **********Bundesbank officials fear that forming such a bank when some nations have high inflation rates and others have low ones could cause the central bankers to settle on an inflation rate higher than the Bundesbank's inflation fighters would like. At the same time, if low-inflation forces dominate the bank, they could force high-inflation countries, like Greece and Portugal, to crack down on inflation brutally, perhaps causing politically unacceptable domestic economic crises. **********Before the Rome meeting, Jacques Delors, president of the community's Executive Commission, had pushed for fixing early 1993 as the date to create the central bank. He was backed by France, Italy, Belgium and Denmark. **********However, several nations -- for the most part, those in southern Europe with high inflation -- wanted a later date. They feared that they could not reduce their inflation rates quickly enough and that some nations wanting to move quickly might decide to set up a European central bank without them. **********Spain's Finance Minister, Carlos Solchaga, proposed starting the central bank on Jan. 1, 1994, to give his and other high-inflation nations time to bring inflation down. The compromise was clinched when Chancellor Kohl, eager to show that German unification would not impede European unification, backed that date.  Questions Remain **********But there are still questions about whether that date is writ in stone. "The community leaders," said Mr. Taze-Bernard of Banque Indosuez, "showed they really don't want monetary union at two speeds, but do they really want to include those southern European countries with high inflation rates?" **********In recent months, German, Dutch and Danish officials have raised some of the reservations expressed by Mrs. Thatcher, although in a less strident way. However, when Italian officials, who headed the Rome meeting, forced a vote on the bank's future, these nations felt compelled to show their commitment to a united Europe. **********The statement issued by the community's leaders said that three years after the central bank is formed, the bank would issue a report on how well convergence is going. If it is going well, the community might move to the next phase of economic union, which would include permanently locking exchange rates and perhaps setting up a single currency. **********At the same time, community leaders left open the door to the British idea of having not a single currency, but a supplemental, common currency based on the European currency unit. **********In their agreement, the leaders also said the central bank would be formed in early 1994 after several conditions had been met. These included ratifying a new community treaty; establishing a barrier-free Europe; giving independence to members of the new central bank; prohibiting community members from the inflationary practice of financing their deficits by printing money, and having the greatest number of nations join the European Monetary System.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/16/busin.body_text: **********The Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago priced a two-part issue of first mortgage bonds totaling $350 million yesterday through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. **********A $125 million issue of noncallable mortgage bonds due in 2000 was given a 9 3/8 percent coupon and priced to yield 9.445 percent, or about 102 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. **********The remaining $225 million of bonds due in 2020 were given a coupon of 9 3/4 percent and priced to yield 9.94 percent, or about 146.5 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. These securities, underwriters said, are noncallable by the utility for the first 10 years. **********Both parts of the financing are rated Baa-1 by Moody's and BBB+ by S.& P.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/15/world.main_headline: Irish High Court Bars Extraditing 2 in I.R.A.
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/15/world.print_headline: Irish High Court Bars Extraditing 2 in I.R.A.
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/15/world.body_text: **********Ireland's Supreme Court has voted unanimously not to extradite two Irish Republican Army members who had escaped from Maze Prison in Northern Ireland. **********Peter Brooke, Britain's Secretary of State for Northern Ireland, said in Parliament today that the ruling, issued on Tuesday, was ''disturbing and difficult to understand.'' An official close to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said ''it tells terrorists they have a safe haven south of the border.'' **********In the decision, the five-judge court upheld appeals against extradition from Dermot Finucane and James Pius Clarke, who are now free. They were among 38 prisoners who escaped from Maze Prison near Belfast in 1983. Both had been serving 18-year sentences, Mr. Finucane for possessing firearms and Mr. Clarke for the attempted murder of a member of a Protestant paramilitary group. **********The court cited ''the probable risk'' that the two would be assaulted in prison - an assertion Mr. Brooke called ''an unacceptable slur'' on the Northern Ireland prison service. **********The British and Irish Governments stressed that it was an independent court and not the Irish Government that had made the decision.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/19/world.body_text: **********Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, a First Deputy Foreign Minister, has been confirmed as Soviet Ambassador to the United States, the official press agency Tass said today. He replaces Yuri V. Dubinin, who will be ''transferred to other duties,'' Tass reported. Mr. Bessmertnykh's appointment was proposed as part of a shuffle of Soviet diplomatic posts in Europe and North America, announced last month.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/30/world.main_headline: Mandela, 'Faceless Man With a Fax,' Negotiates His and His Nation's Future
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/30/world.print_headline: Mandela, 'Faceless Man With a Fax,' Negotiates His and His Nation's Future
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/30/world.body_text: **********For the last week, audiences packing a popular dinner theater in a grimy industrial quarter of Johannesburg have reserved one of their biggest laughs for a line offered by the country's best-known political satirist, Pieter-Dirk Uys. ''Who would have thought,'' Mr. Uys has said each night, strictly deadpan, ''that a faceless man with a fax machine could run the country from a prison?'' **********The predominantly white audiences have needed no help identifying the reference to Nelson Mandela, who is the country's and perhaps the world's most famous political prisoner. **********Lately, Mr. Mandela has added to his renown as the symbolic leader of millions of blacks a curiosity value of a highly unusual kind, since he has been negotiating, with the aid of a fax machine and a group of white prison officers who appear to act as much as assistants as captors, not only the terms of his own release but the outlines of what could be the future of South Africa. **********With quickening intensity, South Africans everywhere from the plush northern suburbs of Johannesburg to the dusty back alleys of Soweto have been snapping up the final editions of newspapers at street-corner stands, silencing gatherings to listen to the television news, and collectively sitting on the edge of their seats for news of what everybody seems to regard as one of the most momentous events in South African history: the release of Mr. Mandela, who has been continuously in South African jails since Aug. 5, 1962. **********Midnight Vigil **********On Saturday night, editors of the country's biggest newspaper, The Sunday Times, sat edgily in their offices until after midnight. They were waiting for a call from reporters with mobile telephones stationed outside Victor Verster Prison 40 miles northeast of Cape Town, and at other spots along the route that Mr. Mandela is expected to take back to his home in Soweto, the black satellite city outside Johannesburg, when the country's white rulers finally decide to let him go. **********When the editors finally let the reporters go home, it was because of a further twist in what had already become an enticingly improbable saga. **********According to officials close to President F. W. de Klerk, a move to release Mr. Mandela immediately, two weeks before the most widely predicted date in mid-February, was halted when Mr. de Klerk and other top officials decided that conditions they had set for the release of the 71-year-old black leader had not been met. **********Primarily, these involve a ''commitment to peace'' from Mr. Mandela's exiled associates in the African National Congress, a pledge that they will halt, or at least suspend, the sporadic guerrilla attacks against Government and other targets that they have conducted since Mr. Mandela went underground to lead an armed struggle against domination by the country's white minority in 1961. **********But Winnie Mandela, the black leader's wife, implied after visiting Mr. Mandela on Saturday that the delay came at her husband's behest, after the Government failed to meet his terms. **********These include the ending of the ban on the African National Congress and dozens of other proscribed black groups, the lifting of a state of emergency declared by the Government during anti-Government turmoil in 1986, the release of about 300 political detainees and an end to all ''political'' executions, by which Mr. Mandela means the hanging of blacks found guilty of murder and other capital crimes while engaged in anti-apartheid protests. **********Whether Mr. de Klerk is ready to meet some or all of Mr. Mandela's terms, and to announce a firm date for the black leader's freedom, is expected to be known on Friday, when the President addresses the opening session of Parliament in Cape Town. **********In the meantime, the suggestion advanced by Mrs. Mandela - that her husband might yet refuse to take his freedom, after more than a quarter century in jail that included years spent working in a lime quarry, picking seaweed and building roads - has added intrigue to a situation that has no obvious parallel in the annals of political detention. A Shadow Government?  As Mr. Uys's remark at the Market Theater in Johannesburg suggested, many South Africans are bemused by the idea that a man long presented to them as a Communist and a terrorist has emerged, while still in prison, as a sort of one-man shadow government. **********But perhaps the most striking thing of all is that many whites appear as excited by the situation as blacks, and that the feeling is detectable in some improbable places. **********A visitor who met last week with a high-ranking officer who was previously head of the widely feared Security Police reported that the officer, until recently charged with hunting down and prosecuting members of the African National Congress, compared the situation with the Boer War, the most traumatic event in the history of South Africa's ruling ethnic group, the Afrikaners. ''He seemed absolutely fascinated,'' the visitor said. **********For the moment, many whites and blacks have their attention fixed on the unusual details of Mr. Mandela's continuing incarceration. **********For more than a year, he has been living in a spacious bungalow home about four miles from the main prison building outside Paarl, in the mountainous wine country behind Cape Town. The bungalow was previously the home of the white man who was the prison's deputy governor, and Mr. Mandela has the use of a swimming pool on the bungalow's grounds. He is also helped in his communications with his associates outside the prison, and in greeting a stream of visitors, including high-ranking Government ministers, by three white prison officers. Newspapers have noted that the officers are confined to using the servant's quarters at the home, cramped outbuildings that have been converted to offices and temporary sleeping quarters. **********As described by The Sunday Times, Mr. Mandela has developed relationships with his white captors that seem more like those of equals than of those between a prisoner and his guards. The paper said that visitors to the home have reported that the white guards refer to Mr. Mandela with respect, and call him by his first name, and that one of them, identified as Warrant Officer Greg Gregory, has developed a particularly close relationship with Mr. Mandela, having been transferred with the black leader through three prisons: the notorious Robben Island fortress off Cape Town, Pollsmoor jail outside the city, and finally to Victor Verster. **********Still a Prisoner **********But other aspects of Mr. Mandela's situation make it plain that that in many respects he is still treated as a prisoner. Visitors are searched, letters and other documents passing in and out of the bungalow are read by prison staff, although not censored, and Mr. Mandela has a radio and television set that can pull in South African broadcasts, but nothing from abroad. **********This means that much of what he hears has passed through Government censors, since the South African Broadcasting Corporation, which dominates broadcasting, is under tight Government control. The black guards at the home are armed, and the facsimile machine is situated in the main prison, not in the bungalow. **********Another paradox is that Mr. Mandela has become one of the most widely quoted political figures in the country, second only to Mr. de Klerk, although South Africa's Prisons Act makes it an offense to quote a prisoner or to give any details of his incarceration. **********Another oddity, captured in Mr. Uys's remark about Mr. Mandela's being ''faceless,'' is that none of the photographers covering the story have yet been allowed to take a current photograph of the black leader. The editor of one major newspaper said that he had been told that major international photo agencies have offered sums of up to $300,000 for pictures of the black leader in prison. **********For his part, Mr. Mandela, who is said to be fit, but white-haired and slimmer than he was when he was imprisoned for life, is said to have been amused, while taking a stroll on the prison grounds recently, to have gone unrecognized by photographers gathered outside the gate. **********''He was enormously tickled,'' one of the black leader's lawyers said. ''There he is, the center of world attention, and these hawk-eyed newspapermen didn't even recognize him.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/03/busin.main_headline: Business and Health;   Most Want U.S. To Pay the Bill
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/03/busin.print_headline: Business and Health;   Most Want U.S. To Pay the Bill
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/03/busin.body_text: **********A LARGE number of Americans say they would gladly exchange their health-care system for one in Canada, which is entirely financed by the Government. **********Surveys by The Los Angeles Times in March, NBC last year and Louis Harris & Associates in 1988 all showed that majorities of at least 61 percent of those polled favored a comprehensive national health plan. In the Harris poll, respondents chose the Canadian way in preference to both the American approach and the British system of Government-controlled doctors and hospitals. The choice in The Los Angeles Times poll was between the American and Canadian systems only. **********Canadians go to their own doctors, who practice independently but are all in the system. All medical bills are paid with tax money. **********The surveys worry employers and insurers. Many employers believe that higher taxes would outweigh their savings under a Canadian-style system (although American auto makers with plants in Canada have not found this to be so). And health insurers fear that their business would be decimated if the Government took over. But health-insurance experts say the Canadian system is not really the issue and that most Americans know little about either its strengths or its weaknesses. **********''The issue is financial insecurity,'' said Robert J. Blendon, chairman of the Department of Health Policy and Management at the Harvard School of Public Health. Even people who have health insurance worry that their coverage may be cut back or eliminated and that they may be unable to afford medical care, he said in an interview. Americans pay 26 percent, on average, of their own health-care bills. At least 16 percent do not have either private or Government insurance. **********''When a lot of people think about health care, they see a dollar sign, they see risk, they see catastrophic danger,'' said John Erb, a managing consultant in New York with Foster Higgins, an employee benefits consulting firm. In a new study of the public's feelings about health care, Dr. Blendon, along with Robert Leitman, a senior vice president with Harris; Ian Morrison, an economist with the Institute for the Future in Menlo Park, Calif., and Karen Donelan, a Harvard research associate, looked at 10 countries. They found that the degree of satisfaction with the system was highest in Canada, followed by the Netherlands, West Germany, France, Australia, Sweden, Japan, Britain and Italy. Satisfaction was lowest in the United States. The United States and South Africa are the only major industrial countries that do not have Government-paid health-care systems. **********But the low approval rating and widespread preference for Canada's system did not mean that Americans were dissatisfied with their doctors and hospitals, or even that they believed national spending on health care was too high, the researchers said. ''Rather, this response indicates the high level of public frustration with our current health financing arrangements,'' the Blendon group said in Health Affairs, a quarterly journal. **********Businesses of all sizes are also frustrated, said Karen Berg Brigham, health-care policy manager with the United States Chamber of Commerce. They have all been hit by rapidly growing health costs, and many small employers have had difficulty getting affordable coverage. In a survey last winter of 1,101 small-business executives for the Chamber of Commerce, 21 percent said the United States should adopt a Canadian-style system, while 56 percent opposed the idea and 23 percent were undecided. **********But Ms. Brigham said the demonstration of interest in the survey should not be seen as an endorsement of Government health insurance. She noted that many foreign systems were largely financed by payroll taxes. ''This is of great concern to business, especially small businesses, she said. ''The payroll tax is one of their largest costs.'' ''The majority of employers would find their costs increasing under a Canadian system,'' said Mr. Erb of Foster Higgins. ''But for Rust Belt manufacturers with huge numbers of retirees who have expensive health-care needs, spreading the risk to the Government might lower an employer's costs.'' **********The health insurance industry has also found that people are concerned about losing their insurance, said Edward Neuschler, director of policy studies with the Health Insurance Association of America, a trade group. But in a survey last year for the insurers by the Roper Organization, the overwhelming percentage of respondents ''were pleased with their current coverage and benefits,'' he said. The insurers group has proposed changes in state laws and a privately financed reinsurance plan to make it easier for small-business employees to get and keep affordable coverage. **********The Blendon article said the United States spent $2,051 per capita on health care in 1987, or 28 percent more than Canada, which was second with $1,483. Sweden was next, at $1,233; then France, $1,105; West Germany, $1,093, and the Netherlands, $1,041. Australia spent $939; Japan, $915; Italy, $841, and Britain, $758. **********But the Canadians also have problems with health care. Costs are rising as rapidly there as in the United States, said Mr. Neuschler of the Health Insurance Association. And when Americans are told that Canadians often must wait for long periods for certain complicated operations, like a coronary bypass or hip replacement, ''they do not at all like the notion,'' he said. Indeed, Americans are largely uninformed about the Canadian health system, Dr. Blendon said. He added, ''If it weren't for the high costs in the U.S., the world would probably be discussing why Canada is so expensive.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/05/world.main_headline: In a Tribute, Chile Reburies Allende
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/05/world.print_headline: In a Tribute, Chile Reburies Allende
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/05/world.body_text: **********The Allende family, led by one of the former President's daughters, Isabel Allende, organized the funeral with the help of the Aylwin Government, which sought to soften the effect of the funeral by not declaring national mourning or asking for military honors. **********The remains of Dr. Allende, who died as the presidential palace was under attack from the armed forces on Sept. 11, 1973, were disinterred this morning from an unmarked grave in a cemetery in Vina del Mar and driven to Santiago. **********The Alameda Bernardo O'Higgins, the widest thoroughfare in Santiago, was lined with people waving Chilean and Socialist flags as the caravan made its way to the Cathedral, where Archbishop Carlos Oviedo Cavada presided over a religious ceremony ''to present his soul to the Lord.'' Church officials said it was not a Mass. **********'Respect for the Church' **********The Archbishop said this was ''not the time or place to judge his public life and government,'' but he did refer to the fact that Dr. Allende was not a practicing Catholic. **********Despite Dr. Allende's lack of religious faith, the Archbishop said, he was the ''good son'' of a mother ''who was a very good Catholic'' and, as a result, he ''showed great respect for the church.'' **********Mr. Aylwin, whose speech was the main event in a ceremony just outside the cemetery before the coffin was placed in a new family mausoleum, said he was there ''to comply with the mandate of my conscious as a Chilean and a democrat.'' **********Like many others in recent days, including members of the Allende family, the President was careful to say that Dr. Allende deserved public tribute not just because he was President but also because of his more than three decades in democratic politics. **********This seemed an attempt to confront the argument of those who feel that the Allende Government - marked by property confiscations, economic mismanagement and general chaos - was so bad that it, as much or more than the military, was responsible for the rupture in Chile's democratic tradition. **********Mr. Aylwin, leader of the Christian Democratic Party, made clear he had come to bury Dr. Allende and not to praise him. He said Dr. Allende had been ''an idol for some, detested by others'' but that ''honoring a dead man is not an act of proselytism.'' **********''As the whole country knows, I was a political adversary of Salvador Allende,'' Mr. Aylwin declared as muffled boos came from the crowd. ''I say this because the only language in which we can understand each other is the language of the truth. I am here to give testimony to the truth.'' **********''I have to tell you, in all frankness,'' he continued, ''that if the same circumstances were to be repeated, then I would again be a decided opponent. **********''But the drama lived by Chile since 1973 has taught us that those circumstances should never repeat themselves. It is the duty of all Chileans to avoid them.'' **********Referring to as many as 2,000 Chileans who died for political reasons in the aftermath of the coup and whose remains have not been returned to the families, Mr. Aylwin said that even as Chile buried Dr. Allende it had ''another debt - with compatriots who still don't rest in peace.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/20/busin.body_text: **********The Soviet Union has opened a bank in the Chinese capital for the first time since relations between the two natons soured in the early 1960's, an official of the Soviet bank said today. The Vneshtorgbank (Foreign Trade Bank) began business on Jan. 12. The merchant bank still has no permanent offices in China and is operating in diplomatic quarters, the official said. Ties between the two countries became normal last May when President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union visited China, the first senior leader to go to Beijing in nearly three decades.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/17/world.main_headline: Fear Grows That Ethiopia Will Bar Relief to Famine-Stricken Area
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/17/world.print_headline: Fear Grows That Ethiopia Will Bar Relief to Famine-Stricken Area
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/17/world.body_text: **********Concern is growing over the reluctance of the Ethiopian Government to allow relief agencies to distribute food to the four million to five million people facing starvation in northern areas of the country, relief officials and American legislators say. **********Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar has just written to President Mengistu Haile Mariam of Ethiopia expressing concern about the threat of a major famine in the country and urging him to cooperate with relief agencies. On Jan. 5, Representative Tony P. Hall, Democrat of Ohio, the chairman of the House Select Committee on Hunger, also wrote to the Ethiopian leader voicing concern. **********The Bush Administration has urged Moscow to use its influence with the nominally Marxist Ethiopian Government to allow relief agencies into regions where the population will soon be facing starvation. **********Two Rebel Movements **********United Nations officials and Congress members say President Mengistu is dragging his feet because most of those affected by the Ethiopian drought are in areas held by the Eritrean People's Liberation Front and the Tigre People's Liberation Front, two rebel movements that have been fighting the Government in Addis Ababa for years. **********This contrasts with the situation in 1985, the time of the last great Ethiopian famine, when the bulk of those affected were in Government-controlled areas. Then, President Mengistu allowed international agencies to bring hundreds of thousands of tons of food into the country. **********In recent months the two rebel armies have been making gains on the ground, and President Mengistu has found that the Soviet Union is increasingly reluctant to supply his forces with arms and assistance. **********Last November, the Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, Yuli M. Vorontosov, visited Addis Ababa to say that Moscow would end its military treaty with Ethiopia when the accord expires in 1991. **********The President's View **********As a result, officials believe that President Mengistu has little incentive to agree to requests by the United Nations and Western governments to open routes that could be used by relief convoys to carry food and medicine to famine-stricken civilians in rebel areas. **********The idea of creating such routes was tested in the Sudan last year. The Government under Prime Minister Sadiq al-Mahdi and the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army, which was fighting in the south, agreed to let relief supplies pass along designated routes to famine-stricken civilians in the southern part of the country. **********The system worked well at first, and 111,000 tons of food and medical supplies have reached southern Sudan. But relief officials say the new Sudanese Government of Maj. Gen. Omar Hassan Ahmed al-Bashir, which took power shortly after the agreement was reached, recently changed its mind and stopped the movement of supplies to the south. **********Supplies Are Backed Up **********Relief flights into Government-controlled cities in the south have been halted since Dec. 3. Barges loaded with food are being held on the Nile, outside Khartoum, and a relief train loaded with 1,500 tons of supplies has been held in a siding since September. **********The Sudanese Government has accused the United Nations Children's Fund, which is running the relief operation, as well as private Western humanitarian organizations of aiding the rebel forces by smuggling arms and ammunition and by giving them food. **********Last November, the Ethiopian Government admitted that famine was threatening Eritrea and some other areas of the country and asked for 330,000 tons of food assistance. **********But the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization now thinks that Ethiopia may need up to 1.1 million tons of food, while the State Department estimates go as high as 1.6 million tons.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/11/world.main_headline: Rights Group Sees Failure by Guatemala Chief
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/11/world.print_headline: Rights Group Sees Failure by Guatemala Chief
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/11/world.body_text: **********President Vinicio Cerezo of Guatemala has failed to move against a surge of killings, abductions and torture perpetrated by the army, according to a report released this week by Americas Watch, an independent human rights group. **********The Guatemalan military ''remains a law unto itself,'' the real power in a country that supposedly became a civilian-ruled democracy four years ago, according to the 118-page survey entitled ''Messengers of Death.'' The report said the majority of the army's victims were students, church workers, Mayan Indians, human rights workers, trade unionists and journalists. **********Americas Watch said it could not determine the number of victims since the army would not allow local human rights groups to operate freely and collect data. The report offered the University of San Carlos in Guatemala City as one of several examples of the deteriorating situation. The university has been the target of ''a wave of killings and disappearances'' since August 1989, it said, adding that of 14 members of the university community abducted, 6 have been found dead and 5 remain missing. **********Claudia Arenas Bianchi, spokeswoman for President Cerezo, said: ''Americas Watch is incorrect. The President is doing all he can to control violations of human rights. We're advancing, although there are still some obstacles. The army is complying as it should within the democratic framework.'' **********Americas Watch is a New York-based human rights organization that has been writing reports from Central America for much of the last decade. Its surveys have been critical of leftist as well as rightist governments. **********The group did not hold Mr. Cerezo directly responsible for the killings, but charged that he acted as if his country's human rights problem was little more than a public relations problem. ''Instead of bringing the perpetrators to justice,'' the report charged, ''the Cerezo Administration has consistently tolerated and worse still, apologized for, unspeakable abuses committed by the men the President supposedly commands.'' **********U.S. Envoy Called Back **********The Americas Watch findings came only days after the Bush Administration withdrew Ambassador Thomas Stroock for a week's consultation in protest against the Guatemalan Government's failure to prosecute a number of recent human rights cases. A senior State Department official, speaking anonymously, said that Mr. Cerezo ''could do much more'' to rein in the army. **********Mr. Cerezo, a Christian Democrat who was inaugurated in January 1986 as the first civilian President of Guatemala in 16 years, began his term promising to end human rights abuses. But his power has steadily declined, especially after two unsuccessful coup attempts in 1988 and 1989. He will be replaced as President after an election scheduled to be held later this year. **********Guatemala has long been accused of having one of the worst human rights records in Latin America. Between 1979 and 1985, as the army put down a growing guerrilla insurgency, more than 40,000 Mayan Indians were killed. The army forced tens of thousands more Indians into militarized camps known as ''model villages.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/21/world.main_headline: Gold's Lure vs. Indian Rights: A Brazilian Conflict Sets the Amazon Aflame
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/21/world.print_headline: Gold's Lure vs. Indian Rights: A Brazilian Conflict Sets the Amazon Aflame
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/21/world.body_text: **********Named Operation Free Forest, a two-week police action in the northern Amazon has led a third of 45,000 illegal gold prospectors to leave Yanomami Indian lands, Justice Ministry officials say. **********But controversy flared this week after the Justice Ministry sought to soothe angry miners by offering them mining rights to about 7 percent of the jungle land claimed by the Yanomami. **********Officials are weighing the cultural importance of the Yanomami, considered to be the last major isolated tribe in the Americas, against the economic importance of an area estimated to have produced $1 billion worth of gold since 1987. **********Singer Joins the Battle **********Throughout the vast, mineral-rich Amazon, the battle between Indians and miners is becoming increasingly common and sharp. **********Last week, a federal judge ordered the closing of the sole access road to the world's largest modern tin mine, Pitinga, which accounts for 10 percent of world tin production. **********The judge ruled that an 18-mile stretch of road illegally cuts across a reserve of the Waimiri-Atroari Indians in Amazonas State. Since the Waimiri-Atroari started having frequent contact with whites 15 years ago, their number has dwindled from 3,000 to fewer than 400. **********Moving to protect another Amazon tribe, the Kaiapo, the British rock star Sting met on Tuesday in Brasilia with President Jose Sarney and a Kaiapo chief, Raoni. After the meeting, the singer reported that Mr. Sarney had agreed to sign a decree allowing about $2 million in international funds to be spent to demarcate a 19,066-square-mile reserve for the 2,000 Kaiapo in Mato Grosso State. **********But the sharpest clash in years came in recent days in Roraima State in the far north of Brazil where the federal Government has succumbed to growing national and international pressure to protect the Yanomami. **********Miners Stage Protests **********On Jan. 3, six medical teams were flown to remote Indian communities sprinkled around the 36,367-square-mile area recognized as ''Yanomami indigenous lands'' by Funai, Brazil's Indian protection agency, Since the gold rush started three years ago, the 10,000 Yanomami have been decimated by imported diseases, largely malaria, influenza and measles. **********But the next phase of Operation Free Forest - cutting off food and fuel to jungle miners - caused tensions to rise in Boa Vista, the young capital of Roraima. In that frontier state, mining is the last source of employment and the largest source of tax revenue. **********As police reinforcements started to arrive early this month, demonstrations by miners broke out almost daily in Boa Vista's central square. The square holds the city's only major monument, a cement rendering of a man in a broad brimmed hat panning for gold. **********''The People of Roraima Back the Miners'' read one banner at a demonstration at which prospectors applauded speakers who alternately attributed the Government's evacuation policy to multinational mining companies and the Vatican, a reference to official Roman Catholic support for Yanomami rights. **********One afternoon, angry miners set fire to grass outside the residence of the local Catholic Bishop, Aldo Mongiano. The Italian-born bishop, who now has police protection, has complained that telephone death threats against him increased after President Sarney announced the evacuation policy last month. **********Police Occupy Airstrips **********The miners' fears were fulfilled on Jan. 8, when the federal police occupied Boa Vista's international airport and seven unregistered dirt strips in the area. With as many as 400 takeoffs a day last month, the strips provided airborne umbilical cords, bringing food, diesel fuel and other supplies to the jungle mining camps. **********Since occupying the airstrips, the police have required pilots to file flight plans and have not allowed planes to take off with food and diesel fuel. **********Defying the police, a handful of pilots, known in Boa Vista as cowboys, repeatedly buzzed the control tower of the city airport on the first night of the flight ban. When a government plane tried to drop leaflets over the city, other planes flew so close that the shaken pilot was forced to land. **********Complementing announcements on the Amazon radio, the leaflets are to be dropped over the miners' 82 clandestine dirt strips and 200 river barges. They inform miners that they are working illegally on Indian land and offer them free transportation back to their towns of origin. **********So far about 18,000 miners are believed to have voluntarily deserted such mining camps as JB, Caveira and Burnt Bean. A Yanomami village that became the miners' major air hub, Paapayiu, is now a federal police base. **********But with 6,000 men holed up in mining camps around Bahian Ant, a particularly rich area, the police fear the hard part may be yet to come. **********Miners Stock Up **********Several miners have boasted that they flew in enough provisions last month to enable them to hold out in the jungle until March 15, the day Fernando Collor de Mello is to be inaugurated as the next President of Brazil. Mr. Collor, a free market conservative, easily swept the Amazon in the December elections. Roraima voters gave him his largest state margin in all of Brazil. **********Mr. Collor has not made public his stand on the gold miners. **********Early this month Rubem Vilar, a senator from Mr. Collor's home state, Alagoas, traveled to Boa Vista to express solidarity with the miners and to report by telephone to the President-elect, who was on vacation in Europe. **********On Monday, one of Mr. Collor's environmental advisers, Apoena Elles, said of the Yanomami lands, ''Now the situation has reached such a point that it is practically impossible to evacuate the area.'' **********To lure the miners out of the woods and to defuse the threat of violence in Boa Vista, Brazil's Justice Minister announced last week that a deal had been reached to allow the miners to prospect for gold in 2,567 square miles of national forest in Roraima. **********Accord an 'Escape Valve' **********''We have reached a solution Brazilian-style - with sugar and affection,'' the minister, Saulo Ramos, announced on Jan. 9. ''Taking out the miners is not like lining up pupils at a boarding school.'' **********Romeu Tuma, director general of the federal police, hailed the arrangement as an ''escape valve.'' **********An accord signed by Roraima State officials and miners' representatives requires the miners to deliver their firearms to the police, adopt equipment to cut the use of mercury in gold refining and pay a tax to be used to build and support schools and medical clinics for the Yanomami. **********''Gold miners are not animals to be hunted in the forest,'' said Romero Juca, the Governor of Roraima. **********But Indian rights groups, Catholic church leaders, environmentalists and federal prosecutors immediately denounced the arrangment as a violation of a judge's order last October that the miners be withdrawn from all Yanomami lands, an area twice the size of Switzerland. Critics said the new arrangement would set a precedent for opening up the two-thirds of Yanomami lands that are now classified as national forests. **********'A Complete Disaster' **********''It will be a complete disaster because the miners leave a trail of devastation wherever they go,'' said Fernando Cesar Mesquita, president of the Brazilian Institute of Environment and Renewable Resources. ''They level nature around the mines. They leave the rivers useless.'' **********Bishop Mongiano said, ''The miners are going to continue spreading diseases which kill the Indians, stealing their food, and polluting the river waters with mercury.'' **********International reaction has been sharp. Last week, Survival International, a private Indian rights group, sponsored a vigil in front of the Brazilian Embassy in London. In Washington, four American environmental groups cited the Yanomami drama and urged the World Bank not to approve a $160 million low-interest loan for development in Rondonia State, another area of the Amazon frontier. **********Mr. Collor is expected to be questioned on the matter when he embarks on a world tour that brings him to the United States Jan. 25 to 26.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/27/world.main_headline: Evolution in Europe;   As Soviet Union Grows Tense, U.S. Tourists Start to Shy Away
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/27/world.print_headline: Evolution in Europe;   As Soviet Union Grows Tense, U.S. Tourists Start to Shy Away
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/27/world.body_text: **********American tourists, who flocked to the Soviet Union in record numbers in 1988 and 1989, are thinking twice this year, travel companies and agents specializing in Soviet tours say. **********Though Americans are still eager to witness the changes in Soviet society, tour operators say, they are wary of running into perestroika's unlovely offspring - crime and ethnic unrest. Jay Schaffner, president of Anniversary Tours Inc., estimates that about 100,000 American tourists will visit the Soviet Union this year, down from about 120,000 last year. **********While tour operators say they have no sure way to measure the decline in the number of tours and the size of tour groups, they think that the travel advisory about street crime issued earlier this year by the State Department, the reports of tension in the independence-minded Baltic states and the violence in the Caucasus have helped depress the market. **********Neither Peak Nor Valley **********''It's a political market,'' said Caroline Cavalli, president of the Russian Travel Bureau in New York. ''If somebody sneezes on either side, it affects it. For 20 years we've had totally peaks and valleys. This is not really a valley, but it's not a peak either.'' **********A continued increase in prices, which have nearly doubled over the last five years, has not helped, they say. ''What's happened with this whole perestroika business is that every Soviet company is trying to make more hard currency than ever before,'' said Sidney Reiner, president of Cosmos Travel. **********The price increases have been steep, particularly from 1987 to 1989, when there was a 25 percent jump in Soviet-controlled costs, Mr. Schaffner said. And, Ms. Cavalli said delicately, ''there has to be a commensurate increase in service'' - a reference to the often-haphazard and sometimes churlish attention lavished on tourists in Soviet hotels and restaurants. **********Mr. Schaffner said the State Department's advisory on crime had caused four high school groups and two student groups from Northern Illinois University to cancel their plans, although one of the university groups recently rebooked for October. **********Perennial Frustrations **********Paradoxically, the falloff in tourism has not shortened the visa lines at the Soviet consulate in Washington, where a three-hour line of business executives, scientists, professors and tourists recently stretched for two blocks. **********The perennial frustrations of Soviet travel, from creaky bureaucracies to nonexistent restaurant service, have lessened somewhat over the last few years, but tour operators say Americans' curiosity and willingness to endure frustration may be eroding, particularly when there are new places to be curious about. Ms. Cavalli said the summit meeting between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev may change that. **********''Some of this is going to be cyclical, especially if there's something new out there,'' said Deborah Kolt, president of the Washington-based Academic Tours Abroad Inc. ''Berlin is swamped. You can't get a hotel bed in Berlin to save your life. People are going to Hungary and Czechoslovakia.'' **********A first class twin-bed room in a four-star hotel in Moscow costs about $143 a night, Intourist officials say. A 15-day group tour, which in the mid-1980's could sell for as little as $1,400, now is almost impossible to find under $2,200 - and often costs $2,800 or more. **********Pressure on Exchanges **********The same drive by Soviet organizations to insure their economic future by bringing in as much hard currency as possible is also putting pressure on the academic and cultural exchanges. Most exchanges are based on reciprocal visits, with Americans paying for the Soviets who come here and Soviet organizations hosting American students, writers, artists and musicians there. **********But the Soviet airline Aeroflot and some Soviet hotels are insisting that all tickets and rooms for foreigners must be paid for in convertible currency, not the increasingly scorned ruble. Soviet hosts - educational institutions, the Soviet concert agency Goskontsert, the Academy of Science -are reluctant to part with convertible Western currencies, which are in short supply in most Soviet organizations and are often the only way of paying for sophisticated technical equipment. **********''The ideas for exchanges are there, the interest is there, but it's increasingly hard to put these things together,'' said Molly Raymond, deputy coordinator of the President's United States-Soviet Exchange Initiative, a United States Information Agency office that handles exchange activities.
