''I see a lot of frustration out there.'' **********In particular, she fears that the new scramble for dollars and the determination of Aeroflot to earn hard currency are raising new complications for the growing array of American-Soviet exchanges. Many are fledgling efforts involving small towns, high schools or community hospitals that may have large resevoirs of good will, but little understanding of the frustrations involved. **********Aeroflot's Requirement **********Aeroflot earlier this year announced the requirement that all foreigners' tickets be paid for in convertible Western currencies, regardless whether they were tourists, who have always paid hard currency, or the guests of Soviet organizations, who have not. **********Aeroflot officials could not be reached for comment, despite several telephone calls. But the Soviet airline, like most other Soviet industries and service organizations, is part of the Government-mandated self-financing program, learning how to survive in an quasi-market economy. **********''I can understand why they are doing it,'' said Vasily Istratov, a Senior Research Fellow from Moscow based at Middlebury College. ''They are trying to teach themselves how to manage in real business.'' **********''We have a growing power of individual institutions and a deteriorating power of the center,'' he said. ''The situation is imbalanced in the country as a whole. The thing you can be sure of is hard currency.'' **********Mr. Istratov works with 65 Soviet students who are studying at 25 schools around the country as part of the undergraduate exchange program of the Intercollegiate Consortium. **********Charles Dillingham, president of the Entertainment Corporation U.S.A., said that Aeroflot brought up the issue of ticket prices in connection with the planned Soviet tour of the English National Opera Company later this month, but that Goskontsert, the Soviet sponsor of the tour, defused the problem. **********Could the regulation limit future eudcational and cultural exchanges? **********''No question.'' Mr. Dillingham said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/09/busin.main_headline: Will Hospitals Buy Yet Another Costly Technology?
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/09/busin.print_headline: Will Hospitals Buy Yet Another Costly Technology?
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/09/busin.body_text: **********Because of a small but growing number of cases like Andrea's, the developers of PET scanners say they are finally emerging from the medical wilderness. **********''After about 15 years of PET, the market is expanding rapidly,'' said Jerry Robinson, manager of the PET-cyclotron program at the General Electric Company's Medical Systems unit in Milwaukee. **********Indeed, the industry leader, the Siemens Medical Systems unit of West Germany's Siemens A.G., is installing 15 PET systems this year with its partner, Computer Technology Inc. of Knoxville, Tenn., triple the number for 1989. In all, about 30 PET systems - costing $3 million to $6 million each - are expected to be installed this year worldwide. That is a large increase given that the technology - which uses isotopes to track metabolism rates involving a variety of ailments - is now available in little more than 100 research hospitals. **********Moreover, the Federal Medicare program is taking a fresh look at PET to see if it has become a routine and cost-effective procedure that the Government would pay for, rather than just a research tool. A decision is expected next year. If the Government extends coverage for the procedure, which typically costs $1,200 to $2,200, private insurers would be pressed to follow suit. Only a few insurers now provide reimbursement. **********But despite these good omens, it is far from clear that PET scanners will become a medical fixture any time soon. Industry experts note that the Medicare study is coming at a time of tough budgetary constraints. And many insurers and employers are loath to unleash yet another big-ticket medical procedure after struggling for years against spiraling health costs. **********MEDICARE was severely criticized when it approved CT and magnetic resonance imaging (M.R.I.) for reimbursement ''and everybody went out and bought one,'' said David J. Archibald, a vice president with Siemens Medical Systems in Hoffman Estates, Ill. ''In today's cost-containment environment, you have to show that PET is not only useful but cost-effective compared with other procedures,'' said Sheri Samotin, a managing consultant with the Wilkerson Group, a health-care consulting firm based in New York. **********Some heart specialists say PET's value has been established in deciding whether to do bypass surgery, which can cost $30,000. By detecting whether cells in the heart muscle are metabolizing glucose, PET can tell if an otherwise inactive area is sufficiently alive to warrant a bypass. **********Researchers have also used PET in preparing for brain surgery, screening for Alzheimer's disease and spotting tumors that other scanning methods miss. **********PET systems employ a cyclotron to produce short-lived isotopes that emit particles known as positrons. The isotopes are joined chemically to natural substances like glucose or oxygen and injected into the patient's blood stream. Scanning machines then track the so-called tracer materials as they are metabolized in the body. **********Medical diagnostic imaging exploded into $8 billion in worldwide sales in the 1980's. Analysts say General Electric and Siemens each had more than $3 billion in medical imaging and equipment servicing sales last year. Thousands of hospitals and medical groups routinely screen patients and make diagnoses with CT and M.R.I. scanners. CT is based on X-rays while M.R.I. uses radio waves in a strong magnetic field to cause atoms to emit detectable energy. **********Although it detects things that CT and M.R.I. do not, PET has had trouble being accepted as a routine procedure eligible for insurance reimbursement. **********A few insurers have recently started to pay on a case-by-case and doctor-by-doctor basis. Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Florida, for example, said it covers PET scans to determine if heart bypass surgery or angioplasty, an alternative treatment for blocked coronary arteries, is worth trying. **********But the national Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association does not recommend paying for PET, although a study group is weighing the possibility of coverage in the future. The Health Insurance Association of America, an insurer trade group based in Washington, also plans a study this fall. **********The Federal Government review is the most important of all since insurers and employers rarely pay for a procedure until Medicare does. **********The Public Health Service will probably finish reviewing PET by year-end, said Dr. Thomas Holohan, director of the service's Office of Health Technology Assessment. But he said its recommendation would not go to Medicare until the Food and Drug Administration formally approves fluorodeoxyglucose, the tracer molecule in most PET scans. The F.D.A. will probably make its recommendation late next spring, after PET users compile records about the drug's safety, said J. Michael McGehee, the Washington-based executive director of the Institute for Clinical PET. The institute is gathering data in support of reimbursement. **********Several professional groups have cautiously endorsed PET. The American College of Cardiology said in March that the imaging ''appears to be useful'' in deciding whether to proceed with coronary bypass surgery. But the heart specialists added that PET's value in routine screening for heart disease has not been established. **********The American College of Radiology recently declared that PET also offers ''unique information'' in selecting patients for surgery for epilepsy who are not helped by drugs and in assessing brain tumors. **********But some experts remain skeptical about reimbursement. ''Everyone says that probably within a year, Medicare will start paying for PET,'' said Philip G. Drew, a consultant to radiologists and equipment makers in Concord, Mass. ''I think that is wishful thinking. I don't think it will take off.'' **********In any event, the PET industry has been trying to spread the high costs of the technology to stimulate sales. **********''It looks as though the cost of setting up a PET center is going to drop dramatically,'' said Neal C. Bradsher, a health-care securities analyst with Hambrecht & Quist. **********CTI Services, a unit of Siemens's partner, Computer Technology Inc., recently financed a cyclotron on the grounds of St. Joseph's Hospital in Tampa, Fla. CTI hopes to sell isotopes to several nearby hospitals, which would then not need their own cyclotron. U.C.L.A. may offer a similar service. **********The Positron Corporation, a privately held startup company based in Houston, has a system that goes a step further, eliminating the cyclotron entirely. It employs rubidium 82, a recently approved isotope, which is made with a much less expensive generator. Rubidium is now primarily used just for heart scans, however. **********Three University of Pennsylvania scientists - Gerd Muehllehner, Joel S. Karp and David Mankoff - cut costs by designing a scanner that uses six sodium iodide detectors instead of the thousands of tiny bismuth germanate detectors in other PET scanners. **********''The cost is just under $1 million, compared with $2 million to $3 million for other PET scanners,'' Dr. Karp said. UGM Medical Systems, a startup based in a university building, is making the machines. **********Other researchers, including some financed by the Government's Strategic Defense Initiative, are developing smaller, less costly, cyclotrons and alternative ways of producing isotopes, said G.E.'s Mr. Robinson. **********For its part, G.E. is working on engineering changes to make PET ''more reliable'' and easier to run with fewer high-priced physicists and chemists, Mr. Robinson said, adding, ''There will be a true clinical market in three to five years.'' **********KEEPING UP WITH THE RESEARCH **********Advances in the more established medical imaging techniques may complicate the prospects for PET, even as the companies that make the positron emission tomography scanners scramble for a niche in the market. **********''Medical imaging technology is advancing so rapidly it is difficult for most of us to keep up with it,'' said Dr. Gerald M. Pohost, a cardiologist and director of the University of Alabama Center for Nuclear Imaging Research in Birmingham. He said studies with magnetic resonance imagers, which are already widely used by physicians, ''can lead to images that look like PET.'' **********The center in Birmingham recently got an M.R.I. system from Germany that it describes as ''twice as powerful as any M.R.I. system now in clinical use.'' **********Dr. Pohost said M.R.I. studies have already had some success in determining whether an organ is being rejected after a transplant operation. The non-invasive scan could supplant the biopsy that is currently used whenever rejection is suspected. He also envisages a capability in which M.R.I. would look at fats inside the heart. **********Other researchers are working on magnetic resonance angiograms, which provide images of the blood flow without the need for injecting tracer materials. **********''From the patient's perspective, the fact that M.R.I. technology is non-invasive makes it very attractive for research, diagnosis and therapy design,'' Dr. Pohost said. **********In July, Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston announced plans to open a center for diagnostic imaging research. The hospital is associated with Harvard Medical School. **********The Sterling Drug Company, which makes imaging agents and is a unit of the Eastman Kodak Company, has pledged $18 million for the center, which would study M.R.I., magnetic resonance spectroscopy, PET and ultrasound. Spectroscopy and PET produce images of different aspects of metabolism.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/14/busin.snippet: LEAD: Managing a company is really like one big game of golf.
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/14/busin.main_headline:
The Executive Life;

Office or Golf Course, The Game Is the Same
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/14/busin.print_headline:
The Executive Life;

Office or Golf Course, The Game Is the Same
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/14/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: Managing a company is really like one big game of golf. **********Managing a company is really like one big game of golf. **********Just ask Harold (Red) Poling, chairman of the Ford Motor Company. Mr. Poling, an avid golfer with an eight handicap, believes his office game parallels his golf game. He says he strives for consistency in corporate decision-making just as he does on the links. **********''The three most important things in business and in golf are consistency, dependability and predictability,'' Mr. Poling said. ''If my game is good, it's because I'm consistent in my swing. I don't need a big wide fairway.'' **********In fact, the theory that an executive's golf game has direct correlations to how he or she performs on the job and in life is the subject of a new book on corporate leadership, called ''The Executive Trap,'' by Jay Hall, a Houston management consultant who has a doctorate in psychology. Having concluded that executives play all of their games the same way, Mr. Hall uses the game of golf to illustrate how executives make decisions. **********Mr. Hall, of course, is not the first to draw parallels between the types of games or sports people play and the way they function in life. Child psychologists have long studied play to gain insight into childhood disorders and learning habits. And common sense dictates that the hard-driving executive is likely to be just as relentless at his weekend tennis game as he is in the board room. **********Indeed, the way men and women learn to play games, and the importance they attach to those games, has always been recognized to be an outgrowth of their personalities. ''There's no question that all of us are affected by similar things in our lifestyle and in our golf,'' claims Jim Flick, a noted golf professional and 1988 Professional Golf Association Teacher of the Year. ''The toughest executives to teach golf to are engineers, accountants and lawyers. Because their work is so detail oriented, they are too tense and too controlled in their swings. They have no sense of rhythm in their golf swing. On the other hand, more hang-loose businessmen like salesmen are among the easiest to teach. In both work and in golf, they tend to look at the big picture. They never get bogged down in details.'' **********But what is novel about Dr. Hall's spiel is its focus on the game of golf as a key to understanding some of the problems that plague top executives. ''In its construction, golf is the one game that most nearly parallels human life experience,'' Dr. Hall said. ''In golf, you play the course, instead of playing someone else, and it is the only sport where people must call infractions on themselves. Integrity is what keeps it going. The temptations to cheat are the same as the moral decisions you have to make in life.'' **********In short, he claims, nothing duplicates the subtle nuances, exhilaration and bad breaks of life as well as the game of golf. And nothing, his theory goes, poses a bigger dilemma to executives both on the golf course and in the office than their ambivalence about making decisions. **********''We've got an epidemic of flawed executive leadership,'' Dr. Hall claimed. ''These executives either do not know how to make a decision or, once they do, are afraid to make it for fear that once they do, they'll have to give up something else that is important to them.'' **********In the office, such ambivalence might arise over a decision to give up some power to achieve better communication with colleagues. The equivalent on the course might be a conflict over whether to sacrifice distance in a particular shot for, say, accuracy. **********In Mr. Poling's case, it is not as much a matter of decision-making as playing strategically. He says he tries to imbue his management style with the same strong focus on strategy he uses in golf. ''In golf, as in business, you need to play strategically,'' he said. ''As you walk up to the next shot, you're not looking at the beautiful scenery around you. Instead, you're watching the terrain, noticing the impact of the wind, looking at the green to see the hazards. Then, if you miss the shot, you're trying to see how it can contribute to the game.'' **********He says he also reaches for balance in his game. ''Everyone likes to hit a drive the farthest, but you actually use a driver less than you do a putter,'' he said. ''You ought to put just as much emphasis on putting as on the rest of your game.'' **********Finally, Mr. Poling notes, an executive must be sensitive to timing - and act accordingly. ''In our business, you must get the product to market on time. If you delay, you'll miss the whole market for that product,'' he said. ''I learned about timing at a golf club in England, where the requirement was that you had to be finished with your game in three hours or less. My family and I would play 18 holes in three hours; over here you wouldn't even think of being able to do that. It showed me what you can do if you just concentrate.'' **********Mr. Hall named another Ford executive, David Scott, as a person who embodies his theory. Mr. Scott, who happens to be Ford's vice president of external affairs, is indeed enthusiastic about Mr. Hall's principles. ''So much of golf is between the ears,'' he said. ''I've gone from a 13 handicap to a nine handicap and my improvement has to do with applying some of the principles I've learned over the years in management to my game.'' But he said the real expert on the relationship between the sport and the office is his boss: Mr. Poling, whom he suggested as an interview. **********''He's got a beautiful, compact, consistent swing,'' he said. ''And in business, the way you get the best product is through teamwork and consistency.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/11/world.main_headline: Questions Arise as Whales Avoid Baja Waters
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/11/world.print_headline: Questions Arise as Whales Avoid Baja Waters
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/11/world.body_text: **********The thousands of gray whales that are normally drawn to the warm bays of Baja California to give birth have failed to show up so far this season, and the authorities say they do not know why. **********''This is the first time this has happened,'' the head of conservation for the Department of Ecology and Urban Development, Graciela de la Garza, said on Friday. **********Speculation about the reason for the whales' disappearance range from the effects of last year's oil spill in Alaska to a new cold-water current in the Pacific, near Mexico's western peninsula. Normally about 2,000 gray whales migrate to Baja California, giving birth to about 1,000 calves before returning to Arctic waters, marine mammal experts said. **********Only 12 to 20 have arrived so far this year, the Mexican authorities say. An American group said that 40 to 60 whales were spotted in recent days at one of four bays. **********Salt Content Attracts Whales **********The whales use the Vizcaino Biosphere Reserve, a six-million-acre protected zone, because high salt content helps those pregnant float and give birth, said Jorge Hernandez, a marine biologist for a committee that oversees the reserve. **********They calve in the bays of San Ignacio, Guerrero Negro, Magdalena and Ojo de Liebre, or Eye of the Hare, known to whale admirers in the United States as Scammon's Lagoon. **********The whales usually begin arriving in the first week of November. By April, most have left for Alaskan waters, Mr. Hernandez said. **********But the few that arrived this year did not start appearing until mid-December, the reserve's interagency coordinator, Ulises Cesena Montano, said. **********''We don't know the reasons,'' he said. ''There are only hypotheses.'' Anelio Aguayo, a marine mammal expert at the National University in Mexico City, cautioned that there are frequently ''transitory'' variations in the numbers of whales in the different lagoons. **********'We Need to Wait' **********''We need to wait for the end of the season and then see what the outcome is,'' Mr. Aguayo said. **********An ecological group made up of Mexican artists and intellectuals, the Group of 100, has suggested that an industrial salt plant in the reserve's buffer zone might be damaging water quality. **********But Miss de la Garza said the plant complies with environmental regulations and that constant monitoring has shown no degradation of water quality in Guerrero Negro, where the company operates. **********''We don't have serious water pollution problems in Baja California,'' said Mr. Cesena said in a telephone interview from La Paz. **********Some Blame Exxon Valdez **********Homero Aridjis, a poet who heads the Group of 100, speculated that the Exxon Valdez, which spewed 11 million gallons of oil in Alaska's Prince William Sound last March 24, the worst in United States history, might have affected the whales' migratory path. **********Davud Rugh, a biologist at the Washington marine mammal laboratory, said the whales' path runs near the port of Valdez. **********''That's why we ask if massive whale deaths might not have occurred all along the migration route,'' Mr. Aridjis said. Mr. Cesena said, ''It would be interesting to check out that theory.'' But, he added, ''I consider the water pollution theory very remote.'' **********He said the prevailing theory is that a a rare cold current is keeping the whales from their accustomed haunts in warmer water. The current is less than a mile from land in some places, he said. **********The temperature, strength and exact route of the current, called the Corriente de la Nina, are still being studied, and an aerial search is being conducted for whales in the Pacific, Mr. Hernandez said. **********''Once the cold water is past, maybe the whales will appear,'' Mr. Cesena said. He said only 20 whales have appeared so far. Miss de la Garza said the number could be as low as 12.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/18/world.main_headline: Peru Suggests U.S. Rethink Eradication in Land Where Coca Is Still King
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/18/world.print_headline: Peru Suggests U.S. Rethink Eradication in Land Where Coca Is Still King
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/18/world.body_text: **********Slipping his pistol into a desk drawer, Uchiza's Mayor smoothed his shirt and posed proudly by the city seal formally adopted here last month. **********"These leaves represent our most important crop," the Mayor, Demetrio Diaz Guevara, said with civic pride, pointing to an embroidered sprig of coca leaves. **********Indeed, as if jumping to life off the new municipal flag, coca is everywhere in this Amazon boomtown: soft and leafy in backyard gardens and on hillside plots, or crackly and brown on black plastic drying sheets. **********At tax time, some peasants even trudge into City Hall bearing 100-pound sacks as tribute. Eradication Effort's Failings **********This bumper crop is bad news for the United States, which is the major consumer of the end products of the jungle harvest: cocaine and crack. **********During the 1980's, the United States Government spent millions of dollars seeking to eradicate coca-leaf cultivation here in Peru's Upper Huallaga Valley, source of the raw material for half of the world's cocaine. **********A few miles from here, on the far bank of the muddy Huallaga River, stands the most visible evidence of the American effort, Santa Lucia base. From this heavily fortified base, helicopter-borne teams of American and Peruvian anti-drug agents destroyed in the last year about 150 coca-leaf processing laboratories and dozens of coca-bush nurseries. **********The eradication campaign has slowed crop expansion to a 10 percent annual increase. Paradoxically, without the American effort, coca cultivation probably would have exploded, setting off a price collapse and bankruptcy for many coca farmers. Drug Issue Becomes Marginal **********Today, many Peruvians and Americans are suggesting a reassessment of policies toward coca production. **********President Alberto Fujimori, an agronomist who took office on July 28, has retired top police officers involved in eradication efforts and declined to accept $36 million in American military aid. The money was to be used in part to intercept the small planes that take off daily from Uchiza's dirt airstrip, carrying up to 1,500 pounds of coca paste for cocaine powder refineries in neighboring Colombia. **********Advocating a gradual approach, the President proposed making alternative farm crops attractive by clearing away bureaucratic and infrastructure obstacles that peasants face here. **********In Washington, the drug issue has become increasingly marginal. With hundreds of thousands of American soldiers massed for war in the Persian Gulf, drugs no longer seem to be nation's "gravest domestic threat" -- a phrase used by President Bush last year. American Reporter Slain **********While Peruvians and Americans debate a new approach to the coca harvest, leaders of the new coca-growers union here complain that few policy makers make the 230-mile flight from Lima to this frontier town of 50,000 people, the largest in the Huallaga Valley. **********The dearth of visitors stems largely from the region's reputation for danger. **********Last year, a visiting American freelance reporter, Todd Smith, was kidnapped while he waited at Uchiza's airstrip for a plane out of here. Several days later, his mutilated body was found on Uchiza's main square, bearing a placard that said, "This is how Yankees die." **********More recently, on Oct. 19, the Peruvian Army general in charge of troops in the valley was ambushed and severely wounded as he drove on a road near here.  Changing Town's Violent Ways **********Such incidents are variously attributed to drug traffickers or two Marxist guerrilla armies that seek to win growers' support in the valley. **********Today, having just come from the wake of a former Mayor who was shot to death Wednesday night, Mr. Diaz said he was working to change Uchiza's violent ways. Carefully stepping around a sawed-off shotgun he keeps within reach of his swivel chair, Mr. Diaz warmly greeted a visitor to the town offices and handed out copies of Uchiza's first "Trade, Tourism and Services Guide." **********Published last month, the full-color brochure reveals that Uchiza has one Roman Catholic church, five Evangelical Protestant churches, five pool halls, 20 air-taxi services and 28 bars. Advertisers include two of Mr. Diaz's businesses -- Uchiza's only television station and Porky's, a discotheque that regularly attracts some of the best salsa bands from Lima. **********Turning on a overhead fan to move the humid tropical air through his office, the 34-year-old Mayor then pressed into a visitor's hand copies of the city's first newspaper, a monthly that started publication in September. Dependence on Coca Harvest **********"Eradication is not the solution," the current edition's editorial said about the coca harvest. **********"Violent eradication would leave peasants without an economic base to survive, increasing the chances that 200,000 peasants would join the subversive groups" it continued, echoing a widespread sentiment here. **********Mr. Diaz, a native son who was overwhelmingly elected last November, estimated that 80 percent of Uchiza's economy revolved around the coca leaf. The coca growers, inhabitants of the tin-roof shacks that dot the deforested hills around here, are largely refugees from the left-wing terrorism that plagues the Peruvian Andes. **********Peru's Government calculates that one million people of the nation's population of 22 million depend on coca harvests for their livelihood. Probably the nation's largest export, Peru's coca-leaf harvest annually sells for $1 billion to $1.5 billion. **********Climbing behind the wheel of his car for a tour of the town, Mr. Diaz said that the major obstacle blocking a switch to legal crops is transportation. **********He said the road to Lima was so bad that it takes 38 hours for a truck to travel the 270 miles to the capital on the Pacific Ocean. **********Because of high transportation costs, bribes demanded by guerrillas and policemen, and export monopolies, coffee growers in the valley receive only 30 percent of their export price. In constrast, American farmers generally receive 90 percent of the price of products at the port, according to the Institute of Freedom and Democracy, a free-market research group that prepared Mr. Fujimori's anti-drug proposal. **********"To send a load of wood to the coast is as expensive as sending the same wood from the coast to Rotterdam," said another member of the city tour, Rolando del Aguila Hidalgo, adviser for the newly created Institute for the Integrated Development of the Upper Huallaga. Change 'If It's Profitable' **********On the city tour, Mr. Diaz took pains to point out the kind of American aid that locals appreciate: a steamroller, three dump trucks and a road grader, all provided by the United States Administration for International Development. **********Working on clearing new city streets, the American-provided road building equipment is the kind of development aid that residents here say could eventually allow crop substitution. **********"All our 1,400 members grow coca," Justo Silva Vallon, manager of the Upper Huallaga Agricultural Cooperative, said in an interview at the cooperative's newly inaugurated office building. **********"The peasants want to change -- if it's profitable," he continued, referring to such alternative crops as coffee, cocoa and corn. **********A more militant stance was taken by Mario Campo Roldon, a board member of a new group, the Defense Front Against Coca Eradication in the Upper Huallaga. **********"We are tired of studies, speeches and promises," Mr. Campo said, his chest glistening with sweat in the Amazon heat. "We want to substitute, but we want concrete facts -- better roads, agricultural extension services." **********Growers here said they were skeptical of Mr. Fujimori's drug proposal of Oct. 26, saying it was intended more to mollify American public opinion than to deliver services here. Indeed, the speech was written by officials in Lima who are keenly aware that six months from now, the United States Congress must certify that Peru is cooperating in the war on drugs in order for Peru to win a large portion of the $250 million in American aid proposed for Peru in 1991. **********The minimal interest shown by Peru's army in stopping the drug trade was illustrated at the end of the day at the airport here, one of the busiest of 150 strips estimated to be used to ship coca paste north to Colombia. **********Asked about the large number of late-model, long-haul airplanes parked in the grass by the dirt strip, the local army commander replied, "What's the point of arresting drug dealers if more are just going pop up to take their place?"

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/18/world.main_headline: U.S.-Peruvian Teams Renew Drive on Coca
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/18/world.print_headline: U.S.-Peruvian Teams Renew Drive on Coca
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/18/world.body_text: **********After a yearlong break to strengthen security, a joint Peruvian-American force has resumed eradication of coca plants in the Upper Huallaga Valley, a guerrilla stronghold in northern Peru that is the source of half of the world's cocaine crop. **********''This time, we are targeting the seedbeds,'' a United States Embassy official said of the clandestine nurseries. ''One square meter can hold as many as 10,000 seedlings.'' **********For the United States, the world's largest cocaine-importing country, eradication is an emergency measure against Peru's swelling crops of coca leaf. The State Department says coca leaf production in Peru jumped 25 percent last year, to 124,408 tons. **********Peruvian workers, carried in American-supplied helicopters, are to cut through the seedbeds with gas-powered weeders. Piloted by Americans, the UH-1H Huey helicopters will leave from Santa Lucia, a fortified base built with American money in the heart of the Huallaga Valley. **********The eradication program was suspended in February 1989 after workers and helicopters came under heavy fire from guerrillas of the Shining Path, the Maoist-oriented movement that has forged a tactical alliance with coca growers. Since then, the Peruvian Army has carried out a counterinsurgency campaign in the valley, killing 1,300 guerrillas. The Santa Lucia base started operating in September. **********Laboratories Are Destroyed **********Flying sorties from the base in January and February, Peruvian national police units and United States Drug Enforcement Administration teams have destroyed 24 coca-processing laboratories and dynamited three airstrips used by traffickers from Colombia. **********Peru is to receive $36 million in American military aid this year, the first substantial military aid here since 1969. The aid includes river patrol boats, trucks, tents and rations. In addition, the police will receive about $19 million, mostly for air transport. **********The aid may be used against narcotics traffickers or against their guerrilla protectors. ''In the case of the Upper Huallaga, the security situation is exacerbated by subversion,'' the American official said. ''You can't draw a black and white line.'' **********American reconnaissance will identify coca seedbeds, whose lime green color stands out against the dark green of the mature bushes In the Huallaga Valley, an estimated 200,000 people depend on coca growing for their livelihood, and there have been predictions that the renewed eradication will bring intensified attacks on American targets. In the last two months, bombs caused minor damage at the residence of Marine guards of the United States Embassy in Lima and at an embassy warehouse. **********Guerrillas Have Mortars **********Late in February in Ayacucho, 500 miles south of Santa Lucia, the army reportedly uncovered a Shining Path arms cache that included mortars. **********''It is the first time that Shining Path has had mortars,'' said Gustavo Gorriti, a Peruvian journalist who is completing a three-volume history of the movement. ''Santa Lucia is very vulnerable to mortars.'' **********At the United States Embassy, an official scoffed at the suggestion that the guerrilla group might attack the new base. ''If you look at the Shining Path, they never pick the hard targets,'' he said. ''They always go for soft targets.'' ''We have night vision, flares, automatic weapons, bunkers and choppers waiting on the ground,'' the official continued. ''If they attack Santa Lucia at night, we can light up that sky.'' **********Strategy for combating coca cultivation is a major issue in the campaign for presidential elections on April 8. **********The novelist Mario Vargas Llosa, the leading candidate in public opinion polls, advocates a two-fold strategy. ''Raise the cost of cultivation through police action,'' he said in a recent speech. At the same time, he said, he would make crop substitution attractive by giving peasants title to their lands, as well as credit, crop advice and free-market prices. **********Peruvian peasants have increasingly turned to coca cultivation because of the enormous demand for cocaine in the United States.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/25/world.main_headline: Bulgarian Communists Agree to Delay Voting
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/25/world.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;   Bulgarian Communists Agree to Delay Voting
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/25/world.body_text: **********The Communist Party has agreed to remove its representatives from the work place and to postpone elections by a month, until June, the state press agency said. **********The Communists' Supreme Council also decided on Friday to let Communists vote on whether to change the name of their party to the Bulgarian Socialist Party, the agency said. **********Communist Party members would be eligible to vote in the May referendum, the agency said. Communist parties in other Eastern bloc countries have changed to Socialists professing democratic ideals, in an attempt at winning support before elections. **********The Supreme Council agreed in principle to abandon the Communist Party's right to organize in factories, enterprises and administrative units, a key demand by the democratic opposition, participants in the meeting said. **********The Supreme Council proposed to hold Bulgaria's first multiparty elections in June, not in May as previously announced. The opposition, however, has demanded a wait until November.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/11/world.main_headline: Gorbachev Explains Proposed Union Pact to Party
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/11/world.print_headline: Gorbachev Explains Proposed Union Pact to Party
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/11/world.body_text: **********President Mikhail S. Gorbachev told Communist Party leaders today that they had nothing to fear from his proposal for a new treaty on the union, which proposes dropping the word "socialist" from the country's name and replacing it with "sovereign." **********The treaty plan, intended to refine the structure of the nation, contains "strong expressions of the ideas and principles we connect with socialism -- its humanistic, democratic nature," Mr. Gorbachev told the party's Central Committee in a closed-door session. **********Mr. Gorbachev, who is also head of the the Communist Party, urged partyleaders to create a "strong political desire for the preservation and renewal of the union," despite separatist strains that have brought declarations of sovereignty and independence all over the nation. **********"What is profitable for separatists is absolutely fatal for the majority of workers," Mr. Gorbachev said, according to a text of his speech that was was carried by the Government press agency Tass. **********Several of the 15 republics already have dropped "Soviet socialist" from their names as a rejection of decades of Soviet Communism. **********Last week, hard-line members of thenational Parliament demanded that Mr. Gorbachev suspend steps toward democratic reforms as a way to hold the union together. They suggested that he be replaced if he does not take action. **********Some European leaders also have expressed fears that civil strife could cause millions of Soviet citizens to flee across international borders. **********Mr. Gorbachev's draft treaty, which would replace a document dated 1922, envisions changing the country's name from "Union of Soviet Socialist Republics" to "Union of Sovereign Soviet Republics." **********The President said his proposal wasa government document, not the statement of a political party. **********"Will there be a union of strong sovereign states or a crumbling symbolic formation?" he asked the members of the Central Committee, a policy-making group for the 17-million-member party, which has been steadily losing members and authority. **********The draft treaty never mentions the words "socialism" or "Communism." It divides powers between the central Government and the republics, and says "economic development strategy" will be determined jointly. **********It would give more economic power to the republics, while retaining Kremlin control over the military, foreign policy, transportation, energy and other key industries. **********Six republics have already said they will not sign and have demandedKremlin endorsement of their sovereignty declarations. **********All the Soviet republics except Kirghizia in Central Asia have declared some form of autonomy or independence. **********Lawmakers in Kirghizia had sovereignty on their agenda as they opened a session today. Tass reported that the Speaker of the republic's Parliament, Absamat Masaliyev, resigned today to concentrate on duties as a Communist Party official, Tass reported. It was unclear whether his resignation was connected to the republic's sovereignty debate. **********In Moscow, Mr. Gorbachev also criticized the "war of laws," in which national and republic lawmakers have passed conflicting legislation, paralyzing the economy. He has said the treaty is needed to stave off economic collapse. **********"If patches of land, divided by customs barriers, independent currencies or even border guards form in place of an all-union market, vast opportunities will be lost," he said. **********He reiterated his insistence that no republic can secede without a referendum. **********Mr. Gorbachev also rejected proposals for adopting new constitutions in each republic before signing the Union Treaty. He said inter-republic agreements were acceptable only if they did not supplant the Union Treaty. Nearly a dozen such bilateral treaties have been signed. **********Earlier today, Tass said rumors that Mr. Gorbachev will step down as Communist Party chief were "totally unfounded." Such rumors have been circulating for a year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/16/busin.main_headline: Fed Blocks Banks' Merger, Citing Concerns on Capital
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/16/busin.print_headline: Fed Blocks Banks' Merger, Citing Concerns on Capital
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/16/busin.body_text: **********In the clearest signal yet of the importance the Federal Reserve Board places on banks maintaining high levels of capital, the nation's central bank today rejected a proposal by the Bank of New York to acquire a $2.7 billion Connecticut bank-holding company, citing concerns that the resulting institution would not have sufficient capital reserves. **********The Bank of New York, which has $19.1 billion in deposits and is the country's 12th-largest bank, had proposed to pay $195.6 million in the merger with Northeast Bancorp Inc., New Haven, which is the parent of the Union Trust Company, Stamford. **********The rejection was the first in several years by the Fed of an acquisition application by a major bank-holding company. **********The Bank of New York said in a brief statement that ''in view of this decision, the acquisition cannot proceed.'' Northeast could not be reached for comment. **********In recent years, banking regulators have forced the industry to build capital reserves, which are a percentage of an institution's assets that are held in reserve to absorb future losses. **********But Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, has urged even higher levels. Just last month, he told the Senate Banking Committee that the single most effective means of insuring stability and strength in the banking system was high levels of capital. **********Today's action gave the Fed an opportunity to demonstrate publicly what it has been saying privately for a long time, said one banking expert who asked not to be named: ''They expect very high capital ratios.'' **********Even before today's decision, however, the merger was in doubt. Bank of New York and Northeast were in a dispute over the value of the Connecticut concern. Northeast had placed its acquisition value at about $500 million. But Bank of New York said that, after looking at the institution's books, a large reduction in the value of its loans would be needed and the actual value of the institution was $195.6 million. **********In 1983, when the two companies agreed to merge as soon as Connecticut law allowed acquisitions by out-of-state banks, Northeast's banking market was thriving. But in January, J. Carter Bacot, chairman of the Bank of New York, said that the weakening trend in the New England ecnomy suggested that the Connecticut company faced difficult times. Earlier that month, Northeast had announced a big increase in troubled loans that cut 1989 profits to $632,000 from $34.6 million in 1988, The Connecticut legislation was approved in March to permit banks in that state to be acquired by out-of-state banks, but because of the financial dispute between Bank of New York and Northeast, industry analysts had been expecting that even if the Fed approved the transaction, it would not have been completed by the two parties. **********Nevertheless, today's signal on capital requirements will not be lost to the industry. **********Mr. Greenspan appears to have strong support for his position on the board, where the vote to reject the Bank of New York's application was unanimous. **********''The board has stated that it expects banking organizations contemplating expansion proposals to maintain strong capital levels substantially above the minimum levels specified by the board's capital adequacy guidelines,'' the Fed said today. **********''The board carefuly analyzes the effect of expansion proposals on the preservation of strong capital levels and has adopted a policy that there should be no significant diminution of financial strength for the purpose of effecting major expansion,'' it said. **********High Amount of Good Will **********In particular, the Fed said it was rejecting the bid by the Bank of New York because the resulting institutions would have very high levels of so-called intangible capital, particularly good will. **********Good will is generally the premium paid in an acquisition above the market value of an institution, and regulators have complained it is, in essence, a worthless book entry and does not represent a real cash cushion. **********''After the proposed acquisition, tangible capital ratios for the combined organization would not be substantially above the board's minimum capital levels and would be less than the current average levels of the Bank of New York's peer group of the nation's largest regional banking organizations,'' the Fed said. **********Future Implications **********The implications of today's action for the banking industry are significant. It would appear that in the future, only the banks that can maintain profitable businesses and continue to build large capital pools will be permitted to expand through mergers or acquisitions. **********Bank of New York had proposed to pay $195.6 million for Northeast Bancorp either by selling subordinated debt, or through a cash and stock transaction. **********But the Fed said in its statement that in addition to overall measures of capital falling unacceptably low as a result of the merger, either financing technique would leave the bank's levels of cash-like capital assets, often referred to as tangible capital, below levels agreed to under an agreement made between Bank of New York and the Fed when it acquired the Irving Bank Corporation in 1989. **********The Fed said that antitrust issues, such as excessive concentration, were not a concern. **********The Fed announcement was made after the close of stock trading.On the New York Stock Exchange earlier, Bank of New York shares fell 12.5 cents each, to $24.50. In over-the-counter trading, Northest Bancorp was up $2 a share, to $17.50.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/21/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY; Cutting the Computer Wire Snarl
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/21/busin.body_text: **********Swarming under floors, above ceilings and through elevator shafts of virtually every modern office building are hundreds and thousands of wires and cables. Forming bunches as thick as a fat man's waist near the center of each floor, they fan out across offices to telephones, answering machines, lamps and computers. **********But as more machines crowd the nation's desks, this snarl of wiring threatens to throttle some companies' ability to rearrange staff and departments. To eliminate the newest and fastest-growing family of wires -- the ones connecting computers -- electronics and computer companies have begun introducing products to link computers with light, radio and microwave signals. **********Last month, the NCR Corporation introduced a personal computer circuit board that sends and receives ultrahigh-frequency radio signals at a rate of two million bits a second and costs $1,395. The Photonics Corporation, Campbell, Calif., has been shipping since September 1989 an infrared light device that transmits one million bits of data a second, costs $1,195 and serves four computers. **********Motorola Inc. says its wireless product, expected early next year at a price up to $2,000 a unit, runs at 15 million bits a second, fast enough for all the standard networking software now used with wires. And Apple Computer Inc., in preparation for its own entry into the market, is petitioning the Federal Communications Commission to set aside for computer communications some radio frequencies very similar to those now used by cellular telephones. **********A few small companies have been selling wireless computer links for more than a year, but these have been fairly simple devices that moved data and programs too slowly to meet most demands. The recent products are up to 700 times faster. But while the cost of computers has plummeted as their speed has increased, wireless computer links remain expensive. **********"Technologically, it works, but it's expensive and the question is, what will make people pay up?" said Andrew Kessler, an electronics industry analyst at Morgan Stanley & Company. **********Wireless computers could have many applications. Investment bankers could set up a task force at a takeover target's headquarters and start exchanging financial models within minutes. Department-store cash registers, which are now connected by wire to computers that track sales and inventory, could be moved frequently as new displays are set up. **********The current rat's nest of copper wiring in most buildings presents several problems. Moving a computer that is part of a network to another desk is time-consuming and can, according to Motorola, cost $200 to $3,000, depending on the age of the building. The wires are often severed, jostled loose or simply misconnected, which accounts for more than half of all network failures. Clogged Buildings **********The wiring conduits of some buildings, particularly older ones, have become so stuffed that a company seeking to install more gear must raise the floors, lower the ceilings or move to a new address. Salomon Brothers Inc., for example, is moving out of its headquarters on Water Street in downtown Manhattan in part because the continued installation of more sophisticated equipment would force the investment bank to gut and rebuild several floors. **********The availability of wiring even affects rents on commercial property. "It can make a difference of anywhere from a couple dollars a square foot to $10 or $20 a square foot," said Brendan P. Weiden, an associate partner in electrical engineering at Jaros, Baum & Bolles, a large engineering consultancy in New York. **********American companies spend about $3 billion a year wiring computers together, a fast-growing market that is prompting heavy investment in wireless alternatives. **********"We've spent a prodigious amount of money on this technology, many, many tens of millions of dollars," said Edward F. Staianao, the president of the Motorola division that produces cellular telephones and computers. Three Types of Products **********Although many companies are going into wireless computer communications, the products of Photonics, NCR and Motorola are representative of three broad categories. **********The Photonics device is a fancy version of a television remote control. It involves bouncing infrared light signals off ceilings or walls to relay information to other computers. The advantages are that it seems to be cheap and safe. The problem is that it requires a large, open office, because the signal does not go around corners or through doors. **********The NCR system uses ultrahigh-frequency radio waves and Motorola uses microwaves, both of which can travel through doors, thin walls and people without disruption. **********The NCR system uses a new transmission technology that relies on encoding an ultrahigh-frequency radio signal from each computer with a different code. Much as a person at a dinner party hears many voices but listens to only one, computers on this system can send and receive coded signals over the same broad band of frequencies with each computer decoding only the signal of the computer with which it is communicating. **********This system divides and distributes the signal across many different frequencies, with only a little data on any one frequency at a time. NCR was forced to use this technique because its product uses radio frequencies shared by products that cause interference, like wireless microphones, some walkie-talkies and theft-prevention devices at department-store exits.  Motorola's Approach **********Motorola has taken a different approach. The Federal Communications Commission in April granted the company exclusive rights in all the nation's larger cities to several microwave frequencies. Because interference with other devices is not a problem, Motorola will be able to forgo coded signals and use the better-known technology of several computers each taking turns a few milliseconds long on the same frequency. **********What has prevented electronics companies until now from using products that take turns has been the problem of echoes. Stray signals can bounce off walls and arrive out of turn at a receiver, interfering with the next computer's signal. **********Motorola says it has solved this problem. Instead of broadcasting a signal that covers an entire office, its product uses a hexagonal antenna that sends a tight beam to the intended receiver. "It's kind of like looking through a telescope at another guy looking at you through a telescope," said Alan P. Zabarsky, the general manager of Motorola's unit for wireless computer networks. Concerns Over Health **********Public concerns that high-frequency radio waves and microwaves pose a cancer risk are a drawback, although little energy is used to send signals. "I don't think there's any hazard at those levels, but try to convince people of that," said Richard C. Allen, president of Photonics. **********NCR says its system uses only a tenth of the maximum power allowed by even the world's most stringent health regulations. Motorola says its higher-frequency signal uses only 4 percent of the power of NCR's system because the signal is sent in only one direction. **********"When I broadcast focused, I broadcast less, because I don't spray it everywhere," Mr. Zabarsky said. **********Doing away with the wires that connect computers still leaves the snarls of telephone lines that wiggle through most offices. Motorola is testing tiny wireless telephones using different microwave frequencies from its computer connections, and Mr. Staiano acknowledged that combining these telephones with the wireless computer links was a likely move.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/25/world.body_text: **********Conflict over United States policy toward El Salvador flared up today in Congress as a Bush Administration official defended the conduct of the Salvadoran armed forces and resisted efforts to reduce American aid. **********Bernard W. Aronson, the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, said the killings of six Jesuit priests in El Salvador in November were an aberration. **********''This is a very dirty war in El Salvador,'' he said. ''I don't think it indicts the armed forces if a unit commits an atrocity. I don't think it's the norm.'' The Government of President Alfredo Cristiani does not tolerate the killings and is vigorously investigating them, Mr. Aronson said. **********He testified at a hearing of the House Foreign Affairs Committee that was repeatedly interrupted by demonstrators protesting United States policy in El Salvador, especially the continuation of military aid. **********Military Aid Defended **********Mr. Aronson said the suspension of such aid would not help peace negotiations and would produce ''even more savage violence'' in El Salvador. ''If El Salvador did not have the means to defend itself,'' he said, ''it would be a much more hellish, violent and brutish place.'' **********But several House Democrats agreed with Representative Sam Gejdenson, Democrat of Connecticut, who said, ''We ought to stop aid for a period of time.'' **********He said ''the pipeline of money from Washington'' had given Salvadoran military men a sense that they had a free hand to violate human rights. ''If I were a Salvadoran military officer, I'd figure I could take this money to the bank, no matter what I might do,'' Mr. Gejdenson said. ''This Administration and its predecessor have lost credibility.'' **********Mr. Aronson said in response: ''Our aid is not a blank check. We have expectations as to how the aid will be used.'' **********He said the United States was prodding El Salvador to continue its investigation of the Jesuit killings and to pursue possible suspects beyond the eight military men who have already been arrested. **********''This investigation is not over, nor should it be over,'' Mr. Aronson said. ''I have been assured by President Cristiani that it will not end until every possible question and lead has been exhaustively investigated.'' #15 Are Arrested The United States Capitol police arrested 15 people in the audience who disrupted the hearing by shouting objections to American policy in El Salvador. The police arrested nine others who marched through a nearby corridor chanting, ''Stop the funding, stop the war, U.S. out of El Salvador!'' **********Mr. Aronson declined to say if the Administration would support Congressional efforts to attach conditions to American aid for El Salvador, which now totals $1.4 million a day. But he encouraged Congress to keep up the pressure, saying, ''I don't think it hurts for you to keep pressing us, and we will keep pressing the Salvadoran Government.'' **********Mr. Aronson said the Federal Bureau of Investigation had helped the Salvadoran Government search for the killers of the Jesuit priests. But in response to questions, he said, ''The judicial system down there is not exactly a model of justice,'' and he declared that the Salvadorans ''do not have a justice system worthy of the name.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/14/busin.main_headline: The Pedestrian Sneaker Makes a Comeback
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/14/busin.print_headline: The Pedestrian Sneaker Makes a Comeback
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/14/busin.body_text: **********They are advertisements with a wink. A playful young mother lies on her back and balances her giggling tot on her ankles and feet, which are clad in plain white canvas sneakers. The caption: ''Keds introduces weightlifting shoes.'' **********Barbara A. Scott, marketing vice president for Keds, says the intended message is ''you don't have to sweat your brains out to wear our shoes.'' **********That no-sweat marketing approach by Keds in its new television and print ads is a deliberate contrast to the frenetic athletes and dancers prancing through the typical sneakers commercial. So far, it has helped Keds capitalize on what many industry analysts say is a fundamental change in consumer preferences for casual footwear. Consumers seem to be moving back toward the mostly simple designs of sneakers that are Keds's staples. The shift is already hurting brands like L.A. Gear, whose sales of expensive shoes in elaborate designs and unusual color combinations have plummeted. **********Except for Nike Inc., the industry leader, most footwear companies have seen sales of their most expensive shoes drop off, while the less expensive, and therefore less profitable, brands continue to sell well. Largely because of this trend, Salomon Brothers estimates that 1990 industry sales, in terms of dollars, will grow 10 percent, compared with nearly 30 percent as recently as 1988. **********There is much uncertainty in this part of the footwear industry. A lot of it stems from the fact that the companies are really more marketers than manufacturers. Many of the major companies get their shoes from the same factories in Taiwan and South Korea. **********''Shoes are all basically the same,'' said David Lubars, whose Leonard Monahan Lubars & Partners advertising agency developed the campaign for Keds. ''What you try to build is an image of what's cool and who wears the shoe.'' **********Owned by the Stride Rite Corporation of Cambridge, Mass., Keds has become the country's fourth-largest brand, overtaking Converse Inc., analysts say. Keds's casual footwear is not really in the same league as the brawny athletic shoes made by Nike and Reebok, or L.A. Gear's fashion sneakers. But analysts note that 80 percent or more of athletic shoes never go near a basketball or tennis court, anyway. Instead they wind up as street shoes worn around the house or out to the mall and movies. **********Until recent months, Keds seemed to be out of favor. Sales had slowed so much that Stride Rite announced last December that it expected revenue to grow by just 10 percent in 1990. Stride Rite's stock plunged on the news, prompting a hostile takeover bid by Walsh Greenwood & Co., the Greenwich, Conn., investment concern, which Stride Rite successfully resisted. **********Sales have rebounded since then and analysts are now projecting Keds's growth rate will top 20 percent, or double that of the industry, to $270 million in sales this year. Once known mainly as a children's brand, Keds have had especially strong appeal since the late 1980's to working mothers and professional women, who often buy several pairs. At about $20, these canvas sneakers cost a third of the average leather-bound Reeboks or Nikes, which average $60 or more. **********Sales are sluggish or declining in much of the $5.3 billion athletic footwear industry, but analysts say Keds could still flourish in an economic recession because of their low price. **********Hardest hit among the major companies has been L.A. Gear, the California-based company whose expensive fashionable shoes appeal mainly to young women. Earlier this summer, L.A. Gear announced a sharp drop in net income for the second quarter. Company officials cited reluctance by recession-conscious retailers to stock expensive footwear and sales volume moving toward cheaper L.A. Gear shoes. L.A. Gear's stock plummeted 22 percent. Recently, the company said the third-quarter net would also be down. **********Nike continues to prosper using a powerful advertising campaign that features the multiathletic talents of Bo Jackson. With projected 1990 sales of more than $1.5 billion, Nike may post sales growth of 30 percent this year, coming on top of a 20 percent rise last year. **********But even Nike's latest results disappointed investors accustomed to runaway growth. When Nike reported last month a first-quarter earnings rise of 31 percent, to $99.7 million, and a 38 percent gain in revenues, to $833.6 million, its stock fell. Nike closed Friday at $30, up $2 a share, in over-the-counter trading. **********Reebok, at No. 2 with $1.3 billion in projected 1990 sales, said recently that it expects a third-quarter drop in profits and a flat year for earnings. Converse, Avia and Adidas are expected to show sales declines, analysts say. Most footwear stocks are trading near their 52-week lows. **********''In the last six months, there has been a dramatic shift from fashion-oriented shoes back to basics,'' said Heidi R. Steinberg, a footwear analyst with Salomon Brothers. ''People don't want a lot of doodads anymore.'' **********Steven B. Frankel, an analyst with Adams, Harkness & Hill in Boston, noted that Keds, lacking high profile endorsements by expensive celebrity athletes or rock stars, was in a good marketing position. **********''Keds are not in as fickle a market as L.A. Gear,'' Mr. Frankel said. ''They don't need Michael Jackson. They don't need Bo Jackson. They are getting Mrs. Jackson from 1234 Anywhere Street, U.S.A.'' Reebok, for one, disagrees. Unlike most footwear companies, Reebok has managed to market its athletic shoes well to men and women, and says it is too early to tell if there has been a fundamental change. **********''There's a lot of shifting back and forth going on out there,'' said David C. House, vice president for sales for the Reebok brand. ''Where it stops nobody knows.'' But like other footwear companies, Reebok is seeing an increase in the sales of its less expensive models. **********Keds practically invented the sneaker. Around the turn of the century, shoemakers were gluing melted, or ''vulcanized,'' rubber onto canvas tops. In 1917, the U.S. Rubber company introduced Keds, the first popularly marketed sneaker, so nicknamed because the wearer's footsteps were so quiet. **********The brand was originally named Peds, Latin for foot, but another company already had registered the name. So Keds, with its evocation of kids, was chosen instead. The first Keds had black soles and chestnut brown canvas tops. **********Sneakers changed little until the 70's and early 80's, when nouveau sports like jogging and aerobics gained in popularity. Phil Knight, a runner at the University of Oregon, and his coach, Bill Bowerman, invented Nikes, named after the Greek goddess of victory, because they wanted shoes that were lighter and had better traction than the available tennis and basketball shoes. In the 80's, Reeboks, named after a swift African mammal resembling a gazelle, became popular mainly with women seeking comfortable shoes for aerobic exercises. **********As those changes swept by, Keds's sales started sinking. The company tried to compete with a shoe called Pro-Keds, but sales were lackluster. ''Keds was left in the dust,'' said Ms. Scott, Keds's marketing vice president. **********But the company noticed that its shoes had become fashionable among some young women who wanted simple sneakers. The shoes gained cachet from photos and mentions in fashion magazines showing them as complements to white pants and khaki shorts. They were also popular in places like beach towns in Southern California and the Soho district of Manhattan, possibly because they were inexpensive and were perhaps considered an ''anti-fashion'' fashion statement. **********To expand the shoes' appeal more to young professional women, Keds in 1988 hired a small advertising agency in Providence, R.I., to develop a new approach. **********The agency, Leonard Monahan Lubars, conducted interviews with consumers, known as focus groups, and asked them oddball questions like ''If Keds were a building, what kind of building would it be?'' One frequent answer: A country house with a white picket fence around it. Nike, by contrast, was often described as a glass-and-steel skyscraper. Those reactions ''told us a lot of things,'' said Mr. Lubars, executive vice president and creative director. ''It told us 'anti-athletic' might work.'' With a modest budget, it also meant the company would not need to hire expensive athletic stars to hawk the product. **********Keds and the ad agency also came up with a new slogan: ''Keds. They Feel Good,'' that they hoped would attract young professionals while still evoking kid appeal. The television ads have the lighthearted approach of the print ads. One TV ad shows a couple playfully arguing. The woman throws a Keds shoe at the man. The tag line is, ''Introducing Keds debating shoes.'' **********Keds also expanded the product line. The shoes now come in about 20 styles and more than half a dozen colors. The basic design of a simple canvas top remained, however. **********Since starting its new campaign, or what marketers call repositioning, Keds sales have boomed. Sales to retailers nearly quadrupled, to $227 million in 1989 from $60 million in 1986. Keds also grew from a quarter of Stride Rite's sales in 1986 to half in 1989. **********Following its success with female customers, the next step for Keds is to get more men to buy the shoes, said Ms. Scott. Future ad campaigns will highlight Keds in a more masculine style.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/14/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;   Sun-Times to Sell Building
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/14/busin.body_text: **********The Chicago Sun-Times Company announced today that it would sell its newspaper building and build a new printing plant to replace its outdated presses. **********The Sun-Times, which in the last five years has suffered a 17 percent decline in its weekday circulation, to 536,000, said that new presses would help the paper compete with The Chicago Tribune, which has a weekday circulation of 720,000. **********The Sun-Times building, which was built in 1957, occupies prime real estate on the banks of the Chicago River, just north of the Loop. Newspaper officials set the value of the property at about $89 million. **********James B. Shaffer, vice president of the company, said virtually all of the money from the sale of the building would go toward the new printing plant that will house presses that use offset technology. The Sun-Times is currently printed with letter presses, and its reproduction is much less sharp than that of The Tribune. **********Officials at the newspaper said that the news, advertising and business operations would be moved to another site downtown. They said the company intended to build a 300,000-square-foot printing plant, preferably within the city limits. **********The newspaper is owned by the New York investment firm of Adler & Shaykin, which bought it from Rupert Murdoch in 1986 for about $145 million. **********The move is the latest effort to bolster the tabloid, which outsells The Tribune within the city. Sam McKeel, former publisher of The Philadelphia Inquirer and Daily News, joined the company as chief executive last June. Dennis A. Britton, a former assistant managing editor of The Los Angeles Times, became editor and senior vice president in December.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/18/busin.body_text: **********Trans World, Northwest and United joined other airlines yesterday in imposing an additional 4.2 percent fare increase that will raise domestic tickets by a total of 9.5 percent since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. The higher rates go into effect on Oct. 1 as airlines try to recoup some of the extra money spent on jet fuel, which has risen by about 50 percent since the Aug. 2 invasion. Last month, airlines lifted domestic fares 5.3 percent to partially offset the higher fuel costs. The second wave of fare increases was begun by Pan Am, which announced a 4.4 percent increase on top of its earlier increase. Airlines that responded last week with announcements of additional 4.2 percent fare increases included American, America West, USAir, Delta and Eastern.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/11/busin.body_text: **********The California Supreme Court has ruled that patients have no right to share in profits if their blood or organs become the source of lucrative scientific research. **********The court said that John Moore, a leukemia victim whose spleen was removed for medical reasons, could not sue biotechnology researchers and commercial laboratories on the claim that his personal property was being misused. He did, however, win limited rights to sue on more narrow grounds. **********The 5-to-2 decision, which was announced on Monday, said researchers used the victim's spleen without his knowledge to develop a blood protein. **********Allowing such a suit ''threatens to destroy the economic incentive to conduct important medical research,'' Justice Edward Panelli said. **********The court unanimously allowed Mr. Moore, a Seattle resident, to continue his suit on a claim that the doctor who removed his spleen and withdrew blood samples over several years had failed to disclose his personal interests before getting Mr. Moore's consent to the procedures.
