https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/12/world.main_headline: FRANCE INCREASES ITS FORCES IN GULF
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/12/world.print_headline: STANDOFF IN THE GULF; FRANCE INCREASES ITS FORCES IN GULF
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/12/world.body_text: **********France's Defense Minister, Jean-Pierre Chevenement, said today that his nation would send about 4,000 reinforcements to Saudi Arabia, raising the number of French troops there to about 10,000 men. **********Confirming a report that first appeared in Le Monde, Mr. Chevenement said the decision to increase France's force was a direct result of the United Nations resolution sanctioning the use of force if Iraq does not withdraw from Kuwait by Jan. 15. **********The troops and their equipment will also give offensive potential to France's force in Saudi Arabia, which has been primarily a defensive one. **********French officials said the first reinforcements would be 800 marine artillerymen who will be armed with 18 to 24 155-millimeter guns. They are to be followed by the deployment of 40 of France's heaviest battle tanks, the AMX-30.  More Fighter Aircraft **********French officials said they wuld also add an unspecified number of Mirage and Jaguar fighter planes to supplement the 29 French aircraft already in Saudi Arabia. **********The 6,250 troops that France now has in Saudi Arabia are equipped with anti-tank helicopters and light armored vehicles. French officials said the goal of their force until now had been to repel an Iraqi tank invasion. **********Mr. Chevenement said the new deployments are a response to the changing posture of the anti-Iraqi alliance in the Gulf. **********"We must assure the best conditions of security for our forces for whatever hypothesis can be imagined," Mr. Chevenement said. "We must be ready for any eventual situation." **********Last week, the chief of staff of France's armed forces, General Maurice Schmitt, traveled to Saudi Arabia to evaluate the needs of France's troops.  No Compromise, Dumas Says **********On Monday, French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas told a meeting of defense and foreign ministers of the Western European Union, the nine-nation European defense organization, that there could be no compromise on a "complete" withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait. "Mr. Saddam Hussein would be mistaken if he interpreted the dialogue that is opening as a sign of weakness," he said. **********Mr. Dumas, who was chairman of the Paris-based Western European Union meeting, added, "Europe's determination remains unaltered in the crucial stage we're entering." **********With the group exhorting Mr. Hussein to withdraw from Kuwait, he added, "This is the last chance offered to Iraq for a peaceful solution." **********At the meeting in Paris on Monday, the Western European Union officials backed a call by French President Francois Mitterrand and German Chancellor Helmut Kohl that the European Community should assume some defense responsibilities as part of its efforts to establish greater political and economic integration. That idea is expected to be on the agenda when the leaders of the European Community meet over the weekend in Rome.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/10/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Calspan Awarded Air Force Contract
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/10/busin.body_text: **********Arvin Industries said its Calspan Corporation unit had been awarded a five-year contract to operate and maintain aerospace flight dynamics test facilities at the Air Force's Arnold Engineering Development Center in Tennessee. Total value of the contract over the five years is $276.5 million, Arvin said. **********The company said the contract calls for testing and analysis in more than 20 wind tunnels, ballistic ranges and space environment chambers. Calspan was first awarded a contract at the Arnold Engineering Development Center in 1980; it was renewed for five years in 1985.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/07/busin.main_headline: I.B.M. Is Joining Metaphor To Create a New Software
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/07/busin.print_headline: I.B.M. Is Joining Metaphor To Create a New Software
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/07/busin.body_text: **********Both Metaphor and I.B.M. will invest in the new partnership, called Patriot Partners. Metaphor recently left its original business of manufacturing specialized computer work stations for market analysis applications and is focusing on developing software for advanced personal computers. **********The Patriot Partners' software, which the companies said would be designed to be commercially available in two to three years, would permit an application developer to write a program once, then sell it for a variety of different computers. The new software will act as a go-between for each application and different types of computers. Today, a software author must write different versions of a program for each different computer or operating system, a time-consuming process. **********An I.B.M. executive said that the announcement with Metaphor would not affect the computer maker's relationship with Microsoft, which is focused on operating systems. **********''We've had our ups and downs in that relationship,'' said Joseph M. Guglielmi, president of International Business Machines' applications solutions division. This doesn't affect any specific relationship with Microsoft.'' **********A Microsoft spokesman said that I.B.M. had explored a variety of different technologies with different companies. He said that Microsoft was preparing similar software, but was not yet ready to disclose its strategy. **********Recently, analysts have said, the two companies' strategies have appeared to diverge since Microsoft introduced Windows 3.0, a graphics-oriented software program designed to control applications on a personal computer running the older MS-DOS operating system. Last year I.B.M. and Microsoft publicly agreed that the newer OS/2 would be the operating system for advanced applications, while Windows would be confined to older personal computers with less memory and speed. **********But since then Microsoft has continued to hedge on how soon OS/2 will be a major force in the personal computer market - a decision that industry executives said has irritated I.B.M. The more advanced operating system has experienced disappointing sales since it was introduced in 1987, and applications developers have not rushed to develop programs for it. **********But analysts said that I.B.M. had begun to try to distance itself from the Redmond, Wash. software publisher. ''I.B.M. is probably interested in finding ways to reduce their dependence on Microsoft,'' said Michelle Preston, a computer industry analyst at Cowen & Company. **********David E. Liddle, Metaphor's president, said that the new program, which will be aimed at powerful personal computers and work stations, will be designed for operating systems like OS/2 and I.B.M.'s version of Unix, known as AIX. **********Separately, Borland International Inc., a Scotts Valley, Calif. software publisher, said that it would develop its software for the new Metaphor-I.B.M. program.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/28/world.main_headline: East Germany Is Still Spying On the West, Magazine Says
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/28/world.print_headline: East Germany Is Still Spying On the West, Magazine Says
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/28/world.body_text: **********East Germany has bugged telephone conversations of West German Government officials for years, and evidence indicates it continues to do so, a news magazine reported today. **********East Berlin's eavesdropping targets in Bonn include the Chancellor's office, Government ministries, political parties and Parliament, the Hamburg-based magazine Der Spiegel said. **********It quoted unnamed renegade East German agents and officials in the West German capital. **********''The entire political and administrative area was monitored to a degree of perfection that shocked us,'' it quoted an unidentified Bonn official as saying.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/21/world.main_headline: Violence by Bands of Racist Skinheads Stalks East Germany
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/21/world.print_headline: Violence by Bands of Racist Skinheads Stalks East Germany
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/21/world.body_text: **********Less than a year after the fall of the Communist Government of East Germany, which had preached ''anti-fascism'' as a central article of faith for four decades, right-wing radical organizations are gathering strength here. And some of them openly echo Hitler's anti-Semitic slogans. **********A West German television report on the far right broadcast this week estimated that at least 30,000 people, mostly young, are engaged in militant nationalist politics in East Germany. **********Since last March, virtually every week has seen reports of rallies where Nazi slogans and salutes were manifest, of violent physical attacks on foreign workers, of swastikas and anti-Jewish epithets daubed on walls and on tombstones. **********A common denominator in this scene is young men identifiable as skinheads - most of them young factory workers - whose hostility is directed against anyone they deem ''un-German,'' including political leftists, blacks and other foreigners, Jews and homosexuals. **********Mozambicans Are Beaten **********On May 1 in the brown coal mining town of Hoyerswerda, skinheads assaulted a group of workers from Mozambique, beating some so severely that they had to be hospitalized. Last Tuesday, skinheads boarded an elevated train in East Berlin's Ostkreuz station, surrounded a lone worker from Mozambique, beat him and stabbed him in the lung. **********On April 20, right-wing radicals gathered on the Alexanderplatz here to celebrate the 101st birthday of Hitler. A month later, they assembled again to form a human swastika in front of the East German Parliament. **********German political commentators seem to be at a loss to explain the new phenomenon, although there is general agreement that it represents at least partly a reaction to the years of strict punishments meted out to right-wing radicals under the Communist Government. Some of the skinheads have told journalists that their fathers had served in the Communist secret police, suggesting that joining the far right was their way of challenging parental authority. **********There are about 190,000 foreign citizens in East Germany and for many of them, ''the climate has become raw and perilous,'' said Florentine Friedman, a correspondent for the German Press Agency. **********Gypsies Are a Target **********Almuth Berger, the East German Government's Commissioner for Foreigners, explained the atmosphere that has developed since the fall of the Communist system this way: ''Before the change, everything concerning hostility toward foreigners was made taboo.'' Her colleague, Anetta Kahane, said that the East Germans and the foreigners were ''not prepared for each other.'' The two women have been preoccupied in the last three months with finding lodgings for thousands of Romanian gypsies who have made their way here seeking a better life. The gypsies, too, have been subjects of skinhead attacks. **********Alarming for the East German police is the recent discovery that right-wing radicals have been able to assemble arsenals by purchasing assault weapons from disaffected Soviet soldiers. There are still over 300,000 Russians stationed in East Germany. **********''With a couple of bottles of vodka and some luck you may be able to purchase a Kalashnikov from a Russian,'' a police officer said. **********Police Are Thwarted **********The Peoples Police, as they are still called here, have been hampered in maintaining surveillance over the right-wing radicals because, with the dissolution of the Communist Ministry for State Security last spring, the department that dealt with rightists was also eliminated and its files sealed. **********It now appears that West Germany's far right Republican Party, organized in 1989 and subsequently successful in gaining votes in various state elections, will be permitted to campaign in East Germany in the all-German elections set for Dec. 2. This week, however, the attempt of 30 Republican party members to open a campaign stand in the Frankfurter Allee elevated station ended in a hail of stones thrown by a group of men wearing masks. **********The Republicans may be able to channel some of the energies of the far right in East Germany, but it appears that not until unification of the two Germanys takes hold and Federal German police authorities weigh in will the current outbreaks of right-wing violence in East Germany be contained.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/02/world.print_headline: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;   In Last Hours of 2 Germanys: Awaiting Unity and Revelry
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/02/world.body_text: **********The two Berlins and the two Germanys began the final countdown today to the moment, at midnight Tuesday, when they will drop the ''East'' and the ''West'' from their names and once again become a single nation with a single capital. **********The autumn air was heavy with anticipation as tens of thousands of visitors poured into Berlin - all but formally reunited in the 11 months since the Berlin wall was breached, and its subways, streets and currencies were merged - for the huge reunion party planned to start with the raising of the black, red and gold flag by the Reichstag. **********Large-scale police reinforcements also converged on the city, including several hundred paramilitary border guards, to keep watch against violence threatened by the Autonomen, the anarchic radical bands that have disrupted previous civic events in West Berlin. **********A Symbol Then and Now **********All around the Reichstag, the battered home of former German parliaments that has stood as a symbol of German longing since it burned in 1933 at the dawn of Hitler's dictatorship, men worked to set up a new flagpole and speaker stands and to prepare the grounds for the politicians and people who will proclaim the new German state at the stroke of midnight. **********It was here that the last Kaiser, Wilhelm II, abdicated in 1918, and it was over the brooding, neo-classical ruins of the Reichstag that Soviet soldiers raised their flag in May 1945 to proclaim the capitulation of Berlin. It was here, too, in 1948, during the blockade of West Berlin by Communist forces, that Mayor Ernst Reuter appealed to the world, ''You peoples of the world, look upon this city.'' **********The division of Berlin left the building - restored inside but still bullet-scarred on its exterior - abutting the Berlin wall, and generations of Western politicians stood on its eastern balconies to express their indignation. **********Still Bonn For Awhile **********Now, back at the center of what will once again be the capital of Germany, the Reichstag will be the backdrop for the official reuniting of the Germanys and the site of the first sitting of the all-German Parliament on Thursday -though the Parliament will then return to Bonn until a newly elected legislature determines its permanent new home. **********The moment of unity will be preceded at 11:55 P.M. by the ringing of the Liberty Bell at the Schoneberg Town Hall, a copy of the Liberty Bell in Philadelphia that was given to West Berlin. **********Then at midnight, seven young athletes each from East and West Germany will raise a 540-square foot flag while the national anthem is played, including the refrain, ''Unity and justice and freedom for the German fatherland, for that let us all aspire.'' **********The flag and the anthem are both those of West Germany, as will be the formal name of the new state - the Federal Republic of Germany - since under the conditions of union, East Germany will accede to West Germany as five new states in the Federal Republic. By the same logic, the West German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, will become Chancellor of all Germany, and the West German President, Richard von Weizsacker, will become the head of state for the entire country. **********The capital will formally return to Berlin, though most ministries and Parliament will continue to work in Bonn at least for a while, and the Government has left it for the parliament that will be elected on Dec. 2 to decide what will move and what will stay. **********Once the flag is raised, the celebrations will really begin, with half an hour of fireworks followed by concerts from 16 separate stages built on both sides of the Brandenburg Gate. Officials lifted a ban on firecrackers for the night. **********Some Leaders Demur **********Mr. Kohl had hoped to have the leaders of the Allied powers, including Presidents Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, lead the celebrations, but they signaled their reluctance and the idea was canceled. **********The moment of unity is being preceded and followed by a steady progression of formalities required to conclude 40 years of division of the Germans into two states and two cities. **********In New York today, foreign ministers of the two Germanys and the four World War II victors formally signed documents suspending all Allied powers over Germany, thus restoring full sovereignty to the new Germany. The action was taken because the formal ''two plus four'' treaty will come into effect only after it is ratified by all the powers. **********Berlin, which has technically been maintained under direct Allied control since the war, will be formally set free on Tuesday, when the four military commandants go to the Schoneberg hall and relinquish their responsibilities to Walter Momper, the West Berlin Mayor who at midnight will become the Mayor of all Berlin. **********Kohl Overwhelmingly Elected **********In Hamburg today, the Christian Democratic Union of Mr. Kohl held a congress at which it merged formally with the East German Christian Democrats, following the earlier mergers of the Social Democrats and the Free Democrats. The convention re-elected Mr. Kohl as party leader by 98.5 percent. **********Lothar de Maiziere, the East German Prime Minister, who will become a Minister Without Portfolio in the all-German Government, seemed emotionally shaken during the proceedings. He said that membership in the East German Christian Democrats had been ''the only alternative to the Communist Party if you did not want to withdraw from public life.'' **********At 5 P.M. Tuesday, Mr. de Maiziere will preside over the last session of the East German Parliament, and then over a ''celebration of unity'' at the Schauspielhaus concert hall, at which Kurt Masur will conduct Beethoven's Ninth Symphony. **********For all the scheduled celebrations, the day of unity was not being met with enthusiasm across the West German spectrum. **********The anarchists, with their tendencies to violence, posed a direct threat. But many other groups planned peaceful demonstrations to counter the official jubilation. **********A 'Day of Meanness' **********To most Germans, the demonstrations were part of the inevitable price of holding major events in Berlin. West Berlin has always been celebrated for its vibrant counterculture, and its people have rarely resisted a chance to march and demonstrate. **********The most original was scheduled by an organization calling itself the Bureau for Unusual Events. Organizers declared Unity Day ''The Day of German Meanness'' and scheduled a demonstration at which they would proclaim an ''Autonomous Republic of Utopia.'' Following West Germany's model, they intended to offer Germany the right to accede. **********In East Germany, union remains a matter of some bitterness for the Communist Party, reformed and restyled the Party of Democratic Socialism, and for the citizens' movements that sprang up around the Protestant churches a year ago. **********The Party of Democratic Socialism had planned a rally titled ''Adieu G.D.R.,'' but canceled it after the police said they could not guarantee security. The New Forum and various citizens' movements announced that they would hold a requiem on Wednesday at the Gethsemane Church, one of the major centers of the popular revolution a year ago. Some Protestant churches in East Berlin declined a request to ring their bells on unity day. **********Diplomats and Generals Involved **********Unity will also mean the uniting of all the Western diplomatic missions in East and West. The United States Ambassador to East Germany, Richard Barkley, will formally cede his post at midnight Tuesday, and Vernon A. Walters, the Ambassador to Bonn, will become Ambassador to all Germany. The embassy, however, will remain in Bonn for now, with the East Berlin mission as a branch. **********Though the Allied commanders will formally cede their responsibility for the city, reduced contingents of American, French and British troops will remain in West Berlin as long as Soviet troops remain in East Germany. The arrangement was reached after Bonn signed an agreement with Moscow agreeing to let the Soviets withdraw their forces over three to four years. **********At unity, the armies of East and West Germany will merge, temporarily forming a formidable force of 530,000 - 430,000 from the west and 100,000 from the east. The force will be reduced over four years to an all-German army of 370,000, the limit to which West Germany has agreed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/01/world.main_headline: SALVADORAN JUDGE SEEKS HELP OF U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/01/world.print_headline: SALVADORAN JUDGE SEEKS HELP OF U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/01/world.body_text: **********A judge's request that two United States officials testify in the investigation of the killings of six Jesuit priests last November has prompted a spirited debate between American officials here and in Washington. **********The petition by the judge, Ricardo Zamora, may force the United States to choose between its tradition of protecting diplomatic immunity by having American officials excused from testifying about their work and the political necessity of helping bring the Jesuits' killers to justice. **********The judge's petition, which is expected to be formally presented to the United States Government in the coming weeks, is the latest twist in a closely watched case that has become a test of the decadelong American effort to foster democracy here. **********Nearly every day there has been a new disclosure about the case. President Alfredo Cristiani and the army Chief of Staff, Rene Emilio Ponce, acknowledged recently that they had authorized what amounted to a scouting trip for the killers, a search of the Jesuits' house three days before they were slain. **********Lawyer Quits Case **********A lawyer for a high-ranking officer accused of destroying evidence as part of an attempted cover-up has resigned because of death threats. And some evidence that supposedly was burned has been found. **********The disclosures have led even some critics to begin praising Judge Zamora for making an innovative effort to investigate the killing of the Jesuits, who advocated a negotiated settlement to the civil war. **********The killing of the priests, their housekeeper and her daughter on Nov. 16 on the campus of the Jose Simeon Canas University of Central America came as leftist guerrillas were mounting an offensive in their war against the United States-backed Government. **********There has been little real progress in the case since January, when President Cristiani announced the arrest of a colonel, the highest ranking officer ever charged with an abuse of human rights here, three lieutenants and four privates. **********Resignation Demanded **********The acknowledgments by President Cristiani and Colonel Ponce prompted speculation that they cooperated with the attempted cover-up and may have authorized the operation that ended with the killing of the priests. Rebel leaders apparently came to that conclusion and in an effort to score propaganda points took time out from peace talks last week to demand the President's resignation. **********Judge Zamora's request that the two United States officials testify is part of his continuing investigation of the attempted cover-up. For more than a month after the killings, some United States and Salvadoran officials asserted that the guerrillas had killed the priests to discredit the Government and the army, which has long been linked to death squads by international human rights monitors. **********Both the Salvadoran and United States Government have asserted that they did not learn of the military's responsibility for the killings until the beginning of January, six weeks after the slayings. But the investigation has found that some senior Salvadoran commanders knew of the army's involvement earlier. **********At least one United States official stationed here, Maj. Eric Buckland, was informed of the army's involvement by mid-December, the investigation has found. But he reportedly waited two weeks before informing his superior, Col. Milton Menjivar, commander of the United States military group, who provided the information to the Salvadoran high command. **********Judge Zamora is seeking to have Major Buckland and Colonel Menjivar testify about how they obtained their information and the delay in relaying it. Some American officials fear that waiving diplomatic immunity and allowing the officers to testify would set a precedent that could come to haunt American diplomats around the world. But officials here argue that the United States may be blamed if it declines to allow them to testify and the case collapses. **********State Department and Pentagon officials said the request, which is winding its way through the judiciary and the Foreign Ministry, would be considered once it is officially presented. ''We want this case resolved,'' a State Department official said. ''We want to cooperate.'' **********Pressure on U.S. Likely **********The United States is likely to come under intense political pressure here and in Washington to waive the officers' immunity and allow them to testify. A refusal would undoubtably lead to new criticism from Jesuits and Western diplomats, many of whom already have questioned the American commitment to unraveling the conspiracy behind the Jesuits' killing. **********But some judicial officials said a defense motion to transfer the case to another jurisdiction is likely to stall the investigation before the United States is forced to make a decision on waiving immunity. Judge Zamora denied an almost identical motion earlier this year and is presumed likely to reject the new petition. **********But the new motion comes under another section of the criminal code. Unlike the previous decision, the defense can appeal the judge's ruling on the new petition. Judicial officials said they thought an appeal could delay the prosecution almost indefinitely and lead to the collapse of the case.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/15/busin.body_text: **********A year after announcing tighter restrictions on many discount fares used by business travelers with an eye toward increasing revenue, the nation's airlines have been quietly giving large companies a break. **********They are waiving restrictions on discount fares for travel agencies with big corporate clients, industry experts say, and providing their biggest customers with opportunities not afforded the individual traveler. **********Coming at a time when the airline industry is facing higher costs because of a big jump in the price of fuel and the rising need for capital to pay for new planes, the practice of waiving restrictions has already had an impact on airline profits, some experts say. **********Protecting Market Share **********Yet the airlines feel they need to offer the breaks to protect their share of the large market of business travelers. The breaks, offered only to their biggest customers, also serve to tie travel agencies more closely to certain airlines. **********The behind-the-scenes waivers stand in sharp contrast to the industry trend of tightening restrictions and increasing cancellation penalties on discount fares. For example, the lowest discount fare now carries a cancellation penalty of 100 percent. Several years ago the cancellation penalty was only 25 percent. **********The waiving of requirements like ticket purchases seven days in advance and weekend stays for travelers can produce huge savings for companies, said executives of large travel agencies and some airlines. These executives, who were reluctant to discuss the subject, spoke on the condition that they not be identified and refused to disclose specific arrangements. **********Various Arrangements **********The practice is far less widely known but apparently far more common than arrangements in which large companies negotiate special fares directly with carriers for employees on heavily traveled routes. Discounts for companies are usually limited to certain routes that employees fly frequently; industry experts said the waivers of fare restrictions represent much more of an erosion in airlines' fare structures than the corporate discounts. **********The executives noted that in most cases the travel agencies go to airlines that either dominate their areas or are seeking to break into new markets, and that the resulting arrangements are confidential and informal. While the agencies, whose commission is based on the fare, make less money a ticket, they expect to come out ahead because of the increased volume that comes with keeping large customers. **********Few Pay Full Fare **********The waivers help explain why there has been no significant change in the number of people who travel on a discount fare despite the recent tightening of restrictions. **********''The published fare today has become almost insignificant,'' said Julius Maldutis, the airline analyst for Salomon Brothers. ''Very few people pay the full fare.'' **********The president of a large travel agency on the West Coast said the average cost of air travel for business customers had risen 31 percent, to $463, from the time before airlines tightened restrictions on their fares late in 1988 until the beginning of 1989. But since then, it has dropped to $439, even though full coach fares have increased. **********Reasons for Lower Averages **********He attributed the drop partly to the practice of waiving restrictions and partly to the special fares that corporations have been able to negotiate with airlines on the routes heavily used by their employees. **********The savings for customers can be huge. The regular coach fare between New York and Chicago, for example, is $680 round trip, while the fare requiring purchase seven days in advance and a Saturday-night stay is $348 round trip. **********The regular coach fare between Dallas and New York is $936 round trip, while the corresponding discount fare is $438. **********Because business travelers must often travel on short notice and do not want to stay for a weekend, they frequently do not qualify for a discount fare with such restrictions. **********Most Fliers Get Discounts **********Mr. Maldutis found that about the same percentage of people, 90.5 percent, traveled on a discount fare in 1989 as did in 1988, 91 percent. Mr. Maldutis also found that the average discount went up to 66.5 percent of the full-coach fare from 63.2 percent. He attributed these results largely to the waiving of restrictions. **********But now, in addition to the waivers, the three-day advance-purchase fare has crept back into some markets. **********The recent waivers have further divided the travel agency industry between big companies with enough influence to secure special deals from airlines and smaller agencies that can no longer compete for business travelers because they cannot get similar breaks. **********''It's highly selective on what kind of travel agencies will get the waivers,'' the head of a large East Coast travel agency said. ''Higher-volume agencies like ourselves are able to get the preferred arrangements.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/14/busin.body_text: **********The Commerce Department intends to abandon its computerized model of the economy, one of very few in the Government, and the monthly publication associated with it called Business Cycle Developments. **********Allan H. Young, the director of the Bureau of Economic Analysis, called the moves part of ''a restructuring of our program'' to better utilize resources at a time of budgetary restraint. But he said the department would continue to compile its index of leading indicators, which had been thought to be a candidate for elimination. **********About 30 pages of data contained in Business Cycle Developments will be retained and published as part of the Survey of Current Business, another monthly publication, Mr. Young said. The changes, assuming Congressional approval, are to begin this spring. The 12 employees performing the affected work will be transferred to other duties. **********The disappearance of the department's economic model, which was for internal Government use, will force various Federal agencies to obtain such services from the private sector. **********It could not immediately be determined to what extent, if any, the Federal Reserve would make available its model of the economy to other bodies. Mr. Young described the two systems as ''basically equivalent.''

Air Bag Venture With the Japanese

Air Bag Venture With the Japanese
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/06/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: The rush to install air bags in American-made cars has spawned a joint venture between a moribund wire maker in Niles, Mich., and the American trading arm of a Japanese steelmaker. **********The deal signals the quickening pace of commercial activity in the fledgling air bag industry. Manufacturers and their suppliers are hoping that the North American market for air bags will grow fivefold or sixfold by 1995, when virtually all passenger cars sold in the United States will be equipped with the safety devices to meet Federal requirements. **********The trend in favor of air bags accelerated last week when the General Motors Corporation said it would install air bags on the driver's side of all its American-built cars by the fall of 1995. **********Even before G.M. threw its full support behind air bags, National-Standard and other suppliers of air bag components were scrambling to meet the growing demand. National-Standard estimates that it will need more than 100 special high-speed looms to weave enough wire cloth by 1995. The company will not disclose how many looms it now operates, but a spokesman said the joint venture would add a significant number of new machines, at a cost of about $250,000 each. **********Indeed, analysts say National-Standard's ailing balance sheet forced the company to find an equity partner willing to invest in new equipment or risk falling behind as air bag demand takes off. The company suffered operating losses in four of the last five years, and reported large net losses in 1987 and 1989. Long-term debt doubled from 1986 to 1989, reaching $45.9 million last year. And in the current year the company has lost money in each of the last three quarters. National-Standard cut its dividend by half in 1987, and stopped paying any dividends the next year. **********The financial damage was caused by a contraction in the company's primary business - supplying wire cord for tires - which shifted to overseas producers where labor and energy costs were lower during the 1980's. **********With the air bag business growing rapidly, National-Standard struggled to shift gears. Company officials say they expect sales of wire cloth to air bag manufacturers to grow from a small percentage to a quarter of revenues in three years. But the investment required was steep, and National-Standard did not have the wherewithal to handle it alone. ''We looked at the projections for growth in air bags, and we could not see ourselves adding all of that capacity on our own,'' said Jerry W. Ridener, the company's marketing manager for wire cloth and filters. **********Enter Toyota Tsusho. The Japanese steel and machinery manufacturer began supplying stainless steel wire cloth to National-Standard last year, when the American wire maker discovered that it could not meet all of its orders for the cloth. National-Standard says it worked with the Japanese company to develop wire cloth that would capture certain gases in the air bag propellant while allowing nitrogen to pass through and inflate the air bag. **********The Japanese company has deep pockets, also. Toyota Tsusho is affiliated with the Toyota Motor Corporation, and supplies much of the steel used by the Japanese car maker. Toyota Tsusho enlarged its presence in the United States in the mid-1980's when it opened a steel distribution center in Georgetown, Ky., to supply sheet metal to Toyota's only wholly owned American car factory. **********Neither partner in the joint venture will say how much it is investing in the plant, and a location has not yet been selected. But the Japanese say the commercial prospects for the new plant are good. **********''The wire cloth business is growing and we expect it to grow further, because of the interest in air bags,'' said Hiro Igarshi, senior consultant with Toyota Tsusho and manager of the new plant. **********Analysts and industry experts say demand for the wire mesh will surge as more air bags are added to the passenger sides of cars. At present, passenger-side air bags are in all Porsche models, the more expensive Mercedes cars and certain of Ford's Lincoln Continental and Town Cars. While each driver's-side air bag requires about five ounces of wire cloth, the passenger side bags are larger and use about two pounds of the cloth. **********''That's the real point of the deal,'' Mr. Ridener said. ''While there is enough manufacturing capacity in place to supply wire cloth for all the driver-side air bags, there isn't nearly enough to handle'' the passenger side.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/08/world.main_headline: Campaign for Early German Vote Stalls
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/08/world.print_headline: Campaign for Early German Vote Stalls
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/08/world.body_text: **********The campaign by the conservative Government leaders of Bonn and East Berlin to push forward the unification of Germany by seven weeks collapsed today. **********The collapse resulted from an impasse between Bonn's governing coalition and the opposition over how and when to proceed to bring West and East Germany together, ending 45 years of national division. **********The proposal, made four days ago in a surprise move by Chancellor Helmut Kohl and Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere, both Christian Democrats, was rebuffed by the leadership of the West German Social Democrats, the main opposition group in the Federal Parliament. That occurred in a midday meeting between Mr. Kohl and his opponent for the chancellorship, Oskar Lafontaine. **********The Social Democrats refused Chancellor Kohl's invitation to take part in a hasty change of West Germany's Constitution to permit the elections to take place Oct. 14, before the regular legislative period is concluded at the end of November. Their votes would be required to obtain the two-thirds majority needed to amend the Constitution. Only a week ago the agreed date for national elections was Dec. 2. **********No Confidence Is 'Not Opportune' **********Chancellor Kohl also said he would not take the only other Constitutional route to advance the elections, which would be to deliberately lose a no confidence vote in Parliament, forcing new elections. **********At a news conference this afternoon, Mr. Kohl said a no confidence vote was ''not opportune.'' **********The deadlock left undecided the matter of when unification and all-German elections will take place. **********In a strategy session this morning, Chancellor Kohl and the leaders of his coalition partners, the Bavarian Christian Social Union and the Free Democratic Party, agreed to submit their plan for Oct. 14 unification and elections to the Bonn Parliament on Thursday, if only to force the Social Democrats to commit themselves on the legislative record to a later date. **********Advancing German Elections **********Similarly, Mr. de Maiziere's governing Christian Democratic Union is scheduled to propose to the East German Parliament on Wednesday earlier unification and elections, recommending Oct. 14 as the date. **********Adding to the confusion is the possibility raised over the last 24 hours that the East German Parliament may be asked to vote tomorrow simply to accede to the Federal Republic immediately under Article 23 of the Bonn Constitution. That would supersede the act of unification currently contemplated under a formal political treaty being negotiated between the two German states, although it would not advance the date of elections. **********While most political analysts in Bonn believe that the idea of advancing the election originated with the West German leader, the Chancellor and his aides maintain that the initiative came last week from Mr. de Maiziere. **********Mr. Kohl said his party wants German unification and the unity elections to take place as close together and as soon as possible. He called that ''the commandment of responsibility in an extraordinary historic situation,'' arguing that the sooner Germany is unified the sooner East Germany's deteriorating economy can be straightened out. According to official figures released today, unemployment in East Germany almost doubled between June and July. **********Mr. Lafontaine said the Social Democrats also wanted unification to take place soon, and that it should take priority over national elections. He proposed Sept. 15 as the date for unification, with the elections to be held either on Nov. 18 or Dec. 2. **********The latest maneuvers of Mr. Kohl's coalition and Mr. Lafontaine's opposition made it apparent that both sides have begun to look at the last stages of the German unification process in terms of short-term partisan advantage. ''Wait two days,'' said a senior Kohl aide, to see how the Chancellor would exploit the issue in a parliamentary debate scheduled for Thursday. **********In back-to-back news conferences, Mr. Kohl and Mr. Lafontaine sought to use their unification-calendar dispute as fodder for their election campaigns which in effect opened today.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/29/busin.body_text: **********The New York investor Julian H. Robertson Jr. has acquired a 5.1 percent stake in the Georgia Gulf Corporation, an Atlanta-based chemical company. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Robertson said he had bought the shares as an investment. **********Georgia Gulf recently completed a restructuring plan to block a hostile $1.1 billion bid by the Texas investor Harold C. Simmons. Mr. Robertson acquired his 1.74 million shares for an average price of $6.76. The stock closed at $7 a share today on the New York Stock Exchange, unchanged from Monday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/12/world.main_headline: Lebanon Officially Asks Syria for Military Help to Oust Aoun
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/12/world.print_headline: Lebanon Officially Asks Syria for Military Help to Oust Aoun
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/12/world.body_text: **********Frustrated by the ineffectiveness of a siege against the rebel Christian chief, Michel Aoun, the Government of President Elias Hrawi has officially asked for Syrian military intervention to oust the renegade general from sectors he controls in East Beirut. **********Politicians and press accounts said the request for military assistance was conveyed on Wednesday to the Syrian Vice President, Abdul Halim Khaddam, and that Mr. Khaddam then summoned the American and French Ambassadors to discuss the matter. **********Syria has 40,000 troops in Lebanon, and they control two-thirds of the country. [Thousands of Syrian troops and columns of tanks moved toward the enclave held by General Aoun's forces, The Associated Press reported from Beirut, quoting the Lebanese police. The Syrian forces took up positions in Beirut and the mountains near the capital, the police said.]  But General Aoun said in an interview at his bunker here that he does not expect a Syrian attack. **********''Damascus is much too intelligent to respond to an impotent, unpopular Government like Hrawi's,'' said the defiant general. **********On Sept. 28, the Syrian-supported Hrawi Government imposed a blockade of areas controlled by General Aoun within the 300-square-mile Christian enclave in central Lebanon. **********Life in East Beirut came to a virtual standstill because of the blockade. Most shops and other businesses have been closed throughout the two-week siege, and flour, gasoline and fresh vegetables became scarce. But several members of Mr. Hrawi's Cabinet criticized the siege as inhuman and quietly allowed their militias to let food and gasoline shipments to pass through the lines. **********Overture to U.S. Diplomats **********General Aoun said a military action against him would ''destroy forever the Taif peace accord,'' a pact redistributing political power that was approved last year by the Lebanese Parliament. The general, who was named caretaker head of government by a previous President, Amin Gemayel, has rejected the accord and asserts that he is the country's sole legitimate ruler. **********In an overture to the United States, the general welcomed the return of American diplomats to their embassy here. the United States. **********Aoun's Main Supplier: Baghdad **********''We will provide them with the security they need in case they ask us,'' the general said. In September 1989, supporters of General Aoun surrounded the embassy in in East Beirut and forced its personnel to flee to Cyprus. **********General Aoun also hinted at policy changes intended to mollify Washington. **********''I would like to tell them that we understand their vital interests in the area and we are ready to adapt our policy to suit these interests,' he said of But it was unclear how General Aoun proposed to change his policies to satisfy the United States. His bitter foe, Syria, has joined the American-led military response to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, and the Baghdad Government was the main supplier of General Aoun's forces before the international blockade stifled most Iraqi exports. **********The general suggested that he might step down, but at the same time insisted that he would not accede to the Hrawi Government. **********Release of Anglican Expected **********BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 11 (AP) - A newspaper reported today that Terry Waite, the Anglican Church envoy who has been held hostage for 44 months, will be freed by Saturday. **********The short, unattributed report in Al Anwar, an East Beirut newspaper, said ''most of the British hostages also could be freed in a step that would set the stage for the release of all the hostages.'' **********Britain and Iran agreed last month to restore diplomatic relations, which were severed for 18 months. **********The front-page report said an official Iranian delegation was to arrive in Damascus, the Syrian capital, today to prepare the agenda for a visit by the Iranian Foreign Minister, Ali Akbar Velayati. Mr. Velayati, the report said, was to discuss the hostage issue with Syrian officials, among other topics.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/05/busin.body_text: **********The South Korean Government said today that it would double, to $2.8 billion, its low-interest loans for export industries in an effort to stimulate its economy. **********In a joint news conference, economic ministers said the Government would also drop a controversial plan to require the use of real names in financial transactions that was intended to promote a fair economic environment and prevent tax evasion. **********But the Government now fears that real-name financial transactions would cause a capital flight and send money into land and housing speculation, the Deputy Prime Minister, Lee Seung Yun, said. **********Mr. Lee, who also serves as the top economic minister, said the Government would consider more preferential loans and tax privileges to encourage business activity and industrial investment. Policies will also be developed to check inflation, he said. **********Despite a series of special measures last year, South Korea's economy has suffered from a sharp slowdown in exports, high inflation and low capital investment. **********The country's economy grew 6.7 percent in 1989, the lowest gain in eight years. Its current account, the broadest measure of trade, has moved into the red in recent months.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/07/busin.body_text: **********Bolstered by sharply higher earnings at its energy subsidiary, Salomon Inc. yesterday reported earnings for the fourth quarter of $68 million, or 42 cents a share, in contrast to a loss of $38 million in the comparable period a year ago. **********For the quarter, Salomon's revenues rose 38.9 percent, to $2.5 billion, from $1.8 billion in the fourth quarter of 1988. **********Earnings in the securities business were meager, and the firm's commodities business suffered a large loss. **********Brokerage Earns $1 Million **********The Salomon Brothers brokerage earned only $1 million in the fourth quarter, compared with $81 million in the fourth quarter of 1988. Analysts said the firm was significantly affected by the plunge of the stock market on Oct. 13, when the Dow Jones industrial average fell 190.58 points. **********The firm also took heavy losses in trading in the stock of the UAL Corporation, the parent to United Airlines, when a buyout deal of the company collapsed. **********For the year, Salomon Brothers generated pretax earnings of $490 million, up slightly from the previous year's results of $485 million. **********At the same time, the commodities segment of the company reported a loss of $117 million, in contrast to a profit of $48 million in 1988. Discontinued operations and the establishment of other reserves accounted for about $40 million of the 1989 loss. The division was also hurt by trading losses in the first quarter in nonferrous metals. **********Analysts Disappointed **********''The earnings were a little less than I had estimated,'' said Michael Goldstein, a securities analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein Inc. ''The securities firm did a little worse than I was expecting, and the commodities did considerably worse.'' **********Doyle Lyons, a securities analyst with Merrill Lynch & Company, commented, ''The results underscore the fact that they have high risks and they have chosen to pursue a risky mix of business.'' **********Phibro Energy continued to be the driving force behind much of the earnings at Salomon. During the fourth quarter, it earned $125 million, compared with $142 million in the fourth quarter of 1988. For the full year, Phibro had pretax revenues of $367 million, an increase of 67 percent over the previous year. **********Profits Up for the Year **********For the year, Salomon had profits of $470 million, or $3.26 a share, up 67.9 percent from $280 million, or $1.65 a share, in the previous year. **********The firm reported revenues of $8.99 billion in 1989, compared with revenues of $6.1 billion in 1988. **********The sharp increase in the quarter reflects special charges a year ago. In 1988, the firm established a provision of $180 million to pay for the transfer of certain foreign earnings to the United States. As a result, earnings in 1988 would have been $460 million without the charge, or $10 million less than this year. **********Salomon's stock fell 62.5 cents yesterday, to $21.375, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/27/busin.body_text: **********Price Waterhouse, a large accounting firm that recently picked up the Toronto affiliate of Laventhol & Horwath, a midsized rival, said yesterday it is also in merger talks with Laventhol's Vancouver affiliate. **********Though all the partners involved must vote on the merger, both sides were confident of concluding the deal shortly. ''It is anticipated that the merger would be effective July 1,'' said Gordon Webster, a partner in the Toronto office of Price Waterhouse. **********He declined to comment on reports that Price had invited Laventhol's three other Canadian affiliates to sign on as well. **********The defections leave Laventhol with a void in Canada and come as the firm is struggling to recover from a string of lawsuits filed against it for its audit work. **********The two Canadian affiliates, which employ a total of 38 partners, are expected to add about $25 million United State to Price's annual billings and should push Price ahead of Coopers & Lybrand into fourth place in the Canadian rankings, according to the International Accounting Bulletin, an Atlanta-based newsletter.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/11/world.main_headline: Police Fired on Crowd, Jesse Jackson Asserts
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/11/world.print_headline: SOUTH AFRICA'S NEW ERA;   Police Fired on Crowd, Jesse Jackson Asserts
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/11/world.body_text: **********The Rev. Jesse Jackson said today that the South African Police had fired on a crowd of blacks gathered to welcome him in a black shantytown outside Cape Town. But a police statement said that the shots had been had fired by a black civilian fighting a rival black group. **********The incident occurred shortly before dusk, as Mr. Jackson and other Americans, including his wife, Jacqueline, were visiting Crossroads, a squatter settlement. Speaking to reporters later, Mr. Jackson and the Rev. Allan Boesak, an anti-apartheid leader who was one of the hosts for his visit, said that the police had opened fire on a crowd of about 2,000 blacks in front of the Crossroads Town Council offices, where they were waiting to greet the Jackson entourage. **********''If the police, who reacted this way to 2,000 people, display the same mentality when tens of thousands of people are on the streets to welcome Nelson Mandela tomorrow, what could be an occasion of great hope could be a disaster,'' Mr. Jackson said. **********Shortly after Mr. Jackson gave his version of the incident, the police headquarters in Pretoria issued a statement denying police involvement.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/09/world.main_headline: Link Sought in North Sea Ferry Fires
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/09/world.print_headline: Link Sought in North Sea Ferry Fires
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/09/world.body_text: **********Opening an arson investigation into the ferry fire on Saturday that killed as many as 135 people, the Norwegian police said today that they were checking for links between the predawn blaze and earlier North Sea ferry fires, at least one of which was deliberately set. **********The Assistant Chief of Police, Magnar Aukrust, said the authorities began examining arson as a possible cause after the captain, members of the crew and some passengers of the Scandinavian Star said they believed the fire was set deliberately. But Mr. Aukrust said the police had uncovered no motive for arson in the fire on the Danish-owned ferry, which was making an overnight trip from Oslo to the Danish port of Frederikshavn. **********''We are basing our work on the concrete theory that it was arson,'' Mr. Aukrust said at a news conference at Oslo's police headquarters. ''We are interviewing crew and survivors about what they saw and checking names on passenger list against records of known arsonists.'' An estimated 340 people from the ferry were rescued. **********Mr. Aukrust, whose office is investigating the disaster with maritime and police officials in Sweden and Denmark, said the disaster on Saturday might be linked to several recent fires on Danish North Sea ferries. **********Comparing Passenger Lists **********Mr. Aukrust said that investigators were comparing passenger lists from the Scandanavian Star with those of other ships on which fires broke out. **********''We might then narrow down the field of possible suspects,'' he said. ''But we have no concrete leads or suspects yet.'' **********In September, the Danish police concluded that arson was responsible for a fire on a Danish North Sea ferry that was sailing from Goteborg, Sweden, to Harwich, England. Two Swedish passengers were killed. **********Fire also broke out on a Danish ferry traveling in September 1988 between Norway and Denmark, but all 230 passengers were evacuated in lifeboats. **********In the fire on Saturday, many passengers reportedly suffocated as they tried to flee down smoke-filled corridors. Some survivors said fire alarms did not work and that the crew seemed unprepared for the emergency. **********Mr. Aukrust said that several of the 358 known survivors had reported seeing piles of burning clothes or linen in corridors. Hugo Larsen, the ferry's Norwegian captain, has been quoted as saying that three separate fires were started deliberately outside cabins and that the crew managed to put out two but was unable to control the third. **********As the ferry continued to burn today at a dock in the port of Lysekil on Sweden's western coast, the authorities here said the captain had a list of 493 passengers and crew on the Scandanavian Star. But Mr. Aukrust said it was still unclear exactly how many people were on board. **********Rescue workers struggled against the smoke and flames today in an effort to retrieve the bodies. **********The ferry, equipped with a casino, pool, disco, sun decks, restaurants and shops, could carry 800 passengers and crew. The passengers were mainly Norwegians who were taking advantage of cheaper prices in Denmark. **********The fire was the worst North Sea ship disaster since March 6, 1987, when a car ferry, the Herald of Free Enterprise, capsized off the Belgian port of Zeebrugge, killing 189 people. Blame for that accident was placed on personnel who failed to close bow doors. **********After the fire on the Scandinavian Star, news reports quoted survivors as saying that the blaze began on a low deck, beneath the ferry's water line and near the stern, and spread upward. **********Ferry Fire Off Britain **********LONDON, Monday, March 9 (AP) -Fire broke out today on a car ferry carrying 297 people from Britain's western coast to Ireland, killing a crew member, a spokesman for the Royal Air Force said. **********He said the fire, which erupted beneath a car deck, was brought under control and the vessel was returning to Milford Haven, 180 miles west of London, under its own power. **********Nine people who suffered from smoke inhalation were taken to a hospital by helicopter, the spokesman said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/12/world.main_headline: Palestinians Give Passionate Support To Hussein as a Hero and a Liberator
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/12/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;   Palestinians Give Passionate Support To Hussein as a Hero and a Liberator
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/12/world.body_text: **********If Saddam Hussein is having trouble finding admirers elsewhere in the world, he need only visit this modest village. **********The working people here, as in the rest of the West Bank and elsewhere in the Arab world where Palestinians live, see the Iraqi leader as nothing short of a bona fide hero, a liberator, the restorer of Arab pride. **********''Every honest man is with Saddam, every one, every one,'' Hassan Amin, a 50-year-old shopkeeper, said as he and a cluster of friends and neighbors stood around his store this afternoon, caught in an impassioned debate about the events swirling around them. **********'Saddam Is Our Leader' **********''These other Arab leaders who are against Saddam, they are all worried about their own seats,'' Ali Mahmoud, a painter, added. ''They don't have support of 1 percent of their people. Saddam is our leader, and I'd go fight for him to remove the Americans and the traitor, King Fahd,'' the Saudi leader. **********A half-dozen other young men in the store had been leaning against the vegetable rack but stood up forcefully to nod in agreement with that. **********A week ago, opinion in the West Bank seemed divided. Many people in the street sided with President Hussein. During demonstrations at the Rafah refugee camp in the Gaza Strip a week ago, youths throwing stones at an Israeli army patrol gleefully chanted: ''Saddam is coming! He's on his way! Saddam is going to sweep you away!'' But many others worried that the Palestinian cause would be seriously neglected as long as the world's attention remained focused on the Persian Gulf conflict. **********''We the Palestinians are now entering a deep freeze of minus 60 degrees,'' Bethlehem's Mayor, Elias Friej, complained a week ago. **********'Unacceptable' Occupation **********And some other respected members of local society compared the Iraqi occupation of Kuwait to the Israeli occupation of the West Bank and said one was no more justifiable than the other. **********''Occupying land by force or the occupation of one country by another is unacceptable and could encourage further aggressive intentions in the region, especially by Israel,'' said Rawda Basir of Nablus, a leader of the Palestinian Women's Action Committee. **********But when American troops began landing in Saudi Arabia, the equation suddenly changed. Many Arabs reacted much as the people of Latin America have so often in the past: they bristled at United States interference in the region, no matter what the cause. **********As it is, many Palestinians and other Arabs feel deep resentment toward the United States. They believe American support in this region is tilted heavily toward Israel. **********Many Palestinians resent the oil-wealthy Arab nations, too, because they believe that Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the other countries that have found oil beneath the sand should have shared more of the wealth with their poorer Arab brothers. **********Swelling Resentments **********In the last week, the force of these resentments burst forth and seemed to swell with every new report that more American forces had arrived. **********Suddenly in the Palestinian popular mind, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia and the emirates - all them for years the world's largest financial contributors to the Palestine Liberation Organization - became nothing more than American dupes, puppet regimes, their leaders mere quislings. **********''What these other Arab leaders are doing is selling cheap oil to America so the Americans can improve their economy and use it to support our enemy, Israel,'' fumed 52-year-old Fakhri Takatka, who runs a family-owned stone quarry on the edge of town. ''It was wrong for King Fahd to call foreign troops onto Arab land.'' **********President Hussein, who sold the United States as much oil as it would buy, until the boycott last week, has been transformed in the popular mind so that now he is the modern-day Saladin, the Byzantine-era Muslim warrior who drove out the crusaders. **********''This is an Arab problem; America has no right to be here,'' said Achmed Dakatka, a science teacher. ''Saddam is not Hitler. He's the second Saladin.'' **********Unwavering Support **********Not one of the two-dozen residents of this small town interviewed today wavered in his support of President Hussein. And in several other West Bank and Gaza Strip cities this afternoon, Palestinians reported that hundreds of residents held marches in support of the Iraqi leader. **********None of those interviewed expressed any fear, either, that Arabs might also suffer if war comes this way. **********President Hussein has threatened to incinerate half of Israel with chemical weapons. Today, farmers and others on Israel's northern border with Jordan reported that Israel was moving tanks and artillery to the area, to be ready if Iraq decided to attack. **********Many Palestinians have seen newscasts on Jordanian television, widely watched in the West Bank, showing the Iraqi leader bending down to embrace Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O. leader, who has often visited Baghdad. **********Last night, most homes tuned in television and radio reports of President Hussein's speech to the Arab people in which he played on themes that could not but help rouse passions. **********''Oh, Arabs, Oh, Muslims and believers everywhere,'' the Iraqi leader said, ''this is your day to rise and defend Mecca, which is captured by the spears of the Americans and the Zionists. Revolt against oppression, corruption, treachery and backstabbing. Keep the foreigner away from your holy shrines.'' **********Defense of the Muslim Shrines **********Mecca, in southwestern Saudi Arabia, is at least 600 miles away from the nearest concentration of foreign troops. But here in Beit Fajar, some Palestinians were ready to go fight for the defense of the Muslim world's holiest shrines. **********''From the blessed Al-Aqsa Mosque and in the name of the Islamic world and Islamic law,'' the Mufti of Jerusalem, Saed Addin Al-Alami, wrote in a public letter to President Hussein today, ''we appeal to you to abolish the filth of the American Army and their collaborators from the holy lands, to purify these lands and to rescue the two holy mosques from the Americans and the pagans.'' **********Here in Beit Fajar, 35-year-old Youssef Takatka nodded his head as he said: ''Saddam is right to ask us to help him liberate the holy places from foreign forces. Maybe it's not good to have the whole world against the Arabs, but Saddam is the only one fighting for the Palestinians.'' **********Many Palestinians also feel that it is only a matter of time until Saddam Hussein comes to their aid. **********''In the long run, he will come back for us,'' said Jack Y. Khazmo, who edits a weekly publication, The Magazine of the Palestinian Masses. ''If Saddam succeeds in getting the oil weapon, he will show the world there is another power, an Arab power, and he will use the weapon for us'' **********But standing against the back wall in Hassan Amin's general store this afternoon, 60-year-old Musa Mohammed Hussein, the only man dressed in traditional Arab headdress and full-length shirt, had a different view. **********''The prophet Mohammed said people should share three things: fire, water and grass,'' he said. ''It's true that the Kuwaiti Emir should have shared more. **********''But Saddam is not Saladin,'' he went on. ''We are like a people drowning, trying to grab any straw. Saddam is our straw.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/17/busin.main_headline: New England Bank Weighs Bond Swap
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/17/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   New England Bank Weighs Bond Swap
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/17/busin.body_text: **********The Bank of New England Corporation is considering an exchange of all or part of its $700 million in bonds, which could reduce the value of its present shareholders' interest in the company, the company said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. **********Market officials said that some holders of the debt had proposed that they exchange each $1,000 worth of bonds for $250 in cash and $250 in stock in the company. The problem with this offer, analysts said, is that the company is trying to conserve its cash to protect its remaining capital. The company, which has sold $5 billion in assets and is negotiating the sale of a subsidiary bank in Rhode Island, has shareholders' capital equal to only 1.64 percent of equity, well below the 3 percent level regulators want it to have by the end of next May.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/08/busin.main_headline: Du Pont Offers $1.85 Billion In Zero-Coupon Securities
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/08/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;   Du Pont Offers $1.85 Billion In Zero-Coupon Securities
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/08/busin.body_text: **********E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company is offering $1.85 billion in zero-coupon convertible discount notes with final maturity of June 14, 2010, through the First Boston Corporation as sole manager. The size of the issue was originally to have been about $1.3 billion. **********Proceeds from the offering are expected to total $404.3 million and will be used to pay short-term debt incurred by an extensive share repurchase program. **********Underwriters said the notes, which pay no interest, are priced at $215.55 for every $1,000 of notes to yield 7.75 percent if held to maturity. They also feature a ''put'' option that allows note holders to sell the notes back to the company after 5 years, 10 years or 15 years for cash, common stock or subordinated repayment notes. The method of payment is at the option of the company. **********The notes are convertible into common stock at a price of $47.375 a share - the highest conversion premium ever for a zero-coupon convertible. Moody's Investors Service gave the issue a rating of A-3, and the Standard & Poor's Corporation gave it AA-.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/15/world.main_headline: U.S. to Rent Cruise Ship for Gulf G.I. Furloughs
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/15/world.print_headline: STANDOFF IN THE GULF; U.S. to Rent Cruise Ship for Gulf G.I. Furloughs
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/15/world.body_text: **********The Pentagon said today that it would pay the Cunard Line of Britain $31 million to divert a luxury cruise ship to the Persian Gulf so American soldiers and marines can enjoy brief furloughs from duty in the parched Saudi desert. **********The 800-passenger ocean liner, the Cunard Princess, has canceled its bookings for the next six months so it can begin gulf duty, Cunard said in a statement today. **********Pentagon officials said they were reviewing other proposals from cruise-ship operators to charter ships in the gulf as well. They declined to say whether other contracts would be awarded. **********The proposal to lease cruise ships for troop furloughs was conceived by Army officials as "a flexible solution to the difficult problem of how to get these troops some R and R" while on desert duty, an Army official said today, using the abbreviation for rest and recuperation leave.  Curbed by Saudi Customs **********Troops in the Persian Gulf now have access to weight rooms, movie theaters and swimming pools. But both the variety of entertainment and the ability of American servicemen and women to travel freely are constrained by Saudi political concerns and Islamic religious sensitivities. **********The 526-foot, 17,495-ton Cunard Princess, by contrast, will be able to provide alcohol and, presumably, other diversions such as uncensored movies that troops now in Saudi Arabia are not allowed. **********A Pentagon spokesman, Lieut. Col. Stu Wagner, said the vessel would take on its passengers at a port in a less restrictive Arab nation, but he declined on security grounds to name the locale. He said the ship might embark on seagoing trips as well. **********According to Rose Komes, an agent with AAA Travel in Gaithersburg, Md., the Bahamas-flagged Princess offers a range of delights not usually available to desert troops. No Gambling on Board **********"They've got a barber shop, a beauty salon, a card room, a duty-free shop, an exercise room, a gym, a library, paddle tennis, a pool, a putting green and a whirlpool," she said. "And a casino." **********Colonel Wagner ruled out roulette. "There will be no gambling on board," he said. **********He said any of the 410,000 troops scheduled for service in the gulf would be eligible for two- or three-day furloughs on the Princess or any additional ships providing they have been on duty for at least two months. **********Spouses and families of the troops will not be allowed to join their relatives on board, he said. **********"Not everyone is going to make it on, obviously," he said. But he added that the services were devising what he called an equitable plan to insure that all eligible military personnel have an equal chance to take the vacations. Terrorism Is Discounted **********The Washington Post, which reported the chartering of the ship today, quoted anonymous military officials as speculating that the Princess could become a prime target for terrorists. But an Army official, who spoke today on condition of anonymity, discounted the danger. **********"It's not a security problem," he said. "We control the seas, and own the air. There will be M.P.'s on board. Besides, the ship will be out in the gulf somewhere." **********Before it was chartered by the Defense Department, the Princess had been scheduled to ply the waters around the Canary Islands as well as the Mediterranean and the Black Sea in the winter and spring. **********Cunard officials said today that passengers who had booked passage on cruises beginning Dec. 15 and 22 would receive full refunds of their fare and complimentary cruises on another Cunard ship. Passengers booked on later cruises would receive refunds and $1,000 discounts on a future cruise.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/27/world.main_headline: Poland Promises to Help Soviet Jews Fly to Israel
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/27/world.print_headline: Poland Promises to Help Soviet Jews Fly to Israel
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/27/world.body_text: **********Three days after Hungary's airline responded to threats of terrorism by saying discontinue charter flights of Soviet Jews to Israel, Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki of Poland said that his country would take up the emigres' cause. **********Speaking at an American Jewish Congress dinner here on Sunday, Mr. Mazowiecki said, ''Just as in the Middle Ages, Poland gave refuge to Jews fleeing persecution, so today Poland will not evade humanitarian assistance to Jews emigrating from the Soviet Union.'' **********An aide to the Prime Minister said that Poland's borders would be open to all Jews wishing to leave the Soviet Union and that Poland would provide safe transport to Israel. **********In Warsaw, an official of Lot, the Polish state airline, confirmed yesterday that his company was studying a request to fly Soviet Jews to Israel from Poland. **********The executive director of the American Jewish Congress, Henry Siegman, who helped arrange Mr. Mazowiecki's appearance at the dinner, characterized the Prime Minister's remarks as ''kind of a reproach to the Hungarians for capitulating to terrorism.'' **********''Perhaps it will encourge other Eastern European countries to stand fast,'' he said. **********Hungary's airline, Malev, announced last week that it was halting flights between Moscow and Tel Aviv because of a threat from Islamic Holy War for the Liberation of Palestine, a shadowy terrorist group based in Lebanon. **********The Hungarian Foreign Minister, Gyula Horn, said yesterday at a news conference in Budapest that his Government was seeking a way around the decision by Malev, which is not Government-controlled. A Malev spokesman in Budapest that the airline would be happy to add flights to Israel, ''but at the moment, without Soviet Jewish immigrants.'' **********An estimated 100,000 Soviet Jews are expected to settle in Israel this year, and as many as 750,000 over the next six years. Arab countries and the Palestine Liberation Organization have demanded that the Soviets halt the exodus. They argue that many of the immigrants will settle in the occupied West Bank and the Gaza Strip, areas that the Palestinians claim as their own. **********Mr. Siegman said that representives of the American Jewish Congress would meet in Washington with the Hungarian Ambassador. ''We hope to pursuade the Hungarian airline to resume its flights,'' he said. ''We hope to convince him that there is no better way to encourage terrorism than to capitulate to it.'' **********Asked why Jewish leaders apparently bypassed Western European countries, searching mainly in the East bloc for flights for emigrating Soviet Jews, Mr. Siegman said that using Western cities like Geneva, Rome or Frankfurt would be more expensive. **********''The Eastern nations provide the most direct route,'' he said. ''The cost is horrendous to begin with. Western European destinations are far out of the way; they would virtually double the cost.'' **********Raphael Rothstein, a vice president of the United Jewish Appeal, said a group of 150 American Jews planned to meet in Moscow today with Yuri A. Reshetov, an official in the Soviet Foreign Ministry who deals with Jewish affairs, and urge him to ask the Hungarians to resume the charter flights. **********Mr. Rothstein said 10,000 to 13,000 Soviet Jews who have been issued visas are awaiting transportation to Israel. ''They are all people who could go right away if there were flights,'' he said. **********Mr. Rothstein said he understood that Israel was negotiating with Finland and Yugoslavia to provide flights for Soviet Jews. **********In Washington, representatives of the American Jewish Committee met yesterday with State Department and National Security Council officials and foreign diplomats to ''express serious concern about roadblocks to immigration at a time of growing apprehension among Soviet Jews'' about conditions in the Soviet Union. **********Mr. Rothstein said the United Jewish Appeal had raised $100 million for ''Operation Exodus,'' a program for resettlement of Soviet Jews. He said it hoped eventually to collect $420 million.
