https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/09/busin.snippet: LEAD: IN its second season of trying, a cable sports network has made some progress in signing up sponsors for national broadcasts of high school sports.
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/09/busin.main_headline:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;

Gatorade Sponsoring High School Games
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/09/busin.print_headline:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;

Gatorade Sponsoring High School Games
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/09/busin.body_text: **********LEAD: IN its second season of trying, a cable sports network has made some progress in signing up sponsors for national broadcasts of high school sports. **********IN its second season of trying, a cable sports network has made some progress in signing up sponsors for national broadcasts of high school sports. **********Many prospective advertisers had balked because of criticism that national television exposure and big-money sponsorships would corrupt high school athletics. But after a yearlong search, SportsChannel America, a cable station seen in about 11 million homes nationwide, has found its first sponsor: Gatorade, the sports drink. **********The Quaker Oats Company, which makes Gatorade, is reportedly paying $600,000 annually for sponsorship rights to 25 Friday-night high school sports events a year, mainly basketball and football. **********SportsChannel, co-owned by NBC and the Cablevision Systems Corporation, agreed in March 1989 to pay a reported $250,000 annually to the National Federation of State High School Associations for five-year broadcast rights to selected games. The federation represents about 90 percent of the country's public, private and parochial schools. **********When SportsChannel struck its deal, executives at the Woodbury, L.I., cable network envisioned signing up four national sponsors quickly. But that did not happen. **********''There was a lot of criticism in the press,'' said Peter T. Knobloch, SportsChannel's senior vice president for national sales. **********''They thought we were commercializing high school athletics,'' he said. ''That hurt us initially. But the fact that we have the first sponsor is going to generate more interest.'' **********High school sports are a mania in many parts of the country, illustrated by the large crowds and local and regional television and radio coverage attracted to events like Texas football, Indiana basketball and Minnesota hockey. But not until the SportsChannel deal were there any regularly scheduled national broadcasts. **********SportsChannel America figured advertisers would jump at the chance to become involved because high school students are a target market for many consumer products companies. **********No ratings of the broadcasts are available because SportsChannel is not seen in enough homes, but the network estimates that its broadcasts are seen in as many as 200,000 to 300,000 homes. **********The federation and SportsChannel contend that the broadcasts are a good idea because they try to focus attention on the benefits of many extracurricular activities, ranging from band to cheerleading, not just high-profile athletics. **********Anti-drug and other promotional messages were created for the games, and announcers add facts like grade-point averages to their discussions of athletes. No advertising was accepted from beer companies. And rather than pitting far-flung schools against one another in pseudo-championship games, the broadcasts are limited to regularly scheduled contests from different parts of the country, like local rivals in Louisville, Ky., and western Texas. **********The money generated from the games is minuscule compared with that on the college level. The federation uses the money it receives to cover expenses, give participating schools $1,200 and to finance drug and alcohol education projects and other programs, said Warren S. Brown, the federation's assistant executive director. **********Yet despite the federation's careful treading, there remains strong sentiment that national commercial television will corrupt high school sports. **********''I don't care how they try to justify it, I think it's bad,'' said H. G. Bissinger, the author of ''Friday Night Lights,'' a book that looks critically at the phenomenon of Texas high school football. ''There is enough pressure on the kids already. In some places they already get 20,000 people a game. They don't need to be on television.'' **********Barry Frank, group vice president at the International Management Group, a large sports marketing company, agreed. ''I wouldn't touch this with a 10-foot pole,'' he said. ''I thought it was a dreadful idea to do this initially, and I still think it's a dreadful idea because of the pressures you put on the kids and coaches.'' **********Executives at Gatorade said they based their involvement not on the expectation of big ratings or a quick increase in product sales but on what they believe to be the long-term benefits of promoting high school sports.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/29/busin.body_text: **********Michigan's Governor, James J. Blanchard, today proposed legislation that would bar the leading oil companies from running service stations. **********''The huge gasoline price increases consumers have suffered since Iraq invaded Kuwait reflect the stranglehold major oil companies have on the oil industry,'' Mr. Blanchard said in a statement. **********The Governor said the proposed law would spur competition by allowing gasoline stations to find the best price being offered by oil companies. **********Since the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait by Iraq, retail prices have jumped nearly 20 cents a gallon, according to the American Automobile Association. **********The Governor, a Democrat, also proposed comprehensive ''open supply'' legislation allowing service station operators to buy fuel from any supplier that offers their own brand of gasoline. **********Currently, the leading oil producers require dealers to buy all gasoline from their own distribution networks, Mr. Blanchard said. **********Oil industry officials reacted negatively to the proposal. Neal Geary, a spokesman for the Amoco Corporation, said the legislation would harm consumers in the long run by wiping out a class of competition, the oil company-owned service station. **********The legislation, which Mr. Blanchard said aims to ''break up the oil monopolies,'' would prohibit oil producers or refiners from either owning or operating retail service stations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/02/busin.main_headline: Pep Boys Chief No Kin Of Manny, Moe or Jack
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/02/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;   Pep Boys Chief No Kin Of Manny, Moe or Jack
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/02/busin.body_text: **********Pep Boys - Manny, Moe & Jack, a chain of 280 auto supply stores, has a new chief executive. **********Mitchell G. Leibovitz, 44, the Philadelphia-based company's president, has added the title that up to now has been held by Benjamin Strauss, 53, a son of Maurice Strauss, a company founder who was the ''Moe'' in the company's name. **********Benjamin Strauss will continue as chairman, one of two founding-family members still on the board. The other is Lester Rosenfeld, son of Emanuel Rosenfeld, the original ''Manny.'' **********Mr. Leibovitz is the first chief executive from outside the founding families. ''This promotion probably reflects the transition the company has made over time,'' he said, ''from a family-dominated company to much more of a public company. A board once dominated by insiders is now dominated by outsiders.'' **********The Strauss and Rosenfeld families own much less of the stock than they once did, although descendants of the founders still hold about 20 percent, Mr. Leibovitz said. **********The company was founded in 1921 by Manny Rosenfeld, Moe Strauss and W. Graham Jackson, or ''Jack.'' Mr. Jackson left in the late 1920's and Moe Strauss brought his brother, I. M. Strauss, into the business. In the company logotype that shows the likenesses of Manny, Moe & Jack, Jack's likeness was replaced by I. M. Strauss's but the name ''Jack'' was retained. ''It should have been ''Manny, Moe & I. M.,'' Mr. Leibovitz said. **********In the 1930's I. M. Strauss left and founded a rival chain called Strauss Stores. **********Mr. Leibovitz was an accountant with Seidman & Seidman familiar with the Pep Boys business when he joined the company in 1978 as controller. ''I became very close to Moe, who died in 1982,'' Mr. Leibovitz said. **********The company embarked on a five-year expansion plan in 1986, the year Mr. Leibovitz became president, after a long period of little growth. Sales have moved to $800 million annually from $350 million then. The plan is to build a national automotive after-market retail and service chain with a doubling in the number of stores, to 320, by the end of next year, Mr. Leibovitz said. **********Mr. Leibovitz, a Philadelphian, is a graduate of Temple University with an undergraduate degree in liberal arts and a master's in business. He is a Temple trustee.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/09/busin.body_text: **********The proposed acquisition by Northern Telecom Ltd. of the remaining 73 percent of the outstanding shares of STC P.L.C. for about $2.6 billion has prompted Moody's Investors Service Inc. and the Standard & Poor's Corporation to place the senior debt rating of Northern Telecom under review with negative implications. **********The review, which affects up to $1 billion in debt, was prompted by the concerns of both rating agencies over the added debt burden that will result from the purchase of the STC shares. Both rating agencies will also be examining the potential benefits of combining the two companies' product lines. **********The purchase is expected to be made with bank debt and proceeds from the sale of STC's computer business, STC International Computers Ltd., to Fujitsu Ltd. of Japan. **********Northern Telecom, based in Mississauga, Ontario, is one of the largest suppliers of telecommunications equipment in North America, while STC, based in London, is one of the United Kingdom's leading telecommunications companies. **********Northern Telecom's senior debt is currently rated Aa-3 by Moody's and A+ by S.& P.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/31/world.print_headline: Upheaval in the East;   Visiting U.S. Lawyer Expert on the Baltics
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/31/world.body_text: **********William J. H. Hough 3d, the Manhattan lawyer who is advising the Lithuanian government, published a legal study of the republic's 1940 annexation by the Soviet Union and testified before Congress on the subject. **********Although Mr. Hough is not of Lithuanian descent, he is known as ''a friend of the Baltic cause,'' Victor A. Nakas, manager of the Washington office of the Lithuanian Information Center, said last night. The center, which is run by Lithuanian-Americans, distributes information about events in Lithuania. **********His 232-page paper, published in 1985 in the New York Law School Journal of International and Comparative Law, was entitled, ''The Annexation of the Baltic States and Its Effect on the Development of Law Prohibiting Forceable Seizure of Territory.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/01/world.main_headline: Cambodia Gives Partial Backing To U.N. Plan for Ending the War
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/01/world.print_headline: Cambodia Gives Partial Backing To U.N. Plan for Ending the War
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/01/world.body_text: **********The Vietnamese-backed Cambodian Government today gave its qualified endorsement to a new United Nations peace plan under which it would share power with the three guerrilla groups it has been fighting for 11 years. **********At the same time it also agreed to a major United Nations role in Cambodian affairs during a period leading to elections, the official Cambodian press agency said. **********Cambodia's endorsement of the plan was announced in Phnom Penh as United States officials met with Vietnamese diplomats here in New York to discuss the same matter. **********Until today, there was some question as to whether the Vietnamese-backed Cambodian Prime Minister, Hun Sen, would go along with the peace proposals. They require not only that he share power with the three other factions but that he also turn over the administration of five of his most important ministries to the United Nations. **********The press agency quoted Cambodia's Deputy Prime Minister for Foreign Affairs, Hor Nam Hong, as saying the United Nations plan ''could constitute a basis for discussions among the Cambodian parties.'' He added, ''Certain points of the documents are worth discussing in fuller detail in order to be able to reach an overall solution to the Cambodia problem.'' **********The peace plan, first made public earlier this week, was drawn up over eight months by the five permanent members of the Security Council: the United States, the Soviet Union, China, Britain and France. It calls for the creation of a Supreme National Council made up of the Phnom Penh Government and the three guerrilla factions that have been fighting to overthrow it - the Khmer Rouge and two non-Communist groups, the People's National Liberation Front and a group led by Prince Norodom Sihanouk. **********The three guerrilla groups have welcomed the peace plan. **********In Beijing today, Prince Sihanouk said in a statement that the three guerrilla groups ''fully support, without any reservation, the most recent proposals and peace plan of the five permanent members.'' **********''We engage ourselves to implement it,'' he added. ''In Jakarta, the three delegations of the Cambodian National Resistance shall make everything possible to favor peace.'' **********All four factions are scheduled to meet in Jakarta, Indonesia, in September to draw up plans for the Supreme National Council. **********The plan calls for an interim United Nations administration in Cambodia, with specialists from the world organization taking over five key ministries until after elections are held. It also calls for the disarming of the guerrilla factions by a peacekeeping force of as many as 10,000 troops under a United Nations command. **********Mr. Hor Nam Hong said in Phnom Penh Thursday that his Government accepts that ''a major role'' would be ''played by the United Nations in the transitional period, notably the right to organize free and fair elections.'' **********''We also accept that certain important ministries may be supervised by the United Nations,'' he said, ''so that the elections can take place in a neutral political environment.'' **********According to some reports, however, Prime Minister Hun Sen still has reservations about the plan. Reuters said diplomats in Phnom Penh said he was concerned about sharing power and about the practical aspects of disarming the guerrillas, particularly the Khmer Rouge. **********After Thursday's talks between the United States and Vietnam at the American Mission to the United Nations, Trinh Xuan Lang, the Vietnamese chief delegate to the United Nations, said, ''We appreciate and welcome the talks led by the permanent five in contributing to the search for an early solution to the Cambodian issue.'' But he added, ''All matters relating to the internal affairs of Cambodia as well as the subject of Cambodia must be decided and agreed upon by the Cambodians themselves.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/28/world.main_headline: A Bulgarian Town's Killer Is Industrial Pollution
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/28/world.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;   A Bulgarian Town's Killer Is Industrial Pollution
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/28/world.body_text: **********In this valley under the snowcapped Balkan Mountains, old people remember the time when everyone grew roses, acres of roses, which they pressed into oils for perfume and medicine. **********They also recall the excitement when the copper plant arrived, evidence of progress under Communist rule, they were told, that would bring them new jobs and modern homes. **********What most people here still do not know is that for much of the last 30 years the enormous and shabby industrial compound on a hillside above the town has been poisoning their land and, in many cases, their bodies with lead and arsenic. **********Arsenic has been found in alarming quantities as far as 25 miles away, but the authorities have kept this secret from the local population. When the plant spilled about 200 tons of arsenic in 1988, contaminating farmland and killing cattle and sheep, the disaster was covered up for nine months. **********Deformities and Cancer **********At the local hospital, doctors speak of a frightening rise in the number of babies born with deformities, of cancer and chronic mouth and lung disease. They say infant mortality here is almost three times the norm for Bulgaria and they cite an abnormal number of people with high blood pressure and dental problems among the town's 35,000 inhabitants. **********''When I started here in 1976, there was no cancer,'' said Dr. Nikolai Ivanov, a hospital surgeon. ''Last year we had at least 45 cases.'' **********But local officials have repeatedly assured workers that tests show nothing abnormal in their blood or in the environment. Doctors complaining to the plant management were promptly denounced as troublemakers by local Communist Party bosses. **********In other parts of polluted Eastern Europe the authorities have started to make an inventory of the disastrous legacy of unrestrained industrial growth and is asking for help in the West. But in Bulgaria the subject is still treated as a state secret. **********Hiding of Medical Reports **********Environmentalists, who include doctors and engineers, say that even in today's more politically lenient climate they are harassed, followed or intimidated. Several physicians said that medical reports in state-run factories are routinely hidden or falsified. **********The arsenic, lead and copper in the dust of Srednogorie - at least 70 times the permissible level, according to a secret Government document - is said to make this town one of Bulgaria's most dangerous. But at least 10 other cities are struggling with their own serious pollution problems. **********Sofia, the capital, once praised for its clear mountain air, lies trapped in frequent haze oozing from two giant steel plants at Pernik and Kremikovtsi. The latter alone reportedly dumps 20,000 tons of grime a year on Sofia's center, eight miles away, and siphons off one-third of the capital's water. **********In the northern city of Ruse, a chemical plant just across the border in Romania often makes breathing difficult. But when a ''Defend Ruse'' committee was formed, some of its members were run out of the Communist Party and others lost their jobs. Industries have poisoned the bays of Burgas and Varna, on the Black Sea. **********A Gradual Poisoning **********The gradual poisoning of Bulgaria matches the enormous pollution and environmental disaster now being recognized throughout Eastern Europe. Its fate was perhaps less predestined, though, because Stalin originally assigned Bulgaria, with its fertile soils and moderate climate, to be the East bloc's garden, to provide grains, fruits and vegetables to its neighbors. **********But that agricultural vocation began to change in the 1950's as heavy industries came in. Last year, Bulgaria, which once exported two-thirds of its farm produce, was forced to import food. A Communist Party report says that almost 60 percent of land is now ''damaged'' by excessive use of fertilizers, pesticides and industrial fallout. **********The steel and chemical industries are also increasingly having trouble finding workers. To attract laborers to the steelworks at Krimikovci, the Government has promised to exempt young men from military service if they will work there five years. **********From the outside, Srednogorie's copper plant, which employs 1,500 people, looks grimy enough, with its bulky slag heaps and its chimney spewing yellow smoke. Inside, it seems more like a battlefield. The grounds are strewn with rusting metal and discarded machinery. An old sulfur plant has disintegrated into a forest of blistered pipes and tanks. Some workers in a great hall with cauldrons and smelters wore gas masks. Others did not bother to protect themselves. **********Dangerous Toxic Clouds **********Twice last year, when controls failed, the plant emitted such dangerous toxic clouds that it had to close down and the children of Srednogorie were evacuated to other towns, said Deltcho Vichev, an engineer of the Ministry of Metallurgy and a plant consultant. **********But the worst incident came in December 1988, when workers discovered cracks in the retaining walls of a vast reservoir, the dumping ground for the plant's toxic waste. Its mud contains high concentrations of arsenic, lead and other discards left after copper, silver and gold have been taken from the ore. **********''The Government decided secretly to let water out of the reservoir to diminish the pressure on the walls,'' said one expert familiar with the incident. The highly poisonous sludge was spilled into the Pirdopska River, which feeds the Topolnika River, which is used to irrigate some of Bulgaria's best agricultural land. **********According to an unpublished Government study, 200 tons of arsenic was released and some lands irrigated with river water had concentrations of arsenic at 4,000 times the permissible level. Near the village of Poibrene, farmers told researchers that their sheep were aborting and cows ''were going mad'' and dying. **********Government 'Said Nothing' **********''The Government knew everything but said nothing,'' said the expert, himself a Government employee. ''The whole summer they let people go swimming and fishing in that river.'' **********Nine months after the spill, after continuous pressure from experts and from Eco-Glasnost, the Bulgarian environmental movement, the authorities imposed a five-year ban on fishing, swimming or using irrigation water from the Topolnika. But they have not warned people against eating produce from the area. Experts say at least 150,000 acres of badly contaminated land should be banned for agriculture. **********The arsenic in the soil around Srednogorie and on the fields downstream is likely to remain there. ''It does not decompose,'' said Mr. Vichev, who joined Eco-Glasnost because ''those of us who understand the seriousness of pollution must speak out.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/16/world.main_headline: 140 BLACKS SLAIN IN SOUTH AFRICA AS FACTIONS CLASH
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/16/world.print_headline: 140 BLACKS SLAIN IN SOUTH AFRICA AS FACTIONS CLASH
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/16/world.body_text: **********After three days of increasing factional bloodletting that spilled across black townships east of Johannesburg, the police reported tonight that at least 140 blacks had been shot, stabbed, beaten or burned to death. **********The violence surpassed in its ferocity anything witnessed in the anti-apartheid protests of the mid-1980's and seemed to suggest that the virtual civil war that has taken thousands of lives in Natal Province over the last three years is taking root in the industrial heartland of the Transvaal. **********The number of people wounded in the clashes was over 100, a police spokesman said. **********As in the fighting in Natal, the precise causes of the upsurge in violence as well as the motives and profiles of those taking part differ from township to township. Though the conflicts often revolve around struggles for dominance by rival gangs, they also reflect patterns of tribal enmity and competition between people who identify with the African National Congress and others who affirm their allegiance in Inkatha, a movement of the Zulu tribe. **********Encampment Set Afire **********Early today columns of smoke rose from wrecked and burned squatter shacks at a place called Crossroads after a dawn attack by what residents called Zulu impis, or battalions. They looted and torched the encampment in Katlehong township, leaving people to burn to death inside, according to police and residents' accounts. **********''We just keep on finding bodies,'' said a police officer, who asked not to be identified. **********Shortly afterward, on scrubland near a migrant workers' hostel occupied by Zulus at nearby Thokoza, hundreds of Xhosa-speakers seeking vengeance massed and charged, repulsed only by gunfire from inside that felled some of their numbers. **********In Vosloorus, 13 bodies lay on a police-station floor after a night of fighting between rival factions distinguished by tribe and affiliation to the the African National Congress of Nelson Mandela and the Inkatha movement of the Zulu Chief, Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi. **********At a squatter camp called Phola Park near the Thokoza hostel, hundreds of women fled crude homes of zinc sheeting today, their belongings piled on their heads. ''I would rather they burned my shack than burned me and my clothes,'' one woman said. **********As passions deepened, toward late afternoon, a crowd of people in Thokoza ran down a single, unidentified man, poured gasoline over him and set him alight on the ground, apparently because he was thought to be a member of the Zulu tribe, South Africa's biggest, numbering at least six million. **********South African Army units were ordered to reinforce the already strengthened police units, which according to reporters in the townships today opened fire on township residents with shotguns and tear-gas at close range. **********African National Congress officials accused the police of siding with Inkatha, a charge the police denied. Many of the dead, hospital officials said, had died from high velocity gunshot wounds. **********The South African Red Cross said it was planning to set up refugee camps for those made suddenly homeless. **********As heavily armed white policemen moved to disarm the rival bands, officers smashed down the locked doors of abandoned shacks in the Phola Park squatter camp to retrieve spears and clubs. More ominously, in the single men's hostel police officers uncovered a cache of Soviet-made assault rifles, pistols and hand grenades, a police spokesman said. It was not immediately clear which faction had hidden them there. **********''There can be no winners, only losers and untold misery when opposing parties fight each other as is happening on the East Rand,'' Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok said in a statement. **********Conversations with combatants, hostel residents, squatters and political leaders left the impression that the fighting had built spontaneously from a single incident Sunday when a Xhosa man was killed in the hostel here. Afterward, attack and counterattack fed on rumor and vengeance inspired by tribal, political and social rivalries. **********The killings brought to around 200 the number of deaths in a week that has seen major outbursts of violence in Port Elizabeth, Sebokeng township south of Johannesburg, and three townships on the East Rand - Thokoza, Katlehong and Vosloorus, all close to one another about 20 miles southeast of Johannesburg. **********The violence is not related to the so-called armed struggle by the African National Congress, whose suspension Mr. Mandela ordered last week, Rather, combatants and residents said today, it seems part of a broadening sense of rivalry between the congress and Inkatha that has confronted many people with political choices that draw heavily on tribal identities. The tensions have sharpened since clashes between the congress and Inkatha spread last month from Natal to Transvaal townships, including Sebokeng and Kagiso, west of Johannesburg.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/30/busin.body_text: **********Nintendo of America, the video game company, is ''talking to a number of agencies'' about its advertising account, an advertising executive said yesterday. The incumbent, McCann-Erickson/ New York, is participating in the review, the executive said. The account bills about $15 million. Nintendo officials did not return telephone calls for comment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/11/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   McDonald's Changes Its Campaign Slogan
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/11/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   McDonald's Changes Its Campaign Slogan
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/11/busin.body_text: **********After extolling the ''good time, great taste of McDonald's'' for six years, the fast-food icon is changing its advertising slogan. Effective tonight, the theme will be ''You know the one, McDonald's, for food, folks and fun.'' In a statement, Paul D. Schrage, McDonald's senior executive vice president and chief marketing officer, called the new theme ''a message that reflects the basic values that set McDonald's apart.'' **********McDonald's agency, the Leo Burnett Company, said it had created more than 25 television and radio commercials in support of the new theme. In one television spot, a young man wins over his blind date by telling her that he is a ''McDonald's kind of guy'' who does not like restaurants with names that include foreign words. Another ad, called ''Good Earth,'' maintains that McDonald's food is wholesome and nutritious. **********''Food, Folks and Fun'' was first used in a recent commercial that documented the opening of a McDonald's in Moscow.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/26/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Bell Atlantic Plans Earnings Charge
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/26/busin.body_text: **********The Bell Atlantic Corporation said it would take a one-time charge against its fourth-quarter earnings of about $40 million, or 10 cents a share. The charge will reduce the value on Bell Atlantic's books of the company's non-telephone financial services, which include equipment leasing and lending to other companies and real estate projects. **********Bell Atlantic, based in Philadelphia, said that the businesses were doing well and had no credit problems but that their market value had fallen. Marion M. Boucher, an analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc., said Bell Atlantic's investments outside the telephone industry now appeared more vulnerable to an economic downturn than many investors had thought. Bell Atlantic's stock fell 87.5 cents yesterday, to $50.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/01/world.main_headline: Pilot of Helicopter Describes Ceausescu's Escape Attempt
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/01/world.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: DICTATOR'S FLIGHT;   Pilot of Helicopter Describes Ceausescu's Escape Attempt
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/01/world.body_text: **********Nicolae Ceausescu's brief and vain attempt to escape capture was described today by his helicopter pilot as a scrambled flight in which crew members were held at gunpoint and one of them sat in the Rumanian dictator's lap. **********The pilot, Lieut. Col. Vasile Malutan, said that at one point he had told Mr. Ceausescu that their aircraft had been spotted by radar and would probably be shot down. **********''That frightened him,'' Colonel Malutan said, and led to an order to land immediately. Once on the ground, he said, the toppled dictator, his wife, Elena, and two security guards stopped a passing car, ordered its four occupants to get out and then drove off. **********Soon afterward, the Ceausescus were spotted in Tirgoviste, 45 miles northwest of Bucharest, and according to some accounts were surrounded by peasants and soldiers. They were arrested, reportedly consigned to an armored car and three days later, on Dec. 25, executed by a firing squad. **********Most Complete Account **********Details of the attempted escape, the most complete to come to light so far, were included in an interview with the pilot published today in Rumania Libera, one of the newspapers that sprang up after Mr. Ceausescu's ouster. **********The pilot, an 18-year veteran, said he and two other crew members had been ordered to fly their helicopter from the Bucharest Airport and land it on the roof of the downtown headquarters of the Communist Party's Central Committee. He said they did not realize what was happening until they saw a crowd surging toward the roof. **********At the same moment, the Ceausescus were being hustled - almost carried, Colonel Malutan said - to the helicopter by their bodyguards. Accompanying them were two party loyalists who are now under arrest, identified as Emil Bobu and Manea Manescu. There was not room for them all, and as a result, the pilot said, his mechanic ''had to be seated in the dictator's lap.'' **********Their first destination was Snagov, a town 20 miles north of Bucharest where the Ceausescus had a summer retreat. Other helicopters were to meet them there. But instead, Colonel Malutan said, a superior told him over the radio that he was on his own. **********He was then ordered to fly to a special military airfield at Boteni, to the northwest and not far from Tirgoviste. This time, though, the overloaded helicopter had trouble taking off, so Mr. Manescu and Mr. Bobu got out. **********The helicopter headed to Boteni. One of the security guards ordered that there be no more radio contact and, the pilot said, pointed a machine gun at the crew. But the pilot said he maintained radio contact anyway. A few minutes later, he told Mr. Ceausescu that the helicopter had been spotted and that he had been told the Government had been overthrown. **********Mr. Ceausescu, he said, replied: ''No. Those are only horrible lies. Are you not serving the cause?'' **********But when he then told the deposed leader that they not only had been seen but were in danger of being blown up, Mr. Ceausescu became frightened and ordered that they land, which they did on a road near Boteni, he said. **********As Mr. Ceausescu left the helicopter, Colonel Malutan said, he asked again, ''Are you serving the cause?'' **********The colonel said he replied, ''Which cause should I serve?'' **********His last view of the man who had guided this country through 24 repressive years was of his hijacking a car and driving away.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/06/busin.body_text: **********The Tonka Corporation said several suits had been filed Monday by shareholders in Federal court in Minnesota in response to the company's announcement last week that it expects a significant loss for the second quarter on lower sales. The toy company said the plaintiffs seek unspecified damages and have asked that a class of shareholders be certified for litigation. Tonka said it believed the suits were without merit and that it would defend against them.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/22/busin.main_headline: Retired Top Executive Hired as Celgene Chief
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/22/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;   Retired Top Executive Hired as Celgene Chief
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/22/busin.body_text: **********For a small company with no products on the market, the Celgene Corporation has some high-powered executives. And now it is getting another, John L. Ufheil, the former chief operating officer of Mallinckrodt Inc. **********Mr. Ufheil, 56 years old, who retired from Mallinckrodt a year and a half ago, will be president and chief executive of Celgene, a publicly traded biotechnology company formed three years ago as a spinoff of the Celanese Corporation. **********He will succeed Louis Fernandez, Celgene's first chief executive, who becomes the company's chairman. **********Frank T. Cary, the former chairman of the International Business Machines Corporation and Celgene's current chairman, becomes chairman of the board's executive committee. **********Celgene, based in Warren, N.J., is concentrating on making specialty chemical products. ''A lot of the other biotechnology companies are concentrating more in the pharmaceutical side and not in the specialty chemical and the bioremediation side,'' Mr. Ufheil said. **********Bioremediation products are used to clean up toxic wastes, Mr. Ufheil said. In addition to bioremediation, Celgene is also seeking to develop lightweight, high-strength polymers for aircraft and industry through a technology known as biocatalysis, he said. **********Mr. Ufheil said he had had no intention of returning to work after he retired from Mallinckrodt. **********''Lou contacted me and started talking about Celgene,'' he said. ''Over a period, I was encouraged to join.'' **********Mr. Fernandez, a former chairman of the Monsanto Company, said in a statement that ''with the company now moving toward commercialization of its unique technologies, this is a good time to make this planned change.'' **********Mr. Ufheil joined Mallinckrodt, whose main business is chemicals, in 1981 when it was an independent company. A year later it was acquired by Avon Inc. and in 1986 by the International Minerals and Chemicals Corporation. Mr. Ufheil took an early retirement option offered to Mallinckrodt executives. **********He is a graduate of Bradley University in Peoria, Ill., and worked for Baxter Travenol Laboratories from 1959 to 1975.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/19/busin.body_text: **********Continental A.G. of West Germany said its supervisory board voted to reject a proposal from Pirelli S.p.A. of Italy to merge the two companies' tire operations under Pirelli's control. Instead, Continental will draft its own proposal to present to Pirelli, a Continental spokesman, Dieter von Herz, said. A spokesman for Pirelli said the company had no immediate comment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/21/busin.main_headline: Fax Corp. Is Accused of Franchise Fraud
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/21/busin.print_headline: Fax Corp. Is Accused of Franchise Fraud
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/21/busin.body_text: **********The fast-growing industry built around credit-card-operated facsimile machines may be attracting fraudulent operators, a Federal Trade Commission official said yesterday. **********The official said the agency had obtained a court order on Monday freezing the assets of one of the largest franchisers in the business, a New Jersey company that reportedly defrauded investors in 500 distributorships of up to $29 million. **********''This really appears to have been a very successful scam,'' said Eileen Harrington, the associate director of the F.T.C.'s division of marketing practices. **********Convicted 48 Times **********The chairman of the company involved had been convicted of fraud 48 times, the commission said, and was involved in a 1979 proposal to buy Helena Rubinstein Inc. that never got off the ground. **********Several thousand self-service facsimile machines have been installed nationwide in hotels, airports, local stores and neighborhood post offices over the last four years. They allow users to transmit documents electronically over telephone lines to anywhere in the United States, and charge from $1 to $10 a minute for the service. **********The largest company in the field is Hotelecopy Inc., which has a contract to install 263 credit-card-operated machines in local post offices, including several already in service in Manhattan. Hotelecopy owns its equipment, but most companies in the industry are franchisers that sell the machines and a territory to would-be entrepreneurs. **********Hearing Next Month **********A Federal marshal served a temporary restraining order Monday on one of the largest of these franchisers, the Fax Corporation of America, which is based in Little Falls, N.J., and on its chairman, Seymour L. Butan, Ms. Harrington said. Issued by a Federal judge in Newark at the F.T.C.'s request, the order froze Mr. Butan's and the company's assets pending a hearing next month at which the commission will seek restitution for 500 franchisees who paid $29 million for territories and equipment, she said. **********Mr. Butan, who is 59 years old, did not return numerous telephone calls seeking comment. **********In December 1979, Mr. Butan announced that he had assembled $40 million in cash and a $20 million line of credit from a consortium of European banks for the purchase of Helena Rubinstein, a beleaguered cosmetics division of the Colgate-Palmolive Company. But the European consortium denied having authorized any funds and, in May 1981 Mr. Butan was sentenced by a New Jersey state court to 10 years in prison and fined $46,000 on 18 counts of fraud unrelated to the Rubinstein bid. He served less than three years of the sentence before he was released on probation. **********In a legal brief filed Monday and unsealed yesterday, the F.T.C. cited Mr. Butan's 48 convictions for fraudulent activities. **********Misrepresentations Charged **********The commission charged in the brief that Fax failed to disclose or misrepresented the potential earnings from franchises, the availabilty of refunds and the true identities and criminal records of its principals. Had the information been made available to potential investors, Ms. Harrington said, ''we think it very likely that no one would have invested.'' **********Fax also sold franchises for areas where it had no legal right to install machines, like Logan Airport in Boston, and sometimes failed to give franchisees the proceeds from machines it serviced on their behalf, she said. **********Fax's legal problems may retard the installation of public facsimile machines, said Mario DiNatale, the president of the FaxIt Corporation, which is based in Mount Laurel, N.J., and both sells and franchises credit card-operated facsimile machines. **********''It's going to hurt my business,'' he said. ''It's going to hurt the industry.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/12/busin.main_headline: Formica: When a Household Name Becomes an 'Also-Ran'
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/12/busin.print_headline: Formica: When a Household Name Becomes an 'Also-Ran'
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/12/busin.body_text: **********No company likes to be knocked off the mountaintop by competitors, but the experience is especially galling if that mountain bears the company's name. Consider the case of the Formica Corporation, whose name is to laminated plastic countertops what Xerox is to copiers and Polaroid to instant photography. **********Formica enters the 1990's proudly describing itself as the world's largest producer of consumer laminates, which are layers of paper mixed with plastic resin and bonded under pressure and heat. The 77-year-old company brought in revenues of $410 million last year, selling products ranging from chairs to wall paneling. **********But the sadder truth is that Formica is the No. 2 company in its market in the United States, fighting to regain its historic lead after having been outhustled and outsmarted through most of the 1970's and early 80's by Ralph Wilson Plastics, a Temple, Tex., subsidiary of Premark International Inc. **********Wilson is hardly a household name among homeowners, who still call all plastic laminates ''formica,'' but contractors and architects know it well. Its Wilsonart products now command about 45 percent of the American market, compared with 32 percent for Formica, which generates less than half its sales domestically. **********''When I got into it 27 years ago, Formica was the supplier and everyone else was an also-ran,'' said Dale LaRose, a vice president for the Pioneer Plastics Corporation of Auburn, Me., a smaller competitor. ''But the one word that came up in the marketplace for them was arrogance. Wilson recognized that service would become more important.'' **********In fact, the Wilson-Formica case was used in a recent book, ''Competing Against Time,'' as an example of how nimble companies focus on speed to gain strategic advantages. The authors, George Stalk Jr. and Thomas M. Hout, concluded that Wilson now ''owns the market'' and labeled Formica an ''also-ran.'' **********When Vincent L. Langone, Formica's chief executive, heard the assessment, he was furious. In his view, Formica should have been credited with recognizing the opportunities in overseas investment, where its operating returns amount to 20 percent, nearly double the domestic margins. He also argues that Formica remains the industry's design leader and a technology leader, citing its early introduction of a European method of pressing laminates with a textured steel plate to produce a matte finish without the use of specialty papers. **********What makes him angriest, though, is the book's implication that it is describing the current state of competition in the industry. ''We can get any non-standard product to customers in less than two weeks,'' he said. ''It was an accurate description of the 1970's.'' **********In any case, Formica is still struggling to overcome that legacy. With a continuous stream of new products and financial support for dealers, which is helping them price products more competitively, Formica has managed to stop the market-share erosion. The company also estimates that Wilson's operating income as a percentage of sales has declined from more than 16 percent in 1985 to about 10 percent last year while Formica's has risen to more than 11 percent from more than 8 percent in the same period. **********That comparison is disputed by Bobby D. Dillon, Wilson's president. Premark does not release separate performance figures for Wilson, but Mr. Dillon said his company's income as a percentage of sales was significantly higher than Formica estimates. **********An important feature of Wilson's strategy against Formica is a network of 15 regional warehouses that provide one-day delivery of its products to distributors. In addition, the company designed its products to use a simplified, albeit more expensive, group of resins that allowed it to quickly make any items the distributors did not have in stock. **********That meant Wilson could provide almost any product within 10 days, compared with as much as 25 days for Formica and other competitors, according to a study made by the Boston Consulting Group for the Pioneer company five years ago. That allowed dealers to keep less inventory, a cost saving often shared with customers. The consultants' study was used in ''Competing Against Time.'' There is scant evidence that Formica is about to regain market share from Wilson, and Mr. Langone is dismayed to have to fight the battle on Wilson's terms. **********''We have to be able to match Wilson's speed,'' he conceded. ''I'm not sure the market really needs it since you can get most products from a dealer's stock right away, but we have to be able to say we can do it.'' Still worse, from Formica's perspective, its three attempts to raise domestic prices in the last five years have failed when Wilson and smaller competitors decided not to follow. **********Formica needs the cash to pay down heavy debts piled up when management and an investor group took the company private last summer in a deal that valued the company at $365 million. Formica needs $40 million annually just to meet interest payments; $50 million when including the interest liability that has been deferred for five years as part of the buyout financing, said David Schneider, Formica's chief financial officer. The company had a net loss of $5.1 million on sales of just more than $100 million in the first three months of 1990, a quarter in which it paid $12.6 million in interest. **********The buyout was the latest in an accelerating series of ownership changes at Formica, which is based in Wayne, N.J. Founded in 1913 by two Cincinnati men who invented the laminate to replace the brittle mineral mica as an insulator, Formica caught the attention of avant-garde designers in the 1930's. They used it to add modern touches to furnishings in ocean liners, Art Deco furniture and landmark buildings like the Library of Congress and Radio City Music Hall. But it took the building boom after World War II to make Formica an icon of middle-class culture and a high-flier on Wall Street. **********The 50's boom in laminates encouraged Formica's major plastic resin supplier, the American Cyanamid Company, to buy Formica in 1956. Once it became part of the multinational chemical and pharmaceuticals company, Formica's pulse gradually slowed, just as competition was heating up. **********''There's no question that Formica had its head in the sand for years,'' said Andy MacLachlan, president of Winde Distributors Inc., who has been a distributor of Formica products in Woburn, Mass., since 1950. **********''Cyanamid didn't invest as much capital as entrepreneurs would, and they began to rely on the strength of the brand name at a time when all the competitors were saying, 'That's the guy to get,' '' said Mr. Langone, who joined Cyanamid in 1967 and became Formica's marketing director in 1981. Mr. Langone stayed with the company as president and chief operating officer when Cyanamid sold Formica to managers and an investment group in a 1985 leveraged buyout valued at $200 million. Cyanamid executives will not comment on Formica's decline during the years Cyanamid owned it. **********Formica went public two years later, but by 1988 found itself fending off approaches from investment groups led by Malcolm Glazer and then Samuel Zell. That led to the board's decision to sell the company again, and eventually to last year's management buyout. **********''To say I haven't been distracted from time to time wouldn't be true,'' said Mr. Langone, who became chief executive in 1988. **********The distractions notwithstanding, Formica distributors say the company has made great strides in beefing up service and support. ''We have been able to get things much faster in the past six to eight months,'' said Mr. MacLachlan, who now thinks he is on a more competitive footing. **********In addition, Formica is pushing premium-priced products that look more solid, like its eight-year-old Colorcore line, and Surell, a new material that can be made to resemble stone and is intended to compete with Du Pont's highly successful Coriann line as a material in sinks and tubs. Coriann and its competitors cost 10 times as much as traditional laminates at wholesale. **********''Du Pont has 90 percent of the market in this country so we are shooting for second place here, but we think we have the distribution to beat Coriann overseas,'' said Mr. Langone, happy to talk about the possibility of knocking someone else off a mountain.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/28/busin.main_headline: It Looks Like a C.D., but Wait ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/28/busin.print_headline: WALL STREET; It Looks Like a C.D., but Wait ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/28/busin.body_text: **********WHAT'S in a name? Considerably less than is in a prospectus -- as one can discover by looking closely at the chameleon-like investment products being advertised across the country these days by Welco Securities, a tiny brokerage house in Bala Cynwyd, Pa. **********The products, which offer eye-grabbing yields, are called "demand certificates" and "fixed-rate certificates," terms that evoke the popular certificates of deposit, or C.D.'s, offered by banks. On first glance, the sales material from Welco reinforces that impression with its emphasis on high yields and references to "penalties for early redemption." But look again: These certificates are not being offered by a federally insured bank, but by a company called the Equipment Leasing Corporation of America, also of Bala Cynwyd. **********Ah, the more knowledgeable investor might say, these must be equipment-leasing certificates, which are typically secured by some specific piece of hardware purchased with the investors' money and then leased out to someone else at a profit. But these are not equipment-leasing certificates either, and they are not backed by any collateral. **********They are, in fact, nothing more than the unsecured i.o.u.'s of Equipment Leasing -- a company revealed by its prospectus to be facing a daunting array of financial problems and potential conflicts of interest. **********One might get a different impression of the company from the sales material from Welco, which says Equipment Leasing will use investors' money to buy equipment and lease it to "credit-worthy business firms nationwide." But in faint microscopic print at the bottom of that sales brochure, investors are advised to read the prospectus carefully before investing. And those who do may get a far less comforting picture of the company standing behind these "certificates." **********Equipment Leasing is the slim subsidiary of a feeble outfit called the Walnut Leasing Company, owned by William Shapiro, a lawyer and accountant who settled a few minor squabbles with state securities regulators in Pennsylvania in the late 70's and in New York in the mid-80's. Walnut's own equipment-leasing business started to sour in 1983, and for the past two years, auditors have been warning that Walnut's chronic losses and reliance on borrowed funds raise "substantial doubts regarding its ability to continue as a going concern," the Equipment Leasing prospectus reports. **********Walnut, too, has been selling unsecured notes to the public, calling them "thrift certificates." About $6 million of its $15.5 million in outstanding notes fall due in the current fiscal year and the company, as noted, is short of cash. So Walnut is selling a new $40 million issue of "senior thrift certificates," and may use some of the proceeds to pay off its earlier notes. Walnut warns investors, however, that if its losses continue, it may not be able to repay the notes when they mature. **********In 1986, Walnut set up Equipment Leasing and transferred some of its stronger leases to the new subsidiary. Then Equipment Leasing started borrowing money from the public, selling about $7 million worth of unsecured notes that went by the name of "money market thrift certificates." **********Kenneth S. Shapiro, an officer of both Welco and Equipment Leasing and the son of William Shapiro, refused to field any questions about the companies or the issues. "We have a policy that we don't give any interviews to any members of the press, and if you quote us, we will take action," he said. "It's all in the prospectus." **********What the prospectus shows about Equipment Leasing's business, among other things, is that about $2 million, or 25 percent, of the company's $7.8 million worth of lease contracts with customers are in arrears; $1.2 million of that is more than four months late. **********Equipment Leasing can't be blamed for all these credit problems, though, since it buys all its business services, including credit checks and collection work, from Walnut. Its transfer agent is Financial Data, another of William Shapiro's companies, and it has engaged Mr. Shapiro's law firm to collect delinquent accounts. The same firm rendered the legal opinion in the prospectus. And Welco Securities, the underwriter, is owned by Mr. Shapiro and run by son Kenneth. **********In other words, the whole shebang being held up to investors -- the parent company, the subsidiary, the law firm, the transfer agent, the underwriter -- boils down to Bill Shapiro and his son. **********And with the credit markets casting a cold eye on even the largest corporate borrowers these days, what interest rate should investors be paid for lending money, without collateral, to the Bill and Ken Show? The National Association of Securities Dealers requires Welco to get an independent opinion on that, so Welco hired Grigsby, Brandford & Powell of San Francisco to offer its view. **********That small brokerage firm agreed that the yields on the notes should be "at least" one percentage point above six-month Treasury bills for notes maturing within two years; two points above that six-month rate for notes maturing in two to five years, and three points higher for notes maturing after that. (Those rates are more than commercial banks offer, but considerably less than the yields on the "junk" bonds of some major corporations, which can be as much as 30 percentage points above Treasury rates.) **********In practice, of course, Equipment Leasing is offering rates higher than those minimums -- but not a lothigher, considering the risks. Recently, the effective yield on the two-year note was 11.5 percent, less than four percentage points higher than the yield on two-year notes being sold by the Treasury. **********Like Equipment Leasing, the Treasury's parent is deeply in debt and is constantly selling unsecured notes to pay the bills. But so far, no one has seriously suggested that Uncle Sam may not survive long enough as a "going concern" to repay his debts. The same, unfortunately, cannot be said for the parent of Equipment Leasing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/01/busin.main_headline: Philip Morris's Profit Jumps On Sale of Rothmans Stake
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/01/busin.print_headline: Philip Morris's Profit Jumps On Sale of Rothmans Stake
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/01/busin.body_text: **********The Philip Morris Companies, the world's largest consumer products company, said yesterday that its earnings more than doubled in the fourth quarter, partly because of a large gain from the sale of its stake in a British company. **********For the year, profits at the company - whose brands include Marlboro cigarettes, Jell-O gelatin, Cheez Whiz spread and Miller beer - were up by 26.1 percent. **********In 1989, for the first time, food dwarfed tobacco as the company's largest subsidiary. It accounted for more than 50 percent of Philip Morris's annual revenues, with tobacco at almost 40 percent and beer at nearly 8 percent. But tobacco, despite years of diversification, continues to account for 65 percent of the New York-based company's annual profit. And much of that comes from one brand, Marlboro. **********The large quarterly gain for the company was prompted by strong operating earnings and Philip Morris's sale of its 29 percent stake in the British tobacco and luxury-goods company, Rothmans International P.L.C., for $455 million. **********In the quarter, the company's net income totaled $863 million, or 93 cents a share, up from $342 million, or 37 cents a share, in the corresponding period of 1988. **********For the year, Philip Morris's net profit climbed to a record $2.94 billion, or $3.18 a share, from $2.33 billion, or $2.51 a share. Its annual revenues rose by 41 percent, to a record $44.76 billion from $31.74 billion. **********The company was aided substantially in the year by the results of Kraft Inc., the huge food company it acquired in December 1988 for $12.9 billion, as well as the November sale of the Rothmans stake. **********The Rothmans sale resulted in a net profit gain of $152 million in the quarter, or 16 cents a share, Philip Morris said. The company had been Rothmans's second-largest shareholder for eight years but had felt stymied by the European Community's rules that prevented it from a having managerial role and easily increasing its stake. **********Without the sale of the stake, Philip Morris's earnings advanced by 19.5 percent in 1989, to $2.79 billion, or $3.02 a share. **********Last year, Philip Morris combined Kraft with its previously acquired General Foods Corporation unit, giving the subsidiary revenues of $22.93 billion and pretax profits of $2.14 billion last year. Kraft's revenues totaled $9.88 billion in 1987. **********Industry analysts said the resulting production gains from efficiencies of scale improved performance despite slow growth in the food industry. Kraft General Foods' operating revenues, the unit's sales from the food business rather than from combining the two companies, rose by 1.9 percent, and operating income surged by 26.2 percent for the year. Dollar figures were unavailable. **********Tobacco and Beer Gains **********Philip Morris also posted strong double-digit profit gains in beer and tobacco, especially in its international operations. Only its financial-services and real estate subsidiary reported relatively weaker gains because the company stopped selling houses in its Mission Viejo development in Southern California, where the real estate market has softened. **********Philip Morris's stock closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at $37.875, up 87.5 cents a share. It was the fifth-most-active issue on the New York Stock Exchange, with 2.5 million shares being traded. **********The analysts said Philip Morris's earnings were in line with their expectations. They said they were especially impressed that the company could curb interest expense from the Kraft purchase. Interest costs, mainly from the Kraft deal, totaled $1.73 billion by the end of the year, up from $670 million a year earlier. **********''It was an extraordinary performance all around - again,'' said Lawrence Adelman, an analyst for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in New York. **********The analysts say Philip Morris makes much of its tobacco money through fat profit margins gained by manufacturing efficiencies and price increases for skillfully marketed brands. 11.6% Increase The company's American tobacco unit reported an 11.6 percent gain in revenues in 1989, to $9.49 billion, and a 16.8 percent gain in pretax profits, to $3.61 billion. It had a ''slight gain'' in unit sales for the United States market, which has been shrinking, to 219.5 billion cigarettes, and a gain in market share, to 41.9 percent, from 39.3 percent. It said Marlboro Lights, a low-tar version of the market leader, contributed to the gain. **********International tobacco, which has been a growth business for Philip Morris, reported a 3.6 percent rise in revenues in the year, to $8.38 billion, and a 30.1 percent gain in pretax net, to $1 billion. Unit sales rose by 7.7 percent, to 360.7 billion cigarettes. International profits rose sharply, partly because a British unit, which had $550 million in revenues, was spun off last year into a joint venture. Its sales are reported separately, but its profits are included in Philip Morris. **********The Miller Brewing Company, Philip Morris's beer unit, reported an 18.9 percent gain in pretax profits last year, to $226 million, on a 5.3 percent gain in revenues, to $3.43 billion. Miller's shipments were up by 3.7 percent, to 41.9 million barrels, despite sluggish growth in the industry. **********The financial-services and real estate business reported a 16.2 percent drop in revenues, to $527 million, and a 6.1 percent gain in pretax net, to $173 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/04/world.main_headline: Voices of the New Germany: Hope, Guilt, Fear, Joy and Deep Satisfaction . . . In the Words of the Prominent, Glimpses of a Nation's Complex Feelings
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/04/world.print_headline: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;   Voices of the New Germany: Hope, Guilt, Fear, Joy and Deep Satisfaction . . . In the Words of the Prominent, Glimpses of a Nation's Complex Feelings
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/04/world.body_text: **********The feelings of the Germans toward their reunification have always been complex and contradictory. **********On the official level, the two Germanys were diametrically opposed in attitude; West Germany enshrined the longing for unity in the Constitution while East Germany considered division permanent and immutable. **********On the personal level, attitudes among people ranged from open longing to open disdain. **********There were those, like Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, who had been compelled to flee the East and lived in the hope of reunification. There were also West Germans, often of an older generation, who harbored feelings of guilt about division, since it had singled out a portion of the nation for prosperity and freedom, and a minority for poverty and repression. **********In East Germany the yearning for unity was more universal because it figured as a taboo and because the nation was compelled to live with images of the West always on its television screens. **********But there were also Germans on both sides who found certain propriety in division. Those ranged from leftists who saw in union the potential for a revival of German nationalism and dangerous ambition to East German intellectuals who dreamed of transforming the Communist dictatorship into a benign, socialist ''third way,'' free of the commercialism of the West. **********But in the end, union came in a way neither the advocates nor the critics expected, and which neither side could avoid. Whether skeptical or jubilant, the majority of Germans were compelled to accept that unification was suddenly a fact. **********Reactions ranged widely, from open jubilation to deep skepticism. With the merger of the economies of the two Germanys on July 1, an anxiety set in in both Germanys over the realization that unity would cost considerably more than anyone had expected, in mass unemployment in the East and higher taxes in the West. **********But it has been clear to anyone in Germany over the last 11 months that that for all the grumbling, for all the public expressions of skepticism, there is also a deep satisfaction. **********Here are the reactions of nine Germans from varying generations and walks of life. They are not necessarily representative of the nation at large, but they illustrate at least the complexity of a nation's response to its unexpected fortune. **********Hans Modrow **********'It Comes at the Expense Of the Citizens' **********A Communist with a reputation as a reformer, he was named transitional Prime Minister of East Germany in November 1989 and led the country until elections in March 1990. 62 years old. **********I wish I could describe Oct. 3 as a historical day without any reservations. Doubtlessly the overcoming of the decades-long division of the German people is of great historic moment, and this not only for the Germans. This day is also of no small importance for the other people, particularly in Europe, as well as for East-West relations generally. **********A dangerous hotbed of confrontation, where the mightiest military alliances equipped with sophisticated weapons of mass destruction were facing each other, has been abolished once and for all. **********But if I said at the beginning that I am not without reservations, it is because this unification was done in such a way that it comes at the expense of the citizens of the former G.D.R. and, sooner or later, of the people in the Federal Republic of Germany too. **********The crises in industry and agriculture, soaring unemployment figures, growing social tension and increasing existential fears in East Germany are only a few consequences of the Kohl and de Maiziere Governments' crash course toward unity. A gradual merger of two equal states, for which concrete proposals were submitted during my term as the G.D.R.'s Prime Minister, could have helped to avoid many problems that came up, and still will come up. **********Gottfried Forck **********'A Lot of Work Remains to Be Done' **********Evangelical Protestant Bishop of Berlin-Brandenburg. 66 years old. **********A year ago in many towns of the G.D.R., we assembled for intercession services in churches. We prayed for more justice and freedom. But on Oct. 3, 1989, there was no telling whether our payers would help us toward these ends. Then, through nonviolent demonstrations, a bloodless revolution began as a result of which the Socialist Unity [Communist]  Party had to give up its claim to being the leading party. Christians could interpret this only as a gift of God. **********The cracking of the wall, the opening of the borders, free elections, negotiations for the unification of the two German states, the currency union and now the merger happened in such a rapid succession that we Germans hardly came to our senses. If we had given ourselves more time, many things could have been resolved in a better way. For example, many people in the G.D.R. became jobless as a result of the introduction of the market economy. Moreover, the past under socialist rule has not been dealt with sufficiently. **********Therefore a lot of work remains to be done. **********Ute Lemper **********'Unification Brings A Lot of Problems' **********A popular singer and actress from West Germany. 27 years old. **********There is not a lot to celebrate today because the unification brings a lot of problems with it. Aside from the economic problems the East will have to deal with, there are also very real psychological problems. Those people were educated in a different way for over 40 years. Now they feel guilty that they have themselves believed the wrong things and taught their children the wrong things. **********There is also great fear. The fear in the West is mostly about the cost of unification and higher taxes. But in the East they are concerned about not only their livelihood but also about being relegated to the status of a third-class country for the next 15 years. **********I have made a number of tours in East Germany this last year. I just returned from Weimar. It is devastating to see. Nothing has been done to maintain the beauty of the cities. The infrastructure has fallen aapart. **********The people are demonstrating again now, because they are losing their jobs and they are afraid of the future. **********But there are positive things, things we could learn from the East. Like their use of language. They try to tell the truth. They are not like our politicians, used to issuing empty phrases or outright lying. We have learned to look behind the words to turn them over and examine the meaning. But in the East they are more sincere, more honest and it is like a fresh wind. **********Hans Joachim Friedrichs **********'A United Germany Does Not Frighten Me' **********Television news anchor. 63 years old. It's primarily a gut feeling, but I am elated at the thought of no longer living in an artificially divided country. I went to boarding school in what became the Soviet zone soon after my departure and the G.D.R. a few years later - the other Germany, a sovereign state as the Communists would have it. I am older, and like many of my generation I have been unable to perceive the German Democratic Republic as anything but a piece of Germany, temporarily but thoroughly separated from the rest. The idea of a united Germany does not frighten me. I see no new superpower arising east of the Rhine - smallness in geopolitical terms had its rewards and its charm in the last 45 years. This, I think, is well remembered by the majority of my countrymen. By and large life has been good to them, much is at stake, they will not want to risk it. **********Petra Kelly **********'Fear That Germany Will Start to Bully' **********A founder of the environmental Green movement. 42 years old. **********I come from the town of Gunzburg in Bavaria, the hometown of Dr. Mengele, and watching the procedures leading up to the 3d of October has aroused fear. Fear that Germany will start to bully or subtly to intimidate its neighbors through economic power, political strength and even militarily, because even with reduced troops it is still a strong army with powerful weapons and even its nuclear options are being held open. **********I am also angry. Angry that the incredible speed with which this process has been taking place has overridden all the usual parliamentary procedures. We have been completely overwhelmed and forced to accept things without going through the usual and very necessary parliamentary steps. **********Also I fear that the citizens groups and the Greens in both East and West Germany have been incredibly weakened by this process. The economic power groups, business and the banks have had the say and they are determined to make a carbon copy there of what we have here. All our ecological, environmental and yes, social concerns are being overwhelmed and there will be no chance to correct the many mistakes we have made here. They will just be repeated in the East. **********Michael Friedman **********'Both German States Have a Responsibility' **********A lawyer specializing in international relations, a member of the Frankfurt Jewish Community and of the directorate of the Central Council of Jews in Germany, and a member of the Frankfurt city parliament. 34 years old. **********The feelings that I have as regards the unification of Germany are ambivalent, controversial and marked by my personal life. The outcries for freedom and democracy from the East, and also from the G.D.R., have moved me and have made me once again aware of the fact that these values rank among the highest benefits of modern civilization. The fact that the Germans in the G.D.R. have now reached these goals gives reason for joy and shows that, in the final analysis, freedom can never be suppressed. **********From the Jewish point of view, but not only from the Jewish, it must be reminded that both German states have a responsibility with regard to their common past - National Socialism and the Holocaust. In the last decades it was scandalous enough that the G.D.R., because it posed as an ''anti-fascist state,'' shrugged off its responsibility. **********The mental, personal and collective grappling with the Holocaust must not be considered obsolete or barred by the statute of limitations, because this conflict became tangible for 16 million Germans only in the 1990's. On the contrary, any kind of change in the G.D.R. as a free state must be related to the confession of the outrages of contemporary G.D.R. citizens. **********Helmut Schmidt **********'The Great Victory Of the Will for Freedom' **********Chancellor of West Germany from 1974 to 1982 from the Social Democratic Party. Today he is publisher and regular contributor with the liberal weekly Die Zeit. 72 years old. **********On the 9th of November 1989, when the Communists finally had to open the Brandenburg Gate between the two parts of Berlin and when the wall started to crumble, this was the great victory of the will for freedom. **********Only once in all my life did I have another experience which has affected me in the same deep-going way and which caused the same indescribable joy, namely the reunion with my wife upon coming home from World War II. **********The abolition of barbed wire and death strips between the two halves of my people was a cause for enormous joy and of deep gratitude for the vast majority of us Germans. The festivities on the 3d of October therefore are just an official footnote. But they remind the Germans, so I am convinced, to rest our hopes and our confidence on a persistent continuation of the hitherto policies of the Federal Republic of Germany. **********Manfred Stolpe **********'Original Enthusiasm Has Dimmed' **********Former president of the Consistory of the Protestant Church in Berlin-Brandenburg. He is now running on the Social Democratic ticket for Premier of the newly established state of Brandenburg. 54 years old. Rarely in history will the passing away of a sovereign state be greeted by so little mourning and such widespread satisfaction and even relief as in the case of the G.D.R. Only one year ago, the Communist gerontocracy at the helm was toppled by people who courageously claimed the simple truth that ''We are the people.'' Twelve months later, however, the original enthusiasm has dimmed considerably. A certain disenchantment about democratic procedures has seized people who by this year's end will have been called upon to vote four times. They were prepared for hardship but the actual balance sheet of four decades of economic mismanagement and social suppression proves to be even more disastrous than expected. Nevertheless, the tenacity with which people in East Germany pursue their course is impressive and deserves the sympathy and respect of all people who joined their rejoicing a year ago. What these people now really need is visible support and a measure of understanding which takes into account that the abolition of a political setting - as despicable as it may have been - leaves people in a psychological void. **********Carl H. Hahn **********'An Ultimate End To the Chapter' **********Chairman of the Management Board of Volkswagen. 64 years old. **********The unification of the two German states puts an ultimate end to the chapter of horrors of World War II and its consequences. It is to be hoped that this biggest European catastrophe of recent history was the last of its kind. We all are deeply moved these days. Without the political commitment of the United States, the abolition of the division of Germany and Europe would have been impossible - even a free Western Europe had never come into existence. Without the brave men of Solidarity in Poland, the moral force of the Polish church and the courage of Gorbachev, such a revolution could not have been brought about without bloodshed. **********The pace of changes demonstrates how much despair had accumulated in the people of Central and Eastern Europe after decades of Communist dictatorship. Probably, the people on this old continent will never forget Oct. 3, and those in Germany and Berlin will commemorate this day in a spirit of particular gratitude and humility.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/24/busin.main_headline: New Task for the Computer: Making Clothes
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/24/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;   New Task for the Computer: Making Clothes
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/24/busin.body_text: **********Engineers and computer scientists at two colleges here say they have harnessed computers to standard industrial sewing machines to produce a larger variety of garments more quickly and cheaply than conventional clothing factories do. **********The industry, which has long trailed others in integrating computers in its factories, is taking seriously the experiments by the group from Southern College of Technology and Georgia Institute of Technology. ''What those colleges are doing is not a pipe dream,'' said William O. Mitchell of the American Apparel Manufacturing Association, which represents clothing manufacturers. ''It is a way of getting things done a lot more quickly and getting improved quality.'' **********Plants Using the Technology **********Southern Tech and Georgia Tech engineers said that new computerized systems are in use at an Arrow Shirt plant at Buchanan, Ga., and at a number of children's clothing makers including the William Carter Company of Griffin, Ga., and Health-Tex in Gadsden, Ala. **********Such technology is also in use by a blue jeans maker, the Lee Apparel Company, and by the Russell Corporation of Alexander City, Ala., which makes, among other things, jerseys for several National Football League teams. **********A tiny, experimental clothing factory capable of making a few dozen pairs of pants a day has been set up on the campus of Southern College of Technology in Marietta, an Atlanta suburb, to demonstrate to clothing makers what might be done even in the small, rural plants that have been the main producers of clothing in the United States. The industry has depended heavily on simple sewing machines manned largely by unlettered operators. **********A Different Operation **********''In a normal manufacturing situation, you see big plants with lots of intensive technology operating three shifts a day, seven days a week,'' said T.
