Dale Stewart, research technician at Southern Tech, ''The apparel industry has never been that way. For the most part, these are small, rural factories and the work force is young housewives with kids who can't or won't work the second and third shift. So if you're the owner of that plant, you can't depend on having a lot of expensive equipment that you'll pay off by running high volume.'' **********Therefore, ''we needed to make sewing machines more versatile,'' Mr. Stewart said. ''And computers seemed to be part of the answer.'' **********The Georgia group determined that instead of buying a new machine or retooling existing equipment to do each new sewing job, specialized computer chips could be programmed so that a single machine could be used for several different jobs with only minor mechanical adjustments. **********While some industrial sewing machines already come equipped with computer chips, many of these machines are still used for only one task. The Georgia group has been developing ways to reprogram these chips so that the machines can perform a variety of sewing jobs. **********Assembly Line Improved **********By reprogramming the machines, the engineers have converted an old straight assembly line into a more versatile line with many subassembly stations. Each computerized piece of equipment can work at a number of tasks instead of one. **********For example, after finishing enough zippers to supply all the lines at the factory that need them, the machine can be reprogrammed to work on another task instead of sitting idle. By switching to another task, a machine can help finish other work that otherwise would take longer to perform and slow up the whole assembly line. **********In a conventional assembly line, ''substantial inventory is tied up with work in progress and the first garment can take days to emerge from the sequential process,'' said Wayne C. Tincher, professor of textile engineering at Georgia Tech. **********But with the more versatile computerized machines, the first garment might show up at the end of the assembly line in 40 minutes, Mr. Tincher said. **********Single System Envisioned **********In the future, the Georgia scientists said, a large assembly line making several kinds of garments could be directed by a single computer system. Each operator would see on a computer screen the pieces of fabric next to arrive and get instructions on how they are to be sewn. The computer would then direct the actual sewing operation. **********''That's downstream a little way, but it's definitely coming,'' said Mr. Mitchell, who is director of research and development for Oxford Industries, a clothing maker in Vidalia, Ga. **********Such new technology is likely to require operators more skilled than present workers. ''We're talking about somebody who, at a minimum, can read and take direction from a computer screen,'' said Mr. Stewart of Southern Tech. ''But if someone has a good basic education, they may not need as much training on each machine. We're able to use college students here who have had only four hours of training.'' **********Mr. Mitchell agreed. ''In the past, the most important thing has been the dexterity of the operator,'' he said. ''I think in the future, the dexterity of the mind will be as important as dexterity of the fingers.'' **********Cut in Jobs Expected **********Mr. Stewart said the new technology might cut the labor force in some plants by 20 percent but not by any more. **********''You can't get robots to do this work,'' Mr. Stewart said. ''Robots are very good at grasping and manipulating a solid object like a steel rod, but they can't do anything with something that's going to flop around like a piece of cloth.'' **********An official of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union said the union does not think that workers will be displaced. Indeed, the union has encouraged the adoption of the new technology, said Carl L. Proper, assistant to the president of the I.L.G.W.U. **********''We think that in the long run a more modern industry is going to provide better jobs and more jobs for the firms that use it,'' Mr. Proper said. ''We do try actively to encourage employers to use the best appropriate technology.'' **********Mr. Proper said he is familiar with the Southern Tech demonstration plant and thinks its technology is feasible. **********'Starting to Happen' **********''I think what the people at Southern Tech are talking about is starting to happen,'' he said. ''The clothing business was behind other industries in installing and having available to it computer technology. There is a significant trend in that direction now.'' **********Mr. Proper is also executive director of the Council for American Fashion, a labor-management group that deals with technology issues. He said future garment industry workers would have to be more educated. **********Mr. Mitchell said American clothing makers would be forced to adopt the new technology if they wanted to keep their plants in the United States. **********''I hate to put it this way,'' he said, ''but the only alternative to new technology is being forced offshore to the Caribbean or Central and South America.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/27/world.main_headline: Former Prime Minister Re-elected in Sweden
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/27/world.print_headline: Former Prime Minister Re-elected in Sweden
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/27/world.body_text: **********The Swedish Parliament confirmed Ingvar Carlsson as Prime Minister of a new Social Democratic Government today, 12 days after he resigned when his economic austerity policy was rejected. **********The vote - 175-101 with 59 abstentions - came after Mr. Carlsson revamped his proposals to rescue Sweden from an inflation that is approaching 9 percent. **********The vote ended the worst political crisis for the Social Democrats since they returned to power in 1982 after a six-year period in opposition. **********Mr. Carlsson's Cabinet resigned on Feb. 14 when Parliament rejected his economic program. He was asked to form a new Government last week after the centrist opposition parties failed to devise a common policy. **********The Social Democrats, who control 156 seats in the 349-member Parliament, won support from the Communist Party, which holds 21 seats, after Mr. Carlsson abandoned a proposal to impose a two-year freeze on wages and prices and to ban strikes. The new 17-point program would bring in foreign workers from the Soviet Baltic states to alleviate a labor shortage that is contributing to inflation, and increase taxes on alcohol and tobacco.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/24/world.main_headline: Evolution in Europe;   LITHUANIA ACTION BY BUSH EXPECTED
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/24/world.print_headline: Evolution in Europe;   LITHUANIA ACTION BY BUSH EXPECTED
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/24/world.body_text: **********After meeting with members of Congress on Tuesday, President Bush is expected to announce some limited American actions in response to the Soviet Union's economic crackdown in Lithuania, Administration officials said tonight. **********The officials declined to say specifically what Mr. Bush would do, but the options he has been considering include the suspension of one or more of the five sets of trade and commercial negotiations now under way with the Soviet Union. **********''We will be taking action, mostly in the economic domain, that will express U.S. displeasure and U.S. concern about Soviet behavior in Lithuania,'' an official said. **********Administration officials said the actions contemplated by the United States were not intended to interfere with arms control negotiations or with the schedule for the next Soviet-American summit meeting, which is scheduled to begin late in May. **********Allies Are Consulted **********The Administration had been delaying any retaliation for the Soviet Union's economic moves against the Lithuanians for as long as possible, hoping the Baltic crisis would resolve itself. **********But as the Kremlin's sanctions tightened late last week, the United States began a round of consultations with its allies to make certain it had backing for whatever steps it might take. **********The Administration also wanted to make sure it had the support of Congressional leaders before acting, the official said. **********Officials said there has been some reluctance in the Adminstration to take action against the Soviet Union over Lithuania out of concern that it might interfere with the progress made over the last year or so in Soviet-American relations and disrupt efforts to forge a new political order in Eastern Europe. **********But pressure has steadily built on Mr. Bush to respond in some way as Soviet actions in the Baltic republic have grown increasingly harsh. Mr. Bush discussed his options with President Francois Mitterrand of France last week at a meeting in Florida and with other Western leaders in telephone conversations and other diplomatic contacts over the weekend. **********Signs of 'Flexibility' **********Marlin Fitzwater, Mr. Bush's spokesman, said today that Mr. Bush would meet with Congressional leaders on Tuesday morning in the White House to discuss the Lithuanian situation. ''I would not expect any announcement on the courses of action from us before that point,'' Mr. Fitzwater said. **********Mr. Fitzwater declined to say what, if anything, the White House would do in response. ''The final decisions by the President have not been made,'' he said. Mr. Fitzwater said the United States saw encouraging signs of ''flexibility'' in the most recent Soviet statements on Lithuania. **********Two of the negotiations that could be affected by sanctions against the Soviet Union - on civil aviation and on trade - are scheduled to resume on Tuesday. Officials said American negotiators had been instructed to proceed with both sets of talks. **********Using the trade talks as leverage against the Soviet Union could be particularly effective since they are a precursor to the granting of favorable tariff arrangements to the Soviet Union and an important milestone in Moscow's efforts to improve ties with the West. **********Other Talks Under Way **********The United States and the Soviet Union are also engaged in talks on an investment treaty, on the extension of import-export credits to Moscow, on tax agreements and on other commerical arrangements that Mr. Bush proposed last December in Malta during his meeting with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. **********The two countries also recently completed negotiations on a new five-year grain agreement that was expected to be signed at the next meeting between Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev, which is scheduled to be held in Washington from May 30 to June 3. **********Agriculture Secretary Clayton K. Yeutter, asked about possible sanctions during a luncheon with agriculture writers, ruled out using the grain pact with Moscow as leverage in the Lithuanian crisis. **********''I don't believe there's any chance whatsoever of a grain embargo being used in that situation or in any other situation,'' Mr. Yeutter said. **********At his daily news briefing today, Mr. Fitzwater was asked about reports from Moscow that quoted a Kremlin spokesman, Arkady Maslennikov, as saying the Soviet Government would not insist on an outright repeal of Lithuanian's declaration of independence. Mr. Maslennikov suggested that the Lithuanians could ''freeze'' their proclamation of independence, perhaps for a period of two years. **********Mr. Fitzwater said: ''The statements this morning do appear to show some flexibility. We are hopeful that that's the case.'' **********He said the statements were ''being factored in'' as Mr. Bush contemplates his response to Moscow's latest moves in Lithuania.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/14/busin.body_text: **********President Bush took issue today with the main elements of Representative Dan Rostenkowski's plan for cutting the deficit, those that would raise taxes and lower Social Security benefits. **********But at a news conference where he announced a proposal to give aid to Nicaragua, the President was careful to set a tone indicating that he saw the Rostenkowski plan as the basis for negotiations with Congress. **********Democratic leaders in Congress applauded Mr. Rostenkowski's initiative. But, fearful of the political consequences, they said they could not endorse it until the President relaxed his firm opposition to new taxes. **********Too Early to Tell **********It is too early to tell whether Mr. Rostenkowski's proposal, which embraces sizable tax increases and spending cuts over the next five years, is an important step toward breaking the longstanding political deadlock over the budget or merely another round in the shadow boxing that has dominated the relationship between President Bush and the Democratic Congress. **********After saying at his news conference that he could not support a tax increase or a freeze in Social Security benefits, the President declared: ''I don't want to appear totally inflexible, but I'm not about to stand here and give him - give Dan or the Congress - the idea that I want to accept several of the things that are in his approach. But will I be willing to talk when they get all these proposals out there? Certainly. Are we prepared to negotiate? Absolutely.'' **********Source of Power **********Mr. Rostenkowski, an Illinois Democrat, heads the Ways and Means Committee, which must initiate all legislation involving taxes and Social Security. That makes him perhaps the most powerful committee chairman in Congress. **********But within his own party, he is something of a maverick with a history of working with Republican Presidents. The sweeping Tax Reform Act of 1986, the most important tax legislation in the last half-century, could not have been enacted had Mr. Rostenkowski not joined forces early on with Ronald Reagan. **********Before going public with his budget proposal, Mr. Rostenkowski discussed it in general terms with the White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu, and the President's budget director, Richard G. Darman, Mr. Darman said today. **********Last weekend, in an opinion article in The Washington Post and in a television interview, Mr. Rostenkowski described a comprehensive proposal that would reduce the budget deficit by $55 billion in the next fiscal year and lead to a surplus by 1995. **********About 60 percent of the package would involve spending reductions, including slightly larger annual cuts than the President wants at the Pentagon, a one-year abolition of Social Security cost-of-living increases and a one-year freeze in spending for most other Government programs. The rest of the package involves tax increases, including higher income tax rates for the wealthy and an increase in the gasoline tax. **********It was the first time in many years that an important politician had come forth with a budget plan that included the politically unpopular measures that many, if not most, economists believe are essential to bring the deficit under control. **********The plan and the President's response to it left Democratic leaders uneasy. They fear that if they push the proposal, Mr. Bush will block it or veto it and then attack Democrats in an election year for wanting to raise taxes and cut retirement benefits. Mr. Bush gave no hint in his news conference that he would not attempt such a political maneuver. **********The Speaker of the House, Representative Thomas S. Foley of Washington, said today that he found the President's response ''foggy'' and ''confusing.'' **********Mr. Foley has been saying for several years that a package like Mr. Rostenkowski's, with additional taxes and spending cuts, was the only way to achieve real budget reduction. But he said today, as he has many times before, that enactment of such a plan was ''politically and governmentally impossible without the prior approval of the President.'' **********Mr. Bush has an ''absolute veto,'' Mr. Foley added, and Democrats gain nothing by proceeding alone to try to raise taxes or reduce Social Security payments. **********Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the Democratic majority leader, picked up on the prospect of a Presidential veto that could not be overridden after the Democrats had stuck out their political necks. **********''The President has a pen that's worth two-thirds of us, and that's all you need to know,'' he told reporters. **********Despite these reactions, the first buds of support for Mr. Rostenkowski from backbenchers began to bloom today. Representative Thomas J. Downey of Suffolk County, a Democrat on Mr. Rostenkowski's Ways and Means Committee, and Representative Jim Slattery of Kansas, a Democrat on the Budget Committee, were among several lawmakers who spoke on the floor of the House today in favor of the initiative. **********Wake-Up Call **********''It's about time this Congress had a wake-up call,'' Mr. Downey said. **********A Republican member of the Ways and Means Committee, Representative Rod Chandler of Washington, urged Congress and the President to ''throw off the shackles of campaign rhetoric.'' **********And a senior member of the Ways and Means and Budget committees, Representative Bill Frenzel, a Republican from Minnesota, said in a speech in Minneapolis that he disagreed with aspects of the Rostenkowski proposal but added that ''today it's time to be thankful for leadership, even though it may be flawed.'' **********Most lawmakers kept their own counsel, and no one could measure yet the degree to which support in the cloakrooms might convert into votes on the floor. **********Mr. Darman at his own news conference declared, ''Ultimately, serious deficit reduction has to be done on a bipartisan basis.'' **********But the budget director refused to give any political ground, saying the Administration was not inclined toward flexibility on either tax increases or Social Security cutbacks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/07/busin.main_headline: Fed Voted in May Against Lower Rates
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/07/busin.print_headline: Fed Voted in May Against Lower Rates
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/07/busin.body_text: **********Federal Reserve policy makers concluded at their May meeting that inflation posed too great a danger to allow interest rates to decline, minutes of the meeting released today show. **********The eight-week-old records were made available amid signs that the policy makers had decided at their most recent gathering on Monday and Tuesday to stand ready to shift their policy and nudge interest rates lower if the economy weakened further. **********Unidentified Government officials outside the Fed were quoted in published reports today as saying they believed the directive adopted earlier this week allowed a relaxation of the tight credit policy if additional signs of economic sluggishness emerged. **********Analysts were split over whether the June employment report released today by the Labor Department provided such evidence. The unemployment rate slipped to 5.2 percent, from 5.3 percent, but non-farm job growth was a weaker-than-expected 40,000. **********In May, members of the Federal Open Market Committee voted by 10 to 1 to maintain the existing credit policy and directed central bank officials to be equally ready to raise or lower rates, depending on developments on inflation and economic growth. **********Members agreed that ''current information on business conditions pointed on balance to relatively moderate but sustained economic expansion.'' At the same time, the members ''generally agreed that the prospects for significant reductions in inflation pressures during the quarters immediately ahead were not promising.'' **********W. Lee Hoskins, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland and a prominent advocate of a tough anti-inflation policy, voted against the directive. He argued for a tighter credit policy ''to help assure that progress would be made toward a reduced rate of inflation.'' **********Mr. Hoskins said tighter credit would ''enhance the credibility and effectiveness of monetary policy in countering the persisting strength of inflationary pressures,'' according to the minutes. **********Other members, who were not identified, went along with the directive but said that ''the need to contain and ultimately to reduce inflation might well require a firming of policy at some point.'' **********The Federal Reserve has been fighting inflation with higher interest rates since early 1988. In mid-1989 it began nudging rates down amid concern that the economy might topple into a recession. However, since late December, the Fed has held steady. The Federal funds rate, the interest charged among banks for overnight loans, has hovered around 8.25 percent since then. **********The open market committee, which is made up of the seven Fed governors and five of the system's 12 regional bank presidents, meets in secret eight times a year to formulate monetary policy. Minutes are released about six to eight weeks later, a few days after the next meeting. There was one vacancy among the governors at the time of the May meeting.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/09/busin.body_text: **********Ten years late and either several billion over budget or $382 million under, depending on how it's counted, the Philadelphia Electric Company's Limerick 2 plant began commercial operation yesterday, the company said. **********With Limerick 2 in operation, the company said it was not using any oil-fired generating plants except for backup. At 1,100 megawatts, Limerick makes enough electricity to meet the needs of about 1.3 million average homes, the company said. **********Limerick 2, near Pottstown, 30 miles west of Philadelphia, was designed by the General Electric Company and makes electricity by boiling water directly in the nuclear core. It is the 40th and last of its type. **********Only three other reactors are under active construction. Limerick 2 is the 109th reactor in commercial operation. **********In 1982 with 30 percent of the work completed, construction of Limerick 2 was stopped because of rapidly rising costs. It resumed in 1986. **********The final cost was $2.9 billion, well below the $3.2 billion limit set by the Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission when it allowed work to restart in 1985. But when construction began in 1974, Limerick 1 and Limerick 2 were supposed to cost $1.4 billion combined, with completion by 1980. **********The reactor completed a ''warranty run'' of 100 hours at 100 percent power on Saturday and was declared commercial yesterday. Philadelphia Electric is seeking an 18.1 percent rate increase, spread over five to 10 years, to pay for the plant.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/04/world.main_headline: Civilian-Troop Clashes Kill 8 in a Soviet City
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/04/world.print_headline: Civilian-Troop Clashes Kill 8 in a Soviet City
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/04/world.body_text: **********Five soldiers and three civilians died in the southern Soviet republic of Uzbekistan over the weekend during several hours of violence touched off by a clash between youths and troops returning from leave, the official press agency Tass said today. **********The agency also reported that in the troubled border region between the republics of Azerbaijan and Armenia, four Azerbaijani policemen were killed, three wounded and two reported missing on Sunday. Tass said the policemen had been attacked by Armenian fighters, three of whom were killed and two wounded. **********Tass said Interior Ministry troops had been sent today to the scene of the violence, the village of Martunashen in Azerbaijan's Khanlar district northwest of the disputed Nagorno-Karabakh region. **********In Uzbekistan, the Mayor of Namagan, Erkin Mamakulov, said six soldiers, whom he described as drunken, had been harassing young women passengers on a city bus on Sunday night and demanding that the bus change its route. **********A crowd surrounded the bus and began to beat the soldiers, four of whom died, Tass said. More soldiers were sent to the scene, the crowd grew, and a fifth soldier was killed, along with three civilians, the agency said. Twenty-nine soldiers and 22 policemen were injured, some seriously, it said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/23/busin.main_headline: Philip Morris Will Buy Suchard's Europe Units
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/23/busin.print_headline: Philip Morris Will Buy Suchard's Europe Units
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/23/busin.body_text: **********Philip Morris Companies Inc., the world's largest consumer-products company, announced plans yesterday to become the world's second-largest coffee manufacturer and marketer by buying most of a Swiss coffee-and-candy giant for $3.8 billion. **********Philip Morris agreed to buy the European operations of Jacobs Suchard A.G. of Zurich, which makes the expensive triangular chocolate stick called Toblerone and is a leading coffee seller in France and West Germany. Suchard had revenues of $4.7 billion last year. **********Philip Morris, based in New York, already owns Maxwell House, the second-best-selling coffee in the United States after Procter & Gamble Company's Folgers. **********Revenue of About $4.3 Billion **********Combined with Suchard, it would have coffee revenue of about $4.3 billion. Nestle S.A., based in Vevey, Switzerland, sells the most coffee in the world, with about $5 billion in revenues from various brands in 1989. **********The 60 percent share of Suchard about to trade hands is owned by Klaus J. Jacobs, who thought of himself as a David taking on the Goliaths of the food business, Mars and Nestle. By agreeing to sell his stake and thereby dismantling his conglomerate, Mr. Jacobs appears to be abandoning the challenge. **********Philip Morris said it planned to make a tender offer later for the remaining Jacobs Suchard shares, which are publicly owned. Philip Morris stock closed at $46 yesterday, up $1.625, and was the third-most-active issue on the New York Stock Exchange. **********Analysts hailed the move by Philip Morris, long a Wall Street favorite for its strong stock performance and profitable acquisitions. **********''Investors love the deal because it isn't a mega-acqusition that dilutes Philip Morris's shares and puts it deep into debt,'' said Rebecca B. Barfield, an analyst with First Boston. For a conglomerate of Philip Morris proportions, a relatively modest acquisition is anything costing less than $5 billion. **********Ms. Barfield estimated that the dilution of shares, the reduction in value for current shareholders, would be perhaps two cents a share or less this year. Philip Morris had earnings last year of $3.18 a share. **********Lawrence Adelman, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds, said Philip Morris was acquiring the Suchard businesses for a ''very attractive price.'' He noted that Philip Morris was spending less than a dollar for each dollar of Suchard revenue. Interim financing will come from Philip Morris credit lines and Swiss banks, Philip Morris said. Financial advisers to Philip Morris on the transaction were Rothschild & Cie., France, and Rothschild Bank A.G., Switzerland. **********'Baby, Watch Out' **********Mr. Adelman was especially excited by Philip Morris's prospects in the freer European markets anticipated at the end of 1992. Food companies are less profitable in Europe because factories are smaller and distribution less efficient because of trade barriers. **********''Once you can run a truck from France to Italy,'' Mr. Adelman said, ''baby, watch out. You're going to see some very favorable improvements in profit margins.'' **********The Suchard deal would move Philip Morris's business further out of cigarettes, still its main source of profits led by Marlboro, the best-selling cigarette in the world. It would also add $3.9 billion in revenue to the $44.8 billion Philip Morris posted in 1989. **********The deal also fits Philip Morris's strategy of trying to build global products by using brands, technology and marketing across foreign borders. So far, the company's major world brand is Marlboro, and to a lesser extent, Philadelphia cream cheese, which is sold in 40 countries, and Tang powdered soft drink, which is sold in 70 countries. **********Michael A. Miles, Philip Morris's vice chairman, was good humored and clearly exultant about the transaction. ''Oh, this deal makes us twice as big a company in Europe as we used to be,'' said Mr. Miles, who is also head of the huge Kraft General Foods subsidiary based in Chicago. ''Other than that, we didn't do so hot.'' In 1989, Kraft General Foods had European revenue of about $3 billion. **********Some Not Included **********But the deal does not include several large businesses, like E.J. Brach Inc., the leading maker in the United States of sugar confectioneries, such as jelly beans. Mr. Jacobs will retain these businesses, which have revenue of about $800 million. **********The parent company's troubled reorganization of Brach helped lead to a 10 percent decline last year in operating profit to 275 million Swiss francs, or about $190 million at current exchange rates. In the 1989 Jacobs Suchard annual report, Mr. Jacobs bluntly called the effort, with its frequent change in Brach management, a $50 million ''failure.'' **********According to S.G. Warburg & Company, an investment house, Jacobs Suchard's 1989 revenue was sliced into about $1.9 billion in coffee sales; $1.9 billion in chocolate; $521.3 million in a cocoa trading company, and $388.7 million in sugar confectioneries, mainly the Brach candy business in the United States. **********Suchard's major coffee brands are decaffeinated coffee. Candy brand names include Tobler, Toblerone, Brach, Sugus and Nabob. **********In France, for example, Philip Morris will be able to add its 2 percent coffee-market share to Suchard's 38 percent. In Germany, Philip Morris adds 6 percent, from its HAG brand, to Suchard's 21 percent. **********The deal's terms call for Philip Morris to acquire Colima Holding A.G., whose principal asset is Mr. Jacobs's shares, and then make a tender offer, whose conditions will be announced before July 10. Jacobs Suchard's board has recommended the transaction to shareholders. **********AT A GLANCE: Philip Morris **********All dollar amounts in thousands, except per share data           Three months ended       March 31   1990   1989        Revenues   $11,388   $10,610        Net Income   775   590        Earnings per share   $0.84   $0.64                Year ended        Dec. 31   1989   1988        Revenues   $44,759   $31,742        Net income   2,946   2,337        Earnings per share   $3.18   $2.51                          Total assets, Dec. 31, 1989   $38,528        Current assets    9,380        Current liabilities   8,943        Long-term debt   13,646          Stock price, June 22, 1990        N.Y.S.E. consolidated close   44 3/4        Stock price, 52-week range   33 5/8-45 1/2        Employees,Dec. 31, 1989   157,000        Headquarters   New York

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/12/world.main_headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Attempts Have Been Made to Break Trade Embargo Against Iraq, U.S. Officials Say
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/12/world.print_headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Attempts Have Been Made to Break Trade Embargo Against Iraq, U.S. Officials Say
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/12/world.body_text: **********Disclosure Seen as Deterrent **********None of the oil deliveries or the payments appear to violate the United Nations sanctions, which apply only to oil sales or other trade with Iraq conducted after Aug. 6. **********The Bush Administration is citing the oil shipments and efforts to break the trade ban to United Nations diplomats in an effort to underscore American resolve and to deter potential violators by making it clear that illegal trade with Iraq will be detected and revealed. **********United States intelligence agencies have uncovered efforts by private concerns in two dozen nations to smuggle goods to Iraq and have immediately notified the host governments and urged them to take legal action, Administration officials said today. **********One Government official said several of those concerns were ''professional sanctions-busters,'' experienced in breaking embargoes against such nations as Rhodesia, that are now seeking to sell their services to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. **********That official said the companies were based in such locations as Brazil, Eastern Europe, Switzerland, Austria and Britain. They are described as ''fronts'' with no real corporate structure, none of them well known internationally. **********None of those Governments were aware of the concerns' secret overtures to Iraq, the official said. He said Eastern European smugglers were proving a particular problem because the region's new democratic governments were ill-equipped to track or thwart illegal deals. **********Some Deals Are Reported **********The Associated Press, citing a State Department document, reported today that Cuba and Romania had struck oil deals with Iraq and that two unnamed companies in Western Europe had secretly offered to smuggle food into Iraq. The report also said unidentified companies in Eastern Europe, East Asia and Africa had offered to smuggle weapons and other goods as well. **********Romania's Ambassador to the United States, Virgil Constantinescu, today denied the A.P. report and issued a list of his nation's oil purchases since Aug. 5, all from nations other than Iraq. **********Mr. Constantinescu said in a written statement that Iraq had offered to give Romania about one million metric tons of oil to settle past debts but that the offer had been rejected. He also said Romania had canceled two contracts with an American oil company, Chevron Corporation, for 150,000 metric tons of Iraqi oil. **********An Administration official, speaking on condition that he not be named, said that Iraq had discussed oil sales to Romania but that it was uncertain which nation had raised the prospect of a sale. **********Romania, like many Eastern European nations, had conducted a busy trade with Iraq and is suffering economically from the trade embargo. **********Officials said the Cuban oil shipment had been unloaded from the Iraqi-flag oil tanker Amuriyah, which docked in Cuba in the last week of August. Shipping officials said the Amuriyah left the Turkish city of Ceyhan on July 31, two days before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, after taking on a cargo of crude oil at an Iraqi pipeline that terminates on the Mediterranean Sea near Turkey's border with Syria. **********Cuba has been hit by oil shortages stemming from a slowdown in deliveries by its major supplier, the Soviet Union, and President Fidel Castro recently imposed drastic energy conservation measures throughout the island.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/13/world.main_headline: China Waits Anxiously for Ruling On Its Trade Status With the U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/13/world.print_headline: China Waits Anxiously for Ruling On Its Trade Status With the U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/13/world.body_text: **********A highly charged issue is looming in relations between the United States and China, and it has Chinese officials and intellectuals concerned over their future, their standard of living and their contacts with the West. **********The issue is most-favored-nation trading status, and the concern is over whether the United States will renew favorable treatment on tariffs to China. By June 3, President Bush will make a recommendation to Congress for a vote, and Chinese officials and business executives are worried that Mr. Bush might not recommend renewal or that Congress would block it. **********As a clear gesture of conciliation toward the United States, China announced Thursday that it had released 211 political prisoners, and had earlier lifted martial law in Lhasa, the capital of Tibet, but diplomats reacted cautiously. They said it was not clear whether one or two actions would be enough to ease American indignation at political repression in China. **********Benefits of Trade Status **********China, which exported about $12 billion worth of goods to the United States last year, has benefited enormously in the last decade from most-favored-nation status, which gives Chinese exports the same relatively low tariffs of 10 percent to 25 percent that the United States imposes on goods from most other countries. If the status were revoked, China would have to pay up to 90 percent duty on some items, mostly apparel, toys and electronics. **********''If most favored nation is not renewed in June, and if Congress approves, then it could hurt both countries,'' Wei Mingyi, president of China International Trust and Investment Corporation, said in a recent interview. ''Trade between the two countries could be set back by 20 to 30 years.'' **********The issue comes a year and a half after China began an austerity plan that has left the economy virtually stagnant, with zero industrial growth in the first quarter this year compared to the same period last year. Inflation is down and growth rose slightly in April, but some Chinese and Western economists say it will be a tough task to stimulate the economy significantly again without bringing back inflation, which reached double digits in 1989. **********Threat to China's Exports **********From China's point of view, the threat to its exports could not come at a worse time. Revocation of most-favored-nation status could cut China's exports to the United States by about 50 percent in the first year, and more in the following years. This would mean a decline in China's exports of about $6 billion in the first year alone, amounting to about 11 percent of its total exports last year of $52.5 billion. **********Trade between China and the United States has soared in recent years, and last year it rose by 43 percent over 1988 to $17.8 billion. But trade frictions between the two countries could rise regardless of whether most-favored-nation status is revoked, because of China's mounting trade surplus with the United States. In the first two months of this year, its trade surplus with the United States was $1.3 billion, or 79.2 percent higher than the surplus for the same period last year, according to statistics from the United States Department of Commerce. **********At that rate, American economists estimate, China's trade surplus with the United States could reach $11 billion this year, possibly making it the country with the second highest trade surplus with the United States, after Japan. **********A small minority of Chinese intellectuals interviewed say they are so disillusioned with the Government that they support revocation of most-favored-nation status, but the great majority appear to favor continuation of the trade benefits. **********'Torn Over the Issue' **********''We feel torn over the issue,'' a Chinese researcher said. ''On the one hand, we want the United States to punish the Chinese Government for what it did. But on the other hand, we know that such a punishment would affect our own personal lives, and frankly, we don't like the thought of having to endure the suffering.'' **********Most intellectuals say the Chinese Government would retaliate, probably at first by raising tariffs or restricting American imports, such as wheat and technology and equipment. But their anxieties go far beyond the impact on trade between the two countries. They say the Chinese Government would close its doors at least slightly to the world, restricting travel to America, cutting cultural exchanges and access to a wide range of Western things from books to fashions to ideas. **********It is uncertain how the revocation of most-favored-nation status would affect Chinese politics. On the one hand, it would hurt the economy and perhaps increase the pressure within the leadership for the removal of Prime Minister Li Peng, who is in charge of the economy. **********On the other hand, many Chinese say that the most likely outcome is that the hard-liners would seize the occasion to begin a campaign for self-reliance instead of openness, and encourage a new wave of anti-Americanism. **********''It will deal a blow to the reformers,'' said a Chinese businessman. ''It will foster an anti-Western attitude.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/18/world.main_headline: Socialist Victory Seen In 2d Bulgarian Round
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/18/world.print_headline: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;   Socialist Victory Seen In 2d Bulgarian Round
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/18/world.body_text: **********Bulgarians went to the polls today in runoff elections that pitted the former Communist Party against opposition groups for control of Parliament. **********The former Communists, who now call themselves Socialists, won the first round of voting on June 10. They were expected to clinch their victory today with support from voters favoring a slower pace to democratic change. **********State television reported some voting irregularities, including illegal canvassing near polling stations. But the voting appeared to go smoothly. **********The 400-seat Parliament, the first freely elected legislature in Bulgaria in 58 years, will have a substantial number of opposition lawmakers, marking the end of rubber-stamp approval. **********The Socialists got 172 seats in the first round. They need 29 of the 81 seats being decided in the runoffs to gain a majority. The main opposition alliance, the Union of Democratic Forces, won 107 seats in the first round and other opposition groups got 40.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/22/busin.body_text: **********The United States economy will skirt a recession through 1991 and set a postwar record for the longest period of business growth, the nation's top business economists predicted today. **********The National Association of Business Economists said 82 percent of the 68 professional forecasters surveyed in April and May said the business expansion would continue slowly through next year. **********If so, the current expansion would top the record of 106 months of economic growth from February 1961 to December 1969. The present expansion began 90 months ago, in November 1982. **********The forecast was considerably more optimistic than a similar survey last May, when 63 percent of the economists predicted a recession this year. Ninety-six percent of those questioned for the current survey said the economy would continue growing through this year. **********The forecasters said the economy, as measured by the gross national product, would grow 2 percent this year and 2.4 percent in 1991. The G.N.P., the total output of goods and services, rose 3 percent last year. **********They also said inflation, which was 8.1 percent in the first quarter, reflecting in part weather-related rises in food and energy prices, would drop to an annual rate of 3.7 percent in the last nine months of the year. That would make the 1990 inflation rate 4.7 percent, down from 4.8 percent in 1989.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/29/world.main_headline: 2 Ex-Military Chiefs Urge Bush to Delay Gulf War
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/29/world.print_headline: MIDEAST TENSIONS; 2 Ex-Military Chiefs Urge Bush to Delay Gulf War
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/29/world.body_text: **********Two former Chairmen of the Joint Chiefs of Staff urged the Bush Administration today to postpone military action against Iraq and to give economic sanctions a year or more to work. **********"If in fact the sanctions will work in 12 to 18 months instead of six months, the trade-off of avoiding war with its attendant sacrifices and uncertainties would, in my view, be worth it," said Adm. William J. Crowe, who appeared with Gen. David Jones. **********"It's curious," Admiral Crowe continued, "that some expect our military to train soldiers to stand up to hostile fire but doubt its ability to train them to occupy ground and wait patiently." **********The testimony by the two retired officers before the Senate Armed Services Committee was significant because it reflects a strong current of opinion within the active military and because the two men remain influential with Congress. The hearings took place as the United Nations Security Council prepared to meet Thursday to vote on a resolution authorizing the use of force if Iraq does not pull out of Kuwait. **********In recent weeks, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, commander of American forces in the Persian Gulf, and Gen. Alfred Gray, the Marine Corps Commandant, have urged that the United States avoid a rush toward war and give economic sanctions more time to work.  Kissinger Opposes Delay **********The remarks by Admiral Crowe and General Jones were warmly received by the committee's Democratic members, who have called for restraint by the Administration. **********But in his appearance before the panel, former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger argued that the United States could not afford to wait a year for the sanctions to work because the prolonged presence of American forces in Saudi Arabia would destabilize the country and other moderate Arab states. **********"The issue in Arabia is not American staying power but the host country's domestic stability," Mr. Kissinger said. **********"Conditions in the gulf are not even remotely comparable to Europe or Northeast Asia," Mr. Kissinger said. "There, American forces contributed to domestic stability. In Saudi Arabia they would threaten it." **********The sharply conflicting assessments were a microcosm of the escalating debate over American policy in the Persian Gulf. **********The Bush Administration's decision earlier this month to almost double the number of American troops in the Persian Gulf and to seek a United Nations Security Council resolution authorizing the use of force in an offensive against Iraq shattered the bipartisan Congressional support for the Administration's gulf policy that developed in August when President Bush announced that he was sending American troops to Saudi Arabia for defensive purposes. **********The two former military chiefs, whose testimony came before Mr. Kissinger's, echoed the assessment of former Defense Secretary James Schlesinger, who testified on Tuesday, that the economic sanctions would be effective in persuading Iraqi troops to leave Kuwait if only the United States would give them time to work. Anti-U.S. Sentiment **********In his testimony, Admiral Crowe, the top military chief in the in the later part of the Reagan Administration and the first year of the Bush Administration, also argued that an American strike against Iraq would inflame anti-American sentiment in the Arab world. **********General Jones, the top military official during the Carter Administration and the early part of the Reagan Administration, said he also believed the embargo would work and expressed concern that the American military buildup would create pressure for premature action. **********"As we build to 400,000 troops, however, the support, morale, training, cultural and readiness problems rise sharply the longer the troops remain in forward garrisons," General Jones said. "My main concern with this latest scheduled reinforcement isn't that we might choose to fight, but rather that the deployment might cause us to fight -- perhaps prematurely and perhaps unnecessarily." **********Mr. Kissinger agreed that the growth in the size of the American force in Saudi Arabia would make it more difficult to extend their stay there. Mr. Kissinger argued that that merely strengthened the case for taking military action against Iraq early next year. Muslim Month of Fasting **********If the economic sanctions have not forced Iraq to withdraw its troops from Kuwait by the spring, a situation that Mr. Kissinger suggested was very likely, the United States would face a decision of going to war against Iraq or risking contributing to the destabilization of Saudi Arabia. **********"I do not believe we can maintain 400,000 troops much beyond the spring of next year," he said.  "I am nervous about the period that begins with Ramadan." **********"By the time it is evident that sanctions alone cannot succeed, a credible military option will probably no longer exist," said Mr. Kissinger, who remains an influential figure among White House officials. **********General Jones sought to balance his call for patience by sending a clear warning to President Hussein. **********"The country is unified in seeking that he does not succeed," the retired general said. "How badly he is hurt is his choice. If we take military action, we're not going to stop in Kuwait.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/12/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;   Will Panama's Woes Frustrate Democracy?
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/12/busin.body_text: **********On Central Avenue in downtown Panama City, clothing stores are slowly reopening, selling jeans for $3, cotton shirts for less than $2 and plastic shoes for 99 cents. Shoppers browse under the protection of private security guards carrying shotguns, machine guns and revolvers. **********The scene is a graphic reminder of the economic and political problems plaguing this country, which until recent years was growing faster than the other nations in Central America. **********The economy has been battered by two years of sanctions from the United States, domestic restrictions on bank accounts to prevent runs and governmental corruption. The ousted Government of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega has been accused of stealing hundreds of millions of dollars. Now rashes of looting, street violence and other crimes have left many stores without even their shelves. **********Political leaders of the main parties acknowledge that survival of the fragile new democracy after 22 years under military rule depends on how the economy fares in the coming months. **********A Service Economy **********What makes the process particularly tricky is that unlike other nations in Latin America, Panama's economy is largely based not on goods, but on services. Its financial center, free-trade zone and commerce from re-exporting merchandise represents the largest component of the economy in the country of 2.4 million people. **********''There isn't a business that hasn't been touched,'' said Sam Kardonski, whose family owns the Tower International Bank, the Western Insurance Company and also runs the Sanyo Electric Corporation's Latin American operations. ''But even though the economy is down, there is a ray of hope. The tension that had been building up over the past years is broken.'' **********For its part, the coalition Government is embarking on a mix of policies that is partly Thatcherite privatization and partly Keynesian spending for public projects. At the same time, officials say they intend to ease price controls and ease trade barriers. **********''We have a very difficult cash flow situation,'' Finance Minister Mario Galindo said in a recent inteview. ''It is very difficult politically for us. The next few months will be critical.'' **********Taxes: 'Anybody's Guess' **********Asked for a projection about how much the Government can expect to receive from 1989 taxes, Mr. Galindo shrugged his shoulders and said, ''It's anybody's guess.'' **********He said the cash problems had forced the Government to decide to sell the state's main businesses, which include sugar and banana companies, a cement factory and Panamanian Airways. The utilities will remain in state hands. **********One critical decision that must be made soon involves what to do with new foreign aid and existing revenues. The choice is a relatively simple one: create public projects to stimulate growth and promote employment, or alleviate the crushing $3.8 billion foreign debt and thus make the country credit-worthy again. Interest payments on the debt were suspended two years ago. **********American dollars are used by most Panamanians as standard currency. The official currency, the balboa, is fixed to a gold standard and the Government is unable to print new money. This means that Panama has no inflation problem, but it also means that the only ways of adding to the public coffers are by taxing or borrowing. **********Chaotic Transition **********But credit has been hard to come by. And taxes, originally due on Dec. 31, could not be collected because of the chaotic political transition that followed the American invasion earlier that month. Taxes are now due on Thursday. **********In the meantime, the Government payroll is being met with Panamanian money that had been frozen by the United States Government. **********''The situation is very touchy,'' said Ruben Carles, the Comptroller General and a former economics professor who has provided a steady diet of disclosures to local reporters about what he says is the corruption under the military. ''We cannot satisfy foreign creditors first, leaving aside work on hospitals and other socially responsible construction.'' **********To the regret of American officials here, Panamanian leaders have said they are considering spending at least $200 million for building projects, a move aimed at reviving the moribund construction industry. A senior American official said the United States has been pressing for more spending to reduce foreign debt, which represents almost a third of the Government's total debt of $5.98 billion. With a gross domestic product of $1.76 billion, Panama has one of the world's highest ratios of debt to gross domestic product. **********U.S. Aid Package **********The Bush Administration has said it will provide a $1 billion assistance package, consisting of grants and loans to promote economic development and incentives for American investment and trade with Panama. Congress recently approved the first portion of the package, $42 million in emergency aid. **********The entire package, about half of what Panama requested, also includes financing for an emergency public works program, new housing to replace that damaged by American troops, money to help Panama reduce its foreign debt and a decree lifting restrictions against American imports of Panamanian sugar. **********''We are like a very sick man who needs his medicine desperately,'' Mr. Kardonski said. **********A bloated Government payroll employs more than 150,000 people, padded by thousands of jobs created by the Noriega administration that were of no value to the country. **********Still, officials say that a serious increase in unemployment, now more than 16 percent, will lead to political insurrection. **********Fear of Unemployment **********''We have to cut public spending, but we don't want to lay off 30,000 workers,'' Mr. Galindo said. Before the crisis, the unemployment rate was just under 12 percent. **********Local banks have been facing a liquidity crisis that has been caused by severe restrictions on withdrawals imposed two years ago. **********Banking officials say that under the regulations, $1.5 billion, or almost 20 percent, of the assets in bank accounts has been frozen under restrictions that limit the size of withdrawals from time deposits and savings accounts. The restrictions are scheduled to end by June 30, but may end by April if officials can persuade depositors not to take out their money immediately and cause banks to collapse. **********Only a dozen banks have closed since the sanctions, leaving the number at 110. **********The banking commission is considering setting up a contingency fund and a special discount rate for short-term borrowing in cash-tight situations, but no decisions are expected before the end of this week. Bankers report that while foreign deposits have begun to trickle back in, the refusal by most Latin American nations to recognize the new Government has made lending hard. **********Establishing a Police Force **********American troops have also been helping Panamanians establish a local police force, although many business executives are skeptical. **********Looting has left them picking up the losses, since insurance policies have clauses that limit liabilities for acts of war. Without a fully trained local police force, street crime still persists - jails were opened during the invasion and many common criminals remain at large. There is also widespread fear that when the invasion force of American troops leaves the country by the end of February, violence will flare again. **********The violence severely damaged businesses in Colon, a city on the Atlantic Ocean side of the Panama Canal that is 50 miles from Panama City and is the heart of the largest free-trade zone in Latin America, re-exporting $4 billion in goods each year. The bulk of these goods are from businesses in the United States, Korea and Japan. **********But despite all the hardship, some business leaders are upbeat about the future. **********Mr. Galindo, the Finance Minister, said just about the best news he heard recently came from the National Brewery, makers of the beer sold under the label Cerveza Panama. **********Reflecting on a conversation with one beer executive who told him that rising consumption of its product means that the company will be paying a record amount in taxes, Mr. Galindo said, ''I suppose the recent events have encouraged beer drinking.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/28/busin.main_headline: Demand in U.S. Lifts Machine Tool Orders
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/28/busin.print_headline: Demand in U.S. Lifts Machine Tool Orders
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/28/busin.body_text: **********Orders for American-made machine tools increased 8.9 percent in April from March, rising to their highest level since September, according to a trade association. **********Analysts said that the results reflected slight increases in capital spending by domestic manufacturers, especially aircraft companies. **********Machine-tool orders climbed to $289.4 million in April, the Association for Manufacturing Technology said in its monthly report, scheduled for release today. That followed a 36.6 percent increase in March, when new orders soared to $265.8 million. **********New orders from domestic manufacturers climbed 39.8 percent in April from the March level. But orders from foreign customers plunged by more than two-thirds. **********Officials of the machine-tool companies attributed the rise in domestic orders to more robust demand from aircraft makers and slightly increased demand from auto makers. **********Compared with the levels of April 1989, new orders were up 19.3 percent. **********Despite the overall increase in machine-tool orders, some economists said the figures reflected the economy's sluggishness, as well as a reluctance by manufacturers to spend more heavily to upgrade plants and equipment. **********''The economy has not been generating much profit for companies,'' said Neal M. Soss, the chief economist at the First Boston Corporation. ''And that is not the environment in which you expect buoyant capital spending to occur.'' **********The strength of tool orders generally reflects the strength of industrial production. Economists consider patterns in machine tool sales to be important indicators of capital spending by manufacturers. **********Machine tools are power-driven devices that cut or shape metal parts used in products like appliances, vehicles, aircraft and construction materials. **********Optimism About Detroit **********In recent months, auto makers sharply curtailed their machine-tool orders because of slumping sales. The auto industry accounts for about a third of domestic machine-tool sales. **********But Richard Priebe, a spokesman for the Cross & Trecker Corporation, a Bloomfield Hills, Mich., machine-tool maker, said that Detroit was slightly increasing capital spending and that orders from auto companies should grow the rest of this year. **********''Domestic auto companies are looking at the new generation of engines,'' he said. ''And changes in emissions standards mean that there will be considerable expenditures that will affect machine-tool companies.'' **********Analysts said the sharp decline in foreign orders did not reflect declining interest in American-made machine tools. Rather, they said, the demand in March was unusually high because of a $63 million order to Cross & Trecker from Soviet auto makers. **********Indeed, new orders from foreign customers were up 47.6 percent for the first four months of this year, compared with the similar 1989 period. For this year's January-April period, overall new orders declined by 9.1 percent from the 1989 level, and domestic orders were off 16.5 percent. **********Since April of last year, new orders from domestic manufacturers have risen 23.3 percent, while orders from foreign customers have fallen 11.2 percent. **********Shipments of machine tools declined 10.6 percent in April, to $258.2 million, from $288.9 million in March. The level of shipments was up 3.5 percent from the April 1989 level, however. Also, shipments increased 11.1 percent in the first four months of the year, compared with a year earlier. **********Cutting Tools **********New orders for metal-cutting tools, which include boring mills and lathes, were up 4.4 percent in April from the previous month and were 35.4 percent higher than in April 1989. **********But new orders for metal-cutting tools dropped 12.3 percent for the first four months of this year, compared with the similar period of 1989. Metal-cutting tools typically account for about three-fourths of orders. **********Orders for metal-forming tools increased 22.1 percent in April from the March level. But orders for new metal-forming machine tools decreased 8 percent in April, compared with April 1989. For the first four months, new orders for metal-forming tools dropped six-tenths of 1 percent, compared with the similar period of 1989. **********The machine-tool order backlog for April was $1.71 billion, up from $1.68 billion in March. The backlog in April 1989 was $2.29 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/11/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Cyanamid Completes Shulton Sale
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/11/busin.body_text: **********In June, American Cyanamid agreed to sell the men's toiletries and fragrances portion of the Shulton Group, including Old Spice, to the Procter & Gamble Company. The price was $370 million, American Cyanamid said, less the amount it would ultimately fetch for Breck and Lady's Choice personal care products. Carter-Wallace Inc. bought Lady's Choice for an undisclosed price several weeks ago. **********Later in June, American Cyanamid sold Pine-Sol cleaner and Combat insecticide to the Clorox Company for $465 million. Later, the rights and trademark to Pierre Cardin fragrances were sold back to Mr. Cardin for an undisclosed amount, probably about $50 million, analysts said. **********Analysts said the total sale price realized for the Shulton Group -which they estimated at about $900 million - was excellent. The divestiture could yield $500 million to $600 million after taxes are paid. **********In a statement, John W. Teets, the chairman of Greyhound Dial, said the acquisition of Breck is ''a perfect fit'' with the company's other consumer toiletry products, which include Dial and Tone bar soaps, Liquid Dial soap, Boraxo hand cleaner and Dial antiperspirant. **********Hair care is a new category for the company. Greyhound Dial, which is based in Phoenix, also sells Armour Star canned meats, Purex laundry detergent, Brillo soap pads and Magic Sizing spray starch. **********The Breck line includes hair sprays, shampoos, hair conditioners, gels and hair colors. **********American Cyanamid's shares slipped 62.5 cents today, to $50.875, on the New York Stock Exchange, while Greyhound Dial was off 25 cents, at $26.375.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/11/world.main_headline: Evolution in Europe;   Amid Soviets' Changes, Who Owns the Papers?
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/11/world.print_headline: Evolution in Europe;   Amid Soviets' Changes, Who Owns the Papers?
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/11/world.body_text: **********Last April, just as a newly elected group of insurgents were about to take over Moscow's City Hall, the local Communist Party laid claim overnight to the capital's main newspaper by simply erasing all references to the City Council, or Mossoviet, from its masthead. **********In making its play for control of the paper, Moskovskaya Pravda, and its 725,000 readers, the party bared one of the oldest fictions of the Soviet system. **********''Moskovskaya Pravda was always a party paper,'' said its editor, Valery P. Lysenko. ''All the main decisions, on personnel, finances, were made by the party, even when technically they were joint decisions with the Mossoviet. The role of the Mossoviet was a formality. The Mossoviet itself was a formality.'' Today, a different reality has set in. Power has shifted from the party to a more open political arena. The cities of Moscow, Leningrad, Lvov and Volgograd, and even the Russian republic itself, have moved beyond the total control of the party, choosing their leaders from a new crop of independent-minded politicians. **********But the party, while forced to acknowledge its losses at the ballot box, is fighting hard to keep the rights, privileges and property accumulated during its 72-year monopoly on power. **********The press in particular has emerged as a critical battleground, one where the party refuses to cede its advantage. **********Battle Ends in Draw **********''The Communist Party is no longer the party that dominates everything,'' said Valery P. Yevseyev, deputy editor at Moskovskaya Pravda. ''It is just one of many. And in these conditions -particularly with the new law on property - every party committee and organization has to worry about itself and its future.'' **********In Moscow, the battle over the press has ended in a draw. The Communist Party has refused to give up either Moskovskaya Pravda or the city's afternoon paper, Vechernyaya Moskva, which has daily sales of 650,000, to the newly elected city government headed by Gavriil K. Popov, an economist who is an insurgent leader. **********The staffs of both papers have endorsed the party line, although Vechernyaya Moskva, the livelier and less political of the two, has stated its intention to become totally independent someday of both party and government. **********Independence, in this case, would mean keeping the profits the paper earns, 97 percent of which now go to the party's central coffers. **********In the meantime, the Mossoviet, left without a press voice, is setting up its own newspaper and weekly journal. But to do so, it must rent a printing plant owned by the Communist Party. **********Newsprint, which is a scarce and precious commodity in the Soviet Union, is another matter. Newsprint for the newspaper's initial run of 200,000 will come from reductions of about that size in the newsstand sales of the two party papers - a decision made by party leaders that has set off protests from the editorial staffs. **********Given the party's waning political influence, this economic dependence is particularly galling for newly independent local authorities. The party, meanwhile, is ready to make the most of its economic clout. **********Vladimir Perel, director of the giant Moskovskaya Pravda plant, which now prints five million copies a day - including many nonparty publications handled on contract - said it is inevitable that the plant will give first priority to party newspapers. **********''If our typography stays party property, our first task will be to put out our own products,'' he said. ''After that, we have to work on the basis of profit.'' Who Owns What?  Untangling who owns what in a society where party, people and government were always proclaimed to be one is a potential legal nightmare. In the case of Moskovskaya Pravda, for instance, the party insists that it has paid for everything over the years -equipment, building, staff and distribution costs. **********But the government newspaper Izvestia reported recently that in Volgograd, where the party committee had refused to hand over either one of two newspapers to a newly elected city government, expenses for these publications had been traditionally carried by departments of the local government. **********''We are so used to stereotypes that we consider these publications to be the property of the party,'' Izvestia wrote. **********In Leningrad, where another insurgent group has taken control of local government, the party agreed to divide the city's two newspapers, giving the Vecherny Leningrad, the evening paper, to the Leningrad City Council. **********With the election of Boris N. Yeltsin as President of the Russian republic, the identity of Sovetskaya Rossiya, now identified as a paper of both the Communist Party's Central Committee and the Russian republic, is also open to question, although few expect the party to relinquish control. **********''It is impossible to fight them,'' said Valery Vyzhutovich, a reporter at Izvestia and a member of the 40-member commission at the Mossoviet that has been negotiating with the party over the fate of the city's newspapers. ''It is better just to start our own and compete with them.'' **********Everyone, including the editors of the party papers, agrees that competition will badly shake up the party papers, which still reproduce large and boring chunks of verbatim transcripts of speeches and interviews by party leaders. In a period saturated with political events, the party press continues to provide little objective reporting and uninspired analysis. **********Mossoviet plans to issue the first edition of its weekly, to be called Stolitsa, or Capital, in July, and its editor, Andrei Malgin, is certain that in winning the battle, the Communist Party has lost the war. **********''We are going to be so sharp, so interesting to our readers that we won't even be competing with them,'' he said. ''No one will want to read them anymore.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/16/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene;   High Hopes And Deep Fears
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/16/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene;   High Hopes And Deep Fears
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/16/busin.body_text: **********IS this a time for economic euphoria, depression or a bland, boring and sluggish condition between those extremes? **********Generating euphoria is the collapse of Communism and the end of the cold war. This week brought agreements between the Soviet Union and the West on a framework for negotiating the reunification of the two Germanys and cutbacks in conventional forces in Europe, with the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, so eager to get a deal to rescue his nation's failing economy that he is willing to accept bigger cuts than President Bush. **********Some analysts are hailing these events as the triumph of capitalism; they hold forth the promise of a continuing decline in military spending that sooner or later will enable the United States to wipe out its budget deficit, raise its savings rate, eliminate its trade deficit and regain its world leadership. Euphoria is also fed by hopes that the opening up of Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union may provide a vast new area for capitalist development that would rekindle the postwar boom. **********But fears of depression feed on the mountain of debt and the danger that it could collapse and wreck the economic structure. It would be an irony beyond belief if, in the hour of capitalism's triumph, when the Communist states are seeking a model, capitalism should collapse under the weight of its speculative excesses. Such fears were heightened this week by the failure of Drexel Burnham Lambert, the mother of the ''junk bond'' revolution, now in disintegration. **********''Drexel illustrates the overall problem of too much debt - Government debt, consumer debt, corporate debt,'' said William N. Griggs, managing partner of the investment advisory firm Griggs & Santow. ''A disaster is brewing,'' he added. James J. O'Leary, economic consultant to the United States Trust Company of New York, agrees. ''We have already seen the serious consequences of this overhang in rising delinquencies and foreclosures of commercial and home mortgages which have occurred during the strong business expansion,'' he said. ''The very heavy overhang of debt seems bound to pose much greater dangers in an economic slowdown or a possible recession.'' **********But when will the disaster arrive - and must it come? The stock market this week shrugged off the Drexel debacle, which it had expected. Some on Wall Street even felt that the fall of Drexel was a good and necessary corrective to a decade of excess and hazardous debt. **********Most economists, including Mr. Griggs and Mr. O'Leary, still expect continuing slow growth and also see it as part of the remedy for past excesses. The consensus forecast of the 50 economists and economic forecasting groups surveyed this month by Blue Chip Economic Indicators calls for the American economy to grow at the sluggish rate of 1.6 percent in 1990, with a moderate pickup to 2.4 percent in 1991. **********The Bush Administration is somewhat more optimistic, but its forecast is just within the upper limit of the private economists' range; it foresees 2.4 percent real economic growth in 1990 and 3.2 percent growth in 1991. The Congressional Budget Office is closer to the midpoint of the private economists' range, forecasting 1.7 percent growth this year and 2.4 percent in 1991. No euphoria, no depression, not even a recession. **********What is the logic behind the nearly unanimous forecast of continuing but sluggish growth? Roger Kubarych, manager of Henry Kaufman & Company, speaks for most economists in stressing the sustaining role of the Federal Reserve. Mr. Kubarych, a former Fed economist, contends that with the economy slowing the Fed has ''latitude to bring down interest rates and ignore the dollar.'' Indeed, a decline in the dollar would spur United States exports and help stave off recession. The Fed has husbanded its resources and can afford to feed more reserves to the banking system, which is facing heavy risks at home and abroad. **********Gently but firmly, the Administration is also leaning on the Fed to keep the economy growing. In its annual Economic Report, the President's Council of Economic Advisers plainly states, ''The Administration's primary economic policy goal is to promote further growth.'' It contends that monetary policy can deliver on that growth objective, consistent with its aim of holding down inflation. In fact, that is why it expects no recession now: It says that when inflation becomes intolerable, politically or economically, there is ''little choice but to tighten monetary policy, which typically brings on a recession,'' but it sees no such need now. **********The immediate issue is whether the Fed is easing enough to head off a recession, which could turn into something far worse if it brought the debt structure crashing down. That would worsen pressures for trade protectionism, aggravate strained relations with Japan, exacerbate the third world debt problem and that of some major American banks. It would hurt those Communist nations now striving for political and economic freedom and links to world markets. A depression and climbing unemployment would be the worst possible advertisement for capitalism. **********For the longer run, the issue is whether the Administration is doing enough, through its own fiscal policies, to solve the Federal deficit problem, which has so hampered the United States' ability to tackle the country's domestic social problems or provide international leadership.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/06/busin.body_text: **********The Delaware Chancery Court ruled today that National Intergroup Inc., a beleaguered company whose businesses include metals, retail stores and wholesale drug distribution, must submit its amended shareholder rights, or ''poison pill,'' plan to a shareholder vote before it can be declared effective. **********Ruling on a case brought by two National Intergroup shareholder groups - Centaur Partners and Walker Street Associates - Vice Chancellor Maurice Hartnett ruled that under company bylaws, changes to National Intergroup's rights plan made on Jan. 26 were invalid because they had not been approved by shareholders. **********National Intergroup said it would appeal the ruling to the Delaware Supreme Court. **********In January, National Intergroup tightened its rights plan, reducing to 10 percent from 20 percent the amount of stock someone would have to acquire before it would be effective. A shareholder rights plan makes a takeover attempt much more expensive. **********In the face of the pressure from the dissident shareholders, National Integroup last month announced a plan to divest itself of most of its operations and rename itself the Foxmeyer Corporation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/22/busin.body_text: **********Japanese securities firms are halting equity-linked financing of Japanese companies at home and abroad until the falling Tokyo Stock Exchange recovers, officials said today. **********To minimize damage and risks to stock and bond holders, the firms agreed on Tuesday to suspend stock and bond underwriting for at least a month, said Nobuo Kurakazu, director of securities at the Daiwa Securities Company. **********The first-time maneuver is also intended to stop the flow of additional shares and prevent the market's current value from being diluted. The moratorium involves new convertible bonds, warrants and common stocks. **********Mr. Kurakazu said companies would halt underwriting until the stock market started showing signs of stability. **********Japan's financial markets were closed today for the vernal equinox, a national holiday. **********''We can no longer continue normal sales activities under the current market situation, where prices of stocks and bonds have kept sinking,'' said Hiroshi Tanaka, chief of the underwriting division at the Yamaichi Securities Company. **********The Tokyo Stock Exchange's 225-issue Nikkei stock average has lost almost 21 percent of its value since the beginning of the year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/23/world.main_headline: U.S. Diplomats Return in Force to Nicaragua
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/23/world.print_headline: U.S. Diplomats Return in Force to Nicaragua
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/23/world.body_text: **********On the southern edge of Managua, workers are readying an office building for a tenant that is determined to change the neighborhood. **********The building is one of the city's biggest. The reported rent, $1 million for three years, is the highest anybody here can remember.
