And the tenant would have been unthinkable a year ago: the United States Government. **********After a decade of little more than a token American presence here, United States diplomats and other official personnel have begun to return to Nicaragua in numbers unseen since relations between the two countries collapsed with the start of the guerrilla effort by the United States-backed contras. **********Welcomed by the country's new, pro-American Government and kept busy with $300 million in American aid this year alone, the United States diplomatic mission here has increased abruptly from a low of 8 members last December to more than 60 diplomats and development officials today. **********The influx has been overseen by Harry W. Shlaudeman, a veteran Foreign Service officer who was called out of retirement by President Bush to become the first American Ambassador here since Richard W. Melton and seven other embassy diplomats were expelled in July 1988. **********''There's been a tremendous change from the embattled atmosphere of the past,'' said Stedman D. Howard, the new embassy spokesman. ''There's also the sense of starting all over.'' **********Envoys Were Harassed **********In a decade as representatives of a superpower that was essentially at war with Nicaragua's leftist Sandinista Government, American diplomats here were followed, restricted to specified areas, ridiculed in official newspapers and broadcasts, and menaced by mobs. **********But the embassy's isolation here was outstripped only by the scant attention it was paid by its own Government through most of the war. Having defined Nicaraguan politics as part of a broader East-West conflict, diplomats say, neither the Reagan Administration nor the Bush Administration placed much store in their beleaguered outpost. **********With the election in February of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, whose candidacy received strong American support, the embassy's status changed overnight. **********But Nicaraguan politicians say the rapid resurgence in the official American presence here has been tempered by caution about appearing to dominate Mrs. Chamorro's fledgling Government, or recalling America's ubiquitous influence over the former dictator, Anastasio Somoza Debayle. **********The embassy's political activities focus almost exclusively on the small circle of advisers surrounding Mrs. Chamorro. **********The embassy's principal message, other foreign diplomats say, has been that Nicaragua's economy must be revived if the new President is to have any hope of long-term political survival. And they say that after Washington's apparent 10-year preference for confronting Sandinista influence through military means, economic emphasis seems to have become the cutting edge of the American approach.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/22/busin.main_headline: J. B. Lippincott Is Sold For Over $250 Million
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/22/busin.print_headline: J. B. Lippincott Is Sold For Over $250 Million
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/22/busin.body_text: **********Harper Collins, the publishing subsidiary of Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, announced yesterday that it had sold its J. B. Lippincott unit to a leading Dutch scientific and technical publisher for more than $250 million as part of an effort to reduce its debt. **********The sale of Lippincott, a Philadelphia-based company that is one of the top three American medical publishers, comes as the News Corporation is pursuing a policy of retrenchment after a rapid expansion. **********Earlier this month, Mr. Murdoch's group reported a 74 percent drop in profits for the first nine months, to $93 million. The company said the results included a $24 million loss for the third quarter. **********The News Corporation's debt is estimated at about $6.5 billion, and Mr. Murdoch recently said no further large acquisitions were planned. $800 Million in Debt George Craig, chief executive of Harper Collins, said last month that Harper had about $800 million of debt and that he hoped to raise about $500 million through the sale of Lippincott and other assets. **********Robert L. Biewen, Harper's vice president for educational and professional publishing, said the sale of Lippincott to Wolters Kluwer N.V., which is based in Amsterdam, came after a vigorous auction. ''We were paid about 20 times earnings,'' he said. ''That is a very good price.'' Lippincott has annual sales of about $100 million. **********Wolters Kluwer, which specializes in professional, scientific and educational publishing, had net income last year of about $75 million on sales of $1 billion. Bruce Lenz, the senior vice president of the company's American unit, said that after the Lippincott purchase about 17 percent of the group's revenue would come from the United States. **********''We think we paid a fair price, although it was at the higher end of pre-sale estimates,'' he said. ''We aim to develop the international side of Lippincott's business.'' **********Publishing executives said other companies that had bid for Lippincott included Simon & Schuster, Groupe de la Cite of France, Pearson and Reed, both of Britain, and the Thomson Group of Canada. **********Pieced Together **********Harper Collins was formed last year after the News Corporation acquired William Collins P.L.C. in a deal valued at about $700 million. Collins was merged with Harper & Row Inc., which the News Corporations had acquired in 1987 for about $300 million. **********Apart from Lippincott, two Australian units of Harper - Angus & Robertson, a bookseller, and Gordon & Gotch, a magazine distributor - have also been put up for sale. The overall aim is still to raise at least $500 million, Mr. Craig said. **********The purchase of the Harper Collins units over the last three years has been among the transactions that added to Mr. Murdoch's debt. Mr. Murdoch has also bought the 20th Century Fox Corporation, Metromedia television stations and TV Guide. Moreover he started the Fox TV network and Sky Television, a British satellite television service that has accumulated heavy operating losses in its start-up phase. **********As the Lippincott sale was announced, Advertising Age, the weekly trade publication, printed a report that quoted unidentified sources as saying that Mr. Murdoch was trying to sell TV Guide, which he bought in 1988 for about $3 billion. But a spokeswoman for the News America Publishing Corporation, the American unit of Mr. Murdoch's group, said the report was absolutely untrue. Late yesterday Mr. Murdoch offered to pay Crain Publications, the publisher of Ad Age, $1 million if it could verify its report but Crain refused the offer. **********Harper has said it decided to sell Lippincott, a profitable company, to concentrate on what it calls its core businesses of general-interest, educational and religious publishing. It has spent heavily in these sectors in recent years, buying the Zondervan religious publisher and the Scott, Foresman & Company textbook publisher, as well as beginning a mass-market paperback publishing division in the United States.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/14/world.main_headline: Two Germanys Seize Second Terror Suspect
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/14/world.print_headline: Two Germanys Seize Second Terror Suspect
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/14/world.body_text: **********East and West German officials teamed up to capture a second leftist terrorist suspect, and a newspaper said today that the police were on the trail of another such fugitive. **********The West German authorities hailed the joint effort that led to the arrest late Tuesday of the terrorist suspect, 46-year-old Inge Viett. **********The East German press agency, A.D.N., said Miss Viett, wanted in several attacks, was captured Tuesday night in her apartment in the East German city of Magdeburg. Officials said Miss Viett's neighbors called the authorities after seeing West German wanted posters that had been put up throughout the city. **********Another suspected member of the Red Army Faction, Sussanne Albrecht, was captured June 6 in East Germany, and newspaper reports say that the authorities are close to arresting a third suspect, Silke Maizer-Witt. **********Miss Viett has been accused of taking part in a 1972 bombing that killed one man in West Berlin and in the slaying of a West Berlin judge in 1974.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/01/world.main_headline: U.S. Sees Cut in Nuclear Shells
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/01/world.print_headline: U.S. Sees Cut in Nuclear Shells
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/01/world.body_text: **********The Bush Administration has proposed to the Western allies the eventual withdrawal of nuclear-tipped artillery shells now deployed by the United States in Western Europe, an Administration official said tonight. **********The official confirmed the proposal after a report on the move appeared in The Washington Post. The United States has been expected for some time to announce plans for a unilateral withdrawal of the shells, which are largely aimed at concentrations of Soviet troops in Warsaw Pact nations. The alliance has become less of a threat to the West since the upheaval that toppled Communist Governments in Eastern Europe last fall. **********The Bush Administration recently canceled modernization of its stockpile of nuclear-tipped artillery shells in an anticipatory move. **********Details Still Undecided **********The Administration official confirmed a report in The Post that the United States had made the proposal in advance of the NATO summit meeting next week in London. He said a timetable for the withdrawal had not been set. **********At a meeting of NATO defense ministers in May in Alberta, Canada, the West German and Dutch representatives said the Western alliance should move quickly to remove nuclear-tipped artillery shells from West Germany. **********The West Germans argued that the weapons had no use other than to explode in East Germany, which is soon to be united with West Germany. **********Two private groups, the Arms Control Association and the Natural Resources Defense Council, estimate that the United States controls 1,450 nuclear-tipped artillery shells in Europe. Most are based in West Germany, with others in Greece, Italy, the Netherlands and Turkey.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/07/busin.body_text: **********Officials of Continental Airlines, which is entering its fourth day under protection of the bankruptcy laws, said yesterday that despite an initial downturn in bookings, the carrier had yet to cancel a flight as a result. Instead, it is now having some of the smoothest operations in some time, they said. **********Continental's load factors, a measure of how full planes are, were 53 percent for the first three days of this week, slightly ahead of 52.6 percent for similar days last year. On Monday, the airline had a load factor of 53.6, compared with 54.5 percent on a similar day last year; on Tuesday, 51.5 percent, compared with 49.6 last year, and on Wednesday, 54 percent,compared with 53.8 last year. **********"I've been amazed," said John W. Nelson, the executive vice president of marketing, at a news conference at the airline's huge concourse at Newark International Airport. He also announced yesterday that the airline would begin service from Newark, one of its main hubs, to Frankfurt in June.  Passed an Important Hurdle **********Mr. Nelson also said that travel agents continued to book on the carrier, a fact that was confirmed in interviews with executives of some of the top travel agencies. **********Thus, the airline appears to have passed over an important hurdle -- holding the confidence of customers that the carrier will keep flying, so it is safe to book in the months to come. **********There was a loss of bookings on Monday morning after the airline announced that it had filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, citing financial pressures from the high cost of fuel and its huge $2.2 billion debt, Mr. Nelson said. But it was lower than Continental management had feared. **********He declined to give the Monday loss figures but emphasized that in the following days the carrier saw no decline of customers on its flights. **********Indeed, passengers at the terminal yesterday shrugged off the bankruptcy filing. "I heard on the radio that they were flying," said David Hoffman, who was waiting for a Pittsburgh flight. "I pretty much took their word for it." **********Continental workers at the terminal, where the airline employs close to 6,000, said they were making an extra effort to reassure customers in the hope the carrier would survive. **********"They're more confident if we show confidence," Maggie Cameron, a gate agent, said. We don't want to give up. We want to protect our job. **********Cheryl Mucci, who works in the President's Club, the private lounge used mostly by business fliers, said that many of them wanted to keep flying on the airline so that it would survive and they could cash in their frequent flier miles.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/04/world.main_headline: Mexico's Ruling Party Acts to Curb the Power Brokers
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/04/world.print_headline: Mexico's Ruling Party Acts to Curb the Power Brokers
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/04/world.body_text: **********Changes Endorsed **********The tone of the convention, which was attended by more than 8,500 party delegates, had strong public backing from President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, who has described such political changes as an essential part of his program to modernize the Mexican economy and political system and to strengthen Mexico's international role. **********The delegates did not discuss a widely rumored plan to make a symbolic break with the past by renaming the party. But the meeting was dominated by endorsements of change from Mr. Salinas's top lieutenants. **********''We are going to put an end to the political perversion of centralized decisions,'' declared Luis Donaldo Colosio Murrieta, the party's president, in his opening address on Saturday. ''We are going to put an end to anti-democracy and the imposition of policies from the top.'' **********Critics of Mr. Salinas said the party's commitment to democracy was still far from complete and that the changes were intended as much to manage as to satisfy demands for genuine change. Others noted that efforts to reduce the traditional power of the leaders of the sectors had strengthened the President's position by undercutting rival power bases. **********Critics of Mr. Salinas inside and outside the party also say that the importance of measures such as the use of secret balloting in choosing party leaders will largely depend on who is permitted to vote. They suggested that the overall control over party membership and policy would remain in the hands of the President and his close advisers. **********Group Refuses to Take Part **********Although the official slogan of the convention declared that ''All Voices Participate,'' members of the Critical Current refused to take part as a group in the discussions, accusing party leaders of monopolizing the debate and agenda. When Rafael Espinosa Cardenas, a 27-year-old political scientist and Critical Current member from Mexico City, took his assigned turn at the lectern at a convention working session on party statutes, the moderator conducted a snap vote to end discussion and turned off Mr. Espinoza's microphone as he tried to speak. **********Foreign scholars of Mexican politics have watched carefully for signs of greater democracy inside the party. **********''I don't think there is any question that President Salinas wants to modernize the party,'' said Robert Pastor, an American expert on Mexican politics who was an adviser on Latin America to President Jimmy Carter. **********But many experts describe the move toward democracy less as a matter of principle than as a grudging attempt to salvage the party's fortunes. And they note that the sacrifices required by Mr. Salinas's economic reforms make any step toward greater democracy risky for party leaders and, on a broader level, for the party itself. **********''The question,'' said Mr. Pastor, ''is whether the economic reforms will work and whether democracy will wait.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/30/world.main_headline: Israelis Kill 4 Palestinians and Wound 125 in Gaza
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/30/world.print_headline: Israelis Kill 4 Palestinians and Wound 125 in Gaza
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/30/world.body_text: **********In a marked escalation of violence in the Israeli-occupied territories, Israeli troops shot and killed four Palestinians today and wounded more than 125 demonstrators in a series of clashes in the Gaza Strip, the Israeli Army and Palestinians said. **********The worst of the violence began when soldiers shot and killed two masked men in the Rafa refugee district who had refused to stop and submit to a search, the Israeli Army radio and Palestinians in Gaza said. **********After news of those deaths spread, angry Palestinians pelted the soldiers with stones. Troops then opened fire, killing another two Palestinians. **********Palestinians in the Gaza Strip said the toll of the wounded could reach as many as 250 when a complete count is received from hospitals.  Violence Escalates **********Disturbances had occurred earlier in Rafa and Khan Yunis, another Gaza refugee district, but tens of thousands more demonstrators took to the streets as news of the initial deaths spread. **********Palestinians and the army radio said the protesters threw firebombs at soldiers when they entered Rafa and Khan Yunis. At least 100 Palestinians were wounded in Rafa and another 25 in Khan Yunis, the Palestinians said. The bodies of the first two killed were taken away by the army, they said. **********The death toll was the worst in single day since Oct. 8, when at least 17 Palestinians were slain by the Israeli security forces at Al Aksa Mosque in Jerusalem. The clashes today in Gaza follow wide predictions of an escalation of violence in anticipation of "Fatah Day" on Tuesday. **********Tuesday is the 26th anniversary of the first anti-Israeli attack by Yasir Arafat's mainstream Fatah wing of the Palestine Liberation Organization. In the raid on Jan. 1, 1965, Fatah guerrillas infiltrated Israel and placed a small bomb at the country's National Water Carrier. One guerrilla was later killed in a clash with the Jordanian Army.  'We Will Hear About Massacres' **********"The occupied territories and this whole area are becoming a jungle for sure," said Faisal al-Husseini, a Palestinian leader, in an interview at his Jerusalem home today. "We will hear about massacres here if things continue to drift this way." **********The Palestinian uprising began three years ago, but the violence has sharply increased since the killings at Al Aksa on Oct. 8. **********Palestinians in Rafa and Khan Yunis said in telephone interviews today that thousands of Palestinians in the two refugee districts clashed with about 200 Israeli soldiers. They said the troops chased scores of masked Arabs who were hanging decorations and painting slogans to celebrate the Fatah anniversary. **********Medical staff at Nasr hospital said that one man was wounded in the abdomen and was taken away by the soldiers despite protests by hospital doctors and staff members of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency, which looks after Palestinian refugee affairs. 4 Killed in Lebanon Shelling **********BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 29 -- Artillery and rocket duels raged between Lebanese guerrillas and Israeli troops in southern Lebanon today, killing eight Lebanese, including four children from the same family, the police said. **********The police reported that artillery shells hit three villages in southeastern Lebanon, including Ras al Tineh, where the four children were killed. **********A spokesman for the pro-Iranian Party of God said its artillery retaliated by shelling Israeli territory. The bombardment was continuing late this evening. **********Earlier, an Israeli Army spokesman said troops fired artillery toward sources of hostile fire after Katyusha rockets struck Galilee in northern Israel, across the border from Lebanon.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/20/world.main_headline: Upheaval in the East: Muslims;   Experts See No Broader Islamic Uprising
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/20/world.print_headline: Upheaval in the East: Muslims;   Experts See No Broader Islamic Uprising
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/20/world.body_text: **********American experts on the Soviet Union are interpreting this week's riots in Azerbaijan as a revolt rooted in local history. They say the unrest is not part of a larger movement of the Soviet Union's 45 million Muslims, who have long been viewed as a potential challenge to Moscow's centralized control. **********Nonetheless, they said, the Azerbaijani revolt may portend further difficulty for President Mikhail S. Gorbachev since any current challenge to Soviet central control is likely to be closely watched by other groups with grievances, Muslim and non-Muslim alike. **********''We've been seeing a growth of ethnic splits and violence and unrest throughout the Soviet Union,'' said Nancy Lubin, a political scientist at Carnegie-Mellon University in Pittsburgh. ''But it's a mistake to look at any of these conflicts as primarily pan-Islamic in nature.'' **********''Muslims in the Soviet Union are very divided among themselves,'' she said. #16 Percent of the People Are Muslims Accounting for about 16 percent of the Soviet population, Muslims are a large and growing minority. In the last 40 years, the Muslim birthrate in the Soviet Union has been two or three times the rate for the Slavic and other European groups. **********But important distinctions divide groups of Soviet Muslims. The Azerbajanis, congregated along the border with Iran, are Shiites, but most Soviet Muslims are Sunnis. **********Ethnic divisions exist as well. The Soviet Muslims are concentrated in a southern arc across Central Asia that encompasses six Soviet republics: Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan, Kirghizia, Tadzhikistan, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan. **********While popular fronts voicing various grievances against centralized Soviet control exist in Central Asia - the largest, Birlik, is in Uzbekistan - their grievances differ from republic to republic. **********''Are they going to say: 'Aha, we have Muslims fighting infidels. We should rise up too?' '' Professor Lubin said. ''That's not going to happen.'' **********The divisions among Soviet Muslims exploded into view in June when armed gangs of Uzbeks clashed with the Meskhetian minority, fellow Muslims who were relocated from their native Georgia by Stalin in 1944. The riots, which the Soviet authorities said left at least 67 people dead, suggested that ethnic loyalities may be more binding than religious identity. **********Just as the clash between Uzbeks and Meskhetians was rooted in the particular history of the region, rather than religious identity, so is the current conflict in Azerbaijan, scholars say. **********'Ethnic Quarrels, Cultural Quarrels' **********''What sets the Armenians off from the Azerbaijanis are ethnic quarrels, cultural quarrels,'' said Prof. Robert Legvold, director of the W. Averell Harriman Institute for Advanced Study of the Soviet Union at Columbia University. ''There's not some kind of historic jihad of Muslims against their neighbors.'' **********Several of the experts cautioned that some Western analysts tended to overemphasize the potential for unified action by Soviet Muslims. They said, for instance, that many Western analysts first viewed the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan as motivated by the desire to block the influence of Shiite fundamentalism. **********But Soviet Muslims tended to be less receptive to such pan-Islamic sentiment than Westerners had originally predicted, they said. **********''We've seen that the prospect of a unified Muslim threat to the Soviet state has been exaggerated in decades past,'' said Mahnaz Ispahani, author of a book on Asian political geography.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/15/world.main_headline: Ethnic Enmity Governs A New Soviet Republic
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/15/world.print_headline: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;   Ethnic Enmity Governs A New Soviet Republic
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/15/world.body_text: **********It has no borders, no money and no legal authority, but the Trans-Dniesterian Moldavian Soviet Socialist Republic already has a Parliament. **********''This is not a fight over portfolios,'' Igor N. Smirnov, the temprorary chairman of the temporary Supreme Soviet, declared defensively. ''This is a split among the people of Moldavia.'' **********Both solemn and absurd, the gathering in the old chambers of the Tiraspol City Council was yet another symptom of the political confusion now paralyzing government in the Soviet Union. **********Power, once tightly held by Moscow, has not just been decentralized; it is being pulverized, as different groups and regions assert their sovereignty, autonomy or simply their desire to do things their way. **********'Mono-Nationalism' in Moldavia **********Recently, on the shores of Lake Baikal in Siberia, yet another Soviet Socialist Republic - Buryatia - sprang into being, proclaiming that its laws take precedence over those of the Russian republic and of the Soviet Union. **********Here on the left bank of the Dniester River, the new republic was formed in reaction to what leaders of a dominant Russian-speaking community call the ''mono-nationalism'' of Romanian-speaking ethnic Moldavians now in control of the republic of Moldavia. **********''It is our answer to the refusal of the Moldavian Government to listen to the population of this region,'' said Vyacheslav Zaglyadsky, a member of the temporary Parliament in Tiraspol. ''We are confronting the existence of a nationalist dictatorship, which has replaced the dictatorship of the center.'' **********With the largest concentration of Russians, Ukrainians and heavy industry in Moldavia, the Trans-Dniester, population 800,000, was part of the Ukraine until 1940, when it was joined together with an annexed Bessarabia to form the newest of the Soviet Union's 15 republics. Last month, it became the second part of Moldavia to push for greater autonomy. The other is the Gagauz republic, formed earlier this summer by Turkic-speaking Orthodox Christians who are also unhappy with policies made in Kishinev, the Moldavian capital. **********Scorn for Mini-Republics **********The Moldavian nationalist movement, in power in Kishinev for more than a year, has treated the emergence of the mini-republics with scorn and outrage. Some leaders on the extreme wing of the ruling Popular Front have publicly threatened to take up arms to stop the break up of Moldavia, while others dismiss the demands of the ''secessionists'' as a provocation engineered by Moscow to distract them from their own drive for sovereignty. **********''I refuse to take them seriously,'' said Moldavia's Prime Minister, Mircha Druk, ''until they understand that in little Moldavia, it is stupid to try to create a new state. Moldavia is indivisible. **********Mr. Smirnov, sitting here in the city of Tiraspol where non-Moldavians make up 80 percent of the population, looks at the conflict in a different way. The legal right of Trans-Dniester to exist is no greater and no less than the right of the Soviet republics - including Moldavia - to unilaterally declare sovereignty, he said. **********''I predict there will not be 15 republics but many more,'' said Mr. Smirnov, a factory director who came to Moldavia from Russia several years ago. ''Maybe 30 or 40.'' **********A central issue dividing Moldavia has been the switch in official language from Russian to Romanian. But there is also a fear among non-Moldavians -who make up almost 36 percent of the republic's 4 million population - that the nationalists, by branding all criticism as anti-Moldavian and all critics as 'enemies of the people,' will prove to be as intolerant as their Communist predecessors, perhaps more so. **********Former Party Members **********Several ethnic Russians said in interviews that they would leave the republic if they could find a way to get a residence permit to live elsewhere. In the last two years, more than 30,000 Moldavian Jews, almost half the republic's Jewish population, have already left or have applied to emigrate, according to Aleksandr Brodsky, chairman of the local Jewish Cultural Association. **********The fact that many of the Trans-Dniester's new leaders are former ranking Communist Party members, directors of local industry and other notables of the Soviet era has laid them open to the accusation that their bid for autonomy is a last-ditch attempt by the Russian elite to retain old privileges.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/09/world.body_text: **********After 19 years of independence in which this vulnerable nation has known little else but human tragedy and natural disaster, the capital is alive today with new hopes. **********Against long odds and with stunning speed, an eight-day revolution last week not only brought down the eight-year-old military Government of Lieut. Gen. H. M. Ershad, but also did it with the decisive support of the army. **********Bangladesh, with between 110 million and 120 million people, is one of the most poverty-stricken and overpopulated nations in the world. And the potential for mass violence is just below the surface in this highly emotional society, many people say. **********Tonight Mr. Ershad, who formally relinquished power to an acting president on Thursday, is in protective custody in the military cantonment near the center of Dhaka. Reporters who tried to reach him were turned away. **********"Curfews were violated in a way I never remember happening before," said Kamal Hossain, a lawyer and former Foreign Minister who was a leader of the opposition to General Ershad. "Journalists closed down newspapers. We shut down the courts. All university teachers and vice chancellors resigned. Doctors quit. The civil service walked out.  'The Time Was Up' **********"By then, Ershad began to realize that the time was up," said Mr. Hossain, who is also a leader of the Awami League, the party of Bangladesh's founder, Sheikh Mujibur Rahman. **********The fate of General Ershad is the hottest topic of debate in Bangladesh. The students at Dhaka University, who are credited with finally galvanizing a long-simmering opposition movement, are clear about what they want -- trial and hanging for the general -- and are willing to return to protests in the street to get it. **********But while calls for speedy trials and executions are coming from the young -- drunk on the glory of their achievement in uniting at least 20 warring political parties in a final push against the Ershad Government -- older and more experienced political leaders are pondering the possibility of allowing the former president to go into exile. **********Trials for abuse of power and corruption could provoke those in the military still wavering in their support. **********Summary courts could also lead into uncharted areas of potential embarrassment to the two major opposition figures, Sheik Hasina Wazed, Sheikh Mujib's daughter and political heir, and Khaleda Zia, the widow of another assassinated president, Ziaur Rahman.  Opponents Hard-Pressed to Unite **********Sheikh Hasina's Awami League has accused the late President Zia of playing a role in Sheikh Mujib's assassination. On the other hand, the Awami League was and is widely assumed to be laced with corruption, particularly when it was in power from 1971 to 1975. **********Today Mrs. Zia, the leader of the popular Bangladesh National Party, was conciliatory in an interview, saying that she was not in favor of banning General Ershad's Jatiya Party, as the students have been demanding. **********Sheik Hasina, who heads an eight-party alliance, and Mrs. Zia, with a seven-party coalition, will be hard pressed as it is to stay united in the next three months. Elections must be held during that period. They will also be challenged by a five-party leftist alliance, which sees a chance to expand its following among the poor. **********Interviews with political leaders, students and diplomats provide the following account of what happened in Bangladesh since early October: **********On Oct. 8, all major campus wings of national political parties except the Awami League joined in an alliance. The Awami League would also later become part of the All Bangladesh Students Union. **********On Oct. 10, the police fired on students demonstrating outside a Government office building against Mr. Ershad's apparent plan to run for another term after his current term ended in 1991. Opposition groups never recognized his initial election, saying that only about five percent of voters actually cast ballots.  Swore Oath Over Slain Student **********Students took one of the five bodies, that of a fellow student they identify only as Zahid, and carried it to the front of the main campus, where they swore an oath of unity over it. Student leaders at that point more or less decided to force the political parties into a similar union. **********A series of demonstrations and strikes followed. The Ershad Government then made what many consider its fatal mistake: It released criminals and allowed them to go armed into the university campus to break up the student front. **********On Nov. 27, a gun battle broke out on the Dhaka campus. A professor of physiology who was also an officer of the Bangladesh Medical Association was killed, provoking a mass outpouring of grief and rage. **********As professional groups began to ally themselves with the students and politicians, Mr. Ershad declared a state of emergency and imposed curfews. They were flagrantly violated. **********A former military officer said that at that point, junior officers in the army began to criticize the President openly. Within a few days, members of the Bangladesh Rifles were laying down their arms rather than shoot protesters. **********After a hedged resignation offer on Sunday, which was promptly and decisively rejected by his opponents, Mr. Ershad agreed to leave office unconditionally on Wednesday.

They said there were no foreigners among the victims. Railway spokesmen said the train crashed into a stopped freight train early Thursday in the rural Sangi station, apparently because of an improperly set switch. **********Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto said soon after the crash, ''The possibility of sabotage cannot be ruled out.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/23/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Shuttle Hires Consultants From Politics
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/23/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Shuttle Hires Consultants From Politics
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/23/busin.body_text: **********BATTLING for the loyalty of air travelers in the Boston-New York-Washington corridor, the Trump Shuttle has retained two prominent political consultants, one Democrat and one Republican, to advise it on marketing strategy. **********Trump has hired Roger J. Stone, a Republican consultant from Washington whose clients have included Presidents Nixon, Reagan and Bush, and Douglas E. Schoen, a Democratic New York consultant who has worked for Mayors Edward I. Koch and David N. Dinkins. **********The two men, who have individually advised the Trump Shuttle's owner, Donald J. Trump, on national and local real estate issues, will now help him craft communications campaigns for his commuter airline, which is fighting the Pan Am Shuttle for market share. **********''This is like a political campaign,'' Mr. Stone said. ''Two candidates fighting for at least a 51 share, using the same tools: TV, radio, print, direct mail, telephones.'' **********Analysts say the Trump Shuttle has a 45 to 50 percent share of the shuttle traffic between New York, Washington and Boston. When it was the Eastern Shuttle, it controlled the market, but a strike by machinists, which was supported by other unions, hobbled the Eastern Shuttle and reduced its share to about 26 percent before Mr. Trump took control in June. **********Already in its brief life, the Trump Shuttle's marketing campaign has had more wrinkles than a shar-pei puppy. The airline chose Scali, McCabe, Sloves as its agency last spring, after a highly public search in which Mr. Trump boasted of the low compensation he planned to give his agency. Then, a few weeks after its release, Scali's first campaign for the shuttle, which involved unlikely celebrity pairings, was publicly criticized by Mr. Trump in a speech to airline executives. **********Scali appears to be taking in stride the appointment of two high-profile political advisers to the shuttle's marketing team. **********''I haven't had the experience ever with a political consultant hired by the client and working alongside us,'' said Robert Levenson, Scali's vice chairman, ''but I have to assume that if Donald hired these people, he has some trust in them and value in their opinions.'' **********Mr. Stone and Mr. Schoen both credited Scali's work. ''Instead of fixing something that's broken, we're coming in to add a strategic dimension,'' Mr. Schoen said. **********The use of political consultants by product and service marketers is not new. Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., for example, has for several years supplemented its ad agency with the Sawyer-Miller Group, a Democratic political consulting firm. Although Mr. Schoen's firm, Penn & Schoen Associates, is known primarily as a political survey research organization, both it and Mr. Stone's organization, Black, Manafort, Stone & Kelly, have served numerous manufacturers and service companies. **********Both firms have been embroiled in controversy. Mr. Stone, who is 37 years old, a suave figure who was once featured in a GQ magazine fashion spread, resigned as an adviser to the Republican gubernatorial campaign of Jim Courter in New Jersey last year; a colleague of Mr. Stone had admitted using political influence to secure loans from the Department of Housing and Urban Development. **********Mr. Schoen, 36, ran unsuccessfully for a Queens Congressional seat in 1983. **********In 1987, a dozen people previously retained by Mr. Schoen's firm were indicted on charges of forging signatures on nominating petitions for a candidate that had engaged the firm. Ten were convicted on a variety of forgery-related charges. Neither Mr. Schoen nor his firm were charged with any wrongdoing.  In an interview, the two consultants affirmed that they intended to concentrate on identifying and communicating to niche audiences within the business traveler market, which accounts for about 85 percent of shuttle passengers. Direct mail, they said, is likely to play a large role in their strategy. **********While welcoming their participation, Mr. Levenson of Scali objected slightly to their comparison between marketing the shuttle and marketing a political candidate, particularly to the metaphor, often used by political consultants, that their nonpolitical clients ''face an election every day.'' **********''It shouldn't be put in those overly dramatic terms,'' Mr. Levenson said. ''There are much longer-term considerations that maybe political consultants don't know. They're trained to get their guy elected and then their job is over. I don't think they're accustomed to longer-term issues like brand-imaging.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/26/busin.main_headline: No Epidemic Is Expected From Drexel's Killer Flu
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/26/busin.print_headline: No Epidemic Is Expected From Drexel's Killer Flu
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/26/busin.body_text: **********Aftershocks from the collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. swept through the markets last week, as traders openly questioned the financial health of several other Wall Street firms. But top financial officers of a number of large brokerage firms and leading credit analysts said the problems that suddenly engulfed Drexel are unlikely to be repeated. **********The way Drexel financed its operations was particularly perilous, they said, and is atypical of the rest of the Street. ''Drexel's capital structure and business was far different from other brokerage firms,'' said Jeffrey Bowman, an analyst at Standard & Poor's. ''For others to experience similar problems is highly remote.'' **********Specifically, Drexel relied heavily on a technique called ''double leverage'' to finance its broker-dealer operations. Double leverage means a firm borrows at the holding company level and lends those funds to a subsidiary, which in turn can use the money as collateral with which to raise more money. Essentially, the same funds can be put to work twice. **********Twice as Much as Competitors **********Double leverage is common on Wall Street and in banking, but Drexel was twice as double leveraged as its competitors. **********Financial executives say double leverage need not be risky, provided the broker-dealer uses the funds to finance short-term investments rather than to support assets that do not generate cash or that are unable to be sold quickly. **********Salomon Brothers' parent company, for example, is one of the brokerage industry's heaviest borrowers of commercial paper, which are short-term corporate i.o.u.'s. And Salomon's holding company, Salomon Inc., does indeed lend those funds to its broker-dealer subsidiary. **********But Donald S. Howard, the firm's chief financial officer, said Salomon uses the commercial paper only to finance short-term investments in its broker-dealer and backs those investments with readily marketable collateral. **********When Liquidating Is Easy **********If the holding company suddenly needs to repay its commercial paper debt, it can quickly liquidate the short-term investments of its broker-dealer and send the cash upstream to the holding company. Unlike in Drexel's case, the regulators would presumably allow such a transfer because the broker-dealer still had other funds that qualified as capital, the financial cushion required by industry regulators. **********Merrill Lynch & Company also borrows heavily in the commercial paper market and funnels the money to its broker-dealer in the form of equity, but it does not borrow against that money. Again, on the surface it is double leveraged, but not the way Drexel was. **********What Drexel appears to have done was to borrow at the holding company level in the short-term commercial paper market and use that money to finance its subsidiary's portfolio of high-yield, high-risk ''junk bonds.'' Those bonds became increasingly illiquid and did not produce the required cash flow. Because the commercial paper was counted as part of the broker-dealer's capital, instead of more flexible short-term loans, the regulators would not allow the broker-dealer to channel any excess money back to the parent company. **********''It was a very imprudent capital structure,'' said a financial executive at a large Wall Street firm. ''My guess is that it's not practiced by anyone who intends to live for a long time.'' **********Bank Loans Hard to Get **********Drexel's financing appears to have differed from that of other firms in several other important ways. Since it had made its mark as a junk bond firm, those bonds made up a far higher percentage of its inventory than at other firms. That made it harder to get bank loans secured by the assets in its portfolio. **********Traditionally, banks have been willing to lend 85 cents for every dollar of a junk bond that a securities firm owned. But as conditions in the junk bond market deteriorated and credit concerns grew, that willingness disappeared. By September, said one senior executive of a Wall Street firm, banks were lending only 75 cents for every dollar of junk; by December that had fallen to 60 cents, and by January it was down to 50 cents. **********At the same time that its access to secured lending was drying up, Drexel was also being shut out of the market for unsecured commercial paper. Actually, among leading brokerage firms, Drexel had been one of the least dependent on the commercial paper market. At the end of the third quarter of 1989, for instance, it had only $700 million of commercial paper outstanding, or about 2 percent of its total liabilities, compared with 5 or 6 percent at several other firms and 12.9 percent at Merrill Lynch. **********But even that small amount became critical as its other alternatives evaporated. In the last week of November, Standard & Poor's downgraded the rating on Drexel's commercial paper from A-2 to A-3. Fitch Investors Service, the other leading agency to rate Drexel's debt, announced a similar downgrade, from F-2 to F-3, in the first week of December. **********'Out of the Market' **********That sharply reduced the pool of potential lenders, since many banks, corporations and other institutional purchasers of commercial paper are not permitted by their investment guidelines to purchase paper with that low a rating. **********''There is no A-3 market to speak of - it trades by appointment only,'' said one financial executive of a large Wall Street firm. ''When you go from A-2 to A-3, you're essentially out of the market.'' **********Senior executives at other firms said that if their access to commercial paper dried up, they would turn to their banks, with whom they have agreements to provide emergency credit. But Drexel does not seem to have had any such ironclad agreement, for its banks turned down its 11th-hour request for financing. **********''Drexel, it is my understanding, had no back-up facilities to support its commercial paper, and very few highly liquid unencumbered securities,'' said D. Bruce Brunson, the treasurer of Merrill Lynch. By contrast, a firm like Merrill Lynch has nearly $6 billion in guaranteed back-up credit lines and securities it could pledge in exchange for more credit. **********Data Not Available **********Efforts to discern exactly how securely financed other Wall Street firms are is difficult because the data are not publicly available. Publicly held firms have to release details about their holding companies' balance sheets only once a year, at year-end, and they never have to release the specific financial status of their broker-dealers. With private firms like Drexel, the amount of disclosure is even less. **********Those concerned about a brokerage firm's credit risk are forced to rely on the rating agencies, which are privy to more internal financial data of public firms, and to some extent even private ones. Credit analysts at these agencies said one of the most important issues they focus on in deciding a firm's debt rating is how it could deal with a liquidity crisis of the sort Drexel just experienced. **********Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's have assigned the highest possible ratings for all the major brokerage firms with the exception of one. The Paine Webber Group is rated one notch down, at A-2 or P-2, depending on the agency, and credit analysts say that is because of less-than-stellar operating performance, not liquidity problems.
