https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/26/busin.body_text: **********The Foxboro Company, a Massachusetts-based industrial controls company that has received inquiries from a number of suitors in recent weeks, agreed yesterday to be acquired by Siebe P.L.C., a British safety products and engineering company, for $52 a share, or $655 million. **********Under the agreement, Siebe said it would buy Foxboro's 12.6 million shares in a cash tender offer to begin on Friday. Siebe's shareholders will be asked to vote on the offer by July 27. **********Foxboro's stock soared $12.875 yesterday, to $51, on the New York Stock Exchange, where almost 1.2 million of its shares were traded. Its gain of 33.8 percent was the best of the day. **********Foxboro systems are used to record and control such manufacturing conditions as temperature, pressure, humidity and liquid levels. Many of its customers are in the chemical and petroleum industries. **********Siebe has rapidly expanded in the last five years. The company has made several acquisitions in the United States, including its purchases of Ranco Inc. of Dublin, Ohio, and the Barber-Coleman Company of Rockford, Ill., in 1987. The company has also acquired leading controls concerns in West Germany and in Japan. **********For the fiscal year that ended March 31, Siebe's pretax profits rose 19 percent, to $310 million, on sales of $3.3 billion. Four years earlier, the company had operating income of $25 million on sales of $300 million. **********''We want to buy Foxboro because it is involved in technologies that do not overlap with those of our company,'' said E. Barrie Stephens, vice chairman and chief executive of Siebe, in a telephone interview. **********Mr. Stephens said the company's strategy is to ''become one of the major controls players in the world,'' adding that the purchase of Foxboro would make it a stronger competitor against industry giants like Honeywell Inc. and Johnson Controls Inc. **********The deal with Seibe came after a four-month auction process involving at least three bidders for Foxboro. Officials close to the transaction said several bids were received that were close in price. **********Foxboro reported a $4.6 million net loss last year, largely a result of start-up costs associated with early versions of its intelligent automation series product and with foreign-exchange losses, the company said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/06/world.main_headline: Foes Seen as Desperate to Stop Bhutto
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/06/world.print_headline: Foes Seen as Desperate to Stop Bhutto
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/06/world.body_text: **********Still in question is whether Prime Minister Ghulam Mustafa Jatoi will attempt to bar Ms. Bhutto from the poll through a special judicial process or will try to charge her with treason, based on unsubstantiated reports that she had shared vital information with the national enemy, India. **********A treason trial could be held in camera, for national security reasons. That would almost certainly provoke fears of a repeat of the kind of trial given her father, the late Zulfikar Ali Bhutto. **********Wait for Evidence and Charges **********Analysts in Islamabad and here in Lahore, the country's intellectual capital, say that those courses of action could be self-defeating. **********''Will the ineptitude of the interim Government make Benazir Bhutto more popular?'' a political analyst asked. **********The caretaker Government that replaced Ms. Bhutto has yet to produce the conclusive evidence of corruption and malfeasance that were cited as the reasons for her dismissal. **********For two weeks, one official or another has been promising the imminent formal filing of charges against the former Prime Minister in one or both of the special tribunals drawn from the judiciary. The unexplained delays daily weaken the Government's credibility, though they heighten the possibility that the intent in raising the charges was not so much to prosecute as to intimidate Ms. Bhutto into dropping out of political life. **********Ms. Bhutto's Pakistan People's Party, now preoccupied with the difficult task of choosing candidates for national and provincial elections while attempting to hold the party together for the coming campaign, has failed to proceed with its promised court case challenging the dismissal. **********The People's Party is also discussing what approach to take to the tribunals being put in place with jurisdiction over all members of the former national and provincial governments dismissed or dissolved in August, including those of Ms. Bhutto's opposition. The former Prime Minister says that she will not appear in such a court, but has not specifically announced that she would not field a defense. **********Reports circulate that Ms. Bhutto may be negotiating with President Ghulam Ishaq Khan or the military. Two versions, both denied by Ms. Bhutto, say she will either leave politics in return for immunity or send her husband, Asif Ali Zardari, into exile. **********Mr. Zardari, who could face criminal charges in regular courts of law, since he was not a member of the Government, is widely believed to have amassed a fortune in unethical or criminal use of his relationship to Ms. Bhutto. He has been granted what South Asians call ''anticipatory bail,'' paid in advance of an expected arrest.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/30/busin.body_text: **********The world's main cocoa-growing nations are scheduled to meet in Ghana this week to discuss ways to maximize export earnings in a market with ample supplies. **********The five-day meeting of experts from the Cocoa Producers' Alliance to start on Monday in Accra, Ghana, might not produce any new price-support measures, cocoa trade and officials said on Friday. But they said progress was expected in coordinating views on how to operate and finance a plan to monitor and regualte exports. **********''If we want to accomplish something we have to contemplate a loose system of coordination on research, verification and control of sales,'' one official said. **********Five members of the group sent representatives to a meeting in January in Ivory Coast. **********They were Ivory Coast, the world's biggest producer, Brazil, Ghana, Nigeria and Cameroun. **********The meeting was held when cocoa prices were around their lowest levels in more than 14 years as a result of six consecutive years of overproduction. **********Prices have recovered somewhat in recent weeks amid reports of a smaller surplus this season, concern about drought and unrest in Ivory Coast.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/23/busin.main_headline: President Is Named At Prime Computer
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/23/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;   President Is Named At Prime Computer
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/23/busin.body_text: **********Prime Computer Inc. yesterday named as its new president John J. Shields, a former senior vice president at the Digital Equipment Corporation, and said he would become chief executive in a year. **********Prime, based in Natick, Mass., was taken over last fall by J. H. Whitney & Company, a Wall Street investment firm. Whitney then installed James F. McDonald, 49 years old, a former chief executive of Gould Inc., as its chief executive, and he said yesterday that he had taken the top post at Prime with the stipulation that it was a 24-month deal. **********''The first thing I did was start working on recruiting,'' Mr. McDonald said yesterday. ''We talked to four people. When Jack left D.E.C., I called Jack and spent quite a bit of time with him. We shut off all the other candidates immediately after we met with Jack the first time.'' **********Mr. Shields, 51, one of the top executives at Digital after 28 years there, said his reasons for leaving the company had been personal and private. ''I haven't discussed that with anybody,'' he said yesterday. **********''The notion was I was going to do a bit of sailing this winter, take my boat down to the Caribbean and coming from the Grenadines back up here,'' Mr. Shields said. But those plans were scotched with the offer from Prime. ''I talked with the folks at Prime and Whitney and others and determined there was enough critical mass and potential here,'' he said. **********Prime has faced problems besetting the minicomputer industry, along with the task of recovering from a hostile takeover attempt by MAI Basic Four Inc. before its acquisition by Whitney. It is also saddled with heavy debt from the $1.13 billion Whitney acquisition. **********''I've been at it about six months,'' Mr. McDonald said. ''We've come out ahead of the bank plan for the fourth quarter. We're doing O.K., but we still have a lot to do.'' **********Prime has said it plans to be a major participant in computer-aided design, minicomputers and computer services. ''I've had fairly broad experience in these areas,'' Mr. Shields said, adding he would be working within the framework in place. ''The changes already put in place make sense,'' he said. ''My job will be to help develop some of the longer-term strategies.'' **********Mr. McDonald has been named vice chairman, while continuing as chief executive through a one-year transition. When Mr. Shields becomes chief executive, Mr. McDonald is expected to continue on Prime's board. **********''I'll go off and maybe do another one of these,'' he said, referring to his role in the Whitney acquisition.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/26/busin.main_headline: Citicorp Floating Securities Are Backed by Credit Cards
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/26/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;   Citicorp Floating Securities Are Backed by Credit Cards
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/26/busin.body_text: **********Citicorp yesterday priced the first-ever issue of floating-rate securities backed by credit card receivables. The bank holding company, the largest issuer in the $20 billion, three-year-old market for credit-card-backed securities, is offering $700 million of the new floating issue through the Money Market Credit Card Trust 1989-1. **********An underwriting group led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets priced the securities at 100. The firm said the issue, which has a final legal maturity of June 10, 1996, and an expected final maturity of June 12, 1995, carries a rate that floats monthly at 10 basis points above the Federal Reserve's index of top-grade, 30-day commercial paper. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point. **********The collateral behind the issue consists of Visa and Mastercard receivables from Citicorp's credit card banks. This issue is rated Aaa by Moody's Investors Service and AAA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, based on a letter of credit issued by Union Bank of Switzerland that covers 6 percent of the debt offering. **********People who follow the corporate bond market said yesterday that the financing was the same one that Citicorp planned for December 1989 but postponed because of market conditions. The size of this financing has been scaled back from the $1 billion planned last year. **********Underwriters said that because of a renewable feature in the issue, money market funds with one-year investment restrictions were allowed to participate.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/25/world.main_headline: BRANDT IS HAILED IN EAST GERMANY
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/25/world.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;   BRANDT IS HAILED IN EAST GERMANY
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/25/world.body_text: **********Waving the black, red and gold banners of West Germany and the green and white of Saxony, enthusiastic crowds cheered Willy Brandt late Friday here and in Plauen and demonstrated impatience with the pace of reunification. **********The former West German Chancellor, who is widely regarded as the leader who first breached the barrier between the Germanys two decades ago, came to the southern rim of this country, where East Germany and West Germany touch Czechoslovakia, to attend his party's congress in Leipzig. **********But he did not speak as a partisan, and by shouting ''Willy! Willy!'' while local Social Democrats spoke, the majority of the tens of thousands who filled the market squares of both towns made clear that they had not come to hear Social Democratic campaigners but to hear a recognized leader of all Germany. Mr. Brandt was elected honorary president of East German Social Democrats today. **********When Joachim Richter, the Social Democratic leader in Zwickau, spoke on behalf of his party, the nighttime crowd of 60,000 filling the square jeered and whistled until he cut short his speech and ceded to Mr. Brandt. **********The man who won the Nobel Peace Prize for taking the decisive first steps toward reconciliation between West Germany and what was then Communist Eastern Europe spoke from the balconies of neo-Gothic town halls to advocate unification. But he spoke of a prudent approach, in a spirit of reconciliation, after economic safeguards have been put up to protect East Germans against West Germany's economic advantage and without giving offense to other nations. **********In what is regarded as the most nationalist and anti-Communist region of East Germany, Mr. Brandt warned against creating incidents against the many Soviet soldiers garrisoned in the area and actions that might increase the burden borne by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet President. **********''He has so many difficulties at home, we don't want to give him difficulties, too,'' Mr. Brandt said in the afternoon rally in Plauen. ''Some people are waiting for that. I have great respect for Gorbachev. I hope he makes it.'' **********And as the crowd of about 40,000 cheered, Mr. Brandt repeated softly, ''I hope he makes it.'' **********But Mr. Brandt, a longtime spokesman for German socialism's internationalist tradition, responded to the intense nationalism of his public. Recalling that a French minister whom he did not name had voiced concern to him that a united Germany might be too strong for the rest of Europe, he said, ''I would say to him that that is our problem.'' **********'Easy, Easy,' He Advises **********When he metioned the presence of foreign troops in East and West, a heckler shouted, ''Throw them out!'' **********Mr. Brandt responded, ''Easy, easy.'' But he invited the crowds in both rallies to look forward to the day ''when we will again be among ourselves.'' **********Plauen, and the region as a whole, has seen the greatest defections from East Germany since last summer. Informal estimates in Plauen put the rate of decline in the population, which stood at 78,000, at 18 percent. In Zwickau, a Social Democratic volunteer said the town numbered 128,000 people, but added, ''It must be a lot less now.'' **********Hugo Miltner, a teacher with a heavily bandaged arm after a serious home accident, said he shuddered at his daily hospital visits. ''It is catastrophic,'' he reported. ''There is nobody left, not even to clean the clinic or keep the equipment working.'' **********Mr. Brandt appealed to East Germans not to run away. Conceding that he, too, would have considered flight were he in the same situation, he urged patience and hard work in this part of the nation and said he was confident that with West German help prosperity would come. ''We must light a fire under rear ends in Bonn if they don't direct enough resources here,'' he said. **********In southern Saxony and Thuringia a visitor gains a sense that the East German state has ceased to exit. Driving along 100 miles of potholed roads between Leipzig and Plauen, past the decaying facades of houses that have received little care in half a century, one sees everywhere, fluttering from windows, on village squares, even at the entrances of publicly owned factories, the flag of West Germany. **********Even the frequent Saxon and Thuringian flags represent a rejection. The Communist regime dismantled the historic lands and divided their state into smaller districts, which offended traditional sentiments. The parliament to be elected on March 18, in the first free voting since 1932, will restore the borders of the former kingdoms and principalities. They are, in addition to Saxony and Thuringia, Saxony-Anhalt, Mecklenburg and Brandenburg. **********The West German flags are mainly produced by removing the Communist emblem of a hammer and compass from East German banners. ''We know how,'' a journalist remarked. ''In 1933 we sewed black swastikas on red party flags, in 1945 we removed them again. Now we are restoring the unadorned black, red and gold of the republic.'' **********A day of random conversations in the three Saxon towns reflected virtually unanimous sentiment in favor of unity now, as well as conservative sentiments based on hatred of Communism, but uncertainty on whom to support. Many complained that few specific programs had been put forward. **********''Many Germans are not strong in the backbone,'' Mr. Miltner said. ''The party was the backbone here for all these years, so now they don't know what to do and think.'' **********On a popular level, much unity has been forged already since the border was opened three months ago. Long lines on the highways near the frontier show how common its crossing remains even after the thrill of novelty has worn off. **********Advertising boards in Plauen announce concerts and soccer matches in Hof, the nearest West German town. Buses bring West Germans from Hof, Ingolstadt or Coburg for cheap day trips to their Saxon cousins, and Plauen's few coffee houses are crammed with Bavarians marveling aloud at the low cost of the same pastries that they fancy at home. **********But before Mr. Brandt spoke in Plauen, the square had to be cleared of stands from which West Germans were hawking a variety of fruits and vegetables that astounded townspeople. In a country that lives in virtual commercial isolation, displays of kiwi fruit from Italy or South Africa, bananas from Ecuador, tomatoes from the Canary Islands, pineapples from Ivory Coast or cucumbers from Crete were looked at like museum pieces. **********There was astonishment at the sight of tomatoes, cucumbers or strawberries in February. Endives and Chinese cabbage were mysteries for many. **********The drawback was that only West German marks were accepted, a currency that sells on the black market at as much as 10 times the official one-for-one rate. Many East Germans spent money that recent visits with friends and relatives put in their pockets. Soviet soldiers looked on as if through plateglass windows, and a group of Vietnamese ''guest workers'' took a while before deciding against investing their one Western bill of 10 marks in pineapples that reminded them of home. **********A dealer tantalized onlookers. ''Don't you want to, or can't you?'' he asked in a broad Bavarian accent. **********''We're waiting for prosperity,'' an elderly woman with her hair in a large bun responded in equally dialetical Saxon, the area being one of Germany's major linguistic divides. ''We've had nothing for 40 years.'' **********The longer lines formed at a state-owned stand, which sold comparable imported produce in East German marks, at four or fives times the prices in Western marks. **********'What Have We Had?' **********A 70-year-old retired household worker said she could not afford such things in any currency, ''not on a pension of 425 marks,'' or $257, a month.'' She said she had come only for Mr. Brandt, although she believes no politician. ''They all cheated us,'' she said, worrying about what reunification would do to the value of her pension and savings. ''What have we had in these 40 years?'' **********She said she remembered hearing that Ernst Thalmann, the pre-Nazi Communist leader, had spoken on the same square. The woman said she did not remember whether Hitler had spoken in Plauen. ''He didn't interest me,'' she said unconvincingly. **********The woman and a friend said they had attended the anti-Communist demonstrations, which, as in most towns, continue as weekly events. But they said they did not join in. Expressing what appeared to be a political philosophy of wide applicability, the first woman said, ''We stand on the corner and cheer.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/01/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;   Hussein Seeks a 'Debate' With France
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/01/world.body_text: **********President Saddam Hussein said today that Iraq would seek to open a ''debate'' with France over the Persian Gulf crisis. Passages of his speech implied that Iraq might be prepared to enter such talks with a less than unyielding stance. **********In a broadcast message, Mr. Hussein wavered between a harsh line suggesting that Iraq would fight to defend its seizure of Kuwait and more conciliatory passages implying that a deal could be struck to avoid war. **********In the more aggressive sections, Mr. Hussein used vituperative language against the United States, calling it the ''haven of evil'' and saying there could be no solution unless Washington first withdrew its forces from the region. **********But the core of his message was directed at President Francois Mitterrand of France. In a speech last week at the United Nations, Mr. Mitterrand said that all of the issues raised by Mr. Hussein in the last two months, including the fighting in Lebanon and Palestinian demands for a homeland, could be discussed if Iraq withdrew its troops from Kuwait and met other demands of the United Nations. Those demands include the restoration of the Government of the Emir of Kuwait. **********Hint of a Change **********Mr. Hussein said that Iraq's priority in talking with France would be to insure that the situation in Kuwait ''should not be restored to the previous situation before Aug. 2.'' **********This remark differed significantly from his previous statements that Iraq's annexation of Kuwait was irreversible. Some Western diplomats here said it implied that Baghdad might eventually settle for a compromise -or that Mr. Hussein might at least be trying to signal for tactical reasons that it might accept a settlement. **********The Iraqi leader's message took the form of a greeting to Arabs and other Muslim peoples on the birthday of the Muslim prophet, Mohammed. The occasion, an opportunity for the kind of festivity that this city has not seen since the invasion of Kuwait, drew tens of thousands of citizens into the streets of Baghdad tonight in processions of lighted candles and beating drums. **********Perhaps because his primary audience was made up of Arabs and other Muslims, Mr. Hussein took his hardest line yet on the two issues he has addressed in virtually all of his messages on the Kuwaiti issue: the demand that any resolution include a settlement of Palestinian grievances with Israel, and that an ''Arab solution'' to the crisis be found - but only after a withdrawal of American troops. He also renewed Iraq's pledge to fight if its hold on Kuwait is challenged militarily. **********'Prepared for Fighting' **********''Iraqi forces under all circumstances and events will be prepared for fighting in defense of Kuwait province,'' he said. Nevertheless, he took a milder tone in responding to the Mitterrand speech, which his Government had welcomed in general terms shortly after it was delivered. **********Mr. Hussein said today that ''in spite of our objections,'' Iraq viewed the speech as different in tone from others made by Western leaders. ''We intend to make contacts with the French Government to explain after inquiry, questioning and dialogue our views accurately, so that everything is based on clear ideas and actions,'' he said. **********''What annoys us'' in the attitude of the United States and other Western nations, he added, ''and is rejected by us from the start,'' is ''not our disagreement on views, but rather the biased, prejudiced viewpoint that passes judgment without showing readiness to conduct a debate.'' **********Asks for 'Peaceful Tone' **********''Thus if debate supersedes threat and intimidation, and if a peaceful tone of politics supersedes the tone of deploying armies with the threat of using force, then it does not matter where do we agree or disagree in the first place with this or that initiative, including the initiative of Mr. Mitterrand,'' Mr. Hussein said in the official English translation of his remarks. **********''What is important indeed,'' he continued, ''is that any serious debate should seek a possible and fair solution, that the solution should be comprehensive so that we enjoy peace, and all concerned in the region should base their future on a firm foundation unshakable against changes of circumstances.'' **********Some Arab intermediaries have suggested that Iraq might accept the restoration of Kuwait as an independent state if Kuwait surrendered some strategic territory to Iraq, including a vast oilfield on the Iraq-Kuwait border and two strategic islands that command the entrance to Iraq's new oil port at Umm Qasr, north of Kuwait. **********Suggested compromises have also included payments of billions of dollars from Kuwait's vast financial reserves to compensate Iraq in a dispute over oil prices and crude pumped from the disputed field. **********Arab Proposals **********Leaders who have supported Iraq or at least avoided an outright condemnation of its actions in Kuwait, like King Hussein of Jordan and Yasir Arafat, the head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, have called for negotiated settlements that would include the establishment of a new government in Kuwait, perhaps after elections supervised by the Arab League. **********The implication is that the Emir's Government, which has ruled without a parliament for most of the 29 years of Kuwait's independence and was bitterly unpopular with some poorer Arab countries, might not be restored. **********The broadcast version of Mr. Hussein's message, read over Baghdad radio and television tonight, attracted wide comment among Western diplomats here, who have been poring over his speeches for the first sign that the Iraqi leader might be ready to back out of Kuwait. **********Only a week ago, in his last major pronouncement on the Kuwaiti issue, Mr. Hussein implied that Iraq might not wait for the American-led multinational force in Saudi Arabia and the Persian Gulf to attack, but perhaps would strike first if its people were ''strangled'' by the United Nations trade embargo. **********The diplomats cautioned that the message appeared to have been written in two parts. One part seemed to be intended to convince supporters that Mr. Hussein is prepared if necessary to endure a catastrophic war over Kuwait, they said, and the other to hold out the vague prospect of a compromise with the nations whose forces are arrayed against Iraq's. **********Suggestion of Pragmatism **********The diplomats said the contradictions could be interpreted in various ways. They said it was possible that the Baghdad Government was entering a more pragmatic phase, positioning itself so that it can hang on to Kuwait for the time being while holding out the possibility of a withdrawal. **********From the Western viewpoint, the diplomats said, the least attractive interpretation is that Mr. Hussein is simply trying to forestall any military attack by the United States or its allies by drawing France into talks. **********In itself, the Iraqi leader's decision to seek talks with France was not surprising. For a decade and more before the invasion of Kuwait, France had been the Western nation with the closest ties to Baghdad. **********French companies were the major foreign contractors for the Iraqi nuclear plant that was destroyed by Israeli bombers in June 1981, and French weapons, including the Exocet missile that struck the United States frigate Stark in the Persian Gulf in May 1987, helped to sustain Iraqi forces in their eight-year war with Iran.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/24/busin.body_text: **********Poland's Deputy Finance Minister, Marck Dabrowski, said today that he thought Poland's currency, the zloty, could be made fully convertible within three years if the country can ease its debts. **********He said after a speech to international bankers in West Berlin that convertibilty was a Government goal that could not be met without easing repayments on Poland's $39 billion debt. **********The Polish President, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, has called for a substantial reduction in Poland's debt. **********Mr. Dabrowski said Poland was talking with commercial banks, as well as Western nations, on debt reductions. ''Nobody has definitely said no, but nobody has said yes either,'' he said. **********Poland owes commercial banks about $9 billion and has official debt of around $30 billion. **********Earlier Mr. Dabrowski told the conference there were no signs that a devaluation of the zloty would be necessary within the next months. Poland has devalued the zloty by about 50 percent since the Solidarity-led Government took office in September. The Government wants to unite the official and free-market rates of the zloty against the dollar to make the currency convertible on the domestic market.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/20/world.main_headline: Vote Dispute Sours Party's Victory in Mexico
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/20/world.print_headline: Vote Dispute Sours Party's Victory in Mexico
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/20/world.body_text: **********By renewing doubts about the fairness of Mexico's political system, the lopsided victory of the governing party in elections here appears to have turned into a public relations defeat for President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, diplomats and political analysts say. **********With the official vote count completed late Sunday night, Mr. Salinas's Institutional Revolutionary Party was declared the winner by a landslide in the elections held here on Nov. 11 in Mexico state, just outside the capital. **********But as the debate over allegations offraud and ballot irregularities continues, experts on both sides say the vote damaged Mr. Salinas's struggle to overcome his party's reputation for electoral abuse. The election may ultimately prove even more damaging, they warn, to his wider campaign to reshape Mexico's economy and its international image. **********Foreign experts say that the appearance of corruption or election fraud could particularly discourage the foreign investment that Mr. Salinas needs to smooth the transition to a more open economic system. It could also serve as ammunition for foes of other elements of the Government's economic strategy, like the conclusion of a free trade agreement with the United States. **********That agreement is to be a central item on Mr. Salinas's agenda when he meets with President Bush next week for two days of discussions in the northern city of Monterrey. **********"The worry is that this will give people who would be hurt by the free trade agreement a more respectable reason to oppose it," a diplomat said. "Instead of saying, 'This is going to hurt my business,' they will say, 'How can Bush make deals with a dictatorship?' " **********Even before the balloting, leaders of the P.R.I., as the party is known, acknowledged that they had more atstake than simple victory or defeat. **********"We not only have to win the elections," Ignacio Pichardo Pagaza, the state Governor and a leading P.R.I. official, said before the vote. "We also have to convince public opinion that we won them cleanly."  Questionable Margins **********But the potential conflict between those goals quickly became apparent as the vote was counted and the party began to roll up improbably high margins in a state it had lost decisively in national elections only two years ago. **********The results released today showed that the party won all 34 directly contested seats in the state legislature and leadership in 116 of the state's 121 municipalities. It received 53 percent of the vote in a field of eight parties. **********The results have been directly challenged by large opposition groups like the Democratic Revolutionary Party and the National Action Party, which have accused the P.R.I. of irregularities ranging from ballot stuffing to tampering with voter lists. **********The appearance of election fraud has also hurt smaller parties, which in some municipalities received fewer votes than the number of candidates on their slate, curiously suggesting that some candidates had not even voted for themselves. **********"Before, the central characteristic of Mexican elections was their lack of competition," wrote Lorenzo Meyer, a respected Mexican political analyst and Government critic, in a recent front-page column in the Mexico City daily newspaper Excelsior. "Today that characteristic has been reduced to the simple absence of credibility."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/29/world.main_headline: U.S. Missionary Shot to Death At Home in South Lebanon
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/29/world.print_headline: U.S. Missionary Shot to Death At Home in South Lebanon
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/29/world.body_text: **********An American missionary was killed Tuesday night by masked gunmen at his home in the Israeli-designated ''security zone'' in southern Lebanon. **********Security officials said three gunmen broke into the residence of the missionary, William Robinson, in the village of Rashaya Foukhar and shot him three times. **********The attack was confirmed by officers in the United Nations peacekeeping force in southern Lebanon. Mr. Robinson's wife, Barbara, also an American, told the United Nations officers that the gunmen took family jewels and cash in the house before escaping. **********Buffer Zone for Israel **********Rashaya Foukhar is within the 6-mile deep and 50-mile long enclave Israel carved out in southern Lebanon five years ago to be a buffer against cross border raids by Lebanese and Palestinian guerrillas into northern Israel. **********A statement issued here by the Lebanese National Resistance Front said its guerrillas killed Mr. Robinson to ''deter the establishment of Zionist settlements in southern Lebanon.'' **********The front consists of several leftist factions aligned with Syria and is led by the Soviet-oriented Lebanese Communist Party. They and a separate guerrilla movement made up of Muslim fundmentalists backed by Iran have been active against Israeli troops and their Lebanese Christian Militia allies who patrol the security zone. **********U.N. Role Requested **********Lebanese newspapers have published a petition signed by 5,000 inhabitants of Rashaya Foukhar to the Lebanese President, Elias Hrawi, asking him to intervene to evict Mr. Robinson from their village. The Hrawi Government last week asked the United Nations to look into the mass activity. **********The petitioners asserted that Mr. Robinson was using an orphanage that he ran as a pretext to bring in Jews from Israel to settle in the outskirts of Rashaya Foukhar. Israel denied there was such a plan. **********Mr. Robinson originally came to southern Lebanon nearly 10 years ago, and worked as a technician for Middle East Television. He quit three years later and decided to establish a center for handicapped children. He moved into the public school in Rashaya Foukhar, and, according to the inhabitants, began engineering works for building homes for 100 families he supposedly intended to invite from Israel. **********U.S. Condemns Killing **********WASHINGTON, March 28 (Reuters) - The United States condemned the killing of Mr. Robinson today, but said it had warned him to leave Lebanon. **********''We deplore this act of terrorism against an American citizen,'' said the State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler. ''Mr. Robinson was in Lebanon working on a humanitarian mission, so far as we know.'' **********She said the Robinson family had lived in southern Lebanon for several years running an orphanage. They were independent of any organization but had received some support from the Pentecostal Holiness Church in Oklahoma City, she said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/20/busin.body_text: **********Ten people, including three high-ranking bank officials, have been arrested in connection with a multimillion-dollar fraud at a Mexican bank, the Government newspaper, El Nacional, reported today. **********In the latest scandal in Mexico's state-run banking system, Banco del Pequeno Comercio was defrauded of $46 million over two years when a number of checks were cashed without money to back them up, the newspaper said. **********The newspaper quoted Mexican officials as saying those arrested included the bank's treasurer, Heribeto Alcantara Medina; his deputy, Gloria Carrillo Garcia, and an official in the credit department, Emma Zepeda Chavez. **********Mexico's banking system, which was nationalized at the beginning of the country's debt crisis in 1982, is scheduled to be returned soon to private hands.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/07/busin.body_text: **********DO consumers still benefit from the regulation of long-distance phone rates? Not so long ago the American Telephone and Telegraph Company was almost universally regarded as a puma amidst newborn kittens -- a powerful beast, whose predatory instincts made it untrustworthy out of sight of its Government keepers. **********But in the last few years A.T.&T.'s rivals, notably the MCI Communications Corporation and U S Sprint, have grown claws of their own. And with the support of the Bush Administration, the Federal Communications Commission is proposing to lengthen A.T.&T.'s leash, with the thought of one day letting free markets rather than regulation protect consumers' interests. **********That would suit A.T.&T., which would like to move aggressively to shore up its 60 percent-plus share of the lucrative large-customer business market. But the proposal is drawing howls of protest from competitors that have only recently grown comfortably profitable. **********A.T.&T.'s rivals score a few points in the resulting war of words between distinguished economic consultants. But to the degree that the hired guns succeed in raising doubts about the potential for healthy competition in long-distance phones, a larger, unspoken question becomes more difficult to ignore: How does the simulated rivalry between a handful of phone companies that apparently cannot be allowed to fail better serve the public better than a plain old-fashioned regulated monopoly? **********Under current rules, all long-distance phone companies are free to set rates, offer new services and negotiate special deals for valued customers. Check that: all but one. As a "dominant carrier"A.T.&T. cannot raise or lower rates by 5 percent or more without permission from regulators. And it must provide plenty of notice to its rivals in case they want to match the offer. **********The commission argues that the rationale for this discrimination against A.T.&T. is losing its force. A.T.&T.'s rivals are now big enough, rich enough and competent enough to deter a predatory price-cutting attack. **********What is more, the commission says, U S Sprint and MCI's enormous investments in excess capacity make it unlikely that A.T.&T. would be able to gouge customers. If the phone giant raised prices, competitors would be well positioned to take away their business. **********Three consultants for U S Sprint, Steven Salop, Steven Brenner and Gary Roberts of Charles River Associates demur. The costs of transforming the smaller phone companies' maze of fiber-optic cable into a functioning network would exceed the commission's estimate by billions of dollars. Moreover, for some A.T.&T. customers -- notably those with 800 numbers that would have to be changed --leaving the A.T.&T. family would be expensive. **********But it is not rate increases that U S Sprint fears. Just the opposite: A.T.&T.'s rivals worry about price cuts that would force them to sacrifice profits in order to hang onto valued customers. And here the Charles River trio offer a novel argument in defense of their client. **********Many potential customers, they assert, including some who were burned after Ma Bell's breakup, incorrectly believe that non-A.T.&T. service is inferior. Thus if A.T.&T. were free to price as it wished, it would discriminate, lowering rates to gain savvy price-sensitive customers and raising rates for customers who believed A.T.&T's advertisements. At the very least, Steven Salop argues, deregulation should be delayed until customers are given time to see how good non-A.T.&T. service can be. **********The best guess now, analysts argue, is that the F.C.C. will find a politically acceptable compromise, deregulating at a sufficiently cautious pace to keep U S Sprint and MCI from taking their case to their friends in Congress. Indeed, the one near certainty in the not-so-brave new world of long-distance telephone regulation is that, once established, every company will be given sufficient support by regulators to stay in business. **********Therein lies the rub. As the architects of telephone divestiture in the early 1980's understood, it takes competitors to create and maintain a competitive market. But the addition of profitable service providers was a means of insuring competition, not an end in itself. The F.C.C. now finds itself running a cartel, favoring smaller companies over the larger one in the expectation that the market will someday be self-sustaining. **********But what happens if, as seems increasingly likely, that someday never comes? Is America really better off with a telephone cartel regulated in the interests of its weaker members than with a monopoly that must justify its pricing policies to the Government?

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/24/busin.main_headline: UAL Will Let Davis Buy Additional Shares
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/24/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   UAL Will Let Davis Buy Additional Shares
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/24/busin.body_text: **********The UAL Corporation said yesterday that it had changed its standstill agreement with Marvin Davis to allow the West Coast investor to buy additional shares in the company. **********The step was aimed at bringing in other bidders and providing some leverage for the UAL board as its advisers begin talks with a team headed by Coniston Partners, the New York investment firm, which has allied itself with three unions of United Airlines. **********The Coniston group has offered to buy the carrier for $150 a share in cash, $25 a share in notes and 25 percent of a new stock to be issued after a takeover. The bid has an estimated value of about $180 to $190 a share, or a total of about $4 billion. **********The board said that the offer was inadequate, and it directed its advisers to find alternatives. **********Mr. Davis, a Los Angeles billionaire, reached a standstill agreement last September, which limited how much stock he could buy. He had put UAL into play in August when he bid $240 a share and later raised his offer to $275 a share. His bid was topped by an offer made by the pilots' union and UAL management for $300 a share. **********The effort fell through when the pilots and UAL's management could not complete the financing. UAL's stock has fallen dramatically since then, but revived somewhat on the Coniston offer. UAL closed today at $157.125, up $5.125, on the New York Stock Exchange. **********Mr. Davis had no comment on the UAL step. He has conceded in the past that any outside bidders would be at a substantial disadvantage since they would not have the wage and benefit concessions from the pilots, machinists and flight attendants, which are all now part of the offer with Coniston.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/07/world.main_headline: Manila Court Frees Aquino Opponent on Bail
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/07/world.print_headline: Manila Court Frees Aquino Opponent on Bail
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/07/world.body_text: **********Senator Juan Ponce Enrile had accommodated himself pretty well to the week he has spent in confinement on charges of complicity in the December coup against President Corazon C. Aquino. He has spent that time in a two-room air-conditioned apartment, filled with friends, political supporters and a maid to keep things tidy. **********The rich and powerful politician, who is Mrs. Aquino's best-known rival, was even giving daily news conferences until the Government stopped them two days ago, apparently deciding that he was getting too much publicity. **********But now, Senator Enrile is out of prison. In something of an embarrassment for the Government, the Philippine Supreme Court today ordered him released on bail while it considered his legal challenge to charges of conspiring in the coup. He was freed today. **********Mr. Enrile was arrested Feb. 27 on a charge of rebellion combined with murder, which the Government argued is a non-bail offense. But Mr. Enrile, who denies any involvement in the failed coup, argued that the charge no longer exists in the penal code. **********Bail of More Than $4,500 **********The court emphasized today that its order to release Mr. Enrile on bail of just over $4,500 should not be construed as a judgment on the validity of the charge, which it will rule on later. The vote was 10 to 4, with one abstention. **********That will end, for the moment, an extraordinary series of events in which Mr. Enrile, the only opposition member of the Senate and a likely presidential candidate in 1992, was arrested in the Senate building and then allowed to hold court in custody at police headquarters. **********Even though the Senator's daily news conferences were stopped, it was still possible to interview him by telephoning his staff for an appointment and then signing in as a family friend. **********In a conversation on Monday, Mr. Enrile called himself ''a political prisoner,'' saying his refusal to condemn the December coup did not mean that he supported it. **********While he said he was opposed to violence to reach political ends, he went on to say that the principles of a ''mature democracy'' like the United States could not be fully applied to a ''third world'' country like the Philippines. **********''I'm not implying the use of a coup d'etat to overthrow a democratic government,'' he said. ''But I won't just condemn it like that - I would have to study the reasons for it.'' **********This sort of argument is characteristic of Mr. Enrile, who helped organize a coup against Mr. Marcos, his original patron, that was overtaken by the popular uprising that put Mrs. Aquino into office in February 1986. The coup was to be carried out by his aide, then-Lieut. Col. Gregorio B. Honasan, and young army officers. **********In his post as martial law administrator, Mr. Enrile was responsible for the conditions of imprisonment of Mrs. Aquino's late husband, Benigno, and he regulated her visits to him. **********Mrs. Aquino, despite her discomfort with Mr. Enrile, made him her Defense Minister. She dismissed him nine months later after a failed coup attempt against her by his followers, led by Mr. Honasan. Elected to the Senate and now one of Mrs. Aquino's bitterest opponents, Mr. Enrile is a major figure in a revived nationalist party. **********Mr. Honasan, who has also been charged in the latest coup attempt, is still at large. The Government's case against Mr. Enrile now seems to hang on allegations by dining-room staffers that the two men met at a dinner party at Mr. Enrile's house on Dec. 1, the first day of the coup. **********Mr. Enrile, now 66, was born in northern Cagayan province as the illegitimate son of a laundry woman. As a teen-ager, he traveled to Manila to confront his wealthy lawyer father, who took him in and educated him. **********Became Wealthy Along the Way **********He became a lawyer and later studied at Harvard. Recruited by Mr. Marcos, he became Customs Commissioner, Justice Minister and then Defense Minister. Along the way he also became wealthy, and currently has significant real estate holdings and lucrative logging concessions. **********Mr. Honasan is regarded as the son Mr. Enrile never had, while Mr. Enrile replaced Mr. Honasan's father, a soldier who died young. **********Teodoro Benigno, once Mrs. Aquino's press spokesman and now a regular critic of her in a newspaper column, said that the move against Mr. Enrile was a necessary show of strength. ''I think the strategy was to make people realize that she is serious about these threats to her Government and that she is not afraid of Enrile,'' he said. **********Yesterday, Mr. Enrile said that he was ''playing politics - I'm playing chess with Mrs. Aquino.'' The prize, he said, was ''my liberty.'' Government officials believe that the real prize at stake is the presidential palace.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/13/world.main_headline: Bush Tapes a Message for Iraqi TV
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/13/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;   Bush Tapes a Message for Iraqi TV
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/13/world.body_text: **********Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq denounced the speech Mr. Bush delivered to Congress on Tuesday night. The official Iraqi press agency quoted Mr. Aziz as saying: ''The U.S. President's address is a model speech by an imperialist ruler who wants to impose his power on the world. Most of the globe's peoples, the Arabs in the forefront, reject that and insist on preserving their independence and free will.'' A Simulated Debate?  In making his tape for broadcast in Iraq, officials acknowledged that Mr. Bush was running the risk that it would be edited, although they were taking steps to make that harder technically. It could also be preceded or followed by a rebuttal from President Saddam Hussein himself, creating the appearance of just the kind of debate that Mr. Bush has rejected. **********White House officials said it was Mr. Bush who first brought up the idea of getting time on Iraqi television, at a news conference in Kennebunkport, Me., and that once the opportunity was offered by the Iraqi Government, the President felt it was worth taking a chance. **********The audience in Iraq will not be large. The British Broadcasting Corporation, which publishes such statistics, estimated in June that there are 1.5 million televisions in Iraq, which has a population of 17.9 million. But many of those people live in areas where they do not have access to television at all. **********Mr. Bush wrote much of the message himself and went over the contents in at least two meetings with experts from the National Security Council and the State Department, said Mr. Fitzwater. **********He said Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger would give the tape to Mohammed al-Mashat, the Iraqi Ambassador, by Thursday morning. Then, the United States would give Iraq five days to air it before releasing the tape, Mr. Fitzwater said. **********'A Little More Hopeful' **********Mr. Fitzwater, who has expressed skepticism that Iraq would broadcast the tape unedited, said today that he was ''a little more hopeful'' that would happen. He did not explain what caused the change. **********Mr. Mashat has said that Iraq's state-run television would ''of course'' air the message ''in its entirety, without editing.'' **********To try to prevent the Iraqis from editing the tape, the White House was including its own voice-over translation and subtitles in Arabic, which were done by the Voice of America. **********The tape was produced by Sig Rogich, Mr. Bush's scheduling chief and public relations consultant. In it, Mr. Bush stands in front of his desk in the Oval Office, with the American flag behind him. He read his remarks from a TelePrompter, pausing once to pull a piece of paper from his pocket and read a quotation, Mr. Rogich said. He and other officials refused to say what was on the paper. **********Mr. Fitzwater quoted Mr. Bush as saying in the tape that ''we have no quarrel with the Iraqi people, that the Iraqi Government has forced incredible hardships on the people of Iraq by virtue of their naked aggression against Kuwait, that we are in the Persian Gulf to defend Saudi Arabia, and that we want a peaceful resolution, we want peaceful coexistence with the people of Iraq.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/13/busin.body_text: **********The Tishman Realty and Construction Company, which built the World Trade Center, Epcot Center and many other landmark developments, is finding it must expand into projects it once ignored, like prisons, schools and government buildings, in an effort to offset the downturn in the nation's real estate markets. **********The 92-year-old company, as close to a blueblood as exists in the real estate business, has built a strong reputation on projects that also include the John Hancock Center in Chicago,Renaissance Center in Detroit and the twin towers of Century City in Los Angeles. It has been selected to modernize and expand Kennedy International Airport and add a building to the Rockefeller Center complex. **********But with the real estate development business in a sharp downturn, the company is seeing fewer of its traditional private clients in need of a construction manager. So it is expanding into less glamorous works. Tishman has just begun the Niantic Women's Prison in Connecticut, and is competing for several other large prison contracts. It has won a contract to serve as the Government's construction consultant for the final component of the 70-acre Federal Triangle Development in Washington. That complex will be the second-largest Federal building in the nation, after the Pentagon. **********The company is also seeking out development projects in Eastern Europe as that region modernizes, and it has signed an agreement to build housing complexes in Israel for the current flood of immigrants there. Although the profit margins on projects like these are generally slimmer than in doing construction management for big New York City developments, the company is determined not to be hostage to the fortunes of the private real estate industry. **********Finally, the company, whose reputation allows it to raise money more easily than some of the troubled developers it often represents, is increasingly doing projects for its own account - in other words, projects that it will own - with a focus on hotels. **********''We saw what was happening and knew that the boom years could not go on forever in New York, but we have offices and a lot of businesses outside New York,'' said Richard Kielar, a vice president of the company, in explaining why Tishman was turning to projects it once ignored. **********John L. Tishman, the 64-year-old chairman and chief executive of the company, and a grandson of the founder, comes from a family of old money that has long maintained a low profile while contributing large sums to medical and educational charities. **********The company is owned primarily by Mr. Tishman, who lives in Manhattan and Bedford in Westchester County, and although it is now private, it was publicly traded from 1928 to 1976. The other main principals are two senior executives, Irwin Miller, president and chief executive of the construction business in New York, and Abraham S. Bolsky, head of the construction business on the West Coast. **********Ran Into Trouble in 70's **********Tishman Realty learned in the 1970's just how painful it can be to be tied almost exclusively to big private projects, mostly in New York City. At that time, commercial property values were falling sharply in the city, little building was being done and Tishman suffered large losses on one of its major office projects in New York City. The company was liquidated in 1976 and its construction and research arm, along with the Tishman name, was sold to the Rockefeller Center Corporation. In 1980, officers of the Rockefeller subsidiary, including Mr. Tishman and several colleagues, bought back the business. **********Among the other well-known members of the Tishman family who were part of the company before it was sold in 1976 to the Rockefellers are Mr. Tishman's cousin, Robert V. Tishman, who with his son-in-law, Jerry I. Speyer, transformed the finance and development arm of the old company into Tishman Speyer Properties. Alan V. Tishman, another cousin, is a principal in the brokerage and building management firm of William A. White/Grubb & Ellis. **********Tishman, which now has more than 700 employees, wears a number of hats. Usually it serves as the construction manager on a major office building or a project like Epcot Center, for a client like Metropolitan Life or Walt Disney. But it might simply serve as a client's representative, ironing out difficulties between the contractor and the client. Or it might simply serve as a construction consultant to a client. **********But Tishman also has substantial business in real estate development for its own account. The company says it has completed or begun more than $1.2 billion worth of development projects for its own account. It remains to be seen whether some of those projects will prove to be a drag on earnings, given the problems of the current real estate market. **********'Very Highly Regarded' **********Real estate executives say Tishman is a leader because it consistently delivers well-made buildings while limiting cost overruns. ''They are very highly regarded,'' said William Conway, a managing director of Jones Lang Wootton, an international real estate company. **********While most of the nation's real estate developers and construction companies are at wit's end in search of financing for new projects, Tishman is handling about 50 projects valued at close to $4 billion with little sign of slowing its pace. So far, the company's new contract award volume this year has reached close to $1.5 billion, down from $2.5 billion in 1989. **********''We are satisfied in this market to have that much,'' said Mr. Kielar, the Tishman vice president. ''In all fairness, I wouldn't expect to reach that $2.5 billion figure.'' **********Mr. Tishman agreed. ''We are not unhappy with the volume that seems to be heading to us this year, but we are very unhappy about the troubles with financing'' that our developer clients are having, he said. **********But those financing troubles may be a blessing in disguise for Tishman. **********In many instances, bank lenders now require that developers put more equity than debt in new deals that only a year ago could have consisted almost entirely of debt. Because these banks have raised the hurdle that proposed developments must clear to get financing - or have simply stopped lending to new real estate projects - those developers with large, stable sources of capital are at a big advantage. **********Foreign Investors Lured **********Tishman has managed to get around the financing squeeze that most developers are facing by attracting foreign equity investors. **********''We have a number of foreign sources of equity that are waiting and asking for products,'' Mr. Tishman said. ''These are not the lenders or banks but equity participants.'' **********These foreign equity participants are overwhelmingly private Japanese companies and a few wealthy individuals looking to diversify into upper-tier American commercial real estate projects. Moreover, according to Tishman, much of its construction financing is now also coming from Japanese lenders rather than American banks. **********Probably the most spectacular and widely watched of Tishman's recent projects is the Walt Disney World Dolphin Hotel, a whimsical 27-story monolith with 1,509 rooms that was designed by the architect Michael Graves and sits next to Epcot Center in Orlando, Fla. **********The hotel, crowned by a pair of six-story dolphins and four flower-shaped fountains, is opposite the Walt Disney World Swan hotel, also built by Tishman. Both are owned by a consortium including Tishman, the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and the Aoki Corporation, a Japanese company that owns Westin Hotels and Resorts and is one of Japan's largest contractors and developers. **********A Focus on Hotels **********Tishman has moved boldly into the hotel business. Two years ago, it announced a real estate investment fund - a joint venture with Aoki -that will exclusively sponsor Tishman developments and acquisitions. The Tishman Development and Acquisition Fund, as it is called, expects to put about $2 billion into the hotel business in its first five years. **********So far, the fund has developed the $185 million Sheraton Chicago Hotel and Towers. Earlier this year, Tishman, as a construction manager, broke ground on a 400-room luxury hotel in Osaka, Japan, that will be the first such project to be built by an American construction company. **********''We are very interested in hotels right now, especially resort hotels,'' Mr. Tishman said.  At a time when occupancy rates for most hotel chains are sliding and price wars are cutting into earnings, Tishman still thinks there are opportunities for the developer that can identify unexploited niches, particularly in the big-city hotel markets. The company is developing resort hotels in Puerto Rico and Southern California.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/25/world.main_headline: Bhutto's Hunted Brother Is Hoping to Return
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/25/world.print_headline: Bhutto's Hunted Brother Is Hoping to Return
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/25/world.body_text: **********Mir Murtaza Bhutto vanished from Pakistan more than a decade ago, a hunted young man with a famous name, obsessed with revenge. **********''Only violence will answer violence,'' he used to tell his sister Benazir when they were in exile during the regime of the late President, Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, who had sent their father, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, to the gallows. **********As she recounted the conversations in her autobiography, ''Daughter of the East,'' Ms. Bhutto would reply, ''Violence only breeds violence.'' The two fought often on this crucial issue, she wrote, also noting how she had admonished her brother about his luxurious style of living abroad. **********The younger Mr. Bhutto's name is back in circulation in Pakistan these days as the political future of his sister grows more uncertain. Now based in Damascus, Syria, he wants to come back, encouraged by feelers from some People's Party members. **********Ms. Bhutto, by all accounts, does not want to see him. In her 20 months in office, she never exonerated or pardoned her brother for crimes in which he more or less admitted complicity as head of an armed militant organization, Al Zulfikar. **********Mumtaz Bhutto, their uncle (once or twice removed) and a Sindhi politician with his own party, said in a telephone interview today from his home in Larkana that he had met 36-year-old Mir Murtaza in Athens in June and found him eager to come home. **********But Pakistanis, most of all Ms. Bhutto and her husband, know that if her brother returns, he, as the only male heir alive, will almost automatically inherit their father's political legacy and possibly the leadership of his party, even though his sister is a year older. He will, that is, if he does not go to prison immediately. The caretaker Government of Prime Minister Ghulam Mustafa Jatoi would move to arrest him if he reappeared, officials say. **********Mir Murtaza Bhutto is a wanted man because of charges that he was behind the March 1981 hijacking of a Pakistani airliner and the killing the following September of a prominent Pakistani philanthropist, Zahur Elahi. Mr. Elahi was riding in a car with the judge who had signed Mr. Bhutto's death warrant in 1979. **********Both attacks were the admitted work of Al Zulfikar, founded by Mir Murtaza and his younger brother, Shahnawaz, who had fled to Kabul after their father's death. In Kabul, the two young men married Afghan sisters, who followed them into eventual exile in Europe. In 1985, Shahnawaz Bhutto, his marriage failing, died in Cannes under mysterious circumstances. Ms. Bhutto says he was poisoned, and calls him a ''martyr.'' His widow and daughter moved to the United States after the French cleared her of involvement. **********Mir Murtaza'a marriage also collapsed after his brother's death. In Syria, where he finally settled, he married again. This year, he and his wife had a son, whom they named Zulfikar. **********The decision to settle in Damascus, apparently with the help of the Syrian Government, has led many Pakistanis to assume that the Al Zulfikar organization may have links with international terrorist organizations, and may have had a hand in the death of General Zia, who was killed in an unexplained plane crash in 1988.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/03/busin.main_headline: Deal for Kay Is Valued at $410 Million
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/03/busin.print_headline: Deal for Kay Is Valued at $410 Million
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/03/busin.body_text: **********Ratners Group P.L.C., the world's largest jewelry retailer, announced in London yesterday that as expected it would acquire Kay Jewelers Inc., the third-largest American jewelry chain, for about $410 million in stock. **********The transaction, which was approved on Sunday by the directors of both companies, will strengthen the position of Ratners as the second-largest American jewelry dealer after Zale's, which is operated by Peoples Jewellers Ltd. of Canada. Ratners already owns Sterling Inc., a large American retail jeweler it purchased three years ago for about $200 million. **********Kay, based in Alexandria, Va., has been struggling for the last two years with slow sales in its older stores, a rise in delinquent accounts in its receivables and a squeeze on profits. Last year, Kay's sales increased to $426.6 million, from $420.3 million the year before, and the company reported a small net income of $196,000, against a net of $10.9 million in 1988. **********Kay Shares, Bonds Jump **********Investors yesterday welcomed the Ratners acquisition, pushing Kay's stock up $3.375, to $14.25 a share. The stock was the fifth most active on the New York Stock Exchange, with almost 1.5 million shares traded. **********Kay's high-yield bonds also soared yesterday on the takeover news, Salomon Brothers said, and were the biggest gainers. The 12.875 percent issue due in 1999 rose $15 for each $100 of face value, to $80, and the 12.50 percent issue due in 1996 rose $5, to $65. **********The Ratners stock, however, fell 11 pence on the London market to close at $:2.64, or $4.62 Ratners, which has about a 50 percent share of the British jewelry market, reported pretax profits of $196 million on sales of $1.45 billion in its fiscal year ended Feb. 3, compared with $139 million on sales of $1.3 billion in the previous year. **********With the addition of Kay's 494 stores, Ratners will operate a total of 967 stores in the United States, including the Sterling units, which operate mostly in the Midwest under various names. Peoples, which owns Gordon Jewelry stores as well as Zales, operates about 1,100 stores in the United States between the two chains. **********Kay has four store divisions: Kay Jewelers, with 344 stores; J. B. Robinson, 82 stores; Marcus, with 48 leased departments in department stores, and Black, Starr & Frost, 20 stores. **********Will Sell 2 Units **********In a news conference in London yesterday, Gerald I. Ratner, the chairman and managing director of Ratners, said the company planned to sell the Marcus leased departments and the Black, Starr & Frost stores. He said the company, which already operates about 1,200 stores in Britain, eventually wanted to have as many as 1,500 jewelry stores in the United States. The company, which plans to achieve a 10 percent share of the market in the United States, expects that its share with Kay will now rise to 5.7 percent, from 2.8 percent, even with the sales of Marcus and Black, Starr. **********To acquire Kay, Ratners will issue new preferred stock valued at $17 a share for 12.4 million Kay shares and will assume some debt. Ratners will offer one new Ratners American convertible preferred share for every share of Kay common. One Ratners preferred share will be convertible into three of the Ratners ordinary shares as American depository shares. The $17-a-share value is an estimate by Ratners of the worth of a preferred share upon conversion. **********Ratners said that each preferred share will pay an annual dividend of $1.06, and a listing of the new depository shares will be sought on the NASDAQ. **********Analysts generally said the offer was a fair one for Kay's shareholders and would provide financial relief for Kay. **********''Kay's borrowing ability is enhanced, and the deal provides some relief from the pressures the entire jewelry business faces in this country,'' said Kenneth M. Glassman Jr., a retail analyst for Wheat First Securities, Richmond. ''Retail jewelry sales have been soft, and retailers have been pressured by their high leverage due to carrying so much installment credit.'' **********Although Kay has been a troubled company, Peter C. Keefe, the research director for Johnston, Lemon & Company, an investment banker in Washington, said: ''It's a good deal for the shareholders, but it's really not a bailout for Kay. If it had been, Ratners would not have offered $6 a share above the market price, but less.'' **********Gilbert Harrison, the chairman of Financo Inc., which along with Paine Webber represents Ratners in the Kay acquisition, said, ''This deal has been under way for almost a year. Ratners wanted Kay for its good brand names and strong locations.''
