https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/21/busin.body_text: **********The Zenith Electronics Corporation said today that it was involved in a ''major dispute'' with Groupe Bull of France over the final price for Zenith's computer operations. Groupe Bull described the disagreement as a normal business matter. **********The two companies have agreed to submit the dispute to an accounting firm for arbitration if they cannot resolve it in 60 days. **********On Dec. 28, Groupe Bull paid Zenith $496.4 million in cash, but the companies agreed that the final purchase price was to be set after Groupe Bull took possession of the Zenith operations and determined their value. **********Big Difference of Opinion **********Zenith said it had expected to receive another $55 million from Groupe Bull. Instead, Groupe Bull is seeking a refund of $49 million, plus interest, Zenith said in reporting in its operating results for 1989. **********''Clearly, we have a difference of opinion of significant magnitude,'' Zenith's chairman and president, Jerry K. Pearlman, said in a statement. **********Patrick Marx, a spokesman for Groupe Bull, said price adjustments were a fairly routine aspect of large acquisitions. ''We hardly consider it a major dispute,'' he said. ''Disputes of this nature are not at all unusual.'' **********Under the agreement announced on Oct. 2, the purchase price was to be the book value of the computer operations, plus a $91.9 million premium. At the time, Zenith said the computer business's book value was about $515 million, giving the transaction a value of $607 million. $55 Million Decline On Dec. 28, the closing date, Zenith acknowledged that the book value had fallen by $55 million because of a drop in inventories and receivables, lowering the price of the computer company to approximately $552 million. According to the terms of the contract, Groupe Bull paid Zenith 90 percent of the estimated purchase price, or $496.4 million. **********In reporting its earnings, Zenith said its remaining business, consumer electronics, had declining profits in the fourth quarter but had lost money for the year. The Glenview, Ill., company did not report consolidated earnings that reflected the computer business because of the dispute with Groupe Bull. **********Zenith's consumer electronics business had net income of $4 million, or 15 cents a share, down 46.7 percent from $7.5 million, or 29 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1988. Revenue rose slightly, to $443.2 million, from $439.8 million a year earlier. **********For the year, Zenith's consumer electronics business lost $17 million, compared with a loss of $11 million in 1988. Zenith's sales from continuing operations rose 10.6 percent, to $1.55 billion, from $1.40 billion in 1988. **********Zenith's shares fell 62.5 cents today, to $8.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/27/world.main_headline: U.S. Reaches Trade Deal With Moscow
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/27/world.print_headline: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;   U.S. Reaches Trade Deal With Moscow
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/27/world.body_text: **********The United States announced today that it had reached broad agreement with the Soviet Union on a trade pact that should be ready for President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to sign when they hold their next summit meeting in Washington in late May. **********Once it is approved by Congress, the trade agreement could pave the way for the Soviet Union to be granted most-favored-nation treatment by the United States. This status, already enjoyed by some Eastern European countries, would provide the Soviet Union with additional trade privileges. **********United States tariffs average about 5 percent for countries with most-favored-nation status, but for countries like the Soviet Union that do not have the privilege, they can be 10 times as high - that is, 45 or 50 percent. The United States does not permit the export of some strategic goods to the Soviet Union, but that is a different matter that is not affected by most-favor-nation status. **********Disagreement Over Small Points **********After three days of talks here, the Deputy United States Trade Representative, Julius L. Katz, noted that the two governments were still in disagreement over three or four small points. He declined to identify them, but he said they should be resolved through diplomatic exchanges in the coming weeks. **********There had been some speculation that the talks could be suspended because of Washington's disapproval of Moscow's policies toward Lithuania. Mr. Katz said the Lithuanian crisis was not discussed during the meeting. **********''Fundamentally, we have reached agreement on the text,'' he said. ''It is still the intention that the agreement be signed at the Washington summit between May 30 and June 3.'' **********The agreement would initially be for three years. Then it could automatically be renewed for a further three years if neither side objects. It is expected to bring a moderate increase in bilateral trade, as well as provide the Soviet Union with easier access to American goods needed for its modernization program. **********Toward a Market Economy **********''The agreement looks toward development of a market economy in the Soviet Union but reflects the fact that they are not quite there at this point,'' Mr. Katz said. Before the trade agreement can be signed, President Bush has insisted, the Soviet Union must adopt a new emigration law, a demand that prevented a trade pact signed between the two countries in 1972 from coming into force. **********Mr. Katz said he did not know when Moscow's new legislation would be approved, but he noted that the link between the trade agreement and a more flexible Soviet emigration policy was clear and understood. ''I am not sure if it will be ready in time,'' he said. **********Describing the contents of the provisional agreement, Mr. Katz said that in addition to the exchange of Most Favored Nation treatment, it called for the establishment of trade offices by both governments and travel facilities for Soviet and American businessmen. **********Making It Easier for U.S. Business **********Before the talks began, United States officials said Washington was particularly eager to make it easier for American companies to operate in the Soviet Union, not only as traders but also as investors who can repatriate their profits without difficulty. **********Mr. Katz noted that the two governments planned to sign separate letters dealing with trade facilities, financial relations, tourism and protection of all aspects of intellectual property, such as patents, copyrights and sound recordings. The draft agreement also includes provisions dealing with national security questions. **********He said that Soviet access to official American loans, such as trade financing from the Export-Import Bank, was not covered in the planned trade agreement. He added that the Bush Administration would be required to seek Congressional approval if such a privilege was granted to Moscow.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/05/busin.main_headline: Business Scene; Chemical Industry Faces Oversupply
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/05/busin.print_headline: Business Scene; Chemical Industry Faces Oversupply
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/05/busin.body_text: **********CHEMICAL manufacturers illustrate a troublesome shortcoming of free markets. For three years, they have been expanding operations, even as they worried that their new plants would produce much more than anyone wanted to buy. And, as these plants come on line, their fears are coming true. Chemicals used in the manufacture of hundreds of household items are once again in oversupply. **********That hurts. Consumers might soon get a price break on things like drugs, soap, paint and plastic zipper bags, but profits are down at companies like Dow Chemical, Union Carbide and Monsanto, and some new plants are not being opened on schedule. Dow, for example, had planned to open a huge ethylene plant in Freeport, Tex., in 1992 but will wait until 1993. By then, Dow hopes, the demand for ethylene might again exceed the supply. **********The chemical industry is not alone in going through cycles of abundance and shortage. Similar cycles also afflict steel, paper and other bulk commodities -- and many are entering an oversupply phase today. But chemicals seem to get hit the hardest, perhaps because the industry is so huge and so basic to the rest of manufacturing. **********Half a decade might pass before the demand for chemicals catches up again with the supply. This time around, the weakness in the American economy will almost certainly prolong the process. But the main problem is not the economy; it is that alternating periods of too little production capacity and then too much come in cycles that no one seems to be able to control. **********Peter Spitz, chairman of Chem Systems, an industry consulting firm, explains why. "Imagine it is 1988," he said. "Demand is rising, chemicalplants are operating at full capacity and people are making lots of money. You are a chief executive of a chemical company and you say, 'My God, someone has to build another plant, and it is very profitable.' **********"So you announce a new plant, and one new one is probably okay. But your competitor says, 'I'm not going to let him get ahead of me and steal market share.' So he announces a new plant. And then a third announces. And if you put all these guys in a room, they seem like a crazy industry. But each one has a rationale." **********The emerging oversupply, as new plants come on line in the early 1990's, is greatest at the petrochemical end of the industry. Such basic materials as ethylene and propylene are made in huge quantities and then used to produce specialty chemicals like drugs, fertilizers or plastics. Petrochemicals get hit the hardest because the manufacturing process requires high-output plants to keep down production costs. **********The new Dow plant in Texas, for example, will produce 1.5 billion pounds of ethylene a year, a quantity equal to nearly 4 percent of current ethylene consumption in the United States, which is 39 billion pounds a year. Put another way, the Dow plant, if it were operating today, would produce enough ethylene to cover, by itself, the 3 percent growth in ethylene sales nationwide that is expected this year. And Freeport is not the only new ethylene plant. Some nine billion pounds of production are being added over the next five years, said John Lillich, Dow's director of investor relations. **********The chemical industry also indulged in rapid expansion in the 1970's, resulting in a huge oversupply through much of the 1980's. Operations were closed wholesale and some companies, like Monsanto, switched from commodity petrochemicals to production of specialty items, like fertilizers and synthetic fibers. **********By all accounts, the 1980's crisis frightened the chemical industry, and in the current expansion cycle many efforts are being made to keep growth under control. While Dow and other companies have delayed plant openings, Amoco Petroleum, Oxy Petrochemicals and others have simply canceled plans to build plants. "There was an element of poker playing in the plant announcements," said Peter Coombes, editor of Chemical Week. "They frightened each other into not building." **********But subduing the chemical industry's expansion cycle might not be easy. Sales are still sufficient to keep plants operating at 80 percent to 90 percent of capacity, well ahead of the nightmare levels of the early 1980's. Big chunks of this production are exported, however, thanks to the weak dollar. And new plants opening in East Asia, Latin America and Europe might soon shrink exports. **********The Mideast crisis has also thrown a monkey wrench into the industry. Many petrochemicals are made from petroleum and rising oil prices are forcing the industry to seek price increases for their chemicals -- not an easy task in a weak economy and a period of oversupply. **********Perhaps more frustrating, petrochemical exports from Kuwait, particularly naphtha going to Japan, have been cut off. So the Japanese are shopping in the United States, competing with Monsanto, for example, for the naphtha that Monsanto buys to make synthetic fibers. **********The upshot is temporary shortages and rising naphtha prices, just when new supplies should be bringing down the price, said R. G. Potter, president of Monsanto Chemical. "Basically, the Mideast crisis is overwhelming the overcapacity issue," he added.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/22/world.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;   Top Spy Flees to Soviets
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/22/world.body_text: **********Markus Wolf, the retired chief of East German intelligence, has taken refuge in the Soviet Union to avoid possible arrest at home in an arms export scandal, a West German newspaper reported today. **********He lived in the Soviet Union for many years and once called it his ''second homeland.'' Mr. Wolf is believed to have had close ties to the K.G.B., the Soviet intelligence service. **********The Suddeutsche Zeitung said that East German prosecutors believed that Mr. Wolf was involved in the illegal arms operation and may even have directed it. **********The East German authorities have said the the exports were handled by Alexander Schalck-Golodkowski, chief foreign trader for the ousted Communist Government. **********He fled to West Berlin when the operation was discovered in December and spent several days in jail, but a judge said there were no grounds in West Germany for holding Mr. Schalck-Golodkowski and released him in January. **********Mr. Wolf retired in February 1987 from the State Security Ministry, where he was in charge of the espionage section and directed such agents as Gunter Guillaume, a close aide to Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany in the early 1970's. Mr. Brandt resigned when Mr. Guillaume was unmasked.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/10/busin.main_headline: Zenith Bets the Store on New TV
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/10/busin.print_headline: Zenith Bets the Store on New TV
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/10/busin.body_text: **********Among many consumers, the television sets of the Zenith Electronics Corporation have a reputation as old-fashioned and stodgy. But in stark contrast to that perception, the 67-year-old company is now betting its life on developing a television technology so advanced that most American manufacturers have shied away from it. **********The product is high-definition television, which by providing twice the resolution of current broadcasts can produce images and sounds of movie quality. HDTV technology is also likely to have applications ranging from medical imaging to computer graphics. It will be ''our Normandy landing'' for establishing a strong position in the electronics markets of the future, said Jerry K. Pearlman, the company's chief executive. **********But many industry analysts question whether Zenith, which pioneered FM stereo in 1961 and stereo sound for television in 1984, will be able to survive as an independent company long enough to reach its latest goal. **********For one thing, HDTV research is extremely expensive, and there is no guarantee that the market will materialize soon or in the way Zenith wants. Large Japanese and European companies, as well as a few American companies, have been racing Zenith to develop a desirable HDTV technology. **********For another, Zenith, the last American manufacturer of television sets and maker of the second-most-popular brand, faces intense competition in its existing markets from aggressive, well-financed international competitors like Philips N. V. and Thomson S. A. Also posing a threat are East Asian companies that Zenith has accused of ''dumping'' television sets in the United States at below-market prices, while keeping their home markets closed. **********All told, Zenith's consumer electronics operations, which are dominated by television sets but also include videocassette recorders and video cameras, have not been profitable since 1984, according to company financial statements. **********What is more, the company can no longer look to its profitable computer business, which it sold last December to the French company Groupe Bull to raise cash when a buyer could not be found for the consumer electronics business. **********''This is a company that doesn't make any profits, that is in an intense battle,'' said Russell L. Leavitt, an analyst with Salomon Brothers. ''Unless HDTV develops sooner than expected, it's not clear that Zenith is particularly well positioned.'' **********To complicate matters, Zenith and Groupe Bull are locked in a $100 million dispute over the purchase price of the computer company. Groupe Bull paid $496 million for the business in December and is now demanding a $49 million refund. Zenith maintains it is owed additional money from Bull, perhaps as much as $50 million. **********The initial proceeds from the sale were used to help reduce Zenith's crushing debt load to $222 million, from $560 million. Zenith, under pressure from its banks, faced a severe cash squeeze last fall. **********But investors, skeptical of Zenith's chances, have dropped the company's stock price to $9.125 from a 52-week high of $21.875. The company's shares are trading at about half of the company's book value, or liquidation value, of $16.73. **********Merger Predicted **********And some analysts are questioning whether Zenith will be able to survive much longer without a partner. ''Somewhere down the pike Zenith will join forces with somebody else,'' predicted David Lachenbruch, editorial director of Television Digest, a newsletter. ''There is a view that they are likely to find a complementary manufacturer and get together in terms of a merger. We don't have a lot of companies that are just in the consumer electronics field.'' **********Mr. Lachenbruch speculated that Zenith might combine with a semiconductor maker or an electronics-components manufacturer to become less dependent on the vicissitudes of the consumer-electronics business. Others said Zenith might align with a multinational company to gain access to markets abroad. But Mr. Pearlman said the company planned to remain independent. **********Many of Zenith's problems are attributable to forces outside the company's control and which are not limited to Zenith. The consumer electronics industry as a whole has not been profitable in the United States for the last two decades. A spokesman for Thomson Consumer Electronics Inc., a division of Thomson S. A., which is owned by the French Government, confirmed that its RCA brand, the market leader, has lost tens of millions of dollars in recent years. **********Critical of Competition **********Zenith, which is based in Glenview, Ill., has argued that a big part of the problem is that Japanese and other foreign competitors have been selling their television sets in the United States at extremely low prices in an attempt to gain market share. **********While the Federal Government has issued anti-dumping orders against foreign manufacturers in some countries, including Japan, new low-price producers operating from Thailand, China, Mexico and Malaysia have kept a steady stream of low-priced imports flowing into the country. (To take advantage of low-cost labor, even Zenith makes a number of its television sets in Mexico.) In the face of the brutal price cutting, other United States manufactures have left the business. **********Zenith is also competing against Philips N. V. of the Netherlands and Thomson, two powerful conglomerates that are investing heavily in their United States television operations. Propelled by the largest adverting budget in the industry, about $25 million, Philips, which owns Magnavox and Sylvania, is on the verge of unseating Zenith for the No. 2 position in the market, said Mr. Lachenbruch of Television Digest. Zenith has trailed the market leader, Thomson's RCA brand, for much of the decade. **********Market Share Shrinks **********In 1989, Zenith controlled 12 percent of the market, down from 18.5 percent in 1983, according to Television Digest. **********Although Zenith's products are regarded as technically sound, the company is plagued by an unfashionable image, many retail consultants and industry analysts say. Rodney Pounders, the assistant manager of a Fretter Inc. consumer electronics store in Chicago, said Zenith television sets, with their bulky wood consoles, ''look like the television sets that Grandpa and Grandma used to have.'' **********''When young people come in to buy a TV, they don't buy Zeniths purely because of the way they look,'' Mr. Pounders said. **********Mr. Pearlman acknowledged that product styling had been a problem but said: ''We have done a lot of work in that area. Our current research shows we are getting sharply improved marks.'' Even in 1989, a rare year in which prices for color television sets actually rose (such sets on average cost less than they did in 1963), Zenith's consumer electronics division posted a loss on continuing operations of $17 million, on sales of $1.5 billion. The company attributed the loss to higher material and labor costs. **********Most analysts think that in 1990 Zenith will essentially break even, posting either a small loss or profit. **********With limited resources, Zenith is trying to focus on a two-pronged plan. It is investing heavily in its flat tension mask, a high-resolution color monitor that provides brilliantly clear pictures, even in the glare of direct sunlight. While the mask was developed as a monitor for computers, the company plans to use it as the picture tube in its HDTV system. **********Zenith has already invested millions in research on the masks and plans to invest $30 million over the next two years to modify a factory to make them in varying sizes for computers and eventually for television screens. **********While the product has potential, ''it's not a company maker,'' said Robert M. Johnson, an analyst with Rotan Mosle Inc., a brokerage firm in Houston. **********The other, more important focus, is on HDTV. Zenith will not say how much it is investing in research -only that it is in the millions. The company's engineers face the complex task of developing a new system to broadcast and receive the high-definition television signals, which contain five times as much information as conventional signals. **********F.C.C. Ruling Helps **********The company's proposed method received a boost when the Federal Communications Commission stipulated that conventional sets must be able to receive HDTV broadcasts. By contrast, the satellite-based systems under design in Europe and Japan would make the current generation of television sets obsolete. **********The F.C.C. is expected to select a transmission system as the standard for this country in 1992. Zenith is betting that its system will be selected, providing the company with lucrative royalties from users of HDTV. Even if Zenith's system is not chosen, the company will be able to sell the high-definition television sets it develops. **********To accelerate its HDTV work, Zenith teamed last summer with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in a $24 million research agreement. A.T.&T. is working on the integrated circuitry for a prototype system. **********But Zenith faces serious competition in its HDTV work. A Government-backed effort in Japan includes broadcasters and major electronics companies. This group, which is thought to have the lead, has invested 10 years and $900 million in developing a system, and began daily test broadcasts in Japan last summer. **********European Effort **********A European research consortium financed by Western European governments, with the research being conducted by companies like Philips, Thomson, Bosch and the British Broadcasting Corporation, is developing its own HDTV standard. The consortium plans to have a system ready in time to broadcast the 1992 Olympic Games in Barcelona, Spain. **********Philips and Thomson are also working on a standard in the United States, where they have teamed up with NBC to develop an HDTV system that meets Federal requirements. **********Within the industry, there is a wide divergence of views over how soon HDTV will be commercially viable. Last month, a senior vice president of Thomson Consumer Electronics, Joseph Donahue, said HDTV would not be a money maker until 2005. **********''That is nonsense,'' Mr. Pearlman said. ''If the process keeps moving, we think HDTV is a 1993 consumer electronics product. The widespread view that HDTV isn't coming is only being tossed about by those people who have no system to propose.'' **********Mr. Pearlman has been critical of the Government for providing far less financing for HDTV research than have the Japanese or European governments.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/10/busin.body_text: **********A Federal judge took the first steps yesterday toward consolidating hundreds of thousands of asbestos cases from around the nation into one large class action before him, in what he described as an effort to control the enormous legal costs. **********At a hearing in Brooklyn, Federal District Judge Jack B. Weinstein urged lawyers for scores of defendants and tens of thousands of plaintiffs to agree upon establishing of a class-action lawsuit to achieve ''peace in the national legal war over asbestos.'' **********He indicated that if they did not reach an agreement, he was likely to try to impose it upon them. **********A 'Wasteful' War **********Reaching beyond the more than 500 Brooklyn Navy Yard asbestos cases that are being heard before him, Judge Weinstein said a national solution was required to resolve ''this wasteful, inefficient war over asbestos.'' Asbestos-related cases form the greatest number of personal-injury lawsuits in the nation's state and Federal courts, and are crowding dockets in many jurisdictions. **********The judge's moves toward consolidation are expected to be opposed by the plaintiffs' lawyers, some of whom have reaped enormous fees in individual cases. Nonetheless, if he succeeds, the effect of Judge Weinstein's maneuvering could be to cut back the legal fees substantially and to get some funds to plaintiffs who are now being given i.o.u.'s. **********The sizable legal fees have substantially depleted the trust set up by the Manville Corporation. The trust, which assumes all legal liability from the corporation's asbestos production, enabled it to arise from bankruptcy two years ago. **********In trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, Manville's shares were unchanged at $6.75 each. **********Mismanagement Is Charged **********Several lawyers for plaintiffs and other asbestos defendants have said that the trust is a casualty of mismanagement, of poor planning and of lack of oversight by the bankruptcy judge who set it up two years ago, who had also been warned repeatedly about its decline. **********Originally conceived as a vehicle for keeping court costs down by settling cases promptly, the trust is now a defendant in 90,000 cases before 500 state courts in 374 jurisdictions and in all 96 Federal courts. **********As a first step toward overhauling the deteriorating trust, Judge Weinstein yesterday issued an order effectively freezing it from spending any additional money in settlements or legal expenses. **********For most of the last 50 years, the Manville, based in Denver, was the nation's largest producer of asbestos, a white, flaky, fire-retardant substance once widely used in construction and as insulation. It was later identified as carcinogenic. **********The trust has effectively run out of cash, spending $974 million in settling the first 22,000 cases at an average of $43,509 a claim, well above the trust's architects' projections of $25,000 a claim. It is now facing more than 130,000 claims, and expects no new funds until the final quarter of 1991. **********The trust's problems have forced it to offer a payout proposal to asbestos victims under which tens of thousands are to receive nothing until well into the next century. Many of these victims are elderly and have fatal or serious diseases, including lung cancer, asbestosis and mesothelioma, an often fatal tumor of the lung. **********New Basis of Payment **********Under the trust's existing structure, payments were made based on filing order, rather than on the nature of the disease or the victim's need. Judge Weinstein said yesterday that he would instead take into account the severity of the injury and means of the victim. **********''Those workers and their families who were most seriously injured must secure compensation immediately,'' the judge said. He said he would order the establishment of a structured compensation plan, like workers' compensation. **********The judge told a lawyer for the trust at the hearing that it must operate ''on equal-protection grounds.'' **********''You're practically a quasi-governmental entity,'' Judge Weinstein said. ''These are cases that affect a substantial number of workers across the country.'' **********The judge said he would soon meet privately with Dr. Irving Selikoff, a leading medical scientist in asbestos-related diseases, to ascertain his estimates of asbestos claims. Asbetsos diseases often take decades to become apparent. As a result, Judge Weinstein said he would establish a national registry for potential victims and a system of medical monitoring. **********The trust's general counsel, David Austern, declined to comment yesterday on the judge's actions, saying he would have to take it up with the trustees before deciding what course the trust would pursue. **********Judge Weinstein has lined up a lawyer to serve as a court-appointed special master once he approves a class action. He has also told an analyst from the Rand Corporation, Mark Peterson, to begin work on devising a complex mathematical matrix to be used as basis for compensating victims. Mr. Peterson is expected to be attending the meeting between Judge Weinstein and Dr. Selikoff. **********Judge Weinstein is hearing the Brooklyn Navy Yard cases with Justice Helen E. Freedman of State Supreme Court. Last month, the judges in effect reopened Manville's bankruptcy proceeding by ordering the original bankruptcy judge who approved the trust, Burton R. Lifland, to revamp it. Judge Lifland, in turn, gave the task to Leon Silverman, a partner at the New York law firm of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson, who helped organize the trust. **********Some Meetings Held **********At the hearing yesterday, Mr. Silverman said he had begun meeting with the lawyers for the plaintiffs, defendants and had explored ''realistic options.'' **********He added that the trust's problems reflect a ''broad national problem that is becoming increasingly acute.'' Mr. Silverman did not provide precise details on how the trust would resolve its financial plight. But Judge Weinstein said refinancing could be accomplished through loans or advances from the corporation, or by selling some or all of Manville's stock now in the trust's portfolio. **********The trust's assets include the equivalent of an 80 percent interest in Manville, but the stock cannot be sold unless certain conditions are satisfied. Earlier efforts to sell Manville stock and an effort by the corporation to buy some back have failed. **********People involved in the case said Mr. Silverman told Judge Weinstein privately last week that he intended to support a class-action suit to help resolve the trust's predicament. The judge gave Mr. Silverman until Aug. 6 to devise a restructuring.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/15/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   2d Account Back at Waring
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/15/busin.body_text: **********''Who says you can't go home again?'' a pleased Saul Waring, president of Waring & LaRosa, asked yesterday. **********Six weeks ago, Perrier returned its advertising account to the Waring agency after four years with Hal Riney & Partners. And yesterday morning, Fisher-Price, the children's product and toy company, told Mr. Waring that it would consolidate its domestic advertising account, measured at more than $36 million by Leading National Advertisers, at his agency. **********Waring & LaRosa became **********Fisher-Price's agency in 1969 and helped to build the company's image. But in 1986, Fisher-Price split its account, giving parts to Backer Spielvogel Bates and the J. Walter Thompson Company, as well as to Waring. **********Most recently, Waring advertised infant products; Backer Spielvogel Bates, which will retain the European portion of the account, handled products for young children, and Thompson advertised products for older children. **********Executives at the agencies said the consolidation was unexpected. Strawn Cathcart, the vice president for marketing at Fisher-Price, cited the company's desire to work with a single agency in support of its ''current increased focus on basic products.'' **********Before Mr. Cathcart took his job in February, he had worked with Waring as Fisher-Price's director of marketing for infant products. A spokeswoman said that Fisher-Price's long association with the agency, and not this particular connection, made the difference.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/22/world.main_headline: Pakistan Plans to Try Hijackers Of Soviet Jet, but Moscow Differs
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/22/world.print_headline: Pakistan Plans to Try Hijackers Of Soviet Jet, but Moscow Differs
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/22/world.body_text: **********Eleven convicts from a Siberian labor camp who hijacked a Soviet jetliner to Pakistan and requested political asylum will go on trial here, Pakistani television said today. But the Soviet press agency Tass reported that the hijackers would be extradited to the Soviet Union. There was no explanation for the differing reports. **********The convicts surrendered on Monday two hours after the Aeroflot TU-154 landed here with 29 passengers and nine crew members. **********Pakistan's official television network said the hijackers were being interrogated and would be put on trial in Pakistan. A Foreign Office spokesman said no formal extradition request had been received from Moscow. **********Soviets Sending Escorts **********But Tass quoted Gulyam Aliyev, deputy K.G.B. chairman in the southern republic of Uzbekistan as saying that Soviet law officers would travel to Karachi to escort the prisoners home. **********Pakistan has in the past refused to extradite hijackers, preferring to put them on trial here. Palestinian guerrillas involved in a 1986 Pan Am hijacking that ended in Karachi were tried in Pakistan. One was sentenced to death and the others to long prison terms. The death sentence has not been carried out. **********The Soviet hijacking began on Sunday when convicts from a Siberian labor camp overpowered their guards and took over the jet as it was flying from Neryungry, where the prison is located, to the nearby city of Yakutsk. **********The prisoners forced the commercial aircraft back to Neryungri, where 6 prisoners and 41 women and children got off. Two more convicts then boarded, and the aircraft flew west to Krasnoyarsk in Siberia. **********Changed Destinations **********After two hours of negotiations, the plane was refueled and flew to the Soviet city of Tashkent, where a new crew came on board and the hijackers demanded to leave the country. **********They originally wanted to go to New Delhi but were allowed to land in Karachi because the plane was low on fuel. **********There have been at least 13 hijackings or attempted hijackings of Soviet aircraft since late in May. **********Tass quoted a Deputy Interior Minister, Ivan Shilov, as saying that there would be an investigation into how the convicts managed to commandeer the plane. The agency said one of the prisoners apparently smuggled weapons onto the fight in an artificial limb.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/16/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   China Cancels Grumman Deal
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/16/busin.body_text: **********China has pulled out of a $502 million deal under which the United States had agreed to help modernize 55 Chinese F-8 fighter jets, the Pentagon said today. **********Cancellation of the deal, with the Grumman Corporation of Bethpage, L.I., to provide new cockpit electronics and radar, follows President Bush's suspension of arms sales to China last June because of the crackdown on demonstrators. **********''I can't tell you why the Chinese made this decision,'' a Pentagon spokesman, Pete Williams, told reporters. He said China notified Washington of the decision last month. **********Mr. Williams said there had been no decision on when to return two F-8 jets to China. The aircraft were shipped here to be updated by Grumman. **********In New York, a Grumman spokeswoman, Miriam Reid, expressed disappointment. **********''We certainly had expected production to go forward,'' she said, adding it was an important program to Grumman because of its size and the potential for military work with China. **********Grumman's shares rose 12.5 cents today, to $14.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/27/world.main_headline: Mulroney Hints at Force Against Mohawks
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/27/world.print_headline: Mulroney Hints at Force Against Mohawks
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/27/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Brian Mulroney said today that unreasonable demands by militant Mohawk Indians may force the Canadian Government to send in the army to end six-week-old standoffs at two places in Quebec. **********Mr. Mulroney told reporters that he was tired of Mohawk stalling while the federal and Quebec governments negotiated in good faith. He called some of the Mohawk demands ''bizarre'' and said they would never be accepted by the federal Government. **********If the Mohawks do not begin negotiating seriously, Mr. Mulroney said, he may have to send in troops to clear Indian roadblocks in Oka and Chateauguay. **********The tense standoff at Oka, west of Montreal, was touched off by the Town Council's attempt to expand a golf course on land claimed by the Mohawks. A Quebec provincial police officer was shot and killed during an aborted raid on the Mohawk barricade on July 11. It is not clear which side shot him. South of Montreal, Mohawks at the Kahnawake reservation blocked a commuter bridge near Chateauguay in support of the Oka Mohawks. **********Canadian officials have attributed the roadblocks to a Mohawk group called the Warriors Society, which says Canada has no jurisdiction on Mohawk land.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/07/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;   Magazine Revenues Increase by 10.9%
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/07/busin.body_text: **********Advertising revenues in magazines monitored by the Publishers Information Bureau rose to $6.642 billion in 1989, up 10.9 percent from the year before, according to figures released by the bureau. Advertising pages rose 3.5 percent, to 177,000. **********Time remained the revenue leader, increasing 6.8 percent, to $373 million. Business Week remained the page leader, increasing 7.1 percent, to 4,914. **********Among the leaders in revenue gains were The Atlantic, up 39.9 percent; Conde Nast Traveler, up 78 percent; Country Home, up 38 percent; Entrepreneur, up 68.5 percent; and Vanity Fair, up 51.1 percent. **********Magazines that lost revenue include Jet, down 6.5 percent; Manhattan,inc., down 10 percent, and National Journal, down 17.6 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/11/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;   Rates Increase At Citicorp Sale
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/11/busin.body_text: **********Interest rates rose modestly yesterday at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper. **********The bank holding company sold $50 million in 91-day paper at an average rate of 8.21 percent, up from 8.16 percent last week, but still below the 8.23 percent rate at the end of June. **********Citicorp said it also sold $50 million in 182-day paper at an average rate of 8.16 percent, up from 8.092 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/21/busin.main_headline: Avrett Finds Way to Offer Global Link
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/21/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;   Avrett Finds Way to Offer Global Link
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/21/busin.body_text: **********''WE'RE more like the old-fashioned agencies that have grown with their clients,'' said Jack Avrett. But even though his agency, Avrett, Free & Ginsberg, has resisted the acquisition offers that flow to small, successful package-goods agencies like congratulatory telegrams to newlyweds, Mr. Avrett and his colleagues have found another way to grow: Concord International. **********Concord is one of several networks of advertising agencies from around the world that share creative and marketing philosophies but not ownership. These networks, based in Europe, act as matchmakers, referring one member agency's client to a member in another country, and allowing members to seek clients that may need international service the individual agency could not supply. **********''The whole philosophy is that we can lead clients into new markets through agencies of quality and independence,'' said Stuart Grau, Avrett's vice president and director of new business development. **********Avrett (the ''a'' is long, as in agency) has already benefited, albeit mildly, from its recent decision to join Concord. It has been invited into two agency reviews, for an Italian gourmet-food company and for a European textile manufacturer. Each client wants to expand its marketing into the United States. **********For advertisers, the affiliate network concept allows the creation of global brands that ''have a common identity in every market'' and require ''consistent branding and communications'' to appeal to international consumers, as the network's literature states. While this is a rationale behind the formation of the large multinational marketing communications conglomerates in recent years, ''Concord is for clients who like smaller agencies and entrepreneurs,'' said Mr. Avrett, his agency's chairman. **********In addition to Avrett, Concord's members include agencies in Belgium, France, West Germany, Britain, Italy, the Netherlands, Spain and Switzerland. **********Since its birth 19 years ago, Avrett has been known for slowly pushing the boundaries of packaged-goods advertising, gently drawing marketers of over-the-counter drugs and pet foods away from their traditional reliance on copy toward more visually exciting television ads. ''We've placed an enormous concentration on visual impact in categories not accustomed to it,'' said Frank Ginsberg, the agency's president and creative director. **********Even though the agency does a lot of copy-testing, Mr. Ginsberg says frankly that such research does not work and foresees less use of it on behalf of packaged-goods advertisers in coming years. **********For years, Avrett was known as the ''chow, chow, chow'' agency, after its 1973-74 commercials for Purina Cat Chow that helped popularize anthropomorphic animals as a marketing device. **********Mr. Ginsberg also claims credit for introducing the pop music of the 1950's and 60's to mainstream advertising, with the agency's 1975 campaign for Nair depilatories that featured the tune ''Who Wears Short Shorts?'' **********More recently, the 100-person agency, which bills about $130 million annually, tried an unusual tack with its ads for Del Webb's Claridge Casino Hotel in Atlantic City. Eschewing the glitz and glamour of most casino advertising, Avrett shot a quiet black-and-white commercial with an actor playing a high roller explaining why he prefers the Claridge. **********''We turned their problems into strengths,'' Mr. Avrett said. ''It's the smallest casino, so we positioned it as intimate.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/02/busin.main_headline:
NEW JERSEY CONVERSIONS;
Condo Is Helping Buyers to Meet the Down Payment
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/02/busin.print_headline:
NEW JERSEY CONVERSIONS;
Condo Is Helping Buyers to Meet the Down Payment
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/02/busin.body_text: **********Despite a sluggish market and flat prices for all residential properties, first-time buyers still face a large obstacle to homeownership: Saving enough money for a down payment. **********Recognizing this, a New Jersey sponsor of a condominium conversion is trying to help potential purchasers stretch their dollars at a 227-unit building in East Orange, N.J. The sponsor is offering a "use and occupancy fee program" to fill 100 vacant apartments in the 24-story building, called Executive House on Prospect Street. **********The development is on a prime residential strip in this city of 85,000 residents, 13 miles from the Lincoln Tunnel. The condominium is owned by Executive House Associates, a team of investors from New York, Boston, Connecticut and London. They also did the converting. **********The partners bought the structure, built in 1965, nearly two years ago and invested $3.5 million in renovations. They installed new air-conditioning systems and improved amenities, including a swimming pool and two tennis courts. There is a range of apartment types, from studios to three-bedroom units. Typical prices for vacant one-bedroom apartments range from $70,000 to $90,000, and for two-bedroom units from $105,000 to $110,000. **********Under the program, buyers contract to occupy an apartment for one year on a leased basis at a monthly cost equivalent to the market rent. Half of this so-called occupancy fee is returned to purchasers to put toward a down payment on the units, selling from $57,500 to $139,750, if they decide to buy by the end of the year. Otherwise buyers may extend the contract, or continue to lease the unit and forfeit the rebate. **********The cost of the units, most of which have terraces, is locked in when the contract is signed, but would be lowered if prices fall, Mr. Lieberman said. That price includes a space in an 260-car garage. The monthly maintenance fees range from $159 to $420, excluding utilities. Units are refurbished with new kitchens and baths once a buyer receives a mortgage commitment. **********The occupancy fee -- which includes monthly maintenance -- ranges from $575 for a studio to $1,350 for a three-bedroom apartment. These fees are comparable to the rents paid by many tenants in the 127 renter-occupied apartments, which are rent-controlled. Under New Jersey law, renters who do not choose to buy are entitled to lease renewals for three years after conversion. The elderly and disabled have unlimited renewal rights. **********Barry Lieberman, one of the investors, said the intent was "to provide a way for purchasers to get half their down payment and an incentive for them to close on their units." He said failure by a renter-occupant to buy would not necessarily mean that a rental lease would not be renewed. **********On a $90,000 one-bedroom unit, for instance, the average monthly occupancy fee of $850 would generate $5,100 toward a down payment, Mr. Lieberman said. **********Sponsors hope such promotions will lead to sales in a weak market that has hurt entry-level housing most. **********"The condominium market in New Jersey is still sliding into the abyss and there is no real improvement expected through 1991," said James W. Hughes, chairman of the Department of Urban Policy and Planning at Rutgers. Changes in the tax laws, tightened financing and an uncertain economic climate also took a toll. **********The East Orange area has a stockpile of condominiums in all price ranges, said Sandy Nash, manager of the Livingston office of Weichert Realtors. Prices have declined 10 percent over the last year, she said, noting that the average selling price for a two-bedroom condominium is now $105,000. **********While programs like the one at Executive House are viewed as an effective marketing tool, they are not being used at every conversion. For the concept to work, said Dr. Hughes, there should be a wide enough margin between what the sponsor paid for the unit and its market price and a sufficient rental income from the building. "Sponsors also need deep pockets and the staying power to wait a year for units to be sold," he said. **********The program's success also depends on whether the buyer is able to secure a mortgage. For their part, sponsors should have a financing package with an approved lender available to buyers, said Elliot R. Jacobs, president of the Home Investors Mortgage Corporation of Hackensack, N.J., a subsidiary of Constellation Bancorp, a bank holding company. Mr. Lieberman said he and his partners expected to have financing in place before the year ends. He said 32 contracts had been signed since the program began in September. **********Dexter Humphrey, an electrical engineer for Bell Labortories in Murray Hill, N.J., rents an apartment elsewhere in East Orange, and is taking advantage of the program to buy a two-bedroom unit. "It is giving us the necessary time and money to achieve homeownership," Mr. Dexter said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/18/world.main_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Romania;   ROMANIAN LEADERS COURTING MILITARY
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/18/world.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Romania;   ROMANIAN LEADERS COURTING MILITARY
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/18/world.body_text: **********The provisional Government's abrupt dismissal of Defense Minister Nicolae Militaru on Friday after days of protests by army officers is the latest step in its troubled quest for post-revolutionary credibility. **********Demonstrations are almost a daily affair here now, nearly two months after the downfall of the dictatorship of President Nicolae Ceausescu. **********Protesters are demanding more pay for truck drivers, objective news reports on television, an end to Communism, and, above all, the rooting out of the secret police apparatus, the Securitate. Yet even when the slogans are angry, the crowds seem good-natured, enjoying and testing their new freedom. **********Perhaps the most startling protest came this week, when scores of uniformed officers from the army and air force staged what was in effect a four-day sit-in at the seat of Government, the Foreign Ministry building on Victory Square. The protesters, supported by hundreds of other officers and many more students and civilians, demanded the ouster of General Militaru and the Minister of Internal Security, Gen. Mihai Chitac.  Tense Talks Are Shown on TV Romanian television, a focus of political conflict in its own right, finally broadcast scenes of the officers meeting with a Government representative, Vice President Gelu Voican Voiculescu, hammering on the table as they made their points. **********The protest was the Government's most serious challenge to date, for the military played a crucial role in the earliest hours of the revolution, and its alienation could be a major threat. **********The soldiers' refusal in December to fire on protesting students caused Mr. Ceausescu to flee within hours. They also secured the revolution by battling the diehard security police and executing the dictator and his wife, Elena, after a cursory military trial. **********For the army officers, the immediate issue is the second-class status they suffered under Mr. Ceausescu. The late dictator had funneled most of the money and the most sophisticated arms and equipment to the Securitate, his own elite President Guard and the anti-terrorist unit that fought to quash the rebellion. **********Diplomats said that although military service was universal, the army was used mostly for conscript labor, harvesting potatoes, building roads and digging canals. A lack of training and discipline was obvious in the streets during the revolution, as soldiers fired off rifle volleys and barrages of tank fire, ripping the tops off buildings at the slightest perceived threat. **********A Search for Untainted Generals **********The army protesters, mostly junior officers including a few colonels, contended this week that General Militaru, who was brought back from retirement at the age of 73, was too old and too much a part of the old regime. Their list of demands said he had created ''a state of tension in the army.'' **********His successor, Lieut. Gen. Anastase Stanculescu, was on a list of approved candidates suggested by the protesters. But General Stanculescu, who served as First Deputy Defense Minister under the old regime, is another example of the provisional leadership's difficulty in finding leaders untouched by Romania's dark past. **********Appearing today before about 200 officers assembled in the ornate Parliament building, President Ion Iliescu said that General Stanculescu ''has prestige in the army and is appreciated by its command.'' He said General Militaru had failed to establish ''real communication with the army's command'' and ''aggravated the situation to a point where it became a source of tension in the whole society.'' **********But indicating the political difficulties that he and the Government face, Mr. Iliescu also complained of ''an atmosphere of terror and distrust, inherited from the dictatorial regime.'' **********No Word on Security Minister **********There was no immediate word on the future of the Internal Security Minister, General Chitac, who has been accused by insurgent officers of ordering troops to fire on demonstrators in Timisoara in the first days of protests preceding the revolution. Under the agreement that ended the officers' sit-in, a Government investigation on the army's role during the revolution is supposed to be completed in two weeks. **********But the Government appeared to be mounting a defense of General Chitac, with a report on state television saying that he had avoided using chemical grenades in Timisoara.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/10/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;   New Sallie Mae Note Offering
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/10/busin.body_text: **********The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, yesterday priced $650 million in floating-rate notes due April 11, 1991, at a price of par to yield 45 basis points more than the 91-day Treasury equivalent yield. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. **********Interest on the floating-rate notes, which Sallie Mae generally offers each month, will be adjusted on the day after each weekly Treasury bill auction, with interest paid at maturity. The notes are issued in book entry form and not bearer form, in $1,000 amounts and $1,000 increments thereafter.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/31/world.main_headline: Arab Nations Consider Shift in Tactic Used Against Israel at U.N.
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/31/world.print_headline: MIDEAST TENSIONS; Arab Nations Consider Shift in Tactic Used Against Israel at U.N.
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/31/world.body_text: **********Arab countries are discussing a proposal to end the efforts they have made since 1982 to expel Israel from the United Nations at this year's General Assembly, Arab diplomats said today. **********The Arabs are considering an alternative under which the General Assembly would reaffirm Israel's obligation to obey resolutions of the Security Council and the General Assembly. **********The Security Council is expected to debate Israel-related issues in the next few days when the Secretary General of the United Nations sends his recommendations for better protecting Palestinians under Israeli rule. The moves follow the killings of Palestinians at Al Aksa Mosque in Jerusalem on Oct. 8 after the stoning of Jewish worshipers at the Western Wall. **********After a meeting of Arab representatives to discuss the new strategy today, the chairman, Mohammed A. Abdulhasan of Kuwait, said they need more time to consult with their governments about the plan, which is being promoted by the Palestine Liberation Organization. **********The General Assembly is to debate the report of its credentials committee on Wednesday when the Arabs traditionally mount their challenge to the Israeli delegation. But Mr. Abdulhassan said he will probably now seek a postponement. **********For the last eight years the Arabs have sought to amend the credentials committee's report to strike out the Israeli delegation, effectively expelling Israel from the General Assembly. By tradition one of the Nordic countries then introduces a procedural resolution proposing that the Assembly take no action on the Arab motion, effectively accepting the Israeli delegation's credentials. **********This Nordic motion to admit Israel has been winning by an increasing majority in recent years. In 1978, 85 countries voted to admit Israel by supporting the Nordic motion, while 39 voted for expulsion and the rest either abstained or were absent. Last year only 35 countries voted to expel Israel, while 95 voted for admission. The Soviet Union, which traditionally has voted with the Arabs, abstained. **********South Africa, the only other United Nations member that is excluded from the General Assembly, does not even bother to submit its delegation's credentials for approval. Support Wanes **********Arab diplomats say they might drop their challenge to Israel this year, citing falling support and their expectation that the Soviet Union would vote in favor of admitting Israel. But at the same time, they want to focus world attention on Israel's continued occupation of land it seized in the 1967 Arab-Israeli war. **********They also calculate that an attempt to link Israel's admission to its obligation under the United Nations charter to respect Security Council and other resolutions dealing with the occupied territories would win much broader support than another attempt to expel Israel. **********"What we really want is to affirm Israel's duty to obey the Security Council's resolution on Jerusalem and the occupied territories," said Nasser al-Kidwa, the Palestine Liberation Organization's observer at the United Nations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/06/busin.main_headline: Curbs Are Placed On Coast Savings
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/06/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Curbs Are Placed On Coast Savings
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/06/busin.body_text: **********Coast Savings Financial Inc., the parent of the nation's 10th-largest savings institution, said it did not expect to meet a new Government requirement for financial strength and that Federal regulators had placed restrictions on its operations. Coast said bids for 27 branches of its Coast Federal Bank it had put up for sale were lower than expected and that it would not sell its eight branches in central California. **********Without the sales, the company said, it expected to fall short of the Government's new requirement for risk-based capital. Analysts had estimated that the sales would bring a gain of about $60 million. Coast, based in Los Angeles, said Federal regulators plan to restrict its ability to increase its liabilities and will require the company to file a plan within 60 days detailing how it plans to meet the capital requirements.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/19/world.main_headline: Salvador Peace Talks End in Bitterness
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/19/world.print_headline: Salvador Peace Talks End in Bitterness
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/19/world.body_text: **********Six days of talks between the Salvadoran Government and leftist rebels ended here today with both sides saying there was almost no chance of a cease-fire before elections next March. **********The two sides said the latest round of talks, the sixth in a series that was intended to culminate in a Sept. 15 cease-fire, had failed to make any substantial progress and even appeared to be regressing on the main point - guerrilla demands for substantial changes in the Salvadoran armed forces. **********''Leaving here empty-handed is a major setback,'' said Col. Mauricio Vargas, the military's representative on the Government delegation. ''Everything the Government does is seen as insufficient and everything it doesn't do as a reason to fight.'' **********Ana Guadalupe Martinez, a senior member of the rebel delegation, said: ''It has been terrible. Their commission isn't here to negotiate, it's here to buy time.'' **********New Meeting Scheduled **********The only agreement to emerge from the talks was to meet again, ''no later than Nov. 4.'' **********But representatives of the two sides and a diplomat monitoring the negotiations said that the campaign for next March's legislative and municipal elections was likely to delay any substantial progress until after the vote. **********Without progress in the negotiations, leftist parties allied with the rebels are considered likely to boycott the elections, raising new questions about the vote's legitimacy and setting back United States efforts to promote a democratic resolution of the differences between the two sides. **********The rebels said they would try to capitalize on El Salvador's longing for peace by launching a national and international ''political offensive.'' They proposed a brief cease-fire so that a guerrilla delegation could travel to San Salvador for a nationally televised debate with the Government, but the Government rejected the idea. **********The guerrilla campaign, which comes amid indications that the rebels have nearly completed plans for a military offensive, also is to include what amounts to be a promotional tour of the United States and the publication next week of the most detailed overview of their philosophy and goals in several years. It is being billed as an effort to show how they have adapted to the collapse of the Communist bloc and how an orthodox Marxist-Leninist revolutionary movement has been transformed into a pluralistic, democratic group. A Response to the U.S.  The political offensive is an effort to increase international pressure on the rightist Government of President Alfredo Cristiani and a response to American charges that the guerrillas are an anacronism, little more than a violent vestige of Soviet expansionism and revolutionary romanticism. **********But the campaign also appears to be an effort to marshal domestic political support and rebuild a consensus in the sometimes fractious rebel ranks. Some guerrillas and their civilian allies have openly criticized their commanders for publicly abandoning the goal of a military victory. **********The rank and file's criticism became acute two months ago when the two sides signed a human rights accord, the first formal agreement since the start of the war. Combatants said that the agreement - which will give the United Nations broad responsibility to investigate abuses - handcuffed the guerrillas by drawing them into the peace process without requiring substantial Government concessions.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/19/busin.print_headline: Banks Seen Closer to Trump Pact
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/19/busin.body_text: **********Bankers negotiating a $60 million loan package for Donald J. Trump moved closer to agreement yesterday after the contributions of some large New York banks were reduced, people involved in the talks said. **********The Bankers Trust New York Corporation and Citicorp were allowed to reduce their contribution by roughly 25 percent, they said, in exchange for increased contributions from the Chase Manhattan Corporation and the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company. **********Over the weekend, the banks had been involved in a dispute about how much each would contribute and the quality of the collateral each would receive. **********Issue of Collateral **********Also at issue was what collateral would be used to secure any new loan. Last week, the major banks had temporarily agreed that the Trump Plaza, one of the developer's Atlantic City properties, would be used to secure the new loan. It was not clear how much control of his holdings Mr. Trump would have to sacrifice to secure new financing. **********The plan under discussion is to lend the troubled developer $60 million and temporarily suspend some of his interest payments on about $2 billion in debt. Bankers also said yesterday that there was some discussion of lending Mr. Trump a little more than $60 million, but that no decisions were made. **********''Once these big banks agree in principle again, the task will become convincing the foreign banks again to go along,'' a banker said. ''If the foreign banks do not go along - particularly those in the Citibank and Chase syndicates - we still do not have a deal.'' **********The banker also said there was pressure in the meeting to get the agreement done by tomorrow or Thursday, in time to give Mr. Trump the money to make a $43 million payment due to his bondholders next Tuesday. The meetings are now expected to go around the clock and, those involved said, the attention will shift to the Japanese members of the syndicate. **********Guaranteed Loans **********Bank officials and attorneys also said the amount of personally guaranteed loans that Mr. Trump got from the banks was around $400 million. The bankers and attorneys asserted that the largest share of these personally guaranteed loans was from Bankers Trust and totaled $140 million. They also said Citibank had made more than $100 million of such loans to the developer. **********Mr. Trump, who on Friday failed to make payments to banks and bondholders, faces a cash squeeze that could push his real estate and gambling empire into bankruptcy. He is in technical default on about $352 million of bonds used to finance one of his Atlantic City casinos, but has a 10-day grace period in which to make payment to bondholders and avoid an actual default. According to First Fidelity Bancorp, the retiring trustee on the bonds, the 10-day grace period will expire at midnight next Tuesday. **********Bankers involved in the talks with representatives of the Trump Organization also denied a report that the developer was threatening some of the banks with the possibility that he might file for bankruptcy protection. **********''He has been very professional about the whole thing,'' the banker said. ''In fact, he has been very nice about it because there is no benefit to him either if he goes into bankruptcy, because it would destroy his name.'' **********The meetings of bankers are generally run by Joseph Manganello, executive vice president and chief credit officer at Bankers Trust. Mr. Manganello, who directs Bankers Trust's major ''workouts,'' or attempts to salvage troubled assets, is in charge of the ''offering sheet,'' which is the list of terms that the bankers debate for hours at a time. **********According to several people in the meetings, which include at least two representatives from each of six banks, Mr. Manganello runs the offering sheet chiefly because Bankers Trust, along with Citibank, is one of the banks with the largest loan exposures to Mr. Trump and it would be contributing a major portion of the proposed loan package. **********Bonds related to Mr. Trump's casinos were slightly lower or steady yesterday in thin trading. Trump's Castle bonds that mature in 1997 and carry a 13 3/4 percent interest rate were at about $55 for each $100 of face value, down about $4 since Friday. Bonds associated with the Taj Mahal traded about $53, holding fairly steady since Friday, and the bonds of Trump Plaza traded at about $84, also largely unchanged.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/25/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Support Sought By UAL Pilots
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/25/busin.body_text: **********United Airlines pilots, struggling to complete a proposed $4.4 billion buyout of the carrier, today accused the chairman of the UAL Corporation, Stephen M. Wolf, of trying to undermine their effort. **********In a letter to pilots, the **********United Airlines unit of the Air Line Pilots Association said Mr. Wolf was telling the company's board that employee ownership was not widely supported by the union's members. **********''Unfortunately, some members of the board believe him, and the board will decide our collective future on Oct. 9 based on Mr. Wolf's allegations,'' the group said. **********The pilot-led group has until **********Oct. 9 to arrange financing for the $201-a-share deal, which the board accepted in April. UAL stock fell sharply after the release of the four-page letter. **********UAL was off $8.50 a share today, to $92.25, on the New York Stock Exchange. **********UAL said in a statement that its executives had not yet seen the union's letter and thus could not comment. ''There is, however, a growing concern within the industry and among United employees about being a highly leveraged carrier during these uncertain economic times,'' the company said. **********The union is asking every **********United Airlines pilot to convey support of the proposed buyout to the UAL board by letter or Mailgram.
