https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/11/world.main_headline: Rights Group Assails Iraq for 'Ruthless' Repression
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/11/world.print_headline: Rights Group Assails Iraq for 'Ruthless' Repression
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/11/world.body_text: **********A new human-rights monitoring group, Middle East Watch, assailed the Government of Iraq today for what the group termed ruthless suppression of dissent, apparently seeking to counter Baghdad's assertions that it has entered a period of liberalization in the aftermath of the Iran-Iraq war. **********In a report published today, the New York-based group concludes that the Iraqi Government ''denies its citizens virtually all basic rights and ruthlessly suppresses even the small gesture of dissent.'' The organization said that among the abuses it documented were ''forced relocation and deportation, arbitrary arrest and detention, torture, disappearance, and summary and political execution.'' **********The organization describes itself as a nongovernment group linked with other human rights groups that form Human Rights Watch, set up in 1987. **********It said it was not able to visit Iraq to substantiate its findings, which were based on ''scores of interviews in the United States and Europe with Iraqi emigres, Western diplomats and journalists, and others who have spent time in Iraq.'' The publication of the report coincides with Iraqi statements suggesting that greater political freedoms are being permitted in a country long viewed as one of the most repressive in the Middle East. Recently, President Saddam Hussein said a new constitution was being prepared to enhance freedoms. **********The Iraqi authorities offered no immediate comment on the Middle East Watch report, which called Iraq ''a well-organized police state'' and ''one of the most brutal and repressive regimes in power today.'' **********The report took exception to policies of both the Reagan and Bush Administrations, saying that they put ''the nurturing of new, friendly relations with the Iraqi Government well ahead of human rights considerations.'' Criticism of the U.S.  Despite Iraq's use of chemical weapons and its human rights abuses, the report said, the United States resumed credit guarantees to Iraq for the purchase of American agricultural products. ''The Bush Administration has given only lukewarm support to Western efforts to condemn Iraqi abuses before the U.N. Human Rights Commission,'' it said. **********''Today most observers of the Iraqi scene judge the repression to have been so successful that, outside the Kurdish areas, virtually no known opposition remains,'' the report said. Iraq has a Kurdish minority whose numbers are disputed but are generally reckoned by Western diplomats in Baghdad to account for about one-fifth of a population estimated at 16 million. **********For decades, Baghdad has sought to crush Kurdish dissent and, after a cease-fire stilled the Iran-Iraq war in August 1988, the Iraqi Govenment was widely accused of using chemical warfare to quell Kurdish revolt, a charge Baghdad denied. **********Iraq has been accused of severe human rights abuses for years and has generally sought to deny widespread assertions that it is a state run by secret police agencies loyal to President Hussein. **********'Public Relations Effort' **********The report said that, in addition to denials, Baghdad had also sought to ''obscure its violations'' through ''secrecy, initimdation, false and misleading claims, lobbying in international fora and a public relations effort in the United States tutored by hired advocates and abetted by a growing business lobby.'' **********The report is available for $15 from Human Rights Watch, 485 Fifth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/11/busin.body_text: **********The company earned $67.7 million, or $1.67 a share, on sales of $3.8 billion in 1989. In the process, it sold 13 billion bananas, about a third of the world's supply of the fruit. Bananas are by far the world's most popular fruit. **********Now emboldened, the company is beginning to spread the Chiquita name to other fruits and packaged goods and to push into new markets, particularly Eastern Europe. **********Keith Lindner said his company's first big target would be the Dole Food Company, the world's No. 2 banana producer, behind Chiquita. **********''We would like to buy the company,'' Mr. Lindner said. ''We will be a very competitive bidder on that.'' He said that when formal bidding started, probably this month, Dole would probably fetch $1.6 billion to $2.5 billion and that Chiquita would probably bid on the low end of that range. Dole's parent corporation, Castle & Cooke Inc., said it was considering selling Dole to concentrate on the real estate business, but would not say when it would actually accept bids. **********The Lindners' path in pushing Chiquita to where it is now was not entirely smooth. They broke up the United Brands conglomerate, selling $150 million worth of operations, ranging from a feed business to a telecommunications company. **********Efforts to make the meatpacking operations of Chiquita's John Morrell & Company unit more profitable led to a series of bitter clashes with union meatpackers. **********In 1989, the National Labor Relations Board contended that Morrell had illegally tried to circumvent union contracts by closing two meatpacking plants and reopening them with lower-paid workers. **********Keith Lindner attributes the labor problems and allegations of safety lapses to former management. The plants in question were closed in 1982 and 1983, before the Lindners had a controlling interest. **********Founded in 1899 **********Founded in 1899 as the United Fruit Company, it changed its name in March to Chiquita, its foremost brand name, and the corporate headquarters were moved to Cincinnati. **********Before the Lindners took over, the company was known nearly as well for its links to a coup and payments of bribes in Central American countries, where it grows most of its bananas, as for its fruit. Later a failed diversification effort and mismanagement of the company's banana empire took it to the verge of bankruptcy. **********While the company has since benefited from a long rise in demand for bananas and the consequent higher prices, management, especially Keith Lindner, has received high marks. **********''Efficient and modern distribution is the key to success for Chiquita,'' said Timothy S. Ramey, an analyst at County NatWest USA. He said the company had improved its profit margins by careful management of its shipping costs, for instance. **********People eat more bananas than any other fruit, Chiquita and food-industry analysts say. The Agriculture Department said per capita consumption of bananas in the United States in 1988 was 24 pounds out of a total per capita fruit consumption of 97 pounds. Apples were No. 2 in the United States, with under 20 pounds consumed per person. **********Still, some analysts warn that it is just a matter of time before a down cycle begins. Bananas are highly perishable, leaving producers with little room to manipulate supply and shape prices. And, while prices are strong now, high prices typically result in increased production, which eventually causes prices to plummet. **********For that reason, Michael Kennedy, an analyst with IDS Financial Services Inc. in Minneapolis, said he was avoiding Chiquita stock. ''I know what the ending is,'' he said. ''I just don't know how many chapters are in the book.'' **********Keith Lindner, 31 years old, acknowledged banana prices were volatile but maintained that much of the volatility was from quarter to quarter. **********More Stock Issued **********In May, Chiquita completed a 6.1-million-share secondary offering at $20.125 a share. Since then, more Wall Street analysts have begun following the company, and many have issued buy recommendations. The Lindner family still controls about 63 percent of Chiquita and plans to maintain a controlling interest. **********Earlier this year, the stock reached a high of $29.75, before falling along with the turbulent market. [Chiquita gained $1 Monday, closing at $25.75 a share on the New York Stock Exchange.]  Well Positioned While many companies are talking about exploiting Eastern Europe's newly opened markets, Chiquita already enjoys 43 percent of Western Europe's banana trade and is in an unusually strong position to profit immediately from the opening of new markets. **********In the United States, Chiquita has just begun placing the Chiquita name on a growing number of products like kiwis, melons and pineapples. Fresh fruit represents 45 percent of the Chiquita's sales and more than 90 percent of operating profits. **********The company is also marketing packaged goods like Chiquita Caribbean Splash, a blended juice that is being introduced nationally this year. **********The company's prepared foods division, mostly meats and packaged goods, accounted for 54.6 percent of sales in 1989 but only 7 percent of profits. Banana sales bring in 60 percent of the company's profits. **********The company intends to push its meat group, including John Morrell, harder. It also sells meats under the brand names Rath Black Hawk, Partridge and Scott Petersen. The meat group also makes and sells Nathan's Famous hot dogs under license from Nathan's Famous Inc. **********Some analysts said they were surprised at Chiquita's plan to bid for Dole because of potential antitrust problems. But Mr. Lindner said that would not be an issue if Chiquita agreed to sell Dole's North America banana business. **********Even with no bananas, Dole would be a major presence in the international fruit business. It is one of the leading suppliers of pineapples, grapes, lemons, strawberries and many other fruits and vegetables. **********Move Into Packaged Goods **********Chiquita is also using joint ventures with General Mills Inc. and the Beech-Nut Nutrition Corporation. And the company is introducing pouched fruit purees for use in home baking. **********An earlier attempt to put the Chiquita name on something other than a banana skin failed. In 1987, the company stopped selling its frozen juice bar, which it had introduced in 1985. Faced with fierce competition and costly marketing, the company lost about $50 million on the venture, analysts estimate. **********Carl H. Lindner, the family's secretive patriarch, was once regarded as one of the country's most savvy investors. Operating through his family-owned American Financial Corporation, he has built a far-reaching billion-dollar empire with holdings ranging from insurance to communications. In October 1989, Forbes magazine estimated Mr. Lindner's fortune at $830 million. **********But twice in the 1970's, he ran afoul of the Securities and Exchange Commission when it charged him with fraud and stock manipulation. Mr. Lindner settled all the charges without admitting or denying guilt. **********In the case of Chiquita, the Lindners took over a company with a sullied reputation. In 1954, United Fruit hired a public relations strategist to create favorable public opinion in Guatemala for support of a C.I.A.-led coup against a President who favored land reform. **********In 1975, the company's chairman, Eli Black, leapt to his death from his office in the Pan Am Building in Manhattan a few months before it was disclosed that the company had bribed senior Government officials in Honduras. **********Labor Unrest Is Common **********Panama and Honduras are Chiquita's two most important sources of bananas, supplying more than 50 percent of the company's bananas. Colombia, the Philippines, Ecuador, Costa Rica and Guatemala also grow Chiquita bananas. About half of the bananas Chiquita sells are grown by the company, the rest are purchased under contract from suppliers. **********Chiquita regularly faces strikes by its Central American pickers. Just last month, the Honduran military was sent in to break a 40-day strike by Chiquita pickers seeking higher wages. Keith Lindner said strikes were simply a fact of life in the banana business. **********Analysts said Keith Lindner takes a different view of things than his father. For one thing, Chiquita has a more conservative balance sheet than other Lindner properties. He is also more open with the shareholders and analysts. Keith Lindner said he had to persuade his father to go forward with the secondary offering, saying, ''He doesn't like to sell anything.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/08/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Stock Plan Announced By Playboy
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/08/busin.body_text: **********Playboy Enterprises Inc. announced a recapitalization plan today aimed at helping the company finance acquisitions and other activities without diluting the controlling stake of its founder, Hugh Hefner. **********The recapitalization, subject to shareholder approval, would establish two classes of common stock, including a new class of nonvoting stock. It would increase the number of Playboy shares from 15 million, to 37.5 million, including 30 million shares of nonvoting stock, the company said. **********The plan would not dilute the holdings of Mr. Hefner, who owns 70.6 percent of the common shares currently outstanding. Mr. Hefner said he would vote to approve the plan. **********Under its present structure, Playboy could not raise money by selling additional common stock without reducing the relative stake held by Mr. Hefner, who is chairman emeritus and Playboy magazine's editor in chief. **********''We believe that the proposed recapitalization will provide Playboy with increased flexibility to use equity in future acquisitions, financings and employee benefit plans without diluting the voting power of existing stockholders,'' Christie Hefner, Playboy's chairman and chief executive, said. **********Playboy stock closed up 12.5 cents today, at $12.875 a share, in New York Stock Exchange trading. **********Under the plan, Playboy stockholders will receive half of a class A voting share for each of their current Playboy shares, followed by a dividend of three nonvoting class B shares for each of the class A shares they received in the split. **********The recapitalization includes a ''minority protection'' feature intended to help insure that the two classes of stock trade at approximately equal market prices, Miss Hefner said. The provision requires that anyone wanting to buy a specific voting position of the class A voting stock must buy a proportionate amount of the nonvoting shares. **********Playboy is talking with potential publishing partners about forming an alliance similar to its link with duPont Publishing Inc., she said. Playboy in 1988 acquired a 20 percent interest in the publisher of the duPont Registry, a monthly magazine for car buffs. **********Buzz Zaino, an industry analyst and managing director of the Trust Company of the West in New York, said the recapitalization would help Playboy make similar deals. ''It does provide her the flexibilty to expand the business with the use of stock, either by selling stock in a public offering or using the stock to acquire other business,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/18/world.main_headline: Arabs Divided on Call for Talks on Soviet Jews
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/18/world.print_headline: Arabs Divided on Call for Talks on Soviet Jews
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/18/world.body_text: **********Arab governments are resisting a call by King Hussein of Jordan for a summit meeting in the next few weeks to discuss the prospect of a huge influx of Soviet Jews to Israel, among other issues. **********Senior Arab officials and diplomats in this oil-producing region said such a meeting would be premature and yield only meaningless or potentially harmful results. **********''What is the point of a showdown with the Soviet Union now over immigration since the Russians have clearly and firmly ruled out any action about immigration from their side?'' a senior Arab minister from an oil-producing country said in an interview. **********Soviet Jewish Immigrants **********Despite such arguments, King Hussein seems resolute in his efforts, warning Arab leaders this week that Soviet Jewish immigration threatens not only Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied territories but Jordan, Lebanon and Syria. **********Largely because of relaxed Soviet emigration policies and new limits on the number of Soviet Jewish refugees accepted by the United States, Israel is expecting 50,000 to 100,000 Soviet Jews to arrive this year, raising Arab worries that they will be resettled in the territories. **********After talks with President Saddam Hussein of Iraq last week, the Jordanian monarch met this week with King Fahd of Saudi Arabia in an apparently unsuccessful attempt to press his case for the meeting. **********Jordanian officials said King Hussein also is planning visits to Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates and Egypt. **********In his visit to Saudi Arabia, King Hussein urged a summit meeting to deal with ''the dangers facing the Arab nation,'' said Foreign Minister Marwan al-Kassem of Jordan. Mr. Kassem told reporters in the Saudi capital that several other crucial questions would be put on the agenda. **********Mr. Kassem said the Arab leaders should examine the continuing strife in Lebanon, the peace process between Palestinians and Israelis, growing disputes over limited water resources and the unresolved status of the war between Iraq and Iran, which ended in a cease-fire in 1988. **********'Very Delicate' Cairo Talks **********Expressing skepticism about the usefulness of a summit meeting, diplomats from Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and Bahrain noted that Arab summit proposals to resolve the 15-year Lebanese crisis had failed to materialize because of sharp differences among Lebanese religious and ethnic groups. **********On Palestinian-Israeli talks, Arab officials speaking privately said Egypt had made it known it is in a ''very delicate'' stage of talks with the United States and Israel on holding free elections for Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. **********The Egyptians say their efforts could easily be ruined if subjected to discussion or criticism at an Arab summit meeting. **********In interviews over the last few days, Saudi, Kuwaiti, Egyptian and Bahraini officials asserted that the biggest risk of an ineffective summit meeting would be to further erode the credibility of Arab leaders among their people. **********''It will only underscore our inability to make a difference,'' said a senior Arab minister who asked not to be identified. **********Virtually none of the resolutions adopted at Arab summit meetings in Jordan, Algeria and Morocco since 1988 have been successfully carried out. **********Pledges of Financial Aid **********Officials of the Palestine Liberation Organization have repeatedly asserted that pledges at a summit meeting in Algiers of tens of millions of dollars in financial aid to support the Palestinian uprising in the West Bank and Gaza against Israeli occupation have failed to materialize. **********In addition, a peace accord for Lebanon sponsored by the Arab League has been imperiled by vicious fighting among Lebanese clans. **********Some officials from Arab oil-producing countries also have expressed suspicions that a summit meeting may be a ploy by poor Arab nations to make new requests for financial assistance.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/14/world.main_headline: No Lenin, No Marx and, Just Maybe, No Communist Party in Prague
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/14/world.print_headline: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;   No Lenin, No Marx and, Just Maybe, No Communist Party in Prague
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/14/world.body_text: **********In his faded jeans and blue, short-sleeved polo shirt sporting a ''Levis'' label, Vasil Mohorita, a tall 38-year-old, looks nothing like his grizzled, somber-suited predecessors. **********There isn't a Lenin portrait on his office wall or a Marx bust on his desk. His bookcases do not contain the visibly unopened classics of Communism that once were the obligatory props of such offices. **********''I hope this proves we are different from our predecessors,'' said Mr. Mohorita, who has been the Czechoslovak Communist Party's First Secretary since shortly after it was expelled from power last November. **********For much of this nation, however, the revised inventory of the party chief's office is not proof enough. Thursday afternoon, many thousands gathered in Old Town Square and in squares in other towns to shout their anger at a speech last Sunday, in which Mr. Mohorita announced an end to ''national understanding'' and ''the beginning of a hard and uncompromising struggle.'' **********Speakers demanded that the party be banned and that its former leaders be prosecuted. Demonstrators cheered the Government's decision to move to confiscate without compensation the party's properties, which it has evaluated at 7.5 billion crowns (about $250 million). **********'We Have No Choice' **********In a 90-minute interview, Mr. Mohorita said he meant his remark to apply only to the party's opposition to the Government's economic reform program, not as a termination of the party's acceptance, since last November, of an opposition role in a pluralistic political system. **********''As a party of the left we have no choice,'' Mr. Mohorita said. **********The leader's assessment of his party's numerical strength clearly leaves it no hope of soon regaining absolute power or any share in government. He said he did not believe the official count of 750,000 members remaining in a party that numbered 1.7 million a year ago. ''This includes many who haven't yet turned in their membership cards,'' he said. **********He estimated real strength at between 300,000 and 500,000 in a nation of 15.5 million. **********If he allowed himself to dream about the Communists' future chances at playing anything but an opposition role, he said, ''It will take many years.'' At the earliest, he added, ''a success of the left, including our party, could come by the next elections, six years from now.'' **********But Mr. Mohorita said he would not rule out a possibility that in some years ''our party may have to dissolve itself.'' He said the party contained opposing factions, although he rejected reports that it might split in the course of a series of regional and national meetings between next weekend and Nov. 4. **********Name Change Expected **********''It is my bad luck now to be the leader,'' he said with a grin, defining himself as a man of the middle way in the renewal of his party. ''For the conservatives I represent a reformer and a social democrat, and for the reformers of the social democratic kind I represent a conservative.'' **********In traditional Communist vocabulary, into which Mr. Mohorita lapses frequently, a ''social democrat'' is a traitor to the interests of the working class. **********The First Secretary said he would still call himself a Communist, even if not a Bolshevist, but added, ''I'd say we don't attach ourselves to the word ''Communist.'' He said he expected the upcoming national congress to change the party's name to ''Party of Labor and Democratic Socialism.'' **********He said the party rejected such hallowed points of doctrine as the dictatorship of the proletariat. ''I feel we must deal with reality,'' he said. He described himself as ''accessible and tolerant,'' and, despite his rapid rise in the hierarchy under the dogmatic rule of the former leader, President Gustav Husak, as a man who strongly opposed the old regime's rigid and intolerant ways. **********Gorbachev a Milestone **********Mr. Mohorita advanced to the inner circle of leadership as head of the party's youth organization, a traditional way station to the top. His entire career has been as a Communist functionary. He said the coming to power of Mikhail S. Gorbachev was a milestone in his political life, although he said he would not be so arrogant as to compare himself to the Soviet leader. **********More emphatically, he said he would ''definitely not'' liken himself to Boris N. Yeltsin, Mr. Gorbachev's liberal rival. **********Despite the absence of the works of Marx and Lenin in his office, Mr. Mohorita said it was necessary to know them, ''whether one decides to follow them or not.'' As for the ''practical'' works of Lenin on how to organize revolution, the First Secretary said, ''I don't take them as textbooks.'' **********Mr. Mohorita is the first to lead the party from its comparatively modest quarters in a downtown building it recently bought from the Government. Its old and vast premises, on the Vltava River embankment, now belong to the Government. **********Mr. Mohorita agreed there was irony in the new headquarters' location in the Street of Political Prisoners, a name given to it by the Communist regime in tribute to Czechoslovaks jailed under German occupation. But he made it clear that he was not referring to his party's imprisonment of tens of thousands of non-Communists during its 41 years of rule. **********Mr. Mohorita said he did not think he would be imprisoned.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/13/busin.main_headline: Keating Blames U.S. Delays for Lincoln's Seizure
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/13/busin.print_headline: Keating Blames U.S. Delays for Lincoln's Seizure
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/13/busin.body_text: **********Charles H. Keating Jr. asserted in court today that Federal regulators held up approval of two transactions that would have brought the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association into compliance with the Government's capital requirements in December 1988, four months before regulators seized it. **********Mr. Keating, chairman and chief executive of Lincoln's parent, the American Continental Corporation, said that officials of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board refused to take action on a $100 million offering of high-yield ''junk bonds'' that Lincoln filed with the Federal agency in July 1988, even though they had agreed to do so. **********He also said that during the summer of 1988 he had concluded an agreement to purchase Pima Savings and Loan of Phoenix, which he said had a broad deposit base. But he said bank board officials were not willing to process the change of control. **********The regulators' finding in December that Lincoln had a capital deficiency of $114 million began a series of events that led to Lincoln's seizure last April. **********Regulators' Caution Cited **********James P. Murphy, an attorney for the Office of Thrift Supervision, told reporters after the hearing that the transactions were held up because regulators had uncovered questionable transactions at Lincoln and were proceeding cautiously. **********Mr. Keating's testimony continued for the third day today over repeated objections from Mr. Murphy that it was not relevant to the hearing. **********Federal Judge Stanley Sporkin continued to overrule the objections, giving Mr. Keating wide latitude to discuss evidence of what he referred to today as ''a personal vendetta'' against him by Edwin J. Gray, the former chairman of the bank board, and others. **********When the proceedings began in December, Judge Sporkin ordered that testimony be taken only on a small sample of Lincoln's real estate transactions. **********''The more I get into this, I think an organization has a right to a hearing,'' he said today. **********Prosecutor's 'Delicate Task' **********Mr. Murphy admitted that he would have a difficult time in his cross-examination of Mr. Keating, scheduled to begin on Tuesday. **********''It's a delicate task about how you go back into things that you don't think are germane,'' he said. **********Mr. Keating also concentrated on the fact that Kevin O'Connell, a key figure in the bank board's examination and subsequent takeover of Lincoln, is the son of William B. O'Connell, a past president of the United States League of Savings Institutions and a harsh critic of Lincoln's wide real estate investments. The league is a trade association based in Chicago. **********Mr. Keating said bank board officials promised to remove Kevin O'Connell from the Lincoln case but did not do so. **********Memo Introduced as Evidence **********Mr. Keating's attorney introduced into evidence a copy of a memo written by Kevin O'Connell on April 7, a week before the Government seized Lincoln. **********''Even our lawyers are finally getting the message,'' the memo said. ''Under every document is another scam, and they seem to finally understand what type of thieves we are dealing with and why we need to get them out.'' **********The memo referred to the withdrawal of $40 million from Lincoln on April 6, shortly before the takeover.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/25/busin.body_text: **********Citing continued weakness in demand for steel and higher operating costs, the USX Corporation and the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, yesterday reported sharply lower first-quarter earnings. **********USX, which operates the nation's largest steel business and is a leading energy company, said that its net income dropped 40.5 percent in the first quarter, largely because of a nearly 40 percent reduction in operating earnings in the company's steel division. **********USX reported net income of $176 million, or 66 cents a share, compared with net income of $296 million, or $1.09 a share, in the period last year. Sales for the quarter rose 5.2 percent, to $4.69 billion, from $4.46 billion in the first quarter of 1989. Operating income from the first quarter of 1989 included a $119 million gain from settlements of three lawsuits involving USX's Texas Oil and Gas unit, and a favorable $60 million change in Marathon's inventory market valuation. **********The company attributed the lower earnings in steel to lower prices and the effects of the sale of the company's plant in Lorain, Ohio. year. USX reported operating earnings of $60 million in the steel division on sales of $1.3 billion, compared with operating income of $99 million in the first quarter of last year, on sales of $1.5 billion. **********USX's major energy holding, Marathon Oil, had operating income of $242 million on sales of $3 billion, relatively flat compared with the operating income of $241 million on sales of $2.4 billion in the first quarter of last year. **********USX's Texas Oil and Gas unit had an operating loss of $5 million, on sales of $230 million, compared with operating income of $99 million, on sales of $1.5 billion, in the first quarter of last year. The results a year earlier for the unit included a gain of $144 million from the settlement of lawsuits. **********Bethlehem **********Meanwhile, Bethlehem, the nation's second-largest steelmaker, said its earnings dropped 67.1 percent, to $21.3 million, or 20 cents a share, compared with net income of $64.7 million, or 78 cents a share, in the comparable period last year. Sales for the quarter were down 13.6 percent, to $1.22 billion, from $1.4 billion in the period last year. **********Walter F. Williams, chairman and chief executive of Bethlehem, said that the results for the quarter were negatively affected by lower steel prices and higher costs, in part because one of the company's blast furnaces was closed for relining. ''Steel demand was particularly strong in early 1989,'' Mr. Williams said. ''And the lower shipments in the first quarter of 1990 resulted from weaker demand,'' primarily from the construction and automotive markets.'' He said that there had also been reduced shipments of semifinished steel to other steel producers and more intense competition in the market for structural steel products.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/16/busin.main_headline: Sun Accord With I.B.M. On Patents
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/16/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Sun Accord With I.B.M. On Patents
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/16/busin.body_text: **********Sun Microsystems Inc. said yesterday that it had entered into a cross-licensing agreement with the International Business Machines Corporation, tacitly acknowledging I.B.M.'s claims to having pioneered a popular advanced computer design. **********I.B.M. has said that it has notified a number of computer makers that it believed they were infringing on its patents for a type of computer known as RISC, or reduced instruction set computing. This innovative approach to computer design yields faster data processing at lower cost. **********''We were one of those companies that got one of the letters from I.B.M.,'' said Michael Morris, a Sun Microsystems spokesman. ''We had our own view on whether we had infringed on the I.B.M. patents.'' **********I.B.M. has not identified the other companies. **********I.B.M.'s Patent Library **********Mr. Morris said Sun had ultimately decided that it made sense to enter a licensing agreement with I.B.M. because of the breadth of I.B.M.'s patent library. **********Neither I.B.M. nor Sun would disclose the terms of the agreement, which covers both companies' patent libraries. Sun officials said that because of the number of I.B.M. patents, compared with Sun's, the Mountain View, Calif., work-station maker would make a royalty payment to I.B.M. that would be spread over five years. Sun said the payments would not have a significant effect on its financial position. **********I.B.M., which is based in Armonk, N.Y., had notified Sun in June 1988 that it believed Sun was infringing its patents. **********The first RISC research was conducted at I.B.M. by a group of researchers led by the computer designer John Cocke in the mid-1970's. Mr. Cocke's group developed a prototype machine called the 801 Minicomputer that was completed in 1980. **********Independent RISC Projects **********In the early 1980's, a number of researchers at the University of California at Berkeley and Stanford University pursued independent RISC projects that led to commercial RISC chips. The Berkeley researchers coined the term RISC. **********Berkeley designers later worked with Sun Microsystems to develop a RISC computer design known as Sparc. The Stanford designers formed MIPS Computer Systems Inc. of Sunnyvale, Calif., which makes its own version of RISC used in work stations and other computers. **********In recent years, virtually every leading computer maker has introduced a RISC-based computer or announced plans to develop a system based on a RISC chip developed by a major semiconductor supplier.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/20/busin.body_text: **********The owners of WSNS-TV in Chicago lost a lengthy license renewal battle today when the Federal Communications Commission, in a rare move, said a competing applicant was more deserving to run the station. **********The commission granted the Monroe Communications Corporation a license to build a new TV station on Channel 44. It said Monroe was more qualified than the current licensee, Video 44, which had switched the station's format to a subscription movie service. Monroe, which began seeking the license in 1982, also contended that Video 44 had broadcast obscene material, but the F.C.C. did not reach a decision on that allegation. **********The F.C.C. almost never denies license renewals to incumbents and had already given Video 44 a renewal in 1989. But the commission reconsidered the case under orders from a Federal appeals court in Washington. **********Video 44 may appeal the decision to the appeals court. Otherwise, it must discontinue operations 90 days after the F.C.C. formally releases its renewal order. **********Video 44 officials did not immediately return a call seeking comment. **********Monroe's principals include prominent Chicago business executives like Robert Haag, the co-founder of the Alberto-Culver Company, and Wayne Fickinger, the former president of the J. Walter Thompson advertising agency.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/11/busin.main_headline: Northwest to Acquire Stake in Hawaiian Air
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/11/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Northwest to Acquire Stake in Hawaiian Air
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/11/busin.body_text: **********Northwest Airlines will invest in the struggling Hawaiian Airlines in exchange for some of the Honolulu-based carrier's lucrative South Pacific routes, the airlines announced today. **********Northwest would own 25 percent of Hawaiian Airlines after paying $20 million to the airline and its parent, HAL Inc. The payment includes $7 million as a secured loan, a statement said. **********John Dasburg, president and chief executive of St. Paul-based Northwest, said the deal would expand Northwest's international strength and increase its presence in Hawaii. **********Under the deal, Northwest will receive Hawaiian's Australian routes. Northwest dominates United States traffic across the North Pacific and reaches such South Pacific cities as Manila from Japan. But Northwest has longed for a chance to close the loop over the Pacific with southern routes to Australia. **********Hawaiian Airlines will transfer to Northwest its operating authority to fly between four Asian cities. In addition, Northwest will lease two widebody aircraft, to be operated by Northwest pilots, to Hawaiian Airlines so it can operate seven flights a week on the route between Honolulu and Fukuoka, Japan. **********Tom Talbot, chairman of HAL, said the airlines would also cooperate in marketing and operation areas, producing new revenue, saving money and increasing efficiency. **********Hawaiian Airlines, Hawaii's largest airline, serves 22 international and domestic destinations in the Pacific. It operates more than 200 daily flights between the major Hawaiian islands. **********The stock of HAL Inc. jumped $1.125 today, to $10.125, on the American Stock Exchange, where its 12.5 percent rise was the sixth best of the day. NWA Inc., Northwest's parent, is closely held. **********Separately, Northwest announced it was lowering fares between United States cities and seven Canadian destinations. The discounted fares are available for travel between Jan. 11 and Feb. 19, as long as tickets are bought before Jan. 16. **********The lower fares are for travel to and from Montreal, Toronto, Winnipeg, Edmonton, Quebec City, Vancouver and Victoria.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/20/world.main_headline: French Trial Ordered In a War Crimes Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/20/world.print_headline: French Trial Ordered In a War Crimes Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/20/world.body_text: **********A French appeals court today overturned a ruling that the case of an aging Frenchman accused of crimes against humanity in World War II should be handled by a long-defunct special court and ordered his trial by an ordinary criminal court. **********The move followed protests that a decision by the Prosecutor General's Office last month to send the case of the Frenchman, Rene Bousquet, to the Special High Court of Liberation was tantamout to postponing his trial indefinitely and avoiding a new airing of French collaboration with Nazi occupation forces. **********Mr. Bousquet, a former police chief in German-occupied France who is now 81 years old, has been charged with approving the deportation of 194 Jewish children who later died in Nazi concentration camps. He was tried as a collaborationist in 1949, but new evidence against him has now been presented. **********Serge Klarsfeld, the Nazi-hunter who brought the case against Mr. Bousquet, said a trial could take place within a year, but he noted that the Prosecutor General's Office still had five days in which to file a new appeal to the French Supreme Court. **********"Today's decision reflects the determination of the judges to exercise their independence, but we'll have to see if the politcal power abandons its pressure," Mr. Klarsfeld said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/14/busin.main_headline: German Bank Aide Quits in Bond Dispute
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/14/busin.print_headline: German Bank Aide Quits in Bond Dispute
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/14/busin.body_text: **********A feud that has raged for weeks between several leading French banks and a West German bank over $3.5 billion in bond sales took its latest turn yesterday with the resignation of an official at the German bank. **********In recent weeks, Deutsche Genossenschaftsbank A.G. of Frankfurt has been in a heated dispute with nine French banks that asserted that the German bank had refused to make good on what the French financial institutions said was an agreement to repurchase the disputed West German bonds. **********French banking officials said that last Wednesday the DG Bank had agreed to buy back all the bonds and make good on any losses suffered in the dispute, and all but one of the French banks accepted the agreement. West German bonds have plunged recently over fears of inflation and uncertainties about currency unification with East Germany, and the value of these six billion West German marks, or $3.5 billion, in bonds has plummeted by about $350 million. **********Taking Responsiblity **********The West German bank said in a statement today that a deputy vice chairman of the bank had resigned to take responsibility for the disputed bond dealings. **********The statement said that Karl-Herbert Schneider-Gaedicke, head of DG Bank's securities department, had sent a letter to the chairman of the bank's supervisory board, stating that he resigned today to prevent further damage to the bank, which is the nation's sixth largest. **********Officials at DG Bank have denied that they had made any commitment to repurchase the bonds in the original dealings. And in his letter, Mr. Schneider-Gaedicke said he had no knowledge of any such commitment. **********French bankers said that DG Bank's former chief bond trader, Friedrich Steil, had sold them the bonds and made an oral commitment to repurchase them at an agreed price. DG Bank officials maintained that they were not liable for any oral promises that they said had been made by Mr. Steil. **********Fraud Accusation **********DG Bank has dismissed Mr. Steil and accused him of fraud. Mr. Steil is under investigation by the West German state attorney's office. **********Even as it agreed to make good on the bonds, DG Bank officials said they were delaying a decision whether to bring a lawsuit to determine which side was liable for the losses suffered in the bond dispute. Last week's agreement gives each side up to 12 months to file legal claims against the other. **********In their agreement with French banks, DG Bank officials have stipulated that if any officials at the French banks participated in the purported fraud, then French banks should absorb part of the losses. **********Among the bond holders were Banque Nationale de Paris, with 1.13 billion marks, or $660 million, in bonds, and Caisse des Depots & Consignations, the huge investment arm of the French Government, with slightly less than one billion marks, or $584 million, in bonds. Other holders included Credit du Nord, a subsidiary of Compagnie Financiere de Paribas, and Societe Generale Alsacienne de Banque, a subsidiary of Societe Generale. **********DG Bank has made a provision for 280 million West German marks, or about $163 million, in its 1989 financial statements to cover the drop in the value of the bonds. Banking officials have said that unless the value of the bonds recovers somewhat, it might have to make a further provision for its 1990 statements. **********Today's DG Bank statement said that Bernhard Schramm, chairman of the bank's supervisory board, had accepted Mr. Schneider-Gaedicke's resignation and that it did not reflect any acknowledgement of fault.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/04/world.main_headline: Iranian Oil-Producing Region Jolted by Strong Earthquake
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/04/world.print_headline: Iranian Oil-Producing Region Jolted by Strong Earthquake
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/04/world.body_text: **********A strong earthquake jolted the Iranian province of Khuzestan today, a little more than a month after an earthquake in the north killed 40,000 people. **********Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency, monitored in Nicosia, said the temblor struck at mid-afternoon and measured 5.5 on the Richter scale. Reports on damages or casualties were not immediately available, the report said. Khuzestan is part of the oil-producing belt in southern Iran. **********The news agency said several strong jolts had also shaken the town of Ardebil and surrounding areas in the northwestern province of East Azerbaijan over three days. **********The recent temblors caused panic because of the earthquake on June 21 that registered 7.3 on the Richter scale and killed 40,000 people.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/13/world.print_headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   2 of Iraq's Pilots Are Said to Bolt
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/13/world.body_text: **********Two Iraqi Air Force pilots have defected by flying their MIG planes to a base in northern Saudi Arabia, diplomats in the Middle East said today. **********The diplomats, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the Soviet-built aircraft had landed on Saturday at the Hafer al Batin base, the main center for the foreign troop buildup in Saudi Arabia. **********The United States State Department said it had not heard the report. The Kuwaiti Embassy in Washington said it had heard the report but could not confirm it. **********The United States and other foreign countries are sending forces to Saudi Arabia to defend against any attack by Iraq, which invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. **********The diplomats in the Middle **********East said that the planes were MIGs but that they did not know the precise type. The pilots were not identified, and there were no other immediate details. **********Iraq has at least 70 MIG-23 ground attack fighters, as well as 70 MIG-21 and 18 MIG-29 fighters. It also has eight MIG-25 reconnaissance planes and a variety of MIG training planes.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/06/world.main_headline: Murder Charge Ruled Invalid for Philippine Senator in Failed Coup
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/06/world.print_headline: Murder Charge Ruled Invalid for Philippine Senator in Failed Coup
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/06/world.body_text: **********In a rebuff to President Corazon C. Aquino, the Supreme Court ruled today that the Government's charge of rebellion against Senator Juan Ponce Enrile should not have included murder and was invalid. **********The decision nullified the criminal cases filed by state lawyers against Mr. Enrile and about 20 other civilians linked by the Government to a failed army coup attempt in December. **********Chief Justice Marcelo Fernan said the court voted 11 to 2 to nullify the Government's charge. **********''The President will abide by the decision of the court,'' a spokesman for Mrs. Aquino, Adolfo Azcuna, said. **********'A Triumph for Justice' **********In its 18-page decision, the Supreme Court also recommended that the Philippine Congress tighten up the law on rebellion, saying the offense was treated with relative leniency, an aberration in a country ravaged by coups and guerrilla attacks. **********Justice Fernan said the case against Mr. Enrile was returned to the lower court. He said the charge should be reduced to rebellion. The Government must amend the charge if it wishes to proceed with the prosecution. **********Mr. Enrile, a former Defense Minister dismissed by President Aquino in 1986, greeted the ruling as ''a triumph for justice and the people.'' **********The chairman of the Senate Defense Committee, Ernesto Maceda, said the ruling seriously embarrassed the Government. ''The President should fire all the officials who caused the filing of those charges,'' he said. **********Murder Charge Ruled Invalid **********State lawyers charged Mr. Enrile and other members of the opposition with ''rebellion complexed with murder'' arising from the deaths of 113 people during the weeklong coup attempt last December against President Aquino. **********Justice Fernan told reporters that the court believed that people linked to the coup should only be charged with rebellion and that attaching an additional charge of murder was invalid. **********Rebellion under Philippine law is punishable by a maximum of 12 years in prison, and those charged are eligible for bail. Combined with murder, it is a capital offense and bail is not granted. **********The Supreme Court decision was a fresh blow to Mrs. Aquino's efforts to take a tough stand against threats from right-wing rebels to launch another coup and a series of killings by Communist rebels opposed to American military bases in the Philippines. **********The court-martial of 21 officers involved in the attempt to topple Mrs. Aquino in December has been held up by legal disputes. **********Opposition lawyers protested the double charge, saying the Government acted vindictively to make sure that the defendants stayed in jail for the duration of the trial.
