https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/27/world.main_headline: Israel Not So Clear Now on Settling of Soviet Jews
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/27/world.print_headline: Israel Not So Clear Now on Settling of Soviet Jews
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/27/world.body_text: **********A disagreement appeared to break out today among the leaders of Israel's new Government over whether Soviet Jewish immigrants would be settled in the occupied territories. The dispute adds further confusion to Housing Minister Ariel Sharon's statement on Sunday night that the migrants would not be settled in occupied land. **********Immigration officials said they had been notified of no policy change. They said Soviet immigrants who chose to live in the West Bank or Gaza Strip would still be permitted to move there and would be given Government money to subsidize living expenses, just as if the immigrant had chosen to live inside Israel. **********On Sunday night, Mr. Sharon, a longtime and ardent proponent of increased Jewish settlement, said that ''due to the problems we have,'' immigrants would not be settled in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. ''We will not send any Jew who comes from Russia to Judea, Samaria or to Gaza because we understand the seriousness of the situation,'' he said, using the biblical names for the West Bank. **********Ministerial Divisions **********His statement took the nation by surprise. Still, Mr. Sharon, who is chairman of the Inter-Ministerial Committee on Immigrant Absorption, has declined to elaborate. Because Israeli ministries are essentially individual fiefs, officials from other offices would not speculate on what Mr. Sharon's statement meant. **********Today, however, Finance Minister Yitzhak Modai, a longtime political ally of Mr. Sharon, told reporters, ''If the Russians make it a condition that they don't want Russian Jewry to settle because of their political considerations and interests, we will abide by it because we want Russian Jewry here at any cost and under any circumstances.'' **********But Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, who has spent much of the last year fending off political challenges from Mr. Sharon and Mr. Modai, said Mr. Sharon's remarks were nothing new. **********''That was my opinion even before Sharon's statement,'' he was quoted as telling the Parliament's Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee on Monday. ''It's the same policy.'' **********As if to underscore that, the Prime Minister's office disclosed that Mr. Shamir had sent a cable to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union weeks ago, making a similar pledge. **********Sharon-Shamir Dispute **********This afternoon the Prime Minister told the Israeli radio: ''Of course he said that nobody will be sent by us to certain territories and to certain locations. But everybody in a democratic society has the right to settle wherever he wishes.'' **********The apparent conflict suggests that even before Mr. Shamir's new Government has finished its first month, the wary alliance between political enemies, Mr. Sharon and Mr. Shamir, may already be wearing thin. Mr. Sharon has made no secret that he wants Mr. Shamir's job. **********As for the Soviet immigrants, at the Absorption Ministry, Jewish Agency, Prime Minister's office, Finance Ministry and other agencies holding some responsibility for settling Soviet Jewish immigrants, officials said they had received no new directives. **********''I don't know of any change,'' said Ida Ben-Shitrit, an Absorption Ministry official. ''If a Soviet immigrant wants to go to a kibbutz, he will get money to go to a kibbutz. If he wants to go to Ariel,'' a West Bank settlement, ''he will go to Ariel. **********''He will not be stopped,'' she added, ''but we will not send him.'' **********For several months, Israeli officials, trying to assuage Soviet and American concerns, have been saying that it is not Israeli policy to direct Soviet immigrants to the West Bank and Gaza Strip. And in fact only a tiny number have chosen to move there. About 4,000 Soviet Jewish immigrants have moved to East Jerusalem, which was part of the West Bank until Israel annexed it in 1967 and which Israelis consider part of Israel. **********'Modest but Significant' **********Senior immigration officials explained that behind all the debate and dispute was what one called a ''modest but significant'' policy change. They explained it this way: **********Before, Israel made no attempt to direct immigrants to any particular place. But under Mr. Sharon's new policy, Israel will actively encourage Soviet immigrants to move to the Negev, Galilee, Jerusalem, Tel Aviv or other points inside Israel. All new immigrant housing will be built inside Israel; none will be built in the West Bank or Gaza. **********But if an immigrant chooses to move to the West Bank, the Government will not stand in his way and will give him the subsidies and other benefits given to those who live inside Israel. **********Once an immigrant or anyone else chooses to make a permanent home in the territories, the immigrant receives Government benefits that exceed any given to other Israelis, with the possible exception of those who live in the most remote villages and small towns.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/13/world.main_headline: Hong Kong Calls China Talks Useful but Sees No Progress
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/13/world.print_headline: Hong Kong Calls China Talks Useful but Sees No Progress
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/13/world.body_text: **********The Governor of Hong Kong said today that his three days of talks with Chinese officials had been useful, but neither side reported major progress in easing tensions between Hong Kong and Beijing. **********There was no sign of new conciliation on the Chinese side to accompany the lifting of martial law, which took effect on Thursday. On Thursday and again today, Chinese officials made comments that were widely perceived as reproachful of the British position. **********The Governor, Sir David Wilson, who was on his first visit to Beijing since the army crackdown in June, said he told Prime Minister Li Peng and other officials about the opinions in Hong Kong about proposed democratic changes. **********The June crackdown has increased alarm in the British territory that Beijing will suppress dissent and ignore local opinions after Hong Kong reverts to Chinese rule in 1997. **********Draft Law Faulted **********China is now completing work on a ''basic law'' that will govern the territory after 1997, and many Hong Kong residents assert that the recent drafts of the law do not provide for enough democracy and will erode confidence in the territory's future. Sir David said he hoped that his comments on Hong Kong views would be taken into consideration by those drafting the basic law. **********''I've been explaining the views that people in Hong Kong have both on short-term political developments and the hopes that people have for long-term development, for steady and continued development of the political structure,'' the Governor said at an airport news conference before returning home. **********He said he also asked for Chinese assistance in reducing the flow of Vietnamese refugees, many of whom travel by boat along the Chinese coastline before landing in Hong Kong. He also said that the Chinese had repeated their criticisms of a recent British proposal to provide passports to 50,000 Hong Kong Chinese and their families before 1997, and that he had explained the reasons for the proposal. **********''I can't say that in these discussions we have solved every problem,'' Sir David said. ''But I do think that as a result of these meetings, it has been possible to increase understanding on both sides and get back to resuming the sort of practical dialogue which we need if we're to deal with practical issues in Hong Kong at the moment.'' **********Beijing Assertions of Subversion **********The official New China News Agency tonight quoted Prime Minister Li as saying he was glad to see that ''on some issues, the two sides are drawing closer.'' The agency did not eleborate, but it said that Mr. Li also called on China and Britain to take steps to prevent damage to relations between Hong Kong and Beijing. **********But earlier, there seemed to be some tension in the air. When Sir David referred in the presence of reporters to difficulties in the political climate, Mr. Li reportedly responded, ''Maybe that's your feeling, but I feel fine.'' **********On Thursday, Li Hou, deputy director of China's Hong Kong and Macao Affairs Office, said to Sir David, in front of reporters, that some Hong Kong residents were trying to harm the relationship with China. He seemed to suggest that the Hong Kong Government should do more to stop such conduct. **********At his news cnference today, Sir David addressed the Chinese concern that Hong Kong is being used as a base from which to subvert Communist rule in the mainland. **********''We in Hong Kong have no wish, we have no intention, that Hong Kong should be used as a base for subversion against China,'' the Governor said. ''In particular, we don't want people from outside Hong Kong to come to Hong Kong to use it as a battlefield against China. At the same time, we treasure our own liberties and freedoms in Hong Kong.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/05/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; A.T.&T. Extends Card's No-Fee Plan
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/05/busin.body_text: **********The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it was extending for 85 days its promise never to charge an annual fee to customers who sign up for its Universal card. Customers who apply for the card by next March 26 and use the card at least once a year will never pay an annual fee, A.T.& T. said. The previous deadline for applications had been Dec. 31. The Universal card is a combination of a Mastercard or Visa credit card with an A.T.& T. Calling Card. **********The telecommunications giant introduced the card on March 26 of this year and has opened about 4.1 million accounts. Card holders have charged $3.3 billion in purchases and telephone calls to the Universal card, the company said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/06/busin.main_headline: G.E. Shows Bright Side of East Europe
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/06/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;   G.E. Shows Bright Side of East Europe
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/06/busin.body_text: **********AMERICAN advertising's fickle relationship with Eastern Europe will take another turn toward sweetness - and most definitely light - this weekend with the release of a General Electric Company commercial that celebrates G.E.'s venture to produce light bulbs in Hungary. **********The 30-second spot, which was partly staged, was created by BBDO New York and filmed in Budapest by Joe Pytka, the commercial director. It is filled with symbols of liberation, some universal, like whirling dancers, and some very American, like an office meeting. Not surprisingly, the spot is bathed in light - a metaphor for freedom and, not incidentally, a G.E. product. **********Five years ago, American advertisers routinely ridiculed the cultural and economic poverty of Communism. The ''Russian Fashion Show,'' a commercial for the Wendy's hamburger chain, was a parody of the Paris couture, with beefy babushkas in identical gray sack suits substituting for slender models. **********But last year, as the Soviet Union's policies of political openness began to affect the nation's allies, American companies started to flirt with advertising images of the East bloc that were by turns heroic, romantic and familial. BBDO has specialized in these ads; it has done two for Pepsi-Cola, one promoting Soviet-American friendship and another underscoring the notion that Russians are just like Americans. **********BBDO's G.E. commercial, which is to make its debut Sunday morning on several public affairs programs, represents a new wave of pro-Eastern advertising, filmed on location and serving as a witness to the opening of Eastern Europe. It is the second quasi documentary to promote a venture by an American company in the East bloc. Several weeks ago, the McDonald's Corporation released an advertisement about the opening of the company's first restaurant in Moscow. **********Celebration is the theme of G.E.'s new commercial, entitled ''Hungarian Rhapsody.'' ''The last 20 years, there've been so many down moves in the world,'' said Ted Sann, executive creative director of BBDO New York, ''this is a chance to reverse it.'' **********The commercial's goal, however, has a harder edge. As explained by Barbara J. Parsky, G.E.'s manager of corporate advertising, the spot is aimed primarily at the financial community, to showcase G.E.'s aggressive global expansion. The campaign illustrates G.E.'s $150 million acquisition in November of half of the Tungsram Company Ltd., Hungary's largest light-bulb maker. **********The spot opens in fading sunlight, as the camera sweeps over the Danube River separating Buda and Pest, the Hungarian capital's two principal districts. As the strains of a ''Hungarian Rhapsody'' by Liszt gradually build, a young man says in accented English: ''Freedom's all that matters. Freedom is everything.'' **********As the sun sinks, the camera zips between scenes of people lighting candles and smiling. ''There's a new light shining over Eastern Europe,'' says the announcer, who proceeds to explain briefly the G.E.-Tungsram arrangement. **********More Hungarians are seen: working in their offices, meeting in the Tungsram factory, congregating in groups, marching over a bridge. Their faces glow. ''Everything is changing,'' one woman says. Another adds, ''I'm so happy.'' The candles reappear, but they are increasingly interspersed with electric lights switching on, illuminating museums, monuments, a ballet and a waltz party. **********The camera freezes on a little girl lighting one last candle as the company's 11-year-old corporate slogan appears on screen: ''G.E. We bring good things to life.'' **********The company could not bring every good thing to light. Its advertising agency had hoped to film the lighting of the Hungarian Parliament. But the building is lighted only when Parliament is in session. **********''They would have had to vote on it,'' said Al Merrin, the BBDO senior creative director for the project. ''We couldn't wait.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/20/world.main_headline: Tunisians, Seeking Roots, Turn Toward Iraq
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/20/world.print_headline: MIDEAST TENSIONS;   Tunisians, Seeking Roots, Turn Toward Iraq
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/20/world.body_text: **********The contrasting Western and Muslim faces of this former French protectorate mix comfortably in the bustling streets of downtown Tunis as car horns honk over the sound of midday prayers and girls in tight jeans move past women draped in traditional Arab gowns. **********But while the dream of many young men is to emigrate to Europe and both French and Italian television programs are rebroadcast locally, the growing Arab identity of this North African nation has come to light in the strong sympathy that many ordinary Tunisians feel for Iraq in the current crisis. **********''We like Saddam Hussein,'' a policeman in his 40's said without hesitation, echoing a widely held opinion. ''He is courageous. He wants all Arabs to be equal. He wants to give the money of the rich Arabs to the poor Arabs. The emirs gave us nothing.'' **********A 62-year-old Tunisian, who boasted that he had traveled the world, felt little differently when the subject came up. ''Kuwait is not important,'' he announced in fluent French. ''It is part of Iraq. It is not worth a war. The United States has no right to intervene.'' **********A Muslim Opposition **********For President Zine al-Abidine Ben Ali, though, the gulf crisis has proved less straightforward. Tunisia has long benefited from being a friend of the United States and its economy is enormously dependent on trade with Western Europe and the remittances of 250,000 Tunisians living in France. **********The strongest opposition to his three-year-old Government comes from the Islamic Renaissance Movement, known as Nahda, which gained ground in the 1980's in reaction to the Westernization of Tunisia that was tasking place under his predecessor, Habib Bourguiba. **********And since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, it is the Arab voice of Tunisia that has been raised on the streets. ''What you hear is the fruit of the accumulated frustration of the Arab world,'' a Government official said. ''The Western response has turned Saddam into a political and religious hero.'' **********In preparing his own response, Mr. Ben Ali has therefore measured the risks of a domestic Islamic backlash against the dangers of Western reprisals. And he has chosen a policy that balances strict adherence to United Nations resolutions on a trade embargo with public disapproval of the Western military buildup. **********Keeping the Peace at Home **********In his only major speech on the subject to date, he criticized American troop deployments more than the Iraqi invasion. He boycotted an Arab League summit meeting, creating the impression that he was trying to avoid condemning Baghdad. He has also promoted a so-called Arab solution to the crisis, urging Saudi and Kuwait leaders to be patient and reminding Western visitors of the need to appease Arab public opinion. **********But his main priority has been to maintain peace at home. And in this, he has been successful. Tunisian officials say experience shows that any American attack on Iraq would result in angry protests here, but to date there have been only demonstrations against the American presence in the gulf, organized by the Government party as part of what officials call their ''management'' of the crisis. **********Diplomats looking to explain Tunisian grass-roots support for Iraq recognize the impact of President Hussein's televised messages. With a strong appeal to Arab nationalism, their exploitation of envy of rich Saudis and Kuwaitis and their defiance of the United States and Israel, they have been well received throughout the Arab world. **********But in Tunisia, many political experts go further, noting that pro-Iraqi sentiments also reflect the population's strong desire to reassert its Arab identity and Muslim traditions after 30 years in which both were suppressed as part of the Bourguiba Government's drive to modernize Tunisia. **********Reversal of Policies **********Under Mr. Bourguiba, not only was French preferred over Arabic as the language of Government, but he also banned prayers on television, ordered Tunisians to work all of Friday, denied the mullahs the right to decide holy days and had his police persecute leading members of the Islamic movement. **********After Mr. Ben Ali seized power in November 1987, however, these policies were reversed, with the new President displaying his Muslim colors by visiting holy places in Saudi Arabia on his first trip abroad. **********When he visited France on his next trip, he then surprised his hosts by speaking publicly in Arabic. **********While stressing that he is the Muslim leader of a Muslim country, though, his own version of Islam is far from fundamentalist. He continues to encourage emancipation of women, he is building a Western-style market economy and to this day this country remains one of the most cosmopolitan in the Arab world, visited by two million foreign tourists a year. **********When he met leaders of the Islamic Renaissance Party to encourage them to take part in a more open political system, however, he refused them the right to identify themselves as a Muslim party. ''My party is also Muslim,'' he reportedly told them. ''We are all Muslims.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/12/world.main_headline: G.I. Accused of Murder in Panama Invasion
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/12/world.print_headline: G.I. Accused of Murder in Panama Invasion
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/12/world.body_text: **********The Army said today that it had charged a paratrooper with premeditated murder and aggravated assault during the invasion of Panama. It was the first time since the Vietnam War that a soldier was charged with murder in a combat situation. **********The soldier who was charged, First Sgt. Roberto Enrique Bryan, 42 years old, is a Panamanian-born member of the 82d Airborne Division with more than 19 years of Army service. **********The Pentagon had portrayed the December invasion as a model of discipline, in which soldiers took great care to protect civilians and to capture Panamanian soldiers alive. **********Sergeant Bryan was charged with murder on Tuesday in the killing of an unidentified Panamanian man near the Madden Dam in Panama ''by shooting him with an M-16 rifle on or about Dec. 23.'' **********The three charges of aggravated assault also involve incidents at the Madden Dam. Sergeant Bryan is accused of hitting a Panamanian man in the hand with the butt of an M-16 rifle and striking a man in the head with the butt of the rifle on Dec. 20. He is also accused of hitting a Panamanian man in the back with a rubber hose on Dec. 21. **********A lawyer for Sergeant Bryan denied the accusations. ''Mr. Bryan is innocent of the charges,'' said Mark Louis Waple, Sergeant Bryan's civilian lawyer. ''He did nothing more than honestly and honorably serve his country during Operation Just Cause in the recent invasion of Panama.'' **********Mr. Waple said Sergeant Bryan had no record of disciplinary action and had been selected to attend the Army's Sergeant Major Academy in 1991. Sergeant Bryan has been assigned to the 82d Airborne for 10 years and was awarded the Army's Meritorious Service Medal in 1984, Mr. Waple said. Army officials said last month that the service's Criminal Investigative Command was investigating another case involving a different soldier who is accused of killing a Panamanian soldier who was taken prisoner. That soldier belongs to a unit that was stationed in Panama, and Army officials declined today to discuss the status of that investigation. **********According to the Uniform Code of Military Justice, the maximum penalty for premeditated murder is death. Other penalities include life in prison, dishonorable discharge, forfeit of pay and allowances and reduction in rank. **********According to military procedures, the accusations against Sergeant Bryan are to be be brought before a military officer. **********The investigating officer plays a role similar to that of a grand jury in a civilian court. But there are some differences. The proceeding before a military officer are ususally public, and Sergeant Bryan would have the opportunity to present evidence and to cross-examine Government witnesses. **********The investigating officer would then make recommendations to Maj. Gen. James H. Johnson Jr., commander of the 82d Airborne, as to whether there should be a court-martial and, if so, on what charges the defendant would be tried. **********Army officials said last month that the murder charge against Sergeant Bryan stems from an incident at a roadblock. A car carrying Panamanians drove up and a grenade was later thrown at the Americans, wounding some of them. The Americans fired at the Panamanians, and Sergeant Bryan is accused of killing one of the Panamanians who survived. **********A relative of the sergeant disputed the Army's account, saying that Sergeant Bryan did not commit murder. **********The investigation of Sergeant Bryan's actions was one of a series into accusations of criminal acts against American soliders in Panama. Army officials assert that the cases demonstrated the service's ability to investigate itself. **********About 24,000 soldiers and Marines were involved in the Panama invasion, which began on Dec. 20. An Army official said inquiries were made into more than 60 cases of possible wrongdoing. The inquiries led to about 20 formal investigations. Most of those cases have been dismissed. **********The investigation of the accusations were carried out by the Army's Criminal Investigation Command.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/14/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices fell sharply yesterday in repeated waves of computerized program selling, with the Dow Jones industrial average sliding 43.07, or 1.64 percent, to 2,582.67. **********Professional traders began selling heavily barely 20 minutes after the opening bell and repeatedly pounded the market, playing the price differential between the most widely held stocks and stock index futures. **********Birinyi Associates, which monitors program activity, said that a total of 98 minutes of heavy program selling during the day trimmed the Dow by 61 points. 3d-Largest Impact It was the third-largest negative impact on the Dow this year to come from program trading and was only 22 points away from the biggest decline eight months ago. **********Since the Dow average itself fell just 43.07, the implication was that program selling accounted for practically all of the market's weakness. **********In an indication that the drop ranged well beyond the 30 Dow blue chips, the broader Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 3.89, or 1.2 percent, to 318.65. **********With many traders and investors out of the market for a while, activity slowed to 123.4 million shares, from 129.9 million Wednesday. **********With 1,009 individual stocks sinking lower, 93 - including Hilton Hotels, CNA Financial and Digital Equipment - hit new lows. **********Of the 1,945 individual stocks traded yesterday, only 9 hit new highs and 430 rose. **********'Trend-Conscious' Traders **********''You have a market with just traders,'' said Michael Metz, chief market analyst for Oppenheimer & Company, ''and they're very nervous and trend-conscious.'' **********Traders appeared to react to a sharp drop in the dollar after Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said that if Congress and the Administration came to terms on a credible budget agreement, the Fed could be expected to ease short-term interest rates. Lower interest rates would make the dollar less attractive to foreign investors. **********But Mr. Metz argued that the Fed may be precluded from easing because of the inflationary impact of a weaker dollar. ''The Fed is now forced to hold interest rates higher than it would like to,'' he said, ''to keep the dollar from collapsing any further.'' **********The market was also affected by rumors early in the day about fighting in the Middle East, including one report that Iraq had bombed Israel, which ''took the market down 25 points and kicked in the programs,'' said John A. Conlon Jr., head of the equities division at Rothschild Inc. **********He said that individual investors had become ''extraordinarily cautious,'' and that many were watching for today's report on the producer price index - one of the first significant indicators of the impact of crude oil prices on the economy. **********Among the new lows, Hilton slumped 2 1/4, to 29 1/4, touching a new low of 29 after saying heavier competition in Las Vegas and a drop in gambling profits at its hotel there would cut third-quarter profits 50 percent. **********Digital Equipment, a technology favorite, slid 2 3/8 in heavy trading to 59 1/4, a new low, after Furman Selz, a Manhattan investment firm, cut its earnings estimate and no longer recommended it. **********Weak Insurance Stocks **********CNA, in a weak insurance group, fell 2 1/2, to 61 1/2, after hitting a new low of 61 3/8. Ohio Casualty was down 1 3/8, to 38 1/8; St. Paul 1 3/8, to 52 7/8; General Re 1 3/8, to 73 5/8; Marsh & McLennan 1, to 68 1/8, and AIG 1/2, to 65 1/8. **********Technology stocks also weakened, with I.B.M. down 2 7/8, to 105, in heavy trading. On Wednesday, Barry F. Bosak, a computer analyst for Smith Barney, increased his earnings estimate on the basis of new products and foreign currency advantages. **********Among the Dow stocks, 3M fell 1 1/8, to 77 1/2; Chevron 1 1/8, to 76; Kodak 1 1/8, to 40 3/8; Alcoa 1, to 67 1/4; General Electric 1 5/8, to 60 3/8; Merck 1 1/8, to 80; United Technologies 1 3/4, to 47 7/8, and Primerica 1 1/4, to 26 5/8. **********Stocks Fall in Tokyo **********TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 14 (Reuters) - Stocks in Tokyo fell today, with the Nikkei index off 177.62 points, to 24,897.46, a drop of 0.71 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/02/world.main_headline: Chinese Exiles Fight for Change and Attention
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/02/world.print_headline: Chinese Exiles Fight for Change and Attention
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/02/world.body_text: **********Hu Ping is a veteran in the struggle for democracy in China, but in his tiny office in Queens, where he presides over the oldest Chinese dissident organization in America, Mr. Hu finds that there is one thing worse than being denounced: being ignored. **********Last year, China's official press regularly excoriated the 43-year-old Mr. Hu and the organization he leads, the Chinese Alliance for Democracy, but that only tended to draw more attention and win more respect for his organization in China. Now the surge of attention that accompanied the 1989 Tiananmen Square democracy movement is fading. Mr. Hu finds himself losing influence on the mainland and in the United States, where the Alliance's voice of dissent is being challenged by other Chinese exile groups that have sprung up since the crackdown. **********Mr. Hu and his colleagues are being forced to come to terms with the predicament that overseas dissidents of many relatively closed societies face: they may speak more freely overseas, but they risk becoming irrelevant at home in China. **********''In some ways, when you are overseas, you can exercise greater influence, because you can say what you want,'' Mr. Hu said in an interview. ''But although we are outside the Communist Party and we can do things, they are of little use.'' **********Even Fang Lizhi, China's most famous dissident, has hardly had an impact in China since he was allowed to leave in June. **********Morever, as disturbing events unfold in the Middle East, the Chinese Alliance and similar groups are losing a valuable asset: America's attention. **********And quarrels among dissident groups - laced with charges that one leader or another is a spy for China -have weakened their impact. By several estimates, there are hundreds of local and national dissident Chinese groups overseas. Washington is now headquarters for several of them, including the Independent Federation of Chinese Students and Scholars. A Paris-based group, the Federation for a Democratic China, shares an office with the Alliance. **********Some of the exiles say they have been sobered by the lack of any clear sign that the hard-line Government in Beijing will collapse soon, as many dissidents hoped. **********Mr. Hu says his group, which has 2,000 members and 60 branches worldwide, had a great hope that the May demonstrations last year would lead to fundamental change in China but recognizes that it cannot be of much direct help to the Chinese opposition. Instead, its mission calls for a steady effort to educate the rest of the world about the human rights issue in China. Mr. Hu devotes most of his time to writing, sometimes for the group's Chinese-language magazine, China Spring, which it tries to circulate on the mainland, despite a Government ban. China Spring, with a circulation of 11,000, was founded in 1982, a year before the editors formed the Alliance. **********Internal Disagreements **********The Alliance has been weakened by internal disagreements, which last year led to the ousting of one of its founders, Wang Bingzhang, and a lawsuit by two senior officers against another member who is alleged to have accused them of being spies for the Chinese Communist Party. **********Last June, another member, Shao Huaqiang, declared that he was employed by the Chinese state security agency and then applied for asylum in the United States. **********After the battle with its cofounder, the Alliance separated its operations into an administration, a board of directors and an ombudsman. In February it moved its operational headquarters nearer to Congress, in Washington, while Mr. Hu remains in Queens with the editors and writers of China Spring. More recently, it has been trying to forge ties with other major dissident groups, particularly the Federation for a Democratic China. **********But even if the Alliance became more influential in China, the group's leaders realize that their struggle will be a protracted one. **********''The risks you can take are limited,'' said Chen Jiaying, an editor at China Spring. ''The Chinese people are willing to pay, but you can't ask them to pay for democracy with their lives.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/17/world.main_headline: CARTER SAYS SYRIA AIDS ON HOSTAGES
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/17/world.print_headline: CARTER SAYS SYRIA AIDS ON HOSTAGES
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/17/world.body_text: **********Former President Jimmy Carter said in Damascus today that President Hafez al-Assad of Syria promised to help win freedom for hostages held in Lebanon. **********President Assad and other Syrian officials ''are using their good offices and have assured me in every possible way'' that they will try to help, Mr. Carter said at a news conference. He added that the officials would try ''to both locate the hostages and convince those who might be holding them they should be protected and released.'' **********Mr. Carter spent two days in Damascus during which he met with Mr. Assad and Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa. Mr. Carter, who was in Cairo before going to Damascus, went on to Amman, Jordan, today. **********Syria has 40,000 soldiers in Lebanon, who control two-thirds of its territory. Their sphere of influence includes areas where Iranian-backed fundamentalists believed to be holding 8 Americans and 10 other Western nationals are thought to operate. Those regions are the Bekaa, Lebanon's eastern valley, and Beirut's predominantly Muslim Shiite southern suburbs. **********Mr. Carter spoke on the fifth anniversary of the kidnapping of Terry A. Anderson, the chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press and the Westerner who has been held hostage the longest. **********The former President did not seem to be discouraged by the latest statements purporting to come from the kidnappers. Those statements discounted an early release for the captives and even threatened to kill them. In an account given by the official Syrian press agency and received in Beirut, Mr. Carter said of Mr. Anderson, ''My own conviction is that more opportunities exist now for his release than ever.'' **********Mr. Carter said he was encouraged by the new attitude in Iran. **********''I think now there is a growing desire on the part of the Iranian Government and the United States Government to work out the problems between them and us,'' he said. ''And there is no doubt that Iran has influence on those holding the hostages, although not complete control.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/07/world.main_headline: Gorbachev Will Visit Japan Next Year
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/07/world.print_headline: Gorbachev Will Visit Japan Next Year
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/07/world.body_text: **********According to a Japanese Foreign Ministry spokesman, Mr. Kaifu told Mr. Shevardnadze that ''it is Japan's earnest hope that the Soviet Union would give serious thought to the return of the four islands to Japan.'' **********But the Prime Minister did not repeat warnings that Japan would offer little financial aid or investment for the Soviet economy until the islands are returned. The four islands were seized by the Soviets in the last days of World War II, and now serve as strategic bases for Soviet forces. **********Peace Treaty Sought **********Mr. Kaifu said today that he would like to use Mr. Gorbachev's visit to ''make a good start of discussion on a peace treaty and the territorial issue.'' But so far neither side has budged, at least publicly. **********Nonetheless, Japanese officials said they sensed some easing of the Soviet position, born perhaps of increasing interest in Moscow in having Japan infuse money and technology into its badly faltering economy. **********''There is some softening of the rhetoric on the Soviet side, and they used some conciliatory expressions,'' a senior Japanese official said today. ''But that does not mean that they are being more forthcoming than before.'' **********The prospect of Mr. Gorbachev's visit here in April has greatly heated up the longstanding territorial issue, which has brought into a stalemate Japanese-Soviet relations since the end of the American postwar occupation. And increasingly, Japanese experts are betting that Mr. Gorbachev will come to view the startegic value of the islands as far less important that attracting Japanese yen to help rebuild the Soviet economy, particularly in areas neighboring Japan like Siberia. **********Attitudes May Be Easing **********There have been some signs of easing attitudes on both sides. On Monday, Ivan Frolov, a Politburo member and chief editor of the newspaper Pravda, told Japanese reporters in Moscow that Mr. Gorbachev would bring with him ''something historic'' in his visit to Tokyo. But he did not say anything explicit about the islands, called Etorofu, Kunashiri, Shikotan and the Habomais. **********Japan, at the same time, has been making small gestures. While Mr. Shevardnadze has been locked in negotiating sessions, millions of Japanese have been following the medical condition of a three-year old Soviet boy from Sakahalin Island, an area not in dispute. The boy was flown to a Japanese hospital last weekend for emergency skin grafts after an accident left him badly burned over 80 percent of his body. It was the first time anyone from the Soviet Union was brought into Japan on short notice for sophisticated medical care, and today Mr. Shevardnadze thanked the Japanese for the gesture, saying it would be remembered. **********Mr. Nakayama and Mr. Shevardnadze also signed a series of accords, agreeing to some limited ''technical assistance'' to the Soviet economy, cultural exchanges and exchanges of scientists who can explore the lessons of the Chernobyl nuclear accident. **********But the overarching issue of the visit has been the question of the northern islands, and for the first time even business leaders and the governing Liberal Democratic Party are openly disagreeing on how to handle it. Eiji Suzuki, the chairman of a major business group, said this week that ''I am afraid Japan will be left behind'' if Japan continues to insist on a solution to the territorial issue before Japanese business is free to enter large-scale deals with the Soviets. **********Returning Only Two Suggested **********Not long ago Shin Kanemaru, a powerful former Deputy Prime Minister, revived the idea of taking back only two of the islands, a move that Japan and the Soviet Union nearly agreed to in the mid-1950's. **********But Mr. Kaifu, speaking on Monday at an annual rally seeking the return of all four, insisted that the Soviet Union ''cannot put the northern territories to the side'' if it wants to improve ties. **********The debate has also led to an unusual series of detailed historical arguments that stretch from an 1855 agreement between the two nations - which recognized the islands as Japanese territory - to the Yalta agreement, which appeared to give them to the Soviets. While the argument rages, the two nations have been unable to sign a formal treaty ending World War II. **********''An overriding condition is that we should not put off the conclusion of a peace treaty with the Soviet Union any further,'' Haruki Wada, a political commentator, wrote recently in The Japan Times. ''It is morally wrong for our generation to pass on the settlement of postwar issues to a future generation which knows nothing of World War II. It would only complicate matters to do that.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/29/busin.main_headline: Soviet Airline Agrees To Buy G.E. Engines
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/29/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Soviet Airline Agrees To Buy G.E. Engines
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/29/busin.body_text: **********The General Electric Company's aircraft engine division announced yesterday that Aeroflot, the Soviet Union's national airline, had chosen its jet engines to power 10 twin-engine airplanes from Airbus Industrie. **********G.E. said that the deal was worth $150 million and that the company would be paid in hard currency through Airbus, the European plane maker. G.E. officials said the sale was the first by a Western jet engine maker to Aeroflot, the world's largest airline, with more than 3,000 airplanes. **********The announcement of the deal, which G.E. executives said was signed three weeks ago, came a day after the company was apparently stunned by an agreement between its rival Pratt & Whitney and a subsidiary of West Germany's Daimler-Benz A.G. **********Pratt & Whitney, a subsidiary of the United Technologies Corporation, said it had agreed with Motoren- und Turbinen-Union to invest in each other and be partners in future engine developments. **********''We feel very upset about what happened; it came as a surprise to us,'' said Brian H. Rowe, a senior vice president of G.E.'s engine division. Alluding to the German company, he added, ''We had worked with them for 30 years and had an excellent relationship.'' **********G.E. and Pratt & Whitney are the leading suppliers of engines for large jet airliners, with Britain's Rolls-Royce P.L.C. as a minor factor. In many cases, when one company wins an order, it comes at the expense of the others. **********That was the case with Aeroflot, G.E. officials said. ''They could have put Pratt or G.E. engines on those aircraft and they chose G.E.,'' Mr. Rowe said. A spokesman for Pratt & Whitney confirmed that the company had sought the order. **********G.E. officials said that Aeroflot, like other Eastern European airlines that have purchased Western equipment, had agreed to have high-technology maintenance performed by Western companies, probably Lufthansa, the West German airline, or KLM Royal Dutch Airlines of the Netherlands. **********In addition to the Aeroflot arrangement, G.E. said it had contracts totaling $131 million to sell jet engines to the national airlines of East Germany, Poland and Czechoslovakia. **********It said the Romanian airline had signed a letter of intent to purchase G.E. engines and that CFM International, a 50-50 joint venture of G.E. and Snecma, a French engine maker, was negotiating to sell engines to the Hungarian airline.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/29/busin.body_text: **********The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that the nation's stock exchanges generally performed well during two tumultuous days of trading in October 1989, but it found that further measures could be taken to reduce sharp swings in stock prices. **********In a report prepared by the S.E.C.'s division of market regulation, the agency recommended that the major exchanges consider adopting "flexible capital requirements" based upon the trading activity of each stock. **********It also recommended that the exchanges take further steps to assure that market specialists have access to enough cash during times of heavy trading. Right to Buy at Set Price **********The S.E.C. also said that improvements could still be made in the halting and reopening of trading of stock index options during periods of heavy trading. These options are securities that confer a right, but not an obligation, to buy a basket of stocks at a set price within a certain period. **********Looking at the processes of settlement and clearance, the agency recommended that the Options Clearing Corporation, which collects margins to protect against adverse movements on short positions, should consider a further increase in its margin requirements to assure against "frequent dramatic market moves."  Several Measures Adopted **********Following the 1987 stock market crash, the exchanges adopted a variety of measures to reduce market volatility, including "circuit breakers" to halt trading temporarily when the Dow Jones industrial average falls by predetermined amounts. Today's report said that many of the measures that had been adopted were successful in October 1989, but that further steps should be taken. **********On Oct. 13 of last year, the Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 190.58 points, or 6.91 percent, with 112 million shares changing hands during the last hour of trading on the New York Stock Exchange. **********The day's events, fueled in part by an announcement that the financing was not available for a proposed buyout of United Airlines, raised concern among many traders that it could represent the start of a repeat performance of the stock market plunge that had occurred two years earlier. **********The next day of trading, a Monday, the market fell in its first 40 minutes of trading by an additional 63.16 points, or 2.46 percent, before rallying and closing up for the day by 88.12 points in the fourth-heaviest day of trading ever at the New York Stock Exchange.  'Reasonably Orderly Markets' **********The S.E.C. report said that over all the major and regional exchanges had performed well. "Although there were some instances of questionable individual performance, specialists generally acted in a manner consistent with their obligation to maintain fair and orderly markets and to protect investors and the public interest," the report added. "Specialists increased their dealer participation and stock purchases and generally maintained reasonably orderly markets in their stocks." **********It found that while specialists on the New York Stock Exchange had generally performed "reasonably" on Oct. 16, those at the American Stock Exchange were "inconsistent." In particular, the agency raised concerns about sharp price declines even though there were often few imbalances that would require the specialists to commit their own capital. **********In addition, nearly a quarter of American Stock Exchange shares had not opened for trading more than an hour and a half after the exchange opened. On the New York stock Exchange, fewer than 1 percent of the stocks were not trading at that time.  Disparity in Performance Cited **********"The disparity in specialist performance underscores the need for the Amex to develop and for the N.Y.S.E. to continue developing relative, objective standards of performance for evaluating specialists," the agency said. **********The report found that the options exchanges were under considerably more pressure in October 1989 than during the market crisis of two years earlier, but that they "performed significantly better in terms of maintenance of price continuity and market liquidity, the efficiency and cost of executions and overall operational efficiency." **********"Nevertheless," the report said, "concerns about the ability of options exchanges to provide a continuous market in stock index options during extreme market conditions, especially when the primary stock index futures contracts have ceased trading, resurfaced during October 1989."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/16/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;   Montreal Bank's Head Young, Conservative
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/16/busin.body_text: **********The Bank of Montreal finished installing a young management team yesterday by naming Matthew W. Barrett, 45 years old, as chairman to succeed W. D. Mulholland, who is retiring at age 63 after eight years in the post. **********Mr. Barrett, who was named president of the bank in 1987 and chief executive in July, will continue as chief executive, one of the younger ones in the world's senior banking circles. He will be succeeded as president by F. Anthony Comper, 44, who has been the bank's chief operating officer since July. **********Despite the move to younger managers, Mr. Barrett stressed a conservative approach. ''We don't have an appetite for moving out on the risk curve,'' he said, ''and we don't have an appetite for great gobs of LBO's,'' referring to leveraged buyouts. He added, ''We will continue to be quite conservative and the focus will be on quality, not volume.'' **********Mr. Barrett said that the bank would stress its business in North America over overseas business and that it would seek to build its American business up to half of the bank's earnings. ''We are a little less than halfway there,'' Mr. Barrett said. **********''We believe we have a distinct advantage because we are the only major bank with full operating capacitites in both Canada and the U.S.,'' he added. **********The bank will continue to be somewhat diversified, Mr. Barrett said. For example, it recently entered the securities industry through an acquisiton. But Mr. Barrett added that he was ''less enthusiastic about rushing headlong into multiple new businesses'' and would pursue a ''stick-to-your-knitting strategy,'' despite the temptations of deregulation. **********Mr. Barrett has spent his career with the bank. ''I was still in diapers when I joined,'' he said. ''I was 18 and a junior, not quite cleaning out inkwells. I'm an Irishman who joined a Canadian bank in London, England, and that's a long story, but I've been clawing my way up ever since.'' **********He transferred from the bank's London office to Canada in 1967 and entered its executive ranks in 1978 at age 34. **********The new president, Mr. Comper, joined the bank in its branch network in Toronto in 1967 after graduating from the University of Toronto. **********The bank's board also created two new positions, appointing Jeffrey S. Chisholm vice chairman for corporate and institutional financial services, and Alan G. McNally vice chairman for personal and commercial financial services.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/10/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Electric Car Draws Interest
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/10/busin.body_text: **********The General Motors Corporation said its experimental electric car had attracted great interest and that it expects recommendations within three months from a team studying the feasibility of producing the vehicle. **********G.M. introduced the experimental electric car, called the Impact, on Jan. 3. Since then, the auto maker has received a surprisingly strong reaction to the car and is seriously considering its market potential, the company's chairman, Roger B. Smith, said in a speech at the Chicago Auto Show. **********Mr. Smith said G.M. was still doing customer surveys, engineering studies and assessment of manufacturing costs. **********''Customer reaction around the world has been, to my mind, nothing short of astounding,'' **********Mr. Smith said. ''We've had calls from prospective customers from Perth to Paris.'' **********Mr. Smith said the Impact might cost about twice as much to operate as a comparable internal combustion car, but he added that battery technology should improve considerably every three to four years. **********General Motors' shares rose 62.5 cents today, to $42.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.
