https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/18/world.main_headline: STUDY FINDS LEAKS OF DATA ON I.R.A.
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/18/world.print_headline: STUDY FINDS LEAKS OF DATA ON I.R.A.
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/18/world.body_text: **********An independent police report published today says that British security forces passed information about Irish terrorism suspects to outlawed Protestant paramilitary groups in Northern Ireland. **********The report was issued in Belfast by John Stevens, deputy chief constable of Cambridgeshire, England, who was assigned to the task by the police chief in Northern Ireland. He and a team of English detectives spent eight months investigating assertions that Protestant terrorists had links with members of the Royal Ulster Constabulary, the army and the Ulster Defense Regiment, a largely Protestant organization similar to the National Guard in the United States. **********''I have been able to draw firm conclusion that members of the security forces have passed information to paramilitaries,'' the Press Association, Britain's domestic news agency, quoted Mr. Stevens as saying at a news conference. ''However, I must make it clear it is restricted to a small number of individuals, who have gravely abused their positions of trust. This abuse is not widespread or institutionalized.'' **********Reaction Is Critical **********Reaction to the report was mainly critical. Sinn Fein, the political wing of the I.R.A., called it a ''whitewash and coverup.'' The group claimed there was clear evidence that a ''significant group'' of Royal Ulster Constabulary members had been consistently passing information to ''loyalist death squads.'' Peter Robinson, deputy leader of the Democratic Unionist Party, called the report a ''cynical political exercise brought out to appease nationalists.'' **********Mr. Stevens said that it was clear that official information produced by the Royal Ulster Constabulary and the army had been passed illegally to Protestant paramilitary groups. The groups used the documents and other information to enhance their own intelligence systems and as an aid in targeting people suspected of being I.R.A. terrorists. **********He said that it was impossible in many cases to trace those responsible for the disclosures because of the ''serious lack of controls and adequate accounting procedures relating to the distribution of security force documents, coupled with the age of the documents themselves.'' He published 83 recommendations for improving the handling of intelligence and investigation terrorism, including the establishment of an anti-terrorist squad. But he acknowledged that ''in the present climate,'' information leaks from the security forces ''may never be completely eliminated.'' **********The police chief in Northern Ireland, Hugh Annesley, appointed Mr. Stevens in September to investigate allegations of collusion after the BBC broadcast a report that members of an illegal Protestant terrorist group, the Ulster Freedom Fighters, had showed him a list of Irish Republican Army suspects they said they had obtained because of a ''breach of security,'' and said they had used it to assassinate a Roman Catholic man, Loughlin Maginn. **********Loss of Security Document **********Suspicion of collaboration between the Protestant authorities in Northern Ireland and Protestant terrorists there is one of the reasons for support for I.R.A. terrorism from the Roman Catholic minority in the north. Among other things, Mr. Stevens looked into the disappearance from a high-security Belfast police station last year of a confidential bulletin-board poster showing the photographs and names of 12 people suspected of being members of the I.R.A. and the loss of a security document from an Ulster Defense Regiment base. **********Mr. Stevens said that 94 people had been arrested in connection with his inquiry and 59 of them had been charged or reported for alleged offenses under the Prevention of Terrorism Act or other security statutes. The British authorities charged two privates in the Ulster Defense Regiment with Mr. Maginn's murder. No members of the Royal Ulster Constabulary have been charged as a result of the investigation, Mr. Stevens said. **********The British Secretary of State for Northern Ireland, Peter Brooke, said in the House of Commons today that he still had the fullest confidence in the Ulster Defense Regiment but that he found some findings in the report ''painful.'' **********''It has highlighted shortcomings and deficiencies in several important areas,'' Mr. Brooke said. ''I am fully aware of the great efforts that continue to be made by the regiment steadily to improve its effectiveness and professionalism, and I have no doubt that the overwhelming majority of its members impartially serve the whole community in Northern Ireland.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/15/world.main_headline: Rio Journal;   A Most Unlovely Slum (Even if the View Is Nice)
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/15/world.print_headline: Rio Journal;   A Most Unlovely Slum (Even if the View Is Nice)
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/15/world.body_text: **********Santa Marta hill affords an exhilarating postcard view of Rio's tourist attractions - Sugar Loaf Mountain, South Atlantic beaches and the Christ statue high on a neighboring mountain peak. **********But the atmosphere on the hill is anything but that of a postcard. For example, when restoration workers raised metal scaffolding around the Christ statue recently, a little girl in the Santa Marta hill slums asked her mother, ''Why are the men putting Christ in jail?'' **********Cramped, violent and poor, the hillside community of Santa Marta is one of many favelas, or slums, that are home for about half of Rio's seven million inhabitants. **********Sociologists once dubbed Brazil ''Belindia'' - an affluent Belgium surrounded by an impoverished India. A tour of Rio's India starts where the maps end. **********Life in a Half-Lit World **********Airbrushed out of the minds of the affluent, most favelas do not appear on city maps. Indeed, many maps paint Santa Marta pastel green, implying perhaps that the hill, home to 10,000 poor people, is a park. **********In the middle-class Botafogo neighborhood, a cobblestone street gave way to a snaking, climbing alley. Ramshackle houses quickly closed in, forcing an intimacy with the sounds and smells of the inhabitants - blaring radios, crying babies, cooking oil and untreated sewage. **********Of unpainted wood and rough brick, the shanties are jammed so tightly together that the afternoon sun dims. Children raised in this half-lit world, half a mile from the beach, have a gray pallor. **********A woman laboring up the path with a bag of groceries stopped long enough to complain that her adopted son had been killed the night before by a rival cocaine trafficking gang. **********Gang War Under Way **********A few twists and turns later, the alley opened to a small patch of sunlight. Three young men, clearly working as lookouts for a drug gang, sat on a rock, one cradling a shotgun. With a nod, they let a group of visitors pass. **********''Those boys are going to die,'' said Frances O'Gorman, a community organizer well versed in the politics of the favela's cocaine gangs. In brief, she explained, Zacarias's gang recently wiped out the Long Hair gang, only to confront the ruthless Red Falange. At stake is Santa Marta, a prime location for distributing cocaine to Rio's beach-front neighborhoods. **********''I have never known a year as violent as this,'' said Ms. O'Gorman, who has worked on the hill since the late 1970's. She said that at the self-help group she advises, United Social Works of Santa Marta, one-third of the 20 council members have recently fled the favela in face of gang death threats. **********Halfway up the hill, the rooftop play area of the Social Works center offered a reprieve of sunshine, fresh air and the sweeping view of sea and mountains. From a slum on a far hillside came an irregular series of pops. **********''There's a shootout going on,'' said Anita de Souza Barbosa, general coordinator of the social group. It is not a terribly unusual occurrence on the hill. In the 1980's, homicides in greater Rio de Janeiro tripled, hitting 7,654 in 1989. **********Day Care for 68 Children **********Slum dwellers get little solace from calling the police. Members of Rio's underpaid military police routinely appear in newspaper crime pages here - as suspects. **********At the social center, Mrs. Barbosa showed the broken hinges of a food storeroom door she said had been kicked in by police ''looking for drugs.'' **********''They threatened to come back and take our typewriters,'' the community organizer said, referring to typewriters used for teaching secretarial skills to slum girls. **********On May 1, Mrs. Barbosa's 19-year-old son, Alcemir, was badly beaten by policemen in front of his shack. **********A rare bright light on the hill, the center provides day care for 68 children of mothers who work, most of them as housemaids. **********But, reflecting the slum's precarious health conditions, only 38 children were at the nursery on a recent afternoon. A contagious skin infection kept the rest at home. **********Urban Amenities Installed **********A new, city-run health clinic was another bright spot on the tour. Indeed, a few of the amenities of urban life are slowly penetrating a slum formed over 30 years ago by rural migrants from Brazil's interior. **********Muddy alleys, once slippery with sewage, are gradually being paved with cement. Electric wires and plastic water pipes now reach into most corners of Santa Marta. Last year, the city installed a garbage collection bin at the slum's entrance and started reinforcing the hillside to prevent mudslides. **********In March 1988 a tropical downpour unleashed a mudslide that swept 60 houses down the hill. ''Eight of my neighbors died that night,'' said Raimunda Sampaio, whose dark, four-room cement shanty stands next to the reinforcing work. **********A drawn woman who looked decades older than her 48 years, Mrs. Sampaio said she came to Rio at age 18 from a rural town in Brazil's northeast ''150 leagues from the coast.'' Twenty-two years of marriage produced 12 children; 10 survived. **********''I came to make a life for myself, and I made only babies,'' she said as a naked grandchild wobbled uncertainly next to a water barrel. **********New President Supported **********Five minutes away, through a maze of alleys, stood a house of greater hope. With the help of the social center's credit union, Joana Barbosa dos Santos was replacing her wood and tin shanty with a house of brick and corrugated roofing. **********A migrant from the northeast, Mrs. dos Santos worked for over three decades as a housemaid for families in Rio before retiring recently, without a pension. Three of her children work in local supermarkets, each earning little more than Brazil's legal minimum monthly wage - $70. **********Mrs. dos Santos echoed what polltakers have detected - lower class support for the radical economic plan of Brazil's new President, Fernando Collor de Mello. To battle Brazil's 5,000 percent annual inflation, Mr. Collor froze prices and blocked savings accounts. **********In a recent poll, 45 percent of the lowest-income people interviewed said they were ''totally in favor'' of the economic plan, double the approval rate expressed by respondents with medium or high incomes. **********''At least you buy something today - rice, cooking oil - and you know that tomorrow it will be the same price,'' Mrs. dos Santos said. ''No one up here has any savings. We just work to eat.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/31/busin.main_headline: Centel Plans to Sell Electricity Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/31/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Centel Plans to Sell Electricity Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/31/busin.body_text: **********The Centel Corporation said it intended to sell its electricity operation, which provides service to more than 136,000 customers in Colorado and Kansas. Centel said it expected to reach an agreement to sell the business before the end of the year. The operations generated revenues of $165 million and earnings of $29 million last year. **********The Chicago-based company said it had received considerable interest from several organizations seeking to acquire the properties. Centel, which declined to name the interests, said the intended sale was part of its strategy to focus on its local exchange telephone and cellular communications businesses. In the last three years, Centel has acquired more than $1 billion in cellular properties and has sold its cable television operations, its Federal systems division and has divested itself of its interest in two long-distance carriers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/07/world.main_headline: Ferry From Norway Catches Fire; 150 Are Missing and Feared Dead
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/07/world.print_headline: Ferry From Norway Catches Fire; 150 Are Missing and Feared Dead
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/07/world.body_text: **********About 150 people were missing and feared dead after a ferry caught fire in the North Sea today, the Norwegian rescue service said. **********''Approximately 150 people are still missing,'' said Eldboerg Vaage, a spokeswoman for the service. ''We fear they were trapped on board by the fire.'' **********Earlier, the service said all 500 people on board were believed to have been rescued. **********The Scandinavian Star, traveling from Norway to Denmark, issued a distress signal after a fire broke out on board about 30 nautical miles south of the Faerder lighthouse at the mouth of the Oslo fjord. It was still blazing after dawn broke. Most of the 395 passengers and 100 crew members abandoned ship in lifeboats and were picked up by other vessels, helped by helicopters from Norway, Sweden and Denmark. **********''What we know is that 335 people have been saved,'' the rescue service spokeswoman said. **********She said the estimate of missing increased because rescuers had believed at first that the Stena Saga, a ferry which came alongside the stricken vessel, had picked up around 200 people. **********''But we found they only had 60 on board,'' she said. **********Most of the people traveling on the Scandinavian Star were believed to be Norwegians.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/08/busin.main_headline: Carnival Cruise's Chief Adds Chairman's Title
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/08/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;   Carnival Cruise's Chief Adds Chairman's Title
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/08/busin.body_text: **********Ted Arison, an immigrant from Israel who founded Carnival Cruise Lines Inc. in 1974 with one ship, is turning over the title of chairman to his son, Micky, 41 years old, the company's president and chief executive. **********Ted Arison, 66, plans to stay on the board and act as a consultant, the company said on Friday. **********The Miami-based cruise line has 15 ships operating under three different company names in the Caribbean, South Pacific and Mediterranean and in Alaskan waters. **********The company, which was incorporated in Panama in 1974 and began selling stock to the public in 1987, has added a hotel and casino complex in Nassau, the Bahamas, the Crystal Palace Resort, to its holdings. The cruise line is the world's largest based on the number of passengers carried, the company says. **********Not all of Ted Arison's projects have turned out so well. Part of his business empire included the Ensign Bank, a New York savings institution that was declared insolvent last month by the Government. The institution has remained open under the control of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the Government bailout agency. Mr. Arison said at the time through a spokesman that the bank was being recapitalized and that he was ''shocked and outraged'' by the action of the regulators. **********Mr. Arison's other interests include a real estate company based in Atlanta and a majority stake in Miami Heat, the National Basketball Association team. **********Micky Arison, who has been running the day-to-day Carnival operations for the last 11 years, has characterized his father as an entrepreneurial dreamer while he termed himself more of a manager. **********His father will continue to be involved in the overseeing the four ships that the company has under construction or on the drawing boards. The 2,600-passenger Ecstasy, being built in Finland, is scheduled to enter service on June 2 in Miami. An Italian shipyard, Fincantieri, is building the three others. **********The growth of Carnival came through its stress on low-priced packages coupled with heavy advertising. With its new ships, it is moving into other segments of the cruise market - higher- and lower-priced vacations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/17/busin.body_text: **********Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed for the week ended yesterday. **********Analysts at Donoghue's said the well-received government quarterly refunding last week, plus reduced fears of inflation, both here and abroad, helped move rates lower in the fixed-income markets. ''And the markets are in the process of correcting those earlier expectations,'' said Walter S. Frank, chief economist at Donoghue's. **********Donoghue's seven-day compounded average yield for a taxable money market fund rose 4 basis points, to 8 percent. The temporary increase was the result of the recent rally in short-term fixed-income securities, analysts noted. The 30-day average yield remained unchanged at 7.98 percent. **********Assets of taxable funds decreased by $2.3 billion for the week, to a total of $374.7 billion, with institutional assets up by $200 million, to $79.3 billion. Consumer assets, meanwhile, were off by $2.5 billion, to $295.4 billion. Fund managers pointed to the Treasury's refunding and stock market rally as explanations. **********The average days to maturity of securities held in managers' portfolios was unchanged at 44. **********Among the general-purpose money market funds with assets of more than $100 million that are surveyed by IBC/Donoghue's, Summit Cash Reserves, distributed by Merrill Lynch Funds Distributors Inc., Princeton, N.J., led with a yield of 9.62 percent. **********Yields of tax-exempt funds were down for the week ended yesterday, as assets decreased by $262 million, to total $75.3 billion. The decline was not viewed by analysts as significant. The average seven-day compounded yield was down 7 basis points, to 5.67 percent. For investors in a 28 percent tax bracket the equivalent yield in taxable securities is 7.875 percent, and 8.462 percent for those in a 33 percent bracket. **********Donoghue's reported that for the third consecutive week the Calvert Tax Free Reserve California portfolio, distributed by the Calvert Group, Washington, had the best yield at 6.40 percent, down 9 basis points from the previous week. The spread over the seven-day average yield narrowed by two basis points, to 73. **********By comparison, The Bank Rate Monitor's national index shows bank money market account yields off a basis point, to 6.22 percent, and six-month certificates off 3 basis points, to 7.99 percent. One-year certificates declined by a basis point, to 8.17 percent, and five-year certificates fell 3 basis points, to 8.21 percent. Two-and-a-half year certificates remained unchanged at 8.20 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/21/busin.body_text: **********Hurt by weak earnings, Citicorp and the Chase Manhattan Corporation, the nation's first- and second-largest banking companies, are cutting costs and focusing on the most prestigious part of their businesses: handling large corporate clients. **********The more austere approach at Chase was signaled on Thursday, when senior officers were told that the international advisory committee - a group of 19 of the world's most prominent business executives headed by David Rockefeller, chairman of the bank in the 1970's - would hold two meetings later this year at Chase's headquarters in New York rather than in London and Brussels as planned. **********And Chase directors, in an apparent effort to set an example for the rest of the bank, agreed to shift a meeting later this year from Williamsburg, Va., also to the more economical setting of Chase's headquarters building near Wall Street. **********'A Massive Effort' **********Chase officials declined to comment publicly on the changes. ''It is true, however,'' said Fraser P. Seitel, a spokesman for Chase, ''that we are engaged in a massive effort at Chase to do two things - boost revenues and reduce operating expenses by $300 million a year.'' **********Bank insiders said the changes were disclosed Thursday morning when Thomas G. Labrecque, Chase's newly named chairman, briefed senior officers about the previous day's board meeting. **********At Citicorp, cost-cutting is concentrating on the global finance group, which lends to large corporations in North America, Europe and Japan. The bank said yesterday that it was reorganizing the group's management structure in ways that ''ultimately will result in fewer people and lower costs.'' Job Losses Acknowledged While both Chase and Citicorp are still working on details of how to reorganize their corporate lending businesses, they acknowledge that many jobs will be lost. At Chase, executives estimate that more than 3,000 employees might be cut, out of its work force of 42,000. Citicorp, with 90,000 employees, has not indicated how many jobs might be lost as it reorganizes the 15,000-employee global finance group, but analysts expect that a cut of several thousand is likely. **********A large number of the layoffs are expected in New York City, where both banks are based. But both are continuing to expand their consumer banking business, which employs the greatest number of workers. **********''We are witnessing truly major efforts to control costs, the like of which American banks have never seen before,'' said Thomas Hanley, a managing director at Salomon Brothers. **********While the cost-cutting ''is long overdue,'' Mr. Hanley added, a determined management could cut costs more than might now be expected. At Chase, for example, ''I expect they will ultimately achieve cost savings substantially greater than the $300 million target they have set,'' he said. **********Frank DeSantis, an analyst of large New York City banks at Paine Webber Inc., said the actions at Chase were a reminder that ''it is amazing what people can do in a crisis.'' Spending on meals and lodging for directors and the advisory committee is not the major problem at Chase, but ''the changes are symbolic and show a willingness of management to cut expenses starting at the top and going down,'' he added. **********The shifts of meetings were suggested by Mr. Labrecque, whose announcement was loudly applauded at the normally uneventful monthly meeting of the senior officers, bankers at the meeting said. The 51-year-old Mr. Labrecque, an executive with 26 years of experience at Chase, was named in June to succeed Willard C. Butcher as chairman at the end of October. Mr. Butcher, who is retiring, was selected by Mr. Rockefeller to run the bank during the 1980's. **********Profits Rather Than Prestige **********Because Chase has been well known in banking circles for lavish spending on entertainment of clients and senior employees, analysts saw the willingness to cut spending on meetings of the advisory committee and the directors as a sign that under Mr. Labrecque the bank will become more concerned with profits than prestige. **********The international advisory committee was created by Mr. Rockefeller as a way for Chase to benefit from the economic and political insights of key business leaders. Henry A. Kissinger is a member of the committee, along with Giovanni Agnelli, the chairman of Fiat S.p.A., and Lord Carrington, chairman of the Christies International auction house and a former British Foreign Secretary. **********Under Mr. Rockefeller, and to a lesser extent Mr. Butcher, the chairman of Chase has tended to be more involved with activities like the international advisory committee, leaving to subordinates the nitty-gritty work of controlling costs and avoiding bad loans. **********Mr. Labrecque has already indicated he will be more active than his predecessors in the daily management of the bank. **********Employee-Protection Plan **********Other action taken by Chase's board on Wednesday included approval of a plan to protect all employee severance pay agreements and retirement funds if control of the company changed. The so-called ''tin parachutes'' would not necessarily prevent an unwanted acquisition or merger, but they have been adopted by other banking companies because they make employees more confident about their future. **********The need for cost-cutting is especially evident at banks like Chase and Citicorp, which have been hurt by a decline in wholesale lending and other financing for large corporations. While the banks still maintain expensive networks of foreign offices, corporate treasurers have learned how to borrow more cheaply in the securities markets or from foreign banks. During 1989, the decline in the wholesale banking business with large corporations accelerated, as the number and size of corporate takeovers and leveraged buyouts dropped. **********Citicorp executives say they do not have a target for how many jobs will be cut in the next few years. But analysts said they expected Citicorp would cut costs in its global finance group by at least 10 percent, with the loss of several thousand jobs. Profits in the global finance group, headed since January by Michael A. Callen, fell 69 percent in the second quarter, to $42 million, as operating expenses rose along with the costs of bad loans. **********Change in Measurements **********To improve the performance of the global finance group, Mr. Callen said that the practice of measuring bankers' performances by earnings of each profit center would be de-emphasized and replaced by measures of market share, rankings compared with other banks and the total amount of revenues from a corporate client. **********Mr. Callen said he was beginning to review staffing in each of 50 different activities of the global finance group with a goal of cutting back the layers of management. **********Citicorp and Chase are not the only money-center banks acting to reduce costs. Earlier this week, the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, the eighth-largest banking company, said it was planning to cut 1,400 jobs and reduce costs by $125 million annually. Most of the cuts are also expected in the corporate finance area.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/17/busin.body_text: **********The Grumman Corporation, the nation's 10th-largest military contractor, pleaded guilty to two criminal counts of unauthorized use of secret Pentagon documents, the Justice Department said today. **********It said the company was ordered by a Federal judge in Alexandria, Va., to pay $2.5 million in fines and damages as part of the plea-bargaining deal. **********Grumman becomes the fourth large company to plead guilty in the long-running investigation into unauthorized trafficking in documents by contractors and military officials. **********The other companies that have pleaded guilty are the General Motors Company's Hughes Aircraft unit, the RCA unit of the General Electric Company and the Boeing Company, the world's largest aircraft manufacturer. The Pentagon has taken no action against any of the companies. **********Justice Department officials said Grumman, an aircraft manufacturer based in Bethpage, L.I., obtained secret military budget and planning documents from 1978 to 1985. **********The company's guilty plea was expected after a former Grumman marketing analyst, Harry Kotellos, pleaded guilty on Monday to illegally obtaining and distributing secret Pentagon budget reports in the early 1980's. **********Mr. Kotellos, a retired Air Force lieutenant colonel, faces a maximum penalty of five years in prison and $250,000 in fines when he is sentenced May 18. Grumman said it discharged Mr. Kotellos last week.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/25/busin.main_headline: California Bankers No Longer Fear Outsiders
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/25/busin.print_headline: California Bankers No Longer Fear Outsiders
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/25/busin.body_text: **********For years, California bankers have been bracing for the second California gold rush. Come next January, banks from other states can expand into the state's huge and lucrative market. And bankers in the state have feared that New York giants like Citicorp, Chase and Chemical would swoop in and buy large California banks, creating continent-spanning empires. **********But as the magic date draws near, it is shaping up to be a less earthshaking event than was thought when the California legislature approved the interstate banking bill in 1986. Most New York banks, weakened by problems with third world debt, can no longer afford to buy a huge California bank. And the California banks, having had five years to prepare, have armed themselves for the conflict. Like Japanese banks, they have bought up attractive independents in the state, leaving little for the New Yorkers. **********''Most bankers have forgotten whatever fears they might have had at the time,'' said Howard Gould, the former California banking superintendent who is now managing director of the Secura Group, a consulting firm in Pasadena, Calif. **********Indeed, the major banks in the state, with the exception of First Interstate Bankcorp, are entering the new era in a stronger position than ever. And they are likely to have the fast-growing economy of the nation's largest state and its ringside seat on the Pacific Rim to themselves, maintaining what some consumer groups see as an oligopoly. **********In fact, the California banks could end up becoming the nation's premier banks, eclipsing their rivals in New York. It is not surprising, then, that rather than 1991, attention here is focused on the new leaders of three of the state's four largest banks, who were recently appointed to replace executives who shaped those institutions for more than a decade. **********At BankAmerica, the state's leading bank, Richard Rosenberg, a marketing whiz, is replacing A.W. Clausen. At Security Pacific, the state's second-largest bank, Robert H. Smith has just replaced Richard J. Flamson. At First Interstate in Los Angeles, down-to-earth Edward M. Carson is expected to reverse some policies of the expansion-minded Joseph J. Pinola. Only at Wells Fargo & Company, ruled by penny-pinching Carl Reichardt, is no change in the works. **********Not everyone is convinced that 1991 will be a ho-hum affair. ''It's a sort of once-in-a-lifetime event,'' said Mr. Smith. **********While New York banks may not be able to afford to buy into California, there could be mergers of equals between big banks in both states. In addition, California banks will be able to expand into other states after 1991. While they may shun the crowded New York retail market, other areas like the Southeast, might be attractive. **********Some analysts believe the Japanese-owned California banks may take most advantage of that new opportunity. Never prohibited from buying California banks, Japanese banks have purchased almost all of the state's medium-sized banks and control 25 percent of its banking assets. **********Despite a recent softening in the real estate market and the threat of defense spending cutbacks, California remains almost too attractive for outsiders to ignore. Citicorp, the largest New York bank, is still expected to increase its presence here. And First Interstate, reeling from loan losses, might prove to be a tempting acquisition. ''Everybody figures it will be somebody's Christmas present,'' said one investment banker. **********Some super-regional banks, like NCNB of North Carolina, might also move into California. Comerica Inc. of Detroit staked its claim last September, agreeing to buy Plaza Commerce Bancorp of San Jose next year. **********The 1986 California interstate banking law was the fruit of persistent lobbying for several years by the New York banks. Some consumer groups also favored the move to stimulate competition. There are more than 400 banks in California, but the four giants control about 65 percent of all deposits. Consumer groups say that California consumers receive less interest on deposits and pay higher interest on loans than in more competitive areas like New York. Yet California bankers claim they compete furiously - on service rather than rates. **********But consumer advocates do not expect much change in 1991. The New York banks are not the powerhouses they once were. Although Wells Fargo has only half the assets of Chase Manhattan, its market capitalization is 20 percent higher. The strongest New York banks, J.P. Morgan and Bankers Trust, are not much interested in retail banking, California's main attraction. **********Besides, small banks, with assets below $1 billion, are almost the only thing left to buy. And as David A. Brooks, Citicorp's executive in charge of consumer banking in the West, puts it, Citicorp would have to buy as many as 35 to 40 small banks to become as big a player as it would like in California. **********Another possibility is to buy a savings and loan. Some of the state's thrifts have as much as $20 billion or more in assets - a substantial market position. But some bankers worry that a thrift's customers would leave after a takeover since they typically look for the best interest rates rather than the long-term relations that banks offer. **********That leaves First Interstate, which is considered the most likely takeover candidate in the state. Established before interstate banking restrictions took effect, First Interstate operates in 13 Western states, making it easy for an acquirer to sell off pieces to help finance a purchase. Its banks in California, Oregon, Washington and Nevada are performing well. But the company's results have been dragged down by loan problems in Arizona and, particularly, Texas, which it entered in 1987. The problems caused a net loss of $124.5 million in 1989. **********First Interstate would be the most logical acquisition in the state for Citicorp. But both Wells Fargo and Security Pacific say they would be interested. BankAmerica is also thought to be intrigued. ''It's really a question of who is going to pull the trigger,'' said Donald K. Crowley, an analyst with Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, based here. **********But analysts say everyone is afraid of pulling the trigger for fear of driving First Interstate into the arms of another bank. That could buy First Interstate time. Mr. Carson, 60, who will take over from Mr. Pinola in June, said First Interstate is ''not looking for a buyer,'' although it is not intent on staying independent ''at all costs.'' He added, however, ''if we perform the way we think we will, then it's in our shareholders' best interest to stay independent.'' **********Mr. Carson says that unlike his predecessor, his goal is not expansion, but to ''maximize what we've got.'' He has already cut the holding company's headcount to 200, from 500, and says he would sell off some smaller banks in states like Colorado and Wyoming to raise cash, while keeping its major banks, including those in Arizona and Texas. **********The bank's recent stock offering, through which Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company bought a 10 percent stake in First Interstate, alleviated its capital crunch. Although the buyout firm says it will be a passive investor, analysts say it might eventually buy First Interstate itself or force its sale. **********Bankamerica has undergone a similar transformation. A few years ago, suffering from huge losses from bad loans, BankAmerica was a carcass from which competitors were biting off chunks of market share. Having slimmed down, revved up marketing and put its loan portfolio in order, the bank is a feared giant again. And Mr. Rosenberg, who has headed the bank's California retailing operations since 1987 and will take over from Mr. Clausen in May, is expected to strengthen its retail banking operations in California and elsewhere in the West. **********Mr. Rosenberg and most of the other top brass at BankAmerica are veterans of Wells Fargo, as is Jerry A. Grundhofer, head of Security Pacific's California bank. They have spread a style of banking throughout California that turned Wells Fargo into the state's premier bank in terms of profit growth and stock appreciation, although some analysts are now concerned by its large number of loans in troubled areas like real estate and leveraged buyouts. **********The philosophy, pioneered by Wells's chairman Mr. Reichardt, is simple: Cut costs to the bone and expand by acquiring banks in one's own state, eliminating redundancies and achieving more efficiencies than buying in another state. Wells is now digesting three small banks to further bolster its market share in Southern California. ''San Diego County is bigger than the entire economy of Oregon,'' said Robert L. Joss, a vice chairman. ''Would you buy a bank in Oregon or would you try to expand in San Diego?'' **********If any California bank takes advantage of 1991 to move outside the state or merge with a New York bank, it is likely to be Security Pacific. Security, which has expanded into other businesses like investment banking and consumer finance, believes size is necessary for American banks to compete with giants from Japan and Europe. ''If that means being a $200 billion or $150 billion organization by merging with someone, so be it,'' said Mr. Smith, who has long been the heir apparent and had a role in shaping the bank's policies. **********CITICORP ON THE PROWL IN CALIFORNIA **********John S. Reed, the chairman of Citicorp, has defined three strategic new markets for his bank: Western Europe, Japan and California. That leaves little doubt that the nation's largest bank plans to take advantage of the opening of the California market. **********Citicorp already has more than 5,000 employees in the state, engaged in everything from corporate lending to designing automated teller machines. It boasts more credit card holders in California than any bank except Bank of America. And Citicorp, which has long emphasized retail banking, established a foothold in California in 1982 by purchasing a troubled Oakland thrift and renaming it Citicorp Savings. **********But trying to turn an ailing thrift into a healthy bank was tougher than Citicorp envisioned. Citicorp Savings has assets of only $7 billion and very low profits. Many consumers and businesses in California are still not aware of Citicorp's presence. ''We're not arrogant enough to believe we're here until customers believe we're here,'' said David A. Brooks, who is in charge of consumer banking for Citicorp in the West. **********But 1991 and new thrift regulations could change that. To start, Citicorp Savings will get a new name next month, Citibank Federal Savings Bank, to identify it more as a bank. Citicorp will also be able to combine back office operations of its banks and its thrifts, which could lower Citicorp Savings's costs. **********And Citicorp will begin marketing banking services to its credit-card holders in the state. ''If we could just get our card base to bank with us, we'd be the largest bank in California,'' Mr. Brooks said. **********But Mr. Brooks, a former vice chairman of Crocker National Bank, said the marketing campaigns won't be effective unless Citicorp has more branches. Right now, Citicorp Savings has 95 branches in the San Francisco Bay area, putting it among the top five banks and thrifts. But in Southern California, the 35 branches are woefully inadequate. ''You can't compete without bricks and mortar,'' he said. That probably means acquisitions, starting in 1991. Mr. Brooks would not comment on whether Citicorp would want to buy First Interstate Bancorp. But he did say that to become a major player in the state's largest metropolitan areas, Citicorp would prefer one or two large acquisitions to numerous small ones. **********Some analysts say Citicorp, with its capital base weak and its stock depressed, is not in a great position to make such a move right now. But Mr. Brooks said if the right deal came along at the right price, it could raise the money. ''By the end of the 1990's we will be a big player in this marketplace,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/28/world.main_headline: Convictions Set Aside For 3 in an Ulster Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/28/world.print_headline: Convictions Set Aside For 3 in an Ulster Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/28/world.body_text: **********An appeals court today set aside the convictions of three Irish citizens serving 25-year sentences for conspiring to kill Britain's Secretary of State for Northern Ireland in 1987. **********The three - Martina Shanahan, 24 years old; John McCann, 26, and Finbar Cullen, 29 - were immediately arrested again under Britain's Prevention of Terrorism Act. The Government is considering whether to ban them from Britain. **********The appeals court ruled that the judge at the trial in 1988 should have ordered a retrial because of public comments made at the time by Tom King, then the Secretary of State for Northern Ireland. **********Mr. King was supporting a Government proposal to allow courts in Northern Ireland to draw inferences about guilt or innocence from a person's refusal to answer police questions. Two of the defendants had refused to do so.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/25/world.main_headline: 28 Sudan Officers Executed On Charges of Trying a Coup
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/25/world.print_headline: 28 Sudan Officers Executed On Charges of Trying a Coup
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/25/world.body_text: **********A military firing squad executed 28 officers, including three retired generals and a brigadier, after a summary court-martial on charges of trying to stage a coup, official news organizations reported. **********A statement broadcast on the Government's Radio Omdurman said that a colonel was acquitted but that a court-martial was continuing. **********The executed officers included the two retired senior officers, Maj. Gen. Abdul-Kadir al-Kadaru and Brig. Mohammed Osman Hamid Karrar, who were accused by the Government of being leaders of the attempted plot.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/02/busin.main_headline: Efforts to Speed U.S.-Japan Trade Talks Are Working
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/02/busin.print_headline: Efforts to Speed U.S.-Japan Trade Talks Are Working
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/02/busin.body_text: **********An accelerated effort to ease trade friction between the United States and Japan is yielding results, with recent agreements to open Japanese markets to American telecommunications equipment and supercomputers and the possibility that an accord on satellites will be reached this week. **********Over the weekend, talks on opening the Japanese satellite market to American products were near a successful conclusion but were temporarily adjourned as the two negotiating teams sought further instructions on a technical point from their Governments. The talks are to resume Monday, and an announcement is possible on Tuesday. **********A new test of how far Japan will go in meeting American trade demands will come this week as negotiators meet at the State Department for a fourth round of talks on ''structural impediments'' - the more pervasive obstacles to trade that stem from public policies and cultural habits. These include, for example, land-use policies that make doing business in Japan extremely costly, or levels of spending on such things as housing, schools and public works so low that domestic growth is dampened and dependence on exports for economic growth is increased. **********Concessions Promised **********Japanese officials said their negotiators would bring concessions in their briefcases, but it remains to be seen how far these would go in narrowing a $49 billion imbalance in trade between the countries last year. Over the last decade, the gap was nearly $400 billion. **********Both sides are racing to meet a mid-April deadline for an interim report that could influence feelings in Congress, where frustration over Japanese policies that block imports is rising. A final report is due in July. **********''Japan has, to some degree, opened its market,'' the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, said in a recent interview. ''But we need to have them open it much more, and when people ask how much more, I say I want them to respond to the competitive criteria of price and quality.'' **********Some of the Japanese seem to have heard Washington's message. ''The mounting discontent in the U.S. Congress against the huge Japan-U.S. trade imbalance can be said to be a hair trigger,'' the Japanese Foreign Minister, Taro Nakayama, said recently. ''Deterioration of sentiments towards Japan appears to be spreading nationwide in the U.S.'' **********In the background on Capitol Hill is legislation recently introduced by Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana and chairman of the Senate subcommittee on trade, that increases the chances of reprisal by subjecting the structural impediments to the Super 301 provision of 1988 trade law, which sets rigorous negotiating targets and deadlines. **********The Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act of 1988 provides a structure for the United States to identify and retaliate against unfair trade practices. Last year the United States decided to pursue intensive negotiations with Japan over its trade practices in supercomputers, satellites and wood products. **********Under the law, if the Japanese markets in these sectors are not open by June 16, the United States may retaliate by imposing up to 100 percent tariffs on selected imports from Japan. **********Political stakes are also high in Tokyo, where factions of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party have protested some American demands, particularly one that seeks to eliminate a law that delays the opening of large stores for up to 10 years. The law is intended to protect Japan's many small retailers. **********Pressure on 2 Sides **********Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu is walking a tightrope between opponents within his party and President Bush, who stepped up the pressure on Japan at a meeting with Mr. Kaifu in Palm Springs, Calif., a month ago. **********That meeting is coming to look more and more like a turning point in the long history of trade disagreements between the countries. Mr. Taifu, who had just won election, promised to make changes in structural reforms a priority of his new Cabinet, and seems to have at least partly delivered on that pledge. **********To win support in Parliament, the Japanese leader has argued that the reforms are needed not just to ease frictions with Washington but to help Japanese consumers. **********Polls suggest that he is getting public support. One survey by Nihon Keizai Shinbun, a leading business newspaper, found that more than 80 percent of 10,000 Japanese surveyed agree wholly or in part with American criticism that the Japanese economy should be more open. **********Not as Difficult **********This suggests that trade concessions may not be as difficult to achieve as many in the Government and the ruling party have been saying. **********In addition to seeking a relaxation of restraints on big retailers, who are usually more willing to risk introducing new products, including goods directly imported from abroad, the United States wants, among other changes, a much tougher Japan Fair Trade Commission. **********Moving Rapidly **********While preparing for the new negotiating round on structural impediments, the two Governments have moved rapidly to bridge differences in other areas. **********For example, the Governments, facing retaliation threats, have just concluded a preliminary market-opening telecommunications agreement that could help American companies sell more equipment and services to Japan. And on March 23, they announced a preliminary agreement on measures to open the Japanese market to the most powerful American-made computers. **********The Japanese have shown some flexibility in discussions about market barriers in wood products. An assistant United States trade representative, Don Phillips, is to lead a negotiating team to Tokyo next week to make another attempt to resolve the issue.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/26/world.main_headline: Li Peng Says Soviet Ideas of Change Do Not Apply to China
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/26/world.print_headline: Li Peng Says Soviet Ideas of Change Do Not Apply to China
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/26/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Li Peng of China said today that reports of a rift with Moscow over the waning of Communism had been exaggerated, but he left little doubt that the two neighbors are on different political wavelengths. **********At a news conference ending the first visit by a Chinese Prime Minister since Zhou Enlai's trip 25 years ago, Mr. Li said the Soviet model of political and economic change did not apply to China, and appeared to juxtapose President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's problems of runaway ethnic unrest with what he insisted was solid political stability in Beijing. **********The two countries were to issue separate statements rather than a joint communique on the visit, a decision that was attributed to lack of time but is often a sign of diverging views. **********Mr. Li's visit came almost a year after Mr. Gorbachev ended 30 years of chill between the two nations by traveling to Beijing to normalize relations. **********That visit was largely eclipsed by student pro-democracy demonstrators, who occupied Beijing's Tiananmen Square demanding liberalizations similar to those Mr. Gorbachev has permitted. Mr. Li was central among the Chinese hard-liners who sent tanks to crush the protest. **********Border and Trade Issues **********The Chinese Prime Minister's reciprocal visit this week produced several signs that the normalization continues, including agreements on troop reductions along the 4,300-mile Soviet-Chinese border - with details as yet undisclosed - as well as on trade and on technological exchanges. **********There are believed to be about a million troops facing each other on the two sides of the lengthy frontier. Mr. Gorbachev last year pledged to pull back some 200,000 troops unilaterally. But Western military analysts say the withdrawal has not yet been carried out. A significant reduction in the force level would presumably benefit the economies of both countries. **********Mr. Li said economic agreements signed here included long-term Soviet credit for China to build two power engineering facilities, in return for $735 million in short-term Chinese credits to provide Soviet consumers with textiles and light industrial products. **********A student in Moscow in the 1950's, Mr. Li seemed somewhat at a loss when asked to compare the city of his memories with contemporary Moscow. He said the streets seemed wider and the buildings more modern, but did not mention, if he noticed it, that by Chinese standards the stores are sparsely supplied and the political debate is shockingly frank. He spoke in Chinese through an interpreter. **********'Have to Wait and See' **********Asked about reports that the Chinese leadership blamed Mr. Gorbachev for the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe, Mr. Li dodged the issue of the Kremlin's role and said: ''It is too early to say that they have abandoned socialism and socialist policies. We have to wait and see.'' **********Mr. Li said President Gorbachev had convinced him that the changes under way in the Soviet Union were ''of a socialist orientation'' and disparaged ''speculations'' in the West about ideological differences. **********''It is true that different socialist systems have different views of perestroika and our reforms, but every socialist country has its own reality and real situation,'' he said. **********''Each country should decide for itself how socialism should be built,'' he said. ''We do not have one model to follow.'' **********The decision by the Soviet Communist Party to give up its statutory monopoly on power, Mr. Li said, was ''a choice made by the Communist Party and the people of the Soviet Union'' but that China had no desire to emulate it. **********Confident About China **********The Chinese leader said his willingness to visit Moscow reflected his confidence that China was under solid control and the political leadership united. **********''Some believe that in April, May or June this year more disturbances will affect China,'' he said, referring to predictions that students would try to observe the anniversary of the democracy movement. ''But I am sure that nothing of that sort will happen.'' **********Mr. Li said that the reported ethnic unrest in the northwest of China was ''an event of very small proportions'' and that ''now the situation is stabilized.'' The Governor of the province where the unrest took place accompanied Mr. Li to Moscow, possibly to discuss Chinese concerns that northwest China would be influenced by ethnic unrest across the border in Soviet Central Asia. **********''We earnestly hope that stability will prevail inside the Soviet Union and we also hope that the U.S.S.R. will be able to settle its problems,'' Mr. Li said. **********Asked about the disgraced former Chinese Communist leader, Zhao Ziyang, who was deposed after showing lenience toward the student protests, Mr. Li said he was ''quite well, lives in Beijing, and is still a member of the Chinese Communist Party'' although his activities were ''under study.'' **********''He has a salary which is greater than mine,'' Mr. Li said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/08/busin.main_headline: Icahn Seen As Loser in USX Vote
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/08/busin.print_headline: Icahn Seen As Loser in USX Vote
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/08/busin.body_text: **********Carl C. Icahn all but conceded today that he had failed to win support for his plan to split the USX Corporation. The votes cast at the annual meeting here will not be tabulated for at least a week, but the indications are that the New York financier has come up short in his costly campaign. **********''There are five or six major investors who have told us that even though they agreed with what we have been trying to do, they intend to vote with management,'' Mr. Icahn told reporters after the meeting. **********For its part, USX maintained again today that the Pittsburgh-based company is healthier financially than it had been in years. **********'Businesses Are Humming' **********''Our businesses are humming,'' Charles A. Corry, the chairman, told shareholders. ''We have a solid, balanced energy operation that's growing. We are operating a good metals business that's one of the most efficient steel producers.'' **********For the last month, Mr. Icahn, USX's largest shareholder, has been traveling widely to persuade shareholders to support a nonbinding resolution asking the company's managers to spin off at least 80 percent of its steel business as a dividend to shareholders. Mr. Icahn has insisted that USX shares have been undervalued and that splitting the company would yield a value of $48 a share. **********On the New York Stock Exchange today, USX's shares fell 50 cents each to close at $33.50. **********The shareholders attending the annual meeting here, the home of USX's Marathon Oil Company subsidiary, seemed generally to support management's position that the company should remain intact. **********Renewed Attention **********Still, several institutional investors and analysts said that even if Mr. Icahn failed to win a majority of the votes, he had succeeded in putting considerable pressure on management to improve USX's share price and to give renewed attention to the prospect of separating the company's historical core business from USX's larger energy holdings. **********Mr. Icahn, while suggesting that big institutions had enough votes to deny him the majority he sought, remained upbeat. ''I believe the company will eventually follow the course we have outlined,'' he said, ''and I know many institutional investors who have spoken with management believe the same thing.'' **********Mr. Icahn said today that he would continue to meet with shareholders and with USX management to press for a spinoff of the steel business. ''Even if I do not win,'' he said, ''the higher the vote we get, the more leverage we gain for our argument.'' **********Some investors contend that USX's managers have told them privately that a breakup has been seriously considered and that such a move might be pursued over time. But the company has argued that a spinoff or sale of the steel business would be better timed when the steel market is healthier than in recent months. **********Visible Campaign **********Mr. Icahn has in recent weeks taken on a highly visible campaign, spending heavily on newspaper and television advertising. He said at the beginning of the proxy battle that he would spend as much as $10 million to promote his case. USX, too, has been spending on advertising, saying that it could probably match Mr. Icahn's expenditures in this contest. **********In comments at the meeting, Mr. Icahn urged the company to abolish a ''poison pill'' provision that prevented anyone from acquiring more than 15 percent of the company without it becoming prohibitively expensive. Mr. Icahn, who holds 13.3 percent, said he would like to increase his holdings beyond that point and was willing to sign an agreement promising not to seek control. **********He further accused USX's managers of engaging in a ''widespread campaign'' in which they told shareholders that he intends merely to cause the share price to increase and then sell his stock - he paid in the low $20's for most of his holdings - and take his profits. ''But nothing could be further from the truth,'' Mr. Icahn told shareholders. ''I have been a stockholder for the last four and a half years. I have been a loyal shareholder and a patient one.'' **********Concerns About Cost **********While several shareholders here and elsewhere have acknowledged that the value of their investment might rise under a proposal like Mr. Icahn's, they said they had concerns about the cost and tax implications of creating a second company. **********The analysts have suggested that USX has managed to convince the shareholders that its restructuring plan, which includes selling off the reserves of its Texas Oil and Gas Corporation subsidiary and buying back shares, was sufficient. They have also contended that having two companies would add $115 million a year in operating costs. **********''Management has had a certain inertia on their side,'' said John Jacobson of AUS Consultants in Philadelphia. ''It's difficult for some shareholders to accept that management knows less about how to run the company than Carl Icahn does.'' **********Mr. Icahn said today that his campaign had focused attention on the issue of retaining the company's steel operation. He added that USX's steel business needed more capital investment, ''but that should not come from Marathon,'' he said. ''The steel company needs to bring in equity capital on its own, and it might be good to bring in a foreign investor to help the steel business meet the capital needs of the 1990's,'' he added. **********The proxy battle has been one of the most unusual in recent corporate history. Although they are typically used to oust a board or affect an acquisition by another party, this contest has centered on a resolution that is not binding and asks management to spin off one of its businesses. **********Some analysts have suggested that Mr. Icahn's troubles in gaining more votes in this contest centered on questions about the sincerity of a man regarded by many as simply being a corporate raider. **********''The proposal would have been considered in a much different light if it had not been promoted by Carl Icahn,'' said Howard D. Sherman of Institutional Shareholders Services Inc., a Washington-based firm specializing in consulting institutional investors in proxy contests. ''Icahn is unfairly tainted by simply having been around when a lot of Wall Street criminals were doing their thing. And, unfortunately, that is what a lot of people have focused on.'' **********He added that USX's management has been highly regarded for turning around its steel business after the depressed conditions of the early 80's. ''Management has also done a good job of creating questions in the minds of shareholders on whether Mr. Icahn's numbers add up,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/17/busin.body_text: **********The giant Sumitomo Bank Ltd., whose chairman, Ichiro Isoda, resigned last week in the wake of a stock manipulation scandal involving a branch manager, received more setbacks today. **********A second top executive, Teizaburo Nishi, the vice president in charge of Sumitomo's domestic branch network, announced he was resigning. Also, a spokesman said that the salaries of the bank's top 24 executives would be reduced by about 16 percent for the next six months. **********At the same time, Moody's Investors Service said it was reviewing the bank's triple-A credit rating because of concern over its multibillion-dollar portfolio of real estate loans, particularly to Itoman & Company, a trading concern with more than $5 billion in property-related loans outstanding, many in arrears. **********Osaka-based Sumitomo, the most profitable bank in Japan last year, is regarded as the country's most aggressive bank. **********''Despite their reputations, the big banks have always lent money to the big speculators,'' said Stuart Matthews, banking analyst for Barclays de Zoete Wedd. ''It was very profitable.'' **********Mr. Nishi's resignation was in response to the arrest 10 days ago of Akinori Yamashita, a former branch manager in Yokohama, on charges he had made illegal loans to Mitsuhiro Kotani, a takeover artist indicted earlier for stock manipulation. **********These developments came while a severe stock market slump has taken a big bite out of banks' earnings and reduced their capital. Moody's has lowered the ratings of six Japanese banks this year and is considering lowering four others.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/11/world.main_headline: Argentine Deaths Bring Focus on Health Care
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/11/world.print_headline: Argentine Deaths Bring Focus on Health Care
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/11/world.body_text: **********The recent deaths of about 30 patients in a state-run women's psychiatric hospital - from malnutrition, the hospital union says - has focused attention on the virtual collapse of Argentina's health-care system. **********Although the case produced a series of charges and countercharges about who was responsible and a shake-up in the Health and Social Welfare Ministry, health experts say it is really just one example of problems produced by mismanagement and lack of money. **********As a result, although Argentina still has a high ratio of well-trained doctors to patients, many basic health needs go unmet. **********Union leaders at the Moyano Hospital, which houses 1,650 women with various kinds of mental health problems, asserted last month that 32 patients there had died in June as a result of an inadequate diet. **********Health officials initially denied the charge and said the death toll was actually 28, all from aging and other natural causes. But Health and Social Welfare Minister Eduardo Bauza subsequently blamed one of his aides, Dr. Matilde Menendez, for the state of the hospital and dismissed her and several others. **********The Moyano is a vast complex of 28 wards. Some of the wards are a century old; the newest was built in 1942. They are spread out over 40 acres in the outskirts of Buenos Aires and are described as damp, run-down buildings with skeleton medical staffs. **********After the public scandal over the deaths, kitchen workers said the diet at the hospital was typically 10 days of rice and 10 days of polenta, a cornmeal mush, with only an occasional balanced meal. **********Health officials say about two-thirds of the patients at Moyano do not require permanent hospitalization but have been abandoned by their families and have nowhere else to go. **********Although Argentina has tried to maintain a health system that reached most of the population, officials say the drastic decline in public money for such care in recent years has divided the quality of service along rich-poor lines. **********Reducing the Deficit **********The Government of President Carlos Saul Menem has undertaken the belt-tightening measures as part of its efforts to reduce the immense fiscal deficit, which is blamed for Argentina's high level of inflation. Now running a relatively mild 10 percent to 12 percent a month, inflation was nearly 200 percent in one month a year ago. The hospital situation is further aggravated by the fact that Congress has not yet passed the proposed 1990 budget. **********Most Argentines who can afford it have become members of private health maintenance organizations, with monthly fees that average about $100 per adult covered by the plan. For those who are without such coverage or who are dependent on the social benefits programs of labor organizations, the quality of care is rapidly deteriorating. **********Officials of the Malbran Institute, in charge of preparing and inspecting blood serum and vaccines for the public health system, recently went to President Menem and obtained an emergency payment. They said that the boiler at the institute had broken down and that without it the sterilizing equipment did not work. **********Health statistics released this year showed an overall decline in a number of categories in which Argentina had been at or near the levels of developed, industrial countries. **********Child Mortality Figures **********The figures showed a steady rise in recent years in infant mortality, deaths in childbirth and child malnutrition. And the study noted that many of the deaths of children under 5 could be attributed to preventable ailments like polio. **********Although the main cause of death in Argentina continues to be cardiovascular disease, as in most developed Western countries, the study said that there was a steady rise in infectious diseases like tuberculosis and those caused by parasites.
