https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/27/world.main_headline: How Distinct Is Quebec? French, and That's That
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/27/world.print_headline: How Distinct Is Quebec? French, and That's That
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/27/world.body_text: **********The stop signs here all say ''arret.'' French Canadians have their own national holidays, their own music videos, their own literature. They drink wine at lunch and still smoke with abandon in cafes, offices and public elevators. **********That Quebec is different has long been taken for granted. But the question of how to institutionalize those differences has tormented politicians here and in Ottawa for decades. The collapse of the most recent attempt to accommodate Quebec's distinctiveness within the Canadian federation has once more left the question unresolved. **********Two provinces, Newfoundland and Manitoba, refused to ratify the Quebec agreement, known as the Meech Lake accord. The dissenters complained that the clause granting special status to Quebec had Orwellian undertones: Quebec would become ''more equal'' than the other nine provinces. Quebec is now defiantly exploring the means to go its own way, though without saying exactly how far. **********Signs: French Only **********Had the accord been signed, it is widely assumed that the Quebec provincial government would have used the constitutional guarantees to pursue the same goals, accelerating the pace at which French speakers have been wresting control of issues like immigration, employment and above all language policy. But in that case such expanding of local autonomy would have been carried out within a framework binding Quebec to the rest of Canada. Now the process continues in a less stable political atmosphere. **********Quebec's sign rule - a provincial law passed more than a year ago that banned all English-language signs and billboards - is the most dramatic example of how Quebec has sought to impose French as the official language in the province. Eighty percent of Quebec's population is French-speaking; almost half the people speak little or no English. **********''Our linguistic difference is a kind of shield that protects us against the pressure of North American culture,'' said Alain Dubuc, chief editorial writer for the Montreal newspaper La Presse. '' 'Miami Vice' never caught on here.'' Demography is a far greater threat to French culture than McDonald's or MTV. The province, which had one of the highest birth rates in the Western world 30 years ago, now has the lowest. French Canadians fear that they are becoming an endangered species. Major policy disputes almost always reflect that preoccupation. **********Even without the constitutional accord, Quebec is the only province with its own immigration service. French Canadian civil servants work alongside federal government employees in every Canadian consulate and immigration office from Paris to Hong Kong. Schoolyard English?  Quebec is obliged to abide by Federal immigration regulations and thus has little real power over selection, quotas or numbers. But the province's immigration officials abroad seek to encourage French-speaking immigrants to chose Montreal over Toronto or Vancouver. **********Despite the recent breakdown of constitutional talks, the Quebec provincial government has kept on negotiating with Ottawa for even greater control over how it spends its share of the immigration budget, as well as for more say in the assimilation of new immigrants. **********Quebec already has in place a law that requires all new immigrants to send their children to French schools, regardless of their country of origin or their personal preference. When the largest school board in Montreal recently issued a proposal calling for schoolchildren caught speaking English in corridors or playgrounds to be punished, it further underscored what Canadians view as an irreconcilable philosphical difference between the two cultures. **********''The notion that the collective interests of a majority supersede individual rights is indigenous to Quebec,'' Peter Blaikie, a English-speaking lawyer in Montreal, said. One reason the constitutional agreement collapsed was some provinces' fear that Quebec would use the ''distinct society'' clause of the Meech Lake accord to further restrict minority rights. **********Quebec's economy is the most statist in Canada. The provincial government invests heavily in local businesses and industries. Quebec has its own $37 billion social security pension fund, having opted out of the federal system in 1966. Its stated purpose is to use savers' investments to promote Quebec's economic growth. Last year, when the Steinberg grocery store chain went up for sale, the pension fund intervened to insure that the chain remain in French Canadian hands. **********Low University Fees **********That more European approach is reflected in other fields. Despite a steep tuition rise that will go into effect next year, university fees in Quebec are still among the lowest in Canada. **********Quebec abides by the federal criminal justice system, based on English common law, but in civil cases, it follows the Napoleonic code. There are few significant clashes. Civil courts follow federal rules of procedure, but Quebec civil cases are presented to a judge, not a jury. Three out of nine seats on the Canadian Supreme Court are reserved for Quebec judges. **********On most social issues, Quebec is more liberal. Abortions are easier to obtain than in other provinces. Homosexuality, even among public officials, is generally accepted. **********Quebecers proudly insist that they are less puritanical than their English-speaking counterparts. French Canadian journalists, like Europeans, rarely invade the privacy of their politicians. In the 70's, the marital turmoil of former Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau was a much bigger story outside Quebec than within. That restraint has held up into the 90's. **********''We don't delve into politicians' private lives,'' Mr. Dubuc explained. ''An elected official can womanize. No one will write about it.'' **********'We Are More Expressive' **********French Canadians take enormous pride in their temperament, which they describe as anything but Anglo-Saxon. ''We are Latins, we are more expressive,'' Martine Belleville, a cook in a Montreal vegetarian restaurant, said with an unapologetic shrug. **********She was explaining the spontaneous street demonstrations on the Quebec national holiday of St. Jean-Baptiste, when hundreds of young Montrealers piled into cars and, waving fleur-de-lis banners and beer bottles, happily honked and blocked traffic most of the night. **********They were as noisily exuberant as Brazilians after a victorious soccer match, but they were celebrating the sobering prospect of a more autonomous state. **********''You would never see 200,000 people take to the streets of Toronto to celebrate being Ontarian,'' Jean-Claude Rivest, an adviser to Premier Robert Bourassa of Quebec, said with relish. ''That's what makes us a distinct society.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/07/busin.main_headline: Talking Deals;   Pressure to Sell On Savings Units
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/07/busin.print_headline: Talking Deals;   Pressure to Sell On Savings Units
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/07/busin.body_text: **********LIKE the Landmark Land Company, which recently put its vast real estate portfolio up for sale, other California savings and loan associations are now trying to sell their properties to comply with new Government regulations. **********Not all of them have been buffeted by imprudent real estate loans and investments. Like Landmark, Downey Savings and Loan, a Newport Beach, Calif., institution, has a substantial real estate operation that has performed well for more than 30 years. Nevertheless, it, too, has begun selling assets to meet new rules governing the savings industry's activities in the real estate business. Included in the rules are stricter capital requirements and higher loan-loss reserve standards. **********Bruce W. Harting, a savings and loan analyst with Salomon Brothers, said it took at least six months after the enactment of the Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery and Enforcement Act of 1989 for most savings and loans with large real estate operations to realize that it would be advantageous to divest immediately, rather than to wait until July 1994, as the law allows. Now, many of those companies are bringing their portfolios to market. **********Executives at Landmark, which owns its properties through Oak Tree Savings, a Louisiana-based savings and loan association, acknowledged that the forced sale of its real estate would probably cause the company to dispose of properties below market value to avoid falling short of the new capital requirements. **********''When I first realized what the regulations would mean, I was paralyzed,'' said Gerald G. Barton, chairman and chief executive of Landmark. ''I could not believe this would happen. Why would anyone want to disband one of the best real estate companies in the world?'' **********Downey has easily met all the capital requirements established by the new regulations, but must still sell parts of its portfolio to meet rules that govern what types of real estate investments a savings institution may make. **********Executives at Downey say they realized that later this year and into next a flood of commercial properties would reach the market as savings and loan associations rushed to sell their portfolios and as the Resolution Trust Corporation - the Federal agency charged with financing the Government's rescue of the savings and loan industry - begain selling properties seized from insolvent institutions. So Downey started liquidating its $560 million real estate portfolio early this year. **********So far, the company said that it had sold seven shopping centers for more than $85 million, giving it a $20 million profit, and that it was negotiating the sale of five others, which could bring another $10 million. Its investment in residential properties remains largely in loans to developers. **********''Downey particularly, and to a lesser extent Landmark, are in enviable positions because they have relatively strong balance sheets,'' said Bert Ely, president of Ely & Associates, a consulting firm in Alexandria, Va., and an expert on the savings industry. ''But they are more the exception than the rule among these institutions.'' **********It is Oak Tree's balance sheet that makes Mr. Ely somewhat cautious about Landmark's position. It may turn out that Landmark will need a significant gain on the sale of its real estate assets to absorb losses that may appear down the road in Oak Tree's operations. The company has had large losses on its mobile home operations, it has about $1.2 billion of mortgages on raw land, and questions may arise later about the adequacy of its reserves because of other concerns, like the amount of good will on its books and the amount of money it has moved to its service corporation. **********Depending on the amount of its future losses, Landmark's capital position could deteriorate, requiring a capital infusion from the sale of properties. **********One factor that weighs heavily on the financial condition of savings institutions is whether they are in residential or commercial development and in what markets. **********''Most of the S.& L. companies with real estate development facilities are West Coast companies,'' said Mr. Harting of Salomon Brothers, ''and the residential building market there is still good.'' **********Mr. Harting said he expected significant premiums for the sale of residential development subsidiaries because of the relative strength of the California housing market. The commercial market is more difficult, he said, but it is still a little too early to determine just how much discounting will be necessary in the second half of this year. **********Among the many other California savings units that are now marketing their portfolios are Great American Bank, a San Diego-based company, which is suffering from a large exposure to the depressed Arizona market; GlenFed Inc., a troubled Glendale, Calif., company that is also trying to unload its development subsidiary, and CalFed, the nation's fourth-largest savings unit.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/15/world.main_headline: A RELIGIOUS PARTY HOLDS SHAMIR FATE
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/15/world.print_headline: A RELIGIOUS PARTY HOLDS SHAMIR FATE
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/15/world.body_text: **********The fate of the Israeli Government and its peace initiative lies in the hands of a small, rigorously Orthodox religious party that won 1.5 percent of the vote in the last national elections. **********''I can tell you, I feel very uncomfortable about this,'' Rabbi Avraham Ravitz, head of the Torah Flag Party, said this afternoon as Labor and Likud leaders courted his favor. On Thursday morning the Parliament votes on a motion of no confidence in the Government that will, if the motion passes, bring Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's Government to an end. If the motion fails, however, it will confirm Mr. Shamir as the leader of a narrow, right-wing government without the Labor Party. **********As it stood this afternoon, the Labor Party seemed likely to get votes from 60 of the 120 members of Parliament. Likud seemed likely to get 58 votes, leaving the decision in the hands of Rabbi Ravitz and his little party that got only 34,279 of the more than 2.3 million votes cast in November 1988. **********Heavy Price Proposed **********And tonight, the rabbi told Mr. Shamir that he would give Likud his vote, but at a heavy price: Likud would have to accept the American terms for starting Israeli-Palestinian peace talks, even though Mr. Shamir has already rejected them. And the Prime Minister would have to allow all the Labor ministers, who were dismissed or resigned on Tuesday, back into the Cabinet - a price Mr. Shamir was unlikely to pay. **********Under Israel's political system, this party, which has only two members in Parliament, was able to set such conditions as the Prime Minister's price to stay in power. Late this evening, Mr. Shamir had not responded. **********But whatever may come of Torah Flag's offer and the nation's Government crisis, it seems most likely that Israel's peace intiative, and the American proposal for advancing it, will move forward little if at all. **********If the next Government is headed by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, he will almost certainly remain unalterably opposed to moving forward with the plan, even though he is the one who originally proposed it a year ago. **********Protests From Right Feared **********But even if the next Government is headed by the Labor leader, Shimon Peres, an advocate of the talks, many people here agree that his government would not be able to do much more than talk to a Palestinian delegation. If talks moved beyond that, the protests from the right would grow so strong that Mr. Peres's fragile, narrow government probably could not survive. **********For today, however, the decision on the nation's direction lay with Rabbi Ravitz. If Mr. Shamir refuses his terms and Torah Flag does in fact vote in favor of Labor's no-confidence motion, or if it abstains, then the Shamir Government will fall. **********But if Mr. Shamir gives in and Torah Flag votes in favor of Likud, then the motion will end in a tie, meaning it fails. That will enable Mr. Shamir to control the Government. **********''We shouldn't have to make the decision for the whole nation as such a small party,'' Rabbi Ravitz said. But the rabbi's quandary is the product of the deep divisions in Israeli society that keep the nation and its Government from being able to make decisions. Without a consensus, Israel's proportional-representation electoral system produces government after government so riven with disagreement that it cannot act. **********Change in Mood Sensed **********Before the last national elections in November 1988, Israelis were united in their desire not to see another Labor-Likud coalition government, so poorly had the last one functioned. But after the elections, faced with the specter of a narrow Government dominated by religious parties, Israelis demanded a new ''national unity'' Government. **********Now, 15 months later, the second Labor-Likud Government is about to end, and it has been able to accomplish even less than the first one. Though there has been no accurate reading of the public's temperament, Labor and Likud leaders say they believe the mood has changed again. **********In December 1988, as the Labor-Likud coalition agreement was being worked out after weeks of embarrassing negotiation with the religious parties, about 50,000 people held a boisterous rally in a Tel Aviv park urging electoral reform. **********Most of them were angry at the terms the religious parties were demanding as the price for joining a narrow Government - the closing of restaurant and movie theaters nationwide on the Sabbath, an expansion of military-service exemptions for the Orthodox and a redefinition of who is considered Jewish under Israeli law, a demand that so angered the American Jewish community that it now seems to have been dropped. **********Peace and Electoral Change **********The demands so angered the public that when the Government was formed, Labor and Likud leaders concurred in their written coalition agreement that the top two priorities would be to work toward peace, and to change the electoral system to dilute the power of small parties and end the perpetual Governmental stalemate. **********A joint Labor-Likud Parliamentary committee was formed and it was decided that the principal problem, as the committee saw it, was that the vote threshold for a seat in Parliament was too low. Only about 20,000 votes are needed to win a seat, guaranteeing that small parties will fill Parliament. **********That denies Labor and Likud the ability to build a government without becoming allies of several smaller parties that have different goals and agendas and can at any time withdraw support if their interests are not met, meaning that the narrow coalitions are inherently unstable. **********The electoral reform committee drafted a bill that raised the vote threshold for election to more than double the present level, and at first it seemed to garner considerable support. But last spring the bill fell victim to the very pressures that motivated the legislators to draft it. **********Religious party politicians lobbied heavily against it, afraid that the new system would dilute their power. The secular politicians succumbed, afraid that the religious parties might not support them if the reform bill failed and they were in need of coalition partners again. The bill died. ---- Kollek Cites Bush's Assurance LONDON, March 14 (Reuters) -Mayor Teddy Kollek of Jerusalem said today he had received assurances from President Bush that the United States still opposed any division of Israel's capital. **********At a news conference during a visit to London, Mayor Kollek released a letter from the White House in which President Bush restated the United States policy on Jerusalem, which has been to oppose a division of the city and to promote talks over its future. **********''The basis of our position is that Jerusalem must never again be a divided city,'' said the letter, dated Tuesday. ''We did not approve of the status quo before 1967; in no way do we advocate it now. This was and is my policy.'' **********President Bush recently struck a new note in United States statements on Israel by condemning Jewish settlement of East Jerusalem, annexed by Israel after the 1967 Middle East war and now a mixture of Arabs and Jews. **********Palestinians view Jerusalem as the capital of a future state and most countries, including the United States, do not recognize Israel's annexation of the eastern sector of the city.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/30/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene;   The 2-Front Battle Facing Moscow
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/30/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene;   The 2-Front Battle Facing Moscow
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/30/busin.body_text: **********LITHUANIA'S struggle for independence from the Soviet Union has virtually blotted out from public attention President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's decision earlier this month to accept the advice of his liberal advisers and move rapidly to establish the basis for a market economy. A set of decrees is expected shortly from the Government on paving the way. But the battle to keep the Soviet empire from disintegrating could cause Mr. Gorbachev again to delay his plans for a radical reform of the system. **********Prof. Abram Bergson of Harvard, an authority on the Soviet economy, has said Mr. Gorbachev may be approaching the point where President Roosevelt was in 1941, when ''Dr. New Deal'' had to give way to ''Dr. Win the War.'' But for Mr. Gorbachev, winning the war - as various nationalities seek to secede - means rescuing the economy at the same time. For the economic crisis is worsening the nationalities crisis. **********The Soviet leader's problem is vastly different from Roosevelt's near the outbreak of World War II, when an underemployed market economy, not fully recovered from the Great Depression, could respond vigorously to the pressures of rapidly rising Government wartime demand. **********By contrast, the Soviet Union has an economy so bureaucratic, so lacking in incentives, so demoralized that it could not possibly respond to an increase in demand. The last thing it needs is an increase in demand; it is already suffering from vastly excessive public and private demand, with an enormous budget deficit and a bloated, but largely hoarded money supply, ready to explode into inflation. **********Official Soviet statistics show household savings deposits at 338 billion rubles, but there is a huge, unknown volume of rubles in private hands, believed to be 100 billion to 300 billion. Edgar L. Feige, an economist at the University of Wisconsin, puts the ruble overhang at 1.1 to 1.6 times the annual retail sales of the Soviet Union. To prevent a runaway inflation, if price controls were suddenly lifted, that ruble overhang needs to be mopped up. Mr. Feige believes that can best be done by undertaking a program of ''Socialist privatization'' to lay the groundwork for subsequent market reforms. **********In the first stage of this process, he holds, the constitution should grant and guarantee private property rights; in the second stage, the Government should relinquish ownership of the means of production, which many critics see as the real root of both inefficiency and dictatorship, and redistribute the nation's wealth, in the form of shares in state enterprises, agricultural resources and the housing stock, to its citizens. **********The surplus money collected by the sale of state assets to citizens, and to state and local governments, business enterprises, and foreign investors, would be sterilized, or withheld from circulation. Once monetary balance was restored and citizens provided with income-earning assets to ''buffer'' subsequent economic adjustments, the stage would be set for ending price controls, permitting the price-and-profit system to play its critical information and incentive roles. **********''Socialist privatization'' would obviously not guarantee each citizen equality of outcome but equality of opportunity, a ''level playing field'' at the start of the market system. It would be, in effect, like the start of a new game of ''Monopoly,'' when shares (instead of money) would be divided up equally, though in the longer run there would be unequal distribution of wealth and income, as the assets were better employed by some players, in competition with others. In fact, the real name of the game would be ''Anti-Monopoly,'' to end the monopoly power of state-owned and controlled resources and enterprises. **********But will Soviet citizens accept the inequality of income? Many experts contend that a major obstacle to growth is that the Russian people traditionally have been and still are envious of anyone who makes more money than they do. Prof. Wassily W. Leontief, the Nobel laureate in economics at New York University, says, ''They don't like anybody who makes profits.'' **********But this may be changing, as indicated by the first comprehensive survey of Soviet attitudes, conducted in interviews ranging from one to one and a half hours with 2,485 Soviet citizens in both urban and rural areas. The survey was directed by Ellen Mickiewitz of Emory University, a professor of economics and a Carter Center fellow, and other emigre scholars based at American universities. They found that 84 percent of the Soviet citizens interviewed favored the ''reform'' idea of permitting greater income inequality, while only 11 percent favored the ''traditional'' idea of income equality. **********The respondents were split evenly, however, between those who held that ''the State should be mainly responsible for people's success and well-being'' and those who agreed with the statement that ''people should look out for themselves, decide for themselves what to do for success in life.'' **********Clearly, if an uncertain and divided public, who is nevertheless ready for change and willing to accept inequality, is to be brought together in support of a market system, and energized to produce more, they will need to get not more rhetoric from the top but a real personal stake through ownership of the means of production. **********In effect, this calls for a new revolution, and Mr. Gorbachev will have to take greater risks and show greater decisiveness in leading it. If he fails to do so, his entire effort at economic and political modernization may collapse and hasten the disintegration of the Soviet Union.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/13/world.main_headline: U.S. and Soviets Confident as Trade Talks Open
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/13/world.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;   U.S. and Soviets Confident as Trade Talks Open
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/13/world.body_text: **********The United States and the Soviet Union opened talks today on ending nearly a half-century of trade restrictions. Both sides expressed confidence that an accord could be ready for signature when President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev meet in Washington in June. **********Among other things, an agreement would help the Soviet Union by cutting the unusually high duties that the United States levies on imports from the Soviet Union. **********Mr. Gorbachev is under increasing domestic pressure to show economic improvements. Mr. Bush's decision to seek a trade agreement, which was announced at the summit meeting in Malta in December, is a sign of American support for Mr. Gorbachev's economic and political reforms. **********''We got off to a good, fast start,'' said a senior official at the Office of the United States Trade Representative, speaking at the end of the first day of negotiations. **********The United States team is being led by the Trade Representative, Carla A. Hills, and the Deputy Trade Representative, Julius L. Katz, and includes officials from several other departments, including State, Treasury, Commerce and Labor. **********Asked whether he was optimistic, Yuri N. Chumakov, the Deputy Soviet Trade Minister who heads the Soviet team, said: ''It's not a question of optimism. We are soldiers in this case.'' He was referring to the Malta directive that an agreement be reached by June. He added that his team was ''not pessimistic.'' **********Reflecting more open Soviet emigration policies, Mr. Bush told Mr. Gorbachev at Malta that he would work toward granting ''most favored nation'' tariff status to Moscow as part of a trade accord. The United States is also seeking some concessions from the Soviet Union, especially assurances of greater access to its markets, for example, for machinery and other heavy equipment, where the American share has been running at under 5 percent. **********As Mr. Chumakov put it tonight, the agreement could be ''a very big support for exports of U.S. goods in the Soviet market.'' **********Economists here say American consumers could see prices for products like Soviet vodka drop by as much as $1.25 a bottle. Prices could also be lower for luxury imports like furs and caviar. **********Soviet exports to the United States are chiefly petroleum products, inorganic chemical elements and minerals, and nonferrous waste and scrap metals, as well as vodka and furs. **********Given the intense competition from Japanese, South Korean and Western European exporters, it is unlikely the Soviet Union will sell more consumer goods in the American market, at least over the short term. **********The principal American export to the Soviet Union is food. Over the first 11 months of last year the United States exported $3.82 billion to the Soviet Union, with most of this grain. Imports totaled $658 million. **********Some American officials say they think the easing of trade restrictions over the next three to four years could lead to two-way trade in the range of $10 billion to $12 billion. **********Both American and Soviet officials indicated that the issue that will probably give them the most trouble will be the duration of the agreement.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/13/busin.main_headline: Europe's Quick Pace May Slow a Bit
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/13/busin.print_headline: Europe's Quick Pace May Slow a Bit
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/13/busin.body_text: **********The higher oil prices that are likely to be the legacy of Iraq's military moves in the Middle East will slow but not stop the buoyant economy of Western Europe, economists say. **********Before the current crisis, Western Europe seemed to have everything going for it. The 12-nation European Community's program to turn itself into a single market of 325 million consumers by the end of 1992 had started an investment boom. Higher spending generated by German reunification and the rebuilding of Eastern Europe promised to keep Western Europe's economy growing. **********The expectation among economists and oil companies is that the price of oil will stabilize at $23 to $25 a barrel - provided President Saddam Hussein of Iraq decides not to challenge the American-led forces in Saudi Arabia and the Persian Gulf. **********While those prices are about one-third more than those of a few weeks ago, ''oil prices would have to be a lot higher to put Europe into a recession,'' said Peter Gutmann, an economist at the National Westminster Bank, one of Britain's largest banks. Only a major disruption that sent prices beyond $40 a barrel could bring European expansion to a standstill, he said. **********But that analysis by no means suggests that Europe will feel no pain. Oil at $23 to $25 a barrel will reduce economic growth in Western Europe by as much as one-half percentage point over a year and will increase inflation by one-half to 1 percentage point, most economists agree. The effects of such changes would quickly become apparent. **********Economists now expect the average inflation rate for Western Europe to edge up to 5.5 or 6 percent by year-end, from about 5 percent now. Economic growth is expected to be about 2.5 percent in 1991, compared with the previously expected growth of about 3 percent. Last year, Western Europe's economy grew 3.5 percent. **********There are a number of reasons why the oil crisis will not be felt as severely as the oil shocks of the 1970's. **********For one thing, this increase is not nearly as great as those in the past. In 1973, prices quadrupled when Arab members of OPEC embargoed oil shipments to the United States and some of its allies. In 1979, after the fall of the Shah of Iran, prices doubled. **********In addition, in inflation-adjusted dollars, the price of oil has fallen dramatically since the early 1980's, when it peaked at about $60 a barrel in today's dollars. **********Western Europe has also become much more energy efficient. ''Oil consumption relative to economic growth is much less than it was,'' said William P. Ledward, an economist at Nomura Research Institute Ltd., the London-based research arm of the Japanese securities firm. That dependency has dropped by about 30 percent since 1980, he estimates. **********Strong Forces Behind Growth **********Economists also think Western Europe is in better shape to weather higher oil prices because strong forces are behind its growth. These include the 1992 program and German reunification. **********What happens to West Germany, whose gross national product accounts for 25 percent of the European Community's, matters a great deal to Western Europe. West Germany's growth is expected to slow to 3 percent to 3.5 percent in 1991 from 4 percent this year. But economists say they are not worried. **********With German reunification, ''the strongest impetus for growth in Europe is the acceleration of domestic demand in Germany,'' said John Lipsky, director of international research at Salomon Brothers in London. **********A growing number of economists expect the Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, to lead an interest rate increase on the continent to make sure that the higher oil prices and heavy public spending related to German reunification do not ignite inflation, now 2.4 percent. **********They say the Bundesbank could raise rates by a half to three-quarters of a percentage point within three to six months, which would increase short-term German rates to as much as 9 percent. That means the dollar, which has recently been weakening, could fall during the next six months to perhaps as low as 1.50 marks, from near 1.60 marks now. **********Economists in Western Europe are also confident that the higher oil price will not mean a return to the days of raging inflation. One reason, they say, is that central bankers will act more decisively this time to make sure inflation does not take hold. **********In addition, labor markets are not as tight as they were in 1973 and 1979 in many countries, making it less likely that higher oil prices will set off a wage-price spiral as they did in the past. Although the level of wage increases has been rising in Britain in particular, and to a lesser extent in West Germany and Italy, economists had already been expecting a moderation next year. **********While Britain's unemployment is now a low 5.7 percent, it is beginning to rise. And reunification with East Germany will ease some labor shortages in West Germany, where unemployment is 7.1 percent. In addition, unions are much weaker in countries like Britain and France than they were in the 1970's. **********''I don't think the rise in inflation is going to be a self-generating problem,'' said George A. Magnus, chief international economist at S. G. Warburg Securities in London. **********Impact Will Vary **********While Western Europe as a whole is in good shape to weather the higher oil prices, the effect will vary from country to country. **********The impact will be somewhat less in France, for example, which gets a relatively large portion of its electricity from nuclear power plants. Italy is more vulnerable because its power plants burn more oil. Energy-producing countries like Norway, Denmark and the Netherlands will be even better off, said Mr. Ledward of Nomura. **********Britain, with its North Sea oil fields, is a small net exporter of oil. That means the higher oil prices should have a positive, if minor, effect on its trade balance, which has been deeply in the red. **********On the other hand, Britain's economy is currently the weakest of any major country in Western Europe, and its inflation, at 9.8 percent, the highest. A base interest rate of 15 percent has already caused a recession in the commercial and residential real estate markets, and the Confederation of British Industry had warned that the manufacturing sector was on the verge of a recession even before Iraq invaded Kuwait. **********European Monetary System **********Because they expect Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Government to ease interest rates, many economists expect Britain to avoid a recession. As a matter of fact, they think the higher oil prices will cause the Government to lower interest rates sooner rather than later and to join the European Monetary System, which would tie the pound to the mark. **********The Conservative Government has to hold an election by July 1992, and probably would like to hold one next year if possible. That means getting the economy moving again. And if the Bundesbank raises interest rates, economists reason, Mrs. Thatcher will have to join the European Monetary System so she can lower British rates without causing the value of the pound to plummet. **********British Credibility **********Although lowering rates is often inflationary, tying the pound to the mark would give Britain credibility in the financial markets in connection with its willingness to fight inflation. **********Mrs. Thatcher has promised to join the system, whose member currencies are managed so their value relative to one another does not radically change. So far Mrs. Thatcher has had to be dragged, kicking and screaming, to join the system. She has no desire to see the European Commmunity become a United States of Europe and she fears that proposals to create a single European currency and a central bank will be a big step toward just that. **********During the summer, John Major, Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, made comments that have led analysts to believe that Britain would join the system in the fall. The higher oil prices, said Christopher Dillow, a Nomura economist, ''mean we're still on course.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/26/world.main_headline: Upheaval in the East;   A Former K.G.B. Chief Champions Azerbaijanis
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/26/world.print_headline: Upheaval in the East;   A Former K.G.B. Chief Champions Azerbaijanis
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/26/world.body_text: **********When Geidar A. Aliyev passed through the Moscow office of the Azerbaijani republic this afternoon, a turbulent crowd fell silent and men were startled from their seats, nodding and muttering ''salaam aleikhem'' to the tall, trim figure in navy blue pinstripes. **********Mr. Aliyev, the former head of the Azerbaijani K.G.B., was for 14 years the Communist Party boss of Azerbaijan. Until he suffered a heart attack and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev retired him in 1987, he served as a tenacious old-guard member of the ruling Politburo. **********This week he was back from obscurity to remark upon the violent upheaval in his former domain, declaring his deep sympathy with the insurgent Azerbaijani Popular Front and condemning Mr. Gorbachev's decision to send soldiers and tanks into Baku. **********''The absolute majority of the population is behind the Popular Front,'' he said today during an hourlong interview at the republic's headquarters, now the front's Moscow bastion. **********Defends 'People's Movement' **********Mr. Gorbachev's decision to use force, he said, has cost needless bloodshed and ''strained the situation in Azerbaijan to the limit.'' **********''The situation before the troops were brought in there represented absolutely no threat, either to perestroika or to Gorbachev,'' Mr. Aliyev said. ''It was a people's movement, which developed during the past few years, and I think there was no threat here at all.'' **********Mr. Aliyev's emergence as a critic, unusual in a society where retired leaders generally stay retired, suggested that Mr. Gorbachev's enemies at least sense his vulnerability. **********''Now a lot of things are unpredictable,'' the 66-year-old Communist said. He was evidently relishing Mr. Gorbachev's predicament, if not actually offering himself for a political comeback. **********Mr. Gorbachev and his Kremlin colleagues ''should have had a dialogue with the Popular Front,'' he said. ''They should have spent as much time as possible discussing the situation, and they should not have permitted the difficulties that took shape now.'' **********Blames the Armenians **********''Serious mistakes have been made in the area of ethnic policy,'' Mr. Aliyev said. He declined to make a more general assessment of the Soviet leader's policies. When he was in the Politburo, he was not regarded as an enthusiastic supporter of Mr. Gorbachev. **********Mr. Aliyev said that Azerbaijan's slide into chaos began two years ago, when Armenians laid claim to the Nagorno-Karabakh region of the republic, where most of the population is Armenian. He complained that Mr. Gorbachev had failed to ''nip it in the bud.'' **********''If we want to talk about pogroms, pogroms started two years ago,'' he said when asked about the recent house-to-house attacks on Armenians in Baku. ''In Nagorno-Karabakh, they started killing Azerbaijanis and expelling them from their homes and their lands. And that was done by extremists of Armenian nationality.'' **********Although the Soviet press now portrays him as a former Brezhnev sycophant and the boss of a political machine, Mr. Aliyev seems to command some affection among the Popular Front loyalists. **********It may be simply a case of sharing common enemies, especially Mr. Gorbachev but also the Armenians, who have seized upon the Soviet President's program of political liberalization to press their claim to Nagorno-Karabakh. **********Denies Long Links to Front **********''Aliyev?'' mused one young Azerbaijani as the ex-leader passed through the hall today. ''I'll tell you, I lived in Armenia, and they wrote so critically of him there that he must have done something right.'' **********Mr. Aliyev's open support for the front may also lend credence to accusations, widely heard from Baku intellectuals disenchanted with the Popular Front, that it has forged an opportunistic alliance with remnants of the old Aliyev political machine in Azerbaijan. **********Mr. Aliyev said he has not set foot in Azerbaijan since 1984 and had never met members of the front before Sunday, when he dropped in here to express his condolences and to offer his voice in protest. **********The former Azerbaijani leader said that although some Popular Front leaders are calling for withdrawal from the Soviet Union, he is firmly convinced that secession does not have widespread popular support. **********A Mixed Reputation **********Mr. Aliyev rose through the internal police and headed the party in his republic from 1969 until 1982, when Yuri V. Andropov, then the Soviet leader, brought him to Moscow. **********He built a reputation as a corruption fighter. But since his resignation, several newspapers have published allegations by the former chief prosecutor of Azerbaijan that Mr. Aliyev supervised a corrupt political machine and fended off Kremlin scrutiny by lavishing Brezhnev with extravagant gifts and praise. He was also accused of having dodged the draft in World War II. **********Today Mr. Aliyev dismissed all of those accusations as fabrications and slanders. **********He said he had been ''isolated from any political life'' during his retirement, and that no one in Moscow or in Azerbaijan had called for his advice in the two years since Armenians and Azerbaijanis began fighting anew over Nagorno-Karabakh. **********Nonetheless, he said, ''I knew and I still know the situation in Azerbaijan better than anyone else.'' **********He was asked if he foresees a new political role for himself - a prospect considered unlikely but not unthinkable, in view of the populist resurrection of the deposed Moscow party chief, Boris N. Yeltsin. **********''You know, I haven't thought about this question,'' he said. ''Well, first of all, no one has asked me. And secondly, the situation is so difficult now, I just don't know.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/19/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;   4th Account Lost by Chiat
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/19/busin.body_text: **********Chiat/Day/Mojo lost another account yesterday, its fourth major loss this year. **********Cluett, Peabody awarded its $10 million Arrow Shirts account to Ammirati & Puris, New York. Chiat had won the account in 1986 from AC&R, New York. **********''New people, new management and new objectives made us decide to put the account into review,'' said Matt Chamlin, president of the Cluett Shirt Group, a division of Cluett, Peabody & Company. Bidermann Industries Corporation purchased the company six months ago from William Farley. **********Chiat's New York office recently lost the coveted Reebok account, as well as the Sara Lee bakery and Bissel business accounts. The Arrow account brings total billing losses to around $67 million. **********Chiat declined to comment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/12/busin.main_headline: Digital Planning Sales Venture in Hungary
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/12/busin.print_headline: Digital Planning Sales Venture in Hungary
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/12/busin.body_text: **********The Digital Equipment Corporation is planning to announce today a joint venture to create a Hungarian unit to sell and service its computers. **********Digital officials said the company would invest several million dollars in the subsidiary, to be known as Digital Equipment (Hungary) Ltd. **********Digital, which is based in Maynard, Mass., will own 51 percent of the unit, while two Hungarian state-owned engineering organizations, the Central Research Institute for Physics of the Hungarian Academy of Sciences and Szamilk, a software developer, will share the remainder. **********The unit expects to begin business on April 2. Initially, the venture will not involve manufacturing. **********Catching Up With West **********Eastern European countries lag far behind Western Europe, the United States and Japan in computer technology. And because of central planning with the Soviet bloc trading group, member nations of the group have specialized in certain areas, rather than develop complete computer industries. Hungary has specialized in building disk drives. **********''This is a significant opportunity for us,'' said Mark Fredrickson, a Digital spokesman. He said the company was particularly interested in what it expects will be a quick modernization of the Eastern European banking sector. ''Our customers around the world are going in, and we need to be there with them,'' he said. **********At the same time, Mr. Fredrickson acknowledged that American computer makers could only speculate on how quickly an Eastern European market for computers could develop. Digital began exploring the Hungarian market 15 months ago, he said. **********''It's great that Digital is going in there,'' said Esther Dyson, an industry analyst who publishes a newsletter called Release 1.0. Although several joint ventures have occurred already, she said, recent political events are rapidly accelerating the move toward business cooperation. **********Trade Considerations **********Digital now makes a number of computers that are more powerful than those that can be legally exported to Eastern Europe. Mr. Fredrickson said that last year Digital's Microvax II, a minicomputer, had been approved for export. **********He also noted that the Coordinating Committee on Export Controls, or Cocom, was discussing a relaxation of technology curbs and was scheduled to meet on Wednesday or Thursday. The analysts expect Cocom, which reviews technology sales to Warsaw Pact nations, to loosen high-technology trade restrictions with Eastern Europe but not with the Soviet Union. **********A question still unresolved is whether Digital will service advanced computers that have been illegally exported to Soviet bloc countries. **********Mr. Fredrickson said Digital had heard that Eastern bloc countries were using illegal clones of Digital's computers made in the Soviet Union. He said he did not know if the company would service the machines.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/26/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Publishing; Books Go East and, Maybe, Profits Go West
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/26/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Publishing; Books Go East and, Maybe, Profits Go West
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/26/busin.body_text: **********FARRAR, STRAUS & GIROUX has long published books by authors from the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. But with censorship and other barriers to book publishing toppling in the region, the house recently added what are known as subagents in Berlin and Belgrave, Yugoslavia. **********Like many other publishers, Farrar Straus sees great potential in a region of almost 400 million people, a new and potentially rich market, at a time when book companies are feeling squeezed in their established markets. In addition, as foreign publishers are increasingly drawn to the United States for growth, their American counterparts are also aiming to become global companies. **********"Many of our books are now being published in Poland, Hungary and Yugoslavia," said Roger W. Straus, president of the company. "And I just signed a whole lot of Russian contracts, including three for Isaac Bashevis Singer." **********Those books are being published in translation, but for the time being the biggest opportunity for most American publishers may be in educational and reference books in English. **********Because Eastern European nations are still mired in bureaucracy and confusion and have obsolete printing equipment, few American publishers anticipate big profits for at least half a dozen years. But those who are looking to the East say it is important to establish a presence as soon as possible, both to get to know the market and to be in a position to teach American publishing methods. **********Thus, Bantam Books, which last year began selling books in Hungary, shipped English-language paperbacks to bookstores in Czechoslovakia earlier this month. Now it has its sights set on Poland, Romania and Bulgaria. **********A few months ago, Simon & Schuster signed a co-publishing agreement with Novotrade Ltd., Hungary's leading publisher and distributor, and it is contemplating similar agreements in other Eastern European countries. Novotrade will distribute a wide range of English-language books. Many titles will be translated into Hungarian and then co-published in Belgrade by Novotrade and Simon & Schuster. **********And the University of Nebraska Press has been helping to establish a publishing program at Charles University in Prague, in part by prevailing on Apple Computer-Europe to donate three Macintosh computers and then sending people from Nebraska to teach how to use them. **********Dan Ross, the assistant director of the Nebraska Press, said the program was undertaken with no expectation of repayment or reward. But Nebraska is now exploring the possibilities of co-publishing and translation rights. **********Publishing executives expect the book traffic with the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe will continue to be overwhelmingly West to East, meaning that Americans will sell far more books to the region than they will buy from it. "My sense is that the best books, especially the best literature, may already have come to us from Eastern Europe," said Drenka Willen, who edits the books under the Helen and Kurt Wolff literary imprint at Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. **********But two recent deals suggest that the potential exists for more books from the East than some publishers had anticipated. **********Presidio Press of Novato, Calif., which specializes in military history, has signed contracts with high-ranking Soviet military officers for 4 books and has options on 15 more. "To my knowledge, nothing has come out of the Soviet Union written by their military, for consumption in the West," said Robert V. Kane, the publisher of Presidio. **********The books include "The Afghan Syndrome," which will tell the story of the Afghanistan war from the Soviet point of view, and "Alien Wars," which will describe Soviet military assistance to Egypt and Syria in their wars against Israel, as well as assistance to North Korea and North Vietnam. **********Norman Ross Publishing Inc., a New York publisher of research and reference materials, announced a joint venture with the A. M. Gorky Institute of World Literature of the Soviet Academy of Sciences. The institute will create microfilm and microfiche masters from its own collections and from the collections of other Soviet archives, which Ross will publish and distribute worldwide. The two will also co-publish a series of bibliographies and reference books. **********But before American publishers begin counting their profits from Eastern Europe, they need only recall how their high expectations for sales to China collapsed under Beijing's repressive policies and the frustration of trying to deal with a mammoth, stifling bureaucracy. **********Nevertheless, Peter B. Kaufman, the founder of Pubwatch, a nonprofit organization that coordinates Western help to publishers in Eastern and Central Europe, thinks that some American publishers are still not prepared for the frustrations they will encounter in Eastern Europe. **********"There are all kinds of obstacles in dealing with countries where until recently books were censored and the Governments had a monopoly on publishing, printing, distribution and sales," he said. **********Those obstacles include obsolete printing presses, archiac distribution systems and what Mr. Kaufman described as "oppressive copyright laws put on the books in the early 1950's." Moreover, few of those countries are able to pay in hard currency. **********"They're making progress on that," Mr. Kaufman said. "But while waiting to get their money repatriated, American publishers might want to make contacts and wave the company flag."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/19/world.main_headline: 15 Killed in Attack on Beirut School Bus
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/19/world.print_headline: 15 Killed in Attack on Beirut School Bus
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/19/world.body_text: **********A rifle-fired grenade slammed into a school bus and exploded today during Christian factional fighting, killing 11 schoolchildren and at least four other people, witnesses said. **********''Many of the pupils yelled for help as we tried to extinguish the fire,'' said a soldier at the scene. ''At least one teacher also was among the dead along with the driver.'' **********A police spokesman said the bus was hit while crossing into Christian East Beirut in the afternoon. He said it was bringing children back from school in southern Beirut, on the Muslim side of the so-called Green Line dividing the city, when the grenade ignited the fuel tank. **********''It couldn't be determined who fired the rifle grenade,'' said the spokesman. **********Aoun Forces Blame Rivals **********Gen. Michel Aoun's radio station accused gunmen of Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces militia of firing at the bus. **********''Geagea is taking pleasure today at the sight of the burned corpses of innocent children,'' the broadcast said. **********Mr. Geagea's command could not be reached by telephone. But the pro-Geagea Voice of Lebanon radio station called the attack mysterious. **********General Aoun and Mr. Geagea have been involved in a violent power struggle for control of the 310-square-mile Christian enclave for more than two months. The showdown has killed 892 people and wounded 2,388 since it started Jan. 30. Most victims have been civilians. **********The police spokesman said the bus belonged to the Mraijeh Elementary School, a new private school in south Beirut. **********The gutted wreckage of the yellow bus straddled a curb in an Aoun-controlled area, a few yards east of the gateway. It is the only crossing linking Christian East Beirut and Musiem West Beirut. **********The bus was hit a few hours after a blast ripped through General Aoun's Defense Ministry in Yarze, an East Beirut suburb, killing at least two men.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/08/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS;   Talks Continue At Western Union

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/05/world.main_headline: Quebec Bridge Mends, but a Town Is Scarred
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/05/world.print_headline: Quebec Bridge Mends, but a Town Is Scarred
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/05/world.body_text: **********The dispute began when Oka decided to use 55 acres of land claimed by the Indians to extend a golf course. About 400 soldiers occupied the Indian community in Oka and are now surrounding about 20 armed militants and 30 women and children holed up in a drug and rehabilitation center. Negotiations with the Government are under way. **********Commuters in Chateauguay and other towns just across the St. Lawrence River south of Montreal have been unable to use the bridge into the city since July 11. The time it takes to commute to work has jumped from 30 minutes to 2 hours. **********Property values have plummeted and anger has boiled over, with residents of Chateauguay pelting Mohawk cars with rocks and burning effigies of Mohawks in the streets. **********Most Mohawks on the Kahnawake Reserve, which borders Chateauguay, say they no longer enter the town of 40,000. ''There is no way I would dare to go in there in anything but an armored personnel carrier,'' said Margaret Horn, a 42-year-old Mohawk who lives on the reserve. **********Several residents expressed anger that the Indians were able to disrupt their lives yet receive what they describe as generous Government aid. **********''We pay everything for these people,'' said Serge Lacombe, a supervisor at Pratt & Whitney. ''We support the Mohawks. They don't pay taxes. They don't pay for the hospital. We pay for them and they do this to us.'' **********Indians Stay Home From School **********Town officials advised the 170 Indians registered in the school system not to attend as the school year began today, saying it was too dangerous. **********Many in the town fear that once the troops leave the bridge and the approach roads running through the reserve, the Indians will take over the bridge again. The Mohawks took over the bridge once before in 1988, and a handful of Indians tried to interfere with the repairs on Monday. **********The Mayor of Chateauguay, Jean-Bosco Bourcier, has requested that the Government station police officers along the roads that run through the reserve and on the bridge, a move that the Mohawks said they would oppose. **********''The Mohawks have to accept this,'' he said. ''If this ever happens again it is the beginning of the end for Chateauguay to improve itself. We will never be able to insure that people have a good quality of life here.'' **********Indian leaders have little sympathy for residents of Chateauguay, which has a thriving commercial center and pleasant flagstone houses with big lawns. ''They are so concerned about their mortgages and middle-class way of life,'' Mrs. Horn said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/10/busin.main_headline: The Executive Computer;   Planning for Summertime Is Not Always a Picnic
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/10/busin.print_headline: The Executive Computer;   Planning for Summertime Is Not Always a Picnic
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/10/busin.body_text: **********Electrical fluctuations that seem relatively mild, causing a display screen to flicker or shrink for less than a second, can batter the delicate circuitry inside the computer. In most cases, built-in power regulators absorb the fluctuations and keep things humming along smoothly. But in some cases, power spikes and dips can cause physical damage. Hard-disk drives are especially vulnerable. **********Power surges, brownouts and other fluctuations in an office's electrical system pose a threat year-round. But summer, with its double burden of heat and unstable power supplies, is the most dangerous season. ''The load on electrical systems is significantly higher in the summer,'' said Pat Richardi, a spokeswoman for the Consolidated Edison Company of New York. And the power cord remains the computer's Achilles' heel. **********Early personal computer hard disks typically stored 10 or 20 megabytes (millions of characters) of data and applications. Today's drives often have a capacity of 40, 80 or even hundreds of megabytes, which means the user is putting more eggs in one basket. When the basket breaks, the losses are much greater than ever before. Many people do not realize that, even if the hard disk can be repaired, the data on it are usually lost. Service technicians find it more efficient to replace a faulty disk drive than to spend the time on a service call trying to fix it. That leaves the user watching helplessly as weeks, months, even years of data go out the door. **********Thus, every executive should insist that workers adopt a prudent summer PC survival strategy. Some steps will require effort and the purchase of hardware and software, while others simply require common sense. *********** Workers who do not make regular backups should start immediately. Those in the habit of making backups should do so more frequently. Many programs make the backup process semiautomatic. Among the best is is PC Tools Deluxe ($149 from Central Point Software), which includes a data recovery system as well as a backup feature. *********** Get in the habit of storing work on the disk more frequently. A power spike can make the PC see stars for a few seconds without causing permanent harm, but anything in the working memory that has not been stored is knocked out. *********** Get a good power-line conditioner - commonly called a surge supressor - and install it between the power outlet and the PC. Consider the Masterpiece Plus ($159.95 from Kensington Microware Inc.) ''We strongly recommend surge protection,'' said Ms. Richardi of Con Edison. *********** Consider getting an uninterruptible power system. These devices, which cost several hundred to several thousand dollars, are standby battery systems that detect when power has failed and, faster than a blink, provide standby power. The user then has time to save important files. Such devices used to be bulky and expensive, but like everything else in the computer industry they are becoming smaller, more powerful and less expensive. For an individual PC, prices start at $350. The device will also power a lamp during a blackout. *********** Make sure the PC is not plugged into the same power line that services an air conditioner or other power-hungry electrical device. Each time the air conditioner kicks on, it sends a spike along the line. Ask the electrician about ''clean'' lines. *********** Get a good hard-disk diagnostic program and use it. Such programs can often alert the user to potential hard-disk problems, and, in some cases, they perform minor software surgery to correct problems. Disk Technician Advanced ($149 from Prime Solutions Inc.) is our choice for the PC side. *********** Make sure the PC has proper ventilation. Overheating can cause all sorts of errors. *********** Summer heat usually leads to iced tea or ice cream in the office. Be careful. The computer doesn't like those any better than it does hot coffee, especially when they drip onto the keyboard. *********** In offices where windows are left open, try to protect the PC from grime and other contaminants. Grit and grime, even particles of cigarette smoke, can get inside the PC and cause overheating. (In some areas of the country, ants can be a problem, too. Southern fire ants are attracted by electrical currents and are notorious for gnawing the insulation off wires and cables.) What's more, some people find an open window an invitation to carry out a computer. *********** Shut off the PC when a storm looms. A lightning strike nearby can send a 5,000-volt fast ball down nearby power lines. A good surge supressor can block the blow, but it may give up its life in the process. Unplugging the PC is the best way to guard against a blowout. **********By far the most important rule is to make backups more frequently. That has been said here before, but an astonishing number of PC users never do it. And those who do make backups should amend their habits for the summer. Businesses that back up their disks weekly should consider a midweek backup as well. And companies that back up at the end of the day are using a time that coincides with the arrival home of many workers who crank up the air conditioning. That leads to increased electrical demand and subsequent brownouts or power dips. Better to back up early and often. If all this seems too much, consider Cosmo Lee, a programmer and computer consultant to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, who has brought forth a timely idea. Mr. Lee said recently that he thought many companies spent more money hiring plant-watering services than they invested in protecting the hard disks in their computers. Granted, healthy plants can make the office a very pleasant place to work, but Mr. Lee thought that backups should get at least as much attention as begonias. **********So he began PC Backup Services Inc. in New York City (telephone 212-PC-GUARD). For a fee that he says is only slightly higher than that of a plant-watering service, PC Backup Services will take over a company's hard-disk backup and diagnostic program. Its employees run diagnostic software to identify potential hard-disk problems, install backup software, perform two sets of verified backups and install data recovery software. **********The initial fee is $150 for each PC, plus the cost of floppy disks. Then, once a week, the PC Backup Services team will come back to update the backups and run the disk diagnosis. The weekly fee ranges from $15 to $10 for each computer - the more PC's, the lower the fee. **********PC Backup Services hands the backup diskettes to the owner in a sealed plastic bag and urges that at least one copy be kept off-site, as extra insurance in the case of fire, flood or theft. And, if anything should go wrong with the hard disk, a hot-line phone call will bring the team back to install the backups on a new hard disk. **********So far, the service is available in New York, Boston and Washington, Mr. Lee said. But it seems only a matter of time before he or other entrepreneurs go national.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/31/world.body_text: **********Chun Doo Hwan, the disgraced former President who led an authoritarian government for eight years ending in 1988, returned to his home in Seoul today after two years in voluntary internal exile. **********Mr. Chun returned to the capital from an isolated Buddhist temple in the mountains of eastern Korea where he had retreated in November 1988, after publicly apologizing for official corruption and other abuses committed during his years in power. Mr. Chun was a general in the Korean army when he became President in 1980 after a military coup. **********Hundreds of police officers were posted around Mr. Chun's home to prevent violent demonstrations by leftist students demanding that the Government prosecute him. **********There was only one demonstration today, by about 20 students at a university nearby. They chanted anti-Chun slogans at the campus gates before dispersing peacefully. **********Hundreds of Mr. Chun's supporters, including Buddhist monks bused in for the event, applauded as his car, accompanied by a police escort, reached his house.  Departure Scene Quite Different **********When the Mr. Chun and his wife last saw their home, it was besieged by thousands of student demonstrators calling for punishment of the former president. **********The previous year, in the face of persistent and often violent demonstrations on the streets of Seoul by students opposed to the military Government, Mr. Chun had agreed to relinquish power to a president elected by popular ballot. **********Mr. Chun spoke briefly to supporters before leaving the temple 90 miles northeast of Seoul with his wife, Lee Soon Ja. The couple was reported to have spent much of their time at the temple in prayer. **********"I am grateful to the nation's people, who have consoled us and bestowed such warm consideration on us until we could go home," Mr. Chun said in a departure statement. **********"I will live cherishing the proud memory of my retirement to a private life in February 1988, after realizing the first peaceful transfer of government in our history," he said.  Successor Approved His Return **********The elected president to whom Mr. Chun handed power in February 1988, Roh Tae Woo, said last Monday that he approved of Mr. Chun's return to Seoul. **********Political commentators here say that President Roh, who was a member of the military Government and Mr. Chun's chosen successor, has judged that South Korea's democratic system is now so firmly rooted that it cannot be shaken by the former President's return to the capital. **********But political observers say Mr. Chun has yet to make clear whether he will return to public life, despite his assertion today that he "will continue to live as an ordinary citizen."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/13/busin.main_headline: A Month's Reprieve for Polly Peck
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/13/busin.print_headline: A Month's Reprieve for Polly Peck
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/13/busin.body_text: **********After a three-week cash crisis that has raised concern among investors, large international banks and the British and Turkish Governments, Polly Peck International P.L.C. won a monthlong reprieve today from its lenders. The embattled fruit, electronics and services conglomerate was one of Britain's fastest-growing companies in the 1980's. **********The company's troubles have riveted the attention of the City, as London's financial district is known, and have reportedly brought high-level international talks involving Prime Ministers Margaret Thatcher of Britain and Turgut Ozal of Turkey. **********After a meeting today with Asil Nadir, Polly Peck's chairman and chief executive, the British-led group of banks and insurance companies agreed to extend until Nov. 9 a moratorium on debt repayments. Lenders had granted a one-week moratorium on Oct. 5. Polly Peck at one point in recent weeks suspended payments to its creditors. **********'Considering Our Options' **********The company declined today to say whether it was considering selling any assets. ''We're considering our options, which obviously include the sale of some of our assets,'' a spokesman said. ''There are no sacred cows.'' **********Several Turkish banks have also agreed to help Polly Peck by providing it with an unspecified amount of money, Reuters reported today. ''We have agreed in principle to extend short-term credits of up to one year to Polly Peck subsidiaries in Turkey,'' Burhan Karacam, general manager of Yapi Kredi Bank, a large private Turkish bank, told the news agency. **********A large portion of Polly Peck's operations are in Turkey and the Turkish section of Cyprus. Mr. Nadir, a native Turkish Cypriot who is now a British citizen, is a friend of President Ozal and owns two of Turkey's leading newspapers. **********The company's stock price plunged 55.6 percent on the London Stock Exchange on Sept. 20 with the disclosure of an inquiry by the British Government's Serious Fraud Office into the possibility of illegal trading in Polly Peck stock. Mr. Nadir, who is 49 years old, has denied involvement in any illegal activities. **********After the plunge, the banks withdrew some lines of credit and refused to roll over some loans that had come due, creating the liquidity crisis. Some $:200 million ($394.9 million) in debt falls due in the last three months of this year. **********Polly Peck has repeatedly stressed that its operations are profitable. In the first half of this year, the company had pretax profits of $:110.5 million ($193.2 million) on sales of $:880.7 million ($1.54 billion). **********In a brief statement today, the company said its British-led lenders had agreed to give it a four-week breather until Coopers & Lybrand Deloitte, the accounting firm, completes a report on its condition. **********''Polly Peck would then hope for a significant extension to enable an orderly reorganization to take place,'' the company said. ''Lenders are not unsympathetic to this, but any commitment must wait until the report is available.'' **********Mr. Nadir, who immigrated with his family to Britain in the 1960's, started out with a small garment company, He bought control of Polly Peck, then a tiny textile company, in 1980. Mr. Nadir has turned Polly Peck into a conglomerate whose businesses include fruit, electronics, Pizza Hut restaurants in Turkey and hotels. **********In December, Polly Peck completed the purchase of the Del Monte fruit business from RJR Nabisco Inc., making it the world's largest distributor of pineapples and the third-largest of bananas. $110 Million for Sansui In January, Polly Peck injected $110 million into the Sansui Electric Company, a Japanese consumer-electronics concern, in return for a 51 percent stake. That stake was increased to 72 percent, when Polly Peck combined Sansui with two of its other consumer electronics units. **********During the 1980's, Polly Peck was the best-performing British stock. In 1989, the company had pretax profits of $:161.4 million ($259.9 million) on revenues of $:1.16 billion ($1.87 billion). **********In an effort to raise money to satisfy bankers, Mr. Nadir has reportedly been trying to sell corporate and personal assets and to repatriate corporate funds from Turkish northern Cyprus. Some minor deals have been announced. **********He is said to have also approached the Turkish Government and Turkish banks about financial support. And as the crisis developed, Polly Peck's problems have become something of an international incident. **********In a letter signed by the British Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, the British Government warned the Turkish Government late last month that Polly Peck needed $:100 million ($197.5 million) in rescue money, according to The Financial Times. The British newspaper said Mr. Hurd was responding to a request by the Turkish Economics Minister, Gunes Taner, to ''hold things steady'' with the company's British-led lenders while it considered steps to help Polly Peck. **********Mrs. Thatcher and Mr. Ozal were said to have discussed Polly Peck's difficulties late last month in New York, where they were attending a United Nations meeting. **********Turkish Cyprus Employer **********Polly Peck is believed to account for at least 20 percent of the gross national product of Turkish Cyprus and is the largest private employer, according to The Financial Times. Mr. Nadir has been stymied in his attempts to bring out of Turkish Cyprus half of some $:140 million ($276.4 million) in cash that the company has there, because the Turkish Cypriots lack hard foreign currency. **********Even before the liquidity crisis, Polly Peck had planned to reduce its high debt by floating stakes in various subsidiaries. As of June 30, it owed banks and other creditors a total of $:1.38 billion ($2.41 billion), including $:543.5 million ($950 million) due within a year. Its debt equaled 93 percent of equity. **********In June, Polly Peck sold 15 percent of Vestel Elektronik, a Turkish electronics company, on the Istanbul Stock Exchange. It has been considering floating parts of its Del Monte fruit operations. **********Polly Peck's problems date back to August, when Mr. Nadir jolted investors by announcing he planned to take the company private, only to change his plans less than a week later, causing the stock price first to rise and then drop sharply. His actions drew a reprimand from the London International Stock Exchange. **********But the real crisis began on Sept. 20, when it was disclosed that the Serious Fraud Office had raided the offices of an investment firm controlled by the Nadir family and had questioned Mr. Nadir. Polly Peck's stock price plunged, cutting the company's market value by $1.1 billion before trading was suspended. Trading has not resumed and the stock has lost its position on The Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 leading British companies. **********Collateral Sold by Banks **********It turned out that banks had contributed to the heavy selloff by selling some of Mr. Nadir's shares, which they were holding as collateral. The company later disclosed that both Polly Peck and Mr. Nadir were suffering from cash-flow problems. **********Mr. Nadir still owns 24 percent, or 106 million, of Polly Peck's shares. That is down from 28 percent, or 122 million shares, before the bank sales. At Polly Peck's last trading price of $:1.08 a share, Mr. Nadir's holding is worth $:114.5 million ($226 million). **********Before the crisis, Mr. Nadir's stake in Polly Peck, combined with other personal business interests, made him one of Britain's 50 richest people, according to The Sunday Times in London. In a report published on Sept. 16, four days before the crisis began, the paper ranked Mr. Nadir 36th, with a fortune of $:213 million, or $420.6 million at today's exchange rate.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/24/busin.main_headline: Your Money; Products to Help Trim Tax Bills
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/24/busin.print_headline: Your Money; Products to Help Trim Tax Bills
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/24/busin.body_text: **********A NUMBER of excellent books and computer programs are now available to help taxpayers whittle down their income-tax liabilities. Indeed, studying them can be a profitable way to spend part of a long holiday weekend, for after the first of the year little can be done to reduce 1990 taxes. **********In the remaining five weeks of the year, taxpayers can ask a number of questions and act on the answers, which vary with individual circumstances. These are among the questions taxpayers might ask: ***********With the top tax bracket going up to 31 percent in 1991, from 28 percent this year, would it be a good idea to accelerate income into 1990? ***********Would giving an appreciated asset, like stocks, to charity be advisable? For people not subject to the alternative minimum tax, the full market value is deductible. ***********Is more withholding needed to avoid a penalty for underpayment? ***********Can more money be put into a tax-deferred retirement account like an employer-sponsored 401(k) plan, or should someone with income from self-employment establish a Keogh plan? **********The first step in answering these questions is to organize financial records well, and for people with an I.B.M. or compatible personal computer, the fastest, easiest, least-expensive way to do that is undoubtedly with Quicken, a personal finance program from Intuit. The new Version 4.0 tracks investments, including stocks, bonds, mutual funds, certificates of deposit and collectibles, and provides performance reports, as well as the information on interest, dividends and capital gains needed for Schedule D of the tax return. The program lists for $59.95 and is widely available for about $35. **********For more detailed tax strategies, J. K. Lasser's Your 1991 Income Tax Software, which lists for $74.95, includes both the tax book "J. K.
