Lasser's Your 1991 Income Tax," which has justifiably beenthe best-selling income-tax guide for generations, and a year-end tax planner program. Buyers may send in a coupon to get a free upgrade for the preparation program early next year after the I.R.S. makes available all the forms for filing 1990 returns. People who wait to buy that program will not get the planner. Companion programs for 24 states can be ordered for $29.95. The Lasser program reads Quicken files and allows users to transfer data from them. **********The Lasser tax book alone costs $12.95. In addition, "J. K. Lasser's Personal Tax Strategies 1991" by David S. DeJong and Ann Gray Jakabcin (Pocket Books, $4.95, 349 pages) focuses on year-end strategies and begins with a tabular presentation that makes it easy to find the place in the book where one's particular problems and possible solutions are discussed. **********Another program that may be valuable for people who want an on-screen expert to guide them is Andrew Tobias's Tax Cut, from Meca Software Inc. It is written by Daniel Caine, a tax lawyer, who provides an easy question-and-answer format for novices, as well as a built-in audit function to check the return. It allows users to transfer data from Meca's very thorough personal finance program, Andrew Tobias's Managing Your Money, as well as Quicken and Lotus 1-2-3. Tax Cut offers side-by-side what-if strategies and lets people who have a"mouse" peripheral device use it. Companion programs for 10 states are available. **********People who do not own computers or who are not inclined to such a hands-on approach, but who want enough knowledge for an intelligent discussion with their accountants, can choose from a number of books. **********Ernst & Young's "Tax-Saving Strategies 1990-1991" (John Wiley & Sons Inc., $6.95, 229 pages) is a vest-pocket-size book from the accounting firm that can be particularly helpful in making year-end tax decisions. It is a companion to the firm's tax guide, which provides line-by-line instructions for filling out tax returns and which will be published later. **********Another valuable book is "Julian Block's Year-Round Tax Strategies for the $40,000-Plus Household" (Prima Publishing, distributed by St. Martin's Press, $12.95, 278 pages). The first chapter is filled with year-end tips, and subsequent chapters consider topics like home sales, marriage and divorce, travel and moving expenses, child- or dependent-care expenses, charitable contributions, investments, audits, Social Security taxes and estate planning. Mr. Block is a lawyer who manages to avoid legalese in favor of concise, clear English. **********Price Waterhouse has also lent its name to tax-planning books and has moved from one in recent years to three well-documented books this year: "The Price Waterhouse Personal Tax Adviser," which details year-end and year-round tax strategies; "The Price Waterhouse Investors' Tax Adviser," and "The Price Waterhouse Retirement Planning Adviser." The trilogy is published by Pocket Books at $5.50 each. **********"The H & R Block 1991 Income Tax Guide" (Collier Books, a division of Macmillan Publishing, $9.95) is a large-format, 512-page volume with instructions for filling out the 1990 return, as well as timely advice on the new tax law for next year and help in planning year-end strategies. It also offers advice for those affected by economic and global problems, like reservists called up to military duty, union members on strike and people laid off and conducting a job search. Buyers who decide to have their returns professionally prepared can get a refund on the price of the book if Block does the return.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/20/busin.body_text: **********Representatives of the Group of Seven industrial countries proposed a broad set of regulatory and banking reforms today to combat the growing problem of concealing illegal narcotics profits in banks and other financial institutions. **********A study panel set up by the group was joined by eight other nations, including Switzerland, Austria and Luxembourg, which are known for bank secrecy. The participation of these three nations was taken as a sign that they would support important modifications of their laws and banking practices, although Bush Administration officials said they did not know if any changes would be imminent. **********The proposal calls for the elimination of anonymous bank accounts and accounts held in fictitious names. It also asks for greater international coordination among law enforcement and regulatory authorities. **********Numbered and anonymous accounts have long frustrated investigative efforts to track down drug money and have kept even bankers from knowing the source of funds. In attempting to peel away the layers of anonymity in some European banks and to put pressure on the bankers to change their rules, the recommendations represent a significant step in drug law enforcement. **********''It is the single most comprehensive, significant and forceful international declaration on money laundering to date,'' said John E. Robson, Deputy Treasury Secretary, who headed the American delegation. ''It is a clear recognition of the global nature of the problem and acknowledges the need for rapid and tough actions.'' **********The group also proposed an easing of bank secrecy laws to permit bankers to report suspicious deposits to authorities and called on prosecutors to develop cases against corporations - not just their employees - which engage in money laundering. The committee said bankers should be forbidden to tell customers when they are under investigation. **********The report is to be on the agenda at the meeting in Houston in July of the leaders of the Group of Seven - Britain, Canada, France, Italy, Japan, the United States and West Germany. Several of the eight other nations that participated in the study have long been identified as havens for illegal profits. In addition to Switzerland, Austria and Luxembourg, the group includes Australia, Belgium, the Netherlands, Spain and Sweden. **********Although declarations by the Group of Seven are more often statements of desire and determination than commitments to change, they often lead to, or reinforce, changes in domestic economic policies. **********If adopted by the European countries, the proposals could encourage banking by drug traffickers in laundering havens in Latin America and the Caribbean that did not participate in the report. **********Set Up Last Year **********The study panel was set up last July at the annual meeting of the Group of Seven, even though all of the industrial nations have not yet ratified the Vienna Convention of 1988. That convention set out principles for multinational narcotics investigations and provided for treating money laundering as a crime and for extraditing money launderers in nations that signed the convention. **********Under the laws of seven of the nations in the study group, including the United States, money laundering is already treated as a crime. Four other nations are considering such legislation. Among the Group of Seven, only West Germany and Japan do not outlaw it. **********Congress is expected to strengthen the Federal law this year. The House is scheduled to vote next week on a bill that would set up a procedure for considering the revocation of the license or charter of a bank if it or an employee was convicted of money laundering. The measure is expected to be adopted; a similar proposal has been introduced in the Senate. $85 Billion Laundered Annually The report estimated that each year as much as $85 billion was laundered and reinvested from illegal profits from cocaine, heroin and marijuana. **********In recent years, a number of large international prosecutions have illustrated the use by drug traffickers of major banks and other financial institutions to conceal large amounts of illegal money and to repatriate profits abroad. Earlier this week, the Justice Department announced that it had ordered 173 banks in 23 states to produce the records of more than 750 accounts in a case involving the laundering of $1.2 billion through more than a half-dozen foreign countries. The banks were not accused of wrongdoing. **********There is also concern among some prosecutors and law enforcement officials that the integration of Europe's markets in 1992 will make it easier to launder money as national regulatory barriers are dropped and trading activity increases. **********Some Differences Expressed **********Several regulatory issues failed to gain unanimous support. For example, the report noted a division over whether banks should be required to report suspicious transactions. **********Nor did the report address other important areas, like regulating electronic transfers of money, in the effort to prevent the use of banks to hide narcotics proceeds. With increasing frequency, narcotics traffickers use these transfers to move their profits swiftly between accounts in different countries. Mr. Robson said the Treasury Department expected to complete by summer regulations announced last fall that could require greater record-keeping by banks and clearinghouses of electronic transfers. **********The study did not call for member nations to adopt the reporting requirements of American banks; currency reports must be filed for transactions of more than $10,000. That regulation has stirred considerable debate in a number of nations, most recently in Canada where the opposition has criticized the Government of Prime Minister Brian Mulroney for failing to adopt a proposal similar to American law. **********Rather, the report called upon member nations to ''consider the feasibility and utility'' of a system of reporting large currency transactions to a national central agency.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/28/busin.main_headline: Merrill Lynch Settles Claims From $250 Million '87 Loss
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/28/busin.print_headline: Merrill Lynch Settles Claims From $250 Million '87 Loss
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/28/busin.body_text: **********Merrill Lynch & Company and its insurers have quietly settled a set of claims filed after the brokerage firm stunned Wall Street by announcing in April 1987 that it had lost more than $250 million trading mortgage-backed securities, it was disclosed yesterday. **********In addition, the brokerage house has agreed to release more than $1 million in compensation, plus interest, that it had withheld from Howard A. Rubin, the senior trader Merrill had originally blamed for a substantial portion of the losses, which at the time were among the largest ever reported by a Wall Street firm. **********Merrill dismissed Mr. Rubin immediately after the losses occurred, disclosing that it had given the Securities and Exchange Commission information relating to allegedly unauthorized trading. Earlier this year, Mr. Rubin settled, without admitting or denying any guilt, an S.E.C. action charging that he had aided and abetted a record-keeping violation in connection with the disputed trades. **********The details of the settlement of claims arising from the mortgage-backed operation's losses were first released yesterday by George B. Yankwitt, an attorney for Mr. Rubin. Mr. Yankwitt also said that Merrill, as part of its agreement with his client, had further agreed to provide Mr. Rubin with ''a general release from all potential claims.'' **********Citing numerous news accounts three years ago in which Merrill executives blamed unauthorized trading by Mr. Rubin for the firm's losses, Mr. Yankwitt said, ''It is worth noting that these lawsuits are being settled without him paying anything and, indeed, with Merrill paying him. I consider this a complete vindication of Mr. Rubin's position, which is that he had not engaged in any unauthorized or wrongful trading.'' **********Monica Prihoda, a spokesman for Merrill, would not comment on the nature or details of the ''general release'' cited by Mr. Yankwitt as part of the settlement. But she confirmed that Merrill had received ''a significant payment of $17.5 million'' from the insurance companies that provide its directors and officers with liability coverage to settle various lawsuits, brought by Merrill shareholders on the firm's behalf. **********Those lawsuits had asserted that the Merrill losses were caused by Mr. Rubin, and that his supervisors, Brian Barefoot, Robert Andres and Greg Herschell, had failed to supervise his trading activities. **********''The settlement with Mr. Rubin was to resolve prior contractual claims unrelated to the trading loss,'' Ms. Prihoda said. As for assertions by Merrill shareholders about who was to blame for the losses, she said, ''Merrill Lynch believes all those allegations, except those relating to the conduct of Howard Rubin, to be completely without merit.'' **********'A Very Good Result' **********David A. P. Brower, one lawyer representing various Merrill shareholders who had filed ''derivative actions'' on the firm's behalf, said the plaintiffs were pleased that the settlement had enabled the firm to recover some of its trading losses. ''All the plaintiffs feel that this is a very good result,'' he added. The details of the agreement with Merrill's insurers had been approved by the New York Supreme Court early last month, he said. **********In addition to citing the trading losses, various Merrill shareholders had filed other claims on the firm's behalf against certain of its executives and officers, Mr. Brower said. These claims cited the lease agreement governing Merrill's office space in Battery Park City in New York, various transactions involving the defunct Baldwin-United Corporation, and Merrill's investment in a resort development in St. Thomas, in the United States Virgin Islands. The payment of the $17.5 million represented a settlement of these additional claims as well, he added.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/10/busin.main_headline: Fox's Local Morning Shows Rival 3 Networks' Offerings
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/10/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Fox's Local Morning Shows Rival 3 Networks' Offerings
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/10/busin.body_text: **********The showdown does not rival Bart Simpson versus Bill Cosby yet, but several Fox television stations with local early-morning news programs are giving network programs like NBC's "Today" a run for the advertisers' money. **********While Fox Broadcasting has expanded its prime-time schedule with mixed results, a different strategy is bringing several of its stations success in the morning, in a year that has witnessed a ratings free fall for "Today" and stasis at "CBS This Morning." As more of the stations create their own morning programs, Fox executives see a potential for selling national advertising for what would effectively be a network of shows that share a time period and little else. **********In November, "Good Day New York," the morning program produced by the Fox-owned station in New York, WNYW, moved into second place among the four morning programs, beating CBS and NBC but not ABC's "Good Morning America." **********"Good Day" did it by standing still; its 2.3 Nielsen rating and 11 share, or percent of the audience, was the same as a year ago. CBS was also essentially flat. The biggest change was a decrease in viewers for "Today," from 15 percent of the viewers in the nation's largest television market to 9 percent, and an increase for "Good Morning America," to 22 percent from 19 percent. **********In June, WTTG, the Fox-owned station in Washington, began a two-and-a-half-hour news program, starting at 6:30 A.M. WSVN, the Fox affiliate in Miami, has a three-hour news program, starting at 6 A.M. **********And more competition is on the horizon. In January, the largest Fox affiliate, KTVU in San Francisco-Oakland, will begin a morning news program. The Fox stations are generally alone among independent stations in developing morning programs to compete with the networks. Most others broadcast cartoons and reruns from 7 to 9 A.M. **********A CBS executive said the Fox programs were cutting into the three networks' morning ratings. "These independently produced local programs are making a dent," said David F. Poltrack, the CBS senior vice president for planning and research. **********"There are two distinct groups who watch morning news programs," he said. "The first is the 'on-your-way-outs,' who watch for 15 minutes on the way out to work, and the second is the housewife, home-based group, who watch the program from beginning to end. The news and information appetite is greatest for the on-your-way-out group, and locally produced programs probably serve them more." **********Mr. Poltrack said Fox probably took just under one rating point from the three networks in the morning. Advertising revenue at the Fox shows in the New York, Miami and Washington markets has put them on a par with NBC, ahead of CBS but still well below ABC stations.  No Plans for a Network Program **********Fox executives said they had no plans for a network program in the morning. Indeed, the key, they said, has been avoiding the network route. "What we've discovered is, by having the locally produced morning shows, we have an alternative," said Ian Rae, the executive vice president of Fox News. "If we do it by network, we become another one of those big heavy morning programs." **********In the early morning, a single ratings point can mean a difference of millions in revenue. In New York, where a ratings point represents about 70,438 households, local advertising rates for a 30-second commercial on the morning programs range from about $1,000 on "Good Morning America" to about $200 for "CBS This Morning," station and advertising executives said. "Today" earns about $600 (half what it brought in a year ago), while "Good Day New York" gets about $450. The ABC, CBS and NBC programs have about 175 local spots a week, while Fox has 225 a week. **********Thus, Channel 7 is earning more than $9 million a year from "Good Morning America," while Channel 2, which broadcasts "CBS This Morning" is probably getting less than $2 million. In between, "Today," on Channel 4, earns about $5.5 million and Channel 5, the Fox station, earns about $5.3 million. The rates are down from a year ago, except those for "Good Day New York," which are slightly higher. Different Strategies **********The strategy at WNYW, where "Good Day New York" had its premiere in August 1988, has been to emphasize local news and features. The Washington and Miami programs present much more hard news, including national and international reports from the Cable News Network and Conus, another news network. **********Carolyn Wall, the vice president and general manager of WNYW, said: "We set out to create a morning show that was local, spontaneous and that would attract new viewers to morning television -- people who were not viewing because the networks were designed to play in Peoria, as opposed to a local show that would be snapshot of New York that day. It can be a model in terms of its philosophy and approach, but we could never export it." **********Even the name of the show is an in-joke, a reference to the Australian greeting often heard in the offices of Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, which owns Fox. **********"Good Day New York" evolved from a feature-oriented and somewhat goofy program into one that Joachim Blunck, the third and current executive producer, described as more serious, if still whimsical. In addition to its local news segments, the show features live interviews from the street and sex advice from Dr. Ruth Westheimer. It has a certain New York savvy that is proudly parochial.  Appealing to Young Viewers **********With their essentially upbeat, quick-paced formats, "Good Morning America" and "Good Day New York" appeal to the younger audiences loved by advertisers. "Today" -- which owned that audience until last year -- and "CBS This Morning" have also been trying to reach those viewers. **********Kimerly Montore, the vice president for news at WTTG and the head of news development for Fox, said the success, if not the style, of "Good Day New York," led to the development of an early-morning news program in Washington. **********"Washington is a very heavy news town," she said. "We decided to be a hard, strong news and information program. We put the 'Good Day New York' concept into news makers and news events." **********The rationale at KTVU in Oakland is that viewers might prefer a live news program to the ABC, CBS and NBC offerings, which are three hours old by the time they are shown on the West Coast. 'Enormous Potential' **********Ms. Wall of WNYW said that as more local morning programs were developed at Fox stations, there would be increasing opportunities to attract national advertisers. **********"For us to create a local morning environment has enormous potential," she said, "because you can personalize your message in every market." The three key sponsors for "Good Day New York," for example, are Tropicana, Maxwell House and Isuzu; Maxwell House recently made a long-term commitment to the WTTG show as well. **********"You have to deal market by market," said Mr. Rae, the Fox News official. "Our stations are providing an alternative to the established national programs. I think we've started something of a trend."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/25/world.body_text: **********Nearly two years after President Bush declared his war on drugs, Administration officials say they have made little progress toward blocking narcotics trafficking from Latin America into the United States. **********"We've had a degree of success," said Melvyn Levitsky, Assistant Secretary of State for International Narcotics Matters, "but nowhere near what we want to have." **********Administration officials say better progress has been made on cutting demand for drugs. They say that drug consumption has been reduced among some sectors of American society and that this answers Latin American criticism that not enough is being done to tackle drug abuse at its true source -- the abuser. **********But the Administration's program, as outlined in a White House report to Congress in January, includes among its goals a reduction of imports of cocaine and other illegal drugs by 15 percent by the end of 1992 and by 60 percent by the end of the 1990's. Administration officials said they could not be sure if imports of cocaine, the drug that is exacting the greatest toll on the United States, had been cut by even 5 percent in the last year.  Shipments Redirected **********The officials noted that while they have succeeded in stemming nearly half of the cocaine trafficking through the Caribbean into Florida, statistics on drug seizures indicate that shipments have merely been redirected through Central America and Mexico into the American Southwest. **********John P. Walters, who will be acting director of the Office of National Drug Control Policy when William J. Bennett's resignation takes effect at the end of the month, acknowledged that "there's the risk of failure" in American efforts. **********"These are countries with enormous economic and social problems," Mr. Walters said of the Latin American drug-producing nations. "At times, we're working in areas where governments don't even exercise control." **********For example, Administration officials said that while the Colombian Government has made much progress interrupting the operations of the cocaine ring based in Medellin, Colombia, it has overlooked the growth of the country's other major cocaine ring, operating out of Cali. The disruption of the Medellin ring has also encouraged new drug gangs and coca cultivations to appear in Bolivia, Ecuador, Brazil and Venezuela. **********"It's like hitting mercury with a hammer," said a State Department official who deals with drug policy.  Panama Banking Laws an Issue **********The problem extends even to Panama, where the United States invaded 11 months ago to overthrow a Government allegedly linked to drug traffickers. American officials noted that the new Government is resisting attempts to rewrite banking secrecy laws that are utilized by drug money launderers. Panamanian officials insist that the current laws are more than adequate to prevent such abuses. **********Some officials said they worried that while the Administration concentrated on limiting cocaine production and shipments from the Andean countries, cultivation of heroin poppies was rising in Guatemala and Mexico. **********The Bush Administration approach links trade preferences to anti-narcotics efforts and emphasizes disrupting trafficking organizations by destroying processing labs over the more traditional approach, crop eradication. Central to its war on cocaine is the so-called Andean Initiative, a five-year, $2.2 billion aid program to break up cocaine production and trafficking organizations and strengthen local economies and government institutions. **********Administration officials said that the disruption of some trafficking has caused a substantial drop in coca leaf prices in parts of Bolivia and Peru, prompting some peasants to switch voluntarily to legal crops, and that a modest decrease in cocaine imports in some parts of the United States resulted in a decrease in the potency and an increased in the price of cocaine sold in several American cities. **********But American officials point to Peru as the toughest problem facing the Administration's drug war in Latin America. With 300,000 acres of land planted in coca and 200,000 peasants employed in its cultivation, Peru is by far the largest source of the raw material for cocaine. The Peruvian Army is reluctant to disrupt coca-growing for fear of driving the farmers into the arms of the leftist Shining Path guerrillas, and the rebels profit from the coca trade by taxing traffickers. **********A State Department official who recently traveled to Bolivia described visiting a farm owned by a peasant named Florencio in the Chapare coca-growing region. Florencio had destroyed more than 40 acres of coca plants in the last year in exchange for thousands of dollars in American economic aid, and now cultivates papayas, black pepper and macadamia nuts. **********But not all is going well at Florencio's farm. He and his family still live in a dilapidated shack. He complains that life was easier in the days when the cocaine middlemen used to come to him to buy coca leaves; now he has to drive his pickup truck four hours on bad roads to sell his produce. And he continues to grow a few acres of coca as a hedge. **********"Florencio is the model but he is still not getting ahead," said the State Department official. "He told us he made more money last year growing coca. It's discouraging."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/02/world.main_headline: Editor's Note;   Outcry Erupts at The Jerusalem Post Over New Publisher's Editorial Bent
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/02/world.print_headline: Editor's Note;   Outcry Erupts at The Jerusalem Post Over New Publisher's Editorial Bent
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/02/world.body_text: **********Journalists at The Jerusalem Post, Israel's only English-language newspaper, have mounted a drive to oust the paper's publisher of eight months, saying he is trying to turn the liberal daily into a platform for right-wing views. **********The Post's editor, Erwin Frenkel, resigned last Tuesday after the publisher, Yehuda Levy, a retired army colonel with no background in journalism, indicated that he had decided to take editorial control of the paper. The next day, The Post's news staff voted unanimously to call a strike in January. [Nine senior members of The Post's editorial staff, including the managing editor, David Landau, announced on Monday that they would resign in 30 days unless the publisher was replaced and Mr. Frenkel reinstated.]  Advocates Land for Peace The Jerusalem Post has a circulation of 25,000 on weekdays and 55,000 for its Friday weekend paper, and a circulation of 70,000 for its international weekly edition. It openly advocates territorial compromise with Israel's Arab enemies and has frequently published editorials criticizing the Government's handling of the two-year Palestinian uprising in the occupied territories. **********While most of Israel's mass-circulation dailies are liberal in tone, The Post is generally more to the left than many of the others. **********The Post is widely read by diplomats, tourists, journalists and Jews abroad, giving it a degree of importance in portraying Israel to the world that might seem disproportionate to its readership. **********Mr. Frenkel's resignation and the staff decision to call a strike has generated a furor here, forcing Mr. Levy to deny that he intends to change the paper's editorial slant. **********Calls Accusers 'Incorrect' **********''Whoever is trying to make me look like someone trying to change the paper from left to right is just incorrect, although even this could be within my full right,'' Mr. Levy told the Israeli radio. He declined to be interviewed for this article. **********But in earlier interviews, Mr. Levy said he simply wanted The Post to be more balanced in its coverage. Post editors insist that Mr. Levy's growing involvement in the paper's daily report points to something else entirely, although they cannot produce a wealth of evidence to substantiate their criticism. **********Still, they complain that Mr. Levy recently urged the paper to write about the ''Jordan is Palestine'' crusade, a movement championed by right-wing academics and politicians who believe that a Palestinian state already exists in Jordan. **********They also say he went over the heads of editors to reprimand reporters covering politics and the occupied territories for what he saw as dovish articles, and has said in interviews that the paper should adopt a more pro-Zionist position. **********An Editorial Is Quashed **********Uncertainty over Mr. Levy's intentions peaked in November, when the publisher ordered Mr. Frenkel to withdraw an editorial from the paper's international edition. The editorial, which appeared in the daily, was a reply to criticism from Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, who said The Post's left-wing editorial line undermined ''Israel's position'' in the Jewish world. **********In his editorial, Mr. Frenkel boasted that the paper ''consistently dissented from the Likud's territorialism,'' referring to the refusal by Mr. Shamir's party to cede land for peace. Mr. Frenkel also said The Post was not ''enraptured in its reporting of events by the Prime Minister's reading of Israel's international positions.'' **********The dispute over the editorial so angered Post editors that they now say they are unwilling to compromise with Mr. Levy. Mr. Landau, the managing editor, said ''his action regarding the editorial, which laid down the basic credo of The Jerusalem Post, still resonates.'' **********Other Post staff members asserted that officials in the Prime Minister's office persuaded Mr. Levy to pull the editorial. **********'Address for the Pressure' **********''The Prime Minister's and the Foreign Minister's offices maintain constant pressure on The Post, but until now they did not have an address for the pressure,'' Menachem Shalev, the paper's diplomatic correspondent, said last week. ''Now they do,'' He said Government officials have told him that Mr. Levy has assured them that the paper's editorial line will change. **********Mr. Levy will have the power to effect that change if he does take over as ''responsible editor'' of The Post, an intention he indicated in a letter written in early December to a committee of Israeli newspaper editors. **********Requesting admittance to the group, Mr. Levy wrote, ''As publisher, I intend to become very involved in the work of the editorial staff, and all that this implies.'' **********The letter prompted Mr. Frenkel's resignation. On Friday, Post employees rejected the idea that an interim editor take over until tempers cool, and they delivered an ultimatum to David Radler, the president of Hollinger Inc., a Canadian newspaper chain that owns the daily. Hollinger, which bought The Post in April, pledged at the time to preserve the paper's editorial independence. **********Mood Is 'Militant' **********''I attempted to explain to him what his choices were, that the whole editoral staff speaks with one voice, and he has to choose between a good paper and sticking behind the man he appointed publisher,'' said Joanna Yehiel, The Post's magazine editor. She said Mr. Radler came to ''no conclusions, but he certainly listened.'' **********Other staff members were more blunt. **********''We're trying to drive a wedge between Radler and Levy,'' a reporter said. ''They haven't lived up to their commitment, and that's what has turned the mood so militant.'' **********At the time of the sale, Post employees were ecstatic to learn that their paper was being bought by Hollinger, which owns about 200 papers across Canada, as well as the recently acquired Daily Telegraph of London. The Post had been on the market for several weeks, and its owner, the ailing Koor Industries, was determined to sell to the highest bidder. **********Absentee Ownership **********Koor, which is a part of the Histadrut trade union, led by the Labor Party, had essentially ignored The Post for years, insuring complete editorial independence. Potential buyers who vied for the daily included an Israeli businessman with close ties to the hawkish Minister of Trade, Ariel Sharon, and Robert Maxwell, the British publisher. **********The Post's editors feared that those buyers would alter the paper's dovish positions, and they were relieved when Koor accepted an 11th-hour offer of $17.5 million from the Hollinger group. The Hollinger bid was much higher than the paper's estimated worth, which Israeli newspaper executives put at about $3 million. **********But the relief was short-lived. Although Hollinger newspapers are not known for a strong stance on Israel, Mr. Radler took a greater interest in the country after striking up a friendship with Mr. Levy during Mr. Levy's time in Canada as emissary for the Jewish National Fund. Mr. Radler decided to buy The Post at Mr. Levy's suggestion. **********Immediately after the purchase, Mr. Levy was appointed publisher, and in an interview with another Israeli paper, he hinted that like the suitors the editors sought to avoid, he intended to transform The Post. **********'Something of a Delusion' **********''Altogether, it seems to me that in this matter of editorial independence there is something of a delusion,'' Mr. Levy said in the interview, held in July. ''If my editor takes a line which is not balanced, I think that it is my right and my duty to straighten him out.'' **********In the interview, Mr. Levy recalled serving as a military liaison for the foreign press during Israel's invasion of Lebanon. He said coverage of the Sabra and Shatila massacres was distorted because the press failed to mention that ''the number of civilians killed there didn't even reach 40.'' **********It is this portrait of Mr. Levy that alarms Post editors now. ''Imagine Sabra and Shatila happening today, and we're not allowed to report it,'' Mrs. Yehiel said last week. ''Is that what they want of The Jerusalem Post? Is that what the Jewish people want?''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/10/busin.main_headline: Concern About Inventories Causes Energy Price Surge
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/10/busin.print_headline: FUTURES/OPTIONS;   Concern About Inventories Causes Energy Price Surge
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/10/busin.body_text: **********Energy futures prices surged yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid concerns that gasoline and crude oil inventories would be tight in the near term. **********On other markets, grains and soybeans were mostly higher, copper prices advanced and livestock and pork prices gained. **********West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 1 cent to 71 cents higher, with the contract for June delivery at $18.99 a barrel; heating oil was 11 cents lower to 6 cents higher, with June at 51.34 cents a gallon, and unleaded gasoline was 0.20 cent to 1.49 cents higher, with June at 63.97 cents a gallon. **********Gasoline futures advanced on good cash buying on the Gulf Coast, said Jerry Samuels, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. **********Prices were also helped by American Petroleum Institute figures that showed a draw-down of nearly a million barrels of unleaded gasoline. The figures indicated the drop of gasoline stocks had a particularly large impact on the Gulf Coast region, where prices are higher than those on the mercantile exchange. **********The institute also reported a drop in gasoline output by United States refineries. Mr. Samuels attributed the decline to maintenance work at the refineries. **********Crude oil futures also rose on supply concerns, as labor problems and a gas leak in the North Sea raised the possibility of reduced output there, and as Saudi Arabia was reportedly seeking ways to curb its production. **********Fears of tight supplies and high open interest in contracts about to expire sent copper futures soaring on the Commodity Exchange in New York. **********Adding to the surge was increased labor tension in Peru and New Guinea. In Peru, where a labor dispute at the Southern Peru Copper Corporaion was recently settled, workers at the Centromin mines are threatening to strike as are workers at the Oktedi mines in New Guinea.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/07/world.main_headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Britain Says It Will Send More Forces to the Gulf
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/07/world.print_headline: Confrontation in the Gulf;   Britain Says It Will Send More Forces to the Gulf
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/07/world.body_text: **********''We believe some additional forces will be needed, and their composition is under consideration,'' she told the Commons this afternoon. She also said Britain had now committed itself to provide $10.8 million for refugee relief. **********'Collective Self-Defense' **********Her predecessor as Conservative Party leader, former Prime Minister Edward Heath, called on Western countries to organize a round-the-clock airlift of refugees from Jordan, Iraq and Kuwait. **********The Labor Party opposition leader, Neil Kinnock, and most other speakers explicitly approved the Government's actions in sending a force of about 2,000 people in naval ships, aircraft and ground support units to the area to help deter further Iraqi attacks and help the United States and other countries enforcing the United Nations embargo on trade with Iraq. **********But there was no such broad consensus on whether the British forces could go on the attack, unless there were further attacks by Iraq or explicit authorization from the United Nations. **********'An Inherent Right' **********Mrs. Thatcher argued that Britain was not precluded from taking military action under ''an inherent right of collective self-defense'' under existing United Nations resolutions. **********Those, passed in the first three weeks of the crisis, condemned President Saddam Hussein's invasion, imposed a trade embargo, demanded unconditional Iraqi withdrawal and restoration of the Kuwaiti Government, and authorized minimum force if needed to enforce the naval blockade. **********''We shall not give in to threats and blackmail,'' she said, condemning President Hussein's detention of hostages in Iraq and Kuwait. ''Our resolve, and that of our partners and allies, is absolute. There can be no compromises.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/12/world.main_headline: SOVIETS ARE URGED TO CHANGE FASTER
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/12/world.print_headline: SOVIETS ARE URGED TO CHANGE FASTER
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/12/world.body_text: **********With the Bush Administration on the verge of giving emergency economic aid to the Soviet Union, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d prodded Moscow today to use this assistance to speed up economic changes, not as a cushion to avoid them. **********Mr. Baker and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, conducted a joint news conference at the Houstonian Hotel, where they have been holding two days of talks on a variety of issues, from arms control to the Persian Gulf. **********Administration officials said it was highly likely that President Bush would announce on Wednesday that he is waiving the Jackson-Vanik trade restrictions, so that the Soviets will be free to buy American food on easy credit from the Commodity Credit Corporation. It is also likely that Mr. Bush will announce a provision of emergency medical assistance to the Soviets, after he meets at the White House on Wednesday with Mr. Shevardnadze, officials said. **********On Monday, Mr. Shevardnadze made a public appeal for food and other economic assistance from Washington, and while Mr. Baker confirmed that this would be forthcoming, he added that he and the Soviet foreign minister discussed the importance of "blending" any short-term emergency assistance "with efforts to promote medium or long-term economic reform in the Soviet Union."  'A Vibrant Economy' **********With Mr. Shevardnadze sitting next to him, Mr. Baker added that while he did not want to "minimize the current possible short-term needs of the Soviet Union, it is a country with tremendous resource potential and capabilities, and the right market reform can tap this potential in a manner to give that country a vibrant economy." **********Mr. Baker said he and Mr. Shevardnadze were in full agreement that any American emergency aid "should be transitional" -- meaning, he indicated, that it should be a bridge to a free-market Soviet economy not a crutch for maintaining the current half-way economic liberalization. **********On regional issues, Mr. Baker and Mr. Shevardnadze announced that in order to help promote a settlement of the Angolan civil war, Mr. Shevardnadze would meet on Wednesday in Washington, for the first time, with Jonas Savimbi, head of Unita, an American-backed guerrilla organization that has been fighting to topple the pro-Soviet Angolan government. **********Mr. Baker, for his part, will be meeting with Pedro Van Dunem, the Angolan foreign minister.  Outline of Angola Accord **********Mr. Baker and Mr. Shevardnadze said in a joint statement that they would "outline their concept of a settlement, including a cease-fire agreement; free participation of Unita and other parties in the political process in Angola in the framework of multiparty democracy; the conduct of free and fair elections and the termination of deliveries of all lethal materials to Angola" once there is a cease-fire. **********The two ministers said they made progress on resolving the myriad technical issues still holding up a treaty limiting strategic nuclear weapons, but had more work to do. They were also having to spend a great deal of time haggling over loose ends from the conventional arms reduction treaty they signed in Paris last month, officials said. **********Because the Soviets withdrew so many tanks and artillery pieces from Europe before the conventional arms treaty went into effect, they will not be destroying as much armor as originally projected. Some leading Senators have warned the Administration that unless they can get some ironclad assurances from Moscow about how these thousands of tanks and artillery pieces, now behind the Ural Mountains, will be, in effect, neutralized, if they are not going to be destroyed, the Senate is not likely to ratify the treaty.  U.S. on Gulf Position Backed **********On the Persian Gulf, Mr. Shevardnadze endorsed the American position that Iraq should agree to receive Mr. Baker in Baghdad at an early date, as the Americans have been demanding, as opposed to the Jan. 12 date offered by the Iraqis, which is only three days before the expiration of the United Nations Security Council deadline for Iraqi troops to be out of Kuwait. **********"It is very important that the goodwill grace period that expires on Jan. 14 is taken up with very active diplomatic and political efforts," said Mr. Shevardnadze. "The sooner contacts begin between the Iraqi leadership and the United States, the better it would be."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/16/busin.body_text: **********Unemployment in Britain fell by 23,200 people in January, to a provisional 5.7 percent of the work force, the Government said today. The seasonally adjusted figures showed unemployment at its lowest since October 1980, the year after Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher came to power. The improvement in the unemployment number was tempered, however, by data showing that December's annual rate of increase in average earnings was 9.25 percent, the same as November's. The Conservative Government wants to keep wages down in its battle against inflation, which is now about 7.7 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/11/world.main_headline: POLICE OPEN FIRE IN SOMALI STADIUM
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/11/world.print_headline: POLICE OPEN FIRE IN SOMALI STADIUM
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/11/world.body_text: **********At least 65 people were killed when security forces opened fire on the crowd at a soccer match in Somalia, diplomats said today. The Government had said that only three people were killed when troops fired on people throwing stones at the President. **********Unofficial fatality estimates in the shootings in Mogadishu, the capital, on Friday range as high as 109, according to one diplomat, who said 65 people were confirmed dead at the city's Digfer Hospital. **********More than 100 people were seriously wounded, another diplomat said. **********Abbudllahi Farah Barre, First Secretary at the Somali Embassy in Rome, insisted that only three people were killed in the stadium shooting. He said he did not have exact figures on the number of wounded. **********He said security forces opened fire after ''some provocateurs'' began throwing rocks at President Mohammed Siad Barre. He said the security forces first fired into the air, then on the crowd as people continued to throw rocks at officers. **********Official Version of Events **********The Somali Ministry of Labor, Sports and Social Affairs said the incident was caused by overcrowding and contended that people had been hit by bullets when security forces fired ''high into the air'' to maintain peace. **********On Saturday, the ministry dismissed the incident as a ''chance accident'' and said it had sent condolences to the victims' families. It also said three people were killed. **********In Washington today, the human rights organization Africa Watch strongly condemned the killings, saying they were either the work of a special units known as the Red Berets or that people died in a stampede as they scrambled to avoid the shots. The organization said 100 to 150 people were killed. **********Telephone connections to Somalia were not working today, and it was not immediately possible to reach anyone in Mogadishu. **********Somalia is an impoverished nation on the Horn of Africa. In recent years, the Government has steadily lost control of much of the nation's countryside to insurgencies and warring clans. **********Mr. Siad Barre has ruled the predominantly Muslim nation since seizing power in a coup in 1969.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/26/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY; Getting More Gas From Coalbeds
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/26/busin.body_text: **********A decade after Congress granted the first tax incentives for drillers to gather natural gas from coal deposits, a small group of energy companies finds itself in a booming, subsidized and profitable business. **********By some estimates, more than 500 billion cubic feet of natural gas recovered from coal deposits -- known as coalbed methane -- will flow into pipelines in 1990. That means coalbed methane will amount to 3 percent of the natural gas that analysts expect will be consumed across the continental United States this year. Five years ago, coalbed methane contributed only 10 billion cubic feet. **********Further increases in production are widely expected. Many analysts say discoveries announced in the last five years are enough to meet all of the nation's natural gas consumption for more than four years. And analysts say rising production of coalbed methane should keep natural gas prices from rising substantially for several years. **********Improvements in the drilling technique have played an important role in developing coalbed methane as a reliable and clean energy source. The new technique loosens the coal deposit freeing the methane in such a way that it flows more easily around the well bore. **********But most analysts say these advances would not have been made without the financial aid from Congress. **********"This is one of those examples of where a Government tax-incentive program worked extremely well," said John H. Wood, head of the proved reserves program for the United States Energy Information Administration. "Production is growing very rapidly." **********Methane, like coal, is formed from decaying plant matter that has been tightly packed under extreme pressures for millions of years.  Global Warming **********Energy companies have known since the 1920's that coal layers contain methane, often in large concentrations. Indeed, exploding concentrations of underground methane have killed thousands of miners. The Federal Bureau of Mines estimates that 300 billion cubic feet of methane escapes from underground coal mines each year, contributing to global warming. **********Until the more productive method was developed in recent years, high costs discouraged energy companies from trying to capture methane from the coalbeds. **********Amoco Inc. drilled the first successful methane-recovery well in the San Juan Basin of New Mexico and Colorado in 1977. **********Amoco used essentially the same drilling technology in its coalbed wells through most of the 1980's as it did in its oil and gas wells. Drill bits carved a well to the lowest depth of the coal seam. A pipe was lowered to the bottom of the well and concrete was forced out the bottom of the pipe until it rose up to the surface between the pipe and wall of the well. This formed an outer casing or shell to protect the pipe and prevent mud, gases and coal from seeping into groundwater supplies. **********Small bullets were then shot through the steel pipe and concrete that lay within the coal seam to create holes through which the methane could flow into the well. Next, a mixture of sand and water was pumped under heavy pressure from the surface into the well to further loosen the coal and get the methane flowing more rapidly into the well. Stress-Cavity Technique **********Since 1988, most drillers have used a newly developed method, called the stress-cavity technique, that dramatically accelerates the methane flow rate by exposing more coal to the well bore. The steel and concrete shaft stop short of the coalbed and do not go through it as is the case with the older method. Water and natural gas are pumped alternately from the surface directly onto the coal, carving a huge hole as chunks of coal are flushed back to the surface through the narrow drill pipe. Afterward, a liner pipe is placed at the base of the well to prevent more coal from being sucked in as methane is released from the coalbed. The methane flows through holes drilled in the liner pipe. **********The Devon Energy Corporation, based in Oklahoma City, said it drilled 10 wells this year using the stress-cavity technique near the sites of wells drilled with the older method. J. Michael Lacey, vice president of operations and exploration at Devon, said the payoff was production of 92.8 million cubic feet a day for the new wells compared with five million cubic feet a day at the older ones. **********Drilling costs for both types of methane wells, which average $400,000 a well in the San Juan Basin, are only a part of total development expenses. Additional wells must be drilled, often to depths of 8,000 feet or more, to flush salt-heavy water produced from the coalbed back underground. **********Sources of drinking water no deeper than 400 feet have been badly polluted by water pumped from coalbeds and released at the surface. Local officials filed environmental lawsuits in Alabama this year over water handling procedures at several drilling sites in the Black Warrior basin, delaying drilling programs there. For this reason, ARCO, for one, halted its drilling program at 25 wells instead of completing the 100 wells it had planned. **********Field stations are required to separate the water and methane that flow from the coal layer, as well as remove carbon dioxide from the methane. Pipeline companies limit carbon dioxide to 1 percent of a total natural-gas shipment because the molecule corrodes pipe. Before treatment, carbon dioxide levels in coalbed methane are as high as 15 percent. Pipelines for gathering the methane and connecting to lines operated by pipeline companies are another big expense. **********By all accounts, the drilling advances as well as the $3 billion invested in coalbed methane wells and related equipment would not have occurred without the special tax credit Congress approved in the 1980 Fuel Use Act. The credit amounts to a reduction in taxes on income from sales of coalbed methane. Congress recently estimated that the credit is worth $600 million for the years 1991 and 1992 combined. **********Producers said the credit gave them the financial cushion to experiment and develop the technology for mining the coal gas. The credit was set to expire at the end of this year, but a two-year extension for all coalbed methane wells was included in the latest budget. **********Before that extension, most analysts and producers anticipated a sharp decline in drilling in 1991 for coalbed methane. A resurgence is now expected in 1992. **********"A lot of small companies now realize they have another two years" to organize and finance drilling programs, said G. Warfield Hobbs, a former Texaco geologist who specializes in the economics and financing of coalbed methane production. "It's going to grow exponentially." **********Mr. Hobbs, managing partner of Ammonite Resources in New Canaan, Conn., estimated that 2,400 wells have been drilled for coalbed methane this year, or more than one-third of all natural gas wells drilled in the United States, at a cost of more than $1 billion. He said the amount of methane production should reach a trillion cubic feet a year, or double this year's rate, within a few years. **********John E. Olsen, a natural gas analyst with the First Boston Corporation in Houston, said the effect of the tax credit for producers was that the break-even price of coalbed methane was 25 cents a thousand cubic feet, well below the approximately $2 a thousand cubic feet that buyers are paying at this time of year. (Coalbed methane sells for slightly less than other forms of natural gas.) And for the year, Mr. Olsen said, the tax incentive amounted to an after-tax benefit of $1.26 for every thousand cubic feet. **********Among the major energy companies, Amoco, ARCO and Conoco had the most output from the two largest areas of coalbed methane production. All three were active in the San Juan Basin, and ARCO and Amoco had smaller drilling programs in the Black Warrior Basin. **********Meridian Oil, a Houston-based unit of Burlington Resources, was one of the largest drillers in New Mexico. Smaller independents such as Devon Energy, Taurus Exploration, McKenzie Methane and Energen also were active in coalbed methane this year. **********Many natural gas producers drilling in locations far removed from promising coalbed methane sites opposed the tax-credit extension. They blamed the subsidy for depressing market prices as more coalbed methane was produced, and fear the situation will worsen. Supporters of the subsidy countered that they shoulder the risk of huge losses if their coalbed projects yield little methane. **********Mr. Hobbs said rising coalbed methane output, as well as new natural gas supplies coming on-line in the Arkoma Basin of Oklahoma and in the Mobile Bay field off Alabama, should keep natural gas prices from rising substantially for several years. Cutting Prices **********Domestic producers have already lured some California customers away from Canadian producers by cutting prices on shipments that include large amounts of coalbed methane, Mr. Hobbs said. Canadian producers delivered 1.4 trillion cubic feet of natural gas to American customers last year, and many are concerned they will lose market share in California to marketers of coalbed methane from the San Juan Basin. **********The American Gas Association, a trade group in Washington, estimates probable reserves of coalbed methane at 90 trillion cubic feet. The trade group estimates total probable reserves of all forms of natural gas in the United States at 796 trillion cubic feet. The United States consumed 17 trillion cubic feet of natural gas last year. **********"Most people agree that this is a large resource," said Dr. Wood of the Energy Information Administration. "It's a matter of whether it's economical to get it out of the ground. That in large part is dependent right now on the tax credit."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/30/busin.main_headline: G.E. to Buy Risky Assets Of Kidder
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/30/busin.print_headline: G.E. to Buy Risky Assets Of Kidder
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/30/busin.body_text: **********Kidder, Peabody & Company announced a substantial recasting of its balance sheet yesterday that will shift troublesome assets to its parent, the General Electric Company. **********The move seemed intended to quell potential investor nervousness about Kidder's portfolio of illiquid assets. These include high-yield, high-risk ''junk bonds'' and ''bridge loans'' that were intended to be temporary but that could not be refinanced as investors have grown nervous about whether heavily indebted corporate borrowers can pay their debts. **********G.E. to Own All of Firm **********Kidder said G.E. would pay $750 million for the entire portfolio of junk bonds, bridge loans and equity stakes that it holds in companies. That amount is what each side agreed was the market value of the portfolio, and it was affirmed by KPMG Peat Marwick, the accounting firm. **********Kidder said it would use the $750 million to pay off about $500 million of its short-term debt and to buy back from employees an 11.7 percent stake in the firm, for about $50 million. The remaining $200 million will be paid back to G.E. as a dividend, and G.E. will then own 100 percent of Kidder. **********Dennis D. Dammerman, G.E.'s senior vice president for finance, said the transaction would not affect G.E.'s first-quarter earnings, and ''should not cause analysts to adjust their estimates of a double-digit increase'' in earnings per share. A spokesman for Kidder said G.E. would cover the expense of buying the portfolio from money it had previously set aside for unexpected developments. **********As for the first-quarter results, Michael A. Carpenter, the chairman and chief executive of Kidder, said the firm would break even on an operating basis but would record a loss of less than $25 million, which would reflect the reduced value of the portfolio being transferred to G.E. **********Asked why Kidder would pay a $200 million dividend to G.E., Mr. Carpenter said the firm would not need as much capital after the transactions were completed, because its balance sheet would be much stronger. **********Less Risky Balance Sheet **********As a result of the recapitalization, he said, Kidder's broker-dealer unit will have capital amounting to about $250 million more than regulators require. That is about $100 million more than it had in excess capital before, a change that results not from any infusion of capital, but from the fact that the balance sheet will ultimately be less risky. As such, less capital will need to be set aside under regulatory guidelines. **********Mr. Carpenter said the decision to recapitalize had been entirely Kidder's and had not been forced on the firm because of any problems in obtaining financing or pressures from rating agencies. He said the decision reflected a response to new market conditions and cited the recent collapse of the Drexel Burnham Lambert Group and financial pressures on Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. **********Although Mr. Carpenter insisted that the firm's business strategy would not change, he conceded that the move would probably signal the end of its bridge-lending activities. **********As for Kidder's plans in the junk bond business, Mr. Carpenter said the firm would continue to maintain a trading presence, but on a much smaller scale.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/31/busin.body_text: **********A judge dismissed a suit today that had been filed by the American Continental Corporation against Federal regulators, which accused them of hurting the survival chances of its Lincoln Savings and Loan Association subsidiary by leaking confidential information. **********United States District Judge Richard M. Bilby dismissed the case without prejudice, meaning it may be refiled or reopened. But he added that unless American Continental took action by July 1, the claim would be dismissed with prejudice. **********Judge Bilby precipitated a motion earlier this month by American Continental to dismiss the suit when he barred the company from continuing to pay lawyers to pursue the case. He said that lawyers' fees might consume the equity in American Continental. The company's legal bill was reaching $1 million a month.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/24/busin.main_headline: Europe Sets Prices for Japan's Chips
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/24/busin.print_headline: Europe Sets Prices for Japan's Chips
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/24/busin.body_text: **********The European Community said today that it would set minimum prices for computer memory chips sold by Japanese manufacturers. **********The action, which mirrors one taken by the United States more than three years ago, moves the world further toward a system in which prices of the crucial silicon circuits, known as dynamic random access memories, or D-RAM's, are controlled by government decree rather than by pure market forces. **********The community commission, the policy-making body for the group of European nations, said it was setting up the price system to prevent the Japanese companies, which dominate the market, from selling memory chips at prices below production costs, a practice known as dumping. **********Complaint on Dumping **********The commission had initiated an anti-dumping proceeding against Japanese companies in 1987 after receiving a complaint from European semiconductor producers. Today's action by the community had been expected, and 11 Japanese chip producers have agreed to the plan. **********American semiconductor producers and the United States Government have also complained about Japanese dumping, which helped drive all but two American producers out of the market for D-RAM's in the middle 1980's. But the dumping complaints were dropped in 1986 as part of an agreement between the United States and Japan that set up a minimum pricing system for Japanese D-RAM's and other types of chips. **********Since that time, however, D-RAM prices have largely been higher than the minimum prices and Japanese producers have cut production to shore up prices. **********The agreement has also done little to encourage American companies to re-enter the D-RAM business. Only last week, U.S. Memories, a joint venture aimed at producing D-RAM's, collapsed for lack of investors. **********Uncertainty Over Plan **********Semiconductor industry experts say it is also unclear whether the European system will entice new companies into the market. Siemens A.G. of West Germany has already begun producing D-RAM's. Philips N.V. of the Netherlands and SGS-Thomson, an Italian and French company, have expressed some interest. **********But the minimum pricing system could help American companies sell chips in the European market. The Texas Instruments Corporation has already announced it is building a chip-making operation in Italy. **********The European pricing system is different in some ways from the American system. In Europe, all the Japanese manufacturers will be given the same minimum price based on a weighted average of their costs, plus 9.5 percent. In the United States, each Japanese company is given its own minimum price, based on its production costs plus 8 percent, said Michael Gadbaw, an attorney for the Semiconductor Industry Association. **********Preference for New Chips **********The Europeans will also allow new generations of chips to be sold for ''a certain period of time'' below their production costs. **********The commission said it had requested pricing information from eight Japanese producers - Fujitsu, Hitachi, Mitsubishi, NEC, NMB, Oki, Toshiba and Texas Instruments, an American-owned company that produces in Japan. Three other Japanese companies - Matsushita, Sanyo and Sharp - requested to be included. **********The Intel Corporation, which said Monday that it would become the exclusive marketer of D-RAM's made by NMB of Japan, is also expected to be subject to the pricing system for the chips it gets from Japan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/05/busin.body_text: **********Few products looked more promising. When RJR Nabisco introduced a bite-size version of graham crackers last fall, the company was abuzz. In the in-house lingo, the sweet, crispy snack was very ''more-ish'' (you wanted more of it) and had ''high poppability'' (you wanted to pop it in your mouth). **********But to the company's dismay, sales were sluggish. As it turns out, looks -at least the looks of the box - were the problem. **********So in a crash program, Nabisco's marketing people changed the logo and changed the name to Graham Bites from Honeycomb Graham Snacks. And perhaps most important, in their eyes, they changed the color of the box, from a subdued blue to a bright yellow. As a result, sales of the six-sided snack, reintroduced in May, are strong and getting stronger. **********What the Package Says **********''In hindsight, the old box didn't say, 'I'm a new product; notice me,' '' said James Chambers, the Nabisco product director who oversees Graham Bites. ''With the new box, our sales are in the kill zone all the time.'' **********Nabisco's experience with Graham Bites shows how an eye-catching package design can be crucial in selling a product, even in this age of increasingly sophisticated consumers. **********Marketing consultants say that as packaged goods have proliferated, eye-appeal has become increasingly important. This is especially true for snack foods, which many shoppers buy impulsively as they trudge through a store. **********But consumers tend to shun the new and unfamiliar. So packaged-goods companies have been reluctant to introduce brands because of the high risk of failure - more than 95 percent in most instances. Instead, companies offer easy-to-recognize line extensions, or new versions of established brands, like Nabisco's Graham Bites. **********Even so, success is far from guaranteed. A big question in ''leveraging brand equity,'' as marketers put it, is how close in taste, appearance and packaging to the old product should the new version be? This is treacherous territory, as the experienced executives of Nabisco discovered, because package design is more art than science, more trial and error than application of established principles. **********''More and more marketers are realizing that package design is the final stage of their entire marketing program,'' said John Lister, a principal in Lister Butler Inc., a brand-identity consultant to companies like Nestle, Colgate-Palmolive and Nabisco (but not on Graham Bites). ''What the consumer sees on the supermarket shelf is the last five seconds of your selling effort. It's the stage when the consumer does or does not reach for your product.'' **********There are more than 18,000 different packaged food items in the typical supermarket, 80 percent more than 10 years ago, Mr. Lister said. Yet the average shopping time of 30 minutes has not changed. **********The upshot: the typical person glances at an average of 10 items a second during a shopping trip, up from 5.5 items a decade ago. More than likely, shoppers have gone glassy eyed long before the end of their trip. **********The Cookie Market **********At stake for Nabisco, Keebler, Sunshine and others is an estimated $5.9 billion wholesale market this year for cookies, crackers and biscuits, up from $5.6 billion last year. Nabisco has by far the largest market share, at 44 percent or an estimated $2.6 billion. **********As the major food subsidiary of RJR Nabisco, the tobacco giant that went private in history's largest leveraged buyout at $25 billion last year, Nabisco needs to score big new-product successes to help pay off the parent firm's huge debts. Marketing has long been part of the company's history. In 1899, Nabisco's Uneeda biscuit was one of the first nationally advertised products in the country. **********Graham Bites began as teddy bears. In early 1989, Nabisco executives were toasting each other over the success in the previous year of a new children's snack called Teddy Grahams, bite-size graham cracker snacks shaped like teddy bears. **********In its first year, more than $150 million worth of Teddy Grahams was sold, the biggest new-product success in the industry in more than 25 years. It became the third-best-selling cookie, after Chips Ahoy and the market leader, Oreo, both from Nabisco. **********Focus on the Mothers **********In snacks aimed at children, usually preteens, food companies rarely focus on them because they seldom go unaccompanied to stores. Companies focus on mothers, whom marketers call the family gatekeepers. **********Toward that end, designers strive not so much for what will appeal to children, but for what mothers think will appeal to their children. Even if antic cereal boxes with brightly colored cartoon characters turn children off, a mother will still buy it -at least once. **********Teddy Grahams were an exception. Graham crackers are low in sodium and saturated fat, so they seem relatively healthful. Nabisco thought mothers would buy bite-size graham crackers for their children without the guilt that restrains frequent purchases. And children liked them for the sugar. **********Aiming at Adults **********Nabisco reasoned that the sweet taste and relatively healthful image could also hook adults. So it took aim with an adult version of Teddy Grahams, called Honey Maid Honeycomb Graham Snacks. **********But having focused so much on how to sell the children's snack, Nabisco marketers sought to banish those ideas from their minds when it came to marketing Honey Maid. In hindsight, they concede, that was a mistake. **********There are some marketing rules of thumb on how to design packages for adults versus those for children. **********White packages or relatively restrained colors are said to appeal to adults. The Campbell Soup Company's Pepperidge Farm brand of fancy, expensive cookies are in cream-colored packages, with Old World script or other typefaces that convey a tasteful restraint. The product information is displayed in a fairly straightforward way, with nary an exclamation point in sight. **********Bright Colors, Big Letters **********By contrast, the bright primary colors and big block letters, often at unusual angles, of innumerable cookie, cracker and cereal boxes are thought to appeal primarily to children. Or at least act as a signal to adults that their children will go for the product. **********Nabisco marketers confess to an excessive fealty to the ''mother brand'' of Honey Maid Graham Crackers, a 110-year-old product. Nabisco wanted adults to know that the new snack was similar to the product that at least five generations had bought. **********So the box had a straightforward logo in a subdued blue. The name Honey Maid was the same size as in the original brand. ''It was all very, very much like mother,'' in the words of Bruce J. Wood, senior vice president-marketing. **********By the time the adult snack was placed on supermarket shelves in September 1989, some in Nabisco's supermarket sales force were wondering if the family resemblance was too close. Nabisco's advertsing agency, FCB/Leber Katz Partners, said the name Honey Maid Honeycomb Graham Snacks was too long to advertise, let alone for shoppers to remember. **********Something Was Wrong **********By November, everyone connected with the project knew something was wrong. Supermarket managers were telling many of Nabisco's 2,500 salespeople that many shoppers passed by the product, especially when it was at the bottom bay, or floor level shelf. **********The sales goal for Honeycomb Graham Snacks was a relatively modest $1 million a month, but the product was selling only 75 percent of that. ''It wasn't a bad consumer response,'' said Mr. Chambers, the product director. ''It was just a muddy consumer response.'' **********Luckily for Nabisco, it had introduced Honeycomb Graham Snacks in only half the country - about 15,000 supermarkets and other grocery outlets. As recently as five years ago, the company introduced products nationally with attendant fanfare. Now it offers them in stages, to reduce risk and allow for midcourse corrrections, like package redesigns. **********Packaging Deadline **********To be ready for the April 1990 national introduction of the snack to 30,000 stores, Nabisco had to have a new package prepared by early February, so its salespeople could have something to show supermarket executives. **********For weeks, Thomas J. James, director of graphic design, fiddled with elements of the box. The borders on the front panel seemed stolid and too industrial. The type identifying the flavor seemed too small. And something was wrong with the box's color, though Mr. James was not quite sure. **********The breakthrough in the creative process was a seemingly minor change in December. The honeycomb hexagon on the front panel rested on its side. When the product spilled out of this hexagon, it did not spill convincingly. By rotating the hexagon, so it balanced on point, Mr. James introduced tension and energy into a static design. ''That little thing sparked everybody's thinking,'' he said. **********Marketers began to focus on the individual snack bit, rather than the pile of bits emphasized in the original design. The back panel was redrawn to show a bull's eye design and a hand holding one bit the size of a quarter. And they renamed the product Graham Bites to underscore the idea. **********Conveying an Idea **********''We had wanted people to think the idea of handful, of popping it into the mouth,'' said Mr. Wood, the marketing senior vice president. ''We didn't realize it would be better to home in on one piece.'' **********The last thing to change was the box's color. Because the sweetened crackers were an adult product, Mr. James and the other marketers hesitated to turn to a bright color. But the Nabisco sales force told them that the biggest problem was that shoppers were ignoring the package. **********One of 10 proposed designs was a yellow package. Teddy Grahams came in a pale yellow package. If they were going to go with yellow, it would probably have to be bright yellow. ''We knew we had taken blue as far as we could go,'' Mr. James said. ''Whatever else you could say about yellow, it certainly communicated fun.'' **********It also communicated different. With the early February deadline approaching, Nabisco decided on a package in bright yellow - Pantone Matching System 108 Yellow, to be exact - with large rounded block letters emphasizing the shortened, ''fun'' name of Graham Bites. A tiny honeycomb netting underscored the product's difference from the ''mother brand.'' The box was, in short, a kid box. And, as it turned out, very more-ish.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/25/busin.main_headline: Moody's Reviews Ratings Of 2 Giant Japanese Banks
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/25/busin.print_headline: Moody's Reviews Ratings Of 2 Giant Japanese Banks
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/25/busin.body_text: **********The top triple-A ratings for long-term borrowings of Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank Ltd. and the Fuji Bank Ltd., the largest and fourth-largest banks in the world, are under review, Moody's Investors Service said yesterday. **********Moody's said the ratings for short-term borrowings of the two Tokyo-based banks remained at the highest level of prime-1 and were not under review. **********Dai-Ichi Kangyo and Fuji are both strong operations over all, Moody's said, and a rating reduction, if any, would not be substantial for their borrowings of more than a year. A lower rating would, however, tarnish the banks' image in capital markets, including the markets for interest-rate and currency swaps. **********Interest-Rate Risks **********Because rising interest rates in Japan have reduced bank earnings, Moody's said the two banks need to show that they have plans to control their interest-rate risks in the future. Deborah Kinzer, a senior analyst at Moody's, said deregulation of the financial system in Japan had resulted in banks raising the interest rates they pay on consumer deposits more rapidly than the interest rates they charge borrowers. **********Japanese bank earnings for the year ended March 31 are expected to be announced in May or early June. **********Dai-Ichi Kangyo operates the largest branch system of any Japanese bank and has assets of $430 billion, nearly twice the level of Citicorp, the largest American banking company. But Moody's said Dai-Ichi Kanyo had a long-term problem of controlling the costs of its branch banking system. Because its expenses are higher than other large Japanese banks, Moody's said, the earnings of Dai-Ichi Kanyo are more vulnerable when rapidly rising interset rates narrow the profit margin from lending. **********Real Estate Exposure **********Moody's said a rating review of both banks was justified because of their exposure to Japanese real estate. The rating agency has said it is worried about the possibility that real estate prices might decline. **********Although data were not available on the extent of their risk, Ms. Kinzer noted that the real estate exposure of the two banks was not as great as that of the Yasuda Bank and Trust Company, the Sumitomo Trust and Banking Company, the Mitsubishi Trust and Banking Corporation and the Mitsui Trust and Banking Company.
