The credit ratings for these Japanese banks were lowered earlier this year. **********At Fuji Bank, Moody's said it was also concerned about the risk of loss on loans made in the United States to finance corporate takeovers. **********Ms. Kinzer said the recent decline in the Tokyo stock market was not a consideration for Moody's because only a small part of each bank's stock holdings was counted when measuring their financial resources. **********Masahiro Nagayasu, the manager of the New York branch of the Fuji Bank, said he was puzzled by the Moody's review because other large Japanese banks were vulnerable to losses on real estate or loans for American corporate takeovers to the same degree, or more, than Fuji. He added that Fuji bank had recently created a new group to use financial futures and options to control the risk of rising interest rates.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/28/busin.body_text: *********** Amdura Corp., Denver, said a bankruptcy court had approved the sale of certain assets of its subsidiary, the Amdura National Distributing Co., to the United Hardware Distributing Co., Plymouth, Minn. The purchase price will depend on asset values as of the date of closing. *********** British Gas P.L.C., London, acquired three oil-producing areas in southern Argentina for $89 million. British Gas is in partnership with Cadipsa, a private Argentine group that is formulating plans for additional development of proven reserves. *********** Data General Corp., Westboro, Mass., said there was no truth to a report in The Boston Herald that it was considering a merger with Wang Laboratories Inc. *********** Du Pont Co., Wilmington, Del., said it would invest about $100 million to build a Lycra spandex fiber plant in Singapore. *********** Gradco Systems Inc., Irvine, Calif., said it would explore a possible spinoff of its printer products business to Gradco shareholders. It said its Gradco Systems (Japan) Ltd. unit would continue to conduct the company's worldwide copier business. *********** Justin Industries Inc., Fort Worth, accepted nearly 1.9 Tony Lama Co. shares in response to its $9 a share tender offer and now owns 97 percent of Tony Lama. *********** John Labatt Ltd., London, Ontario, a beverage and food company, and Canada Packers Inc., Toronto, a foods company, said they would form a partnership to combine their flour and flour-related businesses. The new partnership, with headquarters in Montreal, will be named Maple Leaf-Oglivie and will be 60 percent-owned by Canada Packers and 40 percent-owned by Labatt. *********** Louisiana General Services Inc., Harvey, La., an oil and gas company, and the Citizens Utilities Co., Stamford, Conn., said they amended the terms of their previously announced merger. Each Louisiana General common share will be converted into a fraction of a Citizens class B share determined by dividing $19 by the average Citizens share price for the 20 straight days ending three days before the merger is completed. *********** Martin Marietta Corp., Bethesda, Md., an information and aerospace technology company, said it had authorized the purchase of one million common shares and raised the quarterly dividend of its common stock to 37.5 cents from 33.75 cents.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/31/world.body_text: **********China's Communist Party Central Committee concluded a major six-day meeting today, after approving a moderate, cautious new blueprint for the 1990's and warning that the next decade could determine the rise or fall of the nation's Communist system. **********At the long-awaited meeting, the Central Committee formally approved the five-year plan that is supposed to govern the economy from 1991 to 1995 as well as a broader 10-year "program" for the 1990's. No specific measures or targets were disclosed today, but the party leaders issued a communique acknowleging that the Central Committee had held the meeting and mentioning some elements of the economic plans. **********The communique cautioned against rapid economic growth and emphasized the need to raise efficiency and improve the nation's industrial structure. **********Chinese officials and economists had said earlier that the conclusions of the meeting would reflect the compromises struck between the various leadership factions -- in particular, between provincial and central leaders and between hard-liners and liberals. The communique showed little sign of the conflicts between those groups, but its remarkable vagueness suggested that no single faction had dominated the blueprints. Over 500 Leaders Attend **********National television showed the party General Secretary, Jiang Zemin, dressed in a dark Mao-style jacket, giving a speech, as the party's Politburo members sat somberly beside him on the rostrum. The meeting included 171 Central Committee members, plus 107 alternate members and about 300 other Chinese leaders, according to the official New China News Agency. **********"Success or failure in our efforts in the 1990's to consolidate and develop the achievements made in the 1980's and to greatly promote economic growth and social progress will have a direct bearing on the rise or fall of China's socialist system and the future and destiny of the Chinese nation," the communique said, as issued by the press agency. **********In a later passage, it apparently alluded to the collapse of Communist systems in Eastern Europe, saying, "In the face of a complicated and ever-changing international stituation, it is crucial that we manage our domestic affairs well." **********The leaders called for self-reliance, but also endorsed the policy of economic openness. They only briefly mentioned specific areas of economic restructuring, like prices, taxes, labor and enterprise. It also suggested that Chinese leaders did not want to repeat the economic mishaps, including inflation and economic overheating, that accompanied high growth during the last five years; they contributed to the pro-democracy demonstrations in May and June of 1989. Zhao's Fate Not Mentioned **********The document did not mention the fate of the former Communist Party General Secretary, Zhao Ziyang, who was ousted during the Tiananmen Square crackdown more than 18 months ago. Mr. Zhao has been said to be under investigaton, and the party, at least publicly, has still not made any formal determination of his role during the democracy movement. **********No changes in the leadership were announced, and the party did not appear to expand the 14-member Politburo, on which three seats have been vacant since the crackdown. **********The document gave no target economic growth rate, but the official press has said the economy should grow at about 6 percent annually in the next few years. This is dramatically slower than the previous decade's average annual growth, which was about 10 percent.  Splits With Local Authorities **********According to Chinese economists and officials, the meeting had been delayed until now because of serious disagreements between the central Government and the provincial governors over the degree of regional autonomy and taxes that the provinces must hand over to Beijing. Because of severe fiscal deficits, central leaders had been seeking higher taxes from the provinces and greater influence over local markets, but the governors reportedly rejected earlier versions that they felt would have been too onerous. **********One characterstic of the last decade had been the devolution of authority from Beijing to the localities, in an effort to raise economic incentives and spur the economy. In contrast, the new five-year blueprint includes an attempt by central leaders to take back some of that power. Officials have said the plan will give the central Government greater power but not quite as much as it had sought. **********China's leaders also hope to spur ailing state enterprises -- one third of them are losing money -- and preserve the household responsibility system that allows individual farming.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/12/world.main_headline: Iran Welcomes Offer By Moscow on Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/12/world.print_headline: Iran Welcomes Offer By Moscow on Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/12/world.body_text: **********Iran has welcomed an offer by the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, to sponsor a meeting of Iranian and Iraqi foreign ministers to break the deadlock in talks on the Gulf war, the Iranian press agency I.R.N.A. said today. **********The Iranian Foreign Minister, Ali Akbar Velayati, told Mr. Shevardnadze that Iran would consider any Soviet proposal containing a ''systematic and clearly defined formula'' for peace, I.R.N.A. said in a report received here. **********The press agency said that Iran's reply had been conveyed by Deputy Foreign Minister Mahmoud Vaezi, who returned to Teheran on Wednesday after talks with Mr. Shevardnadze in Moscow. The agency did not say when Mr. Shevardnadze offered to sponsor the foreign ministers' meeting. **********Talks on a lasting peace in the Gulf war have made little headway since 1988, when Iran and Iraq accepted a United Nations resolution that halted the fighting.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/04/busin.print_headline: FORUM;   Let's Let Business Be Business
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/04/busin.body_text: **********In a market-based economy that recognizes the rights of private property, the only social responsibility of business is to create shareholder value and to do so legally and with integrity. Yet we do have important unresolved social challenges - from drug abuse to education and the environment - that require collective action. Corporate management however has neither the political legitimacy nor the expertise to decide what is in the social interest. It is our form of government that provides the vehicle for collective choice via elected legislators and the judicial system. **********Whether corporate social responsibility is advocated by political activists or the chief executive officer, the costs of these expenditures, which don't increase the value of the company or its stock, will be passed on to consumers by way of higher prices, or to employees as lower wages, or to shareholders as lower returns. Remember that employees also have shareholder interests by their participation in corporate pension funds. The essential issue is finding the most appropriate and effective way to solve social problems. **********During the last decade, an active market for takeovers has shown little tolerance for managements that are not attentive to shareholder value. Indeed, management's response to the threat of takeovers unlocked billions of dollars of value for the shareholders. It would, however, be a profound error to view increases in a company's value as concern just for the shareholders. Enlightened managers and public officials recognize that increases in stock prices reflect improvement in competitiveness - an issue that affects everyone with a stake in the company - or the economy. **********Nonetheless the chief executives of some of our largest companies contend that shareholder interests should not be their primary obligation. Just as ''corporate social responsibility'' were the buzzwords of the 1960's and 70's, ''balancing the interests of 'stakeholders' '' are the latest code words for the same idea. Hicks B. Waldron, chairman of Avon Products, for example, contends: ''We have 40,000 employees and 1.3 million representatives around the world. We have a number of suppliers, institutions, customers, communities. None of them have the democratic freedom as shareholders do to buy or sell their shares. They have much deeper and much more important stakes in our company than our shareholders.'' **********An approach that attempts to balance the interests of everyone with a stake in the company makes it easier for corporate managers to justify uneconomic diversification or overinvestment in a declining core business, since these moves are likely to be endorsed by people other than the shareholders. For organized labor, it means more jobs - in the short run. Suppliers enjoy the prospect of additional business, and the local community a larger tax base resulting from the increased size of the enterprise. Business decisions based on social criteria also often bring praise for the chief executive officer. It is precisely these decisions that subordinate shareholder interests and that trigger the much maligned corrective mechanisms of takeovers and restructuring. **********There is another view of stakeholders that is both consistent with and supportive of shareholder value: improved competitiveness, and in, the final analysis, socially responsible business behavior. This view recognizes that the company's continued existence and competitiveness depends on a long-term financial relationship with each of the groups that has an interest in the company. Employees want competitive wages and benefits. Customers want high-quality products and services at a competitive price. Suppliers and bondholders have financial claims that must be satisfied with cash when they fall due. Shareholders look for dividends and higher stock prices. **********If the company does not satisfy the financial claims of its constituents, it will cease to be viable. Employees, customers, and suppliers will simply withdraw their support. Thus, a going company must strive to enhance its long-term cash-generating ability. The ability of a company to distribute cash to its various constituent groups depends directly on its ability to generate cash from operating its businesses efficiently and on its ability to obtain any additional funds needed from the debt and equity markets. This long-term emphasis on cash flow as the basis for evaluating the maximum benefit for shareholders among arrangements with other interested parties, is the essence of the shareholder-value approach to management. There are inherent conflicts between shareholders and other groups, but management serves the long-term interests of its constituents best by enhancing its competitive position and thereby also increasing its economic value. **********The rash of takeovers and restructurings has led many to the politically expedient conclusion that shareholders are reaping substantial economic gains at the expense of other interested groups, especially employees. This adversarial view of the shareholder-stakeholder relationship is simplistic and in most cases inaccurate. Employees affected by a work-force reduction initiated as part of a takeover or corporate restructuring can usually point to superior competitors or to a management team that has failed to develop strategies that maximize shareholder value as the real culprit. In the end, it is the quality of management decision-making, coupled with an implementation process that fully embraces the contributions of all stakeholders, that leads to corporate success. **********Social investing, whether carried out by investment groups or by management, is not only at odds with the basic fiduciary duty to maximize value for shareholders, but also goes counter to corporate efforts to gain advantages in an increasingly competitive global marketplace. What can be more socially responsible than to build a sustainable competitive advantage? After all, it is competitiveness that will provide the jobs and the tax base needed for the accomplishment of social goals that are more effectively addressed by government than by the private sector.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/02/busin.main_headline: Yields Put at 9.3% and 9.8% On Offerings by Fannie Mae
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/02/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;   Yields Put at 9.3% and 9.8% On Offerings by Fannie Mae
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/02/busin.body_text: **********Two debenture issues by the Federal National Mortgage Association were priced yesterday through a nationwide group of securities dealers. **********The Fannie Mae sale totals $1 billion, including $400 million in four-year securities and $600 million in 10-year securities. **********Fannie Mae said both issues were priced at par, with the four-year debentures yielding 9.3 percent. The spread over Treasury securities with a similar maturity is 20 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. **********The 10-year debentures were priced to yield 9.8 percent, or about 72.7 basis points over Treasuries. Underwriters noted that the 10-year debentures are callable by Fannie Mae beginning May 10, 1995.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/28/busin.main_headline: More I.R.A. Cash in Stock Funds
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/28/busin.print_headline: More I.R.A. Cash in Stock Funds
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/28/busin.body_text: **********Stock mutual funds had their best season for individual retirement accounts in three years, several fund officials said yesterday, as new industry figures showed that investors have become more willing to put cash into the stock market. **********''We saw a strong commitment to equities in general, but especially to international equities, in I.R.A. accounts,'' said Jane Nelson, a spokeswoman for T. Rowe Price, a leading mutual fund company. **********Henry L. P. Schmelzer, the executive vice president of New England Securities, said that after the October 1987 crash many insurance agents, who sell his firm's mutual funds, were reluctant to push stock funds. **********''We're just beginning to see a return to a fairly good level of comfort among the insurance agents,'' he said in explaining the rise in I.R.A. money going into stock funds. **********Role Remains Critical **********Although I.R.A.'s are less important to the mutual fund industry than they were before 1988, when new rules reduced tax benefits for many investors, they still have an important role. The sales of individual retirement accounts helped gross sales of equity funds climb to $6.7 billion in March, the highest level for any month since April 1987, and up from $5.7 billion in February. **********By contrast, the money managers who run stock funds remain hesitant to invest the money they are being given. At the end of March, 11.9 percent of the assets of stock funds were in short-term money market investments, called cash in the industry. That was up from 11.6 percent a month earlier and the highest level since June 1982, just before the 1980's bull market began. **********''Main Street is more confident than Wall Street,'' said Avi Nachmany, an analyst with Strategic Insights, a division of the Jesup & Lamont Securities Company. **********While some fund officials said overall buying of stock funds slowed in April, as stock prices generally declined, they said the trend still remained positive. Some also reported that the flow of cash out of high-yield, high-risk ''junk bond'' funds appeared to be ending finally. In March, the outflow was $231 million, the smallest in nine months. **********If investors put more cash into the stock funds than they took out, as the officials said, April could mark the 11th time in the last 13 months that cash flow was positive, with a total inflow of $14.4 billion through March, when $3.1 billion came in. **********By contrast, in the 18 months beginning with the 1987 crash and continuing through March 1989, investors put more money into stock funds than they took out only during two months, with net withdrawals of $29.2 billion. **********With the general rise in stock prices, the assets of stock funds have climbed to a record $248.6 billion, as of the end of last month. **********The cash flow figures include purchases of funds, as well as redemptions and transfers between different funds in the same group. They exclude dividends that are automatically reinvested. **********One of the strongest I.R.A. performances was reported by Fidelity Investments in Boston, which said that investments in individual retirement accounts doubled in the 1990 season, which ended when tax returns were due on April 16. Michael Hines, a Fidelity spokesman, said more than half the money went into equity funds, several percentage points more than in 1989. **********While junk bond funds continued to see cash flow out on an overall basis, those who moved cash between different types of funds put money in for the first time since last June, a total of $55 million. That came as junk bond prices generally edged up in the month, with the Merrill Lynch High-Yield Index gaining eight-tenths of 1 percent. In April, high-yield prices gave up most of that small gain, according to Merrill Lynch. **********''One bright light is a turnaround in the high-yield area,'' said Mrs. Nelson of T. Rowe Price. She said that firm's junk bond fund would have shown positive cash flow in April but for one large institutional redemption. She said sales of the fund were rising. **********Some Flow Into 'Junk' **********John Reilly of the Massachusetts Financial Services Company, also in Boston, added that ''in March, we actually had some net cash inflow into the junk bond area. In April, it was just about flat.'' **********Several fund groups reported that sales of other bond funds suffered in April as interest rates rose, driving down the value of existing bonds. **********Funds that invest in Ginnie Maes, mortgage securities issued by the Government National Mortgage Association, seem to be bringing in cash, however. They had a cash inflow of $99 million in March, up from $50 million the month before, when a string of 34 monthly outflows, dating back to March 1987, was ended.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/22/world.main_headline: China's Army Is Cared For in a Lean Budget
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/22/world.print_headline: China's Army Is Cared For in a Lean Budget
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/22/world.body_text: **********The Government acknowledged today that it faced grave budgetary difficulties, but at the same time proposed a budget for 1990 that includes a sharp increase in military spending. **********The National People's Congress, now meeting in Beijing for a 15-day session that will give pro forma approval to the budget and other proposals from the leadership, also agreed today to accept the resignation of Deng Xiaoping from his last formal post, as chairman of the Government's Central Military Commission. Mr. Deng announced in November that he would retire from the post, and today's move was a formality. **********The Congress did not name a new chairman, but it is widely expected to be Jiang Zemin, the Communist Party leader and Mr. Deng's choice to succeed him as China's paramount leader. In November Mr. Jiang succeeded Mr. Deng as chairman of the Communist Party's Central Military Commission, which in practical terms is the same as its Government counterpart. **********The military spending increase, by $6.2 billion, or 15.2 percent, had been expected as a signal of the leadership's appreciation of the role of the People's Liberation Army in crushing democracy protests last year. The army was the major beneficiary in a budget report that was otherwise bleak. **********''The condition for the state budget this year is grim,'' Finance Minister Wang Bingqian told the congress in an address. He presented a draft budget that included a nominal deficit of $1.89 billion, down slightly from last year. **********But those figures were calculated under the Chinese practice of counting borrowed funds as revenue. Using Western accounting practices, the budget gap this year reaches $9 billion, up 14.5 percent. **********Most Western and Chinese economists agree that China's economic difficulties are related less to the military crackdown last June than to the 18-month-old austerity program. The economic slowdown has made it more difficult for the central Government to raise funds, and has meant increased subsidies to money-losing state enterprises. **********The budget proposal also included a 9.9 percent increase in education spending and a 7.9 percent increase in funds for agriculture. It is not clear how such numbers are derived or how reliable they are, and some university faculties have been told that education spending would drop this year. **********Most Western diplomats regard the figure for military spending as a significant understatement of the total, partly because the budget allocation apparently does not incorporate sums the army earns from weapons sales and from civilian products produced by army-owned factories. **********China's leaders have given strong hints - particularly after seeing the Romanian Army help topple a Communist Government in December - that they want to insure the loyalty of the army. In addition, the leadership has been trying to give the army a greater role in maintaining domestic security. **********According to the Finance Minister's report, the two largest allocations, each amounting to about $14 billion or about 20 percent of the budget, are for capital construction and subsidies to money-losing enterprises. **********China has tried to cut spending for inefficient enterprises by introducing a bankruptcy law, but the Government has been reluctant to allow money-losing companies to go bankrupt.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/02/world.body_text: **********Restoration of the Christ the Redeemer statue, cracked and chipped by years of wear on its perch above Rio de Janeiro, began this week, a city spokeswoman said today. Some $2 million will be spent to restore the 125-foot-high monument, which attracts hundreds of visitors every day. The work should be finished by October, in time for the 59th anniversary of the opening of the statue, the spokeswoman, Estela Elliot, said, .

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/03/world.main_headline: Estonia Sends Firmer Signal to Moscow
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/03/world.print_headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;   Estonia Sends Firmer Signal to Moscow
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/03/world.body_text: **********The new Parliament of Estonia told President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today that the Soviet Constitution could not be the basis for realizing the republic's wish to be independent of the Soviet Union. **********The Parliament overwhelmingly approved a resolution addressed to the Soviet leader saying a new secession law scheduled to be debated this week in Moscow did not apply to Estonia. **********This was because the republic became part of the Soviet Union ''not as a result of the free will of the people of Estonia or through legal parliamentary action, but as a result of military intervention and the occupation of the territory of the Estonian republic by Soviet forces,'' the resolution said. **********Hitler-Stalin Pact **********After the Stalin-Hitler pact of 1939, which divided Eastern Europe into spheres of influence, the Soviet Union intimidated Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia into accepting Soviet military bases on their territory. In 1940. Moscow's forces occupied all three Baltic republics, and they were incorporated into the Soviet Union after rigged referendums the same year. **********The Government here has chosen a more measured, less confrontational approach to achieving independence than Lithuania. Nonetheless, today's message to Mr. Gorbachev makes clear that Estonia will not consider seceding from the Soviet Union by adhering to methods that are yet to be decided by the Soviet Parliament. **********In his appeal to the Lithuanian Parliament on Saturday night, Mr. Gorbachev called on the legislators there to renounce their declaration of independence, and said unequivocally that questions of independence could be resolved only on the basis of the Soviet Constitution. The Estonian Parliament voted 68 to 16, with two abstentions, that Estonian deputies to the Supreme Soviet, the standing legislature in Moscow, should not even take part in the debate over the new secession law. **********''We consider it impossible to participate in the debate of the laws in the Supreme Soviet of the U.S.S.R. because our participation in preparing these laws could be construed as our admission of the legality of the inclusion of Estonia into the Soviet Union and its existence as part of the Soviet Union,'' said the letter to Mr. Gorbachev, which is to be signed by Estonian representatives to the Supreme Soviet in Moscow. **********Mindful of Moscow **********Last week, it seemed as if the Estonian Parliament was being highly mindful of Moscow's threats, decrees and warnings intended to pressure Lithuania into revoking its declaration of independence and to intimidate its Baltic neighbors, Estonia and Latvia, into resisting a similar course. **********In the midst of the Kremlin's show of force in Lithuania, the Estonian Parliament voted on Friday to begin a ''transitional period'' in the quest for complete independence from the Soviet Union, stopping short of the sweeping declaration issued by the Lithuanian Parliament in Vilnius last month. **********As a further sign of caution in the republic's bid for independence, the Parliament voted to keep the former Estonian President, Arnold Ruutel, as head of state because of his experience in dealing with Moscow. Lithuania bypassed its former President. Algirdas Brazauskas, and elected Vytautas Landsbergis, a non-Communist music professor who led the republic's independence movement as its head of state. **********But the Estonian Parliament also took the unusual step of voting to work hand in hand in this period with the Estonian Congress, which was elected outside the government structure by people who could prove that they or their ancestors had been Estonian citizens when the republic was forcibly incorporated into the Soviet Union. **********'No Real Power' **********Deputies here said that today's letter to Mr. Gorbachev should dispel any notion that Estonia intended to compromise with the Kremlin. **********''It simply would have been deceiving ourselves to decide something we cannot carry out,'' said Endel Lippmaa, an Estonian deputy to the Supreme Soviet in Moscow, speaking about the decision not to declare independence now. ''We have no real power now to suspend the Soviet Constitution or to get rid of Soviet military presence here. But we can inform Moscow formally what our intentions are, and that the clock is beginning to tick now.'' **********People here said today that they were less concerned with symbolic statements or with immediately ridding Estonia of all Soviet emblems that have been incorporated into the Estonian Government in the last 50 years. **********One of the first gestures of the Lithuanian Government after it declared its independence was to pry the Soviet hammer and sickle off the side of the parliament building. But the legislators here have been carrying on their work forming a new government for its transition to independence amidst the symbols and signs of the soviet government they are seeking to leave. **********Above the entrance to the Parliament building, the blue, black and white flag of independent Estonia snaps in the cold spring wind alongside the red flag of Soviet Estonia, with its rippled stripes of blue and white under a hammer and sickle and a star. In the chamber, the deputies face a glowering relief of Lenin flanked by two bronze crests with the hammer and sickle. And at the desk where the speaker and his deputies sit, there are miniatures of the two flags that hang outside. **********''There is really no reason to change the symbols of state until our situation truly changes,'' said Marju Lauristin, a founder of the Estonian Popular Front who was elected on Friday as deputy speaker of the Estonian Parliament. ''We should not confuse symbols with reality.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/03/busin.main_headline: The Media Business;   Ingersoll, in Swap, Sheds His U.S. Papers
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/03/busin.print_headline: The Media Business;   Ingersoll, in Swap, Sheds His U.S. Papers
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/03/busin.body_text: **********Ralph McA. Ingersoll 2d, who aggressively acquired newspapers in this country over the last decade but has been under mounting financial pressure, left the newspaper business in the United States yesterday to run newspapers in Europe. **********Mr. Ingersoll and his partner, the venture capital firm of E. M. Warburg, Pincus & Company, said they had swapped their matching 50 percent stakes in operations that owned papers in the United States and in England and Ireland. Mr. Ingersoll will have all the English and Irish properties, and Warburg all the American properties. **********Under the swap, Mr. Ingersoll gave up his 50 percent stake in The New Haven Register; The Trentonian in New Jersey; a group of suburban weeklies ringing St. Louis and about a dozen smaller dailies and weeklies. **********In exchange, Mr. Ingersoll, who is 44 years old, received dailies in Birmingham and Coventry, England; The Dublin Press in Ireland and a group of weeklies. **********The agreement means dividing a newspaper empire with an estimated market value of $1.5 billion, but also with heavy debt on the United States papers. **********In an interview yesterday, Mr. Ingersoll said he was pleased with the swap, because it would enable him to operate independently. For Warburg's part, an executive said that the newspapers would be operated as before, and that no sales of properties were contemplated, other than those already being pursued. **********Mr. Ingersoll said the United States newspapers have a cash flow - that is operating profit plus depreciation - of $100 million on revenues of $400 million, and debt of $600 million. **********The English operation is much smaller, Mr. Ingersoll said, with cash flow of $40 million, revenues of $180 million and debt of $109 million. Nevertheless, the trade is equal in terms of equity after debt, he said. **********At the same time, Warburg announced that it would not pay $8.3 million in interest due on $125 million in high-interest ''junk bonds'' issued by Community Newspapers Inc., the operation formerly owned with Mr. Ingersoll that Warburg will now control. Community, whose assets include a group of financially strapped Long Island free weeklies, is negotiating with bondholders to redeem the bonds at a discount. **********The swap was generally welcomed by the bondholders who have financed Mr. Ingersoll's decade-long spending spree. **********''A lot of people felt like Ralph wasn't dealing in good faith,'' said Ned Zacher, a media analyst for the high-yield group at Duff & Phelps Investment Research Company in Chicago, referring to complaints that Mr. Ingersoll had been unwilling to give bondholders timely and complete information on operations. **********Mr. Ingersoll said in an interview yesterday that no cash exchanged hands in his swap with Warburg and that he was free to acquire newspapers in this country in the future, but had no immediate plans to do so. **********Mr. Ingersoll said that he welcomed the transaction as an opportunity to own a newspaper company outright, and that he planned to ring some major European cities with free weeklies, just as he did in St. Louis. **********'Often-Expressed Dream' **********But analysts and associates who have watched Mr. Ingersoll assemble his empire said they thought it unlikely that he would have abandoned it willingly. ''His often-expressed dream was to create a major media company in this country, but at least for now, that's the end of that dream, whatever reason he might give for it,'' said John Morton, a media analyst at Lynch, Jones & Ryan in Washington. **********The Warburg announcement did not offer any reason for making the swap, but in recent months there have been suggestions that the partnership had soured because of Mr. Ingersoll's overly ambitious management, which had created huge debts. **********''Obviously, he was in a lot of trouble,'' said Mark Goodson, the chairman of the Goodson Newspaper Group, which Mr. Ingersoll managed until last year. Mr. Goodson removed his newspapers from Mr. Ingersoll's management after their longtime relationship deteriorated. Mr. Goodson estimated that Mr. Ingersoll lost $10 million in management fees, but Mr. Ingersoll puts the amount at $6 million. **********Warburg said in a statement that Robert M. Jelenic, who has managed the newspapers under Mr. Ingersoll, would continue to operate them and that Warburg would use its $3 billion in equity capital to ''improve and expand'' the operations, except for the Long Island weeklies, which have been up for sale for several months. **********Known for Cost Control **********Mr. Ingersoll is known for an extremely tight cost control, which has given his newspapers a reputation for high profits and undistinguished journalism. **********Mr. Jelenic said that many of the papers, except the Chanry group of weeklies on Long Island, had been operating at levels higher than last year because of additional cost cutting. He said Warburg did not anticipate any trouble servicing any other debt. He did not offer any specific operating numbers for any of the newspapers. **********Mr. Jelenic also said that he had no plans to change the way the papers were operated, and that only the Long Island weeklies were for sale. **********Mr. Ingersoll built his empire in the 1980's by paying top prices for newspapers in this country. His purchases were heavily dependent on debt, mostly through junk bonds, which were sold with the expectation that profits would be high. **********A Well-Known Father **********His rise was viewed with particular interest because his late father, Ralph Ingersoll, who established the company, was a legendary journalists. In the 1940's, the senior Ingersoll founded PM, a liberal New York daily, that failed financially. He then began managing and acquiring newspapers. His son, Ralph 2d, took over the company in 1982 after buying his father out in a bitterly contested deal that left them no longer on speaking terms. **********Most of the papers were in the Northeast, where newspapers generally have seen profits wither recently in a poor advertising climate. **********Earlier this year, Mr. Ingersoll closed The St. Louis Sun, a tabloid that he had started the year before in competition with The Post Dispatch. No competing metropolitan paper had been successfully started in decades, and Mr. Ingersoll was regarded as reckless by many analysts for embarking on the venture. **********Although Mr. Ingersoll has bristled at the notion that he was trying to eclipse his father's accomplishments, it has been widely believed in the industry that the shadow cast by his father propelled him to try to demonstrate that he could do what his father could not: start a successful newspaper. **********Mr. Ingersoll said that once all the equipment was sold, his loss from The Sun would be ''around $25 million,'' but analysts have estimated a considerably higher figure. **********Another Troubled Operation **********The Community Newspapers group is also in financial duress, mostly because of the junk bonds used to buy and expand the group of free weeklies on Long Island, where Mr. Ingersoll intended to compete for advertising with Newsday. **********The bonds included a reset provision under which interest rates were adjusted annually to make up for the difference in value if the bonds were trading at a discount. **********The investment came on the eve of last year's dramatic slowdown in the newspaper business generally and especially on Long Island, which reduced Community's profits well below the levels needed to service debt. **********In its announcement, Warburg said yesterday that the negotiations with holders of Community Newspapers bonds would continue. **********Bond analysts said Warburg's decision not to pay the interest would put pressure on bondholders, as well as on Warburg, which will be considered in default in 30 days, if payment is not made. That could lead to Community Newspapers being pushed into bankruptcy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/26/busin.main_headline: President-Elect of Brazil Pushing Free-Market Ideas
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/26/busin.print_headline: President-Elect of Brazil Pushing Free-Market Ideas
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/26/busin.body_text: **********Beginning a nine-nation tour to put a ''new face'' on Brazil, the country's president-elect, Fernando Collor de Mello, vowed in New York yesterday to restore growth to Latin America's largest economy through privatization, fiscal discipline and debt relief. **********In a speech to 400 business executives and bankers, several of whom had said earlier that Brazil's high inflation and low growth in the 1980's had left them skeptical about its prospects, Mr. Collor put forth his ideas on developing a freer market in his country. **********On his March 15 inauguration, Mr. Collor, a 40-year-old state Governor, will assume leadership of a country that experienced 1,775 percent inflation last year and stopped servicing its foreign debt. After enjoying one of the third world's highest growth rates in the 1970's, Brazil's economy slumped in the 1980's, averaging about 2 percent growth a year. **********Admirer of Thatcher **********Mr. Collor, an admirer of British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's free-market policies, proposed restoring growth through increased foreign investment and deregulation of the economy. **********''The inflation and stagnation paralyzed investments and discouraged the entry of foreign capital,'' Mr. Collor said in Portuguese to the luncheon sponsored by the Americas Society at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. **********Echoing free-market advocates in other Latin American countries like Argentina and Mexico, Mr. Collor blamed Brazil's stagnation on ''the inhibiting and inefficient state, the inflation and financial speculation, the system of privileges that protects and rewards inefficiency.'' **********Last year, Brazil's Congress refused to approve an inflation-fighting package submitted by Brazil's President, Jose Sarney. The plan would have cut Government spending and the Government payroll. Mr. Collor, whose party controls only 5 percent of the seats in Brazil's Congress, did not say yesterday how he would muster political support in Congress to push through his changes. **********Limits to Sacrifices **********Addressing Brazil's debt problem, he warned the audience, which included representatives of New York's largest banks, that there were limits to the sacrifices Brazil could accept to make payments. **********''We don't have the illusion of being able to unilaterally impose a path of negotiations,'' he said. ''But we cannot accept impositions - agreements which resemble loyalty oaths -blocking our growth and condemning us to backwardness and misery.'' **********Mr. Collor won general support from members of the audience. **********''I have seen a lot of Latin leaders come through here,'' said one American banker who had crossed swords with Brazilian officials throughout the 1980's over their inability to service $110 billion in foreign debt, the largest in the third world. ''On a scale of 1 to 10, I put Collor at 9.5.'' **********Henry Kissinger, who also attended a closed-door meeting with Mr. Collor yesterday morning, said: ''I was very encouraged by what he said.'' **********From New York, Mr. Collor travels to Washington where he is to meet with President Bush and others. He will then travel to Tokyo, Moscow, Bonn, Rome, Paris, London, Lisbon and Madrid.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/16/busin.body_text: **********Industrial production fell in April for the first time since January, with a sharp drop in the output of motor vehicles and parts, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. **********The Fed also said that the operating rate of the nation's factories, mines and utilities - which measures not only output but also changes in productivity levels - declined last month from its March level. **********''We are accumulating a dossier that the economy lost some momentum during the last month,'' said William Sullivan, an economist at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. **********The new signs of economic sluggishness followed reports last week that retail sales weakened in April while producer prices dropped from March levels, which economists said might encourage Fed policy makers to consider lowering interest rates. **********Steep Drop in January **********The Fed said industrial production fell in April by four-tenths of 1 percent, marking the first decline since January, when it dropped by a steep 1 percent. The rate rose five-tenths in March and nine-tenths in February, revised from the seven-tenths originally reported for March and the eight-tenths for February. **********The Fed said production of autos and light trucks fell by nearly 14 percent in April from March. But excluding motor vehicles and parts, industrial output was unchanged in April and has shown little movement since January, the Fed added. **********Joseph Carson, an economist at the Chemical Bank, said that when all of the recent figures were analyzed collectively, the greater risk for the economy would be slow growth, not rising inflation. ''What today's data tell us is that the manufacturing sector has yet to hit bottom and that talk of an inventory-led rebound in the economy is mistaken,'' he added. **********Easier Interest Rates Seen **********Mr. Carson said he believed the Fed would not change its credit policy in a hurry, but when it did it would be toward reviving the economy with easier interest rates. **********Many economists expect that the Government will announce on Wednesday an April rise in the Consumer Price Index of three-tenths of 1 percent compared with a five-tenths increase in March. The index measures the change in retail prices for housing, food, transportation and electricity. **********Today's Fed report said that the production of consumer goods was down by 1 percent in April after rises of nine-tenths of 1 percent in March and 1.1 percent in February. Business equipment, a category also affected by the auto industry, dropped nine-tenths last month after gains of 1.5 percent in March and 1.6 percent in February. **********Building Supplies Weaker **********The Fed said output of construction supplies also weakened in both April and March, erasing gains from last fall and early this year when unseasonably warm weather made it possible for builders to continue projects. **********As a result, industrial operations ran at only 83 percent of capacity in April compared with 83.5 percent in March and 83.2 percent in February. **********The last time the operating rate for the nation's mines, factories and utilities was lower was in January, when capacity use fell to 82.7 percent because auto producers cut output and laid off workers temporarily while dealers reduced stocks of unsold cars left over from late 1989. **********Manufacturing output dropped to 82.2 percent of capacity in April from 82.9 percent in both March and February, the Fed said. Operating rates for auto plants dropped to 65.1 percent in April from 75.6 percent in March. **********In contrast, mining output increased to 88.3 percent from 87.4 percent because of gains in the oil and gas sector and continued strength in coal mining, the Fed said. **********The operating rates of utility companies were up to 87.1 percent in April from 86.6 percent in March.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/09/world.main_headline: U.S.-Kenyan Dispute Grows a Little Testier
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/09/world.print_headline: U.S.-Kenyan Dispute Grows a Little Testier
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/09/world.body_text: **********A Kenyan Cabinet member accused the United States today of supporting the opposition, another step in the dispute between the United States and Kenya over the future of democracy in this nation. The American Ambassador denied the accusation. **********The Minister for Livestock Development, Elijah Mwangale, was quoted this morning in The Kenya Times, the newspaper of the nation's sole political party, as saying that he had information to the effect that Kenyan dissidents in the United States were using the Ambassador to pour money into the country to disrupt it. **********Mr. Mwangale said Kenya would ''not tolerate treasonable activities by Americans living in Kenya.'' **********The American envoy, Smith Hempstone, denied that the United States was supporting Kenyan dissidents. **********In a telephone interview, Mr. Hempstone characterized Mr. Mwangale's statements as ''arid nonsense.'' The envoy added, ''It is well known that if anyone knows about illegal money, he knows about it.'' He did not explain what he meant. **********Last week, Mr. Hempstone said Congress favored economic aid to countries that ''nourish democratic institutions, defend human rights and practice multiparty politics.'' **********President Daniel arap Moi took exception to the comments and warned that foreign diplomats should not meddle in the internal affairs of Kenya. **********A traditional ally, Kenya received $65 million in economic aid last year, one of Washington's largest grants in sub-Saharan Africa.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/01/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;   Deluge of Gulf Satellite Data
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/01/world.body_text: **********Intelligence analysts can barely handle the deluge of photographs pouring into the Central Intelligence Agency from spy satellites monitoring Iraqi forces in the Persian Gulf, Aviation Week and Space Technology magazine reported. The respected industry journal will report in its Monday edition that experts at the C.I.A.'s National Photo Interpretation Center said as many as five spacecraft are observing the Middle East crisis zone. Data from the satellites periodically backs up because there is too much to analyze. Copies of the report were provided to reporters in Cape Canaveral.
