https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/11/world.main_headline: EAST TIMOR BISHOP WRITES OF TORTURE
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/11/world.print_headline: EAST TIMOR BISHOP WRITES OF TORTURE
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/11/world.body_text: **********In a letter carried here clandestinely, a Catholic bishop in the former Portuguese colony of East Timor has described the human rights situation there as intolerable and has criticized Portugal and the United Nations for failing to intervene on behalf of the Indonesian-occupied territory. **********''Portugal hopes that time will solve the problem, but meanwhile we are dying as a people and a nation,'' said the Bishop, Msgr. Carlos Filipe Ximenes Belo, who is under strong pressure from the Indonesian military authorities in East Timor. **********Indonesia, which is overwhelmingly Muslim, forcibly annexed the predominantly Roman Catholic territory after Portugal withdrew in 1974. **********Monsignor Belo's letter, which took seven months to reach Portugal, was delivered to Bishop Manuel Martins of Setubal, a major industrial city south of Lisbon, and he read excerpts on national television this week. The letter was written on June 7, four months before Pope John Paul II visited Dili, East Timor's main commercial city. **********Fears Assassination **********Bishop Martins said by phone from Setubal that the letter had been ''carried by many hands'' and reached him through members of a religious order. **********In the letter, Monsignor Belo said he feared he might suffer the same fate as Archbishop Oscar Arnulfo Romero, the Salvadoran primate assassinated in 1980. **********''The situation of the East Timorese is absolutely unthinkable, from the point of view of persecution, torture,'' Bishop Martins said after reading the letter. ''The East Timorese are profoundly isolated and their bishop is profoundly isolated. Many things have been promised, and many hopes created, but it seems there's no morals in politics. Moral principles are invoked only as currency, as means to an end.'' **********The Timorese bishop asked Bishop Martins to press the United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, to reply to a letter that he wrote to him in February 1989. Monsignor Belo complained then that Portugal had not been sufficiently active in seeking a negotiated settlement in East Timor since the territory was invaded by Indonesia in 1975. **********International rights groups say that perhaps as many as 200,000 East Timorese, out of a population of 650,000, have been killed by Indonesian troops. **********Says U.N. Failed to Respond **********Portugal withdrew from East Timor as part of a rapid dismantling of its colonial empire. The United Nations still recognizes Portugal as the administrating power, but Monsignor Belo told Mr. Perez de Cuellar that the United Nations had yet to discharge its responsibilities toward the territory. **********''The East Timorese have never been consulted about their political future,'' he said. **********In the letter revealed this week, Monsignor Belo said the people of East Timor were forced to accept Indonesian rule ''at pistol point,'' and that he was being subjected to harsh attacks by the Indonesian authorities. **********''However, the majority of the population is well aware of the maneuvers practiced by the Indonesian Government and military authorities,'' he wrote. ''The Christian population prays'' and ''waits for the happy day when people can express their aspirations as free men. Monsignor, pray for me. From one day to the next I could follow the path of Bishop Romero.'' **********From the time he was appointed bishop of East Timor in 1983, Monsignor Belo has faced pressure from the East Timorese nationalist movement, known by the Portuguese name Fretilin, as well as from the Indonesian authorities. Supporters of Fretilin and young Catholic radicals initially accused the bishop of being an agent of the Indonesian Government, but Monsignor Belo soon proved to be as outspoken as his predecessor, Martinho Lopes da Costa, who was ordered by the Vatican to retire after Indonesia complained that his sermons fomented nationalist sentiment. **********An 'Intifada' Emerges **********Since the Pope's vsit on Oct. 12, when a melee broke out as students demonstrated for independence, East Timorese persecuted by the police have sought refuge in the Bishop's residence. There are unconfirmed reports that his house was raided by the military in November and that students were removed by force. **********Reports from Fretilin released through the movement's office in Lisbon suggest that a new movement described as ''the Timorese intifada'' has emerged in East Timor since the Pope's visit. Unarmed members of the movement, which is modeled on the Palestinian uprising in the Israeli-occupied territories, have reportedly risked death on three recent occasions in direct confrontations with the Indonesian military.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/02/busin.main_headline: White House Gets Bill Reducing Ads on Children's TV Programs
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/02/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;   White House Gets Bill Reducing Ads on Children's TV Programs
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/02/busin.body_text: **********The House of Representatives overwhelmingly approved legislation today to reduce the amount of television commercials on children's programming by almost two minutes each hour. **********The bill, which was approved last week by the Senate and now goes to the White House, would also compel broadcasters to offer more educational programming for children or risk losing their broadcasting licenses. **********Even though the legislation was approved by a unanimous voice vote in the House, it faces an uncertain future. President Bush has objected to the bill on First Admendment grounds, saying it amounted to an infringement on free speech. But supporters of the bill are hopeful that Mr. Bush will not veto the measure because of his pledge in the 1988 campaign to serve as the ''education President.'' **********Lobbying Since 1970 **********''How can the man who claims that he is the education President veto this bill?'' said Peggy Charren, president of Action for Children's Television, which has been lobbying since 1970 for improved programming for children. **********The House also passed legislation that would require television manufacturers by mid-1993 to build into any television set, with a screen 13 inches or larger, a microchip that would enable the set to show special closed-captions for the deaf. **********Currently, a televison set can be equipped to show closed-captions by buying an attachment that costs $160 to $200. Supporters of the legislation said it would cost manufacturers $5 to $15 for each set to build the capability directly into the television. **********The children's programming legislation at this point has no opponents in the industry, having received the reluctant endorsement of the National Association of Broadcasters. It also had broad support in the Senate. **********Under the measure, commercials on children's television programs would be limited to 10 1/2 minutes an hour on weekends and 12 minutes on weekdays. **********Most children's programs are on Saturday and Sunday mornings and on weekday afternoons. **********The measure would also require that serving the educational needs of children be made a guiding factor when the Federal Communications Commission considers whether to renew a television station's license. **********Broadcasters Are Warned **********''We all know that televisions are on for six or seven hours every day in almost every household in the United States,'' said Representative Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts and chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee's Subcomamittee on Telecommunications and Finance. ''If broadcasters are to use the public spectrum, they will have to show they are taking children's education needs into consideration to justify their licenses.'' **********During the debate, many lawmakers spoke of an ''overcommercialization'' of the public airways, especially in programs directed toward children, who, they contended, were less able to distinguish between a commercial and normal programming. **********Studies by the industry have found that some stations show as much as 11 to 12 minutes of commericals an hour during children's programming on weekends and up to 14 minutes on weekdays. Regular prime-time programming has an average of less than 8 minutes of commercials an hour. **********The issue of regulating children's programming is not new. Until the early 1980's, the F.C.C. limited the amount of commercial time on children's programs and generally required an educational commitment from local broadcasters. **********But when the industry was deregulated by the Reagan Administration in 1984, the guidelines were abandoned and the number of educational programs declined, while the number of toy-based programs proliferated. **********Attempts in 1988 to reimpose regulation were successful in Congress, with the House and Senate passing a bill that was similar to the measure passed today. But after Congress recessed for the November elections, President Reagan vetoed the bill. **********Children's Needs Stressed **********While the authors of the current bill see reducing the advertising content as important, they say that making children's needs a criteria for license renewal is even more critical. **********Under the legislation, the F.C.C. is instructed to develop a system that takes a station's educational and informational programming into consideration. **********''We have to remind broadcasters that they can't get away with showing 'The Cosby Show' and showing Bozo the Clown going to the local hospital,'' Ms. Charren said. ''It's an issue of choice. For the parents who do not want their children to see violent cartoons or 'Looney Tunes,' there should be a choice.'' **********The bill also requires the F.C.C. to examine the role of ''program-length commercials,'' generally cartoon shows based on characters, like the Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles, that are also popular toys. Such toy-based cartoon series have proliferated in recent years, helping to increase sales for toy manufacturers and, lawmakers say, pushing much educational programming to the side. Tough Issues for F.C.C.  The issues could be thorny for the F.C.C., particularly whether it should decide the appropriateness of a children's program and draw the line between a valid program and one that is intended primarily to generate toy sales. **********It also can cause problems for some educational programmers. For example, if the Ninja Turtles is considered a program commercial, regulators at the F.C.C. might also face problems with ''Sesame Street,'' which has won awards and much praise as an educational program but has also provided the basis for a large and lucrative line of toys.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/15/world.body_text: **********An emergency summit meeting of West African leaders to discuss Liberia's civil war has been canceled, the Ivory Coast Government said today. **********No reason was given, but some officials feared the meeting could have widened the dispute over a five-nation military force sent to Liberia to end the fighting. **********The meeting, which had been scheduled for Monday in President Felix Houphouet-Boigny's hometown of Yamoussoukro, was opposed by some members of the 16-nation Economic Community of West African States, including Nigeria and the four other countries participating in the task force. **********The Ivory Coast, Burkina Faso and some other French-speaking countries have opposed the intervention. These countries also have supported the clain of a rebel leader, Charles Taylor, as the legitimate president of Liberia. **********All the nations in the task force are English-speaking except Guinea, a former French protectorate. **********Mr. Taylor and his supporters had been pressing for a summit meeting to push for a withdrawal of the force, which has taken control of the capital city of Monrovia and moved into its suburbs. **********His forces, which invaded from the Ivory Coast on Dec. 24, have overrun most of the country except the capital. **********Troops loyal to the slain President, Samuel K. Doe, and a second rebel leader, Prince Johnson, have been cooperating with the task force and are concentrated in Monrovia. **********Liberia's 10-month-old civil war has left at least 5,000 civilians dead and forced about 250,000 refugees to flee to neighboring countries.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/12/busin.main_headline: A Giant That Takes No Giant Steps
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/12/busin.print_headline: A Giant That Takes No Giant Steps
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/12/busin.body_text: **********Over the last five years, the Tribune Company of Chicago has faced a persistent question from some investment bankers: With the powerful base of its six television stations, why not emulate Fox Broadcasting and develop a new network? **********In light of the strike at The Daily News, Tribune is now facing the most crucial long-term decisions since it went public in 1983. Its policy over the network question suggests that it will act cautiously, avoiding precipitous action. **********Available to 18.7 percent of United States households, the Tribune stations -- including WPIX in New York, WGN in Chicago and KTLA in Los Angeles -- have a reach even wider than that of Fox and one that is exceeded only by the three big commercial networks. So, the argument went, Tribune could grow into a Fox-like network by investing heavily in programming through the acquisition of a studio or the rapid development of its nascent entertainment division.   'More Cautious Approach' **********"They could certainly have taken the Fox route, and plenty of bankers were ready to argue that they should," said Peter Falco, an investment analyst at Merrill Lynch. "But they just have a much more cautious approach. It was too risky for their style of management." **********Such caution, even amid the acquisition fever of the 1980's, is typical of Tribune, a company that prides itself on embodying what Jack Fuller, the editor of its flagship Chicago newspaper, called "the fundamental conservatism of the middle of the country." Making deals with what one banker called "the guys with gold chains in Hollywood" or taking the kinds of risk that Fox's owner, the News Corporation, is prepared to confront, is not where it feels most comfortable. **********Indeed, despite its $2.45 billion in sales last year -- a revenue figure that makes the company larger than other media groups like Knight-Ridder, McGraw-Hill, Washington Post, Dow Jones and The New York Times -- Tribune has managed to keep a generally low profile, at least until The Daily News was struck last month. **********Run by men with a background in finance, Tribune has a buttoned-down culture untouched by the glitz of other media giants. None of the company's top three officers -- Charles T. Brumback, chief executive; Stanton R. Cook, chairman, or John W. Madigan, president of the Chicago Tribune Company -- has any experience as a journalist. The company, over all, has much more in common with Main Street than with Los Angeles or New York. **********Indeed, the only corporate advertisment Tribune has taken out since going public was in 1989, when its Chicago Cubs baseball team, acquired in 1981 for $21 million, won the championship of the National League's Eastern Division. "We prefer to let our actions speak for themselves," said Mr. Madigan, who is widely expected to succeed Mr. Brumback as head of Tribune. **********In recent years, Tribune's results have indeed been eloquent. Net profit last year was $242.4 million, having risen 23 percent annually from the $69.2 million earned in 1983. Over the same period, as a result of efforts to cut costs and make all operations as efficient as possible, the company's return on equity grew to 21 percent, from 10 percent, and revenue soared to $2.45 billion, from $1.5 billion. **********Alongside the newspaper division, which consists of seven papers and accounts for about 65 percent of revenue, the decision to stick to what it knows and avoid gambles in broadcasting and entertainment has also paid dividends. **********Aided by successes like the "Geraldo" show, with Geraldo Rivera as host, which was started in 1988, revenue grew to $584 million last year, compared with $228.7 million in 1983, and operating profits more than doubled over the same period to $96.8 million.  Erratic Newsprint Performance **********Only the company's newsprint operations, which have suffered strikes this year and account for about 18 percent of revenue, have performed erratically. **********This growth has led several analysts to praise the company as one of the best managed in the media business. **********But even before the strike at The Daily News, net income plunged 27 percent in the first three quarters of this year, in line with the results of many other media companies. And that decline came despite the fact that so far Chicago has largely avoided the slump that has shaken the East Coast. **********"There is nothing cheap about a strike," said John Morton, an analyst at Lynch, Jones & Ryan. He and other analysts now expect Tribune's 1990 profits to fall as much as 35 percent from last year. This performance prompts a critical question: What should be done about The Daily News and the Tribune Company's loss-making newsprint operation? **********But Tribune's top executives show no sign of contemplating abrupt changes in direction. Mr. Fuller, the editor of The Tribune, said the company's long history and tradition -- The Chicago Tribune was founded in 1847 -- leads it to shun expediency in favor of measured action. Mr. Madigan, who is 52 years old, said, "We've really looked hard at what we wanted to do to be more competitive in the industry, and rather than takeovers, we've found lots of opportunity to be more efficient." **********A model of the kind of regional strength the company likes is Chicago, where Cubs games are carried on WGN-TV with commercials for The Chicago Tribune, with all three units generating Tribune profits. The company does not want to spread itself thinly around the country. **********The view of management seems to be that the company has leading products in big markets throughout the country -- including Atlanta (where it has the WGNX-TV station); Denver (where it has KWGN-TV); Orlando, Fla., (where it owns The Orlando Sentinel), and Fort Lauderdale, Fla. (where it has The Sun-Sentinel) -- and that it should therefore build on this strength rather than spread itself more thinly. **********Still, some new departures in television and entertainment appear possible. James C. Dowdle, the chief executive of Tribune Broadcasting, told a Paine Webber media conference last December that "if we can isolate the right opportunities, we will make acquisitions of independent television stations in major metropolitan markets, radio stations and add-ons for entertainment." He added that "we will expand our efforts to produce and syndicate mini-series and made-for-TV movies."  'Hard-Nosed' Techniques **********But, in typical Tribune style, Mr. Dowdle, who declined to be interviewed for this article, also talked about keeping a strict control on costs and the company's "hard-nosed development techniques." **********Such a hard-nosed approach is certainly evident in New York. A recently completed company study of the New York market through the year 2005 shows a population increase of two million, an employment expansion of 1.8 million jobs and a doubling of retail sales. Tribune, which also owns WPIX-TV and WQCD-FM in this market, does not want to leave. **********Jim Squires, who was editor of The Chicago Tribune until last year, said the mission of Mr. Brumback, who was named chief executive three months ago, is "fix New York." **********Mr. Brumback declined to be interviewed. But in weighing the decisions for the loss-making Daily News and the newsprint mills, it seems clear that two factors are firmly present in his mind. On the one hand, Tribune will hesitate to take a drastic course, just as when it shunned a Fox-like experiment during the 1980's. On the other, it is a pragmatic company proud of its strong financial performance, and losses will not be tolerated forever.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/14/busin.main_headline: Trade Talks Will Continue in Informal Settings
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/14/busin.print_headline: Trade Talks Will Continue in Informal Settings
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/14/busin.body_text: **********The collapse of global trade talks in Brussels last week in a dispute over farm subsidies does not mean the negotiators are finished. **********Agriculture Secretary Clayton K. Yeutter will visit the European Community's Commissioner for Agriculture, Ray MacSharry of Ireland, on Friday, at Mr. MacSharry's invitation. Mr. Yeutter, who owns a big ranch in Nebraska, and Mr. MacSharry, a former cattle salesman, were the main adversaries at last week's Brussels meeting, which was held under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the world body that oversees trade. **********In addition, the 13,000-member National Association of Manufacturers said on Tuesday that it had invited its counterparts in Europe and Japan to meet in January to "re-energize the momentum" for more liberal trade agreements, said Jerry J. Jasinowski, the association's president.  Retaliatory Pressure Seen **********In the absence of formal negotiations and progress, however, the Bush Administration is likely to face growing pressure from Congress to begin retaliatory actions against nations accused of unfair trade practices. **********The Bush Administration had postponed actions on a number of domestic trade complaints in the hope they would be resolved by agreements reached in Brussels. "We are going to analyze each of the cases on their merits," a senior trade official in Washington said this week. **********If it becomes apparent that the stalemate in Brussels cannot be overcome and that the four years of trade talks known as the Uruguay Round, because they began there, are indeed over, the cases "would be handled in a more confrontational and acrimonious atmosphere than would otherwise have been the case," the trade official said.  Cautious Moves Expected **********The White House is likely to proceed slowly, unwilling to pick a fight with any of its allies, given the delicate situation in the Persian Gulf. **********Still there is likely to be growing Congressional pressure to move on the cases. The ability of Carla A. Hills, the United States trade chief, to deflect action will depend on her credibility in arguing that the Uruguay Round can be revived, one Congressional aide said. **********The Administration faces a deadline around mid-January on a formal complaint brought by the National Pork Producers Council and the American Meat Institute against a European ban on pork and beef imports from the United States. **********The meat producers are asking for retaliation under Section 301 of the Trade Act of 1974, which could involve 100 percent tariffs against European food products. **********The last American action against the European Community came two years ago, when 100 percent duties were imposed on canned tomatoes and instant coffee, among other products.  Aircraft Subsidies an Issue **********The United States could also act against the Europeans in the long-standing conflict over subsidies paid to Airbus Industrie, the European aircraft company that competes with Boeing and McDonnell Douglas. **********But the trade fights are not just with Europe. A tougher stand would also be taken against such major trading partners as Japan and Korea. **********In 1986 and again in 1988 the Reagan Administration rejected petitions from the domestic rice industry against Japan's blanket prohibition of rice imports, saying those restrictions would be addressed in the Uruguay Round. The American industry is almost certain to revive its petition. **********And a new dispute is arising with Japan following its award of a major contract in the Kansai airport project to a Japanese bidder over a more experienced team led by Westinghouse Electric and AEG of Germany. **********Trade relations have also deteriorated with South Korea, where American officials say there has been a backsliding on commitments combined with anti-American rhetoric. One example is a comic book published by the National Agricultural Cooperative Federation, a farm group controlled by the Government of President Roh Tae Woo, showing that foreign food products are unhealthy and that their purchase would force Korean farmers from the land.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/06/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;   AC&R's Aruba Work Stresses Distinctions
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/06/busin.body_text: **********AC&R Advertising's first campaign for the Aruba Tourism Authority has much that is standard to island advertising: beautiful scenery, an attractive couple in bathing suits and a narrator who speaks with a Caribbean lilt. What sets the campaign apart is its attempt to set Aruba apart. **********''On Aruba, we do things a little bit differently. . . ,'' the ads say, and they feature things about the island that are distinctive: square coins, ''almost no rainy days'' and divi-divis, bushy trees that are wind-swept and lopsided. **********Steve Bennett, a senior vice president and management supervisor at AC&R, said the agency created the campaign after interviews with vacationers. ''One of the things they kept on coming back to was that Aruba is different,'' he said. ''They all said it was unusual, but they were unable to put it into words.'' **********The campaign begins on television in New York and Boston on Monday. Print ads will appear in the May issues of magazines.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/02/busin.body_text: **********The Florida Power and Light Company, one of the largest investor-owned electric utilities in the country, yesterday priced $125 million in first-mortgage bonds due 2000 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. **********The bonds have a 9.625 percent coupon and are priced at 99.675 to yield 9.6764 percent, or about 110 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. **********Underwriters said the proceeds from the sale would be used to repay short-term borrowings and to finance additional electric utility projects. **********Noncallable by the utility for five years, the bonds are rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/13/world.main_headline: P.L.O. Sets Condition on Sea Raiders
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/13/world.print_headline: P.L.O. Sets Condition on Sea Raiders
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/13/world.body_text: **********The Palestine Liberation Organization is prepared to discipline the group that attempted in May to attack Israel from the Mediterranean, once the United States agrees to resume and expand its discussion with the P.L.O , leaders of the organization say. **********The talks were suspended in June by the Bush Administration, 18 months after they started. The United States demanded that the P.L.O. punish or expel the Palestine Liberation Front, led by Abul Abbas, as a condition for resuming the dialogue. **********The Abul Abbas group was accused in the attempt to land guerrillas at Tel Aviv from speedboats, which was thwarted by the Israeli Navy. **********The P.L.O. officials said they were prepared to ''handle Abul Abbas,'' as one senior leader put it, but not until Washington committed itself to enlarge the scale and range of the talks. **********''We want a real dialogue, not a mailbox to send questions and wait for answers,'' said Yasir Abed Rabbo, a member of the P.L.O's Executive Committee who headed the Palestinian delegation during talks in Tunisia with the United States Ambassador, Robert H. Pelletreau Jr. 'Clarify Our Positions' **********''It is a process that allows us to go to Washington, to see people in the Congress, in the media and help us clarify our positions to the American people,'' Mr. Abed Rabbo said.  High P.L.O. officials agreed in a series of interviews that their desire to resume talks with the United States was based on a conviction that peaceful negotiations were the most viable option - indeed the only option, many said - to settle the conflict with Israel. **********This was coupled with a widely shared view among Palestinians that the United States has been indispensable to the peace process. **********P.L.O. leaders said that they were striving for an internal accord that would ban all military operations against Israeli civilians, in or outside Israel, by all members. **********The proposal is to be examined next month at a meeting of the Central Committee in Baghdad. **********A Threat of Discipline'' **********''We should name those groups for whose actions we are responsible and those for whom we cannot answer,'' said Saleh Khalaf, the chief of security and second in command of the P.L.O., after Yasir Arafat. ''If any of our groups break the agreement, they will be disciplined,'' **********Asked about terrorist acts by groups that do not belong to the P.L.O., Mr. Khalaf, whose guerrilla name is Abu Iyad, said he was certain that the resumption of ''a significant dialogue with the United States'' would moderate extremist Palestinian tendencies, even outside the P.L.O. and among Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. **********''I am confident we can still control things, but the momentum of events is going against us and against those of us who still speak of peace, or negotiations and of dialogue,'' Mr. Khalaf said. **********Asked what they would do if the United States refused to commit itself to resuming or broadening the suspended discussion, some P.L.O. leaders said that they had no other option under consideration. **********The P.L.O officials conceded that their main difficulty in dealing with extremism was the large number of groups involved in the P.L.O., and opinion in the Arab world in general and, beyond that, in Israel and the West. **********'Anger and Frustration' **********''We want to talk about peace but how can we ignore the anger and frustration our people and the daily killings of Palestinians by the Israeli Army in the occupied territories?'' stressed Bassam Abu Sharif, a senior advisor to Mr. Arafat. ''We are facing conflicting pressures from every direction. We need a break.'' **********Among other things, P.L.O. officials said that militant Islamic fundamentalists in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, who oppose any compromise with Israel, are gaining greater influence, and at the expense of the P.L.O. **********Meanwhile, hard-line Arab countries, particularly Libya, Iraq and Syria, are supporting extremist factions, the P.L.O. officials added. **********They agreed, for example, with Israel's conclusion that Libya financed and trained the Abul Abbas group in the May raid. **********Western officials here and some Palestinians also noted that Iraq might have allowed the Abu Nidal organization to reopen an office in Baghdad, although the group's leader, Sabry al-Banna is still living in Libya under surveillance. **********No Authorization for Raid **********''Abul Abbas did not consult the P.L.O. Executive Committee and was not authorized to undertake any military operations against Israel,'' said Khaled al-Hassan, an influential member of Al Fatah's Central Committee. **********Mr. Hassan was the only senior P.L.O leader to denounce the sea raid immediately, describing it in an article on June 4 in the Lebanese daily Al Hayat as a ''children's game that P.L.O. leaders should be far above.'' **********''I was against this operation from A to Z,'' he said in an interview at his home here. ''It was a complete failure.'' **********Virtually all Palestinian officials interviewed said the punishment of Abul Abbas and his expulsion from the P.L.O. would not, in itself, be a problem. **********''To be very frank, we can sell Abul Abbas,'' said the senior P.L.O. official, who asked not to be identified. He used an expletive to refer to the Palestinian leader, whose group also carried out the 1985 hijacking of the cruise liner Achille Lauro. **********P.L.O. Seeks 'Proper Formula' **********Palestinian leaders said they were racing through meetings to find a ''proper formula'' to satisfy the United States's demands and their own need to control groups like that of Abul Abbas. **********''Every time we make some progress,'' one senior official said, who also used an expletive to describe Abul Abbas ''he does something that sets us back a year and we have to start all over again.'' **********P.L.O. officials acknowledged that they had known in advance of preparations for some sort of military operation by the Abul Abbas group. But they did not know, they said, the specific target nor the timing of the attack, which too place on the last day of an Arab summit meeting in Baghdad. **********Asked to explain the failure of the P.L.O. to learn the details of the Abul Abbas raid, especially since the Israelis appeared to have known about it, a senior official in charge of security said: ''The P.L.O. does not direct much of its energies in intelligence gathering against its own members. We tend to watch extremist outsiders, like Abu Nidal, for example.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/04/busin.main_headline: A.T.&T. Buying 3 Units of Western Union
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/04/busin.print_headline: A.T.&T. Buying 3 Units of Western Union
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/04/busin.body_text: **********The Western Union Corporation, the financially troubled company that pioneered telegraph and telex services, announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell its telex, computer mail and computer data transmission services to A.T.&T. for $180 million. **********The deal raises badly needed cash for Western Union and makes the American Telephone and Telegraph Company a leader in the growing market for sending messages between computers at different companies and homes. **********Yesterday's agreement completes the transformation of Western Union from a telecommunications company to a financial services and overnight mail business. Western Union has already shed four types of telephone service: long-distance, cellular, satellite and private leased lines. **********Western Union is trying to refinance its bonds and has warned the Securities and Exchange Commission that it may have to file for bankruptcy. The company said it would use most of the proceeds from the A.T.&T. deal to redeem part of its $635 million debt. **********Western Union's stock climbed 6.25 cents yesterday to close at 62.5 cents a share on the New York Stock Exchange. The company's $500 million issue of high-yield ''junk bonds'' rose in price from $36 to $47 for each $100 of face value. **********Western Union, based in Upper Saddle River, N.J., is controlled by Bennett S. LeBow, who invested $25 million in the tottering enterprise in late 1987 and arranged the sale of the junk bonds to consolidate most of the company's previous debt. **********The 139-year-old company will retain three businesses: wire transfers of money, bill payments for people who do not have checking accounts, and express message-delivery services like the trademark yellow and black telegram and blue Western Union Mailgram. A.T.&T. will get a third of Western Union's 3,800 employees and 40 percent of its revenues, which totaled $628.7 million last year. **********Western Union will use A.T.&T.'s facilities for its communications needs from now on, said Robert J. Amman, the president and chief executive of Western Union. The exact terms of this service have not been determined and are not linked to yesterday's agreement, Mr. Amman said. **********Western Union's creditors did not force the sale, but they ''were anxious to see us sell a business,'' he said. **********Expanding in Electronic Mail **********A.T.&T. sought the agreement mainly as a way to expand its role in electronic mail, which consists of computer users sending messages to one another, said John R. Smart, the president of A.T.&T.'s business communications systems division. ''As the world of office automation has grown up, many of the simple word processing platforms that many businesses are using would have their value enhanced'' by the ability to send such messages, he said. **********A.T.&T. now has 6 percent of the $400 million electronic mail market, and is buying a Western Union division that has about 27 percent of the market, said Steven K. Sieck, the vice president of electronic services at the Link Resources Corporation, a New York consulting company. **********Western Union's telex business, which has been devastated by the widespread introduction of facsimile machines, is less important to A.T.&T. than electronic mail, but still valued for its loyal client base in countries where other forms of communication are less developed, Mr. Smart said. Many countries still require that letters of credit be sent by telex to be valid, he said. **********Individual Negotiations **********Western Union began trying to sell its remaining communications businesses early this year, said Denis A. Bovin, a managing director at Salomon Brothers who advised the company on yesterday's agreement. Western Union did not auction the businesses, choosing instead to negotiate individually with large telecommunications companies in the United States and elsewhere, he said. **********Leigh Walzer, who follows distressed companies for R. D. Smith & Company, a New York investment research firm, said the $180 million price was slightly higher than he had expected. The agreement with A.T.&T. increases the likelihood that bondholders will accept Western Union's current proposal to refinance its bonds again, he said. **********Western Union is seeking to substitute notes with longer maturities for its $500 million junk bond issue, which pays 19.25 percent interest, and its $30 million issue, which pays 16 percent. The interest on the new notes would be paid with additional notes for the first two years, said Warren Bechtel, a spokesman for the company. **********Western Union said the company's 1990 shareholders meeting, scheduled for Friday, would be adjourned to July 31 to allow time for the preparation and distribution of new proxy materials. The company also said it would file shortly with the S.E.C. an amendment to its registration statement for the proposed exchange offer.
