https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/18/busin.main_headline: U.S. Moves To Shore Up Texas Bailout
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/18/busin.print_headline: U.S. Moves To Shore Up Texas Bailout
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/18/busin.body_text: **********The Resolution Trust Corporation transferred $2.1 billion in deposits late Friday to the Federally owned Sunbelt Savings F.S.B. in Dallas from two insolvent savings institutions. The unusual deal is intended to resolve two expensive situations for the Government. **********The goals of the arrangement are to attract bidders for Sunbelt's costly operations and to avoid paying off depositors of the other two institutions. The move will cost taxpayers $1.7 billion. **********Federal officials were unable to attract acceptable bids for the Bexar Savings Association and the Gill Savings Association, both based in San Antonio, said Steve Katsanos, a spokesman for the Resolution Trust agency. **********High Interest Rates **********A loss estimate of $1.2 billion for Gill Savings makes it one of the most costly rescues recorded by the Government in the savings industry crisis. The loss for Bexar was put at $483 million. **********Sunbelt executives and officials of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation proposed the transaction, Mr. Katsanos said. The F.D.I.C., which insures deposits up to $100,000, controls Sunbelt. **********Unlike other insolvent Texas savings institutions under Federal control that were transferred to private owners, Sunbelt has been a continuing drain on the Treasury. The institution has $9 billion in assets, but only $3.6 billion in core deposits, and the difference must be financed by attracting billions in additional deposits by offering high interest rates. The high operating costs were a factor in discouraging potential bidders, Mr. Katsanos said. **********Bexar Savings and Gill Savings, which collapsed after a few years of fast deals and rapid growth, were known for soliciting deposits by offering high interest rates to savers far beyond the San Antonio region. Yet Mr. Katsanos said the addition of their deposits to Sunbelt would strengthen Sunbelt's core deposits. It will also give Sunbelt a branch network in San Antonio, he said. **********Sunbelt was knit together by regulators two years ago from eight collapsed savings associations at a cost that Government officials then estimated hen at $5.5 billion over 10 years. It includes three former high-flying Dallas-area institutions - Sunbelt Savings Association, Western Federal Savings and Independent-American Savings - and is now the second-largest savings institution in Texas, as ranked by assets, after the First Gibraltar Savings Association, which itself was formed from five troubled Texas institutions. **********Criminal Charges **********The former top executives of the defunct Sunbelt, Western Federal and Independent-American have either been charged with fraud or are the subjects of criminal investigations. These executives, who had many business links between 1982 and 1985 when the institutions grew rapidly, also are defendants in civil complaints that seek hundreds of millions of dollars in damages. **********The Government estimated the defunct Sunbelt's losses at $1.9 billion and assets at $4.1 billion when it was seized in 1988. Losses at Western Federal were estimated at $1.4 billion, while Independent-American's losses were put at $873 million. **********The new Sunbelt's headquarters and most of its branches are in Dallas. It also operates in Houston.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/01/busin.main_headline: Pathe Filing On Bid to Buy MGM/UA
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/01/busin.print_headline: Pathe Filing On Bid to Buy MGM/UA
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/01/busin.body_text: **********In a vaguely worded filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday, Pathe Communications Inc. said it had access to the remaining $450 million of financing needed for its planned $1.2 billion purchase of MGM/UA Communications Inc. **********It said it would obtain the money from an affiliate, but did not detail how the money would be raised. **********The papers described Comfinance S.A., the company that is to put up the money, as a Luxembourg-based affiliate of Pathe. But the commitment was contingent on Comfinance's obtaining the financing, the papers said, and, as has been typical of the somewhat mysterious deal, the papers gave little data on Comfinance. **********A spokesman for Pathe said that Comfinance's principal shareholders were Pathe's president, Giancarlo Parretti, and chairman, Florio Fiorini. **********Asset Sales Seen at Pathe **********One executive who has followed MGM/UA said he believed that Pathe was attempting to sell some other assets, including a real estate business it owns in Spain and that it could use the proceeds toward the purchase of MGM/UA. Mr. Parretti did not return telephone calls requesting comment yesterday. **********Pathe has agreed to acquire MGM/ UA Communications for $1.2 billion, or $20 a share. It has put up $100 million. In its filing Pathe said it was extending the closing of the tender offer to May 10, from yesterday. **********A spokeswoman for Time Warner Inc., which has agreed to guarantee a $650 million loan or to make a six-year bridge loan itself if Pathe cannot arrange the financing elsewhere, said the company had not seen yesterday's filing. Time Warner is eager to see the deal done because it would give its subsidiary Warner Brothers the right to distribute United Artists films. Additionally, the 1,000-film library would serve as collateral for the Time Warner loan. **********Even so, a number of Wall Street analysts said that it was one of the strangest deals they had seen in years. **********''MGM/UA has lost money for the past three years, and Pathe has lost money for the past four years,'' David Londoner, a media analyst at Wertheim & Company, said. ''Put the two companies together and add $650 million to $1 billion of debt to the capital structure. And you have to ask yourself: does this remain viable?'' **********The document filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission states that Comfinance has the right to enlist ''other affiliates of the buyer'' in connection with the $450 million. **********Uncertainty on Financing **********It adds, however, that the obligation of Comfinance and other potential investors to make a $450 million deposit, which Pathe could then use to buy MGM/UA stock, was conditioned, among other things, on their obtaining acceptable financing. There was no indication as to whether that financing was currently in place. **********Although the papers were not filed until late yesterday afternoon, the share price of MGM/UA rose $1.125, to close at $18.625. **********Mr. Parretti was convicted of fraudulent bankruptcy in a Naples, Italy, court on March 30 and sentenced to almost four years' imprisonment in absentia. Although he has appealed the decision, several analysts said that the conviction might make it more difficult for him to obtain bank financing. **********Beyond that, the deal's economics are unusual. **********Last year, MGM/UA lost $74.7 million on sales of $876.6 million. And in 1987 it lost $88.1 million on sales of $450.6 million. The company has debt of about $400 million, primarily high-interest ''junk bonds.'' **********Even if Pathe is able to get $200 million in production loans, it could need additional financing. A traditional big studio makes about 15 films a year for about $25 million each, a total of $375 million. In addition it must pay for prints and advertising.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/15/busin.main_headline: May Stores Appoints Chief of Its G. Fox Chain
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/15/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;   May Stores Appoints Chief of Its G. Fox Chain
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/02/15/busin.body_text: **********The May Department Stores Company has filled the top post at its G. Fox department store chain in Hartford with the appointment of Eugene S. Kahn, a young executive from R. H. Macy & Company. **********Mr. Kahn, 39, joins Fox as president and chief executive from Macy's South/Bullocks in Atlanta, where he has been group senior vice president. John L. Dunham, who continues as the chairman of G. Fox, will report to him. **********Mr. Kahn succeeds Matthew D. Serra, who resigned last week to become president and chief executive of the Seaman Furniture company, a chain in the Northeast. **********Mr. Kahn's appointment was one of two made by May this week. It also named Steven J. Douglass chairman of the May Company, Ohio. Mr. Douglass has been senior vice president and chief financial officer of the Robinson store division in Los Angeles. **********Mr. Douglass succeeds Donald R. Andrus, who moves to Houston as head of the Foley's division there. Thomas J. Hogan continues as president and chief executive of May Ohio. **********G. Fox has 11 stores and is adding a 12th next month. ''Basically, I hope to lead the store to even greater volume and profit increases,'' Mr. Kahn said yesterday. ''I think the store has a terrific record. We plan significant growth with four additional stores on the drawing board.'' **********May Department Stores, based in St. Louis and made up of more than a dozen large department store chains, has been prospering while other department store competitors have been stumbling, notably Federated Department Stores Inc. and the Allied Stores Corporation, the Campeau Corporation's American units that are in bankruptcy proceedings. **********In his new job at G. Fox, Mr. Kahn will be returning to the Northeast. He began his retail career in 1971 as assistant buyer at Gimbels East in New York and was named a buyer for Gimbels New York in 1973. **********In 1976, Mr. Kahn switched to Macy's as an executive with its Bamburger's unit. In 1984, he was named a senior vice president and general merchandising manager, and in 1988 became group senior vice president for Macy's Northeast. He moved to Macy's South last year. **********Mr. Kahn, who is from Cedar Grove, N.J., holds a degree from the City College of New York. He and his wife, Constance, have two daughters.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/15/busin.body_text: **********Canada's largest offshore oil drilling project has been approved, and construction is expected to begin almost immediately, Energy Minister Jake Epp announced today. **********The official termed the Hibernia oil project off Newfoundland's coast a major advance for the economically troubled Atlantic province. The project's price tag is $5.2 billion, equal to about $4.5 billion in United States currency. **********The project is a collaboration of the federal Government, the province and a consortium of four oil companies led by Mobil Oil Canada. **********The companies estimate the Hibernia field has recoverable oil reserves of 525 million to 650 million barrels.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/13/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices tumbled yesterday amid new concerns about higher interest rates and a resurgence of inflation. The drop followed declines in other important stock markets around the world. **********The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 71.46 points, or 2.6 percent, to 2,689.21. **********Yesterday's drop in the Dow industrials was the largest in 13 weeks, since a plunge of 190.58 points on Oct. 13. In terms of points, it was the 13th-largest drop on record. For the week, the Dow fell 84.04 points, or 3 percent. **********Volume on the New York Stock Exchange rose to 183.9 million shares, from 154.4 million on Thursday. Traders said large institutions were buying and selling in only moderate volume. **********1,483 Declines on Big Board **********The declines were broad based, with stocks that fell in price outnumbering those that rose by 1,483 to 217. **********One factor in the decline, analysts said, was a report by the Commerce Department that the Producer Price Index rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in December, sharply higher than the four-tenths of 1 percent many economists had predicted. For the full year, producer prices rose 4.8 percent. **********The Commerce Department also reported that retail sales rose two-tenths of 1 percent in December, in line with what most had expected. **********But some people on Wall Street contended that developments in the overseas financial markets, particularly in Japan, had a greater impact on stocks in the United States than the two economic reports. **********Higher Global Interest Rates **********''Global interest rates are rising dramatically,'' said John Groveman, president of Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company in New York, ''which put pressure on our bond market and, of course, our stock market. This is no time to be a hero.'' **********Mr. Groveman pointed out that the interest rate on the benchmark long-term Japanese bond rose to yield 6.45 percent, from 6.265 percent. It was the first time the yield on that issue had exceeded 6.35 percent since Oct. 5, 1987, shortly before the worldwide plunge in stock prices on Oct. 19, 1987. **********Lower bond prices, a decline in the yen and political uncertainties continued to unnerve Japanese investors yesterday. In Tokyo, the 225-stock Nikkei index lost 653.36 points, or 1.71 percent, to 37,516.77. **********In London, the Financial Times 100-stock index lost 37.8 points, or 1 percent, to 2,380.1. The West German market avoided the sell-off, with stock prices mixed. **********David B. Bostian, managing director and chief investment strategist at Jesup & Lamont Inc. in New York, said renewed apprehension about the political situation surrounding President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union continued to unnerve markets around the world. **********Mr. Bostian added, ''The immediate concern that I have is that if the market does not stabilize next week it could touch off mutual fund switch selling, which was one of the dominoes in the 1987 decline.'' **********Switch selling involves switching from stock funds into money-market funds, and vice versa. **********''It's just a technical decline,'' one trader said about the drop. ''The break below 2,700 was the last blow for the Dow. Other market measures were trading below their year lows at the opening.'' **********Analysts said data on producer prices and retail sales also depressed dollar and bond prices, which exacerbated the weakness in equities. **********The dollar opened sharply lower, but recovered to rise against both the Japanese yen and the West German mark. By late in the day, the bellwether 30-year Treasury issue was off 20/32, to 99 17/32, with the yield climbing to 8.17 percent, from 8.11 on Thursday and 8.06 percent a week ago. **********Among broader measures of the market, the Big Board composite index dropped 4.46 points yesterday, to 188.32, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 8.60 points, to 339.93. **********The 12-point circuit breaker on the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange was put into effect at 2:06 P.M., Eastern standard time, but was activated for only a few minutes. **********When the S.&P. 500 declines 12 points, the circuit breaker goes into effect and trades in stock-index futures cannot be made below that level for 30 minutes. Offers can be made at the limit price, however, or above it. **********The Dow industrials fell 53 points in the first hour of trading. By 11:30 A.M., the loss had narrowed to 38 points before the drop continued. The average remained about 42 points lower through the early afternoon but by 2:30 had fallen 69 points. It extended that deficit to about 79 points about 3:30 P.M. before rebounding somewhat toward the close. **********Airline Stocks Decline **********The Dow transportation average fell 25.07 points, to 1,140.65, pulled down in part by UAL's 4 3/4-point drop, to 159 1/2. **********Philips Industries was a big percentage loser, dropping 2 3/8, to 15 5/8. Analysts said the company's announcement after the close of trading on Thursday that it could not obtain financing for its proposed leveraged buyout reflected its lower profit estimate, the dull outlook for its main markets and disarray in the arranging of such buyouts. **********On the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index fell 7.12 points, to 372.23, while in over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index dropped 9.14 points, to 439.72.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/15/busin.main_headline: Avon Keeps Ringing, but Wall Street Won't Answer
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/15/busin.print_headline: Avon Keeps Ringing, but Wall Street Won't Answer
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/15/busin.body_text: **********His round, jovial face and twinkling eyes belie it, but James E. Preston is getting annoyed. **********Here he is, brimming with plans for Avon Products Inc., the direct-sales beauty company he has run for the last two years. He wants to overhaul the catalogue, change the way Avon's 1.5 million sales representatives are paid, slow down the introduction of new products and speed up delivery of old ones. In short, he wants to repair the damages wrought by an abysmal decade. **********And, he has a shot at carrying out his plans. Sales and profits are up. Debt, head count and other costs are down. The ill-starred diversification into health care that once caused debt to zoom to $1.1 billion - a stunning 82 percent of capitalization - is mercifully fading into memory. Avon's international divisions are doing especially well - foreign sales contributed 48 percent of Avon's revenues and 58 percent of pre-tax earnings last year. And although a court has just invalidated Avon's attempt to strengthen its ''poison pill'' to ward off takeovers, the corporate bigwigs that made hostile runs at Avon in the 1980's are lying low. **********''It may be wishful thinking, but I think we're hitting a period of stability,'' said Mr. Preston. ''Our debt's down, our cash flow's exraordinarily strong and we're in a position to again focus on the future.'' **********That's what he keeps telling the analysts. But no one wants to listen. On Wall Street, Avon is one thing only: a no-growth company that should spend its cash on buying its stock and paying rich dividends - at least until one of the myriad takeover runs succeeds. **********On July 5 Irwin L. Jacobs and the Amway Corporation, two of Avon's spurned suitors, sold 4 million shares - the majority of their stake - to Chartwell Inc., an investor group. The sale gives Chartwell, which already owned 17 percent of Avon, just under 20 percent of Avon's voting stock, the point that would activate Avon's poison pill. Avon's was the most active stock traded that day - yet arbitragers were so certain that no tender offer would come that Avon's stock closed at $37, down 75 cents. (It closed at 37 3/8 on Friday). **********Even analysts who have ''buy'' recommendations on Avon stock are not betting on growth. ''We are not interested in great strategies,'' said Jack L. Salzman, an analyst with Goldman Sachs. ''A direct selling company is only good for generating cash.'' **********Joseph Kozloff, who follows Avon for Smith Barney, agreed. ''Direct selling should be run as a no-growth cash generator,'' he said. **********Wall Street's readiness to write off Avon's future comes despite some fairly comforting numbers. Avon's 1989 sales hit $3.3 billion, up 8 percent from the prior year. Its earnings from continuing operations were $152.4 million, up 26 percent. Despite a charge of $98 million in the fourth quarter, related to its last remaining health care businesses, net earnings were $54.6 million, compared with a loss in 1988 of $404.5 million. And, perhaps most significantly, debt was down to $630 million and continues to fall. **********At issue, then, is whether Avon's greatest strength - its worldwide network of ''Avon ladies'' who sell Avon's products to their neighbors, friends and, increasingly, to their co-workers in offices and factories - has become its greatest weakness. **********In its heyday, that network represented a low-cost, almost foolproof distribution system. The sales people received a 40 percent commission on everything sold, but no base salary. They even paid for the brochures. **********Avon thrived under that system, developing a reputation for excellent management. In fact, though, Avon was not so much well managed as un-managed. ''It was a big numbers game - if Avon wanted to show more sales, it just added more Avon ladies,'' said one former Avon executive who insisted on anonymity. Even Stanley C. Gault, chief executive officer of Rubbermaid Inc. and an Avon director, recalls being ''astounded at Avon's lack of knowledge about its own customer base'' when he joined the company's board in the early 1980's. **********Demographic realities, meanwhile, were about to prick a very big hole in Avon's isolationist bubble. ''By the mid-1970's research reports showed that by 1980 no one would be home to greet the Avon lady, but management didn't want to listen,'' recalled a consultant who worked for Avon 15 years ago. Even Mr. Preston, who was then running Avon's domestic beauty business, conceded, ''We were slow to recognize the flow of women to the work force.'' **********Assuming that its beauty business would generate cash forever, Avon went on a shopping spree. It bought Tiffany & Company. It bought perfume companies. It bought Mallinckrodt Inc., a maker of specialty chemicals, drugs and medical diagnostic equipment. And it bought health care companies. **********The diversification was a disaster. New regulations restricted how much health care companies could charge, at the same time that Avon's beauty sales began shrinking. By the end of the 1980's, Avon had sold Tiffany and many other ancillary businesses. But it was still saddled with a couple of health care companies. And it was drowning in debt. **********In a funny way, Avon's troubles were the best thing that could have happened to Jim Preston. Until the diversification went sour, John Chamberlin, Avon's president, was the heir-apparent to Hicks Waldron, the chairman. But as Avon continued to bail out of its non-beauty products, its beauty business, though battered, was starting to stabilize. And Mr. Preston went from the man who was presiding over the dinosaur division to the humbled company's fair-haired boy. **********''The board recognized that Jim funded the non-cosmetics businesses when they got into trouble,'' said Mr. Gault. Mr. Preston was named president in May of 1988, and chief executive and chairman within eight months. **********He inherited a troubled company. The flow of women to work was a triple whammy. Although a handful of Avon's top sales representatives make as much as $100,000 a year from commissions, most make far less. So, with more lucrative jobs available, fewer women want to sell Avon products; fewer are home when Avon ladies call, and many buy cosmetics at stores near their jobs. **********Mr. Preston readily admits that Avon's direct-sales business is more likely to grow at 3 to 5 percent a year, rather than the 8 to 10 percent the company had been promising analysts in the 1980's. Accordingly, he has been slashing product lines and staff.  By March of last year Avon had cut employment by 28 percent, to 28,400, and halved its dividend to $1. It has closed one distribution center, and it will probably have to give up some expensive Manhattan space when its lease expires in 1997. **********Mr. Preston is taking a more activist approach to the Avon ladies - particularly to the 100,000 or so who account for over 55 percent of domestic sales. He is offering them sales training, and awarding plum territories to the most productive. He has persuaded them to chase their customers to work, so that 30 percent of Avon's domestic revenues now come from workplace sales. **********And Avon is finally investing in formal research. ''We've always pushed products out to the marketplace,'' said Robert W. Pratt, an executive vice president. ''Now we'll let demand pull products and delivery systems out of us.'' **********Avon's latest research tells it that 14 percent of its customers account for 56 percent of its sales, and that this core group is comprised primarily of women who are over 50, unlikely to have college degrees and highly likely to be overweight. Avon now has pinpointed a sizable group of younger, sleeker ''fringe'' consumers. By tinkering with product mix and selling methods Avon expects it can win over enough fringe customers to increase sales by 18 percent. **********And very slowly, and oh so gently, Avon is changing its product and commission structure. Instead of offering enough new products to warrant 26 different brochures a year, it will move to monthly product and brochure changes. It is introducing a two-tiered commission system whereby sales representatives will continue to receive 40 percent commissions on cosmetics and fragrances but only 25 percent on non-cosmetics items like pantyhose on which Avon competes with discount stores and drugstores. **********It is also using a new program called A.C.E. - Avon Career Enhancement - to get Avon ladies to recruit new representatives. Avon tried something similar in the mid 1980's, when it paid some 16,000 Avon ladies a flat recruiting fee. That program was a costly disappointment. This time, Mr. Preston said, Avon will pay a percentage of the recruit's sales instead of a flat fee, and will be ''more selective'' about who participates. **********These moves may put Avon at rights with its demographically changed world. But the miscalculations of the last decade did more than drown Avon in debt; it put it in play. **********Avon thought it had bought some calm this spring, when it avoided a proxy fight with Chartwell by agreeing to form a special committee to find ways to increase shareholder value, and to hire John P. Rochon, a vice chairman of the Mary Kay Corporation, to consult to that committee. But Avon broke off talks with Mr. Rochon last month when he refused to sever ties with Mary Kay. **********At the time, Richard L. Fisher, a Chartwell managing partner, said Chartwell ''will continue to pursue vigorously our objectives of maximizing shareholder value in Avon.'' **********Needless to say, Mr. Preston says that is his goal too. The question is whether Chartwell will give him the chance to reach it.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/24/busin.main_headline: U.S. Says Coastal Can Buy Iraqi Oil
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/24/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; U.S. Says Coastal Can Buy Iraqi Oil
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/24/busin.body_text: **********The Coastal Corporation said it had received permission from the Government to import as much as 2.6 million barrels of Iraqi crude oil shipped in July to Saudi Arabia, before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. But the company must obtain permission from Saudi Arabia first, a company spokesman, Jim Bailey, said. Coastal said it would pay for the oil through an escrow account that would allow access by the United States Government but not the Iraqis. **********The company must reach an agreement with the Saudis by the end of the month because the United States has required that the oil be delivered by Dec. 15. Oil shipments from the Middle East take about 45 days. The Saudi Government opposes the release of the oil, worth about $75 million, and is hesitant to make exceptions to the United Nations embargo, which prohibits trade with Iraq and Kuwait, Mr. Bailey said Monday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/25/world.main_headline: Ethiopian Combatants Agree to Open Port to Food
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/25/world.print_headline: Ethiopian Combatants Agree to Open Port to Food
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/25/world.body_text: **********The Ethiopian Government and the Eritrean rebels opposing it have reached a tentative agreement to open the rebel-held Red Sea port of Massawa to relief vessels, United Nations and State Department officials say. **********The accord could allow thousands of tons of food to reach the more than four million people threatened by starvation in the Horn of Africa, **********The officials said on Friday that both sides had accepted a plan put forward by the Rome-based World Food Program, the United Nations agency thatdistributes famine relief. **********Under the plan, food-carrying ships would be inspected in Djibouti, at the mouth of the Red Sea, to insure that they are not carrying military supplies for the Eritreans.  Food for Both Sides **********The vessels would then sail under a United Nations flag to Massawa, where the supplies would be unloaded and trucked, again under United Nations supervision, to the besieged Eritrean provincial capital, Asmara, where Government forces are holding out. **********Some of the food would be given to the Government supporters in the city.But the rest would be distributed by the Eritrean People's Liberation Front, the rebel organization, to villagers in the surrounding countryside, which its forces control, the officials said. **********Hagos Ghebrehiwet, the rebel group's representative to the United States and Canada, said: "We accept this proposal by the World Food Program. It is now up to the Government in Addis Ababa to show good faith too." **********A State Department official said: "Both sides seem to have given their tentative agreement. And while with the tensions in the area you can never be sure how well any agreement will hold up, we strongly hope the problemwill be solved in this way." **********The accord, if it holds, would end a five-month deadlock that began after the summit meeting in June between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union.  Fight to Recapture Port **********At that meeting, the two leaders agreed to urge the Ethiopian Government of Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam to stop trying to recapture Massawa, which fell to the rebels earlier in the year, so that the port could be used for relief shipments. **********But the Eritrean rebels then refused to allow relief vessels to use the port, a move that angered many of its sympathizers in the United States Congress and elsewhere. **********They accused the rebels of using food as a weapon, seeking to starve the Government garrison at Asmara into surrender. **********Northern Ethiopia is now facing its second year of drought. **********While largescale starvation has been avoided so far, officials of the World Food Program say the situation remains precarious, with 4.2 million people estimated to be at risk unless relief supplies are stepped up. **********Last week, the food program appealed for 100,000 tons of food for the first two months of 1991. **********It estimates that next year, Ethiopia will need about 840,000 tons. **********The effect of the droughts is being aggravated by the country's drawn out civil war. The Eritrean rebels have been fighting the central Government since 1962. The Ethiopian Government faces a similar nationalist rebellion in neighboring Tigre Province.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/19/world.main_headline: Security Council's Military Panel Reviews Naval Efforts to Enforce Trade Embargo
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/19/world.print_headline: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;   Security Council's Military Panel Reviews Naval Efforts to Enforce Trade Embargo
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/19/world.body_text: **********The military arm of the United Nations Security Council met informally today to review naval efforts to enforce the Council's trade embargo against Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait. **********Their meeting came as the five permanent members of the Council moved toward agreement on a new plan to tighten the embargo. **********Their emerging new resolution would impose an air transport embargo on Iraq and occupied Kuwait. It also would provide for the detention of Iraqi merchant shipping and tighten the freeze on Iraqi and Kuwaiti financial assets held abroad. **********The resolution also would threaten new trade sanctions against countries that violated the current embargo and encourage countries to reduce the size of Iraqi diplomatic missions. **********The representatives of two permanent members predicted today that the full Security Council would approve the resolution by the end of the week. **********Today's meeting of the Security Council's Military Staff Committee -its second on the Iraq crisis after a long period of cold-war dormancy - followed a meeting in Bahrain last weekend between senior naval officers from the countries deploying warships in the Persian Gulf. At the meeting, they discussed plans to coordinate patrols and other enforcement activities, Western diplomats said. **********Today's meeting brought together military officers and their political advisers from Britain, France, China, the United States and the Soviet Union, five permanent Council members, which have a veto over decisions. All but China have deployed naval forces in the gulf area. The United States military representative was Col. Robert R. Anderson, military adviser at the United States Mission. **********Western diplomats say such meetings satisfy a Soviet demand that the Military Staff Committee become more involved in coordinating enforcement action. They said the meetings also serve as a reminder that the gulf forces are acting in support of a United Nations decision. **********Role of U.N. Military Committee **********Under the United Nations Charter, the Military Staff Committee, made up of the Chiefs of Staff of the five permanent Security Council members, is supposed to direct military operations mounted by the Council. **********Cold-war tensions kept the committee paralyzed until recently, when the Soviet Union suggested reviving it. The United States agreed, in part at least, to help secure Moscow's backing for the Council's embargo against Iraq and Kuwait, diplomats say. **********China, the most reluctant of the five to consider military action against Iraq, has insisted that the committee discuss only operations approved by the Security Council. So the five agreed that the committee would discuss only naval activities in the gulf. **********Details of the planned air embargo are still being worked, but officials say it would be aimed primarily at civilian cargo aircraft and not at regular passenger planes. **********Under the plan, nearby countries would close their airspace to cargo flights heading for Iraq or Iraqi-occupied Kuwait unless they agreed to be inspected. The Security Council cannot authorize shooting down planes caught violating sanctions, since this is already prohibited by international law. **********Diplomats say that no country that is likely to try to break the embargo has sufficient aircraft to be very successful at it. Civilian aircraft operators would find it impossible to insure planes flying to Iraq or Kuwait or get them refueled at foreign airports. **********Today the Red Cross said that it would postpone an offer to dispatch $100,000 in emergency medical supplies to Iraq and Kuwait after a vigorous United States protest that it would violate United Nations sanctions. **********The United States told the Geneva-based League of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies last week that it lacked evidence that these supplies were needed and that its plans for monitoring their distribution did not meet Security Council guidelines. **********But Jose Aponte, Director of International Services for the American Red Cross, said today that the League would now await an assessment of Iraq's medical needs from Red Cross officials in Baghdad before deciding whether to send the supplies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/27/world.main_headline: GORBACHEV NAMES A PARTY LOYALIST TO VICE PRESIDENCY
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/27/world.print_headline: GORBACHEV NAMES A PARTY LOYALIST TO VICE PRESIDENCY
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/27/world.body_text: **********President Mikhail S. Gorbachev chose a colorless but loyal Communist Party functionary today to fill the new Soviet post of Vice President, his chief deputy in managing state affairs and his stand-in if Mr. Gorbachev cannot serve. **********Mr. Gorbachev's choice, Gennadi I. Yanayev, presented himself as "a Communist to the depths of my soul" and an unwavering supporter of Mr. Gorbachev's programs. His nomination is to be put to a secret ballot of the 2,250-member Congress of People's Deputies on Thursday. **********The choice sent a flabbergasted murmur through the Kremlin Palace of Congresses. A Hard-Working Apparatchik **********Many members, including some close to Mr. Gorbachev, had conjured up their profile of a probable Vice President: a non-Russian to unite the country, a person of popular stature or at least a winning public figure to repair Mr. Gorbachev's diminished prestige, and someone with a reformist reputation. **********Mr. Yanayev, who is 53 years old, is of Russian heritage, is unrenowned outside Communist Party circles, and is regarded as a hard-working apparatchik not associated with any particular innovations or causes. **********His speech today, which stressed the need for law and order and rejected economic "shock therapy," was in keeping with Mr. Gorbachev's recent drift toward a conservative position. 'You Choose Your Own Man' **********After two nationally prominent candidates had publicly spurned the post, Mr. Gorbachev appears to have turned, as he has often done for important appointments, to a man steeped in Communist Party discipline and with a background not unlike his own. **********Like Mr. Gorbachev, Mr. Yanayev (pronounced ya-NYE-yeff) has never stood for competitive public election. He was appointed to Congress in a seat reserved for trade unions. **********The Soviet leader rebuffed suggestions from the hall that he offer a choice of candidates, and debate was cut off after a short series of orchestrated testimonials. **********If Mr. Gorbachev died or was otherwise unable to serve, the Vice President would serve as acting President until a nationwide presidential election could be organized, which under the Constitution must happen within six months. **********Aleksandr M. Yakovlev, a law professor and parliamentary leader, said, "Either you choose a man with appeal, charm -- that's not the case here -- or you choose your own man, reliable." **********Mr. Gorbachev "has chosen a devoted person who will share his views and work as a team," he said. "That's good for the President. Will it be good for the country? That depends not only on the Vice President but also on the President himself." **********Mr. Yanayev's nomination was the first in what many expected to be a series of significant changes in the executive branch after a major reorganization of the Government structure that was given final approval today by the Congress. **********Mr. Gorbachev reported this morning that the last member of his original 1985 top leadership team, Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, was in the hospital after a moderate heart attack. **********The news appeared to affirm the speculation that Mr. Ryzhkov, who has shouldered much of the blame for the country's economic failures, would soon be replaced. Conventional Hard-Liner **********Mr. Yanayev has been an important Communist Party whip in the Congress, the head of a 730-member bloc of party loyalists. **********Like Mr. Gorbachev, the vice presidential nominee holds advanced degrees from agricultural and law schools, and soon after school began his career in the Komsomol Communist youth league. There and later, at the official All-Union Council of Trade Unions, he specialized in contacts with foreign organizations. **********In May he was promoted to head the trade union council, but held the post for only two months before being made a secretary of the Communist Party Central Committee in charge of international affairs, and a member of the party's ruling Politburo. **********His interviews in the Soviet press over the last year have generally been published in the most hard-line newspapers, especially the daily Sovetskaya Rossiya, and have invariably reflected the most cautious and conventional viewpoints. 'He Has Firm Principles' **********Mr. Gorbachev presented his candidate today as a man with wide-ranging experience. **********"He is a mature politician," Mr. Gorbachev said. "He is well-oriented in political issues. He has firm principles. He is an active supporter of perestroika, and an active participant in it." **********One legislator who got the microphone long enough to announce that he would vote against the choice was met with a burst of applause.  In the corridors later, even those close to Mr. Gorbachev strained to find something positive to say about Mr. Yanayev. **********"He is an open, normal person," said Aleksandr N. Yakovlev, one of Mr. Gorbachev's original partners in liberalizing Soviet society. "He was born to be a politician." **********Ivan A. Vakarchuk, a physicist from the western Ukraine, said that he would oppose the nominee and that he believed many others would too, because they feared the prospect of having such an orthodox Communist a heartbeat away from the presidency. **********"The Vice President is a nobody, as long as the President is alive," he said. "But only as long as the President is alive. You have had cases in your country, after Kennedy, after Nixon, where the Vice President arose from nowhere." Little New Executive Power **********The vice presidency was created as part of a package of constitutional changes given final approval today. **********The measures would streamline the Government by making Cabinet ministries directly subordinate to Mr. Gorbachev rather than to his Prime Minister. **********The changes added little to Mr. Gorbachev's enormous constitutional powers, which already included the right to impose direct Kremlin rule -- with the suspension of civil liberties and the use of troops -- in trouble spots. **********One of the few provisions that would have actually increased Mr. Gorbachev's power was stripped from the package before final approval.  Additions to Council **********The Soviet leader had proposed creation of a Supreme State Inspectorate under the Vice President to assure adherence to federal laws and decrees. But many deputies argued that it would have concentrated too much power in the executive office. A Gorbachev aide said the President might bypass the Congress and create the new enforcement service by decree. **********The new Government structure also raised the status of the Federation Council, a group of leaders that is supposed to give the republics a voice in making federal policy and negotiating issues like budget-sharing and centralized food distribution. **********But before approving the changes, the Congress revised the council to include not only the 15 republics but also 20 smaller ethnic jurisdictions, adding to doubts about whether it will operate as a real decision-making body. **********Two separatist republics, Lithuania and Estonia, boycotted a meeting of the council on Tuesday and have said they do not plan to attend in the future. Post Shunned by Shevardnadze **********Mr. Gorbachev said last week that he had planned to name Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze to the post of Vice President. The Foreign Minister is a Georgian who commands enormous respect here and abroad as the co-author of Mr. Gorbachev's revisions. **********But Mr. Shevardnadze told the Soviet press that he would decline the job if offered. Mr. Shevardnadze announced last Thursday he would resign as Foreign Minister and warned that the country was sliding toward dictatorship. **********When one member of Congress protested to Mr. Gorbachev today that Mr. Yanayev and Mr. Shevardnadze seemed to be "diametrically opposite politicians," the Soviet leader insisted that the two men had worked cordially together and, "if their positions do not coincide, they are very close in almost all directions of domestic and foreign policy." **********The other leading candidate for Vice President, according to officials close to Mr. Gorbachev, was Nursultan A. Nazarbayev, the popular and articulate President of Kazakhstan, a republic in Soviet Central Asia. **********But Mr. Nazarbayev had openly belittled the job as lacking in power, telling reporters today: "He has nothing, no rights, no authority. He will just run errands for the President. Such a job does not suit me."

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/20/world.main_headline: In Bhutto's Shadow, Women Who Succeeded
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/20/world.print_headline: In Bhutto's Shadow, Women Who Succeeded
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/20/world.body_text: **********As rumors began to circulate this week that Pakistan's new caretaker Government was about to name its information and broadcasting minister, one of the first visitors to the likely candidate's house was the editor of the country's newest daily newspaper. **********The ritual was not unusual in South Asia, where an unexpected political turn can quickly affect the press, and it pays to put in a good word early. The new paper, The Independent, is planning to begin publication in September. **********What was striking was that both the minister, Abida Hussain, and the editor, Maleeha Lodhi, were women. **********Benazir Bhutto, whose administration was abruptly dismissed on Aug. 6, was Pakistan's most visibly powerful woman, and the first woman to head a Government in the modern Islamic world. But beyond the limelight that surrounded her after her return from exile in 1986, strong and influential Pakistani women have been working in the shadows. **********For these women and many others, Ms. Bhutto's 20-month Government is and always was viewed with mixed feelings. **********It was not surprising that within days of her dismissal, a battle broke out in the country's most militant women's organization, the Women's Action Forum, over whether to condemn the change in Government. Ms. Bhutto's ouster, many in the group argued, was not a feminist issue. A Damaged Cause?  The summary manner in which Ms. Bhutto was dismissed by President Ghulam Ishaq Khan has been widely condemned here. But there is also concern that her perceived shortcomings as a Prime Minister - her failure to push through a legislative program, or to prevent her husband and his relatives from using their connections in lucrative business deals - have damaged the image of women as administrators. **********Leaders of women's organizations say the role of women in Pakistan has been gradually improving for more than a decade, although the gains are often limited to the educated elite. The literacy rate for women in some rural areas is as low as 1 or 2 percent. **********''We know we are only 0.000-something of a percent of Pakistani women,'' a foreign service officer said. ''That makes us feel guilty, and we try to help others when we can.'' This woman and others in the Foreign Ministry are now being assigned to run desks that oversee sensitive policy areas, like Middle Eastern and Persian Gulf affairs. **********They have their counterparts outside Government service. ''I can name you 20 or more women in position of real influence,'' said Nasim Zehra, a columnist who writes on political and international affairs for several Pakistani newspapers. Ms. Zehra is a graduate of Tufts University's school of diplomacy. **********High-Ranking Editors **********In addition to Ms. Lodhi, a graduate of the London School of Economics who was editor of The Muslim before deciding to publish The Independent, Sherry Rehman is editor of Pakistan's boldest and liveliest news magazine, The Herald. Women are advancing to important editing positions at other publications, too. **********Asma Jehangir, the head of the country's Human Rights Commission, and her sister, Hina Jilani, are Pakistan's leading campaigners against forced labor, child abuse and laws limiting women's rights. **********In Karachi, Bilqis Edhi is an equal partner with her husband, Abdul Sattar Edhi, in running Pakistan's largest private charitable organization. Mrs. Edhi, who has concentrated her efforts on helping abandoned and abused women in slum areas, is also the foundation's business manager. **********In Islamabad, Pakistani and foreign women enjoy a relatively congenial working atmosphere. Several Western news agencies and newspapers have female correspondents here. **********But ''it's not as if after Benazir Bhutto took over, Pakistani women suddenly left their burkhas at home and rushed to join the men in different fields of work,'' an Indian journalist, Indira Das, observed after a recent visit. ''Far from it.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/04/busin.body_text: **********The Senate Agriculture Committee, in a voice vote, today approved the nomination of Wendy Lee Gramm to a second term as the head of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. **********Mrs. Gramm's confirmation now moves to the full Senate, where a favorable vote is expected. **********The vote this morning followed a late-night confirmation hearing at which Mrs. Gramm received praise from every committee member who spoke. ''You seem to have gained strength from adversity,'' said Rudy Boschwitz, Republican of Minnesota. **********Mrs. Gramm has frequently clashed with members of the committee, but there has been no public opposition to her confirmation for the chairman's post. **********Mrs. Gramm, who is 45 years old, holds a Ph.D. in economics from Northwestern University. She is married to Senator Phil Gramm, the Texas Republican, and was first selected to head the commission, the primary regulator of futures trading, by President Reagan in December 1987. **********Previously she served as the head of regulatory affairs at the Office of Management and Budget, where she became known in Washington for her strong deregulatory zeal. But industry officials said it would be wrong to say that in her tenure at the commission she had leaned toward either regulation or deregulation. **********''There have been a long list of heads of the C.F.T.C. that weren't willing to take on the exchanges at all,'' said an industry lawyer who asked not to be identified. ''She doesn't jump when they say jump. She is interested in making sure that commerce takes place.'' **********But Mrs. Gramm may still be facing the stiffest test in her ability to regulate the exchanges. The commodity commission has proposed restricting dual trading in the nation's largest commodity markets as a first step toward a possible banning of the practice. **********In dual trading, a floor broker makes simultaneous trades both for customer accounts and for his or her own account, creating potentially serious conflicts of interest. **********The practice is deeply ingrained at the futures exchanges. An industry official said that the commodity commission had received 350 comment letters, most of them opposing the plan. **********Mrs. Gramm has declined to give a timetable for final commission action on the proposal.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/04/world.main_headline: Reporter's Notebook;   How a Vacation Helps Even a Crisis President
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/04/world.print_headline: Reporter's Notebook;   How a Vacation Helps Even a Crisis President
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/04/world.body_text: **********Whatever the reason, the President's demeanor was noticeably sunnier last week. Some traced the change to last Monday morning, when he went fishing at 5 A.M. He floated around the Kennebunk River for an hour or two, catching nothing but grinning broadly when he spied a group of bleary-eyed reporters on the bank swatting frantically at early-morning hordes of moquitoes. **********By Labor Day weekend, he even did not look so grimly determined to enjoy himself as he drove his ball around the Cape Arundel Golf Club course. He even began to make jokes. **********On the 10th tee on Saturday, a reporter's electronic pager went off, disrupting the President's drive. A collective breath was held. But the Chief Executive merely did a playful double-take and smiled. **********Today, as the Summer White House packed up to return to Washington, Mr. Bush could not resist squeezing in another round. Hurried as usual, he roared down the fairway in his golf car. **********But he had forgotten to secure his clubs, and they fell to the ground with a great clatter. **********''I don't need those!'' the President exclaimed, jamming on his brakes. **********''The press did it,'' said Ken Raynor, the club pro. **********Mr. Bush laughed, fixed his clubs and roared off again. Well, not quite. He forgot to release the brakes. **********Work and Prayer **********There were serious moments here. **********Mr. Bush has been working hard, aides said, spending hour after hour with Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, plotting strategy for the gulf crisis and, most recently, working on the summit meeting. **********On Sunday, Mr. Bush spoke to the congregations at St. Ann's Episcopal Church, his customary house of worship, and the First Congregational Church. **********Accompanied by his friend the Rev. Billy Graham, Mr. Bush told those assembled at the Congregational Church: ''These are very interesting times. A week from now, perhaps at this minute, I will be sitting in Helsinki, Finland, talking with President Gorbachev. These are challenging times.'' **********Later, at St. Ann's, Mr. Bush said: ''These are rather trying times, and right now I would suggest that we get our strength from being one nation under God. I know I feel that way; so does Barbara; so does the rest of the family.'' **********Breaking the News **********While the President seemed more relaxed, things were not going so smoothly for his press operation. **********Late Friday night, as word of the impending Helsinki summit meeting began to leak out in Moscow, the White House hurriedly scheduled a news briefing for Saturday morning. **********But Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, did not want to take the podium and get bombarded with questions he could not answer. So a solution was found: Mr. Scowcroft was recruited to give a briefing. **********But Mr. Scowcroft decided he would not announce the summit meeting, and that left him in the uncomfortable position of refusing to comment on what by then was common knowledge. **********Then things got even more embarrassing. Just as Mr. Scowcroft was making his most emphatic refusal to comment, reporters noted that Mr. Fitzwater was on the telephone, scribbling hurriedly on a piece of paper. **********He approached the podium and handed the paper to Mr. Scowcroft, who laughed and said, ''We'll have an announcement at 1 P.M.'' **********Mr. Fitzwater grinned. ''Shows you how fast diplomacy can work sometimes,'' he said. **********Mr. Scowcroft sighed. ''I knew I shouldn't have done this,'' he said with his usual deadpan delivery. **********A Fondness for Initials **********The telephone call turned out to have been from Mr. Bush, who phoned Mr. Fitzwater from the Fidelity, his speedboat, as it plied the Gulf of Maine, to let him know the summit meeting could be announced at 1 P.M. **********Mr. Bush, who likes to do things personally, made the announcement himself, emerging from the door of his house on Walker's Point, the family estate, to speak to a small pool of reporters. **********What was different from other Presidential appearances here was that as befitting the seriousness of the moment, Mr. Bush was in a jacket and tie instead of his customary polo shirt. What was the same was his weakness for acronyms, abbreviations and insider jargon. **********At one point, he sounded as though he was declaring that he had great confidence in his ''sink.'' He was using the standard military acronym Cinc for Commander in Chief and referring to Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, commander of the American forces in Saudia Arabia. **********At another point, Mr. Bush was asked if he expected to talk about things other than the Persian Gulf with Mr. Gorbachev. The President replied, ''I know that we'll have discussions of, as I mentioned, C.F.E., and a C.F.E. agreement would lead to the C.S.C.E. meeting.'' Excuse me? C.F.E. is the treaty on reducing Conventional Forces in Europe. It is to be signed at a meeting of the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, or C.S.C.E. **********Out of Sight, Not Mind **********For White House watchers, the Persian Gulf crisis has offered some interesting twists. **********First, there was the fact that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d was noticeably absent from public view while some officials not always seen in the spotlight were more visible, including Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Mr. Scowcroft. **********Clearly, this did not signal a diminishing of Mr. Baker's status. It turned out that he was on the phone from his Wyoming vacation spot arranging the summit meeting with Mr. Gorbachev. **********This is a Presidential staff that maintains at least the appearance of collegiality. So White House aides routinely brush off questions about whether John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, whose expertise is domestic politics, is ever at odds with Mr. Scowcroft, an expert on diplomatic and arms control issues. **********Still, there may have been a flicker of a smile on Mr. Scowcroft's face on Saturday, when he was asked if Mr. Sununu had negotiated the summit arrangements during his visit last week to Moscow, where he was teaching Kremlin officials how to run an American-style Presidency. **********''No,'' Mr. Scowcroft replied.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/12/busin.main_headline: Soviet TV To Get U.S. Money Show
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/12/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;   Soviet TV To Get U.S. Money Show
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/12/busin.body_text: **********During an installment of the television show ''Adam Smith's Money World'' last November, Donald M. Kendall, the president of Pepsico, speculated that perestroika and glasnost would translate into great opportunities for American business. He advised the business community to take advantage of those opportunities before Japan and Western Europe also got into the act. **********One person well aware of the tremendous changes taking place and already acting on them was the show's host, whose real name is George J. W. Goodman. When ''Adam Smith's Money World'' begins its seventh season on public television in the fall, the weekly program focusing on connections between business and the larger world will also be shown in prime time on Soviet television. **********''Money World,'' which will be dubbed in Russian, will be the first American business program broadcast on Soviet television, where American shows of any sort are a rarity. **********Mr. Goodman and his Soviet colleagues conceded yesterday that much of the information presented on ''Adam Smith's Money World'' would be beyond the comprehension of the typical Soviet viewer, who is generally unschooled in the ways of Western finance. But you have to start somewhere, they said. The show typically deals with one topic, like the savings and loan crisis or inflation, and looks at the larger impact of those situations. **********''We anticipate that the vast majority of the population may have a very difficult time with much of the vocabulary and concepts,'' said Marek L. Bezzubov, the president of Soventure Group Inc., the American half of a joint venture that acquired the broadcast rights from the American producers for Co Star, a Soviet joint venture company that produces and distributes films. **********''It is literally a must for them to start getting acquainted with the business world, and eagerness usually translates into trying to understand,'' he said. **********The half-hour show will be presented on the Soviet Central Television Network sometime between 7 P.M. and 9 P.M., Mr. Bezzubov said. Its competition in that time slot may include news programs, cartoons, sports events and blocks of commercials. In type of programing, it will compete with ''600 Seconds,'' a late-night news magazine that sounds suspiciously like one-sixth of a popular American counterpart. **********Soviet Central TV operates two television channels in Moscow. Two others, presenting similar programing, are Leningrad Program and Moscow Program. There is also a fifth, an instructional channel. **********Talks Began Last Year **********Mr. Goodman said talks with Co Star began last year when he was planning an hourlong special on perestroika and glasnost for the Public Broadcasting System. Because of preliminary work on the special, he said, ''Money World'' was familiar to executives at Soviet Central TV. **********Under the agreement, Co Star will get the broadcast rights to 52 weekly installments of ''Adam Smith's Money World,'' which is produced by Alvin H. Perlmutter Inc. and WNET, the public television station in New York. Co Star will also sell 90 seconds of advertising to American companies doing business in the Soviet Union, like the General Motors corporation and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. **********In return, the American producers will get technical support for the PBS special on perestroika and glasnost, as well as for segments of the weekly program. No money is being exchanged in the deal between Co Star and ''Money World,'' Mr. Bezzubov said. **********'A Fabulous Turn of Events' **********''It's just a fabulous turn of events.'' Mr. Goodman said yesterday in an interview at his midtown office, ''Adam Smith has come to theland of Karl Marx. I think there's enormous confusion because the signals aren't clear there as they go to a market economy.'' **********''Money World'' is underwritten by Metropolitan Life Insurance and Unisys, he said, but he hopes that ''some alert, forward-thinking foundation would put up the money so that we can do a prologue for each show about why we're doing it, a primer to let Russian audiences watch and then tell us what they think of it.'' **********Mr. Goodman said that the program's title presented some problems in the translation. ''We changed the word 'money' to 'finance,' '' he said, ''because they said 'money' had a dark financial tone.'' But given the changes taking place in the Soviet economy, Mr. Goodman added, that is likely to change as well.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/07/world.main_headline: Evolution in Europe;   Daughter of Brezhnev Wins Return of Seized Valuables
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/07/world.print_headline: Evolution in Europe;   Daughter of Brezhnev Wins Return of Seized Valuables
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/07/world.body_text: **********Galina Brezhnev, daughter of Leonid I. Brezhnev, the late Soviet leader, has won a lawsuit claiming a variety of valuables confiscated when her husband was sentenced to prison. **********The newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda reported that Miss Brezhnev won the case on the argument that the valuables - the money, the Mercedes sedan, the furniture, the chandeliers, the collection of antique arms, the country house and the stuffed animals worth 80,837 rubles - belonged to her and not to her husband, Yuri M. Churbanov, who was jailed for corruption. The value of the stuffed animals is about $130,000 at the artificially high exchange rate used for most noncash dollar-ruble transactions here. **********Routine Case, Judge Says **********The presiding judge, A. Yerokhin, was quoted as saying that legally speaking, the case was routine. ''There were no calls, no threats, nothing to influence the trial,'' he said. ''If it were not for the famous name of the plaintiff, I would not even remember the trial. **********''Under the law, Galina Brezhnev was within her rights, since most of the property belonged to her and not her husband, and the Supreme Court had no right, after sentencing Yuri Churbanov, to confiscate it.'' **********The paper also quoted from Miss Brezhnev's testimony explaining the source of the property. **********''The Mercedes was a gift to my father from some Government official,'' she was quoted as saying. ''I had a driver's license, and I drove the car. My father wasn't in the habit of giving gifts to my husbands.'' **********The cash, amounting to 65,492 rubles, or about $111,000, came from her father's estate, Miss Brezhnev said. She said she had bought the country house, valued by the court at 64,000 rubles, or about $108,000, by using money from her mother and by selling a sable coat and earrings of sapphires and diamonds. **********The paper gave no explanation for the valuable stuffed animals. **********When Mr. Brezhnev died in 1982, tales of Miss Brezhnev's life and fortune were rife in Moscow. The story was told that before her marriage to Mr. Churbanov, Miss Brezhnev, a tall beauty in her youth, had fallen in love and married a famed circus performer, Yevgeny Milayev, who had lavished gifts on her. **********Father Opposed First Marriage **********But according to accounts at the time, Mr. Brezhnev was opposed to the marriage and forced his daughter to dissolve it. Instead, he arranged for her to marry Mr. Churbanov, a bland young officer in the Interior Ministry. **********Mr. Churbanov rose rapidly in rank and influence, ending as a First Deputy Interior Minister. In the dismemberment of what is now called Mr. Brezhnev's ''time of stagnation,'' Mr. Churbanov was tried for corruption in December 1988 and sentenced to 12 years in prison. **********Komsomolskaya Pravda seemed satisfied that the trial was aboveboard. ''All the same, I painfully search for an answer to the question: Why do we not have laws regulating the income of the former general secretary, just as we have no laws that would qualify many of the actions of the old regime as criminal?'' wrote the reporter, T. Borisov.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/21/busin.body_text: **********The ICI Financial Corporation, a unit of Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C., is offering $300 million in notes due 2000 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. **********Underwriters said the notes had a 9 1/2 percent coupon and were priced at 99.82 to yield 9.527 percent, or about 120 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. **********The noncallable notes are guaranteed by Imperial Chemical and are rated Aa-3 by Moody's Investors Service and AA- by Standard & Poor's.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/24/busin.main_headline: In Rarity, Utility Seeks Another in Midwest
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/24/busin.print_headline: In Rarity, Utility Seeks Another in Midwest
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/07/24/busin.body_text: **********In a move that is rare among utilities, the Kansas City Power and Light Company made a hostile tender offer yesterday for the shares of a neighboring utility, the Kansas Gas and Electric Company. Kansas City Power said the bid was worth $857 million. **********Analysts said the move had stemmed partly from the two companies' partnership in an over-budget nuclear plant and partly from Kansas City Power's impending need for a new electric plant. Instead of building such a plant, it was seeking to buy an electric company. **********Kansas City Power offered $27 a share for Kansas Gas and Electric's common stock, which had closed Friday at $19.75. Yesterday, Kansas Gas and Electric shares jumped $4.625 each, to close at $24.375 on the New York Stock Exchange. Kansas City Power closed at $31.50, down 87.5 cents, in Big Board trading. **********If combined, the companies would achieve savings of $85 million in the first five years, Kansas City Power estimated. That would come to about 1.4 percent of the combined revenues of the companies. **********A spokesman for Kansas Gas and Electric said the company was studying the offer, which it received yesterday morning. **********The companies are of modest size. Kansas City Power serves the Kansas City metropolitan area in Kansas and Missouri. Kansas Gas and Electric serves south-central and southeastern Kansas, including Wichita. **********They are partners at the Wolf Creek nuclear plant, near Burlington, Kan., about 100 miles southwest of Kansas City. They set out to build the plant in 1973 for $525 million, but finished it 12 years later for $2.9 billion. **********In 1985, the Kansas Corporation Commission, the state's regulatory agency, said the plant was bigger than customers needed, and delayed allowing some of its cost to be passed on to customers. The commission later relented, but it said $283 million of the plant's cost had resulted from imprudent acts of management and would have to come out of the pockets of shareholders. **********'The Final Revenge' **********''Kansas Gas and Electric would not be in this position if they hadn't built the Wolf Creek plant,'' said Gregory B. Enholm, an analyst at Salomon Brothers Inc. ''This is, in a way, the final revenge of a nuclear power plant - to cause the company to be put out of existence.'' **********Mr. Enholm suggested that the opening bid was low. It comes to about 140 percent of the book value of the company, he said, instead of a range of 160 to 200 percent. **********In a letter sent yesterday to Wilson K. Cadman, the chairman and president of Kansas Gas and Electric, the president and chief executive officer of Kansas City Power, A. Drue Jennings, said that if the bid succeeded, his company would freeze rates for all wholesale and retail customers through Jan. 1, 1993. **********No Layoffs Expected **********Mr. Jennings said his company did not expect any layoffs among Kansas Gas and Electric's 1,330 employees. **********In a telephone interview, he added that ''the real synergies should be very measurable'' if the companies combined, and that $85 million over five years was a conservative estimate based on publicly available information. **********He said the offer was all in cash and fully financed. His company said it had executed a $1 billion credit agreement with the Westpac Banking Corporation and the First National Bank of Chicago, and had retained the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation as a financial adviser. **********Mr. Jennings also said that to assuage the fears of neighboring utilities, it had filed an application with the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, which has jurisdiction over wholesale electricity transactions, for changes in policies governing access to its transmission lines. The changes are meant ''to open up the system quite a bit,'' he said, so that other companies could trade power across the combined territory of the merged companies. **********Documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington indicated that the companies had discussed a merger as early as 1983, as well as the possibility that Kansas Gas and Electric would sell generating capacity to Kansas City Power. The filing also says that if the merger is not consummated by the time of Kansas Gas's annual meeting next year, Kansas City Power would consider soliciting proxies to elect its candidates to the target company's board. **********The takeover offer was made conditional on regulatory approval from the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission and the Kansas Corporation Commission, among other conditions.Equitable Life Assurance Societyd (Donaldson, Lufkin)

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/26/world.main_headline: China Finds a Han Tomb and 'Men of Mud'
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/26/world.print_headline: China Finds a Han Tomb and 'Men of Mud'
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/26/world.body_text: **********Workers building a road in central China appear to have stumbled on an archeological treasure: a 2,100-year-old network of underground vaults said to contain tens of thousands of terra-cotta sculptures buried with a Han Dynasty emperor, during one of the greatest civilizations of ancient times. **********The figures, spread over an area as big as 10 football fields, are believed to be part of the burial site of Jingdi, an emperor who ruled from 157 B.C. to 141 B.C. This would be the first excavation of the area around a Han Dynasty imperial tomb, and some Chinese archeologists have described the find as surpassing in artistic quality and in number of artifacts even the famous terra-cotta army discovered near the ancient capital of Xian in 1974. **********The excavation is only in the early stages and so far Chinese officials have been coy about the discovery, refusing to let a foreign journalist visit the site or interview experts who have examined the artifacts. Information about the discovery has emerged only in dribs and drabs in the official Chinese press organizations in the last month. **********'A Pretty Terrific Find' **********Yet from the growing number of accounts published in Chinese-language newspapers, and from accompanying photos published in recent days, a more complete picture is emerging of a vast underground array of scupltures. There are said to be rows and rows of terra-cotta sculptures of men, boys or horses. Each is only about two feet tall, but they reportedly are all carved masterfully with different facial expressions. **********''Reporters recently visited the excavation site, descended a ladder into the moist pit, and saw the terra-cotta figures,'' wrote a journalist in People's Daily. ''They were about 60 centimeters tall, all naked male figures, all armless and all red. The sculptures are thin, and all are different. Some are very handsome, featuring small smiles on their faces. Some have high cheekbones and serious expressions, some stare straight ahead, others seem serene and contented. The figures are so vivid that they almost seem alive.'' **********Foreign experts interviewed by telephone said they had not heard of the discovery, or had seen only the briefest references to it. But they said that China did not have a record of exaggerating archeological claims. **********''It sounds like a pretty terrific find,'' said Michael Loewe, a specialist in ancient China at Cambridge University in England. ''If this really is the tomb of Jingdi, with that size and complexity, then it should certainly be as significant as Qinshihuangdi's tomb.'' **********The tomb of Qinshihuangdi, the first Qin emperor, is only 25 miles away, also in the countryside outside Xian, and attracts several hundred thousand foreigners to Xian annually. **********24 Vaults, Thousands of Figures **********The latest sculptures are considerably smaller than the life-sized warriors and horses buried with the Qin emperor. The Qin excavation, which is unfinished but is believed to consist of fewer than 10,000 figures, is 70 years older than the new find, but consists of only three vaults, compared to the 24 found so far at the Han tomb. **********''Some say there are tens of thousands'' of figures buried in the Han vaults, People's Daily reported. ''Some say there are 100,000. Then there is some talk of a million figures.'' **********K. C. Chang, professor of archeology at Harvard University, said the reports of the discovery were in line with what was known of Han Dynasty burial practices, but that it was too early to assess the magnitude of the find. In particular, he said it was important to examine the craftsmanship to see if the artistic level marked an improvement compared with previous finds. **********The Han Dynasty, of which Jingdi was the fifth emperor, was one of the greatest periods in Chinese history, in which paper and porcelain were invented, philosophical and historical studies flowered, and Chinese culture spread to Korea and Vietnam. While Jingdi came to be overshadowed by his father and by his son, he still is remembered for consolidating the empire and his generally wise stewardship of the nation. **********Workers Find Antiquities **********It is not unusual for China to limit access by foreigners to its antiquities. Because so many Chinese artifacts are abroad, China is particularly sensitive about conducting excavations on its own. National law even forbids foreign nationals from taking part in digs. **********The site was discovered on March 10, as workers were building a new road about 15 miles north of the ancient capital of Xian. At a depth of about 22 feet, their digging tools made an unusual noise and so they stopped for an inspection. They realized they had discovered antiquities, and so archeologists were called in, just as they were in 1974 when a peasant digging a well stumbled across the site of Qinshihuangdi's terra-cotta army. **********Assessment of the new find is difficult because the work has only just begun. The 24 pits each measures about 13 feet wide and between 82 feet and 950 feet long. Some contain horses and carts instead of human figures, and others appear to have been emptied by ancient grave robbers. **********''If only the central Government and the province will give us manpower and financial support, we believe that in two to three years of hard work we can excavate all 24 pits, and we can solve the mysteries surrounding them,'' People's Daily quoted Wang Xueli, an archeologist from Xian, as saying. The newspapers have said that a museum is expected to be constructed at the site. **********China has always been short of people to conduct archeological digs, which is one reason why many known imperial tombs have not been excavated and why major finds often occur when experts are called in to rescue a site that workers or peasants have turned up. But the Chinese Government might be willing to devote considerable resources in this case because of the likely gains from tourism. **********''These men of mud can bring in hordes of Westerners,'' People's Daily quoted local peasants as saying.
