https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/03/busin.main_headline: Way Cleared On Alaskan Oil Project
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/03/busin.print_headline: Way Cleared On Alaskan Oil Project
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/03/busin.body_text: **********Production at a large Alaskan oilfield, discovered in 1989 two miles north of the vast reserves of Prudhoe Bay, is expected to begin within two years now that oil producers and the Federal Government say they have resolved an environmental dispute that had stalled the project. **********The agreement was announced late Friday by the Army Corps of Engineers, ARCO, BP Exploration and Exxon. The Corps of Engineers was the main opponent of the project. It was not clear today whether other challenges might be brought during further licensing steps that might be required. **********It was the second time in a week that big oil companies said they planned to pump more oil from large fields where production was blocked by disputes over environmental worries. The Chevron Corporation said Tuesday that it anticipated that a group of 18 oil companies it heads will produce as much as 20,000 barrels a day from the Point Arguello field, off the California coast near Santa Barbara, by next summer. **********Negotiations in both cases were mediated by high-ranking officials at the Energy Department. The Administration has sought to increase domestic oil output because imports of 200,000 barrels a day of Kuwaiti oil were halted after the invasion by Iraq on Aug. 2. **********Officials at the Army Corps of Engineers and at the Environmental Protection Agency held up production in the Point McIntyre field because they considered existing gravel causeways that extend from land into the shallow waters of the Beaufort Sea a threat to fish that migrate in those coastal waters. **********A commercial fishery situated more than 100 miles west of the causeways relies on the Arctic char, broad whitefish, least cisco and Arctic cisco for its operations. The view of Federal officials was that the causeways appeared to raise salt concentrations and the temperature of the water to levels in some areas near the coast that would be harmful to the fish. Oil Companies' Argument **********The oil companies disagreed, saying years of study at their expense had not indicated any bad effects from the causeways. "It has been and continues to be our position that variations caused by natural factors, like wind and current, far exceed any variations that you could attribute to the causeways," said Paul Laird, a spokesman in Anchorage for BP Exploration, a unit of the British Petroleum Company. **********ARCO, B.P. and Exxon agreed to spend $50 million to clear several water passages in the gravel roadbeds first built for exploration drilling at the Point McIntyre field as well as at the nearby Endicott field. **********The roadbeds extend 2.5 miles to the Point McIntyre field, and 5 miles to Endicott. The oil companies agreed to add a total of 650 feet of clearance for water at several locations in the causeways. The Endicott causeway was built initially with 700 feet of openings; the Point McIntyre causeway contains a 52-foot breach. **********Brian Davies, a vice president for development at B.P., said the settlement announced Friday enabled the oil companies to move ahead with production and "avoids years of dispute and possible litigation." Called a Reasonable Conclusion **********Col. William W. Kakel, Alaska district engineer for the Army Corps of Engineers, said the pact was a reasonable conclusion to the disagreement. He added that the agreement "recognizes that environmental quality and economic reality are both important in North Slope oil and gas decisions." **********The oil companies own rights to an estimated 300 million barrels in the Point McIntyre field. Production from Point McIntyre and from the nearby Lisburne field could reach 100,000 barrels a day by 1994, said Al Greenstein, a spokesman at ARCO's headquarters in Los Angeles. **********Output at the Lisburne field, already in production, is 40,000 barrels a day. The combined output of Lisburne and Point McIntyre will exceed 60,000 barrels when output from Point McIntyre begins by late summer in 1992, Mr. Greenstein said. An expansion set for the summer of 1993 should increase output in the combined project to between 80,000 and 100,000 barrels a day, he said. **********Oil produced from the fields will flow through the Trans-Alaska Pipeline to the tanker port at Valdez, Alaska, with most of the output then shipped by tanker to West Coast refineries. Pipeline Found Sound **********ANCHORAGE, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The company that oversees the Trans-Alaska Pipeline said today that it had completed an investigation of reported corrosion and found the 800-mile pipeline to be sound. State and Federal regulators who supervised the monthlong inquiry by the Alyeska Pipeline Service Company said they had not decided whether to allow the company to increase pressure in the line. Oil producers want to increase the amount of crude pumped through the line, which links the North Slope with Valdez, to about 2.1 million barrels a day, from 2.06 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/24/world.main_headline: Cautious Course Is Charted in Kashmir
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/24/world.print_headline: Cautious Course Is Charted in Kashmir
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/01/24/world.body_text: **********The new Governor of Jammu and Kashmir state, sent specially from New Delhi to deal with anti-Indian agitation by Kashmiri militants, said tonight that he will not allow Kashmir to slip away from India. **********The Governor, Jagmohan, said he would assert the Government's authority ''with human consideration,'' although separatists ''have succeeded in building up a big tempo.'' **********The city's streets are deserted and the people are subdued; soldiers patrol the town, a major tourist center that has been shut down by curfew and work stoppages in the wake of the worst separatist fighting since a revival of anti-Indian feelings began here two years ago. **********Dozens have been reported killed in clashes between security forces and protesters in the last three days in the northern state bordering Pakistan. The violence poses the most difficult political problem to confront the one-month-old Government of Prime Minister V. P. Singh. **********Mr. Jagmohan, who uses only one name, said his strategy would be marked by persuasion, urging militants to give up their weapons while meeting the basic needs of people in the Kashmir Valley. Kashmiris, residents of the only Muslim-dominated state in mostly Hindu India, are angered by what they call the previous government's economic and political neeglect. **********The state was placed under Mr. Jagmohan's rule last week and Srinagar, the capital, has been under curfew much of the last month. **********Tonight, Mr. Jagmohan held intense talks on the situation with top security officials from across the country, including police and paramilitary officers. **********The tensions here worsened on Saturday after security troops swept through several neighborhoods seeking pro-independence militants and detaining hundreds. On Sunday crowds demanding the detainees' release marched through the city, confronting troops. **********The soldiers opened fire. The Government says 28 were killed in that clash and in the two days since then. Local reporters and others say the toll exceeds 50. **********In an interview, Mr. Jagmohan, who was governor of Jammu and Kashmir between 1983 and 1987, said that Islamic militants had taken advantage of the breakdown of the administration under former chief minister Farooq Abdullah. Dr. Abdullah resigned last week after the new governor was named. The two men are critical of each other. **********Two people were killed in Sringaar this afternoon when a paramilitary guard fired at a mob that threw cinders at a car escorting a United Nations vehicle. No United Nations official was injured in the incident. **********Otherwise, the situation today in Srinagar was reported to be largely peaceful. Processions and anti-India rallies were reported from a few other towns and the curfew was lifted briefly in a couple of them. **********A Reservoir of Good Will **********Mr. Jagmohan was a popular governor during his earlier term, and is perceived as having a good record on protecting the environment, increasing tourism and attacking official corruption and wastefulness. But despite his considerable popularity, it is unclear whether he will be able to restore peace to Kashmir in the current atmosphere, charged by the confrontation and fanned by a strong extremist movement. **********In an attempt to calm public anger, Mr. Jagmohan ordered the release of 230 of 237 men arrested during the search operation last week. **********Talking to visitors in the governor's mansion overlooking picturesque Dal Lake, Mr. Jagmohan said he wants ''to create an atmosphere which will enable feelings to cool and enable development to take place.'' **********Mr. Jagmohan said a major problem is the militants' arsenal of arms and ammunition in Srinagar. Mr. Jagmohan said that if the troops are to be withdrawan, as the militants are demanding, ''then the Kalashnikovs must go.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/07/busin.main_headline: Columbia Savings Has A Big Loss
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/07/busin.print_headline: Columbia Savings Has A Big Loss
https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/07/busin.body_text: **********The financial slide of the Columbia Savings and Loan Association quickened today, as the troubled institution reported a $352 million loss for its third quarter after taking a large write-down in the value of its "junk bond" holdings. **********Columbia, which is based in Beverly Hills, Calif., has been trying to sell the junk bond portfolio, which was once worth about $4.5 billion, to prevent a Government takeover. But the new write-down, which depressed the value of the bonds to about $2.5 billion, raises the question of whether buyers would be interested in such a problematic asset. **********Columbia had agreed to sell the portfolio for about $3 billion to an investor group led by a Canadian firm, the Gordon Investment Corporation. But the Government blocked the sale in September, saying the terms were unacceptable, and Columbia is now expected to conclude a new round of bidding next month. **********Edward G. Harshfield, Columbia's president and chief executive, said in a statement today that the bidding process was proceeding. One Columbia executive said privately that the decline in the portfolio's value might even make a new deal more attractive to a buyer who wants to pay less and hold onto the bonds as a long-term investment. **********But the outlook for Columbia as an independent institution remains bleak. Stockholders' equity now stands at a negative $709.8 million, leaving Columbia more than $800 million short of minimum capital requirements.  'Unprecedented Decline' **********Columbia's loss in the latest quarter compared with a loss of $226.3 million in the corresponding period last year. The new loss was caused primarily by a $226.1 million write-down in the market value of the bonds and a $154.5 million addition to reserves to cover losses on the bonds. **********"The high-yield market experienced an unprecedented decline in August and September of this year," Mr. Harshfield said. **********Offsetting junk bond losses, Columbia recorded a $50.3 million special gain primarily from the sale of an investment in Motel 6. **********Despite its troubles, Mr. Harshfield said Columbia could remain in operation. The institution holds about $1.3 billion in cash and short-term investments, which Columbia executives maintain is more than enough to cover withdrawals by depositors.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/24/busin.body_text: **********The Ford Motor Company will close three plants this week and the General Motors Corporation will shut down a Chevrolet Caprice plant for two weeks because of slow sales, the auto makers said Friday. **********Ford said the company's Lorain, Ohio, car plant, which builds Ford Thunderbirds and Mercury Cougars, will close this week, laying off about 2,700 workers. **********Also this week Ford will lay off about 2,500 workers when it closes its Chicago assembly plant, which makes Ford Taurus and Mercury Sable cars, and about 1,900 employees when its medium- and heavy-duty truck assembly plant in Louisville, Ky., is shut down. **********Inventories of the Ford and **********Mercury cars were slightly above the normal 60-to-65-selling-day level for this time of year, according to Ward's Automotive Reports. **********Also, Ford's van plant in Lorain will go to one shift from two this week, putting 650 workers on a temporary layoff. **********General Motors will shut down its Willow Run assembly plant near Ypsilanti, Mich., for two weeks beginning Monday, affecting about 4,300 people. An Arlington, Tex., Caprice plant will be unaffected. Dealer inventories of new Caprices stood at about 96 days at the end of last month, Ward's said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/02/busin.body_text: **********Given the environment in which it has been operating, the UAL Corporation could have become a basket case long ago. As if four takeover bids and three chief executives in four years were not enough, the parent of United Airlines has recently been battered by the rising fuel prices and weakening traffic that have troubled the whole industry. **********Yet for all the turmoil, UAL in the last few months has regained from American Airlines its position as the nation's biggest airline, improved its service record and, thanks to its lucrative Pacific routes, remained one of the most profitable domestic carriers. **********That success will be tested in coming weeks. A group including United's three unions that has made an accepted offer to buy the airline for $201 a share has until Oct. 9 to line up financing. If, as most analysts expect, the deal collapses, the unions will seek an immediate resumption of talks on new contracts, and the negotiations could be difficult. **********Earnings Troubles **********What is more, the airline will face more pressure to cut costs because earnings, which reached a record in the second quarter, are expected to drop sharply in the quarter that ended Sept. 30. In the three months ended June 30, the company reported a 5.1 percent increase in net income, to $148.3 million, or $6.81 a share, on revenue of $2.7 billion. But analysts expect that a weak third and fourth quarter will mean that United's earnings for 1990 will be less than half the $324.2 million in 1989. **********While no one disputes that United's troubles have already caused their share of turmoil at the $10 billion company with 74,000 employees, people who have followed the carrier say it is extraordinary that an organization under such strain could be so resilient. **********''The outlook for United is very promising,'' said John Eichner, a New York-based industry consultant. ''It must be one helluva property if it is doing this well in spite of all of its problems.'' **********United's 6.5 percent operating margin - operating income relative to revenue - in the second quarter was bested only by American Airlines' 7.8 percent and Southwest Airlines' 13.4 percent. The major reason was the Pacific routes: For example. last year United's operating margins ran at 7.1 percent in the Pacific and 4 percent domestically, estimated Thomas Longman, the airline analyst at Bear, Stearns & Company. **********''I am not sure it would be fair to call United the stellar performer in the business,'' Mr. Longman said. ''They just happen to have a nice chunk of their business - roughly 30 percent - in the Pacific.'' **********United's service to the Pacific, which includes daily flights to Japan, Australia and other points in the Far East, is now the largest in the region, having surpassed that of Japan Air Lines and Northwest Airlines. In 1988, United was flying about 31,000 seats to and from the Pacific each week. The figure now stands at just under 50,000. Northwest flies about 40,000 seats a week and Japan Air Lines 32,000. **********Takes the Top Spot **********Helped by its Pacific routes and service to Europe that was introduced last spring, United has moved slightly ahead of American as the largest United States carrier in terms of miles flown by paying passengers. Each airline holds about 17 percent of the market among domestic carriers. **********The airline's improvement in service is evident in several ways: On-time arrivals and departures are up in the last year, and the number of times in a month that United ground crews mishandle baggage is down, according to Transportation Department figures. (These trends are true for the industry as a whole as well.) Analysts say a good part of the credit must go to Stephen M. Wolf, the 49-year-old former chief executive of Republic Airlines and Flying Tiger who became United's chief executive in December 1987, replacing Frank Olson, who in turn replaced Richard Ferris in June 1987. Industry experts say Mr. Wolf has succeeded on a number of fronts. **********New Team Praised **********For one thing, they say, he has assembled what may be the strongest top-management team in the business. Job No. 1 was maintaining the morale of James Guyette, United's longtime head of operations who many industry experts thought would quit when he lost the chairmanship to Mr. Wolf. In addition, Mr. Wolf in 1988 recruited from American Airlines John C. Pope, considered one of the industry's saaviest finance executives, to be United's chief financial officer. And Mr. Wolf promoted Christopher Bowers, another longtime United employee, to the crucial position of head of sales. Industry experts say that United's relations with travel agents have improved markedly under Mr. Bowers. **********Also under Mr. Wolf, United's middle management - the thousands of marketing executives, logistics specialists, strategic and financial planners, and ground-crew personnel -has ''focused on the right things,'' said Robert P. Neuschel a longtime student of United who runs the Transportation Center at Northwestern University. He was referring to the airline's improved customer service. **********More than anything, Mr. Wolf has undertaken to expand the service to the Far East that United began in 1986, when Mr. Ferris paid $750 million for the Far East business of Pan American World Airways. The Pacific service is highlighted in United's two-year-old advertising campaign, produced by Leo Burnett & Company, set to Gershwin's ''Rhapsody in Blue'' and carrying on the ''Friendly Skies'' theme that the airline has used since the 1960's. **********But for all its recent successes, United faces major risks. All three of United's major unions - the pilots, flight attendants and machinists -are working with expired contracts and have agreed to hold off on contract talks until the takeover issue is resolved. But if the union bid for the carrier fails, the employees will seek an immediate resumption of talks. Given Mr. Wolf's tough bargaining position in the past - he has all but said that United's pilots are overpaid - those talks could be protracted and contentious. **********Some Union Resentment **********''There would be distractions, unhappiness and disruptions of all sorts,'' said Rick Dubinsky, the head of United's pilots' union. ''If this deal falls through and you have three unions with open contracts, any thought of this company being a well-run airline under Steven Wolf would be fantasy.'' **********Indeed, some United employees resent Mr. Wolf for the way he has handled himself in past buyout attempts, arguing that he has been too quick to give up and too quick to seek concessions from workers. **********Mr. Wolf, who declined to be interviewed, is not part of the current buyout group and would be replaced by Gerald Greenwald, a former Chrysler vice chairman, if the bid succeeds. But he was a member of the union-management group whose buyout proposal collapsed last October for lack of financing, touching off a steep fall in the stock market. Earlier buyout proposals by the pilots' union (in 1987) and the Los Angeles investor Marvin Davis (in 1989) also failed. **********Having presented its $201-a-share bid to United's board, the union group has been given until Oct. 9 to line up financing. The unions, in turn, have given their banks a deadline of this Wednesday to say whether they as lenders will go along with the deal or support a lower bid. And while the board has technically accepted the $201 offer, it could still decide that it does not like the financing terms that the employees ultimately line up, and reject the deal. Skepticism about the deal's being completed is an important reason that United's stock has fallen sharply in recent months. (But since Mr. Davis offered late Thursday to join the employee buyout of the company, the stock has risen by $12.75, to $103.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.) 'No Compelling Reason' **********''The key is that there is no compelling reason why United has to be sold,'' said Sharon J. Kalin, a stock trader who has followed United since the first takeover bid emerged in 1987. ''The company is not in a cash squeeze, and there is no raider breathing down its neck.'' **********Another concern for United is that it has fallen behind in ordering new aircraft. United is taking delivery of one new jet a week, mostly Boeing 737's used on domestic medium-haul flights and 767's that will be used for travel to Europe. But United has told its suppliers it will hold off on ordering new wide-body aircraft for domestic long-haul flights until the airline's future is clearer. That puts United at a competitive disadvantage, because many of its existing long-haul domestic aircraft are DC-10's, which consume more fuel than new models and require larger crews. **********Moreover, United's European service is still only a token effort - just three flights a day, to Frankfurt and Paris. **********And on its home turf, O'Hare Airport in Chicago, United has begun feeling increasing pressure from American Airlines. American pulled aircraft out of Cleveland to support more flights out of Chicago. American also purchased from Trans World Airlines the rights to fly from Chicago to various European destinations. **********Finally, all the disciplined management in the world may not be able to keep United profitable if the hostilities in the Middle East continue to send jet fuel prices higher, and if the economy weakens further.
